title: Frank R. Gilchrist, Timber Executive, 66
description: Frank R. Gilchrist, who ran the Gilchrist Timber Company and its company town for more than 30 years, died Tuesday at St. Charles Medical Center in Bend. He was 66 years old.

title: Tuckwell Horn Recital
description: Barry Tuckwell is to play sonatas for French horn by Beethoven and Hindemith, tonight at 8 at Weill Recital Hall. The program also includes the Brahms Horn Trio (Op. 40), for which Mr. Tuckwell is to be joined by Daniel Heifetz, violinist, and Marcantonio Barone, a pianist. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Queens Soldier Is Killed in Iraq
description: Capt. Mario Fajardo, who said in his last letter from the Persian Gulf to his family in Queens that he was proud to serve a country that had given immigrants like himself so much opportunity, was killed deep inside Iraq during the ground war.

title: Securities Regulator Will Join the Industry
description: Richard G. Ketchum, one of the most influential regulators of the securities business, will join the industry he helped oversee during his 14 years with the Government.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A8-13

title: CHRONICLE
description: "I am prepard for the consequences," Christian Brando said yesterday just before Superior Court Judge Robert W. Thomas in Santa Monica, Calif., sentenced the 32-year-old son of Marlon Brando to 10 in prison for the shooting death of his half-sister's lover.

title: George Ginsberg, 56; Led Psychiatric Group
description: George L. Ginsberg, a psychoanalyst who was president of the New York Psychiatric Association, died on Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Article 880791 -- No Title
description: A Federal judge in Delaware has ruled that Illinois Tool Works Inc. of Glenview, Ill., should pay $15.4 million to an independent inventor after a jury ruled that the company had infringed his patent on robot spraying systems.

title: NBC to Drop System Of Adjustable Ratings
description: Pier Mapes, the president of the NBC Television Network, said yesterday that the network would abandon an adjustable program-rating system it established last year, because the system had not been a success.

title: A Special Reason To Celebrate
description: After the Vietnam War, the Watergate affair and lesser embarrassments that sometimes made the Government look dumb, clumsy or worse, many career public servants have a special reason to celebrate a swift, successful war.

title: Big East in a Big Jumble As Tournament Nears
description: You are the coach of a college basketball team, say a fourth-place team in a second-tier conference far removed from incessant television attention. You realize that your school's only realistic road to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament is to win your conference tournament.

title: Military Experts See a Death Toll Of 25,000 to 50,000 Iraqi Troops
description: While the exact figure will never be known, military experts said today that 25,000 to 50,000 Iraqi soldiers probably died during the six-week war in the Persian Gulf.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Duck Soup' to 'Lame Duck'

title: Review/Film; Battles of Two Warlords, One Horrid, One Hesitant
description: Haruki Kadokawa's "Heaven and Earth," opening today at the 57th Street Playhouse, is an elaborate but totally weightless Japanese historical film, of less interest for what is on the screen than for how it got there. The movie looks like a wildly expensive vanity production.

title: Morceli Sets World Indoor Record in 1,500 Meters
description: Noureddine Morceli of Algeria celebrated his 21st birthday yesterday by setting a 1,500-meter indoor world record with a time of 3 minutes 34.16 seconds in the Placido Fernandez Viagas track meet.

title: INSIDE
description: New Approach on Hepatitis Frustrated by the reluctance of adults to be vaccinated against hepatitis B, an adult disease, a panel urged the vaccination of children. Page A16. Prosecutors and Ethics A memo from the Attorney General is seen by many defense lawyers as encouragement for prosecutors to ignore ethics rules. Law, page B4. Noriega Witness Dies A crucial Government witness in the drug conspiracy case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was killed in a car crash in Miami. Page A16. Before the Condom Vote The woman who cast the pivotal vote to distribute condoms in New York City schools made her decision after hours of prayer and fasting. Page B1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I'm sure this equals what our parents saw in World War II. It makes the waiting and anticipation worth it." -- Capt. Doug Wisnioski, an American soldier being welcomed in Kuwait. [ A10:1. ]

title: Pornography Producer Slain
description: Artie Mitchell, a leading producer of internationally distributed pornography, was shot to death in a house in this San Francisco suburb Wednesday night, and his brother and business partner, Jim, was arrested in the killing. Doing business under the name Mitchell Brothers, Artie Mitchell, 45 years old, and Jim, 47, produced many sex films, including "Behind the Green Door." The police said they did not know the motive for the killing.

title: 2 CHURCHES WEIGH GAY CLERGY PLANS
description: Separate study commissions of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) and the Epsicopal Church recommended steps this week that would liberalize the denominations' stands against the ordination of active homosexuals.

title: Economic Scene; What Happens To Oil Prices?
description: AN effort to assess the economic consequences of the crushing of Iraq and the expulsion of Saddam Hussein's forces from Kuwait must start with the effect on oil prices and supplies.

title: Drug Patient Is Linked To Spread of TB in 15
description: One patient in a drug rehabilitation center apparently spread a treatment-resistant form of tuberculosis to at least 15 other people there, Federal health officials reported today.

title: Charlotte Baruth, Volunteer, 87
description: Charlotte Baruth, a former president of the New York Federation of Women's Clubs, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gulfstream to Be Host for 1992 Breeders' Cup
description: Gulfstream Park was named the site of the 1992 Breeders' Cup Series today, and for the second time in four years will serve as host for horse racing's day of champions.

title: Hills Stores to Shut 32 More Outlets
description: Hills Department Stores Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year and said it would close 28 stores, announced it would close 32 more and lay off more than 3,000 workers. The discount chain, based in Canton, Mass., said the stores being closed were in Michigan, Ohio, Tennessee, Indiana, Alabama, Illinois and New York.

title: Few in Hong Kong Ask to Be British
description: In a surprising twist, a British offer of citizenship for a limited number of Hong Kong residents nervous about the Chinese takeover of the colony in 1997 has attracted only a fraction of the number of applicants expected.

title: Review/Dance; A 22-Year-Old's Joust With Death
description: Deep down, dance is an art of exaltation, and "Lacrymosa," an astonishingly impressive premiere for the Joffrey Ballet by a 22-year-old novice choreographer, Edward Stierle, makes the case in the most compelling terms.

title: For Children
description: 'Rapunzel' Theaterworks/USA Promenade Theater 2162 Broadway (at 76th Street) Manhattan (212) 677-5959 Recommended ages: 5 to 9 Through March 10

title: International Design From Mid-Century
description: The exhibition of modernist design at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art is like a walk-in textbook on the history of design from 1935 to 1965. This is mostly good. The show has a thorough, exemplary feeling, as if all the bases were being well covered by an inspired teacher. It starts with a section titled "The Modernist Canon," which includes such classics of prewar European design as the bent plywood chairs of Alvar Aalto, Marcel Breuer and Gerrit Rietveld. From there, it moves forward like a series of distinct and clearly explained lectures, each organized around a particular theme.

title: Bid Is Rejected By Square D
description: The Square D Company today rejected a $1.92 billion buyout bid from Groupe Schneider S.A. and then sued the French electronics manufacturer in an attempt to halt any further takeover maneuvers.

title: Bach Cantatas at the Y
description: Erich Leinsdorf is to conduct the New York Chamber Symphony in three Bach cantatas and an excerpt from a fourth, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue. The soloists are the soprano Benita Valente, the tenor John Aler and the baritone Hermann Prey. The program is to be repeated on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Review/Art; Gouaches by Eva Hesse From Her Post-School and Pre-Sculpture Days
description: The small, highly concentrated Eva Hesse show installed in little more than one room of the Robert Miller Gallery packs an emotional punch. It brings together for the first time most of the gouaches Hesse made while she was still a painter, five years out of art school, five years or so from becoming a sculptor. "For the first time," Elizabeth Frank writes of the gouaches in the accompanying catalogue, Hesse "discovers what's truly hers."

title: Key Rates
Cuts for the Arts: Unfair, Unwise
description: Because it's easy to think of "art," whatever its manifold forms, as a luxury, the enormous budget cut inflicted upon the New York State Council on the Arts may not seem very important. What does another production of, say, "Uncle Vanya" really mean to New York?

title: Article 749591 -- No Title
description: The Dutch electronics giant Philips N.V. said today that it had lost about $2.48 billion in 1990, but that it expected to be profitable by late this year.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Price Company, a San Diego-based organization that operates 56 membership-only Price Club retail warehouses, priced $250 million in convertible debentures yesterday through Lehman Brothers.

title: Bottom of the Housing Slump Is Seen in the New York Area
description: The New York area's housing slump may have finally hit bottom, or come close to it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Way to Cut the Mustard As the 80's Tactics Get Dull
description: MADISON AVENUE is reviving one of its oldest tricks as it tries to jolly consumers out of a dour mood created by recession and war.

title: Fight Rekindled Over Plagiarist As Schoolteacher
description: Alfred R. Ruesch is a veteran teacher at South High School here. He is an effective chairman of the English department. He is very popular. He is also controversial. Alfred Ruesch is a plagiarist.

title: The Nasty Case of Winnie Mandela
description: One of the many sad truths about the trial of Winnie Mandela is that the African National Congress has put its reputation in the dock, too.

title: Eric Schepard, Theatrical Agent, 66
description: Eric Schepard, a theatrical agent for more than 35 years, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Iowa Utilities Sign Merger Pact
description: IE Industries and Iowa Southern Inc. said they had signed a definitive agreement to merge the two utility holding companies in an exchange of stock. The merged company will be called IES Industries and will have combined revenues of about $600 million.

title: Transamerica Deal
description: The Transamerica Corporation, the United States insurance and financial services company, cut its stake in the London-based insurance broker Sedgwick Group P.L.C. to 25 percent, from 39 percent. The 59 million Sedgwick shares involved were purchased here by Morgan Stanley Securities and S. G. Warburg Securities for resale to investors. Transamerica said it made a profit of about $30 million after taxes from the sale proceeds of about $245 million.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Company News page on Feb. 5 about job cuts at the French computer maker Compagnie des Machines Bull misstated the number of people employed worldwide by the company. It is 44,400; the company's work force in France alone numbers 17,000.

title: Irish Music
description: Patrick Street's concert is the first of several performances of Irish music in New York City to celebrate St. Patrick's Day on March 17. They include:

title: Transcript of Baghdad's Cease-Fire Order
description: Following is the transcript of a statement by an Iraqi military spokesman announcing a cease-fire order to Iraqi troops. The statement was broadcast on Baghdad radio and translated from Arabic by The Associated Press.

title: Wal-Mart's Net Up 13%; 2 Others Fall
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's fastest-growing retailer, yesterday reported record profits and sales for the fourth quarter and the year ended Jan. 31. But two other leading chains, the J. C. Penney Company and the May Department Stores Company, said their fourth-quarter nets fell below those of the previous year.

title: An Apple Vice President To Head Software Unit
description: Daniel L. Eilers, a nine-year veteran of Apple Computer Inc., has been named president and chief executive of the Claris Corporation, Apple's software subsidiary in Santa Clara, Calif. The appointment is effective March 18.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching to Repair Cracks on Door Hinges
description: The space shuttle Discovery will be moved back to a hangar and its flight delayed from March 9 so engineers can repair cracked hinges on access doors, space agency officials said today.

title: War Damages and Old Debts Could Exhaust Iraq's Assets
description: Iraq has very little money to pay war reparations, and had overdue debts to many creditors even before it invaded Kuwait, current and former United States Government officials and other experts say.

title: Crash Kills Witness in Noriega Case
description: A crucial Government witness in the drug conspiracy case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was killed Wednesday night in a single-vehicle car wreck in Miami, a few days before the witness was to testify in the trial of two of the General's co-defendants.

title: Blues and Rangers Tie, 4-4, As Hull Is Held Scoreless
description: For the third time in their last five games, the Rangers settled for a 4-4 tie, this time against the St. Louis Blues in a match of first-place teams before 17,039 fans at the Arena.

title: 'This Aggression Will Not Stand'
description: Yours is a society which cannot accept 10,000 dead in one battle. -- SADDAM HUSSEIN, July 25, 1990.

title: Vanderpoel Adriance, An Ex-Stockbroker, 81
description: Vanderpoel Adriance, a former stockbroker, investment consultant and governor of the American Stock Exchange, died on Feb. 18 at his home in Shelly Bay, Bermuda. He was 81 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Arizona election results referred incorrectly to the losing candidate for governor, Terry Goddard. He is a former Mayor of Phoenix, not the present one.

title: U.S. Panel Urges That All Children Be Vaccinated for Hepatitis B
description: Frustrated by the widespread reluctance of adults to be vaccinated against hepatitis B, a leading cause of serious illness and death, a Federal panel has recommended that all children be vaccinated instead.

title: 'Junk Bond' Price Rise Continues
description: Prices of high-yield "junk bonds" continued to rise yesterday and finished February with their best-ever monthly return.

title: Some of the Americans Feel Test of Mettle Was Too Easy
description: The war's swift end has left soldiers and marines relieved that there were few American casualties, skeptical of Saddam Hussein's intentions and disappointed that they never got to test their mettle in battle.

title: Good, Bad and Good Days In the Life of Frank Sinatra
description: Some of the most indelible images in "The Voice of Our Time," an adulatory 90-minute PBS special on the career and life of Frank Sinatra, are its many rare clips of the singer in concert when he was the bobbysoxers' idol.

title: Thornburgh Policy Leads to a Sharp Ethics Battle
description: On June 8, 1989, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh sent a memorandum to Federal prosecutors around the country. The prosecutors applauded it as providing an important tool for law-enforcement officials. But defense lawyers and other critics interpreted it as an alarming declaration that Federal prosecutors were free to ignore the ethics rules that apply to every other lawyer in the country.

title: Guitar Quartet
description: The Los Angeles Guitar Quartet -- John Dearman, William Kanengiser, Scott Tennant and Andrew York -- is to play new music by Leo Brouwer, Ian Krouse and Stephen Funk Pearson at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. The program also includes the ensemble's transcriptions of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" Overture, the Telemann Concerto in G and selections from Falla's "Amor Brujo." Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: New Sonata for Organ
description: Robert Fertita, an organist, is to give the world premiere of a sonata by Myron Fink at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street in Manhattan, on Sunday at 5 P.M. The program also includes works by Couperin, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Vierne. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 860-2077.

title: A.T.&T. Plans A Kuwait Link
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was sending equipment to Kuwait City that would make it possible to place international phone calls from the battered capital by Sunday.

title: Scientist in AIDS Rift Offers 2d Look at Virus
description: Dr. Luc Montagnier, a discoverer of the AIDS virus, said today that he would re-examine original samples of the virus to help unravel the mystery of who first isolated it.

title: The Keating Eleven
description: Four and then five Senators met furtively with Federal regulators on two separate occasions in April 1987 to discuss special treatment for Charles Keating, the flashy political contributor. Now, after more than a year of investigating the Keating Five, the Senate Ethics Committee can identify only Senator Alan Cranston of California as worthy of censure by the full Senate. The other four are excused with mild rebukes.

title: Citicorp's Delinquent Loans Expected to Rise Further
description: Citicorp's chief financial officer said yesterday that the company expected loan delinquencies to continue to rise this year, with increases likely to be particularly large in the first quarter.

title: Lessons of Victory
description: At the end of the battle of Agincourt in Shakespeare's "Henry the Fifth" King Henry says: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French That in the field lie slain. . . . Where is the number of our English dead? Edward the Duke of York, the Earl of Suffolk, Sir Richard Ketly, Davy Gam, esquire; None else of name; and of all other men But five and twenty. O God, thy arm was here.

title: Gorbachev Won't Yield Baltic Republics
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Nearly 300 people dressed up and turned out for PHILIP ROTH, who received the National Arts Club's Medal of Honor for Literature last night in New York. The author of 19 books since 1959, Mr. Roth has won the National Book Award and many others. His memoir about his father, "Patrimony," was recently published by Simon & Schuster.

title: G.I.'s Who Beat the Guard Remain Wary
description: Lieut. Gen. Frederick Franks Jr., who commanded the American armor that broke through to crush the Iraqi Republican Guard, strongly urged his forces today to maintain a wary vigilance even though the single entry on his headquarters bulletin board proclaimed: "Ceasefire. 0800. 28 Feb. 91."

title: COMPANY NEWS HDL>Sale Talks Are Held At Revlon
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant headed by the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, is in talks about a possible sale of the company with Procter & Gamble; L'Oreal, the French cosmetics giant, and Unilever, the British-Dutch conglomerate.

title: Mattingly Is Named Captain; Will He Go Down With Ship?
description: One day earlier, Don Mattingly walked into the Yankees' training camp to begin a new season with the same old bad back. Today, with rain interrupting the second day of workouts, he took on another major task.

title: New Bendel's Has It All, But Will It Be Enough?
description: The Henri Bendel that opens tomorrow will be the first large new store on Fifth Avenue in many years. It is a distinction that carries as much uncertainty as it does promise in these days of slow retail sales, even for stores that cater to the affluent.

title: After the War, We Face Some Tough Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Plans Tougher Rules On Emissions
description: Six months after tightening its vehicle emissions controls to match California's strict rules, New York State plans to go even further in 1995, again following California's lead, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 537 money market mutual funds increased by $3.43 billion, to $468.18 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 163 institutional funds increased by $1.03 billion, to $130.24 billion. The 272 general-purpose funds were up by $806 million, to $160.10 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.6 billion, to $177.84 billion, the institute said.

title: Feelings of Pride and Relief, Tempered by a Sense of Fear and Uncertainty
description: This village on the North Shore of Long Island is bursting with expressions of support for the troops in the Persian Gulf: two American flags on every lamppost on the main street, yellow ribbons in store windows, a banner across the village gazebo saying, "God Bless Our Troops. Hope You Come Home Soon."

title: Critic's Choice
description: Adapted from Chekhov's short story "In the Ravine," Romulus Linney's "Unchanging Love" is a plangent play about a conflict between small-town greed and untainted innocence. In it, Mr. Linney has linked his art with that of Chekhov, transplanting the narrative from Russia to the foothills of Appalachia. The characters and themes belong to Chekhov; the dialogue is Mr. Linney's.

title: Review/Film; Coming to America, to a Chilly Welcome
description: In "Misplaced," a proud Polish woman and her teen-age son immigrate to the United States for political reasons, and rebuild their lives in an environment that is often less than friendly. Settling with relatives in Virginia, they must contend with economic hardship, lack of suitable job opportunities, loneliness, and the supercilious behavior of those not eager to make them feel welcome in a new land.

title: Effort Renewed To Give Begging Legal Sanction
description: Advocates for the homeless, who lost a bid last year to legally protect begging in the subway, are quietly pressing a new lawsuit in state court, once again claiming that begging is speech and should be protected under the law.

title: After the War, We Face Some Tough Questions; Preserving the Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: First Brands Stock
description: The First Brands Corporation announced that half of the company's shares outstanding would be offered publicly by two major shareholders. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the First Boston Corporation will offer 10.5 million to 12 million shares of common stock of First Brands. On the New York Stock Exchange, First Brands stock fell 50 cents a share today, to $23.25. That gives the stock being sold a current value of about $240 million.

title: Stocks Mixed After Wide Price Swings
description: The end of the war is expected to give the economy a lift, but stocks fluctuated wildly again yesterday, with prices closing mixed as investors moved out of highfliers and into less-favored stocks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Chile Petitions U.S. on Fruit
description: The Government and the fruit producers of Chile filed separate petitions with the United States Government today, seeking $458 million for the 1989 fruit embargo over a cyanide scare.

title: 7 Ex-Officials of New Jersey Town Are Accused of Looting It
description: Seven former Manchester Township officials, including three former Mayors, have been indicted on charges of conspiring to steal more than $2.2 million in municipal funds between 1983 and 1990, the Ocean County Prosecutor said today.

title: Review/Photography; Collecting Archetypes Of the Rich And Poor
description: Lisette Model was so much a creature of legend -- much of it of her own making -- that when she died in 1983, at the age of 82, her career lapsed into virtual obscurity. Those who remembered her usually remembered her as a teacher, one whose influence can be felt most palpably in the work of Diane Arbus. But as an exhibition of Model's work at the International Center of Photography suggests, her photographs are at least as important as her pedagogy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies on Wednesday about the funeral in Newark for Pvt. Robert Talley, who was killed in the gulf war, misidentified the man at the right. He was the Rev. Jesse Jackson's bodyguard, not the Rev. Maurice Talley.

title: Communities Must Form a Partnership With Officer on the Beat
description: To the Editor:

title: A Homeland Moves To Rejoin South Africa
description: South Africa will appoint four government ministers in Ciskei, a nominally independent black homeland, under an agreement to begin Ciskei's reincorporation into South Africa, the homeland's leader said.

title: The Year Washington Missed a Birthday
description: To the Editor:

title: LTV Share Price Up Sharply
description: The price of the common shares of the LTV Corporation jumped today in heavy trading in the wake of reports earlier in the week that LTV might find a way out of bankruptcy.

title: L.I. Toxic-Waste Dump: No Warning or Cleanup
description: The property looks like nothing special: 10 acres of old warehouses, overgrown fields littered with debris and a vast yard of dirt and dust. A water tower looming overhead says "Liberty."

title: Ames 2d Half Loss
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it would have an operating loss of $44.7 million for the second half of 1990, about $15 million less than earlier projections. In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Ames also predicted it would have operating income of $55.8 million for the current fiscal year, compared with an operating loss of $320.2 million in the just-completed year.

title: Petrovic's Hot Hand Lifts Nets
description: Drazen Petrovic brought a shooter's mentality to the National Basketball Association two years ago from Yugoslavia. But it wasn't until the Nets freed him from the Portland Trail Blazers' bench on Jan. 23 that he got a chance to demonstrate it on a regular basis.

title: James V. Hart, Monsignor, 93
description: Msgr. James V. Hart, pastor emeritus of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx and a New York priest for 67 years, died on Wednesday at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 93 years old and lived at St. Patrick's Nursing Home in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press on the Company News page in some editions on Wednesday about a missed interest payment by E-II Holdings Inc. misstated E-II's corporate affiliations. E-II has not been run by the Riklis Family Corporation since December, and it also no longer owns the McCrory Corporation and other retailing chains.

title: New Alliance Plans Housing in 20 Cities
description: Seven philanthropies and the Prudential Insurance Company of America are beginning an ambitious program to revitalize poor neighborhoods in 20 major cities.

title: How to Honor Victors in Gulf
description: Striving to balance his patriotism and New York City's penury, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would name a "blue-ribbon host committee" next week to recommend an appropriate celebration for soldiers returning from the Persian Gulf war, and to help find ways to pay for it.

title: Daily News and Pressmen End Talks, Deadlocked
description: The Daily News and its pressmen's union abandoned efforts to negotiate a settlement in the 127-day-old strike yesterday, leaving the fate of the newspaper hanging on whether a buyer can be found.

title: TV Weekend; Arabs, Jews and the Roots of the Rage
description: "A Fundamental Conflict" is better than it sometimes looks and sounds. At moments, this first hour of a three-part documentary on world terrorism seems much like all the other scare reports that have crowded the tube since the United States moved into the Gulf. But Sunday night's program, at 8 on the Arts & Entertainment cable channel, goes beyond the pictures of bombed buildings and bloody bodies and a narration that has more than its share of exclamation points, to explore the divisions between Palestinians and Israelis that have made the Middle East a killing ground of contemporary political terrorism.

title: Teheran Speaks Of Iraq's Future
description: The Iranian Foreign Minister said today that the future of Iraq must be decided by its people and that Iran opposes interference by the allies, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Johnson Confident He's the Starting Shortstop
description: The organization's blueprint for the infield is clear in Howard Johnson's head. Having had it etched in his mind for months, Johnson is set to carve the blueprint in stone for the future.

title: Restaurants
description: "Since Eve ate apples, much depends on dinner," wrote Lord Byron, alluding to the affinity between romance and gastronomy, which has been celebrated in literature, theater and art over the centuries. When it comes to restaurants, though, the forums for seduction are becoming as rare as gentlemen's duels for a lady's hand. Economics and fashion dictate that restaurants today be big, boisterous and fast paced. Happily, the Sign of the Dove remains an exception.

title: 7 Indicted on Fraud Charges Over Big Bank Loans to Iraq
description: A Federal grand jury indicted three former officials of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and four Iraqis today on fraud charges involving more than $4 billion in loans to Iraq.

title: Pop Jazz; For Irish, It Isn't Folk, It's Just Music and It's Here
description: For listeners accustomed to mainstream pop music, a traditional ethnic style can seem like a foreign language. But once one gains a basic grasp of a country's ways and practices, the music becomes a conduit for an entire cultural history and racial identity. Patrick Street, a quartet performing traditional Irish music tonight at Symphony Space, speaks the language of Ireland in beautiful and plainspoken tones, melodies, ballads and reels.

title: Market Place; Still More Growth In Biotechnology?
description: WITH most of the premier biotechnology stocks at or near 52-week highs, investors face a tricky decision: Is it time to take profits or is there more growth left in the group? There is no unanimity among Wall Street analysts.

title: Bridge Troubles Are Linked To a Lack of Coordination
description: A New York City Council committee charged yesterday that a serious lack of coordination between the city's Transportation Department and the Transit Authority created the conditions that forced subway traffic to be halted on the Manhattan Bridge.

title: Ford Plans to Reduce Salaried Work Force
description: Faced with mounting losses, the Ford Motor Company announced plans today to cut its salaried work force through layoffs and early retirements, in an effort to save $3 billion by the end of the year.

title: Fortepiano Recital
description: The fortepianist Melvyn Tan is to play Beethoven's Sonatas Nos. 16 and 18 at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program also includes Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 333) and Rondo in A minor (K. 511). Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 674-2433.

title: Iraqis Reduced To a 'Rabble,' General Asserts
description: The guns fell silent across Iraq and Kuwait today, with only isolated exchanges of fire marring the cease-fire between the remnants of President Saddam Hussein's occupying armies and the coalition forces who thrashed them in a 100-hour ground war.

title: Stewart, 0-2 in World Series, Still Sniping at the Winners
description: Last October, in the immediate aftermath of Cincinnati's World Series sweep of Oakland, Dave Stewart said that the Athletics were still better than the Reds. Today, the outspoken Stewart questioned the contracts some players received this winter and cited as Exhibit A Jose Rijo, the pitcher who beat him twice in the Series.

title: Democrats Want to Reduce Power of Florio's Treasurer
description: After chafing for a year under the policies of Gov. Jim Florio's most powerful commissioner, Treasurer Douglas C. Berman, 29 fellow Democrats in the Assembly introduced a bill today that would make him commissioner of a lot less.

title: 2d Lockheed Battle Begins
description: The Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons officially began his second proxy fight for control of the Lockheed Corporation today by mailing proxy statements to shareholders asking them to support his candidates for the company's board.

title: Wyllys Terry Jr., Insurance Broker, 82
description: Wyllys Terry Jr., an insurance broker, died on Tuesday at the Southern Chester County Medical Center at Jennersville, Pa., He was 82 years old and lived in Kennett Square, Pa., and Castine, Me.

title: Olajuwon Returns
description: Akeem Olajuwon, who missed 25 games after he suffered a fracture of the bone around his right eye, returned to the Houston Rockets last night in all-star form.

title: Reviews/Art; Jasper Johns, Cool And/or Confessional
description: For the better part of 40 years, beginning in the 1950's with his cool, ironical renditions of flags and targets and continuing today with his autobiographical meditations, Jasper Johns has rarely been far from the center of attention. Now, with the coincidence of both an outstanding retrospective of his drawings at the Whitney Museum of American Art and works from roughly the last five years at the Leo Castelli Gallery, he is once again conspicuously in evidence. Laid out is the scope of his career, and especially the puzzling last few years.

title: Niagara Mohawk's $150 Million Issue
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Company is offering $150 million in first-mortgage bonds with a maturity of March 1, 2021, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Paul-Harris Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: Paul-Harris Stores Inc. filed a Chapter 11 petition for protection from its creditors on Wednesday. The filing was made in United States Bankruptcy Court in Indianapolis. The retailer may close as many as 41 of its 377 stores, a spokesman, David Sease, said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Energen Corp., Birmingham, Ala., an oil and gas company, named Michael Warren president and chief operating officer. * Hannah-Barbera Productions Inc., Los Angeles, a unit of American Financial Corp., named Sheldon B. Rabinowitz senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Islanders Distracted by Rumor of Sutter Trade
description: Outside influences continue to distract the Islanders on the ice in this winter of discontent for the team that once won four Stanley Cup championships.

title: Iraqi Letter On Compliance
description: Following is the text of a letter from Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq that was circulated here today, as translated by the United Nations from the Arabic:

title: On Disputed Land, Paraguay Reaps a Whirlwind
description: As his five children played barefoot in a manioc field, Cesar Galeano folded and unfolded an eviction order and wondered what the next few weeks would bring.

title: Joy for Marines, And a Little Envy
description: Here at the base of the Marine First Division, euphoria over the cease-fire today was tinged with mistrust of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and with a touch of envy among marines who missed a chance to take part in the battle.

title: Communities Must Form a Partnership With Officer on the Beat; Drug Front Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Subbing for an Old Friend

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Telecommunications Corp., Dallas, a unit of ATC Inc., has acquired a 53 percent stake in Reserve-A-Phone Systems Inc., a Canadian cellular telephone business, for undisclosed terms, and intends to make a formal tender offer for all remaining shares. * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, will purchase the former Merabank Center in Phoenix from the Resolution Trust Corporation for undisclosed terms.

title: The History Of Women
description: Here is a sampling of events in the New York metropolitan area this weekend in celebration of Women's History Month. Today

title: On Stage, and Off
description: No Deal on 'Assassins'

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Percussion by David Moss

title: Young Amateur Impresses Veterans
description: Hardened veterans of the PGA Tour customarily cast a cold eye on phenoms, but Phil Mickelson is being almost universally accepted as someone who belongs.

title: Teen-Ager Angst
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter Hawley Plan
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the West Coast department store chain that filed for protection from creditors in bankruptcy court earlier this month, received court approval for its full $250 million financing arrangment from Chemical Bank. The company said the financing would help to keep its stores full of merchandise.

title: Desert Missions By Commandos Aided in Victory
description: Well before allied ground units swept into Iraq, American commando teams were waging a clandestine war deep inside Iraqi territory, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Mother of All Columns
description: If we think hard enough now, and if after the troops come home we just hang on to what we learned, the United States can pluck a surprise bonus from the victory in the gulf: a few fine victories at home.

title: For Subway Police, a New Pride Over Duty in 'the Hole'
description: Like thousands of police cadets before him, Jose J. Rodriguez was crushed when he was assigned to the New York City transit police force instead of the city force.

title: Down by 19-1, Knicks Rally for Fourth in a Row
description: Somehow the Knicks fell behind, 19-1, last night.

title: General's Widow Wins Bangladesh Vote
description: Khaleda Zia, who transformed herself in less than a decade from the self-effacing wife of a powerful general to a formidable political leader in her own right, today emerged the winner of the freest national election in this country's history.

title: Review/Music; Five Seasons In Premiere By Lieberson
description: No matter how hotly inspired a composer may be, nothing of much artistic value can begin to happen until a workable mold is found for the creative juices. One loosely defined form that has been productive over the centuries for composers like Vivaldi, Haydn, Tchaikovsky and Glazunov concerns itself with the passing of the seasons, an idea that has the inherent appeal to musicians of linking natural forces to logic and mechanics. That the scheme retains its attractiveness was illustrated at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening when the San Francisco Symphony under its music director, Herbert Blomstedt, gave the New York premiere of "World's Turning," by Peter Lieberson.

title: TRUCE HOLDS, BUT U.S. VOWS TO STAY IN IRAQ UNTIL BAGHDAD MEETS ALLIES' PEACE TERMS
description: As war subsided into isolated skirmishing, the Bush Administration said today that it would keep United States forces in southern Iraq until it was satisfied that Iraq would comply with American terms for a permanent cease-fire.

title: Korea to Field Single Youth Team
description: North and South Korea were given permission today to field a single team for the world youth soccer championships.

title: Now, The Chance To Tune In For TV Testimonials On Lawyers (No Guarantees, Of Course)
description: Ronald Reagan once touted Van Heusen shirts, and Frank Gifford pushed Lucky Strikes. But here we are, in Year XIV of the legalized legal advertising era, and it appears no contented client in the history of New York State has ever extolled his lawyer in a television commercial.

title: Fathers and Fetuses
description: When it comes to protecting the fetus, an exclusive focus on the potentially pregnant woman's exposure to toxic chemicals is not warranted by common sense or scientific evidence. The absence of research detailing how the exposure of fathers affects their future babies does not mean that no such effects occur.

title: U.N.L.V. Season Safe
description: Bradley Booke, the legal cousel for Nevada-Las Vegas, said yesterday he had been assured by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that the university's undefeated basketball team would be able to finish its season without any players being suspended for rules violations.

title: Radical Who Mellowed Along With the Voters
description: The Rev. Emanuel Cleaver has clearly come a long way since his arrival here 23 years ago. That was in 1968, a year of racial violence here as well as in several other American cities. The black Baptist minister, a native of Texas, was widely regarded as a radical on civil rights, he recalled today. But so too were many others who served with him in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King's Southern Christian Leadership Conference, like Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta who is now widely regarded as a relative moderate.

title: A SHATTERED CITY STRUGGLES FOR LIFE
description: Behind the newly fluttering flags and the cheers of its residents, this once-thriving city of wide avenues, opulent residences, modern high-rise buildings and massive mosques appeared today as a maimed victim of war whose spine has been hurt and whose nerves and circulation were shattered.

title: Now, Allies and Others Begin Offering Competing Bids for Postwar Future
description: Having stood firmly alongside the United States during the climactic days of the Persian Gulf war, Western European governments are quietly preparing to compete with Washington for political influence in the Middle East now that the fighting is over.

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures and readings in New York City this weekend.

title: Ultimately, Customers Will Bear the Cost
description: Bankers said yesterday that the higher deposit insurance premiums they must pay the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will be spread without great pain among their customers and shareholders. But they complained that all banks, including the strong, were being required to pay for the problems of the weak.

title: Rain Provides Relief, and Problems, for a Parched California
description: A welcome series of storms has brought rain to California the last two days, causing residents to engage in all sorts of activities that, after five years of drought, had become unusual.

title: Robinson No Longer Distracted
description: In less than an hour, the San Antonio Spurs would be playing the Dallas Mavericks but now, instead of shooting baskets at the HemisFair Arena, several Spurs stood staring at the message board where CNN was reporting that Baghdad was being bombed. The war in the Persian Gulf had begun. But that Wednesday night, Jan. 16, others remained in the Spurs' dressing room, transfixed.

title: Stieb Doubles Salary
description: While other clubs complain about soaring player contracts, the Toronto Blue Jays doubled Dave Stieb's salary when they didn't have to.

title: Review/Film; Director Returns to Garcia Marquez
description: No film maker will ever fully capture the gravity-defying magic of Gabriel Garcia Marquez's fiction, but Ruy Guerra comes reasonably close. Mr. Guerra, who adapted his 1983 "Erendira" from a Garcia Marquez story, has in "The Fable of the Beautiful Pigeon Fancier" collaborated with the novelist on an original screenplay and filmed it with a rueful fancifulness very like that which colors Mr. Garcia Marquez's prose.

title: CLAIMING VICTORY, IRAQ HOLDS ITS FIRE
description: Soldiers fired guns into the air in celebration today in Baghdad after Iraq ordered its forces to stop fighting and declared the Persian Gulf war a great Iraqi victory.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $200 million in noncallable notes due March 13, 1995, through Lehman Brothers. The notes, which have a 7 5/8 percent coupon, are being offered to the public at a price of 100, to yield 15 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Comerford O'Malley, Educator, Is Dead at 88
description: The Rev. Comerford J. O'Malley, who served as teacher, president and chancellor of DePaul University in Chicago in a 47-year career there, died Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. He was 88 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL MONETTE, the author of "Borrowed Time," a book about his companion's struggle with AIDS, has helped write an episode about AIDS for the television show "Thirty something." ABC plans to broadcast the show on April 30.

title: Welcome News Of Safe Fliers
description: More than 40,000 Navy, Air Force and Army personnel were shipped to the Persian Gulf from here and the surrounding Tidewater Virginia area, leaving behind perhaps twice that many deeply worried spouses, children and other loved ones.

title: The Debate Goes On
description: Over the buzz of electric hairclippers and the occasional snap of a pair of scissors at S&B Barber Shop in Harlem, a running debate over the Persian Gulf war has displaced the argument over the New York Mets pitcher Dwight Gooden's multimillion-dollar baseball contract.

title: Allies, at U.N., Seek Formal Cease-Fire, Retaining Right to Attack
description: The United States and its Persian Gulf war allies plan to retain the right to attack Iraq if it breaks their peace terms under the provisions of a new Security Council draft resolution that would eventually convert the cease-fire into a formal one, diplomats said today.

title: Strikes Sweep Eastern Germany, Reflecting Increasing Discontent
description: Strikes and work stoppages idled tens of thousands of workers throughout eastern Germany for the second consecutive day today, just days after Germany's Government agreed to raise taxes to bolster eastern Germany's sputtering economy.

title: Consumer Spending In Big Drop
description: Consumer spending, which slipped severely in the final quarter of last year, dropped an additional six-tenths of a percent in January, the Government said today. It was the steepest decline in consumer spending in more than four years.

title: Layoffs at Aetna
description: Layoff notices have started going out to employees of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company as the insurer begins a shrinking of its domestic insurance divisions, a company spokesman, Jon Powell, said. Aetna announced in October that it would eliminate 2,600 positions.

title: Seidman Issues F.D.I.C. Aid Plan
description: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, today proposed a $64.4 billion plan over five years that relies heavily on Government borrowing to shore up the ailing Federal program that protects deposits.

title: Katie Louchheim Memorial
description: A memorial service for Katie Louchheim Klopfer, a former official of the State Department and the Democratic Party, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. at the All Souls Unitarian Church at Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. Speakers will include Eugene J. McCarthy and Theodore Sorensen. Known professionally as Katie Louchheim, Mrs. Klopfer died in Manhattan on Feb. 11 at the age of 87.

title: Study Urges a Business Role In Early-Childhood Programs
description: A leading business group warned yesterday that the national effort to improve schools would fail unless companies played a more active role in health and social programs for young children.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 9 about a fire in Brooklyn that killed three small children misstated the age of one victim, Jonathan Green. He was 2 years old, not 2 months.

title: Review/Theater; Turning Back the Clock
description: "THE SPEED OF DARKNESS," Steve Tesich's new play, is only a few minutes old when a character announces that blood will eventually be spilled on the living-room carpet of the all-American home where it takes place. By the time the final curtain falls more than two hours later, blood has indeed been spilled, and so have guts, shameful secrets and a heap of dirt that stands for the stain on a family and a nation. That's the kind of play Mr. Tesich has written: one that tells you what it is going to do and then does it, messily perhaps, but with a vengeance and, once it finally gets going, with an inexorable grip.

title: Is One Pitcher Worth 1,000 Teachers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Down 0.7%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products declined seven-tenths of a percent from January to February, and averaged 4.6 percent below a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: A Prayer And a Fast: What Turned Condom Vote
description: The woman who cast the pivotal vote to give New York City's high schools the nation's most sweeping condom distribution program is the daughter of a rural Ohio preacher who made her tortured decision in ways the Bible and her father taught her -- by fasting and praying.

title: Cairo Counting Victory's Spoils
description: With the Iraqi Army fully routed, Egypt began looking today to turn its participation in the allied victory into concrete political and economic advantages for itself.

title: Creditors Urge Bankruptcy
description: Creditors are trying to force Gillett Holdings Inc., the parent company of the Vail and Beaver Creek ski resorts, into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Aftermath of the Keating Verdicts: Damage Control, Political Glee
description: The Keating Five case moved today from the Senate Ethics Committee to the unpredictable arena of American politics, with the five Senators struggling to contain the damage while consultants were trading ideas about how to use the issue in the next elections.

title: A Low-Budget High Court
description: Two Supreme Court Justices went to Capitol Hill today to ask a Senate subcommittee to approve the Court's $25 million budget request.

title: Tar Heels Roll Over Georgia Tech
description: Hubert Davis hit three consecutive 3-point shots to give North Carolina its biggest lead of the first half and the Tar Heels beat cold-shooting Georgia Tech, 91-74, tonight in what may have been Kenny Anderson's final home game.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Historic Menu

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: INDICTED FOR IRAQI LOANS A Federal grand jury indicted three former officials of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and four Iraqis on fraud charges involving more than $4 billion in loans to Iraq. Business Day, page D1.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Housing in Westchester Built With Private Funds
description: At a time when many builders have been forced to postpone projects for lack of construction loans, Norman B. Judelson, a White Plains developer, is proceeding with a development of 11 single-family houses in Briarcliff Manor in Westchester County, using private financing. He has formed a partnership, Scarborough Estates at Briarcliff Associates, with three investors.

title: All-Male School Gets Green Light in Detroit
description: The Detroit Board of Education has given its approval for an all-male academy aimed at overcoming the problems of young blacks, but critics have questioned its legality.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hairston Retires
description: Carl (Big Daddy) Hairston, the defensive lineman who spent the last of his 15 National Football League seasons with the Phoenix Cardinals, retired yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; What if the Human Mind Is Basically Beastly?
description: Divorce Among the Gulls An Uncommon Look at Human Nature By William Jordan 205 pages. North Point Press. $19.95.

title: U.S. to Investigate Jordan on Embargo
description: The United States said today that it was investigating reports that Jordan ignored a United Nations embargo and shipped weapons to Iraq during the war.

title: Israel Prepares For U.S. Move
description: Israel lifted its state of emergency this morning and advised citizens to resume normal lives.

title: Support for Iraq Seems to Erode
description: The signs were small but telling and seemed to say that Palestinians and other Jordanians who had been Saddam Hussein's most fervent supporters had begun today to shed a little hope.

title: L.A. Gear Responds to Suit
description: Responding to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by Nike Inc., L.A. Gear Inc. denied today that its new Catapult shoe infringed two Nike patents.

title: Tokyo Is Cautious On Mideast Aid
description: Japan adopted a cautious approach today to suggestions that it undertake a major aid program for the Middle East, as officials showed some embarrassment that fighting had ended with Parliament still debating an earlier pledge to aid the war effort.

title: Soviets Say Their Weapons Were Not Iraqis' Downfall
description: After witnessing the rout of an Iraqi Army largely trained and armed by Moscow, Soviet generals have been quick to insist that they and their weapons are not to blame.

title: New Training Sites And Coach for Trenary
description: Jill Trenary, the three-time United States figure-skating champion and reigning world champion, has switched coaches and training sites.

title: Fortunes and Spoils of War
description: CIVILIZATION'S worst nightmare has always been history's best story.

title: Guillermo Ungo, Longtime Head Of Salvador Democratic Left, 59
description: Guillermo Ungo, a longtime leader of the democratic left in El Salvador, died yesterday at the Spanish Hospital in Mexico City. He was 59 years old and lived in San Salvador.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Clark Equipment Co., South Bend, Ind., is offering $100 million in 9 3/4 percent notes due in 2001 at 99.491 to yield 9.83 percent through First Boston Corp. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by Standard & Poor's.

title: Five Ex-Contra Rebels Killed In Battle at Farm, Police Say
description: At least five former contra rebels were killed and five others wounded today in a gun battle with farmers at a farm organized by the Sandinistas in northern Nicaragua, the police said.

title: A Soviet Military View
description: Soviet generals have been quick to insist that they and their weapons were not to blame for the rout of an Iraqi Army largely trained and armed by Moscow. But some suggested that the performance of Western weapons showed the danger of cutting Soviet military spending.

title: Review/Film; Flying, Falling: Days of the Doors
description: IN the 60's, for anyone who took the Doors half as seriously as the Doors took themselves, wide-screen musical biography was strictly for the Trapp family. It would have been unimaginable that some day movie audiences would relive the moment when the guitarist Robby Krieger (Frank Whaley) pulled a scrap of paper out of his pocket and showed it to the singer Jim Morrison (Val Kilmer) and the two other Doors, saying shyly, "I came up with somethin' . . . I call it 'Light My Fire.' "

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about "Henry IV," Parts 1 and 2, at the Public Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the lighting designer of a 1989 Public Theater production of "Cymbeline." She was Pat Collins, not Jennifer Tipton.

title: Abel Quezada, 70, Political Cartoonist
description: Abel Quezada, a leading Mexican political cartoonist and painter, died today of leukemia at his home in Cuernavaca. He was 70.

title: Though Too Late for Some, War's End Brings Others Joy
description: As Americans around the world celebrated the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war today, Connie and Robert Clark stood silently in their front yard here, staring blankly at a crowd of reporters.

title: Review/Film; A Norwegian Crusoe
description: Nils Gaup's "Shipwrecked," presented by Walt Disney Pictures, is the kind of innocent live-action adventure movie the Disney people used to make before they turned their attention to adult audiences.

title: 2 Big Airlines Resuming Service to Middle East
description: Two of the biggest airlines serving the Middle East, Lufthansa and Air France were moving quickly yesterday to restore service to many cities in the region whose flights had been suspended because of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Taster's Choice Sets Second 'Soap' Episode
description: One of the hottest soap operas on television is unfolding in episodes that are scattered months apart and are no longer than television commercials.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroes on Collision Course Patrick McEnroe, the seventh-seeded player, survived a barrage of 13 aces by Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela en route to a 6-4, 7-6 victory yesterday in Chicago to join his top-seeded brother, John, in the quarterfinals of the Volvo tournament. John McEnroe faces Germany's Alexander Mronz and Patrick McEnroe meets his boyhood-friend, Richey Reneberg, the tourney's second seed, in today's quarterfinals.(AP) Lendl Gains Quarterfinals: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl trounced Nicklas Kulti of Sweden, 6-4, 6-0, to earn a berth in the quarterfinals of the ABN Amro Indoor tournament at Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Lendl, the world's third-ranked player, will face Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland. Paul Haarhuis edged Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, and Jan Siemerink defeated sixth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. In other second-round play, Omar Camporese of Italy ousted Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) N.B.A. Pistons Drop 4th Straight Sherman Douglas won a battle of the guards last night in Miami by scoring 27 points, including the tie-breaking basket with 1 minute 13 seconds left, as the Heat handed Detroit its fourth consecutive defeat, 100-98. Detroit lost despite a season-high 32 points by Vinnie Johnson and 30 by Joe Dumars. But it was another guard, Gerald Henderson, who took the final shot for Detroit, missing the rim on an 18-footer as the buzzer sounded. (AP) Hawks 117, Trail Blazers 109: John Battle scored 18 of his 26 points in the final quarter, sparking Atlanta to its 21st consecutive victory at home. Atlanta has the league's longest home winning streak. Battle had 9 points and Duane Ferrell added 7 in a 22-5 burst that turned an 80-72 deficit late in the third quarter into a 94-85 advantage. Battle capped the surge when he barely beat the shot clock with a 3-pointer out of the right corner with 5:49 to play. (AP) Lakers 121, Nuggets 108: Magic Johnson scored 18 points and added 14 assists as Los Angeles handed Denver its 10th loss in 11 games. The Lakers beat Denver for the eighth straight time by hitting 29 of 38 free throws. The Nuggets were 10 of 14 from the line. (AP) N.H.L. Sabres Rout Nordiques Dave Andreychuk scored the tie-breaker in the second period and Benoit Hogue clinched it with two third-period goals as Buffalo beat Quebec, 5-1, last night. (AP) Blackhawks 6, Whalers 3: Jeremy Roenick had a goal and an assist and Ed Belfour, the goalie, won for the 36th time, lifting Chicago. (AP) GOLF Rarick Leads at Kemper Open Cindy Rarick began protecting her lead a little early, but loosened up and shot a 3-under-par 68 yesterday to keep her ahead halfway through the Women's Kemper Open in Wailea, Hawaii. Rarick played conservatively and made nine straight pars at one point, but came alive when the defending champion, Beth Daniel, began creeping up the leader board. She pulled ahead with birdies on two of her last three holes. Rarick, one stroke ahead entering the second round, was 8-under, two strokes ahead of Daniel, who shot a 68. (AP)

title: SUNY Suspends a Fraternity
description: The State University of New York at Cortland has suspended a fraternity for four years after pledges claimed they were beaten, forced to eat laxatives and required to wear necklaces of chicken feet. Delta Kappa Beta was suspended Wednesday, said Linda Kuk, vice president of student affairs.

title: Managua Faults U.S. Bid to Soviets
description: Nicaragua complained today that a Bush Administration request that the Soviet Union cut off military supplies to the Nicaraguan Army was inappropriate.

title: L.P. Kramarsky, 95, Ex-Hadassah Chief, and Collector of Art
description: Lola Popper Kramarsky, former president of Hadassah, the national women's Zionist organization, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Buying Life Insurance: Where to Start
description: Buying life insurance is often a complicated procedure. And even the advice from experts can be contradictory.

title: Picture Book Prepared On the War With Iraq
description: "Victory in the Gulf," billed as "the complete story of the triumphant American and allied campaign," is scheduled for shipment to bookstores on Thursday.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Underground Police Role Is Detailed by 2 Officers
description: Col. Ali al-Saraf, who returned to duty as a Kuwaiti police officer two days ago, explained today how an underground resistance force had sniped at Iraqi outposts, executed collaborators and published a clandestine newspaper under the Iraqi occupation.

title: Busy Round: Perry Leads; Nicklaus Has 63; Azinger Disqualified
description: The Doral Ryder Open lost perhaps its most motivated player today when Paul Azinger was disqualified for a rules infraction Thursday that was brought to the attention of officials by a television viewer.

title: Auto Makers' Layoff Plans
description: The Big Three auto makers will have 38,950 auto workers on layoff next week as all or part of 17 assembly plants are closed because of slow sales and model changeovers.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia; After the War, the Saudis Prepare For a New Role Among the Arabs
description: The military victory over Iraq has considerably strengthened Saudi resolve to play a stronger role in Arab politics as an ally of the West and an opponent of militant governments in the Middle East, senior Saudi officials say.

title: The Mentally Ill Don't Know That They're Sick; Rehabilitation House
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Some Tax Relief For Gulf Service
description: When war began in the Persian Gulf, Congress and the President rushed to grant tax relief to military and civilian personnel serving in the area.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqis Hail Cease-Fire With a Hail of Bullets
description: Iraqis had a day free of bombing today for the first time in six weeks and began to look ahead to postwar life in their devastated country.

title: Fixed Mortgages Rise
description: Interest charges for new fixed-rate 30-year mortgages averaged 9.4 percent this week, up from 9.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year, adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.53 percent, down from 7.57 percent last week.

title: About New York; Virtual Reality! Hallucination!! Age of Aquarius!!!
description: "I'm not a swami-grab-a-buck," insisted Timothy Leary, who was being paid $2,000 for sharing some decidedly random thoughts with 500 New Yorkers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Dorette Vock Assael, Fundraiser, 59
description: Dorette Vock Assael, a fundraiser for charities, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 59 years old and had residences in Manhattan, Paris and Cannes.

title: Coping/With Children's Safety
description: Design takes on new meaning when there is a small child in the home. Dangers lurk in every room, from kitchen to bath, and the average house can be a mine field of hazards.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page on Feb. 1 about the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit misstated the background of one member. The judge, Laurence H. Silberman, has recently written to The Times that he was Deputy Attorney General of the United States in 1974- 75; he did not serve in the Reagan Administration.

title: Construction Spending Declines 2.6%
description: Construction spending plunged 2.6 percent in January to its lowest level in four years, the Government said today, but some analysts saw signs that the deterioration might be leveling off.

title: Alfred F. Havighurst, Professor, 86
description: Alfred F. Havighurst, professor emeritus of history at Amherst College, died Wednesday at a convalescent home in Leeds, Mass. He was 86 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: Enid C. Baird, Urban League Official, 85
description: Enid C. Baird, executive assistant to three presidents of the National Urban League, died on Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla. She was 85 years old and lived in Port Charlotte and Brooklyn.

title: For Yugoslavia, Breakup Is Best Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; New Works Deal With Alienation And Tiananmen
description: The sixth annual Morningside Dance Festival opened Monday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The program was a jumble. Yet it did include a few solidly crafted pieces.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Prime Minister John Major of Britain misstated the date he took office. It was Nov. 28, not 29.

title: Eleanor King, a Modern Dancer And Choreographer, Dies at 85
description: Eleanor King, a modern-dance choreographer and a member of the original Doris Humphrey-Charles Weidman company, died on Wednesday at the Actor's Home in Haddonfield, N.J. She was 85 years old.

title: Hispanic Nominee for U.S. Bench
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has recommended three candidates, including a Hispanic woman, to fill vacancies on the Federal District Court benches in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; ALLIED GENERALS AND IRAQIS TO MEET SOON ON CEASE-FIRE; BUSH STRESSES P.O.W. RETURN
description: President Bush announced today that allied and Iraqi commanders would meet soon on the battlefield to make arrangements for a permanent cease-fire. Initially set for Saturday, the meeting was later postponed until at least Sunday.

title: Salvador Guerrillas Pledge Not to Disrupt Next Election
description: In a fundamental policy shift, Salvadoran guerrilla leaders have ordered their followers not to interfere with voting in their country's municipal and legislative elections, scheduled for March 10.

title: The Frohnmayer Fumble
description: John Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, denies the agency was harmed by last year's fierce battle over what some Americans -- and especially Senator Jesse Helms -- perceived as Federal funding of smut. "I reject that [ notion ] categorically," he told a House subcommittee at a recent hearing on the agency's proposed budget.

title: Victims Of War
description: Even as U.S. forces, at George Bush's command, raced to victory in the desert, Ron Brown, the Democratic national chairman, was whistling past the graveyard.

title: A Consumer Who Uses Shopping to Try to Alter Many Corporate Policies
description: Consumer advocacy has its personal limits, and three years ago Alice Tepper Marlin found one of hers. Her daughter insisted on eating Skippy brand peanut butter. But Ms. Tepper Marlin's book, "Shopping for a Better World" said that Skippy was a politically incorrect choice.

title: Abel Quezada Dead; Mexican Artist Was 70
description: Abel Quezada, a leading Mexican political cartoonist and painter, died of leukemia on Thursday at his home in Cuernavaca. He was 70 years old.

title: Wells Fargo, Security Pacific Soar on Rumors of Merger
description: The possibility of a merger between the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles and Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco sent the shares of both companies sharply higher yesterday.

title: Colombia Rebel Group Quits After 23 Years
description: A group of rebels, who have been militarily active for 23 years, formally laid down their arms today and returned to civilian life.

title: Editorial Notebook; A World Leader, in Prisons
description: It's a depressing, if historic, milestone: During the 1980's, America locked up so many criminals that the inmate population more than doubled. With the total now above 1 million, and climbing, the United States can now claim the dubious distinction of imprisoning more of its citizens per capita than any other country.

title: Patents; First Woman In Inventors Hall of Fame
description: The National Inventors Hall of Fame this week selected Gertrude Belle Elion to be honored for her pioneering research at the Burroughs Wellcome Company that led to the development of drugs to combat leukemia, septic shock and tissue rejection in patients undergoing kidney transplants.

title: Bridge
description: The grandest play in the game, terminologically speaking, is the Grand Trump Coup. The declarer must ruff a winner deliberately, in order to shorten his trump holding and prepare for a coup position.

title: Rams to Meet Holy Cross in Patriot Final
description: Fordham and Holy Cross moved within two steps of a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament tonight with victories in the Patriot League semifinals.

title: Baseball; Yanks Hope Kelly Shows Even More
description: The 1990 season may have been a long and disappointing one for the Yankees, but it was also the summer in which a star was born.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. RALPH C. BLEDSOE, an official of the University of Southern California, has been named to direct the Presidential library of RONALD REAGAN in Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: Almost Living as One, 2 Princetons Discuss Marriage Again
description: Roger McDonough clearly remembers the last attempt to merge Princeton Borough with the suburban country cousin surrounding it, Princeton Township. It was in 1979, and although the township approved the merger by almost 3 to 1, the proposal lost in the borough by 33 votes out of about 3,000 cast, and was doomed.

title: Transit Officer Kills a Youth in Stopping a Subway Fight
description: A transit officer breaking up a fight yesterday afternoon among three teen-agers in an uptown Manhattan subway station shot and killed one of the youths, who was armed with a knife, transit police officials said.

title: The Perfect Postmodern Anchor
description: Those voices -- they're whispering again. They're saying he's just too weird. He's oddly folksy at one moment, steely-eyed the next. His facial expressions rival Jimmy Carter's eerie grin for incongruity. He looks exhausted, gets more colds than the average 5-year-old in day care and wears his envy of Walter Cronkite with all the subtlety of that flashy sweater vest he donned a few years back.

title: Guidepost; Is Gardening a Jungle?
description: Those who are new to gardening are likely to be confused by the maze of offerings at nurseries. Here is a guide to the pleasures and chores of basic plantings. Category Advantages Care Annuals For bright color all Last for one season. summer; ideal for Many can be seeded planters. right where the plants will grow. Perennials Plants last many years; blooms last just Roots must be lifted a few weeks, so be and divided every few sure to plan for a suc years. cession of blooms. Conifers For permanent land Dwarf species are im scaping; cone-bear portant in landscaping ing, usually with nee so plants don't grow dle-shaped leaves. out of control. Broad-leaved For permanent land Pruning is important evergreens scaping; azaleas and to keep plants under rhododendrons are control. two favorites. Fruit trees The blossoms are a Require sunny, well- springtime asset. drained soil; pollina Dwarf varieties are tors may be needed. ideal for small lots.

title: Patents; Inflatable Pump Sneaker Adjusts to Temperature
description: I. Martin Spier of New York City won a patent this week for a new kind of inflatable pump sneaker that adjusts itself to keep the pressure constant when temperatures change.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The White House; Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on Postwar Plans
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today at the White House: OPENING STATEMENT

title: CHRONICLE
description: KIRK DOUGLAS is expected to recover well enough from his recent helicopter accident to attend two dinners in his honor this month in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Study Finds Older Women Are at No Greater Risk in Bearing Children With Defects
description: Older women have no greater risk of bearing children with many of the commonest birth defects than do younger women, and may even have a lower chance of giving birth to babies with three common congenital deformities, a new study has found.

title: Let Iraq Off the Hook
description: As spoils belong to the victors, so usually do repara tions payment for war damage and suffering. With the war over, the U.S. and its allies can surely demand compensation from Iraq. But they would be wise not to do so.

title: Beliefs
description: Last fall the news media were momentarily fascinated by the notion that the oldest parts of the Bible -- the foundation stones of Judaism, Christianity, Islam and much of Western civilization -- were written by a woman.

title: Fiscal Woes Dim Ticker-Tape Dreams
description: As New Yorkers jockeyed with one another yesterday for the honor of welcoming returning soldiers from the Persian Gulf war, there remained no doubt that the city would mount a parade and a party. The only questions were when and how -- and who will pay for it all.

title: TB Cases Rose By 38% in '90 For New York
description: New cases of tuberculosis rose by more than 38 percent in New York City last year, almost four times the rate of increase of the previous year, city health officials said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KIM BASINGER'S effort to transform Braselton, Ga., into a tourist village-cum-recording and film studio has been derailed for at least a year by a lack of adequate sewage capacity.

title: Intel Loses Trademark Decision
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Intel Corporation is not entitled to trademark protection on the name of the 386 microprocessor, the company's most important product and one of the most valuable franchises in the computer industry.

title: H. P. Baldwin Terry, Insurance Broker, 78
description: H. P. Baldwin Terry, a retired insurance broker, died on Thursday in Weston, Mass., where he lived. He was 78 years old and had lived for years in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

title: Ismail to Compete At Princeton Meet
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail will compete in the IC4A Track and Field Championships for the first time in two years when he runs in the 55-meters event this weekend at Princeton University. Ismail, the Notre Dame football star who is forgoing his senior year to enter the National Football League draft, won the 55-meter event at Princeton two years ago and he is a heavy favorite to win this year. He did not compete last year.

title: Devils Pick Up a Victory on Road
description: The Devils continued one trend and ended another tonight with a 6-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Joe Louis Arena.

title: The Mentally Ill Don't Know That They're Sick; Administrators Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ex-Legislators in Carolina Plead Guilty to Selling Votes
description: Two former South Carolina legislators pleaded guilty today to charges that they had sold their votes to an undercover informer who was assisting a Federal investigation of Statehouse corruption.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Baker/TSA Inc., Coraopolis, Pa., received a $100 million Navy contract for environmental work. * Commerce Bancorp, Newport Beach, Calif., said it was considering the acquisition of American Republic Bancorp, Torrance, Calif.

title: Leo Katcher, Reporter And Writer, Dies at 79
description: Leo Katcher, a reporter, screenwriter, novelist and biographer, died Wednesday at the Tri-City Medical Center in Oceanside, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Oceanside.

title: G.E. Layoffs Set
description: The General Electric Company is laying off 40 people in Syracuse, effective immediately, in expectation of losing a $545 million radar contract with the Air Force, a company spokeswoman said. G.E. has already built two over-the-horizon radar systems, which bounce radio waves off the earth's ionosphere to detect objects up to 1,800 miles away. The company employs about 5,400 people in the Syracuse area.

title: News Summary
description: After the War 4-7

title: Bush Asks Congress for Extension on Trade Talks
description: President Bush asked Congress today for an additional two years to negotiate trade agreements, and several influential legislators quickly responded that they would insist on tougher enforcement of trade laws and commitments to address environmental and social issues arising from trade expansion as the price for going along.

title: U.S. Seeks to Learn if Tests On Pesticides Were Falsified
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was investigating allegations that a product safety testing laboratory in Texas fabricated research needed by chemical companies to license some of the most widely used pesticides in American agriculture.

title: Domino's Pizza
description: The owner of Domino's Pizza Inc., Tom Monaghan, said he had all but given up selling the company during the recession and was again taking charge of day-to-day operations. Mr. Monaghan, who put the company up for sale in September 1989, said two New York investment firms had stopped looking for buyers after rounding up only two offers, both too low.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE>;
Heads of Six New Units Named by Nestle USA
description: Nestle USA Inc., the umbrella company created this year to manage the American operations of Nestle S.A., has been reorganized to combine 15 food and beverage companies into six units. In doing so, the company also made several executive changes.

title: Arkansas Investigation
description: Coach Nolan Richardson of Arkansas closed practice and barred interviews with players and coaches yesterday as an investigation continued into allegations of a rape in an athletic dorm.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Old Glory Returns to Kuwaiti Capital
description: To the thunder of machine-gun fire and the bang of a military drum, Washington's new Ambassador to Kuwait hoisted the American flag above the United States Embassy here today and declared the besieged building open for business.

title: Project Denounced by Prince Gets Go-Ahead in London
