description: A decades-old battle between preservationists and proponents of modern architecture ended Thursday when a property developer, Lord Palumbo, won permission in Britain's highest court, the House of Lords, to demolish a group of Victorian buildings in the City of London.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Thursday about sudden death in young athletes misidentified a Bronx high school student who collapsed and died in a track meet last month. She was Stephanie Companioni.

title: Isadore Hamlin, 74, U.S. Zionist Official
description: Isadore Hamlin, a former executive vice chairman of the American section of the World Zionist Organization, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: Can Bankruptcy Reduce The Price of a Divorce?
description: The dream home of Gerald and Jeanne Farrey Sanderfoot is a simple, split-level ranch house, nestled amid the sea of grain silos in ZIP code 54944. The bay window in the living room overlooks a small duck pond, lending the 27-acre homestead the country feeling its owners sought for their three young children.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; ISRAEL'S LEADERS PUT UNITY ASIDE
description: The unifying threat of Iraqi missile attacks just one day behind them, Israel's leaders began breaking ranks today, issuing plans and pronouncements to stake out their positions on peace initiatives as they anticipate the visit next week by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.

title: Arthur Arzt, Manufacturer, 85
description: Arthur Arzt, a retired manufacturer of corrugated containers, died on Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 85 years old and lived in Bal Harbor, Fla.

title: Dr. David Harker, 84, a Pioneer in Use of X-Rays in Cell Research
description: Dr. David Harker, a pioneer in the use of X-rays to decipher the structure of critical substances in the life process of cells, died on Wednesday at Buffalo General Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons Lose Fifth Straight

title: Key Rates
Oil Climbs Again on Belief that OPEC Will Cut Output
description: Oil prices rallied late yesterday to close modestly higher for a fifth straight session in response to speculation that OPEC would soon take steps to cut production of crude.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "By God, we've kicked the Vietnam syndrome once and for all." -- President Bush. [ 1:2. ]

title: Battling Brothers of 'Yonkers' Actually Get Along
description: "Fight? Us?" asked Danny Gerard, eyes rolling toward the ceiling of his dressing room in the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: The Bullet and the Ballot Box
description: Ten years ago yesterday, an Irish Republican Army member, Bobby Sands, began the fatal hunger strike that made his name and cause -- to force the British withdrawal from Northern Ireland -- familiar to millions and supported by some.

title: New President Is Named At American University
description: Joseph D. Duffey, president of the University of Massachusetts, was named today as president of American University here.

title: Cuomo Forecast Predicts Years Of Budget Gaps
description: Even if the broad budget cuts proposed recently by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are adopted in full, state spending will outpace revenues in the coming years, the Cuomo administration predicted in a report released yesterday.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Jordan; Jordan King Asks 'Forgiveness' Among Arabs
description: King Hussein began an effort today to repair the diplomatic and economic damage his country suffered through its support of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, calling for forgiveness among Arabs and saying there should be no "gloating and apportioning blame."

title: Inland Steel to Cut Workers and Hours
description: Citing lower steel demand, the Inland Steel Company said it would lay off some workers and reduce workweeks for others at its only plant. The company employs 14,700 at the Indiana Harbor Works in East Chicago, Ind. -- 13,140 at its Inland Steel Flat Products Company and 1,560 at the Inland Bar and Structural Company.

title: Edwin H. Land Is Dead at 81; Inventor of Polaroid Camera
description: Edwin H. Land, whose invention of an instant camera changed the picture-taking habits of millions of people around the world, died yesterday in a hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 81 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Pro Basketball; Bianchi Dismissed; Knicks Turn to Checketts
description: Fans who have been chanting "Al must go" at recent Knicks games got their wish yesterday.

title: Banker's Plea In Loan Case
description: A man accused of being a principal mover in a scheme to give Iraq $4 billion in illegal loans told a Federal magistrate today that he was indigent. Prosecutors had moved earlier to seize his home and bank accounts.

title: Child Poverty Twice as Likely After Family Split, Study Says
description: After their parents separate or divorce, children are almost twice as likely to be living in poverty than they were before the breakup, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Prison for Killing L.I. Couple
description: A boarding house manager from Central Islip was sentenced today to 23 years to life in prison for beating and stabbing a tenant couple to death. The manager, Ricardo Ellison, 28 years old, pleaded guilty in January to killing Thomas and Edna Mae Robey.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Sandoz Approves Clozaril Testing
description: Sandoz A.G. said mental health care providers treating patients with its Clozaril drug may begin using their own blood monitoring systems no later than April 1. Sandoz now requires Clozaril providers to use its blood monitoring kit for the required weekly tests.

title: Three Naughty Mozart Texts Are Found
description: Three unpublished canon texts believed to be by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart have been found at Harvard University. The texts, which are humorous and scatological, were replaced by less racy lyrics in the first edition of Mozart's complete works, published by Breitkopf & Hartel early in 1804.

title: U.S. in Compromise at U.N.
description: Washington has dropped efforts to have the U.N. explicitly authorize renewed hostilities if Iraq fails to meet U.S. terms, diplomats said. Page 4.

title: President's Retirement Bringing Shift at Nucor
description: The Nucor Corporation, a leader in an efficient new steel technology, announced a shuffling of its management yesterday under F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman and chief executive.

title: INSIDE
description: Unexpected Extra Teachers A deal to save New York City teachers' jobs from budget cuts has left hundreds who would have normally been laid off sitting idle. Page 25. Inquiry Into Bank Ties Manhattan's District Attorney said he has concluded a foreign bank convicted of money laundering controls Washington's biggest bank. Page 31.

title: Spurs Sign Wingate
description: The San Antonio Spurs agreed to contract terms with David Wingate yesterday, one day after a Maryland prosecutor decided against holding the player for trial on a sexual assault charge. The contract for the guard covers the remainder of this season and the next two years. No other contract terms were disclosed.

title: Rates Increase for Long-Term Debt Issues
description: Long-term interest rates climbed yesterday as more investors moved into issues with shorter maturities. Dealers attributed the trend to a growing belief that the end of the Persian Gulf war will hasten the end of the recession, stimulate demand for credit and lift inflationary pressures.

title: Graffiti on the Metro? C'est Execrable!
description: To the Editor:

title: BBDO Agency Quits L.A. Gear
description: After just two months as the advertising agency for L.A. Gear, the Los Angeles office of BBDO resigned yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Alan T. Schumacher, a retired investment banker, rendered his wife's name incorrectly. She is the former Diana Kissel Barnard.

title: Disarming the Gulf
description: At his magnificent Wednesday briefing signaling the end of the war, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf was asked whether Iraq would rise again to threaten the Persian Gulf. No, replied the allied commander -- not unless "someone chooses to rearm them."

title: Bush Proposes an Alternative Rights Bill
description: The Bush Administration proposed civil rights legislation tonight that maintained its past positions on job discrimination, going against the stand voted last year by Congress.

title: Child Care In Conflict With a Job
description: Diane McCourtney said it made perfect sense to her when she lost her job as an account clerk at Seagate Technology in Minnetonka, Minn., last year because she took off too many days to care for her sick infant.

title: THAI ARMY BACKED ON A CONSTITUTION
description: The military junta that took power in a bloodless coup on Saturday received approval tonight for an interim Constitution from Thailand's constitutional monarch.

title: Haugen Drug Test Reported Positive
description: Greg Haugen tested positive for marijuana after beating Hector Camacho last weekend to win the World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight title, state boxing officials said today.

title: New Healthco Bid At $195 Million
description: Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas-based investment firm, made a new offer of $15 a share, or $195 million, for Healthco Inc., a Boston dental supply company. The offer came after Hicks, Muse ended an earlier bid of $19.25 a share.

title: Police Arrest Taxi Passenger In a Series of Bank Robberies
description: A 47-year-old man wanted in four bank robberies was arrested yesterday as he fled in a taxi after the police said he had pulled off a fifth, at the Bowery Savings Bank branch at 60th Street and Third Avenue.

title: You'd Think the U.S. Wanted to Discourage Resident Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; U.S. Softens Stance at U.N. On Terms for Resuming War
description: Under pressure from the Soviet Union and China, the United States abandoned efforts today to have the United Nations Security Council explicitly authorize the anti-Iraq forces to resume hostilities if Iraq fails to comply with President Bush's terms for ending the gulf war, diplomats said tonight.

title: Margaret Ann Chisholm, Bibliographer, 59
description: Margaret Ann Chisholm, a bibliographer who worked for the Episcopal and Anglican churches, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan and London.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANTONIO CARLOS JOBIM, STING and a host of other musicians will appear in concert on March 10 at Carnegie Hall to raise money for the Rainforest Foundation of Brazil.

title: Injustice Taints the 'Just War'
description: The war in the Persian Gulf was a particularly trying experience for African Americans. True, the stuff of the Civil War movie "Glory" was abundantly in evidence with black soldiers strongly represented, and we even had Gen. Colin L. Powell helping to run the show.

title: Poland Sets Debt Demand
description: Poland said today that it would make no payment on its interest arrears to foreign banks until they agreed to a significant reduction of its staggering debt.

title: Merchant Slain In Brownsville; Relative Robbed
description: Thomas Cerchia closed up Cerchia Brothers Meats, the market he had run for 30 years in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, at about 7:40 last night. His brother-in-law, Peter Dellananna, who worked in the store, helped him lock up, and the two said goodnight and parted ways.

title: Gay Groups Boycott Channel 13's Fund-Raising
description: With Channel 13's annual March pledge drive beginning today, a coalition of gay and lesbian organizations has vowed to urge their supporters not to make donations to the public television station until it broadcasts a regular weekly program focusing on their concerns.

title: BANK REGULATORS SEEKING TO RELAX ACCOUNTING RULES
description: With banks in many regions of the country shying away from making new loans, Federal banking and savings regulators moved to ease that logjam today by recommending a relaxation of the standards used by banks to put a value on their loans.

title: Sri Lanka Explosion Kills 30, Including a Defense Official
description: A bomb explosion killed 30 people near here today, including the Government defense official who is leading the fight against Tamil rebels, officials and witnesses said. Fifty others were wounded.

title: Beloit Acquires 80% Of Polish Company
description: The Beloit Corporation has bought 80 percent of a Polish producer of paper-making machinery, the biggest stake sold to a foreign company so far in a state-owned enterprise in Poland. Beloit, a subsidiary of Milwaukee-based Harnischfger Industries, bought the controlling shares of Fampa for $7 million.

title: U.N.L.V. 4 Reinstated
description: National Collegiate Athletic Association officials yesterday restored the briefly interrupted eligibility of four Nevada-Las Vegas players who violated N.C.A.A. regulations by leaving unpaid a total of $129 in incidental hotel bills during recruiting visits, a U.N.L.V. official said.

title: Kampala Journal; Ugandan Wife Confronts a Custom to Avoid AIDS
description: For two years, Harriet Mutebi suspected that her husband was a carrier of the AIDS virus. A well-to-do member of the Baganda tribe, he had mistresses here and in Kenya, where he traveled for business.

title: Man Who Carried 3 Pipe Bombs Has Sentence Reduced by 8 Years
description: A Japanese man who admitted carrying bombs in his car on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1988, heard his 30-year prison sentence reduced to 21 years and 10 months today by Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. of Federal District Court here.

title: How to Reduce Lead in Drinking Water
description: Lead poisoning, which attacks the nervous system and causes mental impairment, is a leading health problem for American children. As part of a broad effort to eliminate the problem, the Federal Government is working on regulations to reduce the amount of lead in drinking water.

title: Review/Music; Two Rarities By Opera Francais
description: L'Opera Francais de New York, a useful and unusual little company that specializes in rarities of the French repertory, has grown steadily since it was started in 1988 by Yves Abel, a conductor, and Susan Melvoin, a stage director. On Saturday evening, the company offered Andre Gretry's "Deux Avares" and Georges Bizet's "Dr. Miracle," in a double bill at Gould Hall.

title: Eastern Air Admits to Conspiracy
description: Eastern Airlines, under a plea-bargaining agreement, has admitted that it conspired to prevent the Federal Aviation Administration from determining if its employees and managers were falsifying maintenance records and will pay $3.5 million in fines.

title: In Settling Lawsuit, Health Club Chain Admits Racial Bias
description: A Federal judge gave preliminary approval today to a $9.5 million settlement of a lawsuit against a health club chain that admitted discriminating against blacks.

title: Graffiti on the Metro? C'est Execrable!; Never Looked Better
description: To the Editor:

title: News Continues Talks With British Publisher
description: Representatives of Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, and The Daily News continued negotiations yesterday over the possible sale of the newspaper, said James Hoge, publisher of The News.

title: New Fingerprint Computers Speed Rape Suspect's Arrest
description: On Monday night, a Brooklyn woman was bound and repeatedly raped by two men in her home. On Thursday, the detectives arrested a 19-year-old man and charged him in the attack.

title: Concert by the Baltimore
description: David Zinman and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra are to present the New York premiere of John Harbison's Symphony No. 3 at Carnegie Hall on Monday at 8 P.M.

title: No-Layoff Deal Sets 500 Teachers Adrift in the System
description: Each winter, hundreds of New York City high school teachers are laid off because of a seasonal enrollment decline caused by thousands of midyear graduations and drop outs.

title: BankAmerica Bid
description: The BankAmerica Corporation will bid for all of the failed Bank of New England Corporation, BankAmerica's chairman, Richard Rosenberg, said. But Mr. Rosenberg said his interest in the Bank of New England was "only under certain conditions which will be reflected in our bid." He would not give details.

title: The Mentally Ill Don't Know That They're Sick
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times on Tuesday about nitrous oxide in the atmosphere misstated the faculty affiliation of Dr. William C. Trogler and Dr. Mark H. Thiemens. They are at the University of California at San Diego.

title: Barry Charges Bias in Drug Case
description: Lawyers for former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington asked an appeals court Thursday to overturn his cocaine possession conviction, and contended that his six-month sentence stemmed from judicial bias.

title: Buffett's Gillette Stock
description: The Gillette Company, the big consumer products concern, said on Thursday that six insurance units of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. would convert $600 million of Gillette 8 3/4 percent series B preferred stock into Gillette common. Gillette said the preferred shares would be converted into 12 million common shares on April 1. Berkshire Hathaway is controlled by Warren Buffett, the billionaire heralded for his investment acumen.

title: Patents; Obtaining Images Of Damage to the Heart
description: Dr. Sigmund Lasker, a medical professor at the New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., obtained a patent this week on a way to use a rare form of oxygen to obtain images of cardiac damage caused by a heart attack or stroke.

title: Purchasers' Index Posts Small Gain
description: According to a survey of purchasing managers, the nation's manufacturing economy remained in a malaise in February, but it did show a slight improvement from January.

title: Books of The Times; A Soldier's Civil War Diary Sounds Like Crane
description: All for the Union The Civil War Diary and Letters of Elisha Hunt Rhodes Edited by Robert Hunt Rhodes. Illustrated. 256 pages. Orion Books/Crown. $20.

title: The Mentally Ill Don't Know That They're Sick; Time Has Come
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Echoes of Past Scandals On 'Nijinsky-Nijinska' Night
description: As choreographers, Vaslav Nijinsky and his sister, Bronislava Nijinska, were in the forefront of the 20th-century dance avant-garde, so much so that their radically innovative ballets were associated with the most publicized scandals in theatrical history.

title: Travel Overseas Picking Up
description: Some airlines and travel agents with business overseas have reported a surge of bookings as the Persian Gulf war drew to a close. They said that while some Americans were still holding back for fear of terrorism, many others were now comfortable enough to travel abroad again, particularly because of the discounts being offered.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about the case of six men imprisoned in connection with two Irish Republican Army bombings in 1974 in Birmingham, England, referred to their background incorrectly in some editions. They and the I.R.A. denied that they were members of the group.

title: Report on NATO Calls on U.S. To Cut Its Forces by Two-Thirds
description: A panel of 26 experts on Atlantic security, including important members of Congressional committees on the military and foreign affairs, urged the United States today to cut its forces in NATO by two-thirds in an effort to shift the burden of defending Europe to the Europeans.

title: Sasser Must Prove He's Starting Catcher
description: Mackey Sasser's mother and father were divorced when he was 10 years old. Sasser's mother left for Alabama, taking her daughter with her. Sasser and his brother remained in Tallahassee, Fla., with their father, a man who managed one different liquor store after another.

title: Salary Fame Is Fleeting And Henderson Is Angry
description: Fact A: When baseball players began cracking the $3 million barrier in November 1989, Rickey Henderson spent three days as one of the two highest-paid players (with Kirby Puckett).

title: Review/Theater; After Romania's Revolution
description: The recent Romanian revolution did not end with the execution of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife but continued through the subsequent election of his successor. Those turbulent times were chronicled with perspicacity by Caryl Churchill in "Mad Forest," seen last year in London. "The Almond Seller" by Oana-Maria Hock is both a parallel work to that of Miss Churchill and an extension of it, moving ahead into the aftermath and also looking back into a kind of mythical pre-history.

title: Violence and the News Strike: Anger, Blame and Distrust
description: Saubhagya (Sam) Uchhana rooted through the charred magazines and the cracked and soot-covered refrigerator cases that are all that remains of his Club House Smoke Shop on Staten Island.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, Representative Lee H. Hamilton's House Foreign Affairs Committee role was misstated in his article on Feb. 23. He is chairman of the Subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Battleground; Death Stalks Desert Despite Cease-Fire
description: Despite a provisional cease-fire, the battlefields of the Persian Gulf war were not quite quiet today, the second day since President Bush halted the fighting, and there were reports that thousands of Iraqi stragglers were still in the combat zone.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Circuit City Stores Inc., Richmond, named Bernard W. Andrews executive vice president of operations. * Colgate-Palmolive Co., New York, named Andrew Hendry senior vice president and general counsel. He succeeds Harold Obstler, who has retired.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq's Leader; Saddam Hussein's Future: Options Raise Delicate Concern for U.S.
description: As President Saddam Hussein continues to hold on to power in Iraq, the Bush Administration is struggling with how to react if he seeks asylum in another country.

title: Utah Charges Princetonian With Violation of His Parole
description: The Utah Board of Pardons has filed parole violation charges against a 31-year-old man who was attending Princeton University under a false identity.

title: Secret Bank Link to Launderer Seen
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, whose investigators are tracking a string of multimillion-dollar transactions around the world, said yesterday that he had concluded that a foreign bank convicted of money laundering secretly controls the biggest bank in Washington.

title: U.S. to Look Into Death Of Key Noriega Witness
description: Justice Department officials said today that they would examine the circumstances surrounding the death of a crucial Government witness against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega who was killed Wednesday night in a single-vehicle car wreck in Miami.

title: Reinhard Bendix, 75, A Sociologist, Is Dead
description: Reinhard Bendix, a sociologist who was professor emeritus of political science at the University of California at Berkeley, died Thursday after a heart attack outside a classroom where he had given a seminar. He was 75 years old and lived in Berkeley.

title: Belzberg Is Turning Reins Over to Nephew
description: Samuel Belzberg, a 62-year-old financier who rode the takeover wave to become head of one of Canada's foremost dynasties, is surrendering day-to-day control of the centerpiece of his family's empire.

title: Iraq Curses Arab Leaders
description: The Baghdad Radio said today that a "black fate" awaited the leaders of Saudi Arabia, Syria and Egypt for allying themselves with President Bush in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Toyota Buys Stake In Unit of Merrill
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation bought a 40 percent stake in a subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company in Tokyo. Toyota officials said their company, Japan's biggest auto maker, had acquired the share in Merrill Lynch International Capital Management Company through a subsidiary, the Toyota Finance Corporation. The price was not disclosed.

title: Dow Gains 27.72 Points, to 2,909.90
description: Prodded by signs that the economy is mending, stock prices recovered from an early slump and moved ahead briskly yesterday.

title: Report on Graf's Father
description: A blood test has determined that Steffi Graf's father did not father a model's child, a German newspaper reported yesterday. The newspaper Bild said court-ordered blood tests had cleared Peter Graf in a paternity suit filed by Nicole Meissner.

title: King Broadcasting's TV Asset Sale
description: The King Broadcasting Company agreed today to sell its six television stations and 13 cable systems to the Providence Journal Company and its joint-venture partner, Kelso & Company.

title: Iranian-American Sues Pan Am, Saying It Unfairly Questioned Him
description: An Iranian-born American citizen who says he was ordered off a New York-bound Pan American World Airways jet in Miami and questioned for three hours filed suit against the airline yesterday, accusing it of discriminating against him because of his Middle Eastern ancestry.

title: The Clock Has Begun To Tick
description: The new, fresh-faced president of the Knicks, David Checketts, played basketball at Brigham Young University for one season, 1973-74. "But you won't find my name in the records," he said.

title: Index of Leading Indicators Falls for 6th Month in a Row
description: The Government index created to predict turns in the economy fell four-tenths of 1 percent in January, its sixth straight decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AFTER THE WAR: White House Memo; War Introduces a Tougher Bush to Nation
description: War never leaves a nation where it found it, the British statesman Edmund Burke once said. It also never leaves a President where it found him.

title: U.S. Reporter Slain in Algiers
description: The Reuters correspondent in Algeria, Philip Shehadi, an American from Princeton, N.J., was found stabbed to death in his Algiers apartment today, officials at the United States Embassy said. Mr. Shehadi, 33 years old, had worked for Reuters in the Middle East since 1984 and had been based in Algiers since May 1989. The United States consul in Algiers said that Mr. Shehadi's apartment had been ransacked and that the Algerian police had no evidence that the killing was linked to Middle Eastern terrorism.

title: Europe Approves Copter Consortium
description: The European Community's Executive Commission has approved the creation of a German-French consortium that would be the world's second-largest helicopter manufacturer. The venture, Eurocopter, will be set up this year by the state-owned French company Aerospatiale and the Germany concern Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H.

title: On Edward Hopper, Loneliness and Children
description: Three years ago I began teaching a fourth-grade class in a Cambridge, Mass., elementary school. I noticed, right off, that on the playground or in the halls, or even in the classroom itself, the children were often marvelously forceful and vigorous storytellers. But when they were asked to write, they commonly became inarticulate, even fearfully so. "I can't write," was their refrain, and I decided not to take them up directly on that claim.

title: Tougher Tactics to Keep Out Unions
description: When nearly 300 workers who sew shirts for Farris Fashions in Brinkley, Ark., threatened to form a union, the owner of the factory, union organizers say, vowed to close the factory and turn it into a chicken coop if they did. It was not surprising, then, when the workers voted 202 to 60 last December against having the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Union try to negotiate a contract for them.

title: Furor in Japan Over U.S. Funding Program
description: At the height of frictions with the United States last year, Japan created an ambitious new $375 million Government-financed endowment to support scholarly, political and cultural exchanges between the two countries.

title: Blood Pigment Found to Slow AIDS Virus in Test
description: A pigment in red blood cells slows the growth of the AIDS virus in the test tube and strengthens the action of AZT, the chief drug against the disease, researchers reported on Thursday. The pigment, heme, is what gives blood its red color.

title: Molly McEneny To Wed in May
description: Molly Ann McEneny, the director of personnel at the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren, and Kevin John Walsh, a partner in the firm, are planning a May wedding.

title: Hollywood's View of State Goes From Blue Blood to Blue Collar
description: IN the 1968 film "The Swimmer," Burt Lancaster decides to swim across Connecticut -- from one backyard pool to another. As he moves through the yards of the Fairfield County rich, they barely look up from their cocktails to take note.

title: Medical Ethics: New Way to Teach Students to Think
description: TWO dozen high school students barely flinched as they watched blood coursing through tubes leading from a patient's arm into a hemodialysis machine and back again. "It's like a washing machine for blood," Dr. William Chenitz of St. Michael's Medical Center here said of the device, which does the work that the patient's kidneys no longer can.

title: About Cars; The Ultimate BMW Takes a Step Up
description: I don't care how steady you are, it is hard to drive well when the cops are behind you.

title: Dear Mr. President . . .
description: I didn't try to telephone because I knew you'd be busy. So here's a public communication where candor may be easier than in private conversation with a President, especially one who has actually succeeded at something.

title: Official and 18 Others Die in Sri Lanka Bombing
description: A car bomb exploded today on a busy street and killed the head of the Government campaign against Tamil separatists along with at least 18 other people, officials and witnesses said. About 73 people were wounded.

title: An April Wedding For Ms. Fairbanks
description: Theresa Louise Fairbanks, the chief conservator at the Center for British Art at Yale University, and Channing Carl Harris, a landscape architect in New Haven, plan to marry in April.

title: Elisabeth Gitelle and Jay Howard Leve Are Wed
description: Elisabeth Ann Gitelle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gene L. Gitelle of New York, was married there last evening to Jay Howard Leve, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Leve of St. Louis. Rabbi Michael Gelber officiated at the Lotos Club. The bride, 28 years old, is an assistant vice president of Citibank in New York. She graduated from the Dalton School and Emory University and received a master's degree in computing in education from Columbia University. Mr. Leve, 35, is the president of Hypotenuse Inc., a publishing company in New York. He received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University.

title: The I.R.S. Tries to Clean Up Its Act
description: When asked shortly before the Super Bowl this year if he were afraid of another team's quarterback, Bill Parcells, the coach of the New York Giants, replied, "Let me tell you what I'm scared of: spiders, snakes and the I.R.S."

title: Food Supplier Opens Warehouse Outlet
description: BINGING in the 1980's has given way to belt-tightening in the 90's, and no one is more aware of the sharp contrasts between the decades than those in the food industry.

title: Elster Is Aiming To Heal, Stay Put
description: Kevin Elster, having emerged from an early morning meeting with General Manager Frank Cashen, said today that his chief concern was to make sure his surgically repaired shoulder was healthy and that it was his current desire not to be traded.

title: Desert Storm and Then What? A Reader's Guide
description: After Operation Desert Storm there will be an American imperium in the Middle East and we shall be healers. Such is the promise of what will come to pass when the guns fall silent. This is a return to an old theme. Pick up the American trail in Iraq and Kuwait and trace it back from today's expedition to the first American ventures into the Arab and Muslim realms. The themes recur, the history telescopes easily. Always there is the promise that over the horizon -- two or three camel days away, as the Arabs of the desert would have once put it -- there will be bliss: the distant power giving something of its innocence and optimism to a region burdened by its feuds and obsessions. And always there is the response of that world: dependence and resentment, attraction to the power from afar and the need to cover up the attraction and the dependence.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Scene in Kuwait; 7 Miles of Carnage Mark Road Iraqis Used to Flee
description: From the look of the mangled cars, trucks and tanks that stretch for seven miles at a point just north of here, the attack that stopped the fleeing Iraqis dead in their tracks had been sudden, and had caught the escaping force by surprise.

title: Life on the Frontier
description: FROM 1849 to 1867, the Army established more than 20 forts in western Texas to protect travelers and settlers from the Southern Plains Indians, and, in a few cases, the Indians from vigilante whites. A few outposts, like Fort Worth, spawned cities. Others remain isolated on the prairie, still as unpopulated as in the mid-19th century.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TALKING HEADS Political Talk Shows and Their Star Pundits. By Alan Hirsch. Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $17.95.

title: A Cautionary Note on Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Outwitting the Gestapo In the Vilna Ghetto
description: "Underground" is the third play in Joshua Sobol's trilogy about life in the Vilna ghetto during World War II, a trilogy that began with "Ghetto," produced two seasons ago on Broadway. Unfortunately, the new play (in its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater) suffers from some of the same problems that troubled the earlier work. Beneath the evident sincerity, there is an artistic manipulation, exacerbated by the awkwardness of Mr. Sobol's writing. Once again, the playwright's ambition exceeds his grasp.

title: The Name Is Familiar . . .
description: Avery Fisher will celebrate his 85th birthday tomorrow by giving a gift. He is to name the American instrumentalist who will receive an Avery Fisher Prize for outstanding musical achievement and excellence, with its $25,000 cash award.

title: 'The True and Only Heaven'
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Kuniholm To Marry in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Wendy Elisabeth Kuniholm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Kuniholm of Chadds Ford, Pa., and John Barker Sullivan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Sullivan of South Freeport, Me.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/February 24-March 1
description: AFTER THE WAR In 1930, when pearl-diving was the largest industry in Kuwait, Japan's development of cultured pearls wrecked Kuwait's economy. Now one of the world's wealthiest nations, Kuwait has seen its livelihood ruined again, its power and desalting plants destroyed, its oil wells feeding fires that blacken the skies. But few such devastated nations have ever had such gleaming prospects. With an estimated $100 billion in investments abroad, and most of its oil still securely in the ground, Kuwait has the cash and the credit for rebuilding. The Kuwaitis say the allies who fought the hardest will benefit the most; American companies have won about 70 percent of the 200 contracts signed so far. Kuwait has asked the Bechtel Group to manage the reconstruction of its oil industry, potentially a $10 billion task. Caterpillar Inc. is selling diesel engines to provide emergency power; Motorola Inc., portable telephones, and the Raytheon Company, air traffic control gear. Kuwait plans to not only rebuild but also modernize, promoting private enterprise and taking the nation another step beyond reliance on diving for pearls or drilling for oil. Kuwait would just as soon have an economy efficient enough to manage without the hundreds of thousands of Palestinian and Jordanian guest workers, whose political leanings are suspect. The War Payment Plan Even as American companies gain contracts, the United States is likely to continue paying some costs of its Persian Gulf mission. With rebuilding expenses of $50 billion to $100 billion -- in the same range as the post-World War II Marshall Plan -- Kuwaiti borrowing could squeeze credit around the world. Many analysts suggest that payments from allies will more than cover American military expense. But Hermann F. Eilts, a former Ambassador to Egypt and Saudi Arabia who now directs the Boston University Center for International Relations, said that some nations might have second thoughts. Germany is burdened by reunification costs, he noted, and Japanese legislators are likely to renege on the Government's promises to the United States. "When the shooting is over, they find reasons to limit their payments," he said. "That means you and I are going to pay." Return of the Oil Jitters The war ended, but the oil jitters resumed. A barrel of crude, down sharply since the allied assault began Jan. 17, eased back up by $1.47 a barrel to $19.38 last week. Some oil traders voiced fears that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would soon agree to cut back production. And Kuwait is unlikely to resume shipping oil for several months. Iraq, who knows when? But several energy analysts said that the world has already shown it can survive a winter without Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil; the longer run worries them much more. Christopher Flavin, an energy specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, said that with worldwide consumption growing and Soviet production falling, the real squeeze could come in the mid-1990's. G.N.P. Hints at Rebound A revised estimate of the nation's output for the fourth quarter last year provided some evidence that the economy is poised for a rebound in the coming months. The Commerce Department said the the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 2 percent, compared to an initial estimate of 2.1 percent. But inventories were revised down, meaning that manufacturers would have to increase production to meet any stronger demand after the the victory in the Persian Gulf. Economists Turn Upbeat Economists had a mind last week to emphasize the favorable aspects of statistics that still tell of a recession. Consumer confidence remained at depressing levels last month, according to the Conference Board's survey, but analysts noted that it rose for the first time since September. Purchasing managers, responding to another survey, also remained downcast, but again, not as dismal as the month before. The government's index of leading indicators fell four-tenths of 1 percent for January, the sixth straight decline, but economists tended to say that the end of the war, an expanding money supply and a rising stock market in February virtually guarantee that the next report will be more favorable. "You are forming a bottom," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston. "There is no question about that." She said that growth is likely to resume in mid-year. COMPANIES

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Lawmakers Press Court on Death Penalty
description: RECENTLY introduced legislation that lawmakers say is intended to clarify existing language in the state's death-penalty statute may in fact play a crucial role in determining the ultimate fate of the death penalty itself, officials and legal experts say.

title: Tightening the Rules for Investors
description: All investments are not created equal. Never is that clearer than at tax time.

title: No Bed of Roses At a Funeral Home
description: THE most exciting part of a regional theater's season is the slot reserved for new plays.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer accompanying an article on Feb. 3 about Fort Hamilton referred incorrectly to the Transit Authority express bus service to Manhattan. The area is served by the X27 and X28 lines.

title: Surgery on G.O.P. Was Deft, Not Painless
description: Some called it ruthless gerrymandering, others representative democracy in action. Either way, the reapportionment of California's Congressional districts a decade ago was a classic exercise of political power.

title: Travel Advisory; London Hotel Of 1865 Reopens
description: Amid a decline in tourism because of the Persian Gulf war, Hilton International Hotels is reopening the historic Langham Hotel, opposite the BBC's Broadcasting House in Portland Place, tomorrow.

title: DECIPHERING THE M.L.A.
description: Seminars on "The Detective as Pervert," ". . . the Politics of Sexual Deviance," "Gender and Sexual Relationships in the Great Beyond" and "The Lesbian Phallus; Or Does Heterosexuality Exist?" It's been said that the last desperate act of an exhausted artist is to display his genitals. Perhaps the seminar titles are attempts to excite a bored crowd. But, in my eyes, these scholars are not only bored -- they're intellectually bankrupt. MICHAEL D. HASSELL Nashville

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: My wife and I spent New Year's (hogmanay) in Scotland, taking a package -- Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, including brunch, dinners and breakfast on Jan. 2 -- at a hotel several miles from the center of Edinburgh. Festivities began with a drink and dinner. Entertainment included an accordionist, a drummer, a bagpiper, Highland dancers and a ballad singer. Toward midnight we received instruction in group dancing. Caught up in the bonhomie, we stayed for the midnight celebrations. Despite the omission of "Auld Lang Syne," singing and dancing continued for many hours.

title: Headliners; Incomplete
description: The man who, as Jay Huntsman, attended Palo Alto High School in California in 1985 and who, as Alexi Indris-Santana, enrolled at Princeton University in 1989, was arrested in New Jersey last week as James Arthur Hogue, a fugitive from Utah justice. Mr. Hogue had gained admission to Princeton with acceptable S.A.T. scores, clippings from California that portrayed him as a track star, and an unusual biography -- he claimed to be a self-educated ranch hand whose mother was dying of leukemia in Switzerland. He might have gone on fooling the university but for a coincidence: a Yale senior who knew him from Palo Alto High, from which he had been expelled for lying about his background, spotted him at a Harvard-Yale-Princeton track meet. Days later, a Palo Alto reporter called Princeton to ask about Huntsman/Santana, who had been convicted in Utah of possessing stolen property and was wanted there for parole violation. After Mr. Hogue was arrested, a Princeton official commented, "This is a case of a real con artist."

title: What's Doing In: Charleston
description: Some scaffolding remains in the Old and Historic District, and guides eagerly point out Hurricane Hugo's legacy of muddy high-water marks on mansions in the South Battery, but downtown Charleston is fully recovered from the 1989 storm. Today, horse-drawn carriages again carry tourists down cobblestone streets, and local women again weave sweetgrass baskets in the old slave market and offer them for sale.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has two patios with a "Chattahoochee" stone finish. For eight years, we coated these with a clear sealer, applying it twice a year. I cannot find this sealer in stores anymore, and the patios look awful. Can this type of patio be painted?

title: Record $4.4 Million Raised for Neediest Cases
description: Despite war and a declining economy, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund last week completed its most successful campaign in its 79-year history.

title: It Goes to Their Wallets, but Not to Their Heads
description: Will Clark and a friend decided belatedly to attend a ZZ Top concert, and the only tickets they could buy were for general-admission seats. So that's where the San Francisco Giants' first baseman was sitting when another concertgoer, hearing that Clark was somewhere up there, asked a man two rows back if he was Will Clark and could he have his autograph.

title: A June Wedding For Miss Henley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Page Henley Jr. of Radnor, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Lewis Henley to Douglas Paul Lobel, the son of Erwin Lobel of Jericho, L.I., and the late Joan S. Lobel. A June wedding is planned.

title: Moscow 1991
description: FROM THE CITY'S WOODED fringe, even the Moscow dawn seems part of the problem, no tincture of hopeful rose, only a mere renewal of the pewter grayness that envelops this city most days of most centuries. Mayor Gavriil K. Popov, a short, round-edged, sadly smiling figure, is shambling about on the edge of his city as the grayness overtakes the night and he must again confront Moscow's workaday problem: how to give seedling democracy a chance against the resiliency of Communism.

title: Corrections
description: A Posting on Feb. 17 about the Chimney Corners Center development in Stamford, Conn., incompletely identified the developers. George and Paul Gorra of Victorian Properties Ltd. of Manhattan are majority partners.

title: The Indecorous, Rabelaisian, Convoluted Righteousness of Stanley Elkin
description: The monks were serving mulled wine, baked potatoes and pizza, and Stanley Elkin was getting nervous. He hadn't expected that the reading in England, arranged by his friend and fellow novelist Robert Coover, would be held in a monastery, and he certainly hadn't expected his audience of students from the University of Kent to be augmented by monks, much less by teen-age girls on a weekend retreat.

title:
Style Makers;
Lyn Evans, Ceramist
description: A tabletop adorned with ceramics by Lyn Evans burns with color. Delphinium blue, fuchsia, peach: the colors of her classic dishes and serving pieces dazzle like a spring garden.

title: Joy Tracewski and Christopher Silveri to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tracewski of Peckville, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joy Tracewski, to Dr. Christopher Patrick Silveri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Americo Silveri of Dix Hills, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Margot Fonteyn: Enchantment Embodied
description: She was enchanting. That is what the world will remember about Margot Fonteyn. Other ballerinas in her lifetime, whatever their qualities, could never match the spell she cast so consistently the minute she stepped on stage.

title: Miss Vine to Wed Peter A. Drucker
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sherwood Vine of Trenton have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Ellen Vine to Peter Adam Drucker, the son of Daniel Drucker of West Orange, N.J., and Lenore Paddock of Montville, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Another Injury For Sampras
description: Pete Sampras, the defending United States Open champion, suffered an injury to his right Achilles' tendon this afternoon during an exhibition match against Andre Agassi in San Diego.

title: The Last Retreat
description: THE FACES By Tove Ditlevsen. Translated by Tiina Nunnally. 151 pp. Seattle: Fjord Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Wassily Hoeffding, 76, Authority on Statistics
description: Wassily Hoeffding, an educator and internationally known statistician, died Thursday at Haven Hill Nursing Home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 76 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Sara Fanning Weds Thomas Laprade
description: Sara Barrett Fanning, a daughter of Mrs. John A. Van Voorhis and James E. Fanning, both of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday in New Vernon, N.J., to Thomas Victor Laprade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Laprade of Barrington, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James I. Donlon at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: Headliners; Immunizing Children Against an Adult Scourge
description: EVEN the most impressive advances in medical science are of little value if people cannot be persuaded to take advantage of them. Consider the case of hepatitis B. Though an effective vaccine against the disease has been available for a decade, it has been widely ignored. As a result, hepatitis cases have needlessly soared, increasing more than 60 percent in the last 10 years. About 300,000 people in the United States are infected every year by the virus, which is spread through sexual intercourse and contact with contaminated blood. All told, some 1.25 million Americans have chronic infections.

title: The Indivisibility of Ethics
description: In 1981, Peter F. Drucker wrote "What Is 'Business Ethics?' " In that article, he said: "There is only one ethics, one set of rules of morality, one code: that of individual behavior in which the same rules apply to everyone alike." Mr. Drucker attributed this conclusion to a long tradition of Western and Eastern philosophers. That should have laid the question to rest. It did not.

title: School Integration: New Calls for Action
description: AFTER years of study and inconclusive debate about school desegregation in the state, the enrollment in 140 of Connecticut's 166 districts remains 90 per cent white, with 80 percent of the minority-group students concentrated in 10 per cent of the school systems. Now, as the General Assembly confronts the state's nagging fiscal problems, the lawmakers are also studying a report calling for school desegregation. Meanwhile, the outcome of a lawsuit that is scheduled to come to trial this spring could force action on the issue, possibly leading to busing and changes in district boundaries.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Wall Street; Let the Sun Shine on Muni Bonds
description: Sunshine is said to be the best disinfectant -- and that theory certainly helps explain the moldy condition of the nation's municipal bond market.

title: Sunday Dinner; Around Manhattan, Pasta With All the Trimmings
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some casual restaurants that serve pasta.

title: French Phones
description: To the Editor: A footnote to your "Phone Cards Gain in France" for those francophiles obsessed with minutiae. The 1989 telecarte carried a reproduction of an abstract painting by the French artist Baltazar. It was commissioned to honor the official acceptance of the word "telecarte" into the French language by the Academie Francaise and the production of the 100 millionth card. The limited edition telecarte, it would seem, has gone the way of the 10-cent phone call. JOSHUA WATSKY Stonington, Conn.

title:
MUSIC;
New Philharmonic Adds Ballet to Its Program
description: THE administration of the New Philharmonic of New Jersey has tried to stimulate interest in the arts this season by presenting collaborative music, dance and theater programs for adults, educational projects for children and social-musical events for single adults.

title: CBS and the Steel Magnolia
description: Growing up as a smalltown Southern belle, Linda Bloodworth-Thomason was taught to be nice to everyone. She was a cheerleader at her high school in Poplar Bluff, Mo., where she was voted "most popular" in her class. "Women where I'm from are raised as real people-pleasers," she says.

title: From Baguette to Brie, the Paris Picnic
description: In Paris, a city where food preparation is viewed as an art form and where the Michelin guide is as ubiquitous as the Gideon Bible in American hotel rooms, it didn't strike me as the impossible dream to put together a perfect picnic. But my French friends adamantly disagreed.

title: Families Start Tracing Holocaust Survivors
description: SIEGMUND SPIEGEL, an architect who lives in East Meadow, last had contact with his parents before June 1941.

title: A Tax Program May Be Expert, But the User?
description: Melvin L. Steiner, a San Carlos, Calif., accountant, likes to tell about a client who decided to save money by preparing his own tax return on a personal computer.

title: Long Island Guide
description: FROM THE CHAMBERS

title: U.S. to Maintain Force in Gulf
description: The United States wants to maintain a much larger American military presence in the Persian Gulf region than it had before Iraq invaded Kuwait, officials said. Page 19.

title: Message of War Ambivalence Got Left in the Shop Window
description: To the Editor:

title: Scandals Emptied Pews Of Electronic Churches
description: Several years after a cataclysm of sexual and financial scandals toppled two television ministries and tarnished others, Sunday morning television in much of the nation still belongs to the religious broadcasters. But its face has irrevocably changed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Political Memo article last Sunday about the 1992 Senate races misstated the source of sexual-assault allegations made against Senator Brock Adams, a Washington State Democrat. They were made by a House staff member, not by his former secretary. The former United States Attorney in the District of Columbia, Joseph E. diGenova, called the allegations groundless.

title: The Fuzzy Vision of a True Believer
description: DARCY'S UTOPIA By Fay Weldon. 235 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: The One True Picasso
description: A LIFE OF PICASSO Volume One, 1881-1906. By John Richardson, with the collaboration of Marilyn McCully. Illustrated. 548 pp. New York: Random House. $39.95.

title: Miss Badger to Marry Andrew Carey
description: David Badger of Vienna and Mrs. Harold Vogel of Bedminster, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Mars Badger to Andrew Towne Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Carey of New Vernon, N.J., and Throckmorton, Tex. A May wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: JOSEPH S. GRABARZ;
A Legislator Speaks Up for Gay Rights
description: JOSEPH S. GRABARZ JR., a Democratic State Representative from Bridgeport, recently publicly identified himself as homosexual. Mr. Grabarz, a two-term legislator who is 34 years old, graduated from Providence College in 1978. Before being elected to the General Assembly, he taught special education classes in Monroe and Madison, wrote computer programs and worked in Bridgeport city government. Unlike the revelations that have forced some politicians to discuss their private lives, Mr. Grabarz said he wanted to make a public statement about himself and gay rights.

title: Killing of Leader Angers Ex-Contras
description: Since the slaying two weeks ago of Enrique Bermudez, other former comandantes of the anti-Sandinista rebel movement that he led have sought to calm a growing anger in the countryside among his demobilized forces.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SELF PORTRAITS By Osamu Dazai. Translated by Ralph F. McCarthy. Kodansha, $18.95.

title: Troubled Youths as Hosts to Hikers?
description: BACKPACKERS hiking along the Appalachian Trail where it crosses the Kittatinny Mountains here may one day be able to spend the night in a rustic bed and breakfast or enjoy a snack at a lakeside concession stand, if plans being considered by state and Federal officials come to fruition.

title: Brooks: Punch In a Pinch For Mets
description: The scene, enacted again and again at Shea Stadium, has replayed itself again and again on their memory's regret reel.

title: Rarities, Oddities and Bargains in a Secondhand Bookshop
description: IN literary fashion, Riverrun, a comfortably cluttered bookstore on a street sloping down to the Hudson, takes its name from the first word in James Joyce's "Finnegan's Wake."

title: Lisa Gibson Is Married
description: Lisa Anne Gibson, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin C. Bockstiegel of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Paul Locke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Locke of Cincinnati. The ceremony at the Presbyterian Church was performed by Mr. Bockstiegel, the pastor of the church, and the Rev. Raymond Zielezienski, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride, 24 years old, and her husband, 25, graduated from Denison University. She is studying for a master's degree in school counseling at Loyola University in Chicago, where he is an account executive at the Leo Burnett advertising agency.

title: Data Bank/March 3, 1991
Campus Life: Berkeley; Please Don't Feed The Dinosaurs: They Might Gnaw
description: The claws and teeth look real enough, and the sounds are primordial enough, but the dozen dinosaurs on exhibit at the University of California at Berkeley are all robots, part of a continuing display at the Lawrence Hall of Science.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Environment; FOULED REGION IS CASUALTY OF WAR
description: The Persian Gulf war has caused an ecological calamity affecting a large chunk of Asia, and experts say it might take years to clean up.

title: Vilna, With Cossacks and Golems
description: FROM THE OLD MARKETPLACE By Joseph Buloff. Translated by Joseph Singer. 335 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $19.95.

title: States M. Mead, 75, A Retired Admiral And Bank Official
description: Rear Adm. States Morris Mead, a retired member of the United States Naval Reserve who combined a naval career with 28 years as an executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Julia Gallaudet to Marry Michael Angelis in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Gallaudet of Cinnaminson, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Julia Laing Gallaudet and Michael Angelis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Angelis of Montreal.

title: Cynthia Donahue Engaged to Wed D. T. Labrecque
description: Mrs. Laurence A. Donahue of Rumson, N.J., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Cynthia Mary Donahue and Douglas Thibault Labrecque, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Labrecque of Fair Haven, N.J. Miss Donahue is also a daughter of the late Dr. Donahue.

title: Change Proposed in Legal Aid Representation
description: A money-saving proposal by the Dinkins administration that would change the way poor people are represented by Legal Aid lawyers has run into fierce opposition from the lawyers' union, which says the change would hurt clients' representation.

title: Brooke Morrow Has a Wedding
description: Brooke Evin Morrow, a daughter of Robert E. Morrow of New York and Gayle Morrow of Lawrence, N.Y., was married there last evening to Walter Edelstein, the son of Charles Edelstein of Oceanside, N.Y., and the late Celia Edelstein. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal and Cantor Yitzhak Lefkovitz officiated.

title: Full Houses At Syracuse
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: PEACE CORPS: The Peace Corps is trying to re-establish its programs in six Islamic countries, canceled after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Page 26.

title: She Was Jo, and That Was That
description: MOODS By Louisa May Alcott. Edited by Sarah Elbert. 284 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $13. LOUISA MAY ALCOTT Selected Fiction. Edited by Daniel Shealy, Madeleine B. Stern and Joel Myerson. 478 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Neil Simon Finds a Tragic Character at Last
description: No one will have any trouble recognizing "Lost in Yonkers" as a product of Neil Simon's seemingly inexhaustible imagination. For 30 years now, he has been wringing comedy out of domestic discord with a regularity that may safely be termed obsessive. In this, his 27th work for the theater, he's up to his old tricks again, but with one significant difference. He begins "Lost in Yonkers" where most of his other plays leave off.

title: Man Is Charged In Death of His Wife and a Stepchild
description: A 36-year-old Bronx man stabbed his wife and stepdaughter to death Friday afternoon in a frenzied rage that started when they refused to give him money to buy crack, the police said.

title: Style Makers; Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, Book Fair Organizer
description: When Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe and other mothers in the Black Family Cultural Exchange worried about not being able to find suitable books for their preschool children, little did they suspect that by doing something about it they would become role models.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BANTAM LAKE;
Acres of Ice Provide Frozen Fun (but Bundle Up!)
description: NEARLY every weekend, Keith Forgette and his friends rise in predawn darkness, pack their pickup trucks with fishing and camping supplies and drive more than 50 miles to fish on Bantam Lake. On a recent cold, windy Saturday, their equipment included a gasoline-powered auger, a metal drum on legs and a blue plastic sled.

title: Fight Night of the Century
description: In the tradition of the time, the signing of the contracts for Ali-Frazier I was announced at a luncheon at Toots Shor's. Up on the dais, Jerry Perenchio, who was promoting the bout with Jack Kent Cooke and Madison Square Garden, boasted that the gross would be anywhere from $20 million to $30 million. Hearing that, Muhammad Ali jumped to his feet and glanced at Joe Frazier.

title: Ingrid D. Hill Is Married
description: Ingrid Dee Hill, a model in New York, and Richard James Wolff, a real-estate broker, were married yesterday evening at the Hotel Westbury in New York. Rabbi Morris Goldberg officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Irving Hill of Allen, Tex., and Elaine Hill of Redondo Beach, Calif. Mr. Wolff, 35, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Wolff of Hewlett, L.I. A graduate of Boston University, he is the president of R. J. Wolff Associates, a commercial real-estate brokerage in New York.

title: Kenyan Magazine Editor Held After Articles on Opposition Party
description: The Kenyan authorities have arrested the editor of a law magazine that featured the manifesto of a new opposition party announced in defiance of Kenya's one-party state.

title: Fashion; MOTHER MODE
description: FOR JODI NASS, TRYING TO LOOK FETCHING DURING her pregnancy has posed a test of ingenuity. The challenge, says this 30-year-old vice president of Oppenheimer & Company, the New York brokerage, is to put together a wardrobe that is stylish and vibrant but dignified. "I'm happy and proud to be pregnant," says Nass, who is expecting her first child next month. "But in my business, which is 80 to 90 percent male, you don't want to stand out and make people uncomfortable."

title: Through the Form 1040 Step by Step
description: A tax return is like a roadmap to a family's financial life, and the more complex personal finances are, the more complex the tax return will be. Many tax professionals advise their clients year-round on tax and financial planning, but taxpayers themselves still have plenty of work to do this time of year in getting all their records ready for a professional. Studying an expertly prepared return can help taxpayers with this, as well as help them understand tax strategies. Jack Porter, national director of tax practice for BDO Seidman, and Diane Clifton and Chuck DeLanoy, national tax fellows in the firm's Washington office, prepared this return for a two-income couple who were not liable for the alternative minimum tax.

title: Campus Life: Rider; Student Athletes Polish Manners In Etiquette Class
description: Rider College is trying to teach its freshmen athletes what mom didn't about good manners and other good habits.

title: French Phones
description: To the Editor: Permit me to add a word of caution about phone cards. When you arrive in France on a Sunday you can be in a real bind without the card. Post offices and many tobacconists are closed. That cafes carry the card is not widely known. Maybe this information should be posted on all public phones requiring cards.

title: MEXICO
description: Spring -- and the stork -- bring baby animals and other novelties to zoos around the world. Times correspondents tell us about them. Nestled among the leafy shade trees of Mexico City's largest park, the Chapultepec Zoo may be easy to overlook. But with its striking dome-shaped cages, tall aviaries, rare species and staff of highly regarded young zoologists, it has earned an international standing that makes it well worth a springtime visit.

title: Why Music in a Time of War?
description: The outbreak of war challenges the normal expectations of everyday life. This is particularly true when, as now, war confronts us constantly on television and in newspapers. The events, habits and preoccupations of civilian existence, which seem so compelling under ordinary circumstances, suddenly appear pointless when placed against war's death, destruction and terror.

title: Account of Failure: Talks at The News
description: While management of The Daily News and its striking unions share blame for the failure of their negotiations, that failure was from the beginning a likely, if not inevitable, outcome of the strategy of the paper's owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago.

title: If There's a War, He's There
description: Last summer, in the Jerusalem office of his Cable News Network, Ted Turner delivered one of those fiery take-no-prisoners pep talks for which he has become renowned throughout his far-flung empire. CNN, Turner exhorted his minions, is on the cutting edge of a communications revolution. He wanted troops who would hold back nothing, who would take the final step. "I want people," Turner finally thundered, "who are prepared to die for CNN!"

title: Listening to a New Magazine
description: The world of classical-music magazines is generally staid, but change does occur -- usually the demise of one publication or another. The latest shift involves the disappearance of Classical, which devoted a large part of its contents to record reviews, and the emergence in its stead of Classic CD, which is primarily devoted to reviews.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "These aren't negotiations, this is a meeting, and we've already forwarded a list of demands to them." -- Brig. Gen. Richard I. Neal, the American military spokesman in the Persian Gulf. [ 16:3. ]

title: An April Bridal For Pamela Berry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Berry of New Vernon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Jean Berry, to John Wallace Pearson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Pearson of West Hartford, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
Examining Lineage as a Means of Enrichment
description: THE fascination with genealogy takes many forms, most of which have nothing to do with art. Yet, heritage is one of the abiding themes in literature, and a great deal of painting and sculpture have been devoted to memorializing forebears.

title: Amy Craig to Wed Andrew A. Dutter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Craig of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Royce Craig to Andrew Allen Dutter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Dutter of Greenwich, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Executive Computer; Operating Systems for PC's Grow More Confusing
description: Reports that the OS/2 operating system is dead are greatly exaggerated, officials of the Microsoft Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation say. Yet there appears to be a great deal of confusion about the future of OS/2 -- and about the future of personal computer operating systems in general.

title: Surviving a Plane Crash: How to Improve the Odds
description: EVERY airplane crash that is classified as "survivable" has a lesson for future passengers as well as the airline industry. In the fatal crash at Los Angeles Airport last month, at least 17 people who survived the initial impact failed to escape the cabin in time. The causes must remain surmises, but a prime lesson, tragically, is that while passengers half-listen to safety briefings or, at home, gasp at news photos of leaping flames and twisted fuselages, they do not always internalize the connection between the two.

title: The Region; 6 Republicans Hold the Keys For a City Of Democrats
description: IN New York's Romanesque state Capitol, which often seems a wax museum of peculiar politics, one of the most enduring oddities concerns the influence six Republican senators wield over the Democratic bastion of New York City.

title: Elite Kenyan Women Avoid a Rite: Marriage
description: For generations, marriage in Africa has been a rite never questioned. Now, for more and more of the relatively small numbers of university-educated women like 27-year-old Kay Makuku, marriage is a custom to be avoided.

title: Baja: Surfer's Log
description: When I was a teenager, Baja California was, for my friends and me, a big, gritty frontier that ran south forever. We drove down from Los Angeles in unreliable vans, camped in scrubby pastures and on obscure desert beaches, ate $1 lobsters, and surfed. Surf spots were named for the kilometer posts on the highway, which showed the distance back to the border. The farther south one pushed, the more exciting things got. The first time I surfed K181, I was 14 years old and firmly convinced that we had reached the far edge of the known world.

title: L.I.R.R. Eases Way for Spanish-Speaking Riders
description: CARLOS AND MARIA RAMOS, who recently moved to Long Island from New Jersey, wanted to take the train from Central Islip to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. The only place to buy a ticket, however, was from a vending machine.

title: Mass Killings Worsen in Colombia Drug War
description: A car bombing in Medellin recently and subsequent mass killings have exposed the fragility of a unilateral truce declared in July by drug traffickers in their campaign of bombings and attacks on the police.

title: French Phones
description: To the Editor: With regard to using telecartes in France (Travel Advisory, Jan. 6), travelers should be aware that they may soon have no choice but to purchase a telecarte, even if they intend to use their American telephone credit card.

title: Data Update
When Leisure Meant Keeping Busy
description: "NO IDLE MOMENTS," an exhibition at the New Canaan Historical Society's Townhouse through March 31, wends its way from the 1800's to the present, showing how people spent their free time making quilts and weavings, scrimshaw, woodwork, basketry, embroidery and lace.

title: Travel Advisory; Florida Show Honors Flowers
description: If you thought flower paintings belonged in motel rooms or on Mother's Day cards, a visit to the Fort Lauderdale Museum of Art's current show might change your opinion. Entitled "20th-Century Flower Painting," the exhibit contains 63 works. The paintings, presented with wit and sensitivity by Cara Montgomery, reveal a strange and wonderful garden -- Matisse's mysterious pansies, Jim Dine's elegant anthuriums, Alice Neel's posy on a bar stool, Edward McKnight Kauffer's cubist sunflowers. Plucked from both museums and private collections, famous artists (Paul Klee, Pablo Picasso, Elsworth Kelly, Arshile Gorky, Georgia O'Keeffe, Alex Katz, Andy Warhol) bloom beside less well-known contemporary figures from around the United States; not surprisingly, there is a good showing from Florida (Alessandra Gieffers, Richard Frank, David Reesse).

title: Bridge
description: The American bridge scene lost one of its most respected and beloved citizens last month when 85-year-old Lee Hazen died in Manhattan of complications following a heart attack. In a 60-year career in the game he was at the very top as player, administrator and raconteur.

title: Hooray?
description: Ideally, the United States would have won the Persian Gulf war armed not only with smart bombs and Patriots, but with a solid knowledge of Lord Kitchener's victory at Omdurman, the histories of the Crusades, the stories of Saladin and Reginald of Kerak and their meaning to latter-day Arabs, and a few pocket references to the Koran. We will have to learn fast.

title: Correction
description: A review of "Falling" by Colin Thubron on Feb. 3 included an erroneous reference to the author's output, supplied by his publishers. "Falling" is his fourth novel, not his second.

title: Miss von Lilienfeld Weds Charles Berry
description: Charlotte Christine Sybille von Lilienfeld, the executive director of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy in New York, was married yesterday in Seeshaupt, Germany, to Charles Bruce Berry, an institutional bond salesman at Reinoso & Company in New York. Father Dietmar Orth performed the Protestant ceremony at Heilige Maria Kirche.

title: Bank Penalties
description: People who forfeited interest or had to pay a penalty to a bank or financial institution because of withdrawing money from a savings account before the specified maturity date are allowed to deduct the forfeited amount on line 28 of the Form 1040. (Source: The J.K. Lasser Institute)

title: C. S. Bonan Weds Carol L. Quimby
description: Carol Louise Quimby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Clinton Quimby Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Charles Sauveur Bonan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seon Pierre Bonan of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Merton Rymph officiated at the Second Congregational Church, assisted by the Rev. Gregory Richards, an Episcopal minister.

title: INDIAN AIDS REPORT CITES SECOND VIRUS
description: An Indian specialist in sexually transmitted diseases says preliminary tests suggest that there are significant clusters of the immune deficiency virus known as HIV-2 in India. The virus is believed to have originated in West Africa.

title: Corrections
description: The No. 13 fiction entry on the paperback best-seller list in The Times Book Review today is incorrect in some copies. It should read: " 'Shadow Prey,' by John Sandford. (Berkley, $5.50.) Detective Lucas Davenport on the trail of a baffling serial killer." (It is not "Shadow Play" by Katherine Sutcliffe.)

title: Title in Jeopardy
description: Greg Haugen may lose the World Boxing Organization junior-welterweight title he won from Hector Camacho last weekend in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: To tell or not to tell: that is the question, one to which there is no right or simple answer. If a woman at a party has lipstick on her teeth, should she be told? And what about a man or woman with toilet paper stuck to a shoe or dandruff on the shoulder? As for unzipped zippers, do men tell women? Do women tell men? What to do, what to do?

title: Mutual Funds; Gold's Luster in Uncertain Times
description: Because gold prices have been slipping as inflation rises, experts are debating whether gold remains a good inflation hedge. But investors in precious-metals mutual funds -- which primarily buy gold-mining stocks -- are probably more interested in gold's role as an insurance policy.

title: Miss Lebenthal, A Broker, Weds
description: Alexandra Lebenthal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Lebenthal of New York, was married last night to Jeremy Diamond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Diamond of Bowie, Md. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York.

title: All Wrapped Up in Silky Kashmir Shawls
description: When the Aldrich sisters of Providence traveled together to Asia in 1919, they were already launched on a mission of serious collecting that was to last their entire lives -- and also benefit several museums.

title: Life Without Mother
description: FATHER MELANCHOLY'S DAUGHTER By Gail Godwin.404 pp. New York:William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

title: Deluge in Los Angeles Area Causes 2 Deaths
description: The storm that swept out of the Pacific and into this drought-stricken city on Wednesday brought Los Angeles its biggest downpour in more than five years and caused two deaths and damage to homes and beaches before moving out of the region today.

title: The View Through the Plate-Glass Window
description: THE CONSCIENCE OF THE EYE The Design and Social Life of Cities. By Richard Sennett. 266 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Coins
description: The war in the Persian Gulf is the first in 45 years in which American soldiers are not being paid with a special military currency. Because of the relative wealth of Saudi Arabia, the stability of its economy and the ubiquity of the American dollar in the region, military authorities apparently felt that an alternative currency was not needed.

title: The Flowery, Craggy Isles of Scilly
description: The Isles of Scilly lie so far off England's southwest coast that they are often left out of maps of the British Isles altogether. Depending on which islander you talk to, that is a good or a bad thing. They are an independent race out there, handsome, with eyes as clear and blue as the sea and craggy features like the rocks that guard their shores. Their romantic history suggests they are descendants of the last knights of King Arthur, after the sea had overwhelmed their pursuers and cut them off from Land's End. Their recorded history, reminiscent of Key West, runs to smuggling and wrecking and fighting for romantic causes like that of the Stuart pretender, the future Charles II, who fled there from Parliamentary forces in 1646.

title: The Best Games Are Insoluble
description: TRAVELS WITH DR. DEATHAnd Other Unusual Investigations.By Ron Rosenbaum.482 pp. New York:Viking. $22.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Patrick McEnroe Waits for John: Seventh-seeded Patrick McEnroe, returning first serves with well-placed passing shots, rallied from a first-set loss and reached the final of the Volvo Chicago indoor tournament yesterday with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Grant Connell. The final today could match brother against brother. John McEnroe played MaliVai Washington last night. An all-McEnroe meeting would be their second in a tournament; the other came in August 1985. Patrick said that if he does face his brother, it would not be a case of using his good first-serve return against a good server. "John has all the shots," Patrick said. "You never know where his serve will go, and it will be a boost for me in the rankings, if I win. I don't want to be known as John McEnroe's younger brother. I want to be known as Patrick McEnroe. But, he said, "to win, I have to play well." (AP) Lendl Gains Final: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl defeated Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 7-5, 6-4, last night to advance to the final of the ABN Amro World tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Lendl, ranked third in the world, struggled in the first set against Jarryd's backhand slices. But Lendl dominated the second set and will meet Omar Camporese of Italy, who beat Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands, 7-6, 2-6, 7-6. (AP) Golf Rarick Leads Kemper Open: Cindy Rarick is in the right place at the right time. Rarick, who attended the University of Hawaii and has a large following at Wailea, shot a two-under-par 69 Friday and took a two-stroke lead into the final round of the Women's Kemper Open. "When I come to Hawaii, I want to play well not only for myself, but for my friends and fans," said Rarick, the leader throughout the tournament.
