"I play well here and I feel like I have a lot of support over here." Rarick was at 10-under 203. Deb Richard made the strongest move, shooting a 67, and was at 205. Geddes and Dawn Coe were at six-under 207. The three-time Kemper Open champion, Betsy King, was at 208. Third-round victims included the defending champion, Beth Daniel, whose triple bogey on the seventh hole helped her drop from second place into oblivion. She shot a 76 and was at 212. (AP) Track and Field Girl Wins Three Gold Medals: Cathalina Staye of John Jay High School in Brooklyn won three gold medals in the girls' competition and four state records were set in the boys' division yesterday at the New York State interscholastic indoor championships at Cornell University in Ithaca. Staye, a senior, took the 600 meters in 1 minute 37.14 seconds and the 300 meters in 39.5 seconds, and anchored John Jay to victory in the 1,600-meter relay in 4:00.9. Ivan Jeanmarie of Prospect Heights in Brooklyn posted a state record in the 300 meters with a time of 34.19 seconds. Alex Rosen of Oceanside, L.I., broke a 16-year-old mark when he cleared 7 feet 2 inches on his second attempt in the high jump. He jumped 7-0 and 7-1 on his first attempts. The other state marks went to Chris Lopez of Archbishop Molloy in Queens in the triple jump at 50 feet 7 1/4 inches and Jermaine Johnson of White Plains, who went 24 feet 7 1/2 inches in the long jump, a foot more than his previous best indoors. DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx won three boys' events. Frank Guialdo was first in the 55-meter hurdles in 7.49 seconds and the Governors were first in the 1,600-meter relay in 3:23.79 and the 3,200-meter relay in 7:55.50, the fastest time in the nation this year. The Public Schools Athletic League boys team won the title for the third straight year with 125 points. The Catholic High Schools Athletic Association of New York was second at 103, behind Section II Albany with 86 points.

title: Laura L. Hurwitt, Analyst, Marries
description: Laura Lyon Hurwitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Hurwitt of Darien, Conn., was married in Scarborough, N.Y., yesterday to Christopher Daly Towle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ellwood Towle of St. Louis. The Rev. Jack Wortman performed the ceremony at the Scarborough Presbyterian Church.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: Thank you for Robert B. Reich's article "Secession of the Successful" (Jan. 20). It reminded me of a conversation I had with my eldest sister when I was applying to the Peace Corps at age 22. "Don't worry," she said, in an uncharacteristically patronizing tone, "you'll outgrow concern for the poor." Six years and much assimilation later, I realize that Reich caught me just in time: I almost had. PATRICIA B. PASCUAL Hartford

title: Linda Kingsbury Plans June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Richmond Kingsbury of Franklin, Mich., and Point O'Woods, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Jean Kingsbury, to John Vincent Buckley 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Buckley Jr. of San Francisco. A June wedding is planned.

title: Susan Hockfield and Thomas Byrne, Medical Professors at Yale, Are Wed
description: Dr. Susan Joan Hockfield and Dr. Thomas Nilan Byrne, professors at the Yale School of Medicine, were married yesterday at the Battell Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven. The Rev. Harry B. Adams, the chaplain of the university, performed the ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Frederick, Md.;
Duplexes, Yes, But Disguised
description: AT Worman's Mill, a 307-acre planned community here, the duplex is making a comeback in a setting designed to overcome its image problem.

title: Campus Life: Georgetown; 'White Male Writers' Is the Title of English 112
description: The reading list for English 112 is familiar: Hawthorne, Melville, James Fenimore Cooper, Twain. But for many students and faculty members at Georgetown University, the appearance of a course titled "White Male Writers" this semester is as surprising as it is revealing.

title: Family Ties
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Jean Thompson Weiler's "Searching Out Family Roots in Scotland" (Travel, Jan. 20) at the end of which the writer lists the address of the Registrar General in Dublin for those readers interested in searching out family roots in Ireland. For many Irish Americans, ties with Ireland are more than sentimental and nostalgic, for under provisions of the Irish Nationality and Citizenship Act of 1956, anyone born outside of Ireland but with at least one Irish-born grandparent is an Irish citizen. Confirmation of this citizenship is accomplished by a simple process of registration. It is from the Registrar General in Dublin that the birth certificate of one's Irish grandparent can be obtained.

title: A Daylong Tribute to Duke Ellington
description: A free, daylong tribute to Duke Ellington is to take place on March 16 at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. Mercer Ellington and the Duke Ellington Orchestra, Julie Wilson, Bobby Short, Mercedes Ellington and her tap-dance company, Gunther Schuller, Anthony Davis and the American Jazz Orchestra will perform. The event will run from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.

title: A Month of A Different Color
description: Television during February is sometimes beyond belief. The fact that it's sweeps month is bad enough; how many specials about rare diseases, incompetent doctors, murderous parents and child molesters can you bear? But February is also Black History Month -- for those of us who are black, a time of mixed feelings, at least about what's on TV. Suddenly the predominantly white universe of network television and the lily-white world of cable have been transformed. Everywhere you look, it's the Brotherhood Channel.

title: DECIPHERING THE M.L.A.
description: Babble, claptrap and follydoodle have captured the M.L.A. lecterns. The Living Theater was never like this. How can a nonmember get a ticket for next year's extravaganza in San Francisco? I'll pay up to the going rate for a top Broadway show. EUGENE FELDMAN Lewistown, Pa.

title: Travel Advisory; Fire Delays Cruise Ship
description: A fire aboard the giant Sovereign of the Seas, while she was docked in San Juan on Feb. 20, forced the 2,300 cruise passengers aboard to get off.

title: Zoo Animals in Kuwait City Also Suffered Iraqi Torment
description: The captives of the Kuwait City zoo did not escape the ravages of Iraq's occupation.

title: In Senate Ethics Inquiry, the Larger Issues Went Unaddressed
description: When the Senate Ethics Committee began its investigation of five Senators' ties to Charles H. Keating Jr., the underlying question was not simply their guilt or innocence but how far a lawmaker should go in helping a financial backer.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Winston-Salem, N.C.;
Upscale Project For East Side
description: A SUBDIVISION to lure upper-income families is being developed on 35 acres in this city's traditionally black east side.

title: A Glimpse of 1814 Hempstead In the Time of Peter Cooper
description: HONORING the 200th anniversary of the birth of Peter Cooper, the Nassau County Museum Services Division has introduced an exhibition focusing on the inventor and industrialist's time in the Village of Hempstead. The village, established in 1644, was a hub for the area between Jamaica and Huntington in the 19th century. It was a market town in a rural area.

title: Children's Food; Organically Grown
description: My intentions were always genuine, if not resolute. What I couldn't control for my newborn son -- ozone depletion, pesticide runoff, even the college he would attend -- left me with the one course I could control: what he would eat. I nursed him, and when he was ready for more calories, I bought organic baby food -- whole-grain cereals, strained carrots, peas, green beans -- with a passion normally reserved for more intimate endeavors.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; CHAOS IS REPORTED IN IRAQI CITY; U.S. SAID TO WIN NEW TANK FIGHT
description: Allied officials and refugees reported today that Basra, Iraq's second city, had been engulfed in chaos by the arrival of troops and vehicles driven from Kuwait in the last days of the Persian Gulf war, with sidewalks mobbed and streets impassable.

title: Belgrade Sends Troops to Croatia Town
description: Yugoslovia's President sent federal army units today to a small town in the Republic of Croatia after reports of violent clashes between Croatian security forces and Serbian villagers who had seized the local police station.

title: Turning the Corner on Political Correctness?
description: The New Museum of Contemporary art, well known as a champion of politically oriented art, is not quite its usual contentious self these days. True, Gran Fury, the activist art collective, is holding forth from its front window with a display concerning the distribution of condoms and the legalization of prostitution. In addition, there's an unusually beautiful, if history-laden installation by Carrie Mae Weems in the "workspace" gallery that involves various texts printed on wafting pieces of silk and photographs of significant objects -- a hammer and a sickle, say.

title: If This Is Hell, Why Is It So Popular?
description: CITY OF QUARTZ Excavating the Future in Los Angeles. By Mike Davis. Photographs by Robert Morrow. 462 pp. New York: Verso. $24.95.

title: The World; In Thailand's Coup, A Familiar Regional Variation on Democracy
description: THAILAND'S coup d'etat, which a week ago overthrew the first elected Prime Minister since 1976, is a useful reminder of the authoritarian style that runs throughout Southeast Asia, even in those countries that purport to be democracies.

title: Eileen Atkins, In a Class By Herself
description: Eileen Atkins returns to the New York stage this week, esteemed there and in England as a theatrical class act. But to hear her describe it, the miracle is that she ever succeeded at all in a country where her major achievement lay in triumphing over class.

title: What Investors Should Not Ignore
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Raining Violets
description: Before the last patch of spotty snow has melted, violets are already in blossom, sending their pert flowers head and shoulders above heart-shaped leaves. Fed by spring showers, nurtured by the strengthening light, violets put on a brave show before many spring bulbs have sprouted.

title: Global Warming Is One Subject Scientists Can Agree About
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Gets Serious With a New Set of Stars
description: In a recent show at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Nayland Blake, a San Francisco sculptor, provided a compelling metaphor for the state of the American contemporary art market after a decade of hard sell and slick promotion. Entitled "Natural History 1," Mr. Blake's assemblage featured a stuffed turtle with the word HYSTERIA emblazoned on its exposed underbelly. The artist might have been mocking today's bloated art market, trapped in a recession that has hurt auction houses and galleries alike.

title: For the Neediest: A New Record
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received record-breaking contributions for the sixth consecutive year. Generous even in the midst of recession, Americans have responded to the needs of the impoverished and the homeless by donating $4,439,093 to the 79th annual campaign, just ended. This exceeds last year's total by more than $66,000.

title: DECIPHERING THE M.L.A.
description: Articles on the Modern Language Association are as much a ritual as the conference itself: first the circus, then the review ("Deciphering Victorian Underwear," Feb. 10). Anne Matthews's judicious expose includes an equally ritualized nod to "Moby-Dick" as a battered "classic," rejected now by academics as the product of an all-male, all-white ruling class. Implied in this is a triple blindness among academe's glit-crits.

title: INSIDE
description: Furor Over Drug Ads

title: Kathryn Tabner To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John William Tabner of Latham, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Kathryn Lynn Tabner and Michael Mather Boardman, a son of William Mather Boardman of Woodstock, Vt., and Mrs. Richard Craven of New York.

title: Dr. Melissa Foodman, Veterinarian, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Foodman of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Melissa S. Foodman to Warren I. Shapiro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold N. Shapiro of New Hyde Park, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL
description: I am a professor in the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell University and teach a course on housing and feeding the homeless. I have found that volunteerism and public service are the keys to keeping young people engaged in their communities. As one student who had been headed toward a high-paying career in the hospitality industry said, "Working side by side with a homeless man has changed the fabric of my life." This student now manages a single-room-occupancy hotel in Los Angeles.

title: About Men; The Wrong Man
description: THE FIRST LETTER, bearing a West German postmark, began innocuously enough with "Dear Richard," but it quickly got into what seemed a funny, embarrassing mistake. The mistake is still being made, but I don't know anymore whether it is funny or sad.

title: Aggressive Collections by Hard-Pressed States
description: With many of the states facing fiscal crises and the recession cutting deeper into revenues, most are looking for ways to collect more taxes. Because raising income tax rates is politically unpalatable, most of those efforts will go toward tougher collections and auditing efforts, experts say.

title: MUM'S THE WORD
description: Austen Ettinger's About Men column "Mum's the Word" (Feb. 3) deserves a wide readership. As a psychiatrist, I have recommended it to a number of patients with marital problems. Although I try to help them find out what they want to say and how to say it, generally speaking, there's not been sufficient emphasis on how one can remain selectively silent, without "clamming up." The author's comments are of particular interest to me at this time, for I'm completing a work on both destructive and constructive communication. His thoughts on the subject remind us that, at times, silence can indeed be golden. HELEN A. DE ROSIS, M.D. New York, N.Y.

title: Dried Beans Throw Off Label as Winter-Only Fare
description: THE fact that dried beans are among the healthiest foods available has finally sunk in. Now, in some of the more up-to-date restaurants, you are almost as likely to get a helping of beans on your plate as potatoes or rice. The combination can be quite esoteric. Beans are showing up not just with pork or lamb but with fish, too. Grilled tuna is teamed with pinto beans, sauteed skate with white beans instead of the usual boiled potato and salmon with black beans flavored with fresh coriander. No longer are beans a winter food to be cooked with the traditional ham hock and served on the coldest days.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A VISIT TO YAZOO By Charles Neider Penguin, Paper, $6.95.

title: Maas Eyes Change Of Duties
description: On the same day he walked into camp and restated his desire to play left field for the Yankees, Kevin Maas also walked into Stump Merrill's office and asked for a private audience.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TALK BY YEVTUSHENKO

title: Most Savings Banks Remain Healthy
description: To the Editor:

title: L.S.U. Loses Outright Title
description: Greg Carter scored 20 points as Mississippi State defeated Louisiana State, 76-73, today to earn a tie for the Southeastern Conference title with the Tigers.

title: Yachting; Japan's Plan for a Major Effort
description: The day starts out simply enough for the 30 crewmen of Japan's America's Cup challenge team.

title: Carley C. Rand, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Rand of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Carley Coudert Rand to Carl Christopher Weatherley-White, a son of Dr. and Mrs. R. C. A. Weatherley-White of Denver. A June wedding is planned.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JEROME L. MURRAY;
Setting No Limits to Man's Inventiveness
description: FOR the inventor Jerome L. Murray, life has been one discovery after another -- the electric carving knife, the audible pressure cooker, the airplane boarding ramp and the peristaltic pump (which made open heart surgery possible), to name a few.

title: Judging an Inn by Its Book Covers
description: I'M perfectly willing to buy into almost any myth about vacation travel, no matter how feeble or consistently wrong. One to which I subscribe holds that a restful stay at a quiet country inn offers the ideal opportunity to catch up on the Great Books, to finally read those classics of literature and history that got overlooked in college. So if I'm headed to an 1870's inn on a dead-end dirt road somewhere in Vermont, I'll bring along a volume of Thucydides, Virgil, Proust or one of those other authors that Allan Bloom has gotten everyone into such a lather about.

title: Celeste Ford Wed to Fredric Leopold
description: Celeste Ford and Fredric Leopold were married yesterday at the Century Association in New York. Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in New York, the bridegroom's stepfather, performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: INDIAN DIVERSITY

title: Perspectives: Fifth Avenue; Retailers Place Heavy Chips on the 50's
description: INTERNATIONALISM has been on the ascendance in Fifth Avenue retailing for some years, and it is getting yet another upward thrust with a new mixed-use building for Takashimaya, the Japanese department store chain.

title: Spring Sojourns
description: Follow your fancy to faraway places with strange-sounding names. Like the Salento, a remote corner of southern Italy, rich in Baroque architecture, red earth and olives. Or even farther away and stranger sounding, the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, where you might find yourself a guest at a funeral feast of barbecued pig and tuak. Interact with a landscape. Roam around the Carolina Low Country, munching on barbecuq or boiled peanuts as you go. Watch the boobies, terns and frigate birds or catch a wave in Baja California. Get to know Hiroshima throught its monuments to peace. Get to know Paris through its food, and put together a perfect picnic on the way. Poke around the Swedish port cotoes of Goteborg and Stockholm. Or enter a time warp on a voyage to the Isles of Scilly (They're like england in the 50's). Off you go.

title: On Main Street, The Bulls Are Stampeding
description: The public is back in the market, and the speculative stocks are soaring. The money managers, suddenly bullish, are searching for laggards, afraid to stay on the sidelines. All told, it is certainly enough to make a contrarian investor nervous.

title: BERLIN
description: Spring -- and the stork -- bring baby animals and other novelties to zoos around the world. Times correspondents tell us about them. When Cody the rhinoceros stepped onto his Lufthansa flight from Sydney, Australia, in 1988, 60 other passengers got bumped. Ground personnel, it seems, had misjudged the girth of the big black rhino. But Cody made it to Berlin. There he lives with more than a dozen other rhinos, including Klaus of Leipzig, father of the two baby rhinos, due this spring, that are expected to be the hit of the Berlin Zoo.

title: As Asthma Changes, So Do Parents
description: FOR most parents, childhood milestones are fond memories: first smile, first steps, first words. But for a group of parents who meet each month at White Plains Hospital Center, the shared recollections are of a different nature: first breathing difficulty, first trip to the emergency room, first hospitalization.

title: Campus Life: Cornell; Rule Against Flags In Dorm Windows Is Suspended
description: Cornell University has suspended a clause in its campus housing contract that banned the hanging of flags and banners on university buildings. The university's decision came after two students attracted media attention because they refused to comply with the ban.

title: Ms. Rand to Marry Richard Rosenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Rand of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Susan Rand, to Richard Mark Rosenberg, a son of Maj. Gen. and Mrs. Robert A. Rosenberg of Alexandria, Va. A May wedding is planned.

title: Arts Bring Comfort in Patients' Last Days
description: CARVING wooden decoys had been a lifetime hobby for one elderly man who had come to spend his final days at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was suffering from terminal cancer, and his speech and movement had become slow, but he had many questions to ask about a new craft, basket weaving. With the assistance of Kathleen DeMarini, a fiber artist from Branford who works part time at the hospice, the man was about to start a project.

title: AFTER THE WAR: U.N. Resolution; Text of Measure Approved by the Council in 11-1 Vote
description: Following is the text of the resolution approved tonight by the Security Council:

title: For Those Who Wonder Which Side God Is On
description: To the Editor:

title: The Annual Struggle With Woodchucks
description: A FEW snowflakes here, some sunshine there. A bit of rain plus a seesawing thermometer. So far this winter, plants have had their ups and downs as far as the thermometer is concerned. Only summer will tell the real story on just how well these plants have come through. Most vulnerable, of course, are the broadleaved evergreens such as rhododendrons, leucothoe, hollies and certain azaleas that retain their leaves plus the early-blooming plants that have swelled buds.

title: Heather Lee Payson, Writer, Marries Jefferson Camp, a Horse Farm Owner
description: Heather Lee Payson, the daughter of Nancy Lawler Payson and John Whitney Payson, both of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Jefferson Clay Camp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Clay Camp of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Jupiter Island Beach Club in Hobe Sound.

title: Roaming Carolina Low Country
description: Ruin had been too long on my mind. A hurricane had leveled the forests north of my town, Charleston, S.C., and I was needing to see some trees. So on a Thursday I drove south toward Beaufort, 60 miles down the coast. All I counted on was the sight of landscape intact, but I hoped for more. I would be passing through a wedge of rivery wilderness -- an area set aside for Indians during the Colonial era, later the swampy hideout of escaped slaves, and still dotted with plantations -- and though I had no specific itinerary, there were a few things I did want to track down: a strange plantation I had once glimpsed from the road, the ruins of an ancient church, and a mysterious artist near Beaufort who, I'd heard, filled his yard with paintings.

title: Scarfs in Spring Colors to Catch a Breeze
description: As spring approaches, the stylish but winter weary wouldn't think of leaving home without adding a flourish.

title: Plan B Update
description: In the two previous years of the National Football League's Plan B free agency, signings started slowly. This year, they have been slower than ever.

title: AFTER THE WAR: A Reconstruction The Path to War -- Bush's Crucial Decisions -- A special report.; From the First, U.S. Resolve to Fight
description: The Bush Administration began planning an offensive campaign to dislodge Iraqi forces from Kuwait early last fall even as Administration officials insisted in public that the only mission of United States forces was to defend Saudi Arabia and enforce United Nations sanctions.

title: Giving Stein Her Due
description: To the Editor: John Richardson returns us to an era of polemical and reductivist approaches to Gertrude Stein that I had been delighted to see pass away. He seems unaware of the value placed on Stein's writing by many modern writers and critics, and simply buys into Leo Stein's view that his sister was just plain stupid.

title: The Lonely Big Bend of Texas
description: DRIVING into the Big Bend country of West Texas involves a kind of decompression process. First, all signs of human habitation disappear from the landscape, and time passes. Then, there's not a station to be found on the car radio, just static, and more miles go by. All the while the mountains that started out as isolated teeth against a vast sky begin appearing as clumps, then as ranges of red and purple cliffs. The countryside goes from something that is plausibly pasture land to something that is undeniably desert.

title: Pretenders to the Throne
description: Most of the 65 performers interviewed in I AM ELVIS: A Guide to Elvis Impersonators (American Graphic Systems/ Pocket Books, Paper, $8.95) look nothing like the King. In this compendium, whose editor modestly declines credit on the title page, there are child Elvises, a Black Elvis, a Lady Elvis ("Elvis is my life, the very core of me"), Elvises fat and thin, bearded and bald, a father-son Elvis act and El Vez, the Mexican Elvis, who wears "a classic white, double-knit polyester jumpsuit with red, white and green rhinestones and a sequined Virgin of Guadalupe on the back," with matching sombrero. Among this crowd, that outfit shows restraint. Elvises can be seen most weekends at county fairs, Elk and Moose lodges, flea markets, roller rinks and "major shopping centers across the United States." Offstage, an Elvis impersonator might be a poodle groomer, pharmacist, forklift operator, anesthesiologist, even an elected official ("By day the mayor, by night . . . THE KING"). One Elvis accidentally stumbled on his technique while trying to imitate Dean Martin, but about 10 percent got their start at Halloween parties ("Mike's wardrobe has evolved since that first Halloween appearance"). Most sing, although several (including the children) prefer to lip-sync while emoting "Love Me Tender" vibes (the Stanislavsky method is a big help, says one intense Elvis). Except for those who weren't born yet, these people can tell you what they were doing when the King died in 1977, and one says that from time to time Elvis drops in with career advice from beyond the grave. It would seem that nothing is impossible for "the most charismatic person ever on earth except for Jesus."

title: A Catalogue House at Center Stage
description: Letting executives of Hanover Direct Inc., the big catalogue company, lead a tour of their Weehawken, N.J., headquarters is a lot like letting attention-starved children show off their new toys.

title: L.I. Schools Test New Lights To Reduce Glare
description: "THE good news," said Ira Schwartz, technology chairman at Smithtown High School East, "is that the glare is gone, and there is less of an annoying hum."

title: Postings: Home Repairs; Amber Light for Saturdays
description: New York City homeowners inclined to undertake their repairs or improvements on Saturdays may be relieved -- or perhaps surprised -- to learn that they will no longer be breaking the law when they do so. A new statue that took effect in January -- after being passed unanimously by the City Council and signed by Mayor David N. Dinkins -- allows construction activity at one- and two-family homes between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. on Saturdays.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RECALLING ROBESON

title: Lisa Meyer to Marry Alan Richard Chorne
description: Dr. and Mrs. Karl I. Meyer of Melville, L.I., have made known May wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Erin Meyer and Alan Richard Chorne, a son of Marilyn Rheingold of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Daniel Chorne.

title: On Applying Paneling
description: MANUFACTURED wood paneling like plywood and particleboard is more common than solid lumber in everyday furniture and cabinetry. The reasons are paneling's relatively low cost, fewer labor requirements and structural advantages, chiefly resistance to warping.

title: A Little Sympathy for the Yankees
description: Even when it snows up north, the baseball players are down there, taking spring training for all of us. It's time to follow the Jim Palmers, who are getting one more chance, and the Darryl Strawberrys, who are starting over. They make us feel so young. They make us feel as though spring has sprung.

title: Internships Start Careers In Midlife, Too
description: BEVERLY GREGG had not earned a salary for 20 years, since she left her last job to raise three children. But when her youngest finished high school, Mrs. Gregg recalled, she decided to go back to work. But what kind of work?

title: CANADA SPURNED SOVIET SPY IN '61
description: A Soviet military intelligence officer who passed missile secrets to Washington during the Kennedy Administration was rebuffed by Canadian diplomats when he first offered to spy for the West, newly released Canadian intelligence documents disclose.

title: Sing No Blues for Jazz, Since the Music Is Hot Again
description: The explosion in jazz activity over the last half decade hasn't placed many decent new albums in the bins -- blame it on bad or nonexistent talent scouts, even worse producers, indifferent major labels, lack of easy access to foreign labels and unprepared young musicians. But things may be changing: the last month has seen a flood of exciting new recordings.

title: Patricia D. Kreis, A Buyer, to Wed
description: Elba Osorio Kreis of Oakland, Calif., has announced July wedding plans for her daughter Patricia Diana Kreis and Geoffrey Rowen Witt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Witt of Winnetka, Ill.

title: Clark R. Mollenhoff Is Dead at 69; Won Pulitzer for Labor Reporting
description: Clark R. Mollenhoff, a Pulitzer prize-winning reporter, author and syndicated Washington columnist who served briefly as a special counsel to President Richard M. Nixon, died of cancer yesterday at Stonewall Jackson Hospital in Lexington Va. He was 69 years old and lived in Lexington.

title: Music? Lyrics? He Can Get Them for You
description: Before rock music, before demoralizing production costs, before Stephen Sondheim and Harold Prince moved away from the genre, there was the well-crafted Broadway book musical. And one of the chief practitioners of the form was Harold Rome. "Music and lyrics by Harold Rome." His Broadway credits include (and just listing them seems to conjure up those wonderful old Broadway overtures and tapping feet) "Pins and Needles," "Call Me Mister," "Wish You Were Here," "Fanny," "Destry Rides Again" and "I Can Get It for You Wholesale."

title: Done.; A Short, Persuasive Lesson In Warfare
description: THE 42-day war in the Persian Gulf Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's hit-hard, hurry-up, high-tech, hyper-successful campaign to savage Iraq's military and oust it from Kuwait -- was a study in lessons learned.

title: You Can Look It Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Curtis to Wed Arnold A. Oppler
description: Sheldon Curtis of New York and Dr. Naomi Curtis of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Jennifer Curtis, to Arnold Alexander Oppler, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Oppler of Far Rockaway, Queens. An April wedding is planned.

title: Kay Rouse Weds J. Andrew Lark
description: Kay Coleman Rouse, a film executive, and J. Andrew Lark, a lawyer, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Midway (Ky.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Peggy Bright.

title: Traveler's Checks
description: To the Editor: My experiences with traveler's checks have been contrary to John Caffrey's (Letters, Dec. 2). I've never had to pay a fee when cashing them -- on the contrary, when cashing a traveler's check drawn in U.S. dollars in Switzerland, I have gotten a better exchange rate than a friend at the next teller who proffered dollar bills.

title: Special Today
description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine Part 2 Special Today: Your Taxes/Business, Section 3

title:
FOCUS;
The Weak Economy Benefits the Conservationists
description: The downturn in the economy is providing an opportunity for conservation groups to buy land and protect it from development.

title: Review/Music; The Vienna Offers Webern and Mahler
description: A prevailing image of the Vienna Philharmonic is its magnificent intransigence. The distinctive warmth, a tutti sound that is full without thickness, the bending of phrases in music it knows to wonderfully commodious shapes -- all represent provincialism ennobled. Neither a master of elegance like Herbert von Karajan nor a purveyor of spectacular egocentrism like Leonard Bernstein could really work their will on the Vienna's home-grown sound, and both men had the wisdom not to try.

title: U.S. Suspends Aid to Protest Bolivia Drug Post Appointee
description: The United States has suspended $66 million in aid for Bolivia to protest the appointment of a former intelligence chief to head the anti-drug squad, Government officials said today.

title: All About/Medical Supplies; Removing the Warehouse from Cost-Conscious Hospitals
description: In the palmy years before the nationwide squeeze on health-care costs, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston kept a hoard of expensive medical supplies in its 20,000-square-foot warehouse. Like all hospitals, St. Luke's cannot afford to run short of vital items -- least of all in the operating rooms. At St. Luke's, Dr. Denton A. Cooley's teams perform open heart surgery on 3,000 patients each year, using prodigious quantities of supplies.

title: Senegal
description: To the Editor: "Close to the Wild in Senegal" (Travel, Nov. 25), which recently came to our attention, was an excellent introduction to travel in eastern Senegal. As the two Peace Corps volunteers who advised villagers in the creation of the campement (a campground with huts) at Dindefelo featured in the article, we would like to add a point about the project.

title: Bangladesh's Lack of Oil Is Felt in the Fields
description: The old man with the flowing white beard sat on the veranda of his thatched home and looked across scores of acres of parched, cracked earth. In normal times, he said, the fields would be filled with wheat and the air would be filled with the hum of irrigation pumps drawing water and flushing it across the land.

title: Pro Hockey; Islanders Get Timeout to Talk
description: The outside influences that have surrounded the Islanders in this dismal and tumultuous season are having a strong effect on Coach Al Arbour and the players, especially Brent Sutter, the team's captain.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Cozy Spot Where Hopes Are Fulfilled
description: THE LAUGHING LION was named in a contest among customers when it first opened about a year ago. The small neighborhood bar-restaurant, which is just across the road from the Town Hall in the Morris County community of Dover, has the sort of congenial atmosphere, friendly service and good food at reasonable prices that one might hope to find in all neighborhood places.

title: To Help People Learn to Save the Birds
description: I want to express my appreciation for the publication of "Songbirds Dwindling Along With Woodlands" [ Feb. 10 ] .

title: Expanding the Short Form
description: The goal of tax simplication will move closer this year for some people. The "short form," as the 1040A is sometimes known, has been overhauled to allow more people to use it.

title: TORONTO
description: Spring -- and the stork -- bring baby animals and other novelties to zoos around the world. Times correspondents tell us about them. After their bitter winters, Canadians have more reason to celebrate the arrival of spring than most, and the sense of renewal will be strong this year at the Metropolitan Toronto Zoo, often listed among the finest in the world. For one thing, the annual thaw will be marked by the opening of the zoo's new Marco Polo Trail, designed to give visitors a sense of the animals and vegetation that the Venetian adventurer encountered on his overland journey to China more than 700 years ago.

title: Greenlawn Housing On Indian Settlement?
description: A PLAN to subdivide and develop a 48-acre parcel in Greenlawn is being opposed by neighbors.

title: Postings: New Lighthouse; Adding Space
description: It started out in the four-story brownstone of the sisters Winifred and Edith Holt on East 78th Street, and over the years, as it grew in size and in the services it offers, the New York Association for the Blind moved to larger and larger quarters.

title: Tech Notes; Robots That Put on Extra Cheese
description: Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University have developed a voice-activated robot that makes pizza. The goal of the group at the Center for Human Service Robotics was to create a "pizzabot" that could help physically disabled people operate pizza franchises. "From a technical perspective, most of the tasks in a pizza operation are amenable to robotic technology," said K. G. Englehardt, director of the center. Fox's Pizza Dens of Pittsburgh, the nation's sixth-largest pizza franchiser, recently said it will use the pizzabot in its restaurants.

title: Northeast Notebook: Manchester, Vt.; Village Gains Share of an Inn
description: A SUBSIDIARY of Guinness, the British brewer, has signed a contract to buy the 137-year-old Equinox Hotel, a financially troubled but majestic 144-room inn that dominates this New England village.

title: The Military Vs. The Press
description: LIEUT. GEN. PRINCE KHALID BIN SULTAN, commander of the Joint Arab Forces, glanced around at the reporters and television cameras crowding in on him and beamed. The setting was perfect, and the general had good news.

title: Travel Advisory; Bucks County Steam Train
description: Starting this spring, probably in May, the ear-piercing steam whistle of the iron horse will again be heard in the woodlands of Bucks County, Pa. The New Hope & Ivyland Rail Road, once the commercial lifeblood of the area, will soon resume service as one of the country's few active steam-powered trains, albeit in the diminished capacity of a tourist attraction.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Slumbering Luxury-Home Market Stirs
description: BROKERS in the Hamptons say that after one of the dreariest fall and winter sales seasons on record, the high-endhouse market shows signs of reviving.

title: The Multicultural Dictionary
description: To the Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Edwina Davis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Willard A. Speakman 3d of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their niece Edwina Voss Elder Davis to Richard Irwin Gibbons Jones Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Doe Run, Pa. The prospective bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George du V. Davis of Fairville, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Wall Street; Small Stocks: Rallying All Right, but for How Long?
description: Conventional wisdom holds that the last rally in small-company stocks ran from the spring of 1982 until mid-1983 and ushered in the phenomenal eight-year bull market of the 80's. Today, small stocks are booming again, and some theorists see that as evidence that another durable bull market has been born.

title: Open Up the Open
description: For Gabriela Sabatini, Pete Sampras and all their challengers and fans, the U.S. Open will stay in New York City. The No. 1 fan, Mayor David Dinkins, has agreed to rent the United States Tennis Association more parkland. New stadiums and courts, financed by the U.S.T.A., will benefit tennis and city alike. But the general public will be ill served if the new seats wind up on corporate expense accounts.

title: 2 Dissimilar Theaters Are Sharing a Season
description: CONSIDER two unalike theaters, 50 miles apart. Both are professional, purposeful and having a hard time.

title: In Honoring a Friend, An Auction of Art Items Also Benefits AIDS
description: "Nathan had the ability to relate to anyone," said Timothy J. Sweeney, executive director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis. "He could go from a black-tie fund-raiser to a church basement meeting with remarkable ease."

title: College Basketball; A Man of Principle Pays the Price
description: A stiff wind known as the Bora whips off the Adriatic and bustles through this port city caught between two cultures: of Italy and Yugoslavia, whose border lies 10 minutes to the east. And, back in his hometown again, Marco Lokar, the former Seton Hall basketball player, is also caught in the middle: between his dream of being a student athlete in America, which he has all but given up, and the reality of being a pacifist, which he steadfastly remains.

title: Rhode Island Plans a Series of Shutdowns
description: Rhode Island's largest union of state employees rejected a pay-deferral proposal by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1 on Friday, apparently dashing hopes that a series of one-day shutdowns of state government could be avoided.

title: LONDON
description: Spring -- and the stork -- bring baby animals and other novelties to zoos around the world. Times correspondents tell us about them. Some zoo animals inspire less affection than others -- "The camel's hump is an ugly lump," wrote Rudyard Kipling, "Which well you may see at the Zoo" -- but the beleaguered panda is beloved by nearly everyone. So, it is with understandable eagerness that officials at the London Zoo await a promised panda from China, which will, they hope, arrive in the spring or summer.

title: Credits Extended
description: Tax credits for solar energy and geothermal energy property placed in service after Sept. 30, 1990, have been extended through 1991. However, the energy credit for ocean-thermal property was not extended. (Source: The J.K. Lasser Institute)

title: A Terrible Mess Was Born
description: REBELS The Irish Rising of 1916. By Peter de Rosa. Illustrated. 536 pp. New York: Doubleday. $25.

title: Spoiled on Skorpios
description: ALL THE PAIN THAT MONEY CAN BUY The Life of Christina Onassis.By William Wright.Illustrated. 399 pp. New York:Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Phases of War: Making Peace; The Next Step Will Be Building a Solid Future On the Shifting Sands
description: POLITICAL power grows out of the barrel of a gun, as Mao Zedong said. But peace does not; it grows out of human hearts and minds. No place has proved the point better than the Middle East, over and over, for most of this century.

title: The Rainbow Company Offers a Quadruple Bill
description: FOUR years ago, Stefan and Marion Schnabel founded a modest performing group and called it Rainbow. It grew out of readings the veteran actors gave for students at Norwalk Community College, where Mrs. Schnabel taught acting. Within a year, a contract with Actors Equity was drawn up, and Fairfield County had a new small professional theater company.

title: Hiroshima: Peace Enshrined
description: In this city where they said nothing would grow for 75 years, the cherry trees bloom. They bloom along the banks of the Ota, their pink and white blossoms fluttering in the wind, floating on the surface of a river that 46 years ago was laden with the bodies of the burning who had flung themselves in.

title: On the Street; The Quilt Without The Spare Tire
description: A new silk quilted coat for all hours is meeting the needs of women who demand both style and functional qualities in expensive clothes. The Chanel design by Karl Lagerfeld comes in two lengths, hip and knee; both are slimming, and without the usual bulk of down-filled coats. The coat use the Chinese technique of sandwiching a thin layer of raw silk fiber betwen an outer layer of silk and the lining. The coat can go to lunch at Le Cirque, cover an evening dress or be worn for active sports.

title: New China Propaganda Wrinkle: Enjoyment
description: China's propaganda laboratories, after searching for years for a way to flavor "political study" to make it palatable, may finally have hit upon a success.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Cortlandt, N.Y. 358,000 8 Cross Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage, full basement; taxes $6,000. Eastchester, N.Y. 550,000 29 Interlaken Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; 2 fireplaces, 2-car garage, full basement, Jacuzzi, 2,600 square feet; taxes not yet assessed. Peekskill, N.Y. 168,000 4 Mountain View Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, cul-de-sac; taxes $3,935. Monroe, Conn. 180,000 59 Far Horizon Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old frame house; 2-car garage, screened porch, close to schools, 1.6 acres; taxes $2672. Trumbull, Conn. 205,000 159 Huntington Turnpike 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 135-year-old restored colonial; pine floors, 0.75 acre; taxes $2249. Stratford, Conn. 230.000 Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; oak floors, fireplace in family room, ceiling fans; taxes not yet available. OTHER AREAS Freehold, N.J. 168,500 85 Churchill Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, family room, c/a; taxes $3,210. Holbrook, L.I. 136,000 21 Macon Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17- year-old colonial; dining room, fireplace, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Medford, L.I. 112,000 2907 Beechnut Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700.

title: From War to Peace
description: Think of the Middle East as a jigsaw puzzle on a wobbly card table. Saddam Hussein knocked over the table. Now, after the thrillingly quick allied triumph, the pieces are back on the table, leaving the U.S. and its allies with a breathtaking opportunity. But the puzzle needs to be put back together just as quickly.

title: Is an Equitable Tax System Possible?
description: QUESTION: After the tedious ordeal of last fall, is the tax law better now than it used to be, Mr. Goldberg?

title: Bean Moves Into Lead as Nicklaus Fades Into Pack
description: While one past master of the Blue Monster course faded this afternoon, another rode his high-flying game to a one-shot lead going into today's final round of the Doral Ryder Open.

title: Paraguay Jittery Over the Exiled Stroessner
description: Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Alfredo Stroessner, the army general who kept this nation in his iron grip for 35 years.

title: Viewers Are Also Readers
description: To the Editor: Caryn James makes the same mistake as most media members and critics when she assesses the attitudes of TV news viewers [ "TV Gone Kaflooey: Reading Between the Censors," Feb. 10 ] . She assumes that viewers want to sit back and accept as indisputable truth whatever Dan or Tom or Peter may tell us.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE FONDASA Hollywood Dynasty.By Peter Collier.Putnam, $22.95.

title: The Big Spoils From a Bargain War
description: Could paying for the Persian Gulf war prove as easy a ride for Americans as fighting it? Economists take a perverse pride in supplying the rain for every parade. But even the most cautious are showing signs of being swept up in the euphoria of victory.

title: Fine Pieces Crafted From New Zealand's Wood
description: IN ancient times the Maoris of New Zealand hollowed their oceangoing war canoes from the trunk of the mighty totara, the most revered tree of the forest. The timber of this massive tree, growing to a height of 131 feet, was easy to split and carve and very durable, and its thick fibrous bark provided excellent thatching. In the north the totara was rivaled by the kauri, a conifer comparable to American redwoods, with thick, leathery leaves and New Zealand's largest and most renowned timber species. The largest living kauri is approximately 168 feet tall and more than 14 feet in diameter.

title: His Uniform Changes But Clark Doesn't
description: Jack Clark prides himself on playing hardball, whether it's with the bat or for a cause. And no matter how tough the situation, the powerful first baseman would rather change uniforms than change his ways or his opinions.

title: Patricia Matthews to Wed in Summer
description: The engagement of Patricia Allyn Matthews to Seth Charles Farber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Farber of San Francisco, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Matthews of Purchase, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title:
Focus: Maine;
Recession Benefits the Conservationists
description: THE downturn in the economy is providing an opportunity for conservation groups to buy land and protect it from development.

title: Paraguay Jittery Over the Exiled Stroessner
description: Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Alfredo Stroessner, the army general who kept this nation in his iron grip for 35 years.

title: School Basketball; Flying Toward His Future
description: Rodrick Rhodes caught a pass at the free-throw line in a high school game last week and started his ascent. What was he doing? How could a 17-year-old kid expect to remain airborne long enough to reach a basket that was 15 feet away?

title: Combining the Jazz and Classical Worlds
description: CHARLES DARDEN wears more than one musical hat. After taking a week off to conduct the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra in a concert for Black History Month, Mr. Darden will be back at his weekend stand starting on Friday, playing the piano at Bobby Van's restaurant in Bridgehampton.

title: Replay for the 90's: Escape From New York
description: Darryl Strawberry, the best baseball player in New York last season, has left.

title: Campus Life: Swarthmore; Phi Sigma Kappa Loses Its Chapter Over $100,000 Debt
description: The Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity at Swarthmore College has been abolished. College officials expressed doubt about its contribution to the campus after the fraternity ran up about $15,000 in debt for heating and utility services and $85,000 in charges for structural maintenance.

title: Michael Regan to Wed Miss Day in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Day Jr. of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Joan Day to Michael Timothy Regan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Regan of West Caldwell, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: A Stylish Italian Retreat in a Storefront
description: A FAST glance from a Long Island Rail Road train as it rushes through Syosset reveals something new. The drab rear wall of the convenience stores that border the station is broken by a brilliant orange door set against a gleaming white backdrop.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Nostalgia With a Purpose

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Franklin Lakes 386,000 603 High Mountain Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old split level; fireplace, screened porch, full basement; taxes $4,354. Freehold 168,500 85 Churchill Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, family room, c/a; taxes $3,210. Howell 155,000 59 Bernard Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; deck, family room, fenced yard, 2-car garage; taxes $2,977. Lakewood 65,000 182 Governors Square 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old condominium town house; c/a, eat-in-kitchen, monthly charges $90; taxes $1,274. Manalapan 178,000 383 Taylors Mills Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, den, w/w carpeting, patio; taxes $3,199. Maplewood 133,000 31 Kensington Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; full basement, convenient to train, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $4,018. OTHER AREAS Monroe, Conn. 180,000 59 Far Horizon Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old frame house; 2-car garage, screened porch, close to schools, 1.6 acres; taxes $2672. Peekskill, N.Y. 168,000 4 Mountain View Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, cul-de-sac; taxes $3,935. Port Jefferson, L.I. 140,000 15 Puritan Path 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,900.

title: After 3 Years, Expansion Plan for Mall Faces a Crucial Test
description: A THREE-YEAR battle between the owner of the South Shore Mall in Bay Shore and neighbors may reach a resolution this month, when the Town of Islip is expected to rule on a $138 million expansion plan.

title: Gwen Gepfert, a Clothing Executive, Is Engaged
description: John Randolph Gepfert 3d of South Salem, N.Y., and Mrs. John MacGregor Kindred of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwen Joan Gepfert, to Robert Norman Vogt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Edward Vogt of Longwood, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: Pro Football; Pay-Per-View Debate Urged
description: Surprised by the National Football League's disclosure that it may experiment with pay-per-view as early as next year, Representative Edward J. Markey, who heads a House television subcommittee, has asked the league to hold off until there is a full debate on the subject.

title: College Basketball; Fordham Advances In Final Second
description: When the 45th and final minute of the inaugural Patriot League championship game was about to expire and the Fordham and Holy Cross seasons were about to be defined, the Rams suddenly saw something that they had seen twice before.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MARGARET A. FLANAGAN;
Staying Vigilant for the President's Sake
description: SIXTEEN years ago, Margaret A. Flanagan made a major career change. Unhappy with her job as a flight attendant, she decided to become a special agent with the United States Secret Service.

title: Maureen Whalen Married
description: Maureen Catherine Whalen, a daughter of Jane K. Whalen and Dr. Robert E. Whalen, both of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday in Chapel Hill, N.C., to Richard Thomas Popp, a son of Virginia Popp of Brooklyn and the late Harold Popp. The Rev. Timothy O'Connor officiated at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The bride, 25 years old and a graduate of Duke University, is an account representative for the photographic materials division of the Mitsubishi International Corporation in New York. The bridegroom, 32, is a New York City police detective and is studying for a business degree at New York University.

title: A Modest Fund Lets Needy Hospital Patients Know Someone Cares
description: THE Care and Share fund at Northern Westchester Hospital Center here could have been called the Steven and Judi Goldsmith Fund. Ms. Goldsmith, an artist who lives in Chappaqua with her husband and two children, thought up the idea of providing services or goods to needy hospitalized patients, and it was the Goldsmiths who began the fund with a sizable contribution in 1988.

title: The Microwave War
description: Barely 18 hours after the war ended, a man was on Broadway near Times Square hawking victory T-shirts. "We Won!" they said on the front, the words flanked by two American flags. "Operation Desert Storm. Jan. 16-Feb. 27." All I could think of was some smooth small-time entrepreneur, standing with one eye on the television and one on the boys in the back room, yelling, "Roll 'em, Harry" at the moment that the President said, "I am pleased to announce that at midnight tonight . . ." This is some amazing country, where you can turn a commemorative item around in less than a day.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHINA'S CRISIS, CHINA'S HOPE By Liu Binyan. Harvard University, $22.50.

title: A Local Legend Is Branching Out
description: A LOCAL legend is being franchised. Walter's Hot Dog Stand, a fixture in Mamaroneck since 1919, has opened a branch on Tuckahoe Road in Yonkers.

title: Campus Life: Trinity; Fraternity Charter Is Taken Away In Drinking Case
description: Trinity University has for the first time revoked the charter of a fraternity, the Triniteers, after determining that it had violated the university's alcohol policy and Texas alcohol law. The fraternity's sister sorority, the Spurs, was also found to have violated campus policy and state law, and was placed on a one-year probation. In addition, university officials abolished the pledging activities of all 12 fraternities and sororities on campus.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has two patios with a "Chattahoochee" stone finish. For eight years, we coated these with a clear sealer, applying it twice a year. I cannot find this sealer in stores anymore, and the patios look awful. Can this type of patio be painted?

title: War's Cessation Buoys the Dollar
The New Bendel's: Made for the Young and Fancy
description: The new Henri Bendel store is sexy, like a Frenchwoman in slacks and scarf, even if it is the Gene Kelly version of Paris. The store opened to the public yesterday on Fifth Avenue near 56th Street in quarters that are six times larger and visually much more striking than the old store on West 57th Street.

title: Turn Mideast Money Into U.S. Deposits
description: The joke that has been going around since the war in the gulf began goes like this: Kuwait is a banking system without a country being defended by the United States, a country without a banking system. In large part, this is true. But together Kuwait and Saudi Arabia can help fix our banking and savings and loan mess.

title: Your Own Account; Adding Up the Fees
description: Here are fees you can expect if you refinance. They will vary by state, but might total 3 percent to 6 percent of the amount financed, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: WE got off the parkway at Exit 91, turning east, toward Manasquan Inlet. The inlet is famous for its winter sea birds -- winter gulls, loons, grebes and hardy sea ducks.

title: The Nation; Where Have All the Jobs Gone? Follow the Crab Grass
description: ENCASED in the millions of statistics the Census Bureau is releasing on what America looked like in 1990 are a few big mysteries about this decade.

title: Headliners; Getting Ideas
description: Call her Necessity. Gertrude Belle Elion, who holds 40 patents and shares a Nobel Prize, last week became the first woman to be voted into the Inventors Hall of Fame. Ms. Elion, who graduated from Hunter College with top honors in 1937 at the age of 19 and then earned a master's degree in chemistry, was cited for pioneering research at the Burroughs Wellcome Company that led to the development of drugs that combat leukemia and tissue rejection in kidney transplant patients. In 1988, Ms. Elion and her longtime colleague, George H. Hitchings, shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine for their work in developing synthetic DNA components that could disrupt the reproductive cycles of viruses and bacteria. Now 73 years old, Ms. Elion said that her interest in science made her a maverick in her youth, and she was pleased to be enshrined among the Bells and Edisons in the hall of fame, an independent, nonprofit organization in Akron, Ohio. "I'm happy to be the first woman, she said. "But I doubt I'll be the last."

title: Q and A
description: Fire Adjustments Question: I am a member of a cooperative board of directors. Recently there was a fire in our co-op and our managing agent suggested that we hire a fire adjuster to help us determine the amount of damage.

title: Low-Income Housing Credit
description: Congress extended the tax credit for investing in low-income housing through 1991, and a special one-time acceleration election for 1990 is allowed to investors who held an interest in qualifying low-income property before Oct. 26, 1990. Investors may claim up to 150 percent of the credit otherwise allowable in 1990 on Form 8609. Thus, the election increases the 1990 credit by 50 percent. (Source: The J.K. Lasser Institute)

title: Coping With Misconceptions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Anne Bannert, Model, Marries
description: Anne Bannert, a model, and Nathaniel Kramer, a photographer, both in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hamilton Kramer of New York. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dietrich Bannert of Hanover, Germany. The Rev. David Cockcroft, pastor of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Trust Funds
description: Beneficiaries of trust funds who receive a distribution within the first 65 days of the trust's next taxable year can elect to have the distribution treated as if it had occured in the prior year. That is advantageous for those whose tax rate will be higher in 1991 than it was for 1990. (Source: Sidney Kess, tax lawyer)

title: Nassau Joins Suffolk In Budget Cutbacks
description: RESPONDING to a possible revenue shortfall of up to $150 million, Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta is planning deep cuts in services and, perhaps, layoffs.

title: SAN DIEGO
description: Spring -- and the stork -- bring baby animals and other novelties to zoos around the world. Times correspondents tell us about them. A Noah's Ark of rare gifts is arriving in San Diego this year to celebrate the San Diego Zoo's 75th birthday: four koalas from the Currumbin Sanctuary in Australia, Siberian weasels from the Leningrad Zoo, Corsac foxes from the Moscow Zoo, whistling herons from the Berlin Zoo, white-faced scops owls from the London Zoo and Rothschild's peacock pheasants from the Hong Kong Zoological and Botanical Garden. Not least among the new arrivals, in size or importance, is a mate for San Diego's female Sumatran rhinoceros, member of a nearly extinct species that the zoo hopes to breed. (Indeed, this May is rhinoceros month in San Diego, with a city-wide rally to save these animals.)

title: At the Lehman, Works of War and Torture, Politics and Wit
description: THE question of why Luis Camnitzer is not as well known in this country as he should be is both raised and answered by his retrospective at the Lehman College Art Gallery here. Mr. Camnitzer is a Conceptualist who expresses his intelligence and insight largely through wit, and that is no way to act in the great art jungle. There humor must defer to solemnity, much as steam-powered ships once gave way to sails on the high seas.

title: Unbeaten Bowe Stops Biggs
description: Bowe knows boxing, at least enough to beat Tyrell Biggs.

title: When Bigger Trucks Go on the Road
description: The article "Potholes, Traffic Jams and Now a New Worry: Bigger Trucks" (Jan. 27) is erroneous about bigger trucks and their role in freight transport in New Jersey.

title: Reports Say Spain's Army Plotted to Kill King
description: Right-wing army officers planned to assassinate King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, the Defense Minister and other Government and military leaders at an armed forces parade on June 1, 1985, El Pais has reported.

title: Postings: Woodside Mall; Paying the Co-op Freight
description: If the boards of co-op corporations ever daydream, it must be about ways to get someone other than their tenant shareholders to help pay for the ever-rising costs of running a big apartment project.

title: Gutter Ball On Last Roll
description: Del Ballard Jr., needing just seven pins, rolled a gutter ball on his final shot yesterday to lose the Fair Lanes Open to Pete Weber in one of the most bizarre finishes in Professional Bowlers Association history.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Casualties; Wounded G.I.'s Tell Of Barracks Horror When Scud Struck
description: Pfc. Anthony Drees was scrambling for his helmet when an Iraqi Scud missile devastated his barracks. The blast broke one of his legs and shattered the other.

title: Travel Advisory; A Taste of the Desert in India
description: In Rajasthan, where there are more palace hotels than any other place in India, one former maharajah's family thought they would offer tourists something out of the ordinary: a taste of life in a desert village.

title: Real Texas Barbecue: Hold the Sauce
description: "WHATEVER you do, don't embarrass me by asking for silverware or vegetables or plates or anything sissy like that," my guide, a friend and Texas native, hissed at me as we approached the door to the Kreuz Market in Lockhart, Tex., considered by many to be the barbecue capital of Texas. "You order the meat by the pound and it comes on a sheet of brown butcher paper. Try not to step in the pit when we go in."

title: Cartoons for a Small Planet
description: Blue-skinned flying heroes rescue dolphins trapped in tuna nets. Mutant Ninja Turtles recommend that viewers avoid standing for too long in front of open refrigerators. Teen-age journalists opt to print the school newspaper on recycled paper. Say goodbye to the Road Runner school of senseless cat-and-mouse chases: children's television has gone green.

title: 'Hip Hop' Moves Closer to Respectability
description: WITH its show "Hip Hop Nation," Real Art Ways in Hartford would seem to be espousing neo-Radical Chic. After all, the term "hip hop" goes back to the mid-1970's, when it was first used publicly by disk jockey rappers like Love Bug Starsky and D. J. Hollywood. Afrika Bambaataa, who is known as the "grandpa" of hip hop, explained in a recent phone conversation that hip hop is a culture, a "whole musical way of life" that has its roots in Africa but expresses itself in graffiti and fashion as well as music.

title: The World; On the Edge, In the Lands That Wrote The Book
description: IN addition to good wines and cheeses, rousing folk music and rich poetry, the Balkans have given the world the term "Balkanization" -- for the breakup of countries along ethnic lines into antagonistic fragments.

title: Miss McLaughlin, A Student, Weds
description: Kimberly Sue McLaughlin, the daughter of Edward Francis McLaughlin of New York and Caroline McLaughlin of San Mateo, Calif., was married yesterday at the San Francisco Golf Club to Pierre Leon Pellissier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Pellissier of Whittier, Calif. Judge Albert Dover of Nevada County Municipal Court performed the ceremony.

title: Sunday Menu; Fresh Fish Stew With Orange and Fennel
description: Does the mention of fish stew conjure up images of a big mess in the kitchen? Well, his speedy, simplified version is meant to entice you into putting aside your objections.

title: Principal Pleads Not Guilty To Charges of Abusing Boys
description: The suspended principal of an Elmwood Park elementary school has pleaded not guilty to charges that he touched young boys at his school and photographed students for sexual gratification.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday with an article about Woody Allen and Mia Farrow included erroneous identifications supplied by the Photoreporters agency for the child shown with Mr. Allen and for the date and place. The picture, on page 30 at the top center, showed him holding his daughter, Dylan Farrow, on the set of the 1987 film "Radio Days."

title: Travel Advisory; Peru Warning
description: The Department of State has authorized the voluntary departure of nonessential government personnel and their dependents from Peru for the duration of the Persian Gulf war.

title: When Bigger Trucks Get on the Road
description: The article on triple trailers in New Jersey raises a very distasteful argument that says a measure of highway safety should be sacrificed for the benefit of greater profits of trucking and trucking-dependent industries.

title: Eager to Read the Books They Write
description: PILES of colorfully bound books are neatly stacked on shelves. The unmistakable clutter of publishing -- book covers in various stages of readiness, manuscripts waiting to be proofread -- takes up almost all the available space on counters and floor. To the almost archaic clatter of typewriters -- signaling the transformation of still more manuscripts into final publication form -- a writer confers about book-jacket design in a corner of this sunny space.

title: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; U.N. Approves Measure Bolstering Allies' Rights
description: The Security Council easily approved a resolution tonight that effectively endorses President Bush's call for allied troops to remain in the Persian Gulf until Iraq has complied with his peace terms.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Frederick, Md.;
Duplexes, Yes, But Disguised
description: AT Worman's Mill, a 307-acre planned community here, the duplex is making a comeback in a setting designed to overcome its image problem.

title: Passage Rites on Sulawesi
description: Celebes, as it was known when it was part of the Dutch East Indies, or Sulawesi, as the island is called today, is fixed into the vast Malay Archipelago that stretches between Australia and Southeast Asia. This archipelago, which is now almost entirely the Republic of Indonesia, adorns the equator like an elaborate necklace, its islands dangling north and south from the line dividing the world into hemispheres. Sulawesi, a large, orchid-shaped bauble, is suspended at its geographic center: east of Borneo across the Macassar Strait and west of the Moluccas, or Spice Islands, which lured the likes of Christopher Columbus and Sinbad the Sailor.

title: Campus Life: Maryland; A Regent's Seat For Frank Perdue Draws Protests
description: Frank Perdue has been a University of Maryland system regent for barely a month, but a number of student groups and faculty members on the College Park campus say they want him out.

title: Miss Gutzweiler Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Gutzweiler of New Cumberland, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Cassandra Eileen Gutzweiler and Jonathan Wilson Kimnach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson H. Kimnach of Woodbridge, Conn. Miss Gutzweiler, 24 years old, graduated from Beaver College, as did her fiance. She is an interior designer with Celeste Callaghan Interior Design in Doylestown, Pa. Mr. Kimnach, 27, is an account representative with Rollins, Burdick, Hunter, an insurance firm in Trevose, Pa.

title: Irene Sinrich Married to Mark Sudac
description: Irene Leslie Sinrich, a vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust, and Mark Thomas Sudac, a vice president of the IBJ Schroeder Bank, both in New York, were married last evening in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

title: Campus Life: Middlebury; Fraternity Chapter Prepares to Fight Its Termination
description: Delta Kappa Epsilon, the only one of six fraternities to defy a Middlebury College mandate requiring that women be admitted on an equal footing, has begun preparations for a court battle against the board of trustees and administration.

title: Choral Choices Abound For State's Concertgoers
description: IF you agree with John Clarke, who wrote in 1639 that "the voice is the best music," you'll have at least a dozen opportunities this week to enjoy voices raised in musical chorus. Today at 4, Richard Donohue conducts the South Congregational Church Choir of Hartford in a program of music for Lent and Easter at the Second Congregational Church of Middle Haddam. Poetry, songs and instrumental pieces from the 4th through the 20th century will retell the Passion story, with the Sanctus from Leonard Bernstein's "Mass" offered in tribute to the composer and conductor. For information, call 267-6425 or 633-1382.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: EMERGENCY ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES;
Cleaning Up After Other People's Mishaps
description: THE muskrats are splashing about and just last week, the deer returned. The lab reports on the water samples are encouraging.

title: Jury Duty Pay
description: People who were called to jury duty in 1990 must report what they were paid for their service on line 22 of Form 1040. Because this money is reported to the I.R.S., people who fail to report it could receive a deficiency notice from the I.R.S. In cases were employers continued to pay jurors their regular salaries but required them to turn over their jury pay, they can then claim an offsetting deduction on line 30. (Source: Julian Block, tax lawyer)

title: For East European Film Makers, the Picture Is Uncertain
description: At the beginning of Piotr Mikucki's new feature film, "Bad Connection," Thomas, a former member of the Polish Solidarity movement, asks a series of painful questions about his identity: "Am I a taxi driver or a sociologist? Am I a man who deeply loves music, or is Mozart simply an escape? Am I a revolutionary or merely a coward?"

title: Headliners; Just in Time
description: The consensus in Washington seems to be that Dr. David Kessler stepped in as head of the Food and Drug Administration not a moment too soon. The agency, which some regard as the most influential regulatory body anywhere, has been stressed by budget cuts and racked by scandal in recent years even as its workload was increasing. Dr. Kessler, who was sworn in as the F.D.A. Commissioner last week, has degrees in law and medicine and taught food and drug law at Columbia Law School while serving as director of medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Sidney Wolfe, head of an advocacy group that has been one of the F.D.A.'s harshest critics, said Dr. Kessler's appointment was promising. Dr. Wolfe said the appointment came "at a key time," with the agency "demoralized unlike anything I have ever seen." Peter B. Hutt, a lawyer and consultant who serves on some F.D.A. panels, said the new commissioner appeared to be "the perfect person to hold this job." He added, "If he can't do it, no one can."

title: Gorizia
description: To the Editor: A couple of points about Gorizia ("A Not-Very-Divided City" by Paul Hofmann, Travel, Dec. 16): The castle is not a ruin, it is complete and in good order down to the furniture. Several years ago I saw an excellent show of Venetian paintings, Canaletto, Titian, etc., at the castle and had a terrific lunch at Lanterna d'Oro next to the castle.

title: A Catalyst in Crafts Makes a New 'Leap'
description: AT the age of 71, Hortense Green is about to begin her fourth career. "The sixth if you count being a wife and mother," she said. Mrs. Green, who has promoted crafts artists for the New Jersey State Council on the Arts since 1979, has moved to a national stage by taking a similar job with the American Craft Council in New York.

title: Technology; Microchips for Drug Compounds
description: Borrowing technology from the electronics industry, a new pharmaceuticals company here hopes to speed the pace of drug discovery by creating chips containing thousands of potential drug compounds on a 1-centimeter square.

title: Ms. Leonard to Marry Christopher C. Getch
description: May wedding plans for Cathy Marie Leonard and Dr. Christopher Caldwell Getch, the son of Mrs. Robert G. Greeley of Milton, Mass., and John S. Getch of Sandwich, Mass., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Leonard of Butler, Pa.

title: Streetscapes: The Steinway Rowhouses; A Sour Note on Historic Status
description: A SWEET little group of 29 two-story red-brick rowhouses is clustered at the crossroads of 41st Street and 20th Avenue in Astoria, Queens. They were built as workers' housing in the 1870's for the nearby Steinway piano factory.

title: Lynn S. Klotz to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Klotz of Wilton, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Lynn Stowe Klotz, and Matthew John Vincent Salt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Salt of Broadmayne, Dorset, England. Miss Klotz, 29 years old, graduated from the University of Connecticut and is a graphic designer for R. H. Macy & Company in New York. Mr. Salt, 32, graduated from University College in London and practices with Caldari Architects in New York.

title: Mutual Funds; As the I.R.A. Season Draws Near
description: Like crocuses, mutual fund advertisements -- coaxing investors to open individual retirement accounts before April 15 -- are harbingers of spring. So far, they have succeeded: Mutual funds had captured almost a quarter of the $465.4 billion I.R.A. market at the end of 1989, the most recent totals from the Investment Company Institute, a trade group. That's a bigger chunk than the I.R.A. money invested through banks, savings institutions, life insurance companies, credit unions or brokerage firms, which also offer the tax-deferring I.R.A.'s.

title: Richard Helsden Phillips, Retired Rear Admiral, 84
description: Rear Adm. Richard Helsden Phillips, retired, a highly decorated veteran of World War II, died last Tuesday at the National Hospital for Orthopedics and Rehabilitation in Arlington, Va. He was 84 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: How Water Companies Manage Supplies
description: The letter by Bill Ellinger, head of the Long Island water suppliers' association [ Feb. 17 ] , refers to me inaccurately as a "self-styled environmentalist whose tenuous comprehension of water issues has not improved over the years." Rhetoric notwithstanding, perhaps he is unaware that I have an M.A. in geology (Columbia, 1950), that I am an adjunct senior professor at Hofstra and that I have received awards from NASA (1968) the New York Professional Engineers Society (1969), the Association of Conservation Districts (1985) and the Nassau Bar Association (1986).

title: It's the Same Old Song (Well, Not Really)
description: For a live album recorded in 1974, Badfinger's "Day After Day" sounds almost too good to be true. Listening to "Baby Blue" and the band's biggest hit, "Day After Day," with its crisp, crackling drums and robust harmonies, one might think the CD was recorded last year. And, in fact, parts of it were.

title: Daniel Pyne Did It: 'The Hard Way'
description: What first intrigued the writer Daniel Pyne about "The Hard Way," a comedy thriller that is as much a sendup of the way Hollywood perceives the real world as it is a story of cops and bad guys, was the idea of trying to fashion a parody with some depth, rather than a predictable cliche.

title: You Can Look It Up
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A Spec Office Center for Woodcliff Lake
description: IN the northwestern corner of Woodcliff Lake lies a patchwork of apple orchards, farm markets and new office buildings, symbols of this Bergen County community's rich farming past and its present as a contemporary corporate address.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Boston;
56-Unit Co-op In Dorchester
description: THE first 19 families have moved into a 56-unit co-op project at the converted 19th-century Brooks School in the Dorchester neighborhood.

title: Octavio Paz Liked It, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: DePaul Surprises Redmen
description: Less than a week after turning in a superb effort against Georgetown, St. John's closed out its regular season this afternoon by watching DePaul shred its man-to-man defense en route to a convincing 79-69 victory at the Rosemont Horizon.

title: Talking: Co-ops; Resales And Tax Liabilities
description: A POLICY statement issued in December by the New York State Attorney General's office will make it faster and cheaper for financially troubled cooperatives to sell the shares they acquire from a conversion sponsor who has defaulted on his monthly maintenance obligations.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Ray Lema: 'Gaia' Mango 162 539 895-2; all three formats.

title: Brooke Byers to Wed Eugene Goldman
