description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Califano Jr. of New York and Washington have announced the engagement of Mrs. Califano's daughter Brooke Alison Byers to Eugene Goldman, the son of David L. Goldman of Verona, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: MUM'S THE WORD
description: "Mum's the Word" is a curious article by a former advertising man. Is avoiding a conversation after "moments of crisis" a good idea? Like it or not, we must talk to each other. The question appears to be not should we, but how can we do it better? HAROLD BELMAR Brooklyn

title: Penny Murphy to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Wilfred Murphy of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Paula Graham Murphy to Theodore Harkness Ashford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Harkness Ashford of Wilmington, Del. A June wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Pop page on Feb. 3 about clarinetists referred incompletely to the album "New Orleans Reunion." It is available on CD as well as cassette.

title: Lauri S. Weiser and William Min Are Engaged
description: Mrs. Sherman E. Weiser of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Lauri Sue Weiser to William Eui-Shik Min, the son of Drs. Chang H. and Sung J. Min of East Islip, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Small Banks Resist Trend On Profits
description: DURING the 1980's, when many commercial banks were reporting fantastic rates of return from real estate ventures, managers at New Haven Savings Bank considered getting into those areas, too. "But we have learned from the past that prosperity does not last forever," said New Haven's vice president, David R. Rice. "So even when it's most tempting, we do not participate."

title: The World of Alsace
description: THE profusion of heart-shaped cookies and breads, the carved timbers of medieval and Renaissance houses, the whimsical old-fashioned shop signs and other glimpses of the past give Strasbourg in northeastern France a quaint and charming air. In this capital of the Alsace region, streets still bear the names of the medieval tradesmen who lived and worked there. Menus are filled with names like choucroute, backenoffe and flammekuche and people speak French with a special rhythm and accent. To decipher these remnants of Strasbourg's rich history and culture, a visit to its small museums gives an intimate portrait not only of this cosmopolitan city but of the art and tradition of Alsace.

title: The Region; In Lawsuits, How Much Should the Courts Keep Secret?
description: THE growing national debate about the long-standing practice of sealing court records and the terms of settlements in civil suits has recently brought about changes in the New York court system, and bills that would further restrict the secrecy stamp are now being considered by state legislatures in Trenton and Albany.

title: Herman G. Berdolt, Banker, 88
description: Herman G. Berdolt, retired senior vice president and controller of the Greenwich Savings Bank, died on Thursday at Huntington Hospital in Huntington, L.I. He was 88 years old and had been a lifelong resident of Manhattan until he moved to Huntington Station, L.I., two years ago.

title: Cynthia Dunham To Wed in the Fall
description: Cynthia Brooke Dunham's engagement to Craig Albert Lange, the son of Gail J. Lange of Bridgewater, N.J., and the late Albert H. Lange, has been announced by her parents, Nancy L. Dunham of Morristown, N.J., and Richard C. Dunham of Lakeville, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Michael Milken is expected to begin serving his sentence in a minimum-security prison in the San Francisco area. * January new home sales. * Expected announcement of an international consortium to modernize the Soviet air traffic control system. * Two-day conference on investing in Soviet real estate begins in New York. TUESDAY: January factory inventories, orders and shipments. * February auto sales. WEDNESDAY: Mortgage Bankers Association survey of mortgage delinquency for the fourth quarter. * Labor productivity and costs for the fourth quarter. THURSDAY: Major retailers report February sales. * Consumer installment credit for February. FRIDAY: February unemployment.

title: In Defense Of a Montauk Founder
description: An article [ "New Exhibition Sheds Light on Ancient Montauk Indians," Jan. 27 ] maligns the memory of one of Montauk's founding fathers, Arthur Benson. As publisher of the local newspaper, I rise to his defense.

title: College Basketball; Fordham Advances In Final Second
description: When the 45th and final minute of the inaugural Patriot League championship game was about to expire and the Fordham and Holy Cross seasons were about to be defined, the Rams suddenly saw something that they had seen twice before.

title: Pirates Pull Out Victory
description: Seton Hall came to Byrne Arena for its final regular-season game today, trying to secure a spot somewhere in the middle of the pack for next week's Big East tournament. Boston College, in last place in the conference standing, came in spoiling for an upset.

title: The Nation; The Budget Chief: Disarming Critics With a New Tact And Good Behavior
description: FEW public servants have ever commanded a process as complex as the Federal budget more completely than Richard A. Darman.

title: Elizabeth Briggs, Manager, Weds
description: Elizabeth Harriet Briggs and James L. P. Glidden were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., by Ann Mandel, a justice of the peace, at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram 127,500 20 Albright Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21- year-old colonial; den, basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,700. Hauppauge 158,000 10 Calico Tree Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; dining room, den, finished basement; taxes $3,200. Holbrook 136,000 21 Macon Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17- year-old colonial; dining room, fireplace, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Medford 112,000 2907 Beechnut Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Port Jefferson 140,000 15 Puritan Path 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $3,900. Williston Park 175,000 233 Collins Avenue 5-bedroom, 1- bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, Florida room, basement, 1- car garage; taxes $3,500. OTHER AREAS Monroe, Conn. 180,000 59 Far Horizon Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old frame house; 2-car garage, screened porch, close to schools, 1.6 acres; taxes $2672. Peekskill, N.Y. 168,000 4 Mountain View Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, full basement, cul-de-sac; taxes $3,935. Freehold, N.J. 168,500 85 Churchill Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, family room, c/a; taxes $3,210.

title: Brookhaven X-Ray on New Path to Heart
description: EQUIPPED with the world's brightest X-ray beam, researchers at the Brookhaven National Laboratory are stepping up the fight against heart disease by using a new technique, transvenous angiography.

title: New York Area Grows Fastest At Its Fringes
description: Until about five years ago, the John Deere dealership in Goshen, N.Y., sold mostly farm equipment. But as some barns and silos gave way to offices and shopping plazas and wooded ridges sprouted subdivisions, it has been selling fewer hay balers -- and more lawn mowers and snow blowers.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: Recalling your feature on skiing bargains (Travel, Nov. 11), I'd like to share my experience in Austria. Friends and I just returned from two weeks at a ski area near Salzburg that cost only $30 a night, including breakfast. Miles of pristine skiing are accessible within easy reach of the Landhaus in Neubert, a warm and cozy pension, where we stayed with 20 other skiers (mostly Europeans).

title: Q and A
description: Farm Vacations

title:
Commercial Property: Downtown Miami;
The Plight of Just One Building Has a Ripple Effect on the Market
description: THE difficulties of one downtown office building are having a significant effect on the commercial real estate market in this semi-tropical city.

title: On Language; Endgame War Game
description: "IT'S THE BEGINNING of the endgame," said William Quandt, one of the phalanx of former diplomatic officials, now in think tanks, who come crashing through television screens at each development in the Middle East. He was reacting to an announcement on the Baghdad radio that Iraq would consider withdrawal from Kuwait if a series of conditions were met, and his characterizing words were seized upon by ABC's Peter Jennings, John McWethy and Sam Donaldson.

title: Soviet Plans for Armenia Quake Recovery Stall
description: Government officials now concede that most of the ambitious plans for recovery from the Armenian earthquake of 1988 are in disarray.

title: 80 Days That Saved the World
description: THE DUEL 10 May-31 July 1940: The Eighty-Day Struggle Between Churchill and Hitler. By John Lukacs. 258 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $19.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Solvang, Calif.;
Windmill Gets Observatory
description: A $1.2 MILLION reproduction of a 16th-century Danish observatory tower is being built in Solvang, a former Danish settlement that is now a tourist attraction in central California.

title: Self-Promotion Is An Art in Itself
description: To the Editor: John Richardson's attempted dismemberment of Gertrude Stein makes it clear that he is the perfect biographer for that lifelong abuser of women, Pablo Picasso [ "Picasso and Gertrude Stein: Mano a Mano, Tete-a-Tete," Feb. 10 ] . I had not realized, however, that Picasso's vastly overblown artistic reputation was deflating so rapidly that it was necessary to stick pins in Stein in order to keep Picasso afloat.

title: Topics of the Times; Dancing Day
description: In New York, at the slightest hint of warm weather, the street performers emerge. Maybe they've been in garrets, maybe at auditions, but now they're facing the public, the toughest public they'll ever know. Never mind that the audience is nonpaying. It's on the fly, between lunch and shopping, and it's hard to capture.

title: Review/Theater; Some Dancers, Mice, An Elephant and Others
description: With "Blue Heat," John Jesurun continues his idiosyncratic experimentations in the uses of sound, light and video to create a multiplex environment. This time, his setting (at Intar Two) is a scooped-out space that in a shimmering light looks like the inside of a plushly lined coffin.

title: Death and Robbery Strike 2 Brothers-in-Law in Brownsville
description: Friday night, as on most nights for the last 30 years, Thomas Cerchia closed up the family market, Cerchia Brothers Meats in Brooklyn, and said good night to his brother-in-law, Peter Dellananna.

title: Miss Rosenberg Wed To Anthony W. Soslow
description: Joanne S. Rosenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Anthony White Soslow, the son of Theodore J. Soslow of Elkins Park, Pa., and Patricia Kulsziski of Greenport, L.I. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Union League Club.

title: Brown Lost a Chance to Air Free Speech Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Do It Yourself, Or Go to a Pro?
description: Mildred Mailick, a professor at the Hunter College School of Social Work, and her husband Sidney, a professor at New York University, have had their tax returns professionally prepared for more than 30 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War 16-19

title: Rose Returning
description: Pete Rose is returning to the autograph circuit.

title: The Sparrows And Exotica
description: To the Editor: Reading the reviews of David Hirson's new play "La Bete" by the Times critics Frank Rich and David Richards was like watching someone shoot down an exotic bird that has magically appeared among a flock of sparrows. One wondered at the violence of the attack. Wholly absent from either review was a sense of how unique an event "La Bete" is, or how exhilarating.

title: CALIFORNIA IS TORN BY POLITICAL WARS OVER 7 NEW SEATS
description: The huge population shift that transformed California over the last decade has produced an intense struggle over the political riches that the shift has produced: the seven Congressional seats that California has gained at the expense of New York and other Northeastern states.

title: Paraguay Jittery Over the Exiled Stroessner
description: Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Democracy has become the way of the land since the February 1989 coup that ended the rule of Alfredo Stroessner, the army general who kept this nation in his iron grip for 35 years.

title: A Big Deal
description: The San Francisco Giants reached agreement on a two-year contract yesterday with Matt Williams that is the richest pact ever for a player not yet eligible for arbitration. The third baseman, who led the National League in runs batted in with 122 last season, will earn $600,000 this year and $2 million for the 1992 season. . . . The Dodgers' Ramon Martinez, who posted a 20-6 record last season with a 2.92 e.r.a, agreed yesterday to a one-year contract. Martinez had been asking for about $500,000 while the Dodgers were offering approximately $400,000. Terms of the pact were not immediately revealed. Martnez, who had remained at home in the Dominican Republic during the dispute, will begin workouts at Vero Beach, Fla., on Wednesday. Martinez was also not eligible for arbitration. . . . The reliever Rob Dibble and the Cincinnati Reds agreed yesterday on a one-year contract worth approximately $500,000. (AP)

title: Paramusical Notions That Turn to Dust
description: Some melodies, as the 19th-century music critic John Keats pointed out, are best left unheard. Agreed. I don't mean to put any composers out of work, but many works that promise great things simply do not need to be written. I have in mind not so much the innumerable works of minimal creativity that flood out of publishing houses each year. Those do need to be written, if only to insure that reviewers will not run out of material to deplore. I refer instead to certain stimulating paramusical concepts that excite the composer's imagination but turn to dust when written down and performed.

title: The Youngest Victims of AIDS
description: IN THE ABSENCE OF ANGELS A Hollywood Family's Courageous Story. By Elizabeth Glaser and Laura Palmer. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: 6 Sue Ex-Ruler of Haiti, Charging Torture
description: Six Haitians have charged in a Federal District Court suit here that Prosper Avril, the military ruler of Haiti in the late 1980's, had them tortured as political opponents.

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Dario Mariotti;
A Hotelier Sees Broad Overbuilding, Especially on the Island
description: NOW managing director of the Mayfair Regent, a luxury hotel at Park Avenue and 65th Street in Manhattan, Dario Mariotti has worked for hotels in Italy, Switzerland, Spain and Germany, including the Gritti Palace in Venice and Le Grand in Rome, where he was assistant manager until 1975. Then he helped open the Omni International in Atlanta and later worked at the San Juan and El Convento in Puerto Rico.

title: Sweden's Two Aquatic Cities
description: The young commentator on the Goteborg canal-boat trip looked like a Valkyrie. She sat in the prow of the boat, wearing a bright yellow oilskin, her flaxen hair streaming in the wind, exuding bonhomie and robust good health. "Please be prepared to get a little wet when we reach the open harbor," she announced. "And I shall be warning you to keep your heads down when we go under the low bridges." With good reason -- the lowest of the bridges barely allowed the boat to squeeze beneath and required the passengers to flatten themselves on the seats. I shared the trip with 30 primary school children, as blond and merry as the commentator, all furiously taking notes on clipboards for their class project on Goteborg history. When we got back to base after the hour-long trip, they all piled off the boat and I sat tight. "We are finished," said the Valkyrie, kindly. "I know," I said. "I want to go round again." I haven't done that since sitting the movie through twice as a child.

title: Headliners; Soul Off Ice
description: James Brown, known to two generations of fans as the hardest working man in show business, will shortly be back on the job. The South Carolina state parole board last week granted the soul singer parole after he had served two years of two concurrent six-year sentences on assault and weapons charges. He was arrested in 1988 after he brandished a gun in an Augusta, Ga., insurance office and then led police on a high-speed chase from Georgia to South Carolina. The 57-year-old entertainer, whose energetic performance style inspired Prince and Michael Jackson, among others, said his prison experience and community work he did at the end of his sentence had "really reopened a lot of people's eyes about James Brown and reopened James Brown's eyes about things he has to do for himself as well as other people." And his absence may even have made his fans fonder. He said he expected to release a new album in April and has already booked a spate of concerts. "My career has gone to an all-time high," he said. "I can't believe it."

title: Camera
description: No sooner do I praise Canon's entry-level automatic SLR, the EOS Rebel, than along comes an updated, fancier model. The new EOS Rebel S is part of a gaggle of cameras, lenses and other equipment introduced recently at the Photographic Manufacturers Association meeting and trade show in Las Vegas.

title: Probation Officers Adapt To a Changing Caseload
description: AS the cost of building prisons and holding prisoners rises, the County Probation Department has been under pressure from county officials to provide effective alternatives to jail.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Armed Teen-Agers in Kuwait City Stir Worry as They Take Revenge
description: Nearly a week since Iraqi troops fled, this city remains largely under the control of heavily armed teen-agers who man checkpoints and stop people at random in search of Iraqis and those who collaborated with them. Some resistance fighters say they have killed Iraqi secret policemen.

title: Sunday Outing; Worth $35 to a Wrecker, Boscobel Is Now a Gem
description: On May 21, 1961, when Boscobel, the reconstructed Federal-style home of States and Elizabeth Dyckman, was formally reopened here in Putnam County, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller called it "one of the most beautiful homes ever built in America."

title: Postings: Moving Uptown; Boots and Saddles
description: One of New York City's oldest specialty retailers, H. Kauffman & Sons Saddlery Company, is continuing a long evolution uptown and upscale. The purveyor of saddles, boots, riding crops and other equestrian goods, which opened in 1875 on Division Street on the Lower East Side, plans to leave its current 24th Street location and open a new store by May 1 at 419 Park Avenue South, at the corner of 29th Street.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Captives; Baghdad releases CBS News Crew
description: The Iraqi Government freed the CBS News correspondent Bob Simon and his three-man crew yesterday in Baghdad after holding them captive for 40 days.

title: Stacy E. Rothaus Wed in Tarrytown
description: Stacy Ellen Rothaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rothaus of New York, was married in Tarrytown, N.Y., last evening to Dean Elliot Poritzky, a son of Boris Poritzky of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Rhoda Poritzky of Ossining, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Levy officiated at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill.

title: Paula Jane Grant Wed To David Shelby Berry
description: Paula Jane Grant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Grant of Washington, was married yesterday in Manchester, Vt., to David Shelby Berry, a son of Nancy Michaels Berry of New York and Charles Nelson Berry Jr. of Oklahoma City. W. Russell Savage, a seminarian at King's Episcopal Chapel in Boston, performed the ceremony at the Wilburton Inn.

title: Patriotism on the Sports Front
description: With the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, will the recent patriotic flowering of flags continue, becoming a permanent part of team uniforms, or prove to be strictly a temporary measure?

title: Cellular Phones
description: The rules for deducting the costs of cellular telephones used partly for business and partly for personal calls have been tightened. If they are used 50 percent of the time or less for business, straight-line depreciation must be used, rather than the more favorable accelerated depreciation. (Source: Sidney Kess, tax lawyer)

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has two patios with a "Chattahoochee" stone finish. For eight years, we coated these with a clear sealer, applying it twice a year. I cannot find this sealer in stores anymore, and the patios look awful. Can this type of patio be painted?

title: Loving Pens Reveal Lawmakers' Inner Lives
description: "Do you know that it frightens and unmans me to know that you are sick," the Congressman wrote his wife. "Your health is the continent, the solid land on which I build all my happiness and hope. When you are sick, I am like the inhabitants of countries visited by Earthquake. They lose all faith in the eternal order and fixedness of things. Your sickness is my Earthquake."

title: Guide Books, a Small Investment for Big Returns
description: If the Internal Revenue Code is the Finnegan's Wake of tax law, then the tax-preparation guides now displayed in bookstores are the Monarch Notes. The guides restate the tax law in an understandable way and highlight its main points.

title: Pro Basketball; The Pressure to Win Is Foremost for Checketts
description: Having restructured their front office Friday, the Knicks are clearly headed in a new direction. But does the departure of Al Bianchi and the arrival of David Checketts represent the beginning of a successful era or yet another error?

title: County to Reassess a Plan to Burn Its Sludge
description: ON the eve of a court-ordered deadline last week, the county received informal Federal approval to withhold its proposal for a $67 million sludge-incineration plant in Peekskill. Missing the March 1 deadline subjects the county to heavy fines, but the money is expected to be returned if the next compliance date is met.

title: A Busy Cellist Performs With Three Ensembles
description: ONE of the busier musicians in the county this week is Judith Davidoff: in addition to her usual teaching schedule at Sarah Lawrence College, the cellist is appearing with three different ensembles in five days.

title: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Prune some more! Especially grapevine and overgrown shrubs and small trees. Wait until buds break open to trim rosebushes. Take cuttings from older geraniums, begonias and other favorites so they'll be large enough to transfer to the garden when spring really comes. Try not to walk on the lawn when it's soggy. The footprints you leave will become trouble spots later. Feeding Birds Indoors

title: H. C. Wedgwood, 82; Led China Company
description: Hensleigh Cecil Wedgwood, former president of his family's internationally known Wedgwood china company, died of complications of emphysema on Thursday at RHD Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title:
Your Own Account;
Time to Freshen Up the Mortgage
description: With interest rates moving down sharply and real estate prices severely depressed, March is shaping up to be the best time in more than a decade to take out a mortgage, refinance the one you have or switch to a fixed-rate mortgage from an adjustable one.

title: Bring Some Order to the 'Junk' Chaos
description: Wall Street is littered with the victims of the "junk bond" debacle. In 1990, more than 100 bond issues, involving almost $18 billion, defaulted. And the default rate is likely to go higher in 1991 if the recession continues.

title: Laura S. Pratt Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Pratt of Westport, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Laura Steele Pratt and Paul Gerard Stewart, a son of Mrs. William J. Stewart and the late Mr. Stewart of Boston. Miss Pratt, 31 years old, graduated from Wheaton College. Mr. Stewart, 35, a University of Pennsylvania graduate, is a referee with the National Hockey League.

title: Drug Makers Set Off a Bitter Debate With Ads Aimed Directly at Patients
description: Prescription drug manufacturers, who have long deluged doctors with advertising, are increasingly waging ad campaigns in the newspapers, magazines and television to woo patients directly. These advertisements for consumers have prompted a raging debate and plans for a crackdown by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Fewer Vans Offer Help On Roads
description: ONE morning last June, Peter Hentschel of Stony Creek was on his way to work in Hartford when his car stopped dead on Interstate 91. His mind filled "with visions of tow trucks and engine rebuilds," he recalled. But he was quickly approached by a Samaritan Van driven by a mechanic who was ready to help.

title: Travel Advisory; New Tax (And Refunds) In Canada
description: Visitors to Canada may be surprised to find a new 7 percent Federal tax on all merchandise, services and accommodations. The levy, called the Goods and Services Tax, was implemented on Jan. 1 and replaces Canada's former 13.5 percent tax on manufactured goods.

title: Singer Adds His Cachet to Library
description: FORTY years ago the fans were clamoring for his autograph. Nowadays, he still gets asked to sign his name to a picture. But as the entertainer Julius LaRosa described it recently, "Times have changed."

title: Mommy Weirdest?
description: Tracey Ullman has always shown an empathy for the characters, both sharp and none too bright, she created on her Emmy Award-winning TV show. Now, in a one-woman play, she makes her Broadway debut as one of the strangest Hollywood moms ever: Florence Aadland, whose 15-year-old daughter, Beverly, a would-be starlet, found fame briefly in 1957 when she became the mistress of Errol Flynn two years before the film star's death.

title: Phases of War: Politics; Did Someone Say 'Domestic Policy'?
description: IT was a familiar political tableau: A Republican President confidently striding across the center stage of foreign policy, while a chorus of Democrats stood in the wings, saying, "Yes, but...."

title:
WINE;
Bargains in Australian Chardonnay
description: AUSTRALIAN chardonnays appear to be perfectly positioned to make major inroads into the county market for premiere French and California wines.

title: The Multicultural Dictionary
description: To the Editor:

title:
FILM;
Is Every Blast From the Past A Classic?
description: The Museum of Broadcasting's series "James Dean: The Television Work" ended yesterday, but the fact that the programs are part of the permanent collection should be greeted with cheers by those inclined to revel without a cause.

title: Meryl Zimberg Marries
description: Meryl Lynn Zimberg and Clifford Alan Katz, lawyers in New York, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Maurice Simcha. The bride and her husband are 27 years old and each received law degrees from Yeshiva University in 1988. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon L. Zimberg of Merrick, L.I., graduated from George Washington University and is an associate in the firm of McDonough Marcus Cohn & Tretter. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving D. Katz of Montgomery, N.Y., graduated from Clark University and is an associate in the firm of Platzner Finegold & Swergold.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: INCREDIBLE JUMBO By Barbara Smucker. 177 pp. New York: Viking. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Travel Advisory; Jazz Notes
description: Wynton Marsalis (trumpet), Tito Puente (percussion) and Gato Barbieri (saxophone) and the singer Nancy Wilson are among artists who will perform at the first Cancun Jazz Festival to be held in Cancun, Mexico, May 20 to 27. They will take part in stage performances. Other musicians will play at nightly jazz jamborees in the resort's hotels. Information about the festival and package tours consisting of air fare, hotel accommodations and concert tickets can be obtained by calling 800-766-5566.

title: Links to Noriega Bought Freedom For an Informer
description: Ramon A. Navarro, a main prosecution witness in the case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, led a precarious double life as a Colombian cocaine dealer and Government informer who bartered his contacts in the drug underworld for a life of freedom in the United States.

title:
ART;
Paintings That Reveal Alchemy of Creation
description: LIKE a judge in a court of law, a critic must make up his mind in the light of the evidence and reverse himself if necessary. In fact, to change one's long-held opinion for the better is one of the most salutary experiences an art writer can have. Such a shift took place recently for this writer with the paintings of Walter Darby Bannard in his exhibition, "Recent Work, 1987-1990," at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: Emily Jahncke to Wed George Davis in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barton Williams Benedict Jahncke of New Orleans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Andry Jahncke, to George Marc Davis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Geoffrey Davis of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: MUM'S THE WORD
description: I do not know Austen Ettinger and would hope he is not a candidate for any unnecessary physical ailments. I do know that many of my clients have recovered from numerous physical ailments once they have dared to be more open and honest in their dealings with others. Research in the field of depression and other forms of mental illness all verify these findings.

title: Style Makers; Amy Lowenthal, Specialty Baker
description: Growing up in White Plains, Amy Lowenthal used her allowance to buy fancy meats and spices while her friends were spending their money on records. By the time she was a teen-ager she had a reputation as a cook for special occasions.

title: Seeing the Boys of Summer in Spring
description: ASK anyone who's been and they'll probably say that spring training isn't what it used to be. Veterans wistfully recall when nearly all of Florida's Grapefruit League baseball stadiums were barely more than fields of dreams transplanted to the tropics. But spring training for the uninitiated still promises an intimacy and informality that seem preferable to the rank commercialism, crude crowds and impersonal arenas of the regular season. Not to mention the sacrifice of weekday afternoon games to the exigencies of television. No other sport celebrates its annual prefatory phase to this degree; none has the good sense to begin the preliminaries in spring, when a new season heralds renewal and when fans from the North desperately need it.

title: Business Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: When War Came the Peace Corps Left, Sadly
description: Seven weeks ago, John Teeple was a Peace Corps volunteer in Tiflet, Morocco, helping rural women run a beekeeping cooperative.

title: Social Events
description: Party for Central Park

title: World Markets; Thai Stocks: Unharmed by a Coup
description: The stock market in Thailand is rumbling along, barely jolted by the military coup a week ago that deposed the first directly elected Prime Minister since 1976. Many analysts also seem unfazed by the bloodless takeover and still see Thailand as one of the most attractive markets in Asia, even though it has already rallied 25.5 percent this year.

title: Man Held in Forest Hills Sex Attacks
description: A 25-year-old Manhattan man was charged last night in a series of six sex attacks and robberies that had cast a pall of fear over Forest Hills, Queens, since September.

title: DECIPHERING THE M.L.A.
description: Grammar may be out at the M.L.A., but your article amply shows that its members make constant use of that fourth major tense of English, pretense. CHARLES OTTINGER Imlaystown, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Stanford; 2 AIDS Victims Leave $200,000 For Gay Students
description: A gay couple in San Francisco, both of whom died of AIDS, have established a $200,000 scholarship fund for homosexual students here and at the University of California at Berkeley and San Francisco State University.

title: A Spider Web in Lights; Some Dress to Match
description: A spider web of white lights decorated the Waldorf-Astoria's grand ballroom for the Jewish Museum's Purim dinner-dance Thursday. The party benefited the new wing on Fifth Avenue.

title: College Basketball; Fordham Advances In Final Second
description: When the 45th and final minute of the inaugural Patriot League championship game was about to expire and the Fordham and Holy Cross seasons were about to be defined, the Rams suddenly saw something that they had seen twice before.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TRAVELING LADIES By Janice Kulyk Keefer. Morrow, $19.95.

title: Camping Out in Baja's Remotest Reaches
description: THERE ARE 11 OF US IN sleeping bags strewn along the beach in the starlight. It is long past midnight. The belt of Orion has barely risen, over the left above the torn outline of mountains. From the constellations one would be able to tell that we are not many degrees north of the Tropic of Cancer, but even at sea level the night is very cold, and gusts of wind from the north, at our backs, keep the coarse desert sand hissing around and onto the sleeping bags. When the wind drops, the long waves that are no more than an inch or so high as they break can be heard shushing the tide line a dozen yards from our feet.

title: South to the Salento
description: If the Salento has been a closed book to all but a little stream of dedicated travelers, it is probably because of its remoteness from the romantic dream that fastens on Venice, Florence, Rome and Naples. Or it may be due to its description as the "heel" of Italy. A peninsula unexplored by Norman Douglas conjures up the image of a cultural wilderness and its early occupation by obscure Messapians and Salentines, the latter possibly of Cretan origin. The southernmost part of Apulia, the Salento has always been exposed, invaded, settled by people from across the sea. Even today you can perceive in the population traces of Arab, Turkish, African, Greek, Spanish and Catalan influences, expressed in manner, stance and physiognomy and confirmed by the foreign words that crop up in its many dialects.

title: The Fine Art of Coping With Taxes
description: Gregory Russell, a Manhattan artist who works in a youth program through the day so he can paint through the night, is attacking the conflict between finding time to paint and earning enough to pay the rent, by taking a close look at his taxes.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Fragile Web of Memories Our recollections of those we love, Alain Robbe-Grillet writes, are composed largely not of dramatic events but of shared pleasures and quiet moments. This passage on his mother is in "Ghosts in the Mirror" (Grove Weidenfeld).

title: Scraping By, Illegally, Mining Kentucky Coal
description: This part of southeastern Kentucky is so poor with so few ways to make an honest living, that many people do not even try. The last time state officials counted they found that fewer than half the adults in Knox County were working.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has two patios with a "Chattahoochee" stone finish. For eight years, we coated these with a clear sealer, applying it twice a year. I cannot find this sealer in stores anymore, and the patios look awful. Can this type of patio be painted?

title: Campus Life: Georgetown; Club Endorsing 'Abortion Debate' Wins Approval
description: Georgetown University, the oldest Roman Catholic university in the United States, has approved the establishment of the first club calling itself "pro-choice" on campus. John J. DeGioia, the dean of student affairs, said approval came after club organizers agreed to change their statement of purpose from one that advocates a woman's right to an abortion to one that promotes debate about the abortion issue.

title: Tibetan Buddhism Is Adapting to American Life
description: IN a recent ritual at Rashi Gempil Ling, a Tibetan Buddhist temple here, five monks seated on a platform in the center chanted in a vibratory monotone. Periodic cymbal clashes or the knock of wooden clappers punctuated the drone. Geshe Tharchin, the lama who led the chant, was presented with a white silk scarf, a traditional Tibetan gesture of honor.

title:
DINING OUT;
Extensive Korean Menu in Ardsley
description: MOOL Lae Bang Ah, or Water Wheel, is the second Korean restaurant to settle in the county, and very welcome it is. The restaurant features both Korean and Japanese cuisine; but in these visits we concentrated on the Korean dishes listed on the extensive menu. Newcomers to this cuisine shouldn't be shy. First of all, the menu, written in both Korean and English, provides diners with descriptions of every dish. And second, with its Mongolian-Chinese influence, Korean food is familiar. Bite-sized meats or fish mingle with finely sliced or shredded vegetables and rice. Ginger, soy sauce, scallions and garlic season most dishes. What makes the difference, however, are the fillips of searing chilies -- sometimes added directly to a dish, sometimes mixed into a paste that can be applied to taste -- and the side dishes of briny kimchee (pickled Chinese cabbage) that appear at every meal. The range of tastes is broad, from mild and soothing to incendiary. Be sure to state your preference every time, as the kitchen's hand isn't consistent in dealing out peppery heat.

title: In 'Buses,' Odd Couple's Common Cause
description: "I DON'T feel much like walking," says a weary Rosa Parks, as she waits for the bus that will assure her place in history. But the time isn't 1955, the place isn't Montgomery, Ala., and Mary Ellen Pleasant is waiting right alongside the woman who has been termed "the mother of the modern civil rights movement."

title: Children's Fashion; BRIGHT IDEAS
description: Designers of children's clothes may follow the trends of grown-up fashion, but they give their work a childlike quality. As with adult clothes, color is everywhere: big, bold and extravagant. Prints especially are witty: dots and stripes; psychedelic fish; stylized flowers, and astral prints. One pattern is juxtaposed with another. Graffiti, an old favorite, has been cleaned up and made fanciful.

title: For Home Theaters, Sound Proves to Be the Big Picture
description: A private projection room was once the privilege of movie moguls -- the ultimate status symbol. Today, home theaters are being installed by the thousands. They have become a major trend in video, proving that luxury still thrives, even during these hard times.

title: Managing; Giving the Environment Teeth
description: Last summer, the International Business Machines Corporation took a giant step backward -- on purpose.

title: Diane Sue Morey to Wed in September
description: September wedding plans for Diane Sue Morey and Saul Jonathan Charles Hoppenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Hoppenstein of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have been announced by her mother, Pat Morey of New York. Miss Morey is also a daughter of the late Robert Morey.

title:
The Executive Life;
Don't Use the B-Word; No Gorillas Need Apply
description: Time-Warner chairman Steven Ross has them. Ronald Perelman, chief executive of Revlon Inc., does too. So do Henry Kissinger and, of course, Donald Trump.

title: Minority Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bane of Medical Second-Guessing
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: NoHo
description: WHEN looking for NoHo, be prepared for a lot of blank stares.

title: Youngsters Take Over a Food Drive
description: EVERYONE knows that Girl Scouts sell cookies. But the Girl Scouts of Westchester-Putnum, branching into another project involving things edible, will also conduct a major food drive this spring.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 3, 1991

A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 3 5 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $6.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
The Battle to Preserve a Dobbs Ferry Dig
description: A GROUP of Dobbs Ferry residents is trying to save an archeological dig on the 44-acre site of a town-house condominium project that itself could become an abandoned artifact.

title: Catharine Deely To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James S. Deely of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Catharine Burton Deely and Patrick Michael Stansfield, a son of James E. Stansfield of Uclid, Ohio, and the late Jane Ann Stansfield.

title: Topics of the Times; It's All in Your Mind
description: A story in The Times a few days ago described a group of cheerleading grandmothers from Sun City Arizona who call themselves the Sun City Poms. With obvious awe, the report said that the ladies, whose average age is 73, perform back flips, cartwheels and flips and that among them is one Pom who does it all with two new hip joints.

title: Chess
description: Nigel Short had to wait three years to get revenge for his 1 1/2-3 1/2 loss to his British countryman Jonathan Speelman in their first world championship candidates match, but now he has got it. He has won their match in the current cycle by a victory and a draw in a two-game playoff after tying the new regulation eight-games series at 4-4. The ultimate winner of the candidates elimination contests will meet Gary Kasparov in the title match in 1993.

title: Ellen M. Di Domenico to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Di Domenico of Allenhurst, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Marie Di Domenico to Dr. George C. Peck Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. George C. Peck of Essex Fells, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Chats With a Dead Lover
description: SWEET EYES By Jonis Agee. 405 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $18.95.

title: Marcia Voorhis, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. M. Baird Voorhis of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcia Ellen Voorhis to William John Andrew, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Andrew of Winnetka, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

title: Old-Fashioned Charm, Bounteous Platters
description: IT is too bad Gail's Station House Restaurant and Bakery can't clone itself over and over again. In addition to a spot next to the train station in West Redding, Gail's has added a Ridgefield location inside a former grocery store. But this kind of cozy and comfortable hangout should be in every Connecticut town. The high walls are decorated with old hats and framed pages from old children's books. Then there is the tin ceiling, the natural wood floors, inlaid wood tables and mismatched chairs. The nostalgic feeling that Gail's evokes makes it especially cheerful and inviting at breakfast on weekdays and even more so on Sundays.

title: Rap Group's Name No Enigma
description: THE cheers that erupted when the Young Black Teen-Agers were introduced at a concert in London turned to jeers when the rap group walked onto the stage.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Military Planning; U.S. Plans a Bigger Presence in Gulf
description: The United States wants to maintain a much larger military presence in the Persian Gulf region than it had before Iraq invaded Kuwait to deter attacks on American allies there, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Researchers Test New Technology To Monitor Traffic
description: A research team in the civil engineering department at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst is developing a project that could bring new technology to motorists and alleviate traffic jams on the state's highways.

title: Brown Lost a Chance to Air Free Speech Issue; For Open Hearings
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bigger Carnegie Hill Historic District?
description: ANTHONY WOOD doesn't live where the East 90's slope toward Fifth Avenue and Central Park, but he walks those streets whenever he can.

title: Nancy McKessy Plans To Marry T. O. Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. McKessy of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ann McKessy to Thomas O. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Owen Miller of Titusville, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Trisha Brown: Simplicity Within Complexity
description: During "Foray Foret," the new work that the Trisha Brown Dance Company will present at its opening on Tuesday at the City Center, a marching band is scheduled to play outside the theater as well as in other locations invisible to the public.

title: A La Carte: Comradeship
description: TWENTY-TWO years ago, Michael Brodsky and Andrei Fedorov worked for the Soviet Government. Mr. Brodsky was with a construction agency, and Mr. Fedorov was a waiter in a state-owned restaurant in Moscow.

title: 'Green Card' Apes 'Pretty Woman'
description: "Green Card" was not conceived as "Daughter of 'Pretty Woman,' " though it seems that way now. Look at Gerard Depardieu holding Andie MacDowell over his shoulder in the posters and newspaper ads for "Green Card," Touchstone Pictures' current romantic comedy about a straitlaced woman and a free-spirited man. Then look at Richard Gere holding Julia Roberts in a strangely similar photograph for "Pretty Woman," Touchstone Pictures' romantic comedy about a free-spirited woman and a straitlaced man. You're not seeing double, and it's no mistake: both ads were created by the same in-house department at Touchstone, which has tried to hitch "Green Card" to the wild success of "Pretty Woman," the third highest-grossing film of last year.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BURN MARKS, by Sara Paretsky. (Dell, $4.95.) After her crazy Aunt Elena is burned out of her fleabag hotel, the Chicago private eye Vic Warshawski is dragged into a case involving real estate developers and the Cook County political machine. "The 'whydunit' in Ms. Paretsky's books is often embedded in the fabric of problems that confront us all," Elaine Budd said here last year. "This extra dimension adds an immediacy to 'Burn Marks' that is not found in many private-eye novels."

title: Unrest in Iraq Reported to Spread From Basra to Three Other Cities
description: Official Iranian and Syrian reports and the accounts of travelers from Iraq today reinforced Western intelligence assessments that civil commotion and possible anti-Government unrest in Iraq had spread from the southern city of Basra to a string of other towns in southeastern Iraq.

title: Political Memo; Quayle Seems Outside The Glow of Victory
description: By all rights, Dan Quayle should be enjoying a little boost right now.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rockets 104, Lakers 95: Kenny Smith scored 15 of his 34 points in the third quarter and added 10 more during a fourth-period rally yesterday as Houston beat Los Angeles and snapped a 14-game losing streak at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif. Vlade Divac scored 23 points and James Worthy added 21 for the Lakers. The Lakers lost for only the fifth time in 28 games, the second time in 18 games at home and slipped two and a half games behind Portland in the Pacific Division race. (AP) Pistons 107, Clippers 98: Joe Dumars scored 14 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter as Detroit ended its longest losing streak in five years with the victory in Auburn Hills, Mich. The Pistons had lost five straight, their worst streak since losing six in a row from Dec. 21, 1985 to Jan. 3, 1986. Spurs 107, Bullets 85: David Robinson scored 12 of his game-high 26 points in the third quarter and handed the Bullets, playing at home in Landover, Md., their sixth consecutive loss. Bernard King scored 19 points for the Bullets, who suffered their 12th loss in 14 games. (AP) Jazz 95, 76ers 92: In Philadelphia, Karl Malone scored 35 points and Thurl Bailey led a late run that carried the Jazz to a victory over Philadelphia. The loss snapped the 76ers' seven-game winning streak. Trailing by 89-86, Utah outscored the 76ers, 9-3, culminating with a Bailey dunk with 5.9 seconds left. Bailey had 6 points in the surge and a season-high 20 points. (AP) Hawks 115, Bucks 106: Dominique Wilkins scored 25 points and grabbed 11 rebounds as Atlanta beat the Bucks in Milwaukee. Atlanta made 26 of 29 free throws to hold off the Bucks. (AP) TENNIS Lendl Upset in Rotterdam: Unseeded Omar Camporese of Italy scored a major upset yesterday, beating top-seeded Ivan Lendl, 3-6, 7-6, 7-6, to win the ABN Amro World tournament in Rotterdam. Camporese ranked 42d in the world, came back from a sluggish start to defeat the third-ranked Lendl. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Jamaican Breaks Mark: Merlene Ottey of Jamaica broke the 4-year-old world 200 meters indoor record at a meet in Sindelfingen, Germany. Ottey clocked 22.24 seconds to shave three-hundredths of a second off the previous best set by Heike Drechsler in Indianapolis in March 1987. (Reuters) Big Day for Christie: Linford Christie of Britain won the 60-meter dash over Andre Cason of the United States and led a British relay team to a world indoor record yesterday in Glasgow. Christie started the seldom-run 800-meter relay team on its way to an indoor record time of 1 minute 22.11 seconds, breaking the mark of 1:22.32 set in 1984 by Italy. Earlier, he ran the 60 meters in 6.55, edging Cason, the runner-up, who clocked 6.59. (AP)

title: Vermont Development Laws May Have Saved Its Banks
description: Vermont is the only New England state that has not had a bank failure in the current economic downturn, and its strict environmental laws -- not shrewd Yankee banking -- are widely credited with saving the state from the worst excesses of the Northeast's real estate boom.

title: New Bench for Staying in Step
description: A new fitness bench has been designed for aerobics students who want a smaller unit for step workouts at home or for traveling. The portable bench weighs nearly half as much as those commonly used for exercise classes and is about one-third as long.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Terror; International Teamwork May Have Foiled Terror
description: A "staggering" global security effort and the reluctant cooperation of other terrorist sponsors in the region probably succeeded in averting spectacular acts of terrorism by Middle Eastern groups during the Persian Gulf war, Government intelligence officials say.

title: Review/Pop; Operatic Bureaucracy
description: Lenny Pickett made his reputation as the saxophonist in the Tower of Power horn section, pumping out crisp, precise riffs. Now, working in the "Saturday Night Live" pit band and as a composer and arranger in groups including the Borneo Horns, he still builds pieces out of short, staccato phrases, letting the horns propel the band -- oom-pahs below, clipped syncopations above.

title: New Tension Over Trade With China
description: As China's trade surplus with the United States rises sharply, diplomats and business executives say relations between the two countries could worsen because of China's import restrictions, software piracy and other issues.

title: 3 Networks Retrench After War
description: Despite their satisfaction with the coverage of the Persian Gulf war, the three broadcast networks face serious economic consequences from the war's costs, and one or more news divisions may be compelled to cut budgets and staff.

title: Foes of Trump Compromise On His 'City'
description: Donald J. Trump has agreed to shrink his long-stalled plans for a huge development on the Upper West Side nearly in half and to give New York City land to reroute the West Side Highway to allow for a waterfront park -- if the Dinkins administration backs the compromise Mr. Trump reached with civic groups that had fought the project.

title: T. E. Sunderland; Businessman, 83; Ran United Fruit
description: Thomas E. Sunderland, a lawyer and business leader who helped lead the United Fruit Company out of a slump in the 1960's, died on Friday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 83 years old.

title: Bid for Metcalf Shares
description: The Air and Water Technologies Corporation, an environmental treatment services company, said on Friday that it planned to make an exchange offer for the 18 percent of the Metcalf & Eddy Companies that it did not already own. The offer provides for the exchange of 0.85 share of Air and Water common stock for each Metcalf & Eddy common share. The stock of Metcalf & Eddy, which treats water and manages waste, jumped $2.75 on Friday, to $18.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Bridge
description: At a tournament nearly 60 years ago two young lawyers, both from Philadelphia, were in conversation. One was B. Jay Becker, already an established star, but the other was unknown to fame. He showed Becker a brilliant play that he himself had failed to see in the session of play just completed, and Becker was impressed by the analysis.

title: Lower Oil Prices Thwart U.S. Energy Goal
description: The next few months are beginning to look like a very difficult time to form a national policy for becoming less dependent on imported oil.

title: Review/Theater; A 'Mockingbird' Translated to the Stage
description: With its stalwart lawyer-hero Atticus Finch, who prods the conscience of a Depression-era town in Alabama, Harper Lee's 1960 novel, "To Kill a Mockingbird," still stands as a reassuring, stately expression of American idealism in the early days of the civil rights movement.

title: Tourney's Name Is Entrant's Name
description: JOHNNY PETRAGLIA could win the $150,000 Johnny Petraglia Open this week in New Brunswick, N.J. Say what? The first Professional Bowlers Association tournament to be held in New Jersey since 1977 is named after a bowler who is still alive. Petraglia has worked at Carolier Lanes, the tournament site, for 20 years and the organizers honored him with the rare distinction.

title: Outdoors: City Dwellers Seek Refuge
description: CITY dwellers who enjoy the outdoors and want fresh air and solitude in an area free of boom boxes, bikes, volleyball players, joggers, picnickers and even smokers, might well consider a trip to their nearest urban nature preserve. For New Yorkers, that hidden respite from social mayhem is the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, which straddles the Queens-Brooklyn line on the South Shore of Long Island.

title: A Rallying Dinard Wins Photo Finish
description: Dinard rallied from a six-length deficit at the stretch for a photo-finish victory against Apollo this afternoon in the $159,400 San Rafael Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: Trail Blazers Find Intensity in Boston
description: With 8 minutes 49 seconds remaining in the first quarter this afternoon, Brian Shaw, the Boston Celtics' playmaker, stepped on Terry Porter's foot and fell while driving to the basket. Shaw had to be helped off the Boston Garden court, and was sidelined for the remainder of the game against the Portland Trail Blazers with a sprained right ankle.

title: Oliver North: Overprotected?
description: Must Government forgo the prosecution of high public officials whenever Congress demands their public testimony? The answer would almost certainly be yes under the legal rules laid down last year by the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington in the Oliver North case.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Generals' Statements; Statements by U.S. and Saudi Commanders
description: Following are transcripts of statements today by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf of the United States, the allied commander, and Lieut Gen. Khalid bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia, the commander of Arab forces, after talks with Iraqi military officers on a permanent cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war: SCHWARZKOPF STATEMENT

title: It's Back to Basics For Today's Skiers Who Lost Knack
description: SOMEWHERE a bunch of things every good skier used to know how to do and took for granted disappeared. These days, it's not surprising to see skiers sliding downhill as they try to climb uphill or rocketing off a bump in the middle of a trail or struggling as they push themselves to a lift at the bottom of a mountain.

title: Using Iraqi Reparations to Build the Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Army in Uganda Accused of Slaying Civilians
description: On the sides of the road leading into this eastern Uganda town stretches of scrubby land lie fallow. Mud huts are empty. Soldiers' checkpoints lend clues that all is not safe.

title: Meyer F. Wiles, Engineer, 83
description: Meyer F. Wiles, an engineer and lawyer who was acting commissioner of public works in New York City in the 1960's, died on Friday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y. He died of heart disease, said his daughter, Judith Cohen.

title: Norris Cashing In On His New Fame
description: NOBODY knew much about Terry Norris before he beat Sugar Ray Leonard to retain his World Boxing Council superwelterweight title last month. Now a lot of people know him. The bank that cashes his checks knows him well.

title: Networks, Motherhood and Careers
description: When Meredith Vieira told her boss at "60 Minutes" that she was pregnant with her second child and would not work full time next year, she hoped that Don Hewitt, the program's executive producer, would say, "O.K., we'll work that out."

title: Cheapest Heart Attack Drug Found to Be Safest
description: In the first direct comparison of the drugs used to dissolve blood clots when a patient is having a heart attack, researchers have found that all three are equally effective in saving lives but that the oldest and cheapest is the safest.

title: Ismail Shows Speed Off the Football Field
description: The Rocket, already a star on the football field, isn't doing too badly in track and field, either.

title: Defying Recession With Exports
description: In an aging brown-brick factory here, hunched over tool-littered workbenches, men and women are coaxing tiny wires into circuit boards as they put together the computer controls that are the brains of machine tools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Last March the career of GLORIA ESTEFAN, the Cuban-born pop singer, seemed in grave danger after she suffered a broken back when her bus was rear-ended on a snowy Pennsylvania highway. But Friday, Ms. Estefan made a triumphant concert return before a soldout, hometown audience in Miami. The concert began a 41-city, 53-day world tour that wraps up in New York City in September.

title: Intel Loses Suit On Trademark
description: A Federal judge ruled Friday that the Intel Corporation was not entitled to trademark protection on the name of the 386 microprocessor, the company's most important product and one of the most valuable franchises in the industry.

title: Teen-Agers Are Found After 6 Hours in Drain
description: Floodwaters swept two teen-agers a mile and a half through a storm drainage system under the Atlanta airport on Friday night, but firefighters were able to rescue them after a frantic six-hour search.

title: Review/Ice Skating; Athleticism Leavened With Artistry
description: Brian Boitano, so pure of style that his technical perfection becomes expressive in itself, and Katarina Witt, whose power is put at the service of a a natural glamour, stand to be the big pop stars of international skating.

title: When Jackson Pollock Was a Scrubber
description: To the Editor:

title: Strikers at Greyhound Feel Forgotten
description: On the first anniversary of the walkout at Greyhound Lines, striking drivers say they believe they have been forgotten by the labor movement and by the people who ride the buses.

title: Julian Wells Wed To Jill Klapholz
description: Jill Sharon Klapholz and Julian Weliczker Wells were married yesterday at the Marriott Hotel in Uniondale, L.I., by Rabbi Frederic Pomerantz and Cantor Shlomo Bar-Nissim.

title: Serge Gainsbourg, 62, Singer and Composer
description: Serge Gainsbourg, the singer and songwriter known for his image of unshaven decadence and his songs full of provocative, sometimes tender lyrics, died late Saturday at his home here, officials said. He was 62 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Colorado Jet Crash Kills 25 A United Airlines 737 jet crashed nose-first into a neighborhood park near the airport in Colorado Springs yesterday, killing all 20 passengers and five crew members. Page A14.

title: Metro Matters; Trying to Give Equal Justice To Jailed Women
description: Karen Ely, a 43-year-old former teacher from Albany, entered the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester in 1983. She is serving a term of from 25 years to life, which means she won't even be eligible for parole until the year 2007.

title: Don't Skimp on Treatment for Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Latvia and Estonia Vote for Sovereignty
description: Voters in Latvia and Estonia heightened their challenge to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday, voting overwhelmingly for independence in the two republics.

title: The Fires of Patriotism And Cold Necessity Put 13 in Harm's Way
description: Sorrow rushes over the hills and swoops into the valleys across western Pennsylvania like a bitter wind these days because soon the funerals will start.

title: Meadow Star Wins Races and Hearts
description: TO the stable people tending her at Barn 15 at Gulfstream Park, she is "little sister." To the groom pampering her in Stall 16, she is "BooBoo." To the clockers, trainers, jockeys and other insiders in the world of thoroughbred racing, she is "the filly."

title: AFTER THE WAR: The West Bank; Palestinians Still Revere Hussein As Their Savior
description: As most of the world watched the Iraqi Army stumble in defeat, Palestinians continue to cling stubbornly to a different image of Saddam Hussein than the one being projected almost everywhere else.

title: Brazil May Abandon Nuclear Sub Program
description: Brazil may abandon its program to build a nuclear-powered submarine if the United States opposes it, Foreign Minister Jose Francisco Rezek said in an interview published today.

title: Salt Lake City Forgot Ban on Arena Seating
description: After three teen-agers were trampled to death at a rock concert here on Jan. 18, members of the City Council demanded an ordinance to ban seatless gatherings on the Salt Palace arena floor.

title: Sweet One For Orange
description: Five days before the Georgetown Hoyas appeared on the floor of the Carrier Dome at noon today, the Orangemen of Syracuse University secured a fifth regular-season Big East Conference championship, but their very first untouched by Hoya hands, or anyone else's.

title: Fate of The News Is Up to British Publisher
description: The final fate of New York's swashbuckling tabloid, The Daily News, now seems to rest in the hands of a British publisher, Robert Maxwell, who has never left any doubts about who is the boss at any newspaper he owns.

title: Gulf Veterans To Be Honored In May Parade
description: The men and women who endured the roar of battle and the swirling sandstorms of the Persian Gulf war will return to the cheers of thousands and the cascading ticker tape of a parade through the Canyon of Heroes, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday.

title: CBS Joins NBC in Dropping Audience-Gauging System
description: Following the lead of NBC, CBS said Friday that it would abandon an audience-measurement system that was extremely unpopular with advertisers.

title: Site Selection For G.M. Car
description: The General Motors Corporation is close to announcing that its Impact electric car will be assembled in low volume at a plant in Lansing, Mich., an automotive industry newsletter has reported.

title: Tender Begins For Square D
description: Groupe Schneider S.A., a French electronics company, yesterday furthered its takeover bid for the Square D Company by beginning a tender offer for all the shares outstanding of the maker of electronic switches and controls.

title: Military Has No Use For Sexist Language
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The "Cheers" actor WOODY HARRELSON, who lost his place as a Mardi Gras grand marshal after being spotted supporting an anti-war rally, received a new invitation to New Orleans this weekend.

title: No Regrets, No Respect, No Comment
description: DURING a recruiting visit by Rick Pitino to a New Jersey high school basketball game last Wednesday, a fan pleaded with Kentucky's coach to return to the Knicks. "No thanks," Pitino said. "I've got one more game and then I'm through for the season." Less than 48 hours later, Pitino's former nemesis, Al Bianchi, was through for the season when the Knicks dismissed him. . . . The Nets' coach, Bill Fitch, is tired of listening to ESPN's hyper announcer, Dick Vitale. "The last time Vitale said anything that made sense was when the doctor slapped him in the behind," Fitch said. . . . Eva Macon left the driving to them and took a 20-hour bus ride from Saginaw, Mich., to Philadelphia on Friday to watch her son, Mark, play in his final home game for Temple. It would have been the first time she had seen him play in person for the Owls. Talk about bad luck. Macon, who had started 120 consecutive games until injuring his ankle two weeks ago, did not play. His mother returned home having never seen her son play a college game. . . . Johnny Unitas, the Hall of Fame quarterback who recently filed for bankruptcy with $3.5 million in debts, is now charging to be interviewed. When a reporter phoned him at his office last week, his secretary said he was out of town. "But," she said, "he told me to tell you that if you want an interview, it will cost you." When asked how much, the secretary giggled and said, "Oh, $50,000. You don't pay. He won't talk."

title: Question Box
description: N.B.A. Playoff Marks

title: Sister Papers Become Direct Rivals in Philadelphia
description: Philadelphians are awakening this morning to an old-fashioned newspaper war with a novel twist.

title: Panel Says B-1 Cannot Cope With Ice and Radar
description: A House panel raised questions today about the ability of the Air Force's B-1 bomber to fly missions carrying either nuclear or conventional weapons because it lacks a system to jam enemy radar.

title: At His Swearing-In, New Head of Rutgers Seeks Campus Unity
description: The 18th president of Rutgers University was sworn in today, promising that the quality of education there would not be hurt by big budget cuts to come if students, faculty members and adminstrators work together.

title: Devils' Loss Angers Coach
description: The penalty killers of the Boston Bruins are the National Hockey League's best when they play at home and 19th when they play away. At Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, with help from the Devils, they played as if the game were happening at Boston Garden.

title: U.S. Balks at Easing Export Curbs
description: Fearful of the political and economic tension in the Soviet Union and arms proliferation in the third world, the Bush Administration has begun taking a harder line on how to restrict exports of technology with military applications.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Atlanta, is offering $50 million in floating-rate notes due on March 11, 1992, at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The interest will be adjusted weekly at 50 basis points more than the three-month Treasury bill. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: Clemens Works on New Pitch (Maturity)
description: Roger speaks.

title: Big Developments Stalled in New York's Real-Estate Slump
description: At Columbus Circle, where the gigantic Columbus Center complex was supposed to be, there is a modern "Hooverville" outside the vacant New York Coliseum, an encampment of homeless people in crudely built shelters who warm themselves at night over fires in open drums.

title: Stenrich to Develop Campaign for WNET
description: WNET, Channel 13, the New York public television station, has recruited Stenrich Group Inc., a direct- marketing firm from Virginia, to develop an advertising campaign to attract and retain members.

title: Clark R. Mollenhoff, Pulitzer Winner, Dies at 69
description: Clark R. Mollenhoff, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter, author and syndicated Washington columnist who served briefly as a special counsel to President Richard M. Nixon, died Saturday at Stonewall Jackson Hospital in Lexington, Va. He was 69 years old and lived in Lexington.

title: Top McEnroe Is Still John
description: John found no particular joy in beating his younger brother Patrick in the battle of the McEnroes here this afternoon in the final of the Volvo Indoor tournament. "I have incredibly mixed emotions right now," John McEnroe said after winning, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4. "Every emotion you can imagine was there: from worrying to how he's doing, to worrying that he might beat you."

title: DIALOGUE: The Gulf War's Aftermath Is the Vietnam Syndrome Dead?; No, Hussein Was One of a Kind
description: All right, so the peaceniks were wrong about one thing. There will be no tens of thousands of body bags coming home and thus no popular reaction of revulsion and horror against the Persian Gulf war. President Bush's popularity ratings are off the charts and even the most hawkish of "pro-sanctions" Democrats are running for cover, musing about 1996. Politically and militarily, Operation Desert Storm is a rout.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraqi Performance
description: The allies have found none of the vast stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons that senior commanders of coalition countries expected Iraq to use in battle.

title: When News Is A Crime
description: One of Secretary of State Baker's aims in the Middle East is, in his words, "to find a way for Israel and Palestinians to begin a dialogue." If anyone thinks that will be easy, here is a story to dispel the illusion.

title: Critic's Notebook; Broadcasters in the Gulf And What They Merit
description: With victory in the Persian Gulf come thoughts of medals. Nominations for the Gulfie Awards having been opened in these pages by William Safire, herewith a few candidates who, by design or happenstance, have lightened the hours of at least one constant viewer of the war on television. All deserve a little statue of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who is a shoo-in for New Face of 1991.

title: CHINESE WHO FLED DROPPED BY PARTY
description: The Chinese Communist Party expelled a senior official today after he had taken refuge in the United States, the official New China News Agency said.

title: Robert Moses Did Much to Assist Water Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: 150 SOMALIS DROWN FLEEING TO KENYA
description: The bodies of more than 150 Somali refugees who drowned fleeing their war-racked country on a rickety, overcrowded dhow were lowered today into a mass grave carved out of the sand at this Indian Ocean resort town.

title: New U.S. Hint on Hussein
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d hinted today that Iraq might be accorded a lighter reparations bill for rebuilding Kuwait if President Saddam Hussein were overthrown.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Thursday the Government plans to auction one-year bills.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council POPULATION COMMISSION -- 10 A.M. POPULATION COMMISSION, PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR 1994 INTERNATIONAL MEETING ON POPULATION -- 3 P.M.

title: DePaul Keeps Hopes Alive
description: This is the time of year in college basketball when victories are rarely assessed on their merit but on the impact they have on the people who decide which 64 teams will be invited to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday New-Home Sales...Jan. New-Home Prices...Jan. Tuesday Factory Orders...Jan. Wednesday Productivity...4th Qtr. Thursday None Friday Employment...Feb.

title: Grey Awarded Dannon Yogurt
description: The Dannon Company, the yogurt manufacturer based in White Plains, has awarded its $10 million advertising account to Grey Advertising Inc., New York.

title: Texas Jolts Arkansas
description: Benford Williams scored 22 points and Joey Wright and Locksley Collie each added 19 today as the Texas Longhorns upset Arkansas, 99-86, in the Razorbacks' last regular-season game as a Southwest Conference team.

title: More Black Lawyers Needed for Judgeships
description: To the Editor:

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: CITY CELEBRATIONS New York City plans a ticker-tape parade, an ecumenical religious service and a fireworks display for returning veterans. Page B1.

title: Cable TV Gives And Takes Away
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Alison Lowy has been named a vice president at Waring & LaRosa Inc., New York. * Robin Koval has been named an executive vice president of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson Inc., New York.

title: Cyanide in a Drug Kills 2 and Forces A National Recall
description: The maker of the popular cold remedy Sudafed announced a nationwide recall of its 12-hour decongestant capsules today after Federal officials said they believed two people had died and a third had become ill from taking cyanide-laced capsules.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait City; Nagging Question Lies Beneath Kuwait's Rejoicing: When Is the Emir Coming Home?
description: Jubilant Kuwaitis continued celebrating the end of fighting in their capital today, but many people were also asking why the Emir of Kuwait has not returned home six days after the first allied troops entered the city.

title: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; U.N. Compromise Plan To Widen Relief to Iraq
description: The United Nations Security Council pledged tonight to exempt more food and humanitarian aid from its trade embargo against Iraq and speed authorization for delivering the supplies to needy people there.

title: Reparations, Without Retribution
description: Now comes the reckoning. There is no way that Iraq can restore lives smashed by Saddam Hussein's war. But rudimentary justice requires that Iraq pay financial reparations for its savage occupation and vindictive scorching of Kuwait.

title: Girl, 14, Is Killed in Drug Gunfire
description: A 14-year-old Bronx girl was killed yesterday morning by a bullet intended for an 18-year-old gunned down half a block away in a shooting the police said was related to drugs.

title: Duke Captures A.C.C. Title
description: Standard strategy after seizing a large second-half lead on the road calls for a college basketball team to use each possession to run as much time as possible off the clock. This afternoon, in a battle to determine the first-place finisher in the Atlantic Coast Conference and an opening-round bye in the conference tournament, that approach almost backfired for tired, foul-plagued Duke.

title: Riyadh to Jerusalem
description: The conflict to stop Saddam Hussein from becoming a nuclear power spawned a peculiarly indefinite farewell among Israelis: "Meet me 6 o'clock after the war."

title: Cambridge Journal; Among the Green Quads, New Dreams of Equality
description: For centuries this venerable university has been a citadel of academic prowess and social privilege, one of those nearly timeless institutions that like the monarchy and the Bank of England define the soul of Britain.

title: Warriors Settle On a Nickname
description: SINCE Tim Hardaway, Mitch Richmond and Chris Mullin of Golden State score more points a game than any other threesome in the National Basketball Association, they needed a flashy moniker. From over 1,500 fan entries, the winning choice was RUN-T.M.C. Some that were not selected included Three Bucketeers, Joint Chiefs of Stats, Pointer Brothers, Totally Tubular Trio, Bloodthirsty Gym Rats from Hell and Barrage a Trois.

title: Tracing a Devious Path to the Ivy League
description: Across the Ivy League in the spring of 1988, bleary-eyed deans poring over the usual stack of superlative-filled recommendations and stratospheric S.A.T. scores were intrigued by one application -- the one from the boy who said he had taught himself everything he needed to know while working as a ranch hand and sleeping under the starry Utah sky next to his horse, Good Enough.

title: Review/Music; A Wind Quintet in Harmony
description: The players in the Virtuosi Quintet perform as soloists and as members of larger ensembles, but since 1983 they have been banding together to explore the wind quintet repertory. On Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, the group played one of the repertory's centerpieces, Anton Reicha's Quintet (Op. 91, No. 3), as well as a few novelties of variable interest.

title: Another Twist to the Knicks' Season
description: Less than two weeks ago, the Knicks looked like a team in chaos. Today they are a team with confidence.

title: Battle Over Rights Bills Emphasizes Sexual Bias
description: With its heavy focus on women, this year's fight over civil rights legislation already has a tone different from last year's conflict or most previous confrontations.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Cease-Fire Meeting; A Hard-Faced Schwarzkopf Sets Terms at Desert Meeting
description: The Iraqi general wore an unsettling grin at the negotiating table, as if he thought that some simple misunderstanding had turned into war quite by accident and might now be ended with a few calm words of understanding.

title: New Jersey Pilot, a Woman, Dies in Crash in Gulf
description: A woman Army helicopter pilot who grew up in Oradell, N.J., and was featured in national news reports last week as she ferried cargo into battle against Iraq was killed in a noncombat helicopter crash on Friday, the day after the cease-fire, military officials said yesterday.

title: Dividend Meetings
