description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 3, 1991: MONDAY Albertsons Inc Metropolitan Finl Corp Aluminum Co Amer Merco Inc Cincinnati Bell Inc TUESDAY Harnischfeger Inds Inc Southwest Gas Corp Premark Intl Inc WEDNESDAY Browning-Ferris Inds Starrett LS Co Handleman Co USF&G Corp Helmerich & Payne Inc Van Dorn Co Stanhome Inc THURSDAY Brown Group Inc Times Mirror Co Englehard Corp WalMart Stores Inc Humana Inc Wolverine World Wide Inc Sierra Pac Res FRIDAY Berry Pete Co

title: In U.S. Technology, a Gap Between Arms and VCR's
description: From the opening salvos of Tomahawk cruise missiles to the final desert tank battles, the performance of high-technology weapons in the Persian Gulf war led to rejoicing over Yankee ingenuity and the quality of American technology.

title: Lebanese President Warns P.L.O. to Halt Rocket Attacks on Israel
description: President Elias Hrawi warned Palestinian guerrillas this weekend that they would no longer be allowed to mount attacks on Israel from Lebanese territory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Lazzeri Meets Alexander Again
description: THERE were things Tony Lazzeri, who was recently and unexpectedly named to the Baseball Hall of Fame after having been dead for 45 years, never, or rarely, talked about when he was a star for the Yankees in the 1920's and 1930's. Those were the glory years when he was the important second baseman and clutch hitter on great pennant-winning teams with Ruth and Gehrig and Meusel and Jumpin' Joe Dugan and Waite Hoyt and Red Ruffing.

title: No Headline
description: After the War A8-12

title: AFTER THE WAR: Egypt; Egypt's Leader Says Postwar Security Is Up to Arabs Alone
description: President Hosni Mubarak said today that only Arab nations should provide for security to preserve peace in the Persian Gulf region.

title: Challenge Yourself As a Racing Test
description: HOW can runners determine if they are prepared to meet racing goals in competition? One way is to race against yourself.

title: Return to Jail Brings a Lesson
description: JOE HAMMOND, a New York City schoolyard basketball star, has a court date on April 2. Back in jail again, Hammond will leave the defense to his attorney.

title: California Readies for Political Brawl Over Both of Its Senate Seats in 1992
description: California politics is erupting into a full-scale, $70 million brawl with more than a dozen contenders maneuvering for two of the state's top political prizes: the United States Senate seats, which will both be open next year. Democrats and Republicans both have reason to hope for a sweep, making the election a potential bonanza as the parties push for dominance in the Senate.

title: Facing Satiric Thrusts, Dinkins Parries
description: Facing an audience of his most persistent observers, chroniclers and critics, Mayor David N. Dinkins proved Saturday night what he has long insisted: He cannot carry a tune in a bucket. But he could and did shed his self-control long enough to poke sharper fun at himself than the City Hall reporters who spoofed him.

title: Crotona Journal; In Priest's Crime War, It's Crucifixes for Guns
description: Vampires are one of the few evils that don't lurk in the dank hallways and vacant lots of the South Bronx. So why does the Rev. John Flynn venture into the night clutching a tiny gold crucifix?

title: Yanks Hope Sanderson Has Good Start
description: Even with all their woeful offensive problems last season, the Yankees began their winter by continuing their never-ending search for pitching.

title: Review/Opera; The Classic Tragedy of 'Elektra' Retold in Words and in Music
description: Carnegie Hall's dual presentation yesterday afternoon of "Elektra" the play by Hugo von Hofmannsthal and "Elektra" the opera by Richard Strauss was a grand occasion, perhaps too grand for the opera.

title: High-Powered Marketing Gives 'Jolson' a Comeback
description: ROGER J. STONE is a fearsome Republican political consultant and tenacious lobbyist whose clients have included Presidents Nixon, Reagan and Bush, as well as Bethlehem Steel, the Trump Organization and T.W.A. But electing Presidents and beguiling bureaucrats pale next to Mr. Stone's latest challenge: Marketing Al Jolson to a youth-obsessed American public.

title: Using Iraqi Reparations to Build the Peace; Restoring Kuwait City
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Friday misidentified Sheldon B. Rabinowitz's employer and its corporate parent. It is Hanna-Barbera Productions Inc., a unit of the Great American Communications Company.

title: Arthur Murray, Dance Teacher, Dies at 95
description: Arthur Murray, the immigrant baker's son who danced his way to fame and fortune as the world's best-known teacher of ballroom dancing, died yesterday at his home in Honolulu. He was 95 years old and had also had another house in Rye, N.Y., for many years.

title: Odelia Luwisch Is Wed in Israel
description: Odelia Luwisch, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Moshe Luwisch of Beersheba, Israel, was married yesterday in Rehovot, Israel, to Yaacov Francus, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Francus of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Laromme Palace by Rabbi Aharon Lichtenstein and the bridegroom's father, who is the Lieberman Professor of Talmudic Exegesis at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: Attitude on Bonds Seems Bearish
description: Some credit market analysts say the recent selloff in the bond market, which has pushed yields to the highest level since mid-January, seems to be a clear manifestation of bearish sentiment overcoming the continued signs of economic weakness that should be bullish for the fixed-income market.

title: Howard Head, 76; Designed Metal Skis And a Tennis Racket
description: Howard Head, the inventor of the Head metal ski and the Prince tennis racket, died yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 76 years old and lived in Baltimore and Vail, Colo.

title: AFTER THE WAR: National Mood; War Heals Wounds at Home, but Not All
description: On the battlefield and at home, it was a victory of stunning decisiveness, like a thunderbolt that had the potential to obliterate the two decades of doubt and drift that began with Vietnam.

title: Scaling Everest, Hold the Oxygen
description: DO you know what you're doing May 11? Gary Scott does. Unless you're an experienced, daring mountain climber, you don't want to be sharing food bars and performance drinks with this guy that Saturday.

title: Utilities Given a Warning
description: A coalition of state energy officials and environmentalists has warned electric companies around the country that if they do not immediately start to plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the coalition will oppose some future rate increases.

title: DIALOGUE: The Gulf War's Aftermath  Is the Vietnam Syndrom Dead?; Happily, It's Buried In the Gulf
description: Not everyone is happy with the outcome of the war. One need not impugn their patriotism or suggest they were rooting for Iraq to say that many unreconstructed liberals regret the disappearance of the Vietnam syndrome -- a reluctance to engage in any overseas military operations and to provide the wherewithal to do so.

title: Fire at Army Base Injures 9
description: Brush fires were ignited by spent ammunition Saturday during field training at an Army post and injured nine members of the Louisiana National Guard. The blazes were fanned by high winds before being extinguished Saturday night, Fort Hood officials said. A base spokeswoman, Eloise Lundgren, said said the fires were started "by routine training that the Louisiana National Guard was doing there."

title: David Bergner, Lawyer, 88
description: David Bergner, a lawyer who had been active in civic affairs, died on Tuesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Delay at Doral-Ryder
description: Lightning and heavy rain caused the suspension of the final round at the Doral-Ryder Open today. Play will be resumed at 9 A.M. Monday morning with the co-leaders, Andy Bean and Russ Cochran, having nine holes to play.

title: Chief Executive Quits at Emery
description: The chief executive of Emery Worldwide and members of his management team have unexpectedly resigned from the money-losing air-freight concern.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I would say very candidly that the Iraqis came to discuss and to cooperate, with a very positive attitude. " -- Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. [ A1:6. ]

title: Life Salvaged, Now Savored: Living Longer With AIDS
description: In the last year, William H. Brevoort studied French, went to Europe twice and celebrated his only grandchild's first birthday. He savored every moment as if it were his last. Mr. Brevoort has had AIDS for more than three years, a time in which at least 20 of his friends have died of the disease, and health statistics dictate that he, too, should probably be dead.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dallas County officials are deciding whether to allow OLIVER STONE, the director, to film portions of the drama "JFK" inside the former Texas School Book Depository. Shooting on the film, which will explore the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy, is scheduled to start next month.

title: Beth Levine Wed To W. G. Squier
description: Beth Susan Levine, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Levine of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to William Georg Squier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Squier of New Lebanon, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony.

title: Canada Economic Drop
description: Canada's gross domestic product fell by 1 percent in the fourth quarter, the Government has announced. It was the third consecutive quarterly drop in the measure. The economy shrank by two-tenths of a percent in the second quarter and three-tenths of a percent in the third quarter.

title: A Landmark Under Renovation Wears Its Own Face as a Mask
description: Even those who already consider Paris something of a stage set are doing a double take in front of the Church of the Madeleine these days. While being cleaned and repaired, the building has been covered by a huge canvas painted to depict the very facade that is hidden.

title: The News Offers to Sell For No Money Up Front
description: Were Robert Maxwell -- or anyone else, for that matter -- to buy The Daily News, he would not pay a penny up front for the paper, according to a person familiar with the sale terms set by the owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago. Instead the real price of The News is said to be a purchaser who is willing to assume some of its long-term liabilities.

title: Coleman Gets Set To Go for the Mets
description: If speed was God's gift to Vince Coleman, it was one that took a while to be unwrapped.

title: Rangers Face Major Choices
description: As his second season as a hockey executive comes to an end, Neil Smith of the Rangers finds himself entering what may be the most pivotal two days of his front-office career.

title: Serb-Croat Showdown in One Village Square
description: The main square of this small Croatian town with a large Serbian population, was, at least for today, the epicenter of Yugoslavia's tensions.

title: 4 Slain in Northern Ireland
description: Gunmen burst into a bar and shot four people to death tonight in the village of Cappagh, about 50 miles west of Belfast, the police said. The bar is frequented by Catholics and the gunmen are believed to be members of a Protestant paramilitary group, the news agency Press Association reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a program to allow some residents of Hong Kong to move to Britain misstated the legal status they would have. The program offers residency and work rights, not citizenship.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Palestinians; With Iraqis Gone, Kuwaitis Turn Wrath on Palestinians
description: Tanks rolled through Kuwait City's Palestinian neighborhoods today as edgy Kuwaiti Army soldiers blocked off entire areas to make house-to-house searches for weapons and people who collaborated with the Iraqis.

title: Review/Met Opera; Czechoslovak Conducts 'Rosenkavalier'
description: The reason some cast-change evenings at the Metropolitan Opera work out reasonably well and others don't work at all might be worth some serious thought by an enterprising musical journalist. Then again, maybe it wouldn't. Perhaps the deciding factors have less to do with as yet unanalyzed chemical processes than with the quality of ingredients at hand. Said another way, some artists, parachuted into productions for which they are not fully prepared, do have talents peculiar to that kind of situation.

title: BBDO Resigns L.A. Gear, Citing Creative Differences
description: WHEN BBDO/Los Angeles abruptly resigned the $60 million L.A. Gear account on Friday after only a little more than two months on the job, many industry executives were not surprised.

title: U.S. Slump Hurts Japan Car Sales
description: The recession in the United States and an unusual burst of frugality among Japanese consumers -- is finally beginning to hurt Japan's largest car makers, forcing them to cut production and rethink plans for constant expansion in North America.

title: Schools Are Not Families
description: What America expects of its public schools these days is nothing less than miracles. Never mind that the children who show up for their first day of kindergarten may have lived their five years in chaos. Give them a good teacher, a decent classroom and an introduction to the alphabet, the reasoning goes, and those children should be on their way out of poverty and into productivity. Not true. It will take a lot more than a strengthened school system, desirable though that may be.

title: Sales Rise for Authors Who Perish and Publish
description: After 12 weeks on the paperback best-seller list, including six weeks as No. 1, V. C. Andrews's "Dawn" is a huge success. "It's nearing three million copies in print," said Jack Romanos, the president of Simon & Schuster's mass-market division. "And it is selling better than any of her other books."

title:
Market Place;
California Utilities In Merger Limbo
description: THE long-proposed merger of two California electric companies into the nation's largest investor-owned utility is in question.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about stock trading on Tuesday referred incorrectly to a price trend. Nine times since 1970, advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded declining stocks, not vice versa, by a ratio of at least 2 to 1 for 10 days in a row.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; U.S. SAYS IRAQI GENERALS AGREE TO DEMANDS 'ON ALL MATTERS'; EARLY P.O.W. RELEASE EXPECTED
description: Iraqi military leaders accepted stringent allied terms today for formally ending the Persian Gulf war, including the prompt return of all prisoners and Kuwaiti civilian detainees, the American commander reported after a two-hour meeting.

title: Forest Hills Rape Arrest Eases Fears
description: Two officers, patrolling in a police car on a quiet residential street in Forest Hills on Friday night, arrested a man they thought fit the description of the person wanted in five sexual attacks and a robbery that had frightened people in the Queens neighborhood since last September.

title: A Region in Mourning
description: Eleven men and two women. Black and white. Laborers and college students. The 13 Army reservists were killed last Monday in one of the final missile attacks of the gulf war.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press in some editions of Business Day on Thursday about the auctioning of broadcast channels referred incorrectly to a recommendation by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, a Commerce Department agency. The agency's plan would affect only new licenses for commercial radio frequencies assigned only to such enterprises as cellular telephones and two- way radios. The agency made no recommendation about frequencies assigned to AM and FM radio or to television.

title: Review/Dance; Morningside Potpourri
description: The second program of the 1991 Morningside Dance Festival opened last week with a bouncy and reflective dance about young love, "Inside the Country," choreographed by Bryan Koulman to songs by Patsy Cline. In "Habitat," performed to music by Michael Bushnell, Mimi Garrard gave the bonelessly resilient Ginger Gillespie a chance to travel about the stage in small, floor-rooted eruptions. And Andrew Jannetti examined angst in "Signed, Sealed, Delivered," a duet for the choreographer, dressed in a suit, and Lauren Naslund that was set to a score by Scott Killian of breathing and other minimal sounds.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up Slightly
description: Stocks in Tokyo were slightly higher today in light trading. Brokers said the market was treading water, uncertain about the prospects for United States economic recovery and interest-rate cuts.

title: Jetliner Crash in Colorado Kills All 25 People Aboard
description: A United Airlines 737 jet bound for the airport here crashed nose first into a neighborhood park this morning, killing all 25 people aboard.

title: Review/Theater; Tracey Ullman by Herself in 'The Big Love'
description: "For the first time in my life, I was absolutely speechless," says Florence Aadland, the Hollywood mother played by Tracey Ullman in "The Big Love," as she recalls her 15-year-old daughter's fateful night of violent sex with Errol Flynn in 1957. If "The Big Love" is any indication, the first time Florence Aadland was speechless was also the last. In this one-woman play that has washed ashore on Broadway at the Plymouth Theater, Ms. Ullmann natters on for two hours, a not inconsiderable proportion of which is devoted to joking descriptions of rape. She refers to the penis by two different affectionate nicknames in the first half-hour alone. '

title: Books of The Times; Reality Was Relative and the Relatives Were Nuts
description: Unstrung Heroes By Franz Lidz Illustrated. 194 pages. Random House. $18.95.

title: Griffey Sr. Hurt in Crash
description: The Seattle Mariners outfielder Ken Griffey Sr. was hurt in a car accident and will be sidelined indefinitely with neck and lower-back injuries, team officials said today.

title: Joseph C. Dey Jr., Administrator and Arbiter of Golf, Dead at 83
description: Joseph C. Dey Jr., generally regarded as the most influential administrator in the history of golf, died yesterday at this home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: Devils Dismiss Cunniff and Bring Back McVie
description: The New Jersey Devils, underachieving with a talented team, today replaced Coach John Cunniff with Tom McVie, the general manager and coach of their top minor league team.

title: Mediate, Long Putter Win on Tour For First Time
description: Rocco Mediate became the first player to win a regular PGA Tour event using a long putter when he beat Curtis Strange today on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff at the Doral-Ryder Open.

title: New Chanel Men's Scent Gets Provocative Campaign
description: WATCH out, Calvin Klein.

title: Campeau Units Report Losses
description: The Campeau Corporation's two department store subsidiaries -- the Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores -- today reported losses in January and said they expected the slow economy would continue to hurt results in the near term.

title: New Study Challenges 'Biodegradable' Claims
description: A NEW study appears to support what environmentalists have contended for some time: that so-called biodegradable plastic products, from disposable diapers to garbage bags, do not disintegrate into their natural elements as their manufacturers say.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about the United Nations Security Council meeting on ending the Persian Gulf war misidentified the man at the right. He was Virenda Dayal, the Secretary General's chief of cabinet.

title: JERUSALEM ARABS SUE OVER A HOUSE
description: A Palestinian family has filed suit against a Jewish seminary in the Old City's Muslim quarter over rights to a house that stood empty for 22 years until Israelis moved in over the weekend.

title: William A. Gardner, Internist, 88
description: Dr. William Alden Gardner, an internist in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chairman of Keye/Donna Quits to Join New Agency
description: The Keye/Donna/Pearlstein advertising agency, a former highflier that has been spiraling downward for some time, has quietly fractured.

title: May This Be the Year of Arab-Israeli Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaragua Devalues Money To Stem Economic Collapse
description: Trying to satisfy Nicaragua's international creditors without setting off another round of violent strikes by Sandinista labor unions, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro began a new economic stabilization program today based on a major devaluation of the currency.

title: Court Ends Tower Plan At St. Bart's
description: The long battle over the future of an office tower next to St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on the East Side of Manhattan ended today when the Supreme Court refused to hear the church's constitutional challenge to the designation of the church complex as a landmark.

title: Review/Jazz; Mark Murphy Improvises By Rules Strictly His Own
description: Few jazz singers are as fiercely iconoclastic as Mark Murphy, who opened a two-week engagement at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street in Manhattan) last Tuesday evening. An eccentric stylist influenced equally by be-bop, the vocalese tradition of James Moody and the poetry of Jack Kerouac, the 59-year-old Mr. Murphy has invented his own rules for improvisations that often incorporate slurred jazz speech-song and husky scat singing.

title: Chess
description: It was either cliffhangers or slaughters in the seven world championship candidates' matches. In Riga, the Soviet Latvian Republic, the Soviet grandmaster Vasily Ivanchuk blasted his countryman Leonid Yudasin off the board by 4 1/2- 1/2. In Madras, India, the Indian grandmaster Viswanathan Anand crushed the Soviet grandmaster Alexey Dreyev by 4 1/2-1 1/2. In Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman felled the German grandmaster Robert Huebner by 4 1/2-2 1/2.

title: Biologists Re-engineer Antibodies
description: ADVANCES in molecular biology are breathing new life into research on monoclonal antibodies, genetically engineered copies of the immune system's front-line defenses.

title: Europe in Talks On Farm Trade
description: Agriculture ministers of the European Community opened negotiations today on a proposal to cut or freeze prices to farmers for their products. Farm groups have already opposed the plan.

title: Salt-Water Crop
description: Scientists have developed a seed-producing crop that thrives in sandy soils irrigated with salt water. The crop, derived from a wild halophyte, Salicornia bigelovii, yields seeds rich in high-quality oil and protein. It could become a valuable agricultural crop in subtropical coastal deserts.

title: Our Towns; Smile! The Photo And a $50 Fine Are in the Mail
description: Don't you just hate it when you're in a real big metropolitan hurry and you pull into the little mall's parking lot and there's not one single space left -- except in the zone for the handicapped? Just sitting there. Empty. Going to waste. Crying out to passing motorists, "Take me. I'm yours."

title: Accounts
description: * DuCair Tsumura Inc. to Sherwood & Schneider Advertising, a New York agency, for its Pierre Cardin and Santa Fe fragrances. Billings were not disclosed. * Intershoe Inc., a shoe manufacturer, to Graf Bertel Dominique, New York. Billings have not been determined.

title: Contractor Chosen for West Side Highway
description: The New York State Transportation Department awarded a $62.6 million contract yesterday to reconstruct a stretch of the West Side Highway.

title: Washington Talk; And Now, a Commission on S.& L.'s
description: Hundreds of articles, scores of scholarly papers and more than a dozen full-length books have been written in the last two years alone on the causes of the savings and loan mess.

title: Printers: Choices In Quality And Cost
description: Most of the excitement in the printer industry these days is found in the non-impact or page printer category, which includes laser and ink-jet printers. The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a high-speed laser printer at the Seybold electronic publishing conference that began here today, and Apple Computer Inc. was said to be privately showing new printer technologies that will be introduced later this month for the Macintosh family.

title: General Gives His Last Briefing for Reporters
description: After briefing the press and millions of Americans on the progress of wars in Panama and the Persian Gulf, Lieut. Gen. Thomas William Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, announced at the Pentagon today that he was making his last appearance before television cameras and reporters.

title: Fibreboard in Pact With Chubb Unit
description: The Fibreboard Corporation signed an agreement settling all personal injury and property damage litigation pending with the Pacific Indemnity Company, a subsidiary of the Chubb Corporation. Fibreboard said that under the settlement, which is subject to court approval in California, it would receive $35 million in cash to be used to pay asbestos-related personal injury claims against it. Pacific Indemnity would also be required to pay $107 million into a trust that would be available to pay future asbestos-related costs.

title: Expanded AIDS Notification Project Urged
description: New York City is "morally obligated" to expand its program of voluntary notification of partners of people with AIDS, a panel appointed by Health Commissioner Woodrow A. Myers Jr. said yesterday.

title: In Latvia, Even Many Russians Vote Independence
description: The Baltic republics were ebullient today after new plebiscite demonstrations of the popular will to be free of the Soviet Union, a will that included significant support from people of the Russian minority, who had been heavily lobbied by the Kremlin to stand by the union.

title: German Approval For Pactel Venture
description: The Pactel Corporation, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, said the German Goverment had issued a letter of intent accepting the plan submitted by Mannesmann Mobilfunk to provide cellular service to the former East Germany. Pactel owns 26 percent of Mannesmann Mobilfunk.

title: Howard Head, 76; Designed Metal Skis And a Tennis Racket
description: Howard Head, the inventor of the Head metal ski and the Prince tennis racket, died on Sunday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 76 years old and lived in Baltimore and Vail, Colo.

title: Assisting Kuwait Work
description: The Commerce Department announced today that it had set up an office to assist and advise American companies seeking contracts being awarded in the Persian Gulf.

title: Clues Hard to Find in Colorado Air Crash
description: Federal investigators, beginning their inquiry into a jetliner crash that killed 25 people here on Sunday, said today that the plane had plunged so forcefully into the ground that it might be harder than usual to find out what happened.

title: Market Place; USX Stock Plan: Not Far Enough?
description: THE decision in January by the USX Corporation to issue new common stock linked to its steel business elated many investors who had long hoped that the energy and steel giant would cast its lot with the oil industry alone.

title: New-Home Sales Lowest Since 1982
description: New-home sales plunged in January to their lowest level in eight and a half years, the Government said today, but analysts, saying buyers had become more active in recent weeks, forecast a modest improvement this year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Analysts Announced
description: Three National Football League quarterbacks, Boomer Esiason, Dan Marino and Warren Moon, will get a chance to be on the other side of the camera this spring. They are among the analysts who will work World League of American Football games for the USA Network.

title: Whalers Trade Francis For Cullen of Penguins
description: The Hartford Whalers, looking to add some scoring punch as the playoffs approach, traded Ron Francis, their leading scorer, and Ulf Samuelsson to Pittsburgh last night for John Cullen, fifth in the league in scoring, and Zarley Zalapski.

title: Key Rates
W. C. Liedtke, 66, A Pennzoil Founder And Friend of Bush
description: William C. Liedtke Jr., who co-founded the Pennzoil Company and helped turn it into one of the nation's largest oil companies, died of cancer on Friday. He was 66 years old.

title: Review/Music; Juilliard Students Sing Mozart Songs
description: It's easy, perhaps too easy, to be cynical about Lincoln Center's 19-month Mozart bicentennial extravaganza. True, it serves partly as an excuse to crowd programs with unthreatening music for a midcult audience. True, too, a lot of the Mozart exotica that no one else can be cajoled into performing has been dumped onto students at the Juilliard School.

title: Harrelson to Consider Alternative Lineups
description: Bud Harrelson, having met with instant resistance to his initial plans for the Mets' batting order, said today that he would be open to different ideas, especially if it became apparent that unhappiness among the players was going to affect the productivity of the team.

title: Leyland, Bonds Dispute
description: Barry Bonds's unhappiness over his contract boiled over today into an obscenity-laced shouting match on the field with Jim Leyland, the Pittsburgh Pirates' manager, who told Bonds, "If you don't want to be here, get the hell out of here."

title: May This Be the Year of Arab-Israeli Peace; No P.L.O. Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough Choice for New York: Pay Debt Cost or Halt Repairs
description: Prices of Manhattan apartments may be soft and the city's bridges may be crumbling, but in one category, at least, New York remains on top: It piles on more long-term debt in most years than any borrower other than the United States Government.

title: Trenton Officials Reach Pact To Alter Florio School Plan
description: The leaders of the State Legislature announced tonight that they had reached agreement to alter significantly Gov. Jim Florio's school-aid program, in a plan that would shift $360 million into relief for property taxpayers.

title: After Iraqis Free 10, the Elation Spreads Quickly
description: At 4:30 this morning, long before the sun rose and disappeared behind rain clouds here, Calvin Zaun was up and running, knocking on neighbors' doors and shouting for all the world to hear: "Jeff is out! Jeff is out! Jeff is out!"

title: At Home Among the Enemy, Kuwaitis Learned to Survive
description: When Iraqi troops overran Kuwait last August, the generally prosperous and easygoing citizens of this rich Persian Gulf emirate had their lives thrown into turmoil. Many suddenly faced choices of resistance, collaboration or something in between.

title: Public Library Bureaucracy Grows as Branches Cut Back Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "There were many people who were ashamed of their Indian past, so they hid it. But a lot of people who went the assimilationist route have come back. And the tribes have been enjoying a renaissance." -- Russell Thornton, a sociologist who is a Cherokee. [ A1:3. ]

title: Price of Prudence
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Breaking Out of a Minimalistic Style, Just a Little
description: Subtraction By Mary Robison 216 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. For readers familiar with Mary Robison's fiction, the title of her latest novel, "Subtraction," might initially seem like the perfect label for her work as a whole: it's evocative of her minimalistic style, her characters' emotionally attenuated lives. In her last two volumes of short stories, the reader became increasingly aware of the limitations of this less-is-more esthetic. Her characters' alienation and willful passivity seemed more and more like a self-indulgent pose, the grudging, deadpan prose, an indication of the author's own inability or unwillingness to connect.

title: Reviews/Theater; Street Smarts Round Out An Ivy-League Education
description: Book learning doesn't stand a chance against worldly wisdom in Dolores Prida's new play, "Botanica," which, under the direction of Manuel Martin Jr., has been added to the current roster of works being presented by Repertorio Espanol at the Gramercy Arts Theater. But Ms. Prida seems to have a bottomless fund of humor that keeps the contest alive even when the outcome is clear.

title: The Stealth Bill
description: When government officials aren't terribly proud of what they're doing, they often resort to the Friday afternoon press release, hoping that the media will be otherwise occupied, along with sources reporters might consult for comment. That's the route the Justice Department followed when, at sundown last Friday, it released its 1991 civil rights legislation; afterward, officials who could discuss the bill were hard to find.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: BASKETBALL: N. B.A. Notebook; Johnson Is Closing In On a Notable Number
description: On April 5, 1984, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, in his 15th season in the National Basketball Association, scored for the Los Angeles Lakers on a soft, left-handed 12-foot hook shot with 8 minutes 53 seconds remaining in a game against the Utah Jazz in Las Vegas, Nev. With that basket, he surpassed the 31,419 points it took Wilt Chamberlain 14 seasons to accumulate, breaking a record some thought would last forever.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD PUNITIVE DAMAGES IN AWARDS BY JURY
description: The Supreme Court rejected a constitutional attack on punitive damages today, leaving juries with the broad discretion over damage awards that they have exercised since the earliest days of the American legal system.

title: The Soviets Ratify a Treaty On Uniting the 2 Germanys
description: The Soviet Parliament ratified a six-nation treaty today putting the legal seal on German unification and formally ending the Allied rights in Germany that stemmed from postwar occupation.

title: Torn by a War, United by a Call
description: Miriam Ali Hasan sobbed and laughed into the telephone receiver, pulling her black veil close, her hands trembling.

title: Review/Jazz; Holmes Trio Adds Power To Standards
description: Thursday night's show at Condon's started out with Richard (Groove) Holmes and his trio rolling down the road, a juggernaut powered by a Hammond B3 organ. The organ has extremely specific cultural and chronological associations, and Mr. Holmes, who knows his way around its deep-fried phrase lexicon, isn't afraid to show its power. In his hands it becomes an engulfing, screaming instrument, no different today from what it was in the 1960's, its heyday as the star of jazz's last gasp as a popular music.

title: Miscellany
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc. has created a separate entertainment division to be based in its Los Angeles office. Richard Taylor will serve as president and chief executive.

title: U.N. Relief Agency Declares Israelis Beat Two of Its Staff
description: The United Nations relief agency for Palestinians said today that Israeli soldiers in the occupied Gaza Strip had beaten two members of its staff in the second such attack in 10 days.

title: Unit Was Mobilized And Treated Badly, Ex-Commander Says
description: The former commander of the Georgia National Guard's 48th Infantry Brigade said today that his unit was mobilized for the Persian Gulf war for political reasons, then was unjustly criticized by Congress and the regular Army.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Clothes for Fall Soothe Rather Than Shock
description: The neat nosegays, rather than elaborate flowering plants, that accompanied invitations to the fall and winter ready-to-wear shows here this week were a sign of the times: Ostentation is out. Extravagant nightly entertainment is a thing of the past, and the clothes, designed under the shadow of war, are more soothing than shocking. Hemlines are coming down, albeit gradually, a sobering fact in itself.

title: Business and Health; Reshaping Laws On Insurance
description: HEALTH insurers are rushing to formulate their own plans for making coverage available to small businesses and individuals. The insurers hope to shape new laws being drafted that will crack down on practices like the blacklisting of certain occupations, red-lining of neighborhoods and price gouging.

title: Fans Mourn Loss of an Interracial Soap Opera
description: Washed out by low ratings, television's first interracial soap opera devoted to the adventures and misadventures of black and white families, "Generations," has left behind a group of disappointed viewers, many of them black professionals, still yearning to tune in tomorrow.

title: Jordanian King Is Said to Express Interest in New Talks With Israel
description: King Hussein of Jordan has recently expressed interest in reviving efforts to negotiate peace with Israel and a solution to the Palestinian problem, possibly along the lines of a 1987 agreement secretly worked out in London with a former Israeli Foreign Minister, a senior Israeli official says.

title: Owens Atop Big East
description: Billy Owens, who led Syracuse to its first outright Big East title, was named yesterday as the conference player of the year. Owens, a 6-foot-9-inch junior forward from Carlisle, Pa., averaged 23.5 points and 11.4 rebounds a game.

title: Cyanide Poisonings Prompt Warning on Complacency
description: People who buy over-the-counter medications may have been lulled into complacency about tampering by packaging changes in the last five years, Federal officials said today as they confirmed that new incidents of cyanide poisoning had left two people dead and one seriously injured.

title: India's Interim Budget Will Reduce Subsidies
description: The minority Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar presented an interim budget today with no new taxes but sharp cuts in fertilizer, food and export subsidies and increases in military spending.

title: Article 352791 -- No Title
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States yesterday announced a $203.5 million drop in its 1990 year-end surplus as a result of lower investment income.

title: Two Foes of Hussein Say Opposition Is Weak
description: Two Iraqi opposition leaders said today that while the Government of President Saddam Hussein had never been weaker, the many Iraqi forces opposed to it, ranging from Muslim fundamentalists to Communists, were also weak as well as divided and had received very little support from the United States and its Arab allies.

title: St. Peter's Beats Iona To Earn N.C.A.A. Bid
description: When the buzzer sounded tonight, the St. Peter's players gathered at center court, danced a little, surrounded Coach Ted Fiore in a group hug, and then danced a little more. The Peacocks had just won their first Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship, but more important, they had earned their first trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sketches, etchings and doodles by pop stars were auctioned last weekend to benefit the AIDS Task Force in Philadelphia. Often, their images were of each other.

title: Moscow Journal; Millionaire's Bad Fortune: Why Is K.G.B. Calling?
description: Artyom Tarasov says he remembers when it was fun to be a millionaire in Moscow.

title: INSIDE
description: Delight in Baltic Region The Baltic republics were ebullient after votes showed the popular will to leave the Soviet Union. Page A3. Hopes on Ending Apartheid The United Democratic Front, a South African anti-apartheid coalition, said progress toward its goal was allowing it to disband. Page A3.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The New York Mets and the United Way of New York City have teamed up to raise money for programs that help homeless youth. VINCE COLEMAN , the team's new center fielder, will act as spokesman.

title: T. E. Sunderland, Businessman, 83; Ran United Fruit
description: Thomas E. Sunderland, a lawyer and business leader who helped lead the United Fruit Company out of a slump in the 1960's, died on Friday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 83 years old.

title: Saudis Are Said to Plan 'Thank You' Promotion
description: Saudi Arabia is expected to begin a $20 million campaign at the end of this month to thank the American people for their help in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Review/Dance; A Mingling of Idioms In 'Lila' at the Joffrey
description: The Joffrey Ballet's premieres this season come from a variety of newcomers or experimental choreographers. "Lila," by Alonzo King, is certainly not your usual approach to mixing the ballet and modern-dance idioms, and its prime interest lies in this area.

title: European Study Finds Few Babies Get AIDS
description: A LONG-TERM European study has found that relatively few pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus passed the virus on to their children.

title: Milken Enters Jail; Shorter Term Is Sought
description: Michael R. Milken entered prison late Sunday to begin serving a 10-year sentence for six crimes involving securities transactions, and yesterday his lawyers filed court papers seeking a reduction of his term.

title: Stiffer Penalties Are Proposed In Crimes Involving Violence
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Bush Administration would propose a mandatory five-year prison term for possession of a gun after a single conviction for a violent crime or a drug offense.

title: Air New Zealand
description: Air New Zealand has ordered five planes from the Boeing Company and has options on others in a deal worth $450 million. The airline will buy four Boeing 767-300 aircraft and one Boeing 747-400 for delivery between August 1993 and December 1995. It also has options to buy additional Boeing 767-300's and Boeing 747-400's with production dates ranging from 1994 to 1999. The airline plans to expand in Western Europe, North America, Australia and Asia.

title: Dow Up 4.21, to 2,914.11, on Heavy Volume
description: Blue chips and smaller stocks gained in heavy trading yesterday, but the broader market was mixed. Earlier in the day, though, several market averages climbed to new highs.

title: Westinghouse Names Winners Of Scholarships
description: A 17-year-old North Carolina girl was named winner of the $40,000 first-place scholarship in the 50th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search at ceremonies in Washington last night.

title: The Desktop Business
description: IT'S not too difficult to become a desktop publisher. Thousands of people have learned the ins and outs of such expensive and versatile programs as Aldus Pagemaker and Ventura Publisher. Less-expensive programs, like Express Publisher and Publish It, are easier to learn and use and are surprisingly effective for smaller projects.

title: Jury Sees Apartment Of Teacher Accused In Husband's Death
description: A jury was sworn in today for the trial of a schoolteacher accused of hiring three teen-age students to kill her husband. The panel began its work by going to see the apartment where the man died.

title: An Ice Storm Paralyzes Western and Northern New York
description: The worst ice storm in decades paralyzed wide sections of western and northern New York State yesterday, knocking out power to hundreds of thousands of homes and shutting down businesses, schools, government offices and transportation over wide areas.

title: Philharmonic Programs In Masur's First Season
description: Kurt Masur's first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic will open with a benefit concert on Sept. 11 at Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestra announced yesterday. The program, to be repeated three times, will offer two works of John Adams, his "Tromba Lontana" and "Short Ride in a Fast Machine," along with Copland's "Old American Songs" and Bruckner's Symphony No. 7.

title: If You Can Make It There
description: Following are the recent changes among head coaches and general managers for pro teams in the New York area: Nov. 6, 1989: Jim Schoenfeld dismissed as head coach of Devils and replaced by John Cunniff, an assistant. Dec. 26, 1989: Joe Walton dismissed as head coach of Jets and replaced on Feb. 6, 1990, by Bruce Coslet, offensive coordinator of Cincinnati Bengals. May 29, 1990: Davey Johnson dismissed as manager of Mets and replaced by Bud Harrelson, third-base coach. June 6, 1990: Bucky Dent dismissed as manager of Yankees and replaced by Stump Merrill, manager of Columbus farm team. Dec. 3, 1990: Stu Jackson dismissed as head coach of Knicks and replaced by John MacLeod. March 1, 1991: Al Bianchi dismissed as vice president and general manager of Knicks and replaced by David Checketts, a league executive. March 4, 1991: John Cunniff dismissed as head coach of Devils and replaced by Tom McVie, coach and general manager of Utica farm team.

title: PROTESTANT GROUP ADMITS KILLING 4
description: A Protestant paramilitary group took responsibility today for shooting and killing four Roman Catholic men and seriously wounding a fifth at a village pub in Northern Ireland.

title: BUSH IS PLEASED BY FREEING OF 10
description: President Bush welcomed the release of 10 allied prisoners by Iraq today, but vowed to win the freedom of "every single" captured soldier and Kuwaiti citizen. The nation's senior military officer said the war would not be formally ended until Iraq accounted for all its prisoners.

title: Review/Theater; Of Women and the Ruling Class (Men?)
description: In "A Room of One's Own," Virginia Woolf used her discerning wit and intellectual acumen to assail the bastion of male prejudice against women as artists. Her two historic lectures and the book that grew out of them are a cornerstone of feminist doctrine and freethinking criticism. Although the essay was written to be delivered in public (at Cambridge University in 1928), it was not regarded as a dramatic piece -- until Eileen Atkins gave it life on stage.

title: Trade Talk Tempers Rangers' Victory
description: Even if the current Rangers' roster changes before today's trading deadline, the ones who go and the ones who stay can remember last night's victory over injury-weakened Philadelphia as one of the season's most thorough performances.

title: Walter C. Bachman, Ship Designer, 79
description: Walter Crawford Bachman, a ship designer and marine engineer, died on Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Colonial Cos., Columbia, S.C., and its principal unit, Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Co., named Stephen G. Hall chief executive. * Cygnet Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., a manufacturer of jukeboxes, named Tyler Wilkins vice president of engineering.

title: Concrete Is Compatible With Scouting
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats to President: Focus on Issues at Home
description: After months as bystanders while President Bush led the country to war, the Senate and House Democratic leaders struggled today to shift some attention back to Congress, domestic affairs and partisan politics.

title: Salt Marsh Interloper Alters A Coastline
description: A PLANT whose progenitor seeds were stowaways with oysters transplanted 100 years ago is spreading in Washington State, drastically altering its coastal landscape.

title: Iraqi Shiites Wait in the Wings for a Role to Play
description: Reports of civil unrest in Basra and several other Shiite-dominated cities in southern Iraq have focused attention on the Shiite opposition in Iraq and whether the country is fertile ground for an Iranian-style Islamic revolution.

title: Church Remains a Landmark
description: The Court let stand a ruling that the landmark status of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York does not violate religious freedom. Page B1.

title: Minnesota Oil Pipeline Leaks
description: An estimated 630,000 gallons of crude oil spilled from a pipeline onto the ground and into a nearby river on Sunday before the flow was cut off, the authorities said. Neither the Federal authorities nor officials at Lakehead Pipeline, the Superior, Wis., company that owns the pipeline, knew what caused the leak.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: EX-COMMANDER COMPLAINS The former commander of a Georgia National Guard brigade said his unit was mobilized for war for political reasons, then was unjustly criticized. Page A18.

title: Arts World Mobilizes To Fight Cuomo Cuts
description: "We have been hit by a Scud missile and you are the Patriots going up to defend us," said State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican, as he opened what he called "an emergency rally" of artists and arts leaders at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall yesterday.

title: 'Play It Sam - Fast!'
description: Wartime vacation diary:

title: Simple Justice for Aliens
description: Amnesty for undocumented aliens was a humane and vital part of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The act offered some three million illegal immigrants release from an underworld culture and gave Congress a basis for controlling the borders and deciding who should live here in the future.

title: 3-Telescope Complex Planned at South Pole
description: A CONSORTIUM of nine universities and research centers plans to install three telescopes at the South Pole to take advantage of its unique conditions for celestial observation.

title: Casualties In Jet Crash
description: Following is a list, released today by United Airlines, of the 5 crew members and 20 passengers killed in Sunday's crash of Flight 585: Crew CHURCH, Lisa, based in New York City, flight attendant. EIDSON, Patricia Karen, based in San Francisco, first officer. GREEN, Harold Leon, pilot. LUCERO, Anita, based in San Francisco, flight attendant. SMILEY, Monica, based in New York City, flight attendant. Passengers BACHMAN, Bonnie, Phoenix. BIRKHOLZ, Dan, 35 years old, Colorado Springs. BODNAR, Andy, Toronto. BROWN, Mildred, Copperas Cove, Tex. CRABB, Dr. Bill, 51, Colorado Springs. CRAWFORD, Clay, 72, Colorado Springs. CRAWFORD, Jo, 65, Colorado Springs. GEISSBUHLER, Robert, 39, Colorado Springs. GERDTS, Pam, 39, Colorado Springs. HOFFMAN, Fred, 40, Colorado Springs. HOLDING, Herald, Colorado Springs. JENKS, Maurice, Littleton, Colo. KAVANAGH, Michael, Barna, Ireland. KODALEN, Kevin, Colorado Springs. KOMOR, Andrzej, 29, Warsaw, Poland. McGILVAR, Paula, 43, Colorado Springs. RIGA, Vincent, 55, Colorado Springs. ROSS, Lester, Atlanta. VAN HANDEL, Pete, 45, Colorado Springs. YOSHIDA, Takashi, Fukushima, Japan.

title: Careers; Two Growth Areas Beckon In Recession
description: BECAUSE of the recession, college students more than ever are searching for growth areas, even if they have to add a master's degree.

title: 3 Are Killed in Crash of Navy Passenger Jet
description: A Navy passenger jet crashed and burned in this suburb of Chicago on Sunday, killing all three crew members.

title: Jury Finds Law Firm Ran Racket
description: One of New York City's most prominent negligence-case lawyers and six associates were convicted yesterday of bribing witnesses and fabricating evidence to win millions of dollars in personal-injury cases.

title: HORCE RACING: Notebook; Excavate's Derby Hopes Setting in the West
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby, which is always littered with broken dreams, claimed one more beaten superstar today, and there are still two months to go.

title: What We Owe the Vets
description: Members of Congress and President Bush have vowed that veterans of the Persian Gulf war will not be treated shabbily, as their parents and older relatives were when they returned from Vietnam. Such avowals are hollow when specific benefits do not accrue to those who carried the real burden of war. Several pieces of legislation should be pressed on an emergency basis in Congress.

title: F.D.A. Acts to Halt Claim for Milk Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: There is one man, and perhaps only one, who continues to have mail addressed to him more than two centuries after his death. He is Edmond Hoyle, who died in 1769 at the age of 97. In 1746 he published rules and advice for five games, and the idea has been copied at frequent intervals ever since. "According to Hoyle" is a phrase that has become part of the language.

title: Q&A
description: Plastic Taste

title: Nets Lose as Mavericks Score With No Time Left
description: Rolando Blackman converted two free throws after time expired tonight to lift the Dallas Mavericks to a 102-100 victory over the Nets.

title: The Democrats: Lying in Wait
description: The biggest "lie" in politics today is that no Democrat is running for President. Who better to expose the truth than the author of Goldman's Golden Rule: A successful liar always tells the truth. (That way, your story always checks out.)

title: Review/Theater; An Inept Mugger and His Victim
description: Remember when Woody Allen's hapless bank robber in "Take the Money and Run" passed a note across the counter to inform the teller that he was armed and carrying "a gub"? A similar spirit of inane ineptitude in the criminal class enlivens "The Experts" by Bill Bozzone. This travesty of sidewalk thievery is not only the high point of Evening B of the Manhattan Punch Line's festival of one-act comedies, it is also the only point.

title: Computers Gain New Respect as Translators
description: AFTER years of limited progress and effort, there is now a renaissance of interest in using computers to translate languages. Scientists believe that with the help of more powerful computers, advances in artificial intelligence and new approaches to translation, the long-sought goal of machine translation may be at hand.

title: World's Film Dealers Converge on Santa Monica
description: If you want to buy the Korean movie, video and television rights for Kevin Costner's next picture, "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves," the American Film Market here is the place to be. But even if you are interested only in acquiring "Chopper Chicks in Zombietown" for exhibition in Suriname, it still makes sense to put in an appearance.

title: New Logo, New Dishes, But Still the Colonel's
description: Its restaurants will continue to sell fried food under a logo bearing the ubiquitous face of its founder, the late Col. Harland Sanders, but Kentucky Fried Chicken is shortening its name on much of its advertising and packaging materials to KFC.

title: Three From Hong Kong Are Jailed by China
description: A Chinese court convicted three Hong Kong residents today on charges of helping pro-democracy campaigners and sentenced them to prison terms of four to five years, a Chinese newspaper reported.

title: Mill Workers Win $57 Million Award For Staying on Call
description: A Federal judge has ordered the I.T.T. Corporation to pay $57 million to 91 pulp mill employees, ruling that they should have been paid for the time they were required to be on call and available for work.

title: Connecticut Acts to Compel Bridgeport to Cut Its Budget
description: The State Treasurer said today that he would seek a court order compelling officials in Bridgeport to lay off 58 employees and carry out other budget-cutting measures ordered by a financial review board.

title: Northwest Pilots Reject Pay Cuts
description: Pilots at Northwest Airlines said they had rejected management requests for a pay cut and that they might seek a stake in the troubled carrier. After meetings this weekend in Minneapolis, the pilots decided that the airline did not need concessions to survive.

title: By Design; Adding Color to Life
description: Details do make the difference. One look and you can tell whether a jacket is this season's, or a leftover that is perfectly nice but not as snappy.

title: Iraq, Seeking to Regroup Forces, Orders an Amnesty for Deserters
description: Seeking to regroup and marshal their war-scarred forces, the Iraqi authorities declared an extraordinary amnesty today for deserters and other soldiers absent from their units.

title: Ex-Chief of Random House Is Taking Job With Wiley
description: Robert L. Bernstein, who headed Random House Inc. for 23 years before his abrupt departure 16 months ago, was named yesterday to be publisher-at-large and an adviser to the trade publishing division of John Wiley & Sons Inc. The appointment takes effect the middle of this month.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about an official of the Palisades Geophysical Institute rendered his name incorrectly. He was Carl Hartdegen 3d, not 2d. The obituary also misidentified a survivor. Carl E. Hartdegen is his son, not his brother.

title: People
description: * Steve Montgomery has joined Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer as an art director. * Larry Cadman has been named senior vice president and creative director at Bozell Inc., New York.

title: Bloomfield Hills Journal; 'Recession' Means Someone Else's
description: In this wealthy enclave 20 miles from the desperate ghettos of Detroit, local celebrities live on forested estates, chic women in shearling and mink casually drop $4,000 on, say, a belt, and the word "recession" is a minor annoyance, a faint description of somebody else's world.

title: CBS Soars On Rumor
description: The stock of CBS Inc. rose $5.25 yesterday, to $179, amid speculation that the company was in talks with The Walt Disney Company.

title: Friends and Relatives Mourn 14-Year-Old Girl
description: Every school day Liedza Rivera and her friends would gather outside Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan before classes began. Yesterday Liedza's friends met at the usual spot, but she did not show up.

title: Holmes Plans Comeback in April
description: Larry Holmes, the 41-year-old former heavyweight champion, is returning to the ring.

title: Msgr. da Costa Lopes, East Timor Cleric, 72
description: Msgr. Martinho da Costa Lopes, who was vicar general of the former Portuguese colony of East Timor when Indonesian forces invaded the predominantly Roman Catholic enclave in 1975, died last Wednesday at Egas Moniz Hospital in Lisbon. He was 72 years old and lived in Alges, a suburb of Lisbon.

title: Fordham Game On Radio Live
description: Officials at WFUV, the Fordham radio station, said yesterday the station would broadcast tomorrow afternoon's basketball game between the Rams and St. Francis in Loretto, Pa. The winner of the game receives an automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: NASA Reduces Cost and Role Of Its Orbiting Space Station
description: A simpler, more modest plan for NASA's space station is taking shape after budget cuts and the discovery of design flaws sent architects back to the drawing board.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * BP America Inc., Cleveland, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of $2.5 billion in debt securities to be guaranteed by its parent company, British Petroleum P.L.C.

title: New Loans To Chrysler Called Near
description: The Chrysler Corporation has reached a tentative accord with its banks that if approved would give the company a financial cushion until its depressed sales and profits improve, financial executives who spoke with Chrysler officials said today.

title: Census Finds Many Claiming New Identity: Indian
description: For the first 43 years of her life, Barbara Anderson did not talk about her ethnic background. But now it is a matter of pride -- and record. On the latest census form, Mrs. Anderson, now 48, checked a different box: American Indian.

title: Review/Pop; Hall and Oates Go Acoustic
description: Daryl Hall and John Oates have joined a ripple of a pop trend -- the acoustic-instruments concert. While synthesizers and other electronics rule pop's commercial heights, MTV's program "Unplugged" has been presenting bands with acoustic instruments, and at least one rock group, Tesla, has performed a concert with acoustic guitars instead of electric ones. Now, Hall and Oates are touring with a primarily acoustic nine-member band, fudging slightly by using Hammond organ, electric upright bass and electric violin.

title: Ojeda Is Impressive
description: Bob Ojeda, obtained by the Los Angeles Dodgers from the Mets last Dec. 17 in a trade that sent the outfielder Hubie Brooks back to the Mets, pitched two scoreless innings yesterday in the club's first intra-squad game at Vero Beach, Fla. The left-hander allowed only one hit.

title: Pianist Wins Fisher Prize
description: The celebration was threefold at a private dinner last night onstage at Avery Fisher Hall. Avery Fisher, for whom the hall is named, celebrated his 85th birthday by presenting the 10th Avery Fisher Prize for outstanding achievement and excellence in music to the pianist Yefim Bronfman. It was also the 15th anniversary of the Avery Fisher Artist Program, which chooses recipients of the award.

title: G.M. Picks Michigan Plant For Building Its Electric Car
description: The General Motors Corporation took a big step today toward producing the first commercially available electric car in modern time, announcing that it had selected a small factory in Lansing, Mich., as the production site.

title: A Tardy Perez Arrives at Yank Camp in Carefree Mood
description: With a carefree look that said, "What, me worry?" Pascual Perez bounded into the Yankee training camp today, pronounced his troubles over and said he hoped to be pitching again by May.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Sports of the Times column on Saturday about the Knicks misidentified a player in some editions. He is Kiki Vandeweghe, not Ernie Vandeweghe.

title: IRAQI CLASHES SAID TO GROW AS TROOPS JOIN IN PROTESTS; FIRST ALLIED CAPTIVES FREED
description: Fierce fighting raged between supporters and enemies of President Saddam Hussein in Basra and up to a dozen other cities in southern Iraq today, rebel leaders and American officials said. It was the worst civil unrest of Mr. Hussein's long rule.

title: Fed to Fight Part of Plan On Banks
description: Alan Greenspan and other top officials of the Federal Reserve Board are strongly opposed to the part of the Bush Administration's proposed banking legislation that would remove some of the nation's largestbanks from the central bank's supervision.

title: Pollution Cases Seek Corporate Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Revlon Deal Would Realign Industry
description: The sale of Revlon Inc., if it comes about, would signal a turning point for the highly fragmented and fiercely competitive cosmetics business in the United States, which last year had sales of roughly $12 billion.

title: The President's Popularity
description: It's a stunning figure: As the Persian Gulf war ended, President Bush's popularity, in a USA Today poll, shot up to 91 percent. That prompted a gleeful Representative Newt Gingrich to say, "The number of people who don't like George Bush is almost down to the number of people running for the Democratic nomination."

title: Patterns
description: Time for Escapism?

title: Senior Vietnamese Criticizes Hanoi's Leaders
description: A second senior and widely admired Vietnamese intellectual has criticized the leadership in Hanoi, calling for individual freedoms, younger leaders and changes in the system.

title: Ex-LeBow Associates In Turnaround Venture
description: William Weksel, a former chairman of the Liggett Group and a business associate of the investor Bennett S. LeBow, has struck out on his own with another former LeBow executive, Robert H. Davies, to start a management turnaround company.

title: A County With Much at Stake Is Wary of Weicker Tax Plan
description: The anxiety and uncertainty that has gripped much of Connecticut since Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced his plan to tax wages has found its focal point here in Fairfield County, the seat of the state's greatest wealth.

title: Review/Dance; Summoning Atmospheres of the Past
description: A program of dance and video by Elisabetta Vittoni and Ariel Herrera, presented on Saturday night by the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, promised more than it delivered.

title: Convicted Bank Agrees to Divestiture Plan
description: The Bank of Commerce and Credit International, a worldwide bank convicted of money-laundering, agreed yesterday with the Federal Reserve Board to divest itself of whatever stake it has in the biggest bank in Washington.

title: Designing Birds Impress Their Mates With Fancy Decor
description: COME into my parlor, beckons the male bowerbird to females that stop to appraise the mating courtyard he has constructed. See my fine bower, he suggests, a perfect avenue and platform of sticks, and see all the decorations I've gathered: bright blue feathers so rare, blue straws and bottle caps and clothespins I stole from someone's line, along with lovely leaves and snail shells, all carefully arranged on my parlor floor.

title: Rating Cut for ITT Financial Unit
description: The credit rating of about $4.9 billion in long-term debt issued by the ITT Financial Corporation was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited weakening asset quality as a principal factor.

title: Medical Examiner Confirms An Infant Starved to Death
description: An autopsy on a Harlem infant who died last month confirmed initial reports that the child had starved to death, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Explosion and Fire At Louisiana Plant Kill 3 and Injure 12
description: An explosion and fire at one of the nation's largest oil refineries killed 3 people and injured at least 12 others, the authorities said today.

title: Gillette Venture
description: The Gillette Company signed a joint venture agreement with Lenninets Concern, a scientific and production group in the Soviet Union, to make razor blades, shaving systems and disposable razors. Boston-based Gillette said the Soviet Union was one of the largest blade markets in the world. It estimated annual sales at 750 million units. Gillette will hold a majority stake in the project, which is expected to begin production in 1992.

title: Crown Prince Returns; Kuwait Cabinet Meets
description: The Crown Prince of Kuwait, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, returned to his country today, the first senior member of the ruling family to fly home from exile in Saudi Arabia.

title: Mercedes Introduces New Luxury Models
description: Mercedes-Benz introduced its latest S Class luxury cars today and raised the price of the series by 20 percent, despite growing competition and declining demand for expensive automobiles.

title: Eleventh Hour for Polish Capitalism
description: The fate of Poland's bold leap from centralized economic control to a market economy is now in the hands of the Paris Club, an obscure but powerful group representing industrialized creditor nations. It will decide, probably in the next two weeks, how much debt relief to grant. The Poles have made a case for massive relief, around 80 percent. The U.S. reportedly favors a write-off in excess of 65 percent. France and Germany are lobbying for a lower figure, around 40 percent, while Japan seems to favor no write-off.

title: Dinkins to List Bias Crimes Against Homosexuals in City
description: The Dinkins administration, trying to persuade the State Senate to pass a bill increasing the penalties for bias-related crimes, announced yesterday that it would compile a list of hate crimes committed against homosexuals in New York City.

title: Forgotten Friends
description: This is a letter of regret to certain foreign friends with whom I have lost touch since Iraq began the Persian Gulf war in August.

title: Charles R. Speers, Executive, 83
description: Charles R. Speers, a former senior vice president of sales for American Airlines, died on Saturday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 83 years old and also lived in Naples, Fla.

title: Japanese Are Hardly Reassured on Nuclear Peril
description: Three weeks after Japan's worst nuclear accident, the Government's efforts to quell public fears have been undercut by damaging new information about human and mechanical failures that led to the near-disaster, and new troubles at other reactors around the country.

title: Tootal Receives 2d Bid by Coats
description: Europe's largest textile company, Coats Viyella P.L.C., offered about $366 million in cash today in its second attempt in two years to acquire Tootal Group P.L.C., a British rival.

title: Gulf Victory May Raise U.S. Influence in OPEC
description: By virtue of its military victory, the United States is likely to have more influence in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries than any industrial nation has ever exercised. But in the short term, the Administration may not try to exercise this influence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A10-12

title: Cardinals' Jose Injured
description: The spring training injury jinx hit the St. Louis Cardinals' camp again yesterday when the outfielder Felix Jose sprained his right ankle during a base-running drill in St. Petersburgh, Fla.

title: Boeing Sees End To Unit's Losses
description: The Boeing Company's military division, which has lost money for several years, will become profitable late in 1991, a company vice president, Gary Bland, said. Boeing expects its overall earnings to rise to $4.50 or $5 a share this year, compared with $4.01 in 1990, Mr. Bland told industry analysts.

title: Detective Denies Guilt in Love-Triangle Case
description: The prosecution's chief witness in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus denied a defense lawyer's suggestion today that he committed the crime.

title: Roger G. Weill Dies; Stamp Dealer Was 81
description: Roger G. Weill, a stamp dealer and collector who once owned some of the world's most expensive stamps, died Saturday at Touro Infirmary in New Orleans. He was 81 years old and lived in New Orleans.

title: Scalia Holds State To Same Plea Rule As Convicted Slayer
description: Justice Antonin Scalia, who announced last month that a death row inmate's lack of a lawyer was no excuse for filing a late appeal, said today that he would apply the same strict standard to state attorneys general who seek extensions of time for the same reason.

title: Bush Energy Plan Could Revive Nuclear Industry
description: A proposal in the Bush Administration's national energy strategy meant to encourage competition in the wholesale electric-generation business could also help revive the nuclear power industry, energy experts say.

title: California Jobless Rate Soars After Cold Ravages Oranges
description: The freeze that ravaged California's navel orange crop sent unemployment rates soaring, with nearly one of every five workers unemployed in one hard-hit county, the state reported today.

title: 9 Die as Fire Sweeps a Colorado Retirement Home
description: Shaken by Sunday's airline crash, this city awoke today to learn that fire had swept through a home for the elderly early this morning, killing nine people and injuring eight others.

title: Last Bensonhurst Trial Begins
description: Before only a handful of spectators, the trial of the last defendant in the Bensonhurst murder case began yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: A.T.&T. Challenges Pact
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday accused the General Services Adminstration of improperly awarding the U S Sprint Communications Company a contract to provide telephone services to the Navy.

title: Rig Count Slips Again
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas continued its seasonal decline last week, dropping by 18, to a total of 949 rigs, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count was 894. Baker Hughes officials said the rig count traditionally falls in the first quarter of the year and continues to decline through April.

title: Board Games
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo is right when he calls New York's Division for Servicemen's Voting a "boondoggle" and "patronage mill." The $140,000-a-year division, one of dozens of state agencies and commissions Mr. Cuomo has targeted for elimination, was created in World War II to help military personnel obtain absentee ballots. Its function is now duplicated by the Defense Department. That leaves the division only one real purpose: to provide one Republican and one Democratic director, appointed by the Legislature, who don't do much more than accrue pension benefits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAULINE KAEL , the provocative film critic of The New Yorker, is retiring from regular reviewing. Ms. Kael, 71 years old, has been writing reviews since 1968.

title: In Distressed Poland, a Success Story
description: For most Polish enterprises, the nation's headlong plunge from Communism to capitalism has produced a story of woe: They have been slow to adapt to consumer desires, their production has plummeted and hundreds of companies are near bankruptcy.

title: Dessoff Choirs to Sing In Chinese and Japanese
description: Choral works by Japanese, Chinese and American composers will be sung in Japanese or Chinese by the Dessoff Choirs on March 21 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Anti-Apartheid Alliance Disbands in South Africa
description: The United Democratic Front, a coalition of anti-apartheid groups formed seven and a half years ago, announced today that it would disband as a result of the political changes under way in South Africa.

title: He Thought Football Was Forever
description: In training camp with the Green Bay Packers in 1967, Travis Williams often fumbled. To the consternation not only of Coach Vince Lombardi but also to that of his teammates who recognized the rookie running back's potential.

title: Seles's Rise to No. 1 Is Delayed
description: Martina Navratilova, thrice defeated by Monica Seles in 1990, pounced on the teen-ager in straight sets, 6-2, 7-6, today, forcing Seles to wait another week before the computer awards her the No. 1 ranking that has been in Steffi Graf's possession the past 185 weeks.

title: Marathon Tennis Game Aids Sleep Researchers
description: ON the seventh day of the 145-hour tennis marathon, Ed VanTregt had to be led to his side of the court, shown how to hold his racquet and how to serve. With only an hour or two of sleep a day, Mr. VanTregt and his opponent, Bobby McWaters, became progressively disoriented and irritable as the match dragged on and would fall asleep as soon as they got off their feet.

title: Albertson's Shares
description: Albertson's Inc., an owner of supermarkets, authorized the repurchase of up to 6.7 million of its common shares between April 1 and March 31, 1992. Albertson's has about 133.8 million common shares outstanding. Since September 1987, the company has bought back the equivalent of more than 4.1 million shares. The company's stock rose $1 today, to $39.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in lackluster trading. Dealers attributed the dull session largely to the lack of any significant economic data. Many investors moved toward the shorter maturities.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Transport Co., Chicago, a unit of Amoco Corp., said it would build a double-hull supertanker to be placed in service in 1993. * Aritech Corp., Framingham, Mass., a maker of burglar alarm systems and components, will sell its European operations for $42.5 million, including assumption of debt, to a group of institutional investors including Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank N.V. and Jan P. Brantjes, general manager of Aritech's European operations.

title: L.A. Joe Group Headed By New York Retailer
description: Meir Panigel, who owns eight clothing stores in New York City, has become the principal shareholder and head of a group that has bought the owner of L.A. Joe, the 70-store closeout chain. The core units of the chain are 55 former Heck's discount stores in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky in what are mostly economically depressed rural areas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The impresario of the "We Are the World" recording, KEN KRAGEN , said that his organization, USA for Africa, has established a fellowship program in the name of the late Representative Mickey Leland. The program will bring leaders of African development programs to the Carter Center at Emory University in Atlanta to study such subjects as human rights and agriculture.

title: March 15 New Deadline for Daily News
description: The publisher of The Daily News said yesterday that the 71-year-old newspaper, once the largest daily in the country, would be closed on March 15 unless it could be sold to a new owner.

title: 6 Americans, Including Woman, Among 10 Released by Baghdad
description: The first 10 allied prisoners released by Iraq since the end of the Persian Gulf war, six Americans among them, walked, drove and flew to freedom today, saying they felt good.

title: Tokyo Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were lower today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 62.54 points, or 0.24 percent, to 25,913.48.

title: High Court to Review A Fed Policy on Banks
description: At the urging of the Federal Reserve Board, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court ruling that invalidated a policy the Fed has relied on for many years in regulating bank holding companies.

title: Wine Talk
description: "CONTAINS Sulfites."

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Royal Academy of Dancing has named ANTOINETTE SIBLEY its acting president, replacing the late Margot Fonteyn. Ms. Sibley, 52 years old, danced almost exclusively for the Royal Ballet from 1956 until 1988. She retired after the death of her mentor, Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Packing Up; U.S. Withdrawal Expected to Be a Long Process
description: Thousands of American troops will be coming home from the Persian Gulf within weeks, but tens of thousands more will probably have to remain for many more months, Pentagon officials say.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Bumble Bee President Becomes Chief, Too
description: Mark A. Koob, president of Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., has been promoted to the additional position of chief executive at the San Diego-based tuna processing and marketing company.

title: Modest Gains for Treasury Issues
description: Interest rates eased yesterday, sending corporations rushing to issue bonds. But the modest decline in interest did not impress many people in the Treasury securities market, which dealers said was still marking time in the absence of much enthusiasm from retail investors.

title: McEnroe Survives 'a Heck of a Match' Against Masur
