description: The stadium was sandblasted by a desert wind that gusted up to 30 miles per hour and intermittently doused players and spectators with grit. The sun was high and hot when the began, but a chill shadow hovered over the court by the time it concluded 2 hours 35 minutes later.

title: Viola Says He Is Ready To Pitch and Negotiate
description: Frank Viola, saying he was convinced that the bone spurs in the elbow of his pitching arm were no impediment to his season and that minor surgery remained only a remote prospect for the future, said today he was finished having the arm examined.

title: Mayors Press Congress For Control Over Cable
description: More than 600 mayors and local officials asked Congress today for legislation that they said would increase competitiveness among operators of local cable television franchises.

title: House Passes Futures Bill
description: A bill to reform trading practices in the futures pits while giving Federal regulators more authority to discipline wrongdoers easily passed the House today 395 to 27.

title: Rangers Get Kocur, a Fast Man With Fists
description: In a significant five-player deal with the Detroit Red Wings, the Rangers yesterday acquired Joe Kocur, the tough forward they have sought all season as the last piece of the puzzle in construcing a lineup they hope will put them into the Stanley Cup picture.

title: Accounts
description: * The baked-goods division of Pillsbury to the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding for all breakfast products. Billings for the entire account total $10 million. Foote, Cone already handled Pillsbury Toaster Strudel, while Leo Burnett handled Hungry Jack products, Pillsbury Instant Breakfast and Farina. * Natural Organics Inc., a manufacturer of vitamins and natural supplements, to Holland Advertising, New York, with a $1.2 million budget.

title: Inquiry Stalls Education Nomination
description: Lamar Alexander, President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Education, expressed confidence today that he would be confirmed despite a continuing Senate investigation into his financial investments.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Dismissed in Trump Case, Analyst Is Awarded $750,000
description: A Philadelphia securities analyst who refused to retract negative comments about a casino owned by Donald J. Trump and was subsequently dismissed won a $750,000 award from his former firm yesterday.

title: How Children of Gay Parents Fit In at School
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Hooked on Oil
description: WASHINGTON

title: A.T.&T. Files Suit In NCR Stock Plan
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked a Federal District Court in Dayton, Ohio, to declare the NCR Corporation's newly created employee stock ownership plan invalid. A.T.& T. said in court papers that NCR directors had breached their fiduciary duties by creating an employee stock plan designed to deny NCR stockholders "the ability to decide for themselves whether or not to accept the A.T.& T. tender offer."

title: Rev. John L. McKenzie, 80, Dies; Leader in Catholic Bible Research
description: The Rev. John L. McKenzie, a pioneering and outspoken Roman Catholic biblical scholar, died last Saturday at the Claremont Manor Convalescent Hospital in Claremont, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: Airlines Deepen Discounts For Members of the Military
description: Most leading airlines are offering deep discounts of 70 percent off full coach fares for military personnel and their immediate families as a token of appreciation for winning the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: O'Neal Out, for Moment
description: Shaquille O'Neal of Louisiana State, the nation's leading rebounder, will not be able to play in the Southeastern Conference tournament this week, and could miss the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament if his fractured leg fails to heal in time.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Turkey; Worried Turks Prefer Iraq to Remain Whole
description: Although eager to see President Saddam Hussein toppled, Turkey is worried that civil disorders in neighboring Iraq could wind up with entire zones controlled by Shiite Muslim fundamentalists and Kurdish guerrillas.

title: Chile Details Over 2,000 Slayings Under Pinochet
description: President Patricio Aylwin has issued a report describing more than 2,000 killings by the secret police during the 17 years of military rule under Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Back Problems Sideline Stewart
description: Payne Stewart has a herniated disk in his back and will miss the PGA Tour's next five events, leading up to the Masters.

title: 'Art of the Deal,' Scaled-Back Edition
description: Donald J. Trump said he would take his name off one of his projects, and that was not even the most remarkable concession he made yesterday at City Hall. He agreed to scrap his plans for Trump City along the Hudson River and instead build a project that was essentially designed by his critics.

title: Airlines Bailout Called Unlikely
description: Any attempt by the Federal Government to bail out the struggling airline industry is likely to do "more harm than good," the head of the Federal Aviation Administration told Congress today.

title: Gunshot Fired at Judge Is Tied to Norplant Case
description: A shot was fired at a judge in his courtroom here Monday, and the gunman's motive may have been the judge's order two months ago that a woman use a long-lasting birth control device as a condition of her probation.

title: Fordham Takes Aim At an N.C.A.A. Berth
description: Trapped somewhere between the achievement of the first Patriot League championship and the reward of a long-sought spot in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, the Fordham Rams will attempt this evening to win the school's first N.C.A.A. bid in 20 years.

title: Jamaica Looks Past 2 Waning Political Titans
description: For years, pitched battles have been fought by Jamaicans in this city's rough-and-tumble slums over allegiances to rival political parties and the two leaders who have long held sway over them.

title: St. Raymond's Gains Final Against Bishop Loughlin
description: The debate over which team is No. 1 in New York State, scheduled to be decided on March 23 in the New York State Federation of Secondary Schools tournament in Glens Falls, N.Y., will be at least partly settled on Friday night at Fordham University in the Bronx. That is when St. Raymond's of the Bronx (24-2) meets Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn (23-2) for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship.

title: Southland in Exit From Bankruptcy
description: The Southland Corporation, parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy after two Japanese companies pumped in $430 million of cash by buying 70 percent of its stock. The stock purchase by the Ito-Yokado Group and the Seven-Eleven Japan Company marked the final step in Southland's coming out from bankruptcy five months after it filed a "prepackaged" restructuring plan.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Friends and former students of Prof. MITCHELL I. GINSBERG have endowed a chair at Columbia University's School of Social Work in his name. Now semi-retired, Professor Ginsberg, 75, has devoted much of his career to the welfare system and homeless. He is a professor emeritus and dean emeritus of the school.

title: College Sports Should Turn Professional
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Expands Network Line
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced products that allow customers to connect computers of different types and makes into larger networks.

title: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'s; Iraq Frees 35 Captives, Saying It Has No More
description: Fighting for its own survival at home, Iraq hastened today to meet allied terms for a formal cease-fire, handing over to the International Committee of the Red Cross what it said were the last 35 allied prisoners under its control, including 15 Americans.

title: Nicaragua Holds Suspect in Killing of Contra Chief
description: Five people, including a Sandinista Army veteran, have been detained in connection with the killing of Enrique Bermudez, the former contra military chief, two weeks ago, the authorities here say.

title: Midland Bank In Shift at Top
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. today became the first leading British commercial bank since the Great Depression to cut its dividend. It also said it would replace its chairman.

title: Bret Easton Ellis Answers Critics of 'American Psycho'
description: As his novel "American Psycho" arrives in stores and death threats are delivered suggesting he should be dismembered like the victims of the book's fictional killer, Bret Easton Ellis seems dismayed that his work has sparked the biggest literary brouhaha since Salman Rushdie's "Satanic Verses."

title: Don Irwin, Journalist, 74
description: Don Irwin, a newspaperman who covered Washington for 30 years for The New York Herald Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, died Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 74 years old.

title: Factory Orders Down In January
description: Factory orders for manufactured goods dropped by 1.7 percent in January, their third straight decline, the Government said today, but analysts saw signs of some improvement by summer.

title: New York City Warned on Homeless
description: New York City is sheltering homeless families under conditions that violate state regulations, and state officials have warned that the violations could result in the loss of state housing money.

title: Books of The Times; The Constitution and Deciding What It Means
description: Interpreting the Constitution The Supreme Court and the Process of Adjudication By Harry H. Wellington 196 pages. Yale University Press. $22.50.

title: Judge Orders Measles Shots in Philadelphia
description: In an effort to curtail the city's measles epidemic, which has devastated the children of two churches that believe in faith healing, a Family Court judge has granted the city the right to immunize six children who are deemed at risk in one of the congregations.

title: Success of Foreman Persuades Holmes to Return to the Ring Again
description: It turns out that George Foreman is the catalyst in Larry Holmes's decision to come out of retirement for a second time.

title: A New Car for Malaysia, New Influence for Japan
description: In the early 1980's, the Prime Minister of Malaysia set a goal that most developing nations would never attempt: to build a national car that would put Malaysians on the move and spur the industrialization of a country known mostly for its rubber plantations and tin mines.

title: Speech by Exxon Chairman
description: In a blunt speech to energy executives in Houston today, Lawrence G. Rawl, chairman of the Exxon Corporation, dismissed concerns that acid rain from coal-fired utility plants damaged forests and lakes. He also expressed doubt that theories on global warming would eventually prove accurate.

title: Erica Jong Elected Head Of Guild
description: At a time of increasing tension over contracts between authors and publishing houses, Erica Jong has taken over the presidency of the Authors Guild and immediately called for "a fairer share of the profits our books produce."

title: Missouri Court Rejects Move for Comatose Woman
description: A divided Missouri appeals court rejected a father's plea today to move his severely brain-damaged daughter to another state that would give him more discretion in removing the feeding tube keeping the young woman alive.

title: Jerome Lipper, Lawyer And Banker, Dies at 54
description: Jerome Lipper, an international lawyer and banking executive, died yesterday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. He was 54 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Dry California Turns to the Pacific
description: With California in the grip of a five-year drought, cities and utility companies in this state are building the nation's first large-scale plants to desalt seawater.

title: New York State Bond Offering
description: New York State yesterday priced $185 million in tax-exempt general obligation bonds through competitive bidding, which was won by a group of underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: British Publisher Is Said to Agree To Buy News, Pending Union Pact
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell agreed yesterday to buy The Daily News provided he can reach a settlement with the paper's nine striking unions, the publisher of The News said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. yesterday priced $700 million in the GTE Corporation's seven-year debentures.

title: Often a Hero, a Firefighter Dies on the Job
description: Almost 16 months ago, an off-duty New York City firefighter, Alfred Ronaldson, rushed to an Orange County school that had been battered by a tornado and rescued at least two children from the rubble. He survived that dangerous situation, as he had many others in a 13-year career in which he won six citations for bravery.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia; Saudi King Says Iraq's President Is Facing the Fate of 'All Tyrants'
description: In his first postwar policy declaration, King Fahd took a severe line toward President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today, accusing him of deception and predicting that he would meet with an ominous end as "all tyrants" in the Arab world have before him.

title: Museum to Give Back Some Artifacts to Indians
description: The board of the National Museum of the American Indian of the Smithsonian Institution announced today the adoption of a new policy on repatriating American Indian remains and cultural materials.

title: Editors' Note
description: Two picture captions yesterday about Iraq's release of allied prisoners omitted identities for two of them. Their identities were unavailable; both captions should have specified that, but only one did.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait City; Palestinians in Kuwait Reported Shot and Beaten
description: Doctors and medical students at Kuwait City's largest hospital said today that in the last five days they had treated scores of Palestinian men who had been severely beaten, slashed and in several instances shot.

title: Hawkins and Eiland Vie For a Yank Starting Spot
description: Every spring, something like this seems to happen. Two players compete for the same job. One wins, the other whines. There is jubilation, but there is also unhappiness.

title: Mosher Is Leaving Theater Company
description: Gregory Mosher, who as director of Lincoln Center Theater helped turn a performance complex that had been largely inactive for eight years into one of New York City's most thriving theatrical enterprises, will be leaving his post at the end of the year, he said yesterday, "to make a break into something new."

title: Budget Gives Poor Humor To Bulgarians
description: According to the local folklore, the residents of this town are renowned for their self-effacing humor and their tightfistedness.

title: Patrick M. Murphy Jr., Lawyer, Is Dead at 52
description: Patrick M. Murphy Jr., a lawyer and partner in the Murphy & Barthol law firm on Long Island, died on Feb. 27 at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in East Williston, L.I.

title: Michelin Finds a New Constellation
description: The 1991 Michelin Guide for France, published Monday, has awarded its top rating, three stars, to the restaurant of the Hotel Cote d'Or in Saulieu, just west of Dijon, the only restaurant to be promoted this year.

title: No Magic for McVie in Return to the Devils
description: The Devils suffered a 4-3 loss to the Islanders here tonight in Tom McVie's return behind the New Jersey bench, but the new coach of the Devils was upbeat and full of optimism.

title: A Wide Range of Help For Minority Students Who Try Engineering,
description: Neffer E. Carrillo had a problem, one more difficult than any he had faced during his four years as an engineering major at the University of Massachusetts. Rich with potential, but penny poor, he had no suitable clothes in which to meet a recruiter from a large company interested in hiring him.

title: Honda Stores Cars
description: About 2,000 new Honda Accords, the best-selling car in the United States for the last two years, are being stored as the Japanese manufacturer resists layoffs at its United States assembly plant, the company said. The cars are being kept at a former Army depot in Marion, Ohio, about 25 miles northeast of the Accord assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, a Honda Motor Company spokesman, Kurt Antonius, said. It is expected that unsold Honda Civics, made at Marysville and nearby East Liberty, Ohio, will also be stored at the depot.

title: Miami's Tropical Flavors And Resourceful Chefs Spice Restaurant Boom
description: Something new is happening under the tropical sun in this metropolis by the sea. From Coral Gables to Miami Beach, from North Miami to Little Havana, a colorful new wave of cooking is washing over the landscape.

title: Beijing Journal; Love, the Starry-Eyed Kind, Casts Spell on China
description: In a nation more famed for prudishness than prurience, where fighting in public was considered more respectable than kissing in public, where people speak a language that has more words describing rice than love, something remarkable is happening: Chinese are turning into romantics.

title: Canada Indicator Drops
description: Canada's composite leading indicator, an index intended to predict future economic activity, fell sixth-tenths of 1 percent in December, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Government agency Statistics Canada said on Monday. The index dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent in November.

title: Loss Posted At Tonka
description: The Tonka Corporation, the nation's third-largest toy company, on Monday reported a loss of $18.5 million in the final quarter of 1990.

title: Olga Kattan, 62, Dies; A Professor of Spanish
description: Olga Kattan, a professor of Spanish language and literature at Brooklyn College for the last 25 years, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: Rally Benefits Some Retailers
description: Amid the general market surge, the stocks of eight retailing companies reached 52- week highs yesterday, reflecting a perception among investors that the recession could end in the current quarter.

title: Market Place; On Dividends, Bad News Grows
description: WHEN it comes to dividends, the good news is almost always much greater than the bad news. That is a sign of the enduring strength of the American economy and a reason for long-term increases in stock prices.

title: Coke-Sony Promotion
description: The Coca-Cola Company and the Sony Corporation announced yesterday that they planned to give away 5.6 million miniature compact audio disks with 6-packs and 12-packs of Coca-Cola beverages.

title: A State May Require Measles Vaccination
description: To the Editor:

title: Unchecked Growth Chokes Long Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns, a Streak-Busting Team, Stop Knicks' String at 5
description: The streak-busters were at work again last night.

title: Wisconsin-Green Bay Gets a First N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Dean Vander Plas scored 18 points and Tony Bennett sparked a 21-3 second-half run tonight as Wisconsin-Green Bay earned its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament bid by beating Northern Illinois, 56-39, in the Mid-Continent Conference tournament final.

title: Britain Lifts Ban on New Heathrow Service
description: The British Government said yesterday that new carriers would be allowed to start service to Heathrow Airport. Scrapping the rules that had barred such service eliminated a big hurdle for United Airlines and American Airlines, which are seeking to take over the London service of Pan Am and T.W.A.

title: Lemuel Tucker, TV Correspondent, 52
description: Lemuel Tucker, a radio and television reporter and correspondent who served with all three major broadcast networks -- NBC, ABC and CBS -- died on Saturday at the Washington Home and Hospice. He was 52 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Elmer Bischoff, West Coast Painter, Is Dead at 74
description: Elmer Bischoff, a pioneer of the Bay Area figurative school of painting, died Saturday at the Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in Berkeley.

title: Book Notes
description: A Literary Windfall

title: 2d Woman Released In Baghdad Comes As Surprise to U.S.
description: Until her name appeared yesterday on a second list of prisoners of war being released by Iraq, Maj. Rhonda L. Cornum of the Army had been listed by the Pentagon as missing in action.

title: Proxy Plan By Simmons
description: The investor Harold C. Simmons said today that he thought 80 percent of the Lockheed Corporation's non-employee stockholders would support him in a proxy battle for three seats on the aerospace company's board.

title: Molson Sheds Agencies; Lintas and AC&R Win
description: Molson Breweries U.S.A., a division of Molson Breweries North America, said yesterday that it had whittled its roster of agencies from four to two: Lintas and AC& R are in, while Angotti, Thomas, Hedge and Trahan, Burden & Charles are out.

title: Out of Coma, He Accuses 2
description: A man who had been comatose since he was beaten more than eight years ago suddenly regained consciousness last week and has given the authorities the names of his two assailants. The 26-year-old man, Conley Holbrook, was beaten on the head with a log on Nov. 27, 1982, and had been in the care of relatives ever since. The people he has named are also relatives, said the Davidson County Sheriff's Department, which is continuing to investigate.

title: L.I.R.R. to Eliminate 41 Trains
description: Starting on Monday, the Long Island Rail Road will eliminate several trains, combine others and sharply reduce service in the early morning hours.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War A14-17

title: Helping Americans Learn That Snails Don't Grow in Cans
description: SOME vocations seem to beg the question of whether it's better to do what you like or to like what you do. Take the people who test drive Rolls-Royces or hand out the envelopes at the Academy Awards, for example. Then there's Mary Lyons, whose job it was to extol the merits of French food and wine.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Environment; Burning Wells Turn Kuwait Into Land of Oily Blackness
description: Barely 10 miles south of Kuwait City, the sun disappears and black oily soot settles on passing cars and coats the flat desert scrub.

title: Viola Hymes, Volunteer, 84
description: Viola Hymes, a former president of the National Council of Jewish Women, died Friday at Methodist Hospital in St. Louis Park, Minn. She was 84 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: Dow Closes At 2,972.52, Up by 58.41
description: Investors climbed on the Wall Street bandwagon yesterday, driving stock prices sharply higher and lifting trading volume to its highest level in almost a month. Several market indexes established new highs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Syracuse, at 25-4, Still Has Something to Prove
description: Jim Boeheim, the Syracuse coach, was recently accepting congratulations for his team's success on the basketball court this season. Finally, Boeheim leaned back in his chair and in his typical matter-of-fact manner said: "It's nice, but it doesn't mean anything. The bottom line now is how you do in the N.C.A.A. tournament. It's too bad, but that's the way it is."

title: New Jersey Officials Reach Pact on Taxes
description: The leaders of the New Jersey Legislature have announced an agreement to alter Gov. Jim Florio's school-aid program by shifting $360 million into tax relief for property owners.

title: About New York; Economic Ills: Poor Are Sicker, Clinic Is Poorer
description: A frail woman stopped by the East New York Neighborhood Family Care Center to pick up some medicine. She also needed to talk.

title: 7-Year Debentures From Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $600 million in seven-year debentures due March 10, 1998, through various securities dealers.

title: Jets Sign Goetz
description: The Jets, continuing their search for offensive-line help, have signed Chris Goetz, a 6-foot-2-inch, 272-pound home-grown offensive guard, as a free agent.

title: Bank Fund and C.D. Yields Still Down, but Moderately
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the week that ended yesterday, but the rate of decline continues to moderate.

title: Stamford Approves A Gay Rights Law
description: The Stamford Board of Representatives has approved a homosexual-rights ordinance prohibiting discrimination against municipal employees or applicants for city jobs because of sexual orientation.

title: HOME IN COLORADO LACKED A LICENSE
description: The Colorado Springs retirement home where nine residents died in a fire early Monday had operated since 1988 without the required state license, which had been delayed because state inspectors had found fire safety violations.

title: Bob Evans Net Up 47%
description: Bob Evans Farms Inc., a restaurant operator and sausage producer, said on Monday that its third-quarter earnings increased 47.4 percent from a year ago as its sales rose by 10.3 percent. The company earned $8.7 million, or 28 cents a share, in the three months that ended on Jan. 25. That compared with $5.9 million, or 19 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter were $126.4 million, compared with $114.6 million last year. Bob Evans Farms owns and operates 250 restaurants in 14 states. It makes and distributes pork sausage under the Bob Evans and Owens names in 23 states.

title: Crime Draws Some of the Lines in Blueprints for Schools
description: When Leon County in northern Florida was planning two years ago to build more schools for its rapidly growing population, members of its school board consulted educators, administrators and architects.

title: The Dream Ticket
description: The Dream Ticket, that perennial fantasy of American politics, is again showing a pretty face and an alluring smile. This time the dream has President Bush paired with Gen. Colin Powell, the black Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as his running mate in 1992.

title: Inquiry Reports Rescue Mix-Up In Subway Fire
description: A Transit Authority investigation into a fatal fire in a Brooklyn subway tunnel has found that train dispatchers initially focused their rescue efforts on the wrong trains, leaving the train in most jeopardy stalled in the tunnel, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Oil Companies' Ad Strategy
description: The end of fighting in the Persian Gulf has caused many of the nation's oil companies to rethink their advertising plans, particularly as the heavy driving seasons of spring and summer approach.

title: Greyhound Dial Is Now Dial Corp.
description: The Greyhound Dial Corporation has changed its name to the Dial Corporation to eliminate any association with bus travel. "In the public's mind, the Greyhound name is so deeply ingrained with buses that the two are synonymous," the company's chairman, John W. Teets, said. "Today, our business and image are completely different." The corporation sold Greyhound Bus Lines to Dallas-based Greyhound Lines Inc. in 1987.

title: President Is Selected By Mills C.
description: A vice provost of Princeton University has been appointed president of Mills College, the Oakland, Calif., women's college that was closed down last spring by students protesting a decision to admit men.

title: Carbohydrates Are Dieter's Best Friend
description: IN 1910, Americans got almost 60 percent of their calories from carbohydrates; by 1980 the figure had fallen to 43 percent. The gap has been filled in by fat.

title: U.S. Surgeon General Opens Campaign on Binge Drinking
description: Surgeon General Antonia C. Novello took aim today at college students' binge drinking during their spring break and called on brewers to stop running promotions that appeal to under-age drinkers.

title: The Spandex League
description: At first glance, the latest attempt to revive women's professional basketball seems noble. Women should have the chances that men have enjoyed for years. But the scheme has nothing to do with equal opportunity, in spite of what the organizers have claimed, and everything to do with exploitation. Their main aim is to cash in on sex appeal.

title: New Banking Restrictions Are Proposed
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee proposed legislation today that would require banks to suspend dividend payments and bonuses for senior executives if they failed to satisfy regulatory requirements.

title: Robert Widlar, 53, Designer of Computer Circuits
description: Robert J. Widlar, a prolific designer of integrated circuits and a colorful personality in the Silicon Valley, died last Wednesday. He was 53 years old.

title: Edgar Lewy, Stamp Cataloguer, 64
description: Edgar Lewy, a philatelic writer and stamp cataloguer who specialized in modern postage stamps, died Feb. 16 in London. He was 64 years old.

title: Bridge
description: A focal point in the play of many hands is the first discard by a defender. It may of course be a signal, which both the other players will eagerly try to interpret. But in a more general way it will give a clue to the nature of the defender's hand.

title: U.S. Rewards Kenya for Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Freed and Missing Troops
description: Following is a Pentagon list of American prisoners of war released by Iraq today, and of those still classified as missing in action: RELEASED ACREE, Lieut. Col. Clifford M., 39, Marines, Oceanside, Calif. ANDREWS, Capt. William F., 32, Air Force, Syracuse. BERRYMAN, Capt. Michael C., 28, Marines, Cleveland, Okla. CORNUM, Maj. Rhonda L., 36, Army, Freeville, N.Y. DUNLAP, Sgt. Troy Allen, 20, Army, Massac, Ill. EBERLY, Col. David W., 43, Air Force, Brazil, Ind. FOX, Lieut. Col. Jeffrey D., 39, Air Force, Fall River, Mass. HUNTER, Chief Warrant Officer Guy L., 46, Marines, Camp Pendleton, Calif. ROBERTS, Capt. Harry M., 30, Air Force, Savannah, Ga. SANBORN, Capt. Russell A. C., 27, Marines, Havelock, N.C. SMALL, Maj. Joseph J. 3d., 39, Marines, Racine, Wis. STAMARIS, Sgt. Daniel J. Jr., 31, Army, Boise, Idaho. STORR, Capt. Richard D., 29, Air Force, Spokane, Wash. SWEET, First Lieut. Robert J., 24, Air Force, Philadelphia. TICE, Maj. Jeffrey S., 35, Air Force, Sellersville, Pa. MISSING BLAND, First Lieut. Thomas Clifford Jr., 26, Air Force, Gaithersburg, Md. BLESSINGER, Staff Sgt. John P., 33, Air Force, Fort Walton Beach, Fla. BUEGE, Senior Master Sgt. Paul G., 43, Air Force, Mary Esther, Fla. BUSH, Specialist David, 21, Army. CLARK, Sgt. Barry M., 26, Air Force, Hurlburt Field, Fla. CONNOR, Lieut. Patrick K., 25, Navy, Virginia Beach, Va. COOKE, Lieut. Comdr. Barry T., 35, Navy, Virginia Beach, Va. COSTEN, Lieut. William T., 27, Navy, St. Louis. GALVAN, Capt. Arthur, 33, Air Force, Navarre, Fla. GRIMM, Capt. William D., 28, Air Force, Hurlburt Field, Fla. HARRISON, Staff Sgt. Timothy R., 31, Air Force, Maxwell, Iowa. HODGES, Tech. Sgt. Robert K., 28, Air Force, Hurlburt Field, Fla. HOLLAND, Maj. Donnie R., 42, Air Force, Bastrop, La. KANUHA, Sgt. Damon V., 28, Air Force, San Diego. KORITZ, Maj. Thomas F., 37, Air Force, Rochelle, Ill. MAY, Master Sgt. James B. 2d, 40, Air Force, Fort Walton Beach, Fla. OELSCHLAGER, Staff Sgt. John L., 28, Air Force, Niceville, Fla. PHILLIS, Capt. Stephen Richard, 30, Air Force, Rock Island, Ill. RICKETT, Sgt. Crystal L., 31, Army. SCHMAUSS, Staff Sgt. Mark J., 30, Air Force, Hurlburt Field, Fla. SPEICHER, Lieut. Comdr. Michael Scott, 33, Navy, Jacksonville, Fla. SPELLACY, Capt. David, 28, Marines. TURNER, Lieut. Charles J., 29, Navy, Richfield, Minn. UNDERWOOD, Capt. Reginald C., 27, Marines. WALTERS, Capt. Dixon L. Jr., 29, Air Force, Navarre, Fla. WEAVER, Maj. Paul J., 34, Air Force, Navarre, Fla.

title: A Real Estate Fortune Dissolves
description: Daniel Mauck Galbreath had a reputation as a conservative real estate developer. But even his cautious stewardship could not save his business or the family fortune.

title: Review/Music; Bach Cantatas With Leinsdorf At the Organ
description: No one ever mistook Erich Leinsdorf for a conformist. Major symphonic conductors have grown increasingly willing to leave Bach, and particularly his vast body of sacred cantatas, to specialists. But Mr. Leinsdorf has always kept a hand in this repertory, and over the weekend he conducted an entire program of Bach cantatas with the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y. Conducted is perhaps too strong a term. He actually presided loosely from a portative organ, chopping the air with his left hand and filling in harmonies with his right.

title: Magazines Find Doing Good Is Paying Off
description: ALTHOUGH times are tough in the magazine industry, a growing number of publishers are in a giving mood, sponsoring charitiable events and programs to create a good impression among advertisers and readers.

title: Howard Slims Down and Reaffirms Its Tradition
description: Less than a year after he was appointed president of the nation's most important black center of higher education, Franklyn G. Jenifer has steered through a set of sweeping changes intended to alter the shape and strengthen the tradition of Howard University.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Libya; WARM TO QADDAFI, EGYPT ADVISES U.S.
description: Egyptian officials are quietly trying to nudge the United States into adopting a more open policy toward Libya, and are saying that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is showing signs of restraining his militant behavior.

title: Several Midlevel Shifts Are Announced by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation yesterday announced a series of medium-tier executive changes.

title: Can't City Hall Stop Inflation of Bureaucracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Government in India Shaken by Walkout Of an Essential Foe
description: Angered by reports that former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is under surveillance, Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party walked out of Parliament today. It was the Congress Party's most stinging rebuke to Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's five-month-old minority Government, an administration that cannot continue without Congress backing.

title: K Mart Profits Up in Period
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's third-largest retailer in terms of sales, yesterday reported net income of $402.3 million, or $2.01 a share, in its fourth quarter. That compares with a profit of $395.6 million, or $1.97 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier, excluding a 1989 provision for store modernization.

title: Panicky Need for Farm Land Leads Nicaraguan Peasants Into Fatal Clash
description: As peasants buried four of their number killed in a gun battle last week, they said it was the need for land that had led them into a fatal encounter with armed operators of a Sandinista-run farm cooperative.

title: Key Rates
Bush's Infant Care Plan Draws Bipartisan Fire
description: Lawmakers from both parties today denounced President Bush's proposal to finance a campaign against infant mortality in 10 cities, charging that it would reduce the money available for clinics and child health programs in hundreds of other cities and rural areas.

title: New Tainting of Cold Remedy Found
description: Federal investigators yesterday discovered a sixth tainted capsule of Sudafed decongestant in Washington State and said the tainted capsules found most recently may have been dropped at stores near exits of an Interstate highway.

title: From the Cities to the Coal Mines, Pain of Cutbacks Is Vivid; Virginia Beach: Will It Choose The 'T' Word?
description: Unlike almost anyone else in Virginia, officials here in the state's largest city are openly talking about raising taxes.

title: Food Notes
description: Fat-Free Cheeses

title: AFTER THE WAR: Chemical Arms; Export Curbs on Allies: Baker's Hard Choice
description: As he prepares for a postwar visit to the Middle East, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d faces a sensitive decision on whether to include Israel and Egypt on a chemical arms watch list.

title: New League Sets Dates
description: Mike Storen, commissioner of the new Global Basketball Association, announced yesterday that at least four American teams, plus European squads from the Republic of San Marino and Estonia in the Soviet Union, would play a 64-game schedule Nov. 27 through March 1992. The season will be followed by playoffs.

title: JET BEGAN TO DIVE IN LAST 6 SECONDS
description: Federal investigators said today that the instruments on a United Airlines jet recorded a normal flight until six seconds before the jet abruptly dived to the ground near the airport here on Sunday, killing all 25 people on board.

title: JUDGES SEE A CRISIS IN HEAVY BACKLOG OF ASBESTOS CASES
description: A committee of Federal judges has concluded that personal-injury asbestos cases are clogging the legal system and that the judiciary is "unable to cope" with the growing crisis.

title: A New Mideast Balance
description: Secretary of State James Baker says he is going to the Middle East to listen and consult, and not to present an American peace plan or impose solutions. But that is what all our Secretaries of State say en route to selling U.S. peace plans.

title: Cuts at First City
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said it had suspended its common and preferred stock dividends as part of a capital-strengthening plan. First City previously announced cost-reduction measures that include closings at non-Texas offices, sales of operations and personnel cuts for $40 million of annual savings. First City's stock tumbled $1.50 a share today, to $5.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 22.2 percent drop was the biggest of the day.

title: 3 Suing on Removal From School Board
description: The conflict between Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and neighborhood school boards flared up again yesterday when three former members of a Queens school board charged in court that they had been removed from their elected posts in violation of their constitutional rights.

title: United Airlines Certificates Priced to Yield Over 10%
description: A two-part financing by United Airlines totaling $198.9 million in equipment trust certificates was priced yesterday through Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: People
description: * Dean W. Proctor Jr. has joined Ayer Inc., New York, as an executive vice president and managing director of account service. * Jeff Johnson has joined Wells, Rich, Greene, New York, as executive vice president-director of new business development.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., an operator of movie theaters, and TPI Enterprises Inc., New York, an operator of restaurants and movie theaters, said their subsidiaries had formed the Exhibition Enterprises Partnership to operate movie theaters. * Baker Environmental Inc., a subsidiary of Michael Baker Corp., Beaver, Pa., an engineering company, signed a 10-year, $100 million contract with the Navy to provide environmental engineering services.

title: Major Sees Gorbachev and Is Reassured on Baltics
description: Offering a strong vote of confidence in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that his dismay over Soviet policy toward the Baltic republics had been eased by the Soviet leader's assurance that "the prospect of independence" was being extended to the rebellious republics.

title: How Children of Gay Parents Fit In at School; One Family's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Ameritech May Offer Credit Card
description: The Ameritech Corporation, the regional Bell company that provides local phone service in five Midwestern states, said yesterday that it was considering the possibility of offering a credit card and was holding discussions with potential partners.

title: Review/Theater; When Innocence Collides With Menace and Mayhem
description: In the roughly five years since Keith Reddin began spending more time writing than acting, he has produced a steady stream of black comedies about the underground of corruption, political and moral, that lurks just beneath the slick sitcom surface of American life. His plays, notably "Life and Limb" and "Rum and Coke," are unfailingly intelligent and are generally produced by the finest resident theaters in and outside New York. Yet Mr. Reddin has not so far caused a serious stir within the nonprofit theater, let alone with a larger public. He is perpetually on the verge.

title: Review/Television; For Young Black Men, A Struggle to Succeed
description: Although Dan Rather introduces tonight's well-reported edition of "48 Hours" as the stories of a few young black men in north Philadelphia "fighting not just to survive but to succeed," the program, at 8 on CBS , is too honest to be heartening. The disarray and despair in the Strawberry Hill neighborhood smother the individual successes like a fog through which specks of light can hardly break.

title: Virginia in Distress: Test for a New Governor -- A Special Report; Can Austerity Be Wilder's Path to Power?
description: L. Douglas Wilder has spent his 14 months as Governor of Virginia watching every politician's nightmare, a plunge in revenue.

title: Down-to-Earth Fare With Views of a Changing Metropolis
description: If you want to eat down-to-earth Cuban fare the way the locals do in Miami, you have to go to one of the counter-service sandwich shops like this one, where the specialty is thick slices of pork on chewy rolls, usually washed down with a beer. La Esquina de Tejas, which means corner of Texas, must refer to cowboy portions.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., the technology company, named Jay G. Kaplan president of the specialty business division for its engineered materials business. * Ernst & Young, New York, the accounting firm, named George Reese to head its practice in the Soviet Union.

title: Review/Fashion; Designers Show Off Lower-Priced Lines
description: When Krizia staged its "Made by Krizia" show here Monday night, it highlighted the fastest-developing area of fashion in Italy as well as in other countries. It focused for the first time on four of the company's subsidiary collections, emphasizing casual clothes like parkas, sweaters and jeans, and ending with evening clothes.

title: Trial to Go On Despite Death Of Witness Tied to Noriega
description: A Federal district judge has again refused to declare a mistrial in the drug conspiracy case against two co-defendants of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, saying there is still no evidence of foul play in the death of a crucial Government witness.

title: Tokyo Stocks Advance
description: Stocks in Tokyo were higher at the close of trading today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 469.51 points, or 1.81 percent, to 26,382.99.

title: 'Spanish Only' Bill Clears Hurdle in Puerto Rico
description: Dealing a blow to Puerto Rico's statehood movement, the Legislature has overwhelming approved a bill that would make Spanish the sole official language of this Caribbean island of 3.6 million people.

title: Virginia W. Milliken, Animal-Rights Advocate, 88
description: Virginia W. Milliken, an animal-rights advocate, died on Friday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 88 years old.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; IRAQ DISAVOWS ANNEXATION, PLEDGING TO REPAY KUWAIT; REBELLION MAY BE SUBSIDING
description: As the most populous section of Iraq seethed with revolt, the Baghdad radio said today that the Government of President Saddam Hussein had voided the annexation of Kuwait, which was announced after Iraq's conquest of the tiny emirate last Aug. 2.

title: Aaron Berkman, 90; Directed Y Art Center
description: Aaron Berkman, former director of the art center at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: Colleges Often Stymied In Selecting Presidents
description: Colleges and universities go through a rigorous selection process each year to choose the brightest students. But many are at loss when it comes to choosing a president.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. ROSLYN HOLLY FITCH, a fellow at the Center for Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience at Rutgers University, has received a $20,000 award for her research in understanding language development. The award, given by the Rita G. Rudel Foundation, supports scientists doing research in behavioral neurology.

title: Bonds Says He's Puzzled by Bad-Guy Image
description: Barry Bonds, the mercurial and sometimes temperamental Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder, admitted today that he unwittingly rubs many people the wrong way. But Bonds also admitted that he was at a loss as to how to change the perception that he is a "problem" for his team and for baseball.

title:
Real Estate;
A Big Shopping Mall in a Suburb of St. Louis Gets Bigger
description: ONE of the nation's largest shopping mall expansions is under way in Richmond Heights, an older suburb about 10 miles west of downtown St. Louis. The $215 million project will more than double the space in the Saint Louis Galleria, to 1.18 million square feet. The new stores are scheduled to open in August.

title: U.N. IS KINDER NOW TO SOUTH AFRICANS
description: When Jeremy B. Shearar became South Africa's chief delegate to the United Nations in 1988, he took over a mission that for decades had seemed like a besieged outpost in the heart of enemy territory.

title: Harry Whitfield Howze, Executive, 86
description: Harry Whitfield Howze, retired vice president of Esso International, died on Saturday at his home in Newtown Square, Pa. He was 86 years old.

title: From the Cities to the Coal Mines, Pain of Cutbacks Is Vivid; For the Poor, No Way to Go But Backward
description: Officials here in Scott County, the state's poorest, say the only way they can absorb the loss of state aid will be to give up badly needed fire trucks and defer repairs on the county's 15 schools.

title: D'Amato Girds for Senate Ethics Hearings
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York returned from the battleground of Kuwait today to face a more personal battle at home.

title: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; Iraq's Moves to Meet Conditions for Truce Termed Insufficient
description: Iraq's announcements still fall short of what the United States and its gulf war coalition partners want before they will agree to a formal cessation of hostilities, diplomats said today.

title: DEALS
description: HOCKEY

title: Timetable for the Build-Down
description: Thousands of American troops will be coming home within weeks, but tens of thousands more will probably have to remain for months. Page A16.

title: Judge Upholds Job Rights of Undocumented Aliens
description: A Federal judge has ruled that undocumented aliens can bring lawsuits under the 1964 Civil Rights Act maintaining that they are the victims of racial or sexual discrimination at work.

title: Unions at Sabena Agree to Layoffs
description: Management and unions at Sabena Belgian World Airlines have agreed to lay off 3,000 of the company's 11,000 workers in a plan to revitalize the national air carrier, a company official said. Most of the layoffs would be achieved through lowering the company's retirement age, said the official, who asked not to be named.

title: INSIDE
description: Trump Makes a Switch

title: The Pop Life
description: On the Charts at Last

title: Microwave Cooking
description: FEW things cook better in a microwave oven than broccoli. It stays a vivid green, and when it is arranged with the florets toward the center of the dish, the stalks become tender while the florets remain firm. Cooked broccoli can be used in stir-fried dishes, salads and other dishes, including the two recipes here, one hot and one cold.

title: Oliver, Armstrong Leave Reds' Camp
description: Joe Oliver, a catcher, and Jack Armstrong, a pitcher, walked out of the Cincinnati Reds spring training camp today to protest their renewed contracts.

title: Review/Television; A Gospel Music Sampler, Starring Patti LaBelle
description: In her usual role as a pop diva, Patti LaBelle's singing can be flamboyant and virtuosic to the point of campy hysteria. But as host and performer on "Going Home to Gospel," to be broadcast tonight at 8 o'clock on Channel 13, she's merely the best-dressed of more than a dozen belters who dedicate their rasps and swoops and hollers to a higher power; as the star, she appears in three different glittering gowns.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; U.S. to Give Israel $650 Million To Offset Costs of the Gulf War
description: After a week of haggling, the Bush Administration and Israel agreed today on a compromise aid package that will give Israel $650 million in cash to help cover its increased military and civil defense expenses during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Meadow Star's Debut Set
description: Leroy Jolley sent Meadow Star through her second brisk workout in a week today and then announced that the undefeated filly would make her 1991 debut on Friday in a six-and-a-half furlong allowance race here at Gulfstream Park.

title: Dinkins Administration to Ask City Workers to Defer Some Pay
description: The Dinkins administration will ask unions representing hundreds of thousands of city workers to defer part of their wages for at least three years to help balance next year's budget, top city officials said yesterday.

title: U.S.-Made Vehicle Sales Off 4.7% in Late February
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in late February, compared with a year earlier, auto makers reported today. Analysts said sales remained fairly weak, but not at the dismally low levels of January.

title: Trump Revises Project Plan For West Side
description: Standing at City Hall in the presence of old enemies eager to embrace him, Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had abandoned his plans for a Trump City on the Upper West Side, and would substitute a much smaller, mostly residential project and waterfront park.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We'll find out what Mr. Maxwell wants, and we'll deal with that. But I'm sure that we'll reach an agreement. We've got somebody here who wants to run a paper and stay in New York." -- George E. McDonald, union leader, on the sale of The Daily News. [ B2:6. ]

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of QUEEN ELIZABETH II's pet Welsh corgi dogs bit her left hand on Sunday, inflicting a wound that required three stitches to close. The accident occurred at Windsor Castle, a spokesman for Buckingham Palace said, when the Queen was trying to break up a dogfight.

title: Austin M. Brues, 85, A Radiation Biologist
description: Austin Moore Brues, a pioneer in radiation biology who studied the effects of the atomic bombs dropped on Japan, died Feb. 27 at his home in Hinsdale, Ill. He was 85 years old.

title: Space, in Proportion
description: At last, NASA has brought proportion to the grandiose program to build a permanently manned station in space. NASA's original goals were breathtakingly ambitious. The station was to serve as a launching pad for trips to the moon and Mars . . . a platform for observing the stars and planets, including the environment of planet Earth . . . a factory to produce exotic materials outside gravity . . . and a biomedical laboratory to study the effects of space on human life.

title: Gene Hill Sagan, 59, A Versatile Dancer And Choreographer
description: Gene Hill Sagan, resident choreographer of the Philadelphia Dance Company, died on Friday at Einstein Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 59 years old.

title: New Immunex Drug Wins U.S. Approval
description: The Immunex Corporation received approval today from the Food and Drug Administration to market a genetically engineered drug that increases the growth of infection-fighting white blood cells in cancer patients who have had bone marrow transplants.

title: Floyd Helps Rockets Set Back Nets
description: Sleepy Floyd scored 27 points tonight to lead the Houston Rockets past the Nets, 112-100.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: AMERICANS seem to have gone grill crazy in recent years. Indeed, grilling can impart a special flavor and texture to foods that cannot be duplicated on the stovetop. A good hot broiler, however, comes close.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. 100th Point for Recchi Mark Recchi scored his 35th goal and 100th point last night as the Pittsburgh Penguins set a team record with their 10th consecutive home victory, beating the Vancouver Canucks, 4-1. Mario Lemieux stretched his point-scoring streak to 11 games and Paul Coffey had three assists as the Penguins surpassed their mark for consecutive home victories set from Feb. 26 to April 5, 1975. Their last home loss was to the Rangers on Jan. 3. The Canucks, who lost their previous two games by 7-1 and 8-0, ended a drought of 156 minutes 24 seconds without a goal when newly acquired Geoff Courtnall scored at 14:29 of the third period.(AP) Red Wings 6, Nordiques 3: Jimmy Carson scored his eighth career hat trick, extending the Nordiques' streak without a victory to 11 games. The Red Wings have won three of their last four games.(AP) Blues 4, Whalers 1: Brett Hull scored twice, giving him a goal against each team in the league for the second consecutive season, and Adam Oates also had two goals to lead the visiting Blues.(AP) Capitals 3, Kings 3: Wayne Gretzky had three assists, including the 1,400th of his career, but Dmitri Khristich's power-play goal with just over seven minutes left gave Washington the tie. Washington, playing at home, ended the seven-game winning streak by Los Angeles, but the Kings extended their unbeaten streak to eight games.(AP) Maple Leafs 6, Bruins 3: Dave Hannan scored two goals to lead Toronto at home. Dave Ellett, Gary Leeman, Peter Zezel and Wendel Clark also scored for Toronto, which put the game away by outscoring Boston, 3-1, in the second period.(AP) WINTER UNIVERSITY GAMES American Skater Wins Michael Chack won the men's figure-skating event yesterday, giving the United States its first gold medal of the three-day-old event at Sapporo, Japan. Chack, who led after the original program at 0.5 points, finished at 1.5 after the free skating. Jung Sung-il of South Korea took the silver medal at 4.0, and Oleg Tataurov of the Soviet Union earned the bronze at 4.5. Japan has eight gold medals, the Soviet Union has two and Austria has one.(AP) TENNIS Sabatini Advances In her first match since early February, Gabriela Sabatini served well and put her groundstrokes consistently into the corners yesterday to beat 18-year-old Erika deLone in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Florida, 6-2, 6-2, held in Boca Raton. Steffi Graf, seeded first, won by walkover when her scheduled opponent, Cecilia Dahlman of Sweden, came down with food poisoning and had to be hospitalized. Claudia Porwik of Germany scored the day's biggest surprise by winning the final 8 points to beat Conchita Martinez of Spain, seeded fifth, 6-4, 3-6, 7-5.(AP)

title: New Yorkers Fear for Literacy as Libraries Cut Back
description: From the thick granite walls of Brooklyn's main library to the former take-out restaurant that is home to the Sedgwick Branch Library in the South Bronx, literacy is taking a beating in New York City's fiscal straits, and libraries are telling sad tales.

title: Lord Redesdale, British Executive, 58
description: Clement N. B. Mitford, Lord Redesdale, a vice president and director of corporate communications in Europe, Africa and the Middle East for the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 58 years old and died of heart failure, a spokesman for the bank said.

title: Videotape Appears to Show Police Beating
description: A bystander shot a videotape early Sunday of what appears to be a group of police officers beating a motorist with nightsticks and kicking him as other officers look on.

title: Albeck Leaves Bradley
description: Stan Albeck, whose teams have lost 20 games in each of the last two seasons, resigned yesterday as Bradley University's basketball coach, after three consecutive losing seasons. Ron Ferguson, Bradley's athletic director, said that although Albeck was not dismissed, university officials believed the decision was the right one. The 59-year-old Albeck is a former head coach of the Bulls, the Spurs and the Nets of the National Basketball Association. (AP)

title: Editorial Notebook; Kurds Are Not Pawns
description: As Saddam Hussein totters, Iraqi Kurds are striking boldly against the dictator whose warplanes once gassed their villages. Kurdish guerrillas yesterday claimed control of five northern towns. Though nervous Turks are dismayed by disorder on their frontier, Americans who want to cripple Iraq may find it tempting to seek independence for Kurds, who account for 15 percent of Iraq's 19 million people.

title: Brown Coach Resigns
description: Mike Cingiser, whose Brown basketball team just finished its ninth losing season in 10 years, resigned yesterday after being given the choice of quitting or being dismissed. Cingiser, who had been working on one-year contracts for the last two years, is the only coach to lead a Brown team to an Ivy League basketball championship and an N.C.A.A. tournament berth, in 1985. Cingiser's record this season was 11-15; in his 10 years at Brown, it was 93-170. (AP)

title: Hearts On Their Sleeves
description: Athletes might as well discard those traditional numbers on their uniforms. Why go around with No. 1 or No. 44 on their backs when they are judged, and judge themselves, on the basis of how much they earn?

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID ROCKEFELLER will pick up an award for the whole family in Washington next Wednesday, when the National Building Museum honors its efforts in building and in conservation. To highlight the family's contributions, the museum will open an exhibition on how they have created, enhanced and preserved special places.

title: A's Try to Lure Henderson
description: The Rickey Appreciation Fund was bulging today, but Rickey Henderson wasn't there to collect the money.

title: 4 Recant Statements Linking Bhutto's Husband to Killings
description: Four witnesses in a murder case against the husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today recanted confessions that they assert they were forced to make under torture.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Journalists; 26 Journalists Are Reported Missing on Road to Basra
description: As many as 26 journalists were reported missing today after entering southern Iraq to cover the civil unrest in the city of Basra, allied military officials said.

title: MCI Is Expecting Gains This Year
description: The MCI Communications Corporation expects to win more customers from competitors this year and to record better profit margins, a company official said. Michael Ozburn, investor relations director, said the company would continue its fight to win customers from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, its larger rival.

title: Power Crews Tackle Storm Damage
description: Amid rising temperatures and bright sun, power crews today attacked the damage from a weekend ice storm that knocked out electricity to nearly 300,000 homes and businesses across western and northern New York.

title: Congress Winks at a Bank Scandal
description: The Federal Reserve Board has finally cracked down on the high-flying Bank of Credit and Commerce International . The bank, based in Luxembourg, has agreed to cut its ties to Washington, D.C.'s largest bank and cease U.S. operations. B.C.C.I. pleaded guilty last year to laundering millions in drug money for, among others, Panama's deposed leader, Manuel Noriega.

title: Economic Scene; Chronic Poverty, Black and White
description: IS the "underclass" problem really just a black and Hispanic problem? It is a conclusion easily drawn, says Ronald Mincy, an economist at the Urban Institute, and not only by racists. Almost all the big-city neighborhoods plagued by chronic poverty and social decline are black or Hispanic ghettos. And it is these neighborhoods that have been the focus of study, not to mention handwringing, by policy analysts.

title: Bangladeshis Keep the Hard Edge Off Islam
description: When a fundamentalist Islamic party won enough seats in elections for Parliament recently to be courted as a governing coalition partner, many Bangladeshis began to think again about the relationship between their Bengali culture and their religion.

title: A Kind Place
description: When I was in Moscow I was mesmerized by shopping. One store for bread, another for vegetables, a third for meat. And three lines: the line to order, the line to pay, the line to pick up purchases. It was a system so inefficient that I could not believe the women around me were not enraged. Instead everyone shrugged, the Russian shrug that means: "Always has been. Always will be."

title: Deborah Zurkow Marries in Paris
description: Deborah Michal Zurkow and Laurent Pierre Debenedetti were married yesterday by Mayor Pierre-Christian Taittinger in the 16th Arrondissement municipal building in Paris. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Zurkow of Wilmington, Del. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. Marion J. Debenedetti and Dr. Pierre A. L. Debenedetti, both of Paris.

title: Tucker's 3-Point Feat Brings Knick Victory
description: Thanks to an improbable shot by Trent Tucker, the Knicks continued their surge tonight.

title: Nicklaus Entering Field Of Sports Management
description: Jack Nicklaus announced yesterday that he would be starting a sports management branch of his company, Golden Bear International.

title: Treasury Acts to Curb Tax Benefits in Bailouts
description: The Treasury Department said today that it would seek to eliminate certain tax benefits that have been claimed by the owners of 199 savings associations sold in 1988 by the Government.

title: Defense Accuses U.S. of Trying to Ensnare Gotti
description: Defense lawyers charged yesterday that Government agents had improperly tried to lure John Gotti into a bid-rigging conspiracy in the construction industry.

title: Metro Matters; Five Years Later, Corruption Fades From Memory
description: Concrete-colored patches of paint on sidewalks around the Bronx County Building are eroding to reveal a red-stenciled imperative. Like stigmata, two words have materialized beneath the camouflage: "Simon Resign."

title: Kaiser Delays Stock Offering
description: Kaiser Aluminum, a subsidiary of Maxxam Inc., said today that it had indefinitely postponed its previously announced initial public offering.

title: Dvorak Doesn't Live Here Anymore
description: Two years ago, Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan bought a small row house on East 17th Street. It hoped to demolish the house and replace it with an AIDS hospice. If everything had gone according to plan, the hospice could by now have been caring for patients. But community residents objected. They and others asked the Landmarks Commission to save the house because Antonin Dvorak, the famous composer, lived in it for 3 of his 63 years.

title: Great Art Works That Really Work
description: GREAT works of art needn't be confined to the walls of museums. It is now possible to own a bit of the Mona Lisa on a wall clock, a Picasso bath towel or a Kandinsky rug.

title: Equal Opportunity for Black Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Indian Government Falls Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar resigned after the collapse of the coalition that had allowed his small party to govern for five months. Page A3. Head of World Bank Leaving Barber Conable is expected to be succeeded at the bank, which dispenses aid to poor nations, by Lewis Preston, formerly of J.P. Morgan. Page D1. Pretty Shoes, Painful Feet A survey found that 88 percent of women wore shoes at least a size small. Not surprisingly, 80 percent had foot problems. Health, page B11.

title: WINNIE MANDELA ACCUSED BY YOUTH
description: The stalled trial of Winnie Mandela on kidnapping and assault charges lurched ahead today when a prosecution witness came forward to testify that the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela had repeatedly slapped, punched and whipped him and three companions who were abducted to her Soweto home in late 1988.

title: Rare Air Burst Examined in Jet Crash
description: Federal investigators looking into the airliner crash that killed 25 people here have recovered important parts of the jet, interviewed witnesses and learned the plane's speed from a data recorder. And, one by one, the most obvious theories about the cause of the crash on Sunday, including an abrubt wind shift, have been tossed aside.

title: Monarch Capital
description: The Monarch Capital Corporation said it was talking with its principal creditors and regulatory authorities on a plan to restructure its debt that would involve separating the Monarch Life Insurance Company and several other insurance-related units from Monarch Capital. The company said no agreement had been reached on a plan.

title: For One Garden, Decades of Devotion
description: THE ravishing gardens around the old brick castle at Sissinghurst in Kent, about 100 miles southeast of here, are among the best known in the world. Scarcely less celebrated are their founders, Vita Sackville-West and Sir Harold Nicolson.

title: A President's 'Misfortune'
description: To The Home Section: Enid Nemy's sensitive account of the social disfavor refracted upon single people [ "Society Looks Askance at the Family of One," Feb. 28 ] recalls an incident reported of Chester Alan Arthur, the only bachelor President of the United States (1881-85).

title: Review/Theater;   Deceptions Defining Soviet Life
description: There is a certain pleasure in being able to savor a play, or any work for that matter, without considering its political impact because it was banned in Moscow or Boston or anywhere else. The pleasure in this instance is compounded by the creative acting and staging of "A Teacher of Russian" by the Moscow Theater-Studio in its New York presentation at the Triplex Theater on Chambers Street.

title: Paraguay Trailblazer: The Would-Be Mayor
description: With curly hair bouncing off the shoulders of a batik shirt, Mina Feliciangeli campaigns for mayor on a platform of neighborhood day-care centers, democratic socialism and "Yankees out of the gulf."

title: Hussein, Battling Uprising, Names Cousin as Internal Security Chief
description: Moving to stifle the worst uprising he has faced, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today put internal security in the hands of a trusted cousin who oversaw Kuwait's occupation and reportedly used chemical weapons against restive Kurds in 1988.

title: City Council Proposes Increasing Its Budget
description: The finance committee of the New York City Council, in anticipation of the Council's expansion later this year to 51 members from 35, yesterday approved a $25 million operating budget, a 14.1 percent increase over the current $21.9 million budget.

title: Review/Television; A High School Under the Microscope
description: The small and big pleasures, problems and perplexities of seniors at Glenbard West High School in Glen Ellyn, Ill., are the stuff of "Yearbook," the engaging new Fox Broadcasting series that begins at 8:30 tonight on Channel 5, right after "The Simpsons." Poking into emotional moments -- the choosing of a homecoming queen, a meeting between a pregnant teen-ager and her shaky boyfriend -- the camera produces snapshots of what it is like to be young these days, at least in a Chicago suburb. The students are neatly introduced and the segments bridged by photo sessions, apparently for the class yearbook.

title: Handicapping the Big East
description: William C. Rhoden: Three Reasons for Syracuse Syracuse will win for three reasons: Eugene William Owens. Billy Owens leads the Orange in scoring (23.5 points per game), rebounding (11.4) and steals (2.6). Beyond that, Owens routinely does the kinds of things that make his teammates better. He sometimes even coaches when the Orange get out of control. Syracuse's backcourt of Michael Edwards and Adrian Autry is rivaled only by Seton Hall's. Malcolm Moran: Seton Hall by Elimination Syracuse's demise has become a Madison Square Garden tradition. Villanova won't do it. Pittsburgh always seems to go home too early. St. John's and Connecticut have to play Providence and Georgetown, teams that must win Friday for an N.C.A.A. bid. That leaves Seton Hall and Boston College, the doormat. If only Marco Lokar were around to see this.

title: Army Pilot's Death Stuns Her New Jersey Neighbors
description: This suburb of 8,000 prides itself on its sense of family and on its local heroes, like the astronaut Wally Schirra, for whom a small park near the heart of town is dedicated. This week Maj. Marie T. Rossi joined those heroes.

title: Charges Outlined in Health Lab Case
description: Congressional investigators testified today that a researcher at the National Institutes of Health had violated Federal laws, and said the acting director of the institutes acknowledged that its investigation of the matter was mishandled.

title: Many Women Buy Foot Trouble With Fashionable High Heels
description: The vernal equinox is a mere two weeks away, and warm-weather hemlines will be short and shoe heels often high to display a woman's newly liberated legs. But for many women, the sexy little pumps of springtime demand that they play a modern version of Cinderella's stepsisters, as they patch their feet with corn pads, bunion cushions and moleskin bands to ease the pain from shoes that truly feel like ill-fitting glass.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Plans to End Clear-Cutting in California
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said today that it would phase out clearcutting of trees on its California timberlands by 1994. Lumber industry officials and environmental groups said it appeared to be the first time a major timber company in California, and perhaps the nation, had given up the practice, which has been strongly criticized by environmentalists.

title: Market Place; Tokyo's Prospects Depend on Rates
description: THE swift conclusion of the Persian Gulf war has cleared up a big uncertainty hanging over the world economy. But in Japan, the removal of that question mark has merely permitted investors to focus on a host of other knotty uncertainties that are leaving the outlook here uncharacteristically muddy.

title: Judge Refuses Bail for Bakker
description: A Federal district judge today decided against bond for the television evangelist Jim Bakker, denying him the freedom he had sought until the end of next month, when he is to appear in court for resentencing.

title: Personal Health
description: Niacin may be on the verge of joining vitamins C, B-6 and E, beta-carotene and calcium as a widely hailed micronutrient miracle. This B vitamin, a pharmaceutical orphan without a corporate sponsor, has been described as the most cost-effective treatment for high levels of cholesterol that are not sufficiently reduced by a low-fat diet. But at least in some forms and amounts, niacin has also caused numerous and occasionally severe cases of nonviral hepatitis. Niacin as a Vitamin

title: Building for Soviet Officers In Baltic Republic Is Bombed
description: A bomb blast slightly damaged a building housing Soviet Army officers and their families today in the Baltic republic of Latvia, the independent news agency Postfactum reported.

title: Doctor Says He Gave Patient Drug to Help Her Commit Suicide
description: In a rare disclosure, a Rochester doctor has told how he prescribed the barbiturates that a 45-year-old female patient needed to kill herself after she refused treatment for a severe form of leukemia.

title: Review/Dance; A High-Energy Feast of New Choreography at the Joffrey's Gala
description: The three world premieres for the Joffrey's 35th anniversary gala on Tuesday night were commissioned, as such things happen nowadays, by Absolut Vodka, and the result was an absolute grand slam.

title: Last Roar Of the Bunion Derby
description: He'll be 84 years old on July 10 but his eyes were as bright as his blue running suit, his voice as spry as his white sneakers. Harry Abrams is a treasure of American sports archeology.

title: Japan's U.S.-Made Cars: Off to Europe
description: Two Japanese automobile makers said they would export some of their American-made cars to Europe. The first shipment of the Honda Motor Company's American-manufactured Accord wagons for Europe is to leave Jacksonville, Fla., next week. The wagon, the first Honda car designed, engineered and manufactured in the United States, will be available in Britain, France, Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Switzerland by next month, a spokesman said.

title: Draft Means Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The Principles of a Form of Madness
description: Making Shapely Fiction

title: But Abandoned-Car Laws Must Also Protect the Innocent
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Mary Lou Quinlan has been named a senior vice president-management supervisor and Todd Brenard has been named a vice president at DDB Needham, New York. * Beverly Beaudoin, Jeanne Chinard and Anne MacDonald have been named executive vice presidents at Ayer Inc., New York. * Betty Fitterman has been named executive vice president-creative director at Lintas New York. * James Bourdganis has been promoted to vice president-internal operations manager at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising. * Geoff Currier has joined Wells, Rich, Greene Inc. as senior vice president in its creative department. * Jack Dickman has been named vice president-national sales manager at USA Today. * Lorraine Thelian has been named director of the Washington office of Ketchum Public Relations.

title: The Last Time Japan Tried to Raise Birthrate; What of Abortion?
description: To the Editor:

title: After 20 Lost Years, Arverne Skeptically Awaits Renewal
description: From the elevated A train rattling through Arverne, Queens, one sees a vast new town stretching along the oceanfront below -- shopping malls bustling with people, thousands of town houses, ribbons of newly carved roads, parks and playgrounds.

title: Citicorp's $600 Million Stock Sale
description: Citicorp announced last night that it had sold $600 million in preferred stock to a broad group of investors and had thus completed one of the key portions of its plan to strengthen its finances.

title: Smoking and Early Coronaries
description: A person who smokes two packs of cigarettes a day is likely to have a heart attack 11 years earlier than a nonsmoker, a new study says.

title: India's Government Quits and Calls for New Elections
description: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's Government resigned today and recommended new general elections as India's political parties braced themselves for a second nationwide ballot in less than two years.

title: Carnegie Announces 1991 Season
description: Carnegie Hall announced the first season of its second century yesterday, taking particular pride in the three concerts by the Berlin Philharmonic in June under Bernard Haitink, in a two-concert cycle of the Mozart violin concertos with Gidon Kremer and the German Chamber Philharmonic Orchestra, in the American debut of the Saito Kinen Orchestra of Japan conducted by Seiji Ozawa, and in a performance by Neville Marriner and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields of Mozart's Requiem and "Vesperae Solennes de Confessore," to occur on the 200th anniversary of the composer's death.

title: Plaster as the Frosting on the Cornice
description: MOST days Bob Kaye walks to work. An ornamental plasterer, Mr. Kaye lives in a turn-of-the-century brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Many of his jobs are in nearby houses with elaborate plaster ceiling medallions, moldings and wall ornaments in need of restoration and repair.

title: Agriculture Nomination Gains
description: As expected, the Senate Agriculture Committee today approved the nomination of Representative Edward Madigan, Republican of Illinois, to be Secretary of Agriculture. The nomination was sent to the full Senate, where it is expected to win confirmation easily. The committee's approval was by voice vote, with no one expressing opposition. Mr. Madigan would succeed Clayton K. Yeutter, who has become chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: Judge Favors Apple Stand On Copyright
description: A Federal judge today dismissed two critical defenses offered by Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard in the software copyright-infringment lawsuit filed against them by Apple Computer Inc.

title: U.S. IN SHOWDOWN WITH CALIFORNIA ON NURSING HOMES
description: The Bush Administration ordered more than 100 investigators to California today to inspect nursing homes after Federal officials said the state had openly defied a Federal law setting more stringent standards for long-term care of the elderly.

title: Arabs Renew Protests in Israel; One Killed
description: After six weeks of enforced calm, Palestinians renewed their protests against Israeli occupation today. A general strike was called in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, riots broke out in several places and within hours one Palestinian was shot dead by Israeli troops.

title: Johnny Revolta, Pro Golfer, 79
description: Johnny Revolta, a golfer who won 19 Professional Golf Association tour events and 22 state tournaments between 1932 and 1952, died on Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: Nicaraguan Aide Says Killer Of Ex-Contra Might Be Dead
description: The man who killed a former rebel leader last month might himself be dead, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

title: The Great Scud-Patriot Mystery
description: The Patriot missile batteries hailed as the technological star of our Persian Gulf victory -- may or may not have stopped incoming Scud warheads.

title: International Energy Agency Ends Emergency Oil Sales
description: The International Energy Agency, a group of 21 industrial nations, decided today to end emergency sales of oil from government strategic reserves, a program instituted to insure sufficient supplies during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Lord Penney, 81, Atomic Scientist And Father of British Bomb, Dies
description: Lord Penney, the father of the British atomic bomb in the 1950's and an adviser on earlier American atomic projects, died on Sunday, his family announced today. He was 81 years old.

title: Alexander E. Fox, Lawyer, 84
description: Alexander E. Fox, a lawyer and a former New York State insurance official, died on Friday at the Cliffside Nursing Home in Flushing, Queens. He was 84 years old and had been a longtime resident of the Bronx.

title: Ian McLellan Hunter, Screenwriter, Was 75
