description: Ian McLellan Hunter, a screen and television writer who won an Academy Award for the 1953 film "Roman Holiday," died on Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Finding to Be Reviewed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is reviewing a finding that Rich Dale, an assistant basketball coach at Missouri, was guilty of unethical conduct.

title: George Patton, 70, A Leading Architect Of Landscape Sites
description: George Erwin Patton, a prominent landscape architect, died on Wednesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 70 years old.

title: Recycling Is Solution For Old Paint Leftovers
description: Before Bill McQuiggan became part of the solution, he was part of the problem. A paint salesman for 15 years, Mr. McQuiggan knew only too well how much unused paint ends up in landfills and how toxins can affect groundwater.

title: 37 Are Reported Killed In Soviet Ethnic Clash
description: Rival ethnic groups with armored vehicles and automatic weapons have clashed in the Soviet republic of Georgia, killing at least 37 people and wounding 150, the Soviet Vice President, Gennadi I. Yanayev, said today.

title: Labor Leaders Harshly Criticize Dinkins on Pay-Deferral Memo
description: Major municipal labor leaders denounced Mayor David N. Dinkins in harsh personal terms yesterday and called his Budget Director a liar for telling a bond rating agency last month that the unions had begun negotiations to defer part of the wage increases they had just won and not finished ratifying.

title: Enterra Gets New Chief As It Seeks Kuwait Jobs
description: The Enterra Corporation, a Houston-based oilfield services company in a position to profit from reconstruction in the Persian Gulf, yesterday named a new president and chief executive, D. Dale Wood.

title: Midway Cuts Fares
description: Midway Airlines Inc. cut its lowest one-way fares 30 percent to 45 percent for tickets sold until next Tuesday to stimulate vacation travel. The airline's lowest one-way fares will range from $29 to $129. The highly restricted fares are valid for travel from April 1 through July 7.

title: Shooting of Kuwaiti Lawyer Has the Opposition Afraid
description: An assassination attempt last week against a prominent critic of the Kuwaiti Government has created a climate of fear among other dissidents, who asserted today that Government loyalists were using violence and intimidation to smother a postwar movement toward democracy.

title: 'Aspects,' the Musical That Had Everything, And Lost Everything
description: When "Aspects of Love" opened on Broadway last year with $12 million already earned in advance ticket sales, the expectation was that a new hit was in the making. The show was written by Andrew Lloyd Webber, who seemed flop-proof, having already written a string of hits, including "Evita," "Cats," and "Phantom of the Opera."

title: Recession Steals Into a Stronghold of Wealth
description: The Rev. Fred Baldwin, the tweed-clad priest at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church, takes tea every day at 4 in the rectory, an Edwardian country house down the hill from the Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: Senate Panel Backs Futures Trading Bill
description: A compromise that would leave regulation of hybrid financial products, part security and part futures contract, in the hands of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was approved by a Senate panel today.

title: Rally Isn't Curing Wall St. Blues
description: After months of gloom, investors returned to buying stocks with a passion in the first months of 1991, sending the Dow Jones industrial average climbing at a giddy rate -- a rise of more than 500 points since mid-January. Investors, who had pulled back from the market as losses spread in 1990, are suddenly making money again.

title: Want Ads Off in Canada
description: Canada's help-wanted index for February tumbled 5.1 percent, extending a slide that started 22 months ago. Unemployment in Canada is at 9.7 percent and is expected to rise to 10 percent when February figures are released on Friday. The help-wanted index, which monitors advertisements for jobs in 20 Canadian cities, is an early indicator of the demand for labor, the Government agency Statistics Canada said.

title: Owens and Murdock Are Hardly the Only Stars in Big East Tourney
description: While Billy Owens and Eric Murdock are the Big East's best-known players, they are only two stars in a conference packed with tremendous individual talent. Following are some of the conference's brighter lights: Boston College

title: 'Last in Line for the Exit'
description: As USAir Flight 1493 touched down in Los Angeles on the evening of Feb. 1, I was looking forward to a pleasant weekend. About five seconds later, I felt a sickening crunch as our Boeing 737, moving at about 100 miles per hour, collided with a SkyWest commuter plane.

title: Molded in Schools, She Helps Mold Them
description: For Sandra Feldman -- who grew up poor in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn; whose father, a milkman, gave up playing the violin when his fingers became too thick from manual labor and whose mother worked in bakeries when she could -- school was "a lifeline, opening the whole world to me." It was, she would later say, the route "to making a real somebody of yourself."

title: Fernandez Warns of Impact of Cuts
description: Maneuvering to win state legislators to his side, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday painted a gloomy picture of life in New York City's schools if budget cuts of $650 million that the Mayor and the Governor have proposed are made.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Roger G. Weill, a stamp dealer, referred incorrectly in some copies to the British colony that issued a pair of rare stamps he bought. It was British Guiana, not Bermuda.

title: The Sitcom, Collapsible but Stylish
description: THE Sitcom chair is a hybrid. Like a camp stool, the steel and canvas chair collapses to form a long cylinder. But like a director's chair or a butterfly chair, it is stylish enough to be in a living room or study.

title: Warily, Labor at Daily News Awaits Talks
description: The leader of the group of unions striking The Daily News said yesterday that the unions were prepared to make significant concessions to the British publisher Robert Maxwell to save the newspaper and also, of course, as many union jobs as possible.

title: BUSH, URGING WIDER PEACE, HINTS AT PRESSURE ON ISRAEL TO YIELD LAND FOR SECURITY
description: President Bush said tonight that he would immediately begin bringing American troops home from the Persian Gulf. But he pledged to maintain a strong diplomatic presence in the Middle East and to redouble efforts to solve the stubborn Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Arab Nations Propose Forming Peacekeeping Force for Gulf
description: Foreign ministers from Arab nations that went to war with Iraq proposed today that additional Egyptian and Syrian troops be sent to the Persian Gulf, as the nucleus of an Arab peacekeeping force that would replace United States and Western forces.

title: Hussein, Battling Uprising, Names Cousin as Internal Security Chief
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 6 -- Moving to stifle the worst uprising he has faced, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today put internal security in the hands of a trusted cousin who oversaw Kuwait's occupation and reportedly used chemical weapons against restive Kurds in 1988.

title: Fire Leaves Dozens Homeless
description: A fire gutted three apartment buildings here today, leaving 25 families homeless, officials said. Five neighboring communities sent equipment and firefighters to quell the blaze, which fire officials believe started in the basement of 309 29th Street, said a city official.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: U.A.W. Local Vote Due on Mazda Pact
description: The United Automobile Workers union Local 3000 will vote on Monday on a tentative contract with Mazda Motor Manufacturing (U.S.A.) Inc. Meetings are set for Friday for the 2,900 members of the local, the only U.A.W.-represented work force at a Japanese-owned assembly plant in the United States. The plant is in Flat Rock, about 30 miles south of Detroit.

title: Kathie Lee Gifford's Self-Spoofing Rise to the Top
description: Just in case you missed Friday's "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee," the syndicated talk show starring Regis Philbin and Kathie Lee Gifford, here's what happened when Regis plugged Kathie Lee's singing gig at the cabaret, Rainbow and Stars, running two shows nightly through March 16.

title: 'Mother of Battles' Mistranslates Arabic
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Morgan Officer Is Seen As Next World Bank Chief
description: Barber B. Conable Jr. told associates today that he would not seek a second five-year term as president of the 155-nation World Bank, the largest dispenser of aid to developing countries.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Raymond C. Cherko and Ralph C. Schauss senior vice presidents. * Bombay Co., Fort Worth, a specialty retailer of home furnishings, said Carson R. Thompson would relinquish the title of chief executive but remain chairman. Robert E. M. Nourse, who has been president and chief operating officer, will become chief executive.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, is offering $200 million in 9 1/2 percent debentures due in 2021 through Stephens Inc. The debentures are noncallable for five years. * Associates Corp. of North America, a unit of Ford Motor Co., is offering $300 million in 8.80 percent notes due in 1996 at 99.65 to yield 8.887 percent through Morgan Stanley & Co. Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Becton, Dickinson & Co., Franklin Lakes, N.J., is offering $100 million in 8.80 percent noncallable notes due in 2001 at 99.732 to yield 8.84 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million in debt securities. * Clayton Homes Inc., Knoxville, Tenn., has filed for $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011 and two million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Conagra Inc., Omaha, is offering $400 million in 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 2021 at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are noncallable and rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P. * FCC National Bank, a unit of the First Boston Corp., is offering $100 million in 8 percent noncallable notes due in 1994 at 99.581 to yield 8.16 percent through Lehman Brothers. The notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * General Motors Corp. is offering $600 million in 8.80 percent senior notes due in 2021 at a price of 99.933 to yield 8.812 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. The securities can be sold back to the company in the seventh year at par. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P. * Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. is offering $100 million in 8 1/8 percent subordinated bank notes due in 1996 at an initial price of 99.41 to yield 8.27 percent through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable notes are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P. * Shell Oil Co. has filed a $300 million shelf offering of debt securities. * Spacehab Inc., Washington, has obtained a $64 million five-year commercial bank loan from Chase Manhattan Bank N.A. Common Stock * First Brands Corp., Danbury, Conn., a consumer products company, has filed for 10.5 million common shares through the First Boston Corp. * Chiron Co., Emeryville, Calif., is offering two million common shares at $57.50 a share through Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Iran Raises Oil Output
description: Iran said today that it was increasing its oil output by 100,000 barrels a day. The Iranian press agency quoted the oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, as saying that as a result of "recent improvements," Iran's production would "increase by 100,000 barrels a day in just a few days' time." Iranian production in February stood at 3.1 million barrels daily, according to the International Energy Agency.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Calgene Inc., Davis, Calif., an agribusiness biotechnology company, and Novamont, a chemical-products company, have entered into a product development and marketing agreement. Novamont also bought $3 million in Calgene preferred stock. * Denison Mines Ltd., Toronto, will cut about 400 jobs from its work force of 1,060 at its Elliot Lake uranium mine in June.

title: Patrick J. Gilligan, Industrialist, 64
description: Patrick J. Gilligan, president of Valley Industries Inc., a steel company based in St. Louis, died on Monday at his home in St. Louis Hills, Mo. He was 64 years old.

title: Non-Designer Show House to Toast Absent Friends
description: NO one would think of calling them amateurs, except perhaps in this setting. A fashion designer, a writer, an architect, a movie set designer, several chefs, a florist and an artist -- all heavy hitters in their fields -- have become decorators for a day.

title: Luring Tourists Back to the Middle East
description: WITH the war in the Persian Gulf over, various countries nearby will soon begin new advertising campaigns to win back tourists.

title: Discovery's Launching Is On Despite Cracks
description: The space shuttle Atlantis will carry an astronomical observatory into orbit as planned next month despite two hairline cracks on door hinges, the space agency said today.

title: Rise in Anti-Gay Crimes Is Reported in New York
description: Violence aimed at homosexuals rose sharply in six American cities last year, including a 65 percent increase in attacks reported in New York City, according to a study released yesterday by a gay-rights advocacy group.

title: Picassos to Walk On (No Hobnails, Please)
description: UNLIKE his father, Claude Picasso does not make art. But he has designed eight boldly colored rugs. Some have segments that can be tied together; others juxtapose materials like wool and leather.

title: Barfield Climbing Walls Over Fences
description: From home plate, the wall in left-center field at Yankee Stadium looks amazingly distant, as if it would take a subway ride just to get there. No one knows this better than Jesse Barfield, who has spent nearly two seasons trying to reach it with his bat.

title: Investigator and Defense Spar in Triangle Murder
description: When Vincent Parco, the prosecution's chief witness in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus, left the courtroom today after five days of cross-examination, jurors might have been left with more insight into the Manhattan private investigator than the crime.

title: Calendar: Jewelry And Quilts
description: Alliance Auction Fabbri Mansion, 7 East 95th Street; (212) 677-7618 or (212) 260-6778.

title: Guilty Plea in Arms Deal
description: A former marketing executive for the Unisys Corporation admitted today that he had conspired to obtain secret Pentagon procurement information while his company was competing for a Defense Department contract.

title: Events: Greenery and Brownstones
description: Trees in the City New York City Street Tree Consortium, 44 Worth Street (Church Street); (212) 227-1887.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "By now, it should be plain to all parties that peacemaking in the Middle East requires compromise. At the same time, peace brings real benefits to everyone. We must do all that we can to close the gap between Israel and the Arab states and between Israelis and Palestinians." -- President Bush. [ A8:3. ]

title: SmithKline Profit Up 71%
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American health and household products company, said today that its fourth-quarter net profit soared 71 percent.

title: General Cinema Rises by 43.8%
description: The General Cinema Corporation reported today that its profits increased 43.8 percent in the first quarter, helped by improved business at its movie theaters.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: COVERING an unfinished ceiling with drywall, or wallboard, is not easy, but it is the only practical way for amateurs to achieve a smooth ceiling that can be painted. The alternative, plastering, is a job for skilled professionals.

title: Utility Financing By Austin, Tex.
description: The City of Austin, Tex., tentatively priced $143.86 million in combined utility system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.05 percent for bonds due in 2021 through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: The Last Time Japan Tried to Raise Birthrate
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Rock; Melodies Amid Rant, Thoughts Amid Rage
description: Plenty of bands talk about making music for "the people." Fugazi means it. The band keeps its prices low, $5 for tickets to its New York shows at the Marquee on Monday and Tuesday nights and $9 for full-length CD's on its Dischord label (which might make people wonder why major labels can't do the same thing). While such prices suggest amateur efforts, Fugazi offers anything but. Its songs are focused, intelligent, hard-nosed and utterly distinctive.

title: Terreri Inspires Devils' Rally for Tie
description: Chris Terreri's solid performance in goal tonight inspired the Devils to rally for a 3-3 tie with the Sabres, which ended a losing streak at two games.

title: The Gulf Gulf
description: Every morning for weeks, people on the bus would talk openly about the war and think nothing of it when strangers eagerly chimed in. War energized daily life. The news was harsh, telling of hostages, Scud horrors, bomb damage, and now, missing journalists. The electrifying reality transcended day-to-day reality. And then, clang! it was over, leaving people exultant at the quick triumph, joyful that there were few allied casualties and also, somehow -- well, glum.

title: Coach Is Interviewed
description: Sven-Goran Eriksson, Sweden's top soccer coach, said he had been in contact with the United States Soccer Federation about a possible job as head coach of the national team.

title: 35 Prisoners Freed and Flown to Hospital Ship in Gulf
description: Thirty-five allied prisoners of war, 15 of them American, were flown from Baghdad to a hospital ship in the Persian Gulf today. Some had suffered injuries when their aircraft went down, officials said, and some had been maltreated by their captors.

title: Electric and Water Bonds Priced by Riverside, Calif.
description: The City of Riverside, Calif., yesterday tentatively priced $118 million in electric and water revenue bonds with yields up to 6.98 percent for an issue due in 2015 through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Mets Line Up To Talk of The Order
description: Bud Harrelson, the manager who has claimed communication as his greatest strength, was unquestionably taken aback by the reception given his first significant message of the spring. Harrelson, who had thought long and hard in creating what he considered the ideal lineup, announced it quietly only to have it send static crackling throughout his clubhouse.

title: Mysterious Fireball Across Skies Leaves A Trail of Questions
description: It zoomed across the night sky early yesterday, a greenish-red fireball. Airplane pilots radioed that it seemed to be hovering over New York City. Or Philadelphia. A baker in Absecon, N.J., worried that it was a scud missile. And then, it was gone.

title: Caesareans Favored for Babies with Spine Defects
description: Babies with a common and often devastating birth defect, spina bifida, are much less likely to be paralyzed if they are delivered by Caesarean, a new study has found.

title: Iraq Closes Window to Outside World
description: Iraq's decision yesterday to expel Western correspondents from Baghdad closes one of the few remaining windows on life in the battered Iraqi capital.

title: Bridge
description: A minor procedural difference between social and tournament play concerns the manner in which dummy's cards are played. The social player reaches across the table, slightly increasing the chance that the opponent will get a glimpse of his own cards. The tournament player, however, announces the card he wants and the dummy is physically involved.

title: Judge Leaves the Way Open for Further Bidding on FNN
description: A bankruptcy judge left the door open yesterday for a bidding war for the troubled Financial News Network Inc.

title: 43 Killed in Crash of Venezuelan Airliner
description: A Venezuelan DC-9 airliner strayed off course and crashed into a mountain in western Venezuela, killing all 43 people on board, an airline spokesman said today.

title: Calling Home, Ex-P.O.W.'s Tell How They Survived It All
description: One of the Americans just freed from captivity in Iraq told his mother that he was roughed up during an interrogation by the Iraqi secret police, his mother said yesterday, but another of the former prisoners said he owed his life to his captors.

title: Michael T. Modny, 74,An Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Dr. Michael T. Modny, an internationally known orthopedic surgeon who held seven United States patents for inventions of surgical pins and nails, died on Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: Transcript of President Bush's Address on End of the Gulf War
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address last night to a joint session of Congress, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley's introduction, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: McEnroe Eliminated By Unseeded Grabb
description: Although John McEnroe's mind is in perpetual overdrive, his body occasionally lags behind and acts its age. His wrist refuses to instill his volleys with their vaunted sting. His feet seem disinclined to chase yet another tennis ball. His shoulder shrinks away from his service motion.

title: Save Gasoline a Better Way
description: The best way to reduce the use of fuel and clean up the atmosphere is for Congress to pass a stiff energy tax. But the Administration's national energy strategy virtually ignores tax hikes or any other conservation measure, an omission that many in Congress rightly want to reverse.

title: New Australian Coin
description: Australia introduced a gold coin today weighing a kilogram, or 2.2 pounds, which it says is the largest coin in the world. The Nugget, made of 99.99 percent gold, has a face value of 10,000 Australian dollars (about $7,700).

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A8-12

title: Brazilian Troops Kill 3 Colombian Guerrillas
description: Brazilian troops killed three Colombian guerrillas on Tuesday in a fire fight in the Amazon jungle near the Colombian border, the Brazilian Army said today.

title: U.S. Hints at Chemical Arms Bunker in Libya
description: The United States suspects that Libya is digging a bunker near its Rabta chemical weapons plant to shield chemicals and bomb components from aerial attack, but so far lacks solid proof to back up its beliefs, American officials said today.

title: Review/Fashion; In Italy, Homey Touches Mix With Sheer Artistry
description: The latest presentations of fall ready-to-wear clothes here have not offered earth-shattering commentaries on the world fashion situation. In formal shows and in showrooms this week, designers have introduced touches of whimsy or expressed the dignity of Italian artistry. It is the homey side of fashion news.

title: A Crown Of Ribbons For Britain
description: IN 1992 Queen Elizabeth II will celebrate the 40th anniversary of her accession, and the British will see a new emblem, a crown of intertwined gray, red, blue and yellow ribbons.

title: Memories Made Marketable
description: PARAMOUNT PICTURES has put a new spin on product licensing. Next year the company will introduce clocks, dishes, linen and stationery that do not tout a new movie, but instead nostalgically recall an earlier Hollywood, when movies were shown in Art Deco palaces and men wore top hats and tails.

title: Detective in Gotti Case Fined by Department
description: A New York City detective who was accused of helping to alert the reputed crime boss John Gotti to a listening device hidden in a Gambino crime family office has agreed to pay a $5,000 fine and will retire with full pension rights, the police said yesterday.

title: Perils to Conservatives In a Conservative Court
description: In its ruling this week on punitive damages, the Supreme Court gave new content to the adage that people should be careful what they wish for -- just in case their wishes come true.

title: MAN IS ARRAIGNED IN COURT SHOOTING
description: A man who described himself as a foe of abortion tried to kill a California Superior Court judge because of the judge's recent decision ordering a convicted child abuser to use birth control, the authorities said today.

title: That Good-for-Nothing Car Is Good for a Laugh
description: As eastern Germany spirals toward economic collapse, people who live here have found a way to escape from the onrushing specter of unemployment and social upheaval.

title: A Grand Exit For Trash
description: EVEN a marine transfer station, where garbage trucks dump their contents onto barges, deserves a grand entrance. On the West Side Highway at West 59th Street, the shedlike marine transfer station now has a neo-classical arch that frames the two plain structures that house the station and offices. At night, those structures glow with neon.

title: University's Revenue Bonds
description: The the University of Texas System is offering $278.19 million in tax-exempt revenue financing system bonds in two parts, with a maximum yield of about 7.11 percent for a bond due in 2013 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Athletics Downplay Henderson's Absence
description: The only person in the Oakland Athletics' camp today wearing a uniform shirt with the number 24 and the name R. Henderson was Kevin Rardin, a 20-year-old part-time student at Mesa Community College, who comes from Oakland and loves Rickey Henderson.

title: Tape of Beating by Police Revives Charges of Racism
description: A two-minute amateur videotape of the beating of a black motorist by a group of police officers has jarred Los Angeles and revived charges that the police department has failed to confront an alleged pattern of police brutality and official abuse of minorities among its officers.

title: Productivity Is Revised Up
description: The nation's nonfarm work force was slightly more productive in the fourth quarter than originally estimated, the Labor Department said today, but the revision did not alter the overall picture of recession.

title: A Revitalized Murdock Is Doing It All for Friars
description: Eric Murdock had begun the 1989-90 basketball season with the very public endorsement of the coaches in the Big East Conference, being voted to the preseason first team. A year ago, the end of that season had shown signs of becoming a nightmare.

title: Amgen Wins Fight Over Drug
description: Amgen Inc. has won a stunning victory in a Federal appeals court here over its chief rival in the biotechnology industry in a case involving the patent rights to one of the most lucrative new drugs on the market.

title: Fordham's Road to N.C.A.A. Blocked by St. Francis, 70-64
description: The speakers above the basketball floor at the Maurice Stokes Physical Education Building were booming a rock-and-roll bass line. The capacity crowd of 3,500, inspired by the anticipation of a first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament bid for St. Francis College, was being encouraged to scream by the voice that came from those speakers.

title: Marilyn Horne Recital
description: Marilyn Horne will sing works by Handel, Vivaldi, Rossini and Copland in a recital at the Church of the Holy Cross, 329 West 42d Street, on Wednesday at 8 P.M. Warren Jones will be the pianist. The recital is a benefit for the church's AIDS relief and education ministries. Tickets are $25 to $200; a limited number of $10 tickets will be available at the door. Information: (212) 627-8880.

title: Greenspan Sees Improved Outlook for Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the end of the war with Iraq "removed a troublesome uncertainty" from the nation's economy and improved the chances that the recession would be relatively short and mild.

title: Bush Urges Quick Action On Crime and Other Areas
description: In his speech to a joint session of Congress tonight, President Bush asked the lawmakers to enact legislation affecting domestic policy in five areas: crime, transportation, energy, education and civil rights.

title: We Should Mind Iraq's Business
description: The Bush Administration's attitude toward a successor to Saddam Hussein in Iraq is mistakenly vague, creating the impression that the Arab coalition partners have been left to sort it out with the Iraqis. The U.S. has even avoided the usual platitudes about the desirability of democracy. This suggests that deference is being paid to the undemocratic sensibilities of the Saudi monarchy and that the preferred outcome is another, though tamer, military regime in Baghdad. More urgently, the lack of a clear American stand is only making it easier for Mr. Hussein, despite defeat, to resume the brutal repression of his own people.

title: Morgan Stanley Issue Yields 9.368%
description: A $300 million debt issue by the Morgan Stanley Group, consisting of notes due on March 1, 1998, is being offered with a 9 1/4 percent coupon at a price of 99.40 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Business and the Law; Bank Regulators Losing in Court
description: A SERIES of Federal court decisions has held that regulators were overzealous in seizing some failed banks and savings and loans and that the Government could be liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in damages to investors.

title: 6 Die as 2 Planes Carrying Collegians Crash
description: Six people were killed Tuesday night when two small airplanes taking Canadian college students home from a spring-break trip to California crashed into a snowy forest.

title: ATOM WASTE PLAN HITS SNAG IN HOUSE
description: Upset that its authority to review a Federal project had been bypassed, the House Interior Committee moved today to delay the opening of the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository.

title: Chronicle
description: IMMANUEL JAKOBOVITS, Britain's Chief Rabbi and the first rabbi to sit in the House of Lords, has been awarded the lucrative Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, it was announced yesterday in Manhattan. The award, worth about $820,000, will be given to him in London on May 7 by PRINCE PHILIP at Buckingham Palace. Lord Jakobovits is the first Jewish recipient of the prize, which was established in 1972 by the financier SIR JOHN TEMPLETON .

title: Square D Advises Against French Bid
description: The board of the Square D Company is advising its shareholders against tendering their stock under Groupe Schneider S.A.'s latest offer of $78 a share, or more than $1.9 billion. The board made the recommendation on Tuesday, pending the outcome of a meeting set for March 15 to consider the French company's offer. The Square D board rejected the same terms last week, but Group Schneider has proceeded with a bid.

title: Purdue Upsets No. 2 Buckeyes
description: Jimmy Oliver scored 27 points, including 9 of Purdue's final 15, as the Boilermakers upset second-ranked Ohio State, 72-67, and kept the Buckeyes from clinching the Big Ten title outright tonight.

title: Chronicle
description: DARRELL ROYAL, an illustrious former University of Texas football coach, has bought the country club of his friend WILLIE NELSON. Last year Mr. Nelson was ordered by a Texas court to pay back taxes and penalties to the Internal Revenue Service, which is demanding $16.7 million.

title: U.N. Group Condemns Burmese on Rights Record
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission has voted unanimously in secret session in Geneva to condemn the military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, for rights violations as a result of a confidential report prepared by a United Nations inspector who recently visited the country.

title: Trump Talks With Banks
description: Donald J. Trump and his advisers are negotiating with bankers to try to rework the financial package that saved the developer from bankruptcy last year, people close to the Trump Organization said yesterday. The talks were first reported yesterday in The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Review/Television; The Earliest Poirot Tale Ends Current Series
description: The current batch of Hercule Poirot stories on public television's "Mystery" series concludes tonight -- at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 21 -- with a two-part version of "The Mysterious Affair at Styles." This is not just another Poirot adventure. This is the one in which he made his debut. This was Agatha Christie's very first detective novel, started in 1916, when she was 25, and eventually published around 1920.

title: Miscellany
description: * FCB International, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to purchase an equity position in Public Communications, a Taiwan agency. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. * Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide said yesterday that it had opened a full-service agency in Dresden, Germany. * The management of EBW Advertising, New York, has purchased the agency and changed its name to Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about allegations of misconduct against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York referred incorrectly to the status of his case. While an inquiry by the Senate Ethics Committee is continuing, the committee has not acted on whether to hold hearings.

title: U.S. Tells of Retaliation Plan That the Israelis Abandoned
description: When Israel was attacked by Iraqi missiles on Jan. 18, Israeli leaders told Washington that they planned to retaliate with a large air and land incursion into western Iraq to wipe out the missile launchers, Administration officials say.

title: Poles Stay Suspicious of Their TV
description: Not so many years ago, one of the most popular pieces of anti-Communist graffiti on walls here was: "Television Lies."

title: Chronicle
description: They won't exactly be alone together, but it will be a sweet moment for MARK LEE and DR. N. JAN DAVIS when they become the first married couple in space. After some review, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's management decided to let the couple fly on the Spacelab mission to which they were assigned before they were married.

title: Pogo Producing Picks A Successor to Liedtke
description: The Pogo Producing Company, an oil and gas exploration and production concern founded by the oilman William C. Liedtke Jr., has named Paul G. Van Wagenen to take the place of Mr. Liedtke, who died of cancer on Friday at the age of 66.

title: Surveys Find Americans Satisfied With Quality of Health Services
description: Although many consumers are worried about the cost of medical care, results of two surveys that were announced Monday found Americans are generally satisfied with the quality of health services.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. King Scores 50 in Loss Bernard King scored 50 points -- the eighth 50-point game of his career -- but it was not enough last night as the visiting Utah Jazz beat the Washington Bullets, 104-93. King was 18 for 31 from the field and 14 of 16 from the free-throw line. It was his second 50-point game of the season; he scored 52 points on Dec. 29 against Denver. John Stockton tied a season high with 27 points for Utah, which sent Washington to its seventh consecutive loss. Karl Malone added 19 points and 12 rebounds for the Jazz, which has won four in a row over all and eight straight against Washington.(AP) Celtics 126, Heat 117: Larry Bird made four 3-pointers in the last eight minutes of the third quarter as Boston, playing at home, spoiled Miami's bid for a franchise-record winning streak. Miami had won three straight games for the second time in its three-year history. But Boston improved its record over the Heat to 10-0. Bird, who made 7 of 10 from 3-point range in a 126-101 victory over Indiana Monday night, made 5 of 8 against Miami.(AP) TENNIS Chesnokov Is Upset Mark Woodforde of Australia upset second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 2-6, 7-6, in a second-round match yesterday at the Copenhagen Open. The unseeded Woodforde, ranked 91st in the world, won the third-set tie breaker, 7-2, to set up a meeting with Anders Jarryd of Sweden in the quarterfinals. Jarryd beat his countryman Jan Gunnarsson, 6-3, 6-2. Other winners were Jonas Svensson and Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, Todd Woodbrige of Australia and Christian Saceanu of Germany. (AP)

title: U.S. Awards Grants to Aid Technology
description: The Commerce Department announced $9 million in matching grants to companies yesterday that are designed to foster innovative civilian technologies and restore American competitiveness.

title: Review/Film; Secrets and Sadism in the Interrogation Room
description: Hidden away in the darkest recesses of many minds, there have doubtless lurked thoughts like those at the heart of "Closet Land," a first film written and directed by Radha Bharadwaj. Ordinarily, those thoughts escape well before reaching the feature-film stage, usually in the form of bad high-school poetry or bad one-act experimental plays.

title: Top Salvador Rebel Alters His Goals
description: Moving away from his coalition's ideological roots, the senior military commander of the Salvadoran rebel army asserted this week that his group could no longer be considered a Marxist movement, and added that one-party rule in El Salvador would be "absurd."

title: Robert Elliott Scher,A Lawyer, Dies at 64
description: Robert Elliott Scher, a lawyer who specialized in labor and health law, died on Friday at Delray Community Hospital in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 64 years old and had moved to Boynton Beach, Fla., in October from Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: The Last Time Japan Tried to Raise Birthrate; Curiosity About Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Long-Term Treasuries in Retreat
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds retreated yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, reiterated his previous remarks that the recession was bottoming out and that banks would soon be readier to make loans. Treasury bill prices were also under pressure until the stock market fell back late in its session, causing a flow of money back into bills.

title: Key Rates
Riverdale Journal; The Young Are Shown A Kinder Face of Islam
description: In a wealthy part of Riverdale, far from the battlefields and mosques of the Persian Gulf, a Jewish teacher is trying to convey the virtues of Islam to her largely Christian and Jewish private school students.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on Tuesday showing a typical antibody mislabeled the light and heavy chains of amino acids that form it, and described the tail incorrectly. The light chains are shorter than the heavy chains, and the tail can vary.

title: Japan Says It Sheltered U.S. Group in Kuwait
description: The Japanese Government disclosed today that it secretly gave refuge to 16 Americans and their families in the days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and then helped them escape from Kuwait City.

title: Time Warner's Cable Plans
description: Time Warner Inc. is expected to announce today that it plans to install an advanced fiber-optic transmission network in parts of its cable television system in Queens.

title: A New Editor for Gourmet
description: Jane Montant, the editor in chief of Gourmet magazine for 15 years, will retire at the end of the month, Conde Nast Publications announced yesterday.

title: Completing the Dreams Of Artists With AIDS
description: WHEN architects and decorators die of AIDS, they leave colleagues and clients whose grief is complicated by an artistic vision left unfinished.

title: Dr. Dale Clement, 81,Head of Pediatric Lab
description: Dr. Dale Hale Clement, a New Haven pediatrician and educator, died on Friday at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 81 years and lived in New Haven.

title: Cease-Fire in the Capital Comes to a Bitter Close
description: Hours before Congressional leaders gave a warm welcome to President Bush at a joint session tonight, the political cease-fire imposed by the Persian Gulf war came to a snarling end.

title: Ban on Replacing Strikers Faces Veto Threat
description: Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said today that the Administration opposed union-supported legislation prohibiting companies from hiring permanent replacements for strikers, as a score of major companies have done in recent years.

title: New Venture For Compaq Called Near
description: After rebuffing an acquisition proposal from the Compaq Computer Corporation, Silicon Graphics Inc. has agreed to sell Compaq a significant minority stake and to collaborate on a new computer work station, people close to both companies said today.

title: Thousands of Albanians Flee Aboard Ships to Italy
description: For the third time in seven months, thousands of Albanians are fleeing their country, this time by sea as well as by land as the Communist Government sinks into what a resident of the capital called paralysis.

title: Little Room for Error In Chrysler's Future
description: It has long been the case at the Chrysler Corporation that whenever auto sales turn sour, the margin for error becomes razor thin.

title: Worrell Back in Action
description: Todd Worrell, one of the National League's premier relievers before being injured in September 1989, saw his first action for the St. Louis Cardinals in 18 months yesterday in St. Petersburgh, Fla.

title: Elizabeth Olds, Children's Author, 94
description: Elizabeth Olds, a writer and artist of children's books, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla., where she lived. She was 94 years old.

title: California Seeks to Ban Whittle's Channel One
description: For the second time in two years, the head of the California public school system is attempting to nullify contracts between the schools and Channel One, the commercial television news show designed for classroom use.

title: Freedom for Missing Soldier Is a 'Miracle' for Her FamilyBy ROBERT HANLEY
description: Donald and Jen Scott stared at the videotape of their 36-year-old daughter, Maj. Rhonda L. Cornum, emerging from the plane that flew her from captivity in Iraq to freedom in Saudi Arabia today.

title: A Republican Blow at Puerto Rico
description: A preoccupied President Bush can be excused for ignoring the Senate's failure to heed a request for self-determination by the people of Puerto Rico. It is harder to forgive Republican members of the Senate Energy Committee whose obstinacy may well deny islanders an opportunity to vote this year on whether to seek statehood, continued commonwealth status or independence.

title: Grand Met in Sale
description: The British food and liquor company Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it was selling its Perfect Pizza restaurant chain in Britian to Scott's Hospitality Inc. in Toronto. Terms were not disclosed. Grand Met said the chain consisted of 154 outlets, and that all the sites were held by leases.

title: Paul S. Mirabito, 75; Led Big Expansion Of Burroughs Corp.
description: Paul S. Mirabito, the former chairman of the Burroughs Corporation, under whose leadership an office machine company became a major military contractor and computer manufacturer, died yesterday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and also had a home in Birmingham, Mich.

title: Northeast Louisiana Wins N.C.A.A. Bid
description: Anthony Jones scored 21 points and had five steals tonight as Northeast Louisiana beat Florida A&M, 87-63, to earn a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Troops Saluted By Ketchum
description: The rush to capitalize on the patriotic fervor unleashed by the American victory in the Persian Gulf war does not stop with advertisers. At least one advertising agency is getting in on the act as well.

title: Jobless Rate in Germany
description: Unemployment soared last month in what used to be East Germany, as the former Communist state struggles through its transition to a market economy, the German Government said today. The Labor Office said 786,992 eastern Germans, or 8.9 percent of the work force, were out of work in February. By comparison, unemployment in the former West Germany last month was unchanged at 1.87 million, or 7 percent, as strong economic growth in the west continued to underpin employment.

title: Cinderella Story Ends For Cardozo, 63-58
description: It appeared as if the third-round upsets in the Public Schools Athletic League tournament were going to continue unabated after Long Island City upended Graphic and Communications Arts of Manhattan, 72-54, last night at the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: How Many Suicides by Vietnam Vets?
description: To the Editor:

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: IT is hard to say no to a crying preschooler, frightened by a nightmare, who asks to crawl into bed with you. Sharing a bed is a way for parents to provide the most fundamental sort of comfort and protection. It offers the child a nest of security.

title: Hasbro on Tonka
description: Hasbro Inc. said its offer for common stock and debentures of the Tonka Corporation had been extended from today until midnight on March 25. Hasbro said about 12 million Tonka common shares, about 82 percent of those outstanding, had been tendered in response to its offer of $7 a share. It said about $3 million in principal amount of Tonka's series A debentures, of $192 million outstanding, had been tendered. About $9.3 million in series B debentures, out of about $130 million outstanding, had also been tendered, Hasbro said.

title: Nathan Schwerner, 80,Rights Worker's Father
description: Nathan H. Schwerner, a retired wig manufacturer who was the father of Michael Schwerner, a 24-year-old civil-rights worker killed by Ku Klux Klan members near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964, died yesterday at Sarasota Community Hospital in Florida. He was 80 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Review/Music; Saluting a Competitor in the Year of Mozart
description: Considering the rush of empathy for Mozart's music in this the 200th anniversary year of his death, current attitudes toward Haydn, his colleague and contemporary, have been considerably more withdrawn. The first man is spontaneously loved by millions; the second is admired and celebrated, but by many fewer and at a cooler temperature.

title: Britain Frees 32 Iraqis
description: Britain today freed 32 Iraqi men whom it had held as prisoners of war at a military camp near Salisbury, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: James R. Bartsch, Inventor, 58
description: James R. Bartsch, an inventor and legal consultant, died on Friday in Manchester, Mass. He was 58 years old and lived in Gloucester, Mass.

title: Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed, Altering Trend
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the week that ended yesterday, the first such week after several weeks of declines.

title: Writing About Feelings May Beat Talking
description: New studies suggest that people who are able to write about their inner thoughts and feelings may enjoy better mental and physical health. The effect is seen among people who have had a variety of traumatic experiences.

title: 10 Additional Journalists Unaccounted for in Iraq
description: Ten additional reporters and photographers were reported missing in Iraq yesterday, bringing to 36 the number of journalists unaccounted for since they left Kuwait City on Sunday and Monday to cover civil warfare in southern Iraq.

title: Wait-and-See Approach Taken By Mets in Talks With Viola
description: Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, conceded today that the organization had officially decided to wait and evaluate Frank Viola's performance in more competitive and exacting circumstances before deciding to go ahead and conduct further talks on a contract extension.

title: Dow Goes Over 3,000 but Eases to 2,973.27
description: The little engine that could just couldn't yesterday.

title: Thin-Envelope Time for the Diaper Set
description: THIS week my lunch hour has had nothing to do with food. My mailbox is all that matters. At the stroke of 1 P.M., I race home and break it open, hoping for news of where my daughter will go to school next fall.

title: Brooklyn Chief Asserts Census Missed One in 6
description: Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn charged yesterday that the 1990 census failed to count one in six Brooklynites, potentially costing the borough more than $500 million in Federal money during the 1990's and leading to a loss in Congressional representation.

title: We Need More Odd Ball Parks
description: One of the worst ideas of the year was advanced the other day by Jesse Barfield of the Yankees. Upset just because he has lost 30 home runs to the power alley at Yankee Stadium, Barfield proposed identical baseball stadiums throughout North America.

title: People
description: * James V. McConnell Jr. has been named president and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson Japan. * Elwanda Edwards, Brenda Fellows, Lisanne Borgnes, Carol Flynn and Tracy Spinney have been named vice presidents of Ayer. * Cynthia Lewis has been named marketing director at HG magazine.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Cafe Crocodile

title: Review/Fashion; Armani and Versace: Last Are Hardly Least
description: After a slow start, the fall ready-to-wear shows ended this afternoon with a clash of cymbals and a roll of drums as Gianni Versace's aggressively feminine clothes and Giorgio Armani's quietly tailored styles were presented back to back.

title: Condom Giveaway Will Never Replace Values; Let Parents Opt Out
description: To the Editor:

title: New Boeing Order
description: The Boeing Company said EVA Airways, a new carrier based in Taiwan, had placed orders for four 767-300 extended-range jetliners potentially valued at $350 million. The agreement consists of two new firm orders plus the conversion to firm orders of two previously announced optional orders. EVA selected the General Electric Company's CF6-80C2B6F engines for all four aircraft.

title:
OIL: AFTER THE WAR;
How to Get Oil To $10 A Barrel
description: When OPEC meets next week, are we likely to see the oil markets go back to business as usual at artificially pegged levels that penalize the world economy?

title: Economic Scene; With Victory, New Challenges
description: IN his address to Congress this week on the end of the Persian Gulf war, President Bush linked economic development to the peace process. With Iraq's aggression repulsed, the new challenge, he said, "is to reach higher -- to foster economic freedom and prosperity for all people of the region." Indeed, he went so far as to suggest that a solution in the Middle East would help bring about a new world order "in which freedom and respect for human rights find a home among all nations." The war, he said, had provided a first test of such a new world, and we had passed the test.

title: Cost per Life: $22,000
description: Here in my study, while late afternoon light laps the wall, I dialyze and ruminate. The subjects of my ruminations are life, death and the flag.

title: Milton C. Nahm, 87, Professor of Philosophy
description: Milton Charles Nahm, professor emeritus of philosophy at Bryn Mawr College, died Monday at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 87 years old and lived in Rosemont, Pa.

title: Condom Giveaway Will Never Replace Values; 'Obsolete Moralism'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tarkanian Still Upset
description: Coach Jerry Tarkanian of top-ranked University of Nevada-Las Vegas continued to be upset yesterday over a visit to his campus on Monday and Tuesday by two National Collegiate Athletic Association enforcement representatives.

title: Health Agency Is Urged to Improve Management of Its AIDS Research
description: The National Institutes of Health needs to improve management of its AIDS research program to deal with budget problems even as the epidemic continues to spread, a study made public today said.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Behind-the-Scenes Complaints

title: Top Story on Moscow TV: Vote 'Da' on Referendum
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's determination to win an important referendum on the nation's future was signaled on the main television news program tonight, with a Government-controlled tide of reports that accused foreigners of plotting against the vote and domestic critics of fomenting civil disorder.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Homecoming; Troops' Return: Here's When and Where
description: The Pentagon announced today that the following units would be returning to the United States from the Persian Gulf on Friday and Saturday. Times given are local. Army

title: At the Movies
description: Fun With Mack

title: The Bunting Goes Up
description: Exactly seven months after rushing two squadrons of F-15 fighters to the Gulf -- the first land-based warplanes ordered to the war zone -- this Norfolk-area air base made frantic plans today for a heroes' homecoming for the planes' and their crews on Friday.

title: Sleepy LaBeef's Living History Lesson
description: The rockabilly singer Sleepy LaBeef is something of an anachronism, not because of the music he plays but because of the way he plays it. Though most pop musicians today think of a live show as a complement to, or re-creation of, an album or studio recording, Mr. LaBeef, who has been performing for more than 35 years, prefers to present his music in a live setting. He will give two shows this weekend in the New York metropolitan area, at Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., tonight, and as part of the Arts at St. Ann's series at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights tomorrow.

title: Unions Told To Cut Jobs At Daily News
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who wants to buy The Daily News, told its union leaders yesterday that he needed to trim more than 800 jobs, or more than a third of the work force, to go through with the deal.

title: Incomplete Justice for Summary Injustice
description: It has been three days now since television gave America a portrait of horror: a renegade band of Los Angeles policemen savagely kicking and beating a suspect lying on the pavement.

title: Howe Looks Sharp in His Yankee Debut
description: Nearly three and a half years have passed since Steve Howe stood alone on a mound and pitched to a major league batter in a game that had meaning.

title: Exxon Valdez Settlement Is Blocked, for Now
description: A Federal judge today blocked a $1.2 billion settlement of civil lawsuits over damage done by the Exxon Valdez two years ago in North America's largest oil spill.

title: Corinne Prevost Abel; Volunteer, 66
description: Corinne Prevost Abel, a volunteer active in civic causes around the world, died last Friday in Colwell, England. She was 66 years old and lived in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Chrysler Dividend Is Halved
description: The board of the Chrysler Corporation cut the auto maker's regular quarterly dividend in half today, to 15 cents a share from 30 cents.

title: Chief Operating Officer Promoted at Medtronic
description: Medtronic Inc., Minneapolis, a maker of heart pacemakers, has not been shy to draw on other companies for management talent. The company announced yesterday that William W. George, who joined Medtronic from Honeywell Inc. in 1989, would become president and chief executive effective May 1.

title: February Sales Down As Wariness Persists
description: Most of the nation's largest store chains remained on a slow track in February, despite the end of fighting in the Persian Gulf late in the month. With consumers apparently showing little early interest in new spring clothing, many merchants yesterday reported declines or no gains in stores open at least a year.

title: It's a New Season for the Knicks
description: A month ago, when John MacLeod insisted that the Knicks were improving, it sounded absurd, hardly believable.

title: Nets Outmatched Again In San Antonio, 111-99
description: Terry Cummings scored 25 points and David Robinson grabbed 20 rebounds tonight as the Spurs beat the Nets for the 11th consecutive time in San Antonio, 111-99.

title: Poll Finds Postwar Glow Dimmed by the Economy
description: The war in the Persian Gulf has given a striking boost to the nation's confidence and morale, but Americans are now turning their attention to the economy and other domestic concerns about which they are far less ebullient, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Du Pont to Stop Emissions of a Gas
description: The Du Pont Company said that within five years its factories would stop emitting a gas that eats away at the earth's protective ozone layer. Du Pont set the timetable to eliminate nitrous oxide, which is produced while making a raw material in nylon.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRESIDENT BUSH presented MARGARET THATCHER with the Presidential Medal of Freedom yesterday in the East Room of the White House. He recalled some advice the former British Prime Minister gave him during a telephone conversation early in the Persian Gulf crisis: "Remember, George: this is no time to go wobbly."

title: Digital to Open Czech Subsidiary
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would open a subsidiary in Czechoslovakia to market, sell and service the company's computers. The division, expected to open in June with about 30 employees, would be Digital's first wholly owned subsidiary in Eastern Europe. Digital owns a 51 percent stake in a joint venture in Hungary. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., is investing about $5 million in the Czechoslovak unit, which will be based in Prague.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Saxophonist, Calmly

title: Article 501791 -- No Title
description: Congress moved considerably closer today to providing $30 billion in new money to rescue the nation's troubled savings and loan industry.

title: Critic's Choice
description: "I've come more and more to believe that movement cannot be abstract; that it carries with it implication and meaning, cultural and associative implications," Susan Rethorst said recently of her dance "Picture This," which will be performed tonight through Sunday in the March in Motion festival at the Kitchen. The new eveninglong work juxtaposes dance sections that have an intuitive logic, as Ms. Rethorst puts it, and scenes of movement and light that have a sense of place and character. She will perform the piece with four other compelling female dancers.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Coach Tom Young of Old Dominion, suspended for two games during the season for an altercation with a Western Kentucky player, was dismissed after a six-year stay in which his teams posted a 90-87 record.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * CNA Financial Corp., Chicago, a subsidiary of Loews Corp., is offering $400 million in notes divided into two parts through Lehman Brothers. A $250 million issue of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1996 is priced to yield 8.73 percent, while the remaining $150 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1998 are priced at 99.053 to yield 9.06 percent. The financing is rated AA by S.&P. * Corestates Capital Corp., a subsidiary of Corestates Financial Corp., is offering $75 million in 8.25 percent noncallable notes due in 1993 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: McDonnell Air Gets President
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the struggling aerospace giant, today named John P. Capellupo president of the McDonnell Aircraft Company, the company's military aircraft division.

title: The War in Military Ads? What War?
description: For all the glamour and accolades that came with the allied victory over Iraq, overt references to the operation may never appear in advertising for the Army, Navy, Air Force or Marines.

title: TV Weekend; Of Fred Astaire, the Dancer Who Faced the Music and Sang
description: With the slightest adjustment of a feature or two, he might easily have looked goofy, a sort of embryonic Don Knotts. He was slight in stature, almost scrawny, and his hairline was just about nonexistent. Yet Fred Astaire became the epitome of movie elegance, seemingly willing himself to be debonair. As time passes and his work can be looked at more objectively, it is more and more apparent that Astaire was one of the most astonishing performing artists of this century.

title: The Poet Judge
description: More than any other people on earth, Americans today are free to think what they wish and say what they think. We owe the breadth of that freedom in significant part to one man, a judge who was born in Boston 150 years ago today.

title: Hard Passage in India
description: India's politicians emerge with little glory from the quarrels that have brought down Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's minority Government. If they now maneuver to avoid elections, Mr. Shekhar's opponents can only deepen a crisis that has shaken the world's most populous democracy.

title: Time Warner Constructing 2-Way Cable TV System
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that by the end of the year, 10,000 of its cable television subscribers in Queens would be able to receive 150 channels and communicate through their television sets to obtain services like electronic banking.

title: U.S.-Norway Trade Dispute
description: Norway has asked a world trade group to mediate a dispute involving accusations by the United States that Norwegian salmon is being dumped on the American market.

title: Senate Panel Approves Ex-Florida Governor as Anti-Drug Director
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today, 11 to 3, to approve the nomination of former Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida as the nation's chief anti-drug coordinator.

title: What's This About the Judge's Husband?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Seeks Charges in Police Beating
description: The Chief of Police of Los Angeles said today that he would seek felony criminal charges against three officers seen beating a prone suspect, apparently not resisting arrest, in an amateur videotape that has stirred national revulsion.

title: CRISIS CONTINUING IN INDIA'S POLITICS
description: Chandra Shekhar, India's caretaker Prime Minister since his resignation on Wednesday, accused Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party today of bringing the country "to the brink of disaster."

title: Reviews/Film; Cops-vs.-Crack Formula By Mario Van Peebles
description: The villain's prized possessions are now computer disks that hold business records of his illicit operations. But beyond that, very little has changed. The staples of the drug-lord exploitation film remain familiar, among them clanking gold jewelry, free-flowing champagne, silk suits and enough gun-toting strongmen to make the whole voyeur-tempting operation perfectly secure. It takes confidence even to revive this genre nowadays, let alone to invest it with anything new.

title: Nguyen Van Hieu, 68, A Founder of Vietcong
description: Nguyen Van Hieu, a founder of the Vietcong and a negotiator at the Paris peace talks during the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today. He was 68 years old.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; GOOD-WILL GOALS IN MIDEAST CITED AS BAKER SETS OUT
description: State Department officials said today that the United States did not expect peace initiatives to emerge quickly from President Bush's call for Israel to give up occupied lands in return for peace, but that it hoped to secure modest good-will gestures from the Israelis and Arabs to establish a measure of trust.

title: Trade Agreements Harmful to Health
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Bombers; B-52 Crews in England Tell of High-Altitude Strikes on Iraqi Targets
description: American B-52 pilots and crew members who flew combat missions from here during the war with Iraq said today that their eight-engine planes had dodged surface-to-air missiles and heavy anti-aircraft fire to strike nuclear plants, Scud missile sites and Republican Guard units.

title: Phillies Invite LaPoint To Training Camp
description: The Philadelphia Phillies yesterday invited the free-agent pitcher Dave LaPoint to training camp as an unsigned nonroster player. LaPoint, 30 years old, was 7-10 with a 4.11 earned run average in 28 games for the Yankees last year, starting 27 games. He has a career record of 80-85 in the major leagues with six teams.

title: Houston Schools Offer Tax Bonds
description: A $147 million issue of limited tax bonds for the Houston Independent School District was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation, which were awarded the financing in competitive bidding.

title: Four Arrested In Japan Case
description: A former professor was arrested on Wednesday on suspicion of accepting bribes from a medical supplier to buy General Electric medical equipment.

title: WPP Cancels Its Dividend As Financial Woes Mount
description: THE magic is clearly gone from the once high-flying WPP Group, some media analysts say. They say the financial problems of the debt-ridden company, which owns J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, are likely to continue for the rest of the year.

title: Council Chief Under Fire, Even for Dullness
description: The New York City Council, which lately has exercised its new powers sniping at the Mayor and other city officials, saw some members hurl charges of cronyism, demagogy and -- (gasp!) dullness -- at their own leader, Speaker Peter F. Vallone, yesterday.

title: Catholic Schools Worry As Closings Draw Near
description: These are fretful times for New York's Roman Catholic schools. In the next few days, the Archdiocese of New York is expected to announce that, because of mounting deficits, a handful of the schools, all in poor neighborhoods, will have to shut their doors.

title: White House Memo; Unable to Out-Hero Bush, Democrats Just Join Him
description: George Bush will not need to visit a flag factory during his re-election campaign. In the heady aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, Republicans are wearing the flag like Caesar's purple mantle, and Democrats are desperately tugging at the hem.

title: Miscellany
description: * Transportation Displays Inc., New York, an outdoor advertising agency, has established a new division, TDI International, which will be based in London. Elliot H. Rittenband will be its managing director.

title: Ruling Bolsters Apple Shares
description: The stock of Apple Computer Inc. moved up today and that of the Microsoft Corporation moved down in the wake of a court decision that was favorable to Apple in its long-running software copyright suit against Microsoft and the Hewlett- Packard Company.

title: Review/Film; 2 Movies Examine Israel
description: Somewhat revisionist, second-generation views of the Israeli experience are presented by two otherwise very different films opening today at the Public Theater.

title: British Tories Defeated In a Former Stronghold
description: Despite Prime Minister John Major's soaring popularity, his Conservative Party suffered its biggest upset in a decade, losing a special election today in a former Tory stronghold in northern England.

title: Our Towns; A Store Offers A Last 'Goodbye, And Thank You'
description: When Lazaar's Stationers first opened for business here, there were no such things as ballpoint pens, computer paper or electronic calculators. They hadn't even invented World Wars back then.

title: Stock Sale By Citicorp
description: Citicorp announced Wednesday night that it had sold $600 million in preferred stock to a broad group of investors and had thus completed a key portion of its plan to strengthen its finances.

title: Auctions
description: A Collection of Toys

title: Philadelphia Again Told to Immunize Youths
description: After learning that a 19-month-old boy is dying of measles as a result of an epidemic here, a judge today reaffirmed his recent order that the city immunize six children deemed at risk of contracting the disease.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Hallmark Cards Inc., Kansas City, Mo., named Jim Toohey president of Hallmark International. * John Hancock Broker Distribution Services Inc., Boston, a subsidiary of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co., named C. Troy Shaver Jr. president and chief executive.

title: Albania, Combating Exodus, Clamps Down on a Port
description: Albania's Communist Government imposed martial law today in Durres, the country's largest port, in an effort to stem mass flights in commandeered ships. It also barred public assembly in three other restive cities, including Tirana, the capital.

title: Long-Term Treasury Prices Soar
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds soared yesterday on expectations that Washington would report a sharp rise in unemployment this morning. If so, it would benefit investors in fixed-income securities because it would lessen the demand for loans, ease inflation pressures and possibly prompt the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; Red Cross Says Iraqis Will Release Journalists
description: Officials of the Red Cross said Thursday that most of the roughly three dozen journalists who disappeared earlier this week while traveling toward Basra in southeastern Iraq to cover civil unrest there would be released by the Iraqis in the next few days.

title: Mets Search for Short-Relief Lefty
description: Sid Fernandez, sick with the flu, did not attend today's team photo session. The spherical Fernandez's absence, though, hardly rated as the largest left-handed void in the picture.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War A8-11

title: Teen-Agers' Beepers: Communications as Fashion
description: Along with the gray-pleated skirts, knee socks, white blouses and sweaters that are the uniform for the all-girls Cathedral High School in Manhattan, many students now bear something that was once the sartorial mark of doctors and drug dealers: a beeper.

title: Placer Ends Talks
description: Placer Dome Inc. and the Corona Corporation, two Canadian mining giants vying for control of the rich Eskay Creek gold property in British Columbia, have broken off talks on a plan to increase Placer's stake in the property. Neither company would say why the talks had broken down. But industry analysts said they expected the companies, both based in Vancouver, eventually to work out an agreement whereby Placer's greater capital resources could be tapped to develop the property. Placer controls 23 percent of Eskay Creek. Corona and its associates control the rest.

title: Market Place; Debt Deal Favors Water St. Fund
description: IN the high-stakes, behind-the-scenes game that is the new world of corporate restructuring, bondholders who start out with similar holdings can wind up in very different positions.

title: At the Bar; The way of the maverick, or putting a bur under plans for an exotic bar convention.
description: For 16,000 lawyers in the State of Washington, the day of judgment is near. This month, in a move costing at least $10,000 in postage, printing costs and apparatchiks' fees, they will vote on a vexing issue: whether to hold their annual convention four years from now in Maui.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion referred imprecisely to its recipient, Immanuel Jakobovits, Britain's Chief Rabbi. In 1988, he was made a life peer, Baron Jakobovits of Regents Park, thus gaining a seat in the House of Lords.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Phoebe Legere

title: Penn State Wins Bid to N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: Penn State tonight won its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth in 26 years and its only Atlantic 10 championship in its final game as a member of the league by defeating George Washington, 81-75.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Kuwaiti Prince Says Martial Law May Last for More Than 3 Months
description: Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, warned tonight that martial law here might have to be extended beyond the three months originally proposed.

title: Both Pilots Were Conscious Before Jetliner's Nose Dive
description: Federal investigators have determined that both pilots of a United Airlines jet that crashed here on Sunday were conscious and physically capable of flying the plane when it suddenly went out of control.

title: Don't Blame Reviewers Of Health-Care Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Villanova Rallies Past B.C., 74-73, to Earn Shot at Syracuse
description: With a little more than two minutes left to play in last night's qualifying-round game of the Big East Conference tournament at Madison Square Garden, Boston College seemed on the verge of salvaging a season that had been tinged with disappointment and most recently by tragedy.

title: Top Fed Rating to Hanover
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it had received the highest rating of "outstanding" from the Federal Reserve after it reviewed the bank's activities in local neighborhoods, including low- and moderate-income areas. But the rating, which is required by the Community Reinvestment Act, was not enough to satisfy some community groups.

title: Simcha Kling; Rabbi, 69
description: Rabbi Simcha Kling, an author, teacher and translator of Hebrew literature, died Feb. 26 at his home in Louisville, Ky. He was 69 years old.

title: Henderson Shows Up
description: Rickey Henderson, the American League's most valuable player last season, arrived a day late in the Oakland camp today and said he might ask the A's to trade him if they won't extend the four-year, $12 million contract he calls outdated.

title: Teachers Help to Plug Arts Education Holes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoken Word
description: Here is a sampling of lectures and readings in the New York metropolitan area this weekend. PERFORMANCE AND LECTURE, devoted to the works of Sholom Aleichem, presented by Philip Nolan and Raoul J. Shorr, at the Kittredge Club, 109 East 39th Street, Manhattan, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $10. Information: (718) 241-7479. GALLERY TALKS AND LECTURES, the Whitney Museum of Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. "Robert Rauschenberg: The Silk-Screen Paintings, 1962-64," today at 12:30 P.M. (lecturer to be announced); "The Drawings of Jasper Johns," today at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. (lecturer to be announced); "The 1980's: Selections From the Permanent Collection," today at 2:30 P.M. (lecturer to be announced); "The Drawings of Jasper Johns" by Leslie Heiner, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 P.M.; "Robert Rauschenberg: The Silk-Screen Paintings, 1962-64" by Ms. Heiner, tomorrow at 3:30 P.M.; "The 1980's: Selections From the Permanent Collection" by Ms. Heiner, Sunday at 3:30 P.M. Free with museum admission of $5 ($3 for the elderly; free for students.) Information: (212) 570-3611. LECTURE, by David Halberstam, who will discuss his latest book, "The Next Century," and be interviewed by Charlie Rose, a former television anchor for Fox Broadcasting and CBS, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $14. Information: (212) 996-1100. LECTURE, by Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the author, poet and member of the Soviet Parliament, who will discuss his latest book, "The Collected Poems: 1952-1990" at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, today and tomorrow at 8 and 10:30 P.M. and Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets, $29.95. Information: (212) 475-5120. "KEEPING THE TRADITION ALIVE," a free three-part discussion on the emergence of Irish music and dance in New York City, on Sunday at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The topics are "What Is Irish Music and Dance?" at 11 A.M., "The Dance Hall, the Ballroom and Broadcasting" at 1:30 P.M., and "The Feis and the Teaching Tradition" at 3 P.M. Information: (212) 534-1672. "PUBLIC DIFFERENCE," a look at bus shelters, signs and tunnels by the artist Dennis Adams, as part of the Street Meets Artist series at the Municipal Art Society, Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, Sunday at 2 P.M. Free, but reservations are required: (212) 935-3960. "GREAT GARDENS OF SCOTLAND," slide show and talk by Martha Prince, a writer, illustrator and photographer, at the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons, Main Street, Bridgehampton, L.I., Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $5. Information: (516) 537-2223. LECTURE AND SLIDE SHOW, on the changes affecting rural life from colonial times to the present, by Christopher Clarke-Hazlett, Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Queens County Farm Museum, 75-50 Little Neck Parkway, Floral Park, Queens. Admission is free. Information: (718) 347-3276.

title: New World Bank Chief Seen Focusing on Debt
description: Lewis T. Preston, retired chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company and President Bush's choice to head the World Bank, is likely to refocus attention on reducing the crushing debt burden of third world countries as a key to lifting global living standards.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The best-selling author and scientist STEPHEN W. HAWKING was struck by a car as his wheelchair was being pushed across a street in Cambridge, England. He suffered a broken arm in the accident on Tuesday, and was released from the hospital on Wednesday, the Associated Press reported.

title: Psychiko Journal; 'The Odyssey' and All That: To Greeks It's Greek
description: Choosing words that have fired the mind for centuries, the teacher started writing on the blackboard and the students concentrated as the opening lines of Homer's "Odyssey" appeared.

title: Katinka Loeser, Story Writer, 77; Collections Told of Suburban Life
description: Katinka Loeser, many of whose short stories were infused with what a critic described as "autobiographical sketches of warmth and charm," died Wednesday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Westport.

title: Nikko International Reshuffles at the Top
description: Less than two years after a change in senior management, Nikko Securities International, the American arm of Japan's third-largest securities firm, has reshuffled, naming Tsuneo Iida chairman and chief executive.

title: Review/Art; A Selection of Work From the 80's, at the Whitney
description: The exhibition of art of the 80's at the Whitney Museum of American Art is likely to confirm the opinions of the museum's admirers and detractors. The show does not include all of the museum's holdings from the decade, but "The 1980's: Selections From the Permanent Collection" provides a substantial opportunity to assess both its acquisitions and its institutional predilections.
