title: War of the Big Lockout Ends in Tenant Victory
description: Her landlord locked her out; a judge ordered her back in. He locked her out again; the police jimmied the lock. The apartment had been trashed; the judge ordered it repaired. The landlord failed to show up in court; the judge ordered him thrown in jail until it was fixed.

title: Housing in Jersey City; Condo Tower Rises Along the Hudson
description: Such is the allure of waterfront living that a Long Island development company is betting that the residences it will begin marketing here on March 16 will sell, even in a soft market.

title: Consumer Debt Plunged 4% in January
description: Consumer credit fell at a 4 percent annual rate in January, the Government reported today. It was the steepest plunge in four years as recession and war curbed personal spending.

title: G.M.A.C. Sets $811 Million In Asset-Backed Certificates
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation priced $811.4 million in asset-backed certificates yesterday through a G.M.A.C. 1991-A grantor trust.

title: Study Faults New York On Poor Care of Schools
description: Although custodians have long been blamed for shabby conditions at many New York City schools, a management study says that much of the dilapidation is actually the result of overly frugal city spending on plumbing, electrical work and other maintenance.

title: Walesa Urges 'Instant' Elections for Poland
description: President Lech Walesa urged Parliament today to dissolve itself and make way for immediate elections to complete Poland's transition to democracy.

title: Debut for Meadow Star
description: Leroy Jolley said today that Meadow Star's 1991 debut at Gulfstream Park on Friday would be not just a glorified workout, but a race. And he conceded that his champion filly would be forced to run a sharp race or risk her perfect record.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday about the space shuttle misidentified the spacecraft that is to be launched next month as planned. It is Atlantis, not Discovery.

title: Break the Boycott
description: The high-level emergency meeting of the Arab nations was held in private, in Damascus. It was called to deal with just one subject: the economic strangulation of Israel.

title: Military and Interim Officials Steer Thailand
description: The Thai military, which overthrew a democratically elected Government on Feb. 23, has put into place an interim administration dominated by respected and experienced civilian technocrats, diplomats and businessmen, and the move has already helped to mollify important foreign investors.

title: Foss Plays Foss
description: Lukas Foss is to be the pianist with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in his own "Solo Observed" at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8. The program also includes Charles Wuorinen's "New York Notes," Schumann's Piano Quartet in E flat (Op. 47), and a Mozart Violin Sonata in G, with James Buswell as the soloist. The program will be repeated on Sunday at 5 P.M. Mr. Foss will discuss his work in a pre-concert talk on Sunday at 4 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Toyota's Pickup
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it had delayed indefinitely its decision on making a large pickup truck. A spokesman, John McCandless, said a soft vehicle market and an uncertain economy had prompted officials to delay their decision. Toyota currently builds a compact pickup in Japan. Ford and General Motors' Chevrolet division dominate the highly profitable full-size truck market.

title: Everywhere Flowers And a Topiary World
description: The New York Flower Show has enough good-smelling greenery to shame a black-thumb gardener whose horticultural aspirations always seem to wither in the original pot on the way home from the neighborhood 5-and-10-cent store. With two acres of blossoms and blooms and trompe l'oeil gardens running the length of a huge pier on the Hudson River, the flower show is the kind of inspiration a luckless amateur needs to pick up a trowel and try again.

title: Key Rates
Security Pacific to Sell $175 Million in Stock
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest bank, said today that it was selling $175 million worth of preferred stock in a bid to strengthen its capital base.

title: Review/Film; A Bad Girl Who Turns Into a True Femme Fatale
description: The most popular film in France during the last 12 months has been "La Femme Nikita," a slick, calculating mixture of French contemplativeness and American flying glass. Directed by Luc Besson, whose dazzling early ingenuity (in his austere science-fiction film "Le Dernier Combat") subsequently gave way to high style and hot air (in "Subway" and "The Big Blue"), "La Femme Nikita" combines hip violence, punk anomie, lavish settings and an old-fashioned paean to the power of love.

title: Fluor's Profits Decline 9%
description: The Fluor Corporation said today that its quarterly earnings fell 9 percent as lower profits from its lead-producing operations more than offset better results in its core engineering and construction business.

title: Review/Art; Sculpture Borne by the Earth and Lighted by the Sky
description: Summer is no longer the only eventful season for outdoor sculpture. As sculpture -- so often costly to make and show -- seems more and more of an outcast in galleries during this economic crunch, it may be finding more of a home in New York City's parks and streets. Sculpture, and public art in general, now almost seems part of the fabric of New York rather than just a guest waiting, or sometimes demanding, to be invited in for a few months each year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Feb. 26 about Alzheimer's disease rendered a comment by Dr. John Breitner of Duke University incorrectly. He said he believed that a substantial majority of cases of the disease had a genetic basis; he did not say all of them.

title: Expos Sign Wallach
description: Tim Wallach, hoping to finish his career with the Montreal Expos, agreed yesterday to two-year contract extension worth $7.5 million. Wallach, a 33-year-old third baseman who batted .296 last season with 98 runs batted in, will be paid $1,725,000 in each of the 1991 and 1992 seasons. The extension calls for a $500,000 signing bonus and salaries of $3.5 million in the 1993 and 1994 seasons. (AP)

title: AFTER THE WAR: War Budget; House, Voting $15 Billion for War, Warns Allies to Pay Their Part
description: The House of Representatives voted tonight to appropriate $15 billion to pay for the Persian Gulf war after warning other countries to make good on their pledges of aid and promising that Congress "may consider appropriate action" if those commitments were not fulfilled.

title: Gaylord A. Freeman Jr., 81, Dies; Led Chicago's First National Bank
description: Gaylord A. Freeman Jr., the former chairman and chief executive of the First National Bank of Chicago and an influential spokesman for business on national and international monetary affairs, died yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 81 years old and lived in Wayne, Ill., and Lincoln, N.M.

title: K Mart Getting A Group Buy
description: Newsweek, the Meredith Corporation and Times Mirror Magazines have offered a group-magazine buy to the K Mart Corporation at the request of the department store chain and its advertising agency, Ross Roy Group.

title: Review/Dance; Trisha Brown Offers Quiet Contradictions
description: Trisha Brown is indisputably one of the most influential choreographers to come out of the seminal post-modernist Judson Dance Theater in the 1960's. Internationally known, she has developed a style that has clearly left its mark on many younger choreographers and dancers working in New York today. But she is most of all an artist of quiet contradictions. And that contradictoriness was the hallmark of the program that opened the weeklong 20th-anniversary season of the Trisha Brown Dance Company, on Tuesday at City Center.

title: Police Warn Luxury-Car Drivers
description: If you drive a luxury car in Queens, beware.

title: Palestinian Journalist Freed From Israeli Jail
description: A Palestinian journalist was freed on bail from an Israeli jail today after an international campaign for his release.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwaitis; Joyous Kuwaitis Return From Iraq But Others Find the Border Closed
description: Hundreds of Kuwaitis released this evening from Iraqi custody cheered, waved and shouted "U.S.A!" as they passed through this desolate border town on their way back to their homeland.

title: Fine, 100 Days. But for What?
description: The challenge President Bush put to Congress Wednesday could hardly have been plainer. We have won the war in the gulf, he said. Now we must apply the same urgency and self-discipline "here at home." Then, invoking F.D.R., he sharpened the challenge: "If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely the Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days."

title: Planning Ahead: Johnson Says He'll Retire After Olympics
description: For the first time in his life as a sprinter, Ben Johnson can see the finish line.

title: No Pain for Hershiser
description: Orel Hershiser took a major step toward returning to the Dodgers' pitching rotation when he threw 54 painless pitches during a workout.

title: Coca-Cola to Build Plants in Poland
description: The Coca-Cola Company will invest nearly $50 million to build three soft drink plants in Poland, a top company executive said. Neville Isdell, Coca-Cola's representative for Northern and Eastern Europe and Africa, said the investment was the biggest announced by any United States company in Poland since the collapse of Communism in 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Like mother, like daughter will be reversed when GLYNIS JOHNS plays Mme. Armfeldt in "A Little Night Music" in Los Angeles next month. Miss Johns won a Tony Award for her portrayal of Desiree Armfeldt, Mme. Armfeldt's daughter, in the original 1973 production of the STEPHEN SONDHEIM musical.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the British publisher Robert Maxwell misstated his involvement with three American weekly tabloids -- The Globe, The National Examiner and The Sun. He does not own them; he sought to buy them in 1990 from the Globe Communications Corporation of Boca Raton, Fla., but the deal collapsed at the last moment.

title: An Infant Boy Is Found Dead Of Starvation
description: An emaciated 7-month-old boy was found dead in a Bronx apartment yesterday morning, and the Medical Examiner's office said the child had died of starvation and dehydration.

title: Medicine for Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Control Board Says Dinkins Plan 'Actually Disguises' Budget Gap
description: The State Financial Control Board issued new warnings yesterday about New York City's handling of its long-term fiscal problems as Mayor David N. Dinkins struggled to rally support in an unusually pointed appeal to black New Yorkers.

title: Restaurants
description: The reopening of Sardi's in November was awaited with the same enthusiasm usually reserved for the debut of a major Broadway show. True, Sardi's was only a revival, but one with a glamorous past and smash-hit potential.

title: Dr. Luther Cloud, 70, Expert on Alcoholism
description: Dr. Luther Atwood Cloud, a physician who was an authority on alcoholism in the work place, died on Tuesday at Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 70 years old and lived in Auburn, Me.

title: Gallery Etiquette: A Duel of Dealers and Browsers
description: WHEN the art dealer Holly Solomon had her gallery on the ground floor of a SoHo building, the scene got so vivid on Saturday afternoons that she put up a sign banning skateboards and fast foods. Then a kiddie stroller collided disastrously with a sculpture, and she added "No Strollers" to the list. Under it, the next day, she found a sardonic scrawl: "No People."

title: M.T.A., Citing Surplus Fund, Votes to Delay L.I.R.R. Cuts
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to put off extensive service cuts on the Long Island Rail Road, one week after it was revealed that the authority had a $93 million surplus fund, most of it marked for the railroad.

title: Review/Film; Playing Policeman in New York City
description: In John Badham's high-concept new comedy, "The Hard Way," Michael J. Fox has the time of his life as a pint-size deliriously self-confident Hollywood icon for whom reality has become an abstract concept, no more easily grasped than the theory of relativity.

title: Review/Theater; Art Imitates Art (and Artists), And the Cost Sounds Excruciating
description: IT has long been a Hollywood axiom that a producer will sign away his blood or perhaps even a testicle or two if that's what it takes to make a deal. The principal joke -- very gruesome, not very funny -- in Arthur Kopit's new play is that "the biggest rock star in the world" would literally demand these human sacrifices and more from producers begging to film her life story. The star's name is Nirvana, and Mr. Kopit's play is titled "Road to Nirvana." It is not paved with clear intentions, let alone good ones.

title: Books of The Times; A Novel of Bleak Lives Backstage
description: An Awfully Big Adventure By Beryl Bainbridge 205 pages. HarperCollins. $19.95.

title: Jack Warren, 73, Dies; Seized Dr. King in '63
description: Jack Warren, a retired deputy police chief in Birmingham whose arrest of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1963 led to Dr. King's "Letter From Birmingham Jail," died Tuesday of complications of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Philip Morris Sets $350 Million Issue
description: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $350 million in notes due on March 1, 1998, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Koor's Debt Plan
description: Israel's Parliament has approved $100 million in Government loan guarantees for Koor Industries, the last piece of a recovery package for the conglomerate. The parliamentary finance committee had previously ratified a $50 million cash grant to Koor, which is Israel's largest industrial group but owes more than $1 billion to banks and bondholders.

title: 'Twin Peaks' to Return, on Thursdays
description: "Twin Peaks" will return to the ABC television schedule on March 28 in the same time slot it occupied a year ago when it became a national phenomenon.

title: 2 Groups Battle Weicker's Tax Plan
description: Two statewide organizations have begun citizens' lobbying campaigns against Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan for a state income tax.

title: Export Controls On 50 Chemicals
description: The Bush Administration issued a new set of export regulations today, expanding the list of potential chemical or biological arms ingredients subject to control from 11 to 50.

title: Death of the Coach's Wife Keeps Game in Perspective
description: There are losses in sport. And there are losses in life. The difference has been made painfully clear to the Boston College basketball players and their coach this week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEE A. IACOCCA and DARRIEN EARLE have set the date: they plan to marry on March 30 in Los Angeles. It is the third marriage for Mr. Iacocca, 66 years old, and the second for Ms. Earle. The couple have been engaged for 15 months. Mr. Iacocca is the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Ms. Earle owns a restaurant in Manhattan Beach, Calif.

title: Drug Dealer May Face Death
description: A man accused of killing to protect his $50,000-a-day drug ring was convicted of murder today in the Government's first test of a 1988 Federal law that allows the death penalty in drug-related slayings. The 31-year-old defendant, Alexander Cooper, was found guilty in the slaying of a colleague who had turned informer.

title: Pearson Sells Elsevier Stake
description: Pearson P.L.C., the big British publishing company, said this week that it had sold a 22.5 percent stake in the Dutch publisher Elsevier N.V. to Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank, for $:313 million in cash, or about $593 million.

title: In Brooklyn Heights, Wisps of Victorian Age
description: As most of New York and the world careen toward the 21st century, in one rarefied corner of Brooklyn, the more genteel days of the late 19th century have yet to end. This was never more evident than on Monday night, when about 70 well-to-do men gathered in an elegant Brooklyn Heights home, much as they and their forebearers have done since the Victorian era.

title: Prime Plans Asian Deal
description: Prime Network, a regional sports cable network, is investing in a new satellite television service aimed at Asia.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraq Reporting Internal Revolt For First Time
description: Iraq acknowledged for the first time today that it was facing internal revolt but claimed a victory in the Persian Gulf war, saying President Bush's speech on the Middle East showed that Baghdad had forced the United States to focus on the Arab-Israel dispute.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; Mideast Pact: Israelis' View
description: On four crucial points, almost everyone in the Israeli political establishment seems to agree:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American National Petroleum Co., Houston, said it would receive $21 million from the Transco Energy Co. in settlement of its suit against Transco's Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corp. unit, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $12.3 million. * Brierley Investment Ltd., a New Zealand investment concern, has sold its 14 percent stake in Lion Nathan Ltd., a New Zealand brewing and retail company, to an unidentified buyer for $170 million (New Zealand).

title: INSIDE
description: Charges Sought in Beating The Los Angeles Police Chief said he would seek criminal charges against officers whose beating of a suspect was captured on videotape. Page A12. Exxon Settlement Put Off Responding to pleas by Alaskan Indians, a judge forestalled a $1.2 billion settlement of lawsuits resulting from the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Page A12. Vying for Infant Health Aid The Government will list 19 cities eligible for $171 million to combat infant mortality, but they will have to compete for the money. Page A12. Transit Cuts Rescinded Angry that they did not know about a budget surplus, transit officials decided to not to make service cuts on the Long Island Rail Road. Page B1.

title: Kenneth T. Downs, 81, Reporter and Executive
description: Kenneth T. Downs, a war correspondent who became a public relations executive, died on Feb. 19 in Champrobert-Larochemillay, a village in central France where he lived in retirement. He was 81 years old.

title: Boeheim Receives Honor
description: As part of the preseason polls last November, Big East coaches predicted that Syracuse, which had been hit hard by the losses of Derrick Coleman and Stephen Thompson, would struggle and finish third in the conference. Instead, the Orangemen surprised everyone by winning the Big East regular-season championship. They finished with a 12-4 record and went undefeated outside of the conference.

title: Insider-Case Settlement
description: Two Dutch businessmen have settled charges that they engaged in an insider trading scheme, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday.

title: More Exact Phone Billing Set For Business, but Not Homes
description: Place a call from New York to Los Angeles at precisely 8 P.M., talk until 8:02:04 and hang up. How long was the call?

title: Winnie Mandela Trial Witness Tells of Stabbing
description: The star witness in the trial of Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, testified today that during the time he said he was held prisoner in Mrs. Mandela's house, her chief bodyguard forced him to go out and take part in the attempted murder of another Soweto youth.

title: Park Ave. Lawyer Indicted As a $3.5 Million Swindler
description: Harvey Myerson, a flamboyant corporate lawyer with a taste for Rolls-Royces, racing cars and raccoon coats, was charged yesterday with bilking clients and partners at his Park Avenue law firm of millions of dollars.

title: Satire: A Haven In Days Of Bore
description: ANYONE who expected the 90's to erupt in fin-de-siecle decadence obviously lost a bet. Fortunately, there are antidotes to this staid era, in irreverent works of social satire. Here, in words and pictures, is a dog on a psychiatrist's couch, a do-it-yourself guide to becoming a 90's prig, Elvis imitators of various races, sizes and species, and some wicked poetry written in the guise of Nancy Reagan. They're jokes, but you can think of them as cultural artifacts.

title: Warnings Preceded London Bombings
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald H. Klein, 58; Led Volunteer Group
description: Donald H. Klein, executive vice president of the American Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training Federation, died on Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: NCR Said To Expect Takeover
description: In a meeting yesterday with securities analysts, the chairman of NCR, Charles E. Exley Jr., appeared to acknowledge that a takeover by A.T.& T. was all but inevitable.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Capriati and Graf Advance Jennifer Capriati beat her doubles partner, and Steffi Graf routed her nation's second-ranked player yesterday at the Virginia Slims of Florida in Boca Raton. Capriati, playing for the second time in 16 hours, advanced to the quarterfinals by sweeping Gigi Fernandez, 6-3, 6-2. A short time later, they teamed to win a doubles match. Graf looked sharp in her first match in more than a month and beat a fellow German, Anke Huber, 6-0, 6-1. (AP) BASEBALL Rocky Start for Clemens Roger Clemens was not kicked out but he was knocked around. Clemens, last seen being ejected from the mound in the American League playoffs, was tagged for five runs and five hits in two innings as the Pittsburgh Pirates battered Boston, 10-7, in an exhibition opener at Winter Haven, Fla. (AP) HORSE RACING Star Standing Wins A three-horse photo was needed to decide the $50,000 Little Bonny Handicap for fillies and mares at Gulfstream Park, and the photo showed Star Standing one head in front of the favored Rigamajig, who was one neck in front of the filly Ahead. With Chris Antley riding, Star Standing ran the mile and a half on the turf in 2:31 3/5 and returned $8.80 for each $2 bet. In a six-and-a-half-furlong allowance race, Romiano closed fast to nip Seurot in the stretch. Much of the interest centered on Happy Jazz Band, who last year ran fourth to Fly So Free in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile and second in the Champagne. This time, Fly So Free was resting in his barn for the Florida Derby, but Happy Jazz Band finished fourth again. Romiano, a Fappiano colt, went the distance in 1:16 4/5 and paid $5.40 for $2 to win.

title: Halliburton Issue Totals $650 Million
description: The Halliburton Company, one of the world's largest diversified oilfield service companies, yesterday priced $650 million in zero-coupon convertible subordinated debentures due on March 13, 2006, through its underwriters, Lehman Brothers and Lazard Freres & Company.

title: 19 Cities Listed for Aid To Cut Infant Mortality
description: Federal officials said today that they had tentatively identified 19 cities eligible for $171 million in Federal grants to combat very high infant mortality, but that the cities would have to compete for the money.

title: Accounts
description: * Schering-Plough Healthcare Products to William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, a health-care advertising agency, for respiratory and women's products. Billings are estimated at $2 million to $3 million. * Angus Inc., San Mateo, Calif., the largest franchisee of Jenny Craig Weight Loss Centers, to Ayer. Billings were not disclosed. The account was previously held by the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Scott S. Huston; Composer, 74
description: Scott S. Huston, a composer and professor emeritus at the College-Conservatory of Music of the University of Cincinnati, died last Friday at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: Gay Group Rebuffed in Bid To Join St. Patrick's Parade
description: In recent years, controversy has become as much a part of the St. Patrick's Day parade as Irish bagpipes, shillelaghs, politicians and green beer.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Coming Home; First U.S. Unit Returns From Persian Gulf to Heroes' Welcome in Georgia
description: More than 100 members of the Army's 24th Mechanized Infantry Division arrived here to a hero's welcome early today, beginning the triumphant return of American troops from the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Profits Expected To Grow at Ionics
description: Ionics Inc., a water purification company, expects strong growth in profits, its president, Arthur Goldstein, said after a speech to investors. He said it was too early to know how much business the company might gain from the rebuilding of Kuwait, where the Watertown, Mass., company has built water desalting plants.

title: Anacomp Chief Settles Charges
description: The chairman of Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis computer services company, has settled civil charges of engaging in what was reported to be an insider trading scheme, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: Chrysler Given Safety Lecture
description: The opening presentation at the Chrysler Corporation's monthly board meeting in New York yesterday may deserve a footnote in the American corporate history books.

title: Depositions Can Be Ordeal as Well as a Protection
description: For Susan Sweetser, being kidnapped and raped in December 1980 was only the beginning of her ordeal. By the time her case was resolved last fall and her attacker convicted, she had been through two trials, two guilty verdicts and two appeals.

title: Courier Takes Control of Pace and Agassi to Advance
description: Andre Agassi has bulked up his body, dusted some of the glitter from his image and has even acquired enough interest in his training regimen to be able to make legitimate reference to his practice habits.

title: Senate Passes Changes in Aid In Florio Plan
description: A proposal to significantly change Gov. Jim Florio's school-aid plan was passed by the State Senate today, coming under attack from education groups and a lawyer who said it would be overturned by the courts.

title: Level With Labor -- and New York City
description: Municipal labor leaders are furious, and who can blame them? A misleading memo from New York City's Budget Director, Philip Michael, told a bond rating agency that negotiations were under way to defer part of the wage increases they had just won.

title: Joseph Selly, 85, Dies; Former Labor Leader
description: Joseph P. Selly, a former labor leader in New York, died on Wednesday at Northridge Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Plantation, Fla.

title: California Not Alone in Its Nursing Home Revolt
description: California decided to challenge a Federal law setting more stringent standards for nursing homes after hearing that many smaller states were also troubled by the costly procedures but were wary of defying the Bush Administration.

title: Condom Giveaway Will Never Replace Values; God Didn't Approve
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacific Exchange Hours
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange expects to extend its trading hours by 30 to 45 minutes a day to attract Asian business, the exchange chairman, Lee Korins, said today. The exchange now closes at 1:30 P.M.

title: Review/Film; Judging a Killer In the Chill Calm Of Prewar Italy
description: At the start of the somberly handsome Italian thriller "Open Doors," a calm, neatly dressed man returns to the office from which he has recently been dismissed. He is armed with a long, sharp knife. With shocking efficiency, he quickly murders two former colleagues who were instrumental in bringing about his downfall. Moments later, after politely leaving the building, he rapes and kills his wife.

title: S.E.C. Charges In Revco Case
description: Federal regulators have accused the son of Revco D.S. Inc.'s founder of tipping off his brother-in-law to a pending buyout of the chain before it was publicly announced.

title: Congressmen Fault F.D.A. On Generics
description: The Food and Drug Administration failed to take early action against abuses and poor quality control by some generic drug companies because of its cumbersome bureaucracy, three Congressmen asserted today.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Veterans; Outpouring of Scholarships and Jobs Await Returning Heroes After the Ticker Tape
description: In a homecoming fit for conquering heroes, a grateful American public will bestow more than ticker tape on troops returning from the Persian Gulf. There are offers of college scholarships, carpenter jobs that pay $22 an hour, free weekends in wine country, even promises to baby-sit the children.

title: For Children
description: Children's Petting Zoo Central Park Fifth Avenue at 67th Street (212) 408-0271 Recommended ages: 1 and up

title: Rangers Lose Face And Newest Player
description: Joe Kocur, acquired by the Rangers on Tuesday to add a dimension of toughness, spent the third period in a local hospital and stayed behind when his teammates headed home tonight after he complained he had trouble breathing.

title: Slovenes Vote to Make Duty In Yugoslav Army Voluntary
description: In another challenge to crumbling central authority, the Parliament of the Slovenian republic voted today to halt obligatory military service for Slovenes in the Yugoslav Army.

title: Stumbling Islanders Are Shut Out by Surging Red Wings, 2-0
description: Tim Cheveldae made 27 saves and Sergei Fedorov had a goal and an assist tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Islanders, 2-0, for their fourth victory in five games.

title: House Approves $200 Million To Speed Benefits to Jobless
description: The House of Representatives today approved a $200 million grant to the states to help them speed the processing of unemployment benefit applications.

title: Dow Declines by 9.90 in Cautious Trading
description: Blue chips and other big stocks weakened yesterday in cautious trading after Wall Street's drive to push the Dow Jones industrial average through the 3,000 barrier fizzled on Wednesday. Smaller stocks moved higher but overall changes were slim.

title: Prison Protest in Texas
description: Federal inmates complaining that they were not being fed enough vegetables took over part of a privately run prison in protest on Wednesday and held the authorities at bay with kitchen utensils and baseball bats before surrendering today. The protest occurred at the Eden Detention Center here, which is run under contract with the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

title: 2 Chains Halting Sales of Drugs in Capsules
description: Two large drugstore chains have halted all sales of over-the-counter drugs in capsules after poisoned Sudafed capsules were found in their stores.

title: Condom Giveaway Will Never Replace Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideological Fight Looms Over Appeals Nominee
description: The Bush Administration's decision to press ahead with its attempt to promote Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp to an important Federal appeals court vacancy may prove to be the kind of full-scale ideological battle over a judicial nomination that has not been seen in the last few years.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "JAZZ DES JEUNES," an evening of Haitian big-band music inspired by American swing, Cuban mambo and indigenous folklore. At the New-York Historical Society Auditorium, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, Manhattan, tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. Admission, $7 and $5 for museum members. Information: (212) 873-3400, extension 246. "HOW THE WORLD GOT WISDOM," a celebration of four African tales featuring African-style percussion and dance. At the Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 and 3:30 P.M. Tickets, $6. Reservations: (212) 666-1716.

title: Tsongas Plans to Enter Race for President
description: Former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts says he plans to announce his candidacy for the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination next month.

title: GTE Announces Merger Expenses
description: The GTE Corporation said it would take a one-time after-tax charge of $245 million for its merger with the Contel Corporation. The charge reflects the costs of completing the merger and integrating the operations of the two companies, GTE said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As a composer for the movie "The Lady and the Tramp," PEGGY LEE wrote the songs and played four of the parts as well. She wants a share of the profits from the videocassette sales of the Walt Disney film and is asking a jury to award her $35 million. The trial began yesterday in Los Angeles County Superior Court.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's like a new trend. More and more girls are getting them. If you go to a club on Friday night, that's all you'll see -- boys with beepers and girls with beepers." -- Caroline Mendes, a 16-year-old New Yorker. [ A1:4. ]

title: Anthony Kerrigan; Translator of Works in Spanish Was 72
description: Anthony Kerrigan, a poet and translator of works by Spanish and Latin American writers, died Thursday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 72 years old.

title: Krykostas Memorial
description: Works by Mark Kyrkostas are to be performed in a memorial tribute to the composer today at 3 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street, Manhattan. Mr. Kyrkostas, who was 38 years old, died of AIDS in December. The performers include Susanna Nason, a pianist; Artemis Theodos, a violinist, and members of the Mark Kyrkostas Quartet. Admission is free. Information: (718) 428-5610.

title: Nederlander (Quietly) Runs Show
description: This has traditionally been George Steinbrenner's day in the sun, but now it belongs to Robert Nederlander.

title: For New Soviet Immigrants in Israel, Hard Times
description: Two years after large numbers of Soviet Jews began moving to Israel, this nation's warm hopes and fond dreams for a comfortable union of two Jewish peoples are running afoul of cold economic reality.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review in Weekend yesterday mistranslated the name of a Spanish dish served by El Parador Cafe, 325 East 34th Street, in Manhattan. Ropa vieja means old clothes, not old rope.

title: Court Rejects U.S. Effort to Keep Exxon Valdez Agreement Secret
description: A Federal appeals court today dismissed an urgent request by the Justice Department to prevent public disclosure of the secret $1.2 billion agreement to settle claims from the Exxon Valdez oil spill two years ago.

title: Deficit Shuts Rhode Island Government
description: Fighting a huge budget deficit, Rhode Island's government shut down today, furloughing for a day state workers ranging from Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun and the Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court to courthouse elevator operators and welfare caseworkers.

title: 'Unhittable' Yankee Hurler
description: He is very tall and very lean and very brainy and quite odd. He is 6 feet 6 inches, weighs 215 pounds, has a degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Pennsylvania, and, standing on the pitcher's mound looking like a stork, appears not to belong there.

title: St. John's and Syracuse Tumble in the Big East
description: After they lost by 10 points to DePaul last Saturday, the Redmen of St. John's rationalized the defeat by saying it was an instance of a team with nothing to prove running into a hot-shooting team in desperate need of a victory.

title: College Hockey; B.U. to Face Maine in Final
description: Boston University swarmed over the Friars of Providence College and beat them, 7-5, at Boston Garden tonight in a semifinal match at the Hockey East tournament.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Intelligence; U.S. WARNS IRAQIS AGAINST USING GAS TO END REBELLION
description: Allied intelligence agencies have intercepted communications from Iraq's military command in Baghdad authorizing the use of chemical weapons against anti-Government rebels in the cities of Najaf and Karbala, Bush Administration and allied officials said today.

title: Unemployment Is at 4-Year High With Jump to 6.5% Last Month
description: The nation's employment picture deteriorated significantly last month, with payrolls shrinking and the jobless rate rising to its highest point in nearly four years.

title: Kendall Stearns, Surgeon, 75
description: Dr. Kendall Stearns, a physician and surgeon in Hudson, N.Y., for more than 40 years, died on Wednesday at Exeter Hospital in New Hampshire. He was 75 years old and had moved to Exeter about a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about a joint venture involving the Compaq Computer Corporation and Silicon Graphics Inc. misstated the location of Compaq's headquarters. It is in Houston.

title: Review/Pop; Paul Simon and African-Style Big Band
description: Paul Simon has discovered the glories of the big band -- not an Ellingtonian orchestra of saxophones and brass, but an African-style ensemble of percussion, guitars, singers, keyboards and horns. With a back rank of four Brazilian percussionists and an American drummer and a front line of three African guitarists (along with Mr. Simon strumming an acoustic guitar), the group can interlock riff with riff, rhythm with rhythm, in a proudly international groove.

title: Economic Lift Is Predicted
description: The end of the Persian Gulf war should lift the world's leading industrial economies out of a slowdown, a senior German monetary official said today.

title: Hatfield Failed to Disclose Gifts Worth $9,265
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield broke Senate rules by failing to disclose $9,265 in artwork that he received as gifts in the mid-1980's from the University of South Carolina.

title: Count d'Ornano, 66, Ex-Minister in France
description: Count Michel d'Ornano, an industrialist and a former French Cabinet minister, died yesterday after he was struck by a car near his home in the Paris suburb of St.-Cloud, Reuters reported. He was 66 years old.

title: Troubled Bridges, Troubled Waters
description: The Dinkins administration says last week's City Council hearing "fully vindicated" the city's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius Riccio, and his approach to bridge safety. But while Mr. Riccio proved an adept witness, New Yorkers have little cause to feel reassured.

title: Review/Music: Guest Conductor Steps In Yet Again for Philharmonic
description: The only certainty for New York Philharmonic audiences this season has been uncertainty. Program makers propose but events dispose. The death of Leonard Bernstein, the decision of Zubin Mehta to join his colleagues in Israel during the Persian Gulf war and, most recently, the illness of Klaus Tennstedt have dealt the schedule especially heavy blows.

title: Dow Drops by 8.17 to Close at 2,955.20
description: In spite of signs that the Fed eased monetary policy to bring interest rates down, stocks dropped sharply in the final two hours of trading yesterday to end in minus territory. Professional program selling was heavy.

title: Religion Notes
description: In Search of the Word

title: Conviction Is Upheld In Computer Jamming
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of a graduate computer-science student from Cornell University who in November 1988 unleashed a rogue program that jammed several thousand computers in a nationwide network.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Baker Outlines Peace Approach; Saudis Say They Will Be 'Active'
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave Saudi leaders Washington's ideas for an approach to Arab-Israeli peacemaking today, and the Saudis indicated that they were prepared to be "active," a senior Administration official said.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Press; 40 Western Journalists Are Freed By Baghdad
description: Forty Western journalists, held captive by Iraq for almost a week, were turned over to the International Red Cross in Baghdad yesterday and were expected to leave the country today.

title: Subway Officials Unveil New Fire-Safety Plans
description: Responding to a highly critical internal report on the handling of a fatal subway-tunnel fire, officials of the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that they would revamp rescue procedures and repair subway tracks wherever they are vulnerable to the kind of short circuit that started the fire.

title: Japanese Star Denied
description: In a country where labor-management relations are generally noncombative, Hiromitsu Ochiai, Japan's only three-time triple crown winner, lost his case yesterday after the first salary arbitration hearing in Japanese baseball history.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "You come home with your head held high and your chest out. You have people honking their horns and waving their flags all along the expressway. It's just a terrific feeling."

title: Dr. Leon Roizin, 78, Drug Researcher, Dies
description: Dr. Leon Roizin, a researcher in the field of drugs that affect the mind and the central nervous system, died on Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Accor S.A., Paris, an operator of hotels and restaurants, said it would acquire about 60 new hotels in the United States in the first half of 1991 for about $120 million. The company said it would acquire one unnamed hotel chain with 100 hotels for about $100 million. The other hotels will be acquired from other companies. * Bankers First Corp., Augusta, Ga., will sell its Athens Federal Savings Bank subsidiary to Synovus Financial Corp., Columbus, Ga., for about $40 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. JOHN JULIAN WILD, a Minneapolis surgeon, and Prof.JACQUES-LOUIS LIONS, a French mathematician, have won the Japan Prize, awarded annually for contributions to science and human betterment. They will each collect prizes of about $370,000 on April 25 in Tokyo.

title: Review/Opera; On a Bold Tack, the Amato Presents 'I Due Foscari'
description: The Amato Opera, now in its 43d season, has won itself an enthusiastic following by balancing standard repertory works with pieces that have been neglected by larger, richer companies. This season, the company's plans include productions of "Tosca" and "La Traviata," but its lure for the more adventurous is Verdi's sixth opera, "I Due Foscari." The production opened last Saturday evening at the company's intimate theater at 319 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, and is to continue on weekends through March 24.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Mutombo And Hoyas Rebound
description: For most of the last two weeks, the Georgetown Hoyas had found themselves in the unfamiliar position of having to hear about their diminishing chances of making the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iran's Leader Calls on Hussein to Quit
description: In a revival of public hostility toward Iraq, Iran's leader called today for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to resign.

title: Japanese Nuclear Plant Reports Shutdown
description: A sudden jump in pressure in a reaction chamber at an experimental nuclear fuel reprocessing plant caused an automatic shutdown Friday night, the latest in a string of problems for Japan's nuclear industry, a plant spokesman said today.

title: Toys 'R' Us Japan Is Moving Ahead
description: The chamber of commerce approved Toys "R" Us Japan's plans to open a store in Niigata, a city on Japan's west coast, despite opposition from toy shop owners.

title: AFTER THE WAR: . . . And His Wife; Stormin'? He Prefers 'The Bear'
description: Brenda Schwarzkopf, the wife of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the United States forces in the Persian Gulf, stepped into the limelight today and pondered what might be ahead for the couple after the general's retirement this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Fernandez Plan Questioned

title: Contract for Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a division of the Lockheed Corporation, has been awarded a $757 million contract by the Defense Department for work on the Trident missile program, the Navy said on Thursday. The contract is for work and services to be performed at Sunnyvale, Calif., and at the Kings Bay, Ga., submarine base. The work is expected to be completed in 1994.

title: Thinking About 1992
description: Here are two notable facts that conceivably might turn the fast-approaching Presidential campaign into a serious contest:

title: Acquisition Of Lincoln's Branches Set
description: The story of the troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association moved one step closer to completion today when the Great Western Financial Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Lincoln's 28 branches from the Federal Government.

title: Air France Cancels Some Cutbacks
description: Air France rescinded part of an emergency plan to reduce wages and working hours by 6 percent, citing a rebound in passenger traffic since the end of the gulf war. Air France said it would resume previously canceled spring and summer flight programs and add new flights to some destinations.

title: Neighbors Ask, How Could Parents Let That Baby Starve?
description: Yvette Beltram was awakened on Thursday morning by hysterical screams that echoed down the corridors of her Bronx apartment building, a newly renovated home for homeless families.

title: East Europe, Gulf Meetings
description: Senior government and central bank officials from the Group of 10 industrial nations will meet on Saturday in Paris to discuss aid to Eastern Europe, the Swiss Finance Ministry said today.

title: About New York; An Extra Dose Of Travelers' Aid For Lost Souls
description: Holden Caulfield, hero of J. D. Salinger's novel "Catcher in the Rye," dreamed of guarding a cliff to keep children from falling. "That's all I'd do all day," he said.

title: Lionel O. Lindsay, N.A.A.C.P. Leader, 87
description: Lionel O. Lindsay, an accountant and former president of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died Wednesday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Oak Bluffs. He was 87 years old and lived in Oak Bluffs.

title: Bud Berman, Manufacturer, 74
description: Bud Berman, a clothing manufacturer, died Thursday at Sarasota Hospital in Florida. He was 74 years old and lived in Osprey, Fla., and in St. Louis.

title: Polish Airline
description: LOT, Poland's national airline, must get rid of all its Soviet-made aircraft before it can offer shares to foreign investors, its manager, Bronislaw Klimaszewski, said. "We must sell all our Soviet-made planes and replace them with modern Western aircraft," Mr. Klimaszewski said. "No foreign investor will buy an interest in our company while 80 percent of its fleet are planes that must bring losses." The Government decided this week to offer a 49 percent stake in LOT to investors while giving a 51 percent interest to the Treasury.

title: Raymond J. Gallagher, Catholic Bishop, 78
description: Raymond J. Gallagher, retired Roman Catholic bishop of the diocese of Lafayette, Ind., died Thursday after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Muncie.

title: Germans Criticize Handling of Report on Official's Role as Informer
description: The German Government's attempt to rehabilitate the former East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, despite evidence that he was once a police informant has set off protests and led to the dismissal of two officials investigating the former government's secret police.

title: Dinkins Backs School Geared to Minorities
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday endorsed the idea of an experimental public high school that would stress the education of young black and Hispanic men, taking sides on an issue that has divided his own longtime liberal and civil-rights coalition.

title: Surgeons' Group Is First to Urge AIDS-Infected Doctors to Stop Operating
description: The nation's largest organization of bone and joint surgeons yesterday advised members who are infected with the AIDS virus to inform patients of their condition and stop performing surgery except in emergencies.

title: Journalists Free, but Others Remain
description: The freeing of 40 Western journalists held by Iraq is cause for rejoicing by family, friends and colleagues. Along with two U.S. servicemen, they have been turned over to the Red Cross. It appears that most of the journalists were captured on the outskirts of Basra and two days later taken to Baghdad. Early reports suggest that they were not ill treated.

title: Of Paul, Asceticism And Homosexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE WAR: Britain; At Air Base West of London, 17 Dead Come Home
description: The bodies of 17 British soldiers killed in the Persian Gulf war were flown home today to an emotional ceremony attended by weeping relatives, military officials and a member of the royal family.

title: John Sylvester Woodbridge, Executive, 94
description: John Sylvester Woodbridge, former controller of Pan American World Airways, died on March 1 at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 94 years old.

title: Coping/With Building a Birdhouse
description: Building a birdhouse can be a satisfying late-winter project, one particularly well suited to an adult and a child working together. The lessons are many: a bit of carpentry, ornithology and ecology. And so are the rewards, among them the sense of accomplishment that comes in building something with your own hands.

title: Give Them More Than Parades
description: As the first troops return from Operation Desert Storm, jubilant Americans are offering them jobs and weekend jaunts, baseball tickets and free baby-sitting. President Bush has granted returning Government employees five days off. The generosity is richly deserved. But in the long run these and all other members of the armed forces will deserve more.

title: Shutdown Warning At Pan Am
description: The operations of Pan American World Airlines could be shut down as early as next week if negotiators from the United States and Britain fail to reach an agreement that would allow Pan Am to transfer its London routes, several advisers to Pan Am said yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Center Drops the Joffrey
description: The Los Angeles Music Center has decided not to extend its contract with the Joffrey Ballet, which has been the center's resident ballet troupe since 1983.

title: James (Cool Papa) Bell, 87, Dies; Legendary Star of Negro Leagues
description: James (Cool Papa) Bell, the sharp-eyed batter and blazing base runner who was widely regarded as the fastest man ever to play baseball, died Thursday night in St. Louis University Hospital, where he had been treated after suffering a heart attack last Saturday.

title: Punitive Damages, Unpunished
description: Bowing to tradition and bending to reality, the Supreme Court decided this week to do nothing about what some people consider runaway damage awards in civil cases. After wrestling for years with the constitutionality of punitive damages, the Court, despite misgivings, now sustains them. The Justices will be content to cheer for reforms at the state level and perhaps set aside a truly outrageous award at some point in the future.

title: Reviews/Music; Soprano Joins 'Luisa Miller'
description: Maria Scapagna, an American soprano who has performed with the New York City Opera and other companies around the country, made a promising Metropolitan Opera debut on Tuesday evening. Ms. Scapagna took over the title role in Verdi's "Luisa Miller," joining a finely balanced cast that included Luciano Pavarotti as Rodolfo, Leo Nucci as Miller, Franco De Grandis as Wurm, Wendy White as Federica and Dimitri Kavrakos as Count Walter.

title: Miami Finds Mixed Results In Fernandez's School Plan
description: Granting teachers in the Miami area a larger voice in running their schools -- the centerpiece of Joseph A. Fernandez's efforts to reform schools first there and now in New York City -- has improved the school climate and teacher morale, but after three years the idea has yet to make a difference in student performance in reading and mathematics, a study of the Dade County, Florida, school system has found.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Louisville Closes in on .500 and N.C.A.A. Bid
description: LaBradford Smith's reverse layup with five seconds left lifted Louisville to a 72-70 victory over Memphis State tonight and moved the Cardinals within one triumph of their fourth straight Metro Conference tournament title.

title: After Latest Scare, U.S. Is Reviewing Use of Drug Capsules
description: After two deaths in Washington state from Sudafed decongestant capsules tainted with cyanide, a Food and Drug Administration study group is mulling the future of over-the-counter capsules.

title: Patents; Unaddressed Question in Amgen Case
description: In handing Amgen Inc. a stunning victory in its four-year patent feud over a top-selling anti-anemia drug, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit this week all but ended one of the most closely watched legal battles in biotechnology.

title: Palsy Victim Cleared in Fight With Officers
description: In a case that the judge called "the saddest story I've ever heard," a man suffering from cerebral palsy has been acquitted of charges that he obstructed a police officer and resisted arrest.

title: Nigerians Speak Warmly of the Peace Corps; Reunion in August
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Spoken Word listing in Weekend yesterday misstated the admission price for a lecture by the author Yevgeny Yevtushenko today at 8 and 10:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 and 7 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets. It is $15, not $29.95.

title: Romanian Money Rules
description: Officials announced today that most restrictions on foreign exchange in Romania would be abolished in an effort to heal the economy and curb the black market.

title: Schooling of Boy, 4, Snarled by Long Hair
description: A school board has refused to waive the dress code for a 4-year-old boy whose parents say they had promised God they would not cut the boy's shoulder-length hair until they are certain he is free of cancer.

title: Recycling Program in New York Falls Behind Second-Year Goals
description: New York City's recycling program has fallen behind the annual tonnage requirements set by the city's mandatory recycling law, the Sanitation Commissioner says.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consolidated Rail Corp., Philadelphia, named Richard S. Pyson vice president-engineering. * Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc., Mount Holly, N.J., said Paul K. Kavanaugh had joined the company as vice president of product development.

title: British Leader Dismisses Loss In Local Vote as a Tax Protest
description: A day after a resounding special-election defeat for the British Conservative Party, Prime Minister John Major and his aides today shrugged off the result as a protest against the Government's unpopular "poll tax" rather than an indication of no confidence.

title: AFTER THE WAR: First Back; Troops Return to a Tumult of Hurrahs
description: After all the remarkable sights and sounds from the Middle East, the most amazing sight of all for many of the troops of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division was the homecoming -- the flag-waving, horn-honking crowd that turned out to greet them in the early morning hours and again this afternoon.

title: Layoffs at Weirton
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation, one of the nation's largest employee-owned companies, will lay off workers and eliminate management positions. A company spokesman, Charles R. Cronin, said the number of layoffs had not been determined. He said Weirton, which has 8,000 workers, had been hurt by the decreasing demand for sheet metal, which represents 60 percent of its business.

title: Longer St. Patrick's Parade May Allow Gay Irish Group
description: Entering the rough-and-tumble arena of St. Patrick's Day parade politics, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had found a way to allow a group of gay men and women to join the celebration: tacking an hour onto what is already billed as the world's longest parade.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The General . . .; 'We Did It As a Part Of a Team'
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of Operation Desert Storm, bid farewell today to some of the first of his front-line troops to head home.

title: Review/Television; Soviet Concert Honors a Favorite Son
description: With the Soviet Union in turmoil, stark contrasts abound. Dec. 1, for example, saw the reinstatement of food rationing in Leningrad for the first time since World War II, but the day ended with celebratory cannon shots and fireworks in Leningrad's Square of the Artists.

title: Chevron Revises Plans for Refinery
description: A unit of the Chevron Corporation revised modernization plans for its Richmond, Calif., refinery because of higher-than-expected costs. Chevron U.S.A. Inc. said it had dropped plans for a 45,000-barrel-a-day coking unit at the refinery near San Francisco because costs would approach $2 billion, compared with a previous estimate of $1.3 billion.

title: George A. Diehl Jr., Engineer, 82
description: George A. Diehl Jr., an engineer and former president of the New Jersey School Boards Association, died on Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: Hallmark Forms Media Subsidiary
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. has formed a majority-owned subsidiary to acquire and operate communications properties.

title: Many Public Employees Out of Jobs As Governments Try to Stem Deficits
description: At this time of the year, Rita Caulfield could usually be found on weekday mornings poring over tax filings in the Boston assessor's office, where she worked as an analyst. Instead, on a snowy New England morning Mrs. Caulfield was in line at the Massachusetts Employment and Training office in this Boston suburb, waiting to receive her unemployment check.

title: OHIO TRUST GETS $250 MILLION GIFT
description: Leslie H. Wexner, the billionaire retailer of women's apparel, has given $250 million of his fortune to support a broad range of organizations and programs, including education.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Coming Home; A Jet Ride Full of Joy and Culture Shock
description: Shortly before the 747 jetliner set down here this morning at the end of its long journey, Maj. Ted Pusey, the adjutant for the First Brigade of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, confronted culture shock.

title: Key Rates
Approval for Merck
description: Merck & Company said its Merck Sharpe Dohme unit's Zocor, a treatment for elevated cholesterol, had received approval from an advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration. The company said Zocor, first introduced in Sweden in 1988, had 1990 sales of $290 million in more than 20 countries. Merck's stock rose $1.375 today, to $105.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NCR Chief Reasserts View That A.T.&T. Bid Is Too Low
description: Charles E. Exley Jr., chairman of the NCR Corporation, said yesterday that his position had not changed and that he still considered A.T.& T.'s $90-a-share cash offer grossly inadequate. Securities analysts who attended a meeting with Mr. Exley on Thursday said he seemed prepared to let the company be acquired if A.T.& T. raised its offer.

title: Decision on U.S. Coach
description: Alan Rothenberg, president of the United States Soccer Federation, says he will hire a coach for the national team next week, and Bora Milutinovic says he expects to be the one. Milutinovic, a 46-year-old Yugloslav who coached Mexico in the 1986 World Cup and Costa Rica in the 1990 World Cup, plans to meet Monday in Los Angeles with Rothenberg.

title: Treat Sweetens Marines' Trip
description: A planeload of 400 American marines flying home from Saudi Arabia had a treat today to break up the trip. During a refueling stop, Peter Secchia, the American Ambassador to Italy, showed up at Leonardo da Vinci Airport with a truckload of donated gelato for the Third Brigade, based at the Kaneohe Bay Marine Air Station. "We're going to give you Italian gelato, the best in the world," he said. "And as you enjoy this ice cream, know how much we enjoy you and are proud of you."

title: Sudan's Relief Needs Could Become Dire
description: To the Editor:

title: Majority on F.C.C. Opposing Networks On TV Rerun Sales
description: In what appears to be a serious setback for television networks, a majority of the five-member Federal Communications Commission now favors continuing to limit the ability of the networks to sell lucrative television reruns.

title: Family of Five Is Asphyxiated By Van Fumes
description: A pediatrician, his wife and their three children were found asphyxiated today by carbon monoxide fumes from a van left running in the family's garage, apparently while they slept, the authorities said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Gains Semifinals Steffi Graf, seeking to end a slump that has cost her the No. 1 world ranking, yesterday won a title that has eluded her since last November: semifinalist. Graf, eliminated in the quarterfinals of her two previous tournaments this year, defeated Meredith McGrath, 6-3, 6-1, to advance to today's semifinals in the Virginia Slims of Florida in Boca Raton. The top-seeded German will play No. 8-seeded Nathalie Tauziat of France. Tauziat beat an injured Mary Joe Fernandez, the No. 3-seeded player, 6-1, 7-5. In the other semifinal, 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati, who is seeded fourth, will play second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini. Capriati won her quarterfinal match against Claudia Porwik, 6-1, 6-4, and Sabatini beat Regina Rajchrtova, 6-2, 6-2. Graf's record streak of 186 weeks at No. 1 will end Monday, when she is replaced in the rankings by Monica Seles. (AP) Edberg Defeats Chang: Stefan Edberg, intent on protecting his No. 1 world ranking, moved into the semifinals of the Newsweek Champions Cup yesterday, but ninth-seeded Michael Chang forced him to survive an endurance test before he emerged with a 1-6, 6-2, 7-5 victory in Indian Wells, Calif. Edberg, the defending champion, fought off five break points in the ninth game of the final set before Chang finally sent a backhand approach into the net. The Swede ended the match by breaking Chang's serve with a deep forehand into corner that Chang backhanded into the net. N.B.A. Suns Win Fifth in Row on Road Jeff Hornacek scored 20 points and five of his teammates were in double figures last night as the Suns won their fifth consecutive road game, 117-91, over the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre. (AP) Bulls 99, Utah 89: Michael Jordan scored 17 of his 37 points in the fourth quarter as Chicago rallied for its 22d straight home victory. (AP) BOXING Witherspoon Wins Split Decision In a bout marked by inept performances, Tim Witherspoon won a 12-round split decision over Carl Williams and took Williams's United States Boxing Association heavywight title last night at the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, N.J. Judges Eva Shane and Joe Pasquale each scored the bout, 115-113, for Witherspoon. The other judge, Jean Williams had it, 116-112, for Williams. "I was hoping they'd call it a draw," said Ron Katz, a matchmaker to the fight's promoter, Bob Arum. "Neither guy deserved to win. If we paid them by the punch, they'd owe us. The 33-year-old Witherspoon (34-3, 22 knockouts) weighed in at 236 pounds. Williams (23-4, 18 knockouts), 31, was 236 1/2. In an earlier bout, Bobby Czyz won a 12-round split decision from Robert Daniels to capture the World Boxing Association cruiserweight title. N.H.L. Blackhawks End Road Slump Jeremy Roenick scored twice in the second period, his 35th and 36th goals of the season, as Chicago defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 5-3, last night for its first victory in six road games (1-4-1). Dale Hawerchuk got his 1,000th point on a second-period goal for Buffalo, which stretched its franchise-record home winless streak to 11 games (o-6-5). (AP) TRACK AND FIELD O'Sullivan and Guidry Triumph Sonia O'Sullivan of Villanova and Ireland and Carlette Guidry of Texas began their quests for double titles yesterday as the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championshps began in Indianapolis. O'Sullivan won the women's 5,000-meter final in 15 minutes 49.46 seconds and her mile heat in 4:41.88. Guidry won the women's 200-meter final in 23.23 seconds and her 55-meter semifinal in 6.80 seconds. Guidry won both titles last year. The championships began yesterday afternoon and last night at the Hoosier Dome, with finals in 11 events and trials in 19 others. The last 19 finals will be held tonight. No athlete attracted more attention than Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, the Notre Dame football star. He qualified for the men's 55-meter final by finishing second in his heat in 6.19 seconds and winning his semifinal in 6.13, the fastest time of the day.

title: Mastercard, in Turn, Names Head for U.S.
description: Mastercard International, not to be outdone by its rival Visa, which named a president for its American operations last month, did the same yesterday. Peter S.P. Dimsey will be the Mastercard president for the United States.

title: Iraqis Facing Food Shortages
description: Despite anticipated bumper crops, Iraqis are expected to face food shortages this year because of the Persian Gulf war, a Congressional report says.

title: Albanian Refugees Taken to Shelters
description: Fearing an epidemic among thousands of Albanian refugees sleeping in the open in squalid conditions at dockside here, the Italian police began rounding them up this evening to move them into local schools for the night.

title: Needed for Tough Times: A $75 Tie
description: For 77 years, American men of means have bought suits bearing the label of Oxxford Clothes, probably the nation's highest-priced domestic suits, at $1,100 to $2,500 each.

title: Orangemen's Blunders Lead to 70-68 Upset
description: From the moment the Big East tournament seedings were announced and Villanova was placed in Syracuse's bracket, Orangemen supporters must have begun to get an uneasy feeling.

title: Five More Days Of Vacation
description: President Bush today ordered that workers who had left Federal jobs to serve with the armed forces in the Persian Gulf be given five additional days of vacation, and that returning veterans be given priority for Government jobs.

title: Books of The Times; How Roosevelt's Successors Compare
description: The Riddle of Power Presidential Leadership From Truman to Bush By Robert Shogan 352 pages. Dutton. $21.95.

title: Dinkins Plans a New Group To Address Fiscal Troubles
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to call together bankers, realtors, labor and other civic leaders in a group modeled after the bailout effort that pulled New York through the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the First Deputy Mayor announced last night.

title: Strawberry Has Big Day Against the Mets but Shuns Big Talk
description: Darryl Strawberry would not look into the dugout of his former team as he rounded third base today, his first home run of the spring having sunk into the swamplands beyond the right-field fence. If there was reason to rub it in against the Mets, there was no desire to insult friends. And so there was no glare, no stare, no pointing of a finger.

title: Ex-Critic of Contract System Is Selected to Head Agency
description: Michael C. Rodgers, who once described the city's contracting system as a ship without a captain, yesterday was appointed to run and revamp it.

title: Transit Authority Can Cut Its Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball; St. Raymond's Wins First Title
description: A standing-room-only crowd of more than 4,000 spectators at Fordham University's Rose Hill Gymnasium last night watched St. Raymond's of the Bronx win its first Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title. St. Raymond's beat Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn, 70-67, in a game between the two top-ranked teams in the state.

title: Review/Dance; For 20 Years, Distinctly Trisha Brown
description: Trisha Brown's choreography has been one big continuing experiment; the proof lies in the 20th-anniversary season of the Trisha Brown Dance Company at the City Center (131 West 55th Street), which runs through Sunday afternoon.

title: Harsh Loophole in Utah Abortion Law
description: Because of an apparent oversight by Utah's State Legislature, a restrictive antiabortion law that goes into effect there next month could allow prosecutors to bring first-degree murder charges against women who have illegal abortions and, at least in theory, subject the women to life in prison or even death.

title: Review/Dance; Fulfillment, Rage, Gentility and Mourning
description: With a combination of movement and speech, Stuart Pimsler Dance and Theater examined some of life's absurdities on March 1 at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Most of the company's comments were witty. All were deftly timed.

title: Brokaw Quits at Iona
description: Gary Brokaw resigned yesterday as Iona's basketball coach after his team had a 17-13 record in his fifth season as the Gaels' coach.

title: My New Post Office, Address Unknown
description: Has the U.S. Postal Service become a monster that is tearing the hearts out of America's small towns? Many of the citizens of Washington, Conn., would answer that question with a resounding, angry "Yes!" And it would seem that our predicament is not unique.

title: 34 Years and a Sore Foot Later, a Reunion
description: A sore foot cured Paula Friedman's broken heart.

title: Brooklyn Man Kills His Wife, Then Himself, Officers Say
description: As officers tried to coax a Brooklyn man to open the door to his house last night, he fatally shot his terminally ill wife and then killed himself, the police said.

title: Move by Harrah's
description: Harrah's, the casino and hotels company, is moving its corporate headquarters from Reno to Tennessee to be closer to its parent, the Memphis-based Promus Companies, and the Atlantic City market. Philip G. Satre, Harrah's president and chief executive, said a move to Atlantic City, Harrah's biggest market, or to Las Vegas had been considered, but it was simpler to move up to 10 key employees to Memphis.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Dec. 19 referred incorrectly to Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. Roche Biomedical Laboratories is a subsidiary of Hoffmann- La Roche, not its parent. The company telephoned to report the error shortly after publication, but this correction was delayed through a procedural error.

title: News Summary
description: After the War 4-6

title: Cox Is Sued in Stock Purchase
description: The Justice Department sued Cox Enterprises Inc. today, accusing it of failing to seek Federal approval before buying $101 million of stock in a rival communications company.

title: Bond Prices Swing Wildly and End Lower
description: The Treasury securities market was buffeted by wild price swings yesterday, with dealers citing confusion about the apparent easing of credit by the Federal Reserve. The Fed did lower a key interest rate, but confusion remained.

title: Latest Victim of Airline Slump
description: The hard times in the airline industry claimed another victim today when Air Europe, a large British carrier, and its parent, the International Leisure Group Ltd., sought bankruptcy protection from creditors and grounded the airline's fleet, stranding 25,000 people.

title: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'s; Powell and Cheney Are to Greet Ex-Prisoners of Iraq on Arrival in U.S.
description: The former American prisoners of war are expected to return to American soil Sunday and will be greeted by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and maybe even President Bush at Andrews Air Force Base, Administration officials said today.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Wolfpack, Tar Heels and Cavaliers Advance in A.C.C.
description: Last season, Kenny Anderson was the key addition to a Georgia Tech squad that won the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament and reached the Final Four.

title: Review/Music; Nod of Thanks to a Hornist
description: Some of the immediate fondness brought by the discovery of a musical masterpiece tends to attach to the performers involved in the revelation. So the affection of many listeners today for Brahms's wonderful Horn Trio (Op. 40) is mingled with gratitude toward the Australian horn virtuoso Barry Tuckwell, whom they first heard play it, live or on record.

title: Drug Dealer May Face Death
description: A man accused of killing to protect his $50,000-a-day drug ring was convicted on Thursday of murder, in the Government's first test of a 1988 Federal law that allows the death penalty in drug-related slayings. The 31-year-old defendant, Alexander Cooper, was found guilty in the slaying of a fellow drug dealer who had turned informer.

title: Meadow Star Scratched
description: Meadow Star's countdown to the Kentucky Derby was interrupted today when the undefeated filly was withdrawn from her first race of 1991 after coming down with a case of the hives Thursday night.

title: Chemical May Play One Role in Healthy, Another in the Ailing
description: A body chemical that improves circulation in healthy blood vessels has the opposite effect in people with heart disease, squeezing off blood flow and possibly contributing to chest pain and heart attacks, research suggests.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTIAN PETROSSIAN, known as the caviar king, has left Saumon Petrossian , the company he helped to build into an international business. Mr. Petrossian has been at odds with his family for some time. In a statement issued Thursday in Paris, Mr. Petrossian said he was resigning as head of the company's American operation because he was frustrated by management's speed in expanding.

title: Read Mario Bush's Lips
description: Mario Cuomo and George Bush have something in common: They don't like to tax the rich. To listen to the Governor, you might think the opposite. In a National Press Club speech last December, he blasted the Government for 10 years of a Robin-Hood-in-reverse economic strategy, "which operated from the naive assumption that you could ignore the middle class . . . giving the already wealthy more wealth through huge income tax cuts."

title: Canada Job Losses Soar
description: Canada's unemployment rate soared to 10.2 percent in February, the highest level since October 1985, the Government said today. Unemployment jumped from 9.7 percent in January as 78,000 people joined the ranks of the jobless, now put at about 1.4 million, the Government agency Statistics Canada said.

title: Going Beyond Social Security
description: This is about the time of year when millions of people are receiving annual statements of the value of their personal retirement accounts and company pensions.

title: Bridge
description: As thousands of players poured into the city on Thursday for the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, two Canadians captured a major title. Mark Stein and Boris Baran, both of Montreal, won the North American Open Pairs, an event that began at the grassroots level seven months ago and is known to most players by its traditional name, the Grand National Pairs.

title: Program to Keep Students in School Succeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 973591 -- No Title
description: The prospective buyer of The Daily News made public yesterday for the first time how much money he needs to save if he takes over the troubled tabloid -- a figure that works out to more than $70 million a year.

title: Boise Cascade Deal Blocked by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission has blocked the proposed sale of a Boise Cascade Corporation mill to Appleton Papers Inc. The commission said the sale of the uncoated white-paper mill would restrict competition by decreasing the number of producers of carbonless paper, even though Boise Cascade had stopped producing the grade of carbonless paper in December.

title: Nigerians Speak Warmly of the Peace Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; At Iraqi Border, Kuwaitis Savor Lonely Freedom
description: Many of the Kuwaitis who have straggled to freedom in the last two days after weeks of hard captivity in Iraq spoke bitterly today of the ragged homecoming they received along a barren stretch of no man's land on the Kuwait-Iraq border.

title: Manslaughter Verdict Brought in Boy's Death
description: A former security guard was acquitted last night of murder but convicted of manslaughter in the death of his companion's 3-year-old son, who died in a Queens hotel after having been beaten for several months.

title: Waterworks Concern Sets Shift in Top Post
description: Although a waterworks holds a spot on the Monopoly game board, water utilities owned by shareholders are not large American enterprises like electrical utilities. The largest, the American Water Works Company, has named a president-elect, George W. Johnstone, to take over its operations next year.

title: The Other Palestinians
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, claimed recently that he is eager to negotiate the future of the West Bank and Gaza. Secretary of State James Baker, in Saudi Arabia today, will visit Jerusalem next week to lead, or cajole, the Israeli Government in the direction of trading land for peace.

title: Levi Disqualified For Altering Driver
description: Wayne Levi, the PGA Tour's player of the Year for 1990, was disqualified yesterday from the Honda Classic in Coral Gables, Fla., after he told officials that he apparently violated a rule during the first round on Thursday.

title: Tax for Connecticut
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Stierle, 23, A Leading Dancer With Joffrey Ballet
description: Edward Stierle, a leading dancer with the Joffrey Ballet who created two ballets for the company this season, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. He was 23 years old.

title: Alvin Ford, 37, Dies; Stricken on Death Row
description: Alvin Bernard Ford, a convicted police killer whose execution was blocked by the United States Supreme Court because of his lawyers' contention that he had become insane on death row, died of natural causes on Feb. 26, a state corrections spokesman said today. He was 37 years old.

title: Man Held in Baby's Death
description: A Harlem man was arrested last night and charged with strangling his four-month-old daughter, who died on Sunday after having been in a coma since Dec. 16. The man, David Valera, a 23-year-old messenger, was accused of choking his daughter, Debra Jimenez, with her bib, said a police spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner. The child lived with her father and mother, Jenovera Jimenez, at 135 West 132d Street, where the assault took place, the spokesman said.
