The mother was not in the apartment at the time and was not charged.

title: Guidepost; Money in the Bank
description: How safe is your money when a bank or savings and loan institution fails? Federal regulators have a three-option plan: the institution can be sold, closed or its deposits transferred to another institution. Here is a guide to how depositors fare in each instance. Closure: All accounts are closed; all insured depositors' money and any earned interest will be returned.

title: Nathan Dambroff, Lawyer, 83
description: Nathan Dambroff, a lawyer who specialized in civil rights, labor and housing cases, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: A Monologue On Poverty Takes On Its Own Life
description: It started last year on the New York stage, moved to England and recently returned. It has two strains, one theatrical and one literary, and it seems to show no signs of going away, despite a largely unfavorable press.

title: Track and Field; Cason Takes 60 Meters; Johnson Finishes Fourth
description: Nothing that happened in the men's 60-meter final of the world indoor track championships here tonight should surprise anybody. Andre Cason has been running well throughout the season, and Ben Johnson, bearing more than the average man, has struggled. And so it was again this evening, when they finished a remarkably close race in which only 12 one-hundredths of a second separated first place from last.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Sixth Child Dies in Philadelphia; 5 Others Are Given Measles Shots
description: A sixth child whose family opposes measles vaccinations for religious reasons died here today, and five others were inoculated against the disease undercourt order.

title: Cough Sidelines Kocur
description: Joe Kocur, the enforcer the Rangers obtained from Detroit on Tuesday, had to make a hasty medical retreat from his first game Thursday night. He had to leave the game not because he was roughed up by his opponents, the Rangers' medical staff said yesterday, but because his persistent coughing was simply more than his body could bear.

title: Doing the End Zone Boogie
description: Repugnant though it is for me to boast of my excellences, present circumstances demand that I put modesty aside and give three cheers and a big locomotive for this column's performance during the recent war.

title: William L. Brown, 77, Geneticist Who Led Crop Breeding Programs
description: William Lacy Brown, a geneticist who directed the development and coordination of breeding programs in maize, sorghum, soybeans and wheat, died yesterday at his home in Johnston, Iowa. He was 77 years old.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; P.L.O. and Israel See Positive Signs in Bush's Mideast Speech
description: A Palestinian said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization was reconsidering a decision not to talk with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the St. Patrick's Day parade misstated the parade date. It is Saturday, March 16, a day before the holiday.

title: Your Money; Personal Finance Perplexes Many
description: Many people, even those who are successful in their business or professional lives, have trouble handling personal finances, and last week Citibank co-sponsored a seminar focusing on women who want more control of their finances. Though the topic is certainly of interest to both men and women, a bank spokesman said the focus was put on women in response to numerous customer comments and requests.

title: Barring of Press From Military Base Upheld
description: A Federal judge today upheld military restrictions against news coverage of the return of bodies of American troops killed in the Persian Gulf war.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. JO IVEY BOUFFORD, 44, who led the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation for four years during dramatic shortages of money, personnel and equipment, will become director of the King's Fund College in London on Friday. She left her job in New York in 1989 to become a visiting fellow at the college, a center for management education for the National Health Service, in which the college is attempting revisions.

title: Ankara Journal; New Dynasty in Turkey? If So, It's an Unruly One
description: In the teahouses and under the minarets, conversations among Turks these days bear whispers of dynasty.

title: Imcera Cutting Stake in IMC
description: The Imcera Group said today that it was reducing its stake in the IMC Fertilizer Group by selling five million IMC shares back to the company for $41.25 a share, or almost $206.3 million.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Timetable; Schedule for Gulf Troops Returning to Home Bases
description: The following are scheduled arrival times Saturday for troops returning to their home bases from the Persian Gulf, as released today by the Pentagon. Times listed are local times. Army

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Seton Hall Gains on Last Shot
description: Two years ago, P. J. Carlesimo stood on the edge of a basketball court and watched a national championship slip away in just this kind of situation: a 1-point game, the final seconds ticking away, the offense looking for one last opening, the defense suddenly cautious.

title: Iraq Frees Journalists
description: Forty Western journalists held by Iraq were handed over to Red Cross officials in Baghdad and were to arrive in Jordan today. Page 5.

title: Prints, Photographs and Drawings in 2 Shows
description: AT the Kornbluth Gallery, in Fair Lawn, is "Important Papers" and, at A. J. Lederman, in Hoboken, a selection of prints from the Printmaking Workshop.

title: Owning Beats Earning
description: ASSETS AND THE POOR A New American Welfare Policy.By Michael Sherraden.324 pp. Armonk, N.Y.:M. E. Sharpe Inc. $34.95.

title: England
description: To the Editor: With all the problems facing air travelers, this is a minor complaint. However, as a frequent flier, I am tired of being ripped off and would like to warn other passengers.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Route 1 Corridor Regaining Momentum
description: AFTER being bloated with new offices during the mid-80's building boom, Princeton's Route 1 commercial market is steadily trimming its excess space and, ever so slowly, improving.

title: Labor Chief Resigns in Dispute With Dinkins and Budget Head
description: New York City's Labor Relations Commissioner resigned yesterday, charging that the city's Budget Director had misled municipal unions and Wall Street. But Mayor David N. Dinkins rejected the charge and said his administration had misled no one.

title: Perspectives: The Rental Option; Murray Hill Building at a Turning Point
description: THROUGHOUT the metropolitan area real estate agents and brokers are reporting a pick-up in interest by potential buyers. Traffic is up, and, in some areas, sales as well. That is a healthy sign, but it has special meaning for new Manhattan condominiums. The level of sales will determine how many of the new apartments will become rentals.

title: Hospitals Let Patients Control Painkillers
description: EXCRUCIATING pain is what many surgical patients recall of their first deep breaths or footsteps in the days after surgery. But patients may increasingly be spared the pain by controlling their medications and receiving continuous infusions of painkillers.

title: Agent Admits Shoplifting
description: A Secret Service agent accused of shoplifting a ski jacket from a sporting goods store while on an assignment to protect Vice President Dan Quayle here three months ago has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor theft charge. The 39-year-old agent, Joyce Fletcher, was arrested Dec. 27 after leaving the store with the $280 jacket.

title: The World; The Sun Has Trouble Setting on the Soviet Empire
description: GEORGE SMILEY might have felt some sympathy for the old Soviet commissars and generals watching Americans take Iraq apart.

title: Sunday Outing; Just off the Bustle of Upper Broadway, A Cultural Oasis for Many Tastes
description: When the Washington Heights section of Manhattan was still considered the country, James Audubon had an estate near what is now 155th Street and Broadway. By the mid-19th century, a parcel of the naturalist's family estate had become a park, and early in the 20th century a piece of the park was set aside for the construction of several museums.

title: Rome's Response to Albanian Influx Criticized
description: As this port strained to handle the 20,000 Albanian refugees who have fled here by boat this week, the authorities in Rome came under criticism today for their response to the crisis.

title: Sunday Dinner; Where the Menu's Not Fussy, Seafood Is Super and Italian Fare Reigns
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: The R.T.C.'s Point Man in Distressed Real Estate
description: In the world of real estate, Joseph E. Robert Jr. has the tricky task of convincing investors to pay good money for bad real estate assets.

title: Thailand
description: To the Editor: The Oriental Hotel in Bangkok is frequently mentioned as a base from which to take day trips. Your readers should be advised that unless you are wearing proper attire (no shorts or T-shirts) they will not be permitted inside the hotel.

title: Notes From the Edge of the Abyss
description: THE ROAD TO BOBBY JOE And Other Stories. By Louis Berney. 182 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: About Cars; The Answer Was Not Rolls-Royce
description: Three weeks ago, we did a trivia quiz here, and it generated a lot more interest than my bank account ever does.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Deal Is Struck on Fate Of Park and Protest Site
description: The University of California at Berkeley has agreed not to build dormitories on People's Park, an open space that has gained international fame as the site of recurring demonstrations, beginning with the Vietnam War.

title: Dr. Granowetter Weds David Bearison
description: Dr. Linda Granowetter and Dr. David Bearison were married at the bridegroom's home in New York last evening by Rabbi Dennis Math. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Granowetter of East Meadow, L.I. Dr. Bearison is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Bearison of Newark.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Northeastern Secures a Bid
description: Ron Lacey scored a game-high 18 points as Northeastern beat Maine, 57-46, in the final of the North Atlantic Conference tournament this afternoon. With the victory, Northeastern captured the league's automatic bid for the National Collegiate Athletic Assocaition tourney.

title: Campus Life: Wellesley; Kosher Kitchen: Idea Was Easier Than the Reality
description: Last spring a majority of the Wellesley College students voting approved a student government referendum that would establish a kosher-vegetarian dining hall on campus. Out of a student body of about 2,000 students, 677 voted for the measure and 417 voted against.

title: 'Baby Bells' Wait; Hope Judge Relents
description: It was probably inevitable that regional Bell telephone companies would come to loggerheads with Federal District Court Judge Harold H. Greene. But the official end of the honeymoon probably dates back to Jan. 13, 1986. Two years had passed since the judge had presided over the court-ordered breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and he had become increasingly suspicious that the new "Baby Bells" were ignoring ordinary telephone customers to rush into new lines of business.

title: Computer Defies Einstein's Theory
description: A supercomputer at Cornell University, simulating a tremendous gravitational collapse in the universe, has startled and confounded astrophysicists by producing results that should not be possible according to Einstein's general theory of relativity.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Politics; Another Gulf War?
description: The question the American soldiers ask as they board planes for home after seven months in the desert is the same one that worries the politicians that live in the region as they turn from preoccupation with military problems to the concerns of civil life.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 10, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 21 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 2 13 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 3 1 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 4 3 THE ANASTASIA SYNDROME: And Other Stories, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) Five stories of romance and the macabre. 5 2 STRAIGHT, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $5.95.) A steeplechase jockey inherits property and a mysterious enemy. 6 6 A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.95.) A young widow's entry into the world of television brings her adventures. 7 3 SLEEPING WITH THE ENEMY, by Nancy Price. (Berkley, $4.95.) To escape a cruel marriage, a woman fakes her death. 8 1 BITTER SWEET, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $5.95.) A widow's ordeal after meeting an old flame, now a less than happily married man. 9 * 6 CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $6.95.) The history of the sea islands told in fictional form. 10 * 2 THE GOLD COAST, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $5.95.) Life changes for an old WASP family when the head of a crime family becomes its neighbor. 11 1 THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) The adventures of two brothers who practice magic in a fantasy land where its use is forbidden. 12 * 6 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Warner, $5.95.) Adam Dalgliesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 13 2 SHADOW PREY, by John Sandford. (Berkley, $5.50.) Detective Lucas Davenport on the trail of a baffling serial killer. 14 7 HARMFUL INTENT, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $5.50.) A physician struggles to clear his name in a "medical malpractice" death. 15 2 BRIGHT STAR, by Harold Coyle. (Pocket, $5.95.) A Mideast conflict leads to war between the United States and the Soviet Union. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 29 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 2 6 SADDAM HUSSEIN AND THE CRISIS IN THE GULF, by Judith Miller and Laurie Mylroie. (Times Books/Random House, $5.95.) A report on the Iraqi President and his invasion of Kuwait. 3 6 THE RAPE OF KUWAIT, by Jean P. Sasson. (Knightsbridge, $4.95.) The invasion of Kuwait as observed by people who witnessed it and escaped. 4 8 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An American woman held captive in Iran. 5 2 A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE, by David Fromkin. (Avon, $14.95.) How, in redrawing the map of the Middle East during 1914-22, the Allies laid the groundwork for contemporary conflicts. 6 3 ARMAGEDDON, OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST CRISIS, by John F. Walvoord. (Zondervan, $8.95.) A theologian says current events are fulfilling the Bible's promise of the Second Coming of Christ. 7 * 4 REPUBLIC OF FEAR, by Samir al-Khalil. (Pantheon, $12.95.) An expatriate Iraqi scholar's account of life under Saddam Hussein. 8 68 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 9 5 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Avon, $5.95.) Prognostications for the next decade. 10 * 1 A KILLING IN THE FAMILY, by Stephen Singular with Tim and Danielle Hill. (Avon, $4.95.) A teen-age girl, manipulated by her father, murders her stepmother. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 15 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 2 4 DESERT SHIELD FACT BOOK, by the staff of GDW. (Game Designers' Workshop, $10.) Data and maps relevant to the war in the Persian Gulf. 3 1 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Ivy, $5.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business. 4 32 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 5 * 12 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: School Basketball; 52-49 Overtime Victory For Lincoln of Brooklyn
description: Abraham Lincoln High School of Brooklyn, the only team in New York City certain that it is capable of beating the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion, St. Raymond's of the Bronx, almost didn't get out of the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament yesterday at Manhattan Community College. Playing for the first time after a two-week layoff, Lincoln barely eliminated Hillcrest of Queens, 52-49, in overtime.

title: Brett's Balancing Act
description: It takes a sharp eye to pick up a fastball, and by most measures George Brett of the Kansas City Royals would seem to have two of the sharpest. There are his American League batting championships, for example, including his league-leading .329 last year. Then there are his scores on standard eye tests.

title: Data Update
The Duke in the Bahamas
description: To the Editor:

title: When Messages Hide in Riffs And Rhythms
description: Without a lot of fanfare, world-beat music has quietly become a dependable pop commodity, with its own bins in record stores and charts in trade magazines. People who pride themselves on cosmopolitan record collections are now likely to own a few CD's with singing in languages other than English -- something to perk up a dinner party that doesn't interfere with conversation.

title: Pro Hockey; Rangers Fall Again To Last-Place Team
description: A team with Stanley Cup aspirations shouldn't lose to last-place teams, but that's what the Rangers have done in their last two games.

title: Campus Life: Maryland; Scientist Seeks Ways to Speed Growth of Fish
description: The world may soon be able to use genetic engineering or special hormones to make fish grow to market size faster and to increase world food supplies, says a University of Maryland marine biologist who is working to make it happen.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vail, Colo.; The High End Is Flying High
description: THOUGH the recession may have eroded property prices and sales elsewhere, it has had no effect on expensive houses in this ski resort.

title: Nurture and Nature, for Asian-Americans
description: AT present count, there are 12 Asian-American artists showing in Rockland County, nine of them at the Rockland Center for the Arts in West Nyack (27 South Greenbush Road), the others at Blue Hill Cultural Plaza, in Pearl River (Orangeburg Road). Between them, the shows prove how unsatisfactory the term Asian-American is.

title: Corrections
description: A Streetscapes column on Feb. 24 about the McAlpin House rendered the name of a spokeswoman for the Landmarks Preservation Commission incorrectly. She is Tracie Rozhon.

title: Audrey Ziss Is Married
description: Audrey Lynn Ziss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Ziss of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday in Mountainside, N.J., to Mark John Bath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ron Bath of Auburn, Neb. Mayor Marc Marshall of Springfield, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Towers restaurant. The bride, 34 years old, was until recently a policy analyst in the New Jersey Office of Management and Planning. She graduated from the University of Vermont and received a certificate in paralegal studies from Long Island University. The bridegroom, 29, is a regional sales manager in Littleton, Colo., for SmithKline Beecham Animal Health in Exton, Pa. He is a graduate of the University of Nebraska.

title: Dr. Maurice Friedman, 87, Dies; Created 'Rabbit' Pregnancy Test
description: Maurice Harold Friedman, a medical doctor and reproductive-physiology researcher who developed the "rabbit test" to determine pregnancy, died Friday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: On Education Panel, Not Enough Teachers
description: The Jan. 27 article titled "Panel Begins Overhaul of Education" first brought a chuckle at the "world class" education goal, then pity at another pointless search for teaching methods and theories, and finally outrage that only 2 of the 28 members of the commission can be considered teachers.

title: Exactly What Is It About Josephine Baker?
description: My interest in Josephine Baker, which led me to spend five years writing a biography of her, began with a serendipitous mention of her name at a time when I felt my life had become predictable and boring. The only kind of music I could listen to was jazz, because I never knew where it would go next. I thought that Baker -- whose moves in every sense seemed unpredictable, whose whole life seemed a jazz improvisation -- was a subject I could spend time with and be psychically nourished by the contact.

title: Of Heroes, Hippies and Hype
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Starring, Killers for the Chiller 90's
description: Every era gets the psychos it deserves, at least in art. Our own violent culture has splattered us with real-life assassins and serial killers who have pervaded our consciousness through television and newspapers and left a disturbing, revealing, often entertaining legacy of fictional lunatics. The past month or so has brought three genres of highly publicized psycho-killers, each an unmistakable product of this cultural moment.

title: Q and A
description: Studying Spanish in Spain

title: As Unemployment Rises, Jobs on L.I. Decline
description: SINCE the 1987 stock-market crash, which signaled a halt to the economic boom on Long Island, the job market has sustained a double-barreled assault.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Medical Research Equal Opportunity Doesn't Always Apply
description: IT was every researcher's nightmare. A new study of the AIDS drug AZT hinted that it might not be as effective in black and Hispanic patients as it is in whites. Why had no one noticed this possible effect before? Because all previous studies had been confined almost exclusively to gay white men.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: A New York Life Of Friends & Others By Brendan Gill Poseidon Press. 348 pages. $21.95.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Stop Freezing Out the Pro Skaters
description: Picture a young woman with a ballerina's grace and a gymnast's well-honed body, gliding across the ice, spinning and jumping in the crisp air. Ah. The beauty of figure skating. Who would suspect that beneath this serene vision lurks a battle as down and dirty as any locker-room brawl?

title: Correction
description: The No. 13 fiction entry on the paperback best-seller list last Sunday was incorrect in some copies. It should have read: " 'Shadow Prey,' by John Sandford. (Berkley, $5.50.) Detective Lucas Davenport on the trail of a baffling serial killer." (The book was not "Shadow Play" by Katherine Sutcliffe.)

title: Neil Dellar Weds Wendy L. Addiss
description: Wendy Luise Addiss, the daughter of Edward F. Addiss of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Patricia F. Addiss of New York, was married yesterday to Neil Alan Dellar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Dellar of Theydon Bois, England. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: A Shot of Adrenaline for Fifth Avenue
description: Maybe it is worth it. After all, whatever else can be said about the 50-story office tower, the row of restored landmarks and the new home for the venerable Henri Bendel store that together make up the just-finished mid-Manhattan project known as 712 Fifth Avenue, this place stands as proof that the tortuous, infuriating and perplexing process of getting landmark projects approved in New York City can actually yield some real public benefit. The angry debate, the long rounds of public hearings and eventually the active involvement in the design of this project by the Landmarks Preservation Commission may have given the developer a seven-year migraine -- as well as added substantially to the project's cost -- but they have created a vastly better design than would have existed otherwise.

title: Lebanese Troops Move Against Militia Forces
description: The Lebanese Army raided militia offices here today in a move aimed at heading off a return of gunmen to the Lebanese capital. The action came at a time of growing tension between the Government and Christian opposition figures.

title: Moments of Heroism and Hope in 'Mockingbird'
description: GOODNESS has everything to do with "To Kill a Mockingbird." Here is a hero, Atticus Finch, and a positively heroic one he is. A pillar of decency, idealism and integrity who "loves everybody," a lawyer for whom a load of stovewood, a sack of hickory nuts and turnip greens, and a crate of holly are more than ample pay from an impoverished client.

title: Paul Mellon's Life in Art: Understated, Oversubscribed
description: Washington has today a National Gallery of Art toward which people move as if magnetized. For the Washingtonian, it is never out of the news. For the first-time visitor, it has legendary status. For the museum watcher, it is a repository of major art, from Duccio and van Eyck to Matisse and Diebenkorn, that sits still and minds its own business. (It is also, and more controversially, a competitive institution that is conspicuous for its hyperactivity.)

title: Review/Music; John Harbison Premiere
description: John Harbison's music seems truly unpredictable, as much in quality as in style. He has long been an eclectic composer, commenting on the past to such an extent that the past seems sometimes to consume him. But beyond style, his works vary sharply in their degree of personality, their sense that the composer has something burning to communicate.

title: AIDS Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: An Antidote to the Blockbuster Syndrome
description: They may lack the glamour and breadth of the large-scale loan show, but two exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art provide further evidence of the benefits of displays based on works from the permanent collections. The first of the Modern's exhibitions is a wonderful and insightful installation, through March 19, of more than 150 portraits selected by the painter Chuck Close that is part of a series called "Artist's Choice." The second, "Art of the 40's," through April 30, brings together over 250 paintings, photographs, prints, drawings, industrial and commercial objects, and architectural models.

title: Blame the Recession on Tax Reform
description: It is clear to all we are in a recession. But what is not so clear is the causal relationship between the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and today's economy. In essence, the act and its successors reduced tax rates and brackets and substantially unified the treatment of taxable income. But it also reduced the incentive to incur debt and take entrepreneurial risk. Investment in real estate also lost many of its incentives.

title: Review/Theater; Pretension and Vanity In Moliere's 'Ladies'
description: In "The Learned Ladies" ("Les Femmes Savantes"), as in "Tartuffe," a scoundrel inveigles his way into a household and turns it upside down. In this case, the rogue is Trissotin, a bogus artist, and his chief acolyte is a woman with intellectual pretensions. With Trissotin as mentor, she gathers female relatives into a salon of precious poetasters, while her timid husband sits on the sidelines thinking about dinner.

title: It Takes People to Make a Strike: Tales of Fear and Courage at The News
description: It has all the elements of a great Daily News story -- violence, ambition, moral dilemmas and the struggle of common people. For the last 137 days, though, the story has been about the paper itself.

title: Dr. Stein to Wed Andreas Smoller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Stein of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Paula Nancy Stein to Andreas Howard Smoller, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Smoller of East Fishkill, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: St. Croix
description: Staying power is everything in the Caribbean, where this year's hot hideaway is next year's has been. And staying power is something St. Croix has in abundance. Perhaps the secret is diversity. St. Croix is the largest of the United States Virgin Islands, but not so large that one can't drive its 28-mile length in an hour. It has mountains, beaches, shopping, good restaurants and a full array of land and water sports. Yet it is not as commercial as neighboring St. Thomas. The landscape, also, provides contrasts: a bona fide rain forest on the west end, more of a desert climate on the drier, sunnier east end.

title: Track and Field; Foster Speeds to Hurdles Title
description: It will be another 16 months before Greg Foster will know if he can fill the one burning hole in his resume, the Olympic title he didn't win in 1984 and couldn't in 1988.

title: One Way for Business to Go Green
description: Last April, Du Pont's oil subsidiary, Conoco, announced it would build new double-hulled oil tankers designed to reduce oil spills. A few days later, the H. J. Heinz Company said it would no longer fish for tuna on dolphin sightings or use drift nets. And in November, McDonald's announced it would do away with its plastic foam "clamshell" hamburger box. These headline-making actions, and others like them, signal important changes in corporate environmental thinking. Yet, double-hulled tankers, dolphin-safe tuna and abandoned polystyrene packaging -- while praiseworthy -- do not make corporations environmentally responsible.

title: Rebecca Handel To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Rebecca Handel to Andrew Fano, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Fano of Great Neck, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Handel of Paramus, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title:
Focus: Berkeley, Calif.;
A New, 198-Unit S.R.O. w/Private Baths
description: CONSTRUCTION financing was gained last week for a 198-unit single-room-occupancy hotel that will rise at the edge of this city's downtown. It will be the first such hotel built in northern California in more than 40 years.

title: Miss Horchow Wed in Dallas
description: Elizabeth Horchow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Roger Horchow of Dallas, was married last evening at the Dallas Museum of Art to Daniel Glenn Routman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Routman of Birmingham, Ala. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: The World; In Kenya, The Lawyers Lead the Call For Freedom
description: IN growing numbers, private practice lawyers in this one-party state have assumed the role that high-status professionals in other repressive societies have played in the fight for greater freedoms. In the Soviet Union, it was the scientists, led by Andrei D. Sakharov, who pushed against the ideological barriers; in Czechoslovakia, writers, symbolized by Vaclav Havel, illuminated the ills of the system; in Latin America, Roman Catholic priests and nuns following the doctrine of liberation theology pressed for democratization.

title: Los Angeles Jury Widens Inquiry in Police Beating
description: A Los Angeles County grand jury has undertaken an investigation of all 15 police officers present early last Sunday when a motorist was clubbed, kicked and stomped by three officers who did not realize that they were being videotaped.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Haverhill, Mass.;
Houses Off Public Links
description: A CONDOMINIUM complex of traditional, clapboard-sided one-family homes with contemporary interiors is now rising in the Bradford neighborhood of this old industrial city about 40 miles north of Boston.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Chemical Arms; Navy Report Asserts Many Nations Seek Or Have Poison Gas
description: A Navy intelligence report has named at least 14 nations outside the Soviet Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that are believed to possess chemical weapons, including American allies like Israel, Egypt, South Korea, Taiwan and Pakistan. It says 10 other nations are believed to be seeking chemical armaments.

title: The Best Part of Every Book Comes Last
description: Some years ago, when I was looking for lively material to discuss in a book about diaries, I knew, even before I got the text of her journals, that Betsey Wynne, a British naval wife during the Napoleonic wars, would make the cut. A single heading in the diary's index was enough to satisfy me: dislikes Bombelles family, 119, 157, 164, 165, 170, 174, 175, 177-9, 183, 184, 186, 187, 190, 191, 202, 207, 208, 211, 213, 220, 224, 225, 229, 230, 231, 235, 236, 254, 260, 261, 271.

title: Highway to Hell
description: ROAD FEVER A High-Speed Travelogue. By Tim Cahill. 278 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Miss Cohn to Wed Douglas T. Healy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Cohn of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jessica Faith Cohn to Douglas Taylor Healy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Healy of Vail, Colo. An October wedding is planned.

title: Incident in Train Cab Casts Doubt on Cuomo's Choice for M.T.A.
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's choice of Peter E. Stangl to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was thrown into doubt yesterday after the disclosure that Mr. Stangl, his wife and two friends rode in the engineer's cab of a commuter train last October and that one of the friends sat at the controls. A State Senate committee said it would meet tomorrow to reconsider its endorsement of Mr. Stangl in light of the revelations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MOLIERE AND HAVEL

title: Arthur Miller Reaches A New Group of Readers
description: With the fervor of people who have finally shed the burden of pretense, a group of illiterate adults had a literary discussion earlier this week with a man whom most of them had only recently heard of, the playwright Arthur Miller.

title: Job Training For Athletes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: One Man's Crusade With Paper That Has Had Another Life
description: JOHN J. ROSSI vividly remembers the moment more than two years ago when he picked up a sow's ear and saw a silk purse.

title: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar; How Symbols Mean
description: To the Editor:

title: County Sales-Tax Dispute Snags a Visiting Cuomo
description: GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO, who came to Westchester on Tuesday to defend his proposed 1991-92 budget, had hardly been seated among the county's business, political and cultural leaders when he found himself confronted with a highly divisive local issue: a proposed $91 million sales-tax increase.

title: C. B. Gladwin Fraser, Minister, 73
description: The Rev C. B. Gladwin Fraser, pastor of the Union Congregational Church for 31 years and a civic leader in Harlem, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

title: Catherine Teller Plans To Wed Peter Malone
description: The Rev. and Mrs. A. Richard Teller of Findlay, Ohio, have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Catherine Alden Teller, and Peter Malone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Malone of North Falmouth, Mass.

title: Wall Street; The Outlook for a Lagging Republic Health
description: The showdown that will decide the Republic Health Corporation's future is between the hospital company's senior management and Gary Winnick, a former executive in the Beverly Hills office of Drexel Burnham Lambert. Mr. Winnick runs PAH L.P., a partnership that is Republic's biggest lender. PAH had lent the hospital chain about $250 million for its 1986 leveraged buyout. It forgave about $50 million when Republic slid into Chapter 11, but refused to make further concessions to help Republic emerge from bankruptcy in better shape.

title: Tech Notes; Listen Up, 18-Wheeler, We Know You're in Tacoma
description: A small company in Washington is planning to market a relatively cheap, palm-sized device that will let truck and taxicab dispatchers keep track of their vehicles by satellite. Developed by Marcor Inc., the device can be mounted onto cars to receive signals transmitted every second by satellites in the Government's Global Positioning System. According to Willie Armstrong, Marcor's senior vice president, the new device can receive signals from as many as eight satellites at once and then relay them through the vehicle's two-way radio to a computer processor at the dispatcher's office. The computer processor then plots the vehicle's location within about 20 yards by comparing the different signals. Although other satellite positioning devices are already available, most are designed for more sophisticated users and cost $2,000 and up. The new device, to be available in September, will cost between $700 to $1,000.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vancouver, B.C.; Utility Builds In the Suburbs
description: THE B.C. Hydro and Power Authority, one of this city's largest employers, is planning to build a corporate complex in suburban Burnaby that will be linked by the SkyTrain light rail system to an office tower the public utility corporation is building downtown.

title: Are the Baymen An Anachronism?
description: The article "State Limits on Bass Size Are Fought by Baymen" [ Jan. 13 ] supports this fishery as promulgated by Arnold Leo of the East Hampton Baymen's Association. The article is replete with misquotes, misleading, untrue and biased statements.

title: Miller Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate

title: Track and Field; Villanova Senior Ends in Split
description: When Sonia O'Sullivan was 15 years old and living in Cobh, Ireland, she wanted to go to a party given by a track club. To go to the party, she had to be a member of the club, so she joined. To be a member, she had to run, so she ran.

title: Homecomings Set for Today
description: The following are scheduled arrival times Sunday for troops returning to their home bases from the Persian Gulf, as released today by the Pentagon. Times listed are local times.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 24 about quilt exhibitions misidentified the curator of a show at the Rye Arts Center. She is Elaine Jones-Bronin; Virginia Avery is the author of "The Big Book of Applique and Quilts to Wear."

title: Unity Brings Many Traumas to What Was East Germany
description: In this gritty industrial town in what used to be East Germany, people have for years lived among slag heaps and strip mines, breathed poisonous air, and tried to shield themselves from the oppression of a Communist police state.

title: Kerry J. Clarke, Prosecutor, Wed
description: Kerry Jane Clarke, a prosecutor with the antitrust division of the Justice Department in Washington, was married yesterday in Greenwood, Va., to Paul Albert Hoffman, a son of of Dr. Graham W. Hoffman of Knoxville, Tenn., and the late Clyde McLeod Hoffman. The Rev. Howard A. LaRue performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: Your Own Account; Some Guidelines on Purchases
description: Here are ways to evaluate a franchise:

title: Campus Life: Pennsylvania; House of Turmoil To Become Base For Aid Programs
description: The house where members of a University of Pennsylvania fraternity planned the kidnapping of a brother in another fraternity last year will become the home for students with more philanthropic interests.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Duke and N. Carolina in Final
description: One staggered, barely staving off the two lowest-seeded teams, while the other cruised. But in the end, it was business as usual at the 38th annual Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament, as second-seeded North Carolina squeaked past Virginia, 76-71, to earn the right to play No. 1 Duke for the conference title.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; A Video to Recruit Minority Students Draws Their Fire
description: To increase minority enrollment at the University of Wisconsin, Madison students produced an 18-minute recruitment video. But when it was shown last month, campus minority groups said it did not portray campus life realistically.

title: Headliners; A Prize First
description: Rabbi Immanuel Jakobovits has a fresh way of looking at old ideas, in the view of the people who award the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion. Rabbi Jakobovits, the Chief Rabbi of Britain, last week became the first Jew to be awarded the prize, which was created in 1972 by John M. Templeton, an American financier. The prize carries a cash award, $820,000 this year, that is deliberately kept larger than the Nobel Prizes because Mr. Templeton considered religion more important than the various disciplines recognized by the Nobels. Rabbi Jakobovits, who became a member of the House of Lords in 1988 when he was named a life peer, was cited for his "enlightened approach to interfaith relations and his originality in interpreting the traditional values of Judaism." Describing his approach to his faith, the rabbi said, "Being progressive in religion means a broadening in our vision, but not necessarily giving up past insights."

title: Campus Life: Rochester; Infighting Flares Over Reshaping A University
description: Administrators at the University of Rochester have been fighting over efforts to reshape undergraduate education and cut back on graduation programs, exposing differences over the university's priorities.

title:
ART;
Focus on the Family
description: AS an exhibition theme, "The Family" might initially promise few content surprises, yet the presentation now at Suffolk Coummuniy College's Peconic Gallery in Riverhead offers a strong range of imaginatively conceived personal and subjective visions.

title: Review/Film; High Finance and Mystery In a Hong Kong Setting
description: With its spectacular harbor and a blazing nightlife that makes Times Square seem dim by comparison, Hong Kong, which is the setting for "Shadow of China," tends to upstage the most dramatic moments in the thriller by the Japanese film maker Mitsuo Yanagimachi. Hong Kong's uncertain future in its final years as a British crown colony also makes it a perfect metaphor for the life of the film's protagonist, Henry Wong (John Lone), who is a sort of Asian Jay Gatsby.

title: Chinese Mountains, Top to Bottom and Inside Out
description: If one image towers above all others in Chinese art, it is the mountain. It looms over Chinese landscape painting. It provides paths between Chinese painting, sculpture and decorative art. By exploring the motif of the mountain, the layers of meaning and the depth of feeling in Chinese art become clear.

title: Dr. Proner Wed To David Gelfarb
description: Dr. Jacqueline Lee Proner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Stanley Proner of Purchase, N.Y., was married in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday evening to David Bruce Gelfarb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Gelfarb of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Melvin Sirner officiated at Beth El Synagogue, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery.

title: The Executive Computer; If Superman Were a Printer . . .
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has come up with a Laserjet printer exceptionally well suited for office printing needs -- the $5,495 Laserjet IIISi, introduced at the Seybold Seminars electronic publishing conference here last week.

title: Walesa Election Plan Rejected by Parliament
description: Poland's Parliament today rejected a plea by President Lech Walesa for immediate elections and voted to delay the balloting until the fall.

title: Gulf Problems That Can't Be Ignored
description: Desert Storm mesmerized the world with its dazzling display of American weaponry. It was the first live war movie. Unfortunately, the economic issues threatening the long-term stability of the region have largely been ignored. The reconstruction of the region, massive external debt, serious economic inequities, high military expenditures, continuing payments for foreign forces -- and the inability to finance them -- are some of the problems that must now be solved.

title: All About/Theme Park Spinoffs; Need a Little Fantasy? A Bevy of New Companies Can Help
description: Mee Industries Inc. is one company that actually brags about operating in a continual fog. Theme park operators like the Six Flags Corporation prize Mee's ability to create mysterious billows. At Six Flags Magic Mountain Park in Valencia, Calif., a layer of fog cools and amazes visitors waiting in line under the broiling sun.

title: Census Finds Northward Shift In Fairfield County Population
description: MOST people have an image of Monroe that includes winding country roads, grazing cows and a historic one-room schoolhouse, said Selectman Kenneth S. Heitzke. But when he thinks about his community, he said, he sees long rows of new single-family houses, clusters of town-house condominiums and shopping plazas. And pointing out one of the few remaining empty parcels of land in town, Mr. Heitzke said, "That's where we're getting our first McDonald's."

title: Marcos Backer Guilty in Murder of 2 Men
description: A former president of a cannery union local, who supported the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philipppines, was convicted of murder Friday in the death of a union reformer and anti-Marcos activist a decade ago.

title: 'Open End' Those Closed-End Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon's Cost Cutting Puts Defense Work in Jeopardy
description: THE Pentagon is delivering a one-two punch to the aerospace industry on Long Island. It is canceling contracts with two major contractors for Navy and Air Force programs worth more than $500 million.

title: Headliners; Pro Whose Bono?
description: Even for a Park Avenue law firm, Myerson & Kuhn seemed to be charging a bit much -- millions too much. Clients complained to Federal authorities, an investigation was launched and last week Harvey Myerson was indicted on charges of swindling his clients and partners out of $3.5 million in two years. The indictment said that Mr. Myerson, who was a law partner of Bowie Kuhn, the former baseball commissioner, used the money for a wide array of personal expenditures, including luxury gifts for friends -- like an $86,000 diamond ring for a woman -- and chartered jets and expensive hotel rooms for friends and family members. Investigators charged that Mr. Myerson stole most of the money -- $2.5 million -- from six corporate clients by billing them for work that was never done. Myerson & Kuhn went bankrupt in December 1989, two years after it was founded. Mr. Myerson denied any wrongdoing and said he would represent himself and "erase the cloud that has been placed over me."

title: More Choices for Homeless Pupils
description: SCHOOL districts in central Westchester with no homeless children have agreed to accept them from other districts beginning in the fall, under a plan being coordinated by the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

title: An American Rude Tongue
description: DEATH SONG By Thomas McGrath. Edited by Sam Hamill. 117 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Copper Canyon Press. Cloth, $19. Paper, $10.

title: THE AGES OF ZIN
description: A DECADE AGO, A LITTLE-KNOWN BICOASTAL WINE RIVALRY developed that threatened to wreak serious harm on the country's fledgling program of wine appellations. Wine appellations, better known as the names of viticultural regions, define the area in which wines may be made. The Napa Valley is probably the country's best-known viticultural region. The Russian River, in Sonoma County, is another; so is the North Fork, on Long Island.

title: MENACE MODIFIED
description: It takes italian designers to glamorize a thug. Or, conversely, to turn a dandy seedy. When they showed their wares for winter earlier this year, many of Italy's style pace-setters did just that by toying with popular Italian stereotypes.

title: The Struggle Within
description: Mohammed glared at the depressingly familiar mustachioed face that filled the screen. The giant television occupied a place of honor inside his vast Bedouin-style tent, complete with satellite TV receiver and crystal chandeliers.

title: Campaign in Manhasset Tries to Spare Club From Developer
description: A PETITION signed by 1,000 residents is putting pressure on the Manhasset Park District to condemn a site to save it.

title: Headliners; Bush Backer
description: Visiting Washington last week to collect a Freedom Medal from George Bush, former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher displayed some of the steel for which she is famous. And Mr. Bush let it drop that at one point during the gulf crisis, she had lent some of it to him. Mrs. Thatcher, who was cited for leading Britain with "fearlessness, determination, integrity, and a true vision," said it was an honor to receive the medal from a President who had just won a victory that "will rank with the greatest in history." At one point in the ceremony, Mr. Bush described how he had called Mrs. Thatcher to explain why he was letting one Iraqi ship through the blockade. She agreed with his decision, but then, he recalled, offered some unforgettable advice: " 'Remember, George,' she said, 'this is no time to go wobbly.' " Later, in a speech, Mrs. Thatcher suggested that Mr. Bush maintain his pluck and be ready to respond swiftly if the "dark forces of reaction" in the Soviet Union threaten a return to repression.

title: Should Stars Set the Agenda?
description: The stars were well represented, specifically Holly Hunter, Danny Aiello and Richard Dreyfuss, and there was the usual expensive party afterward. But when "Once Around" opened in New York earlier this year, the premiere was different in one key respect. Just before the lights went out, the actor Christopher Reeve took the stage, and it seemed the audience was going to get just a bit of exhortation, maybe even a touch of enlightenment.

title: Marci S. Reiss to Wed Eric H. Berger
description: Judge and Mrs. Sidney H. Reiss of Passaic Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marci Susan Reiss, to Eric Hamilton Berger, the son of Roberta Berger of Phoenix and Lawrence Berger of Morristown, N.J. The wedding is to be in May 1992.

title: THE SWEET SMELL OF EXCESS
description: Penelope Green's article "The Sweet Smell of Excess" (Beauty, Feb. 10) was great. She made me wonder what would happen if writers started cashing in on the perfume market. Here are a few possibilities:

title: An Old Hand Seeks To Lure New Faces
description: IF past performances are any indication, the Newport Jazz Festival could have a rival in Westchester now that Richard S. Eisley has become the first president and chief operating officer of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: An Actor Relives a Tumultuous Past
description: Sam Wanamaker relishes the irony of his current role in Irwin Winkler's "Guilty by Suspicion." In the film, opening Friday, the 71-year-old Mr. Wanamaker, who spent 10 years in exile in the days of the Hollywood blacklist, portrays a lawyer who tries to convince his clients to name names before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

title: A Busy Day of Chamber Recitals
description: CHAMBER music rules today, but you'll find a major piano recital, orchestral programs, even grand opera later in the week.

title: THE GUIDE
description: GUBERNATORIAL ROLE

title: Sunday Menu; Tofu, So Bland, Will Always a Borrower Be
description: Before you turn your nose up at tofu, let me assure you that you won't even know it is in this dish of broccoli and gingered beef. Tofu, or bean curd, is so bland in its natural state and so absorbent that it takes on the flavors of whatever it is mixed with. It is available soft or firm and for this type of recipe, either will do but firm is better.

title: In the Shadow of a Big, Bad Boy
description: TREETOPS A Family Memoir. By Susan Cheever. Illustrated. 204 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: Postings: Preservation Award; Council Lionizing a 'Hellion'
description: She has described herself as a "small-sized hellion," but her friends in the city's landmarks preservation movement have come to regard Halina Rosenthal as nothing less than top cat when it comes to working to save historic buildings and neighborhoods and lobbying for zoning laws that favor open skies and friendly spaces over brutal size.

title: I.N. Kireeff, 89, Dies; Noted Russian Dancer
description: Ivan Nickolaievich Kireeff, a classical ballet dancer who toured with Anna Pavlova and later taught in the United States, died on Friday at Glens Falls Hospital. He was 89 and lived in Victory Mills in Saratoga County.

title: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar; Silence of Discourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Rangers Rent a Goon
description: In the Rangers' desperate quest for the Stanley Cup, good hockey players apparently aren't enough. Without even an apology, the Rangers have adopted the rent-a-goon policy. Say hello, politely, to Joe Kocur, whose primary talent is punching people.

title: On Language; Sign Here
description: Welcome, semiotics fans, to lit-crit's glorious new era of post-deconstructionism.

title: The Rise and Fall of a So-So Comic
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is presenting the world premiere of "He Had a Hat" by Henry Slesar.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Jessie Lie Farber's Dec. 23 letter about the people of Bursa was a happy flash.

title: The Youth of America Go Home
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Sebastian Flyte
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Wellon, Banker, Wed To R. S. Kersten, Physician
description: Nancy Lynn Wellon and Dr. Roger Scott Kersten were married yesterday at the Milleridge Cottage in Jericho, L.I. Irving Tenenbaum, a retired judge of Suffolk County Family Court officiated.

title: A 'Smokeless' Ban
description: The use of smokeless tobacco by baseball personnel will be banned this season at all ball parks in four rookie and short-season Class A leagues, Commissioner Fay Vincent said last week.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the actress Eileen Atkins misstated Quentin Bell's relationship to Virginia Woolf. He is her nephew.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Glimpses of Keen Life In even the driest documents of the past one may find an artless aside that brings an individual to vivid life, as H. S. Bennett discovered when examining letters dating to the 15th century. This is from his classic study "The Pastons and Their England: Studies in an Age of Transition" (Canto/ Cambridge University, paper).

title: Stacey Hein Is Married
description: Stacey Lynn Hein, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Hein of Short Hills, N.J., was married there last evening to Dr. David Eric Gross, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Gross of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Ely Pilchik and Cantor Norman Summers officiated at the Chanticler catering hall. The bride, 27 years old, is a certified public accountant and a supervisor of employee financial services at the D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles advertising agency in New York. She is a graduate of Lehigh University. The bridegroom, 28, is a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Montefiore Hospital Medical Center in the Bronx. He is a graduate of City College and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: Miss Warner to Wed J. M. Rusbarsky
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Warner 3d of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Ann Warner to Joseph Mark Rusbarsky, a son of Col. and Mrs. Francis R. Rusbarsky of Websters Grove, Mo. A May wedding is planned.

title: Patricia A. Maerz To Marry in July
description: Patricia Ann Maerz, a psychotherapist in Boston, and Michael Paul Clancy, the deputy secretary of the Law Society of Scotland in Edinburgh, plan to marry in July.

title: Police Storm Protest in Belgrade; 2 Dead
description: Two people were killed and at least 76 wounded today as the police used tear gas, water cannon and gunfire to break up a violent demonstration by thousands of residents calling for the ouster of the former Communist who heads the Yugoslav republic of Serbia.

title:
DINING OUT;
Colonial Charm in Harrison, Inside and Out
description: FROM the parking lot across the street, this charming, porched Colonial simply glows with a welcome that doesn't switch off once diners walk inside. The operation is a family affair: Emilio and Lidia Brasesco and their son Sergio, and even the waiting staff, treat diners as guests in their home. After receiving a warm greeting, customers pass a table laden with palate-tempting samples of appetizers and special ingredients the Brasescos have planned for the evening.

title: If Mahler Had Written a Concerto . . .
description: At long last, the time may be right for the music of Ferruccio Busoni to reach a wider public. For nearly a century it has languished, not entirely forgotten due to a few loving champions, but dismissed by received opinion. Now that stylistic diversity has become newly popular, Busoni's own variety and contradictions are seen less as a liability than as a prescient virtue.

title: Is Saddam Hussein a Phoenix?
description: The biggest unanswered question after the allies' stunningly decisive triumph in the Persian Gulf war is, Will they have to fight Saddam Hussein again? News analysis, page 16.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MOZART COMPENDIUM A Guide to Mozart's Life and Music. Edited by H. C. Robbins Landon. Schirmer, $34.95.

title: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar; The Old Gas Pump
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Singing on Ice

title: On Screen, They're Even Bigger Game
description: When it comes to movies, nothing seems to bring out the animal in man (and sometimes the romance in woman) like a good safari.

title: Looking for Tom Brokejaw or Cyrano de Burgerjoint? Try Bridgeport
description: SEATED around a conference table in an office in downtown Bridgeport, writers, performers and producers were tossing out topical comedy ideas.

title: Reviews/Theater; Wallach and Jackson In Odd-Couple Comedy
description: Sparky and Fitz, the cutely nicknamed husband and wife who jabber away in Craig Volk's "Sparky and the Fitz," are one of the quirkier couples to be found in a contemporary comedy.

title: Creating 'Underpinnings' for the Elderly
description: ONE American in four is 65 or older, and Connecticut's elderly population is expected to increase 14 percent by 2010. Most elderly people want to live as independently as they can, for as long as they can. Many who have some difficulties, like limited mobility, can still remain in their own homes if they have assistance.

title: Iran's Comeback in the Gulf
description: Iran's re-emergence as a gulf power is a breathtaking consequence of Saddam Hussein's defeat in Kuwait. Its enhanced position has been helped by a gradual recovery from its devastating war with Iraq in the 1980's. But the main factor was its decision to sit on the sidelines and not help Mr. Hussein, even after the Iraqi ruler gave up his country's remaining war claims against Iran.

title: Gari Lister to Wed Gerald P. Farano
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lister of Arlington, Va., and London have announced the engagement of their daughter Penelope Margaret Lister to Gerald Patrick Farano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Farano of Smithtown, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Ideas & Trends; When the Government Runs Afoul of Its Own Regulators
description: PROMISING to make a clean break with 40 years of pollution at its nuclear weapons plants, the Department of Energy has signed agreements with states and with other Federal agencies committing itself to abide by environmental laws and clean up the mess. Now the Energy Department has a new problem. In some cases it is violating not only the laws, but also the agreements.

title: Travel Advisory; Celtic Exhibit In Venice
description: "The Celts -- the First Europe" is the theme of an exhibition opening in the white Palazzo Grassi on the Grand Canal in Venice on March 24 and continuing until Dec. 8. It focuses on the people who in the first millenium B.C. spread from their original homes between the Rhine and the Danube as far as Ireland to the west and the Black Sea in the southeast. Celtic tribes and bands, called Gauls by the ancient Romans, invaded northern Italy, raided Rome in 390 B.C., and settled in France.

title: Brett Hull's Golden Opportunity
description: Once he was thought of as an underachiever, Bobby Hull's overweight son, a one-dimensional talent who progressed slowly through the minor leagues, then had an unfulfilling, part-time role with his first National Hockey League team, the Calgary Flames.

title: Stacey L. Bernstein Is Wed
description: Stacey Lee Bernstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Bernstein of Old Westbury, L.I., was married last night at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club to Philip Malakoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Malakoff of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan officiated. Mrs. Malakoff, 27 years old, graduated from Washington University and is a certified public accountant. She is the director of reimbursement at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. Mr. Malakoff, 26, graduated from Emory University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a foreign exchange trader in New York at Manufacturers Hanover Trust.

title: Caitlin Borgmann Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert Borgmann of Missoula, Mont., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caitlin Eve Borgmann to John David Lovi, a son of Lucy Lovi of Dover Plains, N.Y., and the late Albert Lovi. An August wedding is planned.

title: Beth Cody and Donald Kimmel to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Frederic Cody of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Wallace Cody, to Donald Dinning Kimmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Richard Kimmel of Louisville, Ky. A June wedding is planned.

title: Can 'Katya' Last Long At the Met?
description: Unless this weekly prose bite has been overtaken by events too dramatic to imagine at the moment of writing, the political Iron Curtain no longer exists. So far as the Metropolitan Opera is concerned, however, a barrier of old standing remains: the Language Curtain. Though important peepholes were punched in the veil during the company's early history, Met audiences in recent decades have been left largely in the dark about all but a handful of Eastern Europe's classics. "Boris Godunov," "Eugene Onegin" and "Pique Dame" have long been standbys, but more recent attempts to introduce Slavic and other Eastern tongues to the subscribers have been fleetingly successful at best. Works like Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle," Mussorgsky's "Khovanshchina" and Stravinsky's "Rossignol" generate flurries of excitement at first, then lapse back into the shadows of the repertory.

title: Mutual Funds; Stronger Results Without Risk
description: In 1990, the clear winners were risk-adverse investors. Money-market funds, which are essentially risk-free, beat the corporate A-rated bond funds by a full percentage point. Corporate bond funds, which invest in high-quality corporate issues, are not exactly the liveliest investments, but do carry two types of risk: market risk, reflecting changes in interest rates affecting the bonds' value, and the risk of default.

title: 1990 Census: How Fairfield County Changed
description: During the 1980's, Fairfield County's population grew fastest in more rural northern and eastern towns, while most of the cities and well-to-do suburbs along the coast lagged or declined, mirroring changes in other parts of the state.

title: The Real Reason for America's Inability to Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: Why He Jilted Sartre
description: A WRITER'S REALITY By Mario Vargas Llosa. Edited by Myron I. Lichtblau. 164 pp. Syracuse: Syracuse University Press. $24.95.

title: Bursting With Change, New Jersey's Soul Becomes More Diverse
description: AFTER Hong Yoon graduated from dental school and set up his Manhattan practice, he wanted to move his family out of the city and into suburbia. In his search for a community that would offer a touch of Korean culture, Dr. Yoon headed across the Hudson River to New Jersey and found what he was looking for in Fort Lee.

title: Travel Advisory; Blixen Museum
description: The Danish home of Baroness Karen Blixen, who wrote the autobiographical "Out of Africa" and other books under the name Isak Dinesen, is to be opened to the public as the Karen Blixen Museum. The house called Rungstedlund in Rungsted, about 15 miles north of Copenhagen, is where Karen Blixen was born in 1885 and died in 1962. Queen Margrethe of Denmark will open the museum officially on May 14. Until now the garden but not the house has been open to visitors. The author, who lived on a coffee plantation in East Africa from 1914 until 1931, wrote many of her books at the house, which overlooks Rungsted's harbor.

title: The Nation; Judges Struggle To Control A Caseload Crisis
description: FOR months a handful of Federal judges from around the nation has been jockeying, lobbying and handing down opinions in a spirited and unofficial competition to take the lead role in resolving the asbestos-litigation crisis confronting the courts.

title: Anne E. Bartholet, Paralegal, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey Ives Bartholet of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Bartholet and Mathieu Duthoit, a son of Mrs. Didier Duthoit of Paris and the late Mr. Duthoit.

title: A Party Derided
description: There is only one question of any consequence in this city does the Persian Gulf war prove that Democrats lack the toughness to protect America's security? It is an important and unavoidable question. But the answers reflect record levels of instant historical amnesia and analytic hogwash.

title: The Perils and Perishability of a Teen Idol
description: On Aug. 31, Debbie Gibson officially ended her tenure as the pop world's reigning teen queen. She turned 20. That night, she threw a party at the Merrick, L.I., house she shares with her mother and two of her three sisters, a party that had a kind of old-fashioned Hollywood glamour to it. Limousines lined up as an officious-looking man checked off guests' names; valets were on hand at the top of the winding driveway. When the front doors glided open, enough frosty peach light spilled out to illuminate the entire North Shore of Long Island.

title: Slowing Down on the Isle of Itaparica
description: WE had seen enough of cities. My wife and I had spent three days sweating in the Amazon rain forest and then dashed with programmed zeal through Manaus, Brasilia, Rio de Janeiro and Salvador. Dazzled by the diversity of a huge country and frazzled by travel, we sought only two things: solitude and a beach.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THROUGH THE ARC OF THE RAIN FOREST By Karen Tei Yamashita.Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We moved into a new house about six years ago and have always had a problem when someone uses the shower. If either hot or cold water is turned on in another part of the house while the shower is in use, the temperature of the shower water fluctuates wildly from too hot to too cold. Is there something that can be placed on the shower pipes to remedy this?

title: Painters Union Officials Admit Links to Mob
description: For 18 months Paul Kamen was the head of one of New York City's largest construction-trade unions, the painters union, but now prosecutors say a guilty plea by Mr. Kamen on corruption charges confirms that he was a puppet of a Mafia family.

title: The Real Sebastian Flyte
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth L. Danese to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Tracy E. Danese of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Lea Danese, and Jack King Mozley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Mozley of Panama City, Fla. Miss Danese, 29, and her fiance, 41, are both with the Florida Department of Commerce in Tallahassee, she as an international representative in the European section and he as the manager of consumer promotions. Miss Danese graduated from Florida State University and received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia University. Mr. Mozley graduated from Grahm Junior College.

title: Brazil's Cultural Crossroads
description: FEW cities in the New World can claim a longer or more august history than Salvador da Bahia, Brazil's fourth largest metropolis and the principal repository of the country's European and African traditions. And few places anywhere have such a vocation for relaxation or are so hospitable. Salvador may not be the place for those who feel compelled to ask the time every few minutes, but it is ideal for anyone intent on savoring the past and simply enjoying the present.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Handling Defaults by Co-op Sponsors
description: AS the market for cooperative apartments remains soft on Long Island, a rising number of sponsors are defaulting on maintenance payments for units they are unable to sell, real-estate lawyers say.

title: A California Plan for Early Caucuses
description: Thwarted in their efforts to make the state's Presidential primary one of the earliest in the nation, California Democrats have devised a plan they hope will give the state a more prominent role in selecting party nominees.

title: The Region; Union Blow-Up Reawakens Issue
description: DAVID N. DINKINS has built a long and largely quiet political career on the principle of trying to please everybody. But in the relentless spotlight of New York City's mayoralty, he often ends up pleasing no one, least of all himself.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Families; 3 Come Home to Mourn Brother Felled by War
description: At the Greater Jerusalem Baptist Church this morning, shrieks of grief and slow, sad gospel hymns marked the return of four soldiers who had fought in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Good Morning, Vietnam
description: It was as if two wars, not just one, ended with the American-led coalition's quick and decisive victory over Iraq. When the guns fell silent, President Bush proudly proclaimed that "The specter of Vietnam has been buried forever in the desert sands of the Arabian Peninsula."

title: Review/Dance; The Sounds of Movement
description: Anita Feldman believes that dancers should be heard as well as seen. She had them make wonderful noises Monday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church in "Wings and Drumsticks," the program she coordinated for this year's Morningside Dance Festival. Dance movements turned into music, the actions of musicians came to resemble dancing, and dance and music were always in harmony.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Tomba Wins Championship: Alberto Tomba of Italy made a dominating first run stand up yesterday in Aspen, Colo., to clinch the World Cup giant slalom crown with his fourth victory of the season in that discipline. Tomba, who led the young Norwegian Lasse Kjuus by 1.19 seconds after the first run, struggled through a faltering second run that was only the seventh fastest of the afternoon. But he still defeated Austria's Rudolf Nierlich by nearly a half second in combined time. Tomba had runs of 1 minute 5.15 seconds and 1:06.77 for an aggregate of 2:11.92. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg finished third in 2:12.98 and moved a step closer to his fourth World Cup overall title. Girardelli earned 15 points and needs only 13 more to clinch the overall crown. No Americans finished the first run among the top 30 skiers who qualified for the second run.(AP)

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MOUSEHOLE CAT By Antonia Barber. Illustrated by Nicola Bayley. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company.

title: A Touch of the Wild
description: Nature often behaves as if New York were just another wild place. This winter, for example, three red-tailed hawks have made a habitat along the Henry Hudson Parkway. They sit, hunched up, in trees between the road and the river, watching traffic. From time to time, they hunt river rats, which are easy pickings there because the rats always follow the same pathways along the banks.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION: A Political Life in the Reagan Era, by Peggy Noonan. (Ivy, $5.95.) Because of her distaste for the antics of her leftist compatriots, Peggy Noonan found herself swinging so far right that she ended up as a speechwriter in the Reagan White House. Last year our reviewer, Wilfrid Sheed, said, "This is the great strength and pleasure of 'What I Saw at the Revolution': the glee it keeps giving one to find a recognizable human, a comrade, in truly preposterous circumstances, be they left or right." COLLECTED STORIES OF WALLACE STEGNER. (Penguin, $10.95.) In the foreword to this collection, Wallace Stegner says that short stories, which he stopped writing in the 1950's, are best attempted by the young, for they are "made for discoveries and nuances and epiphanies." Last year our reviewer, Anne Tyler, said Mr. Stegner's own attempts range "from stories we nod at knowingly, however excellent they may be, to stories that take our breath away with the unforeseen. . .This collection is as solid as good furniture." Several of the stories were later reworked into the novel THE BIG ROCK CANDY MOUNTAIN ($9.95), which Penguin has also republished. In the book, a family of drifters, led by a violent man named Bo Mason, become involved in rum running in the Northwest.

title: Yachting; Rest and Refuge at a Uruguay Port
description: The port of Punta del Este, Uruguay, became a refuge this week for BOC round-the-world sailors battered by icebergs and high winds during a 7,200-mile voyage from Sydney, Australia.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: THOMAS F. COLASUONNO;
Helping the Deaf Gain More Access
description: MOST deaf people can't speak in the traditional way, but they have nonetheless been making their "voices" heard. One result is last year's Americans With Disabilities Act, aimed at eliminating barriers that prevent deaf and hard-of-hearing people -- among others -- from achieving their potential.

title: Travel Advisory; Stowe Trail
description: An addition to the cross-country trail network in Stowe, Vt., was opened recently. The 1.5-mile trail connects the Mount Mansfield and Trapp's Touring Centers. The groomed trail follows the route of the old Ranch Camp Trail, which dates from the 1930's. It climbs from the Burt Road near Mount Mansfield, reaches the open meadows at Trapp's and continues to the Trapp's Cabin.

title: Nonmarital Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Elisabeth Rippy To Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Elisabeth Hamblin Rippy to Kurt Peter Losert, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Losert of Shrewsbury, Mass., has been announced by her mother, Mrs. David R. Rippy of Wellesley, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: Glimpsing Hungary's Ottoman Past
description: A STANDARD litany of Hungary's historical woes is the century and a half much of the country spent under the Turkish yoke, starting with the defeat of Hungarian forces on a dusty plain at Mohacs on Aug. 29, 1526.

title: Food; Southern Light
description: I LOVE PLAIN OLD SOUTHERN FOOD. I GREW up on the stuff and crave it often. But whether it's because I've lived in New York City for the past 11 years or simply because I love flavors characteristic of other cuisines -- cilantro, ginger and saffron, for example -- I find I'm always fooling around with the recipes handed down from my mother and grandmothers. I don't think it's so terrible to muck with tradition. Besides, it's difficult to create an authentic regional dish if you aren't actually in that region. (Sure, you can make a good coq au vin in Milwaukee. But it won't taste like the one you made in cooking school in Burgundy.) I can't even get self-rising flour here, so my biscuits, for example, are already destined to taste different from those of my forebears. So it doesn't feel so dishonest to spread them with chevre butter before layering on the Smithfield ham.

title: If the Show's a Hit, Handle With Care
description: "Cheers" is 9 years old. "The Cosby Show" has been running since 1984. "L.A. Law" celebrated its 100th episode this season, the series' fifth. All three NBC Thursday-night shows are as familiar and as cherished as a favorite sweater, pulling in good ratings week after week; "Cheers" is the top-rated show on television.

title: Soraya Zarghami, A Producer, Wed
description: Soraya Zarghami, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. G. H. Zarghami of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to George Robert Gage Jr., the son of George R. Gage of Middletown, Ohio, and Mrs. Keith McNamara of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Aloysius P. Kelley, the president of Fairfield University, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: How to Move A Documentary
description: Among the nominees for an Academy Award as best documentary feature this year is "Building Bombs," a 55-minute film about haphazard nuclear waste disposal at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant near Aiken, S.C. The documentary, made by the independent film makers Mark Mori and Susan Robinson and narrated by Jane Alexander, is available from the Video Project, a California distributor of titles about the environment and other social issues.

title: Meadow Star Set for New York Trip
description: Meadow Star, the undefeated filly champion of 1990, continued to improve today from the ailment that delayed her 1991 debut, and prepared to travel to New York to begin her countdown to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Postings: 15,000 Seats; A New Haven Tennis Center
description: Connecticut tennis fans will join the big leagues with the completion in June of the Connecticut Tennis Center, a 15,000-seat stadium on the Yale University campus in New Haven that will be home to the annual Volvo International professional tourament. The Tennis Foundation of Connecticut, a nonprofit group responsible for the project, said the stadium will be the second largest in the nation, following the National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Feb. 17 with an article about Lynchburg, Tenn., mislabeled the state to the west. It is Arkansas, not Kansas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 3 about secession demands in Quebec misstated the leadership history of the Parti Quebecois.
