Rene Levesque was succeeded as party leader by Pierre-Marc Johnson, who was in turn replaced by Jacques Parizeau. A reader wrote to The Times on Feb. 22 about the error, and publication of the correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: At the Public, This Bud's for You, Bard
description: A lot will no doubt be made of the anachronisms that the director JoAnne Akalaitis has sprinkled liberally throughout her staging of "Henry IV, Parts I and II," the 16th and 17th productions in the Public Theater's continuing Shakespeare marathon.

title: Travel Advisory; Garden Week in Virginia
description: Wildflowers, redbud and dogwood will decorate the roads of Virginia when 200 private homes and gardens are opened for the state's Historic Garden Week from April 20 to 28. The Garden Club of Virginia, which organizes the annual event, says it is the only statewide house and garden tour in the country. Most of the houses, many dating to the 18th century and furnished with antiques, are grouped in tours of five or six, with tour tickets $7 to $12.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE PELHAM ART CENTER;
What Toys Say About Bygone Children
description: IT is a toy lover's dream. From whirligig to flipperdinger, from a replica of London's Crystal Palace to one of the space shuttle Columbia, the Pelham Art Center is filled with gadgets, games, dolls and other whimsical delights.

title: Funds Restored to Clinics for Assault Victims
description: After a round of last-minute meetings, New York City officials restored funds late last week to save three clinics in municipal hospitals that provide counseling and other services to victims of rape and domestic violence in some of the city's poorest neighborhoods.

title: Outdoors; Thaw Brings Out Regulars
description: One of nature's most welcome gifts is a February thaw. It's usually a little thing, but like any well-chosen gift, most appreciated. When winter's armor broke a few weeks ago I took my daughter, Lucy, for a fishing trip on the Elsie K., which departs -- weather permitting -- every day at 10 A.M. from Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn.

title: Alyssa B. Licht Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Licht of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alyssa Barrie Licht to James Roy Gronfein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Gronfein of Fort Lee, N.J. The wedding is planned for next year. The couple, both 24 years old, graduated from American University. Miss Licht is studying for a master's degree in social work at Columbia University; Mr. Gronfein is an advertising planner at L.B.S. Communications, a television syndication company in New York.

title: The Region; An 'Aberration' or Police Business as Usual?
description: BLACK people's complaints of police brutality have been made so often for so long that they seem almost part of the fabric of urban life, like homelessness and traffic jams. But like a storm gathering fury across a plain, reaction to the brutal beating of Rodney Glen King by a group of Los Angeles police officers swelled into a national outpouring of outrage last week as networks broadcast a videotape of the incident.

title: Weber Wins in Bowling
description: Pete Weber's fate was in his hands today at the $150,000 Johnny Petraglia Open, and after throwing a strike and a nine on his first two balls in the 10th frame, those hands were raised in triumph.

title:
Gardening;
Under the Leaves Uncommon Fruit
description: I eagerly await this season's harvest of Nanking cherries, pawpaws, maypops and saskatoons, uncommon fruits that are not widely grown. Any gardener put off by the difficulty of raising apples, peaches and other ordinary fruit should consider planting these lesser-known delicacies, which generally are ignored by pests and, in many cases, do not need annual pruning. Their very uncommonness is another compelling reason to grow them -- you cannot buy maypops and pawpaws at the fruit stand.

title: THE M.L.A. CONVENTION
description: It comes, of course, as a shock to learn that a large faction of professors and graduate students at the Modern Language Association's annual convention has concluded that there is no such thing as creative genius; it's like hearing that a convocation of eunuchs has declared that there's no such thing as sexual pleasure ("Deciphering Victorian Underwear And Other Seminars" by Anne Matthews, Feb. 10). But I don't think we need be alarmed, just because so many literature professors have finally admitted that they are bored by literature. Those Boring Dead White Males who wrote satire and comedy (Rabelais, Swift, Sterne, et al.) customarily portrayed theory-besotted professors as preening, droning, ridiculous creatures. Surely, we ought to be grateful to Prof. Andrew Ross and his politically correct colleagues for going to such lengths to carry on this venerable Eurocentric tradition. L. S. KLEPP New York, N.Y.

title: The Nation; Medicare Prognosis: Unwieldy Growth Fueled by More Fees and Beneficiaries
description: MEDICARE has emerged from 10 years of aggressive cost-control efforts as the fastest-growing major program in the Federal budget, and experts see little chance of slowing its growth as the elderly become more numerous and live longer while costs, led by payments to physicians, continue to rise relentlessly.

title: Back to Reality; U.S. Sets a Cautious Course on Mideast Peace
description: JUST as President Bush was about to go to Capitol Hill for his address to Congress on the war last week, his advisers rushed up with a change for the speech. It was only seven words, but for them it was the definition of the postwar Middle East, the heralded "new world order."

title: Israeli Soldiers in Gaza Wound 55 Palestinians
description: Israeli troops today wounded as many as 55 Palestinians, including a 5-year-old girl, in the Gaza Strip's worst violence since the Persian Gulf war began in mid-January, Arab reports said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TRIALS OF AN EXPERT WITNESS Tales of Clinical Neurology and the Law.By Harold L. Klawans.Little, Brown, $19.95.

title: Managing; Farewell to the Training Seminar?
description: John L. Hanson, vice president of human resources at the Parker Hannifin Corporation, recently gave copies of "Keeping the Best," Martin Yate's book on motivating employees, to about 40 of the industrial component manufacturer's managers. "The book says that the first step in satisfying customers is having satisfied employees, and I want to drive that point home," he said.

title: HEPBURN STYLE
description: Shirts like these conjure up images of those two legendary actresses, Audrey and Kate. Both Hepburn women have always had a thumping impact on fashion. Katharine Hepburn's elegant, racy style, based on the elements of men's clothing, has inspired designers for at least 50 years.

title: Retiree Kills Wife, Then Commits Suicide
description: A retired New York City Housing Authority employee who had been "acting irrational" killed his wife, who was dying of cancer, and committed suicide late Friday in their house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Alexander O'Neal: 'All True Man' Tabu/Epic Z45349; CD and cassette

title: Headliners; An Ethical Death?
description: Are there circumstances under which it is ethical and moral for a doctor to help a terminally ill patient reach the end sooner? Dr. Timothy E. Quill seems to have provided, by his own example, the most thorough answer to date. In an article published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Quill described how and why he helped a longtime patient die. The patient, a 45-year-old woman identified only as Diane, had acute leukemia and stood a 25 percent chance of survival if she opted for a grueling regimen of chemotherapy and other treatment. Diane said she would rather die. When she later asked him for barbiturates to help her sleep, Dr. Quill said he knew she had decided to end her life. He prescribed the pills and told her how many would kill her. Authorities in Monroe County, N.Y., where Diane died, say they are investigating the incident. But a medical ethicist, Dr. Ronald E. Cranford, said, "This is a very important case, and people will have trouble criticizing the procedure."

title: Bobbo Druff's Alcoholic Vaudeville
description: THE MACGUFFIN By Stanley Elkin. 283 pp. New York: Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Playwright's Living Monument Nurtures His Memory and Craft
description: THE view through a window at the Thames Landing Restaurant in New London harbor shows a bronze statue of the young Eugene O'Neill sitting on a rock with a pen and a sketch pad in his hand. The monument, based on the playwright's favorite photograph of himself, is one of the first things passengers see when they arrive at the city's train station.

title: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar; Symbol of Affirmation
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Charity Gets 'New' Offices
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago the American Lung Association of the Hudson Valley -- then known as the Westchester Tuberculosis Association -- moved to its current headquarters on Orchard Street in White Plains. The two-story contemporary-style glass, steel and stucco building designed by Joseph Roth Architects of Yonkers received rave notices from its new occupants and won an award for excellence from the American Institute of Steel Construction.

title: On the Street; Young Fancies Turn to Fashion
description: Children are always the first to remove winter coats, hats and mittens in a thaw. Some of the young faces seemed to wonder where the sledding or ice skating had gone last weekend. Rollerblades were the answer for some; one young skater was turned out in a vibrant pink Spandex unitard that had a ruffled skating skirt. Two youngsters in striped tights and sweatshirts licked ice cream cones at an outdoor cafe. And one tyke was dressed in skateboard overalls with the cuffs rolled up. A cap askew on his head and fingerless crocheted gloves made him the epitome of high style for weekends in the park. Denim jackets were for clambering over the Alice in Wonderland sculpture in Central Park as other children watched model sailboats take the winds of March.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Times Magazine today about Britain's role in the Persian Gulf war says that after the war began, British authorities put 34 Arabs in a war-prisoner camp because of their military status, and put other Arabs in prisons in Yorkshire and London. On Wednesday, after the magazine went to press, Britain freed 32 Iraqi men who were held in the camp. On Friday Britain said it would drop all actions against 33 other Arabs it had sought to deport as possible threats to domestic security.

title: Campus Life: S.M.U.; Fun, Fitness, and Fashion At $150 a Pair
description: Students at Southern Methodist University have been rolling around in herds recently thanks to the newest craze to hit campus from both the East and the West Coasts: roller blades.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Ivoryton, Conn. 83,500 Unit 2c Comstock Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/22-bath, 19-year-old town house; laundry room, patio, wooded setting; taxes $817. Southington, Conn. 145,500 118 Union Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; remodeled kitchen, deck, 1-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $1,719. Wallingford, Conn. 122,500 19 Cheryl Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; c/a, eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,270. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. 525,000 3 Central Drive West 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; fireplace, deck, den, 2-car garage, 1.4 acres; taxes $9,529. Scarsdale, N.Y. 432,800 136 Brewster Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old English stucco; fireplace, library, eat-in kitchen, 2 patios; taxes $8,059. South Salem, N.Y. 365,000 27 Scenic Drive 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; formal dining room, family room, fireplace, eat-in kitchen, deck, Jacuzzi, 1.2 acres; taxes $7,743. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. 465,000 5 Devonshire Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-half bath, 25-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, den, eat-in-kitchen, c/a; taxes $6,492. Maplewood, N.J. 223,000 88 Jefferson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-half bath, 35-year-old colonial; porch, fireplace, 2-car garage, h/w floors; taxes $5,110. Levittown, L.I. 140,000 10 Grassy Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700.

title: William Thomas Matschke To Wed Sara Zoe Schepps
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elihu M. Schepps of Holyoke, Mass., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Sara Zoe Schepps, and William Thomas Matschke, a son of Evelyn Matschke of Millerton, N.Y., and the late Albert Matschke. Ms. Schepps, 31 years old, is an associate at the New York law firm of Richards & O'Neil. She graduated from Cornell University and received a law degree from Georgetown University. Mr. Matschke, 36, is the controller of the New York law firm of Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Specthrie and Lerach. He graduated from St. John's University and received a master's degree in accounting from Adelphi University.

title: Columbus
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the sumary of Columbus Quincentenary events set for 1992 (Q & A, Dec. 16). Travelers should be aware, howerver, that the 500th anniversary of the discovery of America is not regarded as an event to celebrate by many native Americans, African Americans and others.

title: Sabatini Stops Capriati
description: With no nod to sentiment, Gabriela Sabatini eliminated Jennifer Capriati, 7-5, 6-2, today in the wind-plagued semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Florida, the tournament at which Capriati made her pro debut last year.

title: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street; Hospital Stocks -- Not Created Equal
description: What would you pay for a profitable hospital company with about $250 million in annual sales, a dozen or so medium-sized hospitals clustered in the South and a fair dose of debt? At least three companies that fit the description have gone public in the last year, but they trade at wildly different multiples. One is at seven times earnings; one at 21 times earnings, and the third at a lofty 36 times earnings.

title: Alabama Leads Push for Cleaner Offshore Drilling
description: Here aboard the drilling platform Glomar Highland IV, a vibrating cacophony of shouting men and squealing steel, the Mobil Oil Corporation is tapping into one of the largest strikes of natural gas ever made in North America.

title: G.M. Plant Is Struggling But Hopeful
description: WORKERS at the General Motors plant here have seen their share of hard times, and last year was no exception, with 450 workers laid off indefinitely in July and another 450 in November.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Defense on Attack: Detectives' Battle
description: As the prosecution's chief witness in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus had his life as a private investigator laid bare in impossible detail by the defense, two men seated near the defendant smiled and punched the air in satisfaction.

title: A Goldberg Variation
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: OPEC meeting in Geneva. * A Federal judge in Dayton, Ohio, hears A.T.& T.'s bid to invalidate NCR's new employee stock ownership plan. * The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. * Housing completions for January. * Scheduled hearing in Federal court on a challenge by five Alaskan villages to the settlement of claims arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill. TUESDAY: Fourth-quarter trade deficit. * Wholesale inventories for January. WEDNESDAY: Retail sales for February. * Federal Reserve beige book. * Auto sales for March 1 to 10. THURSDAY: Business inventories and shipments for January. * Jobless claims for the week ended March 2. FRIDAY: Producer prices, industrial production and capacity utilization for February.

title: Madonna and the New Economic Order
description: THE WORK OF NATIONS Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism. By Robert B. Reich. 331 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Anne B. Seidel To Wed in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. George M. Seidel of Providence and Little Compton, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Beatrice Seidel to Timothy Stuart Douglas, a son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Gordon Douglas Jr. of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Old Black Point, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: The Dark Side of the Sun
description: IT is a bright morning at 7. Suspiciously bright and mild for Newark Airport in February, causing one to think "greenhouse effect." Causing one who is wont to think of the greenhouse effect to think of it, anyway. Causing one who obsesses about the greenhouse effect to think of it yet again. The sun is streaming through the aircraft's lozenge window as we ignore our flight attendant's drill on airline safety.

title: Pianist Takes the Classics on the Road
description: "RELAX," said the tall, casually dressed pianist. "This is an 'informance,' not a recital. It's an informal performance."

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: CARMEN BARROS;
From the Arts to the Art of Interpreting
description: CARMEN BARROS, a classical dancer and actress who appeared regularly in the early 1980's with the Ballet Hispanico of New York and did commercials on Spanish television, said she had found herself at the age of 35 in an uncomfortable position.

title: Monet's Famous Gardens In a Bottle, Not on a Wall
description: The flowers and gardens in Claude Monet's paintings, whose colors and sense of romance have touched art lovers for generations, have now inspired a perfume. The fragrance, Les Fleurs de Claude Monet, has been sold in the United States for about two months. It is a blend of jasmine, iris, lily of the valley, white rose and daffodil, with a touch of lavender and an ambergris base.

title: The Nation; For a Key to Economic Health, See the 'Help Wanted' Ads
description: FOR days, there were signals that the recession might be lifting. New figures showed that factory production rose a bit in February. The war's end suggested that consumers would soon be in a spending mood again. The stock market boomed, and home sales even began to rise. But then on Friday, the Labor Department dashed these incipient hopes, announcing in effect that the recession's end was not in sight after all.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Air War; Unforeseen Problems in Air War Forced Allies to Improvise Tactics
description: Throughout the war in the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon repeatedly asserted that the military campaign was running according to plan. But top military planners and pilots reviewing the successful allied air war against Iraq say they ran into unexpected problems from the very start, forcing tactical improvisations.

title: Pete Rose and His First Day Away
description: The magazine cover did not represent one of the happier stages in the life of Peter Edward Rose. It was the July 3, 1989, cover of Sports Illustrated, and it artfully juxtaposed a glum photograph of Rose with rather damaging testimony from one of his raffish gambling companions from Cincinnati.

title: Style Makers; Anne Gilson Haney, Light-Switch Plate Artist
description: If Anne Gilson Haney owned her duplex apartment in the Back Bay section of Boston, she would probably spread decoupage and stencil work across the walls. Since she rents, she has confined her creative urges to the light-switch plates.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE OUROBOROS By Howard Coale.Ticknor & Fields, $19.95.

title: In the Land of Lambada
description: ON April 22, 1500, a Portuguese nobleman stood on the rolling deck of a caravel and recorded Europe's first vision of what is now called Brazil: coral reefs, fingers of fine white sand, windblown coconut palms and lush mangrove thickets rich with crabs and splashed with the red and green plumage of parrots.

title: 'Other Boroughs' Strategy Bucks Difficult Times
description: A FIVE-YEAR campaign to lure office development to the New York City boroughs outside Manhattan is scoring scattered new successes but encountering tough resistance because of the city's real estate and business downturn.

title: Lydia Kelley and Thomas Nelson to Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome T. Kelley Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Lydia Ann Kelley, and Thomas Matthew Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Nelson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CURTAIN By Michael Korda. Summit, $19.95.

title: Best in Hockey East
description: There was little surprise on Friday when David Emma of Boston College was named Hockey East's player of the year. The relentless 5-foot-9-inch, 175-pound center, a draft selection of the New Jersey Devils, led the league in scoring with 35 goals and became his college's career goal leader with 112.

title: Florida
description: To the Editor: While it is correct that coral may not be collected at Looe Key ("Coral and Clear Water at Looe Key," Travel, Dec. 2), it is implied that it is O.K. to collect it elsewhere. The taking of (even the touching of or standing on) coral is illegal anywhere in the United States, not just in a Federal marine sanctuary.

title: Q and A
description: Inheriting a Co-op Question: My father died and I inherited his Manhattan co-op apartment. I am concerned about my status as far as the board is concerned. Does my ownership have to be approved by the board of directors? . . . Ellen Stern, Manhattan Answer: No. According to Marc Luxemburg, the president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, as a general rule of law, you would have the right to become the owner of the shares. But occupancy rights would depend on the terms of the co-op's proprietary leases.

title: The Roots of 'Made in the U.S.A.'
description: The Museum of Fine Arts is celebrating the 20th anniversary of what can best be described as an American department with a difference. In 1971, long before the term "politically correct" was on everyone's lips, curators in the department of American decorative arts and sculpture decided that in breaking away from the European department, they would declare a new collecting policy, one that went well beyond the refined style of 18th- and early-19th-century Anglo-American arts from Philadelphia, New York and Boston.

title: Denise Baumunk, Auditor, to Wed
description: Earlene Baumunk of Princeton, N.J., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Denise E. Baumunk and James F. Crystal, a son of Lynn F. Crystal of San Antonio and James W. Crystal of New York.

title: Alisa Kwitney Is Engaged To Mark Stapylton-Smith
description: Alisa Kwitney and Mark Stapylton-Smith plan to marry in June.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War 14-17

title: 6 Opinions on School Finance Law
description: WHILE the debate in Trenton about education has recently focused on the amount of money that should be shifted from the Quality Education Act, Gov. Jim Florio's sweeping overhaul of New Jersey public school financing, to property tax relief, other aspects of the law continue to provoke controversy.

title: The Naked And the Dead
description: You never know what will make people laugh.

title: Tapping And Tasting Maple Sugar
description: SPRING comes a drop at a time. On a warm winter day the sound of sap dripping into metal buckets beats out a happy tattoo, signaling the retreat of winter and the approach of spring. Across Westchester and Putnam Counties the maple-sugaring ritual began early with a few warm days in February.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We can see nothing. We just keep firing to let them know we are not asleep and to keep them away." -- An Iraqi major named Assam, outside a village north of Basra. [ 14:1. ]

title: TASTE TYRANTS
description: If there were such a thing as a Commanderie of Wine Drinkers (ordinary laymen and not snobbish and wealthy oenophiles) in this country, they should award their equivalent of the Legion of Honor To Frank J. Prial for his article "Taste Tyrants," subtitled "The smug attitude of insiders drives away a lot of would-be fans." (Wine, Feb. 17)

title:
ART;
Three Members of a Connecticut Family Share 'A Color Heritage'
description: SYNCHROMISM is the only modern art movement born in America before World War I. But this distinction does not make it continually viable or exciting. Synchromism is the use of color applied according to certain immutable laws, and this can mean a disharmony between a painting's surface and its subject matter.

title: Straight Lines Vs. Chinese Boxes
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; As Salvadorans Vote, Rebels Try a Friendlier Form of Persuasion
description: WHEN the people of El Salvador vote in local and legislative elections today, their country's bitter guerrilla conflict will not be far from mind. But in a sign of changing rebel tactics and doctrine, the war may at least be out of sight.

title: Sarah Hurley Plans to Wed Craig F. Reed in 1992
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hurley of Portland, Ore., have announced April 1992 wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Hurley and Craig Frederick Reed, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Ward Reed of Portland.

title: Data Bank/March 10, 1991
Wagner's American Emissary
description: The "Parsifal" tradition at the Metropolitan Opera -- renewed this Thursday evening with a new production directed by Otto Schenk -- is both venerable and startling. It evokes America's heyday of German opera, when the Wagner cult reached Peoria. It also sheds light on Wagner's shifting function in our cultural affairs.

title: Palladio and Log Cabins
description: NORTH CAROLINA ARCHITECTURE By Catherine W. Bishir. Photography by Tim Buchman. Illustrated. 514 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $59.95.

title: The Places Where Americans Live Begin to Defy Description
description: To the Editor:

title: Focaccia, The Latest Addition to the Breadbasket
description: FOCACCIA, a type of Italian flat bread that was virtually unknown in this country five years ago, has taken America by storm. Italian restaurants offer it in the breadbasket and some bakeries prepare it with assorted toppings. Stale focaccia, sliced and toasted, becomes Genoa toast, a type of Italian melba toast.

title: R. F. Dolan to Wed Amanda Corroon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh L. Corroon of Greenville, Del., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Amanda Bassett Corroon, and Richard Francis Dolan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Dolan of Lakeville, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 17 about the financial difficulties of Australian news organizations misinterpreted a comment of Gerard Henderson, executive director of the Sydney Institute, a research group. Mr. Henderson was suggesting that Australia's two most influential media billionaires, Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, would be called "powerful mates" of the Government if foreigners were allowed to increase their media holdings; he did not make the criticism himself.

title: 3 Who Helped Execute the Air War
description: BRIG. GEN. BUSTER C. GLOSSON

title: Root of Pirates' Evils Is Hardly Surprising
description: "How can there be any tension coming off of a championship series on a club filled with players making millions of dollars?"

title: When Patients Don't Pay Doctors
description: I read a doctor's letter to the New Jersey editor on Feb. 3 with a mixture of astonishment and dismay. Can it really be, I asked myself, that nonpaying patients are working such a hardship on doctors that the latter need a publicly financed trust fund to continue?

title: Around the Garden
description: For this week: They crawl. They flit. And they multiply with a speed that both shocks and mystifies. Insects on house plants are now proliferating in these longer, brighter days. The safest control is a weekly upside-down dunking of leaves in a warm soapy water bath. Dishwashing liquids may suffice but, even better, use a product formulated for this purpose, like Safer Agro-Chem's insecticidal soap. Take time, however, to read the label before plunging in. The leaves of some palms, euphorbias and ferns can be burned by strong soaps and a dilute solution may be preferable along with an immediate clear-water rinse. Don't be embarrassed to throw any house plants that are beyond repair into the trash.

title:
MUSIC;
Herbert Film Score to Be Performed
description: THE Wayne Chamber Orchestra's Friday program of music written for film will include a premiere performance of the original Victor Herbert orchestration for a 1916 silent film, "The Fall of a Nation."

title: Is Your Sink Tired? Try a New Faucet
description: REPLACING old faucets not only can revive the looks of a tired bathroom sink, but also stop troublesome leaks.

title: Capital Games
description: President Bush's campaign to lower the capital-gains tax has clung to many rationales. The tax cut, its supporters have claimed, would lower the Federal deficit, spur investment and growth and energize venture capitalists. Yet all these ration-ales are unproven, and it's plain, even from the fine print of White House testimony, that many of these claims are wildly exaggerated.

title: Maria Eisner Lehfeldt, Photo Editor, 82
description: Maria Eisner Lehfeldt, a photo editor and agent who was a founder of the Magnum photo agency, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Egypt; Egyptians' Concerns Turn From War to Jobs and Economics
description: Apart from the usual din of car horns and tangled traffic, a calm of sorts has returned to Cairo University, the sprawling campus across the Nile where antiwar demonstrators battled the police just two weeks ago.

title: Not Afraid of White Folks Anymore
description: FREE AT LAST? The Civil Rights Movement and the People Who Made It.By Fred Powledge.Illustrated. 711 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Company.

title: The Prevalence of Expedient Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
An Ambitious New Breed of Cantonese
description: EXCEPT for an enormous new yellow sign and temple lions guarding the entrance, Phoenix Garden Too still looks like the truck stop it once was. As travelers whiz along Route 46 through the Bergen County borough of Ridgefield, they may not be aware that this former diner was taken over last November by the owners of Phoenix Garden, a highly rated Cantonese restaurant in Manhattan's Chinatown.

title: Are the Baymen an Anachronism?
description: I spent my vacation in the Montauk and Hampton area from Sept. 15 to Nov. 15, 1990, surf fishing. I saw only a few striped bass on the beach.

title: Where Cactus Is Par for the Course
description: EVEN at the airport, you know Phoenix is a serious place for golf. Golf bags are strewn over the floor in the baggage-claim section and their owners are discussing swings and putts before they reach the curb. The choice of Phoenix and its environs by golfers is logical because, with 109 private, public and resort courses, the region is one of the most densely populated golf centers in the world.

title: Suffolk Nears Decision On Historic Bridge
description: A TINY rural bridge supported by concrete pillars and barely high enough for a canoe to pass is creating a controversy in Bridgehampton and Sagaponack, the two communities it joined until it was closed.

title: Topics of the Times; Pay Cut
description: Public interest in Michael Milken, the king of junk bonds, has focused on how long a sentence he would be ordered to serve. Originally, it was 10 years, and the sentencing judge later recommended that he be paroled after three years. Now that he has begun serving his time, at the Federal Correctional Institution in Pleasanton, Calif., attention turns to another way of measuring the transformation of his life.

title: Phone Company Stays Tiny and Profitable
description: MOST people in Connecticut assume that Southern New England Telephone is the only phone company around. But those who live in three northwestern towns know different. Unlike nearly everybody else in the state, they are served by the Woodbury Telephone Company.

title: The Outback Is Burning
description: BURNING BUSH A Fire History of Australia. By Stephen J. Pyne. Illustrated. 520 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $27.95.

title: Ms. Horne to Wed Richard F. Doyle
description: May wedding plans for Kimberly Susan Horne and Richard Frederick Doyle have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. L. Donald Horne of New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Doyle is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Doyle of Sarasota, Fla.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Henefeld Ponders Different Times
description: Nadav Henefeld can look out the windows of his 15th floor apartment in Tel Aviv now. He did not stray very close to the rattling windows during the 43 days of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Style Makers; Hans Koch, Leather Designer
description: Hans Koch has a little shop in SoHo whose walls are a kaleidoscopic display of handbags, belts and jewelry that have become collectibles for a clientele who appreciate the unusual and the special.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: When one's own perceived physical faults become the litmus test for judging others.

title: Broadway's 'Cabaret' Comes to Bridgeport's Cabaret
description: SINCE its supply of home-grown revues cannot be limitlessly recycled, the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport, an original variation on dinner theaters, is now specializing in restaging popular musicals. Audiences are as willing to bring their own comestibles to a serious-minded show like "Cabaret" as to any edition of "Wop Bop a Loo Bop." And it's time "Cabaret" came to the Cabaret.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; U.S. SAID TO PLAN BOMBING OF IRAQIS IF THEY GAS REBELS
description: Bush Administration officials have drawn up plans to use air strikes against any Iraqi military unit that uses poison gas on rebels battling President Saddam Hussein, senior Administration officials said today.

title:
Hers;
As Old as You Drive
description: For me, 1991 is a climacteric. The reasons are so portentous that I prefer to express them in Roman numerals: The L reunion of my college graduating class, my XLV wedding anniversary and -- most alarming of all -- my LXX birthday. Let's contemplate these in order of occurrence:

title: Topics of the Times; High 'Crimes' in Kenya
description: Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi, has craftily exploited the world's preoccupation with Iraq to settle scores with citizens guilty of no greater crime than criticizing the Government. He has been engaged for weeks in a crackdown on critics of the one-party autocracy he instituted in 1982.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 10 Die in Factional Violence Near Johannesburg
description: Ten people were killed and at least 34 others were wounded today as factional fighting erupted in Alexandra, a black township of Johannesburg.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Angry Gay Groups Drown Out Rally By Conservatives
description: Conservative Awareness Week at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst backfired on student organizers last week when gay rights proponents outnumbered conservatives at their own events.

title: Lokar's Stance Draws Fire
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Taylor Lifts Pirates At Finish
description: There have been more talented, more successful basketball teams at Seton Hall University, including the group that two years ago came painfully close to a national championship.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Feb. 10 with an article about Taos, N.M., mislabeled a highway running east and west through Taos. It is U.S. 64, not Interstate 64.

title: Jaime K. Kelly To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Donald J. Mercer of Chatham, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jaime Kathleen Kelly, to James Alan Fairbrother, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Fairbrother of Chadds Ford, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Academic Honors
description: They may not all be leading candidates for the National Basketball Association draft, but one group of 30 college basketball players should have no trouble getting into graduate school. They have just been named to an academic all-America team by a vote of 1,500 college sports information directors.

title: Praised as a Deal-Maker; Faulted as Too Diplomatic
description: When Eric J. Schmertz joined the Dinkins administration early last year as chief labor negotiator, friends and critics alike praised his ability to cut a deal. In more than 30 years as a mediator and arbitrator, he had helped settle 8,000 labor disputes.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;
Redevelopment Of River Island
description: A $2.8 MILLION commercial building with office, research and light industrial space is rising on a neglected 42-acre island in the Allegheny River near downtown.

title: Stamps
description: There are a lot of collectors -- hoarders, really -- who accumulate modern stamps for the wrong reason: to make money.

title: Moscow Publishes New Plan of Union
description: Soviet newspapers today published a new draft of the federal treaty that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopes will be the cornerstone of a revived Union. But almost immediately, his political archfoe, Boris N. Yeltsin, delivered a fiery broadside against the treaty and Mr. Gorbachev.

title: The World; The Kuwaitis Who Stayed Have Some Scores to Settle
description: EVEN as Kuwaitis celebrated along the shoreline drive in the first blush of liberation last weekend -- dancing on top of their cars, clapping to the sound of Arab music -- there was, behind the euphoria, a burning anger in the eyes and the voices of those who had just emerged from what they all described as eight months of hell.

title: Japanese Sailor Is Dead
description: Yukoh Tada, the Japanese sailor who won his class in the first BOC Challenge race, apparently committed suicide Friday in Sydney, Australia, said an official for one of the teams in this year's race. He was 61 years old.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Thomas Lee Randleman's letter (Travel, Feb. 17) refers to the Sixth Arrondissement of Paris as the Marais district. The Sixth is on the left bank; the Marais is on the right bank, mostly in the Fourth Arrondissement. NAOMI GLASS Washington

title: Camper Travel
description: To the Editor: As veterans of four summer-long motor camping trips to Europe and Britain, we have advice to offer that is contrary to that given by Jay Axelbank in "Rooms With a View" (Travel, Dec. 16). The photographs taken at tourist sites with the big camper in the foreground look great, but they are really not necessary to enjoying a trip by camper. All large cities in Europe have campgrounds with all the amenities: Launderettes, hot showers, kitchens to cook in and wash up as well as water for the tank and a place to empty the chemical toilet and gray water. They are all convenient to public transportation and very safe.

title: Route From College to Career Keeps Getting Bumpier
description: AS a sophomore at the University of Connecticut, Steven Hopley began priming himself for success. With dreams of a stellar career in advertising or public relations, he said, he took on an internship at an advertising agency in Hartford without pay or college credit. He then served as the assistant to the university's director of public relations for two years, organizing the mailing of news releases and planning major events. Hoping to keep in touch with professionals in the field, Mr. Hopley said, he joined a statewide public relations association. All the while, he said, "I kept telling myself, 'This is going to pay off.' "

title: FREE VOTE IN BENIN ITS FIRST IN YEARS
description: A year after Benin cast aside its authoritarian one-party system, voters here will take another step on Sunday when they take part in the country's first free presidential election in nearly three decades.

title: Sure Sign of Spring: Dealers Flock to Wilton Antiques Show
description: AMONG many antiques shows that herald the passing of winter in New England, the one sponsored by the Wilton Historical Society has achieved an enviable reputation with dealers and collectors. Now in its 24th season, the event, scheduled for next Saturday and Sunday, began in 1967 as a casual outdoor fund-raising event, in the style of a flea market. Since 1985, when it first moved to the Wilton High School field house, the show has grown in size and distinction, attracting nearly 6,000 visitors during its two-day run. Its profits supply most of the annual operating budget for the historical society.

title: Designers Try to Fit The Price to the Times
description: When Mary Ann Restivo founded her business, her prices rarely topped $400, but little by little they rose, like everyone else's, with inflation. Now she has joined the ranks of designers and manufacturers forced to offer shoppers fashionable clothes at more reasonable prices.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We moved into a new house about six years ago and have always had a problem when someone uses the shower. If either hot or cold water is turned on in another part of the house while the shower is in use, the temperature of the shower water fluctuates wildly from too hot to too cold. Is there something that can be placed on the shower pipes to remedy this?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The "All About" column last Sunday, on the medical supply business, misstated 1990 sales of two privately held companies. The A. Stuart Company said its sales were $750 million in the calendar year 1990. The General Medical Corporation also had sales of $750 million, which brought total health-related revenues of its parent company, R.A.B. Holdings Inc., to $2.2 billion

title: Photographing Hepburn, Ever the Star
description: IN 36 years photographing the newsworthy from Ernest Hemingway and President John F. Kennedy to Nikita S. Khrushchev, there are some celebrities that John Bryson has liked less than others.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SINGING OF THE GREEN

title: The Empire Strikes Back
description: The Flying Scud is a 100-year-old pub on Hackney Road in East London, where Nazi air raids inflicted such suffering 50 years ago. Since the beginning of the war in the Persian Gulf, its owner, Graham Warden, has had the place decked out in Union Jack bunting, and he doesn't give a damn if brazen patriotism offends the Muslims from Bangladesh and Pakistan who have displaced most other people like him from the neighborhood.

title:
Your Own Account;
Buying Your Own Franchise
description: Like many executives today, James J. Oden took a look at his life -- a job as director of corporate accounting for Philip Morris in New York, a wife and two kids in New Canaan, Conn. -- and found his work and commute wanting. And like an increasing number of them, he devised a plan to get out of the corporate world and into his own business.

title: Melissa Boocock, a Teacher, to Wed
description: The engagement of Melissa Brett Boocock to John Angus Soderberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lars Olof Soderberg of Flemington, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roger Brett Boocock of Riverdale, the Bronx. A June wedding planned.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The "Mutual Funds: General Equity" table last Sunday carried month-old figures supplied inadvertently by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. A corrected version appears today on page 19.

title: Postings: Westport Church; Steeple on the Lawn
description: People don't often see a steeple sitting on the front lawn of a church, but lately this sight has become familiar to those passing the Saugatuck Congregational Church on Post Road East in Westport, Conn.

title: Baseball Notebook; He Missed Series, but He's Happy
description: Ron Robinson has a red beard on his face but no World Series ring on his finger. "I spent a lot of time there," he said of his six years with the Cincinnati Reds. "I wish I had been there. But" -- and it was a big but -- "I felt I wasn't treated right there and it was time to move on. Instead of fighting for a job there, I have a job here."

title: CRIME
description: What's a parent's worst nightmare when a child runs away from home? Gareth Sinclair, a private eye whose specialty in Teri White's THURSDAY'S CHILD (Mysterious Press/Warner, $18.95) is finding teen-age truants, says it's the fear that one's own flesh and blood might fall prey to "a terrible stranger." To someone, perhaps, like Robert Turchek, a contract killer who befriends Beau Epstein when that 15-year-old orphan walks out on his wealthy grandfather and lands on the mean streets of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Cari Kelly to Wed T. K. Grundman
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelly of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolynne Anne Kelly to Thomas Kenneth Grundman, a son of Bernice Passaretti of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Charles K. Grundman. A July wedding is planned.

title: Jill Lomove Engaged To Jonathan D. Katz
description: Dr. and Mrs. Barry Lomove of Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Lomove, to Jonathan David Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Katz of White Plains. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Bush's Bank Plan Leaves Consumers Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr; New Rules Lead Some Drinkers To Go Off Campus
description: "It's real name is Roach and O'Brien's but we all call it Roach's," said Giselle Delsol, a Bryn Mawr College senior.

title: SECRECY DEBATED IN FILES ON ABUSE
description: The Commissioner of New York City's Probation Department urged a State Senate panel last week to change a state law that denies her department access to information about child abuse cases in the files of the city's welfare agency.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. BETSY'S WEDDING -- Starring Molly Ringwald and Joe Pesci, among others, Alan Alda's sitcom of a movie "gathers a wonderful cast and gives them tepid characters." (Caryn James) 1990. Touchstone. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.99. 1 hour, 34 minutes. Closed captioned. R. CINEMA PARADISO -- Encouraged by the projectionist in the village theater, a boy grows up with a love of the movies, only to become a jaded director. "I'd rather watch a dozen reruns of 'Diff'rent Strokes.' Not so much magic, and the pretensions are fewer." (Vincent Canby) 1989. HBO. $89.99 dubbed; $92.99 subtitled. 2:23 CC. No rating. DARKMAN -- A disfigured scientist sheathes himself in synthetic skin to battle evil in Sam Raimi's thriller, which "sustains mild interest but never takes off." (James) 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. LD, $34.98. 1:35. CC. R. DAYS OF THUNDER -- As the stock-car driver Cole Trickle, Tom Cruise leads the boys-will-be-boys horseplay, accompanied by "enough upbeat soundtrack music to generate toe-tapping in the dead." (Janet Maslin) 1990. Paramount. $91.95. LD, $34.95. 1:47. CC. PG-13. DIE HARD 2 -- High-tech sophistication and unbridled firepower are a match for the original "Die Hard," and "Bruce Willis is even better." (Maslin) 1990. CBS/Fox. $94.98. 2:04. CC. R. FLATLINERS -- To experience the afterlife, medical students temporarily shut down vital bodily functions. The director Joel Schumacher has created a "stylish, eerie psychological horror film that thrives on its characters' guilty secrets." (James) 1990. RCA/Columbia. $91.95. LD, $34.95. 1:51. CC. R. THE FRESHMAN -- A mob patriarch (Marlon Brando) helps out a film student (Matthew Broderick) in Andrew Bergman's "witty and enchanted comedy." (Maslin) 1990. RCA/Columbia. No suggested retail price. CC. PG. MO' BETTER BLUES -- Spike Lee's film about a jazz musician is unhappily "more Hollywood than Spike Lee." (James) 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. LD, $39.98. 2:09. CC. R. STATE OF GRACE -- As a hot-wired Irish hood, Gary Oldman proves it "possible to be in a wide-open space and still bounce off the walls." (Maslin) 1990. Orion. $94.98. 2:14. CC. R. THE TWO JAKES -- Jack Nicholson's sequel to "Chinatown" starts off with style and finishes as an "enjoyable if clunky movie." (Canby) 1990. Paramount. $91.95. LD, $39.95. 2:17. CC. R. THE WITCHES -- Nine-year-old Luke gets turned into a mouse after he and his grandmother stumble on a witches' convention. Nicolas Roeg's film is a "brilliantly told bedtime story." (James) 1990. Warner. $92.95. LD, $24.98. 1:32. CC. PG.

title:
Piscataway Journal;
Historic Preservation Divides an Old Town
description: FOUNDED in 1666, this township enjoys a rich heritage of historic houses and sites, many dating to before the Revolutionary War. But owners of historic homes here are finding the road to preservation a long and bumpy ride.

title: Adding Nutrients to Enhance the Soil
description: ALTHOUGH new life is just beginning to stir above ground, there is much activity underground. Wise are those gardeners who take advantage of this and supply fertilizer. Just a handful of a well-balanced general garden fertilizer, 5-10-5 or 6-12-6, is sufficient.

title: Travel Advisory; Five Hotels In London Halve Rates
description: Five hotels in central London, trying to win back Americans deterred by a weaker dollar and the Gulf war, are giving the dollar parity with the pound. A room at the Royal Lancaster Hotel in the Hyde Park section, for example, previously quoted at $:160 -- about $320 at recent exchange rates -- can be had for $160. The other hotels are the Athenaeum in Mayfair; the Gloucester, Kensington; Royal Garden, Hyde Park, and White House, Regent's Park. All five are members of the Rank Hotels group.

title: Suzanne Welch and Scott Carpenter Are Engaged
description: May wedding plans for Suzanne Marshall Welch and Scott Raymond Carpenter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence E. Carpenter of Short Hills, N.J., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Welch of Wyomissing, Pa.

title: Camera
description: To judge from the current crop of 35-millimeter single-lens-reflex cameras, you would think that the issue of automatic exposure was pretty much settled. Most top-of-the-line SLR's now offer one version or another of "intelligent" multiple-area metering, in which the camera's computer determines how to bias the exposure in difficult lighting situations.

title: College Hockey; Maine Has an Unlikely Hero
description: Don McKenney, the Northeastern coach, left an epitaph for his team and a reminder about college hockey tournaments: In a one-game elimination tournament, the least likely scenario may prevail and always beware the obscure player.

title: Thailand
description: To the Editor: We left for Bangkok on Dec. 23, the same day as your "What's Doing in Bangkok" appeared and did not get to read it until we returned. I would like to add a couple of items:

title: Review/Theater; Ibsen Allegory on Suffering for Art
description: It is always something of a surprise to encounter the very early or the very late plays of Ibsen, in which the master of naturalism took flight to realms of symbolism and romantic fancy. In these works Ibsen indulged the poet he always insisted he was and turned his attention away from the problems of the individual as a member of society to focus on the inner struggles of the soul, always a difficult task for actors to portray.

title: Anne Sarah Greenberg Has Wedding
description: Anne Sarah Greenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Gregg Todd Michaelson, the son of Rita Michaelson of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club.

title: Currency; Strong Rally For Dollar
Tunica Journal; The Shacks Disappear, but the Poverty Lives On
description: The story of Sugar Ditch, America's most famous sewer, came to a quiet close recently when the families of 11 black tenants vacated the last of the shacks beside it.

title: Mutual Funds; Morningstar's Five Hidden Winners
description: How do small funds grow to be giants? Superior salesmanship is a major factor. So is top-notch performance. But a good track record alone sometimes won't do the trick. With more than 3,000 funds vying for investors' attention, some are simply lost in the crowd.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LATECOMERS Children of Parents Over 35. By Andrew L. Yarrow. The Free Press, $19.95.

title: Style Makers; Bill Simpson, Gourd Engraver
description: "You can't see quality in something that's mass-produced," said Bill Simpson, who prefers to take his time at his craft. Mr. Simpson, 39 years old, engraves and decorates gourds in his studio at 84 Lafayette Street in Brooklyn.

title: Commercial Property: Westchester Waterfront; As Industry Fades, a Melange Grows in Its Place
description: FOR the last 20 years, the industrial waterfront north of Yonkers along the Hudson River in Westchester County has been basically out of business. Burnt-out shells of factories clutter the shoreline and outdated industrial zoning has prevented new kinds of development.

title: Suburbanizing the Stars
description: During the 1950's, as Edward R. Murrow guided television audiences through the all-electric kitchens of Hollywood celebrities (and Senator Joseph McCarthy searched for Communists under every bed), Sid Avery suburbanized stardom for readers of The Saturday Evening Post. In HOLLYWOOD AT HOME: A Family Album, 1950-1965 (Crown, $30), a collection of deglamorizing black-and-white publicity photographs, Marlon Brando is seen taking out the garbage; Jimmy Durante and Rossano Brazzi chat over a back fence; dating couples assemble for a barbecue on Rock Hudson's patio; Frankie Laine drives off to work with a wave to his wife and the kids by the white picket fence. In his introductory essay, Richard Schickel, Time magazine's film critic, explains these mime shows of 50's fun as an awkward attempt by the beleaguered entertainment industry to strike a normal pose. Yet Mr. Avery's glossies inadvertently suggest something very weird. With television sets absent from every frame, the point of view of the camera often seems to be from inside a set peering out, as if television were a kind of magic window into people's homes. Perhaps the couch potatoes of yesteryear found the mirror image of their own paneled walls and plaid upholstery reassuring, but few who look at these pictures today will yearn for a bygone America that loved nothing so much as conformity.

title: Social Events
description: The Glimmerglass Opera

title: Gooden Is Happy to Be Feeling the Heat Again
description: The day is not far off when one or more other pitches will have to be mastered, when the tactical approach to pitching will have to be rethought and redesigned, enhanced by intelligence and humility.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Feb. 10 with an article about the plantation houses of Louisiana mislabeled part of an east-west highway between Baton Rouge and the Mississippi. It is Interstate 10, not 70.

title: Reliving Days Of Knick Glory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Monitor of Greens
description: The commissioner of the PGA Tour has taken steps to remove some of the pressure on the tour's multimillion-member rules committee.

title: Columbus
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the summary of Columbus Quincentenary events set for 1992 (Q & A, Dec. 16). Travelers should be aware, however, that the 500th anniversary of the discovery of America is not regarded as an event to celebrate by many native Americans, African- Americans and others.

title: An Exception to Rule of War: Inflation Threat Is Receding
description: From the Revolution to Vietnam, virtually every American war has sparked a round of inflation. But the Persian Gulf war looks as if it will be an exception. A barrage of signals -- including cheaper oil and raw materials, softer prices at factories, swelling cattle herds and shrinking bonuses for sales workers -- suggests that inflation may retreat.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Hoyas Advance Behind Defense
description: Georgetown, the Big East's sixth-seeded team and a squad some doubted would even be invited to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this year, earned a berth in the Big East tournament championship game yesterday by turning in a classic defensive performance.

title: Linda P. Gall To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Linda Patricia Gall and Gerard Ferrer Joyce Jr., a son of Maureen Joyce of Port Washington, L.I., and Mr. Joyce of Greenwich, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Gall of Garden City, L.I.

title: Mets Must Keep Gooden and Viola
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Pops Mine a Popular Vein
description: Cincinnati is not Boston. But when it comes to a pops orchestra, the Cincinnati Pops under the conductor Erich Kunzel is giving the venerable Boston Pops a run for its recording money. For both, traditional classical "bonbon" programming seems to be giving way to more popular fare.

title: Thrilled by Flowers And the Beach Boys
description: Dinner with celebrities and a wardrobe by top New York designers were a few of the 40 lots auctioned off Monday at Sotheby's cocktail party. The event raised nearly $300,000 for the Manhattan Center for Living, a group that gives help to anyone with a life-challenging illness.

title: 3 Unions at The News Would Bear Brunt of Job Cuts, Leaders Say
description: As talks on the fate of The Daily News continued last night, union leaders negotiating with Robert Maxwell said that almost 700 of the 800 jobs the British publisher wants to eliminate would be from three large unions, the pressmen, the drivers and the Newspaper Guild.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;
176,000 Sq. Ft., Old and New
description: AN unusual $55 million development project combining new construction and renovation of older buildings has been completed off Pennsylvania Avenue midway between the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Someone Must Have a Plan
description: THE END OF LAISSEZ-FAIRE National Purpose and the Global Economy After the Cold War. By Robert Kuttner. 304 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Campus Life: Temple; Rift on Campus As a Cancer Lab Finds a New Home
description: A bitter tug of war is being waged between Temple University and faculty members of its Fels Cancer Research Institute, who have announced plans to move to Thomas Jefferson University.

title: In One Berlin Store, Food Without End
description: EVEN a casual visit to the sixth-floor food bazaar at KaDeWe, Berlin's toniest department store, demands planning. With 30,000 items spread over more than an acre, any lack of strategy can lead straight to utter bewilderment.

title: Queen Victoria's Computers
description: THE DIFFERENCE ENGINE By William Gibson and Bruce Sterling. 429 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: R. J. Forehand 2d to Wed Ann Zegras
description: The engagement of Ann Marie Zegras to Raymond Jones Forehand 2d, a son of Mrs. Jack M. Forehand of Savannah, Ga., and the late Mr. Forehand, has been announced by her parents, Antonia S. Zegras and Peter S. Zegras, both of Westport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Power Skating
description: You don't have to know much about figure skating to know that something special is happening when Midori Ito executes a triple Axel. Skimming -- sprinting -- across the rink at 20 miles an hour, she pushes off with her left foot, leaps clear of the ice, spins three and a half times in midair and lands on her right foot, skating backward. The crowds roar. Rival coaches shake their heads. The triple Axel, named after Axel Paulsen, a Norwegian skater from the early 1900's, is one of the most difficult jumps rated by the International Skating Union. In 1988 Ito became the first woman to perform it successfully in international competition.

title:
FOCUS;
First in 40 Years: A New Northern California S.R.O.
description: Construction financing was gained last week for a 198-unit single-room-occupancy hotel that will rise at the edge of this city's downtown. It will be the first such hotel built in northern California in more than 40 years.

title: Taking the A Line to Functional Fashion
description: Anne Klein's new baby is a bouncing collection of weekend wear that rates as high for function as it does for fashion. Called the A Line, it includes exercise leotards, jeans, parkas, sweaters, blazers, stirrup pants, leather jackets and fake fur coats. And that's not all. Add on microfiber fishing vests, Gortex ski jackets, metalic leathers, sequins, hats, bags, gloves and jewelry, and you come up with one of the most extensive sportswear lines ever introduced.

title: 'Somebody the Sailor'
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston 465,000 5 Devonshire Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-half bath, 25-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, den, eat-in-kitchen, central air-conditioning; taxes $6,492. Maplewood 223,000 88 Jefferson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-half bath, 35-year-old colonial; porch, fireplace, 2-car garage, h/w floors; taxes $5,110. Millburn 339,000 59 Mountain Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 86-year-old Victorian; screened porch, library, 2-car garage, greenhouse; taxes $6,696. South Orange 385,000 57 Mayhew Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, 2-car garage, central air-conditioning; taxes $7,761. Springfield 225,000 103 Wentz Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; central air-conditioning, 2-car garage, full basement; taxes $4,392. West Orange 130,000 2 Caldwell Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 2-half bath, 52-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, den; taxes $3,122. OTHER AREAS Wallingford, Conn. 122,500 19 Cheryl Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; central air-conditioning, eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,270. Scarsdale, N.Y. 432,800 136 Brewster Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old English stucco; fireplace, library, eat-in kitchen, 2 patios; taxes $8,059. Westbury, L.I. 129,000 168 Cypress Lane West 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, central air-conditioning, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: Miracle Of Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: King of New York 1990. LIVE. $89.95. 1 hour, 46 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Christopher Walken makes a chilling drug kingpin in Abel Ferrara's lurid, high-voltage drama. Mr. Ferrara "still works unapologetically in B-movie territory, but does it with A-movie style." Mr. Walken "does a memorable job of taking a fanciful projection of corruption, giving it intelligence and making it flesh and blood." (Janet Maslin)

title: MAN IS CONVICTED IN QUEENS KILLING
description: A 22-year-old Coney Island man was convicted on Friday of killing a prominent Russian cardiologist as he came to the aid of his wife during a robbery on a quiet street in Queens last summer.

title: How to Write A Play Like August Wilson
description: This article is adapted from a talk by August Wilson at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y in Manhattan earlier this year, during which the playwright answered questions about how he works. Mr. Wilson, who is 45 years old and was born in Pittsburgh, has had nine plays produced. His work has won a Tony Award and two Pulitzer Prizes.

title: Lois Ann Fitton Engaged
description: Marjorie Fitton of Lawrenceville, N.J., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter Lois Ann Fitton and William Christopher Draper Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Draper of Basking Ridge, N.J. Miss Fitton, 31 years old, is also a daughter of the late John N. Fitton. She is a senior business planning analyst in New York with the Pfizer Hospital Products Group. A graduate of the University of Virginia, she received an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Draper, 33, is a senior manager in New York with Andersen Consulting, a division of Arthur Andersen & Company. He graduated from the University of North Carolina and received an M.B.A. from the University of Georgia.

title: Arid West Girds for Perilous Fire Season
description: With drought-stricken trees standing ready to flash like torches across a vast area of the American West, fire officials are bracing for what may be the worst fires they have ever fought.

title: Review/Music; Hogwood and St. Paul Chamber Orchestra
description: Under an arrangement that has prevailed since 1987, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra has been ruled by a triumvirate rather than by a single conductor. Within this division of power, Christopher Hogwood's title is director of music, Hugh Wolff is the principal conductor, and the composer John Harbison has succeeded John Adams in what the orchestra calls its creative chair.

title: Panel Asks Stiffer Preparation for CUNY Students
description: A faculty panel has recommended that students entering the City University of New York complete a set of college preparatory courses as tough as those New York State requires for its best high-school graduates.

title: Jill Olk Wed to R. C. Platt
description: Jill Kathleen Olk, a daughter of Mrs. Judith Olk of Wilmette, Ill., and the late Thomas Olk, was married in New York yesterday to Russell Christopher Platt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Platt of Chattanooga, Tenn. The Rev. Francis Fajella performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mrs. Platt, 24 years old, graduated from the University of Michigan and is studying fine and decorative arts at Sotheby's in London. Mr. Platt, 30, graduated from Williams College and received an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School. He is a vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company in London.

title: Return of a Shula
description: After three years as an assistant coach with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Mike Shula, the 25-year-old son of the Miami Dolphins' coach, Don Shula, has joined his father's staff. . . . Chris Evert, the 36-year-old former tennis star, and her husband, Andy Mill, a former Olympic skier, say they are expecting their first child in October. (AP)

title: A (Mostly) Italian Menu, Short and Sweet
description: IT would be difficult to envision a restaurant, other than a short-order luncheonette, in more restricted space than Bluewater Cafe in New Canaan. Further, the cafe has turned a negative into a positive, making its limited space inviting through the use of mirrors and serene paintings on sky-blue flecked white walls, soft lights, glass-topped tables, fresh flowers, candlelight and natural-wood chairs. In short, everything looks new, simple and crisply attractive.

title: Chess
description: It is intimidating to have to struggle over the moves of a tortuous position while your opponent skips along as though the solutions were a foregone conclusion. The truth is that several world champions have been extraordinarily quick players -- so much was so easy for a Paul Morphy, a Jose Raoul Capablanca, a Bobby Fischer.

title: Resurgence of Measles Is Reported in County
description: IN five years of medical training and four years of practice in infectious diseases, Dr. Daniel S. Berman has treated maladies from malaria and Lyme disease to AIDS.

title: Business Diary/March 3-8; By Allen R. Myerson
description: THE ECONOMY A Tough Guy Taking Over at the World Bank

title: About Long Island; It's All in the Family
description: TERMS of endearment often disappear when the boss is Dad. As soon as Irene and Biene Schaefer joined their father, Fritz, in the family business, Landscape by Atlantic Nurseries in Dix Hills, he asked that at work they call him by his first name.

title: English Pianist Wins A $250,000 Award
description: David Owen Norris of Petworth, England, has been named the first Gilmore Artist by the Irving S. Gilmore International Keyboard Festival in Kalamazoo, Mich. Mr. Norris will receive approximately $250,000 in stipends and engagements over the next few years, including some 60 concerts with major orchestras in the United States, Hungary, Belgium, France and Scotland. The award also provides him with artistic management and publicity.

title: Forget Posts a Memorable Victory Over Edberg
description: Three months ago he shaved his head on a dare, fulfilling a childhood wish to look a little more like his dad. Last month he captured his second singles title of 1991 and transcended his ranking, which improved from a career best of 16 to a career better of 5th in the world. Lately, Guy Forget has been steadily shedding his anonymity, too.

title: Streetscapes: The Apthorp; With Shop Signs Muted, The Grandeur Is Evident
description: WHAT'S new and different about the Apthorp apartments at 79th Street and Broadway? Nothing. What's noteworthy about the grand limestone building is, in fact, old and different -- a matter not of addition, but of subtraction -- as a promiscuous palette of large, garish store signs has gradually been removed from the building's Broadway frontage.

title: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'s; A Long Mental Voyage Back for Those Captured in War
description: For the American troops who were prisoners of war in the Persian Gulf, simply coming home to jubilant families will almost certainly not be enough to overcome their weeks-long immersion in fear, say military doctors who will treat their damaged psyches.

title:
THEATER;
How to Write A Play Like August Wilson
description: This article is adapted from a talk by August Wilson at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y in Manhattan earlier this year, during which the playwright answered questions about how he works. Mr. Wilson, who is 45 years old and was born in Pittsburgh, has had nine plays produced. His work has won a Tony Award and two Pulitzer Prizes.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; A Norwalk Developer Builds in Russia
description: NOLAN KERSCHNER, a Norwalk developer who has built more than 3,000 houses and condominium units in Connecticut since 1947, is now completing site work on his 528-unit Rosinka development in suburban Moscow.

title: Stephanie Losee, Reporter, to Marry
description: Steven T. Losee of Boca Grande, Fla., and Mrs. Robert L. Ferris of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Kip Losee to Thomas Alan Unger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Unger of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: Super Bowl Offer for Fans in Boston
description: Minutes before the Buffalo Bills missed a game-winning field goal attempt that enabled the Giants to win the Super Bowl this year, a power blackout in several northern Boston suburbs left viewers in the dark.

title: Animal Rescuers Set Sights on Mideast
description: NOW that the fighting in the Persian Gulf seems to be over, an animal-rescue group in Connecticut is hoping to help in the rescue of birds and animals on the gulf's shores.

title: THE STATE OF THE GOVERNOR
description: As a former New Yorker, I have followed the career of Mario Cuomo with great interest. He remains an enigma to many political observers, as Elizabeth Kolbert points out in her article "The State of the Governor" (Feb. 10). But perhaps they (and she) are too close. Time and distance do wonders for perspective.

title: Staying Power
description: ONE OF USRichard Nixon and the American Dream.By Tom Wicker.731 pp. New York:Random House. $24.95.

title: Plodding Economic Cleanup Efforts Cost Greece in Credit and Credibility
description: Elected last year with a mandate to put Greece's house in order, Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis still seems overwhelmed by the legacy of almost a decade of chaotic Socialist rule that turned this country into the poorest member of the 12-nation European Community.

title: INSIDE
description: Violence in Yugoslavia Two people were killed and dozens injured when Serbian protesters seeking the ouster of their region's hardline leader clashed with police and army units in Belgrade. Page 3.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram 124,000 23 Selway Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, family room, fireplace; taxes $3,400. Kings Park 213,000 6 Willow Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $5,200. Levittown 140,000 10 Grassy Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. Mineola 175,000 272 Evelyn Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 1-car garage, brick and aluminum siding; taxes $3,200. Sayville 160,000 265 Astor Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old Dutch colonial; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,500. Westbury 129,000 168 Cypress Lane West 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, c/a, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. OTHER AREAS Wallingford, Conn. 122,500 19 Cheryl Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; c/a, eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, 0.25 acre; taxes $1270. Scarsdale, N.Y. 432,800 136 Brewster Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old English stucco; fireplace, library, eat-in kitchen, 2 patios; taxes $8,059. West Orange, N.J. 130,000 2 Caldwell Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 2-half bath, 52-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, eat-in-kitchen, den; taxes $3,122.

title: Trudy Larson Is Engaged
description: A September wedding is planned for Trudy E. Larson, the daughter of Mary P. Larson of Stowe, Vt., and Jordan E. Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart I. Greenberg of Dix Hills, L.I. Miss Larson, 24 years old, and her fiance, 22, graduated from the University of Vermont. Mr. Greenberg is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Rutgers University.

title: Charm and Concrete in Bratislava
description: AS I step inside the lemon yellow 13th-century Franciscan church, the oldest preserved building in the jewel-like old center of Bratislava, I am greeted with music.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 10, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve their marital and romantic problems. 2 2 7 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 3 3 4 FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) When she establishes a newspaper in Dakota Territory, a young woman finds familial problems and love. 4 7 5 MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) The romantic and professional lives of a homicide detective become entangled as he investigates a murder in the Hamptons. 5 4 9 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 6 5 21 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age. 7 6 4 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury finds himself a suspect in the strange death of a widow from England's Lake District. 8 8 7 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of marines from Midway to Guadalcanal. 9 9 12 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. 10 5 MIDDLE PASSAGE, by Charles Johnson. (Atheneum, $17.95.) A newly liberated slave learns about himself and the world during a voyage to Africa in the early 19th century. 11 11 7 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia. 12 12 14 JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician uses genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park. 13 * 52 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 14 * 10 9 THE FOURTH K, by Mario Puzo. (Random House, $22.) The tumultuous career of President Francis Xavier Kennedy, cousin of John and Robert. 15 13 18 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 16 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 2 9 4 AND THE SEA WILL TELL, by Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. (Norton, $22.95.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a Pacific atoll. 3 2 6 THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present. 4 4 17 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The recollections of the itinerant television newscaster. 5 5 24 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House. 6 7 31 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 7 6 7 PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor. 8 3 22 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 9 8 8 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish and Muslim children. 10 1 THE NEXT CENTURY, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $16.95.) A journalist's assessment of the prospects for various countries, judged by the temperament of their inhabitants. 11 12 4 THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY NO, by Shintaro Ishihara. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A Japanese politician contends his homeland will surpass the United States and become "first among equals." 12 1 IN OUR DEFENSE, by Ellen Alderman and Caroline Kennedy. (Morrow, $22.95.) How the Bill of Rights affects Americans' lives today. 13 10 8 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 14 17 20 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. 15 16 17 POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 30 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 2 1 14 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about managing your money. 3 19 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a hitchhiker named Waldo. 4 3 14 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 5 4 101 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.)
