Financial advice. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND

title: JERSEYANA
description: IN the early 1920's, young women in Essex County began showing up in the offices of doctors and dentists with such problems as aching bones, ulcers of the gum, tooth loss, anemia, pneumonia and angina. The most common condition was "jaw rot," the painful decay of bone and tissue in the mouth.

title: Eroica C. Racelis to Be Wed to Tracy Williams 3d
description: Eroica Colmenares Racelis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caesar M. Racelis of Manila, and Tracy Evans Williams 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Augusta, Ga., plan to marry in May.

title: Nancy Miner Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Miner of Westfield, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Miner and Michael Eugene Marciniak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Marciniak of Homewood, Ill. Miss Miner, 27 years old, is a financial consultant for Shearson Lehman Brothers in Sarasota, Fla. She graduated cum laude from the University of Vermont. Mr. Marciniak, 33, manages the Shearson Lehman Brothers office in Sarasota. He graduated cum laude from Northern Illinois University and received a master's degree from its business school. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Miller Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Amy Borrus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Borrus of Princeton, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Borrus and Richard M. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Untrivial Pursuits
description: A recent article in The New York Times Magazine indicated that educated Americans are ignorant of basic scientific facts -- for example, why the temperature varies between summer and winter. But are they any better informed about demographic and economic facts that are important to being a responsible citizen?Test yourself.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: Reading the road signs to reach Koyasan in Japan was not as much of a problem as suggested in the Dec. 2 letter of Brann and Ellen Wry. Our main objection was that this 45-mile drive took us five and a half hours one way on a Saturday afternoon and six and a half hours the other way on a Wednesday despite beginning our journey at 5:30 A.M. The traffic was bumper to bumper for most of the trip, and the headache from the diesel fumes took two days to resolve. Our stay in the Tentokuin Temple, however, was the most enjoyable three days we spent in Japan. YOANNA SKROBIK Montreal

title: Corrections
description: A map and chart last Sunday with an article about the growth of population and jobs in communities in the outer ring of the New York metropolitan area omitted identities of the data sources. The population figures were from the Census Bureau; the job figures were from the Regional Plan Association.

title: Anne S. Tobian To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Louis Tobian Jr. of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Simpson Tobian, to Arnold David Berman, a son of Alan N. Berman of Philadelphia and Mrs. Dee F. Shacter of Willingboro, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Bridge
description: The extent to which foreign players were welcomed in American Contract Bridge League Championships used to be a sensitive point. Since the major team championships are a steppingstone on the way to the selection of the American teams for world championships, some thought that these events should be restricted to eligible United States players. For many years there was such a rule, introduced by the late Lew Mathe, who disliked the thought of having to face European players in the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams and similar events.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We moved into a new house about six years ago and have always had a problem when someone uses the shower. If either hot or cold water is turned on in another part of the house while the shower is in use, the temperature of the shower water fluctuates wildly from too hot to too cold. Is there something that can be placed on the shower pipes to remedy this?

title: Residents' Attitudes In Ocean Grove
description: Re: Ocean Grove Journal, "Town Seeking Limits on Rooming Houses" (Feb. 3):

title: Travel Advisory; Diverted Ships Head to Canada
description: New England and eastern Canada will benefit from the decision of some cruise lines to shift ships from the Mediterranean this summer as a result of the Persian Gulf war. Seabourn Cruise Line is replacing its 1991 Mediterranean itineraries with sailings in Quebec and the Atlantic Provinces, which have been largely unexplored by cruise ships, and visits along the coasts of Massachusetts and Maine. The 7- and 14-day trips will be on the 204-passenger Seabourn Pride from May through August and depart from Boston; Montreal, and Halifax, Nova Scotia. The line says that, because of its design, the 10,000-ton vessel will be able to reach straits, waterways and harbors closed to most ships of its size.

title:
The Executive Life;
Where the Baseline Beats the Bottom Line
description: "Did you hear that?" squealed a horrified Suzanne Jenney, an assistant corporate secretary at RJR Nabisco, to a co-worker. "They say Colgate-Palmolive has been having tryouts and kicking people off the team!"

title: World Markets; Searching for the Dollar's Top
description: Since the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, the consensus view on the dollar has reversed quickly. And the change could significantly effect Americans who invest abroad.

title: A Financial Giant's Slippery Slope
description: The Tokyo stock market is finally recovering from a vicious year-long plunge, Wall Street is showing signs of a rejuvenation and, most important, financial systems around the globe are being deregulated. It would seem to be a time of fresh opportunity, yet Yoshihisa Tabuchi, the most powerful individual in Japan's financial markets, speaks like a troubled man.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; In Growing Disarray, Iraqis Fight Iraqis
description: Republican Guard soldiers, their green uniforms dirty and torn, crouched near a cement wall in a small mud-and-wattle village and warily viewed the rooftops above.

title: Suzanne Schwartz, Theater Producer, Marries Colin Davidson, a Publisher
description: Suzanne J. Schwartz, a theater producer, and Colin M. Davidson, a group publisher at Crain Communications in New York, were married last evening at a 19th-century costume ball at the Burden Mansion in New York. Acting Justice Franklin R. Weissberg of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a judge of the State Court of Claims, officiated.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: New Fairfield
description: WITH 40 miles of lakefront, the Town of New Fairfield in western Connecticut is a beacon for boaters. They come from all over the state, from Westchester and from New York City. But in the early part of the century, they would have had little reason to come here.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Captives; 40 Journalists and 2 G.I.'s Go Free After Week's Ordeal
description: About 40 foreign journalists and 2 American soldiers held in Iraq for nearly a week arrived here today in a Red Cross caravan after their release on Friday by the authorities in Baghdad.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Kuwaiti Leaders Tell Baker Democratization Is Coming
description: The rulers of Kuwait told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that they intended to democratize their country in the near future, but added that until the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, is ousted, there will never be peace or stability in the Persian Gulf.

title: Susan Kohm to Marry Philip Nimtz
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kohm of Haworth, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Kohm, to Philip Nimtz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nimtz of Madison, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Nearest Airport Isn't Always the Best Choice
description: WHEN you are stuck in traffic driving to the airport, or hung up in the sky circling, think about avoiding such messes by using another airport the next time.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We moved into a new house about six years ago and have always had a problem when someone uses the shower. If either hot or cold water is turned on in another part of the house while the shower is in use, the temperature of the shower water fluctuates wildly from too hot to too cold. Is there something that can be placed on the shower pipes to remedy this?

title: Are the Baymen an Anachronism?
description: The article states that the debate with the state began when hundreds of dead fish washed up on the beach.

title: Technology; The U.S. Rekindles a Dream for Space
description: It will bear little resemblance to the so-called Orient Express, the dreamed-of passenger space-plane once touted by President Reagan as a possible vehicle for making hypersonic flights between New York and Tokyo in just a few hours. But the Government is slowly zeroing in on the design for an experimental space-plane that would be able to take off and land on conventional runways and roar into orbit at 25 times the speed of sound.

title: Despite Grumbles, The Royal Ballet Is Revitalized
description: The Royal Ballet is a troupe much changed since its last American visit, in 1983 -- as will be evident to audiences at the Kennedy Center in Washington, when the company performs there for 10 days beginning Tuesday.

title: Auto Insurance: Legal Wrangling
description: A LEGAL dispute between three major insurance companies and the State Department of Insurance has stalled a critical part of Gov. Jim Florio's Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act, which swept through the Legislature last year.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ST. PATRICK'S EVENTS

title: Mattingly's Clockwork Routine
description: The alarm clock rings at 6:30 every morning, and Don Mattingly's workday begins.

title: College Basketball: Conference Tournaments; Carlesimo Learns Whom to Count On
description: In two days, Oliver Taylor has accomplished three amazing feats. Twice, he has hit the game-winning basket in the waning seconds to advance Seton Hall in the Big East Conference tournament. And he has raised the I.Q. of P. J. Carlesimo, the Seton Hall coach.

title: Cracow Sonata
description: TAKING THE HEAT By Eugenia Zukerman. 301 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Harvard Panel Narrows Its Search for President
description: The committee to select a successor to Harvard University's president, Derek C. Bok, has narrowed its search to four or five finalists, but with its self-imposed deadline approaching at the end of this month, the committee is still seriously divided, university officials say.

title: Good Minimalism, Bad Baroque
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 South Carolina Legislators Guilty of Corruption
description: In the second trial to result from a Federal investigation of Statehouse corruption here, a jury deliberated only 90 minutes on Friday before convicting two lawmakers of selling their votes.

title: Abundant Platters of Greek Dishes
description: EVERY Long Island town should have a comfortable storefront restaurant where friends can share a Greek salad at lunch and families can enjoy an affordable dinner that is more than a hamburger or slice of pizza.

title: The Great Encourager
description: FORD MADOX FORD By Alan Judd. Illustrated. 476 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $27.50.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington;
176,000 Sq. Ft., Old and New
description: AN unusual $55 million development project combining new construction and renovation of older buildings has been completed off Pennsylvania Avenue midway between the White House and Capitol Hill.

title: Wages of War: A Dearth Of Capital
description: The war is won. Now the world will get to pay for it. One cost may be higher interest rates.

title: Salvador Chief Sees Better Chance for Peace
description: President Alfredo Cristiani says the guerrillas who have fought the Salvadoran military for more than a decade may be experiencing a change in attitude that could "permit a peace accord in the shortest possible time."

title: Carew Joins Indians
description: As the manager of a team that won only 77 games last season, John McNamara of the Cleveland Indians has been on the lookout for some extra offensive punch this year. Now he thinks he has just the man to provide it: Rod Carew.

title: Tax Athletes To Help Budget
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Students and Teachers Join in Annual Festival
description: THE music schools of Westchester are proud of their work in offering the joys of performance to youngsters from every part of the county, and this week several of them are presenting student and faculty artists in a variety of concert activities.

title: Caroline Howard to Wed
description: Lawrence Howard of Hillsborough, N.J., and Rita Howard of Cedarhurst, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Caroline Lisa Howard and Timothy Swann McDarrah, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. McDarrah of New York.

title: Talking: Renting; Bargaining Chips for a New Tenant
description: IN the old days, it was extremely difficult to persuade a landlord to make improvements in a rental unit. So most people automatically assumed they had to take the home in the condition in which it was shown. No longer.

title: Davis Cup: Help Wanted
description: The United States Davis Cup Team, scheduled to begin defense of its 1990 championship in less than three weeks, does not yet exist, and Tom Gorman, the captain, has spent the last week scouring the field of the Newsweek Champions Cup for recruits. But little that has happened here has calmed his nerves.

title: Hard Days for Sports in Eastern Europe
description: Lia Manoliu, the president of Romania's national Olympic committee, arrived in London last week for two days of meetings with other European Olympic officials. Then, she was scheduled to return home. What she really wanted to do was come here to Seville first and watch a day or two of the world indoor track and field championships. Romania has a small team competing, and track and field, after all, remains her first love. She was the Olympic discus bronze medalist in 1960 and 1964.

title: Corrections
description: A Streetscapes column on Feb. 17 about the Miller Highway misspelled the name of the engineer who designed its viaduct. He was J.W. Phau.

title: Arlington Open to War Dead
description: Members of the military who died in the Persian Gulf war can, if their survivors choose, be buried in Arlington National Cemetery, the resting place of some of the most honored Americans, including President John F. Kennedy and Medgar Evers.

title: Kathleen Welch and William Groll to Wed in May
description: May wedding plans for Kathleen Welch and William Andrew Groll, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Groll of Island Park, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Welch of Woodbury, N.J.

title: Peggy A. Wilcock To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bray Wilcock of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Peggy Ann Wilcock to William Brad Gano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Phineas Gano of Bethlehem, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Looking At Their Backs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Credit Card Reviews Stir Dispute
description: As banks are increasing efforts to distinguish between good and bad credit card customers, they are being accused of discrimination by lawmakers who object to more stringent credit standards for customers in economically depressed regions of the country.

title: Chronicle
description: NAM JUNE PAIK will get an award for video arts from the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture at the school's annual awards dinner on April 23 in New York. CHUCK CLOSE will be awarded the medal for painting, and MARTHA WILSON, founder of Franklin Furnace, the performance art group, will get an award for service in the arts.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: CUOMO DEFENDS DEMOCRATS Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York criticized Republican leaders for political attacks on Congressional Democrats who voted against the Persian Gulf war. Page B1.

title: Official Called Drunken Driver
description: The acting head of the Hudson County Parks Division was charged with drunken driving after the police found him asleep in a county car at an intersection, officials said yesterday. Officer Ed Jennings found the parks chief, Thomas McCann, at Newark and Coles Streets at 7 A.M. Saturday. He was behind the wheel of the vehicle and its engine was running, the police said.

title: Agencies Caution Clients On Using Patriotic Themes
description: The temptation to wave the flag in ads seems nearly irresistible now -- companies like the General Motors Corporation and Delta Air Lines Inc. are already using patriotic themes -- but many agency executives said in recent interviews that trying to capitalize on the victory in the Persian Gulf war was a mistake.

title: Barbara Brenner Weds Scott Commer
description: Barbara Jill Brenner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton R. Brenner of White Plains, was married yesterday at the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., to Scott Laurence Commer, a son of Linda B. Commer of Stockbridge, Mass., and Richard H. Commer of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Maurice A. Davis performed the ceremony.

title: Everyone Looked for Washington's Tooth
description: To the Editor:

title: China Issues '61 Deng Speech Stressing Shift From Ideology
description: China today published a 30-year-old speech by the nation's patriarch, Deng Xiaoping, in what appeared to be a call for greater attention to the economy and less concern for ideological campaigns.

title: U.S. EXPERTS SPLIT OVER THE SECURITY OF EUROPE A-ARMS
description: In a top-secret dispute, Federal experts are divided over whether the thousands of nuclear arms the nation deploys in Europe are as safe as they should be from sabotage and theft.

title: U.N.L.V. Entering Tourney At 30-0
description: Top-ranked University of Nevada-Las Vegas recovered after a sluggish first half today to beat Fresno State, 98-74, and win the Big West Conference tournament.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Joffrey 'Romeo' Shadowed By Life
description: John Cranko's "Romeo and Juliet," set to Prokofiev's ballet score, is by now one of the most enduring dance versions of Shakespeare's play.

title: 4 Israelis Slain on Eve of Baker's Visit
description: An Arab assailant who told the police he was sending a message to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d stabbed four Israeli women to death tonight and wounded at least one other woman in the center of West Jerusalem.

title: Nurses, Don't Blame Feminists for Your Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Tamra Lee Fisher Is Wed in Darien
description: Tamra Lee Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Fisher of Gillette, N.J., was married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., to James C. Mooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Mooney of New York. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball performed the ceremony.

title: Market Place; What Is Driving Rallies in Europe?
description: AS world stock markets rallied last week, many brokers in Europe were buying for their clients with one hand and scratching their heads with the other. They were wondering what fundamental economic factors were causing the surge, which began with the Persian Gulf war and picked up after the cease-fire was declared.

title: Up From the Ghetto?
description: "They are now among the worst places in the world to live." That stark epitaph for the black urban ghetto in America comes at the end of Nicholas Lemann's stunning new book, "The Promised Land." I thought of it as I visited North Lawndale, on Chicago's West Side.

title: War Takes a Devastating Toll at the Kuwait Zoo
description: The seven months of Iraqi occupation left many human victims, but a less publicized toll is in evidence here in the piles of carcasses and bones littering the cypress-lined paths of Kuwait City's zoo.

title: A.T.&T. Pressures NCR Board
description: Trying to put pressure on the directors of the NCR Corporation to negotiate a friendly merger, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was willing to raise its offer to $100 a share, if NCR would drop its objections to the deal.

title: With News Talks Near Deadline, Contract Wording Is Revised
description: Negotiators for the unions at The Daily News and Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who wants to buy the strikebound newspaper, bargained all day yesterday and into today as they faced a 10 A.M. deadline set by Mr. Maxwell.

title: New Credits for Soviets
description: Sixteen Spanish banks have signed a deal with the Soviet Union for a $1.5 billion credit line to buy Spanish goods and services, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya has announced. The Spanish Government granted the credit when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Madrid and Barcelona in October. It was decided then that half of the credit would be for industrial and consumer goods, mainly food, the rest for technology and services to help the Soviet Union's food and agriculture industries.

title: Review/Theater; A Sendup of 'Streetcar'
description: There comes a moment in the campy drag show "Belle Reprieve," and it comes quite early, when one is forced to ask, just what is the point of any of the goings-on onstage?

title: Chronicle
description: DOROTHY I. HEIGHT has spent much of her 78-year life building the National Council of Negro Women into an organization with clout. And on Tuesday, she will be honored with a grand tribute, led by BILL COSBY, in Manhattan.

title: Couch Potatoes, Aren't Dupes
description: As scholars of media and popular culture, we spend a good deal of our time resisting the widespread assumption that people are passive consumers of the mass media.

title: Ramapo Advances To the Semifinals
description: Competing in its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 20 seasons of varsity basketball, Ramapo College of Mahwah, N.J., moved into the Division III semifinal round on Saturday night with an 80-77 victory over Kean College of Union, N.J., in the Northeast/Atlantic Sectional championship game in Salem, Mass.

title: Thailand's Ex-Premier Freed; Quits as Leader of Key Party
description: Two weeks after he was arrested at gunpoint and his Government ousted in a military coup, Thailand's former Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, was allowed to return home over the weekend.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in late editions on Saturday about the St. Patrick's Day parade in New York City misstated the starting time. The parade is scheduled to start at 11 A.M. on March 16 and end at 5 P.M.

title: Puckett Isn't Part of Sympathy Lineup
description: DOES Rickey Henderson make you shake with anger with his "Brother, can you spare a million?" cant?

title: Elie Siegmeister, 82, a Composer Rooted in American Idiom, Dies
description: Elie Siegmeister, whose compositions formed part of the cornerstone of the contemporary American symphonic school in the 1930's, died on Sunday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Car Salesman Still Looks to N.F.L.
description: ALI HAJI-SHEIKH is best known for kicking field goals for the Giants, for being injured and for earning a Super Bowl ring with the Redskins. That may be because car sales people don't receive the publicity that football players do.

title: Rebels Have Tough Road to Repeat
description: The Runnin' Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas won the national collegiate basketball championship last spring by crushing Duke, 103-73, and they have been on a roll ever since, winning 30 consecutive games this season.

title: Penn State Women in Top Draw
description: Penn State, Virginia, Tennessee and Georgia were given No. 1 seedings in the draw today for the 10th National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: Nurses, Don't Blame Feminists for Your Status; Sisters, Give Us a Break!
description: To the Editor:

title: Courier Outlasts Forget in Five Sets
description: Jim Courier, a 20-year-old Floridian who serves the way he used to pitch and uses his forehand like a bludgeon, captured the second title of his pro career this afternoon at the Newsweek Champions Cup, defeating Guy Forget of France, 4-6, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6.

title: Dykstra to Testify
description: Len Dykstra of the Philadelphia Phillies said today that he would testify in a gambling case in Federal court this week in Jackson, Miss., but that it would have nothing to do with baseball.

title: Pirates Overpower Hoyas to Take the Big East Final
description: Seton Hall closed out one of the most competitive seasons in Big East history yesterday and made some school history of its own by trouncing Georgetown, 74-62, at Madison Square Garden to win its first Big East tournament championship.

title: 4 Albanians Die as Police Seize Refugee Ship
description: Four Albanians were killed and 10 were wounded when the police moved in with guns to seize a ship commandeered by citizens seeking to flee from the port of Durres, residents in Tirana, the Albanian capital, said today.

title: Dinkins Booed at an Irish Parade
description: On Staten Island yesterday, at the first of New York City's St. Patrick's Day parades, Mayor David N. Dinkins received cheers, jeers and catcalls about budget cuts, tax increases and a proposal to let a gay group march in Manhattan's St. Patrick's parade.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Costly Radio Failure Hurts Westwood One
description: On WNEW-AM, the New York radio station operated by the Westwood One Companies, Frank Sinatra can often be heard singing that if you can make it in New York you can make it anywhere. Unfortunately, in Westwood One's case Mr. Sinatra is wrong.

title: From Hill & Knowlton To Head of GCI Group
description: John D. Bergen, who resigned Tuesday as president and chief operating officer of the United States division of Hill & Knowlton Inc., has been named president and chief executive of GCI Group Inc., the public relations subsidiary of Grey Advertising Inc.

title: Review/Dance; Mixing Energy and Urgency
description: The City Contemporary Dance Company of Hong Kong, whose current tour marks its American debut, is a troupe of strong, beautifully trained and good-looking young dancers. But they were poorly served by the program presented on Friday night at the Triplex Theater.

title: Gunmaker's Liability Deserves Court Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Putter of the Future Or a Threat to Golf?
description: THE long-shafted putter used to be considered golf's weapon of last resort, an unwieldy placebo that allowed old warhorses a few last turns around the greens before being put out to pasture.

title: 3 Die in Florida Crash
description: A small plane crashed into a parking lot at a shopping center shortly after taking off from Key West International Airport on Saturday night, killing at least three people, the police said. "The pilot declared an emergency and was trying to return to the airport," said a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta.

title: H. S. Allan Kastrup, Journalist, 84
description: H. S. Allan Kastrup, former head of The American Swedish News Exchange in Manhattan, an agency sponsored by the Swedish Government, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Sweden.

title: Lord, Dentsu Favored To Win Dole Account
description: The Los Angeles office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners is expected to be awarded the account for Castle & Cooke Inc.'s Dole Food Company. The billings are estimated to be more than $20 million.

title: Chafing Over Snub by Baker, Queen Noor Vows to Win Over Americans
description: In a palace where light splinters through carved shutters and a fountain soothes the stone of a courtyard, an American-born queen sat down to talk and seemed to suggest that the Persian Gulf crisis had reinforced a mission: to persuade her country of birth to understand her Arab land of adoption.

title: Metro Matters; Focus of Scrutiny: How Dinkins Outdraws Cuomo
description: A prominent securities analyst was asked the other day where he would rather invest his own money, in New York City or New York State government bonds?

title: Accounts
description: * JD Cosmetics Inc. to I. Goldberg & Partners Inc., New York, for White Step, a new product that whitens teeth. Billings are $6 million. * True Value Hardware Stores to Killian & Co., Chicago, for a new trade ad campaign. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Reviving a Humbled First Boston
description: When Credit Suisse moved to rescue the First Boston Corporation last year, the once-high-flying investment bank was teetering near the abyss. Now, four months after Credit Suisse took control of First Boston, senior officials here and in New York deny that First Boston has permanently fallen out of the first tier of New York investment banks.

title: Ewing Meets A Cookie Monster
description: ONE scene in the Knicks' locker room last Tuesday was priceless. The 7-foot-1-inch Patrick Ewing was upstaged by a 3-foot opponent. Maurice Cheeks Jr. was sitting in a chair chomping on a chocolate chip cookie when Ewing approached the 3-year-old boy and playfully shouted for a piece of his cookie.

title: M. J. Kaufman Weds Jenifer Daly in Boston
description: Mary Jenifer Daly, a daughter of Sheila Leary Daly of Aurora, Colo., and Timothy F. Daly of Delmar, N.Y., was married yesterday in Boston to Michael Jay Kaufman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Kaufman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbis David Blumenfeld and Ruth Sohn performed the ceremony at the World Trade Center Boston.

title: No. 1 Tourney Question: Can U.N.L.V. Be Beaten?
description: The 64-team field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was announced last night, immediately prompting hundreds of questions in taverns, office buildings and basketball arenas throughout the country. Which bracket is the strongest? Which teams will advance to the Final Four? Which deserving schools were not selected for the tournament?

title: Baseball Union Builds Strike Fund
description: LABOR peace in baseball, always sweet, is sometimes short as well. That is why the Major League Baseball Players Association is guarding against a work stoppage by withholding one-third of the licensing fees usually paid to players by trading-card companies and the like. The basic agreement does not expire until the end of 1993, but it can be reopened after 1992.

title: Minoso Gets Shot In Minor Leagues
description: IT looks like Minnie Minoso will play pro baseball in a sixth decade after all, but it won't be with the Chicago White Sox. It will be with the Class A Pompano Beach Miracles of the Florida State League.

title: Quake Rattles San Francisco
description: A light earthquake jolted parts of the San Francisco Bay area today, causing no damage or injury but rattling windows in some areas, officials said.

title: Los Angeles Agency Aids Military Families
description: Moved by a special section in last week's Newsweek magazine that pictured dozens of United States military people who were killed during the war with Iraq, one small Los Angeles agency has decided to do something for the families of some of those killed.

title: Review/Dance; Motions to Memory and What Might Have Been
description: The Chicago Moving Company certainly can move: sturdily, commandingly and, thanks to the choreography of its director, Nana Shineflug, interestingly.

title: An Impressive Start as Hawkins Stymies Orioles
description: On a sunny but chilly and exceptionally breezy day, the Yankees got six innings of two-hit, shutout pitching against the Baltimore Orioles today as Andy Hawkins looked particularly good in a three-inning stint.

title: Susan Seligson and Gregory Pattenaude Wed
description: Susan Joy Seligson, a lawyer at the State Energy Office in Albany, and Gregory Cox Pattenaude, an engineer, were married yesterday at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Albert Sturmer and the Rev. Jerry Gentile, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Joseph Baer, Leader Of Deliverers Union At Papers, Dies at 79
description: Joseph Baer, a former president of the newspaper drivers' union in New York, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Monroe Township, N.J.

title: U.N. Begins Inquiry Into Rights Abuses in Iraq and Occupied Kuwait
description: The United Nations group charged with encouraging respect for human rights has begun investigations of abuses in Iraq and in Kuwait while it was under Iraqi occupation.

title: U.S. Says Iraqi Loyalists Struggle To Control Widespread Rebellion
description: Iraqi forces loyal to President Saddam Hussein are having increasing trouble quelling more than two dozen revolts in the country, American military officials said today.

title: Inquiry Examines Metro-North Policy
description: Federal and state investigators are looking closely at the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's operating regulations to determine if its president, Peter E. Stangl, violated railroad rules when a friend of his sat in the engineer's seat during a ride in October.

title: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'s; 'Someday' Comes With a Roar for 21 Ex-Captives
description: The long road back from captivity in Iraq ended here today for 21 former prisoners of war, who landed to a Fourth of July-style homecoming from the country's top military commanders, thousands of flag-waving well-wishers and a brass band playing "God Bless America."

title: As Flake Trial Starts, Queens Pays Attention
description: As the conspiracy and tax-evasion trial of Representative Floyd H. Flake and his wife, Margarett Elaine, opens today in Federal District Court, it is being watched by blacks across the city, but nowhere more closely than in the southeastern Queens community Mr. Flake represents and where he is pastor of Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church.

title: Census Shows Profound Change In Racial Makeup of the Nation
description: The racial and ethnic complexion of the American population changed more dramatically in the past decade than at any time in the 20th century, with nearly one in every four Americans claiming African, Asian, Hispanic or American Indian ancestry. The 1980 census found that one in five Americans had a minority background.

title: Justice, and Efficiency, After Arrest
description: Last April, after a judge ruled that New York City took too long with the initial processing of criminal defendants, officials instituted reforms that have now achieved impressive results.

title: Amendment to Alter Utah Abortion Law Is Winning Support
description: The sponsor of Utah's restrictive abortion law said Saturday that he intended to alter a provision that could allow prosecutors to bring charges of first-degree murder against women who have illegal abortions.

title: In Thai Coup, Refugees Are Big Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: Returning Part of Everglades To Nature for $700 Million
description: For a century, man has been swallowing the Everglades in a storm of concrete, smoke, and steel. Now state and Federal authorities are trying to make room for nature in South Florida.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher in Tokyo today as brokers said an apparent easing of credit by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States last week revived hopes of a monetary easing here. But they said trading remained cautious because of a weaker yen and corporate book-closings this month. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 61.85 points, or less than 1 percent, to finish at 26,669.37. At the end of morning trading, the Nikkei was up 75.36 points, to 26,682.88. On Friday, the index rose 209.56 points.

title: Young Germans Still Flocking From East to West
description: Five months into German unity, tens of thousands of eastern Germans continue to embark on a westward trek in search of jobs and a brighter future. Most of those fleeing are young, mobile people with their children, leaving behind a society increasingly marked by age and inaction.

title: New York Lacks Money To Buy Land
description: Early last fall, a decade of negotiations produced a deal that was literally and figuratively trailblazing for 22,000 acres along the Raquette River northwest of this Adirondack village.

title: Greenpeace Wants to Outlaw Making War on Environment
description: The environmentalist group Greenpeace, citing damage caused by six weeks of war in the Persian Gulf, called today for a new Geneva Convention to outlaw the use of the environment as a target of war.

title: Fur Trappers' Venture
description: Canadian trappers have set up a fur auction house that they hope will succeed where Northbay Fur Sales, which recently declared bankruptcy, failed. "We're starting off small," said Don Rumford, an employee of Fur Harvesters Auction Inc. "We also don't have that big debt that Northbay Fur Sales had to carry." Officials of Fur Harvesters, based in North Bay, Ontario, said they thought that the anti-fur movement was waning and that fur prices are about to rebound. The auction house, which is to be run by trappers, plans to hold its first auction in May and is hoping for sales of $1 million to $1.5 million.

title: Filly's Saga Continues
description: Meadow Star's path to the Kentucky Derby seemed to be taking a sharp turn toward New York today. But the trainer of the undefeated 3-year-old filly deferred until Monday a final decision on whether her delayed 1991 debut at Gulfstream Park would be rescheduled for Aqueduct on Saturday afternoon.

title: Adding Roads, or Lanes, Only Increases Automobile Traffic; Price of Raised Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Bank Deadline Reset
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said last week that it would give interested parties two more weeks to submit bids for the three banking units of the failed Bank of New England Corporation.

title: 8 ARAB COUNTRIES BACK BUSH'S PLAN ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: Six Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, along with Egypt and Syria, today endorsed President Bush's broad framework for dealing with the Middle East in the wake of the war with Iraq, including plans for a continuing and enhanced American military presence in the gulf.

title: Islanders Squander Third-Period Lead
description: Their tendency to squander a lead in the third period is one reason the Islanders have been cemented into the Patrick Division cellar most of the season.

title: Heathrow Talks to Resume
description: American and British negotiators recessed talks late yesterday afternoon that are aimed at allowing the transfer of landing rights at Heathrow Airport from two weak United States airlines to two stronger ones. The negotiations are to resume today in Washington.

title: Elizabeth Boris Marries
description: Elizabeth Boris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Boris of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Ronald H. Bernstein, the son of Naomi Bernstein of Elmont, L.I., and the late Paul L. Bernstein. Rabbi Charles G. Agin officiated at Sans Souci of Sea Cliff in Sea Cliff, L.I. The bride, 33 years old, is keeping her name. She is the assistant to the sheriff of Nassau County and directs the drug and alcohol programs of the Nassau Correctional Facility in East Meadow. The bridegroom, 32, is a senior corporate accountant at the Quantum Chemical Corporation in New York.

title: British Tycoon Tries Proven Tactics To Negotiate a Daily News Takeover
description: Robert Maxwell, the 67-year-old British entrepreneur, has a reputation for being as unpredictable as he is hyperactive. Guided by whim and instinct, he buys and sells businesses at a furious pace and runs through subordinates like paper clips. He once even dismissed one of his sons, Ian, for showing up late for a meeting.

title: 2 Held Without Bail In Starvation of Baby
description: A Bronx man and woman were ordered held without bail late Saturday night on manslaughter charges in the death of a 7-month-old boy who starved while he was left unattended for nearly a week.

title: R. J. Mermelstein Weds Ms. Bogus
description: Felice Beth Bogus and Robert Joel Mermelstein were married yesterday at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn by Rabbi Joseph I. Singer. The bride is the daughter of Jerome L. Bogus of Brooklyn and the late Pearl Bogus. The bridegroom is the son of Estelle Mermelstein of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Gerald Mermelstein.

title: Review/Television; Relationships Haunted by Old Wounds
description: Mother and daughter stories are surely one of the more prominent of movie staples. The syndrome in Hollywood is typified by "Terms of Endearment." Characteristic of television's approach is tonight's "Lucky Day," an "ABC Theater" presentation at 9 o'clock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Leftists Run in Salvadoran Elections
description: Pedro Pablo Mendez rose before dawn today, put on a clean shirt and his straw hat and rode a truck into town to carry the banner for supporters of leftist guerrillas in the electorial race for Mayor of Victoria.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales...Feb. Thursday Inventories/Sales...Jan. Friday Capacity Utilization...Feb. Industrial Production...Feb. Producer Prices...Feb.

title: Ohio St. Falls, but Shares Title
description: Rodell Davis scored 19 points and Kevin Smith, a 37 percent free-throw shooter, hit three key foul shots down the stretch today as Iowa upset Ohio State, 80-69, to deny the Buckeyes an outright Big Ten Conference championship.

title: A Rare Window for Peace
description: What a welcome irony looms on the Mideast horizon: It's just possible that Saddam Hussein gave an unintended boost to Arab-Israeli peace. His Scud attacks, meant to incite Israel and win back Arab support, did neither. And his aggression drove Syria, Saudi Arabia and Egypt closer to the U.S. The man who tried to barter Kuwait for Palestine and spur an Arab crusade against Israel has revitalized diplomacy.

title: Benefits Vary For Carriers In U.S. Airlift
description: For some of the nation's airlines, which enjoyed a windfall ferrying troops and materiel to the Middle East, the return trip will provide more welcome business.

title: Man Killed in Shootout at Movie
description: An exchange of words between two young moviegoers ended in a barrage of gunfire outside a theater in downtown Brooklyn that left one of them dead and the other charged with murder, the police said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Someday finally came and we are glad to be home." -- Col. David W. Eberly of the Air Force, a former prisoner of the Iraqis. [ A11:1. ]

title: 2 New Printers From Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce two new lower-cost printers on Monday as part of its strategy to make the Macintosh personal computer and associated equipment more affordable.

title: Traders Left Confused By Latest Jobless Data
description: The credit market this week is expected to focus on the meaning of the Government's employment data and the Federal Reserve's move on interest rates, after an uncommonly volatile session on Friday that erased all of the week's price gains.

title: Gooden Foils Strawberry
description: Dwight Gooden's first fastball to Darryl Strawberry registered 93 miles an hour on the radar gun behind the plate at Holman Stadium. His next clocked in at 94 m.p.h.

title: Dividing Up, Looking Back
description: BASEBALL'S union has set May 20 as a tentative deadline for players who wish to file claims against the $280 million in collusion damages being paid by major league clubs. "Then the hard stuff starts," said Donald Fehr, the executive director of the Players Association. Fehr said $280 million might seem unspendable, "but when you begin to divide it up, that changes pretty quickly." . . . Oregon State played a slow-down offense in its 82-67 loss to Arizona last week, causing the Wildcats' Brian Williams to lament: "That's 50's basketball. It reminded me of 'Hoosiers.' " Williams knows a bit about the era he blasted. His father, Gene, is one of the original members of the musical group The Platters. . . . Stan and Amy Aukamp look like twins and even play like twins. Even though they are not twins, the brother and sister recorded twin-like statistics while playing center for the men's and women's teams at the College of Wooster in Ohio. Stan averaged 16.3 points, 8.9 rebounds and 2.1 blocks a game and Amy averaged 15.3, 10.5 and 2.3.

title: Cuomo Scolds G.O.P. for Assailing Democrats on Gulf War
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today harshly criticized Republican leaders for political attacks against Congressional Democrats who voted against the war in the Persian Gulf, and said that the allied victory does not necessarily mean that the decision to go to war was the best one.

title: How to Protect Babies From Crack
description: There may be no victims of drug abuse who are more pathetic or more costly to society than the crack-damaged babies born to addicted mothers. Yet Medicaid, the Federal-state health insurance for the poor, won't pay the bills for many pregnant women who seek treatment. Now Congress has a chance to correct the policy flaw.

title: Team Unity For Dinkins; Fiscal Message Sent As Labor Chief Quits
description: Moving to impose unity on his fractious staff on Saturday by forcing his Labor Commissioner's oft-threatened resignation, Mayor David N. Dinkins made a determined step to protect his administration's fragile credibility in dealing with New York City's deepening fiscal problems.

title: Old Stories With New Twists Told by Persian Gulf Troops
description: The war in the Persian Gulf, it turns out, was like all other wars this nation has fought -- and like no other.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about a New Haven pediatrician and educator rendered his name incorrectly. He was Dr. David Hale Clement.

title: New Editor For Magazine
description: Lynn Povich, a senior editor at Newsweek since 1975, has been named the editor in chief of Working Woman, a Lang Communications magazine.

title: The Ghost of Kirov
description: Hunger forces change or repression. Early in 1934, as famine stalked the Soviet Union, a movement began within the Communist Party to find an alternative to the ruthless Stalin and his secret police, the N.K.V.D.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Campbell Soup Co. is offering $50 million in 8 5/8 percent noncallable notes due in 2001 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The notes are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: Strawberry Faces a Strong Wind
description: BEHIND the batting cage, Tommy Lasorda pointed to right field at Holman Stadium, where the trees and the flags leaned and blew stiffly toward home plate. "Watch this, watch Darryl turn the wind around," said Lasorda, loud enough for a companion, and for Darryl Strawberry, stepping into the cage, to hear. "Watch this."

title: A New Diversion for Those Who Stay Up Late
description: Two years ago, Arsenio Hall took on Johnny Carson and quickly proved he could hold his own, and then some, against the king of late-night television. Now, emboldened by that success, he is challenging David Letterman for supremacy after midnight.

title: North Carolina Trounces Duke in Final
description: There aren't many occasions when Dean Smith, the North Carolina basketball coach, enters a game with his team as the underdog. But that was the case in the final of the 38th annual Atlantic Coast Conference tournament this afternoon, as the Tar Heels faced top-seeded Duke after surviving close calls against the tournament's two lowest seeded teams, Clemson and Virginia.

title: Sabatini Stops Graf By 6-4, 7-6 for Title
description: There might have been a time when Gabriela Sabatini wondered whether she would ever fulfill expectations and be a worthy opponent for Steffi Graf. Sabatini no longer needs to fret: She has figured out the puzzle and plays Graf with a tailor-made blueprint.

title: Violent Rogue Wind Emerges in Search for Clues to Air Crash
description: Along the front range of the Rocky Mountains, where sailplanes soar on waves of air cascading over the towering ridgeline, aviators and meteorologists are stalking a rogue wind that might have spun a United Airlines jet into a crash last Sunday, killing 25 people.

title: Review/Music; The Boundaries of Freedom
description: In the performing world, great value is placed on interpretive freedom and the individuality it represents. Paradoxically this freedom is most evident when musicians control their instruments thoroughly and play with both discipline and a fully grounded sense of style. These were among the qualities that distinguished Hai-Ye Ni's cello playing last Monday evening, when she made her New York debut at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. By late Friday, the outstanding three-month bills and six-month bills were both bid at 5.96 percent.

title: Voter Turnout High in Benin For Free Presidential Election
description: Anxious voters lined up before dawn this morning in front of polling stations here and across Benin to cast ballots in this tiny nation's first free presidential elections in nearly three decades.

title: Many Kuwaiti Installations Are Reported in Good Shape
description: The damage done to Kuwait's basic installations by retreating Iraqi soldiers appears to be less severe than first thought, Government officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Israel Lowers Shekel's Value
description: Israel lowered the median value of its currency today by 5.66 percent against a "basket" of foreign currencies dominated by the United States dollar. The action will require Israel's central bank to devalue the currency, the shekel, on Monday.

title: Fordham Gets N.I.T. Bid
description: Fordham will make its eighth appearance in the National Invitation Tournament in the last 11 seasons in leading a group of 32 teams that were picked last night to play in the post-season tournament. The Rams will travel to play South Florida on Thursday in the first round.

title: OPEC Cuts: How Much and Whose?
description: When OPEC ministers gather on Monday in Geneva for their first meeting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, they are expected to try to rein in overproduction, seeking to prevent a collapse of crude oil prices.

title: Bridge
description: An extempore partnership eked out a slender victory in the Open Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Saturday night. Larry Mori of Ballston Lake, N.Y., was due to play here with Kitty Bethe of Manhattan, with whom he won a major title four months ago. But she had to work, and he played instead with her husband, Henry Bethe, and the unexpected partnership squeezed through to victory by one match-point.

title: TURMOIL IN SERBIA DEEPENS DIVISIONS
description: The political turmoil in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, which continued today with the arrests of important anti-Communist opposition leaders, adds a new impetus to the forces pulling this multi-ethnic nation apart. The trouble comes after recent moves by Slovenia and Croatia toward seceding from the six-republic Yugoslav federation.

title: INSIDE
description: Roemer Switching Parties Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana told state Republican Party officials that he plans to leave the Democratic Party and run for re-election this fall as a Republican. Page A14.

title: Partner For Tour By Bolshoi
description: The head of Entertainment Corporation U.S.A., the financially pressed British-owned production company, said yesterday that the company would enter a partnership with James L. Nederlander, the theatrical producer, to guarantee the appearance of the Bolshoi Opera in New York and Virginia this summer.

title: Unions Offer Cooperation to Dinkins
description: The leaders of New York City's municipal unions yesterday set aside their differences with Mayor David N. Dinkins over the removal of his chief labor negotiator and urged the Mayor to take the lead in a team effort to solve the city's worsening budget problems.

title: Midtown Journal; Strolling Hidden Nooks In Manhattan's Canyons
description: New York has always had its alleys, shadowy lanes that threaten mayhem or stage-door passageways that whisper of footlights and fame.

title: Outdoors: A Colorful Addition to Florida Canals
description: TWO new gamefish with names as colorful as their glossy flanks rule the vast canal system of southeastern Florida. Butterfly peacock bass and speckled peacock bass -- closely related transplants from South America -- have become stabilizers in only a few years to the rapidly shifting ecology of these canals. In the process, their establishment has injected a new excitement to what had been a typically mundane urban fishery.

title: Louisiana Governor to Switch to Republican Party
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana told a private gathering of state Republicans tonight that he planned to abandon the Democratic Party and seek re-election this year as a Republican, ending months of speculation over his political plans.

title: Reviews/Music; From Cape Cod, Legato With Smiles
description: Gloria Dei Cantores, a 46-member choir that sang an a-cappella program at Town Hall on Thursday evening, might seem an improbable choice for an evening's secular entertainment. With a vocal method that apparently requires simultaneous singing and smiling, with robotically drilled bows and a mostly lugubrious religious repertory, the ensemble looked for all the world like the Stepford choristers.

title: Magazine's Subscribers Get Personalized Comic
description: Young subscribers to Sports Illustrated for Kids may be amazed to see their own names mentioned in the magazine's comic strip, which chronicles the adventures of a child named Buzz Beamer.

title: Labor Chief in Brazil Amazon Is Killed and Another Is Hurt
description: A labor leader in Brazil's Amazon region was killed in his home and another union organizer in the region was shot three times in a separate attack, a church worker said today.

title: Carlesimo Says No To Rumor on Irish
description: If he were so inclined, the basketball coach at Seton Hall University could play the game that takes place every spring. He could wait for a peer somewhere across the country to fall out of favor at an ambitious, high-profile place. He could use the entree reinforced by the Big East tournament championship the Pirates won yesterday at Madison Square Garden, and circulate a business card:

title: Ms. Gershen Weds Joshua Finkelstein
description: Elana Lynn Gershen, a daughter of Mildred B. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., and the late Alvin E. Gershen, was married yesterday at the Jewish Center of Princeton to Rabbi Joshua Steven Finkelstein, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Ezra M. Finkelstein of Syosset, L.I. Rabbi Allan Blaine, an uncle of the bride, and the bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

title: Editorial Notebook; 'The Doors' Distorts the 60's
description: The poster for the movie "The Doors" mimics a photograph of Jim Morrison popular 25 years ago. In the original, Morrison pouted at you from the walls of college dormitory rooms and through the marijuana haze of crash pads from Philly to the Haight. Sex radiated from his bedroom eyes; the naked chest was smooth and birdishly small, but he bared it as a sign of virility. Val Kilmer plays Morrison in the film and pouts well enough. But Mr. Kilmer, among other things, has too much chest hair to be credible.

title: New York State to Sue to Stop Evictions in Rent-Law Fight
description: A New York State lawsuit to prevent a Federal agency from evicting hundreds of rent-regulated tenants from co-operative and condominium apartments in New York City will be filed today in Federal court in Manhattan, state officials said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Dance; 3 Go Their Own Ways and Still End Up Together
description: Bryan Hayes, Sally Gross and Carolyn Lord have been marching to their own drumbeats for decades now. The three choreographers have been at it long enough not to have anything to prove. So a program they shared last Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio was an evening of relaxed and literate pleasures.

title: Dixon, In a First, Is First In Seville
description: The tears trickling down Fred Thompson's cheeks into creases of a smile told the entire story. For all the joys Diane Dixon had brought him, none matched this one. Now, she was a world champion; he was a world champion coach.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A8-11

title: The National Gallery Is Really Making Out Like, Well, a Bandit
description: "They came into my gallery, pointed to an Annibale Carracci drawing and said, 'That's it.' " David Tunick, a New York dealer in Old Master drawings and prints, was not describing a robbery but a donation -- to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, which is waging an all-out gift campaign for its 50th anniversary. Mr. Tunick, who has a long dealer-client relationship with the National Gallery, had been tapped, and coughing up the Carracci was his contribution.

title: Gorbachev The Great
description: Six years after Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, on March 11, 1985, many commentators say his reform efforts have failed miserably. Some charge he has betrayed his betrayed his promises or that he has always been an imposter-reformer. They point to growing economic chaos and ethnic unrest, to his unpopularity at home and recent adoption of authoritarian measures. They conclude he is no longer worthy -- or never was worthy -- of our support.

title: Boxer Displays Hands of Surgeon
description: WHEN he wakes up at 5:30 A.M. and does road work in sweats, he is an unknown boxer called Hackie Reitman. When he dons hospital greens two hours later, he is an esteemed orthopedic surgeon named Dr. Harold S. Reitman.

title: McDonnell's Jet Problems
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation says it has alerted the Air Force to problems with rivets in the wings of the C-17 cargo jets that it is building in Long Beach, Calif. The company describes the problems as minor.

title: Once, Welfare Meant Someone Else, But Recession Brings Home Its Sting
description: Last June, unmarried and six months pregnant, Beth Chiaet, 28 years old, sat stunned as a caseworker told her what it would take to get her application for welfare approved.

title: Caribbean Tourism
description: Caribbean tourism grew by only 3 percent in 1990 because of the recession and the Middle East crisis, the Caribbean Tourism Organization says. In 1989, tourism in the region's 32 countries grew by 5.5 percent, to 10.8 million visitors. The organization said on Friday that the slow growth was a result of difficult economic conditions in the United States, Canada and Britain and a drop in travel since Iraq invaded Kuwait.

title: Nurses, Don't Blame Feminists for Your Status; Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Everest's Changing Land: Tourists and Toothache
description: High in the Himalayas, in terraced farm villages linked by trails too narrow and steep for wheeled vehicles, the Sherpa people of Mount Everest are being swept up in an accidental economic and cultural revolution.

title: Cheers, Songs and Flag-Waving for Town's Troops
description: More than 35,000 people from across the state took to the streets here today for a raucus parade and rally to welcome soldiers returning to Fort Bragg and Pope Air Force Base after months in the Persian Gulf.

title: Blackhawks Gain As Rangers Lose
description: The Rangers' losing streak reached three games tonight with a nasty 5-2 defeat amid the sound and fury of jam-packed Chicago Stadium. The Blackhawks' victory returned them to a first-place tie with St. Louis for the lead in both the Norris Division and the overall standing of the 21-team National Hockey League as the regular season heads into its final two weeks.

title: Chronicle
description: Two years ago, JIM BURROWS started a campaign to honor his late father, Abe Burrows. Now he has established the Abe Burrows Theater Fund at New York University, to be used for renovation of the Tisch School of the Arts building. On Thursday the school will name its theater after the eclectic playwright, director, composer and performer. Mr. Burrows, who died in 1985, attended N.Y.U. from 1929 through 1931.

title: Reviews/Theater; How to Elevate Greed to a Blueprint for Life
description: Harold Rome's 1962 musical "I Can Get It for You Wholesale" is remembered as the show that introduced Barbra Streisand to Broadway and catapulted her to stardom. Richard Sabellico's well-balanced revival at the American Jewish Theater puts the show in perspective but it remains a middling example of its genre.

title: Chief Praises Department Despite Beating
description: In a videotape to members of the Police Department, Chief Daryl F. Gates has vowed to punish all officers involved in the beating of a black motorist and said that his faith in the department was unshaken.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 111, Trail Blazers 109: Robert Parish scored the go-ahead basket on a stuff shot with 32 seconds left in overtime and Dee Brown added two free throws with 16.6 seconds to go as Boston handed Portland its second straight home-court loss. Portland, which has lost five of its last six games, leads the Los Angeles Lakers by two games in the Pacific Division. The Celtics, the leaders in the Atlantic Division, have won four in a row. Larry Bird led the Celtics with 27 points. (AP) Bulls 122, Hawks 87: Michael Jordan scored 25 points for Chicago, and the game grew so lopsided that both teams' regulars sat out the final quarter. The loss was the second straight for the Hawks at home. A club-record streak of 22 consecutive Omni victories was snapped by Phoenix on Thursday. (AP) Warriors 97, Kings 87: The Kings suffered their 27th straight road loss as Chris Mullin hit his first nine shots from the field and finished with 34 points for Golden State. The Warriors kept the Kings from winning a season-high third straight game and put them one defeat away from the National Basketball Association record for consecutive road losses in one season. (AP) Lakers 115, Magic 101: In Orlando, Fla., Terry Teagle scored 12 of his 17 points in the fourth quarter and keyed a 15-4 spurt that enabled Los Angeles to pull away. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Blues 1: Johan Garpenlov, a rookie, had two goals and an assist to help Detroit win in St. Louis. Seven of Garpenlov's 17 goals have come against the Blues, including 4 on Nov. 23 in Detroit's only other victory over St. Louis in eight games. The Blues' Brett Hull scored his 77th goal. (AP) Kings 4, Canadiens 4: Tomas Sandstrom scored two goals and Los Angeles overcame a three-goal deficit to earn the tie in Montreal. (AP) Nordiques 2, Whalers 1: Joe Sakic scored his 39th goal of the season 10 minutes 4 seconds into the third period to snap a tie and Ron Tugnutt stopped 29 shots to spark Quebec in Hartford. The Whalers are 0-6-3 in their last nine games. (AP) TENNIS Svensson Wins Duel of Swedes: Jonas Svensson took control after narrowly losing a first-set tie breaker and beat Anders Jarryd, 6-7, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday in an all-Swedish singles final of the Copenhagen Open. It was the first Association of Tennis Professionals Tour victory of the year for Svensson, who is ranked 12th in the world and was the tournament's top-seeded player. (AP) SKIING Girardelli Is Champion: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg clinched a record-tying fourth World Cup overall title when he finshed fourth in a men's slalom race yesterday in Aspen, Colo., closing out the challenge of Alberto Tomba of Italy. The race was won by Rudolf Nierlich of Austria, but Girardelli earnedenough points to equal the feat of Gustav Thoeni of Italy and Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD School Record for Two-Mile Run: Melody Fairchild, a senior at Boulder (Colo.) High School, yesterday became the first schoolgirl to run under 10 minutes for two miles indoors or out. At the national indoor scholastic championships in the Carrier Dome at Syracuse University, Fairchild was clocked in 9 minutes 55.92 seconds to shatter the national mark of 10:05.15 set by Suzie Tuffey of Peoria, Ill., in 1985. Two other individual national records were posted. Juliana Yendork of Walnut, Calif., erased her mark of 43 feet 1/2-inch when she won the triple jump at 43-11 1/2. She also took the long jump at 20- 1/4. The other national mark came in a heat of the girls' 200-meter dash when Zundra Feagin of Rockledge, Fla., ran the race in 23.67 seconds. AUTO RACING Senna First in Phoenix: Driving a previously unraced Honda-powered McLaren, Ayrton Senna didn't miss a beat yesterday in outclassing the field in the season-opening United States Grand Prix through the streets of downtown Phoenix. The Brazilian led from start to finish in winning the event for the second straight year. His archrival and former teammate, Alain Prost of France, driving a Ferrari, was a distant runner-up, 16.322 seconds behind. (AP) GOLF Pate Wins in Florida: Steve Pate shot a 75 yesterday but still won the Honda Classic in Coral Springs, Fla. He posted a three-stroke victory in winds that gusted to 35 miles per hour. Paul Azinger and Dan Halldorson tied for second. (AP) Davies Takes Inamori Classic: Laura Davies of England shot a five-under-par 67 to win the Inamori Classic by four strokes over Judy Dickinson and Lynn Connelly in Poway, Calif. (AP)

title: Fitness a Year-Round Job for Athletes
description: MAJOR league baseball returned to the playing fields of Florida and Arizona last month, the beginning of the preparation for the season, which begins in April. But for most players, spring training is only the next step in a year-round fitness program.

title: Boston U. and Clarkson Go to N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: Boston University and Clarkson won their respective league tournaments tonight at the Boston Garden to gain automatic bids to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's hockey tournament.

title: Assessing Damage in Kuwait
description: Except for oilfields, the damage done to Kuwait's basic installations by withdrawing Iraqis appears to be less severe than was thought, Kuwaitis and diplomats said. Page A9.

title: Russell Oswald, 82, Prison Chief In New York During Attica Siege
description: Russell G. Oswald, the chief of New York State's penal system at the time of the bloody 1971 uprising in its Attica prison, died on Friday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 82 years old and lived in Schenectady.

title: Review/Dance; Gloom and Doom by the Joffrey Ballet
description: The Joffrey Ballet was especially impressive in some somber works at recent performances at the New York State Theater.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 10, 1991: MONDAY Bandag Inc United Indl Corp Great Lakes Chem Corp West Inc Rykoff Sexton Inc TUESDAY Consolidated Nat Gas Co Fluor Corp Fleetwood Enterprises Oklahoma Gas & Elec Co Flightsafety Intl Inc WEDNESDAY Block H&R Inc Nicor Inc CBI Inds Inc Quaker Oats Co General RE Corp So New Eng Telecomm Heinz HJ Co Wallace Computer Svcs Inc THURSDAY Centel Corp Russ Togs Inc Idaho Pwr Co Super Food Svcs Inc Lincoln Natl Corp Ind Vestaur Secs Inc MBIA Inc FRIDAY Equitable Res Inc SATURDAY Dillard Dept Stores Inc

title: Books of The Times; 'Psycho': Whither Death Without Life?
description: American Psycho By Bret Easton Ellis 399 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. Paperback, $11.

title: The Inside Story On Scouting
description: THE telephone was ringing at Hoop 1 Video last night. And ringing and ringing. Anyone who could not get through to (201) 340-HOOP is probably calling today.

title: Adding Roads, or Lanes, Only Increases Automobile Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: As Rivals Grow, Book Clubs Dress Up Their Marketing
description: FOR decades, book clubs have provided millions of Americans across the country with a steady supply of literature. The Book-of-the-Month Club and the Literary Guild, both founded in 1926, thrived and became pillars of publishing.

title: Harrelson: His Own Man?
description: BUD HARRELSON does not appear alone in the photograph on the cover of the team's 1991 information guide, although he is not joined by any current member of the Mets or their front office. Instead, he is accompanied, basically, by a ghost, for it is a faded, grainy reproduction of the late Gil Hodges's profile that is peering over Harrelson's left shoulder.

title: Big Bank and Equitable Life Clash Over a Deal Gone Sour
description: In a rare clash of financial giants, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has been accused by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of deceiving its partners and reneging on a contract in a real estate investment worth more than $400 million. The bank will press its complaint this afternoon at a hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

title: Ms. Tamres Weds Aaron S. Needle
description: Janet Marjorie Tamres and Aaron Scott Needle were married yesterday at Temple Israel in South Merrick, L.I., by Rabbi Gutman Baras. The bride is a daughter of Trude L. Tamres of Baldwin, L.I., and Herbert J. Tamres of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Z. Needle of Plainview, L.I.

title: Square D Rejects Schneider Offer
description: The Square D Company said today that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from Groupe Schneider S.A.

title: Heat 2d Half Blitzes Nets
description: The Nets won here at Miami Arena in late January. This afternoon, the Heat played as if that loss was fresh in their minds, and used a second-half blitz to defeat the Nets, 101-88, before about 12,000 spectators.

title: Sharpton Will Seek New Judge in Stabbing Case
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who was stabbed in the chest two months ago before a protest march in Brooklyn, said yesterday that the judge assigned to hear the stabbing case should step down because he is a longtime political opponent.

title: U.S. Seeks Broad Ban on Computers
description: American and Japanese officials will meet in Tokyo on Friday to try to renegotiate a seven-year-old secret accord under which the United States and Japan agreed to limit the sale of supercomputers, United States Government officials said this weekend.

title: Political Memo; Democrats Don't Need Sacrificial Lamb for '92
description: Presidential elections are not canceled because the incumbent President is skyrocketing in the public opinion polls.

title: Huge Rally in Moscow Calls on Gorbachev to Resign
description: More than 100,000 people marched through this capital today demanding Mikhail S. Gorbachev's resignation and urging a "no" vote in the referendum on Soviet unity a week from now.

title: Colleagues Say De Niro Has No Peer
description: Fiftieth and Park seemed like Hollywood and Vine when some of the motion picture industry's biggest stars saluted Robert De Niro at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Saturday night.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "In one splendid generous gesture, Walter Annenberg has given a whole new dimension to one of the Met's greatest existing strengths. This is no mean feat, and we are all of us awed by the seemingly inexhaustible public spirit behind this gift." -- Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. [ C12:3. ]

title: Jane Lloyd-Jones, Actress, 69
description: Jane Lloyd-Jones, a stage actress, died yesterday at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. She was 69 years old and had homes in Woodstock, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: I.B.M. Is Planning New Work Stations
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce new models today of its RS/ 6000 family of work stations. The introductions would improve performance at the top and bottom of its product line, which is designed for scientists and engineers.

title: Review/Dance; Japanese Choreography In Contemporary Works
description: The Tokyo Festival Ballet left mixed impressions on Saturday night when it performed at Queensborough Community College in Bayside.

title: Lime Said To Clean PCB Sites Easily
description: In an accidental discovery, Federal workers have found that lime appears to be an inexpensive and effective way to destroy PCB's.

title: Bridge
description: The opening day of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here on Sunday at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals was entirely lacking in drama. The field was cut from 90 to 64, and all the top-ranked teams survived without difficulty.

title: Virginia Bonds Yield Up to 6.9%
description: A $68.8 million bond issue by the Virginia State Public Building Authority was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: How the Mayor Can Help Himself
description: New York's City Hall is in crisis. That has never been more evident than now, as Mayor David Dinkins struggles to convey a sense of control over a government bedeviled by conflict and confusion as well as fiscal stringency.

title: S.E.C. Wins Insider Case
description: The Government has won a $2.7 million judgment against unidentified foreign investors for insider trading in the $6 billion merger of the Contel Corporation and the GTE Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: Annenberg Picks Met for $1 Billion Gift
description: Walter H. Annenberg, publisher, philanthropist and formerly United States Ambassador in London, said yesterday that he would bequeath roughly $1 billion worth of paintings to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Mets' Woes Grow as Fernandez Fractures Arm
description: The Mets' pitching staff, which this spring training has already undergone serious physical scares and the prolonged distractions of contract negotiations, today suffered its greatest setback yet when Sid Fernandez fractured a bone in his pitching arm and was lost for three months.

title: Market Place; Awaiting a Surge In New Offerings
description: INSPIRED by the strength of the stock market and of computer stocks in particular, many small technology companies are expected to offer stock to the public for the first time in the next few months.

title: Boeing Unit Names Jet Subcontractors
description: The Boeing Company's commercial airplane group said it had chosen four subcontractors for its new 777 jetliner. Boeing estimated the initial value of the subcontracts would be just under $1 billion. The 777 will be the world's largest twin-engined jet when it goes into service in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: The Social Events column on Sunday misstated the telephone number for tickets to a benefit on Friday for Cirque Gregoire. The number is (212) 677-1508.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bucks Top Pistons Dale Ellis came off the bench to score 30 points, including 11 in the fourth quarter, leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 96-85 victory over the struggling Detroit Pistons in Auburn Hills, Mich., last night. (AP) Spurs 105, Jazz 96: In San Antonio, David Robinson scored 33 points and Sean Elliott added 18 to give the Spurs a one-game Midwest Division lead over the Utah. Karl Malone had 34 points for Utah, which lost its third consecutive game. John Stockton had 20 assists. (AP) Trail Blazers 104, Cavaliers 96: In Portland, Ore., Clyde Drexler scored 26 points, including 12 in the third period, to help the Trail Blazers break a losing streak at two games. Jerome Kersey added 21 points, all in the first three quarters, and Kevin Duckworth grabbed a game-high 13 rebounds. Brad Daughtery led Cleveland with 24 points and 9 rebounds. (AP) DOG-SLED RACING Butcher in Lead Several top mushers traded the lead of the Iditarod trail race yesterday as they neared the Bering Sea coast. The four-time winner and defending champion, Susan Butcher, took the lead by early afternoon on the race's 10th day. She was among seven racers who had left the Kaltag, Alaska, checkpoint -- 804 miles into the 1,163-mile race from Anchorage to Nome -- by midmorning. (AP)

title: U.S.-Taiwan Trade Talks
description: Taiwan sought United States support today for its bid to enter GATT, the international trade organization.

title: Lower Gasoline Prices
description: Average gasoline prices have dropped 30.2 cents a gallon in the United States since October and are now lower than before Iraq invaded Kuwait, according to the Lundberg Survey of 13,600 gasoline stations nationwide. The average price for all grades of gasoline, including all taxes, at full- and self-service stations was $1.1688 on Friday, down 3.46 cents since Feb. 22. Prices at self-serve stations peaked at $1.4709 on Oct. 19. The July 1990 level, the last one tracked before the Aug. 2 invasion, was $1.1771, Trilby Lundberg, industry analyst, said on Sunday.

title: Experts Assess Mental Fitness Of a Defendant
description: Four psychiatrists say that Vincent (the Chin) Gigante, who prosecutors assert is the boss of the Genovese crime family, is mentally unfit to stand trial.

title: 3 Men to Argue for New Trial in '71 Police Killing
description: The killings occurred on a spring night in 1971, with the victims, two New York City police officers, not having time to draw their guns. The officers were leaving a housing project in Harlem, when they were killed in what many people saw as more than just another example of city violence.

title: Pennsylvania Ballet Calls a Halt
description: The trustees of the Pennsylvania Ballet announced yesterday that the troupe would have to suspend operations immediately because of insufficient funds.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Journalists; A Reporter in Iraq's Hands: Amid the Fear, Parlor Games
description: A week ago three Iraqi soldiers pulled me and a colleague from our Land-Rover in southern Iraq, shoved us into the back seat and sped off into the desert.

title: Ouster From Budget Panel Irks Senator
description: Senator Charles S. Robb's fellow Democrats took the unusual step last week of quietly ousting him from the Senate Budget Committee, and today he accused the panel's chairman of engineering the move to punish him for his fiscal conservatism.

title: Protests by the Serbs Widen in Belgrade
description: Anti-Communist protests widened today in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, and the ruling Socialist Party responded with a huge deployment of police officers on the streets and its own loyalist demonstration of workers.

title: James H. Meisel, 90, Political Scientist, Dies
