description: James Hans Meisel, professor emeritus of political science at the University of Michigan, died March 2 at his home in Bellevue, Wash. He was 90 years old.

title: Knicks Recover in Time to Defeat Nets
description: It was weird, and at times the play was wretched. But when it was over, last night's game was another victory for the Knicks.

title: American P.O.W. Hurt Himself, CBS Reports
description: Lieut. Jeffrey Norton Zaun, one of the Navy pilots captured by the Iraqis during bombing raids in the gulf war, told military officers who interviewed him that some of the wounds to his face were self-inflicted in an attempt to discourage his captors from displaying him on television, CBS News reported last night.

title: Eastern Germany: In Despair - Last of three articles.; Privatization in Eastern Germany Is Mired in a Collapsing Economy
description: For Sale: Thousands of eastern German companies, most in dilapidated condition with disputed ownership, dubious management, outmoded products, vanishing markets, heavy debts and thousands of unnecessary employees. Everything from beauty parlors to shipyards must go.

title: Suns' Chambers Fined
description: Tom Chambers of the Phoenix Suns was fined $2,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for throwing a punch at Kevin Willis of the Hawks in a game last Thursday.(AP)

title: Business Scene; The 'Right' Price For Oil in the U.S.
description: THE gulf war made one thing clear: Even with Iraq and Kuwait not producing, the Middle East can flood the world with enough oil to push crude oil prices down to $15 a barrel and perhaps lower. The United States, in sum, might find itself back in the old days of cheap oil. Is that good news for the American economy? Or would $10-a-barrel oil, once such a blessing, be a curse today?

title: Grand Jury Views Taped Beating
description: A Los Angeles County grand jury opened hearings today into the police beating of a black motorist, and demands for the resignation of Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Los Angeles police continued to mount with the repeated broadcast of a videotape of the beating.

title: Chip Maker Posts Profit
description: Buoyed by a restructuring credit from the sale of a plant, the National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a profit for its third quarter. But revenues fell, and the company realized no operating profit.

title: Don't Whitewash Chile's '73 Coup
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; The Long and Short of Hair
description: Last week the Milan fashion shows made it official. The world's most gorgeous models paraded down the runways, flaunting and tossing their long manes. The big head of hair is back.

title: Uneasily, South Africa Exiles Return
description: Joel Diamond came home smiling from more than 27 hard years of foreign exile, steering a luggage-laden cart through the airport terminal with his left hand while he thrust his right fist skyward in the salute of the African National Congress.

title: Morality's The Thing For This Playwright
description: Back in 1979, Steve Tesich won an Academy Award for "Breaking Away," a delightful tale of youths and bicycles in the Indiana countryside. It was Mr. Tesich's first movie, and he got the Oscar for best original screenplay. Now 12 years have passed, and nothing he has done on stage or screen has quite matched that success. But if you ask the 48-year-old playwright and screen writer about it, he'll say it doesn't much matter.

title: Prosecutor Calls Flake a Tax Cheat
description: Representative Floyd H. Flake and his wife, Margarett, were portrayed by a prosecutor yesterday as tax cheats who abused their position of trust.

title: A 16-Year-Old Virginia Youth Is Charged in 2 Boys' Deaths
description: A 16-year-old youth was charged Saturday with capital murder in the deaths of two boys whose bodies were found dumped in a wooded area near a lake.

title: Dunning the Soviets Proves Tough
description: As a medium-sized maker of paper-handling equipment, the Zerand-Bernal Group Inc. of New Berlin, Wis., has been stung by its share of deadbeats. But company executives say that in all their years of running a business they have never faced a debtor as recalcitrant as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: Patterns
description: Lanvin's 'Strategy'

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel; Israelis Kill 6 Armed Arabs Entering From Jordan
description: Israeli troops shot and killed six heavily armed Arab gunmen who had crossed the border from Jordan this morning, hours before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived for talks intended to foster Arab-Israeli peace, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 4 Unions at Daily News Reach a Tentative Deal
description: Leaders of four unions at The Daily News reached agreements on tentative contracts last night with Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who is seeking to buy the newspaper.

title: Review/Jazz; Euphoric Drumming by Elvin Jones
description: As a member of the John Coltrane quartet in the early 1960's, Elvin Jones completely rewrote jazz drumming. In the process, he changed the nature of both jazz and American music. And he did it simply: where jazz drumming had previously been linear, a series of sequential events following a rigid pattern, he made it seem instead as if several series of events were happening at once, all equally important. If jazz drumming had been a river flowing down a tight course, then Mr. Jones made it into an ocean.

title: Wal-Mart Keeps Gaining on Sears
description: Who's the nation's No. 1 retailer? Wal-Mart or Sears? That is one of the most frequently asked questions in retailing these days. The fact that Wal-Mart, which is less than 50 years old, has been able to catch up to Sears, which dates from the 19th century, testifies to Wal-Mart's rapid growth -- and to Sears's recent decline.

title: Can You Like a Roach? You Might Be Surprised
description: IF absence makes the heart grow fonder, then perhaps the moment has arrived to consider a modest celebration of the cockroach.

title: Weicker, Citing Union Delay, Says More Staff May Be Cut
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that unions representing state workers had failed to give any "positive response" in negotiations over givebacks to reduce Connecticut's budget deficit and that he would re-examine his budget plan for further cuts in personnel.

title: INSIDE
description: The Newest Republican Saying independence "is not enough," Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana announced his switch from the Democratic Party to the G.O.P. Page A16. Teaching an Abortion Law A Michigan law requires schools to tell students how to seek an abortion without parental consent. Page A16. 4 Pacts at Daily News Robert Maxwell reached agreement with four unions in his attempt to buy the paper. Page B1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carter Cafritz Corp., Washington, a real estate and investment holding company, named Robert N. Eisman president. * Columbia Pictures Television, Burbank, Calif., a subsidiary of the Columbia Pictures Enertainment Co., named William F. Phillips senior vice president-film production.

title: Transit User Groups Still Giving Support To M.T.A. Nominee
description: Advocates for subway, bus and railroad riders yesterday reaffirmed their support for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's choice to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. They said that allegations of impropriety involving the nominee, Peter E. Stangl, seemed minor in comparison to the problems faced by the agency, which oversees the region's network of commuter railroads, subways and buses.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say
description: Troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq shelled Shiite Muslim rebels in mosques in the holy city of Karbala, and Iraqi soldiers defected by the tens of thousands elsewhere, opposition leaders said today.

title: Bridgestone Plans To Lay Off 425
description: Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. said it would lay off 425 employees at two tire plants. The announcement came as the company began talks with the United Rubber Workers on a new three-year contract. A company spokesman, Bob Troyer, said 165 hourly workers and 20 salaried employees had been told they would be laid off from the company's passenger and light-truck tire plant in Decatur, Ill. The factory has 1,520 hourly and 300 salaried employees.

title: Head of Waldenbooks Chain Steps Down
description: Harry T. Hoffman, who built Waldenbooks into a $1 billion business that helped to revolutionize book publishing, surprised the industry yesterday by retiring as president and chief executive of the 1,300-store chain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDY BOGGS has more to celebrate than her birthday when she turns 75 years old tomorrow. She has been chosen to receive the University of Notre Dame's prestigious Laetare Medal. The university's highest honor, it has been given to distinguished Roman Catholics since 1883.

title: Marlon Brando Agrees to Tell His Life Story
description: Random House has paid a seven-figure sum for the world rights to Marlon Brando's autobiography, a book sought for many years by publishers but persistently resisted by the reclusive actor.

title: Washington Talk; Congress Stumbles On Honors For Welk
description: Congress hardly ever got into as much trouble over $500,000 as it did last fall, when it appropriated that sum to develop a museum at Lawrence Welk's birthplace in Strasburg, N.D.

title: Cramer-Krasselt Office Is Moen's New Agency
description: Moen Inc., a maker of faucets and other plumbing products, has given its advertising account to the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt.

title: Pre-Derby Pastime: Avoiding Fly So Free
description: Some were running sizzling workouts and hoping for the best. Some were running sizzling races and hoping for more. But most were just running for the hills to avoid tangling with him: Fly So Free, the winter-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby and so far king of the hill among the nation's 3-year-old candidates for this year's racing classics.

title: Budget Politics: How One Agency Copes - A special report.; Delicate Balance: Park Priorities and Cost Cutting
description: The Department of Parks and Recreation is trying to trim $17 million from its $185 million budget, a tortuous exercise that provides a window on the political maneuvering and public balancing act that shapes the budget process in New York City.

title: Fayetteville Journal; Children of Soldiers Relearning Childhood
description: For months, pupils at the Benjamin J. Martin Elementary School here have been talking to the school counselor about their nightmares: Scud missile attacks, tanks out of control and fighter planes shot from the sky.

title: Harold Blumenfeld, Editor, 85
description: Harold Blumenfeld, former executive editor for news pictures at United Press International, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 85 years old and lived in Hallandale, Fla.

title: Hotel Executive to Run New Burger King Unit
description: Completing a management alignment undertaken by its British owners, the Burger King Corporation has named a hotel executive, Barry L. Conrad, to direct the franchise side of the business.

title: Donald Murdoch Frame, 79, Dies; Expert on Montaigne and Rabelais
description: Donald Murdoch Frame, a French scholar and an authority on the works of Montaigne and Rabelais, died on Friday at the Woodbine Convalescent Care Center in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Satellite Data Adapted For Everyday Users
description: IN research for military intelligence, scientists at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico have developed a new technique that greatly speeds the analysis of satellite images and are now adapting it for use in crop forecasting, land-use studies, pollution monitoring and mineral and oil prospecting.

title: Kocur May Be Skating on Borrowed Time
description: A loophole in the legal code of the National Hockey League may allow Joe Kocur of the Rangers to be available for a home game Wednesday night against the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Square D Says It's Holding Talks
description: The Square D Company said today that it was in talks, and analysts said the electrical equipment maker appeared to be seeking a friendly party to prevent a hostile takeover by Groupe Schneider S.A. of France.

title: Maine Gets No. 1 Seeding
description: Maine (30-8-2) and Lake Superior State (35-3-4) are the top-seeded teams in the 12-team National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

title: Frances Weitzenhoffer, an Editor And Art Historian, Is Dead at 46
description: Frances Weitzenhoffer, an art historian, editor and specialist in Impressionist painting, died on Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 46 years old.

title: Baseball's Next Black Manager
description: When asked about his life now as the Milwaukee Brewers' batting coach, Don Baylor laughed and rubbed one of his huge hands across his head.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iran; For U.S. and Iran, a Chance for Ties
description: Iraq's military defeat and the prospect of creating new security arrangements for the Persian Gulf provide an opportunity for the United States and Iran to repair their long-tattered relationship -- if the two sides choose to do so.

title: Under Brennan's Leadership
description: Aug. 8, 1990: Edward A. Brennan replaced Michael Bozic as chief executive of the Sears Merchandise Group. Sept. 14: Consolidated various management jobs at Sears Tower and Offered buyouts to 600 people. Sept. 24: Reduced catalogue unit by 213 people. Dec. 5: Froze 1991 salaries at current levels for 20,000 non-hourly employees. Jan. 3, 1991: Confirmed that 21,000 jobs at 863 retail stores would be eliminated by June. Jan. 10: Announced that 47 McKids stores would be closed by the end of the first quarter. Jan. 30: Addressed rumors about the catalogue business, saying, "Reports that we have decided to sell or close our catalogue business are false." Feb. 11: Announced that job cuts in his group would reach 33,000 by year-end.

title: U.S. Proposes Rules on Disabled in the Workplace
description: The Bush Administration has issued another set of proposed rules for carrying out the new Americans With Disabilities Act, this time on hiring and accommodating disabled workers.

title: Diplomats' Kin Back to Mideast
description: The United States said today that it was allowing non-essential personnel and diplomats' dependents to return to much of the Middle East after pulling them out because of the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: Poison Gas: Only Part of the Problem
description: Reflecting his Persian Gulf war experience, President Bush last week issued a highly welcome pronouncement: The U.S. is tightening controls over exports of chemicals and equipment for arms-making. That's a hopeful, if small, sign that Mr. Bush intends to try stopping the spread of sophisticated arms at the source. But why stop at that?

title: Dr. Harold Marcus, 68, A Psychiatrist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Harold Marcus, an attending psychiatrist at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, died on Saturday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: New Campaigns
description: * While other New York restaurants may employ struggling actors as waiters, Smith & Wollensky, the New York steak house, would like diners to know that its waiters are just that, waiters, with no theatrical ability. In a 30-second television spot that will appear in New York beginning on March 18, the restuarant's waiters butcher famous lines from the stage and screen. "Badges," one waiter mumbles, "we don't need no stinking badges," paraphrasing a line from the film "Treasure of the Sierra Madre." The spot was created by Buckley DeCerchio Cavalier Inc., New York. * By using computer graphics and special backdrops, a new ad for Kool-Aid gives a group of children cartoon-like qualities. In the fast-paced ad, one boy's eyes spin around like a slot machine while a girl rides a geyser of Kool-Aid through the chimney of a house. The 30-second television spot was created by Grey Advertising Inc.

title: Suicide in Alaska
description: The suicide rate for young male Alaska natives is more than twice the rate for young white men in the nation as a whole, two Pennsylvania scientists have reported.

title: Wrestler Is Winner Of Sullivan Award
description: John Smith, a world champion the last four years, yesterday became the first wrestler to win the Amateur Athletic Union's Sullivan Award. The award is presented each year to the nation's outstanding amateur athlete.

title: Review/Television; A 60's Radical Who Retains His Idealism
description: The growing number of lawyer shows on television these days could easily leave viewers with the impression that they are taking law courses in night school. Coming on line this evening at 10 o'clock on ABC is "Eddie Dodd," starring Treat Williams. The series is a temporary replacement for "Thirtysomething," described by the network as "on hiatus" until April 23.

title: Norway's Other Peace Prize Given to Lithuania's Leader
description: President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania received a peace prize from the Norwegian public today, on the first anniversary of the Baltic republic's declaration of independence.

title: No Godzilla Trucks on the Interstates
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Parkinson, Circus Archivist, 67
description: Bob Parkinson, who helped to build one of the largest circus archives in the world, died Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Madison after heart surgery. He was 67 years old and lived in Baraboo, Wis.

title: Put In Bank Card, Pull Out Stamps
description: Banks around the country will be allowed to sell stamps from their automatic teller machines, the Postal Service announced today.

title: Nickelodeon to Offer Music Videos
description: Nickelodeon, the cable channel for children, plans to begin a music video program aimed at creating a new marketplace for children's music.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Technology; U.S. Tells of Prewar Technology Sales to Iraq Worth $500 Million
description: Facing growing scrutiny of trade policy toward Iraq in the years before the Persian Gulf war, the Commerce Department today made public a list of $500 million in advanced American manufactured goods that it said were sold with its blessing to Iraqi Government agencies and private concerns from 1985 until Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwaiti Politics; A New Divide for Kuwaitis: Who Stayed and Who Fled
description: For many of the men and women who stayed, this nation has been divided into camps, between those Kuwaitis who remained here to witness the brutal seven-month occupation by Iraq and the majority of their countrymen who chose instead to flee.

title: Brooklyn Fire Severs Service On 3 Subway Lines All Day
description: An early-morning fire in Brooklyn that caused the partial collapse of a building yesterday prompted the suspension of subway service all day on the J, M and Z lines to Manhattan.

title: Big Slovak Rally Seeks A Break With Prague
description: Tens of thousands of Slovak separatists shouting, "Enough of Prague!" today staged one of their biggest demonstrations for independence from the Czechoslovak federation in Slovakia's capital, Bratislava.

title: Nicholas Martini, Public Official, 86
description: Nicholas Martini, a former Mayor of Passaic who was active in Passaic County and state Republican politics, died on Sunday at the General Hospital Center in Passaic. He was 86 years old.

title: Key Rates
Official Presses Bush On Nuclear Security
description: A SENIOR Congressman who has repeatedly exposed gaps in the security of the nation's nuclear arms complex yesterday pressed the Bush Administration for information on whether nuclear weapons in Europe were as safe as they should be from sabotage and theft.

title: Ann Taylor's Sales Up 20.2% in Month
description: Ann Taylor Inc., the New York-based fashion chain, said its February sales rose 20.2 percent, to $27.7 million, from $23.1 million the year before, while its same-store sales were up 5.1 percent. Same-store sales are those recorded in stores open at least a year. Ann Taylor operates 173 stores.

title: Army in Lebanon Seizes Militias' Smuggling Ports
description: The Lebanese Army said today that it had seized ports north and south of Beirut that had long been controlled by rival militias. The militias fought each other during Lebanon's 16 years of civil strife.

title: Johnson & Johnson Has New Product
description: Using peat moss instead of synthetics, Johnson & Johnson has developed a natural extra-thin sanitary napkin that it says absorbs 12 times its weight in liquid. The brownish peat pads began appearing on grocery shelves in Canada several weeks ago, a spokesman, Robert Kniffin, said. The company, based in New Brunswick, plans to sell the product in the United States but will not say when.

title: Florio School Aid Plan Cut; Homeowners Get Tax Relief
description: A bill that greatly revises Gov. Jim Florio's controversial tax and education program of last year gained final passage in the Legislature tonight. It shifts $360 million from school aid to property-tax relief.

title: More Physicians Broach Forbidden Subject of Euthanasia
description: THE taboo against doctors' discussing how they helped dying patients commit suicide seems to be ending.

title: Washington State Health Care Issue
description: The Washington Health Care Facilities Authority yesterday tentatively priced $80.1 million in revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.46 percent for an issue due in 2018.

title: Iraq to Return the Dead
description: Iraq said today that it would turn over the remains of 14 allied military personnel killed in the Persian Gulf war to the Red Cross.

title: Webster Retires
description: Mike Webster, a perennial Pro Bowl center and a mainstay on Pittsburgh's four Super Bowl champions, retired yesterday after a 17-year career. Webster, who will be 39 years old Monday, spent his last two seasons with the Kansas City Chiefs. (AP)

title: W.B.O. Vacates Title
description: The World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title that Greg Haugen won last month from Hector Camacho has been declared vacant by the W.B.O. because a post-fight drug test revealed traces of marijuana in Haugen's system, Ed Levine, the president of the W.B.O.'s championships committee, said yesterday. Levine said the organization had ordered a rematch.

title: Papandreou, Accused of Taking Bribes, Goes on Trial in Athens
description: Prosecutors today accused former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of taking bribes in return for ordering state companies to deposit money in a troubled private bank.

title: Facing Cuts, Arts Lobbyists Plan to Alter Their Approach in Albany
description: "Nuts to cuts!" say the placards and banners being carried by some 200 lobbyists to Albany for Arts Day today.

title: Sequels of Hit Films Now Often Loser
description: Rumors were circulating in Hollywood last week that 10-year-old Macaulay Culkin, who was paid $100,000 to appear in "Home Alone," was being offered several million to star in the sequel.

title: Printers Catching Up
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC., which has achieved remarkable success in the last five months with its low-cost Macintosh Classic and Macintosh LC personal computers, now has a pair of low-cost, laser-quality personal printers to go along with them.

title: J. L. Bergstresser, 87, Ex-City College Dean
description: Dr. John L. Bergstresser, an educator who was dean of students at City College of New York in the 1940's, died on Feb. 24 at his home in San Francisco. He was 87 years old.

title: Scripps Clinic Gains in Lawsuit
description: The Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation won a round in its patent infringement suit against Genentech Inc., Miles Inc. and Chiron Inc. over recombinant Factor VIII, a genetically engineered protein that prompts blood clotting for hemophiliacs. The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington overturned a 1989 ruling of the Federal District Court in San Francisco, which held that Scripps's patent on Factor VIII was invalid and had been obtained through fraud.

title: Virgin Atlantic Cutting Fares
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways said today that it was cutting its trans-Atlantic fares by 15 percent and offering other promotional fares. Certain New York flights are being offered for as little as $184 one way.

title: Careers; Technology Help Needed In Northeast
description: AFTER a period of broad prosperity in the early 1980's, thanks mainly to the high-technology industry centered on Boston, the Northeast finds itself going through a recession more severe than that in most parts of the country.

title: 'What's My Line' Panel Was Allowed to Look
description: To the Editor:

title: Young & Rubicam Ends Plan for TV Production
description: Joe De Deo, president and chief executive of Young & Rubicam Advertising, confirmed a report in Advertising Age yesterday that the agency had dropped plans to become involved in television production.

title: A TURKISH GESTURE TO KURDS FALTERS
description: A Government plan to soften language restrictions long imposed on Turkey's Kurdish minority has stumbled in Parliament and may die there, a victim of nationalist fears and political maneuvering.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Arabs; Key Parts of Statement By the Arab Ministers
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by the Foreign Ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Syria after talks on Sunday with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Saudi Arabia, as translated by Reuters:

title: A Standoff As OPEC Talks Open
description: OPEC ministers, after jousting with one another today over cutting oil production quotas, failed to reach an accord and scheduled another meeting for Tuesday morning.

title: I.B.M. Forms Alliance Against NEC in Japan
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, revamping its strategy in Japan, said today that 11 major Japanese computer makers would join it in a concerted attack on the NEC Corporation, which dominates the highly fragmented personal computer market here.

title: Yerevan Journal; Down With Communism? Armenians Lift a Glass
description: For the Soviet vineyards' eerie commingling of Bolshevism and bouquet, Edvard L. Hakopyan, the master of Armenian cognac, bears not only a Hero of Socialist Labor medal but also a great nose.

title: Limiting Fat in Diet Is Simply Prudent
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Clean on Goods: Ecology Claims Faulted
description: Under pressure to make their goods look clean and green, many consumer-products companies are making changes in their packaging more on the basis of marketing studies than environmental findings.

title: A Shunned Man of Peace
description: When the Dalai Lama comes to the U.S. next week to open the Year of Tibet, a cultural celebration coinciding with the 32d anniversary of the Chinese takeover of his land, he will scarcely be welcomed by the Administration. It will be yet another of the anomalies in which history seems to be so abundant of late: My former enemy's former friend is now my enemy.

title: Louisiana's Governor Shifts To G.O.P. in Career Gamble
description: In a gamble to save his career and stave off a challenge from a former Ku Klux Klan leader, Gov. Buddy Roemer announced today that he had abandoned the Democratic Party to become a Republican.

title: Peru Unlikely To Get Help
description: Peru, which is pressed for cash, is unlikely to receive assistance from big countries soon to help it bridge an $800 million fiscal gap, despite the end of the Persian Gulf war, the nation's President, Alberto Fujimori, said last week.

title: Review/Theater; Harvey Fierstein as a Loud Mourner
description: Harvey Fierstein has never been an actor one could call demure. The creator and star of "Torch Song Trilogy" is a bellowing clown and operatic ham who suggests a fire-breathing combination of Lucille Ball, Elmer Fudd and a dancing bear. In the revival of Robert Patrick's 1964 play, "The Haunted Host," at La Mama, Mr. Fierstein almost literally chews the scenery playing Jay Astor, a gay Greenwich Village writer mourning the suicide of his roommate and unrequited lover, Ed.

title: Gap Chief in Sale
description: The chairman of Gap Inc., Donald G. Fisher, sold about a million common shares of his holdings in the company, Warren R. Hashagen, the Gap's treasurer, said in response to a question on the company's stock activity today. He said the shares sold represented less than 6 percent of Mr. Fisher's total holdings in the Gap, the San Francisco-based specialty retailer of women's clothes. The Gap's stock fell $2.625 today, to $46.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Thirst for Action on Night Radio Patrol
description: The clock read 23:20, the end of his tour. He had to drive home to Long Island and be back early the next day for grand jury. But Lieut. Walter Conklin was in no hurry to quit for the night.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Egypt; Baker Tells Cairo He'll Put in a Good Word With the I.M.F.
description: Declaring that the United States is encouraged by Egypt's progress in reforming its economy, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he hoped to press Cairo's case for further help from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED BY U.S. AND BRITAIN ON AIRLINE SERVICE
description: The United States and Britain reached an agreement yesterday that will have a broad impact on trans- Atlantic airlines and their passengers. One immediate result is that Pan American World Airways, on the brink of shutting down, will continue to fly.

title: Treasury Issues Advance in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and long-term interest rates fell rather sharply in slow trading yesterday, as credit market participants reacted positively to a big drop in commodity prices.

title: A Hot Ticket Becomes a No-Show
description: A local television crew showed up before the game to see George Steinbrenner. It heard he was coming to watch the Yankees play the Atlanta Braves this afternoon at Fort Lauderdale Stadium. Others heard the same rumor.

title: A State's Fight to Save Babies Enters Round 2
description: Mississippi has turned infant mortality statistics that were once the nation's worst into those that many states envy. But now comes the hard part.

title: Marcos Heirs Sue Philippines
description: The former First Lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos, and her children today demanded the return of all family property seized by President Corazon Aquino's Government. In a petition filed by their lawyers with the Supreme Court, the family of the late President Ferdinand E. Marcos contended that all his property should be turned over to them "in the same manner that the heirs of the known gangsters in the United States, Al Capone, Dillinger inherited their fortunes."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about politics in Turkey misidentified the post that President Turgut Ozal is seeking for his wife, Semra. He is trying to place her in charge of the Istanbul branch of the Motherland Party, not of the entire party.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Saturday misstated the number of hotels in a chain that Accor S.A. said it intended to buy for $100 million. It is 50, not 100.

title: Microsoft's Mouse
description: The Microsoft Corporation said it had developed the first computer mouse designed to work with laptop computers. The pointing device, which is used to manipulate an on-screen arrow and to execute commands, has previously needed a flat surface like a desk or tabletop to operate. Consequently, a mouse has been awkward when used with portable computers. The ball in Microsoft's new mouse sits on top and is rotated using the thumb or index finger. The mouse, which has a recommended retail price of $175, is designed to work with Microsoft's Windows graphics program.

title: Fed Penalizes Italian Bank
description: Federal regulators penalized an Italian bank today that had made secret loans to Iraq through its Atlanta office.

title: Britain Pleased, but British Airways Is Not
description: Obviously jubilant, Transport Secretary Malcolm Rifkind said today that Britain had wrung "a massive package of benefits" for British airlines and consumers in its pact with the United States. In return, Britain will allow American Airlines and United Airlines to use London's Heathrow Airport.

title: Romolo Angelone, Former Diplomat, 94
description: Romolo Angelone, a former Italian commercial attache in New York and Washington and later a businessman in this country, died on Thursday at the home of his son in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 94 years old and lived in Lake Worth, Fla.

title: Sallie Mae Notes Total $850 Million
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced a total of $850 million in notes yesterday.

title: Sears Struggles to Remain No. 1
description: For a host of reasons, Sears, Roebuck & Company's much ballyhooed strategy to lure shoppers with more brand names and lower prices is not working the way the company had hoped. Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive, is convinced it will, but to buy the time he believes he needs, he is focusing on increasing profits by trying to cut costs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War A12-14

title: Dinkins Vows Broader Role In Fiscal Issues
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, facing criticism that his administration's fiscal policy was adrift, vowed yesterday to take a "much further personal involvement" in "all areas" of managing the city's fiscal affairs.

title: Bernard Rosenquit, Artist, Is Dead at 68
description: Bernard Rosenquit, an artist known for his woodcuts and oil paintings, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bush Sends Crime Bill to Congress, Reviving Hotly Debated Proposals
description: Urging Congressional action within 100 days, President Bush today sent lawmakers an anticrime bill that revives Administration proposals that died last year in a fractious debate on Capitol Hill.

title: Sizing Up the Cosmos: An Astronomer's Quest
description: IN the mornings before smog dims the sky like a dirty nebula, Dr. Allan R. Sandage can stand at his office window and see, if not the beginning of the universe, or its end, at least the summit where astronomers first came to the stunning realization that they just might be able to comprehend the origin and fate of space and time, of everything.

title: Review/Fashion; Muir's Silver Moment: Luster, but No Glare
description: Jean Muir, the jewel in the crown of British fashion, presented her fall collection in her showroom as unpretentiously as always. A television crew beginning a four-part documentary on her career was the only sign that something special was going on. She was celebrating her 25th year as the head of her own company.

title: Books of The Times; Once Again, a Madman Who Likes to Kill Women
description: Chicago Loop By Paul Theroux 196 pages. Random House. $20.

title: High-Rise Fires Could Come to New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Health Properties Inc., Los Angeles, which operates health-care homes, will buy the Irvine Medical Center in Irvine, Calif., from American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif. The price is $75 million. * Chicago Title and Trust Co., Chicago, has completed the acquisition of Ticor Title Insurance Cos., Los Angeles, from Westwood Equities Corp. The price was $52 million.

title: Variety Inc. Fills Post
description: Peter Bart, editor of Weekly Variety, has been named to the new post of editorial director of Variety Inc., to coordinate editorial direction and management of both Daily and Weekly Variety and to maximize information resources at each.

title: 2 Million Blacks Not Counted, Head of Census Panel Asserts
description: The Census Bureau's 1990 population figures came under renewed scrutiny today as an analysis by the staff of Representative Thomas C. Sawyer, who heads the bureau's oversight committee, said the census probably missed more than two million blacks.

title: Our Towns; Young and Old Mull Tomorrow And Tomorrow
description: Sheila Henry has a trio of new students in her honors Shakespeare class at Wilton High School this semester. They don't take all the tests. They sometimes fall behind in their daily journal entries. But they never whisper in class. They see literature's relevance to life. And they are not distracted by the non-academic priorities of teen-age life.

title: Soviets Manage a Strong Showing
description: For all the vagaries of track and field, some truths remain, and that was apparent once again on Sunday when the third world indoor championships ended with the Soviet Union maintaining its position as the dominant country in the event.

title: Rig Count Nearly Steady
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas fell by one last week, to a total of 948, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The Houston-based oilfield tool supplier said the count was ahead of the level a year ago, when there were 923 working rigs nationwide.

title: Hostages in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Appointment At Crossland
description: Robert B. Goldstein yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Crossland Savings, one of the nation's largest savings institutions. He is assuming some of the duties held by Maurice L. Reissman.

title: School Aid Plan Is Revised
description: New Jersey legislators gave final approval to a plan to revise Gov. Jim Florio's controversial tax and education program. Under the new plan, $360 million that was to be used for school aid will go instead to municipalities in an effort to reduce property taxes.

title: How to Lose the Peace
description: Only yesterday, the United States showed how swiftly it could win a war in the Middle East. Now the United States is showing how swiftly it might lose a peace in the Middle East.

title: Samuel Ramey in a Series
description: The bass Samuel Ramey, the pianist Mitsuko Uchida, the actress Stockard Channing and the vibraphonist Lionel Hampton are to be guests in this season's Lincoln Center Off Stage series. Mr. Ramey is to appear tonight, Miss Uchida on April 14, Miss Channing on April 28 and Mr. Hampton on June 19. A series subscription is $45; single tickets are $13. Information: (212) 877-1800, extension 633.

title: Germs and Phones
description: Q. Can disease germs lurk on telephone receivers? What about coins and bills?

title: Quebec Liberals Waver on Call for Independence
description: Quebec's ruling Liberal Party has formally adopted a program that puts the rest of Canada on notice that Quebec will move to independence unless the French-speaking province is given sweeping new constitutional powers.

title: J. Read Smith, Lawyer In Brooklyn, Dies at 80
description: J. Read Smith, a lawyer for more than 50 years, died on Friday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: L. A. Cops, Taped in the Act
description: What if there had been no videotape of the three Los Angeles police officers clubbing, kicking and stomping Rodney Glen King while about 10 more stood and watched? There would have been just one more bruised and broken black or Hispanic "perpetrator" who somehow was injured after being routinely stopped in traffic. Police brutality? Mr. King's complaints would have been dismissed as wild allegations. A grand jury hearing in the case, which began yesterday, probably would not have taken place.

title: Jordan Link Reported for Spies Slain in Syria
description: Two undercover agents who were killed by Syrian terrorists last fall, apparently after the United States compromised their identities during a diplomatic exchange with Syria, were working inside Syria for Jordan's state intelligence service, several Bush Administration officials say.

title: The F.C.C. Goes Hollywood
description: Something bizarre is taking place at the Federal Communications Commission. On Thursday the commission is scheduled to approve strict new syndication and ownership rules governing the television networks. That would represent a surprising change of direction, a stunning victory for the major Hollywood studios -- which fear competition from the networks -- and a loss for the consumer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HARRY CALLAHAN and ANDREAS FEININGER are to be honored by the International Center of Photography. Mr. Callahan, 78 years old, will be honored as one of the art's most influential teachers and a master of black-and-white photography, and Mr. Feininger, 84, for his life's work of capturing revealing images of America's cities and architecture.

title: EARLY VOTE CLOSE IN BENIN'S ELECTION
description: Early returns in Benin's presidential election suggested today that a runoff might be necessary between Prime Minister Nicephore Soglo, the front-runner, and the Marxist-Leninist President, Brig. Gen. Mathieu Kerekou, whose power was eclipsed more than a year ago but who made an unexpectedly strong showing in Sunday's voting.

title: High-Tech Stocks Lead Market Decline
description: High-tech stocks tumbled yesterday in heavy trading, and the broader market weakened as well despite clear signs that the Federal Reserve eased monetary policy over the weekend.

title: 2 Network Stocks Fall
description: Stock in both CBS Inc. and Capital Cities/ABC Inc. fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted to reports that the Federal Communications Commission would not dramatically change its program syndication and financial interest rules in favor of the three television networks.

title: New York Acts to Lift Pit Bull Controls
description: The pit bull terrier, widely feared and, in the eyes of owners, maligned and misunderstood, had a taste of sweet vindication yesterday.

title: Former Keating Associate Pleads Guilty to Bond Fraud
description: The former president of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association pleaded guilty today to two Federal securities fraud charges in connection with the criminal investigation of the defunct institution and its former owner, Charles H. Keating Jr.

title: Robert C. Wilson, 75, Lawyer and Reservist
description: Robert C. Wilson, a lawyer, corporate official and retired major general in the Army Reserve, died on Friday at the King Street Nursing Home in Rye Brook, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Auction Houses Are Being Drawn To Unified Germany
description: The man who will represent Sotheby's in Berlin spends a lot of time conferring with builders these days. The newest outpost of the London auction house is a soaring neo-classical palace, just off the boulevard Unter den Linden, that bears the burden of Prussian history on its walls. Built by a merchant in the 18th century, it was bequeathed to Frederick the Great when business failed. Transformed into the Prussian Finance Ministry in the 19th century, it became the seat of the Soviet-German Friendship Society when the Red Army marched into Berlin and planted Communist rulers in the eastern portion of the city.

title: Pathfinder Between Computer And Music
description: IF you've been thinking about taking the plunge into making music with the help of a computer, or if you've already taken the plunge without quite knowing what you're doing, The Book of MIDI, by Steven Rappaport, may be just what you need.

title: A Triple Axel With Rippling Effects
description: At the moment she took off on a triple axel jump last month in the United States national figure skating championships, Tonya Harding was just another skater in search of distinction. The moment she landed, she found that distinction, but to a degree she could never have imagined.

title: Judge Acts to Guard Alaskan Tribes
description: A Federal district judge directed the United States and the State of Alaska today to guarantee that 5,000 Alaska natives would not be harmed by a proposed $1.2 billion settlement of lawsuits arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Duke of Badajoz, 56, Lawyer and Art Patron
description: Luis Gomez-Acebo, the Duke of Badajoz, died on Saturday at his home in Madrid. He was 56 years old and died of cancer.

title: New Date for Appeal
description: Bobby Brown, president of the American League, yesterday gave representatives of Roger Clemens until March 22 to file a brief in the appeal by the Boston Red Sox pitcher of a five-day suspension and a $10,000 fine for his fiery confrontation with Terry Cooney, the home-plate umpire, in Game 4 of last year's American League Championship Series.

title: Policy on Bank Workers Defended
description: The nation's senior banking regulator, L. William Seidman, came under heavy attack today at a Congressional hearing on the plight of bank workers who lost their jobs and benefits after their institutions collapsed.

title: NCR Plunges After Rebuff
description: The stock of the NCR Corporation dropped $2.25 a share yesterday, to $96, after the company rebuffed A.T.& T.'s attempt to negotiate a friendly deal at a higher price.

title: Ammirati Drops Next Inc., Fearing Conflict With Nikon
description: AMMIRATI & PURIS has resigned the estimated $4 million account for Next Inc., the Redwood City, Calif., computer company, because of the possibility that Next and Ammirati's newest client, the Nikon Photo Group will produce competing products.

title: We Rose Above Reality
description: Celebrating another wedding anniversary the other day so soon after the death of Arthur Murray, I decided to irritate our children. They are now adult enough to endure a little irritation, and afterward when I've gone off to bed it probably enhances their sense of maturity to sit around the kitchen table complaining that they have a lot to put up with.

title: Elizabeth Ulman Rowe, Civic Leader, 79
description: Elizabeth Ulman Rowe, former chairwoman of the National Capital Planning Commission and a leader in urban beautification, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. She was 79 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Failed Anti-Qaddafi Effort Leaves U.S. Picking Up the Pieces
description: A two-year-old covert policy to destabilize Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi with United States-trained Libyan commandos has ended in failure, with Washington going to great lengths to find a safe place of exile for hundreds of dissident Libyan fighters it once supported and trained, United States officials said.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $900 million in debt securities and warrants to buy debt securities. * Employee Benefit Plans Inc., Minneapolis, filed for $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Sonics Are Counting on Benjamin to Become an Intimidating Force
description: Forget that Benoit Benjamin once showed up for a Los Angeles Clippers' exhibition game with two left sneakers. Forget, too, that he has battled weight problems, been called immature and been accused of lacking hustle and initiative.

title: Changes in Brain Alter Emotions
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Bids Bring Many Complaints
description: The most intriguing events of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament -- aside from the actual games -- come the day the 64-team field is announced, and the day after.

title: U.S. Reviewing Policy On Protecting Hybrids
description: THE Federal Government is revising its position on the issue of whether hybrid animals merit protection under the Endangered Species Act.

title: Heinz Net Up 10% in Period
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its profit increased 10 percent in the third quarter as sales rose 14.3 percent and the value of the dollar fell against foreign currencies.

title: Janet Jackson Signs Lucrative Contract
description: Janet Jackson has signed what is believed to be the most lucrative contract in the history of recording. The 24-year-old singer, songwriter and actress signed an exclusive contract with Virgin Records it was announced yesterday.

title: North Carolina Faces Loss of U.S. Aid for Cleanup
description: The Environmental Protection Agency threatened today to withhold more than $12 million in Federal cleanup money from North Carolina if it did not develop a plan to dispose of hazardous waste. If the threat is carried out, it will be the first use of harsh Federal sanctions against a state for failing to develop such a plan.

title: Surgery for Hernandez
description: Keith Hernandez, the 37-year-old former Mets first baseman who is starting the second season of a two-year contract worth $3.5 million with the Cleveland Indians, has decided to submit to back surgery. He made the decision yesterday after a second medical opinion that confirmed he has a bulging disk.(AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: As part of the glory of winning the Lions Club International's poster contest, 12-year-old JEAN MICHEL PAIN of Fort-de-France, Martinique, had his first chance to visit New York City, see the Statue of Liberty and meet JAVIER PEREZ DE CUELLAR , the United Nations Secretary General. They spoke in French when Jean Michel visited the United Nations yesterday .

title: Sidney Danziger, Executive, 87
description: Sidney Danziger, a leader in the metals-recycling industry, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: CHEERS IN SCHOOL HALLS As troops began arriving home, smiling faces and cheers filled the halls of an elementary school in Fayetteville, N.C. Nearly half the pupils have a parent or close relative who served in the Persian Gulf. Page A16.

title: Progress Reported On Mental Defect
description: EVIDENCE is mounting to explain how a genetic defect causes the most common inherited form of mental retardation.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Baker Sees Arab 'New Thinking' And Urges Israel to Reciprocate Secretary Is Said to Talk of a Change in Attitude
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d briefed Israeli officials today about what he called "new thinking" from Arab nations on peace with Israel, but said that whether these ideas bear fruit would depend on Israeli reciprocation.

title: Low Oil Prices Are Bad, Some U.S. Experts Say
description: American oil experts are closely watching a fractious OPEC as it meets in its first session since the Persian Gulf war, with many hoping for the same things that some OPEC members want: a new agreement that will hold down production, so prices will stabilize or rise.

title: Palmer Fails To Impress In Debut
description: Nobody, Frank Robinson said, is a Hall of Famer the first time out in spring training. But the Baltimore Orioles' manager was wrong. Jim Palmer made his first exhibition appearance today, and he is a Hall of Famer.

title: REPROACH IN ITALY ON THE ALBANIANS
description: Italians, who sometimes seem as uncomfortable being rich as they were when they used to be poor, have immersed themselves in self-reproach for their Government's slow response in taking care of a new tide of Albanian refugees.

title: Chess
description: Something good happened to Jan Timman between Dec. 20 and Jan. 23. On the earlier date, the 39-year-old Dutch grandmaster lost his Katholieke Radio Omroep exhibition match in Hilversum, the Netherlands, to Yasser Seirawan, a Seattle grandmaster, by 4-2. On the latter date, he began his first-round world championship candidates' match in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and a week later he won from Robert Huebner, a German grandmaster, by 4 1/2-2 1/2.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraqi Loyalists Pound Shiite Mosques, Rebels Say; Opposition Meeting
description: More than 300 delegates from 23 Iraqi opposition organizations assembled today and considered ways to remove President Hussein from power in Baghdad.

title: Schools and Abortion: A New Debate
description: Along with history and math, students as young as 11 years old may learn another lesson in Michigan's public schools next fall: how to seek an abortion without parental consent.

title: Leif Melgaard, Wood Carver, 92
description: Leif Melgaard, an artist whose woodcarvings became museum pieces and also found their way into Norway's royal palace, died on Saturday after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Hershey to Acquire German Company
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said it had agreed to buy the Gubor Schokoladen business of H. Bahlsens Keksfabrik K.G. in Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Apple Cutting Computer Price
description: Continuing its recent strategy of moving to increase market share by cutting profit margins, Apple Computer Inc. announced significant price reductions today on its mid-range and high-end Macintosh personal computers.

title: Math Problem, Long Baffling, Slowly Yields
description: A CENTURY-OLD math problem of notorious difficulty has started to crumble. Even though an exact solution still defies mathematicians, researchers can now obtain answers that are good enough for almost all practical applications.

title: Equitable Officer Tells Court He Lied
description: An executive with the Equitable Life Assurance Society admitted in court yesterday that he had lied to a representative of the limited partners of a real estate venture in which Equitable participated before the insurer declared the venture bankrupt.

title: Bidermann Industries Has a New President
description: Bidermann International S.A., a big clothing maker based in Paris, has named Alfred F. Fuoco president and chief executive of its United States subsidiary, the Bidermann Industries Corporation -- the largest apparel manufacturer in North America.

title: Editorial Notebook; How the Middle East Was Invented
description: Until this century, nobody talked about the Middle East because neither the term nor the states in the region existed. Both were the work of the victors in World War I -- the true begetters of the furies that still rage. Curiously, there are few connected accounts of a very confusing history. A readable exception is "A Peace to End All Peace," written by a New York attorney, David Fromkin (and available as an Avon paperback). His narrative is clear, timely and cautionary.

title: Canadian Indians Embittered Over a Ruling Limiting Land
description: A court ruling denying a claim by Canadian Indians to a vast region of British Columbia has further embittered relations between this country's aboriginal peoples and its nonnative majority, at a time when tensions have been running as high as at any time in decades.

title: A New Dinkins? No, Reassessing
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins used the Neilsen audience rating system yesterday to answer a television reporter who wanted to know what the Mayor meant by vowing on Monday to take a more personal role in running his administration.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Hermitage Must Keep Its Treasures Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudan Sorghum Seeds Kill 28
description: Twenty-eight people died after eating sorghum seeds treated with chemical preservatives, and another 28 were hospitalized in serious condition, the Sudan News Agency reported today. The victims, in the northern Sudan, apparently ate the seeds because they had nothing else. The Sudan is in the grip of a famine affecting about 11 million people, over 40 percent of the population.

title: Lois/GKK's Tasty Approach to High Tech
description: THE ads picture what looks like a large pizza box, with the message that the product within will make executives' lives "a whole lot easier." Inside, it turns out, is a $100,000 computer, without anchovies.

title: A Coke Bottle Uses Recycled Plastic
description: The Coca-Cola Company's North Carolina bottling operation began a limited market introduction here of the first soft drink bottles made with recycled plastic. The 2-liter bottles of Coca-Cola Classic are made with a blend of 25 percent recycled plastic and 75 percent "virgin" resin.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: TO be filed under B, as in Brief and to the Point, or perhaps S as in Signs of the Times. Anyway, this one was spotted by Ralph DeNat in the window of a jewelry store on Hanover Square in Manhattan's financial district. BUSINESS STINKS SALE

title: Doctors Ask Wider California Smoking Ban
description: California's doctors want their state's already strict smoking laws expanded to prohibit smoking in almost all indoor public places.

title: Bomblet in Moscow
description: Secretary of State Baker may have a bomblet to drop Friday in Moscow -- his meeting with leaders from 12 Soviet republics, including Boris Yeltsin, Mikhail Gorbachev's blood rival. Mr. Baker also plans separate talks with leaders of the rebellious Baltic republics.

title: Coleman's Education Continues
description: Some people say there is a curse on the entire franchise of the New Jersey Nets, much like the one that haunts the Boston Red Sox for letting Babe Ruth get away.

title: U.S. Says Five Were Indicted In Schemes Involving Steroid
description: Federal officials on Tuesday announced indictments against three Tucson, Ariz., residents and two operators of a California health club on charges of making, distributing and promoting an illegal and dangerous body-building drug.

title: Downtown Santa Cruz Faces Loss of Historic-Area Status
description: The downtown area, devastated by a major earthquake a year and a half ago, may lose its status as a Federal historic district because many of the historic buildings were destroyed, a state official says.

title: Earle Palmer Brown's Janklow/Bender Deal
description: After a yearlong search, Earle Palmer Brown, based in Bethesda, Md., has found an agency for its fledgling New York office to team up with. The New York office has billings of about $10 million.

title: Aubran W. Martin, 42, Murderer of Unionist
description: Aubran Wayne Martin, one of three men convicted of murder in the 1969 killings of Joseph A. Yablonski, a union leader, and two members of Mr. Yablonski's family, died of stomach cancer on Sunday. He was 42 years old.

title: Olivetti Head Charged in '82 Bank Failure
description: A Milan appeals court today indicted Carlo de Benedetti, the financier and computer executive, on charges of complicity in the bankruptcy of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's largest banking scandal. No trial date was set.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Monday with the column headed "Midtown Journal," showing a walking route through alleys and courtyards of midtown Manhattan, located Shubert Alley incorrectly in some copies. It runs from 44th to 45th street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: Soviet Dance Champions Seek to Overcome Ordeal
description: In 10 years of skating together, the last six as husband and wife, Marina Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko had never taken so much time off as they did after the European championships in January. Yet when the possibility arose that she had used performance-enhancing drugs, the five-day vacation they planned at their country home outside Moscow turned into a three-week nightmare.

title: Turks Claim Benefits of Allied Victory
description: All in all, Turks say, it turned out to be not a bad little war for them.

title: How to Chew
description: To The Living Section:

title: 2 Olympic Teams Get N.H.L. Help
description: The Olympic hockey programs of Canada and the United States got a windfall today when each received a $1 million commitment from the National Hockey League for the 1992 and 1994 Winter Games.

title: O'Neal Back in Lineup
description: Shaquille O'Neal, the nation's leading rebounder and the Southeastern Conference player of the year, will be available tomorrow when his Louisiana State Tigers begin National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament play against Connecticut in a Midwest Regional game in Minneapolis.

title: Latest Tokyo Craze: Tiramisu in a Bottle
description: For trendier Japanese, European flair is in these days, while Americana has lost in luster. But few of the recent Euro-fads have swept Tokyo as thoroughly as tiramisu, which has been transformed from a chic dessert to a marketing phenomenon packaged as candy and even dispensed from vending machines.

title: King Hussein Says He Won't Be P.L.O. Substitute
description: With a new American effort to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict under way, King Hussein said today that Jordan would never agree to be a substitute for the Palestine Liberation Organization in peace talks with Israel. But he said that if the Palestinian leadership asked Jordan to join such talks, he would be willing to, provided the Palestinians gave him a clear mandate and they had the more prominent place in the negotiations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ann Taylor Inc. named Robert S. Bland vice chairman, with responsibility for operations, expense planning and expense management. * Dun & Bradstreet Corp., New York, named William O. Dwyer a corporate vice president and president of Dun & Bradstreet Corp. Japan K.K.

title: Judge Urged to Quit Homosexual's Case; Remarks Called Slur
description: A senior Federal judge here is being asked to disqualify himself from a case because he used the word "homo" in court to describe a homosexual who is challenging his dismissal from the United States Naval Academy.

title: Rebels Try to Join Fast Company
description: Although 35 years have passed, K. C. Jones and Mike Farmer can recall the aura of invincibility that surrounded the University of San Franciso Dons when they were the most fearsome college basketball team in the nation.

title: McDonnell Hints At Jet Project Move
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had run out of room to expand its Douglas Aircraft Company operations here and might have to produce its next-generation passenger jet outside California. The company said it might move the $3 billion MD-12X jet project to a state that offered more incentives. "The probability is that we will go elsewhere," said Donald Snyder, general manager of the MD-12X program.

title: Dinkins Friend Leads Surge in Lobbying Fees
description: Money spent by real-estate developers, city contractors, unions and other interest groups to lobby New York City government rose sharply last year, and a prime beneficiary was a lobbyist who is a longtime friend and tennis partner of Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Credit Cards Back $750 Million Issue
description: Chase Manhattan Credit Card Trust 1991-1, established by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, is offering $750 million in asset-backed securities through Chase Securities. The debt issue is backed by Visa and Mastercard credit card receivables.

title: 7 Years After Killings, Grenada Awaits Ruling
description: When Velma Hylton arrived from her native Jamaica in 1984 to oversee the trial of a group of Marxist hard-liners for the killing of Maurice Bishop, revolutionary Grenada's popular young Prime Minister, her widely shared expectation was that the case would be quickly resolved.

title: Changes Are Proposed In How Math Is Taught
description: Three major mathematics education groups today called for changes in the teaching of mathematics aimed at better preparing American students to compete with youngsters overseas.

title: What We Can Do About Child Pregnancies
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Medical Care Wanting in Rural U.S.
description: Rural Americans are less likely than city-dwellers to have private or Medicaid health coverage, a research organization reported today.

title: Changsha Journal; In China's Cities, the Busybodies Are Organized
description: When Wang Xingzhou's wife threatened to divorce him, he ran down the block to the street committee. Soon a team of elderly women filed into his tiny apartment and showered his wife with a dozen reasons why the couple should stay together.

title: Georgia to Study Cocaine in Newborn Child
description: March of Dimes officials today announced the nation's first statewide study of cocaine exposure in newborn children.

title: Love-Triangle Jurors Hear Gun Testimony
description: A nurse who worked in the same school as Carolyn Warmus, a Westchester teacher accused of killing her lover's wife, testified yesterday that in January 1989 the defendant said she had bought a gun from a private detective.

title: For First Time, Nunn's in Fray for Opposing One
description: Politics is a contact sport, but Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, has often seemed above the fray.

title: St. Patrick's Day Plan For Gay Group Is Denied
description: The organizers of the St. Patrick's Day parade have rejected a compromise offered by Mayor David N. Dinkins that would have expanded the parade to allow 40 more groups, including a gay group, to march.

title: Deal Set on OPEC Cut, But Not All Are Happy
description: OPEC decided today to cut oil production by 5 percent, or about a million barrels a day, which several officials of the group said should push prices higher.

title: Dykstra: Big Stakes But Strictly Amateur
description: Lenny Dykstra portrayed himself in court yesterday as an amateur poker player who lost some big-stakes hands as well as some wagers on golf matches he played in and who ended up owing $78,000 to a man charged with running an illegal gambling establishment.

title: Washington Talk; Low Key Supplants Grandeur For Bush
description: Everyone is talking about George Bush's New World Aura.

title: The Victor Visits to Get Jar of Spoils
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the allied forces that drove Iraq from Kuwait, scooped sand from a beach in the emirate today as a souvenir of his victory.

title: Chase Will Sell Ohio Branches
description: The Chase Bank of Ohio, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said today that it had agreed in principle to sell nine branch offices in the Cincinnati and Columbus areas to Fifth Third Bancorp.

title: Hi, Honey!
description: To The Living Section:

title: American War Prisoners Abused By Iraqi Captors, Pentagon Says
description: A senior Pentagon official said today that Iraq had physically abused American prisoners of war, subjected some of them to psychological torment and threatened the lives of others during interrogation sessions.

title: Support for Restoration of Full I.R.A. Deduction
description: More than 70 percent of the Senate lined up today behind a bill to restore fully deductible Individual Retirement Accounts for all workers, but the Bush Administration immediately rebuffed the proposal.

title: White House Should Name Hispanic Nominee to U.S. Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Semifinalists in P.S.A.L. Still Have a Lot to Prove
description: The four boys' basketball teams in the semifinals of the Public Schools Athletic League city championship -- Grady (22-2), Manhattan Center for Science and Math (22-2), Lincoln (21-3) and South Shore (24-0) -- will be goaded by something besides a city title when play begins today at Hunter College in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers Survive Rally by Heat Byron Scott hit long jumpers on three consecutive possessions in the final three minutes to help Los Angeles hold off the Heat, 102-95, last night in Miami. The Lakers appeared in control when they led by 88-75 with 5:30 left. But they failed to score on their next six possessions. Miami closed to 88-84 with 4 minutes to go. Scott finished with 21 points while Magic Johnson had 21 points, 14 assists and 11 rebounds. (AP) Bulls 131, Timberwolves 99: Horace Grant and Michael Jordan scored 20 points each, leading Chicago to its 23d consecutive home victory. Grant and Jordan sat out the fourth quarter.(AP) Bullets 103, Hornets 100: Pervis Ellison scored a career-high 28 points as the injury-riddled Washington Bullets snapped a nine-game losing streak with a victory in Charlotte, N.C. The Bullets, losers in 15 of their previous 17 games, played without their two leading scorers, Bernard King and Harvey Grant, both of whom are injured. (AP) Rockets 93, SuperSonics 91: Kenny Smith had 24 points, including four free throws in the final 17 seconds, and Hakeem Olajuwon scored 32 points to lead Houston in its home victory.(AP) 76ers 133, Hawks 129: At Atlanta, Ron Anderson, whose 3-point basket tied the game in regulation, scored 7 points in the last 22 seconds of the second overtime to give Philadelphia the victory.(AP) Clippers 126, Nuggets 123: Ron Harper scored 8 of his 23 points in overtime, including a pair of 3-pointers as Los Angeles snapped a five-game losing streak by winning over the stumbling Nuggets at Denver.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins' Home Streak Ends at 11 Jamie Leach and Kevin Stevens scored late in the second period to lift Pittsburgh to a 4-4 tie with Montreal as the Penguins' record 11-game home winning streak ended. Pittsburgh closed to 3 points of the first-place Rangers in the Patrick Division. (AP) Whalers 3, Capitals 2: John Cullen and Terry Yake scored 57 seconds apart in the second period as the Whalers beat Washington at Landover, Md., for Hartford's first victory in 10 games (1-6-3). Washington, which took only three shots on goal in the third period, remained tied with New Jersey for the fourth and final Patrick Division playoff spot. (AP) Maple Leafs 4, Nordiques 3: Peter Zezel's goal midway through the third period gave Toronto the road victory in a battle of the league's weakest teams. (AP) North Stars 5, Sabres 2: Dave Gagner continued his month-long hot streak with his 37th goal of the season as Minnesota won its fourth straight victory. Minnesota is now 10-0-2 in its last 12 home games.(AP) SLED-DOG RACING Butcher Leads in Iditarod Susan Butcher, the defending champion, pushed up the Bering Sea coast yesterday in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, but her long-time rival, Rick Swenson, was close behind as the leaders neared Nome. Butcher pulled into the Shaktoolik checkpoint, which is 934 miles into the 1,163-mile race, about 90 minutes ahead of Swenson. (AP)

title: Key Rates
Lloyd W. Dunn, 84, Recording Executive
description: Lloyd W. Dunn, a co-founder of the Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which issues the Grammy Awards, died on Friday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Theater; The Skeletons in the Closets Of Aristocrats in Old Vienna
description: Few theatrical worlds are more inviting than upper-class Vienna at the end of the 19th century as portrayed in the plays of Arthur Schnitzler. At once opulent and refined, Victorian and bohemian, it is one setting whose denizens come awfully close to having their cake and eating it, too. Schnitzler was psychologically shrewd enough to create characters with depth, and enough of an entertainer to invest even his more hapless creations with a patina of glamour.

title: Data General Unit In Japan to Be Sold
description: The Data General Corporation agreed to sell its Japanese subsidiary, Nippon Data General, for about $46 million to the Omron Corporation, a Japanese maker of automated bank tellers and other automation products. Data General expects to report a gain of about $13 million from the sale, with the actual cash proceeds at about $30 million.

title: Bush Plans to Visit Middle East to Press For Arab-Israel Pact
description: President Bush plans to visit the Middle East soon to highlight the new relationship with Arab allies and to press for a breakthrough in the Arab-Israeli conflict, Administration officials said today.

title: New Chief of Wilson Reorganizes Divisions
description: The Amer Group, a Finnish company that bought the Wilson Sporting Goods Company two years ago, appointed Erkki E. Railo as Wilson's president and chief executive yesterday, replacing Glenn N. Rupp.

title: Acquittal In Murder In Brooklyn
description: The last defendant in the Bensonhurst case was acquitted of a murder charge but convicted of lesser counts yesterday, ending a series of problem-plagued trials in Brooklyn.

title: Rebel-Backed Parties in Salvador Charge Fraud
description: A coalition of center-left parties with support from the guerrilla insurgency accused the governing Arena party today of fraud in local and legislative elections on Sunday and said that could block an expected peace accord.

title: Reviews/Dance; Adding Spoken Words to Movement
description: When "Accumulation" was first performed 20 years ago by the experimental choreographer and dancer Trisha Brown, the sight of a soloist rotating her wrists with thumbs extended and then repeating the movement with gradually accumulated gestures did not quite meet everyone's definition of a dance work.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on March 4 about large construction developments that are stalled in New York City omitted one developer of the Harlem International Center. The developer, the Harlem Partnership, is involved with Morris Saady, a Geneva-based developer, and the Milstein Organization. The chart also carried an outdated developer listing for Heron Tower II, an office tower on the East Side of Manhattan. The Stratagem Group is no longer involved in it.

title: Chrysler Auto Loans Back $600.8 Million of Securities
description: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday priced $600.8 million in certificates backed by auto and light-truck loans through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Books of The Times; Trying to Sift the Real Nixon From the Illusion
description: One of Us Richard Nixon and the American Dream By Tom Wicker 731 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: U.S. Delays Hiring
description: The United States national team will delay hiring a new coach until early next month, the United States Soccer Federation president, Alan Rothenberg, said yesterday.

title: Exxon to Pay $100 Million Fine And Plead Guilty in Valdez Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to plead guilty to a criminal charge arising from the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill and pay a $100 million fine, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said tonight.

title: Chiat/Day/Mojo Takes Seven Addy Awards
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo was the big winner at the "Best of New York" Addy Awards presentation, which was held yesterday in New York.

title: Rijo Puts Aside a Multitude of Negative Thoughts
description: Jose Rijo filed for divorce from his wife, Rosie, this winter, jeopardizing his relationship with his pitching mentor, Rosie's father, Juan Marichal.

title: Review/Theater; Humor in Unlikely Subjects
description: "Feet Brushes and Breath," a three-part series of collaborations by dancers, painters and performance artists, got off to an eloquent and very funny start with "Painted Tooth" on Thursday at the Mulberry Street Theater (70 Mulberry Street). Virtually a solo, the hourlong piece gave Laurie Carlos a chance to let out all the stops as a performance artist and writer. And Ms. Carlos can create or decimate whole worlds with a widening of her eyes or slight drop or rise in her voice.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: VEAL chops are one of the most delicate -- and expensive -- cuts of meat, so I always prepare them with relative simplicity. A well-seasoned, perfectly broiled veal chop can be a joy.

title: Paul Itta Is Dead at 97; New York Restaurateur
description: Paul Itta, a restaurateur who owned Mickey Walker's Bar and Grill in its heyday in the 1930's, died on Sunday at the Sunrest Nursing Home in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 97 years old and had been a resident of Yonkers until two years ago.

title: Friendlier Skies?
description: Airline passengers have not had much good news lately, so they have reason to welcome -- for now, at least -- a British-American agreement that will keep Pan American and Trans World Airlines in business a while longer.

title: About New York; Of Ephemera Like Manhattan: The Long View
description: Sidney Horenstein grew up on the Lower East Side, earned a master's degree in geology from New York University and has been a curator at the American Museum of Natural History for three decades.

title: An Improved Simms Is Eager for Action
description: Three months before the start of what could be the most competitive training camp of his 13-year pro football career, Phil Simms says he feels as though he is in the worst physical shape of his life.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Buffton Corp., Fort Worth, a maker of electronic and plastic products, sold its National Pipe Co. operations to LCP National Plastics Inc., and its National Conduit Co. to its former owner, Jaakko Uuranniemi. The sale of the companies brought Buffton $15.4 million. * Comshare Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., an information company, will purchase the operating assets and business of Execucom Systems Corp., a subsidiary of MPSI Systems Inc., Tulsa, Okla., for about $12 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus in Westchester misstated her age. She is 27.

title: U.S. Airman Is Slain in Blast Walking to House in Greece
description: A powerful bomb blast killed an American Air Force sergeant in an Athens suburb tonight and the police said they believed it was the work of the November 17 guerrilla group, which has killed 15 Greeks and Americans since 1975.

title: Kuwaiti Broadcasts Resume After Pillaging
description: Television is returning feebly to Kuwait City, with about an hour or air time a day. And the Kuwaiti radio, which began broadcasting again on Feb. 27, the day the city was freed, is now on the air more than 12 hours a day with news and public announcements.

title: Bush Digs In on Arctic Drilling Plan
description: President Bush will veto any national energy strategy that does not include his proposal allowing drilling in part of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, the Secretary of Energy told a Senate hearing today.

title: What the Best-Dressed Astronaut Will Now Wear
description: While many products, from automobiles to appliances, have been redesigned to reduce weight, when it comes to space suits for astronauts, the nation's space program has left the weight issue behind.

title: U.S. Trade Benefits From War
description: As a result of the war in the Persian Gulf and its aftermath, the United States is likely to borrow far less from abroad this year than last. Many forecasters expect the deficit in the current account -- the broadest gauge of the nation's imports and exports of goods and services -- to shrink sharply in 1991.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Montreal, is offering $150 million in 9.20 percent debentures due 2001 at 99.933 to yield 9.21 percent through First Boston Corp. The debentures are noncallable and are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: Lime Found Effective in Cleaning PCB Sites
description: In an accidental discovery, Federal workers have found that lime appears to be an inexpensive and effective way to destroy PCB's.
