title: What We Can Do About Child Pregnancies; Restoring the Father
description: To the Editor:

title: Genetics Plans Appeal
description: Genetics Institute Inc., said today that it would ask a Federal appeals court to reconsider a decision last week voiding a patent for the company's top-selling anemia drug. The company also said it would reduce first-quarter earnings by $18.3 million largely to cover potential costs related to the decision. The Circuit Court of Appeals decision on March 5 to invalidate Genetics Institute's patent for pure erythropoietin upheld a patent granted to Amgen Inc. of Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: Leslie Nielsen Starring In Dollar Car Campaign
description: Leslie Nielsen, the actor who is perhaps best known for his slapstick performances in the films "Airplane" and "The Naked Gun," has taken on a new role: the star of new television ads for Dollar Rent A Car.

title: GOLF: Notebook; TV Replay Makes a Ball Playable
description: Although Paul Azinger was disqualified at the Doral Ryder Open after a television viewer saw him commit a rules infraction by moving stones in a water hazard, it is arguable that television may have saved Steve Pate the Honda Classic on Sunday.

title: Review/Film; Aching to Be a Prima Donna, When You're a Man
description: It's tough enough trying to survive in our society as a black male, but "if you're black and male and gay, you have to be stronger than you can imagine."

title: Assembly Leaders In Revenue Warning
description: In a report that seemed to pave the way for new tax proposals, leaders of the Democratic-led State Assembly estimated yesterday that state revenues would be even lower than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had predicted.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CAMILO JOSE CELA, the intellectually flamboyant Spanish writer and 1989 Nobel laureate, and his companion, MARINA CASTANO, a journalist, were married on Sunday in a civil ceremony at the bridegroom's country estate in Guadalajara, northeast of Madrid. Ms. Castano, 34 years old, and Mr. Cela, 74, have been living together since he left his wife of 44 years, ROSARIO CONDE, in 1988.

title: Nevada County In School Issue
description: A $277.58 million bond issue for the Clark County, Nev., schools was priced yesterday to give a maximum yield of 7.14 percent for a security due in 2011 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: I.B.M. Makes Changes In Work Station Line
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced faster versions of two of its work stations yesterday and dropped some prices. But the computer manufacturer continued to steer clear of the highly competitive low-priced end of the work station market.

title: Iraqi Gains Against Rebels Sometimes Fade, U.S. Says
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the situation in the rebellious cities and towns in southern Iraq was fluid, describing a confusing pattern in which Iraqi troops have been unable to permanently pacify areas of unrest.

title: Microsoft In Inquiry By F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the competitive practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the maker of software for personal computers.

title: CAPTIVE'S RETURN TO IRAQ DELAYED
description: The repatriation of more than 60,000 Iraqi prisoners of war held in Saudi Arabia is being delayed by a shortage of transportation in Iraq and by minefields near the exchange site, allied military officials said today.

title: Ex-Gov. LeRoy Collins Dies at 82; Floridian Led Way in 'New South'
description: LeRoy Collins, who was Governor of Florida from 1955 to 1961 and an early "New South" politician who sought to promote racial justice in the region, died in his sleep at his home in Tallahassee yesterday, two days after his 82d birthday.

title: Credit Card Delinquency
description: The number of Americans behind in paying credit card bills rose sharply in the fourth quarter but the combined delinquency rate for seven other kinds of consumer loans was stable, a trade group said today.

title:
AFTER THE WAR: OIL;
Avoiding A Third Gulf War
description: The gulf war is hardly over and a rush has already begun to supply more and better arms to the Middle East. So long as there is a flood of petrodollars to pay for them, it is vain to think that an arms limitation regime or a multilateral agreement to control arms sales can succeed except in the very short run.

title: U.S. and Albania to Restore Full Links
description: The United States will resume full diplomatic relations with Albania on Friday, ending 52 years of nonrecognition, American and Albanian officials announced today.

title: They're Wearing the Green Amid the Great Reds
description: It is often said that Ireland's most important export has been its youth. In the 19th century, famine and despair drove well over a million of the Irish to the United States alone.

title: Wells Fargo Executive Joins Security Pacific
description: Ronald S. Parker, a top executive in charge of corporate lending at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco, left the company yesterday to join the rival Security Pacific Corporation in Los Angeles, officials at Security Pacific confirmed.

title: 23 Colleges Won't Pool Fiscal Data
description: A continuing Federal investigation into possible antitrust violations by some of the nation's leading colleges has prompted them to cancel an annual information-sharing meeting in late March for the first time in more than 30 years.

title: Chip Index Up Sharply
description: The semiconductor industry's key indicator of business prospects jumped in February, a sign that the industry slump might be drawing to an end.

title: John Behan, 72, Trainer of Dogs For Guarding Macy's and Others
description: John Behan, a dog trainer who founded Canine College on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and who provided dogs for protection at places like the Museum of Modern Art, Macy's and the Bronx Zoo, died on Monday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 72 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Rushing From Yacht to Jet, Maxwell Relishes New Role
description: His first, jaunty words as he stepped off his yacht into a waiting Cadillac to complete negotiations with the unions at The Daily News were "I love New York," but the bold lettering on his white baseball cap spoke of another favorite cause: "Maxwell."

title: New Data In Inquiry On Stangl
description: A road foreman with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has told Federal authorities that a friend of the railroad's president, Peter E. Stangl, operated the brakes and throttle while sitting in the engineer's seat during a train ride in October.

title: Margaret K. Chandler, Columbia Professor, 68
description: Dr. Margaret K. Chandler, the first female professor at the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, died on Monday at the Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. She was 68 years old and lived in Piscataway.

title: Mr. Annenberg's Families
description: When Walter Annenberg, the publisher and former Ambassador to Britain, was offered $1 billion for his art collection last year, he wasn't interested in selling. It turns out that what he is interested in is giving it away -- to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and, by extension, to New York City. One billion dollars doesn't even begin to count its value to both.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KEN SUNSHINE, a special executive assistant to Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS of New York, has resigned to become a consultant to the Democratic National Committee for the 1992 Presidential convention. Mr. Sunshine will also act as consultant to the city's host committee for the convention.

title: Ayers Is Coach of Year
description: Randy Ayers, who in his second year as head coach at Ohio State led the Buckeyes to a share of the Big Ten Conference championship with Indiana, was named coach of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association yesterday. Ayers, 34 years old, coached the Buckeyes to a 25-3 record.(AP)

title:
Real Estate;
Turner Office Relocating To 5th Ave.
description: THE Turner Broadcasting System has become the initial tenant in the newly completed office tower at 420 Fifth Avenue, providing a new sign that blocks in the mid-30's are gaining ground in the tug-of-war for tenants in Manhattan's commercial real estate market.

title: What We Can Do About Child Pregnancies; Teaching Parenthood
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Notes
description: Woodward on War

title: Taking On a Top Job Amid Erratic Times At the Philharmonic
description: Allison Vulgamore -- who turned 33 years old just about the time she added a few gray hairs -- took over as acting managing director of the New York Philharmonic on Jan. 1. That was the last piece of good news she heard for quite a while.

title: New Trial Sought in '71 Case
description: Lawyers for three former Black Panther Party members convicted of killing two New York City police officers argued yesterday in Federal court that the men deserve a new trial because authorities had suppressed evidence -- including Federal Bureau of Investigation ballistics tests that contradicted those done by the police -- in the case. The former Panthers, Herman Bell, Albert Washington and Anthony Bottom, were sentenced to 25 years to life for the May 21, 1971, slayings. Judge Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court in Manhattan reserved judgment.

title: Pan Am, Having Won Time, Looks for Cash and Partners
description: Once again, Pan American World Airways has bought time for itself. But even its chairman and chief executive, Thomas G. Plaskett, conceded in an interview yesterday that the airline's long-term survival was far from guaranteed.

title: Stewart Comes Back
description: Al Stewart's retirement lasted two weeks. The 27-year-old forward, who quit on Feb. 26 for unspecified reasons, told the Devils yesterday he wanted to play hockey again and he was immediately assigned to the team's top affiliate in the minor leagues, the Utica Devils of the American Hockey League.

title: Using Bacteria to Control Pollution
description: Bacteria may be better than chemicals or absorbent materials at controlling emissions of volatile solvents that contribute to low-level smog and at eliminating the odors of sewage treatment plants and composting operations, experts in the field say.

title: Technology Issues Drop as Dow Slips 16.84
description: Amid growing concern that a big market slide could be developing, stocks gave way yesterday for the fourth straight trading day.

title: Conviction Set Aside In 1974 Murder Case
description: A Superior Court judge has set aside the murder conviction of Murray R. Gold, a former New York City stockbroker who was first arrested more than 15 years ago in the stabbing deaths of a prominent Waterbury lawyer and his wife on Yom Kippur in 1974.

title: 5 Years After Manes's Death, a Different Queens Blvd.
description: Pastrami King is still there, but Poor Nick's is not. Crossroad Drugs remains, but the big sign over it announcing the politically connected law firm of Pennisi & Dowd is gone. Queens Borough Hall stands, but Donald R. Manes is history.

title: 3 Are Indicted in Attempt To Bomb Chemical Tank
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a Maryland businessman and two associates Tuesday in the attempted bombing last month of a storage tank near shipyards that do work for the Navy.

title: Nycor Complains About Zenith Sale
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation's largest shareholder, Nycor Inc., asked the New York Stock Exchange to investigate last month's sale of about 5 percent of Zenith stock to a Korean company. The request was disclosed in a filing on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Delay Hampered Efforts in High-Rise Blaze
description: Guards at a skyscraper delayed reporting a fire alarm for several minutes, allowing the fatal blaze to destroy an electrical emergency system, the Fire Commissioner said today.

title: After 16 Years, Squatter Leaves Tunnel
description: Back in the summer of 1974, when he was 32 years old and the long railroad tunnel underneath Riverside Park was uninhabited, John Joseph Kovacs and another man moved into a couple of cinder-block bunkers in the southern end. Yesterday afternoon Mr. Kovacs packed his belongings in three cardboard boxes and moved out.

title: House Vote Bars More S.& L. Aid
description: A deeply divided House of Representatives today rejected four measures to provide new financing for the bailout of the savings and loan industry.

title: Soviets Warn of Perils Unless Unity Is Backed
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief adviser on the national union said today that if a popular majority voted in a referendum next Sunday against continuing the union, the nation would be moving "back to 1917 and civil war."

title: Fairfield Coach Resigns
description: Mitch Buonaguro resigned as coach at Fairfield University yesterday. Buonaguro, who came to Fairfield in 1985, will resign effective June 30, when his four-year contract ends.

title: Review/Dance; A Sad and Merry 'Romeo'
description: The Joffrey Ballet filled the stage of the New York State Theater with poignancy and merriment on Saturday, when it presented two performances of John Cranko's "Romeo and Juliet."

title: Miscellany
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations firm, said it would open an office in Budapest on Monday. * Hanna-Barbera Productions Inc. has formed an internal direct-marketing organization, to coordinate all such activities among its divisions. Wendy Moss, senior vice president and general manager of Hanna-Barbera Home Video, will head the group.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of works from the 1980's at the Whitney Museum of American Art misstated the extent of the museum's permanent collection. The museum does own works by the artist Robert Greene -- one painting and one drawing.

title: Home and Hearth Are Even Cozier if a Veal Roast Is in the Pot
description: GUESTS are always impressed with stuffed birds or meat, and breast of veal is a good cut to stuff, because nothing braises and cooks better or produces better-flavored juices than veal.

title: Diamond Sales Hurt by War
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the world's largest diamond producer, said today that the Persian Gulf crisis had hurt diamond sales last year, but that the recent jump in world stock markets should lead to an improvement.

title: Investor Raises Offer for DeSoto
description: The New York investor William Spier, who has been trying to acquire DeSoto Inc. since November 1989, increased his offer for the detergent maker to $5.50 a share. Mr. Spier, chairman of the Sutton Holding Corporation, had indicated in December that he was willing to offer $5.25 a share. But on Friday, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Spier told the DeSoto board he would offer $5.50.

title: Coors in Indiana
description: The Coors Brewing Company announced today that next week its beers would became available in cans and bottles in Indiana. Coors and Coors Light became available in kegs in Indiana in January. Indiana was the last state where Coors was not sold.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDMUND MORRIS, the official biographer of RONALD REAGAN, has revealed that his subject is "the most mysterious man I have ever confronted."

title: Britons Press Hostage Effort
description: Britain pressed for the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon at talks in Syria today by a senior official of the Foreign Office.

title: Reorganizing At Mcorp
description: Mcorp, once one of the largest banking companies in Texas, filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan late Monday that proposes liquidating a subsidiary and pursuing a court battle with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Shutdown at Paper Mill
description: The Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company said on Monday that it would shut down its mill in Kapuskasing, Ontario, for two weeks beginning on Sunday. The company said the shutdown had been caused by a decline in demand for newsprint and specialty ground-wood papers in North America. The shutdown will affect 1,200 employees and will reduce production by 15,000 tons. Spruce Falls is co-owned by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, a paper company, and The New York Times Company.

title: Review/Television; Of Moose, Mounties and Their Mentors
description: This being a pledge week, prime time on public television is crammed with programming not likely to be provided on the system's normal schedule. Forget earnest documentaries and numbing panel discussions. Now, for a brief while, the menu features stars and celebrities, from Luciano Pavarotti in concert to Fred Astaire in movie clips.

title: Baker Sees Israeli and Palestinians But Fails to Narrow Differences
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d concluded talks today with Israeli and Palestinian leaders without either side indicating fundamental change in long-held positions.

title: St. Patrick May Have His Parade, but St. Joseph Has Zeppole
description: SMACK on the heels of St. Patrick's Day, St. Joseph's Day is a holiday with an identity crisis. The day, March 19, is variously described as the Italian Father's Day, a celebration of spring, a thanksgiving, an ex-holy day of obligation and, of course, the name day for all Josephs and Josephines.

title: Film on Gangs Becomes Part of World It Portrays
description: "New Jack City," a film about urban gang violence, has become a part of the world it portrays, touching off fights at movie theaters around the country over the weekend, including a two-hour rampage in Los Angeles and a fatal shooting in New York City.

title: Bloomingdale's Names Official
description: Stuart Glasser has been named executive vice president and general merchandise manager for the men's, boys' and children's apparel divisions of Bloomingdale's. He will report to Marvin S. Traub, chairman.

title: SERBIANS GIVE IN TO 3-DAY PROTEST
description: The Yugoslav republic of Serbia bowed tonight to major demands of anti-Communist protesters who have blocked the capital's downtown area for three days.

title: Fur Industry Depends on Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Inquiry Sought in Police Beating
description: Outraged over the videotaped beating of a suspect by the Los Angeles police last week, members of the Congressional Black Caucus asked the Justice Department today to conduct a wide-ranging inquiry into police brutality in the city.

title: The Pop Life
description: Switching Instruments

title: CHRONICLE
description: "Cyrano de Bergerac" dominated the Cesars, the French version of the Oscars, on Saturday night, carrying off 10 of the 21 awards, including Best Film. The evening's hero was GERARD DEPARDIEU, whose portrayal of the ugly, amorous soldier won the Cesar for Best Actor. After the ceremonies in Paris, crowds thronged the street outside the theater, chanting the actor's name.

title: For Pauline Kael, Retirement as Critic Won't Be a Fade-Out
description: Earth-shattering news does not always arrive beneath banner headlines. It may turn up in small print and almost as an afterthought, like the Editor's Note that followed the Current Cinema column in last week's New Yorker. "We regret that Pauline Kael feels that it's time, after 24 years at the magazine, to retire from regular reviewing," the note began. Within the world of film criticism, where Ms. Kael has been such a formidable and influential presence for decades, that announcement was enough to set off seismic waves.

title: Low-Fat McDonald's Burger Is Planned to Answer Critics
description: In its latest move to counter sluggish sales and answer a growing chorus of criticism of its food, McDonald's plans to introduce a hamburger that is lower in fat. The new hamburger, which the company might announce as early as today, would be the first such product to be available nationwide at any fast-food chain.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Proper Irish Coffee

title: Ellen Rosen, 51, Dies; Ex-New York Official
description: Ellen Israel Rosen, creator of the mayoral office that later became the New York City Commission for the United Nations and Consular Corps, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rams Sign Zendejas
description: The Los Angeles Rams signed the place-kicker Tony Zendejas, left unprotected by the Houston Oilers, as a Plan B free agent yesterday.

title: Free Speech and a Flag, but This Time It's the Stars and Bars
description: For the past week Main Street in this small Piedmont town has been transformed by a sudden flowering of Confederate flags, some in the hands of students protesting outside the high school and others flapping from cars, motorcycles and dirt-red pickup trucks.

title: Bill Would Widen Assaults On Campus Speech Codes
description: The new president of the American Civil Liberties Union today joined a conservative Republican Congressman in an effort to give students at private colleges the same right to utter offensive statements as students at public institutions have.

title: Police Chief Denies Foiling Drug Inquiries
description: After listening for a week to more than two dozen witnesses testify that he had interfered with outside investigations into drugs to protect people, Police Chief James J. Dolan Jr. took the witness stand today in this river city to defend himself vigorously.

title: Albany Bank Takes Offer by Trustco
description: The Home and City Savings Bank, based in Albany, accepted a takeover offer of $25.12 a share in cash and securities from the Trustco Bank Corporation in Schenectady, N.Y. The $72.3 million Trustco offer must be approved by stockholders of both banks. The merged company, which would retain the Trustco name, would have $1.7 billion in assets and 43 branches.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Haugen Ruling Gives Camacho a New Lease
description: In the record books, Greg Haugen still gets credit for his disputed split-decision victory over Hector Camacho on Feb. 23.

title: Beggars and Ethnic Strife's Refugees Make Soviets Turn to Private Charity
description: In the basement of what was once an elegant townhouse in Moscow, behind a door marked Andrei Sakharov Order of Charity and Social Welfare, women wrestle with boxes of donated clothes, printed forms, insistent visitors, incessant calls.

title: Top 64? It Depends on Who's Computing
description: On the eve of the 64-team National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's basketball tournament, everybody seems to agree that the undefeated Runnin' Rebels of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas (30-0) are the giants of the 1990-91 season and that everybody else is a dwarf.

title: Korea Auto Exports
description: South Korea's auto exports to the United States plunged in the first two months of the year from a year earlier, the Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. Association officials said exports to the United States, Korea's biggest export market, fell 21.2 percent, to 17,554 cars, accounting for 43.5 percent of this nation's total car exports. Korea's overall car exports were listed at 40,380 in the first two months of this year, up 2.7 percent from year earlier.

title: Well, the Soup Is Good
description: To The Living Section:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Common sense prevailed and we have a deal." -- Robert Maxwell, on his plan to save The Daily News. [ B4:3. ]

title: BONES OF DINOSAUR NEAR SOUTH POLE
description: American scientists have found dinosaur bones on a windswept mountain near the South Pole, a discovery experts said proved beyond question that the celebrated prehistoric creatures were a global phenomenon.

title: The Battles to Come; A Revival of The News Will Prompt Fierce Fighting for Readers and Ads
description: The likely salvation of The Daily News by Robert Maxwell will raise the curtain on a fierce newspaper war as the paper tries to win back its lost circulation and advertising.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Al Klink, 75, Is Dead; Big-Band Saxophonist
description: Al Klink, a tenor saxophonist who worked with the Benny Goodman, Glenn Miller, Bob Haggart and Sauter-Finegan Orchestras, died Thursday at his home in Bradenton, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Bank Fund And C.D. Rates Drop
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts are down for the second consecutive week, but the rate of decline moderated in the week ended yesterday.

title: Weighing In on the Nutrition Scale
description: If McDonald's McLean Deluxe hamburger, which the company is expected to start selling nationwide on April 26, has the same nutritional value as the hamburger the company began testing in November in Harrisburg, Pa., it is an important nutritional improvement over the current fast-food burger line.

title: Note and Bond Selloff Lifts Rates
description: Pessimism returned to the credit markets yesterday, as a rise in the price of oil and other commodities and worries about coming economic indicators prompted traders to sell Treasury notes and bonds, pushing up interest rates.

title: California Agency Raises $88 Million
description: The Los Angeles County Redevelopment Agency yesterday priced $88.2 million in tax-allocation bonds through competitive bidding, which was won by a group of underwriters led by Bank of America.

title: In Rare Move, Governor Intervenes in Denver School Contract
description: In a highly unusual effort to improve schools, Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado has seized control of bitter contract talks in the Denver school system to prevent a strike and is personally writing a contract intended to overhaul the school system.

title: Japan Objects To U.S. Rice
description: Officials of Japan's Agriculture Ministry have angrily demanded that United States trade officials remove rice samples from a food trade show.

title: Battered Women, Battered Justice
description: For four years I was abused by my boyfriend. . . . I loved him and I thought he loved me. . . . I was scared to death of him. I didn't seek help because I was afraid of what he would have done to me. . . . I got fed up with him and then it was too late. . . . I'm sorry for taking my boyfriend's life. -- Statement by "Theresa," serving 5 to 15 years for manslaughter in New York.

title: 2 Accused of Starving Infant Son to Death
description: A Harlem couple were charged yesterday with manslaughter in the death of their 2-month-old son who, the medical examiner said, was starved to death.

title: Aid Sought From Congress To Ease Asbestos Caseload
description: The judges who make policy for the Federal courts asked Congress today to study ways to help state and Federal courts handle a growing flood of asbestos injury cases.

title: Whitehurst Makes Bid To Succeed Fernandez
description: The metaphor wasn't elaborate because the situation is starkly straightforward.

title: The Truth About My Family
description: Seeing my father, Peter Arnett, reporting live from Baghdad nonstop for 54 days was a proud experience for me.

title: Market Place; Nagging Question In Bond Insurance
description: WITH investors searching for certainty, bond insurance has become a big business. Last year, about $50 billion principal value of bonds were newly insured, up from $45 billion the previous year. In total, about $450 billion in principal and interest payments have been guaranteed.

title: PRETORIA PLANNING TO OPEN ALL LAND TO BLACK BUYERS
description: In one of the most significant steps yet undertaken to break down the barriers of apartheid, President F. W. de Klerk introduced legislation today to scrap all racial discrimination in land ownership and to allow South Africans to live where they choose.

title: Paul Ukena, 69, A Former Baritone With City Opera
description: Paul Ukena, a former baritone with the New York City Opera, died on Sunday. He was 69 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: OPEC to Cut Oil Output

title: Challenge Arises to a New Claim by U.S. AIDS Researcher
description: In a new twist in the dispute over who first isolated the AIDS virus, researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory today challenged the conclusion of a paper by a Government researcher who had said it bolstered his case.

title: U.S. and California End Nursing Home Battle
description: The State of California and the Federal Government reached a preliminary agreement today on the implementation of a new nursing home law that had pitted Gov. Pete Wilson against the Bush Administration.

title: Shoe Imports Up by 4%
description: Shoe imports rose last year in the United States for the first time in three years, the International Trade Commission said today. Imports captured 83 percent of the United States market. Imports of non-rubber shoes -- the vast majority of footwear -- rose by 4 percent, to 900 million pairs, valued at $8.4 billion. Of the total, China shipped 267 million pairs, nearly 100 million more than Taiwan and South Korea, the commission said.

title: Agreement Reached to Save Daily News
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, and the unions of The Daily News reached tentative agreements yesterday on new labor contracts, clearing a major obstacle to the purchase of what was once the largest daily newspaper in the country.

title: Eating Well
description: TALK about bad timing! Last week a new cookbook devoted entirely to root vegetables arrived on the desk. It might be superb, but who cares when the price of asparagus is coming down?

title: Mubarak Says He, Too, Opposes a Mideast Peace Conference Now
description: President Hosni Mubarak said here today that he was opposed to convening an international peace conference on the Middle East "at the present time," because Israel and its Arab neighbors are not yet ready.

title: Mother of Ill Child Wins Jobless Pay
description: The Minnesota Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a woman who lost her job last year because she had frequently stayed home to care for her sick baby was entitled to unemployment benefits.

title: Maxwell to News: Stay Alive
description: There's finally good news about The Daily News of New York. The British media baron Robert Maxwell and the paper's nine striking unions have reached a tentative agreement that clears the way for Mr. Maxwell to buy the paper from The Tribune Company of Chicago.

title: Partisan Fights Erupt on Rights Bill
description: An early but fierce political fight over civil rights broke out on Capitol Hill today as civil rights groups and Congressional Republicans clashed over a bill intended to protect employees from discrimination in the workplace.

title: Bank Dividends Are Questioned
description: The head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, criticized the nation's banks today for paying out big dividends instead of rebuilding capital.

title: It's Official: Palmer Calls It a Career
description: Baseball romantics celebrate the sounds of spring every year: the crack of bat against ball, the snap of ball popping into glove. The sound that Jim Palmer heard while warming up for the Orioles Monday was not romantic; it was climactic. It was the pop of a hamstring and it ended the unlikely comeback attempt of the 45-year-old Hall of Famer.

title: Science and Tradition Aid India's Mentally Ill
description: Sukhanya remembers how it all began almost 13 years ago. Her sister Rama, then 22 years old, suddenly stopped going to college. She turned down offers of marriage. She refused to get a job.

title: People
description: * Dean Stefanides and Larry Hampel have been named executive vice presidents and group creative directors at Scali McCabe Sloves, New York. * William Gray will join BBDO New York on April 1 as senior account director on its Pizza Hut account.

title: Arthur R. Kreutz, 84, Composer and Teacher
description: Arthur R. Kreutz, a composer and professor of music, died on Monday at the Golden Years Retirement Home in Oxford, Miss. He was 84 years old.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Stock prices declined today n Japan, and traders said they took decline on Wall Street on Tuesday as a cue to adjust their positions after five days of advances. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 309.10 points, or 1.16 percent, to 26,418.32, at the close of trading.

title: Administration to Address Fears Raised by Mexico Pact
description: Worried that it may lose authority to negotiate new trade agreements, the Bush Administration told Congress today that it would offer a plan by May 1 on ways to alleviate the impact of a Mexican free trade pact on health, environmental and labor standards.

title: Cats Are Excellent Judges of Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Four young immigrants from the Soviet Union scored a major upset Monday night here at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: White House Should Name Hispanic Nominee to U.S. Court; Diverse Backgrounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Pink Slips, Budget Blues
description: FORECASTERS who have been counting on the recession to melt away with the sunny news from the Persian Gulf got a rude surprise from the Labor Department on Friday. Unemployment reached 6.5 percent in February, the highest rate in four years and a sobering three-tenths of a percentage point higher than a month earlier.

title: Accounts
description: *Zale Corp., the jewelry retailer, to the Richards Group, Dallas, for national advertising of all divisions. Total billings are $35 million. The Dallas office of Bozell Inc. had handled a large part of the account, but resigned because it felt its work for Zale might conflict with its work for the J. C. Penney Shopping Network.

title: WINE TALK
description: POSSIBLY no segment of the wine market has changed as rapidly and profoundly in the past decade as kosher wines. Once seemingly limited to the traditional style -- heavy and cloyingly sweet -- kosher wine has had an explosion of diversity.

title: Bird Protection in Louisiana
description: The state and private groups have signed an agreement to protect more than 12,000 acres of Louisiana land important to water birds and bald eagles. The land, in Terrebonne, Lafourche and St. Charles Parishes, southwest of New Orleans, contains five bald eagle nests and is one of the state's most important nesting areas for water birds, said Nancy Jo Craig of the Louisiana chapter of the Nature Conservancy, a group that tries to protect unique animal and plant habitats.

title: Impact of Tax-Relief Plan Uncertain
description: The revisions to Gov. Jim Florio's Quality Education Act approved by the Legislature on Monday are likely to achieve the goal of easing the rise in property taxes in most of New Jersey's 567 municipalities this year, tax-policy experts here say.

title: A Baker Who Builds And Rebuilds Bakeries
description: WHEN Alou Niangadou left West Africa for Paris in 1979, clutching degrees in mathematics and physics, it was not to start a career in baking. He left, he said, "seeking a better life" than he had in Mali. An apprenticeship at a bakery was the first job he could find, and he loved it. He has never looked back.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A12-14

title: Shakespeare Fest: Learning by Doing
description: "You guys ready?" Cam Magee, the Mistress of Revels, shouted over her shoulder in decidedly non-Shakespearean fashion.

title: Soldiers in Haiti Are Seized In a Lethal Weekend Clash
description: Six soldiers were arrested and dozens of others were disciplined after a weekend clash in which four people were killed, the Government said today.

title: No Convictions in Trial Of Yen Futures Traders
description: In a severe blow to the Government's extensive prosecution of securities-fraud charges in Chicago, a Federal jury yesterday did not return guilty verdicts on any of the 238 charges faced by 12 yen futures traders.

title: American Airlines Begins Round Of Discounts to Encourage Travel
description: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier and the airline that is considered a leader in determining fares, initiated a broad range of price cuts yesterday in the hope of attracting travelers put off by the gulf war and the recession. But it also raised some fares in an attempt to compensate for revenue lost through the many reductions.

title: Review/Television; No Stone Unturned In Special on Gems
description: "Splendid Stones," tonight's National Geographic documentary, catches some of the grubbiness as well as the glitter of the mining, making and marketing of gems. Scheduled at 10 on Channel 13, amid the week's fund-raising gabble, it is a small sparkler in a tin setting.

title: Steinway Sets Piano Venture
description: Steinway Musical Properties Inc., the parent company of the venerable New York piano maker, and the Kawai Musical Instrument Manufacturing Company of Japan announced yesterday that Kawai would manufacture a Steinway-designed piano, for sale by Steinway dealers.

title: Lewis Ready to Run In Indoor Meet in Spain
description: Carl Lewis, the Olympic champion, will run his first indoor race in more than two years when he competes over 60 meters at San Sebastian, Spain, on Friday, one of his coaches said yesterday.

title: Jack Roche, 86, Dies; Radio and TV Writer
description: Jack Roche, a writer and producer for radio and television who specialized in comedy series, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Oilers Edge Islanders, 2-1
description: Joe Murphy and Martin Gelinas scored goals as the struggling Edmonton Oilers beat the Islanders, 2-1, tonight.

title: Metro Matters; Hail The News! Impish Upstart, Twister of Arms
description: When the drug dealing and the devastation became almost unbearable, it seemed as if only one thing kept the Casuso family from abandoning Bushwick: embarrassment.

title: Accord Won't End Finger-Pointing
description: From the very start of the Exxon Valdez accident, when Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood reported just after midnight on March 24, 1989, that his fractured tanker was "leaking some oil," the nation's worst oil spill has been viewed as an indictment of things well beyond Alaska and Prince William Sound.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The President; BUSH ACCUSES IRAQ OF BREAKING TRUCE IN FIGHTING REBELS
description: President Bush accused Iraq today of violating conditions of the Persian Gulf cease-fire by using helicopter gunships to put down insurrections by anti-Government rebels. He said there would be no permanent end to the war until the Iraqi combat operations ceased.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A party for NICHOLAS LEMANN on Tuesday night turned into a double-barrelled celebration: for his new history of the black northward migration, "The Promised Land," published this week and already widely praised; and for the engagement of NANCY LEMANN, a novelist who is his sister. They even share a publisher, Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Eluding I.R.S.: Wealth Helps
description: An estimated 40,000 people with incomes exceeding $100,000 who fail to file tax returns are less likely to be caught than are average earners who do not file, Congressional auditors said today.

title: Calendar: Art That's Accessible
description: Animals and Quilts Museum of American Folk Art, Feld Gallery at Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street; (212) 977-7298.

title: 9 Skiers Killed in Avalanche In Remote Canadian Range
description: Nine Americans and Europeans engaged in the daredevil sport of helicopter skiing were killed by an avalanche in the remote Purcell Mountain range of Canada, the ski tour operator said today.

title: Are We Jubilant at War's End or Just Relieved?; World Policeman's Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland to Start Stock Trading
description: Poland will start trading shares of the first five privatized state companies in April as a precursor to the establishment of a stock market, officials said today.

title: A Restrained Miller With a Successful 'Katya'
description: A conversation with Jonathan Miller is an intellectual roller-coaster ride. The 56-year-old English director, theater administrator, set designer, writer, lecturer, physician, stage personality and wit sends the listener reeling from Romanesque sculpture to Flaubert and Macaulay to the physiology of the retina to the newest epistemological studies in perception.

title: Are We Jubilant at War's End or Just Relieved?; Israel's Safety Margin
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixed Mortgages Rise
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.5 percent this week, up slightly from 9.49 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest level since rates were at 9.56 percent for the week that ended on Feb. 1. Since then, rates fell to 9.25 percent on Feb. 15 before turning up again. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.45 percent.

title: Trump Casino Officer
description: Donald J. Trump made a high-level management change in his Atlantic City casino operations yesterday, naming Dennis Gomes to be the president and chief operating officer of the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort. The Taj Mahal is the largest of Mr. Trump's three Atlantic City casinos. Mr. Gomes, 46 years old, is a former president and chief operating officer of the Golden Nugget Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas. A certified public accountant, Mr. Gomes has also worked for casino regulatory agencies in Nevada and New Jersey.

title: Providence Triumphs In Overtime in N.I.T.
description: Chris Watts scored 9 of his 15 points in the second overtime tonight, including six free throws in the last 16 seconds, giving Providence a 98-93 first-round National Invitation Tournament victory over James Madison.

title:
CURRENTS;
The Little Canopy That Could
description: FIXING up New York City's subway stations is thought to be one way to lure more riders.

title: Subordinated Debt Of BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is offering $200 million in subordinated notes due April 1, 2001, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Slovak Plant Pact With Volkswagen
description: Germany's automotive giant Volkswagen A.G. expanded its interests in Czechoslovakia by signing a joint venture agreement with a Slovak auto parts plant. Volkswagen is expected to make an initial investment of $32 million for an 80 percent stake in the BAZ plant in Bratislava, Slovakia's Deputy Premier, Vladimir Ondrus, said. He said the remaining 20 percent would be held by the Slovak state.

title: Mets Make Offer to Viola
description: Evidently satisfied that Frank Viola's elbow is not a serious long-term physical liability, the Mets today formally offered the star left-hander a contract extension, a deal for three years worth more than $12 million.

title: How to Put New Life Into an Old Trunk
description: A number of years ago, when the storage rooms of many Manhattan apartment buildings were being cleared of disowned property, they yielded a plethora of old trunks of all persuasions and ages, from wood-ribbed to steamer-style. Since modern travelers seldom use trunks, building superintendents were putting them out on the sidewalks on the eve of rubbish collection day.

title: Homosexuals Still Pressing To Join Parade
description: Four days before the St. Patrick's Day Parade, city officials worked furiously to fashion a compromise that would allow an Irish homosexual group to march in the parade. As of last night, efforts to devise a solution had created only confusion.

title: Dow Up 32.68 in Heavy Program Buying
description: The prospect of a further decline in interest rates gave stock prices new bounce yesterday. Renewed leadership in technology stocks plus waves of computerized program buying also drove prices higher.

title: Personal Health
description: Walking has recently surpassed swimming as the nation's leading form of exercise, but surprisingly few people know how to get the most benefit from the time and effort they spend doing it.

title: Chairman Calls Exxon Strong After Valdez Pact
description: Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of the Exxon Corporation, said today that the $1.1 billion settlement reached Tuesday night with Alaska and the Federal Government in the Exxon Valdez oil spill would not have any effect on Exxon's finances or its plans.

title: From Oil Spill to Settlement
description: 1989 MARCH 24: The 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez runs aground on Bligh Reef 25 miles south of Valdez, Alaska, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound, making this the largest tanker spill in United State's history.

title: Grand New Look For Humble Ticking
description: IT was the stuff of brewers' and waiters' aprons, ladies' stays, an emperor's battle tent and feather-filled bedding: rough-hewn blue and white linen twill.

title: Nerco to Buy Oil Wells In the Gulf of Mexico
description: Nerco Inc., one of North America's largest coal producers, said today that it would pay $475 million for oil and gas wells in the Gulf of Mexico, aggressively expanding its interests in oil and gas.

title: Economic Pulse: The Pacific Northwest - A special report.; Northwest's Fortunes, Once Grim, Thrive Despite National Recession
description: Ten years ago, during the nation's last recession, the Pacific Northwest was an economic disaster zone, with unemployment rates exceeding 15 percent in some areas and people leaving in droves. The 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens and the destruction it wrought seemed an apt symbol of the region's fractured economy.

title: Closing of Firehouse In Queens Is Upheld
description: Rejecting an appeal by community groups in Queens, a judge has ruled that the Dinkins administration acted on "sound fire protection principles" when it closed a fire company in one of the more emotionally contested moves to close the city's budget gap.

title: Data General's New Computer
description: The Data General Corporation yesterday announced a new family of computers intended to compete in markets traditionally served by the makers of mainframe systems.

title: Kasatonov's Goal Caps Devils' Rally
description: The Devils' 3-2 victory over Toronto tonight after they fell behind by two goals may be precisely the kind of tonic New Jersey needs for the stretch run to the playoffs.

title: A Troubled Sears Plans To Cut Five Directors
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would shrink its board to 10 members from 15. Although Sears portrayed the move as an effort to give outside directors a greater voice in the troubled retailer's affairs, one result is that it makes it more difficult for a dissident shareholder to win election to the board this year.

title: F.C.C. Vote On Reruns Is Delayed
description: Responding to a last-minute plea from the Justice Department, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission delayed a vote scheduled for Thursday on a proposal that would continue to restrict television networks' ability to sell lucrative re-runs.

title: Cavs Re-sign Wilkens
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers gave Coach Lenny Wilkens a multiyear contract extension yesterday, ending speculation that he might not be back with the team next season.

title: Erin Go Brawl
description: I never felt entirely at home at past St. Patrick's Day parades. As constituted by the Ancient Order of Hibernians -- emphasis on the Ancient -- they reminded me until recently of two perceptions of the Irish: as silver-haired civil servants redolent of Old Spice, and as intoxicated teen-agers throwing up into the hedges of Central Park.

title: Major U.S. Study Finds No Miscarriage Risk From Video Terminals
description: In the most detailed study of its kind so far, Government researchers have found that pregnant women who work all day at video display terminals run no more risk of miscarriage than women in similar jobs without the terminals.

title: Greenspan Hints at Cut In Rates
description: As the Federal Reserve reported the first tentative signs that the recession might be easing, Alan Greenspan hinted that the reduced threat of inflation might make it possible for the central bank to give the economy an additional boost by cutting interest rates further.

title: PROTESTING SERBS SEEK TO OUST CHIEF
description: Huge crowds of anti-Communist protesters intensified their pressure today on the government of the republic of Serbia by calling for the resignation of its president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Review/Television; Ireland and New Sounds In 'Shamrock 'n' Roll'
description: The world of the Irish and Irish Americans is changing these days. And it's not just a matter of a determined group of gay-rights advocates sending shudders through the Old Guard of clergy and Ancient Hibernians who control New York's St. Patrick's Day parade. That's nothing compared with the election of Mary Robinson as President of Ireland. A woman, heaven help us, and one with relatively liberal ideas about divorce and abortion! The land of shamrocks and leprechauns may finally be lurching toward the 20th century.

title: McCartney Decides To Bootleg Himself
description: Paul McCartney has decided to beat record bootleggers at their own game by releasing a limited edition recording of his forthcoming concert on MTV.

title: Review/Recital; Alan Titus Undertakes Schubert's 'Winterreise'
description: Everyone, it seems, is singing Schubert's song cycle "Winterreise" these days. On Friday evening, the American baritone Alan Titus took his turn at Weill Recital Hall, and the effort proved ill advised.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Palestinians in Kuwait Face Suspicion and Probable Exile
description: Saleh Ismail stood trembling in front of the Kuwaiti security officer who had him brought up from a basement.

title: Are We Jubilant at War's End or Just Relieved?
description: To the Editor:

title: Billy Owens Honored
description: Billy Owens, the Syracuse all-American and Big East Conference Player of the Year, made it a clean sweep yesterday when he won the same honor in Division I of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the impact of The Daily News settlement on New York City's three other major daily newspapers misstated the change in advertising lineage from the fourth quarter of 1989 to the fourth quarter of 1990. Lineage in The New York Times declined 19 percent in that period, and it declined 8 percent in The New York Post. Lineage in Newsday rose 4 percent.

title: Albert Einstein, Universe Maker
description: Albert Einstein, whose birthday is today, and George Bernard Shaw greatly admired each other. They first met at a private dinner in London in 1921 and kept in touch mainly through Shaw's American biographer, Archibald Henderson, a mathematician who worked with Einstein on relativity and atomic theory in the 1920's at the Institute of Physics at the University of Berlin.

title: McDonald's New Burger
description: In the latest development in a growing effort to attract health-conscious Americans to fast food, the McDonald's Corporation confirmed today that it would start selling a hamburger that it said would be 91 percent fat free.

title: Dorothy Kramer, 61, Church Official on L.I.
description: Dorothy Kramer, a Long Island church official, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 61 years old and lived in Port Washington.

title: Sax Finds Happiness Being an Ex-Dodger
description: Steve Sax woke up this morning ready to play baseball, just as he always does. Sax was especially eager because the Yankees were playing the Dodgers, the team that shunned him in contract negotiations three years ago.

title: Security Remains Tight
description: Although the Persian Gulf war is over, the tougher security it brought to the nation's airports may remain. Federal officials will soon meet with airline and airport executives to talk about which rules to curb terrorists to make permanent, if any.

title: Hollywood Memoir Tells All, And Many Don't Want to Hear
description: Julia Phillips was so certain her memoirs would offend the Hollywood Establishment that she entitled them "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again." But when she walked into the Polo Lounge of the Beverly Hills Hotel on Monday afternoon, she was graciously ushered to a quiet booth with a commanding view of that day's wheeling and dealing.

title: Tight Deadline Called Problem At Daily News
description: The leader of the striking unions at The Daily News said yesterday that the unions could not approve new contracts in time to return to work until after the deadline set for tomorrow by The News for completing its sale.

title:
CURRENTS;
For Harmony in Design
description: FORGET architectural tours. Chamber Music in Historic Sites matches the music to the setting around Los Angeles.

title: Study Finds Improved Therapy for Rectal Cancer
description: Combined chemotherapy and radiation treatments have significantly lowered the recurrence of rectal cancer after surgery and have improved survival, a new study has found.

title: Talking Deals; Chase Financing Of Spacehab Plan
description: LAST week's announcement that Spacehab Inc. had obtained a $64 million five-year financing package from the Chase Manhattan Bank marked the first time that a leading bank had lent money to send anything other than a communications satellite into space without a guaranteed repayment.

title: Scientists Seeking Possible Wonder Drugs in Tea
description: If preliminary findings stand up to closer scientific scrutiny, tea -- especially the green tea of the Far East -- could become a popular and potent weapon in the war against chronic diseases.

title: Key Rates
Nicola Rossi-Lemeni, 70, Teacher And a Bass Who Sang at La Scala
description: Nicola Rossi-Lemeni, an Italian bass whose performing and teaching career extended over 45 years, died on Tuesday at Bloomington Hospital in Bloomington, Indiana. He was 70 years old.

title: Pacific Approval For Northwest Air
description: Northwest Airlines has won tentative Federal approval to invest $20 million in ailing Hawaiian Airlines and to operate four potentially lucrative Pacific routes. The preliminary order from the United States Department of Transportation was filed on Monday. In addition to opening new Pacific markets to Northwest, the deal would also provide financial relief for Hawaiian, which has defaulted on $150 million in loans from its principal lender, the Security Pacific Bank.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir CHARLES POWELL, who has been a private secretary and the principal foreign policy adviser in the British Prime Minister's office since 1984, will step down March 26. Sir Charles, who was an eminence grise to MARGARET THATCHER , who resigned Nov. 28, had agreed to stay on under Prime Minister JOHN MAJOR until the end of the Persian Gulf war. Among other duties, he dealt with BRENT SCOWCROFT, President Bush's national security adviser.

title: South Carolina Journal; On Second Thought, Forget Lunch
description: If South Carolina legislators wonder whether voters are tired of hearing about the Federal undercover operation that resulted in the indictment of 13 state legislators last year, they should talk to W. R. Britton.

title: Tokyo Stocks Advance
description: Japanese stock prices moved slightly higher today in light trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 124.01 points, or less than half of 1 percent, to close at 26,542.33. On Wednesday, the Nikkei lost 309.10.

title: Duke Enters Governor's Race
description: State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader who won 44 percent of the vote in a recent run for the United States Senate, announced today that he would run for Louisiana governor. Mr. Duke, a Republican, said he was not worried about Gov. Buddy Roemer's switch to the Republican Party. "I'm hitting the ground running," he said. "We've got a great chance to win."

title: Sentencing in Killing Of Anti-Drug Figure
description: One of two men convicted of killing a woman who tried to rid her Brooklyn neighborhood of drugs was sentenced yesterday to a maximum term of 48 years to life in prison.

title: Pepsico Restaurant Deal
description: The shareholders of Collins Foods International Inc. on Monday approved the transfer of its 209 domestic Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants and certain real estate properties to Pepsico Inc. in a tax-free exchange of stock.

title: Syracuse Will Compete With Hungry Squads
description: For Syracuse, the second-seeded team in the East Regional and the highest-rated of the eight squads at Cole Field House here, N.C.A.A. tournament bids have become, like snow, an accustomed part of winter.

title: Money Market Funds Show Only Slight Change in Yields
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report showed mixed changes for the week ended yesterday for the second consecutive week.

title: Topics of The Times; Hoboken Holiday
description: In the menacing, surreal world of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, even the jaded commuter does a double-take: A sign at Gate 33 advertises "Holiday Tours to Hoboken." Now, isn't that straining the limits of fancy? The trip to Hoboken is, after all, only a 20-minute commuter run that costs a dollar.

title: Archibald Singham, 58, Professor And Authority on the Caribbean
description: Archibald W. Singham, an authority on the Caribbean and a professor of political science at Brooklyn College of the City University of New York, died on Tuesday at Tisch Hospital in the New York University Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Sale of Aetna Stake
description: Banco Hispano Americano said it would pay 9.7 billion pesetas, or about $100 million, to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company for its 45 percent stake in the insurance company La Estrella. La Estrella's chairman, Miguel Geijo, said the priceamounted to 45 percent of the company's capital, reserves and potential capital gains plus a 23 percent premium. Aetna estimated it would realize a capital gain of about $32 million for its interest in La Estrella. The transaction is expected to be completed in May.

title: Nagashima Journal; As One More Dam Is Built, Japanese Anger Bursts
description: A foul-smelling epiphany came to Megumi Ohmori a few years ago as she was crossing a bridge and saw construction crews demolishing thick patches of reeds on the riverbank below. Then suddenly she was hit by the stench of rotting fish and birds.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Refugees; Accounts of Iraqi Fighting
description: "They would come in tanks, driving over corpses," Mohsen Khammis said today at a camp for refugees from the unrest in southern Iraq. "They would pour gasoline on dead and half-dead bodies and set them on fire."

title: Proud Campus Days Amid St. Peter's Debut
description: The banner was lowered slowly from a rooftop on West Side Avenue in Jersey City, twisting in a hard wind that made hanging it difficult.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about stock market activity on Tuesday misstated the date that midmonth short-interest positions in individual stocks on the New York and American stock exchanges will be reported. It is March 21, not March 15, for publication on March 22.

title: Topics of The Times; Senator Yes (No)
description: Where does Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York stand on legislation to clean up Federal campaign financing and ethics? In a recent letter to a constituent, he deplored "the ever-increasing cost of running for office" and cited his support last year for several key provisions of S.137, the far-reaching campaign reform proposal sponsored by the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell.

title: B.S.B. Loses Miller Lite Account to Burnett
description: In one of the largest account transfers in the history of advertising, the Miller Brewing Company withdrew its $100 million-plus Miller Lite account from the Backer Spielvogel Bates agency yesterday and awarded it to the Leo Burnett Company.

title: Appellate Panel Grants Reprieve To Law on Tests
description: A Federal appeals court has granted at least a temporary reprieve for New York's landmark truth-in-testing law, which had been ruled unenforceable last year by a judge who said it conflicted with Federal copyright law.

title: Child World Sale Expected in April
description: The CNC Holding Corporation, owner of troubled toy retailer Child World Inc., said it expected to sign an agreement soon to sell its 82 percent interest to a group headed by two former executives of Toys "R" Us Inc. CNC said the sale to the WC Acquisition Corporation, formed by W. John Devine and Ronald Tuchman, is expected to close by the end of April.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Troops; House Approves Veteran Benefits As Part of Appropriation for War
description: Swept by the patriotic fervor that has followed the Persian Gulf war, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a barrage of benefits not only for veterans of that war, but also for other veterans, past and future.

title: Elmo Pope Brown, Executive, 85
description: Elmo Pope Brown, retired assistant vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York, died on March 7 at his home in Columbus, N.Y. He was 85 years old and had lived in East Islip, L.I., for 50 years before moving to Columbus two years ago.

title: Retail Sales Rose by 0.8% In February
description: Retail sales rose in February for the first time in four months, the Commerce Department said today, raising hopes that the worst of the recession may be past.

title: John A. Bellairs, 53, A Children's Author
description: John A. Bellairs, an author of children's books, died on Friday at his home in Haverhill, Mass. He was 53 years old.

title: Poland Sees Debt Cut
description: A presidential spokesman announced on Tuesday that Western creditors might reduce Poland's $48 billion foreign debt by up to 80 percent over three years. The statement followed a meeting between President Lech Walesa and David Mulford, the United States Treasury Under Secretary. Mr. Mulford is negotiating a debt-reduction plan before Mr. Walesa's visit to Washington beginning next Wednesday.

title: Breaking Up Is Becoming Harder to Do
description: THESE days there is so much emphasis on the family that divorce seems to be going out of style. Therapists say many couples struggle harder and longer to stay together than they might have a few years ago. Poll takers find a greater value being placed on the idea of commitment and a happy marriage. And researchers churn out studies suggesting that both children and adults suffer physical and emotional harm from divorce. Indeed, with the advent of books like "Adult Children of Divorce Speak Out" (Simon & Schuster, 1991), the day may be coming when divorce will be considered a pathology.

title: O.K., Saddam, Where's the Uranium?
description: An unfortunate paradox of the destruction of Saddam Hussein's nuclear sites is that Iraq may now find it easier, not harder, to make an atomic bomb.

title: Higuera Sidelined
description: The left-hander Teddy Higuera of the Milwaukee Brewers, who signed a four-year contract for $13 million in December, will be sidelined indefinitely after tests yesterday revealed a torn rotator cuff.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Israel Relief in Jerusalem; For Now, Israeli Leaders Are Grateful Baker Didn't Push Too Hard on Talks
description: Israel's leaders breathed a long, loud sigh of relief this morning as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d took off for the next leg of his diplomatic mission.

title: A Suburban Mall Is Now 'Downtown'
description: ONE has to wonder if malls can survive the injury of economic hard times as well as the artistic bashing they get from things like the new movie "Scenes From a Mall." And now there is an even more serious threat to the hegemony of malls and the subdivisions they rule.

title: Market Place; Private Placement Off to a Slow Start
description: AMID great hoopla last April, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a regulation intended to lead to a strong market for trading private placements. The initiative, known as Rule 144a, was hailed as a breakthrough that could allow American investment firms to play a broader role in the global market, as well as draw foreign companies into issuing their securities here.

title: Joseph Abeles, Photographer, 83
description: Joseph Abeles, a theatrical photographer who befriended dozens of aspiring actors and actresses, including some, like Tony Curtis and Marlon Brando, who went on to become stars, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Brilliant Victory for Soviet Pair and Surprising 3d for U.S.
description: The pairs competition of the world figure skating championships concluded in stunning fashion tonight, not only for the brilliance of the winners, Natalya Mishkuteniok and Artur Dmitriev of the Soviet Union, but also for the wholly unexpected third-place finish by an American couple, Natasha Kuchiki and Todd Sand.

title: Boston Landlord Bankrupt
description: Boston's biggest landlord has filed for bankruptcy after talks with creditors on refinancing $650 million in debt collapsed, a spokesman for him said today.

title: Many in Rochester Still Without Power
description: More than 10,000 homes in the Rochester area remained without power yesterday, 10 days after an ice storm caused wide damage and knocked out power to at least 300,000 homes in western and northern New York.

title: A Defeated Republican Will Be S.B.A. Director
description: Patricia Saiki, a Republican who lost a close race to Senator Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii in the fall, has been nominated as the director of the Small Business Administration.

title: Suit Calls Election System in New Rochelle Biased
description: New Rochelle, long known as one of the New York metropolitan region's best integrated cities, was sued yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan by a legal rights group challenging its election system, contending that it discriminates against black voters and excludes blacks from public office.

title: Final (Four) Words
description: In the words of the immortal bluesman Sonny Boy Williamson, "Everybody's talking, but nobody knows," So it goes with the N.C.A.A. tournament. Adding their voices are Malcolm Moran and William C. Rhoden, who cover college basketball for The Times WILLIAM C. RHODEN EAST North Carolina: Its toughest challenge will be a regional quarterfinal game against U.C.L.A., but the Tar Heels have the right blend of talent this season, plus depth. WEST U.N.L.V.: A victory over Georgetown will put the Rebels on a skyrocket path to the national championship game. MIDWEST Ohio State: Although they faded at the end of the regular season, the Buckeyes are well equpped for this region. Look for a monster game with Duke in the regional final. SOUTHEAST Arkansas: The Razorbacks full-court pressure defense and heart will pull them through a classic confrontation with Indiana. NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP U.N.L.V.: The team's strength is its extraordinary ability to focus on the task at hand, in this case beating Arkansas. When Mike Farmer, the former University of San Francisco forward, was asked what drove the Dons to win consecutive national championships, he said: "If you're hungry, it's like a second piece of pie. You want it." With the aroma enchanced by 30 regular-season victories, U.N.L.V.'s pie is now in sight. MALCOLM MORAN EAST North Carolina: The Tar Heels defeat Oklahoma State after Oklahoma State eliminates Syracuse. WEST U.N.L.V.: The Rebels have an easier route than expected until they survive a regional final against Seton Hall. MIDWEST Texas: The Longhorns end DePaul's joyride and then find a way to deny Duke a fifth Final Four appearance in six years. SOUTHEAST Indiana: The Hoosiers will have opportunities to exploit the Arkansas inside game. NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP Indiana: The Hoosiers are left to preserve both the credibility of the N.C.A.A. and the status of the 1976 Indiana team as the last undefeated champion. They are propelled by pre-game speeches that begin at 6 A.M. and culminate with talks by former Hoosier Quinn Buckner at 8:37, Norman Schwarzkopf at 8:52, and N.C.A.A. executive director Dick Schultz at 9:07. Lyndon Jone's last-option shot beats U.N.L.V. and triggers Hoosier Dome hysteria.

title: India Disbands Parliament; Vote in May Seen
description: The President of India dissolved Parliament today, a week after the resignation of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, paving the way for the country's 10th national election. It is expected to be held in May, on a date to be set by the Election Commission.

title: Bridge
description: It was an upsetting day for favored squads in Tuesday's third-round play in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship.

title: 3 Traders In Settlement
description: Three oil futures brokers accused of fraud last summer in the first charges arising from an undercover investigation of the New York commodities pits have settled out of court.

title: Sematech Awards Contracts to Etec
description: Sematech, the venture of the Government and private companies in semiconductor manufacturing, has awarded two contracts to Etec Systems Inc. of Hayward, Calif., to provide high technology and equipment.

title: Output to Be Cut At Aston Martin
description: Aston Martin, the maker of luxury sports cars, said it was cutting production and dropping one-sixth of its staff of 535. Only four models a week will roll off the factory line in rural Buckinghamshire, northwest of London, instead of the present five or six.

title: Senate Panel Backs President's Nominee For Education Chief
description: By a vote of 16 to 0, a Senate committee today recommended confirmation of former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, President Bush's nominee to be Secretary of Education.

title: Review/Music; Zubin Mehta And Israeli Orchestra
description: Zubin Mehta's other life, conductorially speaking, has been in the news of late, since he flew spontaneously to Tel Aviv and the Israel Philharmonic at the outbreak of the war in the Persian Gulf. Tuesday night, he brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall, and a glamorous audience made it a festive occasion for reasons that went far beyond mere music.

title: Early March Vehicle Sales Down 14.7%
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 14.7 percent in early March, deflating auto makers' hopes that euphoria over the quick allied success in the Persian Gulf war would lift vehicle sales out of the current slump.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: When Houses Sit for Their Portraits
description: MICHAEL BRISTOL is a house painter, the kind who uses watercolors and small brushes instead of rollers and latex paint. For five years Mr. Bristol has painted portraits of houses, both exteriors and interiors, usually working from photographs.

title: Kodak Sells Unit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said on Tuesday that it had sold its Ultralife 9-volt lithium battery business for an undisclosed sum to investors operating under the name Ultralife Batteries Inc. Ultralife said it intended to continue production in Newark of the batteries, which are used mostly in smoke alarms, garage door openers and toys, and to diversify into other lithium battery products. Kodak said it would continue to produce its Supralife and Photolife alkaline batteries, as well as other lithium batteries.

title: Can OPEC Enforce the New Accord?
description: The day after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries struggled to agree to cut production by 5 percent, its 13 members are trying to project a united front. But given OPEC's poor record in enforcing its previous production agreements, many analysts predict that prices could slide because the new output levels could greatly exceed demand and because individual OPEC members, as in the past, might try to increase revenues by producing more than their allocated levels.

title: Two Coaches Censured
description: Bob Knight, the Indiana coach, and the Illinois coach, Lou Henson, were reprimanded and censured yesterday by the Big Ten for their verbal spat after Sunday's game in Champaign, Ill.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AFTER THE WAR: Iraq; Big Street Protests Reported in Baghdad
description: Street protests were reported in Baghdad today and Iraq admitted for the first time that the country was in the grip of an uprising against President Saddam Hussein.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Diplomacy; Baker-Assad Talks Extended; One Topic: The U.S. Hostages
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria held more than six hours of talks tonight about how to promote Arab-Israeli peace talks in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Are We Jubilant at War's End or Just Relieved?; New American Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke and Nestle Name Head of Joint Venture
description: The Coca-Cola Company and Nestle S.A. announced yesterday that they had chosen a top Coke executive, Harry E. Teasley Jr., to run a new joint venture, the Coca-Cola Nestle Refreshments Company.

title: Black Forum Looks at Child Rearing
description: Ruby Dee, the actress and author, uses African folk tales to educate and entertain her seven grandchildren. Tomorrow night she will use these tales to encourage women to become more involved in the educational and moral development of their children.

title: An Annenberg Donation to Los Angeles Museum
description: Walter H. Annenberg, who bestowed a $1 billion art collection on the Metropolitan Museum on Monday, has donated $10 million to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the museum announced yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angles, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities. * Manufacturers Hanover Corp. is offering $100 million in 9.50 percent noncallable notes due March 15, 1994, at a price of 100 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

title: Fly So Free Favored In the Florida Derby
description: Meadow Star finally left Gulfstream Park today and headed by air for New York, where she may or may not put her perfect record on the line this weekend.

title: As Collor Completes First Year, Brazilians Write Off Their Highest Hopes
description: One year ago, Brazilians watched with expectation as Fernando Collor de Mello donned the presidential sash here and vowed to bring Latin America's largest nation into the first world, following a road of low inflation and free-market economics.

title: New York State Revenue Bonds
description: The New York State Housing Finance Agency is offering $90.165 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.898 percent for a bond due 2020 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday omitted in some copies the day on which an American Wine and Food Institute beer tasting will be held. The tasting will be Monday, from 6 to 9 P.M., at the Museum Club and Bridgewaters, at the Fulton Market Building in the South Street Seaport.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE emotional pain of infertile couples can be worsened by the reactions of their parents and siblings. The stress of being unable to conceive can raise barriers not only between spouses, but also between them and their families and friends. However, families and friends can help relieve a couple's pain and become even closer by the way they show their support.

title: Article 252091 -- No Title
description: To allay investor concerns that rising consumer defaults on credit-card loans could cause losses for holders of securities backed by those loans, J. P. Morgan Securities and the MBNA America Bank announced a new variety of credit-card security yesterday.

title: Export Funding Corporation Prices $200 Million in Notes
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in secured notes due July 31, 2001, through underwriters led by the B T Securities Corporation.

title: Not Climbing, but Using the Walls
description: IN Manhattan, a city of high-rises, Jonathan Foster built his bedroom closet as developers build buildings.

title: William Heinesen, Writer, 91
description: William Heinesen, a novelist and poet whose writing chronicled life on the Faeroe Islands, died on Tuesday in Thorshavn, the capital of the islands, where he was born. He was 91 years old.

title: O'Neal Is a Huge Obstacle for UConn
description: The day before his first experience as a focal point in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Shaquille O'Neal of Louisiana State considered one of the three most frequently asked questions about the 7-foot-1-inch, 295-pound sophomore center.

title: Grumman to Cut Space Station Jobs
description: The Grumman Corporation said it would cut 110 more jobs at its space station support division in Reston, Va. The reduction comes on top of the 34 jobs cut in January.

title: Rangers' Downfall Continues
description: If the Rangers need a theme for this harsh month, it could be "Backward, March." A 4-1 loss to the Detroit Red Wings last night extended their losing streak to four games, their longest such skid of the season.

title: To Sell Tax, Weicker Takes It on the Chin
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. rubbed his eyes, took another swallow of Perrier and prepared himself for one more anonymous assault from a listener of the Brad Davis Breakfast Club.

title: Etheridge Knight Is Dead at 57; Began Writing Poetry in Prison
description: Etheridge Knight, who began writing poetry in prison and emerged to win acclaim and awards for his work, died on Sunday at his home in Indianpolis. He was 57 years old.

title: Prices Up on Fed Chief's Remarks
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, aided by comments from the Federal Reserve Board chairman and substantive, though far-from-conclusive, evidence that the end of the Persian Gulf war had not provided a near-term boost to the economy.

title: Dr. Walter Nudelman, Internist, Is Dead at 66
description: Dr. Walter Nudelman, an internist, died on Tuesday at Saint Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Harding Township, N.J.

title: Mary Kay Files Suit Against Avon
description: Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics giant, has been accused by a competitor of digging through a trash bin to uncover trade secrets and confidential documents. The Dallas-based Mary Kay Corporation and the Richmont Corporation, which manages the businesses and investments of a Mary Kay affiliate, contend Avon and two detective agencies improperly obtained company documents. The lawsuit filed in state district court seeks $10 million in punitive damages.

title: Telesphere's Client List
