description: In a further consolidation of the long-distance telephone industry, Telesphere Communications Inc. announced yesterday that it was selling its list of direct-dial long-distance customers to the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Fate of Police Chief in Los Angeles Is Vigorously Debated After Beating
description: From the Mayor's office to breakfast tables in Watts and the San Fernando Valley, the main question in Los Angeles today is: Should Daryl F. Gates leave his job as Chief of Police?

title: Article 312891 -- No Title
description: After hammering out a compromise with the Administration this afternoon, the House narrowly passed a bill tonight to provide another $30 billion to continue the expensive and unpopular bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about cast changes in "Luisa Miller" at the Metropolitan Opera rendered the name of the soprano in the title role incorrectly. She is Maria Spacagna.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * GTE, Stamford, Conn., named S. Donald McCullough vice president and general manager of its European lighting division. * Genovese Drug Stores Inc., Melville, L.I., named Thomas Esposito vice president and director of professional relations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dallas County officials voted Tuesday to allow OLIVER STONE access to the Texas School Book Depository to film "JFK," his film on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. KEVIN COSTNER plays JAMES GARRISON, the former New Orleans prosecutor who maintained that the shooting was a conspiracy between the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHETHER a room is painted or wallpapered, an easy way to freshen or change its appearance is to trim the walls with border strips of wallpaper. The project requires only basic wallpapering skills, so beginners will find it both satisfying and manageable.

title: Review/Dance; Cunningham Opens A Two-Week Season
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which opened a two-week season on Tuesday night, continues on its uncompromising path. For someone who has taught at least two generations of dancegoers to view an art form in an entirely unconventional way, Mr. Cunningham remains remarkably fresh.

title:
CURRENTS;
An Architect, a Teacher And an Opener of Doors
description: WHERE possible, architects like to design everything from the building down to its door handles. But some, like George Ranalli , don't even need to design the building.

title: Carreon Can't Run Well But He Still Hits Homers
description: There are, of course, others across Florida and Arizona with more home runs, more hits, more runs driven in. Still, Mark Carreon of the Mets may have the most impressive numbers of baseball's spring of 1991. They read: three hits in three chances on one leg.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: After the War A10-12

title: Irving V. Sollins, 82, Pharmaceutical Expert
description: Irving V. Sollins, a researcher in steroids and oral contraceptives and an entrepreneur in the pharmaceutical industry, died on Monday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: The Joke's On Whittle For Losing Best Seller
description: Whittle Communications roiled book publishing more than a year ago when it introduced a line of advertiser-sponsored books. Now, the book industry's worries have turned to derision. Whittle let a best seller slip from its grasp.

title: Folding Door Crushes Girl, 9
description: A 9-year-old girl was critically injured today when she was crushed by an electric folding door that is used to divide the gymnasium at the Sunquam Elementary School, the Suffolk County police said. The girl, whose name was not released, apparently became trapped at 2 P.M. when she tried to squeeze between the wall and the door, which was being closed, the police said.

title: Knick Streak Up to 4 As Everyone Chips In
description: Too many Knicks played too well for New York to lose tonight.

title: Fighting Crime With Ceremonies
description: "America is a can-do nation, and today, at home, we must seize the day. The kind of moral force and national will that freed Kuwait City from abuse can free America's cities from crime."

title:
CURRENTS;
To Serve Hors d'Oeuvres From Sea to Shining Sea
description: WITH many people feeling patriotic, the America table by Allegra Hicks should have considerable appeal.

title: Allied War Dead Are Flown to Saudi Arabia
description: The bodies of 14 allied dead were flown from Iraq to Saudi Arabia today aboard a Red Cross plane, the United States military said.

title: Chrysler to Cut Board; U.A.W. Chief Is Out
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that five of the auto maker's 18 directors will not be nominated for re-election at this year's annual meeting in May, including the president of the United Automobile Workers.

title: AFTER THE WAR: France; French Seem Willing to Work With U.S. in the Middle East
description: Having traditionally competed with the United States for influence in the Middle East, France has unexpectedly signaled its desire to work closely with the Bush Administration in trying to settle the Palestinian and Arab-Israeli problems in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday and a front-page article on Monday about a dispute between the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States over a real estate partnership rendered incorrectly the name of a New York developer involved in the dispute. He is Jerry Speyer, a principal of Tishman Speyer Properties.

title: Engineers Support Stangl
description: Peter E. Stangl, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad president who is being investigated for allowing a friend to sit at the controls of a commuter train, received support yesterday from the union representing the railroad's engineers, which endorsed his nomination as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Last Sentencing in Jogger Attack
description: Saying that he was sorry that the law prevented him from imposing a tougher penalty, the judge in the Central Park jogger case yesterday sentenced the last defendant in the case to one and a half to four and a half years in prison.

title: Cutting Jobs: After Handshake, Buyouts and Confusion
description: Eliminating more than 800 jobs at The Daily News, which the nine striking unions agreed to do in marathon bargaining with the British publisher Robert Maxwell, is easier said than done, union leaders said yesterday.

title: AFTER THE WAR: The Hardships; Those 8-Hour Food Lines in Kuwait City: 'There Is No System'
description: Mukaram Mustafa, a mother of five, says she has spent eight hours each day this week standing in line for food.

title: Are We Jubilant at War's End or Just Relieved?; Technology Controls
description: To the Editor:

title: Images of Japan, Ancient and Modern, Make an Old American Craft Seem New
description: AT "Made in Japan: American Influence on Japanese Quilts," the new show at the Japan Society Gallery in Manhattan, the sources of inspiration for the 38 quilts displayed range from ancient symbols to the computer. There is a quilt of miniature kimonos made from robes worn by five generations of the quilter's family, a quilt depicting a trapunto crane tucked behind a lattice cage of silk, and one of planets twirling in space.

title: Goodyear to Cut 1,100 Jobs and Take $65 Million Charge
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, rocked by increasingly sluggish sales for tires, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,100 salaried jobs over the next 12 to 18 months. The giant tire company also said it would take a $65 million pretax charge against first-quarter earnings for the cost of the work force reduction.

title: Books of The Times; Combing Scotland for a Border Collie
description: Eminent Dogs, Dangerous Men By Donald McCaig Illustrated. 212 pages. Edward Burlingame Books/ HarperCollins . $19.95.

title: Amid Inquiry, Transit Lacks An Advocate
description: The uncertainty that clouds Peter E. Stangl's nomination to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority means further disarray atan agency that is struggling with severe deficits, service cuts and possible fare increases.

title: Jimmy McPartland, 83, Cornetist Who Played Chicago Jazz, Dies
description: The cornetist Jimmy McPartland, one of the originators of the brash 1920's variant of Dixieland that became known as Chicago-style jazz, died yesterday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He would have been 84 years old tomorrow.

title: Five Killed in Bronx Fire
description: Five people were killed and 12 firefighters were injured last night in a fire that gutted an abandoned three-story building occupied by squatters in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, fire officials said.

title: Call Up Computer For a Pick
description: If you're a basketball fan who's hooked on suspense, avert your eyes.

title: Bensonhurst Case Ends, Satisfying Few
description: After 19 months of painful legal proceedings, the Bensonhurst case, which once transfixed New Yorkers, has ended, leaving many of those who cared most about it dissatisfied with its results and leaving unanswered many of the questions it raised about race and New York City.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We have a natural longing that these court cases, somehow, will resolve this larger debate over reality: 'Is America a place where a black kid can be killed by a white mob for walking down the street?' " -- Shelby Steele, social critic, commenting on the Bensonhurst case. [ B4:2. ]

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telecommunications company, will acquire the Missouri Telephone Co. for $85 million. * BSN Corp., Dallas, a sporting goods company, said its board had decided that a $55 million offer for two of its businesses was inadequate.

title: Queens Man Guilty In a Slaying in 1980
description: Nearly 11 years ago a woman was stabbed to death in an attempted robbery in Queens. The killing remained unsolved until a man walked into a police station in 1989 and, detectives said, confessed. But later he insisted that the detectives had linked him to the wrong victim and therefore he was not guilty of the murder charged.

title: Carolco Plans To Sell Stake
description: The Carolco Pictures Corporation said today that it had agreed to a three-part transacation in which the company would sell a stake to an Italian media company.

title: All Else Aside, Prisons Waste Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Rescuing The Daily News: A Struggle Down to the Wire; In Final Hour, a Long List of Problems to Settle
description: It was a few minutes after 2 P.M. on Tuesday and less than an hour remained until the final deadline set by Robert Maxwell for the conclusion of his bargaining with the unions of The Daily News. Eight of the 10 unions had settled with Mr. Maxwell, the British publisher trying to buy The News, and he was threatening to leave the country if the other two unions did not reach agreements by the end of the hour.

title: Manhasset Journal; Trafficking in Parking For a Fast-Track Crowd
description: Every morning, like piranhas converging on a tasty ankle, thousands of out-of-town commuters descend on this little hamlet on the North Shore of Long Island, hunting for a place to park.

title: Risk of Malaria in U.S. Is on the Rise
description: Few people contract malaria in the United States, but health officials say the risk may be slowly increasing.

title: Salvadoran Army Vows to Press Jesuit Case
description: The Bush Administration said today that the army high command in El Salvador had pledged in a letter to the Salvadoran Justice Minister to undertake new efforts toward prosecuting those involved in the slayings of six Jesuit priests in November 1989.

title: Bank Profits Fell 31% During Last Quarter of 1990
description: Plagued by a mass of deteriorating loans, commercial bank profits fell 31 percent in the final quarter of last year to $1.39 billion, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: Perrier Agrees To Change Ads
description: Perrier Group of America, the Greenwich, Conn., subsidiary of the French company that bottles Perrier mineral water, has agreed to a Government order to change its advertising.

title: March's Chill Notwithstanding, Spring Is Creeping In All Over
description: THE flood tide of spectacular spring color has yet to come in most parts of the country. It will be some weeks before the larger forms of trumpet daffodils reach their peak of bloom and a bit longer before the many kinds of tulips hybridized in the Netherlands paint the landscape with their exuberant scarlets and crimsons and with more subtle shades of apricot, buff, cream and pale yellow.

title: Choice for a Pivotal Appeals Court Seat Quits Club
description: Less than a week before what promises to be a contentious hearing on his nomination to a pivotal appeals court seat, a Federal district judge today announced his resignation from a Florida country club that has a reputation for excluding blacks and Jews.

title: Trader Mac's Blockbuster Fits Padres
description: Like the osprey, baseball's blockbruster trade is an endangered species. Free agency, long-term contracts and no-trade clauses handcuff general managers. But in the San Diego Padres' new gray road uniforms with navy blue and orange lettering, Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez were living proof that the blockbuster trade still exists.

title: Fluoridation Plan Divides Suffolk Residents
description: In the 1940's, as municipalities around the country began putting fluoride into their water, opponents spoke darkly of Communists and said fluoridation was nothing less than a plot to control America through its faucets. The arguing died down in most places as studies began to show that fluoride did fight childrens' tooth decay, and today, 130 million Americans live in areas with fluoridated water.

title:
CURRENTS;
Past Perfect; Future Tense
description: THE directions were clear: The new editorial offices of The New Yorker magazine were to approximate the "back corridors of a 1940's courthouse" said Jeanne Halsey, the senior designer at L.C.P. Associates , a New York firm.

title: INSIDE
description: Room for Another Rate Cut Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted to Congress that the reduced threat of inflation might make it possible to cut interest rates further. Page D1.

title: Schweik in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Butt, 95, Dies; Founded Store Chain
description: Howard Edward Butt, founder of a chain of 175 supermarkets and 31 video stores, died Tuesday at a hospital in Corpus Christi. He was 95 years old.

title: Delay Worsened High-Rise Fire
description: Guards at a skyscraper delayed reporting a fire alarm for several minutes, allowing the fatal blaze to destroy an electrical emergency system, the Fire Commissioner said on Tuesday.

title: Europe in 1996
description: Fate's croupier, long accustomed to a loser at my position at his table, has murmured amazement at my recent war and market luck and shoved two piles of winnings my way.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about progress on a century- old math problem incorrectly rendered a researcher's name and the school at New York University with which he is affiliated. He is Dr. Manfred Padberg of the Leonard N. Stern School of Business.

title: Stanford, Criticized on Research Costs, Alters Billing System
description: Donald Kennedy, president of Stanford University, today told a House subcommittee that the school was changing its accounting procedures as a result of an investigation that indicates the university may have overcharged the Federal Government as much as $200 million for indirect research costs.

title: Eubank Fined $19,000
description: Chris Eubank, the World Boxing Organization middleweight champion, was fined $19,000 and reprimanded by the British Boxing Board yesterday for butting his opponent in the head during a title fight last month.

title: Trial Told of Mandela Intervention to Save Youths
description: A new witness in the trial of Winnie Mandela on kidnapping and assault charges testified today that he and a companion were held at Mrs. Mandela's house until the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, intervened from prison to have them released.

title: Rutgers Women Upset
description: Right from the beginning, Coach Theresa Grentz could sense something wrong with her Rutgers Lady Knight basketball team.

title: Tough Airport Security Measures May Remain Despite End of War
description: The Persian Gulf war is over, but the tough airport security measures imposed at its start may remain.

title: At Penn State, Something New to Cheer
description: On the northeastern rim of the Penn State campus lies Beaver Stadium, deserted for the winter. Even in its emptiness, the looming 83,000-seat edifice is a steel testament to the place of honor football holds in this rural central Pennsylvania town. This year, however, Linebacker U. has spawned two basketball teams that are vying for a place in school history alongside legendary football squads.

title: Review/Theater; A Mother and Daughter Grow Apart
description: After a father's early death, a woman and her teen-age daughter continue to live together, and to grow apart. That is the first premise of Vivian Gornick's 1987 memoir, "Fierce Attachments" (adapted to the stage by Edward M. Cohen, at the Jewish Repertory Theater). From there, Ms. Gornick tells the story of a self-centered woman who spends her life mourning her loss of a husband, and of a self-contained daughter who tries to discover herself as a woman and a writer away from the domination of her mother.

title: The Airline Agreement: No Losers
description: The airline agreement negotiated this week by the U.S. and Britain does far more than resolve a troublesome dispute over landing rights at Heathrow Airport in London. It will inject foreign competition into domestic air travel, improving service and lowering prices. The agreement also calls for talks to further liberalize access to each other's markets. The outcome could provide an enviable blueprint for later negotiations between the Euro pean Community and the U.S.

title: An Ominously Slow Salvador Count
description: It may take a week or more to count the votes in last Sunday's election for El Salvador's National Assembly. The official excuse is that voters had to choose 84 legislators on a complex ballot. Yet already there are charges of vote fraud from the underdog center-left opposition, known as the Democratic Convergence.

title: Private Builders Offer Efficiencies to New York School Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry B. Hollins, 82, Supplement Publisher
description: Harry B. Hollins, founder of WorldPaper, a newspaper supplement aimed at promoting cooperation among nations to form a new world order, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations; Destruction of Iraqi Chemical Arms Urged in U.N.
description: Britain is pressing the Security Council to demand that President Saddam Hussein destroy all his chemical and biological weapon stocks under international inspection and publicly renounce terrorism before a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war is put into place, diplomats said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In a round of diplomatic musical chairs, RAYMOND G. H. SEITZ is to replace HENRY E. CATTO as the United States Ambassador to Britain. PRESIDENT BUSH said on Wednesday that he would nominate Mr. Seitz, 50 years old, a career Foreign Service officer who is the Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs.

title: Europe Clears Centocor Drug
description: Centocor Inc., a biotechnology company based in Malvern, Pa., said yesterday that its Centoxin drug for the treatment of septic shock had been recommended for approval in Europe. Septic shock, an often- fatal disease, affects about a million patients annually in the European Community and the United States.

title: Loan Troubles Grow for Banks and S.& L.'s
description: Real estate problems for banks and savings institutions worsened sharply in 1990 and shifted from the Southwest to Northeast and Middle Atlantic States, the Government said today.

title: Review/Film; Finding Home in Emotional, not Geographical, Terms
description: Ann Hui's delicate, finely observed "Song of the Exile" tells a tale that is at once singular and universal. The particulars of this largely autobiographical film, which opens today at the Quad Cinema, involve the marriage of a Japanese woman and a Chinese man just after the Sino-Japanese war, and the ostracism faced by the wife as she tried to make peace with her husband's relatives.

title: Iraq: Domestic and Diplomatic Concern
description: President Bush's warning to Iraq on Wednesday to stop combat operations against insurgent forces reflects a strong and recurring desire in the Administration to bring Saddam Hussein's rule to an end, but to do so without crossing the line to direct intervention on the part of the 100,000 United States Army troops that continue to occupy southern Iraq.

title: Los Angeles Chief Taunted at Hearing; U.S. Plans Wide Inquiry on Brutality
description: At a public hearing 11 days after white officers were videotaped beating a black motorist, a parade of elected officials, civil rights advocates and private citizens today accused Police Chief Daryl F. Gates of tolerating and even encouraging brutality by police officers against black and Hispanic men.

title: Blaylock Helps the Nets Run Away From the Pistons
description: March madness, at least for the New Jersey Nets, is finally over.

title: Parker Goes to Angels
description: Milwaukee traded the 17-year veteran Dave Parker to California yesterday for the outfielder Dante Bichette and a player to be named later.

title: A Co-Creative Director Is Hired by Korey, Kay
description: Korey, Kay & Partners has hired Jamie Seltzer, a creative director in New York known for her work on accounts like the Nynex Yellow Pages and Sara Lee.

title: Review/Film; Father and Daughter in the Courtroom
description: Jedediah Tucker Ward (Gene Hackman) is a brilliant San Francisco lawyer who fights for underdog causes, smallish financial returns and, on occasion, great publicity.

title: Regulators Criticized
description: Federal regulators should crack down on weak banks quickly rather than make a prolonged effort to work informally with the institutions' managers, the head of the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Corrections
description: A letter in The Home Section on March 7 referred erroneously to President Chester Alan Arthur's marital status. President Arthur was a widower; the nation's only bachelor President was James Buchanan.

title: Review/Film; Japanese Animation Festival
description: Japanese animated films have become enough of a cult item for the Film Forum 2 to have organized an entire three-week festival devoted to them. "Robot Carnival," which opens the festival today, is an anthology of eight short works by leading Japanese animators organized around the theme of robotics. All eight of the shorts offer a lot more visual pizzazz than Saturday-morning cartoons on television, but only two of the eight begin to transcend the genre.

title: Inventories Rose 0.4% In January
description: Business sales slackened 1.2 percent in January, helping to increase inventories by four-tenths of a percent, the Government said today. That resulted in an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.56, the widest in six and a half years, but analysts said the figure was still not dangerously high.

title: Ex-P.O.W.'s Offer Accounts Of Terror and Torture in Iraq
description: In their first extensive public comments since being released two weeks ago, Americans taken prisoner in the Persian Gulf war today recounted tales of terror, torture and, occasionally, compassion at the hands of their Iraqi military captors.

title: Bush's Education Nominee Is Confirmed in the Senate
description: As expected, the Senate confirmed former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee today as Secretary of Education.

title: The Powell-Cheney Relationship: Blunt Give-and-Take Early in Crisis
description: The low point of the relationship between Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell came in the first hours after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, as the two men and their aides faced a giant map of the Arabian Peninsula in the Defense Secretary's cavernous office on the Pentagon's outer ring.

title: Dayton Profits Off 6%
description: The retailing giant Dayton Hudson Corporation today reported a 6 percent decline in fourth-quarter profits. For the quarter that ended on Feb. 2, earnings totaled $235 million, or $3.21 a share, down from $250 million, or $3.50 a share, in the final quarter of the previous year. Revenues totaled $4.87 billion, up 8 percent from $4.49 billion. For the year, Dayton's profits were $412 million, or $5.44 a share, up from $410 million, or $5.37 a share. Revenues increased 8 percent, to $14.74 billion from $13.64 billion.

title: In Coal Country, a Home-Grown Clinic
description: Near the Appalachian village of Harold, Mud Creek divides into Little Mud and Big Mud. From there, Big Mud runs along Route 979, a twisting, shoulderless two-lane road that carries 22-wheel Mack trucks with tarpaulins stretched over immense cargoes of coal. Every square foot of Big Mud's damp banks seems cluttered with trash, like the lungs of many patients at Eula Hall's Mud Creek Clinic, about seven miles along Big Mud.

title: Going to the Library In Brooklyn in 1916
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Liked Him in the War, You'll Love Him in the Video
description: He riveted them in Riyadh and wowed them in Washington, and now every American can see him joke, witness his withering scorn and watch him point to charts. Coming to a video store near you, it's Gen. H. Norman (Stormin' Norman) Schwarzkopf in "The Briefing" -- co-starring The Reporters.

title: INSIDE
description: Maxwell to Take Over Daily News Next Week

title: Review/Art; Wholesome Enough for Children
description: Michael Craig-Martin makes Conceptual art of an unusually public sort: handsome, accessible, with a sense of common good and shared fun. Mr. Craig-Martin, who was born in Ireland in 1941 and who attended college in the United States in the early 1960's, has lived in London since 1966. Although well known in London as an artist and a teacher, he is making his American debut in the "Projects" series at the Museum of Modern Art and in a show at the David Nolan Gallery in SoHo.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Crusader's Issue: What Should Be Done When a Whistle-Blower in a Legal Firm is Dismissed?
description: Howard Wieder's crusade to make lawyers more honest snuck into Albany last week, two years and at least $100,000 in out-of-pocket expenses after it began. Soon, New York's highest court, the Court of Appeals, will decide whether to take on Mr. Wieder's case, and thereby enter the legal and moral thickets it represents.

title: 6 Are Killed and 15 Firefighters Are Injured in a Fire in the Bronx
description: Six people were killed Wednesday night and early yesterday morning when a suspicious fire ripped through a South Bronx tenement so crammed with furniture and mattresses that firefighters had trouble fighting the blaze, fire officials said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Applebee's International Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a restaurant chain, has named Ronald B. Reck executive vice president of human resources. Robert T. Steinkamp was named a vice president and Stuart F. Waggoner vice president of franchise operations. * Centel Corp., Chicago, has named Charles F. Wright vice president-corporate development and Bryan E. Kneeland vice president-investor relations. Michael J. Small has been named executive vice president-administration/engineering/network operations of a unit, Centel Cellular Corp.

title: Death in the Gulf: 11 Soldiers' Stories
description: For some, life was inconceivable out of uniform; for others the armed forces were just a way station on the route to college and a job. But for 11 soldiers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who served in the Persian Gulf, the end was the same: death in the combat zone. Page B4.

title: Critics of New Denver Airport Say Bad Times Demand Halt to Project
description: Even as workers are preparing to pour the foundations for a new airport here, the first big airfield in the nation in nearly 20 years, bad times have emboldened critics seeking to halt the project.

title: Auctions
description: 30 Works Go on the Block

title: Japan Increases Trade Surplus
description: Strong demand for Japanese products abroad offset the impact of higher oil prices to widen Japan's merchandise trade surplus in February.

title: Newsday Adding Parade
description: Parade, the magazine that appears in 339 Sunday newspapers around the country, will add Newsday to its list beginning on March 24.

title: Ambitious Lovers' Edgy Brush With Popularity
description: The Ambitious Lovers -- Arto Lindsay and Peter Scherer, actually -- have a hit. The group, a favorite on the downtown scene, has spent the last five years both desiring one and, in some ways, avoiding one. It has been an exercise in artistic and commercial equivocation.

title: Blarney for St. Patrick's From Irish Tourist Board
description: Hoping the celebration this Sunday of St. Patrick's Day will make some people homesick for Ireland, the Irish Tourist Board is running an ad today in newspapers in six cities, including New York, Chicago and Boston. The ad appears in The New York Times on page A17.

title: P.L.O. Chief's Tough Line
description: Yasir Arafat shows no sign that the Persian Gulf war has changed his mind about Saddam Hussein or the shape of a regional peace. Page A12.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Assessing B.S.B.'s Loss Of Miller Lite
description: THE loss of any large account is a significant blow, but the defection of the $110 million Miller Lite business to Leo Burnett earlier this week could be particularly devastating to Backer Spielvogel Bates, industry executives and analysts said.

title: Arts in New York Ask Only Fair Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwaiti Emir, Tired and Tearful, Returns to His Devastated Land
description: Looking tired and deeply shaken, the Emir of Kuwait ended seven and a half months of exile today, returning to his devastated country 16 days after the final flight of Iraqi occupiers.

title: South Africa and Namibia Halt Talks Over Strategic Atlantic Port
description: High-level delegations from South Africa and Namibia met in Cape Town today to search for some consensus on the future of Walvis Bay, a strategic deep-water port on the Atlantic Ocean that South Africa kept when it granted independence to Namibia a year ago.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. No Islander Playoffs Gary Roberts scored the tie-breaking goal early in the third period, the 100th of his National Hockey League career, as the Calgary Flames defeated the Islanders, 4-2, last night, extending their home-ice unbeaten streak to a club record 18 games (17-0-1). The loss ended the Islanders' hopes for a playoff berth in the Patrick Division. Joe Nieuwendyk had two goals for Calgary, increasing his season total to 41. Bill Berg and Wayne McBean scored for the Islanders. (AP) SLED-DOG RACING Blizzard Conditions Blowing snow forced three of the five leaders in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog race to reverse course yesterday in the home stretch of the 1,163-mile trek to Nome, Alaska. The whereabouts of the other two weren't known, but they were not feared lost. "It's incredibly bad; I don't remember when I've seen it worse," the musher Tim Osmar said of the so-called ground-blizzard conditions. He was one of the three who returned to White Mountain, just 77 miles from the finish line in Nome. Also turning back was the four-time winner Susan Butcher. (AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers Beat Bucks Craig Ehlo put Cleveland ahead for good with two straight 3-point shots, then sank a clinching 18-foot jumper with 16 seconds left as the Cavaliers beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 103-101, last night at Richfield, Ohio. (AP) SCHOOL BASKETBALL Seton Hall Prep Wins Seton Hall Prep of West Orange, N.J., the boys' Parochial A champion (31-0), found enough weaknesses in the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association defending champions to send Elizabeth High School home without a ticket to the final for the first time in the three-year history of the Tournament of Champions last night in Piscataway, N.J. The Pirates scored a 63-50 victory in the semifinals at Rutgers's Louis Brown Athletic Center and now all they have to do is find a way to stay in the same arena with St. Anthony of Jersey City in Sunday's title game. St. Anthony, 31-1 and the boys' Parochial B champion for the ninth straight year, has been beating opponents by an average of 44 points but fell short of that mark in eliminating Delsea Regional, the Group II champion from Franklinville, N.J., 86-46, in last night's other game.

title: Manufacturers National
description: A. Alfred Taubman said this week that he had cut his stake in the Manufacturers National Corporation to 4.97 percent, or 763,316 common shares. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Taubman, a shopping center developer, said he had sold 46,000 shares in mid-February at $54.50 to $54.875 a share. Mr. Taubman did not say why he sold the stock in the Detroit bank holding company. Manufacturers National's stock closed today at $53.75, down 75 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: A Bush Initiative?
description: In the explorations under way on the possibilities for Arab-Israeli peace, there is one fact of immediate importance. President Bush is going to the Middle East next month.

title: Joseph Mirachi, Cartoonist, 71
description: Joseph Mirachi, a cartoonist and illustrator whose work appeared in The New Yorker, Playboy and other publications, died on Sunday at Dover (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

title: 'Dances With Wolves' Depicts Sioux Well; Banned but Nominated
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. TAKES STEPS TO COMBAT ABUSES ON '900' NUMBERS
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed rules today aimed at preventing fraud and deceit by companies that provide information and services through "900" telephone lines.

title: Good Start For Pirates; Creighton Is Next
description: Behind their hot-shooting guard, Terry Dehere, Seton Hall won its opening-round West Regional game today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, overpowering Pepperdine by 71-51 at the Huntsman Center.

title: 13 Journalists Are Winners of Polk Awards
description: Honoring reports ranging from behind-enemy-lines coverage of the invasion of Kuwait to detailed scrutiny of the insurance business by a four-page monthly newsletter, Long Island University announced the winners yesterday of 13 George Polk Awards in Journalism.

title: Reviews/Art; 'American Beauties': Images of Softness Rendered in Concrete
description: The tone of Mia Westerlund Roosen's installation at the Sculpture Center in Manhattan is set by its bubbly and sarcastic title, "American Beauties." The beauties are breasts of concrete, assembled into a long low machine that seems not so much installed as stored in this exhibition space. The machine suggests the blades of a sexual reaper, or a battalion of baby pacifiers, or a Stone Age chariot of wrathful fire.

title: Army's Role in Politics Deadlocks Yugoslavia
description: Yugoslavia's eight-member presidency adjourned tonight deadlocked on a proposal to expand the role of the national army in dealing with internal political emergencies.

title: Administration Yields on Speeding Jobless Benefits
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Bush Administration has increased the amount of money that it is willing to spend to shore up the management of the nation's unemployment benefit system and has agreed to exclude that money from caps that Federal budget law imposes on discretionary Government spending.

title: Review/Fashion; Fashion's Oddities Show Up in Paris
description: Before the main fashion parade gets into full swing here in large tents at the Louvre, a number of less well-known designers hold shows in smaller rooms around the city.

title: A Win for Pirelli In Takeover Bid
description: Shareholders of Continental A.G., the German tire maker, voted 2 to 1 on Wednesday to scrap the company's main takeover defense, giving Pirelli S.p.A. a victory in its six-month bid to take over Continental.

title: Review/Film; Memories Both Painful And Pretty In 'Reunion'
description: "Reunion," directed by Jerry Schatzberg from a screenplay by Harold Pinter, takes an unusually luxurious view of the Holocaust, in terms of both privilege and time. The latter is what makes the vantage point of an American businessman named Henry (Jason Robards) so contemplative, since he has long since left Germany and distanced himself from the story's principal events. As "Reunion" begins, Henry is preparing for his first trip to Germany in decades and is experiencing a flood of memories that are both painful and pretty.

title: Fordham Romps on Late 15-0 Run
description: Dave Buckner jump-started Fordham's offense with his sixth 3-point basket and the Rams scored the last 15 points of the game to rally for a 76-66 victory tonight over South Florida in the opening round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: POLICE BRUTALITY UNDER WIDE REVIEW BY JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Responding to public outrage over the videotape of Los Angeles police officers beating an apparently helpless man, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Justice Department would review every police brutality complaint to the Federal Government over the last six years.

title: Budget Crisis Will End Schools' Mentor Program
description: The Board of Education, which decided in more prosperous times that its teacher-mentor program was a luxury it could not do with out, now says it is a luxury it cannot afford.

title: At the Movies
description: Spike Lee's Plans

title: TV Weekend; With Josephine Baker Through a Long Life
description: Josephine Baker died in 1975 and received a state funeral in Paris. Since then, hardly a year has gone by without an announcement that the American-born entertainer's story was being adapted for either a movie or a Broadway musical. Well, it's finally happened and Home Box Office got there first. "The Josephine Baker Story" is being added to the HBO schedule at 8 o'clock tomorrow night. Largely because of Lynn Whitfield in the title role, the portrait is vibrant. But a script bent on searching for inspiration and standard movie-biography uplift leaves the overall production seriously flawed.

title: Baby's Death Ruled Homicide
description: A baby girl's death on Wednesday in Brooklyn was ruled a homicide yesterday by the city's medical examiner, the police said. The 6-month-old, Chantel Jones of 666 Hancock Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, was taken to the emergency room of St. John's Hospital early Wednesday by an unidentified person, the police said. The identity and whereabouts of the child's parents were not immediately known. The Medical Examiner's office found that the death was due to a blow to the abdomen and internal bleeding, a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Grace Ridley, said.

title: Paramount and MCA Invest In Satellite Movie Venture
description: In a strong indication of Hollywood's interest in emerging entertainment technologies, Paramount Pictures and MCA said today that they had invested an undisclosed amount of money to help a pay-per-view movie transmission venture for the satellite dish market expand to 10 channels from four.

title: Review/Film; Friendship and Moral Disintegration in 'True Colors'
description: From all of the current films and television shows about the law, Hollywood producers would seem to be very high on ethics these days, though they sometimes have a very peculiar way of demonstrating it.

title: Avon Stake Is Reduced By Chartwell
description: Chartwell Associates L.P. took a big step away from the Avon Lady's door yesterday.

title: Syracuse Stopped Cold at Start of N.C.A.A.
description: Syracuse was eliminated in the first round of the Big East tournament last week. And they didn't last long in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: 4 Winners Of Eclipse Awards Fill Entry Box
description: One of racing's most glamorous days of the year took shape today when four Eclipse Award winners entered three races on two tracks in two states this Saturday, including the 1991 debuts for Meadow Star, Unbridled and Housebuster.

title: For Children
description: 'A Million Menus' Franklin Furnace Archive 112 Franklin Street Manhattan (212) 925-4671 Recommended ages: 3 and up Through tomorrow

title: Bone Marrow Program Cleared of Charges
description: Federal investigators have cleared a foundation for bone-marrow donors of allegations that it had misused funds and withheld names of potential donors from another program that helps to arrange marrow transplants.

title: Nacco Industries Head Becomes Chief in May
description: Nacco Industries, a Cleveland-based holding company with interests in household appliances, coal and forklift trucks, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Alfred M. Rankin Jr., would become president and chief executive after the company's annual meeting on May 8. Ward Smith will continue as chairman but will give up the chief executive's post.

title: John de Braganca, Investment Banker, 79
description: John de Braganca, a former vice president and treasurer of the Rhinelander Real Estate Company and later an investment banker, died on Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Anthony Story, 75, Pilot for MacArthur From 1945 to 1951
description: Lieut. Col. Anthony F. Story, the personal pilot of Gen. Douglas MacArthur from 1945, when he began ruling occupied Japan, until 1951, when he was removed from command in the Korean War, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: Caterpillar Prices Debenture Offering
description: Caterpillar Inc. yesterday priced $250 million in debentures due 2021 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Mackinac Bar and Grill

title: Exxon Said to Offer Millions To Erase 1990 Harbor Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to spend $10 million to $15 million on environmental improvements to New York Harbor in an effort to avoid litigation stemming from a 567,000-gallon oil leak into the Arthur Kill 14 months ago, environmental groups and a government official said yesterday.

title: G.M.-Poland Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation is close to signing a deal with Poland's biggest car maker, FSO, on production of its medium-sized Opel model in Warsaw, the Industry Minister, Andrzej Zawislak, said. But in Detroit, a G.M. spokesman would confirm only that talks were continuing. Mr. Zawislak said G.M. was ready for a capital investment in FSO, but he declined to give more details. News reports said an agreement could be signed this month.

title: Coaching Wins Games In March
description: In college hoops, the players come and go. So, we have discovered, do the broadcasters.

title: Swissair Purchase
description: Swissair, Switzerland's national carrier, said it will buy a majority stake in Crossair, a Swiss commuter airline, in a friendly takeover. Swissair holds 38.3 percent of Crossair's capital and 42 percent of its voting rights. Swissair also reported that its profit tumbled 96 percent in 1990, and it omitted a dividend for the first time in about 30 years.

title: Limit Seen on Reserve Combat Role
description: Military leaders have concluded that the National Guard and the Reserves cannot be sent quickly into combat alongside full-time soldiers, an approach the Army had long contemplated but could not carry out in the rapid mobilization for the Persian Gulf war.

title: Furnace Heating a Luxury In Rochester Power Crisis
description: Utility trucks, four in all, finally made it to Sherwood Road in this Rochester suburb today, almost two weeks after an ice storm crippled electrical service across much of central and northern New York State.

title: Ann Taylor Stock
description: Ann Taylor Holdings, which owns all of the stock outstanding in Ann Taylor Inc., the fashion apparel chain, said it was considering a public offering of its common stock. Ann Taylor was taken private by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners and Joseph E. Brooks and other members of management in a leveraged buyout in 1989. The terms of the stock offering have not yet been determined, but a registration statement and prospectus are expected to be filed on April 1.

title: The Spoken Word
description: GALLERY TALKS, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. "Looking at Modern Art: Architecture," by Christopher Miele, today at noon; "Mythic Imagery: Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko," by Jill Snyder, today at 1 P.M.; "On and Off the Wall: Art of the 1960's and 70's," by Ms. Snyder, today at 3 P.M.; "Henri Matisse: Painter and Sculptor," by Julie Reiss, tomorrow at 1 P.M.; "Art of the 40's," by Ms. Reiss, tomorrow at 3 P.M.; "Marcel Duchamp," by Ann Sass, Sunday at 1 P.M.; "Abstract Expressionism," by Ms. Sass, Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission: $7 ($4 for students and the elderly; under 16, free). Information: (212) 708-9480.

title: Larry Davis Convicted in Killing of a Drug Dealer
description: Larry Davis, who gained near folk-hero status in some quarters after a shootout with police officers and then beat back three attempts by prosecutors to convict him of murder and attempted murder, was convicted last night of killing a drug dealer in a Bronx robbery.

title: Microsoft's Tactics Questioned by Rivals
description: Three years ago when a start-up company called the Go Corporation began to develop software to control a new breed of pen-based computers, it showed its idea to software companies that it hoped would develop word processors, spreadsheets and other applications programs for its system. One group that saw the work was a team from the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Browning's Triple Jumps Lead to 3d Title in Row
description: With a free-skate program packed with triple jumps, Kurt Browning of Canada hit the biggest triple of them all when his scores lighted up inside the Olympic Hall tonight. They earned him a third consecutive men's title in the world figure-skating championships, making him the obvious favorite for the next major international competition, the 1992 Olympics in Albertville, France.

title: Books of The Times; Life in Prague Under Nazi Rule
description: Mendelssohn Is on the Roof By Jiri Weil Translated by Marie Winn. 228 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $23.95.

title: UConn Enjoys a Laugher With a 79-62 Rout of L.S.U.
description: After struggling through much of the season to rediscover the confidence and ease they knew a year ago, the Connecticut Huskies giggled and danced tonight.

title: Here's the Way to Be Irish
description: This is a weekend for celebrating St. Patrick's Day, one of our oldest American ethnic holidays and one that makes a singular assault on the senses. It is a holiday when everyone seems to have an affinity for things Irish, from green bagels to a green center strip running down Fifth Avenue. It is a solemn religious observance that is often overshadowed by a disconcerting ebullience and causes the most restrained onlookers to lapse into bogus brogues.

title: Miscellany
description: * Bozell Inc., will close its Atlanta office, where it handled the Valvoline account, with $15 million to $18 million in billings. The bulk of its regional businesses will be shifted to New York; Alexandria, Va., and Tampa, Fla. Overall billing at the Atlanta office is $30 million annually.

title: The First Lesson Of Philanthropy Is Well Learned
description: Now that she's been around awhile, 7-year-old Elizabeth Ely has developed some theories about how things work in the world. She knows, for instance, that when her Mom tucks her into bed at night, all four stuffed animals -- Daisy, Lilly, Birth Bear and Curious George -- are snugged under the covers with her.

title: Bush's Domestic Record Is His Achilles' Heel; Choose House by Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: Substitute Hinge for Space Shuttle Is Discovered to Be Cracked, Too
description: One of four new door hinges sent as replacements for cracked hinges on the space shuttle Discovery is also cracked, but the split is small and of little concern, a NASA official said today.

title: Bush and Mitterrand United On Peace, Divided on Process
description: President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France said today that they were in accord on the need to lend urgency to the Middle East peace process, but concluded an afternoon of talks in obvious disagreement on how to pursue that goal.

title: Little Change For Stocks on Volatile Day
description: Stocks took a volatile ride in heavy trading yesterday before ending just about where they began. The Dow Jones industrial average gave up 2.97 points to close at 2,952.23.

title: Prices on U.S. Securities Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday.

title: Traders Battle Sales Force Over Pay at Smith Barney
description: With Wall Street shrinking compensation levels across the board, a dispute over pay has erupted at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, pitting the brokerage's institutional sales force against its securities traders, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering $155 million in 7.36 percent callable notes due 1994 at a price of 100 through Prudential Securities. The notes are callable in 1992. * Fresno, Calif., is offering $22.4 million in certificates of participation for the Unified School District with a maximum yield of 7.20 percent for an issue due 2011 through Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. Yields range from 5.25 percent in 1993 to 6.50 percent in 2001. The financing is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Icahn Stake In Southland
description: A group of investment companies headed by Carl C. Icahn disclosed today that it had acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Southland Corporation, operators of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain.

title: Hextall Sidelined
description: The Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Ron Hextall will be out for at least a month with a groin injury, a team doctor said Thursday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: AFTER THE WAR A12-14

title: Housing in the Catskills; A New Project at Windham Ski Resort
description: The shift is away from town houses and toward semiattached houses for one developer of residential lots in this ski resort town who is seeking to find the best market for the 90's.

title: Times in Venture With Ad Group
description: The New York Times and the Association of National Advertisers announced yesterday that they would publish a new magazine to be distributed to the more than 25,000 advertising and marketing executives whose companies are members of the association.

title: Tainted Milk Prompts a Recall
description: Nestle USA has recalled all of a sweetened condensed milk from stores around the country after a can of it contaminated with the hallucinogenic drug PCP sent four members of a Pasadena family to the hospital.

title: Rebel Kurds Claim Control of Iraq Area
description: Kurdish rebels battling troops loyal to Saddam Hussein today claimed control of wide areas of the Kurdish region in the rugged northern part of Iraq, as opposition forces in several parts of the country reported new military gains.

title: A Saintly St. Patrick's Solution
description: All week it seemed that New York City's choice on St. Patrick's Day would be onerous: Give up the wearin' of the green or be a party to bigotry. But thanks to the persistence of Mayor David Dinkins and some cool compromises by others, the battle over the exclusion of gays and lesbians from the St. Patrick's Day parade has been settled amicably.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about benefits for Persian Gulf veterans misstated one provision of a House-passed bill in some copies. It would bar the military from calling to active duty any female reservist, or male single-parent reservist, who had a child less than 6 months old.

title: West Plans 50% Write-Off of Polish Debt
description: Polish and French officials said today that Western governments would announce on Friday the write-off of a large portion of Poland's $33 billion in official debt in a move aimed at helping Poland's transition to a market economy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an assertion that a friend of Peter E. Stangl, the president of Metro North Commuter Railroad, improperly operated a train included a statement misattributed by a spokeswoman for the Federal Railroad Administration. The assertion that Mr. Stangl's friend operated the brake and throttle came from the train's engineer, not the railroad foreman.

title: GTE Completes Contel Takeover
description: The GTE Corporation completed the $6.6 billion takeover of the Contel Corporation in the largest merger ever in the telecommunications industry. The merged company, with a market value of $28 billion and 197,000 employees, will be the country's largest local telephone company and the second-largest mobile cellular communications operator.

title: Jerome (Doc) Pomus, 65, Lyricist For Some of Rock's Greatest Hits
description: Jerome (Doc) Pomus, who with his partner, Mort Shuman, was one of the most successful rock-and-roll songwriters of the early 1960's, died yesterday at Tisch Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: At The News, Anxiety, Elation and Darting Eyes
description: It is a day that Judy Tillinger says she never thought would come. But now that her first day back as a graphic designer for The Daily News is almost here, her expectations for life after the strike are an emotional jumble.

title: Rangers' Rochefort Out Five to Six Weeks
description: The Rangers, who are in the midst of a four-game losing streak, got more bad news yesterday. Normand Rochefort, perhaps the team's most physical defenseman, suffered a fractured veterbra in his lower back in the 4-1 loss to Detroit on Wednesday night and will be out five to six weeks.

title: AFTER THE WAR: THE P.L.O.; Arafat Sees No Damage To P.L.O. in War Stand
description: TUNIS--During the Persian Gulf crisis, Yasir Arafat appeared to be conspicuously on the side of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Now that the war is over, Mr. Arafat does not acknowledge that he hurt his cause by appearing to back the losing side, even though his failure to stand by the Kuwaitis has cost the P.L.O. some $100 million in yearly contributions from the gulf.

title: Slovak Separatists Shout Abuse at Havel
description: Hundreds of angry Slovak nationalists rushed President Vaclav Havel and screamed abuse at him today during a demonstration for Slovak independence.

title: Edict for Henderson
description: The Oakland Athletics have isued an ultimatum to Rickey Henderson, who is in the second year of a four-year $12 million contract. There will be no contract extension and no trade, so it is time for the star outfielder to get ready for the season.

title: Joseph H. Snyder, Consultant, 70
description: Joseph H. Snyder, a management consultant, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: The Music of Burma
description: Kit Young, a pianist; U Win Maung, a singer and dancer, and Daw Lily Kya Nyunt, a singer, are to perform traditional vocal and piano music of Burma at 2:30 P.M. on Sunday at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The performance is said to be the first concert of Burmese music in New York City since 1975. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 545-7536.

title: Democrats: The Burden of Error
description: I miss the Democratic Party. Sometimes I find myself daydreaming that the party I knew will suddenly reappear, if only for a minute, so I can introduce it to younger friends who never got to know it before it passed away.

title: Bank Loan Rated For the First Time
description: In the first rating ever assigned to a bank loan, Fitch Investors Service said yesterday that it had assigned a medium-grade rating of single A to $250 million of loans issued to the Hills Department Stores.

title: Indiana Holds Off Coastal Carolina Rally
description: Indiana built a 15-point lead, then survived Brian Penny's 23 points in the last 10 minutes and beat unheralded Coastal Carolina, 79-69, tonight in the opening round of the Southeast Regional.

title: Sexism, And Hard Choices
description: What do you get when all parties in a dispute do the right thing? Try no dispute. Now try telling that to Meredith Vieira, Don Hewitt and CBS, all of whom seem to think they have a problem.

title: Economic Scene; Israeli Blessings And Burdens
description: THE effort to achieve peace in the Middle East, which President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d are now trying to push, is complicated by the huge influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, the scarcity of land and other resources and the uncertain ability of the Israeli economy to absorb the number of immigrants expected to arrive.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about LeRoy Collins, a former Governor of Florida, misidentified the Tallahassee law firm that he joined in 1970. It was Ervin, Varn, Jacobs & Odom.

title: Modest Weight Gain Found In Those Who Quit Smoking
description: The average smoker who gives up cigarettes gains six to eight pounds over the next five years, but about one in 10 of those who quit smoking will gain 30 pounds or more, a study shows.

title: Grumman Measure Backed
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a last-minute measure today that would make nearly $1 billion available to the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., to rebuild 12 F-14D fighter jets.

title: 'Dances With Wolves' Depicts Sioux Well
description: To the Editor:

title: McCabe Wins Account For Rally's Burger Chain
description: Ed McCabe has not wasted any time picking up his first big account. After only a month in business, McCabe & Company was awarded a $5 million to $10 million account yesterday for Rally's Inc., a hamburger chain based in Louisville, Ky.

title: Museum Honors All Rockefellers and Gifts
description: The Rockefeller clan gathered on Wednesday night at the National Building Museum, where they were given the museum's fifth annual Honor Award for their four generations of efforts to "preserve, enhance and create some of the nation's special places."

title: Ruling on the Hell Fighters
description: A Pentagon investigation into allegations of mistreatment by members of a Harlem-based National Guard unit in Saudi Arabia has found no cause for action, a New York Congressman says.

title: Campo Grande Journal; For Everyone to See, Governors' Dirty Laundry
description: For a no-nonsense farm state, the Governor's palace here presents an odd sight: drying laundry festoons the driveway, policemen watch television soap operas in the reception hall and teachers nap on mattresses in office corridors.

title: Dreams of Beating the Unbeatable Team
description: Although most people expected his team to be shaking in anticipation, Coach Stew Morrill said his Montana Grizzlies were relatively unfazed by Friday's first-round game with Nevada-Las Vegas, the undefeated defending national champion.

title: Maxwell Signs Takeover Deal For The News
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell signed a final agreement yesterday to take over The Daily News, saying he had already begun the fight to rebuild what had been New York's largest tabloid newspaper before a crippling 20-week strike.

title: Darling's Poor Outing Doesn't Worry Mets
description: The off-season surgery on his elbow meant the scrutiny of Ron Darling's performance in spring training would be intense. The loss of Sid Fernandez for three months sharpened the focus. And the fact that Darling had asked out of his scheduled outing earlier in the week insured that today's trip to the mound would be the central drama of the game against the Reds.

title: Arafat Sees No Damage To P.L.O. in War Stand
description: During the Persian Gulf crisis, Yasir Arafat appeared to be conspicuously on the side of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Now that the war is over, Mr. Arafat does not acknowledge that he hurt his cause by appearing to back the losing side, even though his failure to stand by the Kuwaitis has cost the P.L.O. some $100 million in yearly contributions from the gulf.

title: Review/Film; Reliving the Grim Days of Hollywood's Blacklist
description: Humphrey Bogart is known to be a "big, big fan" of David Merrill's, since David (Robert De Niro) is a gifted new director just beginning to take on the trappings of movie royalty, circa 1951. He drives around town in a sleek white convertible, and he gets a warm welcome at the Brown Derby. He is a guest in the screening room of Darryl F. Zanuck, who regards Merrill as his very special protege; there, Zanuck confides his irritation at Howard Hawks over the rushes for Hawks's latest picture, the one with Marilyn Monroe. Merrill's talent has turned him into a legitimate insider. Hollywood hopefuls don't get much more hopeful than this.

title: Market Place; Failure Group Thrives on Disaster
description: After the brief Persian Gulf war, in which very little went wrong for the allied forces, it may be seem odd that a company called the Failure Group Inc. sees a lucrative postwar role for itself. But Failure, the nation's largest consulting firm devoted to analysis of accidents and disasters, figures its skills are sorely needed.

title: U S. Ruling A Setback For T.W.A.
description: In a move that could plunge another airline into financial crisis, the Transportation Department gave tentative approval yesterday for the sale of only three of Trans World Airlines' London routes to American Airlines. It turned down the sale of three others.

title: Barber's 'Souvenirs'
description: The pianists John Browning and Charles Wadsworth are to play Samuel Barber's "Souvenirs" on a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center program at 5 P.M. on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. The program also includes Ravel's Piano Trio in A minor and Mozart's Divertimento for Two Horns, String Quartet and Bass (K. 287). The other performers are to include Fred Sherry and Jian Wang, cellists; Robert Routch and Robert Carlisle, hornists; Ani Kavafian and Carmit Zori, violinists; Walter Trampler, violist, and Lewis Paer, bassist. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Pryor Arrested
description: The former junior welterweight champion Aaron Pryor was arrested yesterday in Cincinnati and charged with drug abuse and aggravated drug trafficking, according to Frank Weikel, a spokesman for the Hamilton County Sheriff's Department. Pryor was arraigned in municipal court and was being held in the county jail on $10,000 bond.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 539 money market mutual funds increased by $2.85 billion, to $471 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 189 institutional funds increased by $659.1 million, to $133.35 billion. The assets of the 260 general-purpose funds were up by $1.82 billion, to $181.8 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds increased by $368.9 million, to $155.85 billion, the institute said.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: Helen Lee, 82, Fashion Designer For Children in U.S. and Abroad
description: Helen Lee Caldwell, a leading designer of children's clothes in Manhattan for three decades under the name Helen Lee, died on Wednesday at Fort Sanders Hospital in Knoxville, Tenn. She was 82 years old and had lived in Knoxville since 1981.

title: Deportees Tell of Torture by Kuwaitis
description: Kuwaiti soldiers deposited a busload of disheveled and hungry Palestinians, Iraqis and Jordanians a few hundred yards inside Iraq today, leaving them without food, water or passports and warning them not to return to Kuwait.

title: Key Rates
Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press on Wednesday showing a Jerusalem meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and a delegation of Palestinian leaders misidentified a participant. The woman at the right was Hanan Ashrawi, dean of English literature at Bir Zeit University, not Zuhaire Kamal.

title: Hope in the Streets of Belgrade
description: Slobodan Milosevic, president of Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, has always claimed to speak for all Serbs when he insists that Yugoslavia's six republics must live in a centralized state and economy. The thousands of Serb protesters in Belgrade's streets demonstrate how massively wrong he is.

title: Merger Talks Are Suspended
description: The military contractors Thomson-CSF and British Aerospace P.L.C. today halted three years of talks about merging their tactical missile businesses.

title: In a Coed Age, the Citadel Stands Fast
description: The Summerall Guards, white dress hats shimmering in the midday sun, executed their silent drill maneuvers on the parade grounds of the Citadel, stepping in unison to the unspoken commands familiar to generations of the guards.

title: Bush's Domestic Record Is His Achilles' Heel; Foreign Policy Blunders
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Survive in Double Overtime, Hit .500
description: The Knicks came perilously close to suffering an embarrassing loss last night. Instead, they escaped with a significant victory.

title: Auburn Coach to Retire
description: Mel Rosen, the head coach for the United States track and field team in the 1992 Summer Olympics, will retire after 27 years as coach at Auburn at the end of this season.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Adding Up 'Miss Saigon's' Advance

title: Senate Votes 97 to 1 For Gulf Veteran Bill Below House Figure
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a bipartisan package of benefits for veterans of the Persian Gulf war that was less generous than the bill approved on Wednesday by the House of Representatives.

title: Honecker Taken to Soviet Union; Germany Demanding His Return
description: Erich Honecker, facing prosecution for actions he took as the longtime Prime Minister of East Germany, has been quietly moved to a hospital in the Soviet Union, and Germany today demanded his immediate return.

title: Review/Film Festival; Growing Up in Paris; Coming of Age in Tunisia
description: THE main attraction of the annual New Directors/New Films series, sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the film department of the Museum of Modern Art, is the opportunity to see movies without preconceptions.

title: Hudson Police Chief Guilty of Interfering In Drug Enforcement
description: James J. Dolan, the Police Chief of Hudson, N.Y., last night was found guilty of hindering drug investigations in Columbia County.

title: One on One With New York
description: REMEMBER the great moment in the movie "The Mouse That Roared," when a medieval-style warrior, named Tully Bascombe, sails into New York Harbor only to find the city totally empty: not a single stockbroker, secretary, police officer, tourist, hot-dog vendor, bicyclist, jogger or what we used to call a "bum" in sight?

title: Federal Reserve
Iraqi Uranium Eludes U.N.
description: The agency charged with halting the spread of nuclear weapons has been unable to find out what happened to the uranium at Iraqi nuclear sites destroyed by the allies at the start of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Judge Orders Release of Campus Crime Reports
description: In a case with wide implications for campus journalists and administrators, a Federal judge has ruled that colleges and universities cannot bar access to records of campus crimes.

title: Review/Dance; 'Neighbors' Disturbs Through Originality
description: "Neighbors," which had its world premiere with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday night, is unusual even by Cunningham standards.

title: Parade Furor Is Settled; Gay Group Will March
description: Irish lesbians and gay men will march with Mayor David N. Dinkins in the St. Patrick's Day Parade tomorrow, settling a furor that transformed preparations for one of the grandest of New York parades into a singularly New York donnybrook.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ABRAHAM SERFATY, the former editor of the Moroccan literary magazine Souffles, and FRANCISCO VALENCIA, the director of El Salvador's only independent newspaper, Diario Latino, are to be awarded Freedom to Write awards by PEN, the writers' and editors' society. The awards, to be presented on April 15 at PEN's annual benefit dinner in New York, provide $3,000 to each recipient.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "They took me to a TV studio and sat me next to the big guy and then told me what questions they were going to ask and they told me what my answers were going to be. I had enough faith in Americans to know that anybody who saw this was going to say, 'This is ridiculous.' " -- Navy Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun, a former prisoner in Iraq. [ A14:3. ]

title: Keeping Sex Out of the Law Office
description: After months of struggle and heated debate, the California Bar Association is about to become the first in the country to adopt a formal ethics rule aimed at regulating sexual relationships between lawyers and their clients.

title: Life Without the Gloss In New Directors Series
description: Movies and television are so inundated with MTV-style images of sexy young bodies springing confidently into action on a rush of pop music that more realistic, alternative visions of youth are increasingly hard to find these days. One place that offers a respite from the depiction of young people as hyper-competitive proto-yuppies or gangsters is the New Directors/New Films series, the annual festival presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Ford Plans to Revise Alpha Project
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to revamp its Alpha project, an advanced manufacturing program, by combining it with part of its product and manufacturing engineering operations.

title: World War II 'Fish' Is Netted; Boat Is Ordered Sunk Off L.I.
description: A 70-foot fishing vessel was ordered sunk with explosives near the Shinnecock Inlet tonight after it snagged a World War II torpedo in its net.

title: Texas Instruments Weapons Contract
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it would continue to develop and test a sophisticated portable antitank weapon, despite the Army's suspension of payments because of delays and cost overruns. The company is developing the system under a $170 million contract awarded in 1989.

title: Yipes! Another Bailout?
description: As the Government gropes for a way to deal with record failures of commercial banks, taxpayers should remember how they were fooled in the collapse of the savings and loans. Why? Because they are in the process of being fooled again in the collapse of the banks.

title: Baker and Syrian Chief Call Time Ripe for Peace Effort
description: After seven hours of talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he and Mr. Assad agreed that they must take advantage of the "window of opportunity" that exists after the Persian Gulf war to produce a comprehensive Arab-Israeli settlement.

title: Duke Enters Governor's Race
description: State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader who won 44 percent of the vote in a recent run for the United States Senate, announced on Wednesday that, as expected, he would run for Louisiana governor. Mr. Duke, a Republican, said he was not worried about Gov. Buddy Roemer's switch this week from the Democratic Party to the Republican Party. "I'm hitting the ground running," he said. "We've got a great chance to win."

title: New Catalogue Position Filled at Bloomingdale's
description: Gordon R. Cooke, executive vice president for sales promotion at Bloomingdale's, has been promoted to the new post of chief executive of Bloomingdale's by Mail Ltd., the department-store chain's catalogue division, effective April 15.

title: Ford Tightens Terms On Rental Fleet Sales
description: The Ford Motor Company today revised the terms under which it sells cars to car-rental companies, reflecting a growing concern that new-car sales are being damaged by growing inventories of slightly used cars.

title: Dinkins's Plans to Speak at Rally On Taxes Strain Ties With Cuomo
description: Politicians attend rallies in Albany with almost the same frequency that schoolchildren arrive for tours of the State Capitol, and they usually attract about as much attention.

title: Bush's Domestic Record Is His Achilles' Heel
description: To the Editor:

title: Preacher Sued Over Retreat Memberships
description: An evangelist who last year bought the Christian theme park that had been created by the Rev. Jim Bakker has been sued by his partners, who accuse him of fraud, conspiracy and breach of contract in his use of $4 million that he received from selling memberships in the retreat.

title: Adolph Coors Abandons Its Longtime Slogan
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the Golden, Colo., brewery, is abandoning a venerable advertising and packaging slogan, apparently in compliance with an order issued by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

title: Japan Asks Aid on New Computers
description: Japanese Government officials this week invited the leading computer companies in the United States and Europe, along with the top research universities on both sides of the Atlantic, to join in a 10-year project to develop advanced computers for the next century.

title: Crucial Gene Is Discovered In Detecting Colon Cancer
description: Scientists have discovered a gene that seems to be the first to go awry when a colon cell begins the long spin toward cancer. The isolation of the gene could offer doctors a means of detecting colon cancer at the earliest possible stage, when it is easily cured.

title: British Free 6 Jailed in '74 I.R.A. Blasts
description: Six men from Northern Ireland jailed since November 1974 for the Irish Republican Army bombings of two Birmingham pubs were freed today by the Court of Appeal, after prosecutors admitted that their confessions and police evidence against them were discredited.

title: Why Pay Ransom to OPEC?
description: OPEC decided earlier this week to cut oil production by about a million barrels a day in an attempt to control oil prices. The modest cut -- 5 percent -- is probably enough to keep prices from collapsing, but it's unlikely to push them much above the current $18 a barrel.

title: 4 Days After Vote, Salvador Still Awaits Result
description: As the slow official count began Wednesday for El Salvador's legislative and municipal elections, the head of the election board from one of the country's 14 departments asked that nobody bring guns to the session.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: RESERVISTS' ROLE: American military leaders have concluded that they cannot rely on reservists to form a large element of the divisions rapidly deployed in war zones. Page A20.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc., a metals and natural gas company, said its Amax Coal Industries subsidiary had acquired Cannelton Holding Co., Charleston, W. Va., a coal producer, from Algoma Steel Corp. for about $100 million. * Brand Cos., Park Ridge, Ill., a specialty technology contractor, acquired Olshan Demolishing Co. and Olshan Asbestos Removal Corp. of Houston, and the operating assets of Folsom Marine Services Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bridge
description: The quarterfinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals began here this afternoon with more than half the top-ranked teams on the sidelines. Two of the top eight seeds were ousted earlier in the week, and three more fell on Wednesday.

title: In a Spa's Embrace: Nirvana of the Body
description: THE man in the Brooks Brothers suit seems different this afternoon. His eyes are glassy, his face is shiny and his gait is slow. In his fingertips he carries a tiny shopping bag. It holds his jar of Calming Cream.

title: Article 991191 -- No Title
description: A $400 million issue of zero-coupon subordinated notes due in 1988 being sold by J.P. Morgan & Company was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: F.C.C. Ruling Will Affect the Diversity of TV Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: Redmen Upbeat on Werdann Status
description: At the point of the year that too often defines the success or failure of a basketball season, the Redmen of St. John's face two questions as they approach the school's 21st appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: So Few Died, but How It Hurt Those Back Home: 11 Stories
description: Two giant flags -- one Ecuadorean, the other American -- hang side by side in Nicolas Fajardo's living room in Flushing, Queens. The banners dwarf a snapshot, taken back home in Ecuador, of an 11-year-old honor student standing ramrod-straight with a tiny gold medal pinned to his jacket.

title: Square D Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge on Wednesday denied Groupe Schneider S.A.'s request to move to Illinois a suit intended to block its attempted takeover of the Square D Company. Square D, a electrical equipment manufacturer, filed the antitrust lawsuit in Federal District Court in New York. Paris-based Schneider has made a hostile bid of $78 a share, or almost $1.9 billion, for Square D. A hearing that had been scheduled for today in New York State was canceled after a judge denied Square D's request that it be closed to the public, Schneider officials said.

title: H. Adams Ashforth, Realty Executive, 89
description: H. Adams Ashforth, who headed the Manhattan real-estate concern of Albert B. Ashforth Inc., for more than five decades before he retired as chairman in 1981, died on Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 89 years old.

title: Critic's Choice
description: "Somehow I feel like a musician of olden times," Bela Bartok wrote from Switzerland to his son in 1939, "the invited guest of a patron of the arts." The patron was Paul Sacher, the Swiss conductor and the founder of the Basel Chamber Orchestra, for whom the Hungarian composer was writing the Divertimento for Strings.
