Mr. Sacher also commissioned Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta and his Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion as well as works by Richard Strauss, Hindemith, Honegger, Stravinsky and others.

title: Winnebago Plans To Recall Workers
description: Winnebago Industries, the recreation-vehicle maker, said it was increasing production and recalling more than 120 workers because of large orders from rental agencies.

title: Review/Film; Martin Sheen and 2 Sons In a Tale of Racial Harmony
description: The members of the Sheen family have grown up to be hearty and strapping, but how that happened is a mystery. It's hard to imagine any one of them asking another to pass the salt without a truckload of attitude getting in the way.

title: The Stangl Molehill
description: New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, facing deep deficits and service cuts, badly needs a leader. But even though Gov. Mario Cuomo offered a fine nomination, that of Peter Stangl, more than two months ago, it remains in limbo because some legislators seem determined to make a mountain out of a lapse in judgment.

title: Laidlaw's Shares Plummet by 20%
description: The stock of Laidlaw Inc. plunged nearly 20 percent on the Toronto and New York stock exchanges after the company said the recession and higher fuel costs could slash second-quarter earnings as much as 50 percent.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic tomorrow from 44th Street to 86th Street from 10 A.M. through the late afternoon.

title: Judge Rules On Northrop
description: A Federal court today dismissed part of a lawsuit that charged the Northrop Corporation with falsifying records on the Stealth bomber program, costing the Pentagon billions of dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MIKE WALLACE spent last night in the hospital, after fainting aboard a plane on a runway at Los Angeles.

title: Katharine Graham's Son To Head Washington Post
description: The Washington Post Company announced yesterday that on May 9 Donald E. Graham would replace his mother, Katharine Graham, as chief executive. Mrs. Graham will continue as chairman.

title: Howard Ashman Is Dead at 40; Writer of 'Little Shop of Horrors'
description: Howard Ashman, an Oscar-winning lyricist and a librettist, playwright and director who wrote and staged the Off Broadway hit "Little Shop of Horrors," died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived in Beacon, N.Y.

title: A Methodical Faldo Develops A Plan for Higher Achievement
description: Nick Faldo is trying to do what for a decade has seemed impossible in men's professional golf: escape the gravitational pull of his peers and establish his own orbit of greatness.

title: Tip-Offs as Daytime Drama on CBS
description: Soap opera life went on as usual yesterday afternoon. Hospital patients still went in and out of comas. Predators still exploited victims. Husbands and wives continued to make love and hate, sometimes with their spouses. Cameras showed everyone's face in tight closeup. And this new detergent got your clothes cleaner than that old one ever did.

title: A Master At Defense Is Duped
description: Melvin Belli built a reputation and a fortune winning sympathy from juries with his sincerity. For the first time in almost 60 years, the lawyer said, a client won his sympathy -- and duped him.

title: Restaurants
description: Eze

title: The Daily News: Wounded Symbol of a City
description: Marie Rindel of Ridgewood, Queens, was talking about her Daily News. Through decades of wars abroad, murders at home and snows in Queens it brought its pugnacious picture of the world to her doorstep.

title: Let the U.N. Do More To Keep World Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from Agence France-Presse on March 7 showing refugees fleeing southern Iraq misidentified the tank in the background. It was an abandoned Iraqi tank, not an American one.

title: Review/Music; The Sweet, The Bitter, And Berg
description: If Romanticism in music is, in part, the unequivocal expression of powerful emotions, Alban Berg's Violin Concerto is as Romantic a work as the early 12-tone composers produced. Even apart from its extramusical association -- Berg regarded it, in part, as a requiem for Manon Gropius, the 18-year-old daughter of his friends Alma Mahler and Walter Gropius -- the concerto conveys with clarity and directness a sense of anguish, world-weary passion and the resilience of hope. All these qualities are furthered, not impeded, by Berg's nontonal language and lush orchestration.

title: Review/Fashion; Paris Is Glowing, Kindled by Lagerfeld
description: Today Karl Lagerfeld catapulted fashion into the next century and beyond with a stunning collection based on gold-, chrome- and bronze-colored bodysuits that glowed under wool daytime suits and wispy chiffon evening dresses.

title: Iraq Accused of Failing to Adhere To Conditions for a Formal Truce
description: Coalition diplomats say Iraq has not fully complied with the conditions set by President Bush and the allies for a definitive cease-fire in the Persian Gulf.

title: Teacher on L.I. Taken Off Duty in Injury to Girl
description: A 9-year-old girl whose neck was crushed by a closing partition door in her school's gymnasium remained in a coma tonight at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset.

title: Review/Opera; New Staging Of 'Parsifal,' Featuring Domingo
description: When the Metropolitan Opera made up its corporate mind that it needed a new production of "Parsifal" -- a questionable decision, considering the memorable strengths of the old one -- the assignment naturally fell to the team of Otto Schenk and Gunther Schneider-Siemssen. Their tradition-conscious stagings of "Tannhauser" and the "Ring" had brought the company surprising successes in the Wagnerian repertory during a time when theatrical egotists were gaining headlines by visiting one idiocy after another on helpless operas.

title: INSIDE
description: Unsettling Inflation News

title: Sled-Dog Racing; Swenson Wins 5th Iditarod in Severe Storm
description: On a day when the wind and the snow blowing off the Bering Sea Coast were so severe that he thought he might be risking his life, Rick Swenson of Two Rivers covered the final 77 miles to this historic gold-rush town and won the 19th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race early this morning.

title: British Economic Dip
description: Britain's gross domestic product suffered a small decline in the last quarter of 1990, the Government said today. The Central Statistical Office said the value of goods and services produced showed a drop of 1.3 percent from the final period in 1989. For the year, the economy grew by five-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Havel Seeks Vote on Czech-Slovak Unity
description: Faced with mounting calls for separatism in Slovakia, President Vaclav Havel is pressing for a referendum to decide if the two regional administrations of this federated nation should go their ways as separate states, officials close to the President said today.

title: Brown Blurs Line Between Speech and Action; Dangerous Further Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro Hockey; Devils Stretch Rangers' Skid to 5
description: The Devils and the Rangers played each other on equal terms in the first two periods tonight, but the Devils were far superior in the third, scoring three times to break the game open.

title: Former Navajo Leader Is Indicted in U.S. Case
description: The longtime chairman of the Navajo Nation, already convicted in two tribal corruption trials and facing a third next week, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on bribery and racketeering charges.

title: Winners And Losers
description: Republican leaders, who were on the defensive last summer about taxes, the budget, abortion and other domestic issues, now are gleefully charging Democrats with having been wrong, at best, and unpatriotic, at worst, in opposing the Persian Gulf war.

title: Trainer Killed by Elephants
description: An animal trainer was killed on Thursday when she tried to break up a fight between two elephants at San Diego Wild Animal Park, which is affiliated with the San Diego Zoo. The 27-year-old trainer, Pamela C. Orsi, suffered fatal head injuries in the clash of the two Asian elephants, each weighing more than two and a half tons.

title: Mayor's Place in Parade to Be With Gay Group
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, dismissing the idea that he was snubbing the Irish community, said yesterday that he would give up the traditional leadoff position in today's St. Patrick's Day Parade and would march instead with an Irish gay group more than two hours later.

title: Head of Tenneco Unit To Quit All His Posts
description: James K. Ashford, president and chief executive of the J. I. Case unit of Tenneco Inc. for the last three years, will resign those posts on April 15 for personal reasons, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Ashford will also yield the board seat to which he was elected last December, as well as his title of executive vice president of Tenneco.

title: Jeff Walker, Executive, 41
description: Jeff Walker, vice president of creative services for Polo/Ralph Lauren, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Toronto Journal; Official Gadfly Finds Canada United in Discontent
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up.

title: 7 Hurt in Israeli Raid on 2 Palestinian Bases
description: The Israeli Air Force destroyed two buildings serving as Palestinian guerrilla bases in eastern Lebanon today, wounding seven people, the police said.

title: Aggies' Coach Resigns
description: Coach Kermit Davis of Texas A&M resigned yesterday in the wake of a school investigation that accused him of recruiting violations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is a terrible moment and time for reflection when officers sworn to uphold the law are indicted for these most serious felonies." -- District Attorney Ira Reiner of Los Angeles. [ 8:1. ]

title: Vendex Unit Trims Its Dillard Stake
description: Vendamerica B.V., the American arm of Vendex International, a Dutch retail concern, is selling six million shares it holds of Dillard Department Stores' class A common stock. The stock is estimated to have a value of about $600 million. The block will be offered in a public issue.

title: Stocks Drop Amid Worry on Economy
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in a session dominated by technical trading. Also pulling prices down were a falling bond market and a report on inflation interpreted on Wall Street as less than encouraging.

title: Sculley Role Shifts at Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. has juggled its top management roles, with its chairman, John Sculley, now focusing on long-term directions, a spokeswoman said today.

title: Toronto Journal; Official Gadfly Finds Canada United in Discontent
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up.

title: Thais Name New Assembly
description: The Thai military junta, which seized power in a coup last month, announced the formation today of a new National Assembly dominated by soldiers. The assembly will be charged with approving a new constitution, paving the way for elections and the return of civilian rule, Radio Thailand said. More than half of the new members are serving or retired officers in the armed forces, the announcement said. The new assembly also includes some former members of Parliament as well as businessmen and journalists, the radio said.

title: Suspended Lawyer Named to State Post
description: Michael G. Dowd, a suspended Queens lawyer known for his role in a corruption scandal and as an advocate for battered women, has been appointed as director of special projects and advocacy in the New York State Office for the Prevention of Domestic Violence.

title: Baseball; Battered Viola Feels Fine
description: Frank Viola, the Mets pitcher who is trying to put to rest all talk of bone spurs and a wounded left arm, was cuffed around by the Blue Jays in a 7-3 loss tonight. But he happily reported no pain in his elbow after making his second start of the exhibition season.

title: Rights and Business Groups Seek Pact on a Job Bias Bill
description: Seeking to avoid a repetition of last year's bitter fight over a bill to discourage discrimination in employment, civil rights groups and representatives of large corporations have been quietly working on their own to forge compromises on the legislation.

title: Rev. Robert Cook, Author, Dies at 78; Led King's College
description: The Rev. Robert Andrew Cook, an evangelical pastor, an author and the former president of King's College in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Institute in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Tannersville, Pa.

title: Rose M. Singer, 94, an Original Member of Correction Board
description: Rose M. Singer, an original member of the New York City Board of Correction and founder and president emeritus of the Friendly Vistors, a service group that helps women in prison, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94 years old.

title: Exhibition on Carnegie Hall
description: "Carnegie Hall: Portrait of a Building," an exhibition of photographs, models and memorabilia that traces the architectural history of the hall, will run through April 6 at the Urban Center Galleries, 457 Madison Avenue, near 49th Street. Hours for the exhibition, presented by the Municipal Art Society, are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Sunday and Thursday. Admission is free. Information: (212) 935-3960.

title: To Church-State Matters, Add Mosques
description: The days before the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which begins tonight with the sighting of the new moon, are solemn and frenetic ones for Imam Al-Amin Abdul-Latif. As the head of a Brooklyn mosque and the president of the Islamic Leadership Council of New York, he is busy teaching the laws of fasting and penance to the faithful. He is also worrying about alternate side of the street parking.

title: Theater of the Deaf Names Co-Director
description: Julianna Fjeld has been named co-artistic director of the National Theater of the Deaf. In announcing her appointment, David Hayes, the artistic director, said Ms. Fjeld would share equally in running the company.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The leading candidate for an Oscar for best adapted screenplay, MICHAEL BLAKE, who wrote "Dances With Wolves," has shunned the usual book tour in favor of visits with children in libraries and high schools. His book, originally published in 1988 in softcover by Fawcett Books , is now coming out in hardcover from Newmarket Press .

title: Hanover Deal With Equitable
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society has reached a tentative settlement with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company over a real estate partnership that the insurance giant put into bankruptcy several months ago.

title: Dublin's Parade Rouses Ire, Too
description: New York City's St. Patrick's Day Parade is not the only troubled one. The organizers of Dublin's parade are being accused of treachery and censorship for barring a float commemorating the Easter uprising of 1916.

title: Your Money; Important Choice Upon Retirement
description: With the country in recession, increasing numbers of employees are being offered early retirement. Those who accept, like all retirees, face a crucial decision: how to take their pensions. The choice they make can play a big role in determining their financial security and that of their families.

title: Jets and Giants Moves
description: The Jets added two Plan B free agents yesterday and the Giants lost one.

title: New Delays in Hotel Plan for Homeless
description: New York City has spent two and a half years and $25 million trying to turn a decrepit rooming house on 42d Street into a model residence for 300 homeless people, but no one lives there yet because the city has been unable to pick someone to run the place.

title: Patents; Appeals Court Ruling on Genetic Engineering
description: A Federal appeals court stepped into a controversial patent issue in biotechnology this week: whether a patent based on purifying a valuable protein from natural sources should cover that protein when it is produced through genetic engineering.

title: Dinkins Won't Attend Rally for More Taxes
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has decided not to attend a pro-tax rally by labor and minority groups in Albany next week, defusing for the moment a confrontation with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has warned the Mayor that he would withold his support for new city taxes if the Legislature raises state taxes.

title: Questions Raised on Lawmakers' Visit to Kuwait
description: Twelve members of the House of Representatives have gone to Kuwait on a visit whose financing has raised questions among the House leadership.

title: Patents; 'Superactive Insulin' Called More Effective
description: Researchers at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City have patented what they described as "superactive insulin," which they said appeared to have 10 times as much effect as normal insulin.

title: Making It a Federal Case
description: The Federal Government's authority to deal with police brutality cases like the one in which four police officers were charged in Los Angeles today rests on a pair of Reconstruction-era laws that lay largely dormant until the civil rights crusades of the 1960's.

title: A. Ross Eckler, Ex-Census Chief, 89
description: A. Ross Eckler, director of the Census Bureau from 1965 to 1969, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Montgomery General Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Secured Credit Cards: Ask Before You Leap
description: As many as 40 million Americans cannot obtain credit, including the two million people a year whose credit cards are revoked, specialists in the banking field say.

title: Northeast Governors to Ask Voluntary Packaging Rules
description: Unable to forge a compromise between industrial and environmental interests on wasteful packaging, the Coalition of Northeast Governors is about to seek voluntary reduction.

title: Gereon Lindsay, Chaplain, 74
description: The Rev. Gereon Lindsay, chaplain at Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center in Wingdale, N.Y., and a member of the Capuchin Franciscan Order, died on Monday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 74 years old and lived at Our Lady of Solace Friary on the center's grounds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DR. ANNE-IMELDA RADICE was appointed Thursday to the No. 2 job at the National Endowment for the Arts by its chairman, JOHN E. FROHNMAYER. The post has been empty since last June. Dr. Radice, 43, chief of the creative arts division of the United States Information Agency, has worked as director of the National Museum of Women in the Arts, curator for the Architect of the United States Capitol and assistant curator at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Bud Freeman, Tenor Saxophonist and Jazz Innovator, Dead at 84
description: Lawrence (Bud) Freeman, a leading tenor saxophonist, died yesterday at the Warren Barr Pavilion, a nursing home in Chicago. He was 84 years old.

title: Barbara Woods Marries
description: Barbara Woods, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William A. Woods of Atlanta, and Stephen M. Daly, the son of Virginia M. Daly of New York and the late James J. Daly, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in New York. Mrs. Daly, 35 years old, works in affiliate operations at Home Box Office in New York. She is a graduate of the University of Georgia. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom, 37, is a New York City police officer. He graduated from Manhattan College.

title: College Basketball: N.C.A.A. Tournament/Southeast Regional; Arizona St. Rallies To Beat Rutgers
description: They almost made it, but in the end, the Scarlet Knights of Rutgers had too much to overcome today: 30 minutes of cold shooting, the power of Arizona State's 260-pound center Isaac Austin and the long-range bombing of Tarence Wheeler. The result was a 79-76 loss at the Omni and elimination in the first round of the Southeast Regional.

title: Bolshoi Producers to Declare Bankruptcy
description: Entertainment Corporation USA, which is producing tours this year of the Bolshoi Opera and dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet, will declare bankruptcy on Monday, a founder and director of the corporation's British parent company said yesterday.

title: Jackie Wackie Set to Go
description: Jackie Wackie will be among seven colts attempting to upset Fly So Free on Saturday in the $500,000 Florida Derby, the main event at Gulfstream Park on Florida's most compelling day of racing in memory. It is a day that will include five stakes races, three winners of the Eclipse Award and a herd of candidates for the Triple Crown.

title: Worrisome Producer Price Data
description: A sobering report on inflation showed today that prices received by American producers advanced four-tenths of 1 percent in February, excluding the prices of energy and food. Many analysts said the increase was unsettlingly high for an economy mired in recession.

title: Toronto Journal; Official Gadfly Finds Canada United in Discontent
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up.

title: Key Rates
LaPoint Bites Hand That Pays Him
description: Dave LaPoint will make almost $1 million this season, even if he does not throw a pitch in the major leagues. The Yankees chose to pay LaPoint not to play for them by releasing the left-hander before spring training.

title: Dental Fillings With Mercury Are Safe, Scientific Panel Says
description: Members of a scientific advisory committee said today that they were confident that dental fillings containing mercury are safe for most people.

title: Cole Porter Centennial
description: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus will celebrate the centennial of Cole Porter's birth with "Anything, Cole," a concert of songs by the composer, at Carnegie Hall on April 7 at 8 P.M. He was born on June 9, 1891. Stockard Channing, Chita Rivera and other guest performers will recreate scenes from Porter's Broadway shows and films. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: World Bank Loan to Iran
description: The World Bank, with United States approval, has given Iran its first loan since 1978, the year before Iranians took hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran, a bank official said today.

title: Ford Expects Sales Recovery
description: The nation's car buyers are returning to dealers' showrooms, and a recovery in car sales from the disastrously weak levels of the last two months should be under way by the second half of 1991, a Ford Motor Company executive said. The executive, Mark Hutchins, general sales manager of Ford's Lincoln-Mercury division, said his dealers reported a 25 to 30 percent gain in customer showroom traffic in the last three weekends from earlier in the year.

title: O.A.S. Aide Presses Salvador Vote Inquiry
description: The head of the observer mission from the Organization of American States says he is trying quickly to resolve implications of fraud in last Sunday's election out of particular concern that the matter could adversely affect peace negotiations with Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: Soviet Vote Becomes Test of Loyalties
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared today that a large "yes" vote in the referendum on national unity Sunday would safeguard the nation against war and restore normalcy to society, while his archrival Boris N. Yeltsin told Russians not to be frightened by such "propaganda."

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Pratt & Whitney Official Is Promoted to President
description: Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine division of the United Technologies Corporation, said yesterday that it had promoted James G. O'Connor to the post of president, succeeding Arthur E. Wegner.

title: British Premier Set to Replace Unpopular Thatcher Poll Tax
description: In the biggest U-turn in British politics in a decade, Prime Minister John Major appears set to scrap the unpopular "poll tax," which his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, introduced in England and Wales only a year ago.

title: For Frequent Fliers, Some New Offers
description: The financial troubles affecting both Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines are creating new frequent-flier promotions: programs that are shared by two major United States carriers. They provide more flexibility plus some protection to travelers should a troubled carrier stop flying certain routes or shut down.

title: Toronto Journal; Official Gadfly Finds Canada United in Discontent
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up.

title: Review/Film Festival; The Awkward Appeal of a Young Man's Chase
description: He is familiar even if you've never seen him before: the lovelorn creep, the campus nuisance, the guy guaranteed to prompt elaborate shows of indifference every time he enters a room. In spite of all this, he is weirdly appealing, perhaps because his efforts to escape his own awkwardness are so clearly doomed.

title: Premieres on Guitar
description: The guitarist David Tanenbaum is to give the New York premieres of works by Peter Maxwell Davies and Sofia Gubaidulina at 8 o'clock tonight at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The program also includes music by Lou Harrison, J. S. Bach, Isaac Albeniz, Luis Milan and Hans Werner Henze. Tickets are $15. Information: (212) 362-8719.

title: China Extends a Friendly Loan to Moscow
description: China has extended a commodity loan valued at $730 million to the Soviet Union, to buy Chinese grain, meat, peanuts, tea and other products, an official newspaper said today.

title: Books of The Times; Facets of Life on the Baseball Diamond
description: Once More Around the Park By Roger Angell 351 pages. Ballantine Books. $18.95.

title: Thomas J. McGreevy, Stockbroker, 58
description: Thomas James McGreevy, a vice president and managing director of the Santa Fe, N.M., office of Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company, stockbrokers, died in a scuba diving accident on Thursday in Bonaire, the Netherlands Antilles. He was 58 years old and lived in Santa Fe.

title: Study Finds Aspirin May Prevent Heart Attacks in Women
description: A new study suggests that small amounts of aspirin may protect women against heart attack, just as they protect men, scientists said yesterday.

title: Automated-Card System Chosen To Collect Fares in New York
description: New York City has selected an automatic fare-collection system for subways and buses, intended ultimately to replace the venerable token with a prepaid fare card.

title: Wheat, Corn and Soybeans Are All Hit Hard in a Selloff
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures closed sharply lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Beliefs
description: By most accounts, a dramatic and pivotal moment occurred last month at the assembly of the World Council of Churches, the organization that loosely links 316 churches with a collective membership of 400 million Christians.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the elimination of the New York City teacher-mentor program referred incorrectly to the status of the mentors, who help train new teachers. Of the 1,850 mentors, 550 are retired teachers, whom the board is laying off; the remaining mentors -- teachers who are not retired -- are to be reassigned within the system. The article also misstated the location of Intermediate School 14. It is in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, not Flatbush.

title: Hong Kong Not Violating Refugee Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: America's 13th Generation
description: As crowds cheer the homecoming of Desert Storm warriors, the nation is throwing what amounts to a coming-out party for post-boomers. These are the young men and women born after 1960 who provided two-thirds of the gulf troops and 80 percent of its casualties.

title: POLAND IS GRANTED LARGE CUT IN DEBT
description: Western governments have agreed to forgive about half the $33 billion that Poland owes them, the French Government announced today, with the creditor nations offering what they called "extraordinary terms" to help ease Poland's transition to a market economy.

title: First Aid for Pets, Given With a Light Touch
description: If you have a pet, it is wise to think about emergencies before they occur and to have a plan of action to follow if the pet becomes ill or injured at night or during weekends or holidays.

title: Some Industries Gain, But No Upturn Is Seen
description: Amid the almost daily evidence of the continued deterioration of the American economy, there are beginning to be signs of improvement.

title: Brown Blurs Line Between Speech and Action; Draft a Law
description: To the Editor:

title: From Toys to TV, Drug Fight Grows
description: The people who produced captivating, and sometimes shocking, advertisements that helped turn public opinion against cocaine and other drugs are expanding their reach into the American psyche with things like bumper stickers on toy cars and trucks and videos that play as motorists pump gasoline.

title: Guidepost; Go Fly the Right Kite
description: Kite-flying season is on its way. Parents who want to buy their children kites that are easy to control can choose from several basic types. Most kites are controlled by a single line to the ground; two-line kites are usually too complex for small children. A child as young as 5 or 6 years old should be able to fly a simple kite, but keep in mind that kites -- especially stunt kites -- can be dangerous if misused. Read directions and safety instructions carefully. Kites made of nylon are the most durable and can last for years, while plastic kites may tear or fall apart after a few flights. The kites below are listed in order of their ease of flying. Delta wing: A triangular, single-line kite with a keel is the easiest to fly. The keel gives the kite stability, and generally a tail is not needed. Parafoil: A single-line parachute-style kite is the most portable kite; it has no sticks and can be folded up easily. The wind fills the kite, and it flies. Diamond: This single-line kite usually requires a tail for balance. Many diamond kites are decoratedwith appliques for children. The kite can be used as a decoration on a child's wall. Dragon: A single-line kite with a semicircular head and a tail that can range in length from 6 to 50 feet. This kite is fun to fly because of the long tail. Stunt: The minimum age for flying a stunt kite is 8 to 9 years. This is a two-line kite; it takes 1 to 2 hours to learn how to make it do acrobatics. It can fly at high speeds. Box/Multicellular: These kites need a lot of wind and close attention to fly. They are not very efficient aerodynamically, and would be difficult for a young child to maneuver. Source: Big City Kite Company, New York City

title: The National Insecurity
description: A man who has worked here for 30 years couldn't get into the building the other day. A "security" problem. He didn't have his new identification card. Our guards are under orders to keep such people out.

title: W. Edward McGough, Psychiatrist, 62
description: Dr. W. Edward McGough, a psychiatrist and a breeder and judge of dogs, died on Wednesday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 62 years old and had his primary residence in Colts Neck, N.J.

title: U.S. Moves Units in Iraq Forward, Apparently as Message to Hussein
description: The United States extended its pattern of sending cautionary signals to Iraq today by sending American tank units in southern Iraq to their forward-most positions along the tentative cease-fire line.

title: Hail the Returning Heroes! (Right After This Message)
description: Returning American troops are heroes to many. To some consumer-products and media companies, they are also a market.

title: Pretoria's Land Plan: More for Blacks
description: As he moves to dismantle apartheid, President F. W. de Klerk's determination to control and direct the pace of the political change in South Africa has been illustrated by the sweeping land legislation that he presented in Parliament this week.

title: Soviet Pole-Vaulter Soars Over 20-Foot Mark
description: Saying the feat was a gift to track and field followers in the United States, Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union yesterday became the first person to pole-vault 20 feet.

title: The Myth of the Intelligent Society
description: To hear ourselves talk, one might think that society is on some new threshold of knowledge and intelligence. The United States and its allies used "smart bombs" and "smart weapons" in the gulf war. The Japanese opened an "intelligent building" in Tokyo late last year. Computer scientists routinely talk of "expert systems" and "artificial intelligence" (even though it is not fully realized). There are even "smart pills" that are supposed to boost memory and intelligence.

title: College Basketball: N.C.A.A. Tournament; Spiders Set Tempo and Syracuse Fell Flat
description: A charm of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Tournament has been its tradition of unheralded teams that seize the national stage for a moment of improbable glory. It happened again on Thursday night at Cole Field House in the first round of the East Regionals when No. 15-seeded Richmond stunned second-seeded Syracuse, 73-69.

title: Scaled-Down Space Station Is Criticized
description: As currently proposed, a scaled-down space station would be inadequate for performing its principal research objectives, two studies by scientific groups have concluded.

title: U.S. Says Jordan Sent No Arms
description: The United States said today that an investigation had turned up no evidence to substantiate reports that Jordan had shipped arms or ammunition to Iraq before or during the Persian Gulf war.

title: Ruth Morley Memorial
description: A memorial service for Ruth Morley, a theatrical costume designer for four decades, will be held at 5:30 P.M. Monday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Ms. Morley died on Feb. 12 at the age of 65.

title: Honecker's Move to Moscow Causes an Uproar in Germany
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had given advance notice to Germany before flying Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader, here for medical care necessary for "humanitarian considerations."

title: For Essex Incinerator, a Shortage of Garbage
description: While New Jersey exports about half its garbage to other states each day, the operator of Essex County's new $340 million incinerator is importing garbage from Brooklyn.

title: Cuomo, Stung by State Budget, Sinks in a Poll
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget woes, which have been around for months, turned up as a poll problem yesterday as his ratings in a nonpartisan survey dropped to their lowest point in his eight years in office.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Atlantis Group Inc., Miami, said it would sell 51 percent of its furniture group to management of the five companies making up the Atlantis Furniture Group and affiliates of Trivest Inc., an affiliate of Atlantis, for about $10 million. * Broken Hill Proprietary Co., Melbourne, Australia, an iron and steel company, said it would lay off more than 300 miners in the Southern coal fields of New South Wales and close the Tower colliery, a decision that could start a strike by the region's 5,000 coal miners.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RANDOLPH M. N. McAUSLAND, the endowment's acting deputy chairman for programs, has been made the permanent deputy. DR. MARGARET JANE WYSZOMIRSKI, a senior faculty member at the Federal Executive Institute of the Office of Personnel Management, was appointed director of policy and planning.

title: Review/Film Festival; Subway Driver Meets Thai Go-Go Dancer
description: Immigration laws have bred a strange new kind of chivalric romance, one becoming common on movie screens. In "Leo Sonnyboy," an overweight, middle-aged subway driver named Leo marries a beautiful Thai go-go dancer named Apia so she will not be deported from Switzerland.

title: Schools Condom Plan Will in Time Save Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND KREMLIN STILL DEADLOCKED ON ARMS TREATIES
description: The United States and the Soviet Union, at the end of two days of high-level talks, said today that they remained deadlocked over two important arms control agreements that are delaying the next summit meeting, which Moscow has proposed for the end of May.

title: Third Airport for London
description: Queen Elizabeth formally inaugurated London's third international airport today. Stansted Airport, 30 miles northeast of London, will open to the public on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Indicts 43 on Charges Of Aiding Money Laundering
description: The Federal authorities announced today that 43 people had been indicted on charges of helping to launder $65 million a year in Colombian drug profits in Miami, New York and Los Angeles.

title: Hong Kong Not Violating Refugee Rights; British Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: East In a region of rampant reversals, Villanova defeated Princeton in the last second, and Eastern Michigan trounced a heavy favorite, Mississippi State.

title: Brazil Pays Part of Debt
description: Brazil paid $300 million today to foreign creditors in an effort to break an impasse over debt payments, the central bank said.

title: Transit Workers Held in Theft
description: Two subway workers turned a Transit Authority experiment with sophisticated automated turnstiles into a considerably simpler venture -- theft -- stealing more than $50,000 in fare receipts, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Uproar Over the Millions
description: When Jim Leyland told Barry Bonds to shut up, grow up, or get out, more or less, a huge percentage of the population, witnessing their confrontation on television newscasts across the country, responded.

title: War Proving Bountiful For Military Recruiters
description: There was a time last fall when Sgt. Glenn Rogers, the top recruiter in his Alabama recruiting brigade, used to come to work, return the few messages on his answering machine and head out looking for potential soldiers. No more.

title: Bush's Education Nominee Is Confirmed in the Senate
description: As expected, the Senate confirmed former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee as Secretary of Education on Thursday.

title: Maurice Zolotow, 77, Show Business Writer
description: Maurice Zolotow, whose hundreds of magazine articles and several books on show business personalities earned him the designation "the Boswell of Broadway," died Thursday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

title: U.S. Jury Shuns New Death Penalty Option
description: In the first test of a 1988 law that allows capital punishment for drug-related murders in Federal cases, a jury today declined to recommend the death penalty for a narcotics dealer who had ordered the killing of a Government informer.

title: F.D.A. Advisers Reject A Drug for Alzheimer's
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration tonight recommended against approving a drug that would have been the first on the market to treat Alzheimer's disease.

title: 2 Found Guilty as Drug Spies
description: Two scientists were convicted today of conspiring to sell trade secrets of Merck & Company and the Schering-Plough Corporation in what prosecutors called one of the largest industrial espionage cases in the nation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Justice to the Rescue
description: The Federal Communications Commission was ready on Thursday to approve a proposal, never made public, that would have handed Hollywood studios a victory over the television networks in the battle for the lucrative $5 billion syndication business. But then the Justice Department got wind of the vote, and on Wednesday persuaded the commission chairman, Alfred Sikes, to delay consideration.

title: Harold Steinberg, 77, Real-Estate Developer
description: Harold Steinberg, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died on Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and had homes in Scarsdale, Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: 2 Agency Directors, Targets of Cuomo, Choose Retirement
description: It will not quite solve Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's $6 billion budget problem. But Mr. Cuomo won a symbolic victory today when it was announced that the two directors of a tiny state agency that the Governor has spotlighted as an example of government waste had filed for early retirement, making it easier for the Legislature to abolish the bureau.

title: Now, Save Prince William Sound
description: Exxon's $1 billion settlement of state and Federal claims stemming from the calamitous Exxon Valdez oil spill is clearly preferable to a long and chancy trial that might have yielded a smaller penalty. But the real test will be whether the money is spent wisely.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: ETHICS QUESTIONS -- At the request of Kuwait, an American construction company seeking business there has paid for a visit by 12 members of the House of Representatives. Page 9. HEROES BECOME CONSUMERS -- Pepsi-Cola and Boeing are underwriting an in-flight video program that will be shown to military personnel flying home. Business Day, page 31.

title: Jackson Examined
description: Bo Jackson's right hip, injured during the National Football League playoffs in January, was examined yesterday in Kansas City, Mo., by the Royals' team physician, while a California newspaper was reporting that the injury could threaten his career.

title: 4 White Policemen Indicted In Beating of Black Motorist
description: A Los Angeles police sergeant and three police officers were charged today with assault with a deadly weapon and misuse of their authority in the beating of a black motorist that was videotaped and repeatedly broadcast around the country.

title: College Basketball: N.C.A.A. Tournament/Midwest Regional; St. John's Holds On; Penn State Stuns U.C.L.A.
description: In the view of Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach whose public outlook holds that the glass of wine is always half full, the unexpected excitement in the second half of his team's victory over Northern Illinois today in the first round of the Midwest Regional was an inevitable result of the flow of the game.

title: Ito Survives Hard Knocks and Gains 3d Place
description: As Kristi Yamaguchi and Tonya Harding of the United States moved into the lead of the women's singles competition of the world figure-skating championships today, Midori Ito of Japan showed once again what a remarkable and lucky skater she has become.

title: I Cantori di New York
description: Mark Shapiro is to conduct I Cantori di New York, a chamber choir, in Leonard Bernstein's "Missa Brevis," Benjamin Britten's "Rejoice in the Lamb," and Maurice Durufle's Requiem at 8 o'clock tonight at St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, 522 West End Avenue, at 87th Street. Tickets are $12. Information: (718) 522-4269.

title: 2 Criminal Summonses Are Filed After a Dog Dies Beneath a Train
description: In an incident involving conflicting testimony, death threats and a lot of news coverage, the humane society issued summonses yesterday against a subway motorman and the Transit Authority after the death of a dog on Wednesday.

title: New York Drivers Are a Menace to Pedestrians
description: To the Editor:

title: College Basketball: N.C.A.A. Tournament/West Regional; Spartans Turn It On In Last 3 Minutes
description: No one gave Wisconsin-Green Bay much of a chance against Michigan State at the West Regional this afternoon. The fifth-seeded Spartans were bigger and deeper than the Phoenix, and had the confidence that comes from playing in the Big Ten Conference.

title: Vote in Czechoslovakia
description: Responding to pleas for separatism in Slovakia, the Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel, is pushing for a referendum as early as June on whether the country's two regional administrations should become separate states, officials close to the Mr. Havel said.

title: Review/Dance; Royal Ballet Shows Off a New Star
description: No, the sun has not set over the Royal Ballet from Britain, and the proof lies in Darcey Bussell, the company's wondrous new find.

title: Islands of Quality, Sea of Decay
description: On Manhattan's East Side, parents at the Lab School, a public elementary school for gifted children, use their own money to hire teachers' assistants and buy mathematics and science supplies. On the West Side, a group of mothers has raised $90,000 in a $150,000 campaign to renovate the playground in Riverside Park at 91st Street.

title: Brown Blurs Line Between Speech and Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Antiseptic Martial Arts
description: In an opening sequence of "The Perfect Weapon," its star, Jeff Speakman, is shown bare-chested, kicking and whirling through karate exercises to the accompaniment Snap's hit hip-hop single, "Power." The body rhythms and moves are so similar in style to the dance routines of rap stars like M. C. Hammer that one is reminded of the forceful impact of martial arts on culture outside of the gymnasium.

title: Mr. Ward's Lesson for Chief Gates
description: I didn't invest 42 years of my life to go down the tubes over an incident that I had nothing to do with. -- Los Angeles Police Chief Daryl Gates.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Drop Sharply
description: Conflicting readings of inflation and consumer sentiment sent prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbling yesterday. Fears of inflation, the bane of investors holding fixed-income securities, were raised when the Government released its Producer Price Index for February before the markets opened.

title: Disturbance Quelled at a Crowded Jail
description: Six inmates at the Somerset County Jail surrendered early yesterday after a disturbance that the sheriff attributed to overcrowding.

title: Head of Yugoslavia's Government Resigns in Dispute on Army Role
description: The leader of Yugoslavia's eight-member ruling council resigned today after his colleagues rejected his plan granting urgent powers to the army to intervene in the country's civil strife.

title: Coping/With Wireless Video Systems
description: Video signals aren't always available where we want them. We may want to watch a tape in a room that has no videocassette recorder, use a camera or camcorder to monitor a sick or sleeping child, or (if cable company regulations permit) send decoded signals from premium channels like Showtime to any room. Installing wires for such purposes involves long, expensive runs around walls or holes drilled through them, and it is hard to hide the wires.

title: About New York; When Paralysis Is No Match For P-o-e-t-r-y
description: Julia Tavalero became a quadriplegic when surgery went disastrously wrong a quarter-century ago. She has since lived in Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island. For the first decade, she was mistakenly thought to be brain dead.

title: Marriott Account Lost; Coke Cites Loan Denial
description: The Marriott Corporation's food service business switched from Coca-Cola to Pepsi-Cola after Coke rejected the hotel operator's request for a loan of up to $100 million, a Coca-Cola Company memo shows.

title: Outflow Is Up at S.& L.'s
description: Net withdrawals at the nation's savings institutions totaled a record $91.2 billion in 1990, up 24 percent from the previous record, set in 1989, the Government said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SPIKE LEEsays he's doing the right thing by taking a teaching job at Harvard University. A frequent critic of Hollywood stereotyping of blacks, Mr. Lee will lecture in the Afro-American Studies Department. "It should be fun," he said Thursday. A spokesman for Harvard said that the teaching offer had been made but not yet formally accepted and that Mr. Lee is to teach in spring 1992.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Dividend Linked To Pet Inc. Spinoff
description: The Whitman Corporation declared a dividend of one share of Pet Inc. common stock for each share of Whitman common stock to accomplish a previously announced spinoff of the food operation. Payment of the dividend is conditional on receipt of a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service by March 28 that the distribution is tax-free to shareholders and the company. If a favorable ruling is received by March 28, the dividend will be paid on April 1.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic today from 44th Street to 86th Street from 10 A.M. through the late afternoon.

title: Midlantic Lays Off 120 in New Jersey
description: Midlantic National Bank of Newark has laid off 120 employees to save about $2 million a year. The chairman of the Midlantic Corporation, Robert Van Buren, said the layoffs were the latest cost-cutting effort by the financial company, which reported a net loss of $195 million last year.

title: Speaker Vallone's Overkill
description: Timing and luck have given Peter Vallone a singular burden. As the first City Council Speaker to serve under New York City's revised charter, he can set powerful precedents for wise, responsible leadership. He's made some progress, which is why it is so disappointing that he recently took such a big step backward, stifling dissent in the autocratic tradition of the past.

title: College Basketball: N.C.A.A. Tournament/East Regional; Nittany Lions, Villanova and North Carolina Advance
description: The Penn State Nittany Lions, playing as if they had seen everything U.C.L.A. could throw at them, stunned the fourth-seeded Bruins, 74-69, this afternoon in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's East Regional.

title: Patents; Tears Tested to Measure Alcohol Level
description: Scientists in Toronto have patented a device that can measure the presence of alcohol within 15 seconds by analyzing vapor from the tears in an eye.

title: Paul Fran, 56, Head of Music Institution
description: Paul E. Fran, the executive director of the Bloomingdale House of Music, died on Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dinkins Chooses Acting Press Aide
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Leland T. Jones, a longtime City Hall press aide, to be his acting press secretary, starting today. Mr. Jones succeeds Albert Scardino, whose resignation took effect yesterday, while the search continues for a permanent replacement.

title: A Fare War With a Difference
description: When American Airlines announced this week what it called the largest fare promotion in its history, it looked like the start of an old-fashioned fare war: one carrier slashing ticket prices, absorbing losses for a while in a gamble to increase its market share.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Pooley Leads by One

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Columbia Pictures Television, Burbank, Calif., has named Alan Daniels vice president, creative services. * KCAL-TV, Hollywood, a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios, has named David J. Woodcock president and general manager.

title: AFTER THE WAR: Another War Begins as Kuwaiti Oil-Well Fires Threaten Region's Ecology; Blazes Could Burn for Two Years
description: Senior Kuwaiti officials say the country is suffering an environmental calamity from burning oil wells that may be costlier and wider in its effect than the material losses of the war.

title: Bridge
description: All of the top-ranked squads were on the sidelines when the semifinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: Industrial Output Falls 0.8% to Lowest Level in 2 1/2 Years
description: Industrial production declined eight-tenths of a percent in February to the lowest level in two and a half years, the Government said today. It was the fifth consecutive monthly decline, and analysts saw it as another sign that the recession was continuing unabated.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VICTOR E. FERRALL JR., a partner in the Washington law firm Crowell & Moring, is the new president of Beloit College in Beloit, Wis. He will replace DR. ROGER H. HULL, who left to become president of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., last September. Mr. Ferrall, 54, is to take over June 1.

title: Dykstra to See Vincent
description: Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, will visit the spring-training home of the Phillies in Clearwater, Fla., today to speak with Lenny Dykstra about the player's gambling troubles.

title: David A. Karetsky, 50, Investor and Sportsman
description: David A. Karetsky, an investor and avid sportsman, was killed on Tuesday in an avalanche while on a helicopter skiing trip in the Purcell Mountains of British Columbia. He was 50 years old and lived in Aspen, Colo.

title: May Wedding for Georgianna Conger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ford deCamp Conger of Aiken, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Georgianna Courtney Conger, to Randolph Appleton Wolcott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wolcott Jr. of Hamilton, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: No Recession For Political Parties
description: Reading the article about party politics and patronage [ "Democrats Clash Over Propriety of Dual Positions," Feb. 17 ] tells me the stench on Long Island is not only from the landfill in Port Washington. These hacks throw around $94,000 jobs as if there was no recession and no large unemployment among middle-level managers and blue-collar workers which threatens the very survival of the middle class and the viability of Long Island's economy.

title: Despite Sorrow, the Joffrey Season Soars
description: It would be foolish to appraise the Joffrey Ballet's otherwise triumphant New York season without taking into account the profound effect that Edward Stierle's choreography, illness and death have had on that engagement. Mr. Stierle became the company's most dazzling bravura dancer after joining in 1986. When two of his ballets were presented at Lincoln Center this season, he was revealed as a major new choreographic talent as well.

title: When It's Warm In February
description: How coincidental that I should return from walking on the boardwalk on Feb. 3, pick up the paper and read "In the Natural State" by Pete Dunne. His subject was memories of a warm day in February. That Sunday was the warmest day in February since the last century.

title: Suzanne Greenwald Is Wed
description: Suzanne Aimee Greenwald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Greenwald of Forest Hills, Queens, was married in Livingston, N.J., last evening to Marc Alan Unger, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Unger of Basking Ridge, N.J. Cantor Erno Grosz officiated at the Livingston Country Club. Mrs. Unger, 25 years old, graduated from Queens College and is a project coordinator of broadcasting for the National Hockey League in New York. Mr. Unger, 26, graduated from Lehigh University and is a certified public accountant with Ernst & Young in New York.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Hudson, Mass.;
Town Changes Mind on Mall
description: THE desire to use real-estate activity to help revive a faltering economy has prevailed over fears that more development will damage the environment and quality of life in this town 28 miles west of Boston and 18 miles east of Worcester.

title: Excerpts From the Address by Hussein on Iraq's Unrest
description: Following are excerpts from the address today by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, as transcibed from a simultaneous translation provided by the Cable News Network, which carried the speech live through the facilities of Iraqi television:

title: The Nation; The 'New Order' Is a Tall Order for the U.S.
description: FOR all of the jubilant comparisons of the triumph in the Persian Gulf to the victory in World War II, Americans have begun to realize that this is not the same world an all-powerful United States faced half a century ago after the defeat of Germany and Japan. Today, threats of civil wars and regional wars survive not only in Iraq and throughout the Middle East, but in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and elsewhere; and the United States, less dominant than it was, confronts severe economic, financial and social problems of its own.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Men's Fashions/ Magazine Part 2

title: Sarah Edmunds Weds Daniel Goodwin
description: Sarah Caroline Edmunds, the daughter of Alice Chase Kaufman of San Francisco and B. Claiborne Edmunds of New York, was married last evening to Daniel Bruce Goodwin, a son of Ira Goodwin of South Salem, N.Y., and Judith Platt of Wyckoff, N.J. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at TriBeCaPlace in New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Union or Disunion? A Crucial Test Today

title: Walking Sticks
description: To the Editor: In addition to the advantages outlined in Susan Allen Toth's article ("With Walking Stick on Solid Ground," Travel, Jan. 20), walking sticks make you invisible to dogs. ROBERT L. FOSTER Vancouver, British Columbia

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We live in a 100-year-old two-story row house. In very cold weather, when we drain the sink or bathtub or flush the toilet in our second-floor bathroom, we get a sound as if someone is tapping with a small hammer on our ceiling. The sound comes from an area where the vent stack is. Our plumber says he does not have an answer to our problem. What do you think is causing the tapping?

title: Managing; Sensitive Topics Take Center Stage
description: It was with schools and other youth groups in mind that Plays for Living Inc. first developed its half-hour presentations on AIDS, prejudice, alcoholism and other issues affecting modern youngsters.

title: Pro Football; Phoenix's First Loss of '91 May Be Super Bowl
description: A year ago at their annual March meeting the National Football League owners tried to reward Bill Bidwill for his 46-year association with the Cardinals and to showcase their newest city, Phoenix, by awarding Super Bowl XXVII in 1993 to the Valley of the Sun.

title: Uncommon Dishes Spark a Chinese Menu
description: RESTAURANTS with panda in the name have proliferated in Connecticut, and one of the more notable is Panda Inn in West Hartford. White walls, segmented by natural wood frames, and hung with Chinese art, booths and tables with dubonnet cloths and high-backed black wood-trimmed chairs all suggest a degree of stylishness beyond that of the stereotypical "gilded dragon" decor.

title: N.H.L. Has 'Goon' Problem
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Stage of Her Life
description: AN AWFULLY BIG ADVENTURE By Beryl Bainbridge. 205 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Restoration in Old Rhodes
description: A team of Greek archeologists, architects, civil engineers and masons on Rhodes, the largest of Greece's Dodecanese Islands, is making progress in its restoration of all buildings within the walled city of Rhodes. These include simple dwellings as well as historic buildings, including some from the Turkish period (1523-1912), and the 14th-century fortifications built by the Knights Hospitalers. In 1960 the old section was designated a protected monument by Greece. The work, which will take many years and cost millions of dollars, is intended to enhance the historic character of the city as well as living conditions for the residents.

title: Ex-Leader of Bulgaria Faces More Charges, Official Says
description: Todor Zhivkov, the ousted Communist leader already on trial for embezzlement of public funds, faces a second trial on charges of persecuting Bulgaria's Turkish minority, the chief military prosecutor has said.

title: Elizabeth Dwyer To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Dwyer of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Joan Dwyer to Michael Keith McMahon, a son of John P. McMahon of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Patricia P. McMahon. A June wedding is planned.

title: When the Citizen Soldiers Go Back to School; Reservist Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Senna Has Room To Improve Driving
description: Ayrton Senna, the Brazilian who already holds the record for most Formula One pole positions, consistently proves that in the search for the ultimate lap time, the edge of the universe is a lot farther out than anyone thought.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 of the Travel section today, about nartional parks, misstates the location of Yellowstone. It is primarily in Wyoming; it is not in Arizona.

title: Christian Retreat Will Halt Membership Card Program
description: The evangelist who bought the Christian theme park once run by Jim Bakker said today that he would end a membership card program promising lifetime, half-price discounts.

title:
The Executive Life;
For Startling Insights, Press Star H. Now.
description: For the last several years, a senior public relations executive in New York has placed a sign on her office door at least once a week admonishing passersby "Do Not Disturb." Then, in the privacy of her office, while talking on the telephone, she sobs, laughs, shouts and whispers. She emerges 45 minutes later, generally looking more peaceful than before.

title: Lorraine Levitt To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jesse Levitt of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Lorraine Elizabeth Levitt to Eric Samuel Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Paul Katz of Pound Ridge, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Mauve-ing of America
description: Martha Stewart. Alexandra Stoddard. Simply to say their names is to recall a dear friend -- I will call her Jane -- for whom living well was much more than the best revenge. It was the Only Thing. No supermarket bar of soap made its way into her bathroom, nor did she ever make a meal out of an end of salami, a heel of French bread and last night's leftover wine. I have, we all have. Jane would have thought it a descent into the gutter.

title: Woodman, Spare That (Um) Sapling
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
For Lambertville, a Second-Home Switch
description: HIGH on Cottage Hill in the southeastern corner of Lambertville is a 22-acre tract that overlooks the Delaware River and, beyond it, the chic community of New Hope, Pa.

title: Where Have All the Voices Gone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila Barnes Is Married
description: Sheila Teresa Barnes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Barnes Jr. of Edison, N.J., was married in Metuchen, N.J., yesterday to Giovanni Paolo Clemente LaBrum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paolo Clemente of Palm Beach, Fla., and Florence. The Rev. Robert W. Barnes performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Francis Cathedral. Mrs. Clemente LaBrum, 32 years old, graduated from Susquehanna University and is an assistant treasurer of the New York branch of the Union Bank of Switzerland. Mr. Clemente LaBrum, 32, graduated from Georgetown University and is a vice president in the foreign exchange department of Morgan Stanley in New York.

title: Children's Books/Biography
description: JULIA MORGAN Architect of Dreams. By Ginger Wadsworth. Illustrated. 128 pp. Minneapolis: Lerner Publications Company.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: The Feelies: 'Time for a Witness' Coyote/A&M 75021 5344; all three formats.

title: From School to Starring Role
description: It's unusual for someone fresh out of drama school to land the title role in the new movie by a director whose previous film won the Academy Award for best picture. It's even rarer when that someone entered the acting profession somewhat late, having spent five years as a telephone engineer.

title: Reaping Innovation From Recession . . . And the Recognition of Visionaries
description: Recently, I asked a random sampling of several dozen of my colleagues and business acquaintances for their thoughts about vision, visioning and what qualities they most identified with visionaries. By vision I mean the ability to correctly foresee the future and navigate successfully through it. I also asked them for their thoughts about putting those visions into action and about which leaders -- in general -- they most regard as visionaries. The results of my informal "poll" were enlightening:

title: Baker Ready to Test Plans for Arab-Israeli Peace
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that his talks with Arab and Israeli leaders had encouraged him to begin presenting specific peace proposals next week to see if the leaders are as interested in reconciliation as they say.

title: Extra Service And Strong Loyalty
description: In "Turkish Immigrants Strike Gold at Gas Stations" [ Feb. 17 ] , you wrote about Turkish service-station owners and attendants. Mr. Enes, the proprietor of the Amoco station that I use and that is on Glen Cove Road just south of Route 25A, told a story illustrating his desire to treat his customers well.

title: Journeys in the Mind's Eye
description: SEVERAL years ago my sister was on holiday in that part of Scotland that is on the top left-hand side of the map. (I don't recall her ever giving any village, loch or moor an identifying name.) By day her husband golfed while she took long walks and the occasional bus ride to a cashmere sweater factory, and by evening they met in the local pub for a predinner drink and a hearty handshake from the dog in residence. A failure at rounding up sheep, he had been given the only job for which he seemed suited: mine host. I long to go to that pub.

title: When the Citizen Soldiers Go Back to School
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about Westchester's waterfront misstated an estimate of the cost of removing toxic wastes from the site of the Harbor at Hastings project in Hastings-on-Hudson. It was $15 million.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: My wife and I visited Czechoslovakia and Austria last fall. Although our visit was delightful in most respects, I ran into one rather distressing situation.

title: Ms. Barhite to Wed Capt. S. W. Carter
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Barhite of Clinton Corners, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Sarah Barhite, to Capt. Steven Whitney Carter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Carter of Hudson, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title: Death, an Arrest and 2 Crashes Among 3 Cabbies
description: A gypsy-cab driver was charged with manslaughter yesterday after he collided with another cab in the Bronx, tried to rob its driver, then sped off and crashed into a third cab, killing its driver, the police said.

title: Cruises
description: To the Editor: In November 1989 I had a confirmed reservation and an assigned cabin on the Norway for a cruise on Dec. 2, 1990, and had paid a deposit.

title: Grape Expectations
description: ANGELS' VISITS An Inquiry Into the Mystery of Zinfandel. By David Darlington. 278 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 24 about Key West misidentified the southernmost city in the United States. It is Hilo, Hawaii.

title: The Dollar's Rally Continues
Channelview Journal; Love, Ambition and the Price for a Child's Success
description: The azaleas and jasmine have bloomed across the Sterling Green subdivision here, and in two nearly identical houses around the corner from each other, two mothers have resumed their routines of car pools and trips to the mall.

title: Wall Street; One More Way to Lose on Airlines
description: One thing you can say for the airline industry: It has certainly offered investors a lot of ways to lose money over the last year.

title: 6 Countries Send Artists To State
description: VISITING Connecticut this week are illustrious artists and ensembles from Finland, Scotland, Spain, France, Canada and Czechoslovakia. First to arrive, tomorrow at 8 P.M., are the members of the Scottish Chamber Orchestra and their Finnish conductor, Jukka-Pekka Saraste. The program at Jorgensen Auditorium, at the University of Connecticut at Storrs, lists Beethoven's Second Symphony, Stravinsky's "Dumbarton Oaks" Concerto and the "Concierto de Aranjuez" by the Spanish master Joaquin Rodrigo, with Christopher Parkening the guitar soloist.

title: Children Are Mobilizing to Protect Their Planet
description: IT makes a jubilant image: a colorful sweep of helium-filled balloons soaring into the air, then fading into tiny dots against a blue sky.

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sieckmann Leads by a Shot in Suspended Event
description: Battling rain and a field of top names, Tom Sieckmann ran off five birdies in six holes today to take the lead after three days of the Nestle Invitational.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Turnout Lifts Hopes for Housing Market
description: AN increasing number of people who apparently feel that prices have bottomed out are starting to show up in real estate offices throughout Long Island, according to brokers.

title: Amy Matthews to Wed Jonathan Feins
description: Lydia S. Matthews and Mortimer J. Matthews, both of Pasadena, Calif., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Amy Procter Matthews and Jonathan Edward Feins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Feins of New London, N.H.

title: Group Keeps Alive Memories of Air Battles
description: IN this tree-lined middle-class community, where yellow ribbons grace sweeping oaks and American flags adorn many front porches, one house on Hartley Place stands out. For Glenn Obertubbesing, 48 years old, it is a distinction born of pride for a nation where the price of freedom has run high, he says, both today and in an era past and nearly forgotten.

title: Wall Street; Currency Traders vs. the Central Banks
description: Traders who have been predicting a rally for the dollar ran up against the concerted force of the leading central banks last week. The score by Friday was Traders 1, Bankers 0.

title: Fly So Free Is Victor in Florida
description: Unbridled gave the performance of the day when he rocketed past six horses in the home stretch and upset the champion sprinter Housebuster at Gulfstream Park today.

title: Technology; Positioning the Electronic Stylus
description: The expected boom in pen-based computers is setting off a furious race to develop a crucial yet often overlooked technology for these machines: the system by which the computer determines the position of the pen.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Developers Divided on Value of Auction
description: THE growing number of property auctions, now accepted as a marketing tool, has divided developers. Some like them because they help dispose of inventory. But others say they contribute to a perception of panic in the industry.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT/Tournament Money: Root of Good or Evil?; Basketball TV Dollars Give Schools Means to Change
description: It is absolutely accurate to say that television revenues derived from the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship will not resolve the many challenges facing intercollegiate athletics today. It is also accurate to say, however, that intelligent utilization of those revenues can, and will, enable institutional personnel to focus on the underlying causes that led to the challenges being faced.

title: Ellen M. Jacobs To Wed in April
description: Ellen Meredith Jacobs and Jeffrey H. Lehman plan to marry in April. Miss Jacobs is a daughter of Dolores Jacobs of Great Neck, L.I., and Jason J. Jacobs of Kings Point, L.I. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Lehman of New York.

title: Cold-Fusion Claim Is Faulted on Ethics as Well as Science
description: The startling assertion by two chemists that they had achieved nuclear fusion in a test tube was based on "invented" data whose publication involved a serious breach of ethics and a violation of scientific protocol, prominent scientists have concluded.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LAST CHANCE TO SEEBy Douglas Adamsand Mark Cawardine.Harmony, $20.

title: In Search for Priorities, Democrats Find a Split
description: As Congress seeks to shift the country's political focus to domestic matters, a split is emerging between the Democratic leadership and rank-and-file members over what the party's legislative priorities should be.

title: Postings: Renaissance Revival; A New Gap for an Old Bank
description: The old Yorkville Bank, a rather elegant little Renaissance Revival building on the corner of Third Avenue and 85th Street, is about to become Manhattan's newest Gap clothing store (there are already about 30). It is to open in May, said a spokeswoman for the retail chain, which has its headquarters in San Francisco.

title: Toll Increase Begins Today
description: Increases in tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike go into effect today, with drivers of passenger cars paying 70 percent more and truck drivers paying twice as much.

title: Travel Advisory; Art in London
description: More than 120 galleries from 16 countries are expected to display the most comprehensive assembly of contemporary art that Britain will see this year at ARTLondon91, the sixth international contemporary art fair, at Olympia, the exhibition center in London, from April 18 to 20. Paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints and photographs will go on sale at prices ranging from $200 to $1.5 million.

title: Dealing Death, or Mercy?
description: Dr. Timothy Quill knows how to frame an ethical issue so it can't be fudged. He's the doctor in Rochester, N.Y., who announced in a medical journal recently that he had prescribed sleeping pills so that a woman with severe leukemia could kill herself.

title:
World Markets;
A Cooler German Auto Market?
description: Recession is biting sharply into most European auto makers' sales and earnings. But Germany's auto market is booming, with new-car registrations climbing 39 percent in January, primarily because of pent-up demand for cars in eastern Germany. Even Daimler Benz's new top-of-the-line Mercedes luxury cars -- the "S" class, priced at $60,000 and up -- have been an immediate hit with critics and customers.

title: To a Tee
description: Golf, as its devotees have observed, is an individualist's sport. So it isn't surprising that the personal stamp of a person's stroke is often reflected in his choice of clothes. From pants with a riotous patchwork design to peaked tartan caps and argyle hose, the game abounds in classical oddities. Recently this somewhat zany repertory has stretched to include shirts and sweaters signed with country club logos, and jaunty golf bags in searing shades of pink.

title: Children's Books/Biography
description: FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT By Russell Freedman. Illustrated. 200 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Chess
description: Of the seven candidates matches for world championship aspirants that ended at the beginning of February, the one distinguished for its spotty play was in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, between Grandmasters Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Gyula Sax of Hungary.

title: Helping the Elderly Manage the Maze
description: WHEN Maria Valdez received a telephone call that her 86-year-old mother had suffered a stroke and could not live alone, she went into a tailspin. Not only did she not get along with her mother, but she and her husband, Roy, were also nearing retirement.

title: Wendy E. Breuer Has a Wedding
description: Wendy Elizabeth Breuer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Breuer of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., to Robert Manson Dewey 3d, a son of Mrs. John W. Cross 3d of New York and Mr. Dewey Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. John P. Duffell performed the ceremony.

title: Suellyn Preston, Principal, Weds
description: Suellyn Preston, the principal of the upper school at Trinity School in New York, was married yesterday to Theodore W. Scull, a freelance travel writer and author, at St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish in New York. The Rev. Craig Townsend and the Rev. John W. Moody, Episcopal priests, officiated.

title: Postings: Forest Hills Auction; 26 New Stories
description: When Kraus Enterprises started raising the 26 floors of the Embassy condo tower on Queens Boulevard at 75th Street two years ago, Forest Hills was deemed ready for another big high-rise apartment building. But the slump came and the project faltered. It was taken over by Crossland Savings and Loan, principal construction creditor of the project, last summer, and the bank continued the construction..

title: A Ragtime Reverie Set to Words
description: Eric Overmyer is not a playwright who does things simply, so it's probably not enough to say that his latest theatrical conceit, "The Heliotrope Bouquet by Scott Joplin and Louis Chauvin" (at Center Stage in Baltimore), is a dream play. It's really three dreams -- wrapping themselves around one another like languid tendrils of opium smoke stirred by a ceiling fan.

title: Q and A
description: Hiking Around Mont Blanc

title: Churchill and Eisenhower
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadow Star Now 8-0
description: In a performance that justified the confidence of the bettors at Aqueduct, who wagered almost 75 percent of the total win pool on her, Meadow Star, the 1990 Filly of the Year, romped to the eighth victory of her unbeaten career yesterday. The victory reinforced her status as a factor for handicappers of the Kentucky Derby.

title: He Had Money, Women, an S.&L. Now Don Dixon Has Jail
description: With a price tag to taxpayers that may reach $500 billion, the savings and loan bailout is destined to become the most expensive financial debacle in the country's history. About 550 failed savings institutions have already been closed, their assets brought under the Government's control to be sold. Deregulation, allowing savings units to invest in everything from raw land to risky "junk bonds," is largely to blame for the failures, but entrepreneurs who rolled into the industry and played fast and loose with the money are also culprits.
