Federal prosecutors won convictions of 403 of them of fraud. Among the most notorious is Donald Ray Dixon, the head of Vernon Savings and Loan, who could soon get the stiffest sentence of any. His story, culled from court documents and interviews, is emblematic of the torrid living that ransacked the industry.

title: From Top of Their World to Professional Ostracism
description: In two years, the would-be co-discoverers of cold fusion have gone from scientific stars at the University of Utah to outcasts estranged from the birthplace of their discovery.

title: Gerard Adams Fiance Of Melinda D. Michael
description: May wedding plans for Melinda Debra Michael and Gerard A. J. Adams, the son of Claartje Radstake of Diever, the Netherlands, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Michael of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Headliners; Keeping Score
description: Winding one's way through the labyrinthine corridors of power in New York City has never been easy, and some say that the combination of a new Mayor and a new City Charter made 1990 an especially dizzying year. A report released last week by the city showed that lobbyists received almost $8.5 million in fees last year, an increase of about a third over 1989. One of every three dollars in new lobbying money went to the law firm of Davidoff & Malito, which is run by Mayor David N. Dinkins's frequent tennis partner Sid Davidoff. Mr. Davidoff, who was a top assistant to Mayor John V. Lindsay, said his company prospered the most because it was "the best." But Gene Russianoff, a senior lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, said what Mr. Davidoff had to offer was access. "This guy is a phone call away from the top levels of City Hall," he said. Mr. Dinkins insisted that Mr. Davidoff was treated no differently than other lobbyists. "All matters are considered on the merits," the Mayor said.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate

title: Officer Held in Assault at Ex-Wife's House
description: A Passaic Township man was critically wounded when he was shot at close range by a Newark police sergeant on Friday, officials said today.

title: Sandra Ward and Dan Costin Marry
description: Sandra Ward, a lawyer in New York, and Dr. Dan Costin, an oncology fellow at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., were married last evening at the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery officiated.

title: LEADER OF SERBIA DEFIES YUGOSLAVIA ON FEDERAL RULE
description: The President of Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest and most powerful republic, declared today that he was defying the collective federal executive body by refusing to recognize its supreme authority.

title: Land War's Vanguard
description: Two days before the ground assault on Iraqi forces began in earnest, a vanguard of more than 3,000 marines secretly moved more than 10 miles into Kuwait, officers say.

title:
DANCE;
A Balanchine Ballet That Offers 'Jazzy Stuff'
description: THE New Jersey Ballet Company and Kean College will celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Wilkins Theater, the campus performing arena, on Saturday at 8 P.M. As the designated resident company of the college, the troupe, based in West Orange, has enjoyed an association that began with a performance featuring two stars of the New York City Ballet, Patricia McBride and Edward Villella.

title: Blue-Ribbon Aura
description: Every dog may have its day, but not at the Westminster Kennel Club. Beginning with the 116th event, next February, the show, which once welcomed any dog, will accept only bona fide American Kennel Club champions, dogs that have accumulated 15 championship points at other shows.

title: Our Future Is Behind Us
description: GENERATIONSThe History of America's Future, 1584 to 2069.By William Strauss and Neil Howe.538 pp. New York:William Morrow & Company.

title: VIEWS OF SPORT/Tournament Money: Root of Good or Evil?; N.C.A.A. Distribution Plan Makes Rich Get Richer
description: For the next three weeks, one of America's most exciting sporting events, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Men's Basketball tournament, will spawn office pools across the land and divert millions of people from their worries about the recession and dwindling job security.

title: The Deadly 'Spoils' of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Strolling in the Sierras Of Ancient Andalusia
description: EVERYONE, it seems, wants to talk about the new Spain. About the state-of-the-art sports complex for the Olympic Games in Barcelona. About Seville transforming itself to act as host to a world's fair. The news is that Spain is outdistancing its stereotypes. The truth is that poets, artists and dreamers can rest easy for in juxtaposition with modernity, the romantic images most associated with Spain live on, especially in Andalusia.

title: The Commuter's Destination Is the County
description: THE initial Census Bureau counts for the lower Hudson Valley, when looked at in conjunction with statistics from other agencies, suggest that Westchester is becoming less dependent on New York City and is a thriving economic entity in its own right.

title: Double Play
description: To celebrate the start of its 10th-anniversary season this week, American Playhouse has chosen a twin bill of Broadway productions. On Wednesday at 8 P.M., the 1991 series will begin with Stephen Sondheim's musical "Into the Woods," staged by James Lapine. The performance, taped live on Broadway, stars Bernadette Peters and Joanna Gleason. Afterward, there will be an interview with Mr. Sondheim.

title: Of Music Makers and Storytellers
description: The life and times of Josephine Baker were relived Tuesday at Macy's Herald Square. The "Uptown Cabaret Downtown" celebrated the premiere of "The Josephine Baker Story," an HBO musical biography of the American dancer and entertainer who became the toast of Paris in the 1920's. The television movie made its debut last night.

title: U.S. in Accord on Child Benefits
description: The Bush Administration has agreed to reconsider the cases of about 400,000 poor children denied disability benefits since 1980 to see whether they qualify under new criteria that the Administration recently established.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIEUTENANT KIJE/YOUNG VITUSHISHNIKOV By Yury Tynyanov. Translated by Mirra Ginsburg. Eridanos/David R. Godine, $18.95.

title: S. B. Tingley Jr. to Wed Miss Spearman
description: June wedding plans have been announced for Laura Elizabeth Spearman and Samuel Bradford Tingley Jr. The bride-to-be is the daughter of Laura Smith Spearman and Dr. William B. Spearman, both of Atlanta. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tingley of Barrington, R.I.

title: Sci-Fi Now Ex-Postman's Bag
description: ALBERT J. MANACHINO of Hicksville writes tales of fantasy. Yet his emergence as a writer for small-press publishers, a career that began when he became a grandfather, may be as unusual as any of his imaginary worlds.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Boito: 'Mefistofele' Eva Marton, soprano; Placido Domingo, tenor; Samuel Ramey, bass; Hungarian Opera Chorus; Hungarian State Orchestra conducted by Giuseppe Patane. Sony Classical S2K 44983; two CD's and cassettes.

title: For Foes of Gulf War, Nation's Victory Is Bitter
description: Despite the nation's euphoria over the allied victory in the Persian Gulf, the war's hard-core opponents in the United States -- the small group against military action of any kind -- remain implacable.

title: Campus Life: Rutgers; Two Fraternities Are Suspended For Violations
description: Update: June 28, 2018

title: Political Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Brunch; 3 Choices When Eggs Benedict Just Isn't Enough
description: The options for Sunday brunch in New York City go far beyond the traditional mimosa-and-eggs-Benedict scenario. One can start the day with everything from an omelet of smoked salmon, chives and sour cream at La Cite, to jambalaya at Joe Allen, to fried quail eggs with lentils and garlic sausage at the Rainbow Room. Here are some of the other dishes being offered. La Cite

title: Independent a Year, Namibia Is Pragmatic at Home and Ideological Abroad
description: When Namibia gained its independence on March 21, 1990, after 75 years of South African rule, some departing skeptics jibed that goats would soon graze on grass poking through the cracked asphalt on Kaiser Street, Windhoek's main thoroughfare.

title: U.S. Vaccine Plan Uses Welfare Offices
description: The Centers for Disease Control is planning to use welfare and nutrition offices to deliver immunizations to poor children, agency officials say.

title: Yancey, a Pioneer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Inside Greenhouses, the Season Has Already Sprung
description: SCARCELY a bud is blooming outside, but a preview of the coming season is waiting in greenhouses throughout the state. Those who wish a taste of spring can find abundant tropical orchids, desert cactuses and even exotic banana and cacao plants.

title: Texas
description: To the Editor: Lest Texans assume that some geological upheaval has rearranged a Big Bend landmark, I would like to point out that the picture on page 1 of the March 3 Travel section is not of the Window, as the caption states, but was taken in the Grapevine Hills in the northern half of the park.

title: What's a Mother to Do?
description: In the still-male world of television news, a maternal image is a dangerous thing. Before Meredith Vieira was fired from "60 Minutes," few viewers knew she was working part time, to be with her young son. Now, because Ms. Vieira is pregnant again and CBS refused to extend the part-time arrangement, she has become a news item herself. Viewers who saw her simply as a reporter now know she has had several miscarriages; they have read that some men at "60 Minutes" were not happy when she brought her infant to the office.

title: Two Reasons for Dancing in the Streets of New York
description: It's been a big week for the good guys, no doubt about it. If you're in the New York City architecture and preservation business, things have suddenly been going so well you could start feeling like Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf. First the United States Supreme Court declines to review the landmarks case involving St. Bartholomew's Church, effectively killing forever the church's plan to erect a skyscraper on a portion of its landmark property on Park Avenue -- and ending the bitterest landmarks dispute of the decade entirely in the favor of the landmarks lobby.
