title:
TELEVISION;
What TV Makes of the Fourth Estate
description: Channel-switching TV viewers might have been thrown off balance if they happened upon a broadcast a few months ago that featured two famous television stars. They would have seen two women, both intelligent, accomplished, gorgeous, blond and instantly recognizable. One was a broadcast journalist and anchor of a prime-time newsmagazine, the other an actress playing a broadcast journalist who anchors a prime-time newsmagazine.

title: Closer Than We Knew
description: MARTIN & MALCOLM & AMERICA A Dream or a Nightmare. By James H. Cone. Illustrated. 358 pp. Maryknoll, N.Y.: Orbis Books. $22.95. THERE IS A BALM IN GILEAD The Cultural Roots of Martin Luther King, Jr. By Lewis V. Baldwin. 348 pp. Minneapolis: Fortress Press. Paper, $19.95.

title: Tina Gitlin Wed To Steven Price
description: Tina Gitlin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Gitlin of New York, was married last evening to Steven Price, the son of Robert Price and Margery Price, both of New York. Rabbis David Lincoln and Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Dr. Alyssa Dweck and Dr. Evan Krakovitz to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Alyssa Dweck to Dr. Evan Krakovitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan Krakovitz of Yardley, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Judith Dweck of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jack Dweck of New Canaan, Conn. Dr. Dweck, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia, graduated from Barnard College. She has a master's degree in human nutrition from Columbia University and a medical degree from Hahnemann University. Dr. Krakovitz, a resident in surgery at the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia, graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received his medical degree from Hahnemann.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: East Regional; Smith Gets a Kick as a Fan and Scout
description: With a mixture of glee and dread, Dean Smith, the University of North Carolina basketball coach, watched Villanova patiently contend with Princeton's methodical strategy Friday night at the Carrier Dome in the last game of the first round of the East Regional.

title: Spring Comes Early And With It, Concerts
description: NO longer must audiences wait for summer to enjoy fine music amid the beauty of Caramoor. Spring is here, and with it four recitals in the Music Room, starting at 8:30 P.M. Saturday when the pianist Jose Ramos-Santana plays Beethoven's Opus 78 Sonata, Schumann's "Symphonic Etudes" and shorter works of Albeniz and Chopin.

title: Transit Authority Urged to Cut Management Jobs
description: As New York State legislators and transit officials look for ways to reduce a $215 million deficit in the Transit Authority budget, the agency's legion of managers and their support staffs have become favorite targets.

title: Baker Meets Officials From Baltic Republics
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with officials from the independence-minded Baltic republics today, a day after praising the Kremlin for "some progress' in the wake of its violent crackdown in the Baltic region two months ago.

title: That Madcap Meryl. Really!
description: The tragic heroine, the brilliant mimic, the woman of a thousand accents, Mary Louise Streep is also something else -- she's a goof.

title: Margo M. Garrett, Teacher, to Wed
description: The engagement of Margo Meredith Garrett to Dennis Leonard O'Brien, the son of Mrs. Dennis O'Brien of Loudonville, N.Y., and the late Mr. O'Brien, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Garrett of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: An Open Letter to R. Henderson
description: Mr. R. Henderson Oakland Athletics Phoenix, Ariz. 85008

title: Travel Advisory; Guide Series
description: The publishers of the Insight city and regional guides -- acclaimed by many travelers for their practical information and lavish illustrations -- are about to issue a series of handbooks on United States cities. The first, on Miami, is scheduled for distribution in June. It will be followed by guides to Los Angeles, New York, Boston and Chicago and, later, to New Orleans, Washington, Seattle, Atlanta, Houston, Dallas-Fort Worth and Philadelphia.

title: New Domestic Supply Of Oil Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Brigham Young; Rules on Dress Are Relaxed In Honor Code
description: The new honor code at Brigham Young University sets broad standards for behavior, affecting everything from sexual activity to tea-drinking.

title: About Men; Downtown Cousin
description: I HAD JUST FINISHED A spending spree for suits, a binge delayed for years, when I hailed a taxi. I wanted to head uptown to buy a sing-along tape machine at a discount electronics store. The cabdriver, like me, was Chinese, and somewhere in our conversation about my good English and his tough life as an immigrant, he learned that I was heading for a midtown store. "Why you do that? You should go Chinatown! Much better than uptown, cousin. You know Chinatown cheaper. Much cheaper."

title: Headliners; For Two Museums, a Very Good Week
description: SINCE 1986, museum officials have deplored the Tax Reform Act, which curtailed gifts of art by drastically cutting the deductions that wealthy donors could claim. Along with galloping price increases, the tax law has dramatically reduced the acquisitions of most art museums and resulted in a flow of high-quality works to auction houses and dealers.

title: Data Bank/March 17, 1991
COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Women; No. 1 Penn State Upset
description: Jeanine Michealsen of James Madison blocked a 3-point shot attempt at the buzzer this afternoon to preserve a 73-71 upset of No. 1-ranked Penn State in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament.

title: Corned Beef and Cabbage? Ireland Refines Tradition
description: AS anyone who has recently been to Ireland knows, there is a lot more to the native cooking than corned beef and cabbage. Today's chefs are rediscovering and refining traditional Irish foods, using high-quality ingredients in imaginative ways.

title: Are Women Directors an Endangered Species?
description: When it came time to hire a director for "Nightmare on Elm Street 6" a few months ago, Rachel Talalay was a logical choice. She had, after all, produced Parts 3 and 4 of the gory saga of Freddy Krueger, and they turned out to be the two most successful movies in the teen horror series. But once she actually began work on the project, Ms. Talalay recalled, she "would occasionally get internal memos telling me, 'Don't be too girly; don't be too sensitive.' "

title: Hollywood Chainsaw Massacre
description: YOU'LL NEVER EAT LUNCH IN THIS TOWN AGAIN By Julia Phillips. 573 pp. New York: Random House. $22.

title: New York City Widens Plan to Warn of AIDS Exposure
description: Expanding its effort to notify those exposed to the AIDS virus, the New York City Health Department has begun warning the sex and drug partners of people whose autopsies show that they were infected.

title: The Iron Butterfly Within Miss Saigon
description: Amid all the fuss that's been made over "Miss Saigon," the one person who seems to have been forgotten is Miss Saigon.

title: College Basketball; Dehere Sparks Pirates' Blitz
description: Terry Dehere, Seton Hall's shooting guard, ignited a second-half scoring blitz as the Pirates raced away from Creighton to win, 81-69, today in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's West Regional at the Huntsman Center here.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOVE & DESIRE & HATE By Joan Collins.Linden/Simon & Schuster, $21.95.

title: In Brooklyn, Wontons, Not Lapskaus
description: The signs of social change and the transformation of a community are often subtle, sometimes brutal and occasionally bizarre.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;
A Golf Course As Enticement
description: HOPING to attract corporate headquarters to Baltimore, a group of executives has developed a private golf club and 34 large and expensive wooded home sites in a 900-acre valley northwest of the city.

title: INTO THE ROSE GARDEN
description: As is usually the case when writing about women and sex, to resort to Freud, as Michael Pollan does in his amusing article, is limiting, to put it charitably. Why does he assume the rose should "abandon . . . herself to one great climax of bloom" or be accused of repression? Like all Freudian readings of female sexuality, this one is based on a male model. The repeat blooming of the hybrid tea rose could be more aptly likened to the female talent for multiple climax. Perhaps the flower Pollan is actually looking for is the peony, with its tumescent red stalks thrusting up out of the early spring earth, and its vigorous but all-too-brief eruption of bloom, not to mention its wonderfully evocative name. (The flower-as-sexual-metaphor game can be played in several ways.)

title: Laura Bliss Soper Engaged To Scott Fitzgerald Budd
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Tappen Soper of Zurich have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Laura Bliss Soper, and Scott Fitzgerald Budd, a son of Mrs. Ralph H. Hood of Newtown, Pa., and John S. Budd of Carona del Mar, Calif.

title: Food; Poetic License
description: WHEN I WAS TEACHING MYSELF TO COOK, I was also teaching myself to write poems. In those days I didn't compare the two ancient and related crafts but simply slogged along, useful mistake by useful mistake.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Not the McLaughlin Group

title: Greenery That Grows Where Grass Doesn't
description: SINCE green is the color for today, it may be the time to start thinking about this color around the property. Of course, the largest spread of greenery that almost everyone grows is the lawn. The ubiquitous cover does a masterful job of protecting open ground and usually is the pride of the homeowner.

title: Pro Hockey; Penguins Are Closing In
description: Mark Recchi and Bryan Trottier each scored twice and Jaromir Jagr had one goal and an assist as the Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 6-3, today.

title: And Now, Back To Us
description: Feeling ill at ease? Nervous? Having trouble concentrating? Do you feel the need for an analysis by someone retired? If you long for the excitement of war reportage, you're not alone.

title: 'Mom Alone'
description: Last year 20th Century Fox released a little film it made for around $18 million, which is lunch money in Hollywood. It was called "Home Alone," and was about a small boy accidentally left behind while his family went to France on vacation.

title: There's Still Some Zip Left in the Theater Season
description: BY now, the expected changes in the state's theater schedules have been made for the expected cost-cutting reasons. All the "to be announced" slots have been announced, and substitutions have been made.

title: What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Between Stairs at Wimpole Street
description: LADY'S MAID By Margaret Forster.548 pp. New York:Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Dana Seltzer Is to Marry Paul Levin in the Fall
description: Honey Seltzer of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter Dana Aynn Seltzer to Paul Adam Levin, a son of Nadine Levin of Rancho Mirage, Calif. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Pro Football; Wyche Still Fighting on Locker Rooms
description: With characteristic zeal, Sam Wyche, the Cincinnati Bengals' coach, is leading a crusade to have the National Football League change part of its policy governing post-game locker-room access to players.

title: Review/Film Festival; Losing Oneself, Truly, In Star Impersonations
description: Ilana Bar-Din, the director of "Legends," saves her scenes of a meeting of the Jonathon Von Brana Fan Club for fairly late in the film, which is a smart idea. The concept of a Jonathon Von Brana Fan Club requires leading up to. Jonathon Von Brana is not, by any reasonable standard, a famous person. He is only the tallest, cutest and generally most plausible of the several Elvis Presley impersonators connected with the Las Vegas revue of the title, a mesmerizingly sad spectacle that Ms. Bar-Din examines with tremendous verve, economy and wisdom.

title: TALKS IN IRAN SEEK TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: Talks are under way in the Iranian capital in an effort to secure the release of Western hostages in Lebanon, say Shiite Muslims well informed about the activities of the Party of God, the umbrella group for clandestine factions holding the captives.

title: Ideas & Trends; How Do You Tell A Victorious War From a Just One?
description: MILITARY experts are already reviewing the Persian Gulf war, assessing battle plans, appraising the performance of weapons and personnel, drawing lessons for the next war. Somewhat more hesitantly, moralists are beginning to do the same. They are looking back at the debate about the war's morality, evaluating the kinds of arguments they made, wondering whether it all made any difference and, like the military, asking what the implications are for the future.

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients Tested After Dentist's AIDS Death
description: A dentist here died of AIDS two weeks ago, and state health officials are now offering free tests for the disease to more than 1,200 of the dentist's patients.

title: Carolyn Holmes to Marry John Coffey
description: May wedding plans for Carolyn Gay Holmes and John Walter Coffey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Coffey of Midlothian, Va., have been announced by her parents, Mrs. David H. Kelsey of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Joseph H. Holmes 3d of Darien, Conn.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: Although I agree with Mark A. Uhlig's description (Travel, Dec. 23) of Zihuatanenjo's Playa de Ropa as one of the most beautiful beaches on the Pacific coast, I was surprised that he did not mention any hotels in the Playa de Madera area.

title: Europe's Loss of Thatcher Slows Unity
description: When Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain resigned in late November, European governments quietly welcomed the departure of the person who time and again for over a decade had fought to slow the process of European integration.

title: Pro Basketball: N.B.A./Friday's Games; Houston Has Winning Look
description: Despite sitting in sixth place in the Western Conference, the Houston Rockets have the look of a champion going into the homestretch of the National Basketball Association season.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland; Countering Suburbs' Lure
description: NEW tax incentives have gone into effect here to encourage the building of housing to keep middle-income buyers in the city.

title: Invasion of the Apartment Snatchers
description: BEYOND THE CURVE By Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. 247 pp. New York: Kodansha International.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on March 3 about a tribute to Duke Ellington yesterday at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, misidentified a participant, Ruth Willard. She was Ellington's West Coast representative for a time but is now a freelance writer, research consultant and oral historian, not a press agent.

title: Hospitals Face Cash Shortfall
description: TWO months after receiving their last payment from the state fund that had reimbursed them for treating the uninsured poor, hospitals with large numbers of charity cases are struggling to meet costs.

title: Pro Basketball; New Ways for Old Knicks
description: The names are the same but the Knicks are different.

title: Silvia Lorello to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Lorello of Short Hills, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Silvia Lisa Lorello and John William Micchelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Micchelli of Convent Station, N.J. Ms. Lorello, 26 years old, graduated from Drew University and studies at the Parsons School of Design. Mr. Micchelli, 26, works for Goldman Sachs as a futures trader on the New York Merchantile Exchange.

title: Northeast Notebook: Wilmington, Del.; Pinning Hopes On a Rehab
description: REHABILITATION work is under way at a 27-year-old, 18-story office building foreclosed last year by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark.

title: In Burbank, Revival and Growth Limits
description: THIS birthplace of Mickey Mouse and Lockheed's Stealth fighter is soon to be home to an unusual 2.5-million-square-foot, $400 million retail and office center. Its presence is already revitalizing a downtown long derided on the Johnny Carson Show as "beautiful downtown Burbank."

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Visalia, Calif;
Narrowing Disparity
description: THE gap in prices between houses in communities near the coast and those farther inland narrowed last year, with homes in some inland areas appreciating at double-digit rates and those in some coastal areas dropping.

title: 'Who Knows? You Could Outlive Your Doctor'
description: EVEN THOUGH I HAD BEEN EXPECTING IT, THE WORDS still stung. You never get used to being told you have cancer. But this time the diagnosis was even worse.

title: Sunday Racing Is Boon to Meadowlands
description: THE recent introduction of Sunday horse racing at the Meadowlands Sports Complex has substantially reduced the loss of revenue at the complex. For several years, profits at the Meadowlands had steadily declined, primarily as a result of a national falloff in racing attendance that has plagued tracks from coast to coast.

title: Latin America Lures Westchester Companies
description: ABUNDANT natural resources, relative political and economic stability for the first time in decades, and 425 million people eager to do business with the United States are making Latin America a more attractive trading partner for Westchester companies.

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: ANGER SPREADING AMONG KUWAITIS
description: On the eve of Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting and prayer, Kuwaitis are deeply unhappy with the returning Government's halting efforts to restore essential services, including water and electricity.

title: 5 Collegians Are Raped at a Texas Resort
description: Five college students taking spring break on this popular resort island near the Mexican border have been raped in apparently unrelated attacks this week, the police say.

title:
Gardening;
For Moss, It Is Easy Being Green
description: After 10 years at their Guilford, Conn., home, Jerry and Roberta Silbert could only describe their lawn as pathetic. No wonder. Their 1.5-acre property was deeply shaded with hemlock, pine and sugar maple. Facing a small lake, the lawn was prone to dampness and, because most of the land sits on rock ledge, the soil was poor. The property was absolutely charming, but the lawn was a flop.

title: Topics of the Times; March, the Miserable
description: At 8 o'clock Friday morning, a New Yorker went out for the newspaper. It was snowing.

title: October Wedding For Miss Kaplan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Kaplan of Teaneck, N.J., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Deborah Michele Kaplan and Howard Mark Falkow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Falkow of Margate, N.J.

title: Ms. Crown Weds William R. C. Ellis
description: Mary Eaton Crown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. E. Crown of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Russell Corson Ellis, a son of Anne Haskell Ellis of Middletown, N.J., and the late John C. Ellis. The Rev. David Toomey performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Poughkeepsie.

title: Headstrong
description: THE N.B.A.'S ALL-STAR show is basketball junk food, a quick and giddy high -- sweet feats from playgrounds past, high-caloric hot-dogging. It is the game reduced, stripped of its fiber of defense. The players binge along with the fans. By unwritten code, there are no hard feelings, no hard knocks.

title: Miss Hall Wed To Paul Whyte
description: Margaret Mary Hall and Paul Madden Whyte were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Kevin T. Royal officiated at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church.

title: McKesson: No. 1 but a Doze on Wall Street
description: The 158-year-old McKesson Corporation is old enough to refer to all but a handful of American companies as young whippersnappers. It is big enough to be the only national force in the growing $22 billion business of distributing pharmaceuticals and personal care products to drugstores, hospitals and mass marketers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. And McKesson is good enough at what it does to have been invited by the Soviet Union to help unravel its infamous distribution logjams.

title: Ellen Sophia Freilich To Wed Mark Pakman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Felix Freilich of Cleveland have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Sophia Freilich to Mark Pakman, the son of Marianna Pakman of New York and the late Lev Pakman. A May wedding is planned.

title: Before Ground War Began, Marines Were Inside Kuwait
description: Two days before the official beginning of the allied ground attack on Iraqi forces, more than 3,000 United States marines secretly moved more than 10 miles into Kuwait to prepare for the land war, senior Marine officers say.

title: Sharp Focus on an Unwavering Gaze
description: "Everything at his touch, under the influence of his gnarled, vigorous drawing, assumes a mysterious solidity, a kind of dilated amplitude." So wrote those often cited and in their way still unsurpassed 19th-century French critics Edmond and Jules de Goncourt about their 18th-century compatriot Jean-Baptiste-Simeon Chardin.

title: Piniella's Formula: Will and Intensity
description: At the request of Bob Quinn, the general manager, Lou Piniella excused himself and left his office to say a few words to the Cincinnati Reds' minor league players on their first morning in spring training.

title: Bottled Message
description: IN THE OLD DAYS, A MAN'S MAJOR concern with smell was that he'd better not. Legend has it that the cowboys of yore took to lilac water, hoping to cancel out the sour notes with a sweet one. But a lot has changed since then. As we nose into the 1990's, fragrance companies are wooing men with the promise not only of smelling decent, or even sexy, but of acquiring an aura that packs a whole image into a single whiff.

title:
ART;
2 Artists View the World in Statements With 3,142 Images
description: LET us take the word of Ik-Joong Kang and Bing Lee, the two artists exhibiting at the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery of the State University in Old Westbury, that their installations comprise 3,142 images. Counting them is possible, but not productive.

title: Joni Mitchell Finds the Peace of Middle Age
description: "Oh I am not old/ I'm told/But I am not young," Joni Mitchell sings in "Nothing Can Be Done," from her new album, "Night Ride Home." The song, which has lyrics by the 47-year-old singer-songwriter and music by her 34-year-old husband, Larry Klein, addresses a subject that is virtually taboo in the youth-obsessed world of pop music -- middle-age resignation.

title: Minimalists Test the Mainstream Water
description: Minimalist classics -- has it come to that?

title: Where Cossacks Crossed the Alps
description: IN the mountainous cantons of Schwyz, Uri and Glarus, in the heart of Switzerland, an unusual hiking route is linked to an astonishing historical episode. In this rugged landscape, Field Marshal Aleksandr Vasilyevich Suvorov, considered the most brilliant of all Czarist generals, carried out one of the most extraordinary feats in either the Alps or the history of warfare -- a sort of late 18th-century Dunkirk achieved without rescuers. As an American writer, J. T. Headley, put it in 1845, Hannibal's exploits were "mere child's play beside it."

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. BENNETT Z. HIRSCH;
How Much TV Should Children Watch?
description: IN October, Congress passed legislation limiting television commercials on children's programming and requiring the Federal Communications Commission to consider whether stations provide sufficient educational and informational programs for children.

title: Margaret Bergen Is Wed in London
description: Margaret Donovan Bergen, a daughter of D. Thomas Bergen of New York and Sarah L. Bergen of London, was married in London yesterday to Brendan Dermot Larkin McCann, a son of Virginia L. McCann of Dublin and the late Ambassador Hugh James McCann. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. John G. McCann, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: The World; The View From Inside A Strained Relationship
description: ON questions like trade, foreign investment, and responsibilities for world security, feelings between the United States and Japan seem to go from bad to worse. Yukio Okamoto, who resigned from the Foreign Ministry recently, spent most of his 23 years as a diplomat massaging the often-troubled Japan-United States relationship. As director of the First North American Division, he was the chief line officer for Japan's fitful response to American requests for aid in the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Okamoto is now president of Okamoto & Associates, a consulting firm that advises Japanese and American businesses on dealings in each other's countries. He was interviewed by Steven R. Weisman, chief of the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times. Following are excerpts from that interview.

title: Random House's Glitzy New Imprint
description: The weekly editorial meetings of Turtle Bay Books can veer almost anywhere. They are never dour and they are never strictly confined to the peculiarities of manuscripts. Joni Evans, the compulsively talkative editor who runs Turtle Bay, leaned forward and confessed, "What we normally talk about at these meetings is our hair. But today nothing about hair."

title: INTO THE ROSE GARDEN
description: Michael Pollan asks, "To look at a flower and think of sex -- what exactly can this mean?" Well, it meant little to me. I've been planting roses since 1963 and never felt the slightest bit kinky when one of them opened. When I work among my roses, I feel a peaceful regeneration of spirit and a sense of wonder at their great charm. I feel protective and compassionate. But sexy? Not yet. MELISSA BIGONET New City, N.Y.

title: ETHIOPIA SUSPENDS MIGRATION OF JEWS
description: The Ethiopian Government has suspended the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel because of what it said were unspecified "irregularities" by Jewish aid agencies.

title: How 'Huck Finn' Was Rescued
description: James Fraser Gluck, a Buffalo lawyer and collector, was both hero and culprit in the travels of Mark Twain's manuscript of "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn." A century ago, he was responsible for the preservation of Twain's heavily corrected text as well as the disappearance of half of it.

title: Mentors Help Women Travel From Welfare to Independence
description: JUST a few years ago, Linda Williams was living on welfare. She had four children but no job, no skills, no money, no car and little hope. When her marriage broke up, she and her children slept in one small room at her mother's house. She went back to college, earned an associate's degree and found a customer-service job at the James River Corporation in Norwalk.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BECAUSE IT IS BITTER, AND BECAUSE IT IS MY HEART, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/ Plume, $9.95.) In a New York industrial town, a beautiful, bookish high school girl is the sole witness to the slaying of a white teen-ager by a black athlete. Last year our reviewer, Marilynne Robinson, called the book "fiction of extraordinary imaginative power."

title: Campus Life: Wellesley; A Higher Profile for Older Students
description: The Continuing Education Program for older students at Wellesley College is moving out of the infirmary and into a higher-profile position on campus.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We live in a 100-year-old two-story row house. In very cold weather, when we drain the sink or bathtub or flush the toilet in our second-floor bathroom, we get a sound as if someone is tapping with a small hammer on our ceiling. The sound comes from an area where the vent stack is. Our plumber says he does not have an answer to our problem. What do you think is causing the tapping?

title: Man Is Held in Peeping Case
description: A 29-year-old man has been charged with crawling under a public toilet in a state park and watching a woman as she used the facility. The man, Gary A. Ecsedy, of Hamden, turned himself in to a park ranger, Peter McGinn, on Friday and was charged with breach of the peace. He was held in $2,500 bail. Ranger McGinn said Mr. Ecsedy climbed under the outhouse at Sleeping Giant State Park on Jan. 19.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hudson, Mass.;
Town Changes Mind on Mall
description: THE desire to use real-estate activity to help revive a faltering economy has prevailed over fears that more development will damage the environment and quality of life in this town 28 miles west of Boston and 18 miles east of Worcester.

title: Census Shows Shift to East and New Sociology
description: ON St. Johns Place in Port Washington, in the house where Myron H. Blumenfeld has lived for 25 years, the bedrooms where his daughters Riva and Eve played with dolls have become offices.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonia Baroque of San Francisco
description: Through the recordings they have made in recent years, the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra of San Francisco has been challenging the East Coast notion that the best early-instrument work in the United States takes place only in New York, Boston and Washington. Nicholas McGegan, the English conductor who has led the group since 1985, brought it to Avery Fisher Hall for an all-Mozart program last Sunday afternoon, and showed that his ensemble's sound is in most respects as trim, transparent and energetic in concert as it is on record.

title: Kathleen Wojciechowski Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Wojciechowski of Barnesville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Greene Wojciechowski to Jonathan Paul Grussing, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul G. Grussing of Downers Grove, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: Weicker Wants State to Rescue Towns and Cities
description: A Weicker administration proposal to rescue cities in financial straits would give the state wide-ranging control over municipal finances, allowing state panels to do everything from laying off workers to writing town budgets.

title: Review/Music; Mackerras Conducts St. Luke's Orchestra
description: Habitual visitors to Avery Fisher Hall have more or less gotten used to an assaultive loudness and nerve-jangling brilliance and tend to associate them with a set of walls and a collection of building materials. Last Sunday evening, however, the Orchestra of St. Luke's under Charles Mackerras reminded us that acoustics have as much to do with people as with a place.

title: Private Schools Struggle to Survive
description: PRIVATE schools across Connecticut, faced with demographic and economic changes, are adding new programs and increasing their recruiting efforts, trying to attract additional students and income. Some schools, attempting to maintain their standards in a tight market, are intentionally reducing their enrollments.

title: Yes, That's A Tunnel; Yes, That's Light
description: Happy days are almost here again. Consumers, at least if one is to believe what they tell pollsters, are now more confident about the future than at any time since early last year.

title: Ice Skating
description: To the Editor: In response to a question (Q & A, Feb. 24) from Rosemarie Baiocchi of New York, you overlooked a premier set of skating facilities near the greatest vertical-drop ski area in the Northeast. I refer to Lake Placid, N.Y. Not only does our region offer the 1980 and 1932 Olympic facilities, including an Olympic Center with four competition-size ice surfaces, but our outdoor facilities also have great variety. Mirror Lake, directly behind Main Street, has several free public skating areas and a toboggan chute. For manmade surfaces, we have the Olympic Speed Skating Oval, open from 7 to 9 P.M. daily, with extra hours, 1 to 3 P.M., on weekends. The Oval charges $2, $1 for children, and rental skates are available at shops around town. PETER C. WILSON Lake Placid, N.Y. The writer is communications director of the Lake Placid Commerce and Visitors Bureau.

title: Ideas & Trends; Saturn: An Outpost of Change in G.M.'s Steadfast Universe
description: EIGHT years ago, the General Motors Corporation boasted that its futuristic Saturn project would revolutionize the auto industry. By starting with a "clean sheet of paper," G.M. said, it would rethink everything from manufacturing and design methods to the often stormy relationship between management and labor.

title: Iraqi Hospitals in Dire Shape, Foreign Doctors Group Finds
description: An international team of doctors just returned from Iraq says the clinics and hospitals they visited were desperately short of electricity, medical supplies and water and have been forced to turn away some acutely ill patients.

title: Signs of Spring Hopeful as Yanks Find Success
description: It is too early to get excited about spring training records, if there is ever any reason at all to get excited about them. There have been too few games even to call the Yankees an improved team. That may not happen until July. It may not happen all season.

title: Dallas Wins Delay in Fight on Voting Rights
description: In the latest chapter of a long voting rights battle between the City of Dallas and racial minorities, a three-judge Federal appeals panel has granted the city's request to delay municipal elections until November, instead of holding them in May as a lower court ordered.

title: North Shore Towns Battle Over Park Land
description: ON the North Shore, where two villages sit side by side, a dispute over 14 acres of land is expected to reach the courts soon.

title: Topics of the Times; The Inner Inner Circle
description: Fees paid by businesses and interest groups to lobby New York City's government rose sharply last year. Not surprisingly, the biggest beneficiary was the law firm headed by Sid Davidoff, a close friend and tennis partner of Mayor David Dinkins's. The firm's $1.64 million in billings far outstripped other lobbyists. Mr. Davidoff's client list rose from 45 to 79 during Mr. Dinkins's first year in office.

title: A May Wedding For Ms. Klineberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Klineberg of Houston have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Katharine Douglas Klineberg, to Richard Coles Edmunds 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Edmunds of Richmond.

title: Suzanne Jackson To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Tillson Jackson of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Bartley Jackson to Joseph Thomas McDevitt Jr., a son of Mrs. Joseph Thomas McDevitt of Camp Hill, Pa., and the late Mr. McDevitt. A June wedding is planned.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sale
description: Bronxville, N.Y. 420,000 91 Ellison Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, playroom; taxes $4,063. New Rochelle, N.Y. 399,000 151 Broadview Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 70-year-old Tudor; marble fireplace, sprinkler system, landscaped; taxes $8,819. Yonkers, N.Y. 460,000 21 Howe Place 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 98-year-old Victorian; den, 2 dining rooms, new kitchen, sun room, 2-car garage w/1-bedroom apartment; taxes $4,302. Deep River, Conn. 395,000 Meadwoods Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new contemporary; 2-story living-room w/window wall, 2-car garage, 3 acres; taxes not yet available. Ridgefield, Conn. 272,000 21 Flat Rock Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old raised ranch; new roof, skylights, new furnace, 1 acre; taxes $3,419. Stamford, Conn. 160,000 40 Riverside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old town-house condominium; 1-car garage, skylight in master bedroom; common charge $124, taxes $3,103. OTHER AREAS Lake Panamoka,L.I. 108,200 55 Setauket Trail 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old log cabin; fireplace, c/a, lake rights; taxes $1,800. Medford, L.I. 120,000 121 Evergreen Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,400. Short Hills, N.J. 750,000 79 Troy Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, c/a, deck, den, 2-car garage; taxes $8,564.

title: For Brooks, It's a Whole New Ball Game
description: Things change. That's the first impression that registered this spring with Hubie Brooks, a newcomer and an old-timer with the Mets.

title: One Solution: Update 'Cinderella'
description: To the Editor:

title: RCA: Curtain Going Up Again
description: It has been more than a decade since RCA recorded its last opera, Mozart's "Magic Flute." Now RCA -- once a major player in the operatic recording field, with such stars as Leontyne Price, Jan Peerce, Robert Merrill and Rise Stevens on its roster -- is returning to the scene with ambitious plans.

title: Margaret W. Reid Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Reid of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Weatherill Reid to Matthew Penn Boyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyer of Washington, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: Design; ENVIRONMENTALLY YOURS
description: GREEN MARKETING. THE TERM CONJURES UP IMAGES OF FARMERS FROM NEW Jersey or Connecticut or the Hamptons setting up ad hoc fruit and vegetable stands in the backs of dilapidated trucks in city schoolyards at dawn. Recently, however, green marketing has taken on a whole different meaning, one in tune with the environmentally hip 1990's. Recognizing the public's desire for a cleaner world, home-furnishing retailers and manufacturers are introducing an immense selection of products -- everything from environmentally correct baby rattles and nontoxic paper clips to unbleached cotton sheets and side tables stained with blueberry juice.

title: History as Told Through Brand Names
description: WHEN Cynthia Holthusen Sanford was its director, the Jersey City Museum had a reputation for good shows that either illustrated the city's history or else exposed, selectively, the newer artists at work in the state. Mrs. Sanford herself was responsible for several of the historical productions and, with some of her colleagues, was continually making studio visits.

title: Effortless Style
description: "Style," observes Michael Lindsay-Hogg, "is something you come to for reasons other than just a liking for clothes." In the case of Jeremy Irons, says the friend who directed him in television's "Brideshead Revisited," and who writes about him in this issue, style is a second skin -- the natural expression of one's moods and idiosyncrasies. By that description, Irons is the consummate man of style, wearing a Savile Row suit with the same ease and conviction as a lightly rumpled sport coat.

title: Campus Life: North Carolina; Seniors' Spirit: Raising Big Sums For the Library
description: Seniors at the University of North Carolina have staged the largest fund-raising drive ever recorded for a student group here, pledging more than $355,000 to rejuvenate the campus library.

title: Airline Seats
description: To the Editor: A silent revolution has taken place in airline seat classification. A year or so ago, my wife and I returned to Los Angeles from Bali in business class on Garuda Air Lines. The seats were approximately 20 inches wide and there was at least 15 inches of space between my knees and the seat in front of me. Also, my seat tilted way back.

title: Search Is On for Next U.N. Secretary General
description: The job pays $183,000 a year and brings a chauffeur-driven Volvo limousine, a mansion on Sutton Place and a role in shaping a new world order.

title: Self-Help Programming?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics: It's Mutual, Not Dual
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise in Delay of Alzheimer's Drug
description: In refusing to speed the approval of a drug for Alzheimer's disease, a Federal advisory panel has dealt a stunning blow to the manufacturer and surprised analysts who thought the Government had entered a new era in its regulation of drugs for devastating and incurable diseases.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What is really scary and eerie is moving through a minefield at night knowing that if you take a step in the wrong direction you could be ending your life. Especially when you go back during the day and look at it and see the mines laying all over the place and you'd say, 'Oh my God, I walked through that.' " -- Col. Jim Fulks, commander of a Marine force that drove into Kuwait before the official start of the ground war. [ 16:5. ]

title: BRITAIN REVIEWING SYSTEM OF JUSTICE
description: The wrongful conviction of six men imprisoned more than 16 years ago for the Irish Repubican Army bombings of two pubs in Birmingham has produced the most intense criticism of the British criminal justice system in over a decade.

title: Travel Advisory; Bahamas Trims Duty on Goods
description: In a bid to encourage cruise passengers and other visitors to spend more on shopping, the Bahamian Government has reduced customs duty on many consumer items to what it calls "duty-free levels" and urged shopkeepers to reduce their markups.

title: Wis.-Platteville Wins at the Finish
description: The Wisconsin-Platteville basketball coach, Bo Ryan, says it's tough to go up against noise. But on Friday night, Shawn Frison scored with three seconds remaining to lift Wisconsin-Platteville to a 96-94 victory over Otterbein in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinals here at Wittenberg University.

title: A Siberian City Will Vote With Little Enthusiasm
description: A neat young man recently walked into the offices of the local Communist Party newspaper and took out an advertisement inviting people to join him in quitting civilization.

title:
MUSIC;
Guest Conductor Sees Orchestral Democracy
description: THE days of the conductor as dictator are gone, said Zdenek Macal, who will be a guest conductor of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in four concerts this week with the violinist Joshua Bell as soloist, a first partnership between the two.

title: THE CARETAKERS
description: Jane Bendetson's moving article said the words that I, and all "well spouses" who care for our chronically ill partners, know only too well. We share her feelings of being alone, fearful, frustrated and repressed. We are forlorn as our dreams of a shared future fade, and angry that we must bear the brunt of our ill spouses' rage at their helplessness and at their feeling cheated by life.

title: A Lose-Lose Strategy for '92
description: I confess I am worried that both political parties, may adopt a formula for victory in 1992 that would sacrifice the civil rights of minorities and women. Backing away from affirmative action -- and inviting the divisiveness that would create in our nation -- would be a hollow victory for either party.

title: Miss Roper Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sumner George Roper Jr. of Hollis, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Roper to Sheldon Frank Werdiger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manek David Werdiger of Union, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Can Razor Cut It vs. Tyson?
description: The idea, as Steve Wynn, the boss of the Mirage in Las Vegas, Nev., tells it, was very simple.

title: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions; A Vanished Circular Driveway, an Old Brochure
description: Where's the Driveway?

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Binghamton; Nude Photographs Prompt Debate Over Free Speech
description: A senior at the State University of New York at Binghamton has invoked his First Amendment rights in the face of the administration's charge that displaying centerfold photographs from Penthouse magazine on his dormitory door was lewd and indecent behavior.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Bowling No Gutter Ball This Time: Del Ballard Jr., who lost a tournament with a gutter ball two weeks ago, defeated Jim Johnson Jr., 223-183, in the title match of the $130,000 Professional Bowlers Association's Long Island Open yesterday in Sayville. (AP) Tennis

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Luminous, Subtle Tales Fairy tales are rich repositories of the myths and symbols of ancient faiths, P. L. Travers argues, using the story of Sleeping Beauty as her example. This is from "What the Bee Knows: Reflections on Myth, Symbol and Story" (Aquarian Press/Sterling Publishing Company, paper).

title: Putting a Trailblazer Back in the Spotlight
description: HISTORY is not always at home in an art gallery. But at the Johnson & Johnson World Headquarters Art Gallery this month, the life and times of Paul Robeson are set forth in an unusual exhibition that opens a window onto the artist's life and his moment in this nation's history.

title: THE CARETAKERS
description: Thank you for printing Jane Bendetson's sad description of the deterioration of a life by disease (Hers: "The Caretakers," Feb. 10). Her story is all the more poignant because of the many stories it represents. We "well spouses" are forced to watch a spouse suffer, change and ultimately succumb to one of the hundreds of different chronic illnesses.

title: How Godzilla Overcame Despair
description: GOJIRO By Mark Jacobson. 356 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.95.

title: Talking: Conservation; Swapping Land for Tax Deals
description: THE news that conservation groups, such as land trusts, are eagerly embracing the downturn in the real estate market as an opportunity to acquire more land comes as welcome news to landowners.

title: Q and A
description: Reverse Mortgages Question: I have been trying to get information on the so-called reverse mortgage. From what little I know, it has advantages particularly for older people, who have close to total equity in their homes. My bank does not offer it, nor do others I have called. Is it available to co-op owners? . . . C. W. Farriss, Manhattan Answer: No. Only the owners of homes and condominiums with deeds qualify for reverse mortgages, according to Ken Scholen, director of the nonprofit National Center for Home Equity Conversion in Marshall, Minn. Co-op owners hold shares of stock, not deeds. A reverse mortgage offers a lump sum, installment income or line of credit to the homeowner, while the lender acquires a debt obligation secured by the property.

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS COUNTRY MUSICIANS
description: Seven members of the country-western singer Reba McEntire's band, along with her road manager and two pilots, were killed early today when their private plane crashed in a mountain area near the Mexican border.

title: In Praise of Springtime and Landscape Design
description: THE Westchester Beautification Committee has chosen the first day of spring for its seventh yearly conference, at which it will present its 1990 awards for excellence in landscaping.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GREENWICH HOSPITAL;
Headache Sufferers Find Relief In Their Special Restful Refuge
description: EVEN for Greenwich Hospital, which enjoys a reputation for luxury, the area known as Four East is exceptionally attractive. Decorated in soft shades of mauve and gray, the unit boasts plush carpeting, attractive artwork, soft lighting and communal sitting and dining areas that resemble those in a hotel. The patients' rooms are furnished with comfortable chairs and daybeds. And, at the end of the hall, a peaceful sunlit alcove has a rocking chair and green plants.

title: The Region; How the Strike at The News Took on a Life of Its Own
description: LEADERS of striking Daily News unions agreed last week to give painful concessions to Robert Maxwell, the British press baron, but were prepared to let the paper die rather than come to terms with the Chicago-based Tribune Company, which had founded The News 72 years ago.

title: Paying Athletes: Cynical Remedy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dispute Over Figures Persists
description: VIRTUALLY no Long Island official will say that the final Census figures are correct. From the Village of Hempstead, where a 22.4 percent increase was among the highest of any in the region, to the Village of East Hampton, where a 25.7 percent loss led all others, officials argued that the figures were too low.

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional; Again, Penders vs. Carnesecca
description: Their rivalry, if a 10-0 advantage can be called that, was once conducted in gymnasiums in Queens and in a small, leafy corner of the Bronx, and occasionally under the bright lights of Madison Square Garden.

title: Dialing for Space in the National Parks
description: IT'S hard to reconcile the idea of planning a camping trip to a national park with calling an 800 phone number to reach a Ticketron office in Chicago. But that is how camping reservations for the 14 busiest parks in the Federal system are now being made. The 800 toll-free number was instituted last month, replacing last year's 900 super-toll number that evoked complaints because 900 numbers are not accessible from all phones.

title: Sensitive Adolescent Among the Village Louts
description: THIEF OF DREAMS By John Yount. 227 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: A May Marriage For Naomi Spitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Spitz of Cranford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Naomi Susan Spitz, to Mark Stanley Jennings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Jennings of Binghamton, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Ossining
description: To the Editor:

title: Daily News Becomes the Fief Of an Often Imperious Master
description: The new owner of The Daily News took a moment out of a hectic, fax-filled hour last week to reflect on his overall management style and business philosophy. "When I pass a belt," Robert Maxwell explained in his sepulchral baritone, "I cannot resist hitting below it."

title: The Executive Computer; In the Latest Type Technology, an Echo of Gutenberg
description: The lost technology of Johann Gutenberg, a process that made his Bible an enduring work of typographical art, has been recaptured in a new technology made possible by the personal computer and Adobe Inc. of Mountain View, Calif.

title: The Real Yoknapatawpha
description: Some citizens of Oxford, Miss., called the young William Faulkner "Count No 'Count"; they figured a high school dropout with aristocratic airs would never amount to much. Even after he won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1949, many Mississippians viewed their state's most famous writer with skepticism, banning his books from school libraries and calling him, as one student did, "an old drunk." So why did he love the place so much? His fellow Mississippian Willie Morris, a novelist and former editor of Harper's Magazine, and the photographer William Eggleston answer the question, each in his own way, in FAULKNER'S MISSISSIPPI (Oxmoor House, $50). For Mr. Morris, who grew up near Oxford, that means exploring not only Faulkner's life and geography but also the colors and gossip of his own childhood. For Mr. Eggleston it means framing fragments of Faulkner's cherished landscape in a bright, crisp noonday light that makes them appear, to a reader of Faulkner, both uncannily familiar and wonderfully strange.

title: Ms. Williamson To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Claude Williamson of Wayland, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter M. Jane Williamson to Stephen Winthrop, a son of Mrs. Nathaniel T. Winthrop of New York and the late Mr. Winthrop. A July wedding is planned.

title:
Focus: Big Crowd in Boston;
Convention Centers as a Selling Field
description: THE success of a two-day sale of bank-owned property that drew 30,000 people to the Hynes Convention Center here has encouraged promoters to try to use similar settings for giant real-estate sales elsewhere.

title: After Rochester Ice Storm, a Scarred Countryside
description: Everywhere, the trees are broken. From the majestic 120-foot red oak off the ninth tee at the Oak Hill Country Club, home to three United State Opens, to the skinniest sapling in a downtown backyard, the ice storm of March 3 coated tens of thousands of trees with devastating weight.

title: Getting Into the Act, Poetically
description: THE Heckscher Museum in Huntington calls its series of evening poetry readings "Live! On Stage: The New Poetry."

title: Higher Job Loss Forecast in New York Region
description: Two new economic forecasts predict that the New York metropolitan region, already faltering, will lose tens of thousands of jobs this year, but disagree over the extent of the losses and the timing of a revival.

title: Nancy S. Lewis To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Nancy Sime Lewis to Dr. Christopher Michael Whelan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Whelan of Bedford, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Lewis Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Stieglitz-O'Keeffe; Lake George Condos
description: Almost anyone would be daunted by the prospect of owning the enormous home on Lake George, about 50 miles north of Albany, where the photographer Alfred Stieglitz and the artist Georgia O'Keeffe once spent their summers. So the plan is to divide the house into five individual condominium units, with each unit divided again into four shares, meaning that one could buy 1/20th of the house.

title:
ART;
Divine Images Span Four Centuries
description: "IMAGES OF THE DIVINE" at the Thomas J. Walsh Art Gallery at Fairfield University is of the caliber of a small museum show. It is a quick survey of Christian art across four centuries, paintings from the collection of the Rojtman Foundation supplemented by etchings and engravings from Associated American Artists, both in Manhattan. Many of the works are first rate, and even a series of 12 melodramatic paintings on the theme of Christ's Passion at the heart of the show is valuable, if only because it allows the rest of the offerings to shine in contrast.

title: Children's Books/Biography
description: MOZART Scenes From the Childhood of the Great Composer. Written and illustrated by Catherine Brighton. Unpaged. New York: Doubleday. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) WOLFGANG AMADEUS MOZART By Wendy Thompson. Illustrated. 48 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Headliners; Party Animus
description: Sometimes heartfelt beliefs force a politician to rise above petty party loyalty. For Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, the operable belief was that he stood a better chance of being re-elected this fall as a Republican than as a Democrat, so he announced last week that he was switching. The move was seen not only as a way to quash challenges from several prominent Republicans who appeared ready to run against him, but also as a way of boxing out State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader with a following of voters who share his white supremacist views. Mr. Duke campaigns as a Republican, though embarrassed local and national party leaders have disavowed him, and keeping Mr. Duke out of the Governor's mansion might well earn Mr. Roemer their gratitude. For their part, Louisiana Democrats said they wouldn't miss the Governor. "He may be proud of this independence," said a state party leader, "but the fact is he has only one political party and that is Buddy Roemer."

title: Counselors Help Children Survive Divorce
description: FRANCES M. ROCK, a psychotherapist who specializes in working with women and children, has decorated her office at the Darien Y.W.C.A. with children's artwork. A collage of magazine pictures, in which every man has been sliced out, was created by an adolescent girl. In a family portrait sketched by a 12-year-old, each member of the family is notably separated from everyone else. A 7-year-old drew his father with four heads, and another boy, whose father left when the child was 2 years old, depicted the man he never knew as an open-mouthed shark.

title: How Innocent Were They?
description: SACCO AND VANZETTI The Anarchist Background. By Paul Avrich. Illustrated. 265 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: Campus Life: William and Mary; Student Accuses Veteran Professor Of Racist Remarks
description: Questions of racism and academic freedom have been raised by a departmental inquiry into complaints that a sociology professor makes disparaging remarks about minorities in class and grades minority-group members and women more harshly than white males.

title: Opening Doors to Old Columbia
description: "THE NORTH devastated the center of Columbia twice," announced my English friend, now a resident of South Carolina's capital. "First in 1865, when General Sherman burned 84 blocks in a single night, then a century later when those twin Northern inventions -- shopping malls and suburbs -- emptied the downtown core." Of course, he exaggerates. Some Civil War historians believe that fleeing Confederate soldiers did at least some of the damage themselves, by igniting cotton bales rather than leave them to the Yankees. And Northern business interests could not have masterminded the Columbians' flight from the city without their compliance.

title: Learning From the Religions of Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Grappling With Modern China
description: Three quarters of a century ago, the novel "Family" by Ba Jin, a devastating portrait of feudal culture in 20th-century China, disturbed and inspired a generation of young Chinese to seek and promote change. The novel set a tone for much of the influential art of China for the rest of the century.

title:
DINING OUT;
In New Rochelle, Extensive Indian Fare
description: CHOOSING at random, diners will fare handsomely at any Indian restaurant in the county. All offer a similar core of long-popular dishes and each has rounded out its menu with a few unusual items worth investigating. With its regular menu listing more than 100 offerings and a recently introduced seafood menu listing another 70, Abhilash promises a particularly rich culinary adventure.

title: Mexico's Village Of Guitar Makers
description: FOR more than 450 years, ever since the Spanish conquistadors arrived in west-central Mexico, guitars have been a way of life in the town of Paracho, high in the Sierra Nevada in the state of Michoacan. It was a priest accompanying the original conquerors, Vasco de Quiroga, who decided that each Indian village should be taught a craft that would enable its residents to support themselves as they were incorporated into the Spanish colonial system. And just as it fell to Santa Clara to become a copper-making site and Uruapan to turn out lacquerware, Paracho soon gained fame as Mexico's principal center for the manufacture of stringed instruments.

title: Author Follows Her Mother's Footsteps
description: IT is not only sons who follow in their fathers' footsteps. Daughters and mothers do so, too, and often with much success.

title: The Baby Bell Conundrum
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Indians Formed the First American Rainbow Coalition
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Co-What?
description: An attempt to storm the gender barriers of the Citadel was beaten back by the school's allies in the South Carolina State Legislature last week. State Representative Sarah Manly said that she decided to push a measure that would force the admission of women to the Citadel, the Charleston military school that is one of the nation's last two state-supported, single-sex four-year colleges, when an American woman became a prisoner of war in the gulf. After a committee tabled the measure by a 6-to-5 vote, Mrs. Manly said she had been thwarted by "the good-old-boy network," and promised to re-introduce the measure next year. One of her supporters, Melanie Smith Lutz, a United States Military Academy graduate who had once dreamed of attending the Citadel, said she was "flabbergasted" by the death of Mrs. Manly's bill. "I never ran into attitudes such as this at West Point," said Mrs. Lutz, whose father and grandfather graduated from the Citadel. "I think we are seeing a backward step."

title: The World; More Precious Than Oil, and Maybe as Volatile
description: AS the Persian Gulf war exploded over issues of oil and honor and expansionism, another, more modest event occurred here: the rains came, fickle but abundant, greening pale deserts and offering a reminder that, in many parts of the Middle East, water is far more rare and precious than oil and could, one day, breed conflict of its own.

title: The Irish Victims of British Justice
description: Two years ago, a British Court of Appeals freed three men and a woman who had been wrongly jailed in 1975 for Irish Republican Army bombings in Guildford and Woolwich. Now a British Court of Appeals has freed, on the eve of St. Patrick's weekend, six men who had been wrongly convicted the very same year for an I.R.A. bombing of two Birmingham pubs, in which 21 people were killed and 160 injured.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Handel: 'La Resurrezione' Lisa Saffer and Judith Nelson, sopranos; Patricia Spence, mezzo-soprano; Jeffrey Thomas, tenor; Michael George, bass-baritone; Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra conducted by Nicholas McGegan. Harmonia Mundi 907027/8; two CD's and cassettes.

title: Man Indicted in Boy's Death
description: A man has been indicted on charges of drowning his fiancee's 3-year-old son in a bathtub. A Broome County grand jury Friday indicted Donald Kenyon, Jr., 23, on murder and manslaughter charges. Mr. Kenyon is accused of putting Mathew Ayers into a bathtub at his fiancee's home near Binghamton to discipline the boy on Jan. 30. Mr. Kenyon had beaten the boy earlier, the police said. The boy's mother, Terri Ayers, 20, married Mr. Kenyon two weeks after her son's death. Ms. Ayers said she and Mr. Kenyon "love each other very much. I don't see where Don did nothing wrong."

title: When Comedy Declares War, What's the Punch Line?
description: In time of war, humor has proven to be a unique survival tool, and the Persian Gulf crisis, being no exception, provided America's all-volunteer comedians with an opportunity to fulfill our need to laugh.

title: Julie Iverson to Wed Joshua Minkler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Iverson of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie Anne Iverson to Joshua James Minkler, a son of Thomas Minkler and Annette Johnson, both of Muncie, Ind. A May wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about women in television news misidentifies the program for which Maria Shriver is the anchor. It is "Cutting Edge With Maria Shriver."

title: Close Contest in Bridge Final
description: The final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, ending a full week of play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, began here this afternoon between teams headed by Zia Mahmood of Manhattan and Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va.

title:
Your Own Account;
Tales From the Franchise Front
description: What Stephen Finch remembers best about his last few years in the corporate world is that the company he was working for was sold three times. "I got to know that when the guys in the trench coats came to tour the company, we were in trouble," he said.

title: A Fall Wedding For Ms. Abrams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Abrams of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori-Ann Abrams, to Jonas Evan Herbsman, a son of Dr. Horace Herbsman of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Brenda Herbsman. An October wedding is planned.

title: Figure Skating; Skating Sweep for the U.S. Women
description: For the first time in the 73 years that women have competed in a singles event at the world figure-skating championships, three from the same country swept the medals, as Kristi Yamaguchi, Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan of the United States placed first, second and third today.

title: Can Atex Keep Its Proprietary Place in the Newsroom?
description: Once the world's premier manufacturer of computerized editorial and advertising production systems for newspapers and magazines, Atex Inc. is finding itself under increasing pressure as more nimble competitors capitalize on new technology to pass the company by.

title: A Wrong Technology At a Wrong Site
description: It is unbelievable to me that our County Administration has spent $1.8 million to study a long-term land-based sludge-management system, required under the terms of a 1989 consent decree, only to come up with a plan that selects the wrong technology at the wrong site at the wrong time [ "County to Reasses a Plan to Burn Its Sludge," March 3 ] .

title: Sunday Outing; On L.I., a Place to See Man and Nature in Sync
description: Here on the South Shore of Long Island, civilization ends and 52 acres of a most civilized wilderness begin. This is the Town of Hempstead Marine Nature Study Area, a place for watching shore birds and waterfowl from the seven boardwalk trails, or fish schools in shallow creeks.

title: 'Williams and Walker,' Cakewalk and Slapstick
description: WHILE Walker strutted, Williams shuffled. In tandem, the black vaudeville team traded on self-mockery in the early 1900's. And they were very popular with whites.

title: Social Events
description: Chaikin On Stage

title: Drive, She Said
description: TAKING THE WHEEL Women and the Coming of the Motor Age. By Virginia Scharff. Illustrated. 219 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.95.

title: A La Carte: An Island First
description: WHEN Ikea, the home-furnishings store, opens on Wednesday in Hicksville, Long Island's first Swedish restaurant will open, too.

title: Heidi S. Kirkland To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. David S. Kirkland of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Heidi Stoddard Kirkland and William Ward Carey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carey of Palm Beach.

title: Handicapped, but Not at What They Do
description: WHEN I.B.M. hired Michael A. Babboni, a young computer systems analyst, for a summer job in 1988, he came to work in a wheelchair. Mr. Babboni is one of thousands of disabled employees at International Business Machines, and their number is growing.

title: Slovakia's Separatist Premier Facing Political Counterattack
description: The Government leader who has charted an increasingly separatist course for Slovakia is coming under heavy attack, after pro-independence protests on Thursday in which angry demonstrators roughed up the popular Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel.

title: Commercial Property: Office Leasing; A Big Drop in 1990 In Mid-Manhattan's Level of Activity
description: HAVING kept at a relatively steady level since 1987, the volume of office leasing in mid-Manhattan dropped dramatically last year, to a total of 15.9 million square feet, from 18.3 million the year before.

title: Anne Maniatty to Wed G. R. Walker 2d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Connie S. Maniatty of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Elizabeth Maniatty to George Richmond Walker 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Walker of Essex, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Jeffrey Osborne: 'Only Human' Arista ARCD-8620; all three formats.

title: Beauty; Manual Labor
description: Laurence White is talking about the care And feeding of the objects that have been his livelihood for the past 15 years; actually, he's talking about his hands.

title: Sideshow to Soviet Votes: Gorbachev vs. Yeltsin
description: Soviet voters will take on the cacophonous political disarray of their country Sunday as they cast ballots on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's referendum on the nation's future.

title: Review/Dance; Unaccompanied Work Is Part of Showcase
description: No one sang in "A Song." There was no accompaniment whatsoever for this work choreographed by Neta Pulvermacher, which was offered last Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y as part of Sundays at Three, a choreographic showcase series sponsored by the Y's Dance Center.

title: Queens Man Stabbed Dead By 2 Posing as Moving Men
description: A 61-year-old Flushing man was stabbed to death by a man pretending to be a mover on Friday evening as the victim's wife was held in a separate room of the couple's apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Police Fight Protesters in Togo for Second Day
description: The police fought anti-Government protesters in the capital of the West African nation of Togo today for the second successive day. A boy died as a result of the violence, and dozens of people were injured, witnesses and first-aid workers said.

title: Children's Books/Biography: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Review/Music; Guarneri String Quartet
description: The Guarneri String Quartet's most interesting playing at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night came with a little catalytic nudge. Left to themselves, the quartet's players displayed a level of ensemble work that was casual to the point to the point of carelessness.

title: Campus Life: Dayton; Art Students Meet, and Draw, Homeless People
description: Three University of Dayton art students timidly approached a man in a shelter for the homeless in downtown Dayton last week, introduced themselves and chatted for a bit. Then conversation ended and illustration began, as the students pulled out sketchbooks and charcoal pencils and began drawing the likeness of the man, Joe McNeal, who comes to the shelter every morning.

title: The Region; Redrawing the Lines That Define Politics
description: AFTER the 1990 Census, lawmakers and their legislative map makers in Albany, Trenton and Hartford have begun readjusting congressional, state and local legislative district lines so they conform to the growth and shifts in population. In part, the process is a politics-as-usual effort aimed at keeping as many incumbents in office as possible regardless of how the population has changed. Yet beyond those parochial interests, redistricting can affect everything in government including the awarding of governmental contracts, the power to override a governor's veto and minority representation.

title: Looking Ahead
description: SUNDAY: Soviet referendum on political and economic unity. MONDAY: Trial in Salt Lake City on former USX employees' claims to millions in pension benefits.

title: Sports Join Bridgeport and Suburbs
description: THE tensions between Bridgeport and its neighbors have entered the world of high school athletics. The principals of the 14 suburban schools in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference recently voted unanimously to grant three Bridgeport schools a three-year trial membership in the league. But some of the suburban coaches and athletic directors said they are worried about sending their teams into Bridgeport to play, adding that the new members might endanger the high status of the 30-year-old conference.

title: Ossining
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Diary/March 10-15
description: COMPANIES British Airways Whines About Its New Competition British Airways P.L.C. wants sympathy. Even after winning permission last week to fly between the United States and the Continent and penetrate the American market in a host of other ways -- rights no other foreign airline has had -- the British carrier is sounding defeated and distraught. It seems British Airways will have to accept some competition from United, American and Virgin Atlantic at Heathrow Airport, London's most convenient. The day before creditors were to seize Pan Am's planes, Pan Am and T.W.A. won British approval to sell their Heathrow routes to United and American. "U.S. negotiators have succeeded in weakening British Airways," a spokesman for the airline intoned, as the company's chairman spoke of reduced profitability. Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, shed few tears. "They're yelping so much it's suspicious," he said. British Airways already plans to invade the Continent by buying a large piece of Sabena World Airlines and forming a new carrier in Germany. The British deal hardly gives America's feeble old international carriers the strength to rise from their wheelchairs. Pan American World Airways, the sickliest case, is earning only enough from its route sale to perhaps survive until someone buys its remaining assets. And Trans World Airlines said the Transportation Department's ban on the sale of three of its six London routes to American, in the interests of competition, imperils its financial health. Maxwell's Plum, or Prune? "Maxwell's Plum," said a Daily News headline Wednesday morning. "Miracle Max!" and "Daily News Lives!" followed that afternoon. Now Robert Maxwell needs to live up to his headlines. The plum he agreed to buy after settling with the unions last Tuesday has shriveled to perhaps half its former circulation of a million-plus, and even less of its former advertising. His purchase of The News -- the Tribune Company is actually paying him $60 million or more to take on the newspaper's liabilities -- is based on agreements by the striking unions to accept sharp staffing cuts. Mr. Maxwell, a British publisher, promised to invest what the News called "mega-money" -- not to mention the mega-time he might need in his trans-Atlantic schedule to lure scores of advertisers, several hundred thousand readers and Jimmy Breslin back to his pages. Exxon, and Taxpayers, Pay Up For a company that earns as much as Exxon, $1.1 billion actually isn't real money. No sooner had the Exxon Corporation agreed to pay such a settlement to Alaska and the Federal Government in the Exxon Valdez oil spill than Lawrence G. Rawl, the company's chairman, said there would be virtually no effect on the company's earnings or image. The company also pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors. Exxon's ability to write off the whole settlement save a $100 million criminal penalty will cost taxpayers an estimated $300 million. A Purge at Chrysler Tough times provided the Chrysler Corporation with the perfect occasion to kick a union leader off its board. Cost-saving, Chrysler called it, adding that four of the other 18 members were leaving as well. In fact, it's the loss of labor's voice, responded Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, a dissident on the board and the only departing member who is not in at least his late 60's. Labor representation, unusual on American boards, hardly seems to have hurt corporate competitiveness in countries like Germany. But by reversing itself on the issue, Chrysler has carried out Detroit's most celebrated boardroom purge since H. Ross Perot left General Motors. McDonald's New Burger No, McDonald's will not draw in the bean sprouts and oat bran crowd with its new, reduced-fat burger. At best, analysts say, the health-conscious might stop sneering so loudly that they embarrass those for whom dieting means ordering the burger and fries without the shake. Diners who do try the "McLean" are likely to be disappointed, said Caroline Levy of Shearson Lehman. "This doesn't even taste like a burger, based on what I've heard," she said. Like the company's recent abandonment of styrofoam containers to placate environmentalists, Ms. Levy said, "It's good for McDonald's image, but I do not see it as good for the bottom line." In Brief American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, reduced its lowest fares -- reviving the 30-day advanced-purchase ticket -- to encourage travelers frightened off by the Persian Gulf war or the recession. But some other fares are rising. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the competitive practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the dominant maker of personal computer software. Microsoft calls the probe minor and limited, its competitors call it broad-ranging, and the F.T.C. is keeping quiet. The House reluctantly poured another $30 billion into the savings and loan bailout last week. THE ECONOMY

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We live in a 100-year-old two-story row house. In very cold weather, when we drain the sink or bathtub or flush the toilet in our second-floor bathroom, we get a sound as if someone is tapping with a small hammer on our ceiling. The sound comes from an area where the vent stack is. Our plumber says he does not have an answer to our problem. What do you think is causing the tapping?

title: Time to Curb the Weapon Makers
description: One of Saddam Hussein's most impressive "achievements" in the period leading up to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was his ability to use financing and advanced technology from the United States and other countries to build up his arsenal. Our policymakers have much to answer for on this front.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 17, 1991
