The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: The Trade Boulez Has Yet to Master
description: Perhaps we expect too much of our famous contemporary composers. It is difficult enough for a Pierre Boulez, say, to maintain his hard-won place as a musical prophet and provocateur in a time when so many avant-gardist reputations seem to rest on sand. To ask that he also produce a body of timeless works may be unrealistic, if not unfeeling. The mere fact that a mature composer has yet to deliver himself of any piece that has passed beyond the tight circle of those who regard listening to music as a monkish discipline should not be allowed to dim his luster as an international celebrity.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BROKEN HEARTLAND The Rise of America's Rural Ghetto. By Osha Gray Davidson. Free Press, $22.95.

title: One Man's Sexual Nightmare
description: CHICAGO LOOP By Paul Theroux. 196 pp. New York: Random House. $20.

title: Guns Take Ever-Higher Toll Among Young Blacks
description: A new Government study has found that nearly half of black male Americans from 15 to 19 years old who died in 1988 were killed by guns.

title: 'Small but Very Liveable' Landmark Is Restored in New London
description: THE Winslow Ames House at Connecticut College in New London was designed in the early 1930's as an efficient structure for modern living. Part of it was prefabricated; it had a built-in radio and asbestos-packed wall panels. Advertisements called it resistant to earthquakes, lightning and vermin.

title: Groups Help Each Other Help the Mentally Ill
description: Last year Robert McDonald, a 44-year-old former systems analyst from Kansas, was in a downward spiral. Suffering from severe depression, he lost his job and his house and was living on the streets in Los Angeles.

title: Eileen O'Hern and William Luby Wed
description: Eileen Marie O'Hern, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Daniel Joseph O'Hern of Red Bank, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Kent Luby, the son of Carol Pope Luby of Warwick, R.I., and the late Frank W. Luby Jr. The Rev. Matthew R. D. Regan performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church.

title: Housing Group Wins Aid of Federal Officials
description: A civic group that cut through barriers, largely bureaucratic, to build 5,000 affordable homes in New York City has attracted the attention of Federal housing officials, who will help finance an expansion of the group's work.

title: Policy Monotheism
description: Americans transform every success and every failure in foreign affairs into a policy doctrine and a political cudgel. We refuse to rest until we possess one lens through which to view the world and one answer for all challenges. We are forever brushing off small but important lessons in the quest for great and single truths.

title: Travel Industry Starts to Rebound From War
description: Unlike some weekends in the recent past, this weekend all the rooms at the Waldorf-Astoria are booked solid.

title: On the Wayward Trail With R.E.M.
description: For any musician who would admit it, punk-rock left popular music with a lingering case of self-consciousness. Punk exposed the musical formulas and marketing mechanisms that even the most sincere individualists were bound to face, and it ushered in a decade of rebellion, denial, irony and overt manipulation. For a band like R.E.M., which became a leader of the white, collegiate, guitar-driven wing of post-punk-rock, that self-consciousness presented a maze of choices.

title: Reflections on Himself
description: Albert Brooks is, to invoke the title of one of his films, lost in America. Actually it's the San Fernando Valley -- Glendale, Brooks guesses. Night is falling and all the streets look remarkably alike, mini-malls everywhere, and Brooks, craning his neck for landmarks from behind the wheel of his Mercedes, is pretending to be embarrassed. "I think we're, like, a foot from where we're going, but I don't know where I am, I really don't," he says, in his trademark half-whine. "Where are we? Lumber City? Oh my God. Now I'm going to have to ask where Burbank is, and you'll have it on tape."

title: Princeton Debates Deer Hunting
description: IT happened before he had a chance to stop. Something dashed across Nassau Street in a blur of movement, and there was a sickening thud.

title: Pro Hockey; Devils Rise as Rangers Fall
description: Fortunes have suddenly reversed for the Rangers and the Devils in the last week. The teams appear to be headed in different directions with two weeks left in the regular season.

title: Karen Shapiro to Wed Dr. Michael Goldaber
description: The engagement of Karen Barbara Shapiro to Dr. Michael Lawrence Goldaber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Goldaber of Valley Stream, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert L. Shapiro of South Dartmouth, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Spring Blooms With Bright Coats
description: There was a time, a mere generation or so ago, when spring meant a new go-to-meeting blue coat and a straw hat trimmed with flowers. Then came the era of dressing down, when the closest thing most women had to a spring coat was an all-purpose poplin raincoat, worn with a scarf tied around the head in bad weather.

title: 'Puritani': Not So Silly After All
description: "I Puritani" doesn't have the most savory reputation. The opera isn't unloved; it contains too much high-quality music for that. But it is patronized -- treated like Bellini's idiot-child opera, lovely but dumb.

title: Keeping the Basement Free of Pesky Leaks
description: EARLY spring, with its wet weather and thawing temperatures, is the season for basement leaks. The surest cure for chronic leaks generally involves installing drains around the foundation, a task for professional basement waterproofers, but simpler methods sometimes work.

title:
DINING OUT;
Some Unusual Choices in Italian Fare
description: AFTER Domenico's burned down about a year ago, the owner of the Italian restaurant next to the Porsche-Audi dealer on Route 46 West decided to rebuild on the same spot. The restaurant, which opened five months ago, was renamed Villa Domenico by the owner, Domenico Parotta, who is originally from Calabria, Italy.

title: A Stamp for McGruff, Not the Bill of Rights
description: More power to the fifth-grade Stamp Action Committee members at Eastchester's Greenvale Elementary School [ "Eastchester Pupils Campaign for a Stamp," Feb. 24 ] . May success crown their efforts to see Eastchester's special connection with the Bill of Rights commemorated on a United States postage stamp. The Postal Service's Citizens Advisory Committee (Washington, D.C. 20260), which can find inspiration in such subjects as Horse Racing (No. 1528), the American Bankers Association (No. 987), Savings and Loans (No. 1911), and even McGruff, the "Take a Bite Out of Crime" dog (No. 2102), can surely find a place on its forthcoming commemorative stamp schedule for a little extra homage to the Bill of Rights. Children, keep up the pressure! LINCOLN DIAMANT Ossining, N.Y. CHARLES DAVIDSON Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The writers are co-authors of "Stamping Our History: The Story of the United States Portrayed on Its Postage Stamps."

title: The Spirit World Prevails in Katonah
description: PAINTINGS. Sculptures in wood, metal and concrete. A crowd of masks. A sprinkling of assemblages and painted gourd vessels. Folk art takes over the Katonah Museum of Art as the Mardi Gras does New Orleans.

title: Sunday Menu; A Broccoli Dish in Search of a New Pasta
description: Orecchiette, the hot new pasta shape that is new only in this country, is suggested for this dish. The pasta is shaped like little ears; hence the name. Should you not want to go to the trouble of seeking it out -- try Italian markets -- small shells will do very nicely, as will the pasta shape called gnocchi.

title: Nancy O. Frankel To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Frankel of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Olivia Frankel, to Henry C. Joselson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Joselson of Rye, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MY BODY By David Guy. Dutton, $19.95.

title: Review/Dance; Symbolism by Power Boothe
description: Power Boothe's new performance piece, "Once and Once," is subtitled "One Woman's Miraculous Attempt to Escape the Tumultuous Sea of Symbols." And indeed it does seem as if Keely Garfield, the choreographer and performer of the piece, is drowning in symbolic characters and slyly extravagant costumes and props, as well as special effects of lighting and film.

title: Tech Notes; Muffling the Thunder in the Sky
description: By the year 2000, according to Federal Aviation Administration rules, the nation's noisiest commercial jets must be phased out of the fleet. The trouble is, these aircraft -- built in the 1960's and 1970's -- include almost all of the Boeing 727's, which are among the most economical planes for carrying passengers and freight. To bring these planes into compliance, the engines must be replaced -- which is expensive -- or modified.

title: Highway-Sound Fences Or Graffiti Targets?
description: When we first spotted the long wooden stretches of berms being placed along either side of the Long Island Expressway in the fall, it seemed as though some cruel joke was being played on us.

title: Review/Dance; A Driver Company Farewell
description: Senta Driver's newest dance pieces are ostensibly her last. Harry, the company that Miss Driver, one of modern dance's least conventional choreographers, formed 16 years ago, is disbanding.

title: Shandling Vs. Seinfeld
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Caribbean Islands Quicken Pace Toward Union
description: Inspired by moves toward integration among the world's industrialized countries, four eastern Caribbean islands have accelerated efforts at total political and economic union.

title: Bill Jensen: Roughing It on 57th Street
description: The display of Bill Jensen's 14 new paintings at the Washburn Gallery on 57th Street in Manhattan is engaging yet baffling. It is filled with canvases that, one way or another, the viewer wants to take issue with. The show starts out like a stimulating argument about the ways and means of painting, but in the end too many of the individual canvases lack coherence.

title: They Made Their Beds
description: EMINENT GARDENERS Some People of Influence and Their Gardens 1880-1980. By Jane Brown. Illustrated. 183 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95

title: Florida
description: To the Editor: While it is correct that coral may not be collected at Looe Key ("Coral and Clear Water at Looe Key," Travel, Dec. 2), it is implied that it is O.K. to collect it elsewhere. The taking of (even the touching of or standing on) coral is illegal anywhere in the United States, not just in a Federal marine sanctuary.

title: Rocks and Other Items In Guidebooks
description: The article, "More Tiffany Treasures Found on L.I." [ Feb. 24 ] about the authors of a tourist guide to Long Island, contains some questionable quotations from these authors, who are described as being involved in history and research.

title: Humorists Who Put the Punch Line on Paper
description: YOU have borrowed a car and you hop in to drive it. Immediately, an alarm goes off, but you don't know how to stop it. You try turning the ignition key -- the siren gets louder. Now it shifts into a high shriek, it declares a national emergency. Thief! it shouts, as you sit sweating. Desperate, you push a button on the key ring and there is silence.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Must punctuality be the thief of time? Tips for those with petty larcenists as friends.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mill Basin
description: AT about the same time that he discovered the island that bears his name, the Dutch navigator Adrian Block mapped the islands and inlets of what is today the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn.

title: Travel Advisory; Airline Oscars
description: "Driving Miss Daisy" was the No. 1 movie on the airlines in 1990, according to the World Airline Entertainment Association. The film, Which won the Academy Award for best picture last year, was shown by more airlines than any other, the main factor used to determine the list. The other top movies, in order, were: "Turner and Hooch," "The Hunt for Red October," "Pretty Woman," "Bird on a Wire," "Steel Magnolias," "Back to the Future, Part II," "Stanley & Iris," "She-Devil" and "The Freshman."

title: Mutual Funds; Why Index Funds Are Not All Alike
description: Investors who buy a fund that tracks the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index may expect the fund's return to approximate the index's. But that's not necessarily the case. In one 1990 quarter, one of the 13 S.&P.-based funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services strayed from the index by more than 5 percentage points.

title: Travel Advisory; Pearl Harbor Marks 50 Years
description: Plans are going ahead in Hawaii for ceremonies to mark the 50th anniversary this year of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. The National Association of Pearl Harbor Survivors will stage a parade Dec. 6 in Honolulu. The next day, President Bush has been invited to address survivors at the Arizona Memorial, where about 1,100 Navy men and members of the Marine Corps who died in the 1941 attack on the ship are entombed.

title: Bonaire
description: To the Editor: As a diver, underwater photographer and frequent visitor to Bonaire, I took great interest in David E. Pitt's article (Travel, Dec. 30). Mr. Pitt is accurate in his description of Bonaire, but he perpetuates a misconception that applies not only to Bonaire but also to any area where divers interact with marine fauna. Feeding the fish, while an exhilarating experience for the diver, is no longer considered a harmless activity.

title: Easter for Children: Sedate but Festive
description: Easter Sunday is a dress-up day for children. A special uniform is called for: sedate for church, but festive and loose enough for ferreting out chocolate rabbits lurking behind couches. And the outfit should be enchanting enough to distract adults at the dinner table from company manners that are still being grown into. Four high-fashion designers from Italy fill the bill.

title:
Style Makers;
Tony Silver and Barbara Glazer, Entertainment Marketers
description: Tony Silver and Barbara Glazer are professional teases. In a modern loft in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, they create the coming attractions, or trailers, that entice audiences to see feature films. They specialize in attracting audiences to films that many moviegoers think they might not like.

title: Beating Case Unfolds, as Does Debate on Lawyer
description: As a nation has watched with fascination the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King by Los Angeles police officers, a separate debate has emerged in the legal community over the way Mr. King's lawyer, Steven A. Lerman of Beverly Hills, has handled the case.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Cutchogue 179,000 500 Crown Land Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old farm ranch; dining room, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,100. East Patchogue 139,000 7 Andreano Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 14-year-old Cape Cod; den, finished basement, pool, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,700. Lake Panamoka 108,200 55 Setauket Trail 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old log cabin; fireplace, c/a, deeded lake rights; taxes $1,800. Medford 120,000 121 Evergreen Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,400. Rocky Point 112,000 4 Misty Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16- year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Sayville 175,000 20 Eastover Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old Tudor; fireplace, family room, dining room, basement, 1- car garage; taxes $4,400. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. 420,000 91 Ellison Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, playroom; taxes $4,063. Ridgefield, Conn. 272,000 21 Flat Rock Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old raised ranch; new roof, skylights, new furnace, 1 acre; taxes $3,419. Howell, N.J. 166,900 20 Pittsfield Road 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 20-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, deck, pool, family room; taxes $3,290.

title: Data Update
Camera
description: If push comes to shove, I'll admit that I'm a black-and-white photographer at heart. I'm one of those odd ducks who love to spend hours in a darkroom developing film and making prints. I shoot color, too, but with color you can never say that you made the picture entirely yourself, unless of course you own a color lab.

title: Article 049091 -- No Title
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has awarded $226.5 million for New York State municipalities to upgrade water works.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: DAYS OF ATONEMENT (Tom Doherty/Tor, $19.95) by Walter Jon Williams is a genre-busting blend of science fiction and police procedural that succeeds on every level. Loren Hawn, police chief of the small New Mexico city of Atocha in the early years of the next century, prides himself on knowing where all the bodies are buried in his jurisdiction. He is handy with his fists, a sure shot, a good ol' boy and team player who does his best to keep this little corner of the world safe for nice people like his wife and their two daughters.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Santa Barbara
description: Nature has both blessed and cursed Santa Barbara. Filling a narrow coastal ledge between the steep Santa Ynez Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, it has a marvelous Mediterranean climate, breathtaking scenery, glorious flora and wide, palm-fringed beaches. But there is a price for living in this earthly paradise, a price exacted by fearsome earthquakes, flash fires, earthslides and drought. Santa Barbara epitomizes the central paradox of the good life in California, a land locked in a fatal embrace with powerful forces of nature that produce both enormous beauty and terrible destruction.

title: The Grand Design
description: THREE AND ONE-HALF YEARS ago in this space, I wrote in praise of Giorgio Armani, who had drawn for me his new, sincere look for men. Sketching the sloping, minimally padded shoulder and creased jacket, he said, "You see? It falls naturally. One must have the courage to show oneself a little bit as one is." But what Armani told me was not only a moral precept, it was a marketing concept. What he also meant is that if power and posturing sold in the 1980's, self-revelation and humility would be bankable now.

title: A June Wedding For Anne Kelting
description: The engagement of Anne Carolyn Kelting to Eric Leslie Kronenberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Kronenberg of Skillman, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Fred J. Keen of Tenafly, N.J., and Howard W. Kelting Jr. of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Nation; Coal Miners Contend Their Plight Is Worsening
description: IN the 1960's people learned that the hazards of coal mines were not limited to explosion and collapse. Mines were bad for breathing. Coal dust in underground mines could cause black lung disease, the generic term for any one of several progressive, often fatal respiratory ailments including emphysema and silicosis.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on March 3 about the Langham Hotel in London misstated the nationality of John Willliam Alcock and Arthur Brown, the pioneer trans-Atlantic fliers. They were British, not American.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CIRCULAR CANVASES

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Howell 166,900 20 Pittsfield Road 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 20-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, deck, pool, family room; taxes $3,290. Jackson 119,900 17 Andover Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old contemporary; patio, 1-car garage, w/w carpeting, family room, deck; taxes $3,093. Lakewood 52,000 154 Coventry Drive 2-bedroom, 1.5-bath, 15-year-old condominium town house; den, eat-in-kitchen; monthly charges $90, taxes $1,388. Short Hills 750,000 79 Troy Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 34-year-old ranch; fireplace, c/a, deck, den, 2-car garage; taxes $8,564. South Orange 505,000 285 Redmond Road 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 41-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, screened porch, c/a, fireplace, patio; taxes $8,608. West Orange 295,000 45 Ferris Drive 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 44-year-old contemporary; den, c/a, eat- in-kitchen, 2-car garage, deck; taxes $5,845. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. 420,000 91 Ellison Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den, playroom; taxes $4,063. Ridgefield, Conn. 272,000 21 Flat Rock Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old raised ranch; new roof, skylights, new furnace, 1 acre; taxes $3,419. Medford, L.I. 120,000 121 Evergreen Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,400.

title: New Mexico
description: To the Editor: Taos-bound travelers would do well to consider one hostelry not mentioned in "What's Doing in Taos" (Travel, Feb. 10). Halfway between the Plaza and the Pueblo, the Laughing Horse Inn is like no other in Taos or anywhere else.

title: Nia Judson Plans To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Judson 2d of Philadelphia have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Virginia Wallis Judson and Collin Farquhar McNeil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa.

title: Where Texas Still Is
description: THE WORLD AROUND MIDNIGHT By Patricia Browning Griffith. 254 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: The Nation;
description: HOW do you put a price on an environmental disaster? Last week the Exxon Corporation and the Federal Government set a benchmark by agreeing that the Valdez oil spill, in which an Exxon tanker dumped 11 million gallons of petroleum into Alaska's Prince William Sound, was worth $1.1 billion. That is the amount the company could pay as a settlement for violating Federal environmental law.

title: The World; Qaddafi Plays Quietly, But He's Still in the Game
description: NO fewer than six times since he was elected, President Bush has said, "The day of the dictator is over." He said it when he invaded Panama to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and again when he prepared to drive Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.

title: Dangerous Thoughts . . .
description: IN SEARCH OF HUMAN NATURE The Decline and Revival of Darwinism in American Social Thought. By Carl N. Degler. 400 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Travel Advisory; Canada Gift
description: Passengers on Air Canada flights at La Guardia and Newark Airports between May 1 and 10 will be given a $50 voucher toward the purchase of a full-fare ticket between New York and Toronto or Montreal. The award is part of the airline's celebrations of the 50th anniversary of its service between New York and Toronto.

title: B. J. Kaplan Weds Susan Futterman
description: Susan Leslie Futterman, a daughter of Jack Futterman of West End, N.J., and Eileen R. Tepper of Jericho, L.I., was married last evening to Bennett John Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour E. Kaplan of New York. Rabbi David Wolf Silverman officiated at the Renaissance Hotel in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THERE were fewer trees and more traffic lights. Rush-hour traffic had thinned, and from the windows of houses, kitchens glowed and televisions flickered. Whippany was not the place I remembered.

title: 'She's Really, Really Rich. Besides, I Love Her'
description: KISS OUT By Jill Eisenstadt. 345 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 17, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve their marital and romantic problems. 2 3 5 FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) A young woman finds familial problems and love in Dakota Territory. 3 2 8 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 4 1 THE EAGLE HAS FLOWN, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A German general and an I.R.A. assassin plot a daring rescue attempt during World War II. 5 6 22 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age. 6 4 6 MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) The romantic and professional lives of a homicide detective become entangled. 7 7 5 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury finds himself a suspect in the strange death of a widow from England's Lake District. 8 11 8 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia. 9 9 13 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. 10 * 8 8 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that the firm he recently joined is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities. 13 5 10 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 14 1 THE DRUID OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) A new volume in a series about the fantasy land of Shannara. 15 2 THE STORIES OF EVA LUNA, by Isabel Allende. (Atheneum, $18.95.) Twenty-three short tales with a variety of themes and settings. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 5 AND THE SEA WILL TELL, by Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. (Norton, $22.95.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a Pacific atoll. 2 1 17 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 3 3 7 THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present. 4 10 2 THE NEXT CENTURY, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $16.95.) A journalist's assessment of the prospects for various countries, judged by the temperament of their inhabitants. 5 4 18 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The recollections of the itinerant television newscaster. 6 6 32 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 7 5 25 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The White House dog's memoirs. 8 3 MAKE ROOM FOR DANNY, by Danny Thomas with Bill Davidson. (Putnam, $22.95.) The late entertainer's autobiography. 9 8 23 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 10 7 8 PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor. 11 13 9 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) A former Moscow correspondent surveys the profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 12 * 9 9 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The nature of God and salvation as perceived by Christian, Jewish and Muslim children. 13 11 5 THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY NO, by Shintaro Ishihara. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A Japanese politician contends his homeland will surpass the United States and become "first among equals." 14 2 BREAKING BARRIERS, by Carl T. Rowan. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The memoirs of the black journalist who served as a Government official during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. 15 14 21 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 15 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about managing your money. 2 1 31 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems. 3 5 102 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Financial advice. 4 4 15 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A new illustrated book in which the game is to find the ubiquitous chap as he travels from ancient Egypt to the present. 5 * 63 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A book of illustrated games. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind

title: These Tigers Were Definitely Burning Bright
description: It was Mad William Blake who wrote, "The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction." And he never witnessed the wrath of the Princeton Tigers after losing a tournament game.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Midwest Regional; UConn Beats Xavier, 66-50
description: In the kind of cruel reality that can intrude on the billion-dollar party known as the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, a foot injury reduced Jamal Walker of Xavier University to a spectator for too long this evening and allowed the Connecticut Huskies to turn a second-round game into 40 methodical minutes.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: East Regional; Run by Richmond Stopped by Temple
description: Both teams were defense-oriented and disciplined and had advanced to the second round of the East Regional by upsetting higher-seeded squads. But in the end this afternoon, Temple was simply too strong inside and broke open a close game in the late going to post a 77-64 victory over Richmond.

title: Miss Gilmartin, Golfer, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Gilmartin of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne Carter Gilmartin, to John Harold MacLean, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. MacLean of Oshawa, Ontario. A June wedding is planned.

title: Topics of the Times; Desert Storm to Capitol Hill
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, is looking for veterans of Operation Desert Storm to run in next year's Congressional elections, positioning them against Democratic incumbents who opposed the war. Most of the people he wants are still in the desert, not yet veterans, and it's a bit early for campaigning anyway.

title: A Footpath Along the Welsh Border
description: STANDING high on the Hatterall Ridge on the eastern edge of the Black Mountains, I had the Welsh uplands to my left and the rich agricultural land of Herefordshire to my right. I was walking the Offa's Dyke Path on the Welsh border, and the sun was shining on a lovely late August day. I thought I had the whole world to myself when I saw two figures on the path coming toward me, an old man and a young boy. I greeted them, then turned toward the east and commented on the marvelous view over the patchwork quilt of fields. "Yes," said the old man in a Welsh accent, "that's England." And in a flash I was back in Offa's time.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ST. PATRICK'S DAY

title: Token Theft: This One May Beat Them All
description: The New York subway system holds many mysteries. How much will the fare go up? Why does the public-address system never seem to work? How do you stop fare-beating?

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Southeast Regional; Kansas 3-Pointers Thwart Pittsburgh
description: Terry Brown, rebounding from a subpar performance, scored 22 points today as Kansas beat Pittsburgh, 77-66, in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's Southeast Regional.

title: Around the Garden
description: FOR THIS WEEK: It's time to think beyond the bright blooms of spring and order the bright bulbs of summer. Because the flower bud is already in place at the time of purchase, bulbs are virtually fail-safe plants. Easily grown summer bulbs include Peruvian daffodil or Ismene (Hymenocallis narcissiflora), which has fragrant, cream-colored daffodil-like blooms; Mexican shell flower or tiger flower (Tigridia pavonia), whose iris-shaped, spotted flowers come in many bright hues, and crinum lily (Crinum X powellii), whose graceful flowers are pink or white. Summer bulbs can be planted as soon as winter frosts fade. Free catalogues are available from such mail-order sources as Dutch Gardens, P.O. Box 200, Adelphia, N.J. 07710, (908) 780-2713 and Van Bourgondien, 245 Farmingdale Road, Babylon, N.Y. 11702, (800) 873-9444. Nonflowering forsythias

title: 'Love's Knowledge'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mysteries of Life In an East Side Pad
description: "I JUST wanted to stay alive. That is not an unreasonable goal!" shouts Al, a nervous advertising executive whose anxiety about his life stems from the sole reason that he lives in New York City.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Pachelbel: Canon in D Various arrangers and performers. BMG Classics 60712-RG; CD and cassette.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: SISTER DOROTHY ANN KELLY;
Fighting Racial Insensitivity on Campus
description: NONE of the incidents of racial and ethnic prejudice that have drawn national newspaper headlines this school year occurred at a Westchester college campus. But 10 local colleges continue to participate in the Westchester County Colleges Racial Diversity Project, which was formed more than two years ago.

title: Property-Tax Relief: A Look at the Figures
description: THE school financing law that was revised by the Legislature last week is intended to produce property-tax relief while increasing school aid to the majority of school districts in New Jersey.

title: Latvian Perceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Beer Shower and Boos for Dinkins at Irish Parade
description: Late for a parade that he had passed up the chance to lead, Mayor David N. Dinkins was booed for nearly 40 blocks yesterday and briefly showered with beer as he and other elected officials marched up Fifth Avenue with a gay Irish group in the St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: West Regional; Underdog Hoyas Not Awestruck
description: Nevada-Las Vegas is the undefeated defending national champion. Georgetown is the unpredictable underdog. But John Thompson, the Hoyas' head coach, said that when they meet Sunday in one of the most anticipated games of the season, Georgetown, the West Region's eighth-seeded team, would not be in awe of U.N.L.V.

title: A Youth Shelter Expands To Include Female Offenders
description: TERRI was feeling at home. After four days in the County Jail, she could appreciate a nice room with a television set, a hot shower and a friendly staff willing to provide her with whatever she needed.

title: Betsy Mitchell Plans Wedding
description: Barbara Robertson Mitchell of Morristown, N.J., and Clyde Mitchell of New York have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Dianne Mitchell and Glen R. Sundin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy S. Sundin of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: Intrigue in Morocco
description: THE SPY WORE SILK By Aline, Countess of Romanones. 316 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: News Unions Work on Contract Language Snags
description: Leaders of some of the unions at The Daily News met yesterday with representatives of the man who has bought the newspaper, the British publisher Robert Maxwell, as they tried to work out last-minute snags in labor agreements reached last week.

title: INTO THE ROSE GARDEN
description: Michael Pollan seems to revel in seeing roses as symbols of women and sex ("Into the Rose Garden," Feb. 17). Pollan's ideal woman, I surmise, must be Rubensesque, or perhaps the Edwardian type, with ample feminine charms prominently displayed. The old roses that he prefers are often, like those bounteous ladies, just too much: lots and lots of petals crowded together concentrically, much like the petticoats of Toulouse-Lautrec's cancan dancers. In contrast, the modern teas tend to be more restrained, elegant and delicate in form.

title: Mrazek Starts Mounting Campaign for the Senate
description: FOR many years, the conventional political wisdom has been that Representative Thomas J. Downey, the senior Long Island Democrat in the House, was a rising star, the Democrat most likely to move on to greener political pastures.

title: Palestinian Indicted, Mainly for Work as Reporter
description: A Palestinian journalist just released from prison under international pressure has been indicted on charges of aiding an illegal Arab group, principally because of his work as a journalist.

title: Reaping Innovation From Recession . . .
description: The worst thing that could happen would be for this recession to end too quickly. That is because recessions -- despite the pain -- are times of creativity and entrepreneurship. They are times when the country renews itself.

title: In Washington, Capital Fun For Children
description: GROWN-UPS who visit Washington on business repeatedly will gradually come to regard the Mall, the majestic setting for the capital's grandest monuments, as a dead space between the Department of Commerce on the north side and the Department of Energy on the south. But children will look at the big open space and see something more important: the perfect spot for flying a kite.

title: What the Framers Didn't Say
description: ON READING THE CONSTITUTION By Laurence H. Tribe and Michael C. Dorf. 144 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

title: Laura Resnic to Wed R. G. Brounstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton Resnic of Holyoke, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Jane Resnic to Richard Gregg Brounstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Brounstein of Oceanside, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Four Relief Pitchers Are Hoping to Save Their Reputations
description: Relief pitchers often have mercurial careers, and four in particular will try to get the mercury soaring their way this year. Mark Davis and Dan Plesac are coming back from disastrous seasons of their own making while Mitch Williams and Bill Landrum hope to regain the 1989 effectiveness that they lost last season because of knee ailments.

title: All About/Dress Shirts; Can Colors and Stripes Rescue Shirt Makers From a Slump?
description: The makers of men's dress shirts are trying to pull themselves out of a sales slump by splashing their goods with color. They want men to drape themselves in bold stripes and solid maroons, greens and browns instead of wearing pallid white and blue.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OUT OF STEP Notes From a Purple Decade. By Jonathan Yardley. Villard, $20.

title: Mike Scott's List
description: He is one of two Houston players left from the Astros' 1986 division championship team, and now Mike Scott appears to be dispensable, too, on a team that has undergone a thorough housecleaning as part of its rebuilding and cost-cutting. Scott said yesterday he had given the Astros a list of 12 teams to which he would accept a trade.

title: Thai Link Lost, Cambodia Feels More Isolated
description: The ousted Prime Minister of Thailand, Chatichai Choonhavan, had been best known for his desire to turn Indochinese "battlefields into marketplaces." He had annoyed his Southeast Asian neighbors, and his Foreign Ministry, by opening a diplomatic channel to the Vietnamese-installed Government in Cambodia.

title: Mutual Funds; Playing the Adjustable-Rate Game
description: Looking for a fund that has everything? High yields? And stable principal? And guarantees by the United States Government or one of its agencies?

title: A Battle Over Sick Pay And Vacation For 2 Officials
description: THE Board of Legislators and the County Executive are in a dispute over benefits for two departing commissioners at a time when state spending reductions have squeezed the county's budget.

title: Lasting Impressions
description: I SUPPOSE THAT LIKE MOST MEN, I regarded my father as my first fashion mentor. Later, I would imitate friends, teachers and public figures, but I originally became interested in clothes for the simple reason that my father wore them. He was always fond of bow ties, having taught me how to tie my own when I was 14 years old and preparing to attend my first formal dance. I wanted to wear a clip-on tie, but he dismissed it as suitable only for little boys and head waiters. So I climbed onto a chair while he stood behind, hugging me in a close embrace, laying his hands over mine and guiding me through the steps until I could do it myself.

title: Fading Star
description: Not long ago, he was the toast of the town, the most valuable player in the Italian All-Star Game and the hero of league-leading Il Messaggero Roma. But now, with the team in a four-game losing streak and Michael Cooper struggling to shake off a lingering illness, the accolades have faded.

title: Article 708191 -- No Title
description: Two leading Hong Kong businessmen have donated $2 million to Yale University and another $2 million to a Yale-administered fund that fosters exchanges between the Ivy League school and the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Yale has announced.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: ARLENE FRIEDMAN;
Revamping One of the Oldest Book Clubs
description: TWENTY years after entering the publishing industry as a secretary for a literary agency, Arlene Friedman is considered a major figure in the industry. In September she became editorial director of the Literary Guild and the Doubleday Book Club. She is the first new director of the guild in nearly 25 years.

title: School Turns Questions Into Gigs
description: THE Westchester Conservatory of Music has frequently been asked to recommend musicians for parties, weddings and other special events. So frequently, in fact, that the school has decided to organize its own entertainment service.

title: Suit Over Reservoir Halts Postal Building Plan
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has blocked construction of a $100 million Postal Service processing center in Westchester County that New York City contended would pollute a major drinking-water reservoir.

title: Margaret A. Nagy Wed To Thomas Bosworth
description: Margaret Ann Nagy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Nagy of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Russell Bosworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood R. Bosworth of Vienna, Va. The Rev. Robert F. Albert officiated at St. Clement Roman Catholic Church.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MAGIC IMAGES

title: On Language; Peacework
description: THE LINGO OF WAR provided this column with a target-rich environment; now for the mopping up.

title: Headliners; Rejection Slip
description: Whittle Communications has made a name for itself by promising advertisers what few other publishers can deliver: a captive audience. The company publishes magazines for doctors' waiting rooms and operates "Channel One," which broadcasts sponsored news programs to high schools. Just about two years ago, Whittle announced that it had signed up nine big name authors, including David Halberstam, who would each be paid an average of $60,000 to write short, 100-page books. Each copy would carry advertising from Federal Express, which would deliver the books free of charge to 150,000 business leaders, politicians and other so-called opinion leaders. Today Mr. Halberstam's book "The Next Century," which is about geopolitical life after the cold war, appears in the No. 4 position on The New York Times best-seller list, but the publisher is not Whittle. Last week Mr. Halberstam said he took the book to William Morrow after Whittle said the manuscript was too long and needed more reporting.

title: New Rules Restrict Borderline-Ill Patients in Nursing Homes
description: EVER since Ed Dwyer, 73 years old, of St. James, received the diagnosis that he had Alzheimer's disease, his six children across the country have tried to figure out how to take care of him.

title: IRAQ'S PRESIDENT PROMISES REFORMS ONCE REVOLTS END
description: Facing bloody civil insurrection in the north and the south of his country, President Saddam Hussein appealed today for the support of the Iraqi people, promising to push ahead with democratic reforms as soon as he crushed the rebellion.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We live in a 100-year-old two-story row house. In very cold weather, when we drain the sink or bathtub or flush the toilet in our second-floor bathroom, we get a sound as if someone is tapping with a small hammer on our ceiling. The sound comes from an area where the vent stack is. Our plumber says he does not have an answer to our problem. What do you think is causing the tapping?

title: Plan May Make Hearth Cold Comfort
description: In trying to separate Americans from their home fires, cities throughout the country are finding that few things are more valued than a hearth with real flames burning real wood, no matter how much air pollution it may cause.

title: Vincent Sees Dykstra
description: They met and spoke for 15 minutes yesterday in Florida, and afterward Commissioner Fay Vincent said it might be several weeks before he decides whether to take action against Lenny Dykstra, the Philadelphia Phillies' outfielder, for his involvement in high-stakes poker games.

title: Tyson Suit Dismissed
description: He didn't get very far in court, but Mike Tyson's former trainer, Kevin Rooney, said he really didn't mind that his $10 million breach of contract suit against Tyson was dismissed on Friday since his real aim was not to win but to bother Tyson.

title: Bridge
description: Domestic triangles consisting of a husband, a wife and another man are common enough; the bridge equivalent is very rare indeed. The third side of a triangle that is believed to be the first in major American championship competition was completed a week ago at the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League in Atlantic City, N.J.

title: When the Citizen Soldiers Go Back to School; Parade or Hospitals?
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; A Class Gift With a Purpose: Creating Teachers
description: To encourage graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to become public school teachers, the class of 1991 has made a $60,000 loan-forgiveness program its senior gift to the institute.

title: U.S. and Iraq to Meet on Request by Baghdad to Shift Its Warplanes
description: American and Iraqi commanders will meet in the Iraqi desert within two days to discuss an Iraqi request to move warplanes around the country, an action that the Pentagon considers a violation of the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.

title:
Style Makers;
Vernita Nemec, Artist and Organizer
description: As the clamor of Canal Street rises to her cluttered loft studio, Vernita Nemec is busy at a typical artist's task: applying for grants. "Times are tough," she conceded. But she is trying to make them a little easier for her colleagues.

title: Dangerous Thoughts . . . And Machines With Big Ideas
description: MODELS OF MY LIFE By Herbert A. Simon. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Basic Books. $26.95.

title: About Cars; Jeep Marks 50 Years of 4-Wheel Drive
description: Say "Jeep" to me and it conjures up a couple of images. One is of me, age 9, trying to carve a model of the little war wagon and seriously whittling my finger. The other is much later, when I was in the market for my first car, and it has me trying to find one of those $50 Jeeps of urban myth.

title: The Question of Visas For Immigrant Workers
description: The article about Turkish immigrants at gasoline stations was a nice piece, in capsulized form, reflecting the involvement of some of my countrymen with the oil business on Long Island.

title: Miss Moore Weds Lieut. David Duff
description: Virginia Happel Moore, the daughter of Comdr. and Mrs. Robert Brevard Moore of Annapolis, Md., was married there yesterday to Second Lieut. David Andrew Duff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Duff of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. John Price performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church.

title: An American Twist to Italian Standards
description: THE year-old Gazebo in Oyster Bay is a restaurant for all seasons. Last summer, its enclosed patio provided captivating alfresco dining. In cooler months, the tiny restaurant scores as a snug retreat.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: HERBERT CASPERT;
Entertaining the Bids at Auction Time
description: HERBERT CASPERT, a bankruptcy and liquidation auctioneer whose office is based here, acknowledges that he has two distinct personalities. One he presents as he sits in his office explaining his business in a genial and self-effacing manner. The other, the one he projects when he's auctioneering, he says, is totally opposite.

title: The Loneliness of the Latchkey Dog: For Owners, Day Care Eases the Guilt
description: He works on First Avenue in Manhattan and she near Madison Avenue. They live in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, so what are they to do about their dog, home alone for hours each day?

title: Jeremy Irons's Effortless Style
description: I'LL NEVER FORGET THE OVERCOAT you wore the first time we met."

title: Lucy B. Baker, Banker, to Wed
description: Francis Ellsworth Baker of Avon, Conn., and Patricia Barry Baker of Newburyport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucy Barry Baker to Steven Lawrence Patricola, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick A. Patricola of Harrington Park, N.J. A January wedding is planned.

title: Victory Lap; Baker Finds Doors Open, Minds Sealed
description: RIDING a wave of optimism in the wake of the American victory in the Persian Gulf war, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d took a grand tour of the Middle East and Moscow last week to see whether that victory could be translated into a breakthrough in the Arab-Israeli conflict as well.

title: Barbara Savini Is Married
description: Barbara Adelle Savini was married yesterday in Miami to Peter Stuart Triestman. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Savini of Atlanta. The bridegroom is a son of Annette Spradlin of Fort Lauderdale and the late Harold Triestman. The Rev. John Phillips performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens. Mrs. Triestman, 34 years old, is the director of sales and marketing at Olek Lejbzon Adler Inc., a furniture restoration company in New York. Mr. Triestman, 34, a Yale University graduate, heads the company. He also heads American Public Telecommunications, an independent communication services corporation.

title: Postings: For Homeless Addicts; Rehab Center
description: In an ambitious expansion of housing and services for homeless drug abusers, a 30-year-old New York City organization, the Addicts Rehabilitation Center of Harlem, has received state funding to build a new, 204-bed facility at 2015 Madison Avenue, just off 128th Street.

title: As Conservation Gains, Tax Losses Alarm Towns
description: JOSEPH RAMPE is the Supervisor of the Town of Warwick in Orange County, N.Y., and like municipal officials everywhere, he worries about taxes. In particular, these days, he worries about the taxes paid by Sterling Forest Corporation, the huge private landholding concern that contributes $337,000 a year in property taxes to the town coffers.

title: Fashion; UNDER IT ALL
description: Who can tell what's underneath? These days, women can have as much fashion, comfort, pleasure and fun with underwear as they have with what's meant to show. A strict business suit may be concealing the laciest of lingerie. Printed boxer shorts that would be quite all right worn outside are tucked into blue jeans. A bodysuit of cotton or Lycra makes a smooth cover-up under virtually everything.

title: Mary Jane Alexander to Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dale G. Alexander of Dafter, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Jane Alexander, to Edward William Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Knight of Traverse City, Mich. A May wedding is planned.

title: Style Makers; Derek Hopson and Darlene Powell-Hopson, Child and Family Psychologists
description: Derek Hopson and Darlene Powell-Hopson, clinical psychologists based in Middlefield, Conn., study racial attitudes among children. Their book, "Different and Wonderful: Raising Black Children in a Race-Conscious Society" published by Prentice-Hall last fall, and it and their studies on the implications of preschool children's racial preferences in dolls impressed Mattel Inc., the maker of Barbie.

title:
FOCUS;
A Convention Center as a Field for Selling Property
description: The success of a two-day sale of bank-owned property that drew 30,000 people to the Hynes Convention Center here has encouraged promoters to try to use similar settings for giant real-estate sales elsewhere.

title: Children's Books/Biography
description: GOOD QUEEN BESS The Story of Elizabeth I of England. By Diane Stanley and Peter Vennema. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Making a Living Off the Dead
description: It must be Gerald Meltzer's lucky day. There he is, coaxed out of the audience and onto the stage of a Las Vegas nightclub, being personally serenaded by Marilyn Monroe. Marilyn teases open his shirt buttons to expose his undershirt, coos "My Heart Belongs to Daddy" adoringly and runs her fingers seductively through what's left of his thinning hair.

title: Van Kills Two at Airport
description: Two women were fatally injured Friday night when they were struck by a van as they walked along a pedestrian pathway from a small commuter plane to a gate at National Airport. The 51-year-old driver, Aaron Standifer of Suitland, Md., was charged with involuntary manslaughter. One of the victims, Yvonne Lethem, 52, of Falls Church, Va., died at the scene. The other, identified only as Isaura Lages, was taken by helicopter to Washington Hospital Center, where she died.

title: 1990 Census: Changes in Westcheser
description: During the 1980's, Westchester County's population grew fastest in the rural northern towns, but the heaviest concentration of residents remained in the southern cities and suburban communities.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE CHAPPAQUA LIBRARY;
Musicians, Storytellers and Actors Explore Social Visions
description: THE event last weekend at the library here was billed as "An Evening of Short Stories, Music and Poetry," and it more than lived up to its promise of variety: onstage and off, there was always a mix of styles.

title: Travel Advisory; Tokyo Nonstops
description: All Nippon Airways, which carries more passengers than any other Japanese airline, has started nonstop service between Kennedy International Airport in New York and Tokyo with three flights a week -- on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday -- in each direction. Departure from Kennedy is at 11 A.M., arriving at Narita Airport, Tokyo, at 2:55 P.M. the next day. Flights from Tokyo leave at 11 A.M. and arrive at Kennedy at 9:15 A.M. the same day. All Nippon now flies to 17 cities outside Japan, including Los Angeles and Washington as well as cities in Europe and the Far East. In Japan the airline's routes connect 29 major cities.

title: Radios
description: To the Editor: Despite the contention of Leslie Paul Davies of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Letters, Jan. 6) that all receivers (shortwave, AM and FM) have oscillators in their circuitry, this is not so. According to Radio Operator's License Q & A Manual, a tuned radio frequency receiver requires no oscillator for the reception of radiotelephone signals. It might still be a good idea, though, as Mr. Davies says, not to play a radio in an airplane unless you are sure no signals will be emitted that might interfere with navigation and communication equipment. FRANCIS TEDESCHI Brooklyn

title: A Contest That's Always Won by a Hair
description: ON Feb. 2, Mayor Marvin Reed stopped shaving. So did Mayor Richard Woodbridge of Princeton Township. In fact, 40 usually dapper professionals, including two lawyers, a social worker and several businessmen, are sporting facial stubble.

title: Coins
description: Sometimes a coin seems to be a one-of-a-kind piece and, because of its uniqueness, worth a considerable amount of money. Such is the case with an 1836-type half dollar, clearly stamped 1837, owned by a collector in Florida.

title: Review/Film; Adultery and Aftermath In a Chinese Village
description: "Ju Dou" was shown as part of last autumn's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 22, 1990. The Chinese-language film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: On the Street; Legs Of the 90's
description: It's spring! Well, almost, and besides, it's the feeling that counts. After all, if it's St. Patrick's Day, there's not long to wait. And in the meantime the long, decorated leg is getting second looks on New York streets. Tights flash images from the Pop Art canvases of Andy Warhol. The most striking are multiple prints of Marilyn Monroe. At a recent SoHo art show opening, multiple television images ran down one woman's legs as she stopped at a Kenny Scharf canvas that consisted of multiple head images echoing the pattern of her tights. All along Fifth Avenue, black and white stripes, diamond and check patterns are worn with short skirts. Even tights in solid colors have raised patterns like herringbone and cable-knit. Stretch velour tights have a corduroy-like surface. Some patterned tights are worn with long jackets and sweaters, a look that is distinctly spring 1990.

title: Baby Is Sought After Mother Is Found Dead
description: The police are looking for a 3-month-old boy last seen 12 days ago as he and his mother were getting into a cab outside their Brooklyn home. The woman was found dead the next morning three miles away, her body burned beyond recognition, and the child is missing, the police said yesterday.

title: Dentist Dies of AIDS, and Patients Are Offered Test
description: A dentist here died of AIDS two weeks ago, and state health officials are now offering free tests for the disease to more than 1,200 of his patients.

title: Ruddock's Long Wait Ending
description: The match has been a long time in coming.

Congressional Democrats found yet another way to remind the nation of the party's crippling liabilities when they ousted Charles S. Robb from a Senate budget panel last week for espousing a heretical doctrine: fiscal responsibility.

title: Elizabeth Farinas Is Married on L.I.
description: Dr. Elizabeth Mary Farinas, the daughter of Dr. Lucila Farinas and Dr. Oscar Farinas of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Frances de Chantal Roman Catholic in Wantagh, L.I., yesterday to Dr. John Edward Rooney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Rooney of New Milford, N.J. Msgr. Edward A. Sweeney and the Rev. John A. Adam officiated.

title: SOVIETS IN MILLIONS DECIDING ON UNITY
description: Soviet citizens voted today on whether to approve President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plea that this nation, so deeply riven by political and economic struggle, should continue as a union.

title: Changes in Albania Rekindle Pride in Immigrants
description: As Albania stumbles from its Stalinist past, a distant footfall is heard in parts of New York.

title: Where Phone Lines Stop, Progress May Pass By
description: Despite the challenges posed by rattlesnakes, dirt roads and a fickle water well, Brett Nybo likes the solitude of life in this dusty, remote hollow.

title: Metro Matters; Leading a Parade Of Diversity, From the Middle
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch vividly recalls when, as a Congressman, he was invited to lead one of New York City's first Ukrainian parades.

title: Streetlight Skimping Will Cost Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Weigh Secrecy Shift
description: Switzerland is proposing to ease strict rules on banking secrecy to crack down on money laundering and iron out loopholes in existing legislation, the Justice Ministry said Friday.

title: One Truism at a Time
description: THE thought for the week was that the University of North Carolina was entered in some quaint little provincial tournament, the Salt City Classic perhaps, or the Central New York Invitational.

title: U.S. and Airlines Delay Safety Measures
description: More than a year after ordering the airlines to take new steps to help passengers get off planes quickly after accidents, the Government has failed to enforce the order and many airlines have not changed their procedures.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up Strongly
description: Stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange scored strong gains by the close of morning trading today.

title: Boy Who Raped 3-Year-Old Given 6 Years
description: A 13-year-old boy has been sentenced to more than six years in a juvenile institution for raping and nearly killing a 3-year-old girl while he was baby-sitting.

title: Wrist Support Adjusts 5 Ways
description: Much of the technique in bowling is concentrated in the player's wrist. To strengthen the joint, Ebonite International of Hopkinsville, Ky., has developed a new wrist support that adjusts five ways.

title: Hottest Story at Murdoch Magazines Is Their Fate
description: There is almost nothing that the magazine industry loves as much as a good rumor, particularly if it is about someone else's magazines. So when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said recently that it might -- just might -- consider selling some magazines if it could not reduce its debt through the sale of other assets, the buzz began.

title: Harlem Journal; Homegirl Makes Good, And Returns to 125th St.
description: Phyllis Yvonne Stickney made the big time and moved out to Los Angeles a couple of years ago, but she still hangs onto her old apartment in Harlem. Harlem is where Ms. Stickney, a comedian and an actress appearing in the movie "New Jack City," found her voice. Harlem, she said, will always be home.

title: Islanders Want A Bigger House
description: EVEN while winning four straight Stanley Cups early in the 1980's, the Islanders were constantly shoehorning seats and luxury boxes and elevators into a boutique arena built for 14,000. Now the Nassau Coliseum is just too small, says the team's owner, John Pickett.

title: Emerson To Sell Stake
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation has signed a letter of intent to sell 10 million common shares, or a 20 percent interest, to Semi-Tech (Global) Ltd. for $30 million.

title: Pilar Primo de Rivera, Fascist Leader in Spain
description: Pilar Primo de Rivera, a fascist leader during the Spanish Civil War, died today in Madrid.

title: Skaters Get a Jump On the Competition
description: Kurt Browning of Canada had one quadruple jump and three combination triple jumps in his free-skate program. Kristi Yamaguchi had seven triples. They were the gold medalists at the 1991 world championships, and their programs were not unlike others.

title: Knicks Start Off on a Roll Then Unravel
description: After leading for 47 minutes and 30 seconds today, the Knicks self-destructed in the final 30 seconds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Why Must Achievers Pay for Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi-Iranian Relations Are Being Restored
description: Saudi Arabia and Iran will resume diplomatic relations within the next 48 hours, the Omani press agency reported today.

title: Serbian Official Declares Part of Croatia Separate
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the President of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, apparently sought to extend his influence today through the proclamation of a "Serbian autonomous region" in an area of Croatia, the neighboring republic to the north.

title: Virginia Advances On Basket at :004
description: Heather Burge's jump shot in the lane with 4 seconds left gave top-seeded Virginia a 74-72 victory over Stephen F. Austin this afternoon in the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's tournament.

title: Jeffrey Feldman Weds Judge Marsha Steinhardt
description: Judge Marsha Lois Steinhardt of the Civil Court in Brooklyn and Jeffrey C. Feldman, the executive director of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, were married there yesterday at the Chapel of Congregation Beth Elohim. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider and Cantor Norma Hirsh officiated.

title: William D. Turnbull Dies at 64; Co-Founder of North Point Press
description: William D. Turnbull, the co-founder and publisher of North Point Press, an influential independent publishing house, died Thursday at his home in Sinson Beach, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: Ship Pierces Pipe, Leaking Oil in California
description: More than 27,000 gallons of light oil leaked into Santa Monica Bay after a tanker apparently pierced a pipeline with its anchor on Saturday night, the authorities said.

title: Russians' Big Worry: New Sales Tax
description: Yekaterina Lebedeva said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev can keep Communists in power in this country, he can keep his vision of a new federated union and he can keep the chintzy pair of vinyl boots she was all set to buy in a department store here.

title: Bronwyn Carlton Wed in Brooklyn
description: Bronwyn O'Neill Carlton, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Carlton of Council Bluffs, Iowa, and Sean Michael Taggart, a son of Sandra Taggart of Brooklyn and William Taggart of New York, were married yesterday at the Pierrepont Street Chapel of the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Harris Riordan-Hendlin officiated.

title: Mets' Best Defense Sits in the Dugout
description: THERE was a day and age when baseball teams measured the worth of their defense by the number of gloves made out of metal. Precious metal, that is.

title: The Right Way to Cut Payroll Taxes
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York startled his colleagues at the end of 1989 by proposing a cut in Social Security payroll taxes. The plan went nowhere, coming at a time of huge Federal deficits. But it was not in vain: it sidetracked President Bush's benighted campaign to lower the capital gains tax. Congress balked at lowering taxes for the rich while denying relief to everyone else.

title: Question Box
description: Babe in the Minors

title: Eastern Who?
description: Undefeated and top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas led 16 teams into the regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament with a 62-54 victory over Georgetown yesterday. U.N.L.V. (32-0) will next play Utah in a West Region semifinal in Seattle on Thursday.

title: For California: A Political Fix
description: California health officials have long boasted that their nursing homes for the elderly set a national standard. But when new Federal regulations tried to upgrade glaring deficiencies in that care, the state applied political muscle in Washington to evade its responsibilities. Lamentably, the Bush Administration appears to be caving.

title: Turning High-School Seniors' Lives Into TV
description: Marlon Golden, a high school senior at Glenbard West in the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn, Ill., asked two girls to the homecoming dance last fall. He tried unsuccessfully to keep the two away from the television set on March 9 when the story was broadcast on the new Fox series "Yearbook," which documents the lives of the school's graduating class. Last Monday morning Mr. Golden was confronted by two angry young women, both of whom are now former girlfriends.

title: Quick Kuwaiti Recovery Is Seen, With the Cost Less Than Thought
description: Kuwait's economy, far and away the strongest among the oil-producing countries before the Iraqi invasion in August put it into a coma, is expected to revive and move back to boom times within two years, say many economic and financial experts on the region.

title: Books of The Times; Nature of the Economy: Changed and Changing
description: The Work of Nations Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism By Robert B. Reich 331 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: More Screens, but Fewer Movies to Choose From
description: Moviegoers in New York these days are caught in a curious paradox. Their choice of theaters is greater than it has been in years, but the choice of films on the movie-house menu has become more limited -- and more like what is available anywhere else.

title: Charles A. Baker, 70, Theater Agent, Is Dead
description: Charles Adams Baker, an agent for scores of luminaries of the New York stage and the chief of the William Morris Agency's theater department from 1950 to 1973, died on Friday in New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Strained Loyalties Threaten to Unravel the Military in Tattered Yugoslavia
description: Is the Yugoslav national army willing to fight, and if so, for whom?

title: Bridge
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship title was up for grabs here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. With 16 deals remaining, Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., Peter Boyd of Falls Church, Va., Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., all former world champions, had a modest lead of 14 imps. The session began with two borderline slam deals which gained them 21 imps, and they emerged 38 ahead to win the championship. But both slam deals could have gone against them, and they would have lost at the end of play by 8.

title: God's Own Cowboys
description: Last weekend, Barry Goldwater, Chuck Connors ("The Rifleman") and James Drury ("The Virginian") were inducted into the National Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City. Without taking away from this trio's status as fine Americans, one must wonder if the inductors might not have reached a bit spiritually in calling them cowboys.

title: Treasury Bills and Farm Credit Offerings
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late in the day Friday the outstanding three-month bills were bid at 5.80 percent and six-month bills were at 5.81 percent.

title: Board Shifts Called Manipulative
description: The decisions last week by the Chrysler Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company to shrink their corporate boards highlight a new phase in the struggle between increasingly powerful shareholders and the corporate managers threatened by their presence.

title: Marine Drowns in Training
description: Second Lieut. Anthony L. Marchinda of the Marine Corps drowned Saturday while participating in swim qualification training at the Quantico Marine base, the service said. A statement from the Marines said Lieutenant Marchinda, 24 years old, of Troy, Mich., was swimming underwater with other members of his training company in the pool at Ramer Hall shortly before he was spotted lying face down on the bottom of the pool about 10:50 A.M. He died a short time later.

title: Germany Sees Sharp Slowdown
description: The economic boom that unity brought to western Germany is expected to slow significantly this year under the combined weight of eastern Germany's severe economic decline, recession in other industrialized nations and the cost of Germany's contribution to the Persian Gulf war.

title: Washington Talk; Searching For Course Of Souter And Court
description: The Legal Times, a weekly newspaper for lawyers that is published here, does not often reprint Supreme Court opinions.

title: Hoffa's Son Seeks Presidency of Teamsters
description: James P. Hoffa has asked officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to declare him eligible to seek the union presidency his father held for 14 years.

title: Lisa Huxley, a Computer Coordinator, Marries Steven Miller, a Law Clerk
description: Elizabeth Webb Huxley, a daughter of Anne Schenck Huxley of Columbia, Mo., and David B. Huxley of Wansford, Cambridgeshire, England, was married in St. Louis yesterday to Steven David Miller, a son of Mrs. Scott Hyde of Amarillo, Tex., and Abraham Miller of New York. Rabbi Susan Talve and the Rev. Steven W. Lawler, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Whittemore House, the faculty club at Washington University.

title: Outdoors: Celebrating Modest Gains on Earth Day
description: COULD it be that Americans may finally be seeing decades of effort aimed at preserving the environment and maintaining wildlife turn into a national change of heart?

title: Review/Theater; The 2 Worlds of Touring Minstrels
description: Humor in the face of adversity was exemplified by those black minstrels who toured the United States in the years after the Civil War. Blackening their faces with burnt cork, they sang, danced, clowned and played the fool for white audiences while knowing that an evening's popularity would be followed by the pain of exclusion and prejudice.

title: 2 From ABC TV See the World
description: THE broadcast team that helps give ABC's "Monday Night Football" its distinct look is going into competition -- with ABC.

title: DUE IN U.S., WALESA STRESSES AID NEED
description: President Lech Walesa insists that he is not coming to America with his "paws" out, but warns that Poland's economic reforms will fail if the West does not provide substantial additional assistance.

title: Opposite Paths For Witt, Muller
description: The student has gone on to fame, glory and the riches available from the capitalist system to those with talent, determination and the right agent. The teacher has been left behind, shackled to the modest ways of the past, destined for a life no better than the one she had.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Still on the Air After 19 Years
description: DICK BUTTON was wistful the other day when the Sullivan Award was announced. Forty-two years earlier he captured that honor as America's top amateur athlete. And it led, in the strange way these things often do, to his becoming a very rich professional.

title: Palestinians Gratified by Israeli Easing of Bar to Migrant Workers
description: Palestinians from the occupied territories were gratified by two actions taken by Israeli authorities today, a week after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d asked the Government to lighten the pressure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: What Next for Anderson?
description: Does Kenny Anderson's good friend Jimmy Jackson know something?

title: IRAQI REBELS TELL OF FIERCE FIGHTING
description: Rebel groups in several parts of Iraq said today that they were locked in fierce fighting with Government troops, a day after President Saddam Hussein told the nation that he had the upper hand in the civil insurrection threatening his regime.

title: St. John's Rolls On; U.N.L.V. Holds Off Georgetown; Hoyas Tough In 62-54 Loss
description: The Nevada-Las Vegas Runnin' Rebels, unbeaten and largely unchallenged in the regular season, were challenged and even jostled at times by the Georgetown Hoyas here this afternoon in the West Regional. In the end, however, the Runnin' Rebels, the defending national collegiate basketball champions, were simply too deep and too good and won, 62-54.

title: Review/Concert; Honoring the Composer Ralph Shapey
description: Ralph Shapey remains one of our crustiest, most original and, in his sometimes dour way, appealing composers. Last Monday evening, one day short of Mr. Shapey's 70th birthday, he was honored at Town Hall by a concert of his own music and that of other composers he feels close to.

title: Canoeing and Kayaking in New York Waters
description: To the Editor:

title: Seven Minutes In Los Angeles - A special report.; Videotaped Beating by Officers Puts Full Glare on Brutality Issue
description: Since it was first broadcast on local television, the videotape of a black man being beaten and kicked for nearly two minutes by a group of white police officers has shamed the city and outraged minority residents who have insisted for years that they are targets of an abusive police force.

title: Julie Newdow Is Married
description: Julie Newdow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Newdow of Rockleigh, N.J., and Ronny Yakov, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Yakov of Tel Aviv, were married yesterday by Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich at Temple Emanu-El in New York. The bride, a singer and song writer, attended Tufts University and is a music student at Columbia University. The bridegroom owns City Offset Inc., a design and printing company in New York. He received a degree in graphic design from Wizo France.

title: New Job Titles At Newsweek Magazine
description: After the announcement last week that Richard M. Smith, the editor in chief of Newsweek, will take on the additional title of president, the magazine has promoted other senior executives who will report to Mr. Smith.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I am very confident about the fact that we will have a boom here."

title: India Has No History of Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Ends Practice Of Dumping Sludge in Sea
description: For the first time in more than 65 years, no New Jersey community is dumping treated sewage into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DWAYNE O. ANDREAS, chairman and chief executive of Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, an agricultural importer, is to receive the Anti-Defamation League's highest honor tonight at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York City. Mr. Andreas, who will be given the America's Democratic Legacy Award, has been active in encouraging private enterprise in the United States to assist other countries, particularly the Soviet Union.

title: Lebanon Nears Pivotal Point in Disarming Militias
description: The Lebanese Government moved today into a pivotal phase of its program to fully disband all private militias, as President Elias Hrawi met with Syria's Vice President to discuss support from the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon in suppressing any opposition to the effort.

title: Dinkins Joins Gay Marchers In an Encore
description: At times ebullient, at times seemingly close to tears of joy, Mayor David N. Dinkins defied his detractors yesterday and joined a rousing dance at an outdoor celebration in Greenwich Village with the Irish lesbians and gay men he had joined in Saturday's abuse-marred St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Long-Awaited Victory for Connors: Jimmy Connors won for the first time since October 1989 when he beat Udo Riglewski of Germany in a first-round match yesterday in the International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Boris Becker, facing the qualifier Steve DeVries in his opening match, lost the first set, fell behind by 5-2 in the third set and trailed by 4-1 in a third-set tie breaker. But he rallied to win, 5-7, 6-3, 7-6.
