The 38-year-old Connors, trying to come back from surgery on his left wrist last October, beat No. 98-ranked Riglewski, 6-4, 6-4, in a match that took near 24 hours to complete because of rain delays.(AP) GOLF

title: INSIDE
description: Safety Measures Delayed The Government has failed to enforce an order issued to airlines last year to take steps to speed the evacuation of planes after accidents. Page B5.

title: Review/Art; National Gallery Puts Its Gifts on Display
description: "Art for the Nation: Gifts in Honor of the 50th Anniversary of the National Gallery of Art" is a statement of esthetic and institutional power that does a great deal to clarify the strengths, weaknesses and present identity of the institution that is by its title America's national museum.

title: Swarmin' for Norman
description: "If nominated, I will not run," said a war hero a century ago; "If elected, I will not serve."

title: Magee Wins Nestle With Eagle Putt
description: Andrew Magee played only three holes today, but he made a 30-foot eagle putt on one of them and it catapulted him to victory in the rain-shortened Nestle Invitational.

title: Handling Trouble in the Great Outdoors
description: THE best and latest emergency medical manuals assume the prompt arrival of an ambulance with paramedics. But what happens when an accident occurs on the Appalachian Trail or on a back-country trip in the Adirondacks?

title: P.R. All-Stars Join Baseball Contest
description: Every fan knows that pitching is crucial in baseball. But making the right pitch is even more important before a team exists.

title: Innis Finally Feels at Home in Clubhouse
description: Jeff Innis's locker was properly appointed with cleats, gloves, mail and miscellaneous memorabilia. Nothing, then, was particularly unusual about the locker, except perhaps that Jeff Innis for once felt he belonged on the seat in front of it.

title: Tisch Approval Is Unanimous
description: The National Football League owners opened their annual March meeting here today by unanimously approving the 50 percent sale of the Giants to Robert Tisch, the president of the Loews Corporation and former Postmaster General.

title: A Beautiful Day For . . . Football?
description: MORE than 7,500 people turned out yesterday at Giants Stadium for a "Meet the Knights" ticket promotion, the team said. The W.L.A.F. team said it had sold 5,000 season tickets to fans who were permitted to watch practice and then meet the players on the field afterward. Season sales are now 15,000, the team said. . . . The Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association are claiming a pro hoops record of going through a season unbeaten at home. With a Saturday night victory they finished 28-0 at home and 50-6 over all. Coach George Karl was praised by his "rookie" forward, Albert King, the former Knick and Net: "He doesn't take any bull from us. That's one of the things that might not happen often in the C.B.A." . . . Darryl Strawberry underwent an off-season religious conversion and referred to his mentor, the Rev. Morris Cerullo, as "my main man." Cerullo earlier bought the Christian theme park that had been created by Jim Bakker. Now Cerullo is being sued by his partners, who accuse him of fraud in using $4 million that he received for selling memberships. . . . Nine years after he retired, Bill McArthur is returning as head football coach at Western Oregon State College. "Why am I back in coaching?" the 72-year-old asked. "Well, my golf game is lousy, my wife won't let me fly planes any more and all the handball players have died, so why not?"

title: More Protests Are Planned Against Longtime Togo Ruler
description: Opposition and student leaders in Togo decided today to press ahead with a campaign of street protests in a bid to end President Gnassingbe Eyadema's 24-year one-party rule.

title: Exhibit Examines Difficulties Facing Jewish Troops in Gulf
description: A small museum here has mounted an exhibition of photographs, letters and medals that shed some light on the delicate balance that Jewish soldiers in the Persian Gulf have had to strike as they try to practice their religion in the Arab world.

title: Rougher Road for the S.& L. Bailout
description: As members of the House and Senate meet this week on the final steps to providing another $30 billion for the savings industry bailout, they are facing an unpleasant political reality: The money will not be enough.

title: Beyond Leisure Suits: New Life for Polyester
description: Polyester. The very name stirs images of tackiness, of Saturday-night swingers in leisure suits making clumsy passes at women in hotel cocktail lounges. Without polyester, the look that some people rudely called the "full Cleveland" would be nothing more than a white patent-leather belt with shoes to match. Polyester, in short, is a cultural smirk, a synonym for bad taste.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A group of former Fulbright scholars will descend on the United Nations Thursday night to honor ALBERTO VITALE, chairman and chief executive of Random House, and RUTH STEINKRAUS COHEN, founder of the International Hospitality Committee of Fairfield County in Connecticut. Mr. Vitale, who was a Fulbright scholar from Italy to the United States in 1957, is to receive an achievement award. Mrs. Cohen, a pianist, is to be honored for outstanding volunteer service. Since 1958, she has matched more than 35,000 foreign students with host families in the New York City region.

title: Closing the Door on China Won't Help Anyone; Taiwan's Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Lord Stanley's Cup Is Running Over
description: A YEAR too soon, they are running out of room to engrave the winners' names on the Stanley Cup. When the cup, first presented in 1893, was refitted in 1963, the base was widened so the players' names on every winning team could be engraved through the 1991-92 season -- the 75th anniversary of the National Hockey League. Instead, after this year's playoffs there will be no more room. Seems that the 1965 Canadiens took up two panels because the engraver's spacing was off.

title: New York at Work; New CUNY Chancellor: Bold, Fast Relief
description: Dr. W. Ann Reynolds swept into the City University of New York six months ago like a Kansas twister on a redecorating kick. She hasn't slowed a whole lot.

title: Wake Forest Falls To Alabama, 96-88
description: Playing uncharacteristically errorless basketball on offense and a suffocating zone defense, Alabama held off gritty Wake Forest, 96-88, today and advanced to the Southeast Regional semifinals.

title: Dr. McGoldrick Weds T.G. Briody
description: Dr. Karen Lee McGoldrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. McGoldrick of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday in Providence, R.I., to Thomas Gately Briody, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Briody of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Nicholas P. Smith performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manning Chapel at Brown University.

title: ALLIES TELL IRAQ NOT TO FLY PLANES
description: At a meeting held in the Iraqi desert, allied generals today formally rejected a request from Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council to move its warplanes around the country.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO REVIVE CREDITS FOR ARMS EXPORTS
description: The Bush Administration is asking Congress to authorize a Government agency to underwrite sales of military goods for the first time since the 1970's.

title: A Nuclear Path to Mideast Peace
description: How can Israel and its Arab neighbors be coaxed to the peace table? And how can all Mideast countries be coaxed to end, and reverse, their deadly arms race? Those were prime concerns for Secretary of State Baker on his peace mission last week -- and the two questions might have the same answer: negotiations over a nuclear-free zone in the Middle East.

title: Albania's Government Frees 120 of Its Political Prisoners
description: Communist Albania freed more than 120 political prisoners today, but opposition activists said the action fell short of a pledge to release all prisoners held for anti-Government activity.

title: Power Restored in Rochester
description: A state of emergency has been lifted around Rochester as electricity was restored to the last homeowners left without power by an ice storm two weeks ago. The ice storm that struck on March 3 knocked out power to 300,000 customers around Rochester. The Monroe County Executive, Thomas Frey, Saturday lifted a state of emergency that had been in effect since the storm hit. Thousands of Rochester residents were still without telephone service, said Diana Melville, a spokeswoman for the Rochester Telephone Corporation.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 18, 1991: MONDAY American Express Co Ameron Inc Del Bellsouth Corp Hartford Steam Boiler Hormel Geo A & Co Standard Prods Co Unocal Expl Corp

title: Our Big Appliances Are Made in U.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Anthony Wins Title By Routing Seton Hall
description: For about six minutes today, the third annual New Jersey Tournament of Champions boy's final looked like the perfect St. Patrick's matchup. Seton Hall Prep, the unbeaten Parochial A champion from West Orange, was leading St. Anthony of Jersey City, the seemingly unbeatable Parochial B champion.

title: Jackie Wackie Ran Despite High Fever
description: At least one mystery was cleared up today as the handlers of the nation's best 3-year-old thoroughbreds counted their casualties on the rocky road to the Kentucky Derby: The dismal performance Saturday by Jackie Wackie, who ran next to last in the Florida Derby after winning nine races in a row, was caused by a 102-degree fever, a cough and swollen glands.

title: Brazil Raises Some Prices
description: The Government of Brazil has announced price increases for steel and cement, signaling a gradual end to a strict price freeze imposed on Jan. 31.

title: Nets Turn Back To Woeful Ways
description: Having beaten the defending champion Detroit Pistons and the Washington Bullets in their last two games, the Nets were well poised tonight to win a third consecutive game for the first time this season. Their opponents were the Charlotte Hornets, who came into the game sharing with the Denver Nuggets the worst record in the National Basketball Association, 18-45.

title: Serious Training For Serious Tennis
description: IN years past, about the only serious training many tennis players did to get in shape and stay in shape was play tennis. Off-court work, if there was any, consisted of occasional distance runs, rope jumping and sit-ups. But that old curriculum is largely passe.

title: No Recession for Executive Pay
description: In the midst of a recession, with layoffs rising and corporate profits weak, pay in 1990 for the nation's top executives rose by bigger percentages than the wages of any other group of salaried American workers.

title: Family Circle Joins Hormel in a Promotion
description: Family Circle magazine has joined forces with George A. Hormel & Company, the processed foods company in Austin, Minn., to promote a special-edition Family Circle cookbook and to celebrate Hormel's 100th anniversary.

title: Celtics Hold Off Barkley and 76ers
description: Charles Barkley signed autographs on the bench, talked to the fans and the scorers and disagreed with the officials on several of the fouls they charged him with today.

title: E. Michigan Wins Its Big One
description: Call it the improbable force versus the indomitable object.

title: Rangers Lose a Game, First Place and Kocur
description: The Rangers not only fell out of first place in the Patrick Division for the first time in 155 days yesterday, losing by 4-2 to the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden; they also lost the pugnacious Joey Kocur, whom they traded for March 5 in hopes of solving their Stanley Cup puzzle, for the rest of the regular season.

title: Pressmen Union At Daily News Approves Cuts
description: The pressmen's union, which would lose more jobs than all but two other unions at The Daily News, last night ratified an agreement that its leaders reached last week with Robert Maxwell.

title: Devotees Seek One Stamp in a Million
description: Donald W. Smith remembers a stamp collector who assured him at a convention that, unlike the other hobbyists there, she had a truly unique specialty.

title: Maybe It's the Mexico City Water
description: THEY are joined as famed images of the 1960's. Now, 23 years after they first burst into the sports world's consciousness by winning Olympic gold medals, Mark Spitz and George Foreman are paired again.

title: Lafayette Journal; Soviet Choices Tough, Even for a Mock U.N.
description: Being a Soviet delegate to the United Nations is perplexing work these days.

title: St. John's Rolls On; U.N.L.V. Holds Off Georgetown; Redmen Top Texas To Gain Round of 16
description: From the time the basketballs begin to bounce in October, dozens of teams from coast to coast spend hundreds of hours working to achieve the kind of results that St. John's created today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A concert and dinner at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington featured short pieces by several of the nation's leading artists, which led the violinist ISAAC STERN to ask, "How often in this city do you see time limited?"

title: Virgin Atlantic Airways Set For First National U.S. Drive
description: VIRGIN ATLANTIC AIRWAYS plans to step up its battle with airline goliaths like British Airways in its first national ad campaign in the United States. The campaign will begin Friday.

title: Bill of Wrongs
description: American conservatives have complained for years about constitutional protections for those suspected of crime. Judges enforcing the rules hobble the police, they say. The Bush Administration is pressing Congress right now to limit some rights.

title: 'Hey, Think Fast!' Is Not So Simple
description: FOR those boys and girls who have been spending the winter oiling their baseball gloves, swinging tennis racquets in their living rooms within inches of fragile lamps or dribbling a basketball in their bedrooms, much to the enjoyment of those living beneath them, the news that the snow on playgrounds is starting to melt whets the appetite for good times ahead.

title: New Turnpike Tolls Infuriate New Jersey Drivers
description: Richard Story pays a toll on the way to his office, half an hour down the road in Edison, N.J. He pays again if his salesman's job takes him back out on the road. And he pays yet again when he hits the road for the trip home at night.

title: A Coup for British Airways In Agreement on Heathrow
description: Shares of British Airways P.L.C. dropped sharply last week after the news that American Airlines and United Airlines would be allowed to fly to London's Heathrow Airport. But the United States made enormous concessions that may greatly benefit British Airways, as well as American consumers, for many years, partly at the expense of American carriers.

title: DIALOGUE: The Party's Politics The Democrats Are Spoiling the Beef; Don't Argue With Victory
description: The guns had barely fallen silent in the gulf before the political artillery was rolled out here at home. Republicans, abandoning the bipartisanship that prevailed during the fighting, have begun denouncing the Democrats as the party of appeasement. A number of Democrats, unwilling to accept the clear lessons of the war, have chosen this peculiarly inappropriate moment to resuscitate the argument that we should have given sanctions more of a chance, and that because we didn't, we will never know if they would have worked.

title: Boy Escapes, Then Dies in Fire
description: An 11-year-old boy who escaped a fire in his family's home on Saturday was killed when he went back inside the burning building. It was not known why the boy, Damion Binnon, went back inside after he, his parents and two brothers fled, said Officer Paul Wolak of the Pittsburgh police. The boy's parents, Eloy and Kathy Binnon, and brother Brandon, 9, suffered smoke inhalation. Another brother, Eloy Jr., 2 1/2, was hospitalized in good condition.

title: Review/Film; Deep Into Apparently Ordinary Lives
description: At the center of "Fallen From Heaven" is a pig as big as a cow. In most Latin-American films, the presence of such a bizarre creature would be a cue to bring on the magical realism, to make the pig fly or at least have some smart conversations. But one of the brightest touches in this alluring film from Peru is that it teeters on the brink of magic without ever resorting to impossible events. Though "Fallen From Heaven" ultimately takes the shape of a dark comic parable about life, fate and death, the route to those giant themes is wry, twisty and lighter than a pig's wings.

title: MCI Discounts Expected On Numbers Called Often
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is expected to announce a service today that will offer residential long-distance customers discount rates for numbers they frequently call.

title: Nueva Germania Journal; From a Bigot's Planting, a Garden of Assimilation
description: A century after its start as a Germanic utopia, the former colony of Nueva Germania now languishes as the least German of all German settlements in Paraguay.

title: Review/Theater; Resisting the Vortex By Living a Life Of Books and Anger
description: One need not be a jaded constituent of New York's literati to recognize Isaac Geldhart, the esteemed publisher and embattled Jewish father who stands at the center of "The Substance of Fire," the new play by Jon Robin Baitz at Playwrights Horizons. A childhood refugee from the "wrecked world" of the Holocaust, Isaac came to New York an orphan, reinvented himself as a bon vivant, married well and found a measure of fame and fortune as a rigorously independent champion of literary books that wouldn't be caught dead on a best-seller list. By the late 1980's, when Mr. Baitz's play unfolds, Isaac has long since been a brand name in the culture industry. He is one of those survivors, of post-war American intellectual firestorms no less than Old Europe's bloodbaths, who run Manhattan with an iron tongue.

title: Industry's Top Mystery: Book Sales
description: WHO knows what's going on in publishing? Well, to be honest, nobody does.

title: Haydn's 'Seven Last Words'
description: The Central City Chorus will perform the choral version of Haydn's "Seven Last Words of Our Savior on the Cross" on Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. Charles Pilling is to conduct the 50-member chorus and orchestra, with the soloists Mary Ellen Callahan, soprano; Deborah Andrews, mezzo; Darrell Lauer, tenor, and Richard Christopher, baritone. Admission is $10. Information: 838-0808.

title: Publishers Are Looking to Libraries for Growth
description: About 25 executives from Bantam Doubleday Dell will each spend two days working in libraries this spring and summer. "Libraries are an important market for our books," said Jack Hoeft, the company's president and chief operating officer, "so we thought it's time to get to know them better."

title: Japan Shuts U.S. Rice Exhibition
description: The United States Rice Council reluctantly withdrew its exhibition here on Saturday after Japan's Agriculture Minister threatened the exhibitors with arrest for displaying 10 pounds of American rice.

title: Howe Too Tense, Merrill Says
description: The morning after Steve Howe was bombed for five runs in one inning in a loss to the Chicago White Sox, the Yankees' manager, Stump Merrill, conceded that something was awry with the relief pitcher.

title: Albany's New Best Friend: Congress, Near Redistricting
description: As happens every 10 years when the Legislature turns its attention to reapportionment, the members of New York's Congressional delegation are returning to Albany with the predictability of the swallows to Capistrano.

title: Closing the Door on China Won't Help Anyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Easing of Inflation Is Expected
description: Although many analysts and credit market participants attribute the rise in bond yields since the end of February to worries about inflation, most expect price pressures to ease for the rest of the year.

title: U.S. Expecting Hussein To Be Out by Year's End
description: As the United States and its Persian Gulf war allies move toward a permanent cease-fire with Iraq, the Bush Administration is basing its actions and its policy on the expectation that President Saddam Hussein will fall from power by the end of the year, officials said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Bernard Chaus Inc. said it had signed an interim line of credit for up to $45 million with its current lending banks. * Browning-Ferris Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million in debt securities.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Consumer Prices...Feb. Housing Starts...Feb. Wednesday Merchandise Trade...Jan. Thursday None Friday None

title: Juan Bosch Quits Party Post
description: Former President Juan Bosch resigned on Saturday as head of his Dominican Liberation Party. Mr. Bosch, 83 years old, lost the presidential election last May to Joaquin Balaguer, 84, of the Dominican Reformist Party.

title: 'Dead' Marine Surrenders, but Mystery Lives
description: The questions began on a May morning in 1987 when an empty kayak belonging a Marine sergeant washed up along the coast near the town of Mendocino.

title: Landmarking Preserves America's Heritage; The Bad Neighbor
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Everyday $2,000 Dresses

title: BRIEFS
description: * Furr's Inc., Lubbock, Tex., a retail grocery concern, completed the sale of its warehouse and transportation assets to Fleming Cos., Oklahoma City, a food wholesaler; the spinoff of 70 of its stores in a management-led buyout, and the sale of seven stores in Abilene, Tex. * Manville Forest Products Corp., West Monroe, La., a unit of Manville Corp., acquired a machinery-based packaging business from Federal Paper Board Co., Montvale, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.

title: German Official Meets With Gorbachev on Arms
description: Suggesting a degree of concern over the recent course of Soviet foreign policy, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany today spent more than three hours with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev discussing the stalemate in arms controls and other problems.

title: A Legacy of Ashes: The Uranium Mines Of Eastern Germany
description: BARREN and black, the ashen hills of nuclear waste stand like treeless offspring of the wooded mountains that cradle the towns and villages of this German frontier region.

title: Market Place; Behind the Drop In Proxy Fights
description: AN even greater decline in proxy battles for corporate control is expected this year than last, when the number fell to 35 from a peak of 41 in 1989. Indeed, so far only 12 are under way or have been threatened.

title: Telephone Records Conflict In Teacher's Murder Trial
description: The prosecution and defense in the Carolyn Warmus trial today produced conflicting telephone records from Jan. 15, 1989, one appearing to link the defendant to the slaying of Betty Jeanne Solomon on that day, the second appearing to offer an alibi.

title: Retirement at Fed Bank
description: Roger Guffey, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City since 1976, has announced that he will retire this year. Three members of the bank's board have been named to a search committee to recommend Mr. Guffey's successor, according to a statement released today. Mr. Guffey, 61 years old, joined the bank in 1968 as vice president and general counsel. He was later named senior vice president and was appointed president in February 1976, succeeding George H. Clay. As president of the regional reserve bank, Mr. Guffey oversees Federal Reserve operations in the 10th Federal Reserve District, which includes Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Wyoming, northern New Mexico and western Missouri.

title: Review/Dance; A Touch of Whimsy From the Royal Ballet
description: Two masterworks by Sir Frederick Ashton and the United States premiere of " 'Still Life' at the Penguin Cafe," a zany delight with a serious message by David Bintley, the Royal Ballet's resident choreographer, made up the British company's second program in its current season at the Kennedy Center.

title: James River to Sell Special Paper Unit
description: The James River Corporation of Virginia agreed to sell its specialty papers business as part of previously announced cutbacks totaling $1.3 billion. Twenty-two mills will be sold to Specialty Coatings Group Inc. for $285 million in cash and $52 million in stock. James River will also receive operating leases on five of the mills as part of the agreement.

title: Bridge
description: All play in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals was expected to be completed by midnight Sunday, but it did not work out that way. An appeal committee had to consider a problem in the Women's Swiss Teams, and its decision left two teams technically tied for the title. An eight-board playoff was necessary to decide which team would qualify for a contest that will eventually decide the American representation in the 1992 World Championships.

title: INSIDE
description: Supreme Court Will Rule On Prayer at Graduations In a new look at the constitutional boundary between church and state, the Supreme Court agreed to decide whether graduation ceremonies at public schools can include prayers that mention God. Page A16.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Boise Cascade Corp., Boise, Idaho, will redeem its 13.125 percent notes due in 1994 on April 15 at 100 percent principal amount. * Chubb Corp., Warren, N.J., will redeem all of its 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated notes due in 1993 at 102.3571 percent of the principal amount of the notes plus accrued interest to the April 15 redemption date.

title: Abitibi-Price
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., the Canadian newsprint producer based in Toronto, said it would close about 200,000 metric tons of its production capacity in 1991, possibly taking one of its newsprint mills out of service. Analysts said Abitibi-Price had about 1.9 million metric tons of capacity, or 12 percent of the North American newsprint market. A number of newsprint companies have announced temporary shutdowns to reduce inventories and strengthen prices. Newsprint demand has been slack because of declines in newspaper advertising and more foreign competition.

title: COPTERS A THREAT, U.S. WARNS IRAQIS
description: The United States has told Iraq that the use of helicopter gunships against Iraqi insurgents represents a "threat to coalition forces" that could draw American military action against the helicopters, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Historically, our cities have been the machines of mobility for low-income people. Now those machines seem to be broken." -- Dr. Mark Hughes of Princeton University, commenting on inner-city despair in Milwaukee. [ D22:1. ]

title: Church Aide Testifies Flake Had a Duty to Live in Style
description: As pastor of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake was duty bound to "look well, dress well and drive well," the church's business manager, Howard Henderson, testified yesterday at Mr. Flake's trial on charges of embezzlement and tax evasion.

title: Separate Board At Unisys Unit
description: The Unisys Corporation today created a separate board of directors for its military business unit.

title: Chrysler Unit Still on Block After Rebuff by Mitsubishi
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was discussing the sale of a stake in the Chrysler Financial Corporation with a couple of potential suitors but that Japan's Mitsubishi Motor Corporation had said it was not interested.

title: Argentines Visit Graves in Falklands
description: Nearly nine years after their sons, brothers, husbands and fathers died in the war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands, 358 Argentines traveled to the windswept islands in the South Atlantic today to pay their respects to their dead.

title: Prices Fall in Sluggish Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose in sluggish trading yesterday, deepening the negative tone that emerged late last week.

title: Fannie Mae Prices 2 Remic Offerings
description: About $600 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities, known as Remics, were priced yesterday by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) in two separate offerings.

title: Another Vegas Verdict
description: Through the years, many boxing people have been suspicious of what has come to be known as a "Vegas verdict." Sometimes it involved which boxer was awarded a decision, as Sugar Ray Leonard was over Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Sometimes it involved which boxer had been awarded more points than he deserved, as Gerry Cooney was before Larry Holmes registered a 13th-round knockout.

title: Connecticut Senator Blurs the Party Line
description: In a city where political brand names are important identification, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut might be labeled Brand X.

title: Securities Ban for Milken
description: Michael R. Milken, the "junk bond" financier who is serving a 10-year prison sentence for his part in Wall Street's biggest scandal, has been permanently barred from the securities industry.

title: U.S. Reviewing FNN Deal
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was investigating for possible antitrust violations the proposed purchase of the Financial News Network by its biggest competitor.

title: Round of 16 Truly Sweet for Redmen, Huskies
description: Back when 20 victories could be considered a standard of excellence for a college basketball team, a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament was enough for a school to consider a season a success.

title: A Full-Length 'Oz' for TV
description: It's not melting! It's not melting! In fact, "The Wizard of Oz" is getting longer, thanks to Federal law.

title: Patrick McEnroe Advances By Beating Becker, 6-1, 6-4
description: Boris Becker, his booming serve strangely subject to ambush, his manner more diffident than defiant, absorbed a two-set lesson from the energetic Patrick McEnroe tonight in the third round of the Lipton International Players championships.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Miscellany
description: * Rivera & Robinson Communications Inc., New York, has changed its named to Rivera & Rivera Communications Inc., to reflect full ownership of the company by Arnold E. Rivera, president and chief executive. Mr. Rivera had previously been one of three partners.

title: Landmarking Preserves America's Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 11 about the publication of a 30-year-old speech by Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, misstated his age. He is 86, not 88.

title: Review/Concert; 18th-Century Swedish Bill By Vineyard Musicke Group
description: Early-instrument groups tend to keep their sights fixed on the German, Italian and French repertories, with occasional dollops of English and Spanish music for variety. But Vineyard Musicke, the resident early-music ensemble at the Vineyard Theater, cast its net a bit further last Tuesday evening, when it played a program of 18th-century Swedish music.

title: Budd Ready for Return
description: Looking tanned, fit and confident, Zola Budd has served notice she will be a force in women's track if South Africa is readmitted into international competition. Now married and known as Zola Budd-Pieterse, the 24-year-old recently set a South African mile record of 4 minutes 27 seconds.

title: Q&A
description: Sand and Stars

title: Reports Show Poor Visibility in Detroit Air Crash
description: Federal investigators made public new information today suggesting that visibility at Detroit Metropolitan Airport might have been below the legal minimum on Dec. 3, when a Northwest Airlines DC-9 jetliner got lost in the fog, wandered onto the wrong runway and was struck by another Northwest jet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AL HIRSCHFELD , whose sophisticated, elegant caricatures have become synonymous with the Broadway theater, received the Edwin Booth Award from the City University of New York Graduate School yesterday. The award, presented amid a gathering of his friends from the theater, is given annually for contributions to the theater. Mr. Hirschfeld, 87 years old, is the first visual artist to receive it.

title: Edward B. Blau; Furniture Dealer, 83
description: Edward B. Blau, an office furniture dealer in Newark for more than 60 years, died on Friday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: The VDT Miscarriage Scare
description: Video display terminals have been exonerated as a threat to pregnant women -- at least for the time being. The ubiquitous office machines have been the object of widespread apprehension, especially since a reputable study in 1988 found that women who worked on them for long periods had more miscarriages than women who did not. But now an even more persuasive study has concluded the opposite. Women who worked on VDT's ran no more risk of miscarriages than those in similar jobs without terminals.

title: Troubled Unisys Names Chief Operating Officer
description: The Unisys Corporation appointed Reto Braun president and chief operating officer yesterday. He had been elected to the board of the troubled computer company last month, causing analysts to speculate that the board was positioning Mr. Braun for a position of increased authority.

title: Treated Mosquito Nets May Offer Best Hope Against Malaria
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Stake In Publisher
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had purchased a 26 percent stake in Dorling Kindersley Ltd., a London-based book publisher.

title: Brad Crandall; Broadcaster, 62
description: Brad Crandall, a talk-show host on WNBC Radio in the 1960's, died on Thursday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 62 years old and lived in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a visit to Kuwait by 12 members of the House of Representatives misstated their party affiliations in some copies. There were 10 Republicans and 2 Democrats.

title: Challenges Lie Ahead, Tagliabue Tells Owners
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, in his address to the National Football League owners today at their annual meeting, painted a rosy picture of the league's success last season and challenged the owners with key issues that he said would be crucial to the league's continued growth and stability in the 90's.

title: Esasky Connects
description: The outburst was only slightly less emotional than it would have been had the Atlanta Braves clinched a division championship. Nick Esasky had just lined a single to left field, and his friends and teammates were ecstatic. "That's a boy, Nick," one player yelled toward first base.

title: Property of a Homeless Man Is Private, Hartford Court Says
description: Connecticut's highest court ruled today that the possessions of a homeless man living under a highway bridge are protected by the same constitutional rights to privacy as the belongings of any house or apartment dweller, even though the man's "home" was technically a public place anyone could enter.

title: An Appeals Court Reverses Convictions in '89 GAF Case
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday reversed the stock-manipulation convictions of the GAF Corporation and a senior executive. The case was part of the scandals that rocked Wall Street after the fall of Ivan F. Boesky, the former stock speculator.

title: Israeli General Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: Only days after the Israeli Air Force began readjusting from a high state of alert during the Persian Gulf war, its officers are riveted by a new problem: a guilty plea by one of its most senior officers in a multimillion-dollar fraud and bribery scandal involving United States military contractors.

title: Stretching Of Greece Detected
description: GREECE is growing. Using navigational satellites to measure the movements of 15 monuments in a century-old triangulation network, British and Greek scientists have found that southern Greece has stretched more than three feet north to south since the original survey was made in 1890. The Peloponnesus appears to have moved southwest, relative to the Greek mainland to the north.

title: Du Pont Ends Use Of Cetus Process
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif., said that E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company had agreed to stop selling research products that use Cetus's technology for multiplying sequences of genetic material. The Geneamp polymerase chain reaction, or P.C.R., technology, is used in new-drug discovery, diagnosis and forensics.

title: 1,970 Will Be Cut From Air Europe
description: Nearly 2,000 employees of Air Europe, Britain's largest independent airline, will lose their jobs because of the collapse of its parent company, court-appointed administrators said. Air Europe is part of the International Leisure Group P.L.C., which was badly hurt by the gulf war's effect on tourism. The airline suspended its flights 10 days ago.

title: Tremor at Paramount: No. 2 Official Is Named
description: In a surprise move yesterday, Paramount Communications Inc. named Stanley Jaffe as president and chief operating officer, making him No. 2 behind the chairman, Martin S. Davis.

title: Yugoslavia's Military Drops Out of Sight
description: The supreme command of the Yugoslav armed forces has sealed itself off and remained out of contact with the country's highest civilian authorities for the last three days, the national executive body said today, expressing its displeasure with what was described as the military's vanishing act.

title: Books of The Times; A Humane Philosopher Argues for Pluralism
description: The Crooked Timber of Humanity Chapters in the History of Ideas By Isaiah Berlin Edited by Henry Hardy. 277 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Jean Tennyson Dies; Singer and Patron, 86
description: Jean Tennyson Boissevain, an operatic soprano and patron of the arts, died on Saturday at her home in La Tour-de-Peilz, Switzerland. She was 86 years old.

title: 70,000 Germans Protest Ecomomy in East
description: More than 70,000 people gathered in eastern German cities tonight in demonstrations harkening back to the pro-democracy protests of late 1989. But this time, they demanded an end to economic deprivation and pledged to turn out every Monday until the region's troubled economy improves.

title: Review/Theater; All the Best of Kander and Ebb
description: John Kander and Fred Ebb have reliably been turning out catchy, jazzy Broadway songs for more than 25 years now, but anyone who is not a musical-theater fanatic would have to think twice to recall the titles of their shows. With the single, whopping exception of "Cabaret" -- their second Broadway effort, in 1967 -- the Kander-Ebb musicals have been also-rans like "The Happy Time," "Zorba," "Chicago," "The Act," "Woman of the Year." Not flops, for the most part, and never embarrassments, just average entertainments and star vehicles that linger for a season or two before being forgotten by everyone but the buffs.

title: David Parkinson, 79, Engineer and Inventor
description: David B. Parkinson, an engineer who in the 1940's invented an electromechanical device for directing antiaircraft guns that significantly increased the accuracy of weapons, died Sunday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 79 years old.

title: S.E.C. Acts On Executive
description: The Securities and Exchange Commisssion won a permanent injunction today against the former chairman of Borman's Inc. for issuing a press release that fraudulently said he knew no reason for the jump in Borman's stock price even though he had agreed to buyout talks.

title: Italy Seeks Extradition in Achille Lauro Case
description: Italy has asked Greece to hand over a Palestinian guerrilla convicted in absentia in the hijacking of a cruise ship in 1985, the police here said today.

title: E. S. Adams Dies at 80; Held Senior Bank Posts
description: E. Sherman Adams, a retired economist and senior banking officer at several institutions, died on Friday at Florida Hospital North in Altamonte Springs. He was 80 years old and lived in Mount Dora, Fla., and Preston, Conn.

title: A's Optimistic
description: Sandy Alderson, general manager of the Oakland A's, said yesterday in Phoenix that the club may be able to resolve its differences with Rickey Henderson.

title: French TV Seeks a Slice of the Hollywood Pie
description: The idea is quite simple: If American movies are invariably the biggest box-office hits in France, if 40 percent of movies shown on French television are American, why not invest directly in Hollywood productions? Two new production companies with ties to French television channels have decided to do just that.

title: Money and Meters: One Firm, Many Companies - A Special Report; Winning New York Contracts: Hard Questions for a Supplier
description: For the last three years, while New York City awarded contract after contract to the tiny Vanguard Meter Service company of Kentucky, complaints were being lodged inside and outside of city government about the company's performance on what now amounts to more than $50 million of water-meter installation work.

title: Triple for Abbott
description: Jim Abbott, who has only one hand but pitches in the major leagues for the California Angels, hit a 400-foot triple yesterday in an exhibition game against the San Francisco Giants at Scottsdale, Ariz. It was Abbott's first hit in a major-league uniform. He bats only during exhibition games against National League teams, when no designated hitter is used. (AP)

title: BASEBALL: A Yankee and a Met Labor to Round Out Their Mastery of the Game; Espinoza Has to Be a More Selective Hitter
description: Alvaro Espinoza did not own a baseball glove until he was 16 years old. He would grab any available glove as a kid in Venezuela and play without error or worry. Not having a steady piece of leather failed to hamper him.

title: Physicists Close In on World's Fastest Supercomputer
description: ON a workbench here at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory physicists are running final tests on a notebook-sized module that will soon become the basic building block of the world's fastest supercomputer. This fall it will begin aiding theorists in refining their understanding of the subatomic structure of matter.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. 76ers Stop Magic With Late Spurt Charles Barkley scored 24 points and Ron Anderson led an 18-4 surge to start the fourth period as the 76ers beat the Orlando Magic, 99-91, last night in Philadelphia. Leading by 69-65 after three quarters, Philadelphia made the score 77-69 on two free throws by Hersey Hawkins. Then the 76ers scored 10 consecutive points to lead, 87-69, with 4:57 remaining. (AP) Bulls 121, Nuggets 108: Michael Jordan scored 15 of his 31 points in the third quarter as Chicago coasted to its 8th victory in a row and 24th consecutive home victory. (AP) Mavericks 104, Kings 86: Sacramento tied the league single-season record with their 28th consecutive road loss. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Providence Tops West Virginia Marvin Saddler scored 21 points and the Providence Friars, playing at home, used an 18-8 surge in the second half to put away the West Virginia Mountaineers, 85-79, last night in a second-round game of the National Invitation Tournament. The Friars (19-12) got 6 points apiece from Saddler and Corey Floyd in the spree that turned a 64-62 lead into an 82-70 advantage with 2:15 left. West Virginia (17-14) fought back to 83-79 with 47 seconds left, but missed four successive shots in the last 15 seconds. (AP) Oklahoma 89, Cincinnati 81: Terry Evans rescued the Sooners (18-14) late in regulation at home, then Bryan Sallier and Brent Price did the damage in overtime of the second-round game. (AP) Stanford 80, Wisconsin 72: Adam Keefe, a 6-foot-9-inch junior, hit his 21-points-a-game average in the first half and finished with 33 points and 14 rebounds as the Cardinal (17-13) beat the Badgers (15-15) in a second-round game at Madison, Wis. (AP) Southern Illinois 72, Southwest Missouri St. 69: Sterling Mahan scored 15 points and Rick Shipley scored 13 points and grabbed 13 rebounds as Southern Illinois (18-13) won a second-round game in Springfield, Mo. Southwest Missouri finished at 22-12. (AP) Arkansas St. 58, Memphis St. 57: Bobby Gross connected on a 3-pointer to put Arkansas State ahead to stay, then hit the clinching free throw with 11 seconds left in a second-round game at Memphis. (AP) Colorado 83, Wyoming 75: Stevie Wise scored 21 points, including 3 on free throws in the final minute, as the Buffaloes (17-13), playing at home, defeated the Cowboys (20-12) in a second-round game. (AP) Oklahoma City Wins N.A.I.A. Title: Mike McCoy and Eric Manuel scored 16 points apiece, pacing a balanced and unrelenting attack that carried Oklahoma City past Central Arkansas, 77-74, last night in the championship game of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics in Kansas City, Mo. The Chiefs (34-3), winning their first N.A.I.A. title, led the Bears of Conway, Ark., almost the entire way. (AP)

title: How Milwaukee Has Thrived While Leaving Blacks Behind
description: This proud workhorse of a city, with its well-swept streets and chic new office towers, has become a striking antithesis to the recession on the coasts. It has an unemployment rate well below the national average, a booming downtown, a generous budget surplus and more jobs than skilled people to fill them.

title: BASEBALL: A Yankee and a Met Labor to Round Out Their Mastery of the Game; Magadan Wants to Be a Hit on Field
description: Dave Magadan couldn't believe the words printed on the pages of the preseason publications. Incredulous, his stare ate up the paragraphs, unable to digest the contents. Infuriated, he bought more, opened the covers and then closed his eyes against the anger flooding into his face.

title: Review/Film Festival; A Jilted Czech in a Case of Overkill
description: The stunning monster at the heart of "Time of the Servants," a Czechoslovak film that can be seen tonight at 9 P.M. and tomorrow at 6 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films series, first appears as a plain, desperately unhappy young woman. Dana (Ivana Chylkova) has just been jilted. Her friends Milan (Karel Roden) and Lenka (Jitka Asterova), a sweet and devoted couple, make the terrible mistake of offering their sympathy.

title: Jewish Emigration Resuming This Week, Ethiopians Say
description: The Ethiopian Embassy here said today that the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel would resume this week after a sudden pause that gave rise to concern in Israel and the United States.

title: 76ers Honor Chamberlain By Retiring The No. 13
description: It was Valentine's Day for Goliath.

title: Review/Fashion; Paris When It Sizzles: 3 Shows That Soared
description: With blockbuster shows, Claude Montana, Christian Lacroix and Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel put top spin on the soaring fall ready-to-wear collections here.

title: In Kuwait, Ramadan Has a Bitter Taste
description: On the first day of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of daylight fasting and prayer, Kuwaitis were busy Sunday standing in half-mile-long lines, waiting for bread, rice, sugar and oil.

title: Gulf Is Swept for Mines In the Aftermath of War
description: In a dark, cramped room deep inside this old minesweeper, the green glow from two sonar screens pulsates as the search goes on for what has turned out to be Iraq's most enduring weapon of the Persian Gulf war: mines.

title: Iran Says Iraqi Leader Will Soon Fall to Rebels
description: Amid reports of new rebel gains in Iraq's mostly Shiite Muslim south, Iran's ranking cleric declared today that President Saddam Hussein would soon fall because insurgents had captured so many Government weapons that they could not be defeated.

title: Warner to Add Data on Drug
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it would give the Government new information this week about the company's new Alzheimer's disease drug. On Friday, a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee had recommended against approval of the drug, called tacrine.

title: Sudan Bows to Pressure and Allows Famine Relief
description: With nearly eight million people threatened by drought-induced famine this year, the Sudanese Government of Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan al-Bashier has bowed to international pressure and agreed to allow a large new relief effort in the country, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: Unions at Daily News Head for Finish Line
description: With members of most of the striking unions at The Daily News set to vote today on new labor contracts, lawyers for some of the unions tried yesterday to work out last-minute details on the contracts with representatives of Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who is buying the newspaper.

title: Gains Seen in Study of African Sleeping Sickness Parasite
description: A MONG the many parasites that infect and kill human beings, perhaps none is so bizarre as the wormlike creature that causes African sleeping sickness.

title: AMR Proposes $1 Billion Offering
description: The AMR Corporation, the Chicago-based holding company for American Airlines, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of up to $1 billion in debts and warrants to purchase debt securities.

title: Small Radioactive Release at Nuclear Plant
description: A small amount of radioactive material was released today at the James A. FitzPatrick nuclear plant, officials said.

title: Nike's Net Is Up by 12%
description: Nike Inc., the nation's largest marketer of athletic shoes, reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped 12 percent, but the performance disappointed Wall Street and Nike's stock price tumbled.

title: How Much Cream in Ice Cream?
description: It's cold and creamy like ice cream but contains little or no cream. Does the less fatty frozen dessert nonetheless deserve to be called ice cream? This question now confronts the Food and Drug Administration as it begins to rethink its "standards of identity" for common food products in light of growing concerns about diet and health.

title: Margaret Kalil; Soprano, 66
description: Margaret Kalil, a soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Thursday at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Montreal. She was 66 years old and lived in Montreal.

title: Home Loan Bank's Debt Securities
description: The Office of Finance of the Federal Home Loan Bank is offering $2.996 billion in debt securities in five separate issues.

title: Our Towns; A Goal of Youth: To Be the Best In Jumping for Joy
description: Here's a story that's really great about some girls you'll appreciate. They work real hard. They dance and cheer. And all of it just happened right here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Green-Thumbed Ecologists Resurrect Vanished Habitats
description: HUMANS can never return to the Garden of Eden, and vanished ecosystems may never be totally restored. But a surprising degree of recovery can be achieved, as recent ventures in ecological restoration by green-thumbed amateurs and scientists attest.

title: Making a Portrait of a Many-Faced Genius
description: "Writing about Picasso is a minefield," said John Richardson, whose bravura biography of the artist has received glowing reviews.

title: History in Review
description: AS educated adults, we of course know the dates and significance of such landmarks in American history as the Homestead Act (1862) and the Clayton Antitrust Act (1914). But children of high-school age may need help that we are too, uh, busy to provide.

title: The Earl of Cromer Is Dead at 72; Former Head of Bank of England
description: The Third Earl of Cromer, a former head of the Bank of England and a former Ambassador to the United States, died on Saturday at his home in London. He was 72 years old.

title: Landmarking Preserves America's Heritage; The Great Lost Spirits
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Olympic Ban May Be Ended
description: South Africa's banishment from the Olympics for more than 20 years could end as early as next February with a limited number of its athletes participating in the Albertville Winter Games in France.

title: In Messages, Officers Banter After Beating in Los Angeles
description: Police officers who had just beaten a black motorist were relaxed and even jocular in their communications with each other and with a desk officer, according to transcripts released by the police today.

title: Arts Agency Sued Over Decency Standard
description: A statute requiring the National Endowment for the Arts to consider "general standards of decency" when awarding Federal grants was challenged in a lawsuit filed today as an unconstitutional restriction on freedom of expression.

title: Three Finals In P.S.A.L.
description: After five months of competition, 97 public high schools from the five boroughs of New York have been whittled down to just six survivors for the city championship basketball games of the Public Schools Athletic League at Madison Square Garden this evening.

title: First-Time Buyers Aid Home Sales
description: Lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes are pushing first-time buyers back into the housing market again after many years.

title: Careers; Students Find Job Search Much Harder
description: CORPORATE recruiting on most campuses is way down, according to Richard J. Lewis, dean of both the college of business and graduate school of business administration at Michigan State University.

title: A New Look At an Enigma Of the Night
description: PROBABLY since the dawn of the human race, children have asked their elders why the daytime sky is blue and the night sky is dark. Parents have not been alone in floundering for answers; while science finally explained the blue sky a century ago, physicists are still pondering the night-sky conundrum.

title: Macy Profit Tied to Bond Repurchases
description: R. H. Macy & Company has repurchased more than $300 million of its bonds, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. Chain Is Said to Plan Tokyo Store
description: Japanese who love to emulate fashionable New Yorkers may get a chance to spend their yen just like Manhattan's shoppers: Bloomingdale's is coming to the Tokyo area, according to reports here today.

title: Apple May Widen Sale Of Operating Systems
description: Apple Computer Inc. is likely to become much more aggressive in competing with the Microsoft Corporation and others as a vendor of operating systems, the basic software for controlling computers, according to Apple officials and industry executives.

title: Itel to Buy Shares Held by Henley
description: The Itel Corporation, a transportation leasing concern based in Chicago, said it would pay $98 million, or $21 a share, for about 4.7 million of the 9.35 million Itel shares held by the Henley Group Inc. It also said it might buy the rest under modified terms at a later date.

title: Is Ball Lightning Real? Lab Is in Hot Pursuit
description: FOR centuries scientists have debated the existence of "ball lightning," a phenomenon thousands of witnesses claim to have seen but that has usually defied scientific investigation.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ford's Europe Leader Picked for New Post
description: The Ford Motor Company has reassigned Louis E. Lataif, president of Ford of Europe, to a new position that will lighten the load of Ford's president, Philip E. Benton Jr., who is recuperating from heart surgery.

title: New Buyers Give Lift To Housing Market
description: For the first time in years, lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes are making it possible for many first-time buyers to enter the housing market. Their buying is adding to the small spurt in real estate activity that was detected first in the sluggish Northeast late in January and that has now spread across the country.

title: To Albany Lobbyists, It's Only Good Times
description: There were more lobbyists than ever walking the halls of the State Capitol last year, and they earned a record amount of money for their attempts to influence state government.

title: Cartoonists On Malice And Mercy
description: They wear a deceptively mild-mannered air, these two skewers of the mighty.

title: Mover of Body's Cells May Hold Answers To Improved Healing
description: CELLS are normally content to stay put, but every so often they must crawl from one spot to another. Skin cells must crawl over a wound to help form a scab. Scavenger cells of the immune system must crawl through layers of tissue to reach hidden pockets of infection. Invasive cancer cells can burrow through membrane tissue and blood vessels to begin their vicious migration around the body.

title: Aldus to Fight Software Theft
description: The Aldus Corporation, a maker of software, today introduced a two-part plan to combat theft of its personal computer programs.

title: Convictions in Killing of Agent Are Upheld
description: The convictions of four men for the killing of an American drug agent in Mexico were upheld today by a Federal trial judge, who rejected arguments that the jury acted improperly.

title: New Education Chief Stresses Commitment
description: On his first day on the job, the new Education Secretary, Lamar Alexander, had lunch with a group of teachers, chatted informally with reporters and then told 500 Education Department employees that President Bush had taken time out from the Persian Gulf war to meet with him three times to discuss education.

title: William E. Harris; Educator, 60
description: William E. Harris, headmaster of the American School in London, died on Wednesday at St. Mary's Hospital in London. He was 60 years old.

title: Issue of Damages Is Not Settled, Justices Indicate
description: The Supreme Court indicated today that it does not regard a ruling two weeks ago as having settled the question of whether punitive damages violate the Constitution's guarantee of due process of law.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
MCI Communications Lets Other Shoe Drop
description: After a month of teaser commercials, television viewers learned last evening why the entertainers Regis Philbin and Kathie Lee Gifford, among other celebrities, were "making lists and sending them" to the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Contract Decision Postponed By Transportation Authority
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee yesterday postponed a decision on whether to award the Cubic Corporation of San Diego a contract to install an automatic fare-collection system on New York City's subways and buses.

title: Review/Film; TV Actor in Screen Debut In a Comedy Adventure
description: "If Looks Could Kill," a comedy-adventure film that marks the screen debut of the television star Richard Grieco ("21 Jump Street" and "Booker"), cannot decide if it's a spoof of James Bond movies or a piece of teen-age fluff.

title: How About de Milo?
description: Officials at NASA are soliciting the public for the names of notable women, after whom features on the planet Venus might be named.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Peter Scarperi has been promoted to chief financial officer of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide.* Bill Brunelle has been promoted to account executive at the Washington office of DDB Needham Worldwide.* Denise Leo has joined Chapman Direct Advertising, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam Inc., as senior vice president, account director.* Stan L. Friedman has been named vice president, marketing for Edward R. Pressman Film Corp.

title: Gooden Gets a New Offer
description: Dwight Gooden, star right-hander for the Mets, said today that the club had offered him a new proposal for a contract extension, one that would pay him $13.8 million for three years.

title: Type Without Tears
description: TRUETYPE is a new technology from Apple Computer Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation that greatly improves the way text appears on the computer screen and on printed documents. Truetype allows the user to make the type as big or small as needed, in any increment, and it gets rid of the jagged lines and broken curves that appear when you least want them.

title: Albany Agency Is Said to Allow State to Pollute
description: New York State's primary environmental regulatory agency is a "paper tiger" that inadequately enforces laws meant to stop other state agencies from polluting, a study by two Assembly legislative committees has concluded.

title: Holiday for Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Louisiana Governor Is a New V.I.P. in the G.O.P.
description: Republicans paraded their latest major convert, Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, around the nation's capital today, touting him as a new standard-bearer in a politically realigning South.

title: Have the Runnin' Rebels Used Up All of Their Romp?
description: In the wake of Nevada-Las Vegas' 8-point victory over Georgetown on Sunday in the West Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, several people are saying that the defending champions looked vunerable in earning their 43d straight victory.

title: Key Rates
Fine of French Rightist Increased After Appeal
description: An appeals court today upheld a judgment condemning a leader of the far right for referring to the Nazi gas chambers as a "detail of history," and increased his fine from about 18 cents to almost $167,000.

title: Encouraging Success in Chile
description: Until last year, Chile was South America's great exception -- the continent's last remaining military dictatorship. Chile, which has just celebrated the first anniversary of restored democratic rule, is still exceptional -- but in a positive sense. It has done more than any of its neighbors to merge democracy and market economics.

title: Iran's Chief Meets Lebanese Amid More Talk on Hostages
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran met in Teheran today with a leader of a pro-Iranian fundamentalist group, the Party of God, amid renewed speculation about a release of Western hostages held in Lebanon.

title: Fast Food Lightens Up But Sales Are Often Thin
description: When McDonald's starts selling its lower-fat hamburger nationwide next month, the sales could be as lean as the burger. At least that is what some restaurant industry analysts say and what the fast-food giant's rivals hope.

title: Bobsled Officials Forced to Resign
description: The United States Bobsled and Skeleton Federation's board of directors has resigned amid allegations of financial mismanagement, officials said today. The directors made the decision Saturday and the resignations are effective immediately, Jim Hickey, the federation's executive director, said.

title: Debt Accord For L.A. Gear
description: L.A. Gear Inc. said today that it had reached an accord with its bankers to revise a lending agreement the company broke when it reported a $7 million fourth-quarter loss.

title: Dinkins Sees Some Gain In Parade Role
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said today that those who had booed him and showered him with beer on Saturday when he marched with a gay Irish group in the St. Patrick's Day Parade were "people who wouldn't vote for me in the first place."

title: Fax Displacing Manhattan Bike Couriers
description: They whooshed through the streets of Manhattan, members of a mobile cottage industry born of the incompatibility of big-city gridlock and the need to get important papers from one office to another right away. They were bicycle messengers, fearless and feared as they raced through red lights, around vehicles and sometimes into pedestrians.

title: Norma Magid, 65; Writer and Lecturer
description: Norma Magid, a prize-winning writer and a lecturer at the University of Pennsylvania, died on Thursday at her home in West Philadelphia. She was 65 years old.

title: Review/Television; Troubles in Big-Time College Sports
description: The phenomenon of sports madness is hardly limited to the United States. That much is evident from those periodic outbursts of mayhem at soccer matches around the world. But, quite understandably, the domestic scene is more immediate and therefore more unsettling. The sports motif can be found even in the way this country goes to war. During the conflagration in the Persian Gulf, comparing battle maneuvers to a football game was commonplace. "We're ready," as one soldier put it for the television cameras, "on the field!"

title: First Fidelity In Spanish Sale
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation announced plans yesterday to raise $220 million in capital by selling 9.5 million common shares to Banco Santander, a Spanish bank.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
A New Partner For Follis & Verdi
description: Follis & Verdi, a small New York agency, has added Sal DeVito as a partner and creative director. It also changed its name to Follis DeVito Verdi.

title: Accounts
description: * Washington Mutual Savings Bank, Seattle, and a subsidiary, Mutual Travel Inc., to the Seattle office of McCann-Erickson, with a budget of $3 million to $5 million. * Mentadent toothpaste, owned by Elida Gibbs, a unit of Unilever N.V., the British-Dutch consumer company, to Lintas Hamburg, part of the New York-based Lintas Worldwide agency. Total billings are about $6 million. Lintas also handles Mentadent in Singapore.

title: Teacher Accused of Murder Says She Tried to End Affair With Boy
description: "I didn't set out to have an affair, but I did," Mrs. Smart said.

title: By Design; Think Paris: Think Beret
description: The classic men's Basque beret is the hit hat of the season. Women are wearing them, on both the streets and the runways of the fall fashion showings. Designers are decorating the berets with high-style touches.

title: Indicted Sergeant Was a Hero in '89
description: Less than two years ago, on an August night in a neighborhood considered one of the most violent in this city, Sgt. Stacey C. Koon of the Los Angeles police fired six blasts of a pistol toward a man armed with an AK-47 assault rifle.

title: Loss Is Expected At Boise Cascade
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation told securities analysts it expects a loss of about $16 million in the first quarter of 1991, largely because of a weak paper market. Net income for the first quarter of 1990 was $33.6 million, while income in the fourth quarter came to $4.8 million.

title: GORBACHEV GIVEN A PARTIAL VICTORY IN VOTING ON UNITY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appeared today to have won a bittersweet victory at best in his fight for national unity.

title: Security Council Reaches Broad Agreement on Terms of Cease-Fire
description: The five permanent Security Council members have reached broad agreement on the main elements of a new resolution for ending the Persian Gulf war and allowing the withdrawal of United States and allied forces, diplomats say.

title: Soviet Hard-Liner Chosen as Envoy to U.S.
description: Viktor G. Komplektov, a longtime Soviet diplomat with a hard-line reputation, has been chosen as the new Soviet Ambassador to Washington, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Miodrag Bulatovic; Novelist, 68
description: Miodrag Bulatovic, a Yugoslav novelist whose books were known for their graphic portrayals of sex, violence and decay and for their black humor, died on Thursday. He was 68 years old.

title: Katutura Journal; For Namibians, After the Battles, a Civics Class
description: As he makes the rounds of high schools in Windhoek, the Namibian capital, Pero Nampila lugs a cardboard carton stuffed with facts about this new nation's most precious possession.

title: Man Held in Killing of Nurse
description: A 52-year-old nurse was stabbed to death in her home on Sunday, and the man who lived with her was charged in the slaying, the police said today. The victim, Gloria Robb, was stabbed in the chest and back with a kitchen knife during an argument, the police said. The man, Lancelot Taylor, 40, a truck driver, asked a telephone operator to send the police to the home at 5:50 A.M. on Sunday. The police said he was waiting in the kitchen with the body when the officers arrived.

title: End-of-Season Suspense and Suspensions Keep Rangers Off Balance
description: Instead of using his muscle to push opponents around and his fists to protect his teammates -- the primary reasons the Rangers acquired him -- Joe Kocur has used his hockey stick and the results have been disheartening.

title: Let's Not Expect Computers to Do It All for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Mabel P. Jenkins, 98, Former Social Worker
description: Mabel Pickford Jenkins, a retired psychiatric social worker in New York City, died on Thursday at the University Village Retirement Center in Tulsa, Okla. She was 98 years old and had lived in Tulsa since 1984.

title: Soldier Who Served in Gulf Is Shot to Death in Detroit
description: A 22-year-old soldier on leave after serving in the Persian Gulf was shot to death today as he loaded his car, the police and a family member said.

title: Digital Expanding Its 'Tolerant' Line
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced an expanded line of "fault tolerant" computers, which keep working even if some parts fail. Such computers are used for airline reservations, Emergency 911 systems, automated teller networks and other uses that have to process hundreds of transactions a second without interruption. Digital's system uses mirror-image components so that if one-half of the system breaks down, the other half takes over.

title: Aid for Czech Business
description: President Bush named directors today for a Government-financed organization to help the growth of private businesses in Czechoslovakia. The directors of the Czech and Slovak-American Enterprise Fund are John R. Petty, former chairman and chief executive of the Marine Midland Bank; David O. Maxwell, former chairman and chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association; Julia M. Walsh, managing director of Tucker Anthony Inc.; former Representative Charles Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, and Milan Ondrus, retired vice president of the FMC Corporation.

title: Company Tied to Democratic Chief Wins Contract
description: A Louisiana-based sludge-treatment company with ties to the Democratic National Chairman, Ronald H. Brown, has been chosen for a $209.9 million contract with New York City, despite complaints from other cities about its performance.

title: Business and Health; Limiting Awards In Malpractice
description: SUPPORT is growing for new Federal legislation that would make it harder for plaintiffs to win multimillion-dollar awards in medical malpractice suits. A number of senators and House members are working on bills to change the system, which the American Medical Association says adds $21 billion a year to health-care spending. The association attributes $5.6 billion to malpractice insurance premiums and about $15 billion to defensive tactics that doctors take, like prescribing redundant diagnostic tests.

title: T-Shirts to Die For
description: First we had Operation Desert Storm T-shirts. Then we got baseball caps, sweatshirts and copyrighted yellow ribbon posters. Now we have Desert Storm trading cards. What does this mean? It means that few of us have actually stopped to ponder what our news stations and manufacturing companies have dropped on our toes in the form of trendy patriotism.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Mortgage Co., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of Chemical Banking Corp., named Stephen J. Rotella president and chief executive. * Gillette Co., Boston, named Robert G. King group vice president-Latin America for its international group.

title: 2 Airlines to Share Jets to Amsterdam
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines agreed to share the Dutch carrier's Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets when twice-weekly flights between Minneapolis-St. Paul and Amsterdam begin April 2. The deal is the first for the airlines since KLM joined a group of investors that bought Northwest in August 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As Congress is taking a second -- and more jaundiced -- look at a $500,000 grant to help put windswept, isolated Strasburg, N.D., on the tourist trail, the village's most famous son was enlisted by those who contend that tax dollars should not pay for fixing up his boyhood home. The National Taxpayers Union in Washington released a letter from LAWRENCE WELK , who just turned 88 years old, in which the retired band leader agreed with the union that the job should be done with private funds.

title: Manila to Sell Utility Stake
description: The Philippine Government, which is planning to sell several state companies, will partly privatize the country's biggest electricity company this year.

title: Slovak Roots: Here, There, And All Over
description: Although separatist passions are flaring in this narrow mountainous republic, its ethnic diversity would appear to make it an unlikely candidate for the raging problems of nationalism.

title: Citing Injury, Royals Decide to Release Jackson
description: The Kansas City Royals took a stunning step today, placing Bo Jackson, the oft-injured two-sport star, on unconditional-release waivers. A lawyer for the Players Association immediately challenged the propriety of the release.

title: Toll-Free Line For Gulf Parade
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins and the citizens committee that is planning the ticker-tape parade for soldiers returning from the Persian Gulf war announced yesterday the creation of a toll- free telephone number which the public can call to donate money to support the effort.

title: John D. Voelker, 87, Judge and Novelist
description: John D. Voelker, the Michigan jurist who wrote "Anatomy of a Murder" and other books under the name Robert Traver, died today. He was 87 years old.

title: Don't Strong-Arm Israel
description: Many well-meaning people imagine there could be peace in Palestine if only the U.S. could browbeat Israel into giving up its claims to yet another slice of the land promised to the Jewish people in the British Mandate. They are deluding themselves and in effect preparing the way for another war that would threaten Israel's destruction.

title: To the Plaintiffs, a Prayer's a Prayer
description: The 1986 graduation ceremony at Nathan Bishop Middle School here was going smoothly until the invocation speaker began thanking Jesus Christ for the students' accomplishments.

title: Tyson Stops Ruddock in 7th, but Only After a Rugged Fight
description: Controversy again.

title: Chess
description: Artur Yusupov had to make two recoveries to win his first-round match for world championship candidates against his fellow Soviet grandmaster Sergei Dolmatov in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.

title: Cahill Road Joins Convoy of Stars on Road to the Derby
description: A new star was streaking along the road to Kentucky today: Cahill Road, full brother to Unbridled, who won the Kentucky Derby last year, and stablemate to Fly So Free, widely ranked as the No. 1 favorite this year.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off a Bit
description: Stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were off slightly in early afternoon trading today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 45.9 points, or 0.17 percent, to 27,146.91.

title: Elizabeth Y. Cobb; Author, 76
description: Elizabeth Youngblood Cobb, a writer on home improvement, died on Sunday at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Conn. She was 76 years old and lived in Chester, Conn.

title: Solidarity's Spark Runs Strike
description: The crane operator whose 1980 dismissal touched off the labor protest that gave birth to Solidarity organized a wildcat strike today at the Gdansk shipyard. About 500 people joined the strike to demand higher pay and push for quicker privatization of the shipyard. It was organized by Anna Walentynowicz, who founded the Independent Trade Union after splitting with Solidarity and its former chairman, Lech Walesa, who is now president of Poland.

title: Lawmakers Back Square D Review
description: The Square D Company said a group of United States senators and representatives had lent support to a Justice Department antitrust review of a hostile takeover of the electrical equipment manufacturer by Groupe Schneider S.A. of France. Jerre L. Stead, Square D's chairman, said in a statement that the Congressmen had Square D operations in their states or districts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article on March 9 about the nation's unemployment rate misstated the effect of two interest rates on the Federal Reserve's control over the economy. The Federal Reserve loses some control when the discount rate is not below the Federal funds rate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTIN SCORSESE won three of the major awards given by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts in London on Sunday. He was chosen as best director for "Goodfellas," which was named best film. Its script, written by Mr. Scorsese and NICHOLAS PILEGGI , won the award for best adapted screenplay.

title: U.S. and Japan Seek Oil-Eating Microbes
description: MICHIGAN State University and the Research Development Corporation of Japan committed themselves yesterday to a $15 million research program aimed at developing microbes that can clean up oil spills and toxic waste.

title: Mexico Closes Giant Oil Refinery To Ease Pollution in the Capital
description: In a move to combat this city's air pollution crisis, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today ordered the immediate closing of the city's largest Government-operated oil refinery.

title: Amerifirst Bank Seized
description: Amerifirst Bank, the nation's oldest federally chartered savings and loan association, was seized by Federal regulators on Friday after it failed to find a buyer for its 54-branch system. The 55-year-old institution was brought down by bad real estate loans and was unable to meet Federal capital guidelines. Amerifirst had $3.7 billion in assets and $2.8 billion in deposits when the Office of Thrift Supervision moved in and created a new Federal mutual association to assume operations.

title: Rest for Hershiser
description: Orel Hershiser, whose comeback from surgery on his right shoulder had been progressing rapidly, was sidelined yesterday with some tenderness in the shoulder. The Dodger right-hander will take a couple days off, then a decision will be made on when he might throw again. (AP)

title: Henry W. Taft 2d, 64; Led Outward Bound
