description: Henry Waters Taft 2d, an executive and former president of Outward Bound, U.S.A., died yesterday at his home in Camden, Me. He was 64 years old.

title: F.C.C. Rivalries Leading to Impasse
description: As an advocate of deregulation, Alfred C. Sikes, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has a sweeping agenda for relaxing many longstanding regulations throughout the communications industries and encouraging new technology.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Soap Opera From Britain Fans Taster's Choice Flame
description: IS there a future together for Tony, the dashing man about town, and Sharon, his sophisticated neighbor, who share a taste for Taster's Choice freeze-dried coffee? True, sparks fly between the two stars of the unusual advertising campaign created by McCann-Erickson -- but what about the other woman Tony is seeing? Is it serious? And how will all this affect coffee sales?

title: Gosh, Ma! Nothing at All?
description: Can't anything be done about basketball? For days it has been inescapable on television and radio and in newspapers, saloons and private homes where men get together to drink beer.

title: Lockheed Fends Off Simmons
description: Dropping his attempt to win three seats on the Lockheed Corporation's board, Harold C. Simmons sold 12 million shares of the military aerospace company privately today for $486 million, or $40.50 a share.

title: Supreme Court to Take Fresh Look At Disputed Church-State Boundary
description: The Supreme Court opened the door today to a fresh look at the constitutional boundary between church and state by agreeing to decide whether public school graduation ceremonies can include prayers that mention God.

title: New Bulk-Call Plan Offered by A.T.& T.
description: After years of hostility toward entrepreneurs who buy blocks of long-distance telephone time for resale to small businesses and schools, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced a service designed for them.

title: German Gains In Privatizing
description: The Treuhandanstalt privatization agency, which has the assignment of selling off former state-owned enterprises in eastern Germany, has sold 1,000 of the 8,000 businesses, a board member was quoted today as saying.

title: One Small Country
description: There was no way to escape writing this column. I thought I was going to write about other things, which I knew would interest more people, like the Soviet Union's approaching civil war or Saddam Hussein's approaching annihilation, or those sickening lynching pictures from Los Angeles.

title: Edmond Chapus, 66, Engineering Executive
description: Edmond F. Chapus, former president and chief executive of Alsthom Inc., one of the world's largest engineering conglomerates, died on Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: New York State and City Run in Place on Budgets
description: Although New York State and New York City are facing combined fiscal troubles of crisis proportions, budget negotiations here have become mired in what even the participants concede are Albany's usual parochial and political concerns.

title: Dow Off 18.32, to 2,929.95, as Trading Eases
description: Stocks fell yesterday with some volatility among blue chips, as trading eased to well below 200 million shares.

title: Honecker's Flight Draws Bitterness
description: At a popular exhibition here where instruments of the old East German secret police are on display, the talk this weekend was angry.

title: To Break the Oil Habit, Tax Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: 76-Year-Old Farmer Guilty of Killing Five Drifters
description: A jury convicted a 76-year-old farmer of first-degree murder today in the deaths of five drifters he was charged with luring to his home as part of a cattle-buying swindle.

title: Dykstra Is Reported To Be on Probation
description: The commissioner of baseball has no plans to fine or suspend Phillie outfielder Lenny Dykstra because of the player's admitted involvement in high-stakes poker games that cost him more than $78,000 in losses, according to a published report.

title: What Kind of Soviet 'Union'?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's idea of how to preserve the Soviet Union appears headed for an underwhelming victory. Although the final tally of Sunday's referendum won't be completed for several days, early returns suggest that the Union is in no imminent danger of coming apart. But they don't answer the question of how it will hang together. The mixed result should be a relief to Americans who have no interest in either Soviet disunion or a federation enforced by Moscow.

title: BUSH SEEKS TO TAP FEDERAL RESERVE TO AID BANK FUND
description: Seeking to keep the Federal deposit insurance program afloat, the Bush Administration will propose that bank regulators be able to increase the amount they can borrow by $25 billion, Administration officials said today.

title: Germany's Top Banker Gives Europe a Warning
description: In a blunt warning, the head of Germany's central bank said today that German monetary union was a disaster that should serve as a "drastic illustration" of mistakes the European Community must avoid as it moves toward a single currency and a European central bank.

title: Yugoslav Army Emerges, Ambiguously
description: After three days of silence in a period of tense political conflict here, the high command of the Yugoslav armed forces issued a policy statement today that left its intentions still ambiguous.

title: What Makes Food Italian? Don't Ask American Chefs
description: NO sooner was that first plate of stylish fettuccine or risotto off the stove than some American had to start fooling with it. But then Italian food in America has always been open to interpretation.

title: 2 Guilty in Resale Of City's Chlorine
description: Two men accused of reselling at least three tons of city-owned chlorine through their swimming-pool supply store pleaded guilty yesterday to obstructing justice.

title: Jets Sign Pickel
description: The Jets yesterday signed their fourth Plan B free agent, Bill Pickel, a nose tackle and defensive end who has spent the last eight seasons with the Los Angeles Raiders, totaling 53 sacks in 121 games. He started 63 games. Pickel, 31, is a native of Queens who attended St. Francis Prep and Rutgers University. The 6-5, 265-pound lineman was a second-round draft pick of the Raiders in 1983. Last season, he started three times.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL

title: CBS Is First Network To Reveal Fall Plans
description: At a meeting with potential advertisers here today, CBS executives described more than two dozen television shows in development and a slate of made-for-television films that will be contenders for the fall schedule. CBS was the first network to discuss fall options. ABC, NBC and Fox are scheduled to unveil plans later this week.

title: JUDICIAL NOMINEE MAY BE IMPERILED
description: The Bush Administration's efforts to elevate Federal District Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp to a pivotal appeals court seat may have been put in jeopardy today after a contentious Senate hearing.

title: N.F.L. Shifts 1993 Super Bowl From Phoenix
description: The 1993 Super Bowl was removed from Phoenix tonight in a vote of the owners at the National Football League's annual meeting. But the city gained a preliminary bid for Super Bowl XXX in 1996, which is likely to hinge on the same issue that made tonight's vote necessary, the failure of Arizona to make Martin Luther King's birthday a paid state holiday.

title: Review/Film Festival; Stories of Hidden Distress
description: In the sly, beautifully modulated Italian film "Peaceful Air of the West," the director Silvio Soldini manipulates his characters' unspoken dreams. The principal figures, who are apparently unrelated as the film begins, are sedate young Milanese professionals with a rich supply of hidden distress but no overt awareness of their own dissatisfaction.

title: Economic Scene; Cheap Oil, Expensive Cartel
description: SAUDI ARABIA, the muscle behind the international oil cartel, made no secret of its aims at the meeting of OPEC ministers in Geneva last week: keeping the price of a barrel high enough to replenish its war-depleted treasury -- but not high enough to weaken the magic kingdom's grip on the market.

title: 6 News Unions Ratify Contracts In Voting Rush
description: With a flurry of activity that included a last-minute meeting between the British publisher Robert Maxwell and union leaders at The Daily News, the members of six unions yesterday ratified new labor contracts.

title: Transit Officials Say Stangl Won't Face Criminal Charges
description: Peter E. Stangl, the president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, who has been nominated to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, will not be charged with criminal wrongdoing for allowing a friend to sit at the controls of a commuter train carrying passengers last October, transit officials said last night.

title: Car Mileage Gain Sought
description: A Senate committee approved a bill today to reduce United States dependence on oil imports by improving gasoline mileage of new cars.

title: Noxious Fumes Sicken Workers At Bronx Plant
description: For the second time in 16 months, large numbers of workers in a Bronx factory were sickened yesterday as carbon-monoxide fumes swept through their building. The source of the carbon monoxide was apparently the same in both incidents.

title: G.M. Deal With Time Warner
description: The General Motors Corporation and Time Warner Inc. announced an agreement yesterday under which the auto maker is expected to spend $80 million over the next year to advertise in a number of the media company's ventures, including Time, Sports Illustrated and Fortune magazines.

title: Youth Held in 6 Murders In Arson in South Bronx
description: A 16-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with the murders of six people who died in a fire that engulfed a three-story tenement in the South Bronx last Wednesday night.

title: Henry Rothschild 2d, Lawyer, Is Dead at 82
description: V. Henry Rothschild 2d, a lawyer in Manhattan since 1934, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and also had a home in Truro, Mass.

title: Leslie Handler, Lawyer, 90
description: Leslie Handler, an estate lawyer for more than 50 years, died on Sunday at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Japanese Take Cautious Tone On Eve of Gorbachev's Visit
description: With the approach of a long-awaited visit by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other senior officials have started cautioning Japanese against expecting a breakthrough in the issues dividing Japan and the Soviet Union.

title: How Clean Are Vegas Back Rooms?
description: At the craps tables in this neon oasis, don't you dare try to slip in loaded dice. At the blackjack tables, you can't count cards. If you develop a system that beats the slot machines, you're banned. House rules. One way or another, the casinos and the gaming commission justify the first commandment of gambling: the house always wins.

title: Merrill Suit Is Settled
description: Harvard University has settled a $135 million lawsuit it brought against Merrill Lynch & Company, a spokesman from the university said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; A Broadway Musical With the Original Stars
description: It's "I wish" time. It's "once upon a time" time. "American Playhouse" begins its 10th season on public television tonight at 8 on Channel 13 with a grand exhibition of Broadway-musical glitter: "Into the Woods," taped in 1989 before an audience at the Martin Beck Theater shortly before the end of its 22-month Broadway run. Members of the original cast who had already left the production -- including Bernadette Peters and Joanna Gleason -- returned for the occasion, and their performances radiate a special verve and exuberance.

title: Rig Count Off Sharply
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas dropped by 40 last week, to a total of 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. The count is identical to that of the comparable week a year ago. The rig count traditionally falls through April.

title: Sundstrom's 2d Goal Ends Penguins' Unbeaten Streak
description: After trailing by two goals entering the third period, the Devils tonight played the kind of hockey that Tom McVie has preached about in his 35 years as coach.

title: Boeing Expansion
description: The Boeing Company proposed a $1.5 billion expansion of its Everett, Wash., production plant that would add nearly 10,000 new jobs in the next four years. The expansion would accommodate construction of Boeing's newest plane, the 777 jetliner, and expanded construction of its 747's and 767's.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about "The Wizard of Oz" misstated the day of the telecast. The film was shown last night on CBS; it is not tonight.

title: Finnish Parliament: Average Age Under 40
description: The new Finnish Parliament elected on Sunday is more than one-third female and has an average age of less than 40.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ABRAHAM D. BEAME is 85 years old today, and for the occasion, a group of his former aides threw a party for him last night. Among those from the Beame Administration (1974 to 1977) who attended were SIDNEY FRIGAND, who was Mr. Beame's press secretary, and the party's organizer, ARLENE WOLFF.

title: Accounts
description: * Nissan Canada Inc. to Perkins/Butler, a subsidiary of Chiat/Day/Mojo, for a direct-marketing program. Billings were not disclosed.

title: No Bitterness in Jackson's Farewell
description: Bo Jackson said today that he had no bitterness toward the Kansas City Royals for releasing him and was confident he would play baseball again.

title: Senator Regrets Arnett Remark
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, who evoked wide controversy for his comments about Peter Arnett, the CNN reporter who remained in Baghdad while it was under attack by the United States, has issued a qualified apology.

title: Hispanic Ads At Little Caesar
description: Little Caesar Enterprises Inc. will announce today that it has selected Font & Vaamonde Inc., a New York agency, to advertise its Little Caesars pizza to Hispanic consumers.

title: Tyson's Victory Marred By Post-Fight Sparring
description: Six rounds into his fight Monday against Mike Tyson, Donovan (Razor) Ruddock was 6 points down on each of the three judges' scorecards. He had been knocked to the canvas twice. He was breathing heavily.

title: An Unknown Casualty
description: With the Persian Gulf war over and won, the Air Force has chosen to disclose a fact that few television viewers or newspaper readers could have suspected while the fighting was going on: The famous "smart bombs" made up only 7 percent of all the U.S. explosives dropped on Iraq and Kuwait.

title: Miramax Films Goes Up Against the Big Guns
description: Late last year, when the big Hollywood studios were coming out with such blockbuster movies as "Bonfire of the Vanities" and "The Godfather Part III," Miramax Films released "The Long Walk Home, " a small, intimate story set against the Montgomery bus boycott of 1955, starring Cissy Spacek and Whoopi Goldberg. Then Miramax watched, chagrined, as one of its favorite films got lost amid the heavy competition.

title: George Sherman, 82, Director of Westerns
description: George Sherman, a director of scores of low-budget westerns, died on Friday at Cedars Sinai Medical Center. He was 82 years old.

title: Rates Rise as Bonds Fall Sharply
description: Bond prices fell sharply and long-term interest rates continued to climb toward 8.50 percent yesterday, as investors sold securities after the Government released more data showing inflation pressures remain despite weakness in the economy.

title: INSIDE
description: New York Officers Charged

title: Brendan O Hehir, Joycean Scholar, 63
description: Brendan O Hehir, a scholar who specialized in the works of James Joyce and William Butler Yeats, died of a brain tumor Sunday at his home in Berkeley. He was 63 years old.

title: No, You're Not Seeing Double
description: Teachers at East Elementary School here sometimes think they are seeing double, or even triple. The school has 12 pairs of twins and a set of triplets among its 480 students.

title: On Not Going Into Engineering Today
description: To the Editor:

title: South Miami Schools Don't Want to Return to Earlier System
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroit Is Getting New Help From Plastics
description: Automotive engineers have puzzled for years over how to use weight-saving plastics in car and truck engines without losing the strength or heat resistance of metal.

title: Dow Plunges 62.13 Points, Or Over 2%
description: Stocks were slammed yesterday by the report on consumer prices for February and by I.B.M.'s prediction of sharply lower earnings.

title: Review/Music; Modernity Amid a Romantic Revel
description: Riccardo Muti led the Philadelphia Orchestra through a sea of Romanticism with a single island of modernity on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall. The program began with the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto and ended with Elgar's "In the South" Concert Overture. Separating them was the world premiere of Bernard Rands's "Ceremonial 3," one of the works that Carnegie Hall commissioned as part of the celebration of its centenary.

title: Chairman Will Leave Wheeling-Pittsburgh
description: D. Leonard Wise, who has been chairman and chief executive of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation for just three months, said yesterday that he would resign as of April 1. Mr. Wise said he was leaving at the request of the investment group that has controlled the company since it emerged from bankruptcy proceedings earlier this year.

title: Company Is Asked About Bias in Hiring
description: Two New York City officials said yesterday that they had written to a restaurant chain in which the city owns stock asking it to clarify its policy on hiring homosexual men and women.

title: Real Estate; 2 Buildings To Be Opened In Cleveland
description: TWO new office buildings set to open in downtown Cleveland this year will enhance Cleveland's ability to provide major tenants with first-class space. They have also raised the city's office vacancy rate to 22 percent, a record.

title: 5 Millionth U.S. Patent
description: The nation's five millionth patent was issued this morning, and the process it registers seems to be a sign of the times. The patent, issued to the University of Florida, covers a bacterial process to make ethanol, a type of alcohol that can be used in place of gasoline.

title: Market Place; USG's Struggle To Buy Time
description: THE problem: owing $800,000 a day in interest payments.

title: CHRONICLE
description: While attending a rehearsal for "The Will Rogers Follies" at the Palace Theater on Monday, BETTY COMDEN slipped and broke her kneecap. But she and ADOLPH GREEN, who together have written the lyrics for this show and many others, are still scheduled to perform their songs at a benefit on Saturday night for Long Island Stage.

title: On Not Going Into Engineering Today; 43,000 Unemployed
description: To the Editor:

title: Hancock Is Said To Lay Off 500
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has reportedly laid off as many as 500 employees, Hancock employees told Boston newspapers. The employees said they were told of the layoffs when they arrived for work on Monday. Company spokesmen declined to comment.

title: Louise Brayton Kline, Preservationist, 79
description: Louise Brayton Kline, a preservationist who oversaw the construction of several buildings at Bard College when her late husband was president there, died on Monday at her home in Barrytown, N.Y. She was 79 years old.

title: Review/Rock; Two Shows: Buck Pets and Replacements
description: For most of the decade, certain pop observers have been bemoaning the decline of thoughtful, melodic songs as rhythm and texture seize the foreground. But old-fashioned, tuneful songs haven't disappeared; they're just hiding behind blaring guitars and a deep distrust of pomposity and professionalism. At CBGB late on Wednesday night, the Buck Pets started and ended most of their songs in a hum and buzz of feedback; the previous Friday night at the Ritz, the Replacements knocked out one well-made song after another as if they were playing in someone's garage.

title: Videodisks Are Integrated With Computers for a Versatile Teaching Tool
description: At a teacher's command, a familiar face appears on a television screen to guide students through a give-and-take talk on a deadly disease: "I'm Ted Koppel, and this is Side One of an interactive videodisk about AIDS," the ABC anchor intones from his "Nightline" desk.

title: Federal Official Tells of Anti-Abortion Moves
description: A top Federal official told a House panel today that the Bush Administration was preparing to take steps to steer pregnant women away from clinics and hospitals where abortion was "pervasive."

title: MGM-Pathe Faces Push By Creditors
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Company, which has struggled to obtain financing throughout its short existence, is facing new pressure from a group of creditors. The creditors plan to ask a bankruptcy court to begin involuntary bankruptcy proceedings against the company if it does not pay about $20 million in late bills.

title: Jan H. van Roijen, 85, Former Envoy to U.S.
description: Jan Herman van Roijen, who served as Ambassador to the United States from the Netherlands for 13 years, died on Saturday at his home in Wassenaar, the Netherlands. He was 85 years old.

title: John D. Voelker Is Dead at 87; Author of 'Anatomy of a Murder'
description: John D. Voelker, the Michigan judge who wrote "Anatomy of a Murder" and other books under the name Robert Traver, died on Monday. He was 87 years old.

title: Mother and Daughter Held In Killing to Obtain a Baby
description: A Brooklyn woman who became obsessed with giving her boyfriend a baby after she miscarried was charged yesterday with killing a young mother and kidnapping the victim's infant son, hoping that the boyfriend would think it was his, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARSHALL S. COGAN likes the Boston Latin School so much that he's acting as host to more than 100 alumni at a benefit in his restaurant, the "21" Club. An investor, the chairman and chief executive of Knoll International Holdings, and a member of the class of '55, Mr. Cogan is also a big Boston Latin benefactor.

title: Lessons About Business And Hard Times as Well
description: Britt Eastland frets about the recession like any other businessman.

title: Clubs Weigh Risks Linked With Jackson
description: With the Kansas City Royals apparently having exhausted their patience and tolerance with the two-sport career of Bo Jackson, other major league clubs pondered today the degree of risk they would be willing to take in acquiring the ailing star.

title: Swiss Promoting Wine Sales in U.S.
description: SWITZERLAND'S wine industry, capitalizing on attention drawn by the country's 700th anniversary this year, is trying to expand its tiny niche in the United States market.

title: Can Tanks Carry Anthrax?
description: Can M1-A1 Abrams tanks or Bradley fighting vehicles carry hoof-and-mouth disease, African swine fever or the anthrax bacteria?

title: It's Not Pretty, but Knicks Win on Road
description: There wasn't much suspense involved in the Knicks' 97-79 victory over the Hornets tonight at the Charlotte Coliseum. Nor did either team display much offensive artistry as the Knicks squared their season record at 33-33, and won on the road for the 17th time this season, surpassing last season's total.

title: Conferees Clear Funds for Savings Bailout
description: Congressional negotiators reached agreement today on a measure providing $30 billion for the savings and loan bailout, clearing the way for final votes on the bill in the Senate and the House this week.

title: Trading Ban Approved
description: Federal regulators have approved a proposal by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to ban dual trading in active contract months starting May 20. The plan is aimed at forestalling a more restrictive proposal by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In dual trading, brokers fill customer orders while trading for their own accounts. Critics say that contributes to fraud.

title: Rebellious Kurds Reported To Take a Major Iraqi City
description: Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq say they now control the city of Kirkuk, a major oil production center and Iraq's fourth-largest city, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: Robert Goulding Jr., Entomologist, 70
description: Robert Goulding Jr., an entomologist whose research into time-release pesticides led to the introduction of the flea collar in 1964, died of a heart attack Friday at a hospital in Corvallis. He was 70 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Bubka Breaks Vault Mark Again Four days after becoming the first pole-vaulter to clear 20 feet, Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union surpassed that barrier again yesterday. Bubka cleared 20 feet 1/2 inch during the indoor Festival of Pole-Vaulting, organized by Bubka to bring the world's best vaulters to his hometown of Donetsk. That was a half-inch higher than his world mark set last Friday at San Sebastian, Spain. The earlier jump was initially reported as 20 feet 1/4 inch, but later revised to 20 feet. Bubka also holds the outdoor mark of 19-10 1/2. (AP) N.H.L. Hull Reaches 80-Goal Mark Brett Hull became the third National Hockey League player to score 80 goals in one season as the visiting St. Louis Blues stalled the Washington Capitals' playoff drive last night with a 2-1 victory. Hull joined Mario Lemieux and Wayne Gretzky in the select club with his first-period goal. Lemieux scored 85 goals in the 1988-89 season, and Gretzky reached the 80-goal barrier twice, the first time in the 1981-82 season when he scored an N.H.L.-record 92 goals. (AP) N.B.A. Lakers Move to Top of Division The Los Angeles Lakers ended Portland's season-long reign atop the Pacific Division, beating the Los Angeles Clippers, 119-105, last night behind 26 points from James Worthy at The Forum in Inglewood. The Lakers extended their home-court winning streak against their crosstown rivals to 27 games. The Trail Blazers, who had led the division since the season's start, lost at Golden State, 136-126, and fell a half-game behind the Lakers, who have won nine consecutive division titles. (AP)

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE cuisine of Indonesia is as varied as its colorful history. Curries washed over the islands as early as 600 B.C., when Indian merchants arrived. By the fifth century A.D., the Chinese were active traders with Sumatra, introducing their soybeans and salty sauces. Others followed in search of exotic spices: Arabs, Portuguese and, in the 17th century, the Dutch, who established the Dutch East India Company. Each group tossed an ingredient or two into the Indonesian broth.

title: Prosecutors Cite Omissions in Flake's Disclosure of Income
description: Federal prosecutors produced evidence yesterday showing that the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, who is a Representative from Queens, had not listed on Congressional disclosure forms thousands of dollars that he received from his church.

title: Study Links Cancer Deaths And Low Levels of Radiation
description: Workers exposed to low levels of radiation at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, a center of nuclear weapons production and radiation research since 1943, had higher death rates from cancer than workers who were not exposed, researchers say.

title: Unsealing of Papers In Gotti Case Sought
description: Several news organizations have asked a Federal judge in Brooklyn to unseal tapes and documents involved in the Government's attempt to disqualify three defense lawyers from John Gotti's pending racketeering trial.

title: 5 Officers Charged in a Death, Lawyers Say
description: Five New York City police officers have been charged in the death of a 21-year-old car-theft suspect who suffocated during a struggle with them in Queens last month, lawyers for the officers said yesterday.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Gets $100,000 Donation
description: Lincoln Center has received a major donation to its new jazz program. The Radisson Empire Hotel has contributed $100,000 to establish a program called the Living Jazz Trust, which is to support educational programs for young people. The trust will help to present special concerts and informal seminars with jazz artists, said a statement from Metromedia Hotels, which owns the Radisson Empire.

title: Panel Tells College Heads To Take Control of Athletics
description: A private commission released a report today that painted a picture of big-time college sports out of control, with powerless university presidents and with underachieving athletes being shoveled through a system primarily beholden to outside financial interests like television networks and booster clubs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alfa-Laval A.B., Sweden, and Tetra Pak Group, Switzerland, will have their $2.8 billion merger agreement reviewed by the Executive Commission of the European Community for compliance with competition rules. * Bundaberg Sugar Co., Brisbane, Australia, rejected a $290 million offer from Tate & Lyle P.L.C., London.

title: DINKINS WILL SEEK $850 MILLION MORE IN SPENDING CUTS
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will ask New York City agencies today to begin cutting $850 million more from their budgets to close a gap that the city now acknowledges is greater than $3 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1, city officials said yesterday.

title: 2-Year Probation For Lowell Team
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today put the University of Lowell on probation for two years after finding that the school's ice hockey coach gave low rents and other benefits to players in violation of N.C.A.A. rules.

title: Topics of The Times; The Dipper, Belatedly Honored
description: Those who grew up not far from the Philadelphia Spectrum, where Wilt Chamberlain's uniform number was retired two days ago, recall stories about Wilt's distaste for jokes about his height. In one, a fan supposedly asks the 7-foot-1-inch basketball player, "How's the weather up there?" Chamberlain upends a glass of water on the fan and answers, "It's raining."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The pace at which we are receiving contributions from our allies is of real concern to me, particularly with regard to the cash-rich gulf states. It is more than just a little disconcerting to see this delay, especially by those countries the defense of which we took up." -- Senator Robert C. Byrd. [ A13:2. ]

title: A Unified, Weak Iraq
description: President Bush's central postwar strategic objective has been to keep Iraq whole and relatively insulated from regional vultures, even if it required a delay in Saddam Hussein's departure.

title: 2 Companies Offer a Mill To Workers
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company offered yesterday to give a paper mill they own jointly in northern Ontario to its employees, provided the provincial power company agrees by April 30 to buy an associated hydroelectric power plant.

title: Pressure Grows Over Police Beating
description: As anger built here today over the police beating of a black motorist and the cavalier comments of some of the officers involved, Mayor Tom Bradley and a number of leading politicians kept up a carefully measured criticism of the police department.

title: DIALOGUE: SPEECH ON CAMPUS Say the Right Thing - or Else; Attack Ideas, Not People
description: Can the university, with its special trust of protecting free speech, be hampered by the restrictions of civility? What kind of a frill is etiquette, anyway, for those in the noble pursuit of truth?

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: F. I, Carpenter, 88, A Literary Authority
description: Frederic Ives Carpenter, an authority on Eugene O'Neill, Robinson Jeffers and Ralph Waldo Emerson, died Saturday at the John Muir Hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 88 years old and lived in Walnut Creek.

title: Abstract Arguments, Real Births
description: In the four months since the Food and Drug Administration approved the Norplant System, a five-year, reversible, low-dose contraceptive, there's been a lot of talk about how to coerce the young and poor into using it. The talk is abstract, way off target. The practical question for public debate is how to make Norplant available to every woman who chooses to use it.

title: Two in Noriega Case Found Guilty of Plot In Shipping Cocaine
description: Two men were found guilty today of plotting with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to trade M-16 automatic rifles for cocaine, becoming the first co-defendants of the deposed Panamanian leader to be convicted in the case.

title: Paris Journal; Vietnam Echo Stuns France: Case of Treachery?
description: As Georges Boudarel remembers things, he was driven by idealism when, in the early 1950's, he joined Communist Vietminh rebels fighting French colonial rule in Indochina and finished up giving Marxist indoctrination classes to French prisoners of war.

title: Kramer Arrested Again
description: Tommy Kramer, a former Minnesota Vikings quarterback, was arrested early yesterday in Bloomington, Minn., on a gross misdemeanor driving-while-intoxicated charge.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The Advertising Council introduced a national public service campaign yesterday for the Points of Light Foundation, a nonprofit community-service organization. The campaign, created without charge by Saatchi & Saatchi, seeks to encourage individuals to tackle serious problems in their communities.

title: Hot-Cross Buns: Giving Tradition A Fresh Accent
description: HOT and cross. That's the way The London Daily Telegraph described a reader who complained about the high price of hot-cross buns in 1972. They had long since increased in price beyond the usual "one a penny, two a penny" of the 18th-century nursery rhyme.

title: Cheney Wants No Limit On Arms for Gulf Allies
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States would not limit the sales of sophisticated conventional weapons to America's allies in the Middle East when their security might be at stake.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Maxwell Seeks More Savings At The News
description: Robert Maxwell said yesterday that he would seek to wring $30 million more a year in savings from The Daily News, in addition to what he has already won by making the unions accept job cuts.

title: Accord Is Reached on Rescuing Redwood Forests
description: Environmentalists and a representative of California's lumber industry have agreed on proposed legislation that would help save redwood forests from logging and would otherwise restrict timber harvesting in the state.

title: Books of The Times; Recounting the Lowlights of the Reagan Years
description: Sleepwalking Through History America in the Reagan Years By Haynes Johnson Illustrated. 524 pages. W. W. Norton . $24.95.

title: Elster's Shoulder Passes First Test
description: Kevin Elster accepted Tom Herr's feed to second base and let loose a hard, abbreviated flip to first. Elster had already conceded that he wasn't going to get the batter going to first, and so as he turned to stride back to shortstop, the question of the moment was whether his shoulder could be declared safe as well.

title: Student Shot On Ball Field
description: A 19-year-old Lehman College student playing softball on a field at the Bronx campus was shot in the abdomen yesterday afternoon and died last night, the police said.

title: Does Bo, Hurt, Know as Much?
description: Bo Jackson's commercials created the impression that "Bo knows" the ins and outs of almost everything, especially sports. Now that the versatile athlete has been sidelined by a hip injury, one thing Bo does not know for sure is how much it will hurt his lucrative endorsement career.

title: DIALOGUE: SPEECH ON CAMPUS Say the Right Thing - or Else; High Noon at The P.C. Corral
description: The new film "Guilty by Suspicion" tells the story of David Merrill, a successful Hollywood director in the 1950's, who sacrifices his career by refusing to name names before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

title: The Baring of Buchenwald, Unfiltered
description: A debate over the meaning of German history has erupted at the site of the former Nazi concentration camp here.

title: Baby Bells Backed by Senate Panel
description: A Senate panel voted overwhelmingly yesterday to permit the seven regional Bell companies to design and manufacture telephones and other equipment.

title: Rio Slum Dwellers Seize Luxury Apartments
description: Carlos da Silva stood today on the balcony of his new 11th-floor condominium apartment and savored a vista that swept from jungle-covered mountains to a lagoon and on to beaches of the South Atlantic.

title: Ernest Bonnamy, Architect, 94
description: Ernest Bonnamy, an architect and interior designer, died on Sunday at his home on Shelter Island, L.I. He was 94 years old.

title: Time for Census Changes Are Running Out
description: Commerce Under Secretary Michael R. Darby raised the possibility today that his agency would not have enough information by the July 15 deadline to decide whether the 1990 census figures should be adjusted to correct for any disproportionate undercount of black or Hispanic residents.

title: Kurds Alone Viewed as Unlikely to Oust Hussein
description: The unrest in Iraqi Kurdistan is the most serious anti-Government revolt in that region in almost two decades, but it alone is unlikely to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Middle East experts say.

title: Court Voids Phone Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court voided a Government license today for a proposed satellite system that aims to provide nationwide mobile telephone service.

title: Captors Link Fate of 2 Americans To Release of Arabs Held in Israel
description: A group that says it is holding two American professors hostage said in a statement here today that they would not be freed until Palestinian prisoners held in Israel were released.

title: Witt Misses First Start With Elbow Soreness
description: Mike Witt, who was likely to be the Yankees' opening-day pitcher in three weeks, missed his first start of the spring today and may sit out the next one as well because of recurring soreness in his right elbow.

title: AIDS DRUG PATENT CHALLENGED IN SUIT
description: A lawsuit announced today challenges the Burroughs Wellcome Company's patent on the AIDS treatment drug AZT and seeks to have it invalidated so other companies could market the drug at cheaper prices.

title: An Institute Worth Saving
description: For the most part, Gov. Mario Cuomo's tough-minded approach to cutting the New York State budget imposes necessary discipline in the face of fiscal disaster. But some sacrifices still seem unwise. A glaring example is the Nathan S. Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research.

title: A Viewers' Guide To an Epic Telecast Of an Indian Epic
description: Now that pledge week is over, just when you thought it was safe to watch public television again, "Great Performances" is bringing a six-hour, three-evening cultural extravaganza to the screens of the unsuspecting. "The Mahabharata," Peter Brook's retelling of the classic Indian narrative poem, will be broadcast in three two-hour segments, beginning at 9 o'clock, on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Rally Protests Cuts in Cuomo Budget
description: Even as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was proposing new spending cuts today, tens of thousands of black and Hispanic demonstrators marched on the Capitol to send the message that they feel unfairly victimized by the Governor's budget and are ready to collect on an old debt.

title: Exports Help Japan in 4th Quarter
description: Japan's economy was sustained by solid export growth in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said today, a trend that is likely to contribute to a rebound in the politically sensitive trade surplus.

title: Correction
description: An article by Maxwell Hart and Jeremy W. Jones on yesterday's Op-Ed page appeared originally in The Martha's Vineyard Times, not The Martha's Vineyard Gazette.

title: Raise Is Deferred By Bloomingdale's
description: Bloomingdale's and the United Storeworkers Union, Local 3, reached an agreement yesterday to defer an $18-a-week increase for store workers until June 1 instead of the negotiated date of March 1.

title: Security Cuts Its Dividend
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest banking company, announced a sharp cut yesterday in its stock dividend and acknowledged that it continued to be troubled by increases in delinquent loans.

title: New President At General Tire
description: General Tire Inc. said Monday that it had appointed a new president and chief executive.

title: A Sailor and a Nurse, Aug. 15, 1945
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Organizes and Arms Rebels Fighting Hussein, Diplomats Say
description: Iran has been organizing and arming many of the Iraqi rebels who have spearheaded the revolt against President Saddam Hussein in southern Iraq, senior Kuwaiti officials and Arab and foreign diplomats here say.

title: Bridge
description: Four doctoral students representing the University of Virginia won the North American College Bridge Championship, played over the weekend at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Atlantic City.

title: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASE, RAISING FEAR OF INFLATION
description: In the second recent dose of surprisingly high inflation figures, the Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in February but that when price gyrations in energy and food are eliminated there was a jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Jackson's Case Is Dividing The Doctors
description: Experts in orthopedic surgery and sports medicine are divided in their opinion about whether the hip injury sustained by Bo Jackson, a star in professional baseball and football and a news-media superstar, is one that will end his career as a professional athlete.

title: People
description: * Richard Kelley has been named a creative director at Young & Rubicam in New York. * Dan R. Long and Luane Spingola have been named senior vice president-creative directors at Lintas New York.

title: Eating Well
description: FOR those of us who don't remember whether to divide the big number into the small number or the small number into the big number to get a percentage, the practice of describing the amount of fat in a product in percentages is more than just baffling. It's incomprehensible.

title: Israeli Army Chief, Stirring Furor, Suggests the Golan Is Expendable
description: The army Chief of Staff, who retires in a month, said in remarks reported today that Israel might safely give up some occupied territories if the nation made satisfactory peace agreements with its Arab neighbors.

title: Davis Cup Team Picked
description: After a selection process that could turn out to be more harrowing than the matches themselves, Tom Gorman, the United States Davis Cup captain, has finally decided on the four-man squad that will oppose Mexico on March 29-31 in Mexico City. The United States, the defending Davis Cup champion, will be represented in singles matches by Brad Gilbert and Jim Courier. Rick Leach and Jim Pugh, 4-0 last year in Davis Cup play, will again anchor the doubles matches.

title: A.T.&T. Pledges Higher Bid If NCR's Board Is Removed
description: A.T.& T. said yesterday that it would raise its offer for the NCR Corporation to $100 a share, if the computer maker's shareholders vote to remove NCR's board at a special shareholders meeting next week.

title: I.B.M. Sees Sharp Drop In Earnings
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be about half of its profit a year ago and far short of most analysts' projections. The prediction jolted Wall Street, which took it as a sign that there were new grounds for concern about a stumbling national economic recovery.

title: Eastern Michigan Making a Name for Itself
description: During his freshman year at Syracuse, Derrick Coleman phoned a high school teammate in Detroit to urge him to join him in the bright spotlight of big-time college basketball.

title: Missing Financial Data Found in Landfill
description: Missing financial records from a South Carolina foundation have been unearthed from a landfill, a newspaper reported today.

title: Bangladesh Gives Post to Opposition Leader
description: Khaleda Zia, widow of an assassinated President, was today named Prime Minister of predominantly Muslim Bangladesh, the state-run television said. She is the first woman to attain that post.

title: Times Books Publisher
description: Peter Osnos, associate publisher of Random House adult trade books, has been named to the additional position of publisher of Times Books. The announcement was made on Monday by Harold Evans, president and publisher of Random House adult trade books. Mr. Evans also recently appointed Peter Gethers as publisher of Villard Books; before that Mr. Gethers was editorial director of Villard. Both Times Books and Villard are independent imprints of Random House Inc.

title: South Miami Schools Don't Want to Return to Earlier System; Causes or Results?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabinet in Kuwait Resigns, Emirate's Envoy to U.N. Says
description: Kuwait's Cabinet resigned today in a move intended to bring in new officials as the nation rebuilds from nearly seven months of Iraqi occupation, the emirate's United Nations ambassador said.

title: Strawberry Still Out
description: Darryl Strawberry missed his eighth straight exhibition game yesterday with a hamstring strain and the Los Angeles Dodgers haven't decided when he will play again.

title: Review/Fashion; It's Called Joie, But in Paris It's Pronounced Ungaro
description: The exhilarating level of the collections presented during the fall and winter ready-to-wear showings in the last few days could not be sustained indefinitely. Only Emanuel Ungaro this morning captured the glitter, exuberance and joie de vivre that made fashion sparkle in the first days of the openings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, named Jeffrey P. Neubert a senior vice president. * Monarch Capital Corp., Springfield, Mass., named Benjamin F. Jones chairman. He replaces Gordon N. Oakes, who resigned.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Jessica Fletcher's fans can relax: ANGELA LANSBURY plans to return next season to "Murder, She Wrote." She has agreed to make 22 new episodes of the show, said JEFF SAGANSKY, president of CBS Entertainment.

title: More Job Cuts By Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation will lay off another 2,000 employees at its Fort Worth plant, reducing the work force to its lowest level since 1985, the military contractor said today.

title: Soviets Say Result of Ballot Is a Mandate for Gorbachev
description: The Kremlin said today that an impressive majority of Soviet voters had "decided the future of this country" by supporting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his referendum over national unity.

title: Lincoln Takes Title In P.S.A.L.
description: Making its sixth trip to the final four in the last six years and its fourth in that span to the final game, Abraham Lincoln High School came away last night with its second Public Schools Athletic League championship since 1986. The Railsplitters from Coney Island beat South Shore of Canarsie, 55-40, in an all-Brooklyn final of the boys' Class A championship game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Justices Protect Unions From Members
description: The Supreme Court today gave labor unions enhanced protection against lawsuits by members dissatisfied with the outcome of a strike or negotiation.

title: House Judiciary Panel Backs Democrats' Civil Rights Bill
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved by 24 to 10 a Democratic-sponsored civil rights bill similar to one President Bush vetoed last year. Earlier, it rejected the President's more modest alternative.

title: Hyundai Increases 1991 Model Prices
description: Hyundai Motor America raised prices on its 1991 cars by an average of 1.5 percent and introduced trim and option packages. The price increases were necessary because of higher manufacturing costs and currency fluctuations, the company said.

title: Carlo Donat Cattin, 71, Italy's Labor Minister
description: Carlo Donat Cattin, the Italian Labor Minister, died on Sunday in Monaco, the Labor Ministry said on Monday. He was 71 years old.

title: Starts in Housing Show February Jump of 16.4%
description: Construction of new homes and apartments shot up 16.4 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today. It was the biggest monthly gain for the depressed housing industry in more than a year.

title: Sanchez's Unusual Serve Trips Up Chang in Lipton
description: Michael Chang likes to think of himself as a multipurpose, multisurface player. But after tangling with the equally flexible Emilio Sanchez of Spain this afternoon at the Lipton International Players Championships, Chang laid his loss to Sanchez's possession of one extra facet: a superior, unreadable kick serve.

title: Brad Crandall, Broadcaster, 62
description: Brad Crandall, a talk-show host on WNBC Radio in the 1960's, died last Thursday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 62 years old and lived in Redondo Beach, Calif.

title: 1988 Standards for Medical Labs Go Unenforced by Administration
description: Three years ago, prompted by chilling accounts of death and suffering caused by inaccurate medical tests from unregulated laboratories, Congress passed a law establishing strict standards for laboratories throughout the nation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Food Notes
description: Just Heat and Serve

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: INSOMNIAC AT THE EQUINOX At last each night is minutes shorter Than the day: my nightly sentence Is reduced -- the electric clock Humming through the hours; The passing footsteps, sirens, trucks; The need to catalogue The day ahead, the years behind. Night by night there's the brightness at the window Minutes earlier; the birds sing Earlier; the day begins. -- LEWIS GARDNER

title: Holders Approve Utilities' Merger
description: Shareholders of the two largest energy utilities in Kansas approved the companies' proposed merger.

title: Norman Withdraws
description: Greg Norman, who lost last year's U.S.F.& G. Classic on a 72d-hole birdie from a bunker by David Frost, yesterday withdrew from this year's event, citing illness.(AP)

title: A Resolute Dinkins; Mayor Grows More Willing to Take Stands Even When He Antagonizes Some Voters
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade with a group of Irish homosexuals and lesbians who had been refused admittance until he intervened crystallized his growing willingness to take unequivocal stands on causes that are important to him, even if others might not like it.

title: Wine Talk
description: EXACTLY 50 years ago Frank Schoonmaker and Tom Marvel published "American Wines," perhaps the first book on the subject for the general reader since the end of Prohibition in 1933.

title: The Pop Life
description: Old and New in Arabic

title: Creditors Quit Eastern Panel
description: Representatives of Eastern Airlines' biggest creditors, frustrated at watching Eastern's assets drain away and the amount they will recover diminish, possibly to nothing, have resigned from the unsecured creditors' committee.

title: Topics of The Times; Saving on Paving
description: New York City's Planning Commission, the local community board and Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, have approved a Transportation Department plan to build a new asphalt plant in Long Island City, to be owned and operated by the city. So should the City Council Land Use Committee, when it takes up the issue today.

title: Allied-Lyons Reports Big Loss on Currency
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British food and liquor company, disclosed today that it had a foreign exchange loss of about $:150 million, or about $285 million, and that its finance director had resigned.

title: Soviet Vote: An Affirmation of Disarray
description: In the end, the first nationwide referendum in the Soviet Union did less to point the nation in any direction than to illustrate its disorientation as Mikhail S. Gorbachev begins his seventh year in office.

title: The Cost of 'Really' Living vs. Just Living
description: It's always fabulous to be rich, and now it's gotten even more fabulous.

title: Fordham Loses to UMass to End Season at 25-8
description: The second-best Fordham basketball season ended last night because the Rams were the second-best team on the court.

title: Emory Move In Sex a Case Spurs Protest
description: About 200 law school students marched to the Emory University Administration Building today to protest the university's handling of sexual harassment allegations against a professor.

title: Spain Seeks to Mend Europe's Ties to North Africa
description: With attention focused on postwar efforts to stabilize the Persian Gulf region and defuse the Arab-Israeli dispute, Spain has begun working quietly to rebuild Europe's bruised relations with its closest Arab neighbors in North Africa.

title: Sherwood Noble, Dairy Queen Founder, 82
description: Sherwood Noble, one of the men credited with founding Dairy Queen stores, died here on Sunday. He was 82 years old..

title: Bombardier Plant May Face Layoffs
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based transportation equipment company, may lay off workers for up to 18 months a its plant here even if it wins a $350 million Federal contract.

title: War Astonishes Chinese And Stuns Their Military
description: China was hardly involved in the Persian Gulf war, but the allied victory has become a national pastime. Publishing houses are printing glossy books on the war, specialists are editing videos, scholars and officials are organizing seminars on its implications for China, and the military is battling for an increase in the defense budget.

title: 5 Coaches Disciplined
description: One head coach was suspended and four others reprimanded for comments they made about officiating during the 1991 Big Eight tourney.

title: Boston Museum Defends Its Claim: How Could Hercules Have a Hernia?
description: A question of whether two halves make a whole is pitting the Turkish Government against the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: P.&G. Wins In Rumor Suit
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, plagued for years by rumors that the company was linked with Satan worship, won a legal judgment yesterday against one of the rumor spreaders that it was able to catch.

title: Thomas's Cast Is Off; He May Return in April
description: Isiah Thomas had the cast removed from his right hand yesterday and the guard could be back in the Detroit Pistons' lineup by the end of April.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about auto sales in early March misstated the size of the Ford Motor Company's Escort automobile and the extent of a cut in its first- quarter production. The Escort is a subcompact, not a compact; production of the car at Ford's two North American plants was reduced by 15 percent, not 25. The article also referred incorrectly to the Escort's recent sales. They fell 21 percent in early March, but were up in February after having declined in January.

title: Some Veterans Fear Reopening Psychic Wounds
description: Bill Soares returned unheralded from Vietnam 22 years ago and began a tortured slide into cocaine addiction, marital discord and chronic unemployment.

title: Miami Fined for Violating Homeless Rights
description: A Federal judge has held the city in contempt after finding that the police violated his ban on destroying the possessions of homeless people camped in parks and beneath overpasses.

title: 'The Word "Sympathizer" Was Not a Good One'
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatric Expert Convicted In a Scheme to Bribe Police
description: A psychiatrist who often testified in court that other criminal defendants were insane has been found guilty of bribing a police officer to frame a Miami lawyer with a cocaine bust.

title: U.S. AGENDA URGED BY ASTRONOMERS
description: Setting research priorities for the next decade, astronomers today recommended a $3 billion national program to build and operate new telescopes for investigating the presence of planets around other stars, the life cycles of stars, the existence of black holes and the evolution of the universe.

title: TAPE FOREVER TIES VICTIM TO BEATING
description: Rodney G. King, whose beating at the hands of Los Angeles police officers on March 3 may long be linked in the public's minds to police brutality, is being described by friends and relatives as quiet and gentle.

title: The Quicksand in Iraq
description: Why prolong the allied occupation of Iraq? The avowed reason for staying on is that Saddam Hussein has yet to meet allied conditions for a permanent cease-fire. The unavowed reason is that by controlling 15 percent of Iraqi territory, President Bush and his coalition partners can help topple the Iraqi leader.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the third straight week in the period that ended yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a writer and lecturer at the University of Pennsylvania misstated her given name. She was Nora Magid.

title: Washington Memo; A Reverie: Unity on Domestic Problems
description: Senator Tom Daschle has this dream: Now that the war is over, the Government and the news media begin to focus on domestic problems with the same intensity they gave the Persian Gulf.

title: About New York; A Cantor, a Choir And Joyful Noise To Escape Drugs
description: The well-tailored woman stands in front. Three dozen people sit facing her, beaming as if prayers are being answered.

title: Power Authority Names An Engineer President
description: The New York Power Authority, which provides one-quarter of the state's electricity, said yesterday that John C. Brons, a nuclear engineer, would become president and chief operating officer.

title: Exxon Guilty Plea Is Expected in Harbor Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation will plead guilty to a criminal charge in Federal District Court in Newark today and will pay a $5 million penalty as part of a deal to settle litigation over a 567,000-gallon oil spill 14 months ago in New York Harbor, a government official said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
COLOMBIA ROILED BY GANG BATTLES
description: In recent months, Government anti-drug efforts have struck major blows to the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring. But far from helping this city to cope with its problems, the easing of the drug lords' hold has left a dangerous power vacuum in the poorer neighborhoods where more than half of Medellin's 2.5 million people live.

title: Japan Gave Refuge To a Polish Yeshiva
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Notes
description: Little, Brown Move

title: The 5th Question At the Seder: Have a Macaroon?
description: "Pierrot, a macaroon! I cannot live without a macaroon." -- "Aria da Capo," by Edna St. Vincent Millay

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified the Security Savings and Loan Association that sold 17 branches to Security Pacific Bank Arizona. It is the one in Scottsdale, Ariz., not in Vineland, N.J.

title: First Fidelity Recast for Future
description: When Anthony P. Terracciano was named chairman of First Fidelity Bancorporation a year ago, his goal was to recast the Newark-based bank much the way many experts predict the entire banking industry will have to change in coming years.

title: Jury in Murder Case To See Phone Bill
description: A judge yester day allowed into evidence a telephone bill that appeared to give Carolyn Warmus an alibi in her murder case, but he cautioned the jury that the bill's authenticity had not been proved.

title: Wyoming Journal; The Iron Horse Makes A Comeback Out West
description: In the past decade, even those with a fierce pride in Wyoming's elbow room had begun to worry about the declining number of elbows.

title: Movie Producers and New York Unions Reach an Accord
description: Negotiators for a consortium of Hollywood producers and two New York unions reached a tentative settlement yesterday that would end a 19-week stalemate that had virtually shut down moviemaking in New York City, a vital part of the city's economy.

title: Landis Gores, 71, Designer of His Own Avant-Garde House
description: Landis Gores, one of five architects who gained international reputations in the 1950's while living and working in avant-garde houses they designed for themselves in New Canaan, Conn., died on Monday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: 14 Wounded in Israeli Raid On a P.L.O. Base in Lebanon
description: For the second time in five days, Israeli fighter bombers today attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base in Lebanon, witnesses said. Lebanese police officials said 14 people were wounded in the attack.

title: Pilots in Runway Collision Call Detroit Airport Markings Confusing
description: Pilots of the two jets that collided in December on a foggy runway today called the Detroit Metropolitan airport unusually confusing and poorly marked.

title: Howard M. Teaf Jr.; Professor, 87
description: Howard M. Teaf Jr., who taught economics for 39 years at Haverford College in Haverford, Pa., died Monday at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 87 years old and lived in Haverford.

title: Mortality Study Lends Weight to Patient's Opinion
description: People's answer to the simple question, "Is your health excellent, good, fair or poor?" is a better predictor of who will live or die over the next decade than even a rigorous physical examination, according to new findings.

title: N.F.L. Is Nearly Unanimous in Stand on Phoenix Super Bowl Issue
description: It took National Football League owners four hours of discussion on Tuesday night to remove the 1993 Super Bowl from Phoenix and to offer a preliminary bid to the city for the 1996 Super Bowl. The fallout, however, from the league's original decision last year continues.

title: Bonwit Chief May Resign
description: Frank Doroff is expected to resign soon as chairman and chief executive of the revitalized three-store Bonwit Teller retail chain, according to executives close to the company.

title: Kodak Expects Weaker Earnings
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it expected to post weaker first-quarter earnings, citing the economic slowdown and a sharp drop-off in tourism that has hurt sales of film and cameras. In the first quarter of 1990, Kodak earned $199 million, or 61 cents a share, on sales of $4.11 billion.

title: Review/Opera; From an Episode of Terrorism, Adams's 'Death of Klinghoffer'
description: Like "Nixon in China" but in more incendiary fashion, "The Death of Kling hoffer" transmutes contemporary history into operatic poetry. Unlike the earlier work by the team of John Adams, composer; Alice Goodman, librettist; Peter Sellars, director, and Mark Morris, choreographer, the new opera, which received its world premiere Tuesday night at the Theatre Royal de la Monnaie, has problems that need refinement. But the potential for eventual triumph is there.

title: Kuwaiti Cabinet, Widely Assailed, Quits
description: The Government of Kuwait resigned today, largely in recognition of its failure to restore basic services including electricity, water and the supply of food 22 days after the country had been freed of Iraqi troops.

title: Loctite Heirs Plan To Sell a Stake
description: The heirs of the founder of the Loctite Corporation have announced plans to sell a 9.8 percent stake in the company. Loctite, the Hartford-based maker of adhesives, sealants and coatings, said it had received notice of a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by Robert H. Krieble, the company's former chairman and chief executive, various members of his family and trustees of various family interests.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Seven hundred Oxford University graduates gathered at at the United Nations on Tuesday night to honor SIR JOHN M. TEMPLETON, the mutual-fund millionaire who has brought modern values to the Oxonians' alma mater by endowing its first business school. The gathering was billed as the largest assemblage of Oxonians in the New World.

title: TBWA Unit Offering Promotional Services
description: TBWA Advertising Inc., New York, has established a subsidiary, Beisler/ Dorr & Company, to offer sales-promotion services.

title: Police Cleared Officers on Their Word
description: The initial police investigation into the death of Federico Pereira, a 21-year-old car-theft suspect, exonerated the five officers involved because it was conducted in the 18 hours after the man's death in Queens and relied entirely on the statements of the officers, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Capital-Hungry Banks Fatten Up
description: Reflecting higher confidence among investors, the banking industry has already raised more capital in stock offerings this year than it did during all of 1990.

title: NCR Is Appealing Stock-Plan Ruling
description: The NCR Corporation appealed a Federal court ruling that invalidated the company's new employee stock ownership plan. The ruling will effectively bar NCR workers from voting the shares at a shareholders meeting on A.T.&T.'s takeover bid.

title: Chrysler's Search for a Japanese Deal
description: When the Chrysler Corporation faced a crisis more than a decade ago that threatened the company's survival, the big question was whether the United States Government would bail it out. It did.

title: Dow Rises by 4.21; I.B.M. Drops Further
description: One day after its worst session in more than five months, the stock market brushed itself off yesterday and posted a small gain in nervous trading.

title: New President Named At Polygram Holdings
description: As a show business lawyer for two and a half decades, Eric Kronfeld helped negotiate recording deals for such musical performers as Lou Reed and the Rolling Stones. Now, by being appointed president and chief operating officer of Polygram Holdings Inc., he will be on the other side of the table, trying to hold down costs and generate new revenues from music-related products.

title: Calendar: Fabric, Silver, A Tractor and Airplanes
description: Diverse Designs Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 860-6862.

title: Japanese Loan to China
description: Japan released $318 million last week in aid to China, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said in a statement. The loan, which was signed on Friday in Beijing, is part of a five-year, $5.95 billion package of Japanese aid to China. Similar amounts were released in November and December. The latest loan bears interest of 2.5 percent and the repayment period is 30 years, including a 10-year grace period. The money will finance the construction of roads, railroads, airports and utilities, the statement said.

title: 5 Officers Charged With Murder In Slaying of a Suspect in Queens
description: Five New York City police officers were arraigned on murder charges yesterday in the death of a car-theft suspect who the Queens District Attorney said was punched, kicked and choked as he was being arrested.

title: Disney Profit Outlook
description: The Walt Disney Company, coming off its first quarterly earnings drop in six years, expects its profits in the immediate future to remain depressed because of disappointing attendance at its theme parks, the company officials said on Tuesday. The chief financial officer, Judson C. Green, speaking at Disney's annual meeting, blamed the Persian Gulf war and the recession for depressed earnings.

title: Safety Record of Northwest Was Criticized Before Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration was pressing Northwest Airlines to tighten up its safety measures more than a month before two Northwest planes collided on a foggy runway here last December, an agency inspector testified today.

title: Shipping Concern Repurchases Stock
description: The American President Companies, the Oakland, Calif., shipping concern, repurchased about 3.8 million shares of its common stock from the Itel Corporation at a price of $20.50 a share. The company said it would complete the repurchase using cash reserves and money provided by a new $100 million credit facility, which replaces an earlier revolving credit line.

title: Those 'Correct' Schools
description: To The Home Section:

title: The Limits of What Reparations Can Achieve; Symbolic Claimants
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: A Daring Magazine and Its Awkward Questions
description: If the editors of Mexico's newest monthly magazine had merely wanted to print their own views about Mexican politics and society, no one might have cared. What has stirred critics of the new magazine, Este Pais, is a much more delicate editorial goal: to publish what the Mexican people think about themselves.

title: I.B.M. Faces a Harsher World in 90's
description: From a technology standpoint I.B.M.'s house is largely in order, most analysts agree. But the company is clearly worried that it is moving too slowly to transform itself into a pared-down company that can compete in the new world of the 1990's, those analysts say.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Banking Corp., New York, named Zissimos A. Frangopoulos treasurer. * Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, Mich., said its automotive components group had named Frank E. Macher general manager of its plastic and trim products division. He replaces W. H. Fike, who has been named president of Ford of Europe. Charles W. Szuluk succeeds Mr. Macher as general manager of the electronics division.

title: Mayor Seeks 10% Tax Rise And Layoffs In Stamford
description: The Mayor of this Fairfield County corporate center is proposing to lay off 174 city workers and raise property taxes 10 percent in a budget that reflects the impact of reduced state and Federal aid as well as a slowdown in Stamford's once-booming economy.

title: Knicks Go Over .500 Mark
description: Patrick Ewing had toned down his scoring while the Knicks began to win consistently. Ewing has now regained his touch, and the Knicks have not lost theirs.

title: United Parcel's Saturday Plan
description: United Parcel Service announced plans today to deliver overnight packages on Saturdays, in its latest challenge to the Federal Express Corporation's dominance in the $8 billion-a-year overnight delivery market.

title: U.S. and Canada to Speed Tariff Cuts
description: The United States and Canada, which have agreed to wipe out practically all trade barriers before the year 2000, announced today that they would speed up some tariff cutting.

title: Aeromexico Sets Order With Boeing
description: Aeromexico said it would buy 10 Boeing 757's and eight 767's, costing about $1.2 billion. The order was Aeromexico's first from Boeing. Gerardo de Prevoisin, the airline's chairman, said the airline had chosen Boeing because the two aircraft matched the requirements of its expansion.

title: The Bauhaus Style, Root And Branch, to Be Shown
description: AS children, the artist Wassily Kandinsky and the architect Frank Lloyd Wright played with toys that would one day inspire the German design school called the Bauhaus. Toys and other artifacts are in an exhibition on design theory and the Bauhaus that is to open on April 8 at the Herb Lubalin Study Center of Design and Typography at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street (at Third Avenue), and run through May 11.

title: NBC-TV Announces Its Fall Season
description: The first television pilots of spring, unlike the first robins and the first daffodils, aren't always a harbinger of things to come. The pilots bear greater resemblance to the arrival of Beaujolais nouveau and its inevitable decline: three fourths of the comedies and dramas never make it onto the network schedule.

title: Leader of Chinatown Group Slain
description: The leader of one of the fraternal societies that have ruled Chinatown for generations was killed yesterday in a hallway outside his office on Canal Street, the police said.

title: The Hawkers Turn Bitter
description: They took to the streets in the first days after the strike began at The Daily News, hawking newspapers with brassy pitches that harkened back to the gritty journalism of manual typewriters and hot type.

title: Personal Health
description: After nearly a half-century of water fluoridation, it is reasonable to expect that all doubts about its safety would have finally been erased and all questions about its effectiveness definitively answered.

title: Trade Gap Up Slightly, To $7 Billion
description: The nation's trade deficit grew moderately to $7 billion in January as imports rebounded, the Commerce Department reported today. But the import growth was substantially offset by stronger exports.

title: Business and the Law; Putting Lawyers Under Scrutiny
description: LAST summer, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin of Washington sharply criticized the bar in a celebrated case of a collapsed savings and loan. Where were the lawyers, he asked, when the institution and scores like it first began to encounter serious financial problems?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column on Monday about an award presented to Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman and chief executive of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, described the company incorrectly. It is an agricultural exporter, not an importer.

title: Bush Greets Walesa With Debt Relief
description: Welcoming Lech Walesa to the White House for the first time since he was elected President of Poland, President Bush forgave an additional $800 million in Polish debt payments today.

title: Excerpts From Court Ruling on 'Fetal Protection' Policy in Job Screening
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Automobile Workers v. Johnson Controls, holding that the Federal law against sex discrimination prohibits employers from excluding fertile women from jobs that might harm a fetus.

title: Senate Backs Bill That Withholds $55 Million Aid Plan for Jordan
description: Despite strenuous White House opposition from President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the Senate voted today to rescind $55 million in military and economic aid to Jordan.

title: Daily News Strike Ends, and Maxwell Marches In to Take the Reins
description: The ninth and final striking union at The Daily News ratified its contract yesterday, and the British publisher Robert Maxwell then assumed ownership.

title: The Limits of What Reparations Can Achieve; War Guilt and Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Gets Bush Bank Plan
description: The Bush Administration sent to Congress today its sweeping proposal to overhaul the banking system.

title: House to Act On Bailout Bill
description: The House will take up a measure on Thursday providing $30 billion in new money for the bailout of the savings and loan industry, Congressional officials said today.

title: E. Paul Charlap, 66, Leader of Company That Develops Drugs
description: E. Paul Charlap, chairman of the Hem Pharmaceuticals Corporation, a Philadelphia drug research organization, and former head of the Savin Corporation, manufacturers of copying machines, died Tuesday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 66 years old and lived in Plantation Key, Fla.

title: People
description: * Cheryl Lodinger has been promoted to senior vice president-account director in the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson. * Joann P. Valenti-Finley has joined Albrecht Advertising and Design, New York, as executive vice president-managing director.

title: Keep Marching for Equality
description: The St. Patrick's Day parade has always symbolized to me the beauty of unity as New Yorkers, regardless of their heritage, walk up Fifth Avenue to the melodies of cultural pride. But last Saturday, instead of the gracious hospitality usually accorded to marchers and dignitaries alike, I was given a taste of the hostility to which, sadly, certain segments of our society are still subjected because of who they are.

title: A Trail to the Top for Young Skiers
description: The easy answer to the question of how young racers get on the United States Ski Team might be "practice," but it takes more than simply running gates to get on a national ski team. Making it to the top level to race in international competitions requires entering local, state and national races with all the mental and physical preparation that is needed.

title: Lebanon Defense Chief Survives Car Bombing
description: Defense Minister Michel al-Murr, who is in charge of plans for disbanding Lebanon's armed groups, escaped an attempt on his life today when a car bomb hit his motorcade, killing 10 people and wounding 25, the police said.

title: Dr. Frank P. Brooks, Gastroenterologist, 71
description: Dr. Frank Pickering Brooks, a noted gastroenterologist and former chief of the University of Pennsylvania's gastrointestinal section, died Monday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Some Scientists See No Danger in a Decade's Delay in Curbs on Warming
description: A 10-year delay in taking action to curb global warming would mean little further increase in the level of warming predicted by the end of the next century, according to calculations by scientists who advise a United Nations panel dealing with climate change.

title: Arts Lobby Seeks Rise In Budget
description: More than 200 artists, writers, arts educators and leaders of arts organizations gathered today to celebrate Cultural Advocacy Day and urge Congress to increase appropriations for the National Endowment for the Arts. At this time last year the arts endowment was under fire from the political and religious right and its future seemed in doubt. Although the life of the endowment has now been extended for three years, panel members and speakers were not celebrating their victory today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Los Angeles jury awarded PEGGY LEE $2.305 million yesterday as her share of the profits from sales of videocassettes of "Lady and the Tramp." Miss Lee wrote the songs and supplied the voices of four characters in the animated Walt Disney film.
