A Los Angeles Superior Court judge ruled last year that the Walt Disney Company had breached Miss Lee's contract by selling the cassettes without her permission. The second trial in the same court was held to determine Miss Lee's award. "The Disney company has not yet decided whether to appeal," said ROY L. REARDON, who represented the company during the seven-day trial.

title: Alzheimer's Ranks Low Among Causes of Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film Festival; Captive in a Desert Where the Sun Doesn't Burn
description: A camel caravan moves across the otherwise empty desert. The pace is surprisingly brisk, in view of the heat of the white-hot sun, which also bleaches nearly all color from the world. There is purpose to the caravan. Its direction remains fixed, though without apparent guideposts.

title: Awaiting Trial on Drug Charges, Noriega Says He Has Found Jesus
description: While awaiting trial on Federal drug trafficking charges, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has declared himself a born-again Christian, a Southern Baptist newspaper reported yesterday.

title: Five-Day Layoff For 35,000 at Fiat
description: Fiat, Italy's auto giant, said it would lay off 35,000 workers for five days beginning on Monday in a cutback of its monthly production by about 20,000 units. Workers will get about 90 percent of regular pay during the layoff period through a special state fund.

title: Envoy No Longer Silent: April Catherine Glaspie
description: For more than seven months, April C. Glaspie kept silent on what she said or did not say to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in their meeting eight days before his tanks rolled into Kuwait last August.

title: Cuban Defects With MIG-27
description: A defecting Cuban pilot flew an unarmed Soviet-built jet into the Boca Chica Naval Air Station near here today. The Navy identified the pilot only as a 38-year-old military officer seeking political asylum. Ensign Robin Perkins said the pilot had radioed his intentions and had been allowed to land his plane, a MIG-27, without incident.

title: JAPAN SHUTS DOWN 2D NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Japan ordered the shutdown of another nuclear power plant today, after an inspection disclosed the same maintenance flaws that are suspected of leading to the nation's worst nuclear accident at a sister plant last month.

title: Envoy No Longer Silent: April Catherine Glaspie
description: For more than seven months, April C. Glaspie kept silent on what she said or did not say to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in their meeting eight days before his tanks rolled into Kuwait last August.

title: Prettier Poly
description: Polyester is more than a fabric. More than the title of a John Waters movie. More than a way to define iceberg lettuce (described as "the polyester of greens" by Mr. Waters). It is also the most invaluable adjective to come out of the 70's, the one that defines tacky for all time.

title: In Exxon Deal, Transportation Chief Wins Another One for the President
description: A week ago Tuesday, Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of Exxon, flew to Washington. In an informal ceremony at the Justice Department just before midnight he signed a $1.1 billion settlement that he hoped would put the nation's worst oil spill, and the two years of civil and criminal cases that followed, behind him and his company.

title: Gillette Move Is Challenged
description: British regulators yesterday asked the Gillette Company to sell its interest in Swedish Match A.B. because the holding might reduce competition in the British market for shaving products.

title: Trumps Settle; She Gets $14 Million Plus
description: Donald and Ivana Trump are closing the book on their highly public divorce. She gets $14 million, a 45-room Greenwich, Conn., mansion, an apartment in the Trump Plaza, and the use of the 118-room Mar-a-Lago mansion in Florida for one month a year.

title: To Stop Mental Health's Revolving Door
description: John Heard is one of thousands of "revolving door" mental patients in New York City. He had been homeless, and in the winter of 1987 he was involuntarily confined to Bellevue Hospital because of suicidal tendencies. After several weeks he was released again to the streets, where he again became suicidal. After more treatment at city and state psychiatric hospitals, he was again released. He remains homeless.

title: Home Improvement
description: FOR smoothing wood, most amateur woodworkers and even professionals think first of using sandpaper. And for removing finish like paint or varnish, they often use liquid furniture stripper. But centuries before either of those items existed, hand scrapers sufficed for both.

title: Reviving the U.N.
description: A couple of decades ago, the British and American Foreign Ministers were sitting around at a Bermuda summit conference discussing who should be Secretary General of the U.N.

title: Chemical Is Found to Shield Cells in Parkinson's Disease
description: In an important advance in brain research, scientists have found a naturally occurring brain chemical that protects and stimulates the nerve cells that die in people with Parkinson's disease.

title: Silver Prices Drop Sharply; Gasoline Up on Supply Data
description: Silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday, erasing Tuesday's gains, after the market failed to rise above recent highs. Other precious metals prices also fell.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Women as capable of doing their jobs as their male counterparts may not be forced to choose between having a child and having a job." -- Justice Harry A. Blackmun. [ A1:3. ]

title: Founder of Airfone Wins Big Settlement With GTE
description: The GTE Corporation announced a costly settlement yesterday with John D. Goeken, who built the first air-to-ground telephone service company and sold it to GTE in 1986.

title: Plugs
description: "Hey, Stormin' Norman! You've just annihilated the fourth largest army in the world! What are you going to do now?"

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN Jim and Sue DiOrio decided to get a divorce last year, they agreed that they should break the news to their 7-year-old son, Nicholas, together. "But when we told him, he said his stomach hurt and he started vomiting and choking," said Mr. DiOrio, a general contractor in suburban Minneapolis. "He said it wasn't fair to him. He kept asking, 'But why can't we be a family?' "

title: Accounts
description: * Vanity Fair magazine, a Conde Nast publication, to Waring & LaRosa Inc. Billings were not disclosed.

title: For Reed, Steady Steps to Be A Met
description: There were seasons not long ago when each night, indeed each trip to the plate, brought another stance. Darren Reed would shift his feet, tinker with his shoulders, adjust the angle of the bat.

title: Envoy No Longer Silent: April Catherine Glaspie
description: For more than seven months, April C. Glaspie kept silent on what she said or did not say to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in their meeting eight days before his tanks rolled into Kuwait last August.

title: 2 Leading Economists Moving on Wall St.
description: Two of Wall Street's more colorful chief economists are shifting jobs on April 1, each taking with him five or six key staff members.

title: U.S. Moves to Punish Japan for Trade in Turtles
description: The United States issued a finding today that Japan was contributing to the demise of an endangered species of sea turtle by encouraging a lucrative domestic trade in eyeglass frames, mirror handles, ornamental combs and other items made from imported turtle shells.

title: Critic's Notebook; For TV, Children Are Made To Exploit
description: Perceptions of children. Old once-upon-a-time style: trustingly open, impressionable, innocent. Today's television model: savvy, wisecracking, born to be a performer. Hey guys, the indefatigable hawkers of products and programs are insisting, there are no age limits out there on markets waiting for exploitation. As the tactics become more brazen, a good many of the results are increasingly dismaying.

title: Charges Relieve Dead Man's Family
description: The 21-year-old man whose death led to murder charges against five New York City police officers was the loving father of a 3-year-old boy and was patriotic enough to try to enlist at the height of the Persian Gulf war, his parents said yesterday.

title: Cuts Loom in Classes For the Handicapped
description: For the first time, New York City school officials are mounting an intense effort to roll back some expensive programs aimed at handicapped students and other children who need extra academic help.

title: Marshal L. Scott, 81, Ex-Head of Seminary
description: The Rev. Marshal Logan Scott, former president of the McCormick Theological Seminary in Chicago, died March 13 at the Fairhaven retirement home in Whitewater, Wis. He was 81 years old and lived in Whitewater.

title: Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed for Third Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report for the week that ended yesterday were mixed for the third consecutive week.

title: Indiana Seeks Arkansas Showdown
description: Spring has arrived in Charlotte, and with it the top four seeds in the Southeast Regional.

title: Slow Recovery Is Seen For Kuwait and Iraq Oil
description: After detailed surveys of war damage to the oilfields of Kuwait and Iraq, Arab oil industry officials say it will be many months before the two countries can export any significant quantity of oil and years before production is returned to prewar levels. For Kuwait, the restoration of the oil industry is expected to lag behind recovery in the rest of its economy.

title: Heroin Spreads Among Young in China
description: Four decades after China eradicated narcotics use across the country in one of the great achievements of the Communist revolution, heroin is spreading rapidly among young Chinese who are bored and unhappy and looking for diversion.

title: Market Place; A Turning Point For Chip Makers
description: FOR Japan's electronics giants, it was supposed to be a sure thing. By early this year at the latest, their mainstay moneymaker -- the one-megabit memory chip, which holds more than a million bits of information -- should have been heading into retirement. It would be replaced by the four-megabit chip, four times as powerful and, more importantly to the sellers, immensely profitable as computer makers all over the world scrambled for scarce supply.

title: Nets Rally and Get By in Overtime
description: For all the weaknesses that have plagued the Minnesota Timberwolves this season, their one strength, perimeter shooting, was almost good enough to defeat the Nets tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A Sense of History for Your Walls
description: FOR years, Bruce Bradbury was fascinated by anything Victorian, especially wallpaper. So in 1979, Mr. Bradbury, a printer in Benicia, Calif., began making his own, copying Victorian wallpaper patterns and creating new designs with a 19th-century feeling.

title: Schering-Plough Drops Suit
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation agreed today to drop its patent-infringement lawsuit against a New Brunswick research concern over the anticancer agent interferon.

title: Guilty in Death of Newborn
description: A jury here found a 19-year-old Cutchogue woman guilty of second-degree manslaughter today for wrapping her newborn son in plastic and setting him adrift on a lake near her home. The defendant, Amy Ellwood, who concealed her pregnancy from her family, gave birth to the child in a bathtub on Sept. 8, 1989. She was accused of wrapping the baby in a plastic bag and setting him adrift in a cooler on Laurel Lake near her home 15 hours after the birth. The body was found Sept. 9, 1989.

title: Etienne Decroux Is Dead at 92; Master of Modern French Mime
description: Etienne Decroux, an actor and teacher who has been called the father of modern French mime, died on March 12 in Boulogne-Billancourt, a suburb of Paris. He was 92 years old.

title: The Madness In March, Et Cetera
description: Despite the Knight Foundation Commission report on big-time college athletics released Tuesday, there remains one confounding question. And it wasn't answered satisfactorily that same night on the wide-ranging, three-hour discussion on the Public Broadcasting System television show, "Sports for Sale," with Bill Moyers.

title: Investor Prepares For DeSoto Fight
description: The New York investor William Spier said he would begin a proxy fight for seats on DeSoto Inc.'s board if efforts to negotiate a takeover fall through. Mr. Spier, chairman of the Sutton Holding Corporation, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was still trying to acquire DeSoto through negotiation. Sutton has proposed a merger in which stockholders would get $5.50 a share in cash and securities.

title: Hawkins Is Wild and Pays the Price
description: Andy Hawkins was hit so hard in the first inning today that if George Steinbrenner had been sitting in the white limousine behind left field, as was rumored, he might have got out and fined the pitcher or got rid of him. It got that ugly.

title: INSIDE
description: Move to Cut Aid to Jordan Over Administraton objections, the Senate voted to withhold $55 million in aid to Jordan in retaliation for Amman's pro-Iraq tilt. Page A14. Trade Deficit Grows A jump in imports pushed the nation's trade deficit up moderately in January, to $7 billion, but exports also showed strength. Page D1. Advance in Brain Research The discovery of a naturally occurring brain chemical may open the way for research on new treatments for Parkinson's disease. Page B10. Michael Jackson's New Deal Michael Jackson and Sony have a new agreement under which the singer will star in his own movies and get his own record label. Page C17. Fashion: A New Front As the first major American designer to show in Paris, Oscar de la Renta leads the way to international marketing. The Home Section, page C1.

title: Dykstra on Probation
description: Lenny Dykstra of the Philadelphia Phillies was placed on a year's probation by Commissioner Fay Vincent because of his gambling activities.

title: For Containers Worthy of Flowers
description: IN the world of flowers, arranging is only half the battle. Selecting the right container is the other.

title: Those Who Were Charged
description: Sgt. Barry Goldblatt, 48,of Syosset, L.I., joined the force in 1968 . . . has 24 excellent police duty awards, eight meritorious police duty awards and two commendations . . . spent most of career in plainclothes street-crime units . . . promoted to detective in 1973 . . . served with Scientific Research Division . . . promoted to sergeant in 1987 . . . transferred to the 112th Precinct in Queens where he was a commander of precinct's anti-crime unit. Police Officer Thomas Leoffel, 25, until recently of Woodhaven, Queens, joined department in 1986 . . . Has one excellent police duty award and one meritorious police duty award . . . assigned to the 112th Precinct in 1990 after serving in the Manhattan Traffic Division.

title: U.S Motor Vehicle Population Gaining
description: To the Editor:

title: Natural Isn't Benign
description: To The Home Section:

title: Sterling Optical Appoints Chief and No. 2 Executive
description: The Sterling Optical Corporation named two top executives yesterday.

title: Anheuser-Busch Has a New Beer
description: The world's largest brewer, the Anheuser-Busch Companies, is introducing another brand of beer in its continuing effort to increase its market share. Anheuser-Busch plans to test-market its latest entry, Natural Pilsner, in Arizona, California and Nevada beginning on Monday. By April 15, the full-calorie brother of Natural Light will also be sold in Ohio, Tennessee and West Virginia.

title: Final Arguments Heard In New Hampshire Trial That Rivals Soap Opera
description: In a murder case that has become New Hampshire's own real-life soap opera, the prosecution charged in closing arguments today that Pamela Smart, a 23-year-old high school teacher, got her "hook so deep into the hormones" of one of her students that he killed her husband for her.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARRY LEVINSON and MICHAEL BLAKE won the annual Writers Guild Awards, Mr. Levinson for "Avalon" and Mr. Blake for "Dances With Wolves." The awards were announced yesterday by the guild's East and West Coast branches in New York and Los Angeles. Mr. Levinson won for best screenplay written for a film, and Mr. Blake for best screenplay adapted from another medium, in this case his own novel.

title: Review/Fashion; New Tricolor In Paris: Stars And Stripes
description: With polished, lively clothes that were international in spirit, Oscar de la Renta's fall opening on Tuesday in the courtyard of the Louvre was a turning point in the marketing of American fashion. It was the first time an American had joined the cadre of top fashion houses in the ready-to-wear showings here.

title: Jacques Koopman, Holocaust Survivor Was a Silver Dealer
description: Jacques Koopman, a British silver dealer, died yesterday at his London home. He was 60 years old.

title: In Paris, Ghastly Music and Frye Boots
description: The French fashion world reacted to the Paris debut of Oscar de la Renta with a mixture of respect, careful praise and a bit of traditional snobbery.

title: Aide to Arafat Is in Hot Water
description: Palestine Liberation Organization officials say a senior aide to Yasir Arafat offered to quit over his reported remarks that Palestinians might settle for less than the entire West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Israeli opinions on territories seized in the 1967 war referred imprecisely to remarks by the Israeli Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron. He spoke in general terms; he did not refer specifically to the Golan Heights.

title: Apple Will Buy Colorado Plant
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would expand its manufacturing capacity by purchasing a 340,000- square-foot building in Fountain, Colo. The building, which is owned by the Data General Corporation, will be Apple's fourth manufacturing plant, adding to existing factories in Fremont, Calif.; Cork, Ireland, and Singapore. Fountain is about 12 miles south of Colorado Springs.

title: Denial by Texas Player
description: Texas defensive tackle James Patton denied an allegation that he switched urine samples during a steroid test.

title: Here We Go Again -- Arming the Mideast
description: Momentum for a new arms race in the Middle East is already building. As Yuli Vorontsov, the Soviet Ambassador to the United Nations points out, everybody was so awed by America's high-tech weapons in the gulf war that every country in the Middle East is clamoring for something similar.

title: Expected Surprise
description: We come now to March 21 and blooming time for all the cliches of spring. As they do year after year, the crocuses open cheerily and the daffodils nod in the breeze. The robins chirp as they hunt for early worms and northbound geese honk in the gathering dusk. Burnished doves moan their doleful love songs and young men's fancies turn.

title: Home Is 18th-Century London, Without Lights, Plumbing Or Unwelcome Relatives
description: DENNIS SEVERS had a Southern California childhood straight out of a David Hockney painting, with blue skies, palm trees and sun. But when he closed his eyes, he would imagine himself in a room composed by Vermeer, rich in candlelight and sumptuous fabrics.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Audition for a Would-Be Star; Coaches Put Young Quarterback Through His Paces
description: The event was played out on a grassy football field with only a handful of coaches, two wide receivers, one football and a 6-foot-8-inch quarterback.

title: Yugoslavia Edges Away From the Brink
description: The major antagonists in Yugoslavia's nationalist political conflicts appeared today to have pulled back from the brink of armed confrontation.

title: Suspect in Fatal Arson Had Called Fire a 'Nightmare'
description: "I heard a lot of people screaming," a 16-year-old said on March 13 at a fire in the South Bronx that killed six people. "The block was full of smoke. The fire was going like a torch. It was a nightmare on this block."

title: Kuwaiti Cabinet Resigns
description: Criticized for failing to quickly restore services in Kuwait, the Cabinet of Prime Minister Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah resigned. Page A15.

title: When a Marriage Is Sunshine vs. Moonlight
description: MIDNIGHT in Los Angeles. A blond woman in a nightgown stares from a window of a bluish-gray house into the backyard where a man sits in the window of a bluish-gray hut. The man looks up from the glowing screen of a word processor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; With Caution, Geer, DuBois Manages a Shift at the Top
description: A GROWING number of mid- sized agencies built in Madison Avenue's heyday in the 1960's and early 1970's now face the difficult challenge of finding new top executives to replace retiring founders.

title: Paramount's Studio Chief Resigns
description: Frank G. Mancuso resigned yesterday as chairman of Paramount Pictures, two days after Stanley Jaffe was named president and chief executive of Paramount Communications Inc., the studio's parent company. That appointment put Mr. Jaffe over Mr. Mancuso; as an independent producer with a contract at Paramount, Mr. Jaffe had effectively reported to Mr. Mancuso.

title: Candidate's Worthiness for Bench Is Questioned by Panel Chairman
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, today sharply questioned the fitness of Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp of a Federal district court in Florida to be elevated to a Federal appeals court.

title: Russ Thomas; Sports Executive, 66
description: Russ Thomas, who worked for 42 years with the Detroit Lions of the National Football League as a player, scout, broadcaster, assistant coach, controller, personnel director and general manager, died in his sleep on Monday night at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 66 years old. A spokesman for the Lions said the exact time and cause of death were unknown.

title: Jackson's Agent Says Yanks Show Strong Interest
description: The Yankees remained noncommittal today about their intentions in the Bo Jackson chase, but his agent described their interest as "very serious."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Marie-Louise Sherwin, Psychiatrist-Priest, 76
description: The Rev. Dr. Marie-Louise Schoelly Sherwin, a psychiatrist and an ordained Episcopal priest, died on Tuesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Metro Matters; Brutal Question: Police Violence, Public Trust
description: In 1935, Police Commissioner Lewis Valentine of New York City interrupted a line-up to berate the arresting officers. Why, he demanded, had they brought in a murder suspect without first "mussing him up?"

title: Home-Loan Issue By Fleet/Norstar
description: Fleet Finance Home Equity Trust 1991-1, a unit of Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., Providence, R.I., is offering about $380 million in securities backed by home-equity loans through the First Boston Corporation.

title: Rangers Clinging in Zany Patrick Race
description: What the Patrick Division lacks in excellence, it makes up in balance and competition. In the other three divisions of the National Hockey League, 11 of 12 playoff berths are clinched. In the Patrick, all four post-season slots are up for grabs with 11 days left in the six-month season.

title: Study Finds U.S. Behind In Key Fields
description: The United States, which had a commanding lead in high technology a decade ago, is now losing badly to foreign competitors in a number of fields considered crucial, a group of executives said today.

title: Crucial Data Were Fabricated In Report Signed by Top Biologist
description: After one of the most celebrated investigations of scientific misconduct in the United States, the National Institutes of Health has concluded that crucial data were faked in a report signed by a leading molecular biologist.

title: At Newsstands Soon: a Daily Slugfest
description: A battle royal among New York City's tabloid newspapers is about to begin.

title: Friend Relives Night of Police Beating
description: As Rodney G. King was beaten by Los Angeles police officers on March 3, other officers seized one of Mr. King's passengers, Bryant Allen, who says he was manhandled and taunted in a racially motivated attempt to provoke him.

title: Army Warns of Diseases Linked to War
description: Doctors who treat soldiers returning from the Persian Gulf should be on the lookout for a variety of exotic diseases, including plague and sand fly fever, the Army warns.

title: A Fast Fire, and a Thai Slum's Slow Poisoning
description: Some of Thailand's poorest still pick their way through the slum where they lived until early this month, when it was destroyed in a huge chemical explosion and fireball. But now they press rags to their faces in a largely useless effort to avoid further chemical poisoning.

title: Can Washington End Hussein's Rule Yet Keep His Country in One Piece?
description: The American downing of an Iraqi warplane today demonstrates the Bush Administration's willingness to use additional military force to humble Iraq as long as President Saddam Hussein remains in power and presages an active postwar pressure campaign to oust the Iraqi leader, Administration officials say.

title: New Avon Campaign About to Get Under Way
description: The sound of a ringing doorbell followed by the slogan "Avon calling" is long gone, but Avon Products Inc. is starting a new campaign to tell consumers that the door-to-door cosmetics and fragrance company is still around.

title: Books of The Times; The Rising and Falling in One Family
description: Caroline's Daughters By Alice Adams 307 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The singer Whitney Houston is the star of a new series of public service announcements for the Greater New York division of the Salvation Army. The spots, which were prepared by MG Productions, New York, will be sent to radio and television stations in the New York area on April 15.

title: Key Rates
Review/Opera; Early Debut for Soprano Who Won Tucker Award
description: Renee Fleming, the soprano who won the 1990 Richard Tucker Award, was scheduled to make her Metropolitan Opera debut next season. But when the flu forced Felicity Lott to postpone her first Met appearance as the Countess in Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" on Saturday evening, Ms. Fleming, who was covering the role, stepped in and made an early and auspicious debut.

title: Minority Scholarships Get Tentative Approval
description: Evidently eager to quell further public controversy about minority scholarships, Lamar Alexander, the new Education Secretary, announced today that universities and colleges should continue allowing scholarships reserved for specific ethnic groups while the Education Department reviewed the issue.

title: Illusion May Shed Light On Fate of the Cosmos
description: In the continuing effort to determine the age and fate of the universe, an astronomer has tested an ingenious measuring technique using an optical illusion in space. The result yields an estimated time of 20 billion years since everything supposedly began with the Big Bang.

title: Envoy to Iraq, Faulted in Crisis, Says She Warned Hussein Sternly
description: April C. Glaspie, the American Ambassador to Iraq, said today that she repeatedly warned President Saddam Hussein of Iraq last summer against using violence to settle his border dispute with Kuwait. But the Iraqi leader ignored the signals because he was too "stupid" to understand how the United States would react, she said.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Orders Training Review
description: Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Los Angeles police said today that he has ordered a "brick by brick" review of training procedures in the wake of the videotaped beating of a black motorist by white officers on March 3.

title: A Suspension For Blinder
description: A two-year suspension of Blinder, Robinson & Company took effect last week after the penny-stock firm dropped an appeal, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: White House Endorses Redesigned Space Station
description: The Bush Administration today endorsed the space agency's plan to build a scaled-down space station, saying the importance of the project in maintaining the country's technical leadership exceeded any limitations in its scientific value.

title: For Design Mart, East River May Yet Prove Unbridgeable
description: IT is quiet these days at the International Design Center, New York, in Long Island City, Queens. The corridors are virtually empty. The 10-acre $150 million complex of furniture showrooms, which seemed so promising when it opened in 1985, seems to have aged prematurely.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Oklahoma Triumphs Bryan Sallier scored 20 of his 26 points in the second half last night as the Oklahoma Sooners advanced to the National Invitation Tournament semifinals with an 83-74 victory over the Friars in Providence. Oklahoma (19-14) went on a 16-4 run early in the second half to pull ahead, 58-44, with 13 minutes 22 seconds left. Providence (19-13) could get no closer than 60-57 with 10 minutes left. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics Set Back Bullets Reggie Lewis scored 22 of his 28 points in the first half, and Kevin Gamble added 20 last night to lead the Boston Celtics past the visiting Washington Bullets, 102-81. (AP) 76ers 107, Pistons 103: Charles Barkley scored 32 points and Hersey Hawkins added 9 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter to lead Philadelphia at home. It was the ninth loss in the last 13 games for Detroit. The Pistons played without forward Mark Aguirre, who was poked in the right eye in practice Tuesday. (AP) Bulls 129, Hawks 107: Michael Jordan scored 22 points and Horace Grant added 20 as the Bulls won their 25th consecutive home game. The triumph was the Bulls' ninth in a row and 20th in their last 21 games. They are 30-3 in the Chicago Stadium and 50-15 over all, tops in the league. (AP)

title: Offer to Acquire FNN Is Raised to $115 Million
description: Dow Jones and Westinghouse Broadcasting sweetened their bid to acquire FNN to $115 million yesterday, meeting the minimum price set by a Federal bankruptcy judge earlier this month.

title: Hewlett's Sprightly New Mood
description: A series of anonymous advertisements ran in newspapers around the country last week. "57 MIPS, under $12K," said one. And at the bottom in parentheses it added, "If you guess Sun, you guess wrong."

title: Peering Through 3 Centuries of Windows
description: "Don't throw stones at your neighbors', if your own windows are glass," Benjamin Franklin warned in 1736. The National Building Museum in Washington presents other lessons of history in the exhibit "Windows Through Time: American Windows From the 1630's to the 1930's," which will be on display through July 21. The exhibit includes 18 original and historic windows from residential and commercial buildings. It also examines glassmaking techniques, along with original tools and materials. The exhibit was assembled to foster a greater appreciation of historic windows in historic buildings, said the curator, Charles Fisher.

title: Samuel A. Turvey, 91, Staten Island Banker
description: Samuel A. Turvey, a retired Staten Island banker who was active in local civic organizations, died on Monday at Carmel Richmond Nursing Home in Dongan Hills, S.I. He was 91 years old and lived in Grymes Hill, S.I.

title: COURT BACKS RIGHT OF WOMEN TO JOBS WITH HEALTH RISKS
description: In one of its most important sex discrimination rulings in recent years, the Supreme Court declared today that employers may not exclude women from jobs in which exposure to toxic substances could harm a developing fetus.

title: 8,000 Orchids Await the Oohs and Aahs
description: Eight thousand speckled, striated and ombred orchids, in shades ranging from ivory to terra cotta to dark purple, bloom at the 1991 Greater New York Orchid Show at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center in Manhattan. The show, which opens today at 10 A.M., exhibits a sampling of the largest group of flowering plants in nature. There are more than 25,000 known species of orchids.

title: Increase in Lyme Cases Creates a Mystery
description: Doctors say they are seeing what looks like Lyme disease in the Southeast and the southern Midwest, parts of the country where it is not supposed to exist. This has left scientists at the Federal Centers for Disease Control wondering if they are witnessing the spread of Lyme, the emergence of a new related illness or merely Lyme hysteria.

title: Review/Music; Isaac Stern Gives Recital (Without the Gas Mask)
description: The sense of occasion surrounding Isaac Stern's recital last Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was heightened, no doubt, by the unforgettable images of his performance in Jerusalem last month during a missile attack. But how distant those embattled days already seemed, with no special security measures anywhere apparent in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium.

title: Burgeonings: Spring Events
description: Drifting Colors Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (212) 220-8777.

title: Riverside Park Journal; A Path Where the City Bumps Against Nature
description: New Yorkers have heard all about the alleged grandeur of nature, but they have always been bothered by a major flaw: Nature is not conveniently located. It was with this problem in mind that a dozen hikers set out along the Hudson River on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Familiar Foes for Seton Hall in the West
description: It might be a little too cosmic to suggest that Seton Hall, Arizona and Nevada-Las Vegas are basketball soul mates. But P. J. Carlesimo, the Seton Hall coach, concedes that for the last three years the teams seem to have been inextricably bound.

title: For the Passover Seder: Traditions to Start Now
description: TRADITIONALLY, the Passover seder table is set with the best tableware in the house. It is never too late to start a tradition: Pieces used for the seder rituals come in many styles.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from the Film Society of Lincoln Center yesterday, about the coming PBS broadcast of "The Mahabharata," misidentifed the actress shown. She was Miriam Goldschmidt.

title: Devising New Identities for Sisal
description: IN the 80's sisal, that thick-textured matting of woven rope, was de rigueur. Now designers and manufacturers are taking sisal one step further.

title: A Hogan Can Be as Good as a Log Cabin
description: To the Editor:

title: Tulsa Coach Dismissed
description: J. D. Barnett, who succeeded Nolan Richardson as coach at Tulsa and complied a 106-75 record over six seasons, was dismissed yesterday. His Hurricane teams failed to win a game in two trips each to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Paris Told to Shape Up
description: The San Francisco 49ers have given Bubba Paris the word: trim down or else. Paris, who weighed more than 360 pounds late last season, was given the ultimatum Tuesday by Coach George Seifert.

title: The Limits of What Reparations Can Achieve
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Players from New York State, mainly from New York City, were outstandingly successful in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, which ended on Sunday in Atlantic City. They were champions or runners-up in all but one of the seven major events contested, a far better record than any other area of the country could claim.

title: Bizarre Priorities on Arms
description: It's a propitious moment to curb arms sales. Iraq has just demonstrated the perils of arming states to the teeth in the Middle East. And arms buyers and sellers are looking to Washington for leadership. But instead of trying to negotiate restraints, President Bush seems eager to reopen the Middle East arms bazaar. It's up to Congress to reverse his priorities.

title: Review/Music; A Cincinnati Chorus Visits
description: Perhaps no other American city has cultivated the classical choral tradition more assiduously than Cincinnati. The Cincinnati May Festival, a choral event presented every two years from 1873 to 1967 and annually thereafter, claims to be the oldest continuous music festival in the United States.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Avery Dennison Corp., Pasadena, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $100 million in debt securities. * Associates First Capital Corp., a subsidiary of Ford Motor Co., has filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of up to $300 million in senior unsecured notes.

title: Language Of Building Decoded
description: ARCHITECTS, decorators and contractors sometimes seem to speak a foreign language.

title: Tax Burden Drives People From New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Visiting Conductor Offers Works He Commissioned
description: Paul Sacher brought a distinctly proprietary air to two works he conducted over the weekend with the New York Chamber Orchestra of the 92d Street Y, and well he might. These pieces, Bartok's Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta (1936) and Stravinsky's Concerto in D for strings (1946), are among the many the Swiss conductor has commissioned for his Basel Chamber Orchestra.

title: Press Reports in Lebanon Say Hostages Will Be Freed Soon
description: Two daily newspapers here reported today that a breakthrough had been made in efforts to free the 12 Western hostages in Lebanon and that some would be released as early as Friday.

title: RJR Plans Stock Sale To Cut Debt
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the consumer-products giant that emerged from history's largest leveraged buyout, said yesterday that it planned to sell 75 million shares, increasing the company's publicly held portion to as much as 22.8 percent, from 17.1 percent.

title: Dinkins Asks Unions to Give Back Gains to Help Shrink Government
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins asked municipal labor leaders yesterday to roll back health-insurance costs and other benefits as he, for the first time, proposed a long-term strategy to close a soaring city budget gap by permanently shrinking the size and cost of the government.

title: Michael Jackson Gets Thriller of Deal To Stay With Sony
description: In what may be the most lucrative arrangement ever for a recording artist, the Sony Corporation announced yesterday that Michael Jackson, the gyrating pop-music icon of the 1980's, had entered into an agreement to create feature films, theatrical shorts, television programming and a new record label for the Japanese conglomerate's American entertainment subsidiaries.

title: More Such Victories Could Balkanize Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Seles Gains In Struggle But Agassi Loses One
description: The defending champions of the Lipton International Players Championships, Monica Seles and Andre Agassi, received some irreverent treatment from their adversaries today and only the women's champion conjured sufficient mettle to survive.

title: Networks Trying to Reopen Rerun Talks With Studios
description: Faced with the likelihood of a big regulatory defeat, the three leading television networks are trying to reopen private negotiations with Hollywood studios over television rerun rights.

title: Review/Dance; A Lifetime of Innovating, and Now the Computer
description: On the eve of his 72d birthday, Merce Cunningham has had one of the biggest triumphs of his career as a dancer and choreographer.

title: Gerald Cramer Dead; Art Publisher Was 74
description: Gerald Cramer, a Swiss art dealer and publisher, died on Sunday at his home in Mies, a suburb of Geneva. He was 74 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.

title: Bailout Called Too Slow In Recouping Money
description: A Senate panel criticized Federal regulators today for what it said was their slowness in recovering taxpayer dollars from rescues of savings and loan associations that failed in 1988-89.

title: A New Chief at Provident
description: John A. Miller, chairman and chief executive of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company, said this week that he would step down in June after 13 years as chief executive.

title: Milking Poor Families
description: What's one of the first things you'd do if you wanted to devastate poor families with young children? Raise milk prices. That's exactly what the Senate has approved, without hearings, as an amendment to an emergency appropriations bill. The provision would raise the price of whole milk by as much as 26 cents per gallon and low-fat milk by as much as 40 cents per gallon.

title: Europe Raises Limit on Goods
description: European travelers will be free this summer to take home more goods that were bought in other European Community countries.

title: Editors' Note
description: Because of a computer typesetting misadjustment, the Money Market Funds table appearing in Business Day each Thursday since Feb. 14 has carried incorrect figures for the total assets of some funds and for their yields. The asset figures have omitted the billions column for amounts of $1 billion or more; a fund, for example, with assets of $12.345 billion would have been shown with $345 million. In addition, since Feb. 21, the column labeled 7-day yield has actually shown the 7-day effective yield, a higher figure.

title: Employers Left With Many Decisions
description: As a result of the Supreme Court ruling today on women's job rights, employers are left with a variety of choices: letting workers decide for themselves whether to accept jobs that might endanger their reproductive systems, reducing all workers' exposure to hazardous substances, using safer materials if possible or equipping all with breathing and other safety devices.

title: Boeing Agrees to Pact With 2 Competitors
description: Faced with increasingly fierce overseas competition, the Boeing Company said today that it had agreed to join forces with two key European competitors in deals to develop supersonic planes and aerospace and military opportunities.

title: Tenant Patrol Captain Slain In Her East Side Apartment
description: A well-liked 81-year-old woman who was a tenant patrol captain in the Rutgers Houses on the Lower East Side of Manhattan was found stabbed to death in her apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Not Starting First Game Angers Reds' Rijo
description: Jose Rijo, the most valuable player in last fall's World Series, is fuming over Manager Lou Piniella's choice of Tom Browning to be the Cincinnati Reds' opening-day starter.

title: PRESSING HUSSEIN, U.S. SHOOTS DOWN AN IRAQI AIRCRAFT
description: Stepping up the pressure on President Saddam Hussein, an American F-15 shot down an Iraqi fighter-bomber over Iraq today. President Bush warned that allied forces would fire on any other aircraft that defy the ban on Iraqi military flights imposed by the forces that drove Baghdad's troops from Kuwait.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Elkem, a Norwegian light metals maker, said it was selling its 50 percent stake in Alcoa Nederland Holding B.V. to Aluminium Co. of America, Pittsburgh, for $80 million to give Alcoa 100 percent of Alcoa Nederland. * First Empire State Corp., Buffalo, a bank holding company, said the investor Warren Buffett had completed the purchase of a $40 million stake in the company.

title: Air Traffic Drops 26.8%
description: International airline passenger traffic dropped by 26.8 percent last month on United States airlines amid a recession and the fear of terrorism, the Air Transport Association says.

title: Buildings As Artists See Them
description: "PERSPECTIVE ON PERSPECTIVE: Architectural and Interior Drawings by New York Illustrators" opened yesterday at the gallery at the New York School of Interior Design. The exhibition includes the work of 25 contemporary artists on such landmark subjects as the Chrysler Building, Grand Central Terminal, the Paris Opera House and even some architectural fantasies.

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading yesterday, as at least some investors apparently decided that after recent sharp declines, notes and bonds were being offered at attractive levels.

title: High Court Overturns Ruling in Weight Case
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a $44,000 award to a nursing student who was dismissed from a Rhode Island college for being too fat.

title: House Committee Approves Bill Assuring Family Leave
description: A measure that would guarantee workers up to 12 weeks' unpaid leave for the birth of a child or because of family illness won a House committee's approval today despite the threat of another veto from President Bush.

title: Europe Tries Bank Reform
description: The European Community has started a drive to cut the cost and increase the speed of the millions of money transfers that banks process daily in its 12 member nations, the community's executive body said today.

title: Threat of Fire Brings Coffee Maker Recall
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that because of fuses that may pose a fire hazard, it was recalling electric drip coffee makers that were manufactured under the G.E. and Universal brands from 1976 to 1984.

title: Loring McMillen, 85, an Engineer And a Founder of S.I. Restoration
description: Loring McMillen, a former civil engineer for the New York Telephone Company whose love of local history led to the development of Richmondtown, a museum and historical village on Staten Island, died on Tuesday at his home in Richmondtown. He was 85 years old.

title: Eric Clapton's Son Killed in a 49-Story Fall
description: The 4 1/2-year-old son of the rock guitarist Eric Clapton was killed yesterday morning when he fell out an open bedroom window on the 53d floor of a Manhattan apartment building.

title: U.S. to Review Way Overseas Air Fares Are Set
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that he and his staff would review whether the United States should continue providing antitrust immunity to airlines so that they can fix prices on international routes.

title: After Death: Hotels, Golf and a Court
description: Not one theologian speculating about the next world has ever imagined a place with three championship golf courses and tour guides who encourage new arrivals to "sit back and have fun!" But then Albert Brooks, whose vision of the afterlife as a conventioneer's daydream is the basis for "Defending Your Life," is no ordinary thinker in any sphere.

title: U.S. EXPLAINS VIEW ON ENVOY TO IRAQ
description: The Bush Administration moved today to counter the impression that it callously left April C. Glaspie, the American Ambassador to Iraq, as a scapegoat for failing to prevent President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait.

title: 92 Senegalese Soldiers Die In Saudi Arabia Air Crash
description: Ninety-two Senegalese soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of the multinational force were killed today when their transport plane crashed at a Saudi air base while landing in smoke-blackened skies, allied officials said.

title: Witness Recounts Audit of Flake in 80's
description: Long before the tax-evasion indictment of the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a $36,000-a-year charge for transporting elderly residents of a federally subsidized Queens housing complex headed by Mr. Flake was found to be unjustified, an independent auditor testified yesterday.

title: George W. Grider; Ex-Congressman, 78
description: Former Representative George W. Grider, a highly decorated submarine commander in World War II, died Wednesday at his home in Memphis. He was 78 years old.

title: Accounts
description: * Richard Barrie Fragrances Inc., East Hampton, L.I., to I. Goldberg & Partners Inc., New York, for its Misha and Baryshnikov fragrances. Billings are $1 million. * Jus-rol, a frozen pastry line recently acquired by Pillsbury, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., to Leo Burnett Ltd., London. Billings were not disclosed.

title: 2 Bands Revive a Sound They Never Experienced
description: There is a definite irony in the way current alternative rock has revived the sound of the 1960's: bands whose members are too young to have experienced that decade first-hand are making liberal use of the imagery, iconography, sounds and dress code of late-60's rock. Tonight, Ride and the Original Sins, two bands that acknowledge 60's influences, though in very different ways, will perform at the Marquee.

title: Our Towns; Hunting for Elk On the Terrain Of Imagination
description: Sadly, but not surprisingly, not one single elk responded to the magnificent elk calls of Mark Shea here the other night. That's probably because the last recorded elk in Connecticut was shot and eaten some 200 years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Coastal Refining and Marketing Inc., Houston, was awarded a $231.1 million Defense Department contract to provide jet fuel. * CPC International Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., a maker of food products, formed a venture with a Hungarian state-owned company, Szegedi Paprika Vallalat, to make and sell soups and other products in Hungary.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: L.A. Gear Files Nike Countersuit
description: L.A. Gear Inc. filed a $3 billion lawsuit today against Nike Inc., charging Nike with trying to monopolize the market for high-tech sneakers and drive L.A. Gear out of business. The countersuit was filed after Nike sued L.A. Gear last month for patent infringement. L.A. Gear, based in Los Angeles, accuses Nike of trying to monopolize the high-technology basketball shoe market. L.A. Gear denied that its new Catapult shoe technology infringed any patents.

title: Rebels Start Slowly And Then Run Away From Utah by 83-66
description: Suspenseful it wasn't. But it also wasn't the kind of one-sided game it figured to be.

title: Turtles Clean Up Their Act But Still Try the Patience
description: QUESTION: How many Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles does it take to screw in a light bulb?

title: Death Penalty Urged in Slayings of 5 Drifters
description: Rejecting pleas for mercy on a defendant whose lawyer characterized him as an old and sickly man, a jury has recommended the death penalty for a farmer convicted of killing five drifters to cover up a fraudulent cattle-buying scheme.

title: Corestates Barring Bid for Bank Units
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation, a Philadelphia banking company, said it would not bid for any units of the Bank of New England Corporation, which were seized by Federal regulators early this year. Corestates, like Keycorp, an Albany banking company that recently said it would not bid for any of the subsidiaries, said the Bank of New England units would not meet its profit goals.

title: Tyson-W.B.A. Lawsuit Knocked Out By Judge
description: A Federal judge has thrown out a lawsuit that Mike Tyson brought against the World Boxing Association for sanctioning the coming heavyweight championship fight between Evander Holyfield and George Foreman.

title: Continental Loss Totals $2.25 Billion
description: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. announced the largest quarterly loss in American aviation history yesterday: $2.25 billion in the fourth quarter.

title: Fed Is Urged to Cut Rates
description: The Joint Economic Committee of Congress urged the Federal Reserve Board today to lower interest rates as "insurance" against a long recession.

title: Review/Art; Shifted Images of the Renaissance
description: Sarah Charlesworth works with issues and strategies that came to the fore in the 1980's. For example, she appropriates images from a variety of sources, including books. She uses photographs not to document reality but to question what reality is and to expose meanings in Eastern and Western art that have not previously been brought to the surface. She dislikes generalizations and makes art that argues that nothing can be known once and for all, and no identity -- whether personal, sexual or national -- is ever immutable.

title: U.S. Seeks Much Bigger Amount To Shore Up Bank Deposit Fund
description: L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that the Bush Administration's plan to shore up the ailing program that protects deposits in the nation's banks calls for an increase in his agency's borrowing authority of $70 billion, not the $25 billion the Administration proposed earlier this week.

title: NCR Accounting Tactic Could Hurt Any Merger
description: As the American Telephone and Telegraph Company continues its pursuit of the NCR Corporation and the NCR board finds itself under increased pressure to negotiate a merger, Wall Street traders say a little-noticed tactic that NCR used early in the takeover contest to make itself less attractive might now backfire and prevent the company from getting the highest price possible for its shares.

title: Roll 'Em,' Says News as Strikers Return to Work
description: With the new owner, Robert Maxwell, pushing the button to roll the presses at the Brooklyn plant, nearly 1,000 union members returned to work last night at The Daily News.

title: Times to Lay Off 61 Employees; Poor Economic Conditions Cited
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that poor economic conditions made it necessary to dismiss 61 employees, all of them members of the Newspaper Guild.

title: How the Elderly Trade Work for Tax Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: Biologist Who Disputed a Study Paid Dearly
description: When Dr. Margot O'Toole, a junior researcher in molecular biology, raised uncomfortable questions in 1986 about the validity of a senior colleague's work, she felt alone.

title: From Russia, Kafka in Wonderland
description: Sitting in a nearly empty hotel dining room, a baffled engineer named Aleksei watches the waiter wheel a dessert cart to his table. "I didn't order dessert," Aleksei says, but this one was custom-made: a cake that stares back at him in the precise size, shape and color of his own head, right down to the lucid, light-blue eyes. Refusing a slice of his own nose, he ignores the waiter's warning that "the chef will kill himself." Bad choice. Even as he heads for the door, Aleksei hears a shot and turns to see the insulted pastry maker keel over right in front of the happily playing band.

title: Holmes Taught Responsibility of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Business Express, Westport, Conn., a commuter airline that is a regional affiliate of Delta Air Lines and is a subsidiary of Marketing Corp. of America, named James J. Malski president. Mr. Malski, who will continue as chief operating officer, replaces James R. McManus, who relinquishes the post of acting president but remains chairman and chief executive. * Cartier Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Cartier International Inc., named Herve Martin vice president, retail.

title: No Easy Paths to Midwest Semifinals
description: When Malik Sealy and his St. John's teammates arrived for practice at the Silverdome today, the day before their Midwest Regional semifinal meeting with Ohio State, Sealy brought along a hand-held video camera.

title: Capitals Get Back Into Playoff Hunt
description: The Washington Capitals entered the Nassau Coliseum tonight with their eyes fixed on the fourth and final playoff spot in the Patrick Division. No problem

title: Minorities A Majority In New York
description: The number of Hispanic residents in New York City grew 26.8 percent in the 1980's as minority groups became a majority of the city's population for the first time, new census figures show.

title: Man Who Beat Gay Men Has the AIDS Virus
description: Doctors say it is possible that a 49-year-old heterosexual man was infected with the AIDS virus through cuts on his hands when he beat up gay men.

title: Panel Says Reports of Rape Soared Above 100,000 in '90
description: The number of rapes reported in the United States exceeded 100,000 last year for the first time, a Senate report said today.

title: We Expect the Police to Give Out Punishment; Civilian Control Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: In Face of Cuts, Fernandez Calls for Increase in Budget
description: Faced with the prospect of chopping $505 million out of next year's budget, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday resorted to stiff-necked bargaining tactics: He asked for $26 million more to spend.

title: Managers Agree To Forgo Pay Raise
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. got a piece of the $400 million in state employee savings he has been looking for when the state's 2,200 management-level employees agreed yesterday to forgo pay raises on July 1.

title: Dagmar Freuchen-Gale; Artist and Illustrator, 83
description: Dagmar Freuchen-Gale, an artist and illustrator for such fashion magazines as Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, died March 9 at a hospital in Fredensborg, Denmark. She was 83 years old and had lived in Fredensborg since the early 1970's.

title: Why Bargain Broadway Tickets Can't Be Sold at Half-Price
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d of 3 Brothers With the Virus Gets AIDS
description: The second of three hemophiliac brothers driven from their hometown after contracting the AIDS virus has developed the disease.

title: Business Deeds Win Accolades
description: The Business Enterprise Trust, a new nonprofit organization committed to highlighting examples of socially responsible business behavior, gave its first award yesterday for "life achievement" to the developer James W. Rouse.

title: Key Rates
Is There A Yugoslavia?
description: The crisis in Yugoslavia could become the most explosive in Europe. Events closely parallel those in the Soviet Union. First, nationalist and democratic demands spread and Communist rule is threatened. Then conservative forces at the country's core assert themselves. One hopes that the resurgence of the Soviet old guard and its crackdown in the Baltics are not precedents for Yugoslavia, but the outlook is ominous.

title: Starring in Tonight's Erotic Video: The Couple Down the Street
description: Without fanfare, video rental stores across America have been stocking shelves for at least 18 months with a new product: amateur adult videotapes.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Vanessa Redgrave's Grievance

title: Bill Shielding Smokers Wins Support
description: A compromise bill that would prohibit employers from denying people a job or a promotion because they are smokers has received the support of legislative leaders and the Governor's office, legislators and an administration official said today.

title: Agent Sees Bo's Injury as 'a Lucky Break'
description: BO JACKSON the athlete may be on the bench, but Bo Jackson the product spokesman may be busier than ever, said Richard Woods, a lawyer in Mobile, Ala., who is Mr. Jackson's agent.

title: Prison in California Bars Reporters From Executions
description: Faced with a Federal trial over allowing television cameras at the state's gas chamber, the warden of San Quentin Prison has banned all reporters from witnessing executions. Previous prison regulations had allowed as many as 14 reporters to watch an execution.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Save Your State: Get Married!
description: Given the nationwide recession, state economic development departments are working harder than ever to draw new sources of revenue. Look at what New York did to keep NBC and lure the Democratic Convention. Just think what Tennessee offered Nissan and G.M.'s Saturn division to get their car factories. It seems that some states are so hungry for funds that no event, no matter how small, is beyond imagination . . .

title: Seton Hall Upsets Arizona; U.N.L.V. Up Next
description: Seton Hall was simply too good to go home.

title: Ford's Big Cars: Not for Taxi Fleets
description: The Ford Motor Company will sell new versions of its Crown Victoria and Grand Marquis models only to individuals, not to police and taxi companies, officials said. Ford will concede some sales to the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division in deciding not to offer the models to fleets in their first year of production.

title: Kuwait Not Yet Open for Business
description: Since the end of the war against Iraq, American businesses and workers have rushed to try to grab a piece of the multibillion-dollar job of rebuilding Kuwait. But despite thousands of hours of telephone calls and millions of dollars spent seeking Kuwaiti business, most companies and individuals are finding that information is scarce and job opportunities are limited.

title: Conductor Cancels
description: The conductor Christof Perick has canceled his current appearances with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall because of a family emergency. Paavo Berglund, who replaced him last night, will also conduct for him today at 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. The programs remain the same, except that Mozart's Symphony No. 33 will be played instead of Symphony No. 25. Information: (212) 874-2424.

title: Knicks Limp to Texas
description: After playing two games in two nights, the Knicks didn't have enough healthy bodies for a full-scale workout yesterday at their practice site in Purchase, N.Y. With only nine available players, Coach John MacLeod held a light drill before the team took off for Dallas, where the Knicks will open a three-game Texas swing tonight against the Mavericks.

title: How the Elderly Trade Work for Tax Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Bar; A probate lawyer's obsession with wills offers yet another peek at the world of the rich and famous.
description: The gravediggers at the Westwood Village Memorial Park say that for a mere $50,000 one can buy the still vacant crypt next to Marilyn Monroe. Groucho Marx, who once said he would not want to join any club that would let him in, considered his membership in the Hillcrest Country Club in Beverly Hills precious enough to pass on to his son. Calvin Coolidge, not unexpectedly, was a model of testamentary taciturnity: his will was but one sentence long.

title: Holmes Taught Responsibility of Power; Coldblooded Opinions
description: To the Editor:

title: Music in Keeping With a Day of Transcendence
description: BETWEEN two improbable extremes lie this year's musical celebrations of Easter. At the Metropolitan Opera on Monday and Good Friday evenings, Wagner's "Parsifal," newly dressed in Otto Schenk's production, will be played. A few blocks to the east, Radio City Music Hall's "Easter Show" offers 24 performances through April 4.

title: Deaf Babies Use Their Hands To Babble, Researcher Finds
description: Deaf babies of deaf parents babble with their hands in the same rhythmic, repetitive fashion as hearing infants who babble with their voices, a new study has found.

title: Marines, Not Designed to Sit, Now Do Just That in Kuwait
description: In a dusty camp for Company A just west of Kuwait City, the Christmas cards from the U.S.O. arrived only recently.

title: Oratorios and Passions
description: Here is a sampling of oratorios and extended musical works scheduled in the New York metropolitan region. Concerts are free unless otherwise noted. GOOD FRIDAY

title: Avon Seeks to Thwart Chartwell Voting Plan
description: Avon Products Inc. made a change yesterday that would thwart a hostile investment group from voting a huge block of Avon stock at the company's annual meeting in May.

title: Arizona's Senate Expels Its Majority Whip
description: The Arizona Senate has expelled its majority whip for taking thousands of dollars from a police informer during an investigation of legislators' vote-selling last year.

title: Review/Art; Down to the Sea Again With Ralston Crawford
description: The art world was fast parting company with Ralston Crawford when in 1948 he painted "Kewalo Close-Up," his crisp, vividly colored geometric interpretation of a boat's hull, which is part of a pleasant exhibition titled "Ralston Crawford and the Sea," at Hirschl & Adler.

title: Martinez Is Confirmed by Senate As Nation's New Anti-Drug Chief
description: The Senate confirmed former Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida today as the nation's chief anti-drug coordinator. The vote was 88 to 12.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Armor All Hires Chief From Kodak Subsidiary
description: The Armor All Products Corporation, which dominates the market for auto cleaners and waxes but has struggled lately, has recruited an outside marketing executive, Kenneth M. Evans, for president and chief executive.

title: Envoy Denounces Soviet TV for Scapegoating U.S.
description: The United States Ambassador to Moscow today assailed the main Soviet evening television news program for reviving the old practice of blaming foreign interference and connivance for Soviet problems.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sarod and Tabla

title: For Children
description: 'Dances of Spring and Freedom' Mark De Garmo and Dancers Jewish Museum (at the New-York Historical Society) 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (212) 399-3368 or (212) 724-1143 Recommended ages: 4 and up Sunday

title: Stocks Soar 23.3% in Buenos Aires
description: The Buenos Aires stock market soared 23.3 percent today as investors responded to the Government's new plan to stabilize Argentina's faltering economy and promote growth.

title: Cowboy Lament: Girl Gone, Ranch for Sale, Bull Won
description: "My Heroes Have Always Been Cowboys" is a folksy down-home movie about H. D. Dalton (Scott Glenn), an aging, rootless rodeo performer whose Moby-Dick is a bull named Thunderbolt.

title: In Suit, White Students Seek Ban on Minority Scholarships
description: Seven white college students filed a lawsuit against the Federal Government today, saying they were suffering racial discrimination under the Bush Administration's decision to let colleges set aside scholarships for minority students.

title: California Rains Make Hard Decisions Harder
description: Three weeks of torrential storms from one end of California to the other have eased the state's water crisis but could be a mixed blessing.

title: Moscow Journal; Flying Aeroflot's Skies, Above a Wobbly Russia
description: Carry-on luggage has been safely stored, including a cage of twittering birds, a chunk of metal that resembles a giant gleaming cog from one of Stalin's dynamos, bags of pungent home cooking, crockery, bootleg vodka, portable air mattresses for the three-day wait in the airport lounge, a circus performer's trampoline -- all the comforts of the lumpen jet set aboard Aeroflot.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "NEW SHOES," a group of young musicians perform new and old songs using dulcimers and autoharps, drums and guitars. At the Bank Street College Auditorium, 610 West 112th Street, Manhattan. Advance tickets for the Sunday benefit at 2 P.M. are $12; at the door, $15. Information: (212) 222-6700, extension 533.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Scientists have a right to be wrong, and a right not to feel guilty for publishing things that are wrong. But they also have an obligation to find out if they are wrong and say so." -- Dr. Mark Ptashne of Harvard University. [ B6:6. ]

title: Another Yankee Start to Forget
description: All the attention being focused on Bo Jackson and whether the Yankees might acquire him has been a blessing for the Yankee starters the last two days. They have been awful, but the intrigue generated by the unsettled Jackson situation has shoved them out of the forefront.

title: Suit Is Settled by Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $15 million to the State of West Virginia to settle a lawsuit that charged the firm with securities fraud.

title: GENSCHER AT EYE OF POLICY DEBATE
description: In the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, a far-reaching political debate has broken out here over how Germany should fulfill its global responsibilities in the years ahead.

title: British Air Giving Away 50,000 Tickets
description: Impatient to fill seats emptied by the war, British Airways announced a bold promotional campaign today aimed at coaxing people into the air again. The airline, Europe's largest, will give away about 50,000 tickets on international flights as part of a broad program of incentives and promotions.

title: Complaints of Fires Prompt G.E. To Recall Coffee Makers
description: The General Electric Company says that because of fuses that may pose a fire hazard, it is recalling electric drip coffee makers that were manufactured under the G.E. and Universal brands from 1976 to 1984.

title: Vanbiesbrouck's Misplay Gives Rangers Their 7th Loss in Row
description: Like the first watermelon seed of spring, the little black puck bounced off the back boards and slid out toward the Rangers' net, to the left of John Vanbiesbrouck.

title: Murder Case In the Village Is Crumbling
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has decided to drop its case against a homeless man who was arrested last summer in the murder of an advertising executive at a Greenwich Village telephone booth, a high-ranking official said yesterday.

title: Rights Group Charges Abuses by the Kuwaitis
description: More than 2,000 people, mostly Palestinians, have been rounded up by the Kuwaiti military since the Iraqis were driven from this country, detained, tortured and in several cases summarily executed, according to a report from a human rights organization.

title: Steppenwolf's 'Grapes,' as It Was on Broadway
description: Public television's "American Playhouse" opened its 10th season this week with a Broadway musical, "Into the Woods." Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the distinguished series turns to a drama that won the 1990 Tony Award for best play. "The Grapes of Wrath" ran for 199 performances on Broadway, including 11 previews, but it is the work of Chicago's acclaimed Steppenwolf Theater Company and the production had already been seen in London at the National Theater before it arrived in New York. This television version guarantees further and richly deserved exposure.

title: Colombia Returns Terror Suspects to Europe
description: Two Belgian men wanted in Europe as terrorists and apprehended in Colombia while on what the police say was an assignment for the Medellin cocaine cartel were returned to Belgium today to face charges, the authorities said.

title: Holmes Taught Responsibility of Power; Advised Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * Cardinal Distribution Inc., Dublin, Ohio, is offering 1.4 million common shares at $33.50 a share through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Inc. * Haemonetics Corp., Braintree, Mass., has filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of six million common shares through First Boston Corp. and Alex. Brown & Sons. Of the total number of shares, 420,000 will be offered by the company and 5.58 million will be offered by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. * Homedco Group Inc., Fountain Valley, Calif., has filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for an offering of 3.7 million common shares at an estimated price of $14 to $16 a share through Robertson, Stephens & Co. * Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Newark, is offering 4.5 million common shares at $26.75 a share through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. RATINGS * Corning Inc.'s senior debt has been raised to A+, from A, by S.&P. The maker of glass products is based in Corning, N.Y. * Delmarva Power and Light Co.'s senior debt has been lowered to A-2, from A-1, by Moody's. The utility company is based in Wilmington, Del. * Executive Life Insurance Co.'s housing bonds backed by investment contracts have been lowered to B, from BB, by S.&P. The insurer is a unit of First Executive Corp., which is based in Los Angeles. DEBT * ARCO, Los Angeles, is offering $300 million in 9 percent debentures due in 2021 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The debentures are priced at 99 to yield 9.098 percent to maturity and are noncallable. * Continental Bank N.A., Chicago, is offering $100 million in subordinated notes due in 2001 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is priced at par to yield 12.50 percent. It has been rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $150 million in subordinated exchangeable notes due in 2001. The notes are exchangeable for a portion of the Magma Power Co. common stock owned by Dow. * PHH Corp., Hunt Valley, Md., is offering $100 million of noncallable notes due in 1992 through First Boston Corp. The notes are priced at par to yield 6.95 percent and are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P. * Phillips Petroleum Co., Bartlesville, Okla., has filed with the S.E.C. for a shelf offering of $550 million in debt securities. * Student Loan Marketing Association has increased the size of its offering of notes due in 1995 to $300 million, from $150 million. The notes were priced at par to float 60 basis points above the Treasury's three-month bill.

title: Extensive Flooding on Oahu
description: Heavy rain over the last week in Hawaii has caused extensive flooding in the last two days here on Oahu, the state's main island. More than 400 houses along the island's northern shore were flooded Wednesday, when thousands of people there were cut off from Honolulu. Today three homes were knocked off thier foundations and carried away by a stream in Pearl City, a suburb 10 miles west of the capital. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Speaker Offers Plan to Raise Income Tax
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller today proposed raising state income taxes by almost $1 billion, breaking sharply with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and throwing budget deliberations here into turmoil with the legal deadline for a budget only 10 days away.

title: Dancer Hurt, Another, Just Visiting, Fills In
description: Robert Hill, an American dancer who is now a principal with the Royal Ballet, suffered a knee injury during a performance of the British company's new production of "Swan Lake" on Wednesday night at the Kennedy Center.

title: New Top Management Is Named at Bonwit
description: Pyramid Companies, the mall developer based in Syracuse, yesterday named new top management for its Bonwit Teller chain and said it would relocate the store's headquarters to Syracuse from New York City.

title: Washington Talk; A Question Of Fairness In Social Security
description: In agencies and re search institutes, at the Library of Congress and in universities around town, thousands of bureaucrats and scholars here spend their days studying the most arcane elements of the Government. Just this week, for instance, the General Accounting Office, the Government's chief auditor, published studies on minority representation at the National Agriculture Statistics Service (basically satisfactory) and on postage costs at the Department of Veterans Affairs (excessive).

title: Air Bags Ordered for 1994 Vans and Light Trucks
description: The Department of Transportation ordered the automobile industry today to install front-seat air bags or automatic seat belts in vans, light trucks, utility vehicles and small buses beginning in 1994.

title: Frederick C. Mennen; Industrialist, 62
description: Frederick Mennen, an industrialist and inventor who founded the Jiffy Pop popcorn business, died Tuesday at his home in Long Beach, Ind., after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Federal Reserve
Brazil Action on Coffee
description: Brazil suspended all new coffee sales today and said it was considering a push for a fresh international agreement to limit exports and increase prices. Traders said the move would send coffee prices sharply higher. Producers and exporters alike were astonished by the news, announced by Economy Secretary Edgard Pereira and the ministry's coffee chief, Ricardo Mesquita, at a news conference in the capital, Brasilia. "The Government has decided to suspend coffee export registrations from tomorrow while Brazil re-evaluates its position on economic clauses," Pereira said. Earlier, he had been quoted in today's editions of the financial daily Gazeta Mercantil as saying that Brazil would not consider new limits on exports as part of a new international coffee pact.

title: Some Texas Eccentrics and Aunt Hallie
description: The place is Austin, Tex. The time, morning, afternoon, night, and morning again.

title: Sacred Exaltation: Calendar of Music For Easter Season
description: This is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in the New York metropolitan area. All are free unless otherwise noted.

title: Murder Case Against 5 Officers: Accounts Clash on Many Points
description: The day after five police officers were charged with murder in the choking death of a car-theft suspect in Queens, the Police Department's top investigative commander raised questions about the only known civilian eyewitness accounts of the fatal struggle.

title: Manila to Let Marcos Return to Face Charges
description: Reversing a long-held policy, President Corazon C. Aquino said today that her Government would allow Imelda Marcos to return to the Philippines, but that she would face charges if she does.

title: Kerkorian's T.W.A. Talks
description: The West Coast investor Kirk Kerkorian has discussed a purchase of Trans World Airlines Inc., but the deal unraveled earlier this week, an aide said today.

title: At the Movies
description: Dennehy in the Ring

title: Paper Includes Gay Couples On What Was Wedding Page
description: The Star Tribune of Minneapolis broke new ground for metropolitan newspapers today when it published two announcements of lesbian "domestic partnerships" on what had traditionally been its wedding and engagement page.

title: Thinking Machines In a Speed Record
description: The Thinking Machines Corporation has established a new speed record in supercomputing, based on a measure used to gauge speed of scientific computations. The supercomputer maker, based in Cambridge, Mass., said its Connection Machine-2 could compute 5,200 mathematical calculations a second in solving a system of linear equations.

title: 2 Receive 10-Day Bans
description: Kelly Chase of the St. Louis Blues and Mike Peluso of the Chicago Blackhawks received automatic 10-game suspensions from the National Hockey League yesterday for leaving the bench to join a fight in a game last Sunday. The suspensions will carry into the playoffs.

title: Psychiatric Care Chain Gets Sale Bid
description: The financially troubled Charter Medical Corporation, the nation's largest psychiatric hospital company, received a $1.1 billion acquisition proposal today from a California-based rival, Community Psychiatric Centers.

title: Justus Buchler, 76, Ex-Professor Of Philosophy at SUNY, Is Dead
