description: Justus Buchler, distinguished professor emeritus of philosophy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and former chairman of the philosophy department at Columbia University, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Chambersburg, Pa. He was 76 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Pinski Zoo's Jazz-Rock

title: The Cancer in College Sports
description: The Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics has spent more than a year seeking solutions to abuses in college sports. Its report, which was released this week, offers commendable ideas that won't substitute for remedial Federal legislation but will certainly be a welcome supplement.

title: Auctions
description: The Baseball Juggernaut

title: Farm Credit Banks In Bond Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering three separate Federal Farm Credit Banks Consolidated Systemwide bond issues worth a total of $2.765 billion.

title: 26.1 Billion Is Added to Debt
description: The Government took on $26.1 billion more in debt last month, but the month's debt was 29.9 percent less than that for February 1990, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Pension Sale Of 'Junk Bonds'
description: California's public employees' pension fund decided on Wednesday to sell its "junk bond" portfolio, which has a face value of about $530 million.

title: Displaced Iraqis Streaming Into Allied-Held Zone
description: Thousands of Iraqi civilians have streamed into small villages and isolated desert communities in Iraqi territory controlled by allied forces, United States Army officials said today.

title: Hilton to Curb Hotel Growth
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is facing a difficult market flooded with hotel rooms, forcing it to curb expansion, the company's chairman, Barron Hilton, said in Hilton's annual report, which was released today.

title: We Expect the Police to Give Out Punishment; All Too Typical
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Dissidents Preparing For Rule if Hussein Topples
description: Iraqi opposition leaders said today that they were preparing to establish a council inside Iraq to pave the way for a national unity government if Saddam Hussein is toppled.

title: 2 Military Air Crashes
description: A plane carrying Senegalese soldiers crashed near the Saudi-Kuwaiti border, killing 98 people. Officials said smoke from burning Kuwaiti oil wells could have been a factor.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Save Your State: Get Married!
description: Given the nationwide recession, state economic development departments are working harder than ever to draw new sources of revenue. Look at what New York did to keep NBC and lure the Democratic Convention. Just think what Tennessee offered Nissan and G.M.'s Saturn division to get their car factories. It seems that some states are so hungry for funds that no event, no matter how small, is beyond imagination . . .

title: Nick Vanoff, 61, Former Dancer Who Became Successful Producer
description: Nick Vanoff, an award-winning producer for theater and television, died on Wednesday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 61 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Court Upholds Access Limits on Phone Sex Lines
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel today upheld Government regulations aimed at denying minors access to "dial-a-porn" telephone services.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MIRELLA FRENI, NICOLAI GHIAUROV and ALFREDO KRAUS have more in common than just singing. They all made their debuts 25 seasons ago at the old Metropolitan Opera House at Seventh Avenue and 39th Street. On Sunday they will sing together in the Met's new home at Lincoln Center, at a benefit performance for the opera's pension fund to be conducted by JAMES LEVINE.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Psychiatric Care Chain Gets Sale Bid
description: The financially troubled Charter Medical Corporation, the nation's largest psychiatric hospital company, received a $1.1 billion acquisition proposal today from a California-based rival, Community Psychiatric Centers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Boy Scouts of Greater New York is honoring MARSHALL HILSBERG, the chairman and chief executive of Lord & Taylor, at a luncheon today at the New York Hilton. Mr. Hilsberg has helped raise nearly $900,000 for a scouting program for 32,000 disabled boys at schools and at a Boy Scout camp on Staten Island.

title: Treasury Issues Rise Modestly
description: Treasury securities posted modest price gains in slow trading yesterday, despite reported heavy selling by Japanese institutions.

title: House Speaker Opposes Bill Withholding $55 Million From Jordan
description: Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, today supported President Bush's opposition to a measure passed by the Senate that would rescind $55 million in military and economic aid to Jordan, as House and Senate negotiators began debating the issue.

title: Rams Pick Up Thomas
description: Rodney Thomas, a Plan B free-agent cornerback left unprotected by the Miami Dolphins, yesterday signed with the Los Angeles Rams. Thomas, a 5-foot-10-inch, 190-pounder, played three seasons with the Dolphins after they drafted him in the fifth round out of Brigham Young.

title: New Concerns Over U.S. Science
description: IN November 1944, with the end of World War II in sight, President Franklin D. Roosevelt wrote to Vannevar Bush, the distinguished engineer who headed the Office of Scientific Research and Development, to ask his advice on four fundamental questions:

title: INSIDE
description: New Tax Plan in Albany The New York Assembly Speaker proposed a $1 billion income-tax increase and fewer spending cuts, leaving budget talks in turmoil. Page B1.

title: Cheaper Space Station Plan Unveiled
description: The space agency officially unveiled plans today for a streamlined space station that would be smaller, cheaper and easier to build. It would be completed by the turn of the century.

title: Granger Tripp; Executive, 68
description: Granger Tripp, a retired advertising executive, died on Wednesday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 68 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

title: Problems of Homeless: The Individual Stories
description: In his documentary "Home Less Home," Bill Brand does something that should not be as unusual as it is. He approaches homeless people with a camera crew and asks who they are, how they became homeless and what they do to survive. The answers, while not surprising, give individual faces to problems that are too easily reduced to generalities. "The American ideal of freedom and justice is out of sync with the facts," he concludes, after having amassed sad and persuasive evidence to corroborate that statement.

title: YUGOSLAVIA RIVALS MEET PEACEABLY
description: The chief combatants in the struggle over the future of Yugoslavia began direct talks here today after many weeks of verbal warfare conducted from the safety of their home constituencies.

title: Spotting Sex Bias on the Job
description: If the civil rights laws mean anything, they mean that what counts in the workplace is the ability to do the job. Some companies, supported by some industry groups, argued that women, even if they were judged to be as competent as men, could be denied work in hazardous occupations unless they proved they were sterile. The rationale was that pregnant women or those who might become pregnant should be protected from hazards that could endanger their fetuses.

title: Gen. Michel Gouraud, French Mutineer, 86
description: Marie-Michel Gouraud, who as a lieutenant general in the French Army played an important role in the 1961 Algerian mutiny that nearly toppled President Charles de Gaulle, died on Wednesday, the army said today.

title: Macon Aims to Go Higher This Time Around
description: With the Temple Owls trying to play their way into the Final Four in the East Region this weekend, Mark Macon is faced with the possibility of having a set of dubious bookends to his basketball career at the university.

title: Master of Manipulation: Cary's 'Mister Johnson' via Beresford
description: When the African clerk who is the title character of "Mister Johnson" speaks of "home," he refers not to his native Nigeria but the England that looms so large in his dreams. He sings of England to fellow villagers, who are amazed at his white suit, pith helmet and European airs; he sings to the white English colonials who preside over the region, and who consider Johnson a valuable but highly fanciful aide.

title: South Africa Seeks U.N. Help on Return of Exiles
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said tonight that South Africa would let the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees help with the return of political exiles who fled the country in protest against apartheid.

title: Invitation to an Animal Party
description: THE Central Park Zoo, a five-and-a-half-acre place that New Yorkers have cared about passionately since the end of the Civil War, has vast powers to enrich people's lives. The zoo, now a part of the New York Zoological Society's growing family of urban animal sancturies, including the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium on Coney Island, is the smallest of the new "landscape immersion" zoos, as they're called, that are rapidly being installed and retrofitted across North America.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Go-Video Inc. said two defendants in its antitrust case had settled by paying the company $3.5 million. The two defendants that settled were the Sanyo Electric Company and the NEC Corporation, both of Japan. The trial against the remaining defendants -- the Sony Corporation, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Victor Company, all also of Japan -- is scheduled to begin on April 2.

title: We Expect the Police to Give Out Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 123091 -- No Title
description: The Government took on $26.1 billion more in debt last month, but the month's debt was 29.9 percent less than that for February 1990, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 543 money market mutual funds increased by $1.32 billion, to $472.57 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 191 institutional funds decreased by $496 million, to $133.03 billion. The 262 general-purpose funds were up by $742.3 million, to $182.62 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.07 billion, to $156.92 billion, the institute said.

title: Bloch Quintets
description: The Portland String Quartet and Paul Posnak, a pianist, are to perform Ernest Bloch's Piano Quintets Nos. 1 and 2 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight at 7. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 570-3949.

title: Sabatini Roars Back As Graf Is Stunned
description: The plot of their match was almost inexplicable, but it contained a chilling parallel entirely appropriate to the relationship that has developed between the two players embroiled in the most painful rivalry in women's tennis.

title: Air Controller in Detroit Crash Defends Actions as Judgment Calls
description: An air traffic controller whose decisions might have contributed to a fatal runway collision in December defended his actions today. He told crash investigators that his decisions were close judgment calls rather than clear errors.

title: Merchant Charged in Girl's Fatal Shooting
description: A liquor store owner has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 15-year-old girl last Saturday after a scuffle over a bottle of orange juice.

title: Producer Ends MCA TV Pact
description: Ron Howard's Imagine Films is ending its television partnership with MCA Inc. and will lay off 30 of its 80 workers.

title: ABC and Fox Announce Fall Plans
description: In separate presentations to advertising industry executives here, the ABC and Fox networks have unveiled their slates of proposed television series for the fall season.

title: Dow Drops 16.58, Closing At 2,855.45
description: The market succumbed to selling pressures toward the end of yesterday's session after holding relatively firm most of the day. Expectations of lower corporate profits and flurries of futures-related trading weighed heavily on investors.

title: Old World Images That Are New
description: For the last 50 years, it has been possible to think of photography as being centered in, and in a sense belonging to, America. Photography's creative nucleus, like painting's, seemed to shift away from Europe when the 1930's ended, taking up residence mainly in the United States. Museums, magazines and the art market have supported expressive photography here to an extent that Europeans, as well as Australialians and the Japanese, could only envy. As a result, curators, critics and collectors have focused their attentions almost exclusively on American photographers.

title: Jetliner Carrying 94 People Narrowly Escapes Collision
description: A jetliner came within 200 feet vertically of a private twin-engine airplane near here on Wednesday night, and both were forced to maneuver to avoid a crash.

title: Housing in Connecticut; Lower-Priced Condos for Stamford
description: A vacant block sits in a streetscape of bulky commercial buildings and modest wood frame houses in the Waterside section of Stamford, and beginning next month it will be transformed into a condominium community. The project initiates a chapter in the neighborhood's rejuvenation and in the city's efforts to provide affordable housing.

title: House Backs Bailout Bill, Sending It to Bush
description: Following a subdued debate of barely 25 minutes today, the House approved the $30 billion bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry that it had rejected last week, and sent the measure to the President.

title: 27 Missing as Navy Planes Collide Near San Diego
description: Two Navy anti-submarine planes on a routine training mission collided early this morning over the Pacific Ocean near San Diego, and the Navy said 27 crew members were missing.

title: Burke Helps Devils Tie No. 1 Team
description: When Tom McVie was brought in to replace John Cunniff as coach of the Devils two and a half weeks ago, one of the reasons was to shake up a lethargic team. For tonight's game against the Blackhawks at Chicago Stadium, McVie made his most daring move, starting Sean Burke in goal in place of Chris Terreri, who started the previous nine games.

title: Miscellany
description: * Business Week magazine and Agpol Trade Publicity and Publishing Enterprise, a printing and publishing company in Warsaw, have signed a joint publishing agreement to produce a Polish-language issue, Business Week/Poland. A pilot issue will be published in June. * Great Scott Advertising Co., a New York agency, said it had picked up all of the clients previously handled by the entertainment division of AC&R Advertising, which the agency disbanded last month. The clients, which represent a total of $12 million to $15 million in billings, include City Cinemas, New Line Cinema, Orion Classics and Miramax, said Lorraine Borden, president of Great Scott.

title: Franco Tinkers to Stay a Cut Above
description: The experiment is one of the more subtle sagas of spring. A pitcher well into his career considers developing another pitch to use deep in the count. It requires, for most, a small sacrifice of ego, a concession to vulnerability. But its gains for those modest enough to be industrious can be multiple, the dividends ranging from critical outs to additional seasons.

title: Unemployment Claims in Jump
description: The number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits shot up to an eight-year high of 519,000 in the week ending March 9, the Government said today.

title: Biederman, Kelly Gets Spanish Food Account
description: Foods From Spain, an arm of the Spanish Government that works with private companies to promote Spanish products in the United States, has assigned its $4 million advertising account to Biederman, Kelly & Shaffer, a New York agency.

title: Harry James Guckert; Publisher, 57
description: Harry James Guckert, a business magazine publisher, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived in North Merrick, L.I.

title: Holmes Taught Responsibility of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: A Second U.S. Victory
description: Brace yourself, everybody: they are at it again.

title: New Technology Sends Law Firms Recruiting Scientists to Be Partners
description: At a growing number of law firms, a doctorate in biology is becoming as indispensable as a law degree.

title: 'Black Rider' Canceled
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday announced the cancellation of "The Black Rider: The Casting of the Magic Bullets," which was to have been performed at the academy's Opera House from June 15 through 26 as part of the second New York International Festival of the Arts. The work, billed as a "comedy-horror musical," is a collaboration by the director Robert Wilson, the writer William S. Burroughs and the composer Tom Waits.

title: Cardinals' Owner Unhappy With Vote
description: The National Football League owners today wrapped up their annual March meeting. Over the past few days they resolved the 1993 Super Bowl issue, completed a package of rules changes that included the altering of team and player on-field conduct policies, examined the solvency of franchises in the league and tabled expansion and realignment for their May 23-24 meeting in Minneapolis.

title: An All-Night Conversation That Becomes a Novel
description: Interviewing Matisse or the Woman Who Died Standing Up By Lily Tuck 148 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.

title: Lord, Dentsu In Mexican Job
description: The Mexico City Tourism Trust, a cooperative venture between several Mexican companies and the Mexican Government, has hired the Los Angeles office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners for an advertising campaign with a dual purpose: to attract Americans to the Mexican capital and to prepare the Mexican people for their arrival.

title: Satisfaction Plus Stability
description: Leslie Levine's reasons for abandoning a scientific career for the law are typical of those cited by others who have made the switch. "I've never felt more secure or more wanted professionally," said Ms. Levine.

title: Surgery for Lebow
description: Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club and director of the New York City Marathon, will have a cancerous tumor removed from his thyroid today, he said.

title: People
description: * Pam Leichter has been promoted to associate media director in the New York office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners, New York. * Elizabeth Halaki has joined Stan Merritt Advertising, New York, as executive vice president-director of account services.

title: 3 Police Officers Are Indicted In Beating of 3 Men for a Cab
description: Three New York City police officers were arrested yesterday on charges of beating and pistol-whipping three men who were using a taxi in midtown Manhattan that the officers, while off duty, wanted for themselves, the Manhattan District Attorney said.

title: Garbage Crews Pressed To Work Longer Routes
description: In a cost-cutting effort that has provoked a heated clash with a major municipal union, the New York City Sanitation Department is trying to reduce the number of people and trucks needed to pick up garbage.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 7.5% on Big Board
description: The number of shares sold short on the American Stock Exchange also fell in the month ended March 15, to 570,297 million shares, or about seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a total of 79.3 million shares, as adjusted. For the last four months the Amex figure has been declining from an adjusted record high of 83.5 million shares reported on Nov. 15, 1990.

title: Inquiry in Death Of Eric Clapton's Son
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that his office was investigating whether criminal charges should be brought in the death of the rock star Eric Clapton's 4 1/2-year-old son, who fell from the open window of a high-rise apartment building on Wednesday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Harry Cipriani

title: We Expect the Police to Give Out Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The state of Texas says that when RAY SIMPSON auctioned PAUL McCARTNEY'S birth certificate in Houston for $18,000 in November, he neglected to pay a sales tax, to record the sale on a receipt and to comply with several other regulations. The Texas Licensing and Regulation Department, which handles auctioneers, has investigated the transaction and told Mr. Simpson to pay $9,000 in penalties and fees.

title: Bo Lesson: Caveat Emptor
description: The next time fans want to know why athletes need to wheedle and wangle and whine for every extra $100,000, they should think of Bo Jackson, tossed on the scrapheap at the age of 28.

title: Arkansas Rolls Over Alabama
description: For 25 minutes, Alabama played on an even basis with a top-seeded Arkansas squad that thrives on disruptive defense and an opportunistic attack. But like a tide slowly washing away the shore, the Razorbacks kept coming. And coming.

title: Can Bo Follow Joe in Yank Order?
description: If the Yankees claim Bo Jackson today, it will be deja vu for anyone who remembers the injury-clouded circumstances that surrounded the Yankees' purchase of Joe DiMaggio from the minor league San Francisco Seals.

title: Daniel J. Murphy, 69, Ex-Professor at CUNY
description: Daniel Joseph Murphy, professor emeritus of English literature at Baruch College of the City University of New York, died on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived in Suffern and Dublin.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: U.N. SURVEY CALLS IRAQ'S WAR DAMAGE NEAR-APOCALYPTIC
description: A United Nations survey of civilian damage caused by the allied bombardment of Iraq calls the results "near apocalyptic." The survey, which was made public today, recommends an immediate end to the embargo on imports of food and other essential supplies to prevent "imminent catastrophe."

title: Restaurants
description: Whenever I used to tell dining companions that I was taking them to a Greek restaurant, they would respond with a slack grin, as if I had suggested we attend an all-night bouzouki competition. Perceptions of Greek food in New York City have been etched largely by those modest storefront spots characterized by washed-out photographs of the Aegean coast, checkered tablecloths and ragged gray lamb gyros in the windows.

title: Yanks Show Signs They Might Claim Jackson
description: Even though the Yankees wouldn't say so, all signs pointed today to the probability that they would claim Bo Jackson on waivers by Friday's 2 P.M. deadline.

title: 80's Building Binge Slows Marriott
description: The Marriott Corporation, which has halted new hotel construction and spent the last few months cutting costs, may have managed to avoid bankruptcy but it will be at least two years before it is likely to resume the growth it enjoyed in the 80's.

title: When Patients Pay for Charity to Patients
description: A growing financial crisis in the care of uninsured hospital patients in New Jersey is nowhere as apparent as in urban hospitals like St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center here.

title: A Real Response to Violent Crime
description: A crowd of neighbors cheered the Federal agents who finally arrested Ruben Floyd for smuggling guns from Ohio to Philadelphia for resale to drug dealers and other crooks. But by the time the arrest took place Mr. Floyd had already distributed a sizable arsenal of sophisticated weapons.

title: Bush Calls Police Beating 'Sickening'
description: President Bush said today that he was sickened by the beating of a motorist by Los Angeles police officers, and he offered only reserved support for the city's Police Chief, Daryl F. Gates, who was an important backer of Mr. Bush in his 1988 campaign.

title: Britain Will Abandon Its Fiercely Disputed 'Poll Tax'
description: Reeling from a year of violent protests and election defeats brought on by an unpopular new "poll tax" for local services, the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major decided today to return instead to some kind of property tax by 1993.

title: Net Gain at Dow
description: The Dow Chemical Company said the initial public offering of its Destec Energy Inc. unit would add an after-tax profit of $215 million, or 80 cents a share, to Dow's first-quarter results. Proceeds from the offering, which closed on Wednesday, will be used by Destec to retire debt and to finance future projects. Dow offered 17.2 million Destec shares, or 27.7 percent of its total shares, at $20 each.

title: Why Bargain Broadway Tickets Can't Be Sold at Half-Price
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Environmentalist
description: When the Australian singer Helen Reddy achieved an international following in the 1970's, she was a very active feminist and rose to fame with her song "I Am Woman," which became the anthem of the women's movement.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Literati including writers (SHIRLEY HAZZARD, FRANCIS STEEGMULLER) and publishers (S. I. NEWHOUSE, HAROLD EVANS, JONI EVANS) mingled with glitterati like designers (BILL BLASS, KENNETH JAY LANE, VINCENT FOURCADE) and the socially prominent (LILY AUCHINCLOSS, JEAN VANDERBILT) at a party at the Museum of Modern Art Wednesday night for JOHN RICHARDSON. The first volume of Mr. Richardson's warmly received "Life of Picasso" was published last month by Random House.

title: British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it would cut another 4,700 jobs on top of the 5,000 reductions announced already. The company said its commercial aircraft operations would lose about 2,500 workers and its Dynamics Ltd. unit would cut about 2,200 jobs by the end of the year. In December, British Aerospace said it was closing two factories and reducing staff by 5,000 over two and a half years. The company has about 125,000 employees. The chairman, Sydney Gillibrand, said the job losses had been caused in part by a military business slump.

title: Du Pont Selling Half-Stake In Coal Concern to Germans
description: The Du Pont Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 percent interest in its Consolidation Coal Company subsidiary to Rheinbraun A.G., a coal mining company based in Germany.

title: Rumor Pummels Green Tree Stock
description: RUMORS can be a powerful thing. Just ask the Green Tree Acceptance Corporation, which finances the purchases of more mobile homes than any other company. The stock plunged yesterday on a rumor of problems with the company's annual report, then recovered part of the loss.

title: Jayhawks Knock Out Hoosiers
description: Kansas raced to a 23-4 lead and Indiana never recovered as the Jayhawks coasted to an 83-65 victory tonight in the semifinals of the Southeast Regional at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: New Technology Sends Law Firms Recruiting Scientists to Be Partners
description: At a growing number of law firms, a doctorate in biology is becoming as indispensable as a law degree.

title: The Spoken Word
description: PERFORMANCE AND LECTURE, on the works of Sholom Aleichem, presented by Philip Nolan and Raoul J. Shorr, at the Kittredge Club, 109 East 39th Street, Manhattan, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $10. Information: (718) 241-7479.

title: Bodies Litter Streets of an Iraqi Holy City Torn by Revolt
description: The following article was cleared by the Iraqi Information Ministry, which took a small group of reporters working for foreign news agencies to Karbala, Iraq, the scene of heavy fighting between Government forces and rebels.

title: Out of the Ashes
description: There was a concert of an extraordinary character here the other evening. It was painful, at times almost unbearable. But it was also uplifting, a testament to the power of the human spirit. Here is the story.

title: Charles C. Batchelder, Arts Patron, 72
description: Charles Carpenter Batchelder, a philanthropist and patron of the arts who was formerly a Manhattan literary agent, died Thursday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 72 years old and had homes in Philadelphia and St. Thomas, V.I.

title: Goalie Survives a Most Busy Night
description: The Boston Bruins couldn't believe what they were seeing. They kept peppering Quebec goalie Ron Tugnutt with shots, and Tugnutt kept stopping them. He made a total of 70 saves, matching the second-highest total in National Hockey League history, helping the Nordiques earn a 3-3 tie with the Bruins in Boston on Thursday night.

title: Israel's Debt Up $260 Million
description: Israel's foreign debt rose by $260 million in 1990, to $24.1 billion, reversing a decline since 1987, the Bank of Israel said on Thursday.

title: KUWAITI PROTESTS DEFY MARTIAL LAW
description: Opposition groups attacked Kuwait's increasingly ineffective Government today at an outdoor rally and other gatherings that defied martial law.

title: What the U.L. Seal of Approval Signifies: A Case in Point
description: Every day, Americans buy millions of products that bear the familiar U.L. seal of Underwriters Laboratories Inc., relying on it as a sign that the product has been tested for safety. But the level of safety that seal signifies is sometimes questionable, Government reports and some product safety experts say.

title: Your Money; Preserving Assets of the Old and Ill
description: When a middle-class elderly person suffers a debilitating illness like Alzheimer's disease that requires long-term custodial care, it can be devastating to a family, financially as well as emotionally.

title: U.S. Downs 2d Iraqi Jet in 3 Days For Violating Allied Military Ban
description: An American F-15 fighter plane shot down an Iraqi fighter-bomber violating a ban on flights today, United States officials said. It was the second such incident reported in three days.

title: Kellogg's Recalls Bunny Gifts
description: The Kellogg Company is recalling 15,576 plush bunnies given away in supermarket promotions because eyes and noses could break off and choke young children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. The toys are white and pink and carry a tag labeled "Kellogg's." They were given away on March 14 and 15 in 33 states and Puerto Rico. People with the toys may call the cereal manufacturer at 1-800-468-9004 or, in Puerto Rico, 1-800-848-4589. A Kellogg's spokesman said no injuries had been reported.

title: They're Always Watching Out for Loons
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinal Says Press Reports Reflect 'Catholic Bashing'
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York has accused the press of tolerating "Catholic bashing," voicing a sentiment that has long been smoldering in Catholic circles in New York and many other cities.

title: Hughes Sues Over Space Shuttle
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company sued the Government today for $288.5 million, contending the Government had broken a contract with Hughes when it barred commercial payloads from the space shuttle after the Challenger disaster.

title: Airline Woes May Damage Pension Unit
description: The airline industry's crumbling finances, highlighted by Continental's announcement on Thursday of a $2.25 billion fourth-quarter loss, have become the top concern of the Federal pension insurance agency, the head of the agency said yesterday.

title: Guidepost; Servicing Power Tools
description: Now, before the gardening rush begins, is the time to check power tools to be sure they will be in working order. Don't wait until the grass turns green. Yearly tune-up servicing is the best way to make any power equipment last. Service centers often offer special repair prices to early-bird customers. Sometimes it is possible to repair smaller pieces of equipment at home using the manufacturer's replacement parts. Here are some of the most-used power tools and repairs they may need: Lawn Mower: General maintenance such as steam cleaning Riding Mower: Carburetor repair, air filter replacement, sharpening of cutting blade Edger: Cutting blade replacement String Weeder: Nylon string cutter replacement Hedge Clipper: Sharpening of cutting blade

title: Selling Puts Pressure on Treasury Notes
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted moderate gains yesterday, while short-term issues were essentially unchanged. The intermediate sector came under some selling pressure, because those maturities were involved in currency-exchange operations conducted by the central banks of several countries.

title: Port Authority Raises Tolls for 6 Bridges and Tunnels to $4
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to increase the basic toll on passenger cars by $1, to $4, on its six bridges and tunnels.

title: Jack Romano, 53, Teacher of Acting
description: Jack Romano, a teacher of acting and a director, died on Thursday at the Roosevelt Division of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It would seem to me in due course Mr. Hussein should realize that one of the best courses of action available to him would be to see if somebody else wishes his job." -- Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ 4:1. ]

title: Playboy Expects Higher Earnings
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc.'s operating earnings for its fiscal year ending on June 30 should double from the $871,000 posted in the first half, the company's chairwoman, Christie Hefner, said. In the 1990 fiscal year, the company had operating income of $265,000.

title: About New York; A Catholic School Beats the Odds With the Basics
description: Agustin Guzman was born into the hard world of East Harlem. His too-young parents, both drug addicts, fought savagely, making the home, in the 18-year-old's phrase, "like hell."

title: Prosecutor Wins Right to Wear Flag Pin
description: As an allegory for these patriotic times, none may be better than the scene today in a Warren County courtroom where a young prosecutor won back the right to wear an American flag pin on his lapel.

title: Corrections
description: The Washington Talk column yesterday about the Social Security system gave an incorrect example of benefits. The married couple who were schoolteachers and whose average annual salary was $50,000 each would together receive almost $2,044 a month, double the maximum benefit to any one individual.

title: ALBANY TO ALLOW LARGER CLASS SIZE FOR HANDICAPPED
description: New York State took a major step yesterday toward scaling back school programs for the handicapped by increasing maximum class sizes for students with learning disabilities.

title: Jackson Unclaimed by Yanks and Other Clubs
description: Despite a burning desire to acquire the kind of glamour that has filled their history but which they no longer have, the Yankees joined 25 other major league clubs today in passing on Bo Jackson and his $2,375,000 salary. The injured Jackson, released by the Kansas City Royals on Monday, went unclaimed and thus became free to join any team under a new contract.

title: Wheaton Surprises Edberg
description: Stefan Edberg, the world's No. 1-ranked men's player, exhibited all the composure of a fish on a bicycle this afternoon during his semifinal match here against an unseeded American, David Wheaton, at the Lipton International Players Championships.

title: PRETORIA'S INQUIRY IMPLICATES ONLY 1
description: A judicial inquiry into the death of 42 blacks in Sebokeng township last September ended today with the judge announcing that he could determine responsibility for only one of the deaths.

title: Chrysler, Banks Set Credit Pact
description: The Chrysler Corporation agreed with a consortium of 38 banks today on a new $1.75 billion revolving credit through the end of 1993. The new credit agreement is smaller than the $2.64 billion credit agreement it replaces, but it constitutes an important financial safety net for the No. 3 auto maker, nevertheless.

title: Harlem Battalion Performed Well in Gulf; Stopping the Fires
description: To the Editor:

title: William Joshua Barney Jr., 79, Prominent Equestrian Executive
description: William Joshua Barney Jr., a prominent figure in equestrian circles for 40 years, died on Thursday at Doctors Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 79 years old and had been suffering from emphysema, a family friend said.

title: U.S. Law on Hospital Care of Poor Faces Test
description: Rosa Rivera had no doctor, no prenatal care and dangerously high blood pressure when she arrived at the emergency room of DeTar Hospital in Victoria, Tex., in labor with her sixth child.

title: As Rebels Surge in Ethiopia, Its Capital Fears a Harsh Fate
description: An eerie tension has enveloped this city as Ethiopians watch what may well be the death throes of their 16-year-old Government and nervously consider what they fear is imminent: anarchy and bloodshed in the capital.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD M. NIXON gave some free advice yesterday in Moscow, where he was visiting at the invitation of the Institute of World Economics and International Relations. He said independence should be granted to the Baltic states, The Associated Press reported.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING American Wins Giant Slalom

title: Svan to Miss Olympics
description: Gunde Svan of Sweden, one of Nordic skiing's legends, stunned the skiing community yesterday with the announcement in Stockholm that he would take next year off and miss the Winter Olympics.

title: Patents; Diesel Engine Recycles Heat to Power Turbine
description: Frank E. Wicks, a professor of mechanical engineering at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., patented a diesel engine for trains and ships this week that recycles excess heat and uses it to power a steam turbine.

title: College Basketball: N.C.C.A. Tournament; Seton Hall Roadblock For Rebels
description: For Nevada-Las Vegas, it comes down to this: to retain the national collegiate basketball championship it must win three more games, and the first of those victories must come against one of the hottest teams remaining in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Seton Hall.

title: Emergency Landing for Jet
description: A Midway Airlines DC-9 carrying 110 passengers and crew members made an emergency landing tonight after suddenly losing pressure, said an airline spokeswoman, Sandra Allen. Midway Flight 776, flying from Chicago to Orlando, Fla., descended 20,000 feet and regained cabin pressure, but the pilot chose to land in Nashville, she said. The pressure loss appeared to have been caused by a clogged air duct, she said.

title: Honus Wagner Baseball Card Goes to Gretzky
description: A multicolored baseball card depicting Honus Wagner, the great shortstop for the Pittsburg Pirates, was sold yesterday for $451,000 to Wayne Gretzky, the Los Angeles Kings hockey great, and Bruce McNall, the club's owner. The purchase, at Sotheby's in New York, represented the highest price paid at auction for sporting memorabilia, about four times the previous record, set in 1989 for another Honus Wagner card.

title: Needed: The Glaspie File
description: What really happened in that famous Baghdad encounter when a startled U.S. Ambassador, April Glaspie, was summoned to a July 25 meeting with Saddam Hussein? Even now, nobody fully knows. A credible answer would begin to establish whether Iraq's misreading of American intentions was a policy failure or the fault of a single diplomat.

title: Sulfur Dealer Indicted In $40 Million Swindle
description: At least nine banks in New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut were defrauded of more than $40 million by an international sulfur dealer, an indictment charges, and prosecutors say he spent the money on a yacht, a French villa and gambling sprees in Monte Carlo and Atlantic City.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Co., New York, a subsidiary of Bankers Trust New York Corp., announced five appointments in its corporate finance group: Scott P. George to managing director, head of the Midwest corporate finance group and head of Bankers Trust-Midwest, Chicago; Jeffrey Stephens to managing director and head of the West corporate finance group, and Richard A. Windatt, J. Andrew Cowherd and Andrew J. McCarthy to senior officers in the New York corporate finance group. * Jordan Marsh, Boston, a subsidiary of Allied Stores Corp., announced four promotions: John Budd to senior vice president and general merchandise manager of home furnishings; Janet Emerson to senior vice president and general merchandise manager for accessories, shoes, intimate apparel and cosmetics; Gary Nixon to senior vice president and director of stores, and John Macht to senior vice president and director of marketing.

title: Albert M. Sacks, 70, Harvard Law Dean and Noted Teacher
description: Albert M. Sacks, dean of the Harvard University Law School from 1971 to 1981, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: USAir Sees Deficit
description: USAir Group Inc. said it expected to post a first-quarter operating loss even greater than the $168 million it lost in the final quarter of last year. The airline also predicted a deficit for the full year, but said it should be less than the $350 million operating loss in 1990. USAir made the projections in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The recession and the decline in air traffic since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf crisis are the main reasons for the projected losses, USAir said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about The Daily News referred incorrectly in some copies to William Goldschlag, a staff member who was roughed up by pressmen at the newspaper's printing plant on Thursday night. Mr. Goldschlag is the Queens editor.

title: How About Puerto Rico's Self-Determination?
description: To the Editor:

title: Top U.S. Auditor Criticizes Plan To Bolster Bank Insurance Fund
description: The Government's senior auditor today sharply criticized the Administration's proposal to bolster the dwindling bank insurance fund by extending its borrowing authority to $70 billion.

title: Mancuso Sues Paramount
description: Frank Mancuso, the former chairman of Paramount Pictures Inc., filed a $45 million lawsuit yesterday charging a breach of contract against Paramount Communications Inc., the company that owns Paramount Pictures.

title: St. John's Conquers Ohio State; Duke Is Next
description: After all the games in Lou Carnesecca's 23 seasons at St. John's -- many of which were played at 33 r.p.m. -- his team manufactured a shockingly complete victory over Ohio State tonight by changing its identity.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
M/A-Com's President Is a Venture Capitalist
description: M/A-Com Inc., a military electronics equipment maker in Burlington, Mass., has named Allan L. Rayfield president and chief operating officer. Mr. Rayfield, who is 56, has been general partner of Forstmann Rayfield & Company, a venture capital firm in Southport, Conn.

title: Clarence Leo Fender Dies at 82; His Guitar Changed Rock Music
description: Clarence Leo Fender, whose mass-produced electric guitars revolutionized the world's popular music, died on Thursday in Fullerton, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: Policing the Police
description: The indictment of five New York City police officers in the death of young Hispanic man, coming on the heels of the nationwide broadcast of a videotape showing Los Angeles policemen beating a black man, has understandably alarmed citizens across the nation. While the public outrage is appropriate, police brutality requires serious study in a sober atmosphere. In the case of New York City, the following suggestions are one way to begin.

title: 11 Held and 3 Fraternities Seized In Drug Raids at U. of Virginia
description: Almost 50 Federal, state and local law officers swept onto the University of Virginia's fraternity row late Thursday and early today, seizing bags of marijuana, hallucinogenic mushrooms and LSD and arresting 11 students on charges of selling drugs.

title: Despite Bleak Polls, Democrats Insist They Aren't a War Casualty
description: The Democratic National Committee met here today to battle the polls, the press and the pundits and to try to send a simple message: Democrats are not dead yet.

title: Girl Who Was Crushed in L.I. School Gym Dies
description: A 9-year-old girl, crushed nine days ago by a motorized school gym partition, died from her injuries today without having regained consciousness.

title: Soviet Oil Industry Outlook Is Called Dismal by Experts
description: The Soviet Union's oil industry is in a steep, continuing decline, and the most likely remedy -- an infusion of Western capital and technology that both Soviet officials and American oil companies had hoped for -- is beginning to seem out of reach, according to experts at a conference today at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. The reason: political uncertainty within the country.

title: Boots Unwise at U.S. Checkpoint
description: At the farthest forward Iraqi position on the road south from Basra to Kuwait, several Iraqi soldiers nonchalantly got off a bus and changed into civilian clothes this morning before boarding again and continuing on the road south.

title: Prayer Days for Troops
description: President Bush today proclaimed April 5 to 7 as National Days of Thanksgiving as American troops return home from the Persian Gulf war. "I urge Americans to unite in prayer and turn to our greatest power," the President said. "We give thanks for the remarkable unity of our people throughout the conflict and especially for the strong support shown for our troops in the field."

title: 84 Key Employees Get Unisys Bonus
description: The Unisys Corporation, a troubled computer maker, said it was paying $480,000 to 84 key employees to prevent further resignations. Unisys, which lost $1.1 billion in the last two years, has recently lost several senior executives.

title: Tornadoes Kill 3 in Tennessee and Kentucky
description: Tornadoes hit parts of Tennessee and Kentucky tonight, killing at least three people and injuring dozens, the authorities said.

title: Ex-Leader of University Is Charged With Misconduct in South Carolina
description: The former president of the University of South Carolina was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of illegally using his public position for personal gain.

title: Business Approach
description: The daily operations of the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta will be handled by a Chicago banker who said yesterday he planned to run the Games as a business and steer clear of political squabbles.

title: Lawmaker Fights Off Mugger
description: Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado fought off a mugger as he was returning to his apartment from a grocery store on Wednesday night. Mr. Campbell, a 57-year-old Democrat who was a member of the 1964 United States Olympic judo team, said the brief fistfight had ended with his being outsprinted as he chased the mugger down the street. Mr. Campbell tore ligaments in one ankle and wound up on crutches but said he was happy that his assailant had not made off with the peanut butter and jelly that the Congressman had been carrying.

title: Goodrich Gives Earnings Outlook
description: Citing adverse economic conditions, B.F. Goodrich said it expected to break even or report a modest loss this quarter. "The recession is taking an especially heavy toll on a number of our businesses that depend on the strength and vitality of economic conditions generally," the chemical company said.

title: Asset Manager For Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday named Robert S. Salomon Jr. chief investment officer of its asset management subsidiary. The move takes Mr. Salomon out of the equities research area, where he has worked for 15 years, and into money management.

title: Prospects Are Seen as Good For Gun Waiting-Period Bill
description: After years of intense battling on Capitol Hill, lawmakers and lobbyists on both sides of the gun control issue agree that prospects this year are the best ever for legislation to create a seven-day waiting period to buy a handgun.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Harry James Guckert, a magazine publisher, misidentified his employer and one magazine he published. He was senior vice president of Geyer-McAllister Publications and the publisher of Geyer's Office Dealer.

title: Pro Hockey; Kisio Could Miss Flyers Game
description: When the Rangers try to end their seven-game losing streak at Philadelphia on Saturday afternoon, they may be without Kelly Kisio, their captain and first-line center.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Tomas Cabrera, Lawyer, 38
description: Tomas Cabrera, former vice president and chief counsel of the Beatrice International Food Company in Miami, now TLC Beatrice of Manhattan, died Sunday at Baptist Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 38 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 27 about the landmark designation of the Manhattan house where Antonin Dvorak lived from 1892 to 1895 misstated the vote by the local community board. Community Board 6 recommended the landmark designation in 1989 by a vote of 21 to 6, not 21 to 16.

title: Sports of The Times; Lenny Dykstra in That Game of Chance
description: One day a number of years ago in a Southern town, a well-dressed man in handcuffs stepped into the elevator in city hall, a building that also contained the jail house. The man was accompanied by several policemen. Getting off the elevator at the same time that the manacled man and his companions got on was the Mayor of the town.

title: American Is Slain in Turkey; Leftist Group Cites Gulf Link
description: The director of a company supplying the United States military in Turkey was killed today, the police said. A Marxist organization claimed responsibility for the killing, calling it its latest strike against Americans.

title: Bridge
description: Canada will compete in the world team championships in Yokohama in October with a squad unused to fame: Doug Heron, Ed Zaluski, John Valliant and Dave Willis, all of Ottowa, Randy Bennett of St. John's, Newfoundland, and Mike Betts of Saint John, New Brunswick. They won a three-way playoff against Mexico and Bermuda for the right to represent the North American zone, in which the United States has separate rights. Play was in Mexico City Feb. 16-18.

title: Vuitton Cuts Stake
description: The investment arm of the Vuitton family sold about a third of its stake in LVMH Moet Hennesey Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods group that has its name on popular handbags around the world. The 450,000-share block, purchased for an undisclosed price by Goldman, Sachs of New York, represents 3.4 percent of the Vuitton Investissements Gestion's capital in the group. Vuitton Investissements Gestion now has less than an 8 percent holding in the company whose luxury goods include Champagne, cognac and perfume.

title: Changing Warehouses Into a Cultural Center
description: Half a mile of water separates the popular, slick and immensely profitable South Street Seaport from an abandoned and forbidding cluster of nine red-brick warehouses on the Brooklyn waterfront known as the Empire Stores. By the end of the decade, this huge complex of prime Brooklyn waterfront buildings could become a cultural and retail center as large as the Seaport, if a preliminary development proposal being presented to community groups ever comes to fruition.

title: Review/Dance; From Sumatra, Dancing Meant to Be Heard
description: Three Sumatran dance companies proclaimed the joy of rhythm on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. They did so with dancing that was loud and clear. Crystalline choreographic designs contributed to the clarity. The loudness resulted from the sounds the performers made as they moved. This dancing was meant to be heard.

title: McDonnell Is Top Supplier
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, maker of the F-15 fighter jet and Tomahawk cruise missile, remains by far the nation's biggest military contractor, the Pentagon said today.

title: National Westminster Names New U.S. Chief
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C., one of Britain's largest financial institutions, announced yesterday that the head of its United States banking operation, which has been plagued by losses, had resigned. It assigned one of the parent company's top executives, John Tugwell, to be chairman and chief executive of the New York-based subsidiary.

title: A.T.&T. Inquiry Barred by F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission denied a request by the NCR Corporation that it investigate the $6.1 billion hostile takeover bid by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. It also denied a request that it bar A.T.&T.'s reliance on the credit and earning power of its regulated phone operations to finance the takeover.

title: Key Rates
Report Says Scientist Used False Claims for Grant
description: A scientist at the Georgetown University Medical Center has been accused of scientific misconduct in applications for two research grants from the National Institutes of Health, The Washington Post reported today.

title: INSIDE
description: Tolls Across Hudson Go Up

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.59 percent this week, up from 9.50 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest since rates averaged 9.61 on Jan. 25. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.44 percent, down from 7.45 percent last week, the lowest since Freddie Mac began tracking adjustable mortages in 1984.

title: 19 Die in Riots in Mali; Emergency Declared
description: The President of the sub-Saharan African nation of Mali declared a state of emergency today after anti-Government riots in which 19 people were reported to have been killed.

title: Dow Up 3.46; Ends Week Off 89.36
description: The stock market ended on a slightly higher note yesterday, after a week of tumult. The main culprits were Tuesday's stronger-than-expected consumer price report and I.B.M.'s stunning report that its earnings would be only half what analysts expected.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A. RICHARD GOLUB, the flamboyant Manhattan lawyer of celebrities, has been vindicated by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, which on Thursday set aside a judgment against him that was based on allegations that he had had a sexual relationship with a client.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on March 2 omitted the names of two of the inventors who patented a method of using magnetic resonance imaging to detect heart damage. They were Pradeep Gupta, director of biomedical engineering at Westchester County Medical Center, and Toshiaki Arai, associate professor of anesthesiology at Kyoto University Hospital in Japan.

title: POWELL SAYS U.S. WILL STAY IN IRAQ 'FOR SOME MONTHS'
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that United States military forces in southern Iraq would seek to maintain pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq "for some months to come," while insurrection whittles away at the Iraqi leader's power.

title: Sasser Discovers He Won't Be No. 1
description: The decision was an emotional one because the physical malady is sad and mysterious. And so Bud Harrelson delivered his verdict today with as much compassion as conviction: Mackey Sasser's difficulty returning the baseball to the pitcher is too great a liability to consider him the Mets' No. 1 catcher.

title: In Essenes, Judaism Had an Ascetic Sect
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for 'The Envelope, Please'
description: Most days, Franklin R. Johnson bills $315 an hour, lunches at bistros like Jimmy's in Los Angeles and huddles with famous Hollywood clients seeking financial advice. But this week he was holed up in a windowless room in downtown Los Angeles stuffing envelopes.

title: Review/Dance; 'Swan Lake' In Notation From 1895
description: The first major production that Anthony Dowell staged after becoming director of the Royal Ballet was "Swan Lake," and it is this new if odd version that is on view through Sunday at the Kennedy Center here.

title: Bush Chooses Chairman of Xerox For No. 2 Post at Education Dept.
description: In a move likely to give the Education Department a higher profile, President Bush said yesterday he plans to nominate David T. Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, as the department's deputy secretary.

title: The Megastate Scene
description: Leaks have been the bane of politicians from George Washington to Richard Nixon, who commissioned the White House plumbers to stanch them. But few leaks ever have presented a greater sub rosa threat than the one just weathered by California's new Governor, Pete Wilson.

title: Pro Hockey; Knicks Rally, Then Lose
description: The Knicks opened their three-game Texas trip with a disappointing defeat tonight.

title: Longer Tenure For Seidman?
description: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said today that an ambiguity in the law could extend his term by two years.

title: Asia Executive For Hachette
description: Didier Guerin, executive vice president for publishing at Hachette Magazines Inc., was named president for Asia-Pacific yesterday and will head all of the company's operations in that region.

title: John F. Andrew, Editor, 36
description: John F. Andrew, an editor and former columnist with The Wall Street Journal, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 36 years old and lived in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Facing the Music
description: Correction: Contrary to information conveyed in a recent column, it was not John Lennon who sang "Why Don't We Do It in the Road?" As many readers have pointed out, it was Paul McCartney. McCartney also wrote the song. This column regrets the error.

title: Interior Official Chides Environmental 'Nuts'
description: The head of the United States Bureau of Mines has told miners, loggers and others who advocate development of Federal land that environmentalists are "a bunch of nuts" and that he does not believe in endangered species.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LESLEY STAHL will join MIKE WALLACE, MORLEY SAFER, ED BRADLEY and STEVE KROFT as a correspondant on the CBS News program "60 Minutes." She is replacing MEREDITH VIEIRA , who was to replace HARRY REASONER, who will become editor emeritus and may do occasional pieces. Last month, CBS News announced that Ms. Vieira was leaving the program at the end of the season to have her second child.

title: British Trim Rates Again
description: Britain reduced interest rates today as the Government moved again to try to lift the economy out of recession amid signs that inflation was slowing.

title: College Basketball: N.C.C.A. Tournament; No. 10 Temple Races By a Tired Oklahoma St.
description: Temple, the No. 10-seeded team in the East Regional, struck a blow for parity by shocking 3d-seeded Oklahoma State, 72-63, in overtime tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Asbestos Justice, Delayed and Denied
description: Asbestos, a miraculous mineral that fireproofed and insulated American homes and buildings for generations, became the cause of a national calamity as hundreds of thousands of people exposed to its dusts and fibers became ill and died. It's a long-running disaster because those decades of exposure spell more lung disease and cancer developing well into the next century. Now, to compound the tragedy, the injustice and gross inadequacy of systems to compensate the afflicted are glaringly apparent.

title: Reebok Shifts Ad Agencies
description: Reebok International abruptly pulled its $40 million account from Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos yesterday and split the business between the New York agencies Chiat/Day/Mojo and Lois/GGK.

title: Reports of Brazil Shift Roil the Coffee Market
description: Confusion and anxiety about the export policies of Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, produced a record volume of trades and, after an initial upward leap, a volatile retreat in prices on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange yesterday.

title: Defense Says Autopsy Helps Queens Police
description: An autopsy on a car-theft suspect who died in a struggle with five Queens police officers offers little evidence to back up accounts by three witnesses who say the officers kicked and beat the victim, police officials and defense lawyers who have seen the autopsy report said yesterday.

title: Film Festival; A Gangster On the Run From Love
description: "Days of Being Wild" is an elliptical melodrama, an atmospheric reverie about love and identity, delivered in the guise of a gangster film. Set in 1960, on the fringes of the Hong Hong underworld, the film crosses B-movie conventions with avant-garde jumpiness, resulting in a disquieting mix of "Hiroshima Mon Amour" and "The Big Sleep."

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., a paper concern, said it would acquire the office products companies of Hillman Co. Pittsburgh, for an undisclosed amount of Alco common stock. * Ashton-Tate Corp., Torrance, Calif., agreed in principle to settle the stockholder class-action lawsuits filed against it and certain of its directors and officers between June and August 1989 and a derivative suit filed in January 1990.

title: F.D.A. Urges Special Access To Rejected Alzheimer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration asked yesterday that an Alzheimer's disease treatment, previously rejected for marketing by an expert panel, be made widely available to patients under an experimental program.

title: New Director at Buchenwald Admits Past and Quits Post
description: The new director of the memorial at Buchenwald concentration camp has resigned after admitting that he concealed his former membership in the West German Communist Party, officials said today.

title: Exxon Enters Its Guilty Pleas; Judge Withholds Acceptance
description: As called for in the plea agreement they reached with the Government last week, the Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary today pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges resulting from the Exxon Valdez oil spill two years ago.

title: Coping/With Makeup Fade-Out
description: Women who suffer from makeup fade-out may find a cure among the latest crop of cosmetics. More and more lipsticks, eye shadows, foundations, eye pencils, blushers and even mascaras have a common theme: longevity. They are intended to be applied and stay put.

title: No-Layoff Deal Hurts Substitute Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Advanced Micro Set to Send Out New Chip
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that it would begin volume shipments of its long-awaited Am386 chip.

title: Congress Withholds $55 Million in Aid to Jordan
description: Congress today approved but modified the revocation of $55 million in aid to Jordan and a ban on military sales to allies who failed to fulfill their pledges of financial assistance for the Persian Gulf war.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Canada Inflation Eases
description: Canada's inflation rate fell a seasonally adjusted four-tenths of 1 percent in February, after rising 2.5 percent in January, according to Statistics Canada, a Government agency. For the last 12 months, the consumer price index rose 6.2 percent, compared with a 6.8 percent rise for the year ended a month before. The report surprised economists, who had earlier forecast increases ranging from two-tenths of a percent to sixth-tenths of a percent.

title: Subway Path Boarded Shut After a Rape
description: In the heart of midtown Manhattan, stretching from 34th Street to 42d Street, there is a little-known subway passageway used by as few as 400 people a day walking between stations or dodging bad weather.

title: Thimphu Journal; Bhutan's King Doth Protest. Now Is It Too Much?
description: "The flaw in monarchy," the King of Bhutan said, "is that you reach that very high and important position not due to merit, but due to birth. Too much depends on one individual."

title: Interco Borrowing
description: A Federal bankrupcty court has approved Interco Inc.'s plan to borrow up to $150 million if needed to help keep it in business. The formal approval on Thursday ratified temporary approval previously granted for the loans. Company executives said they had no plan to tap the money but might do so if business conditions required it. The St. Louis-based Interco sought court porotection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws in late January after it was unable to continue paying on more than $2 billion in debt.

title: U.N. Lifts Iraq Food Embargo
description: After receiving a report warning of "imminent catastrophe," the United Nations Security Council eased its trade embargo on Iraq. Page 5.

title: Review/Opera; A New Star In 'Puritani' At the Met
description: "I Puritani" is an opera that Gilbert and Sullivan could have taken as a model. The soprano goes insane upon hearing that her beloved tenor has betrayed her, enjoys several episodes of demented coloratura and returns to sanity immediately when the report proves unfounded. Within that improbable frame, however, Bellini created a score that has attracted and tested famous singers for more than a century and a half. On Thursday evening, the first "Puritani" of the Metropolitan Opera season found Edita Gruberova challenging for a place in the mad-scene pantheon as Elvira, the emotionally volatile Puritan maiden.

title: Rebuild Iraq -- After Hussein Goes
description: The U.N. report that the "near apocalyptic" allied bombardment of Iraq reduced the country to a "pre-industrial age" means the U.S. owes Iraq's people -- but not its leaders -- full-scale humanitarian aid immediately and reconstruction help as soon as it is feasible .

title: H. Chandlee Forman, Architect, Dies at 87
description: H. Chandlee Forman, an architect, historian and archeologist who served as chief architect of the National Park Service, died Monday at his home in Easton, Md. He was 87 years old.

title: Blue Devils' Long-Range Jumpers Bury UConn
description: The tapes were played. The Duke Blue Devils were studied. The conclusion was simple. If there is an area to be exploited, it is the outside shot.

title: Getty Petroleum
description: In the market for a possible merger partner or an acquisition, Getty Petroleum said its board had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to review a range of strategic options for the company. A Getty spokesman said the company's "main objective" in hiring the investment bank was to establish a link with a refiner to stabilize Getty's supplies of oil products. The spokesman said the options that would be reviewed included a joint venture, a merger or the purchase of a refiner. Getty is an independent marketer of gasoline and other petroleum products with outlets in a 13-state area from Maine through Virginia.

title: Getting Out the Youth Vote
description: Twenty years ago today, Minnesota became the first state to ratify the 26th Amendment, which gives 18-year-olds the right to vote. Within three months, the ratification process was successfully completed. This anniversary is an appropriate time for high school educators to help reverse the troubling decline in youth voting.

title: An Exotic Gay Subculture Turns Poignant Under Scrutiny
description: Jennie Livingston wandered into Washington Square Park in the summer of 1985 and saw some young men performing a stylized dance that made them look like fashion models. They were voguing. Ms. Livingston, who had just arrived in New York City to study film, found the spectacle fascinating and stayed to learn more.

title: Public Land Lost for Want of a Small Sum
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Allows Asphalt Factory Dinkins Wanted
description: A dispute over an asphalt plant that New York City wants to build in Queens has provided a major test of how the City Council will handle intense lobbying both from special interest groups and the Mayor.

title: 30-Year Drug Sentence for Ex-Bolivian Aide
description: A Bolivian who Federal prosecutors say ran a vast cocaine-production network while serving as his country's Interior Minister a decade ago was sentenced here today to the maximum punishment of 30 years' imprisonment for drug trafficking conspiracy.

title: United Nations Eases Rules On Food and Fuel for Iraqis
description: The United Nations Security Council lifted its embargo on food supplies to Iraq today and eased restrictions on shipments of certain critical humanitarian goods including fuel for tucks and electrical generators.

title: Some Veterans Facing New Battles on Return
description: The return of gulf war veterans to workaday life after the cheering stops will bring surprises for managers, co-workers and spouses, as well as the veterans themselves -- and many companies and workers are poorly prepared.

title: Alfred T. Gregory, 89, Aeronautical Engineer
description: Alfred Thorne Gregory, a former chief engineer and director of research in the engine division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, died on March 9 at Huntington Hospital in Huntington, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: British Study Faults Pan Am On Bombing Over Lockerbie
description: A 61-day British inquiry into the 1988 terrorist bombing of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, found today that the airline had not followed international baggage-identification procedures that could have prevented the disaster.

title: Lebow Has Operation
description: Fred Lebow, the 58-year-old president of the New York Road Runners Club and director of the New York City Marathon, was listed in stable condition after having a malignant tumor removed from his thyroid yesterday.

title: Hamilton Standard Post
description: Robert M. Kuhn has been named president of Hamilton Standard, the aerospace division of the United Technologies Corporation, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Kuhn replaces Terry D. Stinson, who has accepted a position outside the company. In his new position, Mr. Kuhn will also be responsible for United Technologies Optical Systems, Microtecnica of Torino, Italy, and Nord-Micro of Frankfurt.

title: J. Bailey Harvey, Professor, 85
description: J. Bailey Harvey, a professor emeritus of speech at the City College of New York and a former director of the Columbia University Glee Club, died on March 16 at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Belmar, N.J.

title: Emory To Reopen Harassment Case
description: Officials of the Emory University law school said today that they would reopen their investigation into the conduct of a law professor who has been charged with sexual harassment by more than a dozen female law students.

title: Review/Dance; From 1983, Elegy And Exaltation
description: This has been a difficult year for the Joffrey Ballet, but one would never know that from the proceedings onstage at the New York State Theater, where the company ended a 35th-anniversary season last Sunday night. Typical of the season's triumphant dancing were performances last Saturday afternoon in a compelling work by Gerald Arpino, the Joffrey's artistic director.

title: New Hampshire Tacher is Guilty in Murder Plot
description: Pamela Smart, a 23-year-old New Hampshire high school teacher, was convicted today of plotting with her 15-year-old student-lover to murder her husband, and was immediately sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

title: Religion Notes
description: Heaven and Hell

title: Little Is Found in Navy Crash
description: Searchers found only small pieces of debris today in the ocean area where two Navy planes collided Thursday off San Diego, and Navy officials say that the causes of the crash may never be known.

title: Daily News Struggles to Print and a Columnist Joins a Rival
description: After a day spent repairing sabotaged presses at The Daily News printing plant in Brooklyn, the newspaper's second post-strike issue was printed without a hitch this morning.

title: Lessons From a Budget Crisis
description: Mayor David Dinkins and Gov. Mario Cuomo are reacting to the downward spiral of New York's economy with more realism than they've displayed in the past. The New York City Mayor's call this week for concessions from city unions is a particularly welcome sign, and the Governor has proposed his own solutions to the latest downturn instead of waiting for the Legislature.

title: Books of The Times; A Wider Literary Road From Japan
description: Beyond the Curve By Kobo Abe Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. 247 pages. Kodansha International . $18.95. Woman Running in the Mountains By Yuko Tsushima Translated by Geraldine Harcourt. 275 pages. Pantheon Books. $22.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about law firms that specialize in biotechnology patent work misidentified a firm and misstated its size. It is Wolf, Greenfield & Sacks, with 36 lawyers, not 8. The article also misidentified a law school that some scientists in New York City law firms are attending at night. It is the New York Law School, not New York University School of Law.

title: Celtic Charged in 2 Deaths
description: Boston Celtics guard Charles Smith pleaded not guilty to motor-vehicle homicide and drunken-driving charges after a hit-and-run accident that killed two Boston University students early today, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said.

title: College Basketball: N.C.C.A. Tournament; Second-Half Blitz Lifts Tar Heels Past Hurons
description: Unrelenting North Carolina broke down Eastern Michigan with a second-half blitz tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, and the Tar Heels gained a convincing 93-67 victory in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's Eastern Regional.

title: Harlem Battalion Performed Well in Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film Festival; On the Road With Cabeza De Vaca
description: Nicolas Echevarria's "Cabeza de Vaca" is a historical film that can probably be best appreciated by those who already know the story of the 16th-century Spanish explorer, Alvar Nunez Cabeza de Vaca.

title: Los Angeles Officers Win Delay on Entering Pleas in Beating
description: Four police officers accused of assault in the videotaped beating of a black motorist won a delay today until next week to enter their pleas in court, while new disclosures continued to feed public anger over the incident.

title: Excerpts From U.N. Report on Need for Humanitarian Assistance in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from a United Nations report on humanitarian needs in Iraq:

title: How About Puerto Rico's Self-Determination?; Hidden Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolls-Royce Plans to Cut 3,000 Jobs
description: The British aircraft-engine maker Rolls-Royce said it planned to drop 3,000 from its work force of 35,000 this year. A company spokesman attributed the cuts to the health of the aerospace industry, which has been hurt by the drop in airline travel during the Persian Gulf crisis. Recession in the United States and Britain, among other nations, has also hurt the industry.

title: Patents; 5 Millionth U.S. Patent: For Ethanol
description: Researchers at the University of Florida won patent 5,000,000 this week -- which the Patent and Trademark Office hailed as a landmark advance -- for a genetically engineered microbe that helps convert wastepaper and yard trash into ethanol fuel.

title: Ms. Perry Weds M. C. L. Hallows
description: Lynn Catharine Augusta Perry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Rowland Perry Jr. of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest to Michael Colin Lloyd Hallows, the son of Henry C. Hallows of Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, England, and the late Jean Hallows. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: College Basketball: N.C.C.A. Tournament; Diary of a Rebel: 'We've Got to Get More Focused'
description: I'm concerned with how we've been playing the last month. We haven't played well since before the Arkansas game.

title: Retirement Study at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union are negotiating how to get some hourly workers to retire early, according to union and company officials who asked not to be identified.

title: New Lasers Aim Directly at Port-Wine Stains
description: LINDA WONG has been stopped by more strangers than she cares to remember in the four years since her son William was born with a port-wine stain from the upper temple down the left side of the face to the neck.

title: California's Ancient Inland Sea
description: SOUTH of Bridgeport, Calif., on U.S. 395, from the pulloff just below the summit of Conway Pass, the Mono Basin sometimes shimmers like a vast mirage. To the south are the soft, wavering volcanic hills of the Mono Craters, to the east is Nevada and the Great Basin; to the north the more pointed Bodie Hills, scene of one of the West's more desperate gold rushes, and to the west, behind you, runs the jagged shadow of the Sierra Nevada. In the center, more or less, improbably turquoise some days against the grays, is Mono Lake, one of the North American continent's most ancient inland seas.

title: SPECIAL TODAY
description: Business World/Magazine Part 2

title: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade; The Cause of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Baron Haussmann, Urban Designer Par Excellence
description: If any city plan can be seen as the environmental expression of national characteristics, then Paris is among the most obvious. It is a veritable diagram of the French proclivity for centralization, rationalism and prestige. It is also proof of what one dynamic individual can do to reshape a city, a kind of leadership many people long for today, as our urban problems often seem insurmountable, especially through design.

title: County G.O.P. Sets the Tone Of Its '91 Campaign
description: JACK KEMP, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, came to Westchester last week to help county Republican leaders open the 1991 political season. But from the opening moments of Tuesday's fund-raising dinner, it appeared he wasn't needed.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Menu in a Young-Spirited Bistro
description: KEEPING up with Hoboken's changing dining scene requires the attention of an avid baseball fan. Restaurants change names and cuisines the way the Yankees switch managers, and chefs move around with the frequency of free agents.

title: Rent Now, Buy Later
description: Renters of the newly released "Ghost" will discover a brief commercial message from Paramount before the movie starts.
