In it, a young couple rouse their snoring dog, Baron, from a couch and ask him to fetch "Ghost" (reviewed at left). Baron prefers "My Life as a Dog," but the man notes that they've watched it three times already. Four, says the woman. The message then points out that anyone who watches a movie so often might consider buying a used rental cassette when they go on sale at the video store.

title: Susan Jacobson to Marry David A. Lewis in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eliot S. Jacobson of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Johanna Jacobson to David Allman Lewis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fraser Lewis of Princeton, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title:
FORUM;
Beware Treasury's Bank Reform Plan
description: THE recently issued Treasury Department proposals for the banking system clearly will be controversial. Two proposals -- to permit nonfinancial corporations to hold a substantial equity interest in commercial banks and to engage in traditional securities market activities -- are especially unwise.

title: Missing Crew in Navy Crash
description: Following is a list of the 27 crew members missing after two Navy submarine-hunting planes collided off the California coast early Thursday: BECKNER, Petty Officer 2d Class Ray D., 29 years old, of Elmwood, Neb. CARMODY, Lieut. Ronald L., 27, Tiverton, R.I. CAVUOTO, Petty Officer 2d Class John, 22, Savannah, Ga. CERINO, Airman Brian M., 21, Saylorsburg, Penn. CHAIKIN, Lieut. (j.g.) David G., 25, Lexington, Mass. COX, Lieut. (j.g.) Martin B., 27, Oklahoma City. DABBS, Petty Officer 3d Class Richard A., 22, Ramer, Tenn. DAVIS, Petty Officer 3d Class Christopher D., 20, Rapid City, S.D. DYER, Petty Officer 1st Class Jimmy W., 31, Riverside, Calif. FARQUHAR, Petty Officer 3d Class Dennis G. Jr., 20, Brooksville, Fla. GERMEAU, Petty Officer 2d Class Michael L., 22, Centralia, Wash. HALL, Petty Officer 2d Class Randall D. Jr., 25, Saginaw, Mich. HAMILTON, Lieut. Mark D., 26, Cedarburg, Wis. HEIKKINEN, Petty Officer 1st Class Daryl J., 31, Chassell, Mich. HOGUE, Petty Officer 3d Class Warren J., 32, Dalton, Ill. McNERNEY, Petty Officer 1st Class Thomas Jr., 30, Pittsburgh. METCALF, Lieut. Ned W., 26, Sarasota, Fla. NEMECEK, Lieut. Comdr. Robert A., 33, Westmoreland, N.Y., a pilot. OWENS, Airman Dorsey C. Jr., 19, Haysi, Va. REDMOND, Lieut. Dennis L., 26, Freehold, N.J. RICE, Petty Officer 3d Class Michael A., 23, Tacoma, Wash. SHIELDS, Lieut. (j.g.) James B., 26, Auburn, Me. SMITH, Petty Officer 2d Class Daniel W., 27, Chetopa, Kan. SPOSATO, Petty Officer 2d Class Francis A., 30, Tulsa, Okla. TAFOYA, Petty Officer 3d Class Richard, 21, Glendale, Calif. TISDALE, Lieut. Comdr. Stephen A., 39, San Jose, Calif. WILLIAMSON, Lieut. (j.g.) Jay A., 27, Moore, Okla.

title: Paul Engle, 82, Poet and Founder of Writing Program at U. of Iowa
description: Paul Engle, the poet and author who nursed the University of Iowa's writers' programs to international acclaim, died suddenly Friday at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. A resident of Iowa City, he was 82 years old.

title: MEDICAL INSURERS VARY FEES TO AID HEALTHIER PEOPLE
description: Private insurers, which once spread the cost of health insurance equally across all groups, are increasingly charging different rates for different kinds of people.

title: Setting Standards for Compost
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: F.H.A. Helps the Elderly; Reverse-Mortgage Insurance
description: About 70 percent of Americans over the age of 62 own their own homes, and 85 percent of those homes have been paid off, leaving millions of Americans with billions of dollars worth of equity that, for many of them, would come in very handy in their old age.

title: Hacker Admits That He Stole A.T.&T. Electronic Passwords
description: In a plea agreement with the Government, a computer hacker has admitted trying to help other hackers steal passwords guarding the computer systems of large corporations.

title: Data Update
So-Called Experts
description: To the Editor: There is no more danger in having the celebrities of the Creative Coalition expressing their views than the obvious harm that can come from the so-called experts who tell us what we supposedly should have heard or witnessed after a Presidential speech or a news event. HARRY EMERSON OTTO Stone Harbor, N.J.

title: Magnolias Provide Springtime Majesty
description: WHAT is it with spring and the color yellow? The first crocus to bloom has yellow flowers. Adonis opens waxy buttercups in shades of deep yellow. Forsythia has yellow bells, and there are even yellow flowers on winter hazels and spice bushes.

title: Rockin' With Nietzsche
description: In an era when Vietnam consumed the national attention, Jim Morrison may well have been rock's point man in the cultural free-fire zone of the 60's. As lead singer and chief lyricist of the Doors, Morrison's dark lyric vision, dramatic stage presence and leonine visage electrified the rock world. When he died -- at the age of 27, probably of a heroin overdose, in July 1971 -- many refused to believe he was gone. If ever a rock star was capable of resurrection, it was Jim Morrison. The Doors' records continue to sell well, in many instances better than they sold when Morrison was alive. His presence returns anew in Oliver Stone's film "The Doors" and in books chronicling his life. In JIM MORRISON: Dark Star (Viking Studio, $29.95), the journalist Dylan Jones charts the star's rise and fall and offers some fresh insights into his motivations and early influences. To his credit, Mr. Jones explores Morrison's embrace of Nietzsche's thought, calling "The Birth of Tragedy" the key to understanding Morrison and the Doors. But there's often a sense that the book has been rushed into print, and it offers us little beyond the boilerplate tragedy. "Dark Star" flickers occasionally, but it will probably take its place with other books on other stars whose grip on the popular imagination extended beyond their lives -- another well-intentioned example of cashing in on a dead legend.

title: Topics of the Times; McHealthier
description: It contains 10 grams of fat. That's too much to qualify as a real health food and probably too little to win over hard-core burger addicts. Still, it's worth welcoming the McLean Deluxe, the low-fat hamburger McDonald's plans to introduce next month at its fast-food outlets.

title:
Style Makers;
Mark Rossi, Home Accessories Designer
description: In a throw-away culture, Mark Rossi has acquired a devoted following for heirloom-quality home accessories made to last.

title: From Cosby's Father to Colonel Pickering, By Way of Norway
description: A new production of Shaw's "Pygmalion" casts a black actress as Clara Eynsford-Hill, a fashionable young lady from the impoverished British upper class, and Earle Hyman (the actor who plays Bill Cosby's father on television) as Colonel Pickering, the military man turned Indian-dialect scholar.

title: For Groupies Only . . .
description: The novelist Eve Babitz slept with Jim Morrison when he was still lean and beautiful, she says in this month's cover article in Esquire. Richard Goldstein, in The Village Voice, recently revisited an interview he did with Morrison more than 20 years ago. And Lisa Robinson began a column in The New York Post a few weeks ago, "I knew Jim Morrison toward the end of his life," when he was bloated and constantly drunk. So here is my own journalistic confession: I never slept with Jim Morrison, I never drank with Jim Morrison, I never saw the Doors in concert and I never even, as Oliver Stone has admitted he did, worshiped Jim Morrison from afar.

title: Longley to Turn Pro
description: New Mexico center Luc Longley, a 7-foot-2-inch Australian, said he was withdrawing from school to enter the National Basketball Association draft. . . . Larry Johnson and Stacey Augmon of the undefeated Nevada-Las Vegas team are among five finalists for the Naismith Award, given by the Atlanta Tipoff Club to the athlete a panel of writers and broadcasters considers the top college basketball player of the season. The other finalists are Shaquille O'Neal of Louisiana State, Kenny Anderson of Georgia Tech and Billy Owens of Syracuse. . . . Ken Griffey Sr., the Seattle outfielder who has pain and back spasms since an automobile accident on March 2, does not have disk or bone damage, the Mariners announced after Griffey underwent a magnetic resonance imaging test. (AP)

title: Wall Street; Off the Beaten Bankruptcy Path
description: John C. Boland, a former newspaperman, labors over his computer keyboard in a brick garret whose walls are lined with vintage paperback mystery novels, while tea cools in a lumpy pottery mug and four cats (one named Mouse) grumble in the cozy kitchen two floors below.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;
New Theater For 2d Phase
description: ONE of the city's largest cinema complexes, with nine screens and 2,600 seats, is being built close enough to a trendy south Philadelphia neighborhood so that residents can walk to it. But the developers expect to lure audiences from throughout the region because a newly opened Interstate-95 ramp slices across the development site.

title:
DANCE;
3 Groups That Found Their Own Niches
description: A CASCADE of modern-dance performances will mark the weekend of April 6 and 7, giving audiences in three areas a chance to experience a spectrum of contemporary dance. For those who follow the development of choreographers whose troupes are very much home grown, the spring season offers an opportunity to see companies that have survived their infancy to occupy a definite place in the state dancescape.

title: The Telly's Take On Americans? Texans All
description: British television viewers, especially those of a certain age, got a great kick out of the gulf war briefings of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. There are several reasons, and some are obvious: namely, that the general was our ally, that the news he brought was overwhelmingly positive, and that he was visibly nerved up to make his performances as dramatic as they were informative. But General Schwarzkopf also embodied a more nostalgic appeal, one that is slightly embarrassing for a Britisher to explain.

title: Streetscapes: The Hermitage/National Hotel; Off Times Square, A 1933 'Remuddling'
description: "THE age of remuddling" was critic Lewis Mumford's term for the wave of remodeling that swept New York City in the early 1930's. In 1933, that wave broke over the 1907 Hotel Hermitage on Seventh Avenue south of 42d Street as part of an early cleanup campaign for Times Square.

title: Merchant Followed and Killed
description: A Lower East Side storekeeper was shot and killed Friday night by would-be robbers who followed him to his apartment after he and his wife closed the store, the police said. Jose Rivera, 67 years old, was shot when two men tried to push into the apartment after him, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. A revolver, which may have belonged to Mr. Rivera, was found under his body, she said. Mr. Rivera and his wife, Angela, had closed their market at 210 Rivington Street about 8:30 P.M. Friday. Mrs. Rivera told investigators she was inside the apartment when she heard a struggle and shots fired outside the door.

title: From the Dylan Archives, Rough Drafts, Missing Links
description: Every modern musician leaves a trail of tape, most of it the scraps of false starts, missed notes and technical flaws; now and then, a whole song is discarded. Only a few performers have spurred the kind of devotion that would make anyone comb through the detritus, but since the 1960's Bob Dylan has been one of them. His official releases were revelatory, his concerts made the studio recordings seem tame, and especially during the 1960's, his songwriting was so prolific that regular albums couldn't contain all of it. As Mr. Dylan cultivated his enigma, fans wanted more.

title: College Basketball; U.N.L.V. Routs Seton Hall to Join Kansas in Final 4
description: The unbeaten Nevada-Las Vegas Runnin' Rebels put on a stunning exhibition of transition basketball here this afternoon, pulverizing Seton Hall by 77-65 in the West Regional final to reach the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for a second year in a row.

title: For Beverly Hills, a New Peninsula Hotel With Villas
description: The Peninsula Group, a Hong Kong hotel company known for its Old World-style luxury properties in the Far East, will open a new hotel in Beverly Hills this summer, its second in the United States.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; University Helps Its Workers Take Their 'Next Steps'
description: As she prepared to di vorce her husband just over a year ago, Charlotte Coates knew that her new life would not be easy.

title: Babies, Sisterhood and Economics
description: A COUPLE of years ago, four women -- two actresses, one director and one playwright -- sat around, talking about an idea for a play. "What's on your mind?" and "What keeps you awake?" were among the questions the director asked.

title: Pro Football; Live From Barcelona: W.L.A.F.'s Kickoff on TV
description: It sounds like an all-comedy radio station.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: Malcolm Browne is astonished that the problems of news correspondents in reporting the gulf war "seem to evoke little sympathy from some of our countrymen." More sympathy might be evident if their writing about these problems were more evenhanded.

title: Wordplay Stages Romantic Fantasy
description: EVEN though Eileen Malloy has just returned from the funeral of her husband, Jack, she assumes -- no, she insists -- Jack will be back. If only for those idyllic and sexy Sunday mornings the middle-aged Irish couple had together.

title: State Feels New Strains as Population Shifts
description: AS the state's population shifts from the densely packed cities of the northeast to the rolling rural landscapes of central and southern New Jersey, political scientists say the trend toward suburbanization is creating a new set of challenges for residents, employers and many state and local officials.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Scientist Hopes Fish 'Antifreeze' Can Save Organs
description: A natural antifreeze found in Antarctic cod could be used to preserve human organs for transplant, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley says. But the scientist, Boris Rubinsky, who teaches mechanical engineering, says he still does not understand how or why the antifreeze works.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: INNOVATIVE INSTRUMENTS

title: Miss Niejadlik To Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Charles Niejadlik of Old Saybrook, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Anne Niejadlik, to Bradley William Kabbash, a son of William Anthony Kabbash of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Varying the Easter-Passover Menu
description: THIS year the observance of the Easter season and Passover coincide, as they are wont to do every few years. Despite differing traditions and dietary restrictions, there are many recipes that would be appropriate for both holidays. They tend to acknowledge the arrival of spring.

title:
ART;
Fiction Comes To Life
description: IN the annals of history, certain figures loom larger than life, providing copious raw material for those biographers and analysts who often spend a great many pages sorting out fact from fantasy.

title: Plural Perspectives, Heightened Perceptions
description: THE CONTINUOUS LIFE By Mark Strand. 63 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. LET EVENING COME By Jane Kenyon. 70 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95. MYSTERY TRAIN By David Wojahn. 85 pp. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ONE, FIVE, MANY By Kveta Pacovska. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books. $16.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Talking: Co-op Deals; Finding Bargains in Adversity
description: ONE person's crisis, popular wisdom has it, is someone else's opportunity. This seems to be the way some adventurous buyers are beginning to perceive apartments in financially troubled New York City cooperatives.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COLD FIRE By Dean R. Koontz.Putnam, $22.95.

title: HUSSEIN SHUFFLES THE IRAQI CABINET
description: President Saddam Hussein shuffled his Cabinet today as he struggled to contain insurgencies in northern and southern Iraq.

title: 5 Japanese Artists Turn Fibers Into Illusions
description: FIVE fiber artists from Kyoto, Japan, need no translator to express their individual approaches to imagery and color. Their work, on display at Montclair State College, says it all.

title: London
description: To the Editor: In "Subway Safaris on London's Tube," Robert Spiers Benjamin states that Sir Francis Chichester made the first solo circumnavigation of the world.

title: Cars of Yesterday Purr Like New
description: WHY restore a rusty hulk instead of buying a shiny new Lexus or Porsche? Maybe to create a touchable memory, or achieve art in motion. Or maybe it is as simple as the reason given by the owner of a perfectly preserved 1962 Thunderbird after taking the car for a spin. "I've never had so much fun in my life," he said.

title: Pay-Per-View Is Dangerous
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On the Street; A Burst of Color in Paris
description: Like a field of crocuses, a major fashion statement blossomed on the streets of Paris last week. Many women were wearing new Chanel suit jackets in Easter-egg colors, a singing palette highly unusual in this fashion capital, which gives styling a high priority and color a low one. In an audience of 1,500 at the Chanel ready-to-wear show for fall, nearly 100 women wore variations on the new jackets in shades of pink, orange and aqua. Many of the jackets have navy or black binding, and many of the wearers have discarded skirts in favor of leggings that range from tights to unitards to biker shorts. When a skirt is worn, the color is most often black or navy matched to stockings or shoes, and the hemline is inches above the kneecap. But what was most unusual was the appearance in Paris of color, most often associated with America.

title: Gary Shedlin Wed To Ms. Winograd
description: Deborah Rae Winograd, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliott Winograd of Deal Park, N.J., was married last evening to Gary Stephen Shedlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Shedlin of Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Short Hills (N.J.) Hilton by Rabbis Jacob Friedman and Jack Stern Jr.

title: India
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a three-week vacation in India and feel that Indian Airlines goes out of its way to alienate tourists. On Jan. 15, I was one of 11 Americans flying from Aurangabad to Udaipur. While we waited to board the flight (IC492), many boxes were loaded as cargo, then after we boarded the plane, we learned that there was an overweight problem and that it would be necessary to remove the baggage of the 11 Americans and that of a French group of about 21 tourists. We received our baggage at 11 o'clock the following evening. In addition to the distress of not having clothing, toilet articles or medications, we lost a half-day's sightseeing because of the time lost in removing the luggage from the plane.

title: Peter H. Ohm, 59, Ran Korean Paper in New York City
description: Peter H. Ohm, founder and publisher of Korea Times, the largest Korean-American newspaper in the New York City area, and the owner of a Korean-American television station, died on Friday at the Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Florida. He was 59 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: The Damage Was Not Collateral
description: The first independent assessment of the damage done to Iraq by allied bombing has painted a grim picture of catastrophic devastation. A United Nations team described the effects of the bombing as "near apocalyptic," knocking Iraq back "to a pre-industrial age."

title: Pro Basketball; On Fire In Chicago
description: Moments after another victory last Monday, Michael Jordan was in the Chicago Bulls' locker room, changing clothes faster than a fireman. He was rushing so he could watch the fight between Mike Tyson and Donovan (Razor) Ruddock.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about St. Croix misstated the date of Hurricane Hugo. It was a year and a half ago, in September 1989, not two and a half years ago.

title: 'Science Matters'
description: To the Editor:

title: Knock-Knock Routine Changing With Times
description: AS with many people, Cathy O'Brien's idea of the Fuller Brush Company was frozen in an earlier time -- in her case, in the visits of a rumpled elderly Fuller Brush man to her mother's walk-up apartment in the Bronx in the 1960's.

title: Lisa McNally to Wed William Cassidy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth McNally to William Charles Cassidy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Cassidy of New Canaan, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title:
FORUM;
The Opportunities in U.S.-Soviet Aid
description: Together the United States and the Soviet Union could exercise control over the world oil market. The Soviet Union is the largest and the United States the second largest oil producer in the world. These two countries are also the world's biggest oil consumers, with the United States consuming almost a third of the world's production.

title: Laura Beth Gratz to Wed Jon Piasecki
description: Mrs. and Mrs. Donald S. Gratz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Beth Gratz to Jon Piasecki, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Piasecki of Chateaugay, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Mutual Funds; Placing Bets on Recovery
description: Judging from where they had put their assets at the end of last year, managers of the five types of stock funds were making very different bets on where the economy was headed.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENTS/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Ghost 1990. Paramount. $99.95. Laser disk, $29.95. 2 hours, 22 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Laura Baumstein Marries
description: Laura A. Baumstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Baumstein of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last night to Stephen F. Sonnenfeld, a son of Johanna Sonnenfeld Lenneberg of Chicago and Peter H. Sonnenfeld of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Selig Salkowitz officiated at the Nancy Brown Studio in New York. Mrs. Sonnenfeld, 27 years old, is an advertising sales representative at The New Yorker magazine in New York. She graduated from Rutgers University. The bridegroom, 30, is an associate media director at Lord, Dentsu & Partners, a New York advertising agency. He graduated from Indiana University.

title: Headliners; In Her Own Words
description: Ever since Iraq invaded Kuwait nearly eight months ago, April C. Glaspie has been taking the fall. As Ambassador to Iraq, she met with Saddam Hussein in late July 1990. A transcript released by Iraq after the invasion said that she had told Mr. Hussein the United States had "no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts," which Iraq -- and some Americans -- took to mean that the United States would not react if Iraq moved on Kuwait. But last week Ms. Glaspie, speaking publicly for the first time, said that the transcript omitted important sentences, such as her insisting that any disputes be settled without violence. She said Mr. Hussein was "too stupid" to realize that Washington meant business. The State Department now says it knew all along that Ms. Glaspie was in the clear. If so, why did she remain a scapegoat? Speaking for herself, Ms. Glaspie said that to respond to the criticism without clearance from her superiors would have been playing the Washington politics game, and "I won't stoop to that."

title:
Europe '91: A Festival of Arts;
50 Celebrations of Past and Present
description: WHILE the major focus of music festivals this year is the 200th anniversary of Mozart's death, other important anniversaries are being marked as well: Switzerland's founding 700 years ago, the deaths of Antonio Vivaldi and Johann Joseph Fux 250 years ago, the birth of Giacomo Meyerbeer 200 years ago and the birth of Dvorak 150 years ago. Two distinctly different composers of wit and originality are being honored on their centenaries: Prokofiev and Cole Porter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Stately Wager Was a Good Bet: Stately Wager drove between horses through the stretch and won the $118,400 Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, strengthening his Kentucky Derby hopes. Stately Wager, ridden by Jorge Chavez, carried 119 pounds to a 1 1/4-length victory over the favored Mineral Ice, which was ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and carried 119 pounds. It was another two lengths back to Vouch for Me in the field of seven. Neither Mineral Ice nor Vouch for Me was nominated for the Derby on May 4 at Churchill Downs. Stately Wager, a Florida-bred son of Bet Big and Regal Departure, notched his second victory in three starts this year. He took Aqueduct's Whirlaway Stakes in his last start. Stately Wager covered seven furlongs in 1:23 4/5, earning $71,040 for Robert B. Cohen, his owner, and returning $9, $4.20 and $2.60 for $2 across the board. (AP) Golf Nicklaus and Watson Falter: All eyes were on the Hall of Famers Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson, who were paired together yesterday in the last group on the course and were only a stroke apart on the top of the leader board after two rounds. But nine other players stole the spotlight as they passed Nicklaus and Watson in the third round of the USF&G Classic in New Orleans. Jim Hallet, never a winner in a four-season career on the PGA Tour, surged into the third-round lead with a 65, which put him at 205, 11 under par. He was six strokes in front of Nicklaus, who shot a 74 for 211, and seven ahead of Watson, who shot a 73. Also ahead of the Hall of Famers were Ronnie Black, Joel Edwards, Billy Mayfair, Ian Woosnam, Kenny Knox, Tom Sieckmann, Phil Blackmar and John Huston. (AP) Hunting for First Victory: Danielle Ammaccapane, seeking her first L.P.G.A. victory, shot a three-under-par 70 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the third round of the Standard Register tournament in Phoenix. The former Arizona State standout, who grew up in Phoenix, was at 214 after two rounds at the 6,514-yard Moon Valley Country Club. Colleen Walker, Michelle McGann and Barb Bunkowsky, the second-round leader, were tied for second, four under at 215. The defending champion, Pat Bradley, had a 78 and fell out of contention at 229. (AP) Bowling Eight-Year Drought Ends: Norm Duke ended an eight-year streak without a victory with a 221-185 victory yesterday over Dave Husted in a Professional Bowlers Association tournament in Parma Heights, Ohio. Duke's only previous victory came in the 1983 Cleveland Open. Husted earned his shot at the title after disposing of Joe Firpo, 227-215, in the semifinal game. (AP) Skiing Swede Wins in Season's Last Slalom: Tomas Fogdoe of Sweden, three times a runner-up in his first World Cup racing season, scored his first victory yesterday. It came in Waterville Valley, N.H., in the final slalom of the season. Fogdoe, 21 years old, blasted from second place after the morning run to complete two heats in 1 minute 42.48 seconds. His victory was assured when Michael Tritscher of Switzerland, who led the first run over Fogdoe by .18 seconds, hooked a ski tip and fell late in his run. When Tritscher fell, second place went to Alberto Tomba of Italy and Rudi Nierlich of Austria, who each completed two runs in 1:42.91, .43 seconds behind the Swede. Marc Girardelli, a four-time overall World Cup champion, clinched his third career slalom title in the first run. (AP) Speed Skating World Record for Chinese Woman: Zhang Yamei of China set a world record in winning the women's 500-meter event at the world short-track championships yesterday in Sydney, Australia. Zhang was timed in 47.08 seconds, breaking the mark of 47.77 set by Christina Sciolla of Italy. Sylvie Daigle of Canada was disqualified in the 500-meter final, but won the 1,000-meter title, beating her compatriot Nathalie Lambert. Willie O'Reilly of Britain won the men's 500-meter and 1,000-meter titles. The races were skated on a 110-meter track. (AP) Road Racing New Jerseyan Wins in New York: Keith Turner of Fort Lee, N.J., won a 20-mile run in 1 hour 49 minutes 31 seconds yesterday in a steady rain at Central Park. Turner finished three-quarters of a mile ahead of John Shanley of Hamden, Conn., who was second in 1:56:20. Gillian Beschloss of the Warren Street Athletic Club of Jersey City was the women's winner in 2:04:10. (AP) Boxing McGirt Stops Montgomery: Buddy McGirt improved his record to 52-2-1 with his 41st knockout, stopping Frank Montgomery in the ninth round of their scheduled 10-round welterweight bout Friday night at the Villa Roma Country Club in Callicoon, N.Y. McGirt, the top-ranked contender of the World Boxing Council and the International Boxing Federation, was in control throughout before catching Montgomery with an overhand right early in the ninth round. He pounced immediately and Referee Arthur Mercante Sr. stopped the bout with 43 seconds elapsed in the round. (AP) Fencing Foil Title to Columbia: Marc Pavese and Ben Atkins led Columbia to the men's team foil title over Notre Dame in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships Friday at Penn State. Pavese beat Notre Dame's Noel Young and Jeff Piper, both by 5-4. Atkins, the individual foil national champion, beat Young by 5-4 and Piper by 5-0, but lost to Phil Leary 4-5.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Will the Mansion Become a 'Money Pit'?
description: PICTURE this: A young couple fall in love with a 24-room mansion on Long Island that is elderly but has a lot of charm and is a lot more house than husband and wife thought they could ever afford.

title: Self-Help for Growing Ranks of Jobless
description: WITH the state's unemployment rate at a seven-year high, it often seems that people can be divided into two categories: those who have been laid off and those who fear that they may be.

title: Michelle Bates to Wed David Deakin
description: Mr. and Mrs. David C. Bates of Stantonville, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Elizabeth Bates, to David Andrew Deakin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Deakin of Bennington, Vt. An August wedding is planned.

title: Michele Rein Is Married To Robert Alan Simpson
description: Michele Jeanine Rein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rein of New York, was married last evening at the Equitable Tower in New York to Robert Alan Simpson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Simpson of Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Stanley Davids and Cantor Richard Botton officiated.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Roberta Silman;
Using Fiction to Probe Women and War
description: MORE than ever before American women were part of the military's recent war effort -- in sharp contrast to earlier conflicts when women served either in behind-the-scenes civilian roles or as nurses. Yet even in the Persian Gulf fighting, women were not the decision makers. It was not they who decided whether to go to war, how to wage it, what weapons to use and when to stop it.

title: Campus Life: Merchant Marine; Cadets Learn the Ropes Hauling Tanks to War
description: Trevor De Lew will never forget the start of his junior year abroad: Wearing a rubber suit to protect him from a chemical weapons attack, he steamed into a Saudi Arabian port on Jan. 15, the deadline the United States had set for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

title: Commercial Property: Suburban Office Development; Overbuilding Leaves Huge Legacy of Empty Space
description: VACANCY rates of 25 percent or more are being recorded in many smaller office markets around New York City, where the accelerated pace of development during the 1980's is having much the same debilitating effect as in Manhattan.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Eating With Our Minds In the 1930's M. F. K. Fisher was a solitary, eloquent voice in the gastronomic wilderness of America. Matters have changed, but her argument on behalf of an "open-eyed delight" in food is still timely. This is from the 1937 book "Serve It Forth," included in "The Art of Eating" (Collier/Macmillan, paper).

title: Amy C. Ravitch To Wed in May
description: Donald N. Ravitch and Gloria M. Ravitch, both of San Francisco, have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Amy Carol Ravitch and Bruce Andrew Friedricks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Friedricks of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Converse in Adland, Playing Catch-Up Ball
description: After more than 70 years in the sneaker business, Converse Inc. is pinning its future on five words.

title: Washington Journal; Cherry Blossom Time Is Months in the Making
description: This city is always in a tizzy this time of year, planning for the Cherry Blossom Festival. It's a touchy business -- throwing a party for a million visitors and not having the guest of honor show up.

title: WOODY AND MIA
description: Eric Lax's "Woody and Mia" (Feb. 24) was a penetrating piece of reporting. The objective stance Lax posed revealed more than many "introspective" profiles on Woody Allen that have appeared in the past; for me, however, the focus was just a little bit too sharp.

title: Yes, It's Spring: Macy's Is in Bloom
description: Underneath the budding pear trees outside Macy's Herald Square last week, an annual spring tradition was in the works. The store's main doors were removed from their hinges, garden hoses uncoiled and trucks filled with lilac bushes, azaleas, rhododendrons, freesia, tulips, amaryllis, primrose and begonias were unloaded and the contents hauled up the main aisle in preparation for Macy's 17th annual flower show, which begins today and runs through April 6.

title: Janet Macomber, Student, Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Macomber of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet Morgan Macomber to Samuel Hart Williamson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Williamson of Portland, Ore. A September wedding is planned.

title: For Groupies Only . . . And Sensitive Souls
description: Jim Morrison didn't need a big, silly movie like "The Doors" to keep his big, silly mystique alive. Almost within minutes after his charismatic, sloppy, unstable, sometimes buffoonish, sometimes inspired self died in Paris in 1971, his legend sprang up: Morrison the rock shaman, the Dionysian stud, the tortured poet, the death-haunted genius dead at 27, still young enough to be a poster pinup. With Oliver Stone's version of the Doors story now carpet-bombing the media, the Morrison mystique threatens to grow from a cult obsession to an epidemic.

title: Republicans Vs. Democracy
description: It was a fine moment for democracy. For years, critics of Congress, liberal and conservative, had condemned its refusal to share responsibility with the President on decisions of war and peace. But in January, Congress rose to the occasion. As it moved to vote on the gulf resolutions, members congratulated one other -- across the partisan lines of their argument -- on the solemnity, even eloquence, of their debate.

title: The Splatterpunk Trend, And Welcome to It
description: From H. P. Lovecraft to Stephen King, modern horror fiction has been concerned with the scariness of the unseen -- of evil spirits and the rustling sound in the back of a dark closet, of ghostly moans and overactive imaginations. Over the last few years, however, there has been a significant shift in horror fiction; the genre's traditional jolt of fright now is provided by acts of violence described in elaborate, gruesome detail. The results, at their most artful and bold, have included the serious popular fiction of Thomas Harris, whose novels "Red Dragon" and "The Silence of the Lambs" are full of a careful measured dread. At its most snobbish and callow, the new horror has led to Bret Easton Ellis's "American Psycho": class animus as a slaughtering ground. And with the rise of so-called splatterpunk fiction, an aggressively grubby underground movement now seeks to compete with more conventional horror writers like Mr. King, Peter Straub and Dean R. Koontz. Most of this new horror fiction trades in the scariness of the seen, the notion that a reader will be frightened -- and entertained? -- by the explicit depiction of horrific acts, including murder and every sort of mutilation of the body.

title: Teachers Assail Special-Education Revision
description: A statewide teachers group, demanded today that the state Board of Regents hold public hearings on a decision to let schools make special-education classes larger.

title: Big Stars, Big Bucks and the Big Gamble
description: Janet Jackson recently signed what has been trumpeted as the most lucrative recording contract in history. The deal, with the London-based label Virgin, was widely reported to have guaranteed the 24-year-old star somewhere between $32 million and $50 million for three albums. That's more than the Rolling Stones, Bruce Springsteen or Ms. Jackson's brother Michael are guaranteed by their contracts.

title: Corrections
description: The Sunday Outing article on March 10 about the museum complex at Audubon Terrace in Manhattan misidentified the building now occupied by Boricua College. It is the former headquarters of the American Geographical Society, not the National Geographic Society.

title: The Romanian Baby Bazaar
description: IT IS BEFORE DAWN ON A JANUARY MORNING, AND AS A photographer and I drive through the dark cobbled streets of Bucharest, we can barely make out the hunched workers, waiting in the numbing cold for their soot-encrusted tram cars. We are following a car in which two women from Oregon, 28-year-old Cindy Dahl and her mother-in-law, Betty Dewhirst, are being driven by a young Romanian man to the city of Ploiesti, about an hour north. He has promised to find a child for Cindy to adopt.

title: Wall Street's Ambitious Top Cop
description: TRIM IN BLUE SHIRT SLEEVES AND striped suspenders, an electronic beeper pegged to his hip, Richard C. Breeden charged into a conference room at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington late on a Friday afternoon. The 41-year-old S.E.C. chairman was responding to an urgent request for a meeting with his legislative staff.

title: Writing Contest Asks Elderly to Give a Legacy of Memory
description: The contest is called "Legacies." The challenge, issued to those over 60, is to write about a meaningful event in their lives. The rewards are $5,000 in prizes, the possibility of publication or adaptation for the theater if the authors win -- and a memory that can be passed on to their grandchildren and great-grandchildren even if they do not.

title: Jersey's 'Gold Coast' Losing Its Glitter
description: THE New Jersey shore of the Hudson River, which emerged in the mid-80's as a powerful new magnet for high-rise office development, is struggling with high vacancy rates, canceled projects and nagging doubts about the capacity of its roads, parking and public transportation.

title: College Basketball; Jayhawks Roar Back for Victory
description: Arkansas likes to bill its relentless fullcourt style of basketball as "40 minutes of hell." But against a disciplined Kansas team this afternoon, the top-seeded Razorbacks were able to make good on their boast for only 20 minutes as the Jayhawks roared back from a 12-point halftime deficit to gain a stunning 93-81 victory in the Southeast Regional final.

title: Smiling In My Size 14
description: For the 35 million American women who wear sizes 14 to 24, and to whom a size 8 dress may be only a distant memory, the choice of spring clothes ranges from a casual orange sweater worn over skinny stretch pants to a red lace gown designed by Geoffrey Beene.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today discusses the increasingly profitable contracts received by pop stars. It discusses Michael Jackson's negotiations with the Sony Corporation.

title: Ms. Cohen Weds Philip A. Fenster
description: Laurie Elizabeth Cohen, the daughter of Alan N. Cohen of New York and the late Joan Cohen, was married last evening to Philip Alan Fenster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fenster of Wayne, N.J. Rabbis David Lincoln and Leon Katz officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: ACCENTS
description: ACCESSORIES MAY BE EXTRAS, but they are actually essentials. It is these added bits that often provide the punctuation points, giving an outfit real panache. It's no surprise that many designers are now as well known for the accessories they show as for the clothes they create. And there are many creators of accessories alone who have become famous on their own.

title: Harvard Finds a Replacement for Its President
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, a 56-year-old scholar of Renaissance literature who is former provost of Princeton University, has been offered the presidency of Harvard University by the committee seeking a candidate to succeed Derek C. Bok.

title: College Basketball; Northeastern Joins Yankee Conference
description: Northeastern University has joined the Yankee Conference, six years after the league rejected the Huskies' bid in favor of several southern schools.

title: Deirdre Deutsch Weds
description: Deirdre Anne Deutsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Deutsch of Malba, Queens, was married on Long Island yesterday to Lothar Josef Kierspel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franz-Josef Kierspel of Frankfurt. The Rev. Thomas LaMont officiated at the Congregational Church of Manhasset. Mrs. Kierspel, 30 years old, is a consultant in New York to women's clothing retailers. She graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton. Mr. Kierspel, 29, is an aluminum trader in the light-metals department of Metallgesellschaft A.G. in Frankfurt.

title: Jori Meltzer to Marry Jonathan E. Wolfe in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Meltzer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jori Anne Meltzer to Jonathan Eric Wolfe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wolfe of Syosset, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Travel Advisory; Virgin Airways Drops Fuel Levy
description: After the British Government decided to award Virgin Atlantic Airways landing rights at Heathrow Airport in London, the airline announced that it was eliminating the fuel surcharges that were added to all its fares in late 1990. Ticket prices were raised 4 to 20 percent by most airlines in response to the rising and unpredictable cost of jet fuel caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. With the end of the war and the drop in fuel prices, Virgin no longer considers the increase necessary.

title: What Science Can't Tell Us
description: SEARCHING FOR CERTAINTY What Scientists Can Know About the Future. By John L. Casti. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Snowmass, Colo.; 12 Home Sites On 6,500 Acres
description: THE largest ranch in the Aspen-Snowmass area, where developers once planned to build a town of 10,000 residents, is now being subdivided into 12 large home sites with price tags of $2 million to $5.5 million.

title: Eastern Europe's Historians, Now Free, Face New Burden
description: After a half-century of misusing history to provide a cloak of legitimacy to governments imposed by the Soviet Union, historians throughout Central and Eastern Europe are enjoying, most for the first time, the satisfaction of practicing their art in freedom.

title: Pro Basketball; Knicks Find Texas to Be a Big Hurdle
description: It did not take long for the Knicks to encounter trouble in Texas.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE COAST OF CHICAGO, by Stuart Dybek. (Vintage, $9.) In one of these short stories about loners, misfits and other marginal lives, a man stands before Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks" feeling that he could fit right in. Last year The Times's Michiko Kakutani said the best of the pieces "possess an emotional forcefulness: they introduce us to characters who want to take up permanent residence in our minds, and in doing so, they persuasively conjure up a fictional world that is both ordinary and amazing."

title: Body and Soul
description: TYPICALLY, A FIGHTER TRAINS ON THE HEAVY BAG in the same manner he attacks a live body. He will step here, step there and throw punches that mimic the arsenal he deploys in an actual fight -- jabs succeeded by hooks and straight right hands.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; The Monster Sale Heads for Connecticut
description: A NEW technique in real estate vending -- the under-one-roof monster sale -- will make its debut in the state next month at New Haven's Park Plaza Hotel.

title: Metro Datelines; Gene Gotti Loses Appeal of Conviction
description: The reputed mob sters Gene Gotti and John Carneglia will have to stay in prison for heroin trafficking after a Federal appeals court upheld their convictions.

title: Wedding in June For Maryann Kirk
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. Kirk Jr. of Rumson, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Maryann Kirk and Glenn John Macchiaverna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Macchiaverna of Seaside Park, N.J.

title: Susan Gold Wed To Jeffrey Freed
description: Susan Beth Gold, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred M. Gold of Vestal, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Howard Freed, the son of Ruth Freed of Paris and New York and the late Elliott K. Freed. The ceremony was performed at the Harvard Club in New York by Rabbi Elihu Schagrin.

title: Elizabeth Greenberg and Cory Frank, Psychologists, Plan to Marry in May
description: Judge and Mrs. Newton Greenberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Elizabeth Emily Greenberg to Dr. Cory Peter Frank, a son of Rita F. Paleschuck of East Hills, L.I., and the late Elliott S. Frank. A May wedding is planned.

title: How Other States' Taxes Compare
description: IF Connecticut adopts a personal income tax on wages, will that harm the state's ability to attract companies, or will the new revenue encourage growth by allowing tax cuts to businesses? And how high are taxes elsewhere?

title: Variation On a Theme
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars; Ownership, Through the Looking Glass
description: There is a delicious sense of voyeurism here. We are comfortable in the dark, a bunch of car writers and Ford executives, all of us fixated on the one-way mirror that allows us to watch and hear a dozen people talking about the pluses and minuses of their new cars.

title: Judith B. Jackson, Student, Engaged
description: Herbert C. Jackson and Dr. Gloria Jackson Bacon, both of Chicago, have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Barbara Jackson to Clayton Linsley Fossett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Fossett of Orange, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Teaching Women About Themselves
description: A WOMAN MAKING HISTORY Mary Ritter Beard Through Her Letters. Edited by Nancy F. Cott. Illustrated. 378 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Solar Eclipse
description: To the Editor: After seeing the list of companies scheduling trips to view the solar eclipse in July (Q & A, Dec. 16), I felt you should know that the Carnegie is planning a solar eclipse trip to Mexico from July 8 to 13.

title: Taking the Fast-Food Chains to Task
description: I found out about cholesterol the hard way. I was a student in the greasy hamburger school of nutrition for my first 43 years and in 1966 I suffered a massive heart attack. I was thin; I didn't smoke; I exercised before it was fashionable. But a shocking 300 cholesterol level got my attention.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Great River 250,000 73 Widgeon Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; den, 2 fireplaces, 0.50 acre; taxes $6,400. title: Tammy A. Weiss To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Weiss of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tammy Anne Weiss to Evan Jay Cohen, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Allen C. Cohen of Massapequa, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Sampler of Music For Easter Week
description: THE blending of sorrow and joy inherent in the commemoration of the death and Resurrection of Christ will be reflected in the musical repertoire to be heard in churches throughout the week.

title: Q and A
description: Selecting Hong Kong Tailors

title: Modern Town Meeting: Neighbors on Cable TV
description: WHEN television viewers here switch channels, they often come across a neighbor competing with Peter Jennings or Murphy Brown for their attention. And as Westchester municipalities negotiate new cable franchise leases, viewers are likely to see more of their neighbors on television.

title: Pro Basketball; Nets Watch Pistons Bounce Back
description: The Nets discovered you don't beat the two-time defending National Basketball Association champion Detroit Pistons without paying a price.

title: Philharmonia Virtuosi Tackles Offbeat Vivaldi
description: WITH all the attention to the Mozart bicentennial, moving the spotlight to other composers provides a welcome change of pace this year.

title: Cuts, but Also Promise, in Mental Health Spending
description: Many states trying to close budget gaps this year are cutting expenditures for the most helpless and stigmatized populations -- the mentally ill and the retarded. But while the cuts are causing a great deal of anguish among patients and families, this seems to be one of the rare cases in which less spending holds the promise of more service later.

title:
MUSIC;
Sisters, as Guest Artists, To Make Trio a Quintet
description: ALTHOUGH the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio and the Kavafian sisters will perform together as a quintet for the first time this week, they all have the same musical outlook, said Sharon Robinson, a cellist who is a founding member of the trio.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about computer publishing systems rendered the name of the Time Inc. Magazine Company's director of development for prepress systems incorrectly. He is Gerard Le lievre.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MILFORD;
Curriculum and Costs Are Sparking Debate On Middle School Plan
description: FOR more than a decade, educators and parents in Milford have been trying to establish middle schools, saying that the school district's program for kindergarten through eighth grade is archaic and lacks some of the most basic elements for 11- to 14-year-olds.

title: Jennifer Burian to Wed
description: A. Ward Burian of Lyme, Conn., and Mrs. John Hanson of Lloyd Neck, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Jennifer Anne Burian and Michael Ehlen Rowe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rowe Jr. of Seattle. Miss Burian, 25 years old, graduated from Denison University. Mr. Rowe, 29, graduated from Western Washington University. He is the vice president for risk arbitrage in the New York office of Robert Fleming Inc., a merchant bank in London.

title: Seeking More Minority Council Members
description: A New York City commission is devising new district lines for an expanded City Council intended to accommodate more black and Hispanic members, and possibly Asian-Americans, homosexuals and other minority groups, including Republicans.

title: Runners Break Sex Barrier
description: To the Sports Editor

title: Writers Counsel Students
description: ABOUT 200 promising young writers from 14 local high schools picked up pointers from 11 published authors this month at a conference here at Westchester Community College, where they were told to trust the creativity within themselves.

title: Looking for Love on Krochmalna Street
description: SCUM By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Translated by Rosaline Dukalsky Schwartz. 218 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a crawl space under our family room, and the floor joists above this space have fiberglass insulation between them. The crawl-space floor is covered with gravel and sheet plastic, and we use this space for storage. To prevent mold, we have an outlet from the heating and air-conditioning duct discharging into this area. Where boxes are stacked against the outside walls, the unpainted cinder blocks are damp and there is a moldy odor from the boxes. Also, flakes that look like salt or lime appear on the wall. What can we do to prevent this?

title: Metro Datelines; One Twin Is Killed, and 2d Is Wounded
description: A 17-year-old Manhattan girl has been charged with fatally shooting one twin and wounding the other during what the police said was a fight over clothing.

title: Governing Salvadoran Party Wins Legislative Vote
description: El Salvador's governing right-wing Arena party has won this month's legislative elections but lost its majority in the National Assembly, final official results announced late Friday showed. Even so, the rightists retained the capacity to pass laws with the support of their parliamentary allies.

title: Nemesis Arrives, Dressed in a Black Suit
description: DAMAGE By Josephine Hart. 198 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.

title: Anna P. Gebelein To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crawford of Grafton, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Crawford's daughter Anna Perkins Gebelein and Stephen John Keegan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Keegan of Greenwich, Conn.

title:
TELEVISION;
Here's the Deal: Find a Writer, Then Shannonize
description: Like detergents, television series are constantly looking for ways to distinguish themselves from the competition. This season, "Shannon's Deal" -- NBC's show about a down-and-out lawyer who never actually goes to court -- is hoping that its script writers will make it stand out from the crowd.

title: THE LESSER-KNOWN LOIRE
description: NOW THAT THE TGV, France's high-speed train, has made the trip from Paris to Tours about the same as going from Grand Central to White Plains, more visitors to France will come to know the wines of the Loire Valley. Not that the Loire is exactly terra incognita. Muscadet, Sancerre and the roses of Anjou have worldwide reputations. But there are some little-known surprises to be found by anyone who takes a car and wanders westward toward Nantes and the sea.

title: France Sees Integration as Answer to View of Immigrants as 'Taking Over'
description: Sifting through his papers, Claude Desvaux counted 203 foreigners among the 280 students attending his public school in the crowded Belleville section of Paris. But the real number, he added with a resigned smile, is much higher.

title: Camera
description: Filing photographs has long been a nightmare, not only for me but for everyone I know. Recently I ventured into the basement of the old family house and discovered my father's complete set of slides of our long-ago family vacations. After brushing off the dust and mold, I found batches and batches of marvelous old images.

title: Cheryl E. Hader And Craig Brod To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Cheryl Elizabeth Hader to Craig Bruce Brod, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Brod of Elberon, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Helen Hader of Millburn, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: WOODY AND MIA
description: What's this, Woody Allen sending out Cartier invitations for his party? What has happened to the bumbling bachelor of "Play It Again Sam?" who doused himself in a full bottle of after-shave before a blind date? Can it be: Woody's gone mainstream? JAMES ENGLISH Flushing, Queens

title: A Better Reason to Expand I.R.A.'s
description: Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and more than 70 other senators are proposing to solve the nation's number one economic problem -- a 40 percent drop in the net national savings rate in the 1980's -- by expanding the use of individual retirement accounts.

title: Harvard Finds a Replacement for Its President
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, a 56-year-old scholar of Renaissance literature who is former provost of Princeton University, has been offered the presidency of Harvard University by the committee seeking a candidate to succeed Derek C. Bok.

title: Currency; Intervention Fails to Dull the Dollar
The Death of a Suspect -- A special report.; In Officers' Murder Case, a Tangle of Contradictions
description: After midnight on Feb. 5, Police Officers James McMorrow and Thomas Loeffel were on routine radio patrol in the 112th Precinct in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Devils Confused By a Tie
description: Montreal's Guy Carbonneau scored with 3 minutes 51 seconds left here tonight at the Forum, and the score earned the Canadiens a 3-3 tie with the Devils.

title:
QUARTER NOTES: A Trimonthly Expression of Opinion;
Postwar Economics
description: THE PERSIAN GULF WAR HAS TAKEN ITS economic toll, worsening the recession by increasing the budget deficit, temporarily spiking the price of oil and dampening consumer confidence. Those should be alleviated as the conflict winds down, but the recession was not caused by the war and will not disappear with the war's end. What's more, in resurrecting a Pax Americana, the Bush Administration has complicated a host of nagging economic issues.

title: What Happened in 1956? Pick a Word
description: Nowhere in the Soviet bloc was history more purposefully used by the old Government and its opponents than in Hungary.

title: Travel Advisory; Israel at Normal
description: Most foreign airlines have either resumed flights to Israel or announced dates when they will. Some European airlines have even added extra flights and larger planes to accommodate the burgeoning traffic for the Easter-Passover season. Hotels and tour operators report ample bookings, though up until now they had been virtually empty since last summer. The Taba Hilton, as an example, had two guests on a recent weekend. All the restaurants were closed as a result. For the weekend of March 30, the manager says, the hotel is fully booked.

title: Informed Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Cover Stories
description: HOW TO MAKE AN AMERICAN QUILT By Whitney Otto. 179 pp. New York: Villard Books. $18.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are undoubtedly a number of adult women who answer to the name Bubbles. Two of the better-known ones were, until relatively recently, Beverly Sills and Leonora Hornblow. Miss Sills is still called Bubbles by a number of friends and doesn't mind at all. "I don't even hear it anymore; it doesn't register," she said. "I was once told that I'd live to regret it, but I haven't." On the other hand, Mrs. Hornblow, who is now rarely referred to by "that" name, minds it a lot.

title: Lawrence Jacobs, 49, Manhattan Architect
description: Lawrence Ronald Jacobs, an architect and the design principal for several corporate buildings in New York City, died on Thursday at New York University Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

OTHER AREAS Madison, N.J. 230,000 105 Madison Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-full bath, 2-half bath, 50-year-old colonial; fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $3,704. Roslyn Estates, L.I. 640,000 75 The Serpentine 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old split level; den w/fireplace, maid's room, 2-car garage, 0.75-acre; taxes $8,000.

title: And the Winners, Very Possibly, Are . . .
description: Somebody told me about a Hollywood party on a long-ago Oscar night. A ballot was issued to every guest, $500 a head to vote, winner take all. It was a fancy crowd, all of them movie-industry insiders, including a famous movie critic. When the critic failed to win the fine fat pot, she became so incensed that she snatched off a high-heeled shoe and hurled it through the screen. And it wasn't even her television set.

title: Seles Defends Title With No. 1 Style
description: Monica Seles, the defending champion of the Lipton International Players Championships, used her first tournament since she seized Steffi Graf's No. 1 ranking two weeks ago to prove why she deserves her label as the best match player of the moment in women's tennis.

title: In Defense of the Training Seminar
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Harvard; Confederate Flags Prompt Protests And Debates
description: A war of words and some bellicose actions continue in a controversy surrounding two Harvard College students who hung Confederate flags inside their house windows.

title: Travel Advisory; Capital Tours
description: The White House and Pentagon will both reopen for their regular public tours, which were suspended during the gulf crisis. The White House tours will resume next Tuesday and will be open to the public from Tuesday to Saturday from 10 A.M. to noon. The Pentagon tours will resume Monday, April 1, and the building will be open to the public Monday to Friday from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. The crowd-control ticket-distribution system for the White House, which is usually in place during the summer months only, will also begin next Tuesday. The National Park Service will distribute the tickets from the Ellipse kiosk starting at 8 A.M.

title: Hong Kong Reels From Rise in Cigarette Tax
description: The Hong Kong Government announced a 200 percent increase in the tax on cigarettes not long ago, and inmates at a drug-treatment jail quickly protested with a hunger strike. Other people rushed to buy out the stock in local stores, and hundreds of smokers boarded trains to China in search of cheap cigarettes.

title: New Postal Rates Apt to Spur Insert Ads
description: WHEN a sample of Sea-Bond, a denture adhesive, goes through the mail, it does not travel alone. Included with the product are inserts from credit card companies, insurance companies and clothing distributors.

title: Lisa Kinstlinger, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Lisa Rachel Kinstlinger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Kinstlinger of Orange, Conn., was married last evening to Michael Robert Lippman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew D. Lippman of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbis Alvin Wainhaus and Myron Geller officiated at the Marriott Hotel in Trumbull, Conn.

title: Managing; The Corporate Role in the Classroom
description: Question: Is business doing enough to help schools shape up?

title: The World; Latin Armies Are Looking for Work
description: WITH civilian governments now the rule rather than the exception, Latin America's armies have to find new things to do. Counterinsurgency operations against foreign-supported guerrillas, a unifying mission since the 1950's, have faded with the decay of Cuba and the Soviet Union. Border disputes, long a pretext for maintaining standing armies, are increasingly papered over in the name of regional economic integration. And the idea of ruling the country seems to have lost its appeal.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO
description: Starting next week, coverage of home video will move to the Thursday arts and entertainment pages, where it will appear every week.

title: WAR TORN
description: Philip Caputo expressed my fears exactly ("War Torn," Feb. 24.). As a Vietnam veteran, I, too, know that war is neither a chess match nor a video game. Slick, censored television coverage of the gulf war obscures rather than reveals the ugly truth. War is dirty, dull, boring, endless waiting that suddenly turns into fright and gore. The quick conclusion of the gulf war with relatively low American casualties could glamorize and popularize war once again. There could be a terrible legacy of this conflict -- a tolerance of war by an impatient, xenophobic and technophilic America. PETER HOLLORAN Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Racism Problems in Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade; Applause for Dinkins
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Rodriguez to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfeo Rodriguez of Philadelphia have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Hannelore Banks Rodriguez and Erik Persons Krishna Farrar, the son of Mitchell Farrar of Custer, Wash., and Carol Brown Farrar of Glendale, Calif. Both graduated from Brown University, where Ms. Rodriguez, 26 years old, is studying for a doctorate in art history. Mr. Farrar, 27, designs and makes custom furniture in Providence, R.I.

title: Liliana Lawry Engaged to Andrew Papadimitriou
description: June wedding plans for Liliana Lawry and Andrew Papadimitriou, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christos Papadimitriou of Boston, have been announced by her parents, Dr. Nancy Early of Longmeadow, Mass., and Dr. John D. Lawry of White Plains.

title: Prenatal Drug Exposure Shadows Children in School
description: IN a special-education class at a preschool in Stratford, a 5-year-old girl talks to herself. The child's teacher, Harriet Lurie, said the girl is hyperactive, has a short attention span and difficulty following directions and focusing her eyes. The girl's mother took cocaine while she was pregnant with her, Ms. Lurie said.

title: Review/Film Festival; Of Guards Less Free Than Their Prisoners
description: The title character in "The Guard" ("Karaul"), Aleksandr Rogoschkin's dark new Soviet film, is Iveren, a young soldier who has the delicate handsomeness associated with the idealized 19th-century romantic poet. He seems, however, to live beyond hope, in self-imposed exile.

title: Alewives Key to Rift Over Pond
description: THE springtime arrival of the alewife in Georgica Pond may settle a simmering dispute between residents of East Hampton and the town's Board of Trustees.

title: The Past Is a Foreign Country
description: THE LESSONS OF HISTORY By Michael Howard. 217 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $27.50.

title: WEATHER SERVICE CITES RADAR FLAWS
description: After repeatedly claiming steady progress in replacing its antiquated radar system, the National Weather Service now says its plan is so flawed that the best solution may be to cancel the $700 million radar contract and begin again with a new manufacturer.

title: Comeback Trail
description: He was a star pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles who found retirement a bit confining. So he decided to try for a comeback this season. Guess what? He seems to be making it.

title: Faulty Gauge in Los Angeles Yields 'Bonus' Inches of Rain
description: Recent rain showers here were more plentiful than first thought: meteorologists say a faulty rain gauge at the downtown Civic Center had been giving false readings since last month.

title: Divided They Stood in Gulf
description: Despite a facade of unity, allied commanders were continually forced to address tensions among the 37 countries confronting Iraq. Page 18.

title: Wall Street; Selling More Shares -- Without Penalty
description: The more, the merrier? That's what Steven G. Einhorn, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, predicts for the stock market. "We believe that a significant amount of new equity supply will develop in the next several years," Mr. Einhorn said. "It's already starting." And despite the fact that new shares dilute the value of a company's old shares, Mr. Einhorn thinks investors will cheer this trend.

title: A Straight Arrow's Inexplicable Fall
description: She was a pioneer, one of a handful of women trying to make it in the financial industry in the 1960's and 70's. Reared on solid Midwestern values, she earned an advanced degree in business when few graduate schools allowed women even to apply. Through quiet determination and hard work, she rose through the ranks of Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company, becoming a respected portfolio manager of "junk" bonds. Ultimately, she became a member of the elite circle of people close to Michael Milken, at a time when Mr. Milken and his firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert, were putting the high-yield, high-risk bonds on the map.

title: Police Chief at the Center of a Storm
description: HIGH-RANKING officials of the state police have asked the Cortlandt Town Board to look into an allegation that the police chief here, Robert L. Pavone, made a racist remark about black state troopers at a social event in January, a state police captain said last week.

title: Witch Doctors and All
description: THE VIPER TREE By Joseph Monninger. 318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

title: Honorable Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchen Histories
description: RUSSIA SPEAKS An Oral History from the Revolution to the Present. By Richard Lourie. 396 pp. New York: Edward Burlingame Books/HarperCollins Publishers.

title: Style Makers; Jennifer Freeman, Quilt Designer
description: The antique Amish crib quilts that fetch small fortunes at auctions these days often use color schemes dominated by rich reds and deep greens instead of conventional pale blues or pinks.

title: Fernandez's Enemies: Calories and Alligators
description: The 3.5-mile hiking trail is cut out of the woods beyond the most distant of the organization's practice fields here. On it are deer, armadillos and the threat of alligators.

title: Edible History Simmers on an Open Hearth
description: RESEARCHING and re-creating 18th-century recipes and remedies has turned from a hobby into a way of life for Cheryll M. Compton of Newtown. Ms. Compton, a surgical nurse who works with a group of doctors in Danbury, spends weekends and evenings cooking over an open hearth as she brings recipes of the period back to life.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: The Plandomes
description: WITHIN easy reach of New York City, yet secluded, the villages of Plandome, Plandome Heights and Plandome Manor occupy an enviable location on Nassau County's North Shore.

title: Arms Sales Heaven
description: Syria, Egypt, Iraq and Turkey each have more main battle tanks than Britain or France. Syria, Iraq and Egypt each fly nearly as many combat aircraft as Germany or France or Britain.

title: Social Events
description: Israel Bond Drive

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portland, Me.;
More Offices In Soft Market
description: A NEW 145,000-square-foot office building is vying for a piece of this city's shrinking tenant market.

title: Focus: Beverly Hills; A Peninsula Hotel, With Separate Villas
description: THE Peninsula Group, a Hong Kong hotel company known for its Old World-style luxury properties in the Far East, will open a new hotel in Beverly Hills this summer, its second in the United States.

title: Pamela Ehrlich to Wed Gideon Barazani in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Ehrlich have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Ehrlich to Gideon Barazani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Baruch Barazani of Haifa, Israel. A June wedding is planned.

title: Daniel Van Doren Wed To Susan L. Schoenfeld
description: Susan Lynn Schoenfeld, a senior project director at the FRC Research Corporation, a market research company in New York, was married yesterday evening to Daniel Van Doren, a property manager for the 130 West 57 Company, a New York real-estate company. Rabbi Manuel Gold performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: Bubka Vaults Over 20 Again
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his own world record for the pole vault today by clearing 20 feet 1 inch.

title: WOODY AND MIA
description: It was a delightful surprise to see Woody Allen and Mia Farrow gracing the cover. They are so quintessentially New York -- filled with wry humor -- that it is a pleasure to have them represent our city. There is a legitimate reality to them, not the collagen-injected mentality and physicality that has led to a permeating look and feel of imitated sameness on another coast. MARY LOU SCHIERLE New York, N.Y.

title: New Soccer Coach
description: The United States soccer team is getting a new lease on its competitive life, or at least an optimistic new coach. So says Bora Milutinovic, a Yugoslav coach in Mexico who announced, a shade prematurely, that he had been selected to replace Bob Gansler, who resigned last month after two years on the job.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 24, 1991
