How to reduce fat in one's diet. 4 14 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. 5 1 SECRETS ABOUT MEN EVERY WOMAN SHOULD KNOW, by Barbara DeAngelis. (Dell, $5.95.) Ways by which women can improve their relationships with men. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Meryl Streep Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Glissando
description: THE DAY AFTER HER NEW YORK RECITAL DEBUT AT CARNEGIE Hall, Midori and I sit at an Upper West Side cafe, engaged in a post-mortem of the concert. Exuding the sober professionalism of a seasoned public figure, Midori comments that she is "very happy," although "there are some places that I want to fix, because we're doing the same program again in Europe." When I casually remark that the audience was filled with her fellow violinists, she suddenly stops, fork suspended over her chocolate cake, and loses all her studied composure. "Who was there?" she demands, decibel level rising. "I want to know who was there! Because I didn't take any visitors after the concert, I didn't know who came. Who did you see?"

title: Around the Garden
description: FOR THIS WEEK: Lengthening hours of sunlight are a reminder that summer will eventually come, and pruning chores are a welcome respite from stuffy rooms. This is a good time to bring overgrown deciduous shrubs and trees under control since their limbs are still bare and you can see what you're doing. This is also a good time to start developing the single-stemmed lollipop topiary known as a standard. Topiary standards can be made of any woody-stemmed plant -- rosemary, myrtle, sweet bay (laurus nobilis), scented geranium, lavender-cotton (Santolina chamaecyparissus) and Australian tea tree (Leptosperumum laevigatum). Select a plant with a strong vertical stem or use a stake and ties to support a weak one. Prune all the lower branches leaving only the twigs on top. When the stem reaches the height you want, clip it off and snip all around to start shaping the rounded head. Continue clipping through the growing season to encourage multiple branching; rotate windowsill plants regularly for even exposure to sun. In about 18 months you should have a respectable-looking specimen. Dead Seedlings

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter to the editor in The Times Magazine last Sunday about people who care for their chronically ill partners misstated the address of the Well Spouse Foundation, a support group. Its address is P.O. Box 28876, San Diego, Calif. 92198.

title: Karen Frey to Wed
description: Karen Taylor Frey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Sterling of Westport, Conn., is to be married in June to William Joslyn Nightingale Jr., a son of Carla C. Nightingale of Rowayton, Conn., and Mr. Nightingale of Darien, Conn. Both are Connecticut College graduates. Miss Frey, 26 years old, is a legal assistant at the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. Mr. Nightingale, 27, is an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Headliners; Upholding a Challenge to the Status Quo
description: TWO years ago, when a Congressional committee decided that the National Institutes of Health was being lackadaisical in investigating allegations of scientific misconduct and decided to hold hearings of its own, outraged researchers complained of a Government "witch hunt" and raised the specter of "science police" breaking down laboratory doors. Some went so far as to compare the situation with the Vatican's persecution of Galileo.

title: Mali Forces Fire on Demonstrators, Killing 5
description: Police officers and soldiers shot dead at least five pro-democracy demonstrators today and wounded dozens more in a second day of violence in Bamako, the capital of Mali, hospital workers said.

title: Paper Reports On How Pilot Lost Control of Jet Fighter
description: Air Force documents show that a $20 million F-16 that crashed near here on Dec. 1 went out of control after the pilot paused to urinate into a plastic pouch during a routine training flight.

title: 2-Year-Old Is Killed; Stepfather Arrested On a Murder Charge
description: A 2-year-old boy was beaten to death on Friday night in his apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said, and the boy's stepfather was charged yesterday with murder.

title: Attacking a Scourge of Civilization
description: Britain is in a recession, and its voters are furious over taxes. So it is time for tax reform, British style, with higher sales taxes on consumers and lower levies on business profits. That was said to be politically popular, which shows that Britain is far from America in more ways than one.

title: Electrical Circuit Task
description: MAPPING home electrical circuits is easy but time consuming. The first step is to draw a floor plan on notebook-size paper. Include all areas served by electricity, even the attic, basement, garage and outdoors.

title: Christine Finch and David Bullock to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Finch of Old Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christine D. Finch to David D. R. Bullock, a son of H. Ridgely Bullock of New York and Sylvia van der Vlis Stuart of Nassau, the Bahamas. A June wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MAKE ROOM FOR DANNY By Danny Thomas with Bill Davidson. Putnam, $22.95.

title: Lesser Gods and Tiny Heroes
description: THE GREAT INDIAN NOVEL By Shashi Tharoor. 423 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $19.95.

title:
College Basketball;
Laettner Holds Key to Duke's Success
description: He plays with a fire that is neither quiet nor quenchable, fed by love of the arena and the challenges it provides. And because Christian Laettner also happens to be 6 feet 11inches and among the most versatile players in college basketball, Duke again is within sight of the Final Four.

title: A Century of Stories . . . And of Terrible Truths
description: THE CROOKED TIMBER OF HUMANITY

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BIKEL GOES POPS

title: Recalling a River Area in Northern Italy
description: ITALIAN ranks as one of Long Island's favorite cuisines. Virtually every community from Manhasset to Montauk boasts at least one local Italian restaurant that has won its heart. Whether it be an elegant northern Italian trendsetter or a homey Sicilian hideaway, the welcome is always warm and the food satisfying.

title: CRIME
description: "When you can see your neighbor's satellite dish," wrote James W. Hall in "Tropical Freeze," "it's time to move on." Heeding his own advice, the Florida master of suspense has moved on, in BONES OF CORAL (Knopf, $20), to a new locale, a new protagonist and a new environmental issue to make our flesh crawl -- although not without a wave to "that guy, up in Key Largo . . . Thorn, whatever the hell his name is," the hero of "Tropical Freeze" as well as "Under Cover of Daylight."

title: Democrats Assail Bush and Talk Tough About '92
description: The Democratic National Committee fortified itself today for the long march toward the 1992 Presidential election with fiery attacks on President Bush and tough talk about the fight it intends to wage next year.

title: The World; Even With a Vote, Sending a Message To Moscow Is Tricky
description: AN old anecdote, from the pre-glasnost underground, resurfaced last week in one of the many conversations about Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the referendum on Soviet unity:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a crawl space under our family room, and the floor joists above this space have fiberglass insulation between them. The crawl-space floor is covered with gravel and sheet plastic, and we use this space for storage. To prevent mold, we have an outlet from the heating and air-conditioning duct discharging into this area. Where boxes are stacked against the outside walls, the unpainted cinder blocks are damp and there is a moldy odor from the boxes. Also, flakes that look like salt or lime appear on the wall. What can we do to prevent this?

title: The Lab as a Battlefield
description: VIRUS HUNTING AIDS, Cancer, and the Human Retrovirus: A Story of Scientific Discovery. By Robert Gallo. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $22.95.

title: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Cober Wed To Eric I. Gentry
description: Leslie Robin Cober, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan E. Cober of Ossining, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Eric Ivan Gentry, the son of Mrs. Allan Seff of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Robert Rozenberg performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill, a restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Challenges on Nature Trip

title: Headliners; Shoes in the Ring?
description: Imelda Marcos is thinking of going home -- not just back to the Philippines, but maybe even to her former address, the Presidential palace. After applying for a passport at the Philippine consulate in New York last week, Mrs. Marcos told reporters that her immediate objective was to take home the body of her husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, who died in exile in Hawaii in 1989, three years after he was ousted from the presidency by Corazon C. Aquino. Mrs. Marcos's lawyer, James Linn, said he would file suit if the passport is denied and that, in continuing to bar her return, the Government was "literally forcing her to have to run for the Presidency." He said that Mrs. Marcos considered the country to be in "dire straits." The Government's position is that if Mrs. Marcos wants to help, she can start by returning the $350 million or so that she and her husband are charged with stealing from the national treasury. Mrs. Aquino said last week that if and when Mrs. Marcos does return, she would have to stand trial.

title: Mud-Luscious, Puddle-Wonderful
description: Early spring in the city means forsythia blooming in the park, crocuses by the stoop, fresh tulips at the Korean grocery. In the country, it means mud.

title: Questions Arise on Engineers' Plan to Prevent Ice Disaster
description: ON a cold February day in 1981, near where the borders of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania converge, the normally docile Delaware River uncharacteristically and unexpectedly unleashed its awesome power.

title: Headliners; What, No C.O.L.A.?
description: In his latest deal with the Sony Corporation, Michael Jackson seems to have developed a new approach to contract negotiations: turn the company upside-down and shake it. Sony announced last week that in a deal tied to the extension of Mr. Jackson's contract with Sony's Epic Records, the entertainer would establish a 50-50 joint venture with Sony Software to produce music videos and create a new record label to attract other superstars. Sony also agreed to produce a full-length film starring Mr. Jackson. All of that is in addition to the six-album Epic deal that repportedly will pay him more than $18 million per album. A Sony executive said the company stood to realize $1 billion. Nobody would say what Mr. Jackson might realize, but the highest paid artist in the business clearly got a raise to end his rumblings about going elsewhere. "No matter what," said one analyst, "they could not afford to have Michael Jackson signed away from them."

title: Corrections
description: Topics of The Times last Sunday referred incorrectly to Connecticut's assistant House minority leader. He is Christopher Burnham, a captain in the 25th Marine Regiment, a reserve infantry unit.

title: Baseball; Odd Seems Ordinary to One Yankee
description: The world of Jim Walewander has never been ordinary and probably never will be. His world includes slam dancing to progressive rock bands, painting graffiti on his apartment walls and carrying his baseball card around for identification purposes.

title: Patricia Ann Brutico Banker, Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo A. Brutico of Old Forge, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Brutico to William Picoli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Picoli Jr. of Old Brookville, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Easter Music: An Expression of the Week's Dramatic Events
description: WITH its combining of music and liturgy, Easter Week presents church music directors with major challenges.

title: Postings: Tradition and Modernity; Moroccan Synagogue
description: Congregation Netivot Israel, 1617 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn, which now looks like a big cube of concrete, will become the first community center and synagogue serving the local Moroccan Jewish community when it is completed late this summer.

title: College Basketball: Midwest Region; Redmen Achieve Balance
description: When five St. John's players scored in double figures in the Redmen's second-round tournament victory over Texas, the uncharacteristic balance could be explained away as a success that was unpredictable, and surely temporary.

title: WAR TORN
description: I find it interesting that the ostensibly war-savvy and presumably war-weary Philip Caputo is not yet ready to leave the "ignorant march from killing field to killing field." He supports the war in the gulf despite his personal experience. Caputo was convinced that "we will win" against Saddam Hussein, but he seems to forget that there are never clear winners or losers in war. For much of this century, armed struggle has continued devoid of clear beginnings and ends -- there has been only the prolongation of conflict with changes of venue and new casts of characters; when the guns go silent, the pain and suffering continues.

title: The World; Yugoslavia Finds That Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: YUGOSLAVIA'S six republics are like people mired in a disintegrating marriage. They hurl insults and scream divorce so often, even casual acquaintances conclude the union will not last. But when they visit the lawyers and calculate the costs of splitting up, they return, reluctantly, to the marriage counselors.

title: Tech Notes; A Mouse That Makes More Antibodies
description: American Biogenetic Sciences Inc., located on the campus of Notre Dame University in South Bend, Ind., has developed a strain of mouse that has been bred for generations in a germ-free environment. The mice breathe filtered air, drink purified water and eat a special diet. They could become super-efficient producers of monoclonal antibodies, which are being used for disease diagnosis and treatment.

title: Pro Hockey; Collapsing Rangers Fall Again
description: Before today's game with the Flyers, Neil Smith compared the Rangers' seven-game losing streak to a serious case of the flu.

title:
Gardening;
Of Disillusionment With the Rhododendron
description: Commercial plant growers who are forced to plan five to seven years ahead must remain aware of public opinion. And at least one Connecticut grower feels there are signs that the rhododendron is sinking in popularity. He believes he knows why.

title: Horse Racing; Jolie's Halo Outruns a Senior Class at Gulfstream
description: Horse racing's senior stars took the stage today, and Jolie's Halo responded with one more rave performance.

title: No More Ernie Pyles
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; A New Policy Fights the Risks Of Passive Smoke
description: Because of rising concerns over the health risk that passive smoke poses for nonsmokers, Wesleyan University has begun a new smoking policy for faculty and staff members.

title: Taking a Trip With a Charter
description: THE appearance of ads for charter flights is a harbinger of spring. In winter, especially this one, there are plenty of trans-Atlantic scheduled-airline seats available, but when the weather begins to warm, ads for charter airlines and operators pop up like crocuses.

title: Campus Life: Connecticut; Students Help Design Courses On Minorities
description: Some students at Connecticut College are not merely going to class these days; they are also helping professors design courses for the future.

title: WAR TORN
description: I must take exception to Philip Caputo's backing down from his belief that sanctions may have worked and stating that "My belief was a child of hope." In this particular case, we will never know if sanctions would have worked or not, and I do not believe that searching for peaceful solutions is naive position. I have grown weary of people reaching conclusions on the effectiveness of something that was not allowed to be attempted completely. Caputo made such claims in his article. The Bush Administration kept saying over and over again that it had exhausted every peaceful means -- but saying it does not make it true. DEBORAH K. EVERING San Francisco

title: Jeanne Koren Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Koren of Buffalo have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Jeanne Marie Koren and Gregory Scott Rudy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Rudy of Denver. Ms. Koren, 35 years old, is a principal in Select Properties Inc., a real-estate sales and marketing company in New York. She attended the State University at Buffalo. The prospective bridegroom, 33, a graduate of Metropolitan State College in Denver, is a driver there for the Emery Worldwide delivery service.

title: Dreams From the Hand of a Master
description: Could there be any better candidate for the title grand old man of cinema than Akira Kurosawa?

title: Debra Telischak and John Moser Wed
description: Debra Lee Telischak, the daughter of Mrs. Alex Telischak of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Telischak, was married yesterday to John Moser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Moser of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: Europe '91: A Festival of Arts; Season of Classics In the West End
description: LONDON theater managers, dependent as they so substantially are these days on American tourists, are bracing for a difficult summer. Will enough customers find the cash and courage to cross the Atlantic at a time when the dollar has dropped and fear of terrorism risen? Those doubts help account for the relative lack of new West End productions in the coming months. The most confident plans are coming from the great national companies.

title: Mustering Creative Power in the Face of Death
description: Edward Stierle, the Joffrey Ballet's most daring virtuoso dancer and a fledgling choreographer, died on March 8 at the age of 23, just three days after the world premiere of his ballet "Empyrean Dances." Mr. Stierle had been ill with AIDS for three months prior to the Joffrey's just-concluded season at the New York State Theater. Though he had grown progressively debilitated, he somehow found the creative energy to fully realize the new work, a 22-minute ballet for 18 dancers.

title: Suffolk to Open Female Drunken-Driving Center
description: PROMPTED by demands for equality and four years of apparent success in reducing recidivism in men with multiple drunken-driving convictions, Suffolk County is planning to add a 13-bed unit for women at its D.W.I. Alternative Facility in Yaphank.

title: 8,313 Abuse Cases: Suffolk Tells What to Do
description: THE numbers on the blackboard, 213,392 and 8,313, had no meaning to the 95 health professionals at a class on detecting and reporting child abuse.

title: Stamps
description: The braid of Balkan republics along the eastern shore of the Adriatic, a federation under the flag of Yugoslavia, risks becoming unraveled. This is not a new risk: the word balkanizatIon gained currency in 1919 to describe the division of an area into its small, quarreling fiefs.

title: Response to Chile Human Rights Report Is Violent
description: This country is being rocked by terrorist attacks after the release of a report detailing human rights abuses under the former military dictatorship.

title: The Magic of the Commonplace
description: ROMARE BEARDEN His Life & Art. By Myron Schwartzman. Foreword by August Wilson. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams.

title: 2 Off-Duty Officers Suspended in Shooting
description: A New York City police officer and a correction officer have been suspended a shooting on Thursday night in which the correction officer fired into a vehicle, injuring a man, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Company Cafeterias Put Health On the Menu
description: IF John Caporrino's experience is any indication, the growing trend of companies taking more interest in the long-term health needs of their employees is paying off.

title: Miss Reagan Wed To S. E. Hughes In Palm Beach
description: Kayce Reagan, a daughter of Mrs. Ogden Mills Phipps of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Joseph A. Reagan, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to Scott Emery Hughes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hughes of Darien, Conn. The Rev. J. Terry Twerell, pastor of the Living Word, a charismatic evangelical church in New York, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WELDED shut long ago, the door to apartment 8C in Building 5 at the Stella Wright housing project in Newark was now glowing red under the heat of an acetylene torch. A few feet away, Gregory P. Sanders waited, wondering what he would find when he and a crew of other housing-project tenants went inside to clean up and reclaim the abandoned apartment.

title: Ms. McGarrahan To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John G. McGarrahan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Sabina Gatheral McGarrahan to Rick Steven Spear, the son of Nomi Spear of Forest Hills, Queens, and Kenneth Spear of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Sarah Tarvin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Tarvin 2d of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Sarah A. Tarvin, and Thomas A. Thurston, a son of Joan Thurston of Marietta, Ga., and the late V. Allan Thurston. Miss Tarvin, a Colgate University graduate, is a real-estate broker with Tarvin Associates in Ridgewood. Mr. Thurston, a Gettysburg College graduate, is a consultant at John A. Earl Inc., a chemicals distributor in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Ms. Trapp Is to Marry C. F. Amendola in June
description: June wedding plans for Elizabeth F. Trapp and Carl F. Amendola, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francesco Amendola of Brooklyn, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Trapp of Brooklin, Me.

title: Young Artists Compete For Chance to Audition
description: SOME of the most talented Fairfield and New Haven County teen-agers may be heard today as they vie for more than $1,000 in prizes, plus the opportunity to audition for a concerto appearance with the Greater Bridgeport Symphony. The finals of the orchestra's 15th anniversary competition for young instrumentalists, sponsored by William and Frances Carlson and Ruth Carlson Horn, begin at 2 P.M. in the Bernhard Center Recital Hall at the Univesity of Bridgeport. The finals are open to the public without charge. For more information, call 576-0263.

title: Sunday Outing: A Visit to an Age of Jousts and Feasts
description: If the name Medieval Times entices you back into childhood fantasies, a visit to Lyndhurst, N.J., should provide a happy Sunday.

title: College Basketball: Women; UConn Advances To the Final Four
description: Kerry Bascom scored 22 points, and Connecticut connected on 7 of 8 free throws in the last 1 minute 9 seconds to beat Clemson, 60-57, today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional title and its first Final Four berth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE JEWS OF ARAB LANDS IN MODERN TIMES By Norman A. Stillman.Jewish Publication Society, $39.95.

title: Europe '91: A Festival of Arts; Paris Recalls Past Glories In a Summer of Art Shows
description: SOME people might describe 1991 as an off year for major summer art exhibitions. After all, "Documenta," the international survey of contemporary art that overtakes the small city of Kassel, Germany, every fifth June or so, is still one year off. The Venice Biennale was held last summer and, skipping two years instead of one, is not due again until 1993. Nonetheless, in Paris, London and Berlin this season, major museum shows are not exactly in short supply, with Paris having the lion's share. Paris

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Honolulu
description: After nearly 32 years of statehood, millions of visitors and vast transformation, Hawaii and its capital, Honolulu, still retain their aura of far-off tropical exotica. To many mainland residents, it seems, three decades of national togetherness are nothing compared with 3,000 miles of separation. Even the most sophisticated ask Hawaiian friends and relatives, "When are you coming to the States?" Visitors, especially in Honolulu, are surprised at the everyday American-ness, and perhaps even more startled that Honolulu has standard modern headaches -- for example, that it has, per capita, more two-career couples and more cars per mile of road than anywhere else in the country.

title: Home-Style Cuisine Acts Like a Magnet
description: PURELY COUNTRY is a label that evokes homey, natural, nostalgic images. A restaurant with such a name is like a magnet for people who eat out a lot and crave a sense of the homemade -- or at least home style, judging by the crowds that fill Purely Country restaurant in the center of Milford.

title: Ms. Wolfram and S. D. Levitt to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Wolfram of Ithaca, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Dana Wolfram, to Steven David Levitt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael D. Levitt of Minneapolis. A July wedding is planned.

title: Don't Call Pigeons, Starlings and Sparrows Urban Nuisances
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware Censorship
description: To the Editor: Richard Bernstein might find that defining political messages will be as difficult as defining art or pornography (not coincidentally). Also not coincidentally, we end up with censorship in both arenas when we try to exclude some of the messages.

title: WAR TORN
description: I was troubled that while Philip Caputo was determined to dispel one misconception about the war, he at the same time raised another.

title: Sunday Dinner; Some Samples of the Lighter Offerings of Oriental Cooking
description: Aside from being exotic and inexpensive, Oriental restaurants offer light and casual meals for the Sunday stroller. Here are three good choices, two Japanese and one Thai. Umeda

title: Europe '91: A Festival of Arts; Catching France's Dance Boom
description: SURPRISES are always possible at festivals. Imagine Darci Kistler and Robert La Fosse of the New York City ballet paying tribute to Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire in the English countryside. Or Zizi Jeanmaire as the wicked fairy bringing her Gallic chic to "The Sleeping Beauty" in Edinburgh.

title: Business Diary: March 17-22
description: THE ECONOMY

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Portland Prefers To Quaff Its Own
description: THE official nickname of Portland, Ore., is the City of Roses, but it could as easily be the City of Suds. There are two dozen small breweries and brewing pubs -- restaurants that make their own beer -- in and around the city, and more in surrounding western Oregon. The Portland area, according to the National Association of Brewers in Boulder, Colo., has more brewing activity for its size than any other metropolitan area in the nation.

title: Businesses Helping New York City Less
description: New York City's banking and business community lacks leadership and is not giving the city the same kind of help it did in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, many executives say.

title: Travel Advisory; Egypt Lowers Tour Prices
description: Although Egypt was untouched by the fighting, the Persian Gulf war took a heavy toll of its tourism. Government officials estimate that Egypt lost $2 billion in tourist revenues during the peak winter season. Now, tombs and ancient monuments that were closed because of the fear of terrorism have been reopened, and local hotels and cruise lines are sharply discounting rates and halving package deals in the hopes of salvaging some sort of business over the spring.

title: Review/Circus; When Spring Appears, Circus Is Close Behind
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has gotten a little more sophisticated in its 121st year. But it is also sweet and silly, with a more intimate atmosphere, fewer showgirl numbers and some adorable animals and exciting daredevilry.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a crawl space under our family room, and the floor joists above this space have fiberglass insulation between them. The crawl-space floor is covered with gravel and sheet plastic, and we use this space for storage. To prevent mold, we have an outlet from the heating and air-conditioning duct discharging into this area. Where boxes are stacked against the outside walls, the unpainted cinder blocks are damp and there is a moldy odor from the boxes. Also, flakes that look like salt or lime appear on the wall. What can we do to prevent this?

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 10 about Costa Rica referred incorrectly to the geography of its beaches. The country is not on the Equator.

title: THE CHIEF STEPS FORWARD
description: Christopher S. Wren's article on Mangosothu Gatsha Buthelezi ("The Chief Steps Forward," Feb. 17) made most informative and necessary reading. It was an excellent summary of the complex situation confronting South Africa today. Most importantly, it clearly indicated that, contrary to generally accepted opinion, Nelson Mandela is only one cog in a most complicated political challenge. DANIEL J. THERON West Simsbury, Conn.

title: Albert McKinley Rains, 89, Dies; Backed Housing Bills in Congress
description: Former Representative Albert McKinley Rains of Alabama, who left his imprint on much of the housing legislation enacted in his two decades on Capitol Hill, died Friday at Holy Name of Jesus Medical Center in Gadsden, Ala. He was 89 years old.

title: India Seeks to Extend Treaty With Soviets
description: India intends to extend its 1971 treaty of friendship with the Soviet Union when the pact expires in August, an Indian news agency reported today from Moscow.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: Can there be a better advertisement for freedom of the press than Saddam Hussein's state-controlled media declaring an Iraqi victory in the war? The only factor keeping Pentagon propaganda different from Iraqi propaganda is a corps of reporters willing and able to get -- and tell -- the real story. PAMELA H. RODERICK Brooklyn

title: Music Fit for an English King, Courtesy of a Minimalist
description: Through some arcane mechanism of compensation, perhaps, Minimalist composers have tended to fasten on projects of epic dimension. So it is no surprise to find Philip Glass associated with the six-hour production of Shakespeare's "Henry IV, Parts 1 and 2" at the Public Theater, just five blocks from the composer's apartment in lower Manhattan. This work, moreover, finds him paired with a familiar collaborator, the director JoAnne Akalaitis.

title: Emily B. Myers, Lawyer, Marries
description: Emily Beth Myers and Albert David Shuldiner, lawyers in Washington, were married there last evening at the Sheraton Carlton by Rabbi Reeve Robert Brenner. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Will S. Myers of Washington. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Shuldiner of Yonkers.

title: Surviving Sexual Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Act Hampers Power Independents
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Lipsman to Marry Daniel Harris
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Lipsman of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeline Sue Lipsman, to Daniel Charles Harris, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew N. Harris of Great Neck. A fall wedding is planned.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: John C. Ford;
The State Offers Help to Crime Victims
description: A WOMAN is assaulted. A man is murdered. A child is molested. These are tragedies the Connecticut Commission on Victim Services sees every day in applications for assistance made by victims of crime.

title: Kenneth C. Swenson, Executive, 48
description: Kenneth C. Swenson, a partner with Campbell Advisors, a Manhattan-based investment firm, died on Friday in White Plains Hospital Center, a nursing supervisor, Kathleen Poli, said. He was 48 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: By Foot to Stonehenge
description: Stonehenge is planning a multimillion dollar renovation to bring England's most famous prehistoric monument back to nature. About $18 million will be spent on closing the nearby road and removing the parking lot and visitors center, officials say. New installations will be built away from the site, and visitors will approach by foot. On Friday, the National Trust agreed to work with English Heritage, a Government agency, on renovation plans.

title: World Markets; The Geography of Diversification
description: With the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, Wall Street surged and stock markets around the world soared with it, highlighting once again the leadership role the American market can have.

title: Building a Sliver, Loophole by Loophole
description: A SLENDER little brownstone is undergoing alteration at 415 East 57th Street. Originally, it had four stories and rose about 50 feet above the sidewalk; now it is on its way to becoming a 15-story condominium apartment building rising more than 150 feet. Yet under New York City's building rules, it is the same building it always was.

title: Homespun Virtues Still Drive A Reigning American Diva
description: A visitor to Marilyn Horne's home high above Central Park enters a peaceable domestic realm governed by a smiling and comfortable monarch, a member, at age 57, of that charmed circle of singers who have retained enough voice, enough public following and enough imagination to enjoy well and truly the autumn years of a vocal career. On Ms. Horne's piano is William Bolcom's new song cycle, commissioned for her and scheduled for a Tuesday premiere at Carnegie Hall; on the coffee table is a new "pirate" CD called "Marilyn Horne: Rarities From Her Repertoire." On her mind are thoughts about art, politics, the arc of a career, and opera's next generation. All of these provoke curiosity; in spite of herself Ms. Horne cannot resist starting with the CD.

title: P. F. Palazzo Weds Lorraine Iannello
description: Lorraine M. Iannello, the daughter of Mrs. Angelo Iannello of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Iannello, was married yesterday to Paul F. Palazzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Palazzo of Southington, Conn. The Rev. Leonard Lewandowski performed the cremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary of Czestochowa in Philadelphia.

title: Legislators Gird for a Marathon of Tax Talk
description: ON Tuesday, the public speaks. Those who think that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan for a 6 percent income tax will help solve the state's financial woes -- and those who don't -- can take a number and line up.

title: Stonewalling Stalin
description: THE DOCTORS' PLOT OF 1953 By Yakov Rapoport. 280 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: Yancey Letter Redux
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Japanese Enlightenment
description: I vividly recall my flight into New York in 1954, at age 26, as Minolta's first representative in the United States. Night was falling, and I could see a bluish glow spreading over the city from its neon heart, Times Square. It was a stark contrast to my Japanese homeland, which was still so poor that, even in Tokyo, electricity was rationed and lights burned feebly for only a few hours each night. Tokyo's prewar commercial center, the Ginza, was only then beginning to recover from the devastation of World War II.

title: Not Euphoric but Perplexed, Nation Deals With the Peace
description: When the war with Iraq ended on Feb. 28, Americans sighed with relief, and many smiled with pride. For a precious few days, the euphoria stilled domestic disputes and indulged a national daydream about solving economic and social woes with something akin to six weeks of surgical bombing. Then America woke up, and the recession was still playing on the clock radio.

title: EDUCATORS CHIDED FOR RACE REMARKS
description: A City College faculty committee has rebuked two professors, one black and the other white, for comments about racial superiority it called "outrageous and possibly offensive" but has recommended that the college take no disciplinary action.

title: And the Winner Is . . . New Jersey, as a Location for Top Films
description: WHEN the Academy Awards are presented in Los Angeles tomorrow, one film veteran with a growing reputation for versatility in supporting roles won't complain as others receive credit -- perhaps even acclaim -- for the performer's work.

title: Settlement in Exxon Spill Deepens Alaska Natives' Feeling of Isolation
description: Here and in other small isolated native villages, the Exxon Corporation's $1 billion settlement of government suits over the Exxon Valdez oil spill has not brought relief, only a further sense of being left out.

title: Naming of Hamadi, a Shiite, May Aim at Placating Rebels
description: The appointment of Saadun Hamadi, a Shiite Muslim from the holy city of Karbala, as Prime Minister of Iraq is seen as an attempt to placate the rebellious Shiite majority in the south.

title: Perk or Punishment
description: IF YOU'RE MORE THAN 5 FEET TALL AND weigh more than 100 pounds, flying is not much fun anymore," says Richard L. Blood Jr., a sales manager at the James River Graphics Group of South Hadley, Mass. Last year he covered 70,000 miles; with his company watching every dollar, the stocky, 6-foot-1-inch sales manager spent most of his time in coach. "You can guess that I don't fit easily into any coach seat."

title:
The Nation;
Police Attacks: Hard Crimes To Uncover, Let Alone Stop
description: JUST as graphic film of police officers beating civil rights demonstrators once horrified America, the videotape of white Los Angeles police officers beating a black man has provoked national outrage against police brutality.

title: Ruth Schiff Cohen to Wed Kenneth B. Hammer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Elliott Schiff Cohen of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ruth Schiff Cohen to Kenneth B. Hammer, the son of Marcia Hammer of Melville, L.I., and the late Dr. Sanford S. Hammer. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kathleen Wray to Wed Jon Baughman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Wray Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Malone Wray, to Jon Steven Baughman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon Alan Baughman of Fort Washington, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Vito Acconci: From Infamous to Naughty
description: Vito Acconci is again the provocateur. For his latest show at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery on Greene Street in lower Manhattan, through April 6, he has installed gigantic metal and plaster brassieres that, depending on how they are turned or twisted, can double as banquettes or shelters. Homages to the bra as a feat of engineering, they may vaguely bring to mind pairs of igloos by the contemporary Italian artist Mario Merz.

title: The Region; With a Final Jolt, New York's Budget Gap Is Open to Its Widest -- For Now
description: AFTER weeks of warnings by assorted Cassandras that the earth was opening beneath New York City's budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins officially acknowledged that it had last week, conceding that the total gap in the $29 billion budget for the coming fiscal year would top $3 billion.

title: Harvard Finds a Replacement for Its President
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, a 56-year-old scholar of Renaissance literature who is former provost of Princeton University, has been offered the presidency of Harvard University by the committee seeking a candidate to succeed Derek C. Bok.

title: Now, a War of Words
description: Five days after their heavyweight bout, Mike Tyson and Donovan (Razor) Ruddock tangled again yesterday, but this time the battle was strictly rhetorical. The fighters made it to a Manhattan television studio to tape a segment to accompany last night's replay on Showtime of their controversial bout Monday in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: College Basketball; North Alabama Wins Title
description: North Alabama got 24 points from Fred Stafford, who led a decisive second-half surge, and won its second National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship with a 79-72 victory today over mistake-prone Bridgeport.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Nashua, N.H.;
Banks Helping Housing Fund
description: A CONSORTIUM of 22 banks in New Hampshire has set up a $5.7 million loan fund to help a nonprofit organization create more moderate-income housing in the affluent coastal region in the state's southeastern corner.

title: Jill Karyn Solon To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Solon of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Karyn Solon, to John David Weiser, a son of Hal Weiser and Annette Hibel, both of New York. A fall wedding is planned.

title:
The Executive Life;
One of Its Own Gets '60 Minutes' Treatment
description: "I'm

title: Sick at Heart
description: THE FEVER By Wallace Shawn. 68 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $20. The Noonday Press/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Paper, $8.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Atlanta; Asian Square, For Shopping
description: CONSTRUCTION of an $8 million, 109,000-square-foot shopping center begins next month to serve a growing Asian population here.

title: Real Estate and Tax Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW WORLD ORDER
description: I enjoyed William Safire's column "The New New World Order" (On Language, Feb. 17) but feel I may have the satisfaction of doing a documented gotcha on the Pharaoh of the Phrasedicks.

title:
ART;
Peat Moss and Wax
description: BOTH Frederic Amat and Roberto Juarez make art with a strong visceral effect, and the impact is quite powerful in the dual exhibitions of their work in the University Art Gallery on the Stony Brook campus of the State University.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NEVER SAY GOODBYE Essays.By Phyllis Rose.Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $18.95.

title: Campus Life: Chicago; 10,000 Volumes Of Yore Getting Renewed Life
description: "Electric Light ing for the Inex perienced" (1904) and "An Inquiry Into the Influence Upon Health of Anthracite Coal" (1868) may not sound like tantalizing book titles in 1991, but they were among the early mass-produced books of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Now they are part of a 10,000-volume preservation effort by the University of Chicago Library, supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Peter Ross to Wed Marcia Jean Groff
description: The engagement of Marcia Jean Groff to Peter Lawrence Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Ross Jr. of Darien, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Groff of Lincolnshire, Ill. An August wedding is planned.

title: How Students Help Elderly Write Poetry
description: While we appreciate the coverage of the project we are doing, [ "Poetry of a Lifetime," Feb. 24 ] , we are concerned about one of the quotations. Alicia Engstrom was quoted as saying, "We talk to the residents and make poems out of it." This is not what we do and not what Alicia says she said.

title: West Coast Innovators in Ridgefield Show
description: THE Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield is presenting four Californians, one from Indiana, another from Detroit, the third from Tennessee and the fourth from Brooklyn, N.Y. They are there to show what is new -- or what else is new -- in their adopted state.

title: Arab Stabs a Jewish Couple; West Bank Protester Is Slain
description: An Arab man stabbed and wounded a Jewish couple today at their home on a farm north of Tel Aviv, and soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian protester in the occupied West Bank.

title: Europe '91: A Festival of Arts; A Season to Celebrate Mozart
description: FROM Savonlinna in Finland, where one can hear "Don Giovanni" in a 500-year-old castle courtyard, to Istanbul, where "The Abduction From the Seraglio" in Topkapi Palace has become a summer staple, Mozart is being celebrated worldwide in this, the 200th anniversary year of his death. But some festivals are doing more celebrating than others.

title: Dr. J. P. Mele to Wed Miss Newhouse
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Newhouse of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Irene Newhouse, to Dr. Joseph Patrick Mele, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Mele of Elizabeth, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Clifton
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Unanimity on Golan's Worth: More Than Peace With the Syrians
description: This tiny kibbutz in the southwestern corner of the Golan Heights was only restating its longstanding position early this month when Ilana Rosenthal, the executive secretary, told the Israeli press that "we believe no settlement should be an obstacle to peace."

title: Hers; Bee Lines
description: IT HAS TAKEN SOME fancy footwork, but I've managed to reach the age of 56 without belonging to more than two or three organizations. I've never been much for becoming a member of a group. This is why, I guess, that I am so tickled to be one now. Perhaps it is the motto: Activa y Superacion, which appeals to my anarchistic and elitist sensibilities. Translated it means, roughly, Surmount Difficulty by Taking Action, Up and Away, Onward and Upward.

title: Ms. Worst to Wed Laurence Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Worst of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Gail Worst to Laurence Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cohen of Brookline, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Signs of Life on the Road
description: ALONG the road from Chicago to New Mexico there were signs to announce motels, signs to honor past presidents, obscure astronauts and movie stars. There were signs of history and destiny, industry and commerce, of candor and folly. Signs of urgency. In Chenoa, Ill., I'd seen a sign that said "Happy Easter" on one side and "Chenoa Needs a Doctor, Can You Help?" on the other. I knew a doctor from Canada who was looking to start a new life and I thought to give the clerk at the counter her name.

title: Harmonies of Easter Blend Sorrow and Joy
description: THE blending of sorrow and joy inherent in the commemoration of the death and resurrection of Jesus will be reflected in much of the musical repertory to be heard in churches throughout the week.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
New Theater For 2d Phase
description: ONE of the city's largest cinema complexes, with nine screens and 2,600 seats, is being built close enough to a trendy south Philadelphia neighborhood so that residents can walk to it.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a crawl space under our family room, and the floor joists above this space have fiberglass insulation between them. The crawl-space floor is covered with gravel and sheet plastic, and we use this space for storage. To prevent mold, we have an outlet from the heating and air-conditioning duct discharging into this area. Where boxes are stacked against the outside walls, the unpainted cinder blocks are damp and there is a moldy odor from the boxes. Also, flakes that look like salt or lime appear on the wall. What can we do to prevent this?

title: A Century of Stories
description: COMPLETE COLLECTED STORIES By V.S. Pritchett. 1,232 pp. New York: Random House. $35.

title: A la Carte: Italian Touch
description: LA Pizzetta, a family restaurant and pizzeria, is a hot little hybrid in East Norwich. Situated on Route 106 just north of Route 25A, it is often a standing-room-only spot.

title: Bridge
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, which ended a week ago in Atlantic City, N.J., lasted a full week. Ninety teams entered, including virtually all the best players in North America and a handful from Europe and other parts of the world, including China. At the finish there were just two left to fight for 64 deals.

title: Westport Steeple
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Schulte to Marry Gregory W. Hamilton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schulte of Norwich, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Catherine Ann Schulte, and Gregory William Hamilton, a son of Mrs. John Hamilton of Portsmouth, R.I., and the late Mr. Hamilton.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE YOUNGEST DOLL By Rosario Ferre.University of Nebraska,Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $10.95.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: MAUREEN A. ENG;
Making the Decision for Hospice Care
description: THERE was a time when death was talked about reluctantly and in hushed tones, if at all. But now, as society grapples with a clutch of death-related issues, from living wills and the use of life-support systems, death is being discussed openly, even at the liveliest dinner parties. And as people struggle to decide how they want to spend their final days, one option is being chosen more often.

title: Commissioner Explains His Caps on Water
description: Your article "State Water-Pumping Caps Under Fire" [ Jan. 6 ] failed to provide a perspective that reflects why the State Department of Environmental Conservation instituted the system of pumping caps and associated water-conservation requirements on Long Island.

title: THEATER REVIEW
description: AS production costs continue to rise, it is becoming more and more difficult for a new play to have its premiere on Broadway. If economic times were different, P. J. Barry's delicate memory play "After the Dancing in Jericho" might have made its debut on the Great White Way.

title: Russell Joyner to Wed Ms. Richardson
description: Mrs. James C. Lattimer of Vincentown, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Brenda Jewel Richardson to Russell Anthony Joyner, a son of Rita M. Joyner of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Trumps Reach a Settlement in Their Divorce
description: Donald and Ivana Trump finally reached a post-divorce settlement of their property Friday night, lawyers for both sides said yesterday.

title: Illegal Aliens Say Census Missed Thousands
description: IN 1982, Mateo Gomez left El Salvador after jumping over a wall at the jail where the Army held him for failing to carry an identity card. That was after his parents were murdered.

title: Globalism and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: They Wanted Him Guilty
description: WHITE LIES Rape, Murder, and Justice Texas Style. By Nick Davies. 402 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $23.

title: Sports of The Times; Bo's Hobby Is Now a Horror
description: In all the commotion over Bo Jackson's future as an athlete, it should be remembered that he defied what happened to happen. And it did.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Strip Shopping Centers: No End in Sight
description: STRIP-SHOPPING centers continue to spring up, albeit more slowly, despite New Jersey's weakening economy and sluggish retail market. Typically, such centers comprise a group of stores, with up to 300,000 square feet of space, that are not enclosed and have no interior passageways between them.

title: Visitation Case Could Redefine Parenthood
description: In a case that could set a national precedent by creating a new legal definition of parenthood, New York State's highest court is considering whether to grant visitation rights to a lesbian who wants to spend time with the son of her former female companion.

title: In Nagasaki, an Election as Catharsis
description: For a long time, Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima kept his feelings to himself regarding the moments in which he clung to life after being shot by a rightist in front of Nagasaki's City Hall last year.

title: State Fights Indians Over Planned Casino at Ledyard Reservation
description: UNLESS the United States Supreme Court stops them, members of a small Indian tribe in Ledyard are ready to turn the town into the East Coast's second casino-gambling center.

title: Article 415491 -- No Title
description: President Bush signed legislation today earmarking $30 billion to bail out depositors in failed savings and loan associations.

title: Ethics as a Business Plus
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Notebook; Jays Hope Team Unity Will Come Together in Form of a Title
description: From the speculation and theories that have emerged from the Toronto Blue Jays' failure to win the American League East championship every year for the last several years, it would seem they should add a psychiatrist, a social worker and a clergyman to the clubhouse staff.

title: INSIDE
description: Harvard Nears a Selection

title: Somewhere Between Life and Death
description: SOMEDAY By Andrew H. Malcolm. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Father and Son: Forms of Address
description: As the author of a recently published book entitled "Your Family Business: A Practical, Step-by-Step Guide For Making Both Your Relationships and Your Business Rewarding and Successful," I read the article "It's All in the Family" [ March 10 ] with great interest and must congratulate the writer on an excellent piece of work. Within the amount of space allotted to her she certainly covered a lot of ground and came up with some wonderful anecdotes and advice.

title: Mutual Funds; Picking Winners at Gabelli Growth
description: When Elizabeth R. Bramwell wrote the prospectus for her fund in early 1987, the Gabelli Growth Fund, she decided to give herself free rein so she could navigate easily among markets. Many of her colleagues are bound by more restrictive bylaws that might keep them in one sector of the market or prevent them from moving too much of their assets into cash. She didn't want to be bound by such restrictions.

title: Food; Passover Hand-Me-Downs
description: HAD THERE BEEN A JEWISH MAYFLOWER, Emily Solis Nathan's ancestors would have been on it. Nathan can trace her American lineage back to the Spanish and Portuguese Jews who arrived in Dutch New Amsterdam in the 1650's. Although most of the original "Pilgrim" Jewish line no longer exists, there are a few descendants like Nathan (no kin of mine, by the way) who represent a cultural, and culinary, link to the past. And many of their traditional dishes will grace the table this Friday evening at the Passover seder, the 336th celebrated in this country.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 24, 1991
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man and a woman, both with successful careers in television, enables them to solve their marital and romantic problems. 2 14 2 THE DRUID OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) A new volume in a series about the fantasy land of Shannara. 3 4 2 THE EAGLE HAS FLOWN, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A German general and an I.R.A. assassin plot a daring rescue attempt during World War II. 4 2 6 FORGIVING, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $19.95.) A young woman finds familial problems and love in Dakota Territory. 5 3 9 COLD FIRE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) A despondent reporter finds hope and romance while she tracks the course of a good Samaritan. 6 5 23 THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) A couple on horseback trek across Europe in the Ice Age. 7 6 7 MAGIC HOUR, by Susan Isaacs. (HarperCollins, $21.95.) The romantic and professional lives of a homicide detective become entangled as he investigates a murder in the Hamptons. 8 12 2 THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that the firm he recently joined is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities. 9 8 9 CIRCLE OF FRIENDS, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The coming of age of women in an Irish village and in Dublin's academia. 10 13 11 THE SECRET PILGRIM, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $21.95.) A member of British intelligence recalls his three decades as a spy. 11 * 19 THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man. 12 53 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 13 * 7 6 THE OLD CONTEMPTIBLES, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury finds himself a suspect in the strange death of a widow from England's Lake District. 14 * 10 9 BATTLEGROUND, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $19.95.) The experiences of marines from Midway to Guadalcanal. 15 * 9 14 POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 18 IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures. 2 1 6 AND THE SEA WILL TELL, by Vincent Bugliosi with Bruce B. Henderson. (Norton, $22.95.) An enigmatic 1974 murder case involving two American couples on a Pacific atoll. 3 3 8 THE PRIZE, by Daniel Yergin. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The role that oil has played in world history from the mid-19th century to the present. 4 4 3 THE NEXT CENTURY, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $16.95.) A journalist's assessment of the prospects for various countries. 5 6 33 YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The different languages men and women speak. 6 9 24 THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf, $50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures. 7 5 19 A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The newscaster's recollections. 8 7 26 MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The White House dog's memoirs. 9 1 RIDERS ON THE STORM, by John Densmore. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Memories of Jim Morrison and the Doors, from the rock band's drummer. 10 15 22 DARKNESS VISIBLE, by William Styron. (Random House, $15.95.) The novelist's memoir of a period of severe depression. 11 * 11 10 THE NEW RUSSIANS, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) The profound changes in the Soviet Union during the past 15 years. 12 12 10 THE SPIRITUAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) Children's perceptions of God and salvation. 13 10 9 PATRIMONY, by Philip Roth. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The novelist tells of his father's struggle with a fatal brain tumor. 14 14 3 BREAKING BARRIERS, by Carl T. Rowan. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The memoirs of the black journalist who served as a Government official during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. 15 2 IN OUR DEFENSE, by Ellen Alderman and Caroline Kennedy. (Morrow, $22.95.) How the Bill of Rights affects Americans' lives today. 16 * 13 6 THE JAPAN THAT CAN SAY NO, by Shintaro Ishihara. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A Japanese politician contends his homeland will surpass the United States and become "first among equals." Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 32 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you. 2 1 16 FINANCIAL SELF-DEFENSE, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about managing money. 3 3 103 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Financial advice. 4 4 16 FIND WALDO NOW, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a fellow named Waldo. 5 * 5 64 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A book of illustrated games. 6 * 20 WHERE'S WALDO? by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) A book of illustrated games. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind

title: Campus Life: Trinity; A Place of Honor For a Woman Who Was a First
description: When Marjorie Butcher was ap pointed as a part-time instructor in mathematics at Trinit College in 1956, she broke a precedent in becoming the college's first female faculty member. Now she is breaking another: the Student Government Association has voted to put her portrait in the faculty dining hall.

title: Postings: Biltmore on the Block; After Three Years, Act III
description: Nothing has been on the boards of the Biltmore Theater since 1987, but it certainly has not wanted for drama. The next act unfolds May 14 in the St. Moritz Hotel, at Central Park South and the Avenue of the Americas, when the theater goes on the auction block for the third time in three years.

title: Review/Theater; Two-Thirds of the Work Of Georg Buchner
description: Few if any playwrights have had a more far-reaching and profound influence on the development of modern drama with such a small body of work than Georg Buchner, the early 19th-century German dramatist who became a forerunner for most schools of 20th-century theater from Brecht to Beckett.

title: Olympics; Olympic Panel, in South Africa, Weighing a Return to Games
description: A delegation from the International Olympic Committee arrived today on a closely watched visit that could determine whether South Africa, after more than two decades of sports isolation, will be allowed to return to the Olympics next year.

title: Dave Guard, 56, Founding Figure of Kingston Trio and Folk Revival
description: Dave Guard, founder of the Kingston Trio, which brought folk music from the coffee houses to mainstream America with songs like the haunting "Tom Dooley" and the rollicking "MTA," died Friday at his home in Rollinsford. He was 56 years old.

title: Pirates Left Reeling
description: Long after the game was over, there was still a significant measure of awe coming from the Seton Hall dressing room. They had seen Nevada-Las Vegas defense, they had buckled beneath it, and they were suitably impressed

title: Sarah Mullen Wed To Douglas Luke
description: Sarah Chappell Mullen, a daughter of Arthur C. Mullen of Monmouth Beach, N.J., and Leigh Barnes Ponvert of Clinton Corners, N.Y., was married yesterday in New York to Douglas Sigler Luke, a son of Mrs. Frank Cowles of Seabrook Island, S.C., and the late Douglas Sigler Luke. The Rev. John Hartnett performed the Episcopal service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Parties With a Purpose: Awards and Celebrations
description: A Metro International Fulbright Awards Dinner at the United Nations Thursday honored Ruth Steinkraus Cohen, founder and head of the International Hospitality Committee of Fairfield County, Conn., and Alberto Vitale, president of Random House. Ms. Cohen was cited for volunteer service and Mr. Vitale for individual achievement. Metro International helps Fulbright scholars and other international students in the New York area.

title: 3 for the Show: Sounds of Music, Sounds of Battle
description: The songwriters John Kander and Fred Ebb are probably the Broadway musical's foremost advocates of the art of positive singing. Sally Bowles's credo has always been theirs, too. What good is sitting around on your duff? Jump right in. Reach for the brass ring. Say yes.

title: Joy Balances the Dark Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: London
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article on the London Underground by Robert Spiers Benjamin (Travel, Jan. 27), I should like to inject some reality into his description of travel on our Underground system. It is slow, inefficient and unreliable. Also, be prepared for filthy, cramped and overcrowded cars, which are inadequately heated in winter and without any air-conditioning in summer. ADAM DADEBY London Robert Spiers Benjamin replies: I never saw much graffiti, if any, on the Underground, and it's certainly as fast as the Paris Metro and remains a good way to get places without getting stuck in traffic.

title: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade; Not All Catholics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; For Communities, Knowledge of Polluters is Power
description: LAST month the New Orleans Times Picayune, Louisiana's most influential newspaper, called the American Cyanamid plant 20 miles upriver "the single largest polluting plant in the state." In October, the Louisiana Environmental Action Network, a Baton Rouge-based coalition of citizens groups, designated American Cyanamid its "polluter of the month," criticizing the company for being responsible for a quarter of the 740 million pounds of toxic chemicals discharged into Louisiana's environment in 1988.

title: Music's Ability to Evoke a Response From 'Forgotten People'
description: THE tics and twitches of patients at Mount Carmel Hospital will be spotlighted tomorrow night when "Awakenings," the film based on the book by Dr. Oliver Sacks, vies for three Academy Awards, including Best Picture.

title: Pro Football; London Beats Frankfurt in First W.L.A.F. Contest
description: A 96-yard touchdown pass and crunching tackles. Pep bands and cheerleaders. A clear, crisp night. All the elements for a perfect fall football evening in a small Texas or Oklahoma town.

title: Q and A
description: Rent-Rise Exemptions Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and would like to know about the rent-increase exemption program for senior citizens. Where can I get information? . . . Claire D. Taylor, Floral Park, Queens 1 Answer: Call the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Department's rent-exemption office at 240-7000. Some Nassau and Westchester municipalities also offer exemptions to their residents. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal provides information on those programs at (516) 481-9494 and (914) 948-4434. Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the division, said regulated localities grant full or partial exemptions from rent increases to tenants 62 years of age or older who meet varying local income limits. In New York City, the limit is $15,000, but certain expenses can be excluded. Landlords are compensated for the lost rent through reductions in their tax bills. Co-op Rental Liability Question: The owner of the co-op we rent told us when we moved in that the air-conditioner was not installed, but instead balanced on the windowsill. When an unaware guest raised the window, the air-conditioner crashed to the ground. Luckily, no one was injured. Now the landlord says he will deduct its price from our security deposit. We believe he was negligent. Are we responsible? . . . Lynn O'Kelley, Manhattan Answer: Probably not. Michael R. Finder, a housing lawyer in Manhattan, said both sides were negligent, but standard leases generally hold landlords responsible for maintaining major appliances. You could sue in Small Claims Court to recover any withheld security money. Vahe Tiryakian, spokesman for the New York City Buildings Department, said the Building Code in general requires owners to maintain safe buildings. Specifically, Local Law 10, the facade safety law, requires owners of buildings over six stories to have the exterior walls and appurtenances -- including air-conditioners -- inspected every five years. Co-op Tax Deductions Question: What determines tax deductions on co-ops? Do all apartments in a building, regardless of size, have the same deduction? Can the deduction change? If so, what would cause that? . . . L. Landis, Manhattan Answer: In nearly all co-ps, the co-op corporation may allocate to each owner-resident a proportionate share of what it pays each year for local property taxes and interest on the building's mortgage. Residents may then deduct their shares of the building's payout from their taxable income along with whatever interest they pay on their own apartment mortgages.

title: Miss Keller Wed To Alan Powers
description: Marjorie Ann Keller, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donal E. Keller of Manhasset, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Alan Scott Powers, a son of Catherine Powers of Syracuse, and the late William R. Powers of Boston. Justice Vincent R. Balletta Jr. of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WESTCHESTER MEDICAL CENTER;
For Burn Patients, It's a Tedious and Grim Road to Recovery
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, 14-year-old Raymond LaVera was in an accident in his Dutchess County home. Flames engulfed him and within seconds half his body was covered with third-degree burns. Soon after, he began intensive treatment at the burn center at the Westchester County Medical Center here, and he has entered the long, tedious process of recovery.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: EASTER EGG ART

title: Review/Film; Flirting by Phone in 'Julia Has Two Lovers'
description: The title character of the erotic comedy "Julia Has Two Lovers" is a restless, thirtyish writer of children's books who shares a beachside apartment in Venice, Calif., with her publisher and fiance, Jack. Devoted but dull, Jack keeps nagging Julia to marry him but cowers in disapproval when she dons a sexy nightgown and plays come-hither games. Julia wants a lover; he wants a housekeeper.

title: Travel Advisory; Teen-Agers' Fare
description: Amtrak last week expanded its children's fare to include youngsters from age 12 to 15 years. Children are allowed a 50 percent discount off the lowest available adult coach fare, provided they are accompanied by a passenger aged at least 18. Children over 12 may travel alone in daylight hours and provided there is no change of trains, but they pay the full fare. Every adult passenger on Amtrak trains is allowed two children's fare tickets. "By extending its fare plan beyond the traditional travel industry cutoff age of 12, Amtrak recognizes that young teen-agers typically travel with their families and constitute an important component of the family travel market," said Timothy P. Gardner, a vice president.

title: Carol Anne Kelty To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Carol Anne Kelty to Douglas Cerruti Moses, a son of A. J. Moses of Monroe, Conn., and the late Donna Moses, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Kelty of Bronxville, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.
