title: Self-Help Organizations Aid Thousands in State
description: "TEN years ago, we spent all our time selling self-help," said Vicki Spiro Smith. "Today, we don't have to sell anymore. Self-help has become an important component in the 90's of the mental health care delivery system and a partial solution to rising costs."

title: Article 243791 -- No Title
description: A jury in United States District Court in Manhattan has awarded $4.45 million in damages to a New York woman after finding that a chemical released from a breast implant caused breast cancer.

title: Dana M. Licameli and Brian R. Martinotti Marry
description: Dana Maria Licameli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August M. Licameli of Fairview, N.J., was married there yesterday to Brian R. Martinotti, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Martinotti of Cliffside Park, N.J. The Rev. Peter Sticco performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Church.

title: Mary Scurlock, Lawyer, to Wed in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arch Chilton Scurlock of Arlington, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Christine Scurlock to Peter Stanwood Adamson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Adamson of Marion, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lesbian Is Denied Custody After Breakup
description: A state appeals court has denied custody and visitation rights to a lesbian who helped rear her companion's two children before the couple broke up.

title: All About/Golf Courses; Can Builders Rely on a Fairway View to Sell Homes?
description: Developers discovered during the 1980's that they could sell whole subdivisions built around golf courses as readily as the new residents could sink one-foot putts. But by now, they have built so many homes on the links that many projects have turned out no better than the slices into the woods.

title: Siobhan McGrady Weds
description: Siobhan Young McGrady, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael McGrady of Northport, L.I., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Marc Pierre Benoit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Benoit of Chatou, France. Judge Louis J. Ohlig of Suffolk County District Court performed the ceremony. Mrs. Benoit, 30 years old, graduated from the School of Culinary Arts at the New York Institute of Technology. She is a chef at the Saturnia Restaurant in the Doral Park Avenue Hotel in New York. Mr. Benoit, 28, is a chef at Le Regence in the Plaza Athenee hotel in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "America went to bed with a great victory and woke up with a victory that no longer seems so great and a world filled with problems that we basically aren't able to do anything about." -- Samuel W. Kaplan, a professor of sociology at Swarthmore College. [ 1:5. ]

title: Kellogg's Recalls Toy Gifts
description: The Kellogg Company is recalling 15,576 toy bunnies given away in supermarket promotions because eyes and noses could break off and choke young children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday. The toys are white and pink and carry a tag labeled "Kellogg's." They were given away on March 14 and 15 in 33 states and Puerto Rico. People with the toys may call the cereal manufacturer at 1-800-468-9004 or, in Puerto Rico, at 1-800-848-4589.

title: Handel's Sexuality: Some Guesswork
description: To the Editor:

title: Foot to the Fire
description: To the Editor: What a breath of fresh air it was to read Richard Bernstein's recent article questioning the qualifications of film and theater professionals who pontificate ad nauseam on important political and social issues.

title: A TOWN OF SERBS ABANDONS CROATIA
description: The most dangerous of the national fault lines that threaten to tear Yugoslavia apart runs through this town huddled beneath a Venetian fortress.

title: Ideas & Trends; Fashion's Outrageous New World Order
description: THE fall fashions shown here last week were by most accounts the strongest in years. While the designers did not reveal any startling new shape that will change women's wardrobes overnight, their collections showed fashion to be on a course that is beautiful and interesting. There was an orgy of small ideas and intriguing developments.

title: Significant Exhibition
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
The Charms of Czech Film Animation
description: OVER the years, the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum on the campus of Rutgers University has made something of a specialty of the history of prints or graphic art from Europe, Japan and the United States. These exhibitions are dependable models of thorough scholarship.

title: The Waiting Wife
description: LONELY GIRLS WITH BURNING EYES

title: Correction
description: An article and a picture caption on March 3 about the art market misidentified the site at which the artist David Hammons sold snowballs. It was on Cooper Square in the East Village section of Manhattan.

title: How Catherine the Great's Dinner Was Served
description: From Peter the Great to Nicholas II, the palace taste in Russian tableware was for sumptuous, stunning or provocative porcelains. All are represented in a landmark exhibition of czarist ceramics on loan from the Soviet Union's State Museum-Reserve in the city of Petrodvorets, formerly Peterhof, to A la Vieille Russie at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street in Manhattan.

title: Answers to a Questionnaire
description: 1) Yes.

title: The World; What the U.S. Wants to Happen in Iraq Remains Unclear
description: FIRST there was the fog of war. Now there is the fog of peace.

title: Solar Eclipse
description: To the Editor: Please note that the Big Island of Hawaii will see 4 minutes and 9 seconds of totality on July 11, not the 6 minutes you mention in "Eclipse Tours in Hawaii" (Travel Advisory, Feb. 10). Although many eclipse observers are opting for the longer (6 minutes 57 seconds) of totality in Baja California, the observing conditions are likely to be better in Hawaii because of cooler, more stable air. The logistical advantages of being in a place with no customs clearance and American electric current and other facilities have also led me to take my expedition to Hawaii instead of Baja California.

title: Moira Coughlin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George E. Coughlin of Bay Head, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Moira Eileen Coughlin and Timothy Jerome Boyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Boyle of Middletown, N.J. Miss Coughlin, 28 years old, is a graduate of the University of Virginia. She is the subscription promotion manager at the Cahners Publishing Company in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 30, is a vice president of Refco Inc., a commodities trading company in New York. He is a graduate of Arizona State University.

title: Tensions Bedeviled Allies All the Way to Kuwait
description: Winning the Persian Gulf war required the allies to overcome national self-interests, political obstacles and a few battlefield pitfalls, senior allied officials say.

title: Football Is Exotic, but It's Not Cricket
description: The cricket season begins in England next month. Yes, it is all true: there really is an interval for tea (called "the tea interval") and you really do get matches that last over 5 days and 30 hours and that finish without a result. Often, as a matter of fact.

title: Alex Witchel, Times Theater Writer, To Marry Frank Rich, Critic, in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sam Witchel of Scarsdale N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Rachelle Witchel to Frank Hart Rich Jr.., a son of Mr. Rich and Mrs. Joel Fisher, both of Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: Travel Advisory; Ecology Gallery Opens in London
description: The Natural History Museum in London offers what it says is the first permanent exhibition on global ecology in the world. The exhibit, which opened this month, is designed to appeal to nonspecialist visitors who wish to know more about the scientific background of environmental matters. The exhibition looks at the earth in space -- the atmosphere, the solid earth, water and the sun's energy.

title: Review/Pop; Celebrating Song Hits and Their Composer
description: Walter Donaldson was one of the great composers of popular songs in the 1920's and 30's whose tunes were much better known than he was. They included "My Mammy," which he wrote for Al Jolson in 1920, "Makin' Whoopee," written for Eddie Cantor in 1928, and such others as "Carolina in the Morning," "Yes, Sir, That's My Baby," "My Blue Heaven," "Love Me or Leave Me," "You're Driving Me Crazy" and "Little White Lies," the song that provides the title for a program of his work being presented on Tuesdays through this month at Eighty-Eight's, 228 West 10th Street.

title: Miss Greer Wed To A. R. Cohen
description: Alison Elizabeth Greer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Greer of Gainesville, Fla., was married there last evening to Andrew Richard Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic N. Cohen of Brockton, Mass. Rabbi Allan Lehmann performed the ceremony at B'nai Israel Synagogue.

title: Headliners; Back Pay
description: The late Walt Disney apparently figured it like this: If Dopey, Donald, Grumpy, Goofy and other "toon" stars worked for nothing, why should the people who merely supplied their voices expect much more? In fact, Peggy Lee settled for $3,500 back in 1952 for providing four of the character voices and co-writing six of the songs in "Lady and the Tramp." But when the company raked in $72 million from video sales of the animated feature in recent years, Miss Lee figured she had some more money coming. California courts agreed, despite a Disney attorney's argument that Walt Disney considered the animated characters to be the real stars of his films, and Roy Disney's testimony that his uncle never shared profits with voice performers. Last week the court awarded Miss Lee $3.83 million. Now Disney is about to hear from other voices, including Mary Costa, an opera singer who was the voice of the princess in "Sleeping Beauty" and who announced a multimillion-dollar suit against Disney in Florida last week.

title: The Future of the Novel

title: Bring the Dollar Down
description: Victory in the gulf dissipated some of the clouds, but the February jump in unemployment shows that the economy is still in trouble. Can the Government lift the country out of recession?

title: Sunday Menu; Colorful (and Healthful) Chicken Curry
description: Wonderful colors. Superb nutritional value. This surprising combination has everything.

title: Reviews/Music; Mahler's 'Resurrection' By Atlanta Symphony
description: Mahler Symphonies are worlds with their own peculiar ecosystems, which might include everything from naturalistic references -- flute lines derived from bird calls, or rhythms based on heartbeats -- to the sounds of the turn-of-the-century European culture, high and low, that were the composer's milieu. In the Second Symphony, the "Resurrection," these elements form the backdrop for an essay about a dual theme that would prove a perennial for Mahler, death and transformation.

title: Travel Advisory; Shrines Opening In Philadelphia
description: An influx of Federal funds will enable Philadelphia to reopen the historic buildings in the city's Independence National Historical Park that have been closed since last Oct. 1 for lack of money. A park official said the new funding will allow the buildings to be kept open for the rest of the year.

title: Harvard Finds a Replacement for Its President
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, a 56-year-old scholar of Renaissance literature who is former provost of Princeton University, has been offered the presidency of Harvard University by the committee seeking a candidate to succeed Derek C. Bok.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: Malcolm W. Browne tells us that the Joint Information Bureau refers to all forms of news as the "product" ("The Military vs. the Press," March 3). That is as it should be, because it makes me the consumer, and in today's world, the consumer has a voice.

title: Drawings and Storyboards Unearth Memories of 'Fantasia'
description: BECAUSE of a theft on March 3, the Museum of Cartoon Art's "Fantasia" show is missing five pieces. They are two watercolors and a celluloid featuring Mickey Mouse as the Sorcerer's Apprentice; a caricature of the animator Vladimir Tytla as the devil in "Night on Bald Mountain" and a photostat of rooftops from the same sequence. All of them belong to the Mike and Jeanne Glad Collection, of which the show is an excerpt.

title: A Leaf From the Rock Book
description: Hip string quartets, a phenomenon of the late 1980's, have given rise to some new variations. Not surprisingly, some of them come from a hip pop label in England. Factory Records, best known in the United States for its band New Order, has developed a new imprint, Factory Classical.

title: Topics of the Times; Bo Knows Mortality
description: The Kansas City Royals' decision to drop Bo Jackson from their baseball team has raised a substantial fuss. That's because Mr. Jackson and his enviable physique seemed indestructible. And he was ubiquitous: running the football for the Los Angeles Raiders in the winter; swatting homers for the Royals in the summer; and hawking Nike sporting goods on television all year long.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19

title: Is It Sculpture? No, It's the Academy Awards Show
description: At the 63d Academy Awards tomorrow night, almost 11 years after the vow he made to himself while escaping a deadly hotel fire in Las Vegas, Ray Klausen is again the art director of the Oscar presentations. It is the seventh Academy Awards show he has designed, but this time there is a big difference for Mr. Klausen, who has won three Emmys for his sets on television. The look of this year's broadcast from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles will match his idea of himself as a sculptor.

title: Boat Project Broadens Students' Vistas
description: FOR nine hours a week, 22 North Shore High School seniors don goggles and aprons and set out to saw and sand into shape a 28-foot boat that promises to anchor them to Long Island's past.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 24 about the Pinnacles National Monument in California misidentified a bird. It was an acorn woodpecker, not a yellow-billed magpie.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: IT'S TEATIME

title: Drug Charges Embarrass U. of Virginia
description: In the 172 years since it was founded by Thomas Jefferson, the University of Virginia has achieved a national reputation for academic excellence and, more recently, for athletic excellence.

title: Nassau Program Excludes Women
description: NASSAU COUNTY has a voluntary treatment program for convicted drunken drivers whose staff is paid with money from the County STOP-DWI program.

title: Crossing by Ship
description: To the Editor: Low-cost, regular trans-Atlantic travel by ship is a potentially large market. Only the Queen Elizabeth 2 sails on anything near a regular schedule, but even the lowest-price passage is expensive for travelers of limited means.

title: Campus Life: Pomona; Fraternity Rooms To Be Converted Into Lounges
description: After more than a year of debate, Pomona College has decided to eliminate fraternity rooms in dormitory basements next fall and convert them into student lounges, ending more than 50 years of exclusive fraternity use.

title: Scientist in Fusion Dispute May Lose His Job
description: One of the two scientists who claimed to have discovered a process in which atomic fusion could be induced at room temperature has been told by the University of Utah that his future there is in jeopardy.

title: Due Homage to Durable Opera Stars
description: Smugness is the eighth deadly sin. I feel compassion for the doddering opera fan who takes pleasure in reminding me that only a person who was there can know how thrillingly Lauritz Melchior boomed out the word "Nothung." Or how exquisitely Elisabeth Schumann phrased "Deh, vieni, non tardar." I myself avoid such smugness at all costs. When provoked, I might mention having heard a Schipa, a Roswaenge or a Pinza -- but only to turn aside some youthful poseur who claims to have heard Jeritza delivering "Vissi d'arte" from a prone position. Memory, when artfully used, can be a sharp weapon.

title: Bonnets That Make Easter Last and Last
description: Most Easter bonnets are more than a combination of fruit platter and parade float worn once, then tucked in a hat box. They are hats to be worn all spring and summer.

title: THE LAST PLAYWRIGHT
description: David Richards's "Last of the Red Hot Playwrights" (Feb. 17) was an insightful profile of Neil Simon. But I must take exception to the statement that Simon could be mistaken for an accountant or a librarian since he dresses "just this side of drab."

title: Mount Vernon Takes Title
description: The Mount Vernon High School boys' basketball team refuses to die. And so does the controversy over the reinstatement of the Knights' 6-foot-2-inch senior swingman, Collin Johnson, by the principal, Andrew Jones, who lifted a ban imposed by the school's athletic director. The reinstatement came just in time for last week's New York State Public High Schools Athletic Association championships here.

title: Chess
description: There are two schools of thought on long chess matches. The purist view is to let the contest go on endlessly andnever mind exhausting the players, the referees and the spectators. Hold to a slow pace to produce perfect chess.

title: Beth S. Lerman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lerman of West Hartford, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Beth Stacey Lerman and Neil George Becker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Becker, also of West Hartford. Both are associates in Hartford law firms, Miss Lerman at Green & Kleinman and Mr. Becker at Berman & Sable. Miss Lerman, 28 years old, graduated from Connecticut College and received a J.D. degree from American University. Mr. Becker, 27, graduated cum laude from Duke University and received a J.D. degree from Emory University.

title: Travel Advisory; Disney World Raises Entry Fee 6 to 8 Percent
description: Walt Disney World, citing the addition of several recently installed entertainment features, has raised its admission prices by 6 to 8 percent.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENTS/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. BETSY'S WEDDING -- Starring Molly Ringwald and Joe Pesci, among others, Alan Alda's sitcom of a movie "gathers a wonderful cast and gives them tepid characters." (Caryn James) 1990. Touchstone. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.99. 1 hour, 34 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Campus Life: Duke; On Special Night, Men Get Lesson On Fear of Rape
description: It is difficult to frighten most college-aged men, but a group of students at Duke University hope that bright orange stickers will startle men into realizing a fear that women find hard to forget.

title: 2 for Whittingham In San Luis Rey
description: Charlie Whittingham will saddle River Warden and Live the Dream in Sunday's $300,000-added San Luis Rey Stakes in quest of a 10th victory in the race.

title: A Frenchman Oddly at Home in Another Land
description: Paintings, like people, look different from day to day. Even more so do they look different from place to place. Old echoes come with them, but a whole slew of new ones may also be activated.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: In his discussion of the attractions of the Swiss town Zug ("High-Powered Swiss Refuge," Travel, Jan. 13), Paul Hofmann omits the Museum an der Burg at 11 Kirchenstrasse. It contains a collection of archeology, art and items relating to the history of the town and the canton along with a model.

title: Interesting Issues in 'Forgiving Typhoid Mary'
description: LATE, too late, in the second act of "Forgiving Typhoid Mary," at the George Street Playhouse, two women drop their adversarial roles. One woman (played by Estelle Parsons) is the notorious carrier of an infectious disease; the other is a doctor (Harriet Harris) who has been intending to inject her with a lethal overdose of germs.

title: Does Mom Like Me? And Who's Dad?
description: SKIPPED PARTS By Tim Sandlin. 338 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title:
Your Own Account;
The Traps Women Fall Into
description: Robyn S. Iskoe specializes in financial planning for the wealthy. She knows the ins and outs of pension plans, can interpret the fine print of the tax code and recite obscure estate-planning rules. But when it comes to her own finances, Ms. Iskoe, 33, admits to a problem: For years, she put off the financial planning she knows is essential because she expected one day to be married and to do these things with her husband.

title: Hunting Elephants Around The World
description: RAY HUNT REMEMBERS THE MOMENT clearly. It was just past 7 o'clock on the night of Jan. 16, and the 47-year-old president of the Hunt Oil Company was in his new, twin-engine Canadair Challenger jet over Nashville and bound for Washington. Suddenly, the pilot, Jim Wilson, called him to the cockpit. Wilson had just spoken to the Nashville airport. "Ray," he said, "the ground controllers are saying that the bombing's started in Iraq."

title: Scrap 15,000 Warheads
description: Start is stopped. That is not all bad, because the strategic arms reduction treaty has been overtaken. We need a new approach to nuclear arms control that takes account of the growing prospect of prolonged civil strife in the Soviet Union, where more than 25,000 nuclear warheads could be captured or stolen.

title: An Overly Ambitious Scott Paper Is Stretched Thin
description: For the Scott Paper Company, the beginning of the 1990's has felt like the death by a thousand paper cuts.

title: The World; As the Dust Settles, Attention Turns to New Arms Sales
description: AT war's end, and with a potentially chaotic peace ahead in the Middle East, the Bush Administration made clear last week that it was preparing to arm its friends in the region against a sea of trouble.

title: Kevin Daly Wed To Miss Farrell
description: Candace Lee Farrell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Farrell of New York, was married yesterday to Kevin John Daly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Daly of Los Angeles. The Rev. John Clermont performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Imam of the Airwaves Mixes Koran and Charisma
description: Each afternoon during Ramadan, the Islamic month of prayer and fasting, television screens all across Egypt and the Arabian Peninsula glow with the animated features of Sheik Mohammed Metwalli al-Shaaraoui, Islam's most popular television imam.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Existing home sales for February. * Auto sales for mid-March. * European Community agriculture ministers meet in Brussels.

title: A Tale of America's Revolution Is Told in One Woman's Battle
description: A WOMAN struggling to safeguard her family in the midst of the American Revolution is the subject of a public television program to be filmed later this year. "Mary Silliman's War" tells the story of a Fairfield family in 1779, the year the town was attacked by British forces and set on fire.

title: Beth Schwartz Engaged to Jamie Jones
description: June wedding plans for Beth Craig Schwartz and Jamie Anthony Jones, the son of Gloria Jones of Sagaponack, L.I., and the late novelist James Jones, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. David Schwartz of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: WAR TORN
description: Philip Caputo's angst-ridden, not quite ambivalent support for the war implies that though war is hell, somebody's got to do it. Caputo, I'm afraid, like so many others, doesn't not want war enough. ANDREA WOLPER New York, N.Y.

title: The Big Test: How to Translate The Talk About School Reform Into Action?
description: COMPARED with Lamar Alexander, Norman Schwarzkopf had it easy. Mr. Alexander, sworn in as Education Secretary on Friday, faces a task that has frustrated generations of reformers: improving American schools.

title: Reviews/Music; The Chamber Music Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center returned to its roots last Sunday evening, in more ways than one. Fred Sherry, who challenged subscribers with adventurous programming in his first season as artistic director, has taken a more conciliatory tack in his second. And perhaps symbolically, he invited his predecessor, Charles Wadsworth, who founded the society and directed it through two decades, to take part in a pair of concerts at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Postings: $1 Million to $1.5 Million; 10 Classic-Style Houses
description: With the New York area's sluggish real estate market making the most expensive homes particularly hard to sell, one development company thinks it has found its niche in the Westchester Town of North Castle.

title: Strife in Georgia Republic Reveals Danger in New Soviet Separatism
description: A tragic and largely ignored civil war -- one far deadlier than the Baltic republics' struggle for independence -- is under way here in the rugged mountains of Georgia, where the Soviet nation's separatist agonies are being played out in the daily clash of gunfire.

title:
DINING OUT;
Rich Tastes of Thailand in Tarrytown
description: THE cozy Siam Orchid II, an offshoot of Siam Orchid that opened on Central Avenue in Scarsdale several years ago, offers a similar menu in its branch on Main Street here. But this new dining spot differs in several ways, all of them a plus for the Tarrytown clientele: while not unflawed, preparations are generally more savory and more carefully prepared; portions of this rich food are extremely generous; and the kitchen offers a broader range of spiciness. Heat is noted on the menu with a chili pepper to the left of the item, and the degree matches the diner's stated tolerance.

title: Amy Arnold to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Arnold of Kinderhook, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Elizabeth Arnold and Peter Tower Gumaer, a son of Elliott W. Gumaer Jr. and Mrs. Alexander D. Hargrave, both of Rochester.

title: The Executive Computer; A Clip-On Mouse for Users on the Road
description: Executives who use laptop computers and the Windows graphical operating system often have a problem. One can operate Windows software using typed keyboard commands, but Windows really requires a mouse. Mice, in turn, require room to roam, and the person sitting in the next seat on the plane or train might not understand why your hand keeps sliding over onto his or her thigh.

title: Corrections
description: A question and an answer in the Streetscapes column on March 17 transposed both the height and the architects of two buildings replaced by the Mony building at 1740 Broadway. The 11-story Sonoma was designed by Thom & Wilson, the 6-story Rockingham by Stephen D. Hatch.

title: Data Bank/March 24, 1991
Sports of The Times; The Tar Heels From All Over
description: There was a brief time when most prominent North Carolina players arrived from the same direction: the underground subway line from Noo Yawk, Noo Yawk.

title: Tales From a Vienna Physicist
description: THE JOY OF INSIGHT Passions of a Physicist. By Victor Weisskopf. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: Mark Twain Out West
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. RESTRICTS USE OF A SMALL PLANE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered the owners of hundreds of Piper Malibu small planes not to fly them in bad weather because they may break up in flight, agency officials said today.

title: End of Run for Shaw
description: In his 10 years as the unquestioned leader of the United States Ski Team, Tiger Shaw, a man of such obvious talent and patience that he has been regarded as an extra coach, demonstrated just about everything it takes to be a champion except for the two things no ski champion can do without -- reliable knees.

title: Metro Datelines; Agreement Saves Landmark Museum
description: Philipse Manor Hall, a national historic landmark, has been saved in a deal that calls for the state and a private group to operate the museum in partnership.

title: On Language; Hit the Pound Sign
description: A SIGN OF THE TIMES is the one-way caller.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO PEACE AT VERSAILLES And Other Stories.By Nina Barragan.New Rivers Press/Talman Company, Paper, $7.95.

title:
Style Makers;
John Callanan, Milliner
description: John Callanan's hats are seen onstage in "Miss Saigon," on the screen in "The Bonfire of the Vanities" and "Working Girl," and on the heads of ordinary women.

title: A Sideshow Stole the St. Patrick's Day Parade; Culture and Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth vs. Aaron: Beat Goes On
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Kristin R. Takala, A Broker, Is Wed
description: Kristin Richards Takala, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Takala of West Hartford, Conn., was married there last evening to Robert Wucker Tishman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tishman of Hollywood, Fla. The Rev. Robert L. Edwards, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky performed the ceremony at the Hartford Golf Club.

title: Technology; Optical Fiber (Almost) at Home
description: Despite years of research and development, telephone equipment suppliers have not yet come up with optical fiber systems that are cheap enough to persuade local phone companies -- or the public utility commissions that regulate them -- to abandon copper wire completely. But they are getting close.

title: French Left Moves to Redistribute Local Aid
description: A plan by France's Socialist Government to withhold national budget revenue from rich communities and give it to poor towns has put a quick and bitter end to a lull in political squabbling that prevailed as the country unified during the Persian Gulf war.

title: NCR and A.T.&T. Talk
description: After weeks of resisting a $6 billion takeover offer from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, NCR, the nation's fifth-largest computer maker, said it would be willing to hold discussions about negotiating a deal at a higher price.

title: MUCH MORE ARMOR THAN U.S. BELIEVED FLED BACK TO IRAQ
description: The number of Iraqi tanks and armored vehicles that survived the American-led land attack that ended the Persian Gulf war is much greater than American military authoritites initially reported, and many of the weapons have been used by the Government of President Saddam Hussein to quell resistance by Iraqi insurgents, American officials say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Popular Victory for Senna: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won the Brazilian Grand Prix yesterday for the first time, delighting his partisan fans. Senna, the world champion, in a McLaren-Honda V12, battled rain, a broken gearbox and challenges from the two Williams-Renaults in posting his 28th Grand Prix victory and widening his lead in the world drivers' championship standing. Riccardo Patrese of Italy finished second in a Williams-Renault, only 2.99 seconds behind. (AP)

title: Fire From Smoking Kills 4
description: A fire attributed to careless smoking killed four people in a two-story rowhouse on Saturday, the authorities said. The fire began shortly after 4 A.M. in the city's Kensington section and was controlled in about 20 minutes, a fire dispatcher said. The fire marshal's office said careless smoking apparently ignited a sofa on the first floor. The victims were identified as Israel Mendez, 31 years old, and his three children, Maxine, 13; Michael, 4, and Christine, 2.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As if fashion modeling isn't hazardous enough, CAROL PERKINS is learning to eat fire. She will perform her feat on Broadway with those madcap magician-artistes, PENN & TELLER, who begin previews on Tuesday at the Eugene O'Neill Theater.

title: Pirates Plan Bonilla Talks
description: Carl Barger, the Pittsburgh Pirates' president, said today that the club plans to discuss a long-term contract with right fielder Bobby Bonilla's representative, perhaps as early as Monday.

title: Transit Authority Consolidating Its Offices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Engle, 82, Poet and Founder Of Writing Program at U. of Iowa
description: Paul Engle, the poet and author who nursed the University of Iowa's writers' programs to international acclaim, died Friday at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. He was 82 years old and lived in Iowa City.

title: Bridge
description: There are paradoxical occasions when a player is hoping that the cards will lie badly for him. An example is the diagramed deal, which was, more or less, played in the Open Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Atlantic City earlier this month.

title: Thai Bar Girls Greet Sailors Like Heroes
description: The young women from Marilyn's A-Go-Go broke through the lines of staring tourists and hit the beach at about 11:30 this morning, and quickly formed an escort party for the 7,000 American sailors coming ashore here for their first liberty since victory in the Persian Gulf war.

title: For Yugoslavia, Unity Still Holds Best Hope; Uneasy Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: NCR Says It Will Talk To A.T.&T.
description: The NCR Corporation yesterday ended weeks of resistance and agreed for the first time to meet with A.T.& T., which has been seeking to acquire it since December.

title: Brighter Days for Machine Tools
description: New orders for machine tools, often an important weathervane for the economy because the equipment is used by a wide range of major manufacturers, are showing surprising strength.

title: Helping Seniors, Sensibly
description: A 1940's version of "Sentimental Journey" played on the battered phonograph, its sweet sound filling assembly room 308. A few of the men and women in the room sang along. Some simply swayed. Then, with a bit of encouragement, couples began dancing while those on the sidelines kept time on their tambourines.

title: C. H. Wimer Wed To Susan Soroka
description: Susan Marilyn Soroka, the daughter of Paul Soroka of Morristown, N.J., and the late Ella Soroka, was married yesterday at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., to Charles H. Wimer, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Manfred Wimer of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and the bridegroom's father officiated.

title: From the Imprisoned Elderly, a Plea
description: Slowed by arthritis, 58-year-old Curtis El is finding it harder and harder to climb into the top bunk bed of his cell at Graterford Prison, a maximum security prison 30 miles northwest of Philadelphia.

title: Miss Burgess Weds Thomas A. Reed
description: Sarah Watt Burgess, the daughter of Mrs. Robert B. Burgess Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Burgess, was married in New Canaan yesterday at Waveny House to Thomas Andrew Reed, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Reed of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Richard Bauer, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Saigon' Previews Begin
description: The helicopter has landed.

title: Drama Builds for 4-Year-Olds
description: They were a year too old to be traveling the road to the Kentucky Derby, but racing's senior stars were traveling a parallel road today, striding toward a season of dramatic confrontations for some of the most accomplished horses in the business.

title: Pirates Try to Hide Sadness
description: At one end of the court Saturday night, there was a post-game euphoria. At the other end, P. J. Carlesimo could neither hide nor dismiss his sadness.

title: Reviews/Theater; An Island Of Spirits And Flesh
description: Don Minch's play with music, "The Balm Yard," depicts life in a West Indian town where the animistic spiritual beliefs and daily lives of the inhabitants are virtually indivisible. Those who are tainted by the materialism of the outside world become alien voices in a society united by reverence for what one character calls "the ground that made me."

title: Campaign in Teheran
description: With weapons, other supplies and moral support, Iran is stepping up its campaign to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the leadership of his Baath Party. Page A8.

title: Chrysler Seeks Sales Curbs on Japan Autos
description: The Chrysler Corporation has asked the Bush Administration to put pressure on Japan to limit car and truck sales in the United States for the next 12 to 18 months, warning that a surge in sales by Japanese auto makers could put it out of business.

title: February Jump In Tool Orders
description: Spurred by sharply higher demand from domestic manufacturers, new orders for American-made machine tools climbed 27.7 percent in February from the January level, according to a report scheduled to be released today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 24, 1991: MONDAY

title: Developer Sued For $60 Million By Three Banks
description: Peter S. Kalikow, one of the largest owners of apartment buildings in New York City, has not repaid $60 million in bank loans that came due in recent months, and three banks have sued him, bankers and lawyers who work with Mr. Kalikow say.

title: R. Timothy Leedy, Publisher, 64
description: R. Timothy Leedy, the publisher and senior vice president of Financial World magazine, died on Saturday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 56 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIAN WRIGHT EDELMAN, president of the Children's Defense Fund, and DR. MATHILDE KRIM, a co-founder of the American Foundation for AIDS Research, received Bryn Mawr College's highest honor Friday night. The college, which does not give honorary degrees, gave the women its M. Carey Thomas Award for leadership in public policy.

title: E. Everett Smith, Executive, 79
description: E. Everett Smith, a retired director of McKinsey & Company, a management consulting concern, died on Friday at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 79 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: McReynolds's Role Becomes Important
description: If the clubhouse of the Mets here isn't divided, there clearly exists any number of degrees of separation.

title: Marketing Quarterbacks
description: The management roster of a new, independent corporation called the NFL Quarterback Club includes some of the finest football players in the game today. But this team plans to use its collective talent to put money in the bank, rather than points on the scoreboard.

title: Recycling Is a Way of Life for Russians: To Survive, They Must Scavenge
description: When her son needed a new shirt, Zoya Begovaya moved up the cuffs on an old shirt of her husband. When she couldn't find sponges in the store, she knotted together old stockings to scrub her dishes. And when the price of newspapers tripled at the beginning of the year, she and her neighbors decided to share a subscription.

title: Free Trade Fatefully Near For Paraguay's 'Hong Kong'
description: In this bustling town on the border of Brazil and Argentina, often called the Hong Kong of South America, smugglers fear that their long and lonely advocacy of free trade is about to become respectable.

title: 12 Killed in South Africa As Blacks Fight Police
description: Twelve people were killed and at least 29 wounded today when the police clashed with supporters of the African National Congress who had gathered outdoors in the black township of Daveyton, east of Johannesburg.

title: Erica Spellman, Executive, Weds
description: Erica Spellman, a daughter of Helen Wilson of New York and the late Mitchell Wilson, was married yesterday to Ethan Silverman, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Martin I. Silverman of Albany. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Emeth in Albany, where he is the senior rabbi.

title: Books of The Times; Appearance of Fact, Inevitable Deception
description: How to Lie With Maps By Mark Monmonier Illustrated. 176 pages. The University of Chicago Press. Paperback, $12.95.

title: Image Makers Look at Themselves
description: A gathering of political consultants agreed this weekend that the images they produce and the money it takes to create them are harming America's democracy. But they couldn't agree on who was at fault.

title:
AFTER THE WAR: OIL;
Pooling Riches in the Gulf
description: Despite the stunning allied victory in the Persian Gulf war, there are many in the Muslim world and in the West who are reluctant to support oil-rich oligarchies whose closely held wealth has made them very unpopular with the poor masses of the Arab world.

title: Governor Backs Los Angeles Police Chief
description: Gov. Pete Wilson defended Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Los Angeles police on Saturday, calling him a dedicated professional and describing efforts to oust him as an "attempted lynching."

title: Karen Langfelder Wed To Jeffrey L. Rosenberg
description: Karen Langfelder, the daughter of Mae Langfelder of Brooklyn and the late John P. Langfelder, was married yesterday at the Fox Hollow Club in Woodbury, L.I., to Jeffrey L. Rosenberg, the son of Lorraine R. Rosenberg of Palm Desert, Calif., and Herbert Ross of Elmhurst, Queens. Rabbi Fred Ackerman officiated.

title: Israelis Move to Expel 4 of Gaza Strip's Arabs
description: The Israeli military issued expulsion orders against four Palestinians from the Gaza Strip this morning, accusing them of directing and taking part in violent acts against Israel.

title: Dara Rosenberg, Teacher, Marries
description: Dara Lynn Rosenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Rosenberg of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Burning Tree Country Club to Joseph Joshua Berger, a son of Toby Tarnow of Hollis, N.H., and Dr. Earl H. Berger of Toronto. Rabbi Hillel Silverman officiated.

title: It's Cheaper to Give Unpaid Leave Than to Dismiss, U.S. Study Says
description: Giving workers unpaid leave for family illness or the birth of a child may be cheaper for employers than letting the workers quit and hiring permanent replacements, according to a study for the Small Business Administration.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE, LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Courier Takes 2d Title in Row
description: Heavy-hitting Jim Courier, the most noteworthy export of Dade City, Fla., outside of its orange juice and the twang of the Bellamy Brothers, secured his second consecutive tournament victory this afternoon with a comeback against David Wheaton in the final of the Lipton International Players Championships. Courier, ranked 18th in the world as this event began and ranked a career-high ninth in the world by its conclusion, gradually overpowered the unseeded Wheaton, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "You shine your badge every day before you come to work, and now the actions of a few have put some tarnish on the badge of every police officer on the force. It's going to take a long time to take the tarnish off." -- Sgt. John Reese of the Los Angeles Police Department. [ B6:1. ]

title: A Ringling Brothers First: The Clown as Star
description: For the first time in the 121 years of the Greatest Show on Earth -- which began a five-week run Thursday at Madison Square Garden -- the headliner isn't a trainer of tigers or a trapeze flier, it's a clown.

title: Corrections
description: An item in the Outdoors column in some copies of the sports section yesterday misidentified a organization that will hold a conservation fund- raising auction at 6:30 P.M. on Wednesday at the Salmagundi Club at 47 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. It is Trout Unlimited, not Ducks Unlimited.

title: People
description: * John Ferraro has been named an account executive at Burkhardt & Christy Advertising Inc., New York, where he will work on the Sony Magnetic Products Account. * Anne Stonier-Watson has been named director of Indo-Ad Direct, the new office that Ogilvy & Mather Direct has established in Jakarta, Indonesia. Irene Juanita and Chandra Suryadinata have been named account supervisors in the agency, and Gamber Anom has been named creative director. * Grey Direct, the direct marketing subsidiary of Grey Advertising, named Peter L. Boggs to the new position of European director.

title: STATES AND CITIES ARE PUSHING HARD FOR HIGHER TAXES
description: A wave of new taxes and tax increases -- the third since the 1930's -- appears to be developing in states, counties and cities.

title: In a Pizza War, It's 3 Rays Against the Rest
description: As Ray's pizzerias proliferated during the last two decades, New Yorkers often wondered who Ray was, but no one seemed to know. The results of a New York Times investigation in 1987 were summed up most poignantly by an employee at one Ray's pizzeria who, after first saying that Ray couldn't come to the phone, finally broke down and confessed, "There is no Ray, really."

title: Laurie E. Muchnick Wed To David Gerard Thomas
description: Laurie Ellen Muchnick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Muchnick of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday at the Hotel Westbury in New York to David Gerard Thomas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Thomas of Cardiff, Wales. Rabbi David Posner officiated. The bride, 26 years old, is an editorial assistant at The Village Voice Literary Supplement in New York. She graduated from Swarthmore College and received a master's degree in journalism from New York University. The bridegroom, 28, graduated from the Welsh School of Architecture at the University of Wales and is studying for a master's degree in architecture at the Polytechnic of Central London.

title: Teheran, Dropping Any Ambiguity, Intensifies Its Drive to Oust Hussein
description: Iran is stepping up its campaign to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and the entire leadership of his Baath Socialist Party.

title: Interest on Bank Reserves Makes Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Review/Dance; Oakland Troupe's New Way
description: The Oakland Ballet is a company of beautifully trained dancers whose freshness and simplicity brought vivid new life to two problematic ballets on Saturday night at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts, in the Bronx.

title: Making Pizza The Ray's Way
description: Just as there is not really one, specific Ray, there is no single Ray's pizza pie.

title: How Grisly Can Boxing Hype Get?
description: IRONIC that last week's savage Mike Tyson-Razor Ruddock fight ended with Referee Richard Steele stopping the proceedings with Ruddock still on, and far from out, on his feet. The end contrasted sharply with the way the fight had been promoted. The selling of Tyson-Ruddock was as blatant an appeal to bloodlust as any of Evel Kneivel's jumps.

title: Fed Expected to Forgo New Interest Rate Cuts
description: Many credit market analysts expect the Federal Reserve to forgo a further reduction in short-term interest rates when its policy-making Open Market Committee meets tomorrow.

title: Miss Meyer Wed To Scott Condron
description: Pamela Meyer, the daughter of Mrs. Louis E. Fitzner Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Richard M. Meyer of New York, was married yesterday at Tarrytown (N.Y.) House to Scott James Condron, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Condron of Milford, Conn. William R. Crosbie, the Village Justice of Tarrytown, officiated.

title: Top Pay Listed At L.A. Gear
description: L.A. Gear Inc.'s two top executives earned $3.47 million and $2.54 million in the 1990 fiscal year while the company's profits fell 43 percent.

title: For Yugoslavia, Unity Still Holds Best Hope; Neighborly Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile's Leader Wins The Right to Release Political Prisoners
description: President Patricio Aylwin has won approval from Congress to free many of the jailed political prisoners detained by Gen. Augusto Pinochet's former military Government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Consumer Pessimism Rises, A Report by Grey Indicates
description: A STUDY to be released today by Grey Advertising found that a majority of consumers were shaken by the Persian Gulf war, discouraged by the recession and saw the American dream of a good life slipping out of reach.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic's Mozart
description: Last week was to have been an island of normalcy for the New York Philharmonic, between a seemingly endless string of conductor defections and a run of makeshift concerts replacing a canceled European tour. Then Christoph Perick, who was scheduled to conduct the subscription concerts in Avery Fisher Hall, suddenly withdrew to deal with a family emergency. As it happened, a replacement was at hand: the Finnish conductor Paavo Berglund, who had made his Philharmonic debut the week before, filling in for an indisposed Klaus Tennstedt.

title: Review/Theater; The Double Jeopardy of 'Pygmalion'
description: With Paul Weidner's production of "Pygmalion," the Roundabout Theater Company steps forthrightly into nontraditional theatrical waters. The revival, which opened yesterday, is novel in casting, design and directorial concept. The approach is refreshing without diminishing the flavor of the popular Shavian classic.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Eighth Avenue between 34th and 59th Streets will be closed today from 10:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus Elephant Walk.

title: Grief and Bitterness Smolder In the Embers of a Fatal Fire
description: Ruben Valladarez is nearly over the worst of his nightmares, the dreams in which terrified faces of old friends stare through him into the flames consuming the Happy Land Social Club -- dreams from which he wakes crying.

title: The Little Birdie Learned to Fly
description: NO tears of anguish were shed by Mark Macon over Temple's loss to North Carolina yesterday afternoon. Nor, of course, should there have been. Not at all.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Cuddly, harmless-looking dogs parade through the newest television commercial for Kodak Gold Film, which will be shown for the first time during the telecast of the Academy Awards this evening. In the spot, one of three that the Eastman Kodak Company is to introduce tonight, the dogs pose humorously as the rock song "Wild Thing" plays incongruously in the background. "No other film in the world gives you more ferocious color than Kodak Gold," an announcer says. "Capture the true colors of your wild thing with Kodak Gold." The spot was prepared by J. Walter Thompson.

title: Rotisserie Baseball: Hot-Stove League Boils Over
description: THE Mets said they had a rookie pitcher who had the stuff that dreams were made of, and the control to go with it. They talked about his 168-mile-per-hour fastball, and you could almost visualize a home-plate umpire explaining to an overmatched batter, "Well, it sounded like a strike to me."

title: U.S. Is Asked To Review Japan Trade
description: Unhappy with the continuing huge trade deficit with Japan, the National Association of Manufacturers has asked President Bush for a complete re-examination of the United States' relationship with Japan.

title: Bolar Fined in Generics Case
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company pleaded guilty to 20 criminal counts on Friday and was fined $10 million for selling adulterated and mislabeled generic drugs.

title: The Lineup Is Set: It's On to the Final Four; Duke Romps Over St. John's By 78-61
description: With one pop in Robert Werdann's right leg, and an afternoon of frustration created by the suffocating defense of the Duke Blue Devils, the surprising run of the St. John's Redmen came to a sudden end this afternoon.

title: Question Box
description: Slugging Teammates

title: Hope Gross, Manager, Marries Dr. Neil Mandel
description: Hope Shelley Gross, the daughter of Tina Arkey of Aberdeen, N.J., and the late Harvey Gross, was married yesterday to Dr. Neil Steven Mandel, the son of Dr. Benjamin and Mrs. Mandel of Brooklyn, at the Grand Marquis in Old Bridge, N.J. Rabbi Neil Cooper officiated.

title: Metering Water: Will It Drown The Landlords?
description: To Robert C. Rosenberg of the Bronx, trickle-down isn't an abstract economic theory. It's a formula for business losses that may presage a renewed wave of abandonment by owners of marginally profitable apartment buildings in New York City.

title: Progress Seen In S. Africa
description: An International Olympic Committee official said today that the major South African sports bodies were committed to forming unfied non-racial groups, a key requirement for the country to return to Olympic competition.

title: Police Brutality, Public Trust
description: The murder indictments last week of five New York City police officers in the death of a suspect in their custody invite comparisons with the videotaped brutality of Los Angeles police. Although the facts in the New York case remain murky, one thing is already clear: Police Commissioner Lee Brown has responded more vigorously to the possible brutality than did Chief Daryl Gates in Los Angeles.

title: Creating a Hall of Fame To Prize Black Heritage
description: In the courtyard of a bustling building in a Queens park lies a patch of grass in the shape of Africa, a modest testament to a big idea.

title: Building an Economy, Bhutan's Way
description: Apple strudel and eclairs are not something a visitor would expect to find in this landlocked, underpopulated, almost totally agrarian mountain kingdom.

title: Merion Pulls Out As Tourney Host
description: LAST week, as quietly as possible, the Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa., slipped off the active stage of golf history.

title: Nancy Stein, Buyer, Weds David Woolf, Executive
description: Nancy Anne Stein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Stein of Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday in Glen Cove, L.I., to David Mark Woolf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Woolf of White Plains. Rabbi Laurence Kotok performed the ceremony at the North Country Reform Temple.

title: British Publishers Are Cutting Back Sharply
description: A spate of job cuts has sent shock waves through British book publishing, with many in the industry saying that the cuts have been unprecedented in their scope and rapid-fire succession.

title: Review/Theater; Doctor, Abused Girlfriend and Child
description: Buried deep within "A Walk on Lake Erie," there may be signs of a serious attempt to come to terms with child murder and environmental suicide, but one would scarcely know it from Randy Rollison's production at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art. The direction and acting compound the failings of Heather McCutchen's play.

title: Review/Dance; Nureyev Farewell That Isn't
description: What was advertised as the "Rudolf Nureyev and Friends Farewell Tour" came here tonight. Anyone who believes the "farewell" in the billing will believe anything; on the eve of this performance at the Tilles Center for the Arts at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, Mr. Nureyev himself issued a disclaimer about any retirement plans to the local press.

title: Court Ruling On Nutrasweet
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed an allegation that the Nutrasweet Company made "misrepresentations" to Government officials in getting patent extensions on the sweetener aspartame, the company said today.

title: Rangers Win, 3-1, and Make Playoffs
description: The Rangers secured a place in the Stanley Cup playoffs last night with a 3-1 triumph over the Islanders that ended their losing streak at eight games.

title: Australia Acts to Ban Political Ads on the Air
description: The Australian Government has set off a nationwide storm of protest by proposing legislation to prohibit all political commercials on television and radio.

title: Age Bias Case Could Limit Right of Workers to Sue
description: If a company dismisses a worker for reasons he thinks are unfair, he can always sue. But what if, upon being hired, the worker had signed an agreement promising not to do so?

title: Clashes and Miners' Strike Intensify Soviet Unrest
description: Political unrest deepened in the Soviet Union today as fresh fighting was reported in the separatist republic of Georgia.

title: U.N.L.V. Coach Relaxes A Bit
description: For the last two weeks, all Jerry Tarkanian could talk about was the fading fortunes of Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: Left With Little but Her Memories: Catalina Ramos
description: Catalina Ramos had hit somewhere near bottom when she met Wilson Pesantes five years ago. At the age of 22, she had no job, four young daughters and had just separated from the man she married at 16.

title: Owners of Some Dogs Should Post Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Major Contribution, Courtesy of a Mota
description: THE way Manny Mota, a 34-year veteran of professional baseball, figures it, the game has contributed so much to his life, to his family's well-being, that he just cannot help reciprocating.

title: Sea Cadet Getting Look of a Winner
description: DUKE ELLINGTON might have disagreed, but it says here that the saddest tail on land or sea belongs to Sea Cadet, a 3-year-old colt who appears to have a lock on making the field in the Kentucky Derby.

title: For Yugoslavia, Unity Still Holds Best Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * The national advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc. said Geo. A. Hormel & Company had disagreed with its recommendation that the company modify claims made in its advertising for its Micro Cup Hearty Soups. Hormel claims that consumers prefer its soups over those of the Campbell Soup Company by a 2-to-1 margin. The case will now be referred to the National Advertising Review Board. * BBDO Los Angeles/San Francisco has started a full-service division, BBDO Hispanica, that will devote itself to advertising aimed at Hispanic consumers.

title: MIXED U.S. REPORT ON CRIME TRENDS
description: The number of Americans victimized by a violent crime rose to 2.3 million last year even as the total number of personal and household crimes fell by one million, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Colorado's Success Is Long Overdue
description: A year ago, amid the hoopla surrounding the end of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the University of Colorado introduced Joe Harrington as its new basketball coach.

title: INSIDE
description: Final 2 for Final 4 North Carolina beat Temple, and Duke routed St. John's to complete college basketball's semifinal lineup heading for Indianapolis. They joined Nevada-Las Vegas and Kansas. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10

title: Review/Music; Setting Agitprop Poetry To the Beat of Current Jazz
description: On Wednesday and Thursday nights, S.O.B.'s presented agitprop poets with a beat, politically committed performers whose music saves them from didacticism. Jayne Cortez's poetry, which praises "revolutionary commitment" and warns of environmental and social catastrophe, has attracted some of the best musicians in contemporary jazz; Macka B., a British reggae toaster (rapper) and singer, performed with Robotiks, a lean four-piece band, as the Mad Professor mixed the sound and added the electronic effects of dub reggae.

title: Iraqi Rebels Report Public Protests in Capital
description: Loyal Iraqi Government troops have been redeployed in Baghdad to protect key Government installations amid reports of public protests in the capital in recent days and continued fighting in the north of the country, rebel groups said today.

title: The Prisoner
description: If his name were Mandela or Sharansky, he would be celebrated in the West. But we are less familiar with the victims of the Chinese tyranny.

title: Burgers, Burgers And Comebacks
description: THE latest addition to Michael Jordan's burgeoning business empire is the McJordan sandwich, a quarter-pound hamburger -- topped with smoked bacon, cheese, barbecue sauce, onions, mustard and pickles -- that recently made its debut at McDonald's franchises in the Chicago area. "What do you want me to say, 'It's bad, don't eat it?' " Jordan said with a smile. . . . Speaking of fast food -- and he often does -- George Foreman, busy training, took time out the other day to return a reporter's phone call. The rotund former champion, who fights Evander Holyfield for the heavyweight title on April 19, was speaking from his car phone. "I've got to do this other call," he said, then was overhead saying, "Get me a cheeseburger, pickles, ketchup. Tell him no mayo." At least he held the mayo, after all he is in training. . . . Jimmy Connors, at 38 on the road back from wrist surgery, stopped off at the Newsweek Champions Cup last month to play pros for $5 a game. In three days, he reportedly took $50 off Andrew Sznajder, $45 off Thomas Muster, and $10 each off Goren Ivanisevic and Henri Leconte. Connors was taking his cue from Bobby Riggs, who maintains there is no better way to get your game in shape than to play for your own money.

title: No Electricity but Kuwait Reopens Its Banks
description: It still has no water and little electricity or food, but Kuwait revived its banking system today, introducing a new currency.

title: It's Not Easy, Proprietor's Wife Says: Elena Colon
description: After she burst out of the Happy Land Social Club's emergency door on the morning of March 25, Elena Colon remembers herself somehow across the street, watching the club burn with her husband, Elias, inside.

title: S. C. Seldin Wed To Jill Goldman
description: Jill Goldman, a commercial imports specialist for the Customs Service in New York, and Stephen C. Seldin, a lawyer in New York, were married yesterday at the Village Temple in Greenwich Village by Rabbi Dennis Math.

title: For the Iraqi-Americans, War Worries Continue
description: News comes in slivers an unexpected fax, a letter forwarded by a Jordanian cab driver, a telephone call from a neighbor who heard something third hand about whether an area of Baghdad survived the bombings.

title: Rumors Roil Coffee Market
description: Traders say that one of Brazil's largest coffee exporters profited from inside information about the Government's decision last week to suspend new export sales of coffee, newspapers reported on Saturday.

title: Jansen on Track For '92 Olympics
description: FOR most people, the memory of the speed skater Dan Jansen is vivid and chilling: sprawled on the ice after falling in both his races at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary. Hours earlier, his sister had died of leukemia and Jansen's failure became one of the Games' most poignant stories.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $300 million in debt securities.

title: He Still Hears the Screams Inside: Roberto Michell Suazo
description: Roberto Michell Suazo had not really wanted to go out that Saturday night. But Francisco Chavez, who shared the room he rented in a Bronx apartment, insisted.

title: Gavaldon Retires From Pro Tennis
description: THE latest casualty of adolescent tennis burnout is Angelica Gavaldon, who two weeks ago quit professional tennis at the age of 17.

title: Overdose Is Suspected in a Teacher's Death
description: A special-education teacher at a Manhattan elementary school was found dead in his apartment in upper Manhattan early yesterday, apparently the victim of a drug overdose, the police said.

title: The Words of Washington On Behaving With Civility
description: "Labour to keep alive in your Breast that Little Spark of Celestial fire Called Conscience," goes the 110th and final dictum in George Washington's "Rules of Civility and Decent Behavior in Company and in Conversation."

title: Top Man at Harvard: Neil Leon Rudenstine
description: Four years ago he could have been president of Princeton University, his alma mater, if he had let his name be placed in consideration. Instead, today, Neil L. Rudenstine was named to what many regard as the most prestigious job in American education: the presidency of Harvard University.

title: Stanford President Apologizes
description: The president of Stanford University has apologized to alumni for the "highly embarrassing" accusations that the school billed the Government for items not related to research projects.

title: Kenneth C. Swenson, Executive, 48
description: Kenneth C. Swenson, a partner with Campbell Advisors, a Manhattan-based investment firm, died on Friday in White Plains Hospital Center, a nursing supervisor, Kathleen Poli, said. He was 48 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Outdoors: Free-Spirited Search for Shad
description: WHEN I took up fly fishing I was captivated by Charles Waterman's written accounts of shad fishing on Florida's St. Johns River.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Feb. 16 misidentified a new game that is based on guessing idiomatic expressions from pictures on cards. The game, not yet on the market, is called Slanguage, not Expressions. The error was reported to The Times early in March, but this correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: Badge Tarnishes on Los Angeles Streets, Police Say
description: The sun was setting Friday evening as Sgt. Philip Alaniz steered his black and white police cruiser down a block of bungalows and neat yards in a gang-plagued section of south central Los Angeles.

title: Espinoza Has Broken Finger
description: An onslaught of nagging injuries to various Yankee players has turned the trainer's room into the most visited place at Fort Lauderdale Stadium and has put three positions in an unexpected state of flux.

title: Review/Television; Brook's 'Mahabharata,' in 6 Hours
description: Marathon theater productions being among my least favorite forms of commitment, I carefully sidestepped the Brooklyn Academy of Music's presentation in 1987 of Peter Brook's nine-hour stage version of "The Mahabharata." And I approached with considerable trepidation the television adaptation of the production, even though it has been condensed to six hours.

title: Museum and a Collector Vie for the Treasures of the Seas
description: Like an old-time chantey sung on a square-rigger heading for a berth in New York Harbor, this is a tale of hidden treasure, sails and schooners and just about everything but walking the plank. Except that nobody in the story goes to sea.

title: Jennings Retains World Title
description: Lynn Jennings of the United States, reversing the tactics that first earned her international acclaim, captured her second consecutive cross-country world title today.

title: Sore Winners
description: Dovish Democrats have been brooding and bristling as Republicans crow about Commander in Chief Bush's bold victory in the Persian Gulf. Most G.O.P. politicians have had the good grace not to disparage the opposition. They believe, correctly, that Mr. Bush will reap the fruits of victory and that a divisive debate won't help his cause.

title: Review/Theater; Radio City Easter Show: Giddiness and Solemnity
description: Last year, after an 11-year hiatus, the Radio City Music Hall revived the annual Easter extravaganza that had been a Music Hall tradition from 1933 to 1979. This season it is back, more finely tuned and more engaging than ever.

title: Stock Market For Poland
description: The lower house of the Polish Parliament has approved a law setting up a stock exchange in Warsaw.

title: Dr. Janet Shapiro Marries
description: Dr. Janet Elizabeth Shapiro, the daughter of Marjorie J. Shapiro of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Byron M. Shapiro, was married yesterday in New York to Gerald Solomon, the son of the late Hilda Newman of Brent Knoll, Somerset, England, and the late Edwin Solomon of London. Rabbi Ronald Shapiro, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the English Speaking Union. The bride is a psychologist at Coler Memorial Hospital in New York. She graduated from the University of Minnesota and received master's and doctoral degrees in clinical psychology from Adelphi University. The bridegroom, who is an artist, graduated from Cambridge University. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: I'll Remember April
description: Secretary of State Baker was hailed at the Gridiron Club dinner for releasing April Glaspie, our Ambassador to Baghdad, "physically unharmed."

title: 2 Killed and 5 Are Injured In Shootings at Restaurants
description: A man walked up to the takeout counter in a Brooklyn restaurant Saturday night, followed by someone with an automatic weapon. As a dozen employees and customers scrambled for safety, the person with the gun sprayed the small room with bullets, killing the man and wounding three other customers, one of whom later died.

title: Troops in Mali Said to Slay 100
description: Soldiers in Mali opened fire on anti-Government demonstrators for the third consecutive day today and a human rights leader said at least 100 people died.

title: Poor Are Rocked by Closing of Gynecological Clinics
description: Thousands of low-income women in New York City must now scramble to find routine gynecological care because the clinics where they used to receive it have been closed or scaled back for lack of money -- victims of city budget cuts and economic problems.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods . . . Feb. Wednesday G.N.P. . . . 4th Qtr. Thursday Personal Income . . . Feb. Friday Leading Indicators . . . Feb. New-Home Sales . . . Feb. New-Home Prices . . . Feb. Farm Prices . . . March

title: Steps Taken to Free the Hostages, Lebanon Leader Tells Beirut Daily
description: Moves are under way to release Western hostages in Lebanon, Prime Minister Omar Karami said today.

title: Stephanie G. Fried Is Wed
description: Stephanie Gayle Fried, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Fried of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., to Robert Owen Senzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Senzer of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated. Mrs. Senzer, 26 years old, is an associate in the New York law firm of Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman. She graduated from Harpur College at the State University at Binghamton and received a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. The bridegroom, 27, is an associate in the New York law firm of Ballon Stoll & Itzler.

title: 'Godfather, Part III' Anything But a Flop
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavia's Voices of Hope and Fear
description: Ever since violent anti-Communist demonstrations broke out on the streets of this capital city on March 9, Yugoslavia has been rocked by a crisis that has threatened to break up this country of 23 million people.

title: Charles M. Spofford Is Dead at 88; Furnished Idea for Lincoln Center
description: Charles M. Spofford, a New York lawyer and civic and cultural leader who also held high posts in NATO, died Saturday evening at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 88 years old.

title: Dragons Win, Diecinueve-Siete
description: Sometimes the world just doesn't seem that big. For three hours today, the majestic Olympic Stadium here could have been the Rose Bowl, Soldier Field or Giants Stadium.

title: St. John's Is Hurt By Werdann Injury
description: In the eighth minute of the game, when the Duke lead was still in single digits, Robert Werdann of St. John's looked toward his bench with a startled expression on his face as he told the coaches and the medics, "I heard it pop."

title: Zappa's Mammoth Official Bootleg
description: In recent weeks Bob Dylan and Paul McCartney have announced plans to release some of their live or unissued recordings, packaged as if they were bootleg records. Now Frank Zappa, typically, has taken the "official bootleg" idea to extremes.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Thursday with an article about budget cuts sought in New York City school programs for the handicapped misstated the total 1989 operating budget for the school system. It was $5.73 billion.

title: The Writer's Reward for 'Wolves'
description: Five years ago, Michael Blake was living in his car in southern California, spending nights in friends' houses and writing a novel about a United States Army officer in the Civil War who is sent to a fort on the Western frontier and deserts his post to become a member of an Indian tribe.

title: China and the Oscars
description: The announcement of the Academy Award nominations on Feb. 13 brought joy to many members of the international film community. Sadly, it brought only consternation to a film maker in China.

title: Long a Jewel of Europe, It Longs to Glow Again
description: One bookstore in this charming old town has a shelf devoted to works by local authors. Goethe, Schiller and Nietzsche are among them.

title: Bias Lawsuit Jolts Suburb Widely Cited As Integrated
description: Whatever else New Rochelle has done, or failed to do, in the postwar decades of suburban expansion, integration of its minority residents is considered a major success. So when four residents filed a lawsuit last week charging that the city's election system discriminated against blacks, many in this suburban city were startled.

title: Miss Schlain Marries George Sweeting
description: Karen Elizabeth Schlain and George Vincent Sweeting, senior tax policy analysts for the City of New York, were married yesterday at the Barclay Hotel in Philadelphia. Judge Norma L. Shapiro of Federal District Court in Philadelphia officiated.

title: Knicks Search for Answers
description: Bad starts have led to bad endings for the Knicks recently.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up in Light Trading
description: Stocks climbed slowly today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in a day of light trading. Traders said they had little incentive to move because today was the last day of trading for March delivery and for the current fiscal year.

title: Accounts
description: * Vernors Inc., a soft-drink subsidiary of A & W Brands Inc., White Plains, to W. B. Doner & Co., Detroit, with a budget of about $2 million. * The Finals, a New York manufacturer of swimwear, to Buckley DeCerchio Cavalier Inc., New York, with a budget of about $1.2 million.

title: Miss Hartman Has Wedding
description: Susan Gail Hartman, the daughter of Eileen Kaplan and Sheldon Kaplan, both of New York, was married yesterday to Maurice Leibenstern, a son of Lucy Leibenstern of Miami Beach and Rubin Leibenstern of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Howard Handler at the Nanou restaurant in New York.

title: Only Stormin' Norman's Sacred at Press Gridiron
description: President Bush teased the Iraqi Air Force. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d confessed he had started the rumors about his replacing Vice President Dan Quayle on the 1992 Republican ticket. And Robert S. Strauss announced he would come out of retirement to lead the Democratic Party "further into the wilderness."

title: Doctors Need Training In Treating Cancer Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: The Field Is Still Open, Time Wanes And, as in '88, the Name Gore Arises
description: Fire in the belly is a rare commodity among Democrats these days.

title: Paramount's Bare-Fisted Boss
description: The early-morning telephone call last Monday to Paramount Pictures' chairman, Frank G. Mancuso, was from his brusque boss, Martin S. Davis, the chairman and chief executive of Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Rachel Anne Shub, Lawyer, Married To Daniel Marc Klaidman, Reporter
description: Rachel Anne Shub, the daughter of Joyce Lasky Reed of Chevy Chase, Md., and Anatole Shub of Washington, was married in Washington yesterday to Daniel Marc Klaidman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Klaidman of Chevy Chase. Rabbi Fred N. Reiner performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: Royals Take a Look Back and Beyond Bo
description: BO JACKSON cannot be replaced. The Kansas City Royals, having said that in so many ways in the last week, have to try to do so just the same.

title: Deal Keeps the Buzz Alive in Los Angeles
description: Starting a new magazine can be an endeavor fraught with financial peril. Eden Collinsworth, who started Los Angeles-based Buzz magazine in October, found that out last month when Buzz was forced to suspend publication for lack of money. Vowing that Buzz would be back, she set out to raise $4 million.

title: Profits May Suffer After Maine Victory
description: Maine, the top-seeded team in the East, knocked Minnesota out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's hockey tournament over the weekend, a result that may hurt in the N.C.A.A. counting house later this week.

title: On the Trail of Research Misconduct, 'Science Police' Take the Limelight
description: They like neither the name nor the implication, but a group of investigators working in cramped quarters at the National Institutes of Health here are known to some as the "science police."

title: Hot-Shooting Davis Passes Off Credit
description: Shortly after North Carolina prevailed over Temple in the East Regional final here today, Hubert Davis, the Tar Heels' 6-foot-4-inch, hot-shooting junior guard, sat in the team's locker room and mouthed the party line.

title: Albany Stilled By Impasse Over Budget
description: Just one week before the legal deadline for a new state budget that must include $6 billion in spending cuts and new taxes, negotiations here have reached a bitter impasse brought on by the sheer magnitude of the task and especially deep divisions over what taxes should be raised.

title: Market Place; Computer Stocks: Small Successes
description: INVESTORS, who seemed to recognize a shift in the fortunes of personal computer makers last week, were not kind to familiar heavyweights.

title: U.S. and Bahrain Near Pact On Permanent Military Base
description: The Pentagon is close to an agreement with Bahrain, an island nation in the Persian Gulf, to establish the forward headquarters of the United States Central Command there, Administration and Bahraini officials said today.

title: Albania Turns In the Throes Of Transition
description: At 2:30 A.M. today, there were knots of mothers and grandmothers gathered around little fires in front of dairy stores along one of this capital's main streets waiting until the doors opened at 8 to buy one quart of rationed milk.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Even in Era of Fax, Industry Is Still Bound to New York
description: WHEN Little, Brown & Company of Boston announced last week that it would move the editors of its adult trade books to New York City later this year, the publisher explained that it would be more efficient to have the department in one city rather than two.

title: The Lineup Is Set: It's On to the Final Four; N. Carolina Holds Off Temple, 75-72
description: North Carolina's point guard, King Rice, sank four crucial free throws in the final 23 seconds here this afternoon to hold off a late surge by Temple, and the Tar Heels eked out a 75-72 victory over the Owls in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional final.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
