description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, an auction tomorrow of two-year Treasury notes and an auction Wednesday of five-year notes.

title: Four Men Are Killed in Crash Of a Small Plane in Alabama
description: A single-engine plane carrying four Georgia men, including a father and his two sons, crashed in a remote mountain area near here on Friday, the authorities said.

title: Deduct Local Taxes From Federal Income Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Relocation Of Homeless Families
description: New York City must move 460 homeless families out of welfare hotel rooms that lack stoves by June 30, a Manhattan judge ordered yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID HAMPTON told a judge yesterday that he was cleaning up his life. And the judge, MICHAEL OBUS of Manhattan Criminal Court, sentenced him to three years' probation.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Borden Inc., Columbus, Ohio, named Frankie Nowlin executive director of the Borden Foundation, its principal vehicle for corporate contributions. * Cannon Pictures, Beverly Hills, Calif., a company that finances, produces and distributes movies, named Jere Henshaw executive vice president in charge of production, a new position.

title: How Investigation of Lab Fraud Grew Into a Cause Celebre
description: AS long as science proceeds relatively smoothly, it appears to be driven purely by reason and the answers given by nature in experiments. But when things go wrong, the human actors shed their masks of professional impassivity, and the emotional undercurrents of the scientific enterprise may suddenly emerge like the wizard behind the curtains in Oz.

title: Witness Contradicts Statements By Flake on Use of Federal Money
description: A main prosecution witness testified yesterday that the Rev. Floyd H. Flake had told him a decade ago of starting a transportation "business" for the elderly to earn some extra income and said he was going to pay taxes on it.

title: Quiet but Uneasy, South Koreans Vote
description: For the first time in 30 years, South Koreans will vote on Tuesday for local government officials. But in sharp contrast to the constant political tumult here since military rule ended three years ago, this election is remarkable for what is missing: strikes, huge rallies and tear gas.

title: The Word From Menuhin at 75: Style
description: Beyond virtuosity as he approaches his 75th birthday, the legendary violinist Yehudi Menuhin says that the most important thing he tries to pass on to his younger students is a sense of style.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: EXPLORING HUSSEIN'S WEALTH Reports that Saddam Hussein had squirreled away billions in bank accounts worldwide reverberated through the business and diplomatic communities. Page D1.

title: Maxwell Is Set To Leave Post
description: A spokesman for Robert Maxwell confirmed today that Mr. Maxwell would step down as chairman of the Maxwell Communication Corporation, the public company he owns, after Mirror Group Newspapers, his privately owned media investment company, goes public.

title: Germany Overtakes U.S. As World's Export Leader
description: A newly unified Germany overtook the United States as the world's leading exporter in 1990, the world's trading organization said today.

title: Ulster Parties Agree to Hold Broad Talks
description: Most of Northern Ireland's political leaders agreed today to begin negotiations aimed at returning a significant degree of home rule to the strife-torn province, which has been largely governed by London since 1972.

title: Japan Chided for Threat
description: In a letter released today, Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan called Japan's threat to arrest United States rice industry representatives at a recent Tokyo food fair "a serious affront" to American farmers. "There are over two million farmers in America," Mr. Madigan said in a letter to Motoji Kondo, Japan's Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries. "Should they band together against buying Japanese products? Or are we united in our goal of accomplishing liberalized trade?" The letter was sent in response to Japan's threat this month to arrest the rice industry representatives for displaying bags of American rice at a food fair near Tokyo.

title: Census in India Counts 844 Million People
description: The population of India has risen to 844 million, a growth of about 161 million in the last decade, according to the first results of a national census released today.

title: Police Beating Unsettles World of Make-Believe
description: Since the days of "Dragnet," the Los Angeles Police Department has been the shining symbol of American law enforcement. A black and white patrol car stenciled with the motto "To Protect and to Serve," zooming past palm trees as it closes in on a wrongdoer, is one of the most familiar and enduring sights on television and in movies.

title: Lukas Makes Contribution to New List of Faces to Watch: Farma Way
description: Wayne Lukas, who trains more winners than anybody else in horse racing, reflected on the mood and mindset of the thoroughbred business and put it this way: "We lost a lot of big names last year. We've got to pick up some new faces."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a voting-rights lawsuit against New Rochelle, N.Y., misstated the city's black population in some editions. Blacks make up 18 percent of the population.

title: Milton Cohen, 78, Dies; Led Group for Disabled
description: Milton Cohen, executive director of the Federation of the Handicapped, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Freed Albanian Prisoners Tell of Others Left Behind
description: After 46 years of rule by a hard-line Communist Government, Albania is seeking to deal with its past political prisoners even as it apparently continues to jail people for political offenses.

title: TV AD INTENSIFIES KANSAS CITY RACE
description: What began as a tepid mayoral contest, with both candidates agreeing to avoid negative campaigns, has heated up in recent days after one candidate fielded an advertisement that the other says deliberately misrepresents his views.

title: Japan Bank in U.S. Bid
description: Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. said today that it had applied to the Federal Reserve Board for approval to establish a securities subsidiary in the United States. A company spokesman said the unit, Industrial Bank of Japan Securities U.S.A., would underwrite and broker commercial paper, mortgage-backed and asset-backed securities, and other instruments.

title: Proud Tradition, Threatened
description: The Federal courts of the Deep South have a proud modern tradition of looking out for racial minorities and the politically powerless. Beginning with President Eisenhower's appointees, the judges often distinguished themselves by bravely confronting local prejudice and vindicating civil rights. But now President Bush, whose judicial choices have been winning easy Senate confirmation, has nominated a candidate who falls far short of that noble standard.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., a maker of hospital products, signed a long-term supply agreement with E. Merck, Darmstadt, Germany, for diagnostic test reagents and instruments that will be marketed by both companies. Terms were not disclosed. * AGS Information Services Inc., Mountainside, N.J., a consulting company and a subsidiary of the Nynex Corp., acquired the assets of the Decision Resources Corp., Washington, a management consulting company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Review/Opera; Three Singers Are Honored After 25 Years at the Met
description: Every now and then, the Metropolitan Opera likes to give itself a party, and the coincidence of three anniversaries -- it has been 25 years since Mirella Freni, Alfredo Kraus and Nicolai Ghiaurov made their Met debuts -- brought on a gala performance at the house on Sunday night. The format included three complete acts with three different sets for three different operas: Gounod's "Faust," Act III; Verdi's "Don Carlo," Act IV, Scene 1, and Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," Act III.

title: Chess
description: Vasily Ivanchuk triumphed in the elite Ninth International Tournament in Linares, Spain, held Feb. 23 to March 14. The 22-year-old Soviet grandmaster scored 9 1/2-3 1/2 against a field of almost all the leading players in the world.

title: Playoffs to Roll Around With Few Surprises
description: There has been virtually no mystery about which of the 16 teams will make the National Basketball Association playoffs. It has been a season with very strong teams at the top, especially in the Western Conference, and extremely weak teams at the bottom.

title: Tsung Chen Tsao, Translator, 74
description: Tsung Chen Tsao, the former chief of the Chinese language translation service at the United Nations, died Friday at St. John's Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens. He was 74 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Earnings Flat At Southland
description: The Southland Corporation said today that soft sales kept its earnings essentially flat for the fourth quarter of 1990 and for the year that ended on Dec. 31.

title: Our Towns; Transplants For Covering Beach Bald Spots
description: The wind was building toward 30 knots. The waves were following fiercely. The rain, which began as a drifting mist, was now flying horizontally off toward New York City with a plummeting wind chill factor. Even the sun had sense enough to stay in, behind a mile or two of low-scudding clouds.

title: British Trade Gap Cut
description: Britain's current account trade deficit shrank sharply in February from January, thanks to a drop in oil imports. The Government's Central Statistical Office said today that the deficit narrowed to $:192 million ($340 million) from a revised $:783 million ($1.4 billion) the month before.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Health page on Thursday about the possible spread of Lyme disease in the Midwest omitted the principal symptom shown by some patients in Missouri. Besides neurological symptoms and positive results in blood tests, these people also suffered from a rash typical of Lyme disease.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; A Comic French Short and a Danish Quest for Sex
description: The animated short "Land of the Snowy Mountains" is an 11-minute comic love tale about humans, animals and a unique mating game played out in an isolated shack in the Tibetan mountains. The lone land surveyor who lives in the shack has a face that looks a little like a mole's, for a very good reason. Soon a fur-covered, tailed creature arrives; she has a very similar face.

title: President's Post Filled By Home Shopping
description: Home Shopping Network, the large operator of television shopping, catalogue and direct-mail businesses, yesterday named Robert T. Sutton, a longtime television broadcasting executive, to the post of president. He assumes one of the hats worn by Roy M. Speer, Home Shopping's founder who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the St. Petersburg, Fla., company.

title: Phone Study In Canada
description: Twenty-five United States companies have attained about a 2 percent share of Canada's long-distance telephone market, estimated at about $6 billion, according to a study.

title: Time to Reclaim the Javits Center
description: Pilferage, featherbedding and unreasonable charges for routine services now jeopardize the success of New York City's Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Daniel Flanagan, 85; Founded Blarney Stone
description: Daniel Flanagan, a real-estate investor and restaurateur who founded the Blarney Stone bar and grill chain in New York, died on Friday at White Plains Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Astros' Young Players Can Be Stars of Future
description: The Houston Astros may have projected a different look for the 1991 season once upon a time, one reflective of a team laden with veterans and considered worthy of a contender's status in the National League West.

title: Bridge
description: If a player who learned the game in the Culbertson era resumed tournament play half a century later, as some have, he or she would find that many bids that used to be forcing are now simply encouraging. In a few situations the converse is true, and an example is the sequence shown in the diagram. It occurred in a Vanderbilt Knockout Team match in Atlantic City earlier this month.

title: China Sees a Greater Role For Free Market in 1990's
description: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that China would move cautiously to expand the role of the market in the 1990's, but he vigorously warned against efforts to subvert the Communist Party's leadership.

title: Business Scene; Judging the Value Of Stock Options
description: ASK the top executives at Time Warner or Digital Equipment how their stock options are doing, and they'll probably frown. Raises for the nation's chief executives are paid increasingly in stock options, but these days many executives find they can't turn their options into cash. The options seem worthless, although viewed through the right lens, they remain rich in current value.

title: Deduct Local Taxes From Federal Income Tax; Rewards for Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockets Halt Bulls And 26-Game Streak
description: Houston ended the National Basketball Association's second-longest single-season home winning streak at 26 games and extended its own overall winning streak to 12 in a row by beating the Bulls, 100-90, here tonight.

title: James P. Erdman, 71, Charity Fund-Raiser
description: James Patrick Erdman, a New York fund-raiser for philanthropic causes, died on Thursday, at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L.I.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Mid-March Vehicle Sales Off 11.1%
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell by 11.1 percent in the middle of the month, as demand for new vehicles continued to sputter at recessionary levels.

title: Killer Not Facing Execution, But Court Clears Way Anyway
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for Ohio to execute a killer who had not been sentenced to death.

title: 18th Suspicious Fire in '91 Adds to New Britain's Fears
description: A suspicious fire heavily damaged the rear of a three-story apartment building this morning, the 18th suspicious fire in this blue-collar city since January and the fourth in the last two days, authorities said.

title: Dow Up 6.93, to 2,865.84, as Trading Slows
description: Stock prices ended with a small gain yesterday after being sharply higher earlier in the day. Blue-chip stocks fell back late in the day after the Supreme Court said it would rule on whether health warnings on cigarette packages protected manufacturers from personal injury suits.

title: Israel Holds Couple Sought by U.S. Since 1989 in Letter-Bomb Killing
description: After years of dispute, the Israeli police have arrested an American-Israeli husband and wife in a West Bank Jewish settlement on a two-year-old extradition request from the United States. The couple are wanted for murder.

title: After the Fire, Lawsuits
description: Though the landlords of the Happy Land Social Club were absolved of criminal responsibility in the deaths of 87 people there, they still face legal battles ranging from charges of building-code violations to a $5 billion suit that was filed yesterday on behalf of the victims.

title: Spending Down 2%
description: Total expenditures for advertising in newspapers declined by 2 percent, to $8.77 billion, in the fourth quarter of last year, from $8.95 billion in the period in 1989, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. For 1990, advertisers spent $32.28 billion in newspapers, a negligible decline from 1989, when advertisers spent $32.37 billion.

title: Access Is Money for City Hall Lobbyists
description: Last March, a lobbyist persuaded Mayor David N. Dinkins to attend a dinner of the Building Contractors Association, which honored Mr. Dinkins for his "outstanding contribution to the building and construction industry."

title: QUESTIONS ABOUND IN SOLDIER'S DEATH
description: Against a backdrop of mounting questions, the police said today that they had arrested a suspect in the slaying of a 22-year-old soldier who was shot to death last Monday, just a day after returning here from service in the Persian Gulf.

title: Sir John Kerr, 76, Dies; Australian in '75 Rift
description: Sir John Kerr, the former Governor General who was at the center of one of Australia's most bitter political disputes, has died. He was 76 years old.

title: Mrs. Ford Criticizes Neglect of Alcohol In U.S. Drug Efforts
description: Betty Ford said today that the Bush Administration's war on drugs had neglected the problem of alcoholism and had encouraged a return to treating drug and alcohol abusers as criminals.

title: Honeymoon for Mayor Continues in the Capital
description: When Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon took the oath of office at noon on Jan. 2, she faced two daunting problems -- red ink and red faces.

title: Investor to Acquire More Macy Stock
description: R. H. Macy & Company said Winmex Investments Ltd., intends to exercise an option to buy 785,916 shares of Macy convertible preferred stock for $25 million. The purchase by Winmex, an affiliate of the Hong Kong investor Sir Run Run Shaw, would be its second in recent months. Macy also said that it had obtained necessary lender approval for the sale of its credit-card operations to the General Electric Capital Corporation. The net proceeds of that sale -- to be completed next month -- are expected to be about $100 million.

title: Spurning Bush, Congress Provides New Money to Fight Infant Deaths
description: Both houses of Congress have rejected President Bush's proposal to finance a campaign against infant mortality in 10 localities by diverting money from other health programs that serve pregnant women and poor children.

title: By Design; Swing Into Pleated Skirts
description: If you are going to buy just one thing this spring, make it a pleated skirt. It will make last season's jackets and tops look up to the minute. The swing of those pleats flipping about as you walk is a sure sign of 1991; it's the opposite of the short, skintight stretch skirt of last year. Movement makes the difference.

title: Goldstar's Stake in Zenith Involves Widespread Links
description: The chief executive of the Goldstar Company, the big South Korean consumer electronics maker, said today that his company's investment last month in the Zenith Electronics Corporation was part of a much broader and previously undisclosed cooperative agreement.

title: Could Vegas Win in Pros? Forget It
description: Not since the U.C.L.A. dynasties of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Bill Walton has a college basketball team roared into the Final Four with the title a virtual formality. After 47 consecutive victories, the Runnin' Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas not only are expected to repeat as champions, but they have stirred conversations that they could compete in the National Basketball Association.

title: Pupils Jabbed With Syringes
description: Three elementary school students found two of hypodermic needles and jabbed seven classmates with them, leading to AIDS tests on the victims today by police technicians. The three boys from Allapattah Elementary School found the syringes behind a store where drug dealers congregate, the police said.

title: Concessions Pledged by T.W.A. Unions
description: Three unions at Trans World Airlines Inc. have offered concessions to aid an effort by the investor Kirk Kerkorian to buy the company. But some of those involved in the takeover attempt acknowledged yesterday that the effort could threaten T.W.A.'s survival.

title: People
description: * Kirk Borland has been promoted to executive account director, a new position, at DDB Needham Chicago. * Greg Geider has joined William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, a health-care agency, where he will be account supervisor on the Roche Dermatologics account.

title: Jackson to Play Less With Wilkins Back
description: Those who enjoy watching Patrick Ewing play against David Robinson will get their wish Tuesday night.

title: Deduct Local Taxes From Federal Income Tax; Hidden Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV BANS MOSCOW RALLIES
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tonight sharpened his political rivalry with Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, by ordering a ban on all public rallies and demonstrations in the capital for the next three weeks.

title: Review/Television; Chess Riddle: What Value Calculation? Inspiration?
description: You don't have to know a rook from a bishop to find tonight's edition of "Nova" fascinating. "The Chip vs. the Chess Master," at 8 o'clock on Channel 13, uses the October 1989 match between the Soviet-born world champion Gary Kasparov and the American-made champion computer Deep Thought to explore the differences between human intelligence and the intelligence of a machine.

title: New York Senate Approves Death Penalty
description: In what has become an annual political ritual, the State Senate approved a bill on the death penalty today although its chances of becoming law appeared remote. The 61-member Senate passed the bill by a 40-to-18 vote, with three members absent.

title: Forgery Is Hinted in Defense Alibi At the Murder Trial of a Teacher
description: The prosecution in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus offered testimony today suggesting that her defense lawyer's major piece of evidence was forged.

title: End of Slump In Magazines Is Foreseen
description: Four prominent magazine executives predicted yesterday that their business would soon start climbing out of the worst advertising slump in nearly two decades and would achieve renewed prominence among marketers by emphasizing editorial quality and new methods of reaching readers.

title: D. G. Bellissimo, 68; Inspired Buffalo Wings
description: Dominic G. Bellissimo, whose late-night craving for a snack inspired Buffalo chicken wings, died on Saturday at his home. He was 68 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: 400 Writers Languish in World's Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: California Timber Industry Rejects Logging Plan
description: The prospects for an agreement to protect old forests and regulate logging in California dimmed somewhat today as the state's timber industry rejected a proposal put forward last week by several environmental groups and a large lumber company.

title: Pro Bono
description: * To capitalize on the popularity of the film "Dances with Wolves," the American Indian College Fund has placed advertisements soliciting contributions in The Los Angeles Times and in the National Edition of The New York Times today. The ads, which feature Jackie Old Coyote, an American Indian, were prepared on a pro-bono basis by Griffin Bacal, a New York agency.

title: Walter McCollough, Church Leader, 76
description: Bishop Walter McCollough, who preached to poor and middle-class inner-city residents as leader of the United House of Prayer for All People, died of heart ailments on Thursday at Howard Uiversity Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: World's Finances Facing Strains As Troubled Areas Try to Rebuild
description: The growing appetite for long-term investment funds may make interest rates higher than they might otherwise have been in coming years as countries in the Middle East and Eastern Europe seek huge sums to rebuild their battered economies.

title: Rival Yugoslav Leaders Discussing Fate of Union
description: The two major adversaries in Yugoslavia's slide toward dissolution, the presidents of Serbia and Croatia, held an unexpected meeting today and promised to seek quick resolution of their differences.

title: U.S. SAYS HUSSEIN IS NEAR A VICTORY OVER SHIITE REBELS
description: Administration officials said today that President Saddam Hussein may be close to crushing the Shiite Muslim rebellion against his authority in southern Iraq. The officials, monitoring intelligence reports from the region, also predicted that he would then prevail over the Kurdish uprising that still threatens Baghdad's control over northern Iraq.

title: Cuts Threaten Studies Of Illnesses in Space
description: Its budget and dimensions steadily cut back, the proposed space station Freedom has only a few scientific missions left. Now critics say it will be unable to perform an important one, studying the physical problems that plague astronauts in space and after they return to Earth.

title: Bush Prods Gorbachev On Arms Pact Dispute
description: In an effort to break a deadlock that has been hampering efforts to schedule another Soviet-American summit meeting, President Bush has written to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev urging him to address Western concerns about a conventional arms treaty signed last year.

title: 3 Die in Texas Fire as Crowd Gets in Way
description: A fire at a home for mentally retarded children killed three of its six young residents Sunday night, and fire officials said they might have saved at least one of the victims had it not been for dozens of people, a few of them drunk, who surrounded the house in an effort to help.

title: PATTERNS
description: Schmoozing and Selling

title: Stanford and Oklahoma Win and Advance to N.I.T. Title Game
description: The clock at Madison Square Garden ran out last night on the University of Massachusetts' dream basketball season.

title: A.T.& T. And NCR Hold Talks
description: The chairmen of A.T.& T. and NCR met for several hours yesterday in New York in an effort to negotiate a friendly end to an often bitter takeover battle, but no agreement was announced afterward. No accord was reached on price and no further meeting scheduled, people close to the talks said.

title: Daily News's Discount Plan
description: To try to win back advertisers, The Daily News is offering enticements that include ad rates that are about 25 percent lower than before the strike began, the newspaper's new advertising director, Les Goodstein, said yesterday.

title: Harsh Lessons of Survival at the Bird Feeder
description: AT backyard bird feeders, the law of nature is sometimes eat and be eaten. The 5,000 feeder-watchers who report regularly to the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology related 946 instances during one winter in which birds seeking a free meal at feeders were attacked by predators, from raptors and snakes to cats and dogs.

title: Raid Notwithstanding, Campus Drug Use Seems Less
description: News of last week's Federal drug raid on fraternity row at the University of Virginia has drawn attention to the issue of drug use on campus. But most students and experts say the evidence, both statistical and anecdotal, points to declining drug use among college students.

title: Missing the Big Picture
description: As film makers, we are greatly flattered but totally unconvinced by the idea that a movie can have a significant effect on the behavior of moviegoers. If influencing people were that simple, Attica would be a cineplex and the Democrats would buy Paramount.

title: Walesa Vows to Fight Anti-Semitism
description: At a meeting with prominent Jews yesterday, President Lech Walesa of Poland repeatedly made explicit statements denouncing anti-Semitism and vowed to fight bigotry in his country.

title: Kevin Costner and 'Dances With Wolves' Win Top Oscar Prizes
description: "Dances With Wolves," an epic western in which the Indians are the good guys and the cavalry the villains, walked away with seven Oscars at the 63rd annual Academy Awards tonight, including best picture, best director and best adapted screenplay.

title: Review Urged of 1984 Police Shooting
description: The State Commission of Investigation today asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to reopen the 1984 case of a Hempstead, L.I., man shot to death by a Nassau County police officer, charging that a prosecutor improperly encouraged the grand jury to rely on the police version of events.

title: Chile's Leader and Army Square Off Over the Past
description: The human rights report that catalogued the deaths or disappearances of more than 2,000 Chileans during 17 years of military rule has led to a major confrontation between the armed forces and the year-old democratically elected Government.

title: The Oscar Winners
description: Picture: "Dances With Wolves" (Orion)

title: Despite Gains in Treatment, Asthma Worsens
description: ASTHMA treatment has vastly improved over the last 20 years. Doctors are more aware of the breathing disorder, are able to diagnose it better and sooner and can provide a larger arsenal of therapies to relieve the wheezing, gasping and struggle for breath that each attack brings.

title: U.S. Says Import Relief Is Unlikely for Detroit
description: White House officials said today that the Administration was unlikely to ask Japan for further restraints on auto exports to the United States to ease the financial plight of domestic auto makers, but that it could offer such assistance as a temporary easing of some regulatory requirements.

title: Max Truex, 55, Dies; Star Runner of 50's
description: Max Truex, who was described by a teammate on the 1960 Olympic team as "this gutsy little runner pounding at you around the track," died Sunday. He was 55 years old.

title: Transit Authority Picks Wrong Automated Fare Card System
description: To the Editor:

title: Bass Stake Is Cut
description: Members of the Bass family said they had reduced their holdings in the First Executive Corporation to 4.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had sold a total of 650,000 depositary preference shares and 60,000 convertible shares. First Executive, a Los Angeles insurance holding company, has been troubled by the falling value of its investments, a substantial portion of which are high-risk "junk bonds."

title: Witt Reports Some Pain Remains in Right Elbow
description: Mike Witt tossed a baseball around for 10 minutes under a blazing morning sun today at empty Fort Lauderdale Stadium and continued feeling pain in his right elbow. The scene on the Yankees' off day was perfect for baseball, but the outlook for Witt was not so rosy.

title: Reviews/Music; Australian Supergroup
description: For aficionados of Australian rock, Jack Frost is a quiet supergroup. Steve Kilbey and Grant McLennan, the main songwriters of the Church and the Go-Betweens respectively, wrote an album of songs together, "Jack Frost" (Arista), and their short tour together as a duo brought them to Wetlands Preserve in TriBeCa on Wednesday night.

title: Hasbro-Tonka
description: Shareholders of the Tonka Corporation, a toy maker, voted to give voting rights to shares acquired by Hasbro Inc. under a tender offer. With the vote, all conditions of the Hasbro tender offer requiring shareholder action have been met, Tonka said. On Feb. 6, Hasbro, a toy maker based in Pawtucket, R.I., offered to buy Tonka's outstanding stock for $7 a share. Enough Tonka shares were tendered, and Hasbro is only awaiting acceptance of its offer to buy outstanding debt to complete the takeover. Hasbro had set a deadline of midnight Monday for tender of subordinated debt. At Tonka's request, Hasbro extended the deadline to 8 A.M. April 9. The extension is the last one that Tonka may request under the terms of the merger agreement.

title: Review/Theater; Feeling of Life Imperiled From One Who Knows
description: In 1984, in the process of collaborating with Sam Shepard on a one-man play entitled "The War in Heaven," Joseph Chaikin had a stroke. As a result, he was left in a state of aphasia, which put the continuation of his career as an actor and director in jeopardy. Despite that fact, he returned to performing, currently in a double bill of monologues -- the completed version of "The War in Heaven" and "Struck Dumb," written with Jean-Claude van Itallie.

title: Feeling the Time Is Right, Burnett Enters East Europe
description: LEO BURNETT is expected to announce today that it will be the latest, if not one of the last, of the country's largest agencies to open offices in Eastern Europe.

title: Movies On the Brain
description: The Academy Awards put me in mind of movies. Here are some thoughts that movies put me in mind of while watching them, usually on a VCR years after everybody else has seen them:

title: Careers; Recruiters Expand Into Outplacement
description: CONFUSION, growing competition and even financial problems abound in two career-oriented service businesses, management recruiting and outplacement. This affects another group, management consulting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The focus has shifted to cocaine and crack to the extent of ignoring alcohol, the No. 1 drug of addiction in this country." -- Betty Ford, testifying at a Congressional hearing. [ A19:1. ]

title: Miss Austin Wed To Ziv Hellman
description: Carolyn Frances Austin, a daughter of Jan Higinbotham Austin and Craig L. Austin, both of San Antonio, was married yesterday in Israel to Ziv Zalman Hellman, a son of Gila S. Hellman of Forest Hills, Queens, and Dr. Marcel Hellman of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Arie Strikovsky officiated at the Shoresh Hotel in the Judean Hills. The bride, 26 years old, is a student at Nishmat, a center for Jewish women's studies in Jerusalem. A graduate of Rice University, she received a master of arts degree from the University of California at Irvine. Her father is a lawyer. Her mother is a counselor at Lackland Senior High School in San Antonio. Her stepmother, Lola Austin, is a psychologist.

title: Deduct Local Taxes From Federal Income Tax; Cut Capital Gains Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: No More Uncle Sucker
description: The Bush Administration is waging a desperate campaign to allow fast track consideration of the "free trade" agreement with Mexico and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It would forbid amendments by Congress and require an up-or-down vote within 30 days. What is it in these agreements that the Administration fears will not withstand scrutiny?

title: Vallone Has Alternative For Budget
description: The New York City Council, in its most ambitious challenge yet to Mayor David N. Dinkins, yesterday laid out its own blueprint for solving the city's worsening financial problems, cutting $400 million from proposed tax increases and slashing 30,000 jobs over the next four years.

title: Pennsylvania Ballet Pulls Back From Brink
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet will not suspend operations, as announced on March 11 by its trustees, a spokeswoman for the company, Luise Moskowitz, said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; One Big Not-So-Happy Family, Including Mistress
description: If one can believe the publicity material for the new Japanese comedy "Homemade Movie," Fumiki Watanabe has a lot in common with those American novelists whose love affairs, often with each other, are no sooner wrapped up than they appear in lightly fictionalized print.

title: Rematch Scheduled
description: Mike Tyson and Razor Ruddock will meet in June at the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., in a rematch of their controversial fight, Tyson's promoter, Don King announced, yesterday. The date will be announced by King and Ruddock's promoter, Murad Muhammad, at a news conference today. It's expected to be either June 22, 28 or 29.

title: Review/Music; Lessons Learned From the Young
description: Perhaps the best time to catch orchestra players is before they have quite turned into them. Routine has not set in. Office politics is undeveloped. Imaginations remain fresh and undamaged by overwork. Qualities like these make youth orchestras interesting diversions for the regular concertgoer.

title: A Scientific Watergate?
description: Five years after disturbing questions were raised about a research paper written in part by the Nobel laureate David Baltimore, the celebrated case is finally moving toward a verdict. Federal investigators have concluded, in a draft report, that the paper contained fraudulent data and did not accurately reflect the laboratory experiments on which it was supposedly based. Worse yet, data subsequently published by the Baltimore group to amend and justify its original paper were almost certainly fabricated.

title: Third World Seeks Advanced Arms
description: The deadly pounding that the West's military forces gave the Iraqis this year has whetted the appetite of third-world nations for advanced weapons, military analysts say. One result,, they say, could be a rapid advance in accuracy and technological sophistication of the developing world's military arsenals.

title: Key Rates
Court to Say If Cigarette Makers Can Be Sued for Smokers' Cancer
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether cigarette makers can be sued for failing to provide adequate warning of the dangers of smoking even though they provided warning labels required by Federal law.

title: Drought Still Threatens West Despite Storms, Report Says
description: Despite recent storms, severe drought continues to threaten much of the West, a Federal water expert said today.

title: Official Result in Benin Vote Shows Big Loss for Kerekou
description: Prime Minister Nicephore Soglo soundly defeated Brig. Gen. Mathieu Kerekou, the discredited former leader, in Benin's first presidential election in 21 years, official results released today indicated.

title: Archbishop Lefebvre, 85, Dies; Traditionalist Defied the Vatican
description: Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the traditionalist prelate whose defiance of Pope John Paul II caused the first schism in the Roman Catholic Church since 1870, died today in Martigny, Switzerland. He was 85 years old.

title: Big Kickoff for W.L.A.F., Come Rain or Come Shine
description: A rainstorm in Barcelona, Spain, that would have washed out soccer, the world's most popular sport, also came close to ruining the grand network television debut of the new World League of American Football.

title: Playoff Spot in Hand, Rangers Aim for First
description: The Rangers are looking to regain first place in the Patrick Division now that they have clinched a playoff spot and have prevented a losing streak from becoming their worst in 29 years.

title: Hussein Hiding Billions? Report Stirs Furor
description: News reports that Saddam Hussein had squirreled away billions of dollars in bank accounts around the world reverberated through business and diplomatic communities yesterday.

title: Library Gets New Yorker's Attic: Rejection, Excuses, Buttering Up
description: Five hundred dusty cartons filled with letters, manuscripts, fiction, commentary, punditry, puckishness and politesse have just been trucked from The New Yorker's offices to the New York Public Library. The cartons, which contain the magazine's archives from 1925 to 1980, have been deeded to the library for the future scrutiny of literary historians and other scholars.

title: Santucci's Ties to Police Strained by Indicting of 5
description: With the murder indictments of five police officers in the death of a suspect in their custody, the Queens District Attorney has once again jeopardized his rapport with the police.

title: Iranian Oil Exports Rise
description: Iran increased its oil exports by 23.2 percent in February, to an average of 2.7 million barrels a day, according to the Middle East Economic Survey. The industry news letter said today that Iran's February production of crude oil was 3.5 million barrels a day, up from 3 million barrels in January and down from 3.8 million barrels in December.

title: London Journal; A Veteran of the Great Tory Wars Exits No. 10
description: He was the Cardinal Richelieu of 10 Downing Street, a civil servant whose mastery of foreign affairs had made him so indispensable to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her successor, John Major, that in the end he become too notorious for his own good.

title: Jackson Status: Uncertain
description: Bo Jackson's agent said yesterday that his client remained uncertain about how quickly he would move to negotiate a contract with a new team. But the agent, Richard Woods, said that he received "a number of phone calls" from teams "expressing interest" in the free agent.

title: Lincoln Officer Pleads Guilty
description: A former vice president of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association pleaded guilty today to a fraud charge in connection with Lincoln's collapse.

title: INSIDE
description: Ban on Pesticide Urged Environmental Protection Agency scientists have recommended a ban on the sale of a pesticide widely used by American farmers. Page A20. Sale Days at S.& L. Agency Federal savings and loan regulators announced that they would sell some seized real estate at bargain prices and even give some away. Page D1. New York Police Reinstate 5 Citing Civil Service law, New York police officials reinstated five officers charged with killing a car-theft suspect. Page B1. Defiant Prelate Dies Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, excommunicated by Pope John Paul II, died at 85 in Switzerland. Page B8.

title: William (Billy) Butler, Jazz Guitarist, 66
description: William (Billy) Butler, a jazz guitarist who co-wrote the rhythm-and-blues instrumental classic "Honky Tonk," died on Wednesday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: The Fish's Mouth
description: Using a new technique to videotape the inside of a fish's mouth, biologists discovered that structures that were believed to capture food particles as they passed through the mouth instead channel food to the roof of the mouth.

title: Q&A
description: Infant Immunity

title: Two Offers to Bonilla
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates' president, Carl Barger, made two multiyear contract offers yesterday to Bobby Bonilla, but the outfielder said those were only a starting point, according to a published report.

title: Reviews/Music; Early Mozart by the Shanghai Quartet
description: With all the Mozart performances being offered around town this season, certain programs are bound to be the equivalent of historical footnotes. The Shanghai Quartet and the pianist Peter Frankl offered a particularly edifying footnote last Tuesday evening, when they collaborated on three of Mozart's early piano concertos in their versions for piano and string quartet.

title: Microsoft Expects Sales to Rise
description: Sales of computer software based on the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 3.0 program are expected to rise 150 percent, to 3.8 million units, in 1991. Microsoft said a study by the International Data Corporation forecast an additional 100 percent increase, to 7.7 million units in 1992.

title: Tape Shows Controller Calm After Fiery Runway Collision
description: In the minutes after a collision that killed 34 people aboard two aircraft here last month, the air traffic controller who had cleared both planes to use the same runway continued calmly directing other flights to take off and land, a recording released here today shows.

title: Harrelson Says Mets' Hits Will Come
description: "With this offense, I don't have to create anything," said Bud Harrelson, the manager of the Mets. "I have an offense that I can just cross my arms on the bench and watch go. It's going to click."

title: A Japanese Airline Duel in the U.S.
description: It took 20 years for Akio Kondo to persuade some of Japan's most cautious, competition-averse bureaucrats to allow All Nippon Airways to fly overseas. When they reluctantly agreed, it took another five years for Mr. Kondo, A.N.A.'s president and chief executive, to muster a direct challenge to his corporate nemesis, Japan Airlines.

title: Samuelson to Compete
description: Former Olympic champion Joan Benoit Samuelson, fresh from a victory in her first outing in five months, has decided to enter next month's Boston Marathon, race organizers said yesterday. Samuelson won a 15-kilometer run in Cincinnati Sunday in her first race since winning a similar run in Toronto last October.

title: Cut-Down Station May Fall Short on Space Biology
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN story of the space age, untold by laconic astronauts schooled to set aside emotion and play down danger, is just how bad weightlessness can be.

title: Books of The Times; Out of the Shadows: A Life of Dickens's Mistress
description: The Invisible Woman The Story of Nelly Ternan and Charles Dickens By Claire Tomalin Illustrated. 317 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * American Municipal Term Trust Inc., Minneapolis, is offering 7.5 million common shares at $10 a share through Piper Capital Management Inc. * Applied Immune Sciences Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 2.3 million common shares through Montgomery Securities. The offering price is expected to be between $10 and $12 a share. * Chipcom Corp., Southborough, Mass., has filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of 1.55 million common shares through Montgomery Securities. The offering price is expected to be between $10 and $12 a share. * Hanger Orthopedic Group Inc., Bethesda, Md., has filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of three million common shares through Paine Webber Inc. * Home Depot Inc., Atlanta, has filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of six million common shares through First Boston Corp. * Medimmune Inc., Gaithersburg, Md., has filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of 2.5 million common shares through Morgan Stanley & Co. The offering price is expected to be between $8.50 and $10 a share. * Reliable Life Insurance Co., St. Louis, is offering to buy 400,000 of its class A common shares at $30 a share. Shares of the company's class B common stock, which are convertible into class A shares on the basis of 10 class B shares for one class A share, will also be accepted for conversion to class A shares. * Ross Systems Inc., Redwood City, Calif., has filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of 2.75 million common shares through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. The offering price is expected to be between $8 and $9.50 a share. * U.S. Bioscience Inc., West Conshohocken, Pa., has filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of two million common shares through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. RATINGS * Beneficial Corp.'s senior debt has been raised to A-2, from A-3, by Moody's Investors Service. The financial services company is based in Wilmington, Del. * Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co.'s senior debt has been lowered to BB, from BBB-, by Standard & Poor's Corp. The company is based in Akron, Ohio. * Kansas City Power and Light Co.'s senior secured debt has been raised to A, from A-, and its senior unsecured debt has been raised to A-, from BBB+, by S.&P. The company is based in Kansas City, Mo. * Reebok International Ltd.'s senior debt has been lowered to Baa-1, from A-3, by Moody's. The athletic footwear company is based in Stoughton, Mass.

title: Police Kill Bronx Holdup Suspect
description: An armed-robbery suspect was shot and killed by the police yesterday evening on a street in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Under Ultrahigh Pressure, Exotic Materials Emerge
description: USING diamonds as vices and cannons as mashers, scientists are squeezing matter into exotic forms presumed to exist in the depths of planets, some of which may find important commercial applications in high-temperature superconducting devices and other innovations.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a front-page picture from Reuters on March 16, about the indictment of four Los Angeles police officers in the beating of a black motorist, misidentified two of the men shown. John D. Barnett, a lawyer for Officer Ted Briseno, was at center; Michael P. Stone, a lawyer for Officer Laurence Powell, was at right.

title: Business Nod For Weicker On Tax Plan
description: Three of Connecticut's largest business lobbying groups said today that they would support Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan to impose a state income tax if other taxes paid by business were reduced and legal limits were put on state spending.

title: Rebuff to Plea By Older Pilots
description: The Supreme Court today rejected the latest challenge to the 32-year-old Federal rule barring people over the age of 60 from serving as pilots on large commercial airplanes.

title: Cummins Factory To Reopen in 1992
description: The Cummins Engine Company will reopen its Walesboro plant in southern Indiana next year and create about 500 jobs there by 1993. The plant will add to production of the B Series engine, a midrange diesel.

title: Raiders Sign Lott To Two-Year Contract
description: All-Pro free safety Ronnie Lott, left unprotected by the San Francisco 49ers, signed with the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday as a Plan B free agent. It was believed Lott signed a two-year contract at slightly more than $1 million per year.

title: Five Officers Facing Trial Are Reinstated
description: The New York City Police Department said yesterday that it was reinstating five officers who had been suspended without pay only last week after they were indicted in Queens on charges of murdering a car-theft suspect.

title: Kansas' Williams: A Mirror Image
description: Dean Smith, the North Carolina coach, said he never suspected that Roy Williams, his former assistant and now the Kansas coach, backed off when the two have played golf together.

title: Giving Machines Their Own Voices
description: WHEN a computer talks, people listen. No matter if its voice is a bit odd and tinny, with an occasional mispronunciation or inappropriate intonation.

title: A Mussel's Genetics Break Inheritance Rules
description: BIOLOGISTS have discovered that a mussel violates a widespread assumption of genetic inheritance.

title: Talk in Jerusalem
description: Inside Israel's Cabinet, some of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's most important ministers are talking to him about trying a kind of do-it-yourself distancing plan for Israelis and Palestinian Arabs.

title: Bahrain Official Gives Outline Of a Regional Accord for Gulf
description: Bahrain's Foreign Minister said today that an overall "security arrangement" would be negotiated to insure a permanent military presence by Western and friendly Arab countries in the gulf region.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Besides its fuzzy title, "Advice From a Caterpillar" offers another oddity: EDGAR LANSBURY directs his son DAVID LANSBURY in the play, which begins previews tonight at the Lucille Lortel Theater in Greenwich Village.

title: U.S. Securities Decline in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose slightly in light trading yesterday, despite a report from auto makers that does little to buttress arguments of a postwar rebound in consumer spending.

title: Toshiba Develops Small Telephone
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it had developed the world's smallest portable telephone. It said its model was lighter than those sold by the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, Fujitsu Ltd. and the Oki Electric Industry Company. Toshiba also said its model runs longer. Batteries provide 65 minutes of continuous talk compared with 48 minutes for Mitsubishi's model, a spokesman said.

title: Equitable Life Names An Investment Head
description: When Brian F. Wruble takes over as chief investment officer for the nation's third-largest life insurance company on April 1, he will help to invest assets that are roughly equal in value to the economy of the former East Germany.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Amazon Forest Loss Is Sharply Cut in Brazil
description: FOREST rangers were murdered, and sugar was poured in the fuel tanks of patrol helicopters during the Amazon's fractious "burning season," but the deforestation rate dropped sharply last year, according to new figures gathered by satellites.

title: Olympic Unit Optimistic on South Africa
description: A visiting delegation from the International Olympic Committee met for more than an hour in Cape Town today with President F. W. de Klerk, whose policy of dismantling apartheid has raised hopes here that South African athletes may be welcomed back into international competition in time for the 1992 Olympics.

title: In Vietnam, a Chance for Friendship Beckons
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Literary Groups Win $270,000 in Grants
description: The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund yesterday announced $270,000 in grants for two New York-based literary organizations.

title: New York Social Clubs Safer, but Problems Linger
description: A year after an arson fire killed 87 people in the illegal Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx, New York City has succeeded in shutting down or forcing owners to meet safety rules at the vast majority of unsafe clubs in the five boroughs.

title: Gasoline Prices Climb Slightly
description: Gasoline prices rose slightly in the last two weeks in expectation of higher demand during the spring, an industry survey found.

title: Syrian Official Voices Doubt Hussein Will Survive Revolts in Iraq
description: Syria's Foreign Minister said today that he doubted that President Saddam Hussein could survive as ruler of Iraq and expressed confidence that the Iraqi opposition would be able to form a new government.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Euro Disneyland, the $4.4 billion theme park being built east of Paris in a venture 49 percent owned by the Walt Disney Company, completed a $670 million financing today that experts said was one of the largest loan placements made during the Persian Gulf crisis.

title: New Orleans Journal; Is Park Saved by Destroying a Part?
description: Even in New Orleans, which dotes on ec centricity, the Piazza d'Italia stands out. Completed 13 years ago, the small rundown park is the quirkiest public place in America's quirkiest city.

title: I.B.M.'s 7-Pound Laptop
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation is unveiling a new laptop computer called the PS/2 L40SX today. The company gave a sneak preview of the machine earlier this month at the giant CeBIT Hanover Fair in Germany and has been testing it with students at the Harvard Business School.

title: Australian Gets Jail
description: The former managing director of a failed western Australian finance company, Rothwells Ltd., was sent to jail today in connection with its collapse.

title: Dinkins Covers Range of Issues With O'Connor
description: For the first time since Mayor David N. Dinkins's march with a gay Irish group in the St. Patrick's Day Parade threw church-state differences into a periodic moment of prominence, Mr. Dinkins held a long-planned meeting with John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday on a range of topics.

title: PRESIDENT OF MALI REPORTED ARRESTED
description: The President of the West African nation of Mali for more than 20 years, was arrested today by soldiers from his own army amid widespread rioting and heavy gunfire in the capital, Bamako, witnesses here reported.

title: U.S. Proposes Change in Air Reservations
description: The Transportation Department proposed rules today that would seek to make airline computer reservation systems fairer to consumers, travel agents and small carriers.

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of events in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday included an incorrect telephone number for information about an exhibition by the Photographers of Northern Westchester in Croton-on-Hudson. The number is (914) 271-3607.

title: DEADLY PESTICIDE MAY FACE U.S. BAN
description: Scientists at the Environmental Protection Agency have recommended a ban on the sale of one of the most poisonous pesticides used in American agriculture, and the agency said today that it would soon decide whether to ban the compound in the United States.

title: Duke Deflecting a Horrible Memory
description: Another spring, another Final Four for Duke. The problem is: another matchup with Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: Physicists Pondering How Antiapples Fall
description: A QUESTION has been bothering physicists for years: does gravity act in the same way on antimatter as on matter? Put another way, would an antiapple fall from an antitree at the same velocity as Newton's legendary apple? Or would the antiapple fall up instead of down?

title: Heart Bypass Data Yield Surprise
description: SCIENTISTS conducting a long-term study of coronary bypass surgery have turned up an unexpected finding. In the patients they studied, the surgery did not reduce the number of heart attacks but over all it did improve patients' chances of surviving them.

title: Market Place; Gillette Getting Vote of Confidence
description: ALFRED M. ZEIEN, who took over as the chairman of the Gillette Company two months ago after Colman Mockler Jr. died of a heart attack at age 61, says his style may be different than Mr. Mockler's but his agenda is the same -- notably, to start turning a profit on Gillette's hot-selling Sensor shaving system.

title: Prices Cut For Assets Of S.& L.'s
description: Armed with $30 billion in new cash for the savings and loan bailout, Federal regulators announced today that they would sell at bargain basement prices some real estate that has already been seized.

title: Review/Pop; Keely Smith Brings Her Lyrics Up to Date
description: Many singers over the years have updated the lyrics of the Vernon Duke-Ira Gershwin standard, "I Can't Get Started," but few have personalized it quite as pointedly as Keely Smith, who sang the song at last Tuesday's opening night performance of her two-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza). "I was instructed by Louis P./Frank Sinatra has had me to tea," sang Miss Smith, who was divorced from her show business partner, Louis Prima, in 1962. Her revised lyric also incorporated references to Robert Mitchum, Clint Eastwood and Las Vegas.

title: Little-Known Carlyle Scores Big
description: For weeks, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia pondered the notion of spending a spare half-billion dollars. Then last month, on the recommendation of American advisers, he used the money to buy up a sizable piece of America's largest banking company, Citicorp.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Posts $9.3 Million Pretax Loss
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company said yesterday that it had a pretax loss of $:5.2 million, or $9.3 million, for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: U.S. Condemns Deportations in Gaza
description: The State Department today denounced Israel's plans to deport four Palestinians from the Gaza Strip, saying that the move was damaging to United States efforts toward Arab-Israeli reconciliation and that Israel should not do it.

title: Review/Fashion; Plaids for Fall: Familiar Faces But New Styles
description: Paris is off on a Highland fling. The tartan plaid is the unifying element that gives cohesion to the fall and winter showings of such diverse designers as Jean-Paul Gaultier and Vivienne Westwood on the wild side and Hubert de Givenchy and Hermes on the sober edge of fashion.

title: Resales Of Homes Jump by 7.9%
description: Sales of existing homes shot up 7.9 percent in February, the first increase since November and the biggest in nearly five years, giving private economists hope that a housing rebound may be heralding the end of the recession.

title: Actors' Equity to File Grievance for Redgrave
description: Actors' Equity has decided to file a grievance with the League of American Theaters and Producers on behalf of Vanessa Redgrave in her dispute with the producers of the national tour of "Lettice and Lovage."

title: Margaret Judson, 91, Historian and Author
description: Margaret Atwood Judson, a historian, educator and author, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Piscataway, N.J. She was 91years old and lived in Highland Park, N.J.

title: In Justice Dept. of the 90's, Focus Shifts From Rights
description: After a decade of Republican stewardship, the Justice Department has grown in manpower and budget but has lost its pre-eminence as the driving force for social change and the center of legal thinking in the Government.

title: F.A.A. Has to Do More for Aircraft Safety; Sprinkler System
description: To the Editor:

title: New Harvard Chief Sends a Strong Signal on Reorganization
description: Neil L. Rudenstine, who was chosen Sunday as Harvard University's new president, plans to create a powerful post of provost to help him oversee academic affairs, which would represent a major reorganization of Harvard's administration.

title: Brett's Fading Friends: It's All in the Game
description: George Brett has watched the scene play out time and time again: A player with tears or anger in his eyes stops by the clubhouse just long enough to remove the vestiges of his stay with a team, or worse, the remnants of a career, from his locker.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock * Medical Marketing Group Inc., a subsidiary of Medco Containment Services Inc., Fair Lawn, N.J., is making an initial public offering of 3.2 million common shares at $12.50 a share through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Amsco International Inc., Pittsburgh, is making an initial public offering of 5.85 million common shares at $14 a share through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc.

title: Rochester Utility
description: The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation said the damage caused by a large ice storm in upstate New York earlier this month would cost it at least $25 million to repair and would cut first-quarter earnings by as much 7 cents a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the utility said the storm destroyed about half of its electrical transmission and distribution system, cutting power to more than 200,000 customers.

title:
Real Estate;
Older Project In New Jersey Rejuvenated
description: THE Plaza Complex, a late-1960's office development at the southern tip of New Brunswick's downtown, is among the earliest projects that led to the transformation of the commercial district from a huddle of aging storefronts and littered lots into a thriving business hub. Now the old complex is undergoing its own rejuvenation to remain competitive in today's soft office market.

title: Language of Love
description: To The Living Section:

title: Newman To Endow New Chair
description: Joanne Woodward was already a celebrated actress when, 10 years ago, she started down the path toward earning her bachelor's degree at Sarah Lawrence College. She graduated with the class of 1990. And as a college trustee since 1986, she had also nudged the small liberal arts institution to be more active on issues concerning the environment, human rights and poverty.

title: In Time for Knitwear Revival, Get Out the Missonis!
description: FROM the classic twin sweater sets of the 1940's to the pyschedelic patterns of the 1960's to the message T-shirts of the 1980's, knitted clothes move regularly in and out of fashion, occupying varying degrees of importance at different times.

title: Refinery Closing Outrages Mexican Workers
description: A week after this city's largest oil refinery was abruptly shut down to ease a critical pollution crisis, the reasons for that decision still linger in the air.

title: Books of The Times; They Wanted Their Rights, and They Got Them
description: Free at Last? The Civil Rights Movement and the People Who Made It By Fred Powledge Illustrated. 711 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $29.95.

title: Big 3 Set Up Pollution Study
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that they had formed a joint research project to study the environmental effects of automobile emissions and manufacturing.

title: For Sicilians Fighting the Mafiosi, Life Is a Trial
description: It has reached the point at Sicily's centuries-old Ucciardone Prison that some say it might not be a bad idea to install a revolving door. That way at least the mafiosi would not have to strain themselves unduly as they go in and out.

title: New Post For Andre Bishop Likely
description: Andre Bishop, the artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, is expected to be named tomorrow to succeed Gregory Mosher as director of Lincoln Center Theater, an official of the theater said yesterday. Mr. Bishop would take over the job at the beginning of 1992.

title: Review/Film; The Pitcher of Spilled Milk as Featured Player
description: It is indeed possible to analyze an idea to death, as is demonstrated by "L'Ange," a highly experimental film by Patrick Bokanowski that opens today at the Film Forum. It is also possible to devote wildly inappropriate degrees of effort to hair-splitting on a minuscule scale. In "L'Ange," Mr. Bokanowski devises very specific images and then repeats and dissects them, altering tiny aspects of lighting, scale and proportion each time, sometimes multiplying motion and sometimes reversing it altogether. The painterly precision with which this has been done does not mask the futility of the exercise.

title: Some Help By Haley Boosts Nets To Victory
description: Jack Haley is the Nets' unofficial cheerleader and their occasional enforcer.

title: Down by Three Goals, Rangers Rally to Tie
description: With help from Mike Richter's inspiring goaltending and Mike Gartner's two goals, the Rangers rallied from a three-goal deficit for a 3-3 deadlock against the Devils last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Peter Dean Forsch; Executive, 72
description: Peter Dean Forsch, a retired vice president and former director of marketing services for the Nestle Company USA, died on Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: Dodgers Sign Carter
description: Gary Carter won a job with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday when the catcher agreed to a one-year contract worth approximately $500,000. Carter, a 16-year major league veteran, will be used primarily as a pinch-hitter. He had been invited to spring training as a nonroster player.

title: Outspoken M.T.A. Board Is Rubber Stamp No More
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, long considered a rubber stamp for its chairman and the agencies the board oversees, is trying to assert itself as the guardian of the region's mass-transit systems.

title: Top Yield 7.274% For Utility Agency
description: The South Carolina Public Service Authority tentatively priced $373.7 million in tax-exempt revenue and refunding bonds yesterday. The top yield of 7.274 percent was for the 7 percent issue due in 2022, offered at 96.625. The underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Eating Well
description: FAT is king of the hill: it has toppled cholesterol, calcium and fiber as the health obsession of the moment. For any who might doubt this, a stroll down the supermarket aisles will reveal lots of products that claim to be fat free or low in fat.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: An Image Maker Quits Politics
description: With political consultants facing increasing scrutiny from the public, the press and from Government officials over the advertising they create, one of the field's most prominent image makers has decided to drop out of the business.

title: Shadow and Substance at the Oscars
description: Perhaps the producers had called in the wardrobe police. None of the women wore dresses that had them popping out at the top and straining the seams at the bottom, and all the men were too plain for Las Vegas -- except for Jeff Bridges, who was wearing a kind of double-decker shirt and something that was maybe a vest and maybe not.

title: Catholic Study Finds Press Tilting Against Church
description: A study sponsored by two Roman Catholic groups says that in covering the church major news organizations give greater emphasis to critics than to supporters of church teachings.

title: HUNGRY CHILDREN PUT AT 5.5 MILLION
description: A field network of researchers estimated today that 5.5 million people under 12 years of age were hungry in the United States.

title: Ismail Considers C.F.L.
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, expected to be the first player taken in the National Football League draft next month, is considering a $6 million, two-year offer to play for the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League, his agent said yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: When the famous Emile Peynaud put away his test tubes and tasting cup for good two years ago, it was commonly believed that the era of the celebrity enologist was over. No way. In the Medoc, these days, if Michel Rolland hasn't been sniffing your barrels recently, you are definitely out of the loop.

title: Computer Hands the Pen a New Setback
description: The computer age is taking another nibble out of the domain of the old-fashioned ballpoint pen. The United Parcel Service, the nation's largest package delivery service, is equipping its drivers with a new handheld computer that has an electronic stylus. Instead of signing a piece of paper with a pen, recipients will be asked to acknowledge getting their packages by using the pen-shaped nylon stylus to inscribe their signature directly on a sensitive membrane embedded in the computer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES BROWN is back. The singer, released from prison in South Carolina Feb. 27, has not appeared in public for two years. On June 10 he is to appear in a pay-per-view television show at the Wiltern Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Keefe Keeps Stanford on Course
description: Adam Keefe, a red-haired Stanford junior with shoulders about as broad as Kevin McHale's, will play center for the Cardinal tonight against Oklahoma in the championship game of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Neta Snook Southern; Aviator, 95
description: Neta Snook Southern, an aviator who helped Amelia Earhart learn to fly, died Saturday at her home here. She was 95 years old.

title: Rifle Lobby Torn by Dissidents and Capitol Defectors
description: With new gun control legislation pending in both the House and the Senate, the National Rifle Association is in the grip of internal turmoil and there are signs that it may be losing some of its effectiveness as one of the nation's most powerful lobbying organizations.

title: In Central Park, Hell on Wheels
description: With spring comes warm weather, longer days and the impulse to spend our weekends in Central Park. It's the closest thing we have to an Arcadian wilderness -- a place where we can forget about life in the fast lane and enjoy life in the slow lane or, better yet, no lane at all.

title: High Court, 5 to 4, Softens Stand Against Confession by Coercion
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today that the use of a coerced confession in a criminal trial does not automatically invalidate a conviction.

title: Armand C. Litman, 62, Oil-Industry Engineer
description: Armand C. Litman, a certified public accountant and an oil-drilling engineer, died on Saturday while walking in Aberdeen, Scotland, where he was vacationing. He was 62 years old and lived in London.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified a Rochester television station in which the Gillett Group was selling an interest. It is WOKR-TV.

title: Pavarotti to Sing In a Concert 'Otello'
description: Luciano Pavarotti and Kiri Te Kanawa will appear with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in concert performances of "Otello" on April 16 and 19 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMITTEE ON NATURAL RESOURCES -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Emir Disparaged at Kuwaiti Forums
description: In a sumptuous room lined with velvet chairs, its marble floor covered with an enormous blue-and-white Persian rug, the Crown Prince of Kuwait received his family's subjects tonight, as he has frequently these days.

title: Family Cannot Be Evicted Because of One's Drug Sale
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that a family of 18 living together in a three-bedroom apartment in a Brooklyn housing project could not be evicted solely because one of them sold drugs from the home.

title: Knicks Play Well Early Against Spurs but Fail in Overtime
description: The Knicks finished their discouraging Texas road trip 0 for 3 tonight.

title: Jacob Geist, 70, Dies; Was Expert on Gases
description: Jacob Myer Geist, a chemical engineer who was an international authority on the liquefaction and separation of gases, died Friday at his home in Allentown, Pa. He was 70 years old.

title: The Oscar Winners
description: Here is a complete list of the 1991 Academy Awards, presented Monday night in Los Angeles: Picture: "Dances With Wolves" (Orion) Director: Kevin Costner, "Dances With Wolves"

title: Japan Acts to Ease Rice Rift
description: Japanese officials will visit the United States this week to try to soothe American anger over the Japanese ban on rice imports.

title: Veterans Deserve Simple Justice on Claims; Mortgage Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate on New York Police Board Heats Up While Complaints Fall
description: New Yorkers are filing far fewer complaints alleging police brutality and misconduct, but this trend has intensified rather than dissolved the debate about brutality and the board that investigates it.

title: After War, Holy Seasons Are Indeed Celebrations
description: A LONG with thousands of Americans in the military, Capt. Terry L. Whiteside was in Saudi Arabia for Thanksgiving and Christmas. And, his family is eager to add, for the birthdays of his wife and two sons. But Captain Whiteside is home for Easter and he (and everyone around him) is ecstatic.

title: Frank Donaldson, 71; Built Filtration Systems
description: Frank A. Donaldson, retired chairman and former chief executive of the Donaldson Company, manufacturer of air filtration systems, died Saturday at his home in Carefree, Ariz. He was 71 years old and also lived in Excelsior, Minn.

title: LACROSSE: Notebook; Syracuse Isn't So Mighty Right Now
description: In this new collegiate lacrosse season, Syracuse has already rejoined the mortals. After three straight national championships fueled by the remarkable but departed Gait twins from Canada, the Orangemen are now just another team, albeit a good one.

title: Helen L. Haskell; Administrator, 90
description: Helen Lacey Haskell, a camp administrator who was active in civic affairs, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: A Rebel Kurd Leader Vows to Fight On
description: A Kurdish rebel leader returned to a tumultuous welcome today in his people's historic homeland, and he told thousands of cheering guerrillas that their fight would go on until "the whole of Iraq is liberated."

title: British Hope Ulster Talks Will Start Before May
description: The British Government said today that it hoped that political negotiations on the future of Northern Ireland would begin by the end of April and said they would last up to three months.

title: February Durables Orders Down
description: Orders for long-lasting goods like cars and refrigerators weakened in February in an economy that was troubled by recession and war, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Four Hijackers Die in a Raid By Commandos in Singapore
description: Government commandos stormed a hijacked Singapore Airlines jet at the airport here today and all four hijackers are dead, a Government spokesman said.

title: Record of Call in Love Triangle
description: An MCI engineer testified today that the telephone company has the computer tape that recorded a call from Carolyn Warmus's home to a New Jersey gun shop.

title: Robert Satiacum, 62, Fugitive Tribal Figure
description: Robert Satiacum, a former Indian tribal leader who spent much of his last years as a fugitive from justice, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at a Vancouver hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: John Chaney Teaches A Lesson
description: There are four very good coaches in the Final Four, but I can't help wishing we could bring along John Chaney of Temple University as an attitude adjuster.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IT is interesting to look at old cookbooks to see how taste preferences change. I was leafing through a copy of Escoffier published by Crown in 1941 and looked up ham. There were 32 recipes for ham, including cured ham a la chanoinesse (braised ham with truffles and noodles tossed in butter and pureed onions), mousse of ham, cold souffle of ham and ham smoked over ashes.

title: Failure of S.& L. in California Could Save a Redwood Forest
description: The collapse of a California savings and loan institution may have an unexpected dividend: the preservation of the largest forest of redwood trees left in private hands.

title: About New York; Giving Dignity To the Poorest, Once, Forever
description: "What amazes me is the number of people who are alone in this world," John Leonard said.

title: USX Write-Down
description: The USX Corporation, the energy and steel concern, said it would take a $350 million pretax charge against first-quarter earnings, close some businesses and try to sell some energy holdings. The company's USS division said it would permanently close some iron and steel operations as well as a pipe mill later this year.

title: Fitch Ratings Agency Gives Warning on G.M. and Ford
description: Fitch Investors Serviceei, expressing concern about the profitability of the nation's two largest auto makers, said today that it might reduce the senior debt ratings of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation.

title: BUDGET RISE CITED IN OCCUPIED LANDS
description: The Israeli group Peace Now published a study today asserting that the Government budgeted more than $500 million during the current fiscal year on settlements in the occupied territories and related expenses.

title: Albany Forces Shutdown Of Family Barge Companies
description: Oil and sludge-barge businesses described by New York State as the worst polluters of New York Harbor were permanently shut down yesterday, and the president of the companies said they were for sale.

title: Arming the New Order
description: Wouldn't it be ironic if the resounding defeat of Iraq, led by the high-tech forces of the U.S., resulted in a third world newly armed to the teeth with smart bombs, ballistic and cruise missiles, helicopter gunships, Patriot-style interceptors and radar-invisible aircraft?

title: Help Iraq Save Itself
description: The idea that a weakened Saddam Hussein, or one of his cohorts, can ultimately hold Iraq together is a pipe dream. Taken as allied policy, this assumption is a license from the victors for the continued butchery of the Iraqi people.

title: The Food of Spring Returns (Anyone See It Go?)
description: LIKE a promising grin, spring slides across the United States. The tight grimace of winter warms and loosens first in Key West and moves north to widen across the Mississippi delta.
