The season tickles both coasts, moving in the East up past Charleston and Baltimore to New York and then Bangor, in the West past Houston and Phoenix and San Francisco toward Seattle.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is tentatively offering $231.2 million in correctional facilities revenue bonds. The bonds, offered through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc., have a maximum yield of 7.95 percent for an issue due in 2019.

title: S.E.C., Firm In a Clash Over Stock
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Morgan Stanley & Company squared off yesterday for a legal battle. The commission charged that Morgan improperly sold certain restricted stock during the 1987 market crash, and the investment house replied that the commission's action could undermine the marketplace.

title: First City's Board to Decide Fate of the Bank's Chairman
description: Directors of the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas are expected to decide at a special meeting on Wednesday whether to remove A. Robert Abboud as chairman and chief executive. He has controlled the bank holding company since a Government-assisted bailout three years ago.

title: Spring Offerings to Enthrall Armchair Cooks and Travelers
description: FROM Greece to China, by way of Ireland and the Caribbean, American cooks are becoming culinary armchair travelers while travelers may well be turning into armchair cooks, if the current crop of cookbooks is anything to go by. More than collections of recipes, the best of these new books also inform us about other places, other people and often other times.

title: Burton G. Tremaine, Executive, 89, Dies; A Collector of Art
description: Burton G. Tremaine, a noted art collector and an industrial executive, died on Saturday at his winter home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 89 years old and also lived in Madison, Conn.

title: Asbestos-Lined Pipe Bursts; 2 Worker Is Hurt in Midtown
description: Stores in one of New York City's busiest retail areas were evacuated and seven blocks were closed to traffic when an asbestos-lined steam pipe ruptured on East 58th Street yesterday afternoon.

title: Henry A. Truslow, 77; Was Textile Executive
description: Henry A. Truslow Jr., a textile manufacturing executive who retired in 1978 as a vice president of Westpoint Pepperell, died yesterday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 77 years old and lived in Saco, Me.

title: For Top Utility Official, A Post on the Railroad
description: George W. Edwards Jr., who led the United Illuminating Company through its most difficult years as an owner of the troubled Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, will join the Kansas City Southern Railway Company next month.

title: Chardonnays Are Dominant In New York Wine Contest
description: REFLECTING the prevailing preferences in wines, chardonnays dominated New York State's principal wine contest last Saturday. Although none took first, second and third prizes, five chardonnays finished among the nine Governor's Cup finalists in the New York Wine and Food Classic.

title: World Cup Pact For Mastercard
description: Mastercard International said yesterday that it would spend $60 million to $75 million over the next four years as part of a sponsorship agreement of with the World Cup, the soccer championship that will be held in several cities throughout the United States in 1994. It will be the first time the championship has been played in the United States.

title: Review/Film Festival; 3 French Sisters and the End of an Era
description: Brigitte Rouan's film "Outremer" brings a Jane Austen-like sensibility to the story of three sisters living in Algeria during the final years of French colonial rule. The movie's opening scenes, set in the late 1940's, present a romantic picture of French colonial life in the days before the nationalist uprising that eventually drove a million Europeans to leave the country. It is a vision that the director, who also co-wrote the film and who plays one of the sisters, spends the rest of the movie demolishing in a story that is subtly colored with Marxist and feminist overtones.

title: Hialeah Mayor Guilty Of Selling His Influence
description: A jury in Federal District Court today found Mayor Raul Martinez of the Miami suburb of Hialeah guilty of racketeering and extortion in the sale of his votes and influence on zoning matters in return for about $1 million in cash or property from developers.

title: Herbert Carr; Political Leader, 70
description: Herbert Carr, former chairman of the Nassau County Liberal Party, died on Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Manhasset. He was 70 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Senate Committee Criticizes, Then Approves M.T.A. Nominee
description: The State Senate Transportation Committee removed the final obstacles today to the approval of Peter E. Stangl to head the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The panel chided him for allowing a friend to operate a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train but said the incident was not serious enough to deny him the post.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Drop in Yield for 4th Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the fourth consecutive week in the period ended yesterday.

title: U.N. Security Council Drafts Plan To Scrap Most Deadly Iraqi Arms
description: The five permanent Security Council members are close to agreement on a plan to end the gulf war that is the most complex and ambitious effort the United Nations has ever made to settle a war and punish an aggressor.

title: Lone Star Steel Bankruptcy Plan
description: A bankruptcy judge approved the reorganization plan of the Lone Star Steel Company, its parent company, Lone Star Technologies Inc., said. The plan will become effective in early April, it said, ending the bankruptcy case the steel subsidiary began in June 1989.

title: Banc One Won't Make Bid
description: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it would not, as had been expected, bid for the banks of the failed Bank of New England Corporation. It cited the weak state of the New England economy as the reason for its decision.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I didn't know she would be that huge; we should have one in Warsaw." -- President Lech Walesa at the Statue of Liberty. [ B2:4. ]

title: Court Rules on Bias And S.& L. Controls
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the provision of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 that bars discrimination in employment does not apply to Americans working overseas for American corporations. It said Congress had indicated no such intent.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about lawsuits against the developer Peter S. Kalikow listed some parties erroneously among those involved. The First National Bank of Chicago and tenants of 101 Park Avenue in New York are not among those suing Mr. Kalikow. The headline also misstated the amount of money involved in bank lawsuits. It is $41 million, not $60 million.

title: Schwarzkopf Says Truce Enabled Iraqis to Escape
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf says that he recommended to President Bush last month to "continue the march" into Iraq to annihilate Iraq's armed forces, but that as a result of the Feb. 27 cease-fire ordered by Mr. Bush significant elements of Iraq's Army and Republican Guard escaped across the Euphrates River and into Basra.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about a letter from President Bush to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev referred incorrectly in some editions to Jack F. Matlock Jr. He is Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

title: Airlines' $1 Billion Loss
description: The world's airlines lost more than $1 billion last month, mostly because of the Persian Gulf war, according to the International Air Transport Association. The 200-member airline group had reported a $1 billion shortfall for January. European airlines accounted for nearly two-thirds of the loss and nearly 60 percent of all flight cancellations. Some 21,400 flights, 6 percent of scheduled traffic, were canceled worldwide in February. Traffic on Middle East carriers was down by half compared with February 1990, as the airlines canceled 38 percent of their flights to the region.

title: Health Care: Drowning in Paper
description: Washington wags say there are 60 million Americans struggling with Medicare -- the 30 million people over 65 who are eligible for Federal health insurance plus 30 million relatives and friends to help them untangle the paperwork.

title: F.A.A. Has to Do More for Aircraft Safety; Doors for Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Brady Sees No Bailout Of Banks
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that no taxpayer bailout of the nation's banks would be necessary if Congress approved the Administration's proposed banking legislation and if the economy avoided a complete collapse.

title: A.T.&T. Adds Fees For New Credit Cards
description: A.T.& T. said yesterday that new applicants for its Universal Card, a combination credit card and a telephone charge card, would receive less generous terms than those who had signed up since the card was introduced a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about high-pressure experiments misstated the atmospheric pressure at the earth's surface. It is one bar, not one megabar.

title: Boy, 12, Dies While Playing In Manhattan Elevator Shaft
description: A 12-year-old boy fell to his death last night while playing in an elevator shaft in the Lillian Wald Houses on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the housing police said.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Down-Home Rivalry Takes A Road Trip
description: The message scratched on a barroom wall, a few 3-point shots from Franklin Street and not far from the University of North Carolina campus, had originally been directed toward Saddam Hussein.

title: INSIDE
description: New York City Aid: Cuomo Warns Unions

title: Veterans Deserve Simple Justice on Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: THOMAS W. EVANS succeeds BARBARA F. GOODMAN as chairman of the trustees of Teachers College, Columbia University. Mr. Evans, 60, is a partner in the Manhattan law firm Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon. Mrs. Goodman is an alumna who had been chairman for 11 years. A graduate of Columbia School of Law, Mr. Evans has written a book on preschool education and founded a national symposium on education and the private sector.

title: F.A.A. Has to Do More for Aircraft Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Ties New York City Aid to Union Concessions
description: Injecting a new element into New York City's budget problems, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that the state might come forward with a major package of aid for the city, but only if the municipal labor unions agreed to make major concessions to the Dinkins administration.

title: Miscellany
description: * Wishner-Cody Corporate Communications Inc., New York, and Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, have formed a cooperative working relationship. Under the agreement, Wishner-Cody will assist Hill & Knowlton with sports marketing, management consulting and publishing projects. In return, Hill & Knowlton will provide Wishner-Cody with access to its resources in the international public relations field.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Associated Merchandising Corp., New York, a merchandise research organization, appointed Donna Barbieri to vice president-general merchandise manager of ready-to-wear fashions and Ebbie Flood Collins to divisional product and merchandising manager of designer, bridge and better sportswear and petite fashions. Soly Srour was also appointed to divisional vice president for production and sourcing. * Bank of Boston Corp., Boston, named Newton Merrill executive vice president and group executive of its national banking group.

title: Yankees Surprised by Lovullo's Success With His Bat
description: He arrived late, but Torey Lovullo is now a prominent piece of the Yankees' plans at third base. All it took was one very good game.

title: Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, a session highlighted by an auction of $11.5 billion of new two-year notes.

title: Economic Scene; Bailing Out Eastern Germany
description: GERMANY, where money talks and nobody walks, seems to have run out of economic miracles. Nine months after unification, the eastern provinces once known as the German Democratic Republic have tumbled into depression. With 30 percent of the labor force without full-time jobs and industrial production down by half, economic union threatens to become a black hole for taxpayers in western Germany.

title: China to Raise Arms Spending Again
description: China's leaders announced a sharp increase in military spending today, despite a rising budget deficit and economic challenges that will mean slower growth in the economy this year.

title: IN OTHER SECTIONS
description: STAYED HOME, AND ANGRY: A Georgia National Guard unit that spent the gulf war training in California feels it was shunted aside and branded a failure. Page A14.

title: Wife and Her Brother Charged in Soldier's Death
description: The wife and the brother-in-law of a soldier who was shot to death on a Detroit street last week, a day after he had returned here from the Persian Gulf war, were charged today with murdering him.

title: Jordan, McGrath Wins Jhirmack Hair Account
description: The Playtex Family Products Corp., Stamford, Conn., has awarded the $10 million advertising account for its Jhirmack hair-care products to Jordan, McGrath Case & Taylor Inc., New York.

title: Key Rates
Midway Enters Bankruptcy And Obtains a Line of Credit
description: Midway Airlines, the first large carrier to start flying after deregulation in 1979, filed yesterday for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Cooper, Nastase and Vilas Are Named to International Hall of Fame
description: A leading amateur of the 1950's and two professional stars of the 1970's were named yesterday to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Review/Theater; An 'Oresteia' Embracing Techniques From India, Japan and the Mideast
description: Ariane Mnouchkine remains one of the world's extraordinary theater directors, and her absence from the United States, New York in particular, remains one of the saddest indictments of America's inability to import major performing artistry from abroad.

title: Larry Johnson Honored
description: Senior forward Larry Johnson of Nevada-Las Vegas was named yesterday as the winner of the Eastman Award as college basketball's top player.

title: Food Notes
description: Easter Treats

title: Lemieux Scores Three As Penguins Top Flyers
description: Mario Lemieux provided all of Pittsburgh's offense with his 26th career hat trick as the Penguins took another step toward their first division title with a 3-1 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Contracts Under New Charter Receive Little Public Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Lets Japanese Concern Buy U.S. Company
description: A Federal District Court has blocked an attempt by the Justice Department to prevent the sale of an American high-technology company to a Japanese bidder. The American company plays a central role in the semiconductor industry's efforts to overtake Japanese rivals.

title: Accounts
description: * Elias Fragrances, a manufacturer of fragrance compounds, to I. Goldberg & Partners Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Actor Named In Tax Suit
description: Price Waterhouse sued Burt Reynolds and his production company last week for $103,895 that the accounting firm claimed it was owed for 1989 tax returns.

title: Katherine Z. W. Whipple; Educator, 97
description: Katherine Z. W. Whipple, former director of health education for the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, died yesterday at a continuing care home in Medford, N.J. She was 97 years old.

title: Powell to Throw Out First Ball for Yankees
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will throw out the first ball for the Yankees' home opener. Powell grew up in the South Bronx, not too far from Yankee Stadium.

title: School Tries Longer Classes for Deeper Learning
description: Eight years ago, when Dr. Joseph M. Carroll, the Superintendent of the Masconomet Regional School District, first talked of having 100-minute-long classes in the high school here, teachers scoffed.

title: Karl Einstein; Business Owner, 69
description: Karl Einstein, a retired New Jersey businessman, died on Sunday at Wayne General Hospital in New Jersey. He was 69 years old and lived in Wayne.

title: Tokyo Stocks Decline
description: Stock prices in Tokyo were down slightly today at the end of the trading session. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 shares was down 234.73 points, or 0.89 percent, to 26,104.65.

title: Pena Is Determined To Erase Mets' Doubts
description: For most of last season, Alejandro Pena was a strange and impenetrable clubhouse presence. He would wander without speaking through the locker room or sit as if hypnotized. He didn't say much, smiled even less, an imperious nod of the head about as loquacious as he got.

title: For Jewish Rep, a Dream Is Dashed Half-Finished
description: The Jewish Repertory Theater and its half-built dream house -- a new 200-seat theater -- are waiting in limbo amid reports that the building they are in will be sold.

title: Bonilla Rejects Offer
description: All-Star outfielder Bobby Bonilla rejected the Pittsburgh Pirates' latest contract offer yesterday, an unusual four-year deal that would essentially have allowed him to become a free agent after each season.

title: Forget the Oscar: These 3 Get Gold Ladders
description: THERE may be people who will remember this week because of a few movie awards, but you can be sure none of them were lunching in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Oscars may be fine for some folk, but what counts for this smiling New York crowd is a 24-karat gold ladder encased in Lucite. The ladder represents election into the American Advertising Federation's Advertising Hall of Fame, the highest tribute in the trade.

title: Study Warns Surgeons of Risks of AIDS Infection
description: Surgeons are often splashed, soaked or accidentally injected with patients' blood in ways that increase their risk of becoming infected with the AIDS virus, a Federal study says.

title: Connecticut Tax Hearing: What, No Rage?
description: By 5 P.M. the barricades set up to contain the crowds stood empty, and the State Capitol police officers assigned to guard the doors to Room 2C had long since wandered off. The signs warning people against cheering or other "public demonstrations" were superfluous in a room that had been largely empty of spectators since midday.

title: Excerpts From Ruling and Dissent On the Use of Coerced Confessions
description: Following are excerpts from the decision in which the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 yesterday that the use of a coerced confession in a criminal trial does not necessarily invalidate a conviction.

title: Hornets, Down by 20, Sweep by Golden State
description: The Charlotte Hornets made their biggest comeback in team history tonight, rallying from 20 points down to defeat the Golden State Warriors, 97-94.

title: French Computer Maker Sees $1 Billion Deficit
description: Underlining the difficulties that European computer makers are having in confronting Japanese and American competition, France's largest computer maker, Compagnie des Machines Bull is expected to announce on Wednesday a record loss for 1990 of more than $1 billion.

title: 'Yellow Pages' Fraud Charged
description: Five men were charged yesterday with fraudulently collecting more than $1 million from businesses after promising that the companies would be listed in yellow pages throughout the country. The United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney, said the five bilked thousands of businesses that made payments of about $100 each but never received the listings. The defendants were identified as David Wells and Joseph Villemaire, both of Toronto; Anthony Ruggiero, of Miami; Sal Restivo, of Plantation, Fla., and Anthony J. Consolazio of Valley Stream, L.I. Their lawyers denied the charges.

title: In Defense of Ottoman Rule in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Luciano V. Sclafani Sr.; Importer, 75
description: Luciano V. Sclafani Sr., an importer of Italian food products, died on Monday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 75 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SIR EDMUND P. HILLARY has been named a special representative of the United Nations Children's Fund to the children of the Himalayas.

title: Man Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: A 51-year-old man believed to be connected to organized crime was found shot to death last night in the lobby of his apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said. The man, Alfred Visconti, of 2020 East 41st Street in the Flatlands section, had been shot several times, a police spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner, said. The body was found by building residents. A man wearing a white baseball cap, white shirt and blue jeans was seen fleeing the scene. The police said Mr. Visconti apparently had ties to organized crime.

title: NCR's Talks With A.T.&T. Break Down
description: Talks between A.T.& T. and NCR broke down yesterday, and A.T.& T. said it was "pressing vigorously ahead" with its proxy contest to replace the NCR board at a special meeting in Dayton, Ohio, tomorrow.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., the mainframe computer company, introduced its Huron software system for writing computer programs. * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., will sell its Lazzaroni subsidiary in Italy to Awint di Gianguido Poracchia of Rome. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Review/Television; An Hour With General Schwarzkopf
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, triumphant supreme commander of the allied forces in the Persian Gulf, is top celebrity of the moment, and the rush is on among big television names for one-on-one interviews. Barbara Walters got there first last week for ABC's "20/20." Tonight at 8 on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 21, the affable general sits for an hour as esteemed guest on "Talking With David Frost."

title: The Pop Life
description: Sampling With a Difference

title: Bronx Hospital Gives Gay Couples Spouse Benefits
description: A Bronx hospital has become the largest private employer in the nation to provide the same health benefits for homosexual workers and their partners as for heterosexual employees and their husbands or wives.

title: Ruling Forces New York to Release Or Arraign Suspects in 24 Hours
description: The state's highest court ruled today that most people arrested in New York City must be released if they are not arraigned within 24 hours, a decision that city officials said could lead to the release of dangerous suspects.

title: Dinkins Faults Rule Reinstating 5 Officers
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had opposed the change in the state Civil Service law that forced the New York City Police Department this week to reinstate five Queens officers who have been indicted on murder charges.

title: Market Place; Analysts Split On G.M.'s Fate
description: AUTO MAKERS typically lose money in sour economies, then make it back in spades during prosperity. But the General Motors Corporation's $1.6 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 1990 was so staggering that it has split Wall Street over whether the No. 1 auto maker can recover its earning power when the economy improves.

title: Review/Television; After the Oscars, Comments on the Prize-Giving
description: Trend-watchers were glad to know that the ponytail remains popular (at least among men), that the name to drop these days is Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's (Bob Hope and Madonna both tried it), and that many of Hollywood's heaviest hitters apparently take themselves elsewhere when Oscar comes to town. But beyond that, the largely suspense-free 63d annual Academy Awards ceremony revealed little of great interest.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column of Business Day on March 19, about proxy battles for corporate control, misstated the size of the stake held by Nycor Inc. in the Zenith Electronics Corporation. It is 7.6 percent.

title: 7 Oscars for 'Wolves' Lift a Troubled Studio
description: The seven Oscars won by "Dances With Wolves" Monday night at the Academy Awards ceremonies, including Best Picture, will undoubtedly give a lift to the faltering Orion Pictures Corporation.

title: Boeing Japan Settlement
description: The Boeing Company today reached a compensation agreement with the families of 54 victims who died in the 1985 crash of a Japan Airlines Boeing 747 jumbo jet, history's worst single-plane disaster.

title: Mali's Dictator Is Overthrown in Coup
description: Soldiers overthrew Mali's military dictator today after days of rioting and promised to replace Gen. Moussa Traore's "bloodthirsty and corrupt regime" with a multiparty democracy.

title: Fox Network In Cable Deal
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable company, with 8.8 million basic subscribers, has agreed to carry the television stations of the Fox Broadcasting Company's network.

title: The Kurds: A Stateless People With a 70-Year-Long Grudge
description: Ever since Iraq was created in 1921, its Kurdish population has been engaged in an almost constant rebellion for some degree of autonomy against the Government in Baghdad.

title: Philip Morris Says Maxwell Will Retire
description: The Philip Morris Companies confirmed yesterday that Hamish Maxwell, the chairman and chief executive for nearly seven years, plans to retire this year in accordance with board policy. Mr. Maxwell will be 65 years old in August.

title: The Mets and Macy's In a 75-Game TV Deal
description: As part of a concerted effort to increase its television exposure, R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it would be a principal sponsor of the 75 New York Mets games that WWOR-TV will broadcast this season.

title: Los Angeles Officers Plead Not Guilty in Beating of Motorist
description: Four police officers pleaded not guilty today in the beating of a motorist they stopped for speeding, while some of their fellow officers refused to cooperate with a Federal investigation into the incident.

title: Bridge
description: There are a few hands that are impossible to bid in standard methods. Nobody has the slightest idea about the right bid on the South hand shown in the diagram when a one-club opening receives a one-spade response, or indeed any other response. A plunge into five clubs seems indicated, but this might either be too high or result in a missed slam.

title: A Bartender Who Stirs and Shakes but Allows No New Twists
description: THE last time bartenders made a dent in the national consciousness, Tom Cruise and Bryan Brown in the movie "Cocktail" were throwing shakers like Indian clubs before a barroom full of groupies. It was not a pretty sight.

title: Court Says Rights Law Doesn't Protect U.S. Workers Abroad
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal law barring discrimination in employment does not apply to Americans overseas.

title: Stocks Rise Sharply, With Dow Up 49.01
description: Stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, as analysts started to predict again that the Dow Jones industrial average could be on its way to the magical 3,000 level that it has flirted with several times.

title: U.S., FEARING IRAQI BREAKUP, IS TERMED READY TO ACCEPT A HUSSEIN DEFEAT OF REBELS
description: President Bush has decided to let President Saddam Hussein put down rebellions in his country without American intervention rather than risk the splintering of Iraq, according to official statements and private briefings today.

title: Thornburgh Orders Drive on Gun Violence
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh ordered United States attorneys throughout the nation today to make targets of violent felons who use guns and prosecute them for Federal firearms violations that carry stiff mandatory sentences.

title: Lebow Recovering
description: Fred Lebow, founder of the New York Road Runners Club and the New York City Marathon, went for a 30-minute walk in Central Park yesterday and turned a few heads doing it. That is because last Friday, Lebow underwent surgery for a cancerous tumor in his thyroid.

title: Contracts Under New Charter Receive Little Public Scrutiny; Highest Wages Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Juliette T. Benton, 92, Lecturer on Literature
description: Juliette T. Benton, a lecturer on books and plays who headed the Wednesday Book Group in New York for more than half a century, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92 years old.

title: Researchers Act to Cut Auto Pollution Further
description: Tailpipe catalytic converters are one of the most successful technologies in the history of air pollution control, eliminating 96 to 98 percent of the carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons, and three-quarters of the nitrogen oxide emitted by car engines. But this is no longer good enough.

title: Consumer Confidence Shows Big Rebound
description: In the first in-depth survey of consumer sentiment in March, the Conference Board reported yesterday that its index of consumer confidence rose to 81 from 59.4 in February -- a record gain for a single month -- reflecting both relief that the Persian Gulf war had ended and optimism that the economy would improve by late summer.

title: China's Students Seek To Avoid Ban on Travel
description: Sometimes Wang Jie dreams of achieving her goal and making it to America, but there is just a hint of apprehension about what will happen if she is admitted to an American prep school and later to an American college.

title: Public Duty: Right Here, and Now
description: New York City is in a war for its future, but does not know how to fight. It has no generals like Powell and Schwarzkopf, no plan and few outside allies. It falls ever deeper into a sinkhole of economic decline, crime, dirt, cynicism and fatalism.

title: Guardsmen Return From War They Didn't Fight
description: For the crowd of dignitaries, the high school marching band and the horde of reporters at Hunter Army Airfield in Savannah, it looked as if the big moment had finally arrived when a plane landed around midnight earlier this month, apparently bringing the first troops home from the Persian Gulf war.

title: Lawrence Welk Encore
description: Reacting to an avalanche of embarrassing publicity, the House and Senate approved an amendment last week that rescinds a $500,000 grant to develop a museum at the North Dakota birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the polka-playing bandleader. A small victory against Congressional pork-barreling? Don't count the savings yet.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Role For a 'Shadow Senator'
description: Don't call the Rev. Jesse Jackson a "shadow Senator."

title: Gloria Holden; Actress, 73
description: Gloria Holden, an actress whose film career spanned three decades, died Friday after a heart attack. She was 73 years old.

title: Suriname's Leader and Rebel Chief Vow to Negotiate Uprising's End
description: In a weekend meeting with Suriname's military strongman, the leader of a rebel group pledged to bring a four-year insurgency to an end, diplomats said today.

title: FINAL FOUR: Diary of a Rebel; 'Mental Aspect' Could Make The Difference
description: For most people, the Final Four is a big party. Everybody wants to have a good time. Our attitude is that you can have a good time after it's all done.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene is Madison Avenue, midtown. The cast of characters, two in-a-hurry middle-aged, business-attired men, one heading uptown, one downtown. Not breaking stride, they greet each other with outstretched arms.

title: GORBACHEV ORDERS INTERIOR MINISTRY TO POLICE MOSCOW
description: Facing popular resistance to an attempt to ban demonstrations in the capital, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered the national Interior Ministry today to take over law enforcement on the city's streets from the democratically elected city government.

title: Coining 'Primavera'
description: To The Living Section:

title: Unocal to Halt Shale Project
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would suspend production at its $650 million Parachute Creek shale-oil plant on June 1 because the project is losing money.

title: Shackling Gets Judge In Trouble
description: A New Jersey Supreme Court justice today described as "Kafkaesque" a case of a woman who arrived late for an appearance before a judge on a minor matter and was subsequently handcuffed to a bench for four hours.

title: Syria Plans to Double Gulf Force
description: Syria is planning to double its 20,000-member military contingent in the gulf as part of efforts by Arab nations opposing Iraq to strengthen security in the region, a senior Syrian official said today.

title: The Star of 'New Jack City' Is Building on Its Success
description: Wesley Snipes, the star of the new movie "New Jack City," was in his car here one day this month when a very excited 10-year-old boy recognized him and approached his window. "Man, you are one great actor," Mr. Snipes recalled the child saying. "I know that wasn't really you up there, but you played the heck out of that role.' "

title: CHRONICLE
description: LARRY FORGIONE, a leader of the new American cuisine emphasizing American products and regional cooking, is creating a new restaurant in Rhinebeck, N.Y., the heart of the Hudson Valley.

title: Open Positions on Nasdaq Short Sales Down 4.2%
description: The N.A.S.D. also said short interest in 1,211 less active over-the-counter securities that are traded in its automated quotation system, but not in the national market system, totaled 43.7 million shares as of mid-March. That represented an increase of slightly more than 4.3 percent from the 41.9 million shares held short in the February period, when 1,186 securities were involved.

title: Limits Set On Suing Regulators
description: In a ruling that brought considerable relief to Federal banking regulators, the Supreme Court held unanimously today that the Government may not be sued for damages when efforts by regulators to rescue troubled savings and loan associations go awry.

title: Syracuse Police Are Accused In Prisoner's Brain Damage
description: A lawyer asked a judge today to preserve a police videotape showing a handcuffed prisoner, now disabled by brain damage, being pushed face first into a Plexiglas window by an officer.

title: In New York, Walesa Worships in 'Little Warsaw'
description: President Lech Walesa of Poland spent much of his last day in America yesterday doing what presidents do on trips like his: pleading his fiscally strapped nation's case to New York's business and political elite. But first he went to church with his countrymen in New York's "Little Warsaw."

title: The U.N. Squeezes Iraq
description: The United Nations seems about to crown military success in the Persian Gulf with hard but equitable peace terms. The conditions for a cease-fire set forth in a draft resolution before the Security Council are remarkable in both their sweep and precision. For Iraq, the price for cessation of hostilities is willingness to destroy terror weapons, pay a portion of its oil revenues into a U.N.-administered reparations fund and recognize the inviolability of Kuwait's frontiers.

title: Book Notes
description: Gamble Paying Off

title: William H. Kennedy; Banker, 73
description: William H. Kennedy, a former president of the American Bankers Association, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Pine Bluff. He was 73 years old.

title: Tyson-Ruddock II Set
description: A rematch between Mike Tyson and Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, who fought a controversial heavyweight fight last week, has been set for June 28 in Las Vegas, Nev., promoters said yesterday. The fight will be held at the Mirage Hotel, a spokesmen for Don King, the promoter representing Tyson, said. (Reuters)

title: Howard Johnson's Switches to Pepsi
description: The Pepsi-Cola Company won a contract to be the exclusive soft drink supplier to Howard Johnson's, replacing the Coca-Cola Company at the nationwide restaurant chain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: 3 Girls Shot to Death on a California Estate
description: Two youths have been charged with killing three teen-age girls on a family's estate here by taking turns firing a shotgun at them in a baffling explosion of violence among high school friends.

title: Prison Guards Stage Sickout
description: Scores of workers at the state prison complex in Cranston staged a sickout today to protest staff cuts and changes in security policies they said had made their jobs unsafe, a state official said. More than 185 of the 239 guards, food service workers and nurses on the first shift called in sick, said Joseph DiNitto, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections. He said no problems had been reported at the prison complex.

title: After Mr. & Mrs. T, Who?
description: That the financial struggle between Donald Trump and his former wife is over (she got $14 million, the house and the old Mercedes) is presumably a great relief to both. But for at least one onlooker it is little short of a disaster.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL Pistons Defeat Pacers, 102-93

title: Whistle-Stop Campaign, the Albanian Way
description: A day in the life of an opposition candidate for the Albanian presidecy begins soon after dawn in a modest apartment. It continues with a campaign speech for state television and an eight-hour drive to two election rallies in eastern Albania and ends a little after midnight at the offices of his party newspaper in Tirana, the capital.

title: Fair Warning on Cigarettes?
description: Cigarettes kill, but Americans have known that for a long time and millions continue to smoke. May smokers nevertheless sue manufacturers for failure to give adequate warning of the dangers? The Supreme Court has agreed to decide a critical part of that question: whether warnings on packages and advertising, required by Federal law since 1966, immunize companies from traditional suits based on state liability law.

title: Reviews/Dance; Bulgarians With Gusto and Kerchiefs
description: A folk ensemble called Pirin offered a sampling of Bulgarian folk dance and music on Saturday night at Brooklyn College. The visitors from Sofia included the Pirin Dancers, the Thracian Orchestra and the Stefanov Bulgarian Women's Chorus. The evening of rousing entertainment was at its best when the jollity was least forced.

title: Farm Banks Plan a Merger
description: Officials of farm credit banks in four cities have discussed merging their district banks to cut costs and strengthen their financial position, district officials in Omaha said today.

title: Review/Television; 'Mystery' Goes Political With a Six-Part Thriller
description: Los Angeles cops have one whale of an image problem these days. True. But just consider the portraits of British and German law enforcers in a new six-part mini-series called "Die Kinder." These internal-security lads are seen as little more than born-and-bred thugs, casually sadistic and even murderous. At this rate, police the world over should wind up about as esteemed as your average Middle East dictator.

title: Nynex, Computerland Said to Talk
description: The Nynex Corporation has been negotiating a possible sale of its computer retailing operations to the Computerland Corporation, people with knowledge of the talks said yesterday.

title: Deficit Dawdling in Albany
description: Four days before New York State's Legislature is supposed to adopt a new budget, Albany is in chaos. It can hardly come as a surprise to lawmakers that they face the unpleasant task of cutting services and raising taxes. They know they have no choice. They have to get on with it.

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
description: A successful auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes and rumors that labor market conditions continue to deteriorate helped to push up prices of Treasury securities yesterday, and interest rates fell.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONNIE WAHLBERG surrendered to the authorities yesterday in Louisville, Ky., where a warrant for his arrest on a charge of arson had been issued.

title: Panel Urges Independent Body to Set Ethical Standards in Science
description: In an attempt to invigorate the ethical standards in science and forestall more outside investigations of misconduct, a scientific panel has drafted a recommendation to set up an independent body to suggest scientific standards and keep track of cases nationwide.

title: Toyota Exports
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it was considering exporting Camry station wagons made in its Georgetown, Ky., plant to Europe. Toyota is to bring some 40,000 right-hand-drive Kentucky-made Camry cars a year into Japan starting in 1992.

title: In U.S., Punitive Damages Have Short History
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; Growing Up to Fear the Law
description: We troubled the policemen for directions to Broad Street. For this they pulled us over, hustled us out and roughly patted us down. Then they rifled the glove box, pulled up the floor mats, dragged the back seat out into Chestnut Street and searched for drugs in the springs.

title: For Apartment Voyeurs, Rated G
description: "DAN'S APARTMENT" is a new cable-television show that lets viewers call in and snoop around Dan's endearingly ad hoc one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pro Bono
description: * The United Hospital Fund, a not-for-profit organization that addresses health care issues, will introduce a print and radio campaign next month intended to recruit 2,500 volunteers for New York City's hospitals and nursing homes. The campaign and its slogan, "Give a little, get a lot," were designed by William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, on a pro-bono basis.* The Stogel Companies, a small New York agency, is donating its time and resources to a campaign for Food For Survival Inc., a not-for-profit group that provides free and reduced-cost food to organizations that serve the poor and elderly. The campaign uses direct mail, among other methods, to solicit food and money for the New York-based charity.

title: Weicker to Accept Cap On Growth in Spending
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., taking the unusual step of personally testifying before the legislature, told lawmakers today for the first time that he would accept limits on the future growth of state spending as part of his budget and income-tax plan.

title: Lacking Balance, the Knicks Take a Step Backward
description: Patrick Ewing attempted a team-record 37 shots Tuesday night. He made only 15 of them.

title: Some Tanning Salons Found to Violate Rules
description: Some tanning salons are violating Federal rules by failing to alert the public to the dangers of their tanning devices, a consumer organization said today.

title: Pinochet Assails Chilean Rights Report
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet issued a sweeping criticism today of a Government human rights report released earlier this month that catalogued the killing or disappearances of more than 2,000 people in Chile during his 17-year military government.

title: T.P.C. Course Pushes The Best to the Limit
description: One of the strongest fields in professional golf will tee off Thursday at the Players Championship on a course with a reputation for infuriating more than inspiring the world's best players.

title: Florio Shifting Style to Let Legislators Set the Agenda
description: Bloodied by last year's tax revolt, Gov. Jim Florio has adopted an oddly familiar style of governing. Mr. Florio, much like his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, is crisscrossing the state as New Jersey's chief cheerleader while allowing legislators to set the public agenda.

title: Holders Approve Saatchi Revamping
description: Shareholders of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company approved the advertising giant's recapitalization plan today, and the company's banks agreed to increase the size and extend the maturity of its credit lines.

title: H. J. Muessen, 88, Former Chairman Of Piel's Brewery
description: Henry J. Muessen, who headed the Piel Brothers brewery, one of New York's many large producers of beer in the first half of the century, died on Monday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Stamford. He was 88 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Indictment
description: When the Supreme Court was considering Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, among the papers was an amicus brief containing the recollections of women who had had abortions. One 70-year-old grandmother described three, all illegal. The last was the worst. She developed an infection and when her husband took her to the hospital, the men from the D.A.'s office arrived at her gurney soon after the doctor did.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Automobiles Peugeot, a unit of Peugeot S.A., Paris, said it would extend temporary production slowdowns into April, closing for three days at its Sochaux plant in France and one at its Mulhouse plant. * BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, will buy the Puerto Rico Telephone Authority in a preliminary deal valued at $2.5 billion, according to people close to the negotiations. But Fabio Garcia Matienzo, president of the Puerto Rico Telephone Authority, denied that there was any agreement and said talks were continuing.

title: Personal Health
description: When patients are told they have mitral valve prolapse, a heart valve abnormality that is by far the most common cardiac disorder in young people, te diagnosis is usually followed by reassurance that the condition is minor and should not interfere with normal activities and a full life.

title: William B. Fretter, Physicist, 74
description: William Bache Fretter, a physicist who was vice president of the University of California from 1978 to 1983, died Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: Textron Names Vice President
description: Textron Inc. said today that it had promoted John S. Kleban from president of Textron Aerostructures in Nashville to group vice president at the company's headquarters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN V. LINDSAY received an award from the Boys Harbor Foundation last night for his aid to the group over the last 50-plus years. The foundation operates a summer camp in East Hampton, L.I., for disadvantaged girls and boys, and a year-round educational and social services center in Manhattan.

title: Mullin Family to Hold Bittersweet Reunion
description: Homecomings are quieter now, more contemplative, for Chris Mullin. Brookville, L.I., is not Brooklyn, and the Mullin family's most powerful voice has been stilled.

title: Officers Capture 2 After 4 Inmates Flee Prison in Catskills
description: Hundreds of police officers, assisted by dogs and helicopters, searched a heavily wooded and sparsely populated region of the Catskills yesterday for two inmates, one a convicted murderer, who escaped overnight from a maximum-security state prison.

title: Infant Health: The Better Way
description: President Bush was right to acknowledge the tragically high infant mortality rates in many American cities. Congress was also right to say, as it did last week, that Mr. Bush's plan to lower those rates was off base.

title: Mets May Open Up Without Elster
description: Manager Bud Harrelson said today he was seriously considering starting the season without Kevin Elster on the roster, a decision hardly expected to sit well with the onetime starting shortstop for the Mets.

title: 15 KILLED AT VIGIL IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The violence racking South Africa's black townships erupted anew today when gunmen raided a funeral vigil before dawn, killing 15 mourners and wounding at least 16.

title: Arnold S. Anderson Executive, 56
description: Arnold S. Anderson, executive vice president and general counsel of the Woolworth Corporation, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Athletes Lead Nonathletes in Graduating, Survey Says
description: A recent survey has disclosed that while athletes at Division I colleges and universities graduate at a higher rate than nonathletes, football and basketball players at the highest level of competition graduate at a lower rate.

title: Review/Film Festival; Future In-Laws Meet And Eat and Eat and Eat
description: "The Story of Boys and Girls," by the Italian director Pupi Avati, is an unusual selection for the New Directors/New Films festival, since Mr. Avati has been directing since 1968 and has a highly accomplished and commercial style. In this charmingly rustic drama, he tells of two families meeting on an important occasion in 1936, the sort of occasion that calls for a 20-course meal and a long, hearty celebration. The most minute details of this happy event, from the dough-kneading to the rabbit-catching, are invoked with great gusto.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed for a 4th Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, and reported yesterday, were mixed for the fourth consecutive week.

title: Michigan Senior Will Try His Best at Meet
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association men's swimming championships, will begin Thursday, and Mike Barrowman is not really prepared.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: INSTALLING a disappearing staircase -- stairs that fold down from a ceiling hatchway and are raised into it for storage -- is worth considering if a larger or more convenient attic entrance is needed. The job is usually not too difficult for a moderately skilled amateur carpenter and a strong assistant, provided a suitable hatchway already exists or can be built as described farther on.

title: Of Gnomes And Spirits In Stone
description: LONELY Alpine shepherds befriended the spirits they found in mountain rocks, then captured their essence in sculptures. Bob Keegan, who studied folk art in Austria, now creates his own interpretation of these "old men of the mountains" for gardens.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
German Unity Favors Siemens
description: SIEMENS A.G., Western Europe's largest electronics concern, has been expanding aggressively into international markets for three years. Yet, when industry experts discuss why the Munich-based company's stock has been gaining favor as a long-term investment, they emphasize the profit potential in the united Germany.

title: Defense Lawyers Assail Court Ruling on Coerced Confessions
description: Civil libertarians and defense lawyers today deplored as an "abomination" and "a horror" the Supreme Court's decision on Tuesday that the use of a coerced confession in a criminal trial does not automatically void a conviction.

title: New York City to Cut Garbage Rate for Businesses
description: For the first time, New York City will lower the rate that the city's 250,000 businesses pay private haulers to pick up their garbage.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pepsico Using New Sign At College Tournament
description: People who attend the N.C.A.A. Final Four basketball tournament in Indianapolis this weekend can size up one of the newest and tallest players in the game of outdoor advertising: a 9-by-12-foot Sony video screen mounted on the side of a large Ford Motor Company truck chassis.

title: A Play Born From the Friendship Between an Author and an Actor
description: The title of the play is "The Substance of Fire." The story behind its creation is the substance of friendship and the substance of failure.

title: Holding Pens Still a Criminal Justice Disgrace
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudden Jump In School Rolls May Be Trend
description: After years of small changes in annual enrollment, the New York City public schools are struggling with a sudden and unexpected leap of nearly 18,000 students this year.

title: Review/Theater; The Trip to the Forum Is Still Full of Laughs
description: "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," the first musical for which Stephen Sondheim wrote both the music and lyrics, is as effervescent today as it was three decades ago. Surviving countless revivals, the 1962 musical remains a surefire combination of low comedy and high jinks, Plautus revamped to serve modern vaudeville purposes.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Excerpts From the Schwarzkopf Interview
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf broadcast last night on the television program "Talking With David Frost," as transcribed by its producers:

title: Surge in Dollar Surprises Some, Worries Others
description: The dollar is back from its recent depths, buoyed by allied successes in the Persian Gulf and hopes for an economic rebound at home. The sudden rally has come as a surprise to currency traders, confounded some forecasters and begun to worry Government finance officials because of its potential impact on exports.

title: All-Natural Bedding: Counting On Sheep, Cotton and Even Milkweed
description: YOUR bed may not be a safe place in which to hide from bad environmental news.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'Killer-of-Enemies,' Myth and Masks
description: Beauty is not an abstract concept for a choreographer like Erick Hawkins, and the dazzling integrated vision in his latest premiere -- dancers, exquisite sculptured masks and decor of pure form -- is no accident. The visual excellence runs consonant with the theme of the piece, the healing power of beauty.

title: U.S. Maker of Ball Bearings Loses New 'Dumping' Case
description: The United States International Trade Commission, in an unusual decision, today threw out an unfair trade case brought by a leading maker of ball bearings against Hong Kong and 13 countries including Canada and Mexico -- removing what could have become another point of international trade friction.

title: Many Competing Bills Chase the Energy Problem
description: Lawmakers have responded to the Bush Administration's national energy strategy with a flurry of competing proposals to raise gasoline taxes, improve automobile mileage, raise energy efficiency in businesses and homes, open sensitive regions to oil exploration, and spend hundreds of millions of dollars for research on conservation and renewable sources of energy.

title: Samuel G. Gallu, 73, Writer and Producer
description: Samuel G. Gallu, a playwright and independent television and film producer, died yesterday at Doylestown Hospital in Doylestown, Pa. He was 73 years old and lived in Solebury, Pa.

title: Viola Counters Mets' Offer With Terms of His Own
description: Negotiations on a contract extension for Frank Viola, expected by both sides to be intense in the days remaining before the start of the season, took a significant but uncertain step today when Viola's agent presented the Mets with a detailed counterproposal.

title: Gorbachev Won't Change the Soviet System; Time to Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: Witt Left Behind to Work Out a New Delivery
description: His teammates left this morning for West Palm Beach and another exhibition game, but Mike Witt stayed behind. On a mound in the Yankee bullpen -- with the stands empty and only a few observers watching him -- Witt took the first step in a new and perhaps uncertain stage in his pitching career.

title: Police Lure: Trolling for Subway Thieves
description: Eyes slack, shirttail flapping, tie askew, the subway rider obviously had had one too many. He staggered through a passageway under 14th Street, oblivious to the swarms of passers-by and the few who seemed riveted by the chain and gold medallion bobbing temptingly around his neck.

title: Reynolds Files Appeal
description: Butch Reynolds, the quarter-miler barred from competition for two years after a ruling that he tested positive for steroids, took his challenge of the ban to a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati yesterday.

title: Ivan von Auw, Literary Agent, 88
description: Ivan von Auw, a retired literary agent who represented some of this century's most prominent writers in the United States, died March 19 at his home in San Juan, P.R., two days after his 88th birthday. He lived in Portugal and Puerto Rico.

title: New Theory Says Antarctica And America Were Once One
description: Two geologists say Antarctica was connected to the western coast of North America about half a billion years ago.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE morning of his wedding almost two years ago, Jim Regier had breakfast alone with his three children from his previous marriage: a daughter and a son in their late teens and another daughter in her early 20's. Although none of the children lived with their father, a magazine publisher in Manhattan, they were very concerned about how this new marriage would affect their lives. They also wondered whether they would still be able spend time alone with their father.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a municipal judge in New Jersey accused of ignoring the rights of defendants referred incorrectly to a hearing before the New Jersey Supreme Court. The judge, Bennett E. Bozarth, was not present.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about reports of money hidden by Saddam Hussein in bank accounts around the world misstated Iraq's oil revenues. Over the last 10 years they were $200 billion in total, not annually.

title: G.N.P. Rate Down 1.6% In Sign of Milder Slump
description: The economy shrank at an annual rate of 1.6 percent in the final three months of 1990, a significantly smaller downturn than previously reported, as spending on the military in the Persian Gulf helped cushion the decline, the Government said today.

title:
TALKING DEALS;
Michael Jackson's Mystery Contract
description: MYSTERY surrounds Michael Jackson, the brilliant entertainer who is painfully shy and enigmatic off stage. And mystery surrounds the terms and potential scope of the singer's elaborate new contract with the Sony Corporation.

title: Board Backs Ballet Troupe's Return
description: The trustees of the Pennsylvania Ballet voted on Tuesday to lift a suspension of operations they announced on March 11.

title: Strike by Soviet Miners Spreads In Rising Challenge to Kremlin
description: What began as a warning strike by coal miners here in the grimy, smoke-choked forge of Siberia has developed into a nationwide action with a simple demand: Out with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, his Government and his Parliament.

title: WIDER PERIL FOUND IN NUCLEAR WASTE FROM BOMB MAKING
description: Engineers rushing to build nuclear bombs in the 1950's dumped millions of gallons of radioactive waste into the ground at the Hanford nuclear reservation near Richland, Wash., a new analysis by the Environmental Protection Agency shows. Dirt from the reservation may be as dangerous as highly radioactive wastes stored in special tanks, the agency said.

title: Elevator Thrill Game Kills a Boy Once Wary of It
description: Boys who knew Edwin Ortiz said he never took part in a thrilling but dangerous pastime in New York City's housing projects called, among other things, "elevator action."

title: Two Named to Hall
description: Scotty Bowman, a longtime coach and executive, and Neil Armstrong, a veteran linesman, have been elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: NCR Deal Is Seen As Closer
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the NCR Corporation moved closer today toward a deal on the eve of NCR's annual meeting.

title: New York Replaces Traffic Agents With Higher-Paid Police Officers
description: At a time when hundreds of brown-uniformed traffic-control agents have been pulled from New York City streets to save money, the Police Department has assigned dozens of blue-uniformed officers to control traffic.

title: Cafeteria Blast Injures 22
description: An explosion rocked a restaurant today, collapsing sections of a floor, shooting glass into a parking lot and injuring at least 22 people, one critically. The cause of the blast at a Colonial Cafeteria in the city's hospital district was under investigation. A worker at a nearby business said he smelled natural gas 50 yards away.

title: Cairo Journal; The Trouble, Says the Zoo, Is a Herd of Humans
description: Pity poor Murad the orangutan. Outside his cage, his public waits for him, stacked three and four deep around the iron bars and well armed with small missiles: peanuts and bits of banana, popcorn and wads of chewing gum.

title: Gorbachev Won't Change the Soviet System; Growing Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: New Tack on Mideast Talks
description: The Administration is exploring the possibility of a Middle East peace conference with the United States and the Soviet Union as hosts. Page A6.

title: Four Big Insurers Settle Texas Antitrust Case
description: In return for an agreement by the State of Texas to drop antitrust charges against them, four of America's largest insurance companies agreed today to contribute $3 million to establish a not-for-profit foundation that will help train and educate Texas insurance regulators.

title: Gorbachev Won't Change the Soviet System
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons of S.& L. Crisis Echo in Talks on Banks
description: The time: Shortly before a Presidential election. The voices: Administration officials, asserting that a federally guaranteed deposit-insurance program needs to borrow only a few billion dollars to stay afloat.

title: Western Union Defers Interest
description: The Western Union Corporation will defer the semiannual interest payment of $2 million due April 1 on its 13 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures. A spokesman said the company had the funds but wanted to conserve cash. He said the company could avoid default on the issue by making the payment before the expiration of the 30-day grace period on May 1.

title: U.N. Council May Let Iraq Use Warplanes
description: If President Saddam Hussein agrees to a cease-fire on the terms the five permanent Security Council members have set out, he will be able to use any remaining warplanes in his air force to suppress Kurdish rebels without risk of the United States shooting them down, diplomats said today.

title: Cardinal Tomasek of Prague, Primate Since 1977, Retires
description: The Archbishop of Prague, Frantisek Cardinal Tomasek, one of the region's toughest Roman Catholic leaders and a staunch anti-Communist, has retired at 91, the Papal Nuncio said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * RJR Nabisco Capital Corp., a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $750 million in senior notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Rockwell International Corp., El Segundo, Calif., has filed for up to $300 million in debt securities that may be offered in more than one series.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It doesn't come up a lot. Some kids once in a while ask, 'So how did you get the virus?' Teachers treat me like a normal kid." -- Joey DiPaolo, a Brooklyn sixth grader who has AIDS. [ B4:3. ]

title: Rings on Furniture? Pantry Holds a Cure
description: NECESSITY certainly is the mother of invention, if I listen to tales of homemade remedies used for damaged furniture.

title: South Africa a Bit Closer to Rejoining Olympics
description: The door long closed to South Africa's participation in the Olympics opened a crack today when the International Olympic Committee offered conditional recognition to a new nonracial Olympic committee formed by South African sports organizations.

title: Robert M. Edelstein, Professor, 48
description: Robert M. Edelstein, a professor of marketing and public policy at Adelphi University, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: 10 Newcomers Entering A Green Winners' Circle
description: TEN new plants have been chosen as the 1991 winners in the All-America Selections in Downers Grove, Ill. At 60 trial gardens around North America, annual flowers and vegetables were judged for color, taste and ease of maintenance by a panel including state officials and seed company horticulturists.

title: Steam-Pipe Eruption Leaves Some Buildings Without Heat
description: A dozen buildings on the East Side remained without steam heat yesterday as Consolidated Edison crews cleaned up after an asbestos-lined steam pipe burst on Tuesday, closing streets and dozens of stores.

title: In Memory Of Those Shot In Civilian Wars
description: Twenty-two men and women died during the 100-hour ground offensive in the Persian Gulf. No monuments will be erected to memorialize the casualties. No sense of sacrifice or loss has been seared on the public consciousness. No parades are planned.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc., Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., named Gary L. Paxton president and chief executive. * Equitable Capital Management Corp., New York, an investment management subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, named John D. Miller, an executive vice president, to the new position of chief investment officer. James R. Wilson will replace Mr. Miller as head of the corporate finance department and will add the title of executive vice president.

title: Brazil Debt Payment Set
description: Brazil said today that it would pay international banks $210 million during the second quarter, equivalent to 30 percent of the foreign bank debt interest coming due in the period. The payment will be the second since Brazil suspended interest payments on medium- and long-term bank debt in July 1989. Brazil paid $350.8 million in the first quarter, on March 15. Brazil's medium- and long-term debt totals $60 billion, almost half of the country's total debt of $121.8 billion. The central bank did not say when the $210 million, which applies to public-sector debt, would be paid.

title: Making Higher Matzoh: Spirituality With a Price
description: Five facts about matzoh:

title: Key Rates
Abboud Out as Chief At Houston's First City
description: A. Robert Abboud, the Chicago banker who arrived in Texas three years ago to lead a $1.5 billion bailout of a Houston bank, was ousted today as chairman and chief executive of the First City Bancorporation of Texas in the face of mounting losses and problem loans.

title: Minnesota Is Placed On 2-Year Probation
description: Lou Holtz and Luther Darville, long gone from the University of Minnesota, still had a major impact today when the National Collegiate Athletic Association placed the school on probation for two years and banned its football team from making a 1991 post-season appearance.

title: Iraqi Refugees Tell U.S. Soldiers Of Brutal Repression of Rebellion
description: Thousands of war-weary refugees who poured into a newly opened United States Army-run camp on the border today told of atrocities by Iraqi troops who are crushing a rebellion in the south against President Saddam Hussein.

title: Rivals Tell of Findings About Superconductors
description: Competing scientists in Europe and the United States said yesterday that they had discovered microscopic structures in certain superconducting materials that might explain one of the mysteries underlying the transmission of electrical current with no resistance.

title: Huge Anti-Communist Rally Honors Day in Serb History
description: Tens of thousands of anti-Communist demonstrators gathered today to commemorate the 50th anniversary of a military coup that overthrew a pro-Nazi Serbian government, and to draw parallels to their challenge to the government of former Communists, which now controls their republic,

title: Follow the Kurds to Save Iraq
description: President Bush was "sickened" at the sight of a man being clubbed senseless by police while a gang of cops looked on. Yet his stomach is not turned at the spectacle of an American army standing by and watching Saddam Hussein's gunships rain death on the Kurdish people for daring to answer George Bush's call for an uprising.

title: Article 090391 -- No Title
description: Lucy Goldschmidt Moses, who donated $80 million during her long life, has left $170 million, the bulk of her estate, for philanthropy.

title: Loss Posted By Tribune Co.
description: The Tribune Company said today that it lost $191.4 million during the fourth quarter of 1990 because of costs associated with The Daily News of New York.

title: Palace Theater Spruced Up, Ready to Light Up
description: The Palace Theater, once famed as the Valhalla of Vaudeville and the house with the oldest surviving box office in Times Square, reopens on Monday after a three-and-a-half-year intermission for extensive renovations and the building of a 43-story hotel above and alongside of it.

title: Doctor Gives Bush Rating of 'Excellent' In Annual Checkup
description: President Bush underwent his annual physical checkup at Bethesda Naval Medical Center today, and the White House physician said in a statement that the examination had turned up no surprises and that Mr. Bush was in "excellent" health.

title: Lift the Ban On 'Baby Bells'
description: The breakup of the Bell System in 1984 is still commonly portrayed as a parochial battle among corporate giants. But its effects are striking at the heart of America's competitive position in the global economy, as our telecommunications industry and elements of the Government have long known.

title: Jet Fuel Costs Rise $3 Billion
description: The spurt in jet fuel prices caused by the Persian Gulf war added nearly $3 billion to United States airline costs over six months, the president of the Air Transport Association said today.

title: Israeli General Is Sentenced To 13 Years in Bribery Case
description: A former chief purchasing officer in the Israeli Air Force was sentenced today to 13 years in prison for receiving $10 million in bribes and kickbacks on purchases of American-made equipment.

title: A TV Outlet for the Work Of Student Film Makers
description: Television viewers roaming the prime-time forest on Monday nights are happening upon some unfamiliar beasts: long and short, color and black and white, unaffected and convoluted.

title: Stanford Takes N.I.T.; First Title in 49 Years
description: It has been a long time between basketball championships for Stanford.

title: Ameil Glass, Surgeon, 90
description: Ameil Glass, a retired thoracic surgeon, died on Tuesday at his home in White Plains. He was 90 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Cunningham Troupe Ends Season
description: Very little in the dances of Merce Cunningham draws attention to itself. Each piece looks like part of a continuous meditation that reveals the soul and body on dark days and light, with new or recurrent problems of movement, gesture and dynamics to be solved along the way. Or so two performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company suggested, in the last week of the troupe's glowing season at the City Center.

title: Latin American Trade
description: The Presidents of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay have signed a agreement to build a common Latin American trading market. The Southern Common Market treaty, known as Mercosur, signed Tuesday, would dismantle trade barriers and encourage cross-border investment and joint projects over the next four years.

title: Los Angeles Chief Fights Rising Pressure
description: As pressure increased for his resignation after the beating by police officers of a motorist, Police Chief Daryl F. Gates of Los Angeles announced a program today to reduce incidents of police brutality in the city.

title: Frames That Only Look Antique
description: CHOOSING a picture frame requires sensitivity and care, said Charles Schreiber, the president of the House of Heydenryk, a custom frame shop on the Upper East Side. "If you notice the frame first when you look at a picture, we've made a mistake," Mr. Schreiber said.

title: Insurance Reform Urged
description: Reforms are needed to stabilize the health insurance market that serves small businesses, Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said. In a speech Tuesday, he dismissed calls for national health insurance, but added, "It is vital that the small group market be stabilized so that the small businesses can get insurance at an affordable cost." Businesses with fewer than 25 employees represent 89 percent of all United States companies and employ about one-third of the country's workers.

title: Wilder Explores a Run for President in 1992
description: L. Douglas Wilder, who has made no secret of his White House ambitions since taking office as Governor of Virginia almost 15 months ago, filed papers today to form a committee of advisers who will explore his prospects as a 1992 Presidential candidate.

title: Hurley Hopes Dreams Don't Come True
description: Just when Bobby Hurley thought it was safe to go back to the Final Four. . . .

title: Fed Eases Bank Rule
description: The board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board voted today to liberalize regulation K, which governs international bank operations. The change will allow a modest increase in the amount of equity underwriting that American banks can do outside the United States, a Fed spokesman said.

title: Corrections
description: The Uncovered Short Sales table in Business Day on Friday, listing shares sold short on the New York Stock Exchange and not yet covered, misstated the figure for CUC International for the month ended Feb. 15. It was 1,795,179.

title: ISRAELIS ADVISED TO KILL ASSAILANTS
description: Israel's Police Minister advised members of the public today to kill any Palestinian seen brandishing a knife apparently with the intent of killing Jews.

title: BUSH AIMS REBUKE AT SCHWARZKOPF FOR TRUCE REMARK
description: President Bush said today that the allied commander in the Persian Gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, was wrong in saying that the President ended the war when General Schwarzkopf wanted to carry out the total destruction of Iraq's forces in the war zone.

title: Not a Trellis? Oh, I See!
description: WHEN it comes to improving a garden wall, there's nothing like traditional French trelliswork for texture or an illusion of depth. A variety of patterns and designs are possible with these mix-and-match panels imported from France.

title: Soviet Opposition Defies Ban on Rally
description: Opposition leaders defied a Kremlin warning today and called on the public to ignore the Soviet Government's ban on staging a rally in the capital Thursday on behalf of Boris N. Yeltsin, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief critic and rival.

title: U.S. OFFERS A PLAN FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: The Bush Administration is exploring the possibility of convening regional peace talks, with the United States and the Soviet Union as hosts, that would serve as the opening for direct negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors, Western and Middle East diplomats said today.

title: New Chief For Philip Morris
description: In a bold departure from having tobacco men as its chairmen, the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, named Michael A. Miles its chairman and chief executive yesterday, effective Sept. 1.

title: Warner-Lambert Meets With F.D.A.
description: The Warner-Lambert Company met with officials from the Food and Drug Administration to discuss Cognex, its Alzheimer's drug. The F.D.A. refused to approve the drug last week and called for new tests to determine its safety.

title: Aldo Ray, Actor, Is Dead at 64; Portrayed Lovable Tough Guys
description: Aldo Ray, a husky, sandpaper-voiced film actor who excelled in military roles and in comedy, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Martinez, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in Crockett, Calif.

title: Browne & Sharpe
description: The Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company said it expected a 'substantial' first-quarter loss because of low orders and reduced shipments in its measurement and machine tool units. The company said it had decided to withdraw from the business of making and distributing machine tools but would continue to provide repair parts, tools, service and reconditioning for its machine tool products. The company said it expected its machine tool segment to lose more than $1 million from the portion of the business being discontinued, but that the closing would generate about $15 million in cash. Brown & Sharpe also said it planned to accelerate cost-cutting measures, including the dismissals of about 140 and 130 employees in its United States and European operations, respectively.

title: Time Warner Starts Test Of a Weekly Life Magazine
description: Life magazine, inching toward a decision about whether to turn itself from a monthly to a weekly magazine, has mailed a test issue of the proposed weekly to a group of subscribers and non-subscribers nationwide.

title: Strict Abortion Law Gains in North Dakota
description: The North Dakota Senate today approved what could become the nation's most restrictive state abortion law and sent it to Gov. George Sinner, who has hinted that he will veto it.

title: Children With a Secret (Spelled AIDS)
description: For two years, 12-year-old Joey DiPaolo kept silent. Then last fall he and his parents decided to tell his school that he had AIDS.

title: Slim Chance Is Seen for Burmese Democracy
description: Nearly a year after the military Government in Myanmar, formerly Burma, was repudiated in free elections, the prospect of any transfer of power to elected civilian authorities has grown increasingly remote, Western diplomats say.

title: Maker of PC Graphics Names New President
description: Radius Inc., a maker of high-performance monitors and personal computer graphics products, has tapped Barry James Folsom to be its new president and chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: In This Corner, Another Italian Government
description: Italian politics is often described as Byzantine and difficult to fathom, but in fact there are a few basic rules that anyone can understand:

title: Magnificent Life Inside a Treasure Chest of Black History
description: The glass wall of Montague's living room offers a sweeping vista of the Hollywood Hills and the snowcapped San Gabriel Mountains. But most visitors do not seem to notice the view because it is usually eclipsed by the facing wall.

title: Nephew to Take Over Tata Company in India
description: Jamshed Ratan Tata, a pioneer of India's industrialization and head of one of South Asia's largest corporations, has retired in favor of a younger relative.

title: Bridge
