description: Pre-emptive opening bids often achieve a triumph by goading the opponents into attempting a contract with poor chances. But the triumph turns into disaster if they make a contract that has not been reached at other tables.

title: Tax-Free Offering By a Texas County
description: Harris County, Tex. is offering $210.9 million in tax-exempt bonds with a maximum yield of 7.15 percent for an issue due 2014 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Tories Defeat Foes' Motion Of No Confidence Over Tax
description: Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party rallied tonight to defeat an opposition motion of no confidence, 358 to 238, despite feuding within the ranks and accusations that Mr. Major was being indecisive on how to replace the unpopular "poll tax."

title: Steinway Changing Amid Tradition
description: Steinway occupies a unique place in the world of music, a near-monopoly both on the concert stage and in the public image of quality. There is a sense that the 12,000 parts of a Steinway grand piano, held together with solid brass fittings and 26 types of glue, is a work of art.

title: A Confident Milutinovic Takes Over as U.S. Coach
description: Bora Milutinovic has taken English lessons for just two weeks, so he can't bark fiery commands at his new players. He doesn't know much about American soccer, or about dreary 1-0 losses to Bermuda and Switzerland.

title: Forest Service Plans Sharp Increase in Fees
description: The Forest Service is preparing a proposal to expand recreation fees at national forests by 70 percent, charging visitors for the first time to use such sites as picnic areas and boat ramps, officials said today.

title: Occidental Board Age Limit Sought
description: A proposal by the Occidental Petroleum Company shareholders would set a mandatory retirement age of 72 for board members, according to a proxy statement. Eight board members or nominees are over 72. Shareholders are also seeking to include a majority of independent, non-management personnel on the board.

title: Century of Ground-Breaking Decor
description: AT the turn of the century, a former Broadway actress named Elsie de Wolfe was tired of the dark, brooding Victorian styles that filled the rooms of New York's salon society. Preferring lots of sunlight, the color green and leopard skins, she embarked on a career that would span almost 50 years and change the look of the nation's interiors.

title: L.I. Needs New Lane To Support Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Considers Cuts
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which has cut more than 2,000 jobs in an effort to cope with the slump on Wall Street, said today that it may have to make further cutbacks this year.

title: Alcoa Reports Recycle Record
description: The Aluminum Company of America said today that it had collected a record 20 billion cans for recycling in 1990, up 17 percent from the previous year.

title: Cable Channel Seeks Funds
description: Outside investors are being sought for a new 24-hour cable television news channel based on The Christian Science Monitor newspaper that would start next month, the head of the project said today.

title: Devils Move Into 3d Place With Victory in Overtime
description: Just when it appeared that the Devils would be involved in their fourth consecutive tie game, Doug Brown scored his second goal of the game 2 minutes 47 seconds into overtime tonight for a 4-3 triumph over the Hartford Whalers.

title: In Cholesterol Struggle, A Giant Among Winners
description: For people who struggle to keep their blood cholesterol down, it can be unnerving to hear about individuals who do so with ease no matter what they eat. Those who struggle might want to stop reading now.

title: Owners Urged to Have Cats Vaccinated for Rabies
description: Citing a surge in cases of rabies in pets as well as in wild animals, New York City and State health officials yesterday urged pet owners to take the unusual precaution of having cats as well as dogs vaccinated.

title: Federal Court Dismisses Suit Over Book as Moot
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed as moot the question of whether a book written by a former Federal prosecutor in the Iran-contra case could be published, because Penguin Books has already issued the book following a lower court decision.

title: Design Ideas With the Marks Of Individuals
description: AROUND these five boroughs, architects and artists have their own way of doing some things.

title: Rare Plants on the Block
description: AFICIONADOS of unusual plants are gearing up for their annual pilgrimage to the Wilmington (Del.) Garden Center's rare plant auction on April 26.

title: Catholic Hospital Revamps To Regain Financial Health
description: St. Agnes Hospital, a 184-bed institution in critical financial condition, announced a major reorganization tonight, which a spokesman said should enable it to "regain its health and survive happily into the future."

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Campaign to Save Water Has the Hollywood Touch
description: A NIGHTMARE in which every water faucet runs dry. A Hitchcockian vision of terror in which a presence stalks a woman enjoying a long hot shower.

title: Texas House Rejects Bill to Alter School Financing
description: The Texas House of Representatives yesterday rejected a bill that would have tried to equalize spending for public schools partly by taking property tax revenue from wealthy districts and giving it to poor ones.

title: Article 504791 -- No Title
description: France's leading computer producer, Compagnie des Machines Bull, reported today as expected that it lost 6.79 billion French francs, or $1.19 billion, in 1990. The loss compared with a $45 million deficit in 1989.

title: S.E.C. Sues Ex-Drexel Aide
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had filed a securities fraud lawsuit against a former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. "junk bond" trader who had worked for Michael R. Milken.

title: Canada-U.S. Panel Is Assailed In Congress on Pork Imports
description: As the Bush Administration tries to line up support in Congress for a free-trade agreeement with Mexico, it has to sort out a dispute between 89 American lawmakers and the Canadian Government about American duties on pork imports.

title: INSIDE
description: South Africa Nearer Games The International Olympic Committee said if South Africa met certain conditions, it could return to the Olympics by 1992. Page B13. All Fingers Do the Walking The listing of names and addresses in the white pages of a phone directory is not protected by copyright law, the Supreme Court ruled. Page D1. Gov. Wilder Files for '92 Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia filed papers allowing him to begin raising funds for a 1992 Democratic Presidential campaign. Page A20. Clue to Superconductors Scientists say they have found microscopic structures that may explain a mystery about superconducting materials. Page D21. Nurturing Adoptive Families Interest is growing in Congress for measures to encourage adoption and to provide tax relief for adoptive families. The Home Section, page C1.

title: Braves Now Look To Sanders for Opener
description: The chances that Deion Sanders, the two-sport pro athlete, will be in the Atlanta Braves' opening-night lineup looked much better yesterday when the team learned that its regular left fielder, Lonnie Smith, would be lost for up to four weeks after undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his left knee.

title: U.S. Panel Endorses Bypass Surgery for Obesity
description: Stomach bypass surgery is an effective option for severely obese people who have failed more moderate weight-reduction strategies, a Federal panel of experts concluded today.

title: Baby Saved From Compactor, Where Mother, 12, Says She Put Him
description: A newborn baby was rescued from a trash compactor in Brooklyn yesterday morning when two maintenance men heard the baby's cries just as they were about to start the crushing machine's motors, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER O'TOOLE is writing his memoirs, of a ribald life and bumpy career, to be published next year by Macmillan of England .

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Arn R. Ashwood has been named vice president-creative director and Sarah C. Belle has been named vice president-management supervisor at Lockhart & Pettus Advertising and Public Relations Inc., New York.* Christopher Culver has been named executive vice president-New York sales manager for Transportation Displays Inc., an outdoor advertising concern.

title: Review/Film Festival; Vanessa Redgrave In a Cursed Triangle Of Love and Hate
description: The central figure in "The Ballad of the Sad Cafe," Simon Callow's screen adaptation of the celebrated Carson McCullers novella, is Miss Amelia (Vanessa Redgrave), a woman of most remarkable aspect. She's more than six feet tall and raw-boned, with hair cropped short like a boy's and as yellow as corn.

title: Stars and Bars Eclipsed After Bull Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Piano-Making at Steinway: Brute Force and a Fine Hand
description: In Steinway's turn-of-the century factory in Astoria, Queens, tour guides proudly tell visitors that the craftsmen and managers are bound to the company for generations. "We believe in nepotism, supremely," said Horace Comstock, the guide on a recent tour, describing a traditional, inbred world.

title: Bass Rights Issue
description: Bass P.L.C., Britain's largest brewer and the owner of the Holiday Inn hotel chain, plans to raise $:557.9 million, or $975.5 million, through a rights issue. under which stockholders can buy five rights issues for every Bass share they own at the discounted price of $:8, or about $14, a share. Bass shares trade for about $16.48. Bass said the proceeds would be used for operations and to reduce its $:1.4 billion debt.

title: Iranian President Disavows Arms Aid to the Iraqi Rebels
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani has categorically denied that Iran provided troops, arms or other kinds of military assistance to Iraqi opposition groups, saying the rebels neither need nor want Iranian intervention.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today for Holy Thursday, tomorrow for Good Friday and Saturday for the first day of Passover.

title: Milan Soccer Club Banned for a Year
description: AC Milan was banned from European club soccer for a year today because it refused to complete a Champions Cup quarterfinal match against Olympic Marseille.

title: No Regrets, Says Organizer of Drug Raid at Virginia
description: There was a moment last Thursday night, just as the drug raid began on the University of Virginia's fraternity row, when Chief John deK. Bowen of the Charlottesville police felt a pang of sorrow.

title: New Coach for Iona
description: Jerry Welsh of Potsdam State College will leave the school he took to the Division III national championship in 1981 and 1986 and become head coach at Division I Iona, both schools announced yesterday. Welsh, who is 55 years old, will replace Gary Brokaw, who resigned earlier this month, and will also serve as assistant athletic director.(AP)

title: Radios and Mine Sweepers: Problems in the Gulf
description: Unproven high-technology American weaponry performed well in the Persian Gulf war, but mundane, essential equipment like mine-clearing gear and radios had serious limitations and were sometimes in short supply, American military commanders say.

title: Jets Get Linebacker
description: The Jets, who have had linebackershigh on their wish list, have landed one of the most promising outside men available, Bobby Houston, a speedy free agent who was a third-round draft choice of the Green Bay Packers last year.

title: Lansford's Snowmobile Scare
description: Almost every day since spring training began, Carney Lansford has been sitting in the Oakland Athletics' medical room, his back propped against the wall. Slowly, he raises his surgically scarred left knee; slowly he lets it down. Up, down. Up, down. His left thigh is wrapped in a muscle stimulator. His left ankle is wrapped with five pounds of lead weights. And his baseball future is wrapped in uncertainty.

title: V.A. ACTS AFTER 43 DIE AT A HOSPITAL
description: The chief of staff of a large veterans' hospital has been demoted and two kinds of surgery discontinued after a Federal investigation showed that poor care might have caused the deaths of patients in the last two years, officials said today.

title: Reagan Reported to Back Gun-Control Bill
description: Former President Ronald Reagan, a longtime critic of gun control legislation, has decided to endorse a measure requiring a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases, The Washington Post reported Thursday.

title: Small Stocks Surge as Market Levels Off Before Holiday
description: Smaller over-the-counter stocks continued to post strong gains yesterday, but the rest of the stock market leveled off as traders pulled back before the holiday weekend.

title: Surrealpolitik
description: The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, was here this week to assure the United States that Germany would abide by its financial obligations in the gulf war effort. Last fall, Germany belatedly increased its contribution in response to allied irritation with its military free-riding, and to outrage at the role of its industry in arming Saddam Hussein. Of the more than $11 billion Bonn pledged to the allied effort, the $5.5 billion directed to the U.S. will be paid by the end of this month.

title: Kansas City Journal; Old Outpost of Slavery Joins Era of Black Mayor
description: Residents of this old frontier town, once the western outpost of pro-slavery forces, awoke today with a black Mayor-elect, their first in history. Family legend has it that the Texas shanty in which he grew up was once a slave cabin.

title: Court Limits Copyright Protection
description: In an important copyright decision, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the alphabetical listing of names and addresses in the white pages of a phone directory was not protected by Federal copyright law.

title: RULING PARTY WINS KOREA LOCAL VOTE
description: President Roh Tae Woo's governing party won a resounding victory on Tuesday, claiming more than half the posts in South Korea's first local elections in three decades.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ZULEMA YOMA DE MENEM filed for divorce yesterday from CARLOS SAUL MENEM, the President of Argentina, saying he had exposed her to extreme public humiliation.

title: Getting Congress To Support Adoption
description: AS part of a broader effort to encourage adoptions and to cover related expenses, Congress is considering a flurry of bills that would provide tax relief for adoptive families.

title: NEC's Portable
description: The NEC Corporation has begun selling a lightweight portable computer it said was the first able to communicate with other computers without a telephone line. People who use laptop computers usually have to get to a phone to send information to or retrieve it from their office computers, unless they also carry a portable cellular phone. NEC's 6.6-pound RC-9801 laptop has a built-in modem and transceiver that allow it to communicate over radio frequencies. So far the service is available only in Tokyo.

title: Now, Even Stoves Can Be Fashion Statements
description: THE avocado of the 1960's is almost extinct; black and white are popular but do not quite inspire passion. Now, for people who believe that a stove is a medium of self-expression, several companies are producing brightly colored new stoves or reconditioning ones from the 1940's and 50's in hues not seen in ordinary appliance stores.

title: Books of The Times; 'The Novel,' Michener's Novel About a Novel
description: The Novel By James A. Michener Illustrated. 446 pages. Random House. $23.

title: Events: Glass and Computer Designs
description: To Help Glassworkers Christie's New York, 502 Park Avenue (59th Street); (212) 966-1808.

title: Herbert L. Werner, 82, Industrial Consultant
description: Herbert Levy Werner, an international management consultant, died on Tuesday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Appreciating Gardens, in a Guidebook
description: VISITING gardens is as much a pursuit for gardeners as turning the soil in spring.

title: SPY CHARGES WIDEN IN GERMANY'S EAST
description: New allegations about activities of the former East German secret police have deepened a scandal that already casts an unwelcome shadow over German political life.

title: Columnists Fire Salvos to Begin War of Tabloids
description: After a bitter five-month strike, some 200 Daily News reporters and editors marched back to work to the skirl of a pipe band yesterday and found themselves in the midst of a bare-knuckled tabloid war.

title: Ronald Wogaman; Museum Official, 40
description: Ronald Wogaman, the former director of education at the South Street Seaport Museum, died on Saturday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cats Have in Many Instances Defended People
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwaitis Find the Easy Life Is a Casualty of War
description: An empty Coca-Cola can blowing in the wind rattled across the street in the middle of the once-bustling downtown commercial district lined with gold and jewelry shops, past a boutique called, simply, "Elegance." The sound was suddenly startling in the silence.

title: Libyan Prince Is Taking Control of Rebels
description: The exiled Prince Idris of Libya has said he will take control of a dissident Libyan paramilitary force that was originally trained by American intelligence advisers, and he has promised to order it into combat against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: Police Contract Talks Stalled, Dinkins Says
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that contract negotiations with the union representing police officers had reached an impasse.

title: Review/Art; Wealth and Welter At Design's Temple
description: MAYBE it requires an exhibition as chaotic as the one at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum to do justice to a collection as eclectic as the Cooper-Hewitt's. Nearly 1,000 objects, spread throughout the museum, make up "The Cooper-Hewitt Collections: A Design Resource." Somewhere among the silverware, model cars, wallpapers, appliances, books, jewelry, prints, chairs, bird cages, lamps and door locks may well be a kitchen sink.

title: Car Output Off in Week
description: United States auto makers are scheduled to make 99,810 cars this week, compared with 108,706 a week ago and 135,907 in the comparable week in 1990, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Light-truck production for the week was scheduled at 64,028, compared with last week's 61,345 and last year's 89,170, the trade journal reported.

title: Study Says 165 in House Can Put Excess War Chest to Personal Use
description: If they leave office at the end of their terms next year, 165 House members could pocket $41 million in leftover campaign money for personal use, says a study made public today.

title: Review/Art; A French Photographer Who Invades Lives And Records Them
description: Since the beginning of the 20th century, the line between art and life has been blurred more times than anyone can count, but that's not stopping a French artist named Sophie Calle from adding some more erasures to this famously fuzzed demarcation. She makes her art by invading the lives of others, with or without their consent, recording their thoughts, shadowing their movements or examining their belongings. Her main tools are the camera and the notebook and occasionally a disguising wig or pair of sunglasses. Her art is basically Conceptual -- combining photographs and texts with an element of performance art -- but its flavor is as French as a Truffaut film or a novel by Marguerite Duras.

title: Can't Somebody Help Our Suffering Libraries?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Drown and 2 Are Missing In a Swollen California River
description: The flooded Calaveras River swept away five young boys Wednesday evening. Two boys drowned and two were still missing today.

title: Governor Issues School Contract That He Says Ends Denver Dispute
description: Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, who three months ago took on the unusual task of personally writing a labor agreement for the Denver Public Schools, has presented his contract to teachers and the school board and told them it was binding.

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts yesterday from a television interview with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf omitted several words. The sentence, part of a discussion of American attacks on Iraqi Republican Guard forces at the end of the Persian Gulf war, should have read, "Matter of fact, they were north of the river and we probably could have, had we gone on for another 24 hours, we could have inflicted terrible damage on them with air attacks and that sort of thing on the far side of the river."

title: U.S. Uncertain of Fate of Iraqi Uranium Big Enough for One Atom Bomb
description: More than two months after allied warplanes first attacked Iraqi nuclear reactors and weapons-research centers, the United States is uncertain whether the raids destroyed 27.6 pounds of weapons-grade uranium that could be fashioned into a single atomic bomb, senior Administration officials say.

title: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; An Executive and His Wife Struggling Overseas
description: These are remarkably productive days for a 29-year-old playwright named Jon Robin Baitz. His play "The Substance of Fire" has just had its run extended at Playwrights Horizon in New York. His "Dutch Landscape" was performed recently at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. And tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the "American Playhouse" presentation of "Three Hotels" provides Mr. Baitz with an opportunity to be both writer and director.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York, is working with the Partnership for a Drug-Free America on a pro-bono print campaign that is intended to reach the parents of teen-agers. Using the theme line "Encourage your kid's habit," one aspect of the campaign advocates participation in such "habit forming" activities as sports, dance and music. Another ad, entitled "A Drug Test for Parents," outlines eight visible symptoms of drug use.

title: Home Loan Bank Picks San Francisco President
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco said yesterday that it had elected Dean M. Schultz president and chief executive, effective April 1.

title: Campbell Soup Bid
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it intended to bid $34.50 (Canadian), or $29.73, a share for all shares of its Canadian affiliate, the Campbell Soup Company Ltd., that it did not own. The parent company said it owned about 71 percent of the Toronto-based affiliate's 14.8 million shares outstanding. It said the offer was conditioned on its being able to buy at least 90 percent of the shares it did not own.

title: Critic's Choice/Music; 'Parsifal,' an Opera Of Transformation
description: Because of the confluence of Passover and Easter, most of New York City's concert halls are closed this weekend. But the Metropolitan Opera is open, and tonight at 6:30 it is offering its new "Parsifal" production. One could do far worse than to invest five and a half hours on Good Friday in Wagner's involved and highly symbolic story of a guileless innocent who is transformed, through moral strength and compassion, into the king of the knights who guard the Holy Grail.

title: Bush Tells Schwarzkopf 'Not to Worry'
description: In an attempt to put out a political brush fire over American policy in Iraq, the White House announced today that President Bush had telephoned Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and reassured him that he was not in trouble for questioning the decision to stop attacking Iraqi forces last month.

title: I.B.M. Taking Big Charge and Cutting Jobs
description: I.B.M. announced yesterday that it was taking a $2.3 billion charge, which will probably result in a large quarterly loss, to pay for the retirement benefits of current employees. The company also said it will shrink its worldwide work force by 14,000 employees this year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The U.S. is interfering in the domestic affairs of Iraq. How can they say they're not intervening when they're making it easy for the Iraqi military occupation to hold on? What they are doing is against the principles of the American nation, which believes in freedom and self-determination." -- Hojatolislam Mohammed Bakr al-Hakim, the leader of an Iraqi Shiite opposition group. [ A6:5. ]

title: TV Refunds by Mitsubishi
description: Mitsubishi Electronics America has agreed to refund $7.95 million to consumers to settle charges that it fixed prices of television sets.

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE AND SLIDE PRESENTATION, Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street, Manhattan. "House of Heritage," a discussion of the history of the museum and the changes affecting the surrounding area, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $2. Information: (212) 431-0233.

title: Market Place; Higher-Risk Funds Lure Investors
description: SINCE the Persian Gulf war ended last month, mutual fund investors have been shifting their money out of conservative investments like government-securities funds and into riskier investments like stock funds specializing in growth companies and high-yield bond funds.

title: SUNY Trustees Vote New Policy On Tuition Rise
description: The 400,000 students at the State University of New York would face automatic increases in annual tuition under a broad new tuition policy adopted today by the system's Board of Trustees.

title: U.S. Opens Defense
description: A patchwork, but still powerful United States team will open its defense of the Davis Cup at Mexico City this weekend. America's top two players, Andre Agassi, ranked fifth in the world, and Pete Sampras, No. 6, were unavailable for this match, which had been postponed from Feb. 1-3 because of concern over the team's safety during the Persian Gulf war. Agassi has a previous commitment and Sampras is injured.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Jazz Wanderer

title: U.S. Overestimates Peril of Radon in Homes, New Study Says
description: A new study suggests that Americans are exposed to only about a third as much radon inside their homes as monitoring devices indicate, and that many have probably spent money needlessly to get rid of the gas.

title: A Child-Mother in the Jaws of New York
description: At 12 years old, the New York City girl is already an orphan, a rape victim and a mother. Now, two days after her newborn son was rescued from the maw of a trash compactor, she has become something more -- a symbol of the violence that stalks the young in some corners of this city.

title: Books of The Times; Portrait of a Family From Shifting Points of View
description: Now You See It By Cornelia Nixon 186 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: Newark's Unsung Delights
description: It happens every time. You let people know that there is a sprawling, historic, undiscovered city only half an hour from midtown Manhattan. You explain that they'll be able to explore celebrated inexpensive restaurants, neighborhood exotica, a world-class museum and engage in a bit of sightseeing.

title: Struggling Valenzuela Is Put on Waivers
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Mexican left-hander who gained stardom with the Dodgers 10 years ago, was placed on waivers today by Los Angeles.

title: Investigator Arrests 5 in 6 Weeks In the Sexual Abuse of Students
description: Saying he is "surprised by the extent of the problem," the New York City school system's new chief investigator yesterday announced his office's fifth arrest in six weeks involving the sexual abuse of students.

title: American Express Notes
description: The American Express Credit Corporation, a unit of the American Express Company, priced $300 million in one- year notes due April 8, 1992, through Lehman Brothers yesterday.

title: Gridiron Hero
description: Following are excerpts from speeches by Robert S. Strauss, the former Democratic chairman, and James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State, at the annual Gridiron Club dinner on Saturday. Landon Parvin prepared both speeches. Robert S. Strauss

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Alaska Air Group Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $220 million in liquid-yield option notes due 2006 through Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: Top Players Honored
description: Larry Johnson of Nevada-Las Vegas and Dawn Staley of Virginia won the 1991 Naismith Awards yesterday as the college basketball players of the year, the Atlanta Tipoff Club announced.

title: Zgon Der Hagopian, Armenian Bishop, 86
description: Bishop Zgon Der Hagopian, former Primate of the Armenian Dioceses of Baghdad and of Milan, died on Monday at the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: American Embassy in Moscow Is Severely Damaged by Fire
description: A fire raged through the American Embassy here today, severely damaging top-security work areas and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of embassy employees from the dilapidated building.

title: Harmony in A.T.&T.-NCR Tune
description: For the first time, A.T.& T. and NCR suggested that a negotiated deal between them appeared to be within reach.

title: Dow Off 3.71, to 2,913.86, in Slack Trading
description: Stocks seesawed yesterday, ending in a small decline, as many traders took the day off in advance of Good Friday and activity dropped to its lowest level since late January.

title: Bottom Fishing With R.D. Smith
description: In the wreckage left behind by failed corporate buyouts and mergers, a young Wall Street firm is defining and dominating a niche as a one-stop shop for investors interested in the securities of troubled companies.

title: Mass for Mario Valentino
description: A memorial Mass for Mario Valentino, a fashion designer with stores in Manhattan and several foreign cities, will be celebrated on Wednesday at 10 A.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mr. Valentino died at his home in Naples on Jan. 31 at the age of 64.

title: Six Sabahs Tied To Retribution
description: Members of Kuwait's ruling family were involved in the killings of Palestinians and others suspected of collaborating with the Iraqi occupation, a Western diplomat said today.

title: Tony Scopino; Dancer, 33
description: Tony Scopino, a tap dancer and a director of the Manhattan Tap company, died on March 13 at Uncas on the Thames, a hospital in Norwich, Conn. He was 33 years old.

title: Restaurants
description: '21' Club

title: Herbert R. Jordan; Executive, 61
description: Herbert R. Jordan, founder and president of the General Tire Company of New Jersey, died Wednesday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf; What Security Threat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; No, Not on MTV, But He's New, This Haydn Guy
description: "Learning about classical music is like learning to eat Chinese food," said Peter Phillips. "It may seem strange at first, but once you taste it, you always want more."

title: Leader of Iraqi Shiites Says Rebellion Has Lost Ground
description: The leader of a major Iraqi Shiite opposition group conceded today that Saddam Hussein's forces had recaptured virtually all cities and towns in southern Iraq and that Iraqi rebel forces were now reduced to fighting mainly in rural areas.

title: Can't Somebody Help Our Suffering Libraries?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Albany, Budget Talk Means Casting Blame
description: With negotiations foundering just three days before a new state budget is supposed to be in place, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the legislative leaders did today what they normally do in times of crisis: they blamed each other.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ajay Sports Inc., Delavan, Wis., which makes golf accessories, said it was in a group called Sports Acquisition Corp. that had offered $8.4 million for the assets of MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc., Fond du Lac, Wis. * Cliggott Publishing Co., Greenwich, Conn., said its officers would buy the company from its parent, Media General Inc., Richmond. Terms were not disclosed.

title: This Court Offers Condoms With Prostitutes' Sentences
description: A judge in Manhattan's arraignment court began his own experiment in AIDS prevention this week, when in place of the usual Criminal Court revolving door, he offered nine prostitutes AIDS counseling, free condoms and a chance to be tested for the disease.

title: Review/Film; 25 Animated Shorts From Britain
description: "The British Animation Invasion," a breathlessly paced new anthology of animated shorts from Britain, doesn't call itself an invasion for nothing.

title: Auctions
description: After the Boom

title: U.S. Diplomats Prepare for Return to Albania
description: Richard T. Muller, one of the first United States Government officials to set foot in this country since 1946, stood with his camera in front of a villa here in the capital and spoke to the blue-uniformed policemen guarding it.

title: New Jersey Buyers Can Sue Sellers Over Polluted Land
description: People who buy property in New Jersey and find out that it was polluted by previous owners can sue the sellers for cleanup and other damages, the State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Reviews/Film; Struggling to the Top With the Five Heartbeats
description: "I think you guys have what it takes to go all the way to the top," says the would-be manager of the Five Heartbeats, speaking in the tried-and-true idiom of the show-business success story. But "The Five Heartbeats," Robert Townsend's saga of a fast-rising rhythm-and-blues group of the 1960's, is more ambitious than most. Mr. Townsend, the director of the satirical "Hollywood Shuffle," takes on drama, romance, racism and show-business muckraking, not to mention the evolution of black music from Motown to rap.

title: Dynamics Gets Korea Jet Deal
description: In a surprising reversal of one of the United States' biggest arms deals, the South Korean Government said today that it was dropping the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from a $5 billion program to build fighter planes for its air force, and would award the contract instead to the General Dynamics Corporation, the maker of the F-16.

title: Manhattan Crowd Assails Turkey's Leader
description: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey was harangued and pelted with eggs by a crowd of about 300 demonstrators as he left a Manhattan hotel last night.

title: 36 Break 70 in Opener of Players Championship
description: Near-perfect conditions led to record low scoring today in the opening round of the Players Championship.

title: Hecklers Disrupt Talk By Former Klan Leader
description: A speech here by David Duke, the Louisiana legislator who was a leader of the Ku Klux Klan and founder of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, was interrupted tonight by relentless heckling by protesters, leading to one arrest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the "By Design" report on the Fashion page on Tuesday, about pleated skirts, omitted the name of a shop at 115 Prince Street in Manhattan. It is the Agnes B. Boutique.

title: New Lighting for Grand Central Elegance
description: Something snapped just after dark yesterday and it lighted up Grand Central Terminal like a 136,000-watt cartoon idea bulb. Mayor David N. Dinkins threw a switch that inaugurated the newest splash of light in the wave of illumination that washes over the Manhattan skyline at night.

title: Review/Piano; Peter Serkin With an Old-New Mix
description: Peter Serkin's career has been a model of unconventional consistency. From his teen-age years to the present, he has explored new and difficult music that most other musicians avoid. He now dips into the 19th-century repertory more often than in his tradition-defying youth, but the 43-year-old pianist continues to be attracted to music by more recent, often living, composers. That is not a sure-fire formula for concert or recital success, but he has attracted an audience that loves him all the more for his history of ignoring sure-fire formulas.

title: Review/Film; A Grand Guignol Along Venice's Grand Canal
description: Paul Schrader's "Comfort of Strangers" is about decadence in Venice, a place of long golden afternoons, steamy nights, grand palazzos, dark alleys, incredible beauty, unrecognized malignancies and, finally, death.

title: 'Easter Oratorio'
description: Frederick Grimes is to conduct the Holy Trinity Choir and Bach Orchestra in Bach's "Easter Oratorio" on Sunday at 5 P.M. at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West at 65th Street in Manhattan. The Sinfonia from Cantata No. 29 is also to be performed. Nancianne Parrella is the organist. Admission is free. Information: (212) 877-6815.

title: James E. Gahagan, 86, Transit Union Leader
description: James Edward Gahagan, a founding member of the first local of the Transport Workers Union, Local 100 in Manhattan, died March 18 at Marian Medical Center in Santa Maria, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived in Santa Maria.

title: Reverse The Reversals
description: Americans who fought and won the war in the Persian Gulf return every day. Their job is finished. Now it is our turn.

title: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf; Opposed Early Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Securities a Bit Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher yesterday in unusually active pre-holiday trading. Dealers and traders said there was also a fair amount of domestic and foreign retail buying, considering that most market participants had closed their books for the quarter and in Japan for their fiscal year as well.

title: Rangers Still Shooting for Individual Goals
description: The Patrick Division race, a constant companion through the heady winter months, was missing from the Rangers' Playland practice rink today for the first time this season.

title: For F-16 Assembly Workers, Extended Life for the Line
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's new agreement with South Korea to supply 120 F-16 fighter aircraft will provide nearly $2 billion in additional revenue to the military contractor through 1999, or one-third the projected contract total of $5 billion, company officials said today.

title: Whitehurst Counting On His Curveball
description: For Wally Whitehurst, the crafting of the curveball began in childhood, an unsophisticated, untutored project undertaken in the late afternoons in his family's patch of southeastern Louisiana countryside.

title: Nike Approach To Women
description: Nike has employed an all- star roster of male athletes, including Bo Jackson and Michael Jordan, to lure men to its lines of athletic footwear. But what about women, who accounted for roughly 42 percent of all athletic shoes purchased in 1990?

title: To Newark, With Love. Philip Roth.
description: "IN my childhood imagination, Newark was always the East Coast of the American mainland," says Philip Roth. "Beyond that was the Hudson River, which was not that easy to cross in the old days. New York was to us as Europe was to New York. So when people say to me, 'You came from New York,' and I say, 'No, Newark,' and they reply, 'Well, it's the same,' I say, 'No, it wasn't.' "

title: Tokyo Stocks Up a Bit
description: Stocks closed slightly higher today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the week at 26,292.04, up 85.12 points, or just over three-tenths of a percent. For the week, the index was down 321.15 points, or 1.2 percent.

title: Sidney M. Kantoff; Executive, 75
description: Sidney Michael Kantoff, a retired textile executive, died on Tuesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Lauderhill, Fla., and Forest Hills, Queens.

title: The First U.S. Stamp Made Outside the U.S.
description: The demand for new stamps caused by the rise in postal rates on Feb. 3 has led the United States to shift printing contracts to private companies, a spokesman for the Postal Service said yesterday, and at least two stamps will be printed in Canada this year.

title: GUN CONTROL BILL BACKED BY REAGAN IN APPEAL TO BUSH
description: In a shift meant to break a logjam in the House, former President Ronald Reagan today strongly endorsed legislation requiring a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun and urged President Bush to drop his opposition to the bill.

title: Tokyo Journal; Who's Not Fit to Be Governor? Just Look at This
description: By the sedate standards of Japanese politics, the race for Governor of Tokyo is not a typical election.

title: 'Junk Bonds' Post Their Best Quarter
description: Completing their best quarter ever, high-yield "junk bonds" posted a return of 6.2 percent in March, according to an index of 340 issues compiled by the First Boston Corporation.

title: A Team That Makes the 3 Can End Up as the Final 1
description: On the night in New Orleans four years ago that Indiana won its fifth national basketball championship, Bob Knight added the numbers to confirm that the college game had been changed forever.

title: Paul B. Johnson; Pediatrician, 99
description: Dr. Paul B. Johnson, a pediatrician who practiced in Manhattan for more than 60 years, died on March 12 at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn. He was 99 years old and lived in Cheshire, Conn., and Saranac Lake, N.Y. Before retirement in 1981 he had lived in the Bronx for many years.

title: A.T.&T. Move Set On Unix Systems
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would announce next Wednesday that a consortium of investors would acquire an interest in its Unix Systems Laboratory operation. It said the investors - Japanese, European and American companies - would acquire 20 to 30 percent of Unix Systems, a software publisher that developed the widely used Unix operating system program for computers.

title: What We Have Wrought
description: Military victory in the Persian Gulf produced a surge of American pride that is undiminished a month later. We crushed Saddam Hussein's forces at a cost of fewer than 200 allied lives.

title: Review/Film; How Elitist Roaches See the World
description: "My name is Naomi and I am 19 years old."

title: Accounts
description: * The National Cable Television Association, an organization that represents local system operators, cable networks and equipment suppliers, to Bozell Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Group W Satellite Communications to Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners, New York, for its Country Music Television, a 24-hour music video network, and Group W Sports Marketing Group. Billings were not disclosed. The agency already handles Group W's Nashville Network, Nashville Network Radio and Request, a pay-per-view network.

title: More on Graduation: Degrees of Separation
description: What are educators to make of the disparity of graduation rates between the male athletes at, say, Duke University and the University of Nevada-Las Vegas?

title: Islanders Fall; Capitals and Devils Clinch
description: Brett Hull finally scored on his 11th shot of the game and Vincent Riendeau stopped 27 shots tonight as the St. Louis Blues topped the 100-point mark for the second time in franchise history with a 3-0 victory over the Islanders.

title: The Good Friday-Passover Connection
description: This year, as Good Friday comes to an end, Passover will begin, and Jews all over the world will sit down to the seder, the ceremonial banquet that commemorates and re-enacts the exodus from Egypt. Though Good Friday and Passover rarely overlap, the connection between them is more than coincidence.

title: Judge Says He's Heard No Evidence Supporting Embezzling Charge in Flake Case
description: Three weeks into the trial of the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a Federal judge indicated yesterday that prosecutors were on shaky grounds with the embezzlement and some other charges against the Congressman from Queens.

title: Pregnant 26-Year-Old Killed In Crash, but Infant Survives
description: A 26-year-old woman who was seven months pregnant was killed in an automobile accident in Queens yesterday, but doctors were able to save her baby, the police said.

title: At the Movies
description: Apted's Sevens

title: Review/Dance; A Dash of Fresh Energy in the Serene Stillness
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company requires a very special dancer: the steps and phrases of movement in Mr. Hawkins's choreography often look simple when in fact the simplicity of the dancer's shape is very difficult to obtain.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Changing Scene

title: Chronicle
description: NIGEL HAWTHORNE will step out of his role as C. S. Lewis in "Shadowlands" on Broadway today to read from Lewis's work in public for the first time. Mr. Hawthorne is to conduct a free reading from "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" at 1 P.M. at F. A. O. Schwarz, Fifth Avenue and 58th Street, as part of the store's promotion of toys and children's books from Britain.

title: Conservative 'Outsiders' Now at Hub of Power
description: When a handful of conservative law students formed the Federalist Society 10 years ago, they very much thought of themselves as an oppressed minority.

title: Mississippi, in Veto Override, Orders Delay Before Abortion
description: The Legislature voted today to override the Governor's veto of legislation requiring a 24-hour waiting period for women who want abortions.

title: Immunex Drug's F.D.A. Approval
description: The Immunex Corporation said that Leukine, its genetically engineered drug that promotes the growth of infection-fighting white blood cells, had been granted orphan drug status by the Food and Drug Administration. Such status gives Immunex seven years to market Leukine exclusively for treating bone-marrow transplant patients with certain cancers.

title: Texan Thrives on a Hard Day's Work
description: For a swimmer who once skipped morning practice to eat doughnuts, Shaun Jordan has certainly changed. The University of Texas senior was a workhorse today, swimming three afternoon heats and three evening finals as the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's championships began in his home pool.

title: Mr. Reagan Finally Leads on Guns
description: The gun control campaign conducted by James Brady, who was wounded in the 1981 Presidential assassination attempt, has touched millions of Americans. But until yesterday, one prominent American remained oddly silent. Ronald Reagan, target of the bullet Mr. Brady stopped, seemed oblivious to his former press secretary's cause.

title: Chronicle
description: When SYLVESTER STALLONE is next seen on screen, he will not be playing a macho hunk and he will speak in complete sentences. In "Oscar," a comedy, Mr. Stallone will be playing a gangster trying to go straight.

title: LOOKING OVERSEAS FOR SCHOOL EXAMS
description: Reacting to concern about the link between education and the nation's economic competitiveness, a Congressional research group, began looking at examination systems in other countries today and their implications for possible national testing of American students.

title: Leaders of Plastics Industry Seeking 25% Recycling Goal
description: Perceiving a strong public demand for environmentally sound products, leaders of the plastics industry said today that they would seek to recycle 25 percent of all plastic bottles and containers produced every year by 1995.

title: Economic Scene; Postwar Goals Of Turkey's Chief
description: PRESIDENT Turgut Ozal of Turkey, a short, rotund man, is an electrical engineer by profession, who describes himself as "logical, rational." Just the eighth president of his country, he is the first who was not a military officer. Interviewed here at Duke University on his swing through Eastern educational institutions, after talks in Washington with President Bush, Mr. Ozal made clear his belief that Turkey, having contributed significantly to the war against Iraq, could play a significant role as a peace maker. And he made no bones of saying that he was seeking economic benefits for Turkey.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: INSIDE
description: Fire at Embassy in Moscow

title: New Honda Has 5 Cylinders
description: The Honda Motor Company introduced a new four-door sedan today with a five-cylinder engine. The mid-sized Vigor will cost $22,000 to $26,000 and is scheduled to go on sale next month.

title: Durufle Requiem
description: Bruce Fifer is to conduct the Cathedral Combined Choirs in Maurice Durufle's Requiem tonight at 8 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1049 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, in Manhattan. The soloists are Mary Ann Hart, mezzo-soprano, and Cheyne Davidson, baritone. Dorothy Papadakos is to be the organist. Admission is free. Information: (212) 662-2133.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times on March 12 depicting the shortest route connecting 532 cities credited the information erroneously. The sources were Dr. Manfred Padberg of New York University and Dr. Giovanni Rinaldi of the Institute for Systems Analysis in Rome.

title:
About Real Estate;
New Rental in Chinatown For Low-Income Elderly
description: A building with two developers, two sets of architects, three lenders and two addresses is rising on a city-owned site at Walker, Baxter and Centre Streets in Manhattan's Chinatown after eight years of planning.

title: More Scams From the Annals of Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Nintendo Is Backed
description: Nintendo of America Inc. said a Federal judge had granted a preliminary injunction that bars the Atari Games Corporation and its Tengen Inc. subsidiary from selling or copying Nintendo's copyrighted computer programs for use in its video games. It said Atari had incorporated the programs into video games that were compatible with those of the Nintendo entertainment system. Atari Games officials could not be reached for comment. Nintendo of America is a unit of the Nintendo Company of Japan.

title: IRAQ, HITTING HARD, REPORTS BIG GAINS AGAINST THE KURDS
description: Iraqi troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein began a major attack today on Kurdish rebels who have occupied a vital oil city in northern Iraq for about a week, diplomats in Cairo said.

title: 2 Gaza Arabs Die and a Jew Is Stabbed
description: Two Palestinians were shot and killed by Israeli troops in the Gaza Strip on Thursday, and one elderly Jew was stabbed and wounded by a Palestinian in Jerusalem's Old City.

title: Jordan Scores 42 as Bulls Rout Nets
description: The Nets tried. They worked the ball. They played defense. Didn't matter. Michael Jordan makes hard work irrelevant.

title: Delta Air Seeks $500 Million In First Offering Since 1962
description: Delta Air Lines announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of seven million common shares, or nearly $500 million at current market prices, its first offering since 1962.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News columns of Business Day yesterday misstated the terms of an offering of stock rights by Bass P.L.C. A right to buy one new share will be issued for every five Bass shares held, not the reverse.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Out From Under the Refrigerator

title: Ramsey Clark Plans Inquiry
description: Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, announced the formation today of an international commission of inquiry to gather evidence on charges that United States committed war crimes in the gulf war. Mr. Clark, a frequent critic of American foreign policy, said the commission's final report would be put before an international tribunal, whose membership he did not disclose.

title: Why I'm for the Brady Bill
description: "Anniversary" is a word we usually associate with happy events that we like to remember: birthdays, weddings, the first job. March 30, however, marks an anniversary I would just as soon forget, but cannot.

title: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf; Information Breakdown
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH POLYGAMISTS ALLOWED TO ADOPT
description: The Utah Supreme Court has tacitly acknowledged the practice of polygamy as an alternative way of life, entitled to at least some legal protection.

title: Ford's First Nationwide Bank Faulted
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that a subsidiary, the First Nationwide Bank in San Francisco, had been criticized by Federal regulators after an examination and that it expected to sign an agreement soon to change some business practices and to pay a fine.

title: Warren Chappell, Illustrator, Teacher And Artist, 86, Dies
description: Warren Chappell, a book illustrator and graphic artist, died on Tuesday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 years old.

title: Myth of Fraternities as Sanctuaries Crumbles With Virginia Drug Raid
description: The 33 fraternities at the University of Virginia exist in a world of their own, having fallen years ago into a crack between school and city jurisdictions. Students interviewed on campus say municipal and university rules on drug and alcohol use applied but were not enforced.

title: Death From Lead Exposure Prompts Call for Yearly Tests
description: Health officials are calling for yearly blood tests for lead poisoning in young children after a Wisconsin infant died from exposure to lead-based paint, the first such death reported in more than a decade.

title: U.S. Urges the Kremlin To Lift Ban on Protests
description: The United States urged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to lift his ban on protests in Moscow "as soon as possible" and said any attempt to use force to stop demonstrations would violate Soviet commitments to human rights under the Helsinki accords.

title: Journalists Meet And See Gloom On Job Security
description: With many news organizations in the economic doldrums and work force reductions becoming commonplace, there is an undercurrent of worry at the annual convention of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists that began in New York yesterday.

title: Rise in Inflation Cited by I.L.O.
description: Inflation was higher in 28 industrialized and developing countries in 1990 than it was the year before, according to a survey released today by the International Labor Organization, a Geneva-based agency.

title: A Positive Drug Test Reported for Maradona
description: Diego Maradona, the captain of Argentina's national team and of the defending Italian League champion, Naples, tested positive for drugs after a recent game, his team said yesterday in Rome.

title: Review/Art; The Flowers That Show Mondrian Had a Softer, More Intimate Side
description: Forty-seven years after Piet Mondrian's death, we are finally getting an exhibition devoted solely to his flowers, those spare, sometimes quivering images that expose many sides of the artist in whose abstract grids nature seems both distilled and stilled.

title: Bloomberg Is Starting Financial News Service
description: Michael Bloomberg is moving into the financial news business. The audacious former Salomon Brothers trader, whose computer terminals deliver financial data and analysis to a loyal following of securities traders, will be in direct competition with such giants as Reuters Inc., Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Inc.

title: Boston's Marshall Fined
description: Mike Marshall, unhappy with a utility role and the failure of the Boston Red Sox to trade him, was fined $250 and threatened with stiffer penalties yesterday for walking out of training camp in Winter Haven, Fla.

title: Review/Film; Some 60's Musicians On the Road to Nowhere
description: Being realists, the five quasi-professional jazz musicians in "American Blue Note" know that they aren't going anywhere, unless it's perhaps someplace they can drive to in their own car. Transportation is often the first -- and sometimes the only -- concern of the Jack Solow Quintet's prospective employers. Musical ability takes a definite back seat, but somehow the group members persevere.

title: 'The Doors' Captures Hysteria of an Era
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Because of printing requirements, some Weekend features appear outside section C today. Restaurant reviews and advertising are on pages A12-13. Television and radio news, listings and advertising are on pages B14-15.

title: Mary C. O'Connor; Community Board Member, 80
description: Mary C. O'Connor, a former chairwoman of Community Board 6 on the East Side of Manhattan, died on Sunday at Bellevue Hospital Center, where she was taken after she was hit by a truck at Second Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Special Education: Sharing the Pain
description: New York's Board of Regents will now allow slightly larger classes for handicapped children. That's a reasonable step to help ease budget pressures in many school districts. But it also ought to prompt a re-examination of educational services for handicapped children.

title: Adios, Freddie, Adios
description: In the clubhouse, where all the players have nicknames, the Dodgers called him Freddie, to Anglicize his given name.

title: New Jersey Redistricting Sets Off Debate on Shift in Minority Voters
description: New Jersey today became the first state to adopt new legislative districts based on the 1990 census, setting off a debate that is expected to be played out across the nation this year over how best to use redistricting to increase minority voters' influence.

title: House and Senate Leaders Are Split On Overhaul of Campaign Financing
description: As proposals to tighten campaign finance laws advance through Congress at the fastest pace in years, House and Senate leaders are divided on whether a bipartisan consensus to overhaul the system can be reached.

title: The General vs. the President
description: What makes the contretemps between Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf and his Commander in Chief so disappointing is that the first time around, he was the very model of a patriotic general.

title: For Children
description: Easter Egg Exhibition and Demonstration Ukrainian Museum 203 Second Avenue (near 12th Street) Manhattan (212) 228-0110 Recommended ages: 8 and up Tomorrow

title: 20 Companies Get U.S. Help With Japan
description: The Commerce Department has picked for special Federal trade assistance 20 American companies willing to make a long-term commitment to develop the Japanese market. The move is unusual for an Administration that has generally been ruled by principles of the free market and non-interference in the corporate sector.

title: Barkley Fined And Suspended
description: Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, yesterday suspended Charles Barkley of the 76ers without pay from the game last night against the Hornets in Charlotte, N.C. The suspension stemmed from his misconduct in Tuesday night's game against the Nets in New Jersey.

title: Cinema Is Battleground Of Geography and Psychology
description: This village of unassuming houses separated by squares of lawn is a snapshot of blue-collar suburbia: quiet streets, neighbors who know each other and children whose dream is to stay.

title: Bank of New York Prices Certificates
description: The Bank of New York priced $750 million in credit card certificates yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: PRISONS FAULTED ON COMBATING AIDS
description: While prisons have more people infected with AIDS than any other public institution, the National Commission on AIDS said today, prison officials have wasted an opportunity to treat and educate those inmates.

title: A Repeat of 1957 Final Is Too Much to Ask
description: Kansas and North Carolina will meet tomorrow evening in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, the first time they have played in the tournament since the 1957 championship game, the only three-overtime game in the history of the N.C.A.A. final.

title: Los Angeles Force Accused From Within
description: In the wake of the beating of a black motorist by white officers of the Los Angeles Police Department, several black officers have joined to accuse the department of a pattern of racial bias.

title: Consumer Spending Shows A 0.6% Climb in February
description: Consumer spending, depressed for months, rose by six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 546 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.93 billion, to $471.25 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 191 institutional funds decreased by $793.3 million, to $132.32 billion. The assets of the 265 general-purpose funds were down by $1.05 billion, to $182.16 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $149.3 million, to $156.77 billion, the institute said.

title: 15 More Areas In Subways To Be Closed
description: Saying it had learned from its mistake in leaving a high-crime subway passageway open until a woman was raped in it last week, the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that it would close 15 more subway entrances and passageways that the transit police consider dangerous.

title: Barnes Foundation Seeks to Sell Some Paintings
description: Trustees of the Barnes Foundation in Pennsylvania have petitioned a court to let it defy its founder's wishes and sell some of his paintings despite the recommendation of members of its own art advisory committee.

title: Great American
description: The Great American Bank said it was out of compliance with a capital plan approved by regulators last November. It said fourth-quarter provisions for loan and real estate losses put its capital levels on Dec. 31 at as much as $155 million less than those required by the plan. The bank had reported a loss of $173 million in the period. Non-compliance with the plan could cause the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision to impose sanctions, Great American said.

title: Lincoln Center Theater Names Andre Bishop
description: The board of the Lincoln Center Theater last night approved the appointment of Andre Bishop to succeed Gregory Mosher as director of the theater.

title: Chronicle
description: MIKE TYSON has acknowledged that he is the father of an 8-month-old girl, MICHAEL TYSON. The boxer said he was the girl's father before a hearing examiner in Family Court in Manhattan on Wednesday. The hearing arose from a suit filed in the fall by the child's mother, KIMBERLY SCARBOROUGH.

title: Chronicle
description: Senator STROM THURMOND, Republican of South Carolina, and his wife, NANCY THURMOND, are separating, the couple said yesterday in a statement to news organizations. Mrs. Thurmond, 44 years old, said she planned to pursue career options, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Thurmond, 88, is the oldest member of Congress. The couple, who married in 1968, have four children.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jazz From Vienna

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Chronicle
description: For KEVIN ROCHE, everything's coming up daffodils. The Associates of the Art Commission, whose members have served on the New York City Art Commission, gave him an award on Tuesday night for making New York a more handsome place.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Mattel Inc., Hawthorne, Calif., named Richard E. Molyneux senior vice president for technology and Larry J. Morgan senior vice president for its Asian operations. * Merck & Co., Rahway, N.J., announced several appointments as part of a realignment of management: Jerry T. Jackson, Richard J. Markham, Dr. Edward M. Scolnick and Dr. John L. Zabriskie to senior vice presidents; Dr. R. Gordon Douglas to president of the company's new vaccine division; David W. Anstice to senior vice president of the new human health division; Richard J. Lane to senior vice president of the human health division in Europe; Clarence A. Abramson to vice president and secretary, and Mary M. McDonald to vice president and general counsel.

title: Bank of Boston Expecting a Loss
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said that it expected a loss in the first quarter of the year, but that it would probebly be smaller than the $186.7 million loss posted in the fourth quarter of last year. "First-quarter results will be reported next month, and while we expect a loss for the quarter, it is likely to be substantially less than the fourth quarter of 1990," the president, Charles K. Gifford, said.

title: Washington at Work; The Secret Star of Capital Comedy
description: Landon Parvin says he is not funny. He says he prefers writing speeches on German reunification to turning out gags about John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.

title: Madison Avenue Criticized By Ad Age and an Author
description: THE agency business is abuzz, not with talk about who will win the next big account, but over a deeper question: Has Madison Avenue lost its creative edge?

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today for Good Friday and tomorrow for the first day of Passover.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S GOLF Alcott Takes Early Lead Amy Alcott, regaining the touch that has eluded her in recent years, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament in Rancho Mirage, Calif. Alcott, who has not won since 1989, forged a 2-shot lead over Ok-Hee Ku of South Korea. Laura Baugh and Pat Bradley were in a group at 70.(AP) TENNIS Seles in Quarterfinals Top-ranked Monica Seles advanced to the quarterfinals of the United States women's hardcourt championships in San Antonio yesterday with a 6-1, 6-4 victory over Claudia Porwick of Germany. Seles will now face unseeded Erika DeLone, who defeated Radka Zrubakova, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday.(AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL 43 Runs Set N.C.A.A. Record After losing by 20 runs a few weeks ago, the Methodist College baseball team did not become overconfident when it scored 15 runs in the first inning yesterday in a Division III game in Fayetteville, N.C. But then the hits kept coming and coming, and the runs followed -- a National Collegiate Athletic Association record of 43 in all -- in a 43-0 victory yesterday over Maryville, Tenn. The previous N.C.A.A. record was set by Virginia Tech in a 42-3 victory against King College in 1902. The previous lower-division record of 37 was set by Bates (Division III) against Thomas of Maine in 1985 and matched by Washburn (Division II) against Mid-American Nazarene in 1988.(AP)

title: Events Justified U.S. Use of Force in the Gulf; Return of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston U. to Meet N. Michigan in Final
description: Tony Amonte, who will be playing for the Rangers some day, had three goals for Boston University before the first period was over tonight at the National Collegiate Athletic Associations's Final Four hockey tournament.

title: Maxwell Selling Pergamon, Cornerstone of His Empire
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who bought The Daily News in New York two weeks ago, announced today that he was selling Pergamon Press, the specialty publishing house in Oxford where he began his business empire 40 years ago.

title: Most Markets Closed Today
description: Because of the Good Friday holiday, most financial markets in the United States are closed today, but there will be limited trading in Government securities.

title: 100,000 JOIN MOSCOW RALLY, DEFYING BAN BY GORBACHEV TO SHOW SUPPORT FOR RIVAL
description: More than 100,000 Muscovites defied a strong show of military force and Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ban on public meetings to rally today behind his rival, Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: The Supreme Court's Harmful Error
description: In wanton disregard of its own precedents, the Supreme Court has announced that the wrongful use of a coerced confession at a criminal trial need not automatically require the reversal of a conviction. Even if the accused was clubbed into confessing, the prosecution's use of that confession can be deemed "harmless error," a minor flaw in an otherwise fair trial.

title: Loud and Nasty: The Hound on Radio
description: EVERY Saturday afternoon at 3, the world becomes a little less refined. While some people are taking in a matinee at the opera or visiting a quiet art gallery, WFMU-FM (91.1) is awakening with a snarl. It is time for the Hound.

title: Pfizer's Executive Move
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that William C. Steere Jr., president of the New York-based health-care and chemicals company, would become chief executive on May 1. He will take over from Edmund T. Pratt Jr., who will retire at age 65 next year after 20 years as chairman. Mr. Steere, who is 54, became president of Pfizer last month, succeeding Gerald D. Laubach, who retired.

title: George H. Dunlap, 85, An Insurance Leader
description: George H. Dunlap, the first general chairman and chief executive officer of Nationwide Insurance, died Wednesday at Riverside Hospital in Columbus. He was 85 years old.

title: Daimler Has 10% of Recycler
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., maker of Mercedes automobiles, said today that it was buying a 10 percent stake in Metallgesellschaft A.G. in what analysts viewed as a step into the car-recycling business.

title: Two Financiers Head National Intergroup
description: Abbey J. Butler and Melvyn J. Estrin tightened their grip yesterday on National Intergroup Inc., the $5.5 billion successor to National Steel.

title: 'Honor' Killing of Wives Is Outlawed in Brazil
description: Brazil's Supreme Court has ruled that a man can no longer kill his wife and win acquittal on the ground of "legitimate defense of honor."

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Pepsico Inc. is offering $500 million in one-year notes through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc. The notes, due April 8, 1992, have a 6 3/4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.922 to yield 6.837 percent, or about 57 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the Treasury's one-year bill. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: At The Bar; A veteran of many battles against law enforcement gone amok is no longer lonely.
description: Years ago, shortly after he had begun the lonely and unremunerative task of representing victims of police brutality, a Los Angeles lawyer named Hugh Manes approached a personal-injury practitioner. How much in damages, he asked, was a broken nose generally worth? Five thousand dollars, he was told.

title: U.N. Sees Kuwaiti Recovery From Sacking
description: Kuwait is making a good recovery from its Iraqi occupiers' widespread destruction, and most basic services should be restored within six months, the United Nations said in a report issued today.

title: Knicks' Skid Hits 4 As Rally Is Wasted
description: Just when it appeared the Knicks were headed for their third overtime in the last four games last night, Mitch Richmond stepped in and handed them a loss instead.

title: Key Rates
Federal Reserve
Campeau Units' Plans Approved
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge approved plans by Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation for remodeling projects costing nearly $60 million. Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. also backed the closings of Jordan Marsh stores in Southbury, Conn., on Saturday and in Hollywood, Fla., on Sunday.

title: Rally Takes Kremlin Terror And Turns It Into Burlesque
description: A fresh snow began falling, bolstering the vast street crowd's remarkable serenity in the face of a show of Kremlin police power that the marchers first took as an insult, then finally mocked as a burlesque of the terror that once made the Kremlin fearful.

title: The Velarde Shuffle: Where Will It End?
description: Randy Velarde has questions, but no answers. He isn't sure whether he is contending for a job at third base for the Yankees or at shortstop, having been shuttled from one position to the other in the last few days. He is still waiting for his batting stroke to appear.

title: Corrections
description: The National Hockey League standings yesterday misstated the playoff status of the New Jersey Devils in some editions. The team had not yet clinched a spot in the playoffs.

title: How to Police the Police
description: If it hadn't been for an alert witness with a videocam, the infamous police beating in Los Angeles might never have come to light. That adds weight to the already strong argument for expanding civilian oversight of big city police departments.

title: Your Money; 11th-Hour Moves To Reduce Taxes
description: Even at this late date, taxpayers can reduce their tax bite for 1990 by making the right filing choices, being alert to recent tax-law changes and contributing to an I.R.A., if eligible.

title: Jack Davis, Canadian Politician, 74
description: Jack Davis, Canada's first Minister of the Environment, died of cancer on Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

title: College Basketball: Final Four; Carolina Coach Plants Psychological Seed
description: Standing on a podium in a hotel ballroom Thursday night, in search of an after-dinner laugh, Dean Smith, the coach of North Carolina, may have introduced the best description of his school's first Final Four appearance in nine years. He called the Saturday semifinal between the Tar Heels and the Kansas Jayhawks a preliminary game.

title: Building Plans for Foley Sq. Are Unveiled
description: Proclaiming that their project will help lift New York's sagging development industry, Federal officials unveiled the final models yesterday for a new Federal courthouse and office building on Foley Square in lower Manhattan.

title: Sharp Settles in Go-Video Suit
description: The Sharp Corporation agreed to pay $1.3 million to settle charges in a suit by Go-Video Inc. that Sharp was part of a conspiracy to prevent Go from finding a manufacturer for a dual-deck videocassette recorder. Only the Sony Corporation, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the Victor Company of Japan are left as defendants in two Go suits. The other defendants settled for about $2 million and were dropped from the suit. The first suit is scheduled for trial Tuesday in United States District Court in Phoenix.

title: Thomas Coming Back
description: Isiah Thomas, the Detroit Pistons' captain, is likely to be cleared next week to begin playing again even though his right wrist will still not be 100 percent, Dr. Kirk Watson, who performed surgery on the wrist Jan. 29 in Hartford, said yesterday.

title: Is Iraq Smashed Beyond Repair?
description: The euphoria of victory is fading even loving to hate Saddam Hussein is becoming passe -- as the Bush Administration belatedly realizes that security in the Middle East does not come out of the barrel of a gun.

title: News Still Faces Woes, Maxwell and Unions Say
description: A week after The Daily News renewed publishing with its union workers, the paper's new owner, Robert Maxwell, and union leaders agree that the paper still faces serious production and distribution problems.

title: Jail Instructor Suspended for Giving Interview
description: The Essex County Jail Annex has suspended an instructor for talking to a newspaper reporter after his superiors said they had denied him permission.

title: College Basketball; Smith Stands By Junior-College Transfer Ban
description: Coach Dean Smith of North Carolina said today that he would love to have any one of the seven players who transferred to Nevada-Las Vegas from junior colleges, but that it goes against his principles to recruit junior-college players.

title: Corporate Underwriting Set Record in Quarter
description: Despite the recession, American corporations sought huge amounts of cash from the public markets in the first quarter of 1991, with the volume bringing slightly increased fees to Wall Street.

title: Broadcasting Museum Fine Tunes Its Name
description: The Museum of Broadcasting on East 53d Street has changed its name to the Museum of Television and Radio. The change was made, said Frank A. Bennack Jr., chairman of the board of trustees, to reflect the museum's expanding collection of material that has been transmitted by means other than broadcasting airwaves, like cable and satellite.

title: Extra Performance by Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic will give nonsubscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall tonight and on Monday and Thursday evenings at 8, to fill a gap in its schedule caused by cancellation of a European tour during the Persian Gulf war.

title: 5 End Up in Hospitals and One Is Sent to Jail
description: A crime, a traffic accident, coincidence and some luck came together early yesterday in a chain of events in Brooklyn and Manhattan that left five people in hospitals and another in jail.

title: Guidepost; Adjustable Is Attractive
description: When adjustable-rate mortgages were introduced in the early 1980's, they were promoted as a lower-cost alternative to fixed-rate mortgages. Now, even with fixed-rate mortgages at their lowest rates in years -- an average of 9.41 percent -- adjustable mortgages, with initial rates averaging about 7.43 percent, are still cheaper. The rate on a variable-interest mortgage rises and falls with a particular financial index. Each lender selects its index based on an analysis of what best protects its own loan portfolio. Almost half of all adjustable-rate mortgages are tied to Treasury securities that are traded daily and mature in one year. In shopping for a mortgage, be aware that other choices are available, like two-step mortgages, which let the lender reset the rate once. Here are the more commonly used indexes, which borrowers may use as a guide in estimating how their present adjustable mortgages may change, or in seeking the best deal: Index Current Rate Rate A Year Ago One-year Treasury (estimated return) 6.41% 8.35% 11th District cost of funds (aver age yield paid on all savings by California savings institutions) 7.85 8.36 National cost of funds (average yield paid on all savings by sav ings institutions nationwide) 6.54 7.92 Source: Federal National Mortgage Association and Bank Rate Monitor

title: Gerald Wilkins May Be Out for Season
description: Just when things were beginning to look bad for the Knicks, they got worse yesterday. Gerald Wilkins, who suffered a severely sprained ankle in his team's 106-104 loss to the Golden State Warriors on Thursday night, was placed on the injured list. That left the Knicks down two regulars for tonight's game against the Nets and probably without Wilkins for the rest of the season.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING New Backstroke Mark

title: Patents; A Biological Sensor to Detect Substances
