description: Researchers at Arthur D. Little Inc., a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., have patented a biological sensor that uses cellular switches called receptors to detect particular substances electronically.

title: Farmers Get Price Rise
description: Prices that farmers receive for raw products rose 2.1 percent in March from February, the first monthly increase since May 1990, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 'A Sea Symphony'
description: Leonard Slatkin will conduct the American Symphony Orchestra and the Boston University Chorus in Ralph Vaughan Williams's "Sea Symphony" at Carnegie Hall at 3 P.M. tomorrow.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KENNY ROGERS and several other country music stars will sing at a concert to benefit the families of REBA McENTIRE's road manager and band members, who died March 16 in a plane crash 15 miles southeast of San Diego.

title: Muffin, the Pit Bull, Enjoys Being Picked Up Like a Suitcase
description: To the Editor:

title: College Basketball: Final Four; Freshman Could Be Key for Duke
description: Nevada-Las Vegas has been the uncontested king of the hill in college basketball for the last year. Beginning with a 30-point romp over Duke for the national championship last spring, through the fall, winter and spring of this season U.N.L.V. has repelled all challenges.

title: Tennis; Courier Upset in Davis Cup But Gilbert Is a Winner
description: Unruffled by the trying playing conditions, veteran Brad Gilbert gained an opening-day split for the United States in its Davis Cup tennis meeting with Mexico this afternoon after Jim Courier lost in his cup debut.

title: Patents; Quake Alarm Said to Give A Few Seconds of Warning
description: It is impossible to predict when an earthquake will strike, but two California entrepreneurs have patented a building alarm that could give people a few seconds to run for cover.

title: Washington's Last Tooth Rests in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: David J. Scott, 68, Marketing Consultant
description: David Janvier Scott, a marketing consultant and former advertising executive, died on Thursday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan and in New Hope, Pa.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bell & Howell Document Management Products Co., Chicago, has named Frank L. Rocks vice president of sales and service. * Dresser Industries, Dallas, a supplier of engineered products for the energy industry, has named John W. Caldwell president of its instrument division in Stratford, Conn.

title: Across Nassau, Democrats Left Live to Squabble
description: Outnumbered by Republicans at all levels of government, with an unpredictable cash flow and a chronically broken photocopier, Nassau County's woebegone Democrats are doing what they do best: squabbling.

title: McDonnell Revises MD-11 Jet Output
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has revised production plans for its MD-11 trijets to allow for a more gradual increase in assembly rates. The company said production over five years would rise, however, to a higher level than previously planned. McDonnell said the new plan calls for delivery of 254 MD-11's between the start of 1991 and the end of 1995, 10 more than were previously scheduled for that span.

title: U.S. to Appeal Pork Ruling Canada Won
description: Siding with Congressional protesters and rejecting a request from Ottawa, the Bush Administration announced today that it would appeal a ruling by a binational dispute-settlement panel that requires the United States to lift $18 million of punitive duties on imports of Canadian pork.

title: Profits Decline at IBM Japan
description: IBM Japan Ltd., a wholly owned unit of the International Business Machines Corporation, said today that profits fell 18.8 percent in 1990, the first decline in five years.

title: Family Lawyer Doubts Case Against 3 Officers
description: In an unusual move, the lawyer for the family of Federico Pereira has said that only two of the five officers charged in the beating death of the 21-year old should have been indicted for murder.

title: INSIDE
description: New Federal Complex Planned for Foley Square

title: Acme Unions Plan a Takeover Vote
description: Unions representing workers at the Acme Markets chain will vote on Monday on a plan to team with a Los Angeles investment group, Freeman Spogli & Company, in a bid to buy the 275-store supermarket chain.

title: Frohnmayer Defends Grant for Prize Film
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts today rebutted charges by the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, the head of a conservative Mississippi-based organization, that the arts agency had helped pay for a film with "explicit porno scenes of homosexuals involved in anal sex."

title: An Ordinary Evening Ends With 3 Girls Slain, Baffling Pasadena
description: The evening started as many others apparently had: with a case of beer, a bottle of whisky, perhaps some drugs. The six high school students often partied together at Katherine Macaulay's gated home overlooking a manicured golf course in an exclusive neighborhood.

title: Bush Meets Estonia's Leader And Renews a Plea for Talks
description: President Bush met today with President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and said good-faith negotiations were the only way to resolve the standoff between Moscow and the independence-minded Baltic republics.

title: U.S. Shifts Complaints On Trade
description: The Bush Administration has found fewer trade barriers in Japan than it did last year, but more in the European Community, Canada, Mexico, China, South Korea, India, Australia and Thailand, according to a special trade report published today.

title: Protect Whistle-Blowers
description: New York public employees who speak up about waste and corruption are more often treated like chumps than champs. The whistle-blowers deserve better protection from the state.

title: Harpoons Miss Tark the Shark
description: Thursday night on "Nightline" the guest suspect was Jerry Tarkanian, the coach of the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball champ, the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, which plays Duke tonight in the semifinals of the Final Four in Indianapolis. It was Ted Koppel's intention, presumably, to nail the towel-chewing coach, who looks the part of a central-casting heavy, with gleaming pate, flat nose, hooded eyes, a half smile and a background that is nearly unparalleled for reputed seediness.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Youths Crossing From Jordan
description: Israeli troops today shot and killed three young men who entered the occupied West Bank from Jordan, including a 12-year-old boy, the army command and the Israeli radio said.

title: Private Philanthropy Should Remain Private
description: To the Editor:

title: Poles Get Wider Travel Rights
description: Six Western European nations ended months of deliberation today by agreeing to lift visa requirements for Poles, apparently setting aside fears that the action could start a vast migration to the west.

title: Sears Officers Lose Bonuses
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's top 12 officers, including the chairman, will not get bonuses for 1990 because of poor performance by the retail division, company records indicate.

title: Webster Suspended
description: The Los Angeles Kings, the team with the second-best record in the National Hockey League, will enter the playoffs without their head coach, Tom Webster. He was suspended on Thursday for four games for exchanging punches with a rival player last week and he decided to waive his right of appeal and begin serving the suspension immediately. The first one was the game Thursday against the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Coping/With Power Surges
description: Every time a personal computer is turned on, electricity surges through its delicate components. If the computer has a hard disk, it must struggle to spin at the proper speed. Cold parts begin to expand as they are heated, only to contract again when the machine is turned off, and the process can cause cracks in the circuit boards.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; Carnivorous Carryings-On In the World of Artists
description: Though it is set in Copenhagen, "Sirup" could easily take place in New York or Paris or any city with a colorful, active, acquisitive art world, anywhere creators and poseurs mingle at gallery openings and are not easy to tell apart.

title: Beliefs
description: The waters returned and covered the chariots and the chariot drivers, the entire army of Pharaoh that had followed them into the sea; not one of them remained. But the Israelites walked on dry ground through the sea, the waters forming a wall for them on their right and on their left. -- Exodus 14:28-29

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. JAMES L. POWELL, the president of Reed College in Portland, Ore., has been appointed chief executive officer of the Franklin Institute, the Philadelphia science center that is the home of the Benjamin Franklin National Memorial. Dr. Powell, 54, a geochemist, has been the president of Reed since 1988. Previously, he was the president of Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa., and before that, served in several positions at Oberlin College in Ohio.

title: More Jet Sales Seen to Eastern Europe
description: The Boeing Company said airlines based in Eastern Europe would buy an average of 12 to 13 new jets a year over 15 years to keep up with a sharp rise in passenger traffic and to replace their aging fleets. It said Western aircraft makers stood a good chance of getting a share of the market, which has been dominated by the Soviet Union.

title: Patents; Drill Cuts Square Holes
description: Erick A. Sandoval, an inventor in Merritt Island, Fla., has patented a drill bit that cuts square holes. The only way to cut squares out of a piece of wood had been to drill a round hole inside the square and then use a jigsaw to cut a line from that hole around the area being removed. The goal of the new invention is to do everything with one tool in one step. The new drill bit features a central rotating shaft that fits into a standard drill like a normal bit. On each side of the shaft is a circular blade that looks like a miniature buzz saw. Through a gear linkage in the shaft, the rotating drill causes the four blades to spin. When the drill is pressed against a piece of wood, each of the spinning blades cuts one side of the square.

title: Bridge
description: The grande dame of American bridge, without any doubt, is Ethel Keohane of Wellesley, Mass., who celebrates her 90th birthday today. She is a living monument to the importance of enthusiasm and willpower.

title: Incaviglia Is Cut by the Rangers
description: Pete Incaviglia, a power-hitting Texas outfielder who put up some big numbers in a couple of categories too many, was cut by the Rangers yesterday to make room for a rotation of lighter-hitting replacements expected to be more efficient on offense and certainly more cost-effective.

title: G.M. Recalls School Buses
description: The General Motors Corporation recalled 15,000 Chevrolet school buses on Thursday because of a potential drivetrain problem. It also recalled about 418,000 1987-90 cars equipped with Quad 4 engines -- Oldsmobile Calais and Cutlass Supremes, Pontiac Grand Ams, Buick Skylarks and Chevrolet Berettas -- because of potential emission problems. The company said it was unaware of any accidents or injuries caused by the problems. Repairs in both recalls will be performed free.

title: Italy's Government Resigns Again; Predictable Uncertainty Returns
description: Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti resigned today, throwing Italy into a period of political uncertainty that sooner or later will give rise to the country's 50th government since World War II.

title: Political Memo; Many Actors and Agendas Vie in Financial Struggle
description: Just as Mayor David N. Dinkins was beginning the most crucial effort of his administration, to win concessions from city unions and gain control of New York City's worsening fiscal problems, the Governor stepped in to help -- and swiftly created an uproar that has stalled the labor talks almost before they began.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the first time in its 155-year history, Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan has selected a Unitarian as its president. The Rev. Dr. HOLLAND LEE HENDRIX, 42 years old, will take over on July 1. He will succeed the Rev. Dr. DONALD W. SHRIVER JR. , 63, who has been president since 1975. While the seminary is now an independent graduate school, most of its previous presidents have been Presbyterians.

title: A Justified Ban on 'Baby Bells'
description: The seven regional Bell telephone companies have won a big, and undeserved, victory in the first round of their battle to manufacture telecommunications equipment. The Senate Commerce Committee has approved a bill, sponsored by its chairman, Ernest Hollings, to overturn the prohibition against manufacturing imposed when the companies were created after the 1982 breakup of A.T.&T.

title: Filing on Stock by Hanover
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that allows the Dai- Ichi Kango Bank of Tokyo to sell the more than 3.3 million Manufacturers Hanover shares it bought in late 1989.

title: Kerkorian, T.W.A. Unions Agree on Bid for the Carrier
description: The unions of Trans World Airlines and the West Coast financier Kirk Kerkorian said yesterday that they had agreed on an offer to buy the carrier. Mr. Kerkorian would put up $250 million and the unions would offer cost savings of $137 million a year.

title: Police Feel Haunted by Specter of Brutality
description: Police Officer Charles Cipriano, usually mild-tempered, was indignant. "If we were out there to hurt someone, come on, we could do something every day," he said, pacing the smoky community patrol office of the 103d Precinct in Jamaica, Queens. "The sergeant -- what do you think, this was his plan, to kill somebody?"

title: The 1,002d Night
description: Ali Ben Bush, may his polls increase, called by his tribesmen "Bush of Arabia, Maker of War and Giver of Peace," summoned his vizier and said, "Tell me what I might see this very night were I to rub my magic lantern, my good Sududam."

title: Bank of Boston's Chief of Corporate Lending
description: While consultants and academicians warn that bank lending to large corporations does not generate enough profits relative to the risks of loss, bankers see enough prospects to stay in the business and to hire talent from competitors.

title: House Prices Are Down: It's a Good Time to Rent
description: Anyone who wants to rent a single-family house will find a lot to choose from these days. That is largely because many homeowners who want to sell aren't doing so because they can't get the prices they want. Some put their houses up for rent, and that can mean a good deal for the renter.

title: Baseball; Mets Take Chance on Raw Talents For Bullpen
description: Bud Harrelson spun on his desk and pointed to the names of pitchers scratched in chalk on his office blackboard.

title: Review/Music; Overview Of Songs By Bolcom
description: Long regarded by an amiably indifferent mainstream classical-music public as little more than Joan Morris's accompanist, William Bolcom has in recent years found himself on an enviable career roll. With his grandiose, three-hour oratorio "Songs of Innocence and of Experience," and his forthcoming opera "McTeague" (scheduled for its world premiere the season after next by the Lyric Opera of Chicago), Mr. Bolcom has become perhaps our most admired post-modernist composer.

title: Baseball; Marshall Ends Red Sox Walkout
description: Mike Marshall, disgruntled and hoping to be traded, ended a two-day walkout today and returned to spring training with the Boston Red Sox.

title: Review/Opera; 'Der Freischutz' in Concert Version Led by Eve Queler
description: Can anyone explain why "Der Freischutz" has a history, at least in modern times, of firing blanks in New York? Carl Maria von Weber's melodrama, a landmark of German Romanticism, last appeared on a major stage here nearly a decade ago in a New York City Opera offering. A decade earlier, the Metropolitan Opera had tried for a revival, but shot itself in the foot with a lamentable production by Rudolf Heinrich.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-4

title: Continental Air
description: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. is in talks with a Houston business group to help it raise capital from local investors, an airline spokesman said. The airline, which is operating under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, is trying to raise $550 million for expansion. The spokesman, who said the discussions were "exploratory and very preliminary," said Hollis L. Harris, Continental's chairman, had met with members of the Greater Houston Partnership, Houston's largest business group, to discuss local investment in the airline, which is based in Houston.

title: Stolen: Late-Model Auto, Officer Inside
description: Chockablock with mayhem and mischief bounded only by diabolical imagination, the annals of crime in New York City plumbed a bizarre new dimension yesterday with a report that a Bronx man had tried to steal a well-marked transit police car -- with a uniformed officer seated in it.

title: Officers' Rights Hinder F.B.I. Inquiry Into Beating
description: Officers in the Los Angeles Police Department have standing orders to cooperate with Federal criminal investigations. But this week F.B.I. agents investigating possible civil rights abuses by the department learned that such cooperation has its limits.

title: Key Rates
Most Markets Shut Yesterday
description: Because of the Good Friday holiday, most financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday, but there was limited trading in government securities.

title: Bond Market Is Unchanged
description: Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday in extremely light dealings. With New York Treasury dealers closed for Good Friday, along with most European financial centers, transactions were few and price moves largely nominal. The corporate and tax-exempt bond markets were closed, as were the stock and commodity exchanges.

title: Auto Layoffs Decline
description: The Big Three auto makers plan to lay off just 12,050 hourly workers next week, the smallest weekly number of the year. The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said Thursday that they would close all or parts of just six assembly plants to bring their products into balance with inventories.

title: College Basketball: Final Four; Johnson Finally Lets His Success With Rebels Sink In
description: Shortly after the University of Nevada-Las Vegas won the national basketball championship last spring, officials at Skyline High School in Dallas planned a day for Larry Johnson in honor of the Rebels' all-America forward, who had been a star at Skyline.

title: Founder of Control Data Plans to Leave Its Board
description: William C. Norris, the maverick founder of the Control Data Corporation, is leaving the board of the computer company he founded in 1957. Mr. Norris, 79, retired as chairman and chief executive in 1986 and has not been involved in the company's management since then.

title: Review/Film; A Warlock Scheming in Los Angeles
description: "Warlock" is a new occult melodrama that's about nothing less than the Uncreation of Man, the film's phrase, not mine. This diabolical scheme is hatched by an off-screen Satan and carried through to near-success by a warlock who aspires to become Old Scratch's son and heir.

title: Four Bid for Units of Bank of New England
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that three banking companies had offered to buy the three failed banks once owned by the Bank of New England Corporation, while a fourth group had offered to buy just one of the failed banks.

title: Newsday's Ad Offer to Auto Dealerships Is Barred by a Judge
description: A Federal judge has issued a temporary restraining order against Newsday, Long Island's only islandwide daily newspaper, saying that one of its advertising promotions may violate Federal and state antitrust laws.

title: ECONOMY INDEX UP, SPURRING OPTIMISM ON RECESSION'S END
description: In a sign that the recession may be approaching an end, the Government said today that its main economic forecasting index climbed 1.1 percent in February, the first advance since June and the biggest in more than two and a half years.

title: 2 American Sailors Accused Of a Pro-Iraq Plot on Carrier
description: Two American sailors were ordered today to face a court-martial on charges of trying to sabotage a carrier in the Persian Gulf in support of Iraq, the United States Navy said.

title: RESEARCH ON DRUG FOR BREAST CANCER
description: Studies are about to begin on 31,000 women at high risk of breast cancer to see whether a drug that blocks the sex hormone estrogen can protect them from the disease.

title: 2 Waiters Lose Jobs for Liquor Warning to Woman
description: Two restaurant workers have been dismissed after trying to persuade a pregnant customer not to order a rum daiquiri because drinking alcohol could harm her fetus.

title: Cow Antibodies Are Linked to Colic in Babies
description: Cow antibodies are a likely cause of infant colic, and mothers who consume dairy products can pass them on in breast milk, a new study says.

title: About New York; Spiritual Journey From Funeral To Easter Bunny
description: Seven years ago, Michael Naimy buried a longtime friend who had died of AIDS. The moment changed his life. And his became a story of love and faith, of honesty and Easter bunnies, and, yes, of resurrection.

title: In Reagan's Cool Shadow
description: If there was one thing George Bush did not like when he was Vice President, it was standing in the shadow of Ronald Reagan. As President, Mr. Bush dislikes being compared with the former President.

title: Three Catholics Killed in Ulster
description: An illegal Protestant group said today that it was responsible for killing two Roman Catholic teen-agers and a 29-year-old man to death in Northern Ireland on Thursday night, and warned of more attacks.

title: Chicago Journal; To Lessen Their Pain, Mexicans Relive Christ's
description: On this bit terly cold day far from the sands of Jerusalem, an unemployed laundry worker donned a white tunic and a crown of thorns and dragged a wooden cross past the cantinas and tortilla factories of Chicago's Mexican neighborhood.

title: Steven Hueglin, 38, Co-Founder of Brokerage Firm in Manhattan
description: Steven J. Hueglin, a prominent municipal bond dealer, died on Thursday at a hospital in Guatemala City. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "What a town, eh? We've had subway trains taken for joyrides, buses stolen and found in other parts of the city and patrol cars gone south for the winter. But this is the first time anyone has ever tried to take a car with an officer in it." -- Al O'Leary, a spokesman for the Transit Authority. [ 1:3. ]

title: Patents; Striking the Nail and Saving the Fingers
description: James P. McMahon, an inventor in Hayward, Calif., has patented a magnetic hammer that may make it easier to pound nails without pulverizing fingers

title: Big Classes, Little Space in Elmhurst
description: At Public School 102 in Elmhurst, Queens, there are a lot of new students and nowhere to put them. A special projects class is held on the auditorium stage, while an English-as-a-second-language class is held behind it. The stage dressing room has been transformed into the school's resource room. Two students sit in front of a computer in a stairwell for a math lesson, as their teacher stands two steps above them.

title: Reviews/Film Festival; Two Roads on the Trail of History
description: Two 50-minute films, Brett J. Love's "Emil and Fifi" from the United States and Andrei Zagdansky's "Interpretation of Dreams" from the Soviet Union, make up the program that will be shown today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 12:15 P.M. in the New Directors/New Films series.

title: Edwin C. Ricotta, Advertising Art Director, 78
description: Edwin C. Ricotta, an advertising art director, died on Wednesday at his home in Wildwood, Fla. He was 78 years old and also lived in South Addison, Me.

title: JAPAN EXPECTING TALK WITH SOVIETS ON DISPUTED ISLES
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said he wants to address Japan's claims to a group of Soviet-held islands when he travels to Tokyo next month, a leader of Japan's governing party said today.

title: Soviets Reported to Hide Looted Art
description: Vast stores of art and antiquities that disappeared from Germany in the aftermath of World War II were stolen by Soviet troops and remain hidden in "secret depositories" in the Soviet Union, an article in the April issue of Art News reports.

title: Baryshnikov Troupe Plans an 18-City Tour
description: Baryshnikov Productions and the Howard Gilman Foundation have announced that the White Oak Dance Project will begin a month-long, 18-city tour on April 19 at the Fox Theater in Detroit.

title: Bank Insurance in S.E.C. Study
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission study indicates that the Federal Government supplies banking deposit insurance far below what it is worth.

title: Boy, 11, Is Shot in the Head in Store, and Owner Is Held
description: An 11-year-old boy was critically wounded last night when he was shot in the head in a grocery store in Queens, the police reported.

title: New-Home Sales Show Biggest Gain in 5 Years
description: Sales of new homes surged 16.2 percent in February, the biggest advance in nearly five years, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts attributed the upswing to lower mortgage rates and the end of the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Airports Resume Baggage Checking at Curb
description: Curbside checking of luggage at the nation's airports is resuming, restoring a convenience to passengers that had been halted for security reasons during the war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Scowcroft Visit to Middle East Made Public
description: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made an unannounced trip to the Middle East this week to consult with American allies on the postwar situation in Iraq, an Administration official said today.

title: Products That Are Wrapped in Messages
description: Companies are increasingly turning to environmental themes to sell products. But now some have taken that trend a step further: they are using packaging and other promotional material for political purposes.

title: Albany Ruling Allows Request For Incinerator
description: New York State yesterday cleared the way for New York City to apply to the state to build an incinerator on part of the Brooklyn Navy Yard site in the Williamsburg section.

title: A Confused Strategy
description: Recent unsettling events in the Middle East raise the question whether George Bush ever developed a coherent national strategy to guide him in the Persian Gulf war and its aftermath.

title: New Nutrasweet Sugar Substitute
description: The Nutrasweet Company, a unit of the Monsanto Company, said it had developed a sugar substitute that is 10,000 times sweeter than sugar and has no calories. The company's patent on its current artificial sweetener expires in December 1992. After that time, competitors will be able to sell their own versions of aspartame, the sweetener now sold under the Nutrasweet brand name.

title: Mazda Price Rise Set on Most Models
description: Mazda Motor of America Inc. will increase prices on most of its 1991 model cars and trucks by an average of 1.3 percent, or about $168 a vehicle, effective April 1.

title: Review/Film; Roaming Camera Catches Life on the Faroe Islands
description: Katrin Ottarsdottir's "Atlantic Rhapsody: 52 Scenes From Torshavn," the first and only feature film by a director native to the Faroe Islands, is also a novelty on another score. Its narrative focus is shifted successively from one character to another, in the manner of a relay race, throughout the film's entire running time. So a scene in which people having breakfast see a fire truck out their window gives way to a scene involving the firemen; when a group of old men sitting by the harbor see a couple of young girls walk by, the camera wanders off with the girls. After the camera lurches abruptly into a hospital room to watch the birth of a baby, it shifts its attention to a maternity ward nurse and her boyfriend.

title: Lillian Day Lederer, a Novelist, Dies at 98
description: Lillian Day Lederer, a novelist, biographer and playwright, died yesterday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan, where she had lived for the last eight years. She was 98 years old.

title: Treasury Securities a Big Hit With Americans Last Year
description: Individual American investors bought a record $120.5 billion worth of Treasury securities last year, according to data from the Federal Reserve Board. The purchases by individuals came to nearly 45 percent of the more than $272 billion in securities issued in 1990 to finance the budget deficit.

title: OLD ALLY WOUNDS GUN CONTROL FOES
description: When John Snyder heard that former President Ronald Reagan had endorsed a national seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases, he said he was reminded of the 146th Psalm: "Put not your trust in princes, the children of men, in whom there is no salvation."

title: Imprisoned in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Utilities to Cut '90 Results
description: Eastern Utilities Associates, a holding company with utilities in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, will reduce 1990 results by $148 million, mostly because of losses on its investment in EUA Power. Eastern, which earned $40.9 million in 1989, said it expects to report a loss for the year of about $130 million. The company said it would cut its quarterly dividend, currently 65 cents a share, to an undetermined amount and does not expect to complete its hostile tender offers for the Fitchburg Gas and Electric Light Company and the Unitil Corporation.

title: Kurdish Rebels Equivocate On Who Holds Oil Center
description: Kurdish rebels fighting in northern Iraq acknowledged in Damascus today that their fighters were retreating from Kirkuk, then reversed their stand and asserted that they still controlled the crucial oil city.

title: How to Keep Guns Safely
description: One of two households in the United States owns a handgun, according to the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence, a nonprofit research and education organization based in Washington.

title: Alcoa Studies Earnings Deductions
description: The Aluminum Company of America said today that it had not decided how to deduct about $1 billion from its earnings made necessary because of a change in how companies must account for retiree health-care benefits.

title: CNN Wins a Peabody for Its War Coverage
description: CNN was recognized for its coverage of the Persian Gulf war as one of 26 winners of the George Foster Peabody Broadcasting Awards.

title: Volunteerism Is Free
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.& T. Job Cuts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would eliminate the jobs of 540 people, including 132 in New York City, who help maintain corporate switchboards. Some workers have been reassigned, some will be placed elsewhere in the telephone industry, and the rest will be laid off, said Kathleen M. Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman. Computer technology has made switchboards more reliable and reduced the need for maintenance, she said.

title: Manboxinzhai Journal; The 'Barefoot Doctors': Shod, but Still Footsore
description: Dr. Su Ke faces little risk of malpractice suits, but there are other hazards of working as a doctor in a remote Chinese village like this one.

title: Soccer; Soccer Star Faces Suspension for Cocaine
description: Diego Maradona, the world's most acclaimed soccer player, has been found to have used cocaine and is expected to be suspended from international play for as long as two years.

title: Avoiding the L.A. Syndrome
description: As a nation, we focus first on one concern, then another, like a teen-ager changing girl friends. The current focus is police brutality. The unlawful use of force by cops is not a new problem. Speeches have never made it go away.

title: Asian-Americans Demand TV Anchor Not Be Let Go
description: Asian-American community leaders, angered by WABC's decision to drop the "Eyewitness News" anchor Kaity Tong, are actively campaigning for her reinstatement.

title: Communist Party Veterans Dropped by Laos Politburo
description: Kaysone Phomvihane, the undisputed leader of Laos's Communist Party since 1955, was re-elected today, but a veteran revolutionary of royal descent and four others were dropped from the party's Politburo.

title: Old Admirer comes to Suspect Yeltsin's Methods
description: When Vladimir Isakov first became involved in politics four years ago, Boris N. Yeltsin was his idol and his cause. Now, during the extraordinary session of the Russian Parliament, Mr. Yeltsin is his target.

title: Iraq's Shiite Majority: A Painful History of Revolt and Schism
description: The bloody rebellion in the towns and cities of southern Iraq represents the most serious uprising by Iraq's Shiite Muslim majority in 70 years. Not since the 1920-1921 revolt for independence against the British mandate in Iraq, which took British troops a year to crush, has Shiite opposition to the central authority in Baghdad been so widespread.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Campus Intellectuals Deny Wide War Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Nathan Tannenbaum, Accountant, Dies at 94
description: Nathan Tannenbaum, an accountant active in Jewish causes, died on Thursday at the Jewish Home & Hospital in Manhattan. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Can 'Image' Cars Help Detroit?
description: Can one sexy car model make a whole company look good?

title: Religious Leader Convicted of U.S. Charges
description: The founder and leader of a community that split off from the Hare Krishna was convicted today on charges he authorized the kidnapping and beating of various members to protect an illegal enterprise.

title: Saving Energy: Still a Tough Sell
description: More than a month after the war in the oilfields, business ventures trying to sell products to keep America's houses, offices and shops comfortably heated while using less fuel are finding that efficiency is still a tough sell. Not only can they not get retailers to carry their insulation, high-efficiency light bulbs and other energy-conserving products, they are also having problems getting these products into homes, even when a third party is willing to pay for them.

title: I.B.M. Moves Into 90's With Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: CPC, McKesson
description: CPC International Inc., a food concern, said the McKesson Corporation had agreed to settle a suit brought by CPC in 1985 involving CPC's purchase of the C.F. Mueller Company from McKesson. CPC did not disclose the terms of the settlement but said the proceeds amounted mostly to a reduction in the purchase price of Mueller, a manufacturer of pasta products, and would not have a material effect on earnings. McKesson, a drugstore operator based in San Francisco, said the settlement would result in earnings reductions of 10 cents a share for the year ending March 31.

title: Yeltsin Assails Gorbachev Rule For 'Stagnation'
description: Flush with the victory of his followers against the Kremlin's strong show of force a day ago, Boris N. Yeltsin assailed the central authorities today for seeking to restore the "period of stagnation" that preceded perestroika.

title: Review/Music; Works for Computer, Piano and Trombone
description: The most interesting moment in Yuji Takahashi's performance of his own "Iki to Ishi" (1990) last Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society came at the start of the work, when Mr. Takahashi's computer started to act up. The composer had been quietly explaining the work, which was in progress, when the electronic sounds stopped suddenly. Looking bemused, Mr. Takahashi said that something was wrong, when a computer voice, similar to that of HAL, the rogue computer in "2001," said: "Are you sure you are making the right decision? I think we should stop."

title: A Contrite Schwarzkopf Says He Agreed '100%'
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said today that contrary to his comments in a television interview, he agreed "100 percent" with President Bush's decision to halt the Persian Gulf war.

title: Fritz Kaufmann, 94, Professor of Economics
description: Fritz Kaufmann, a retired professor of economics, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today for the first day of Passover.

title: Does Bonilla Have Future as a Yank Outfielder?
description: Bobby Bonilla is now officially available for trade. The question is whether the Yankees will be among the teams prepared to offer the Pittsburgh Pirates a deal.

title: Review/Dance; Fort Worth Ballet Offers 'Cinderella' For Family
description: You won't find any Freudian subtexts or flights of scenic fancy in the Fort Worth Ballet's production of "Cinderella," which opened on Wednesday night at City Center, where it will be performed through tomorrow afternoon.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Express Co., New York, will reduce the interest charge on its Optima card to 16.25 percent for purchases, down from 16.75 percent, and 18.40 percent on cash advances, down from 18.90 percent, effective Monday. * California Energy Co., San Francisco, a maker of geothermal power plants, completed the acquisition of geothermal properties in Utah and Nevada from Chevron Corp., San Francisco, for about $51 million.

title: Lee Atwater, Master of Tactics For Bush and G.O.P., Dies at 40
description: Lee Atwater, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and a major architect of George Bush's Presidential election victory in 1988, died this morning at George Washington University Hospital. He was 40 years old.

title: Joseph De Grazia, Ad Executive, 70
description: Joseph De Grazia, a former partner in B. Brown Associates, direct-mail advertising specialists, died on Monday at his home in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: Gunman Wounds 3 Marines On Highway in Saudi Arabia
description: An Arab fired shots at a United States military vehicle as his car overtook it on a highway in eastern Saudi Arabia on Thursday, wounding three marines, an American military spokesman said today.

title: Horse Racing; Meadow Star Hopes to Become a Perfect 9
description: The undefeated filly Meadow Star will shoot for her ninth victory in nine starts this afternoon at Aqueduct. And, with the Kentucky Derby only five weeks away, she may take some major strides toward racing history by running against fillies for the last time before challenging colts in the Triple Crown classics.

title: A Mean Army, Made Leaner
description: America's victory in the Persian Gulf war brought glory to all branches of the armed forces. But it provided special vindication for the U.S. Army, which brilliantly exploited its firepower and mobility and in the process erased memories of its grievous difficulties in Vietnam.

title: Los Angeles Officers Testify That Motorist Acted Oddly
description: Police officers present at the videotaped beating of a black motorist told a Los Angeles County grand jury that his behavior after he was stopped made them nervous, a reaction that one defense lawyer said today could have contributed to the actions of the officers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the arrest of an American-Israeli couple in Israel in connection with two killings in the United States referred imprecisely to a bomb that killed an Arab- American, Alex Odeh, in California in 1985. An F.B.I. official said Mr. Odeh had been killed by a device that exploded when he opened his office door, and not by a letter bomb.

title: Alfredo Campoli, Violinist, 84
description: Alfredo Campoli, an Italian-born violinist who gave his first London performance at age 13 and went on to become a noted concert violinist, died on Wednesday. He was 84 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about I.B.M.'s decision to list as a liability $2.6 billion for some employee retirement benefits misstated the operation of new accounting rules for American companies. Each year, the companies will subtract from earnings part of the cost of eventual retirement benefits for current employees. While that sum will be listed on the corporate balance sheet as a liability, the money will not actually be set aside.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JULIAN H. ROBERTSON JR., a New York investor, is the new chairman of the Strang Cancer Prevention Center, a Manhattan research and diagnostic institution. Mr. Robertson, 58, is the founder and president of Tiger Management , a money-management company in Manhattan. He succeeds SAMUEL H. WOOLLEY.

title: A Lonely Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: Formula One Issues a Ban, Then Kindly Ignores It
description: The international racing authorities, who were expected last week to issue their penalty for the outlaw Indy-car race held in Australia on March 17, seem to be heeding the advice your mother gave you when you were teased in grammar school: just ignore it, and eventually it will go away.

title: Golf; Azinger Leads Zoeller by One Shot in T.P.C.
description: Paul Azinger continued to match what is statistically the best all-round game on the PGA Tour against its most variegated course today and took a one-shot lead going into the final round of the Players Championship.

title: Sidney Blumenthal on Robert Caro
description: To the Editor:

title: POWER STRUGGLE IN KUWAIT BLOCKS NEW GOVERNMENT
description: More than a month after Kuwait's liberation from Iraqi rule, efforts to form a new government here are paralyzed by a power struggle that pits the hereditary rulers, the Sabah family, against an opposition demanding more democracy.

title: Technology; Latest in the Vineyard: Newly Dug Caves
description: The premium wineries of northern California have long demonstrated their devotion to the grape with impressive edifices, from the restored 1885 stone mansion of Far Niente in Oakville to the post-modern temple to wine at Clos Pegase in Calistoga. But in the last few years, vintners have been making a less visible commitment to Bacchus: new caves for the gentle aging of their fine wines.

title: David Landau to Wed Miss Koreman
description: Drs. Neil M. and Dorothy G. Koreman of Miami Lakes, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Koreman, to David Alan Landau, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Landau of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Greatest Chinese Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid Group Tries to Save Services in Tough Era
description: After enduring a series of robberies in her job as a store clerk, a 52-year-old Bronx woman suffered a nervous breakdown and twice tried to take her own life.

title: Hunt for Marcos's Billions Yields More Dead Ends Than Hard Cash
description: After a five-year hunt through the courts and banking systems of three continents, the Philippine Government has uncovered yachts and paintings and silver services and a few hundred million dollars, but not much more of the $5 billion or more Ferdinand E. Marcos is said to have stolen from his country.

title: Hong Kong Agrees to Screen 8 Boat People Again
description: Eight Vietnamese boat people who were part of a landmark legal challenge to the refugee screening process here will be screened again under an agreement reached with the Hong Kong Government.

title: Coins
description: On May 1 in New York City, a pattern piece for a coin will be auctioned that might have changed the American language and sent our monetary decimal system to oblivion.

title: Miss Coe to Wed James J. Boyle 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coe of White Plains have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Laurie MacDonald Coe and James Joseph Boyle 3d, a son of Anne Boyle of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Mr. Boyle Jr.

title: Lynn McLarty to Marry
description: Lynn S. McLarty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin McLarty of North Babylon, L.I., and Frank G. Caruso, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Caruso of Melville, L.I. are planning to marry next March. She is a financial analyst at Manufacturers Hanover Trust in Hicksville, L.I. Mr. Caruso is the assistant general manager of the International Litho Corporation in Philadelphia.

title: Bargain Fares, But How Many?
description: HOPING to fill seats left empty by the combined fear of terrorism and the recession, United States airlines have been advertising a bargain fare to Europe -- $318 round trip to London, Paris and Amsterdam for trips that start between Wednesday and May 20.

title: Realtors Say First-Time Buyers Are Back in the Market
description: ON Feb. 28, a ranch house in White Plains went on the market for $315,000.

title: Recycling: No Longer If, but How
description: AS many New Jersey counties cancel plans for garbage-burning incinerators and gear up to increase recycling, state and local officials have turned their attention to construction of plants that will assist in the collection and sorting of recyclable materials.

title: Troubled-Mothers Program to End in July
description: "MY husband tried to run me and my children over with the car."

title: The Review
description: THE NOVEL By James A. Michener. 464 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: College Basketball; Virginia Women Edge UConn
description: Before facing second-ranked Virginia in the women's Final Four today, the Connecticut coach, Geno Auriemma, made a simple prediction. "If they press us and we get into our halfcourt offense, they're in trouble," he said.

title: Cool Outrage for Los Angeles Mayor
description: The day after the police beating of a black motorist, Mayor Tom Bradley huddled in his office with Deputy Mayor Mark D. Fabiani and a few top aides to watch the videotape of the incident. In the darkened room, they concentrated on the blurry image until it ended. Then there was a long silence.

title: Latest Newspaper War Gets Personal
description: Striking reporters returned to work at The Daily News last week, and in some sense New York's newspapers returned to their roots -- their early 19th-century roots, as recalled by the historian Augustus Maverick:

title: Suzanne Guthrie To Marry in Fall
description: October wedding plans for Suzanne Briggs Guthrie and David Perry Harmon 3d, a son of Melissa Pederson of Glenview, Ill., and Mr. Harmon Jr. of Annandale, Va., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Vanderbilt Guthrie of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Claire Sullivan O'Keeffe, Service Agency Founder, 82
description: Claire Sullivan O'Keeffe, co-founder of Casita Maria, a Bronx service organization, died on Friday at Memorial Mission Hospital in Asheville, N.C. She was 82 years old and lived in Asheville.

title: Miss Densen to Wed Theodore Root
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. M. Douglas of Bedford, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Douglas's daughter, Christie Jane Densen, and Theodore Bobrick Root, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Elihu N. Root of Houston.

title: Virginia Owens to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Owens of River Edge, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Virginia Heather Owens and Dr. John Willis Marcus, a son of Marjorie Marcus of Hanover Park, Ill., and the late Willis Marcus. Miss Owens, 23 years old, graduated from Glassboro State College and is a software instructor at Microtrek Productivity Point International, a computer training concern in New York. Dr. Marcus, 28, graduated from Loyola University and received an M.D. from the University of Illinois. He is a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE OSGOOD FILES By Charles Osgood.Putnam, $19.95.

title: Around the Garden
description: FOR THIS WEEK: Design changes are easier to plot while the trees are bare and the landscape transparent. Now is the time to think about creating three-dimensional interest. Even in the smallest garden, it's possible to alter a flat terrain by developing a sunken pathway.

title: Laura C. Everett To Marry in July
description: Addison L. Everett Jr. of Manlius, N.Y., and Mary M. Everett of Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Chenoweth Everett, to James Walton Stanley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Stanley of Canton Center, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Soviet and American Pupils Find Music a Common Language
description: SCARSDALE

title: Elliot A. Jackson To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilder D. Jackson of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elliot Atwood Jackson to Michael Philip Hitchiner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hitchiner of Portsmouth, England. An August wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard house is finished with an oil stain. Within a year after the stain was applied, mildew stains appeared. We plan to stain the house again this spring. How can we remove the mildew stains and prevent them from coming back?

title: Does Father Know Better?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The people of Albania, blinking in the first political daylight they have been exposed to in almost five decades, will vote on Sunday in multiparty elections organized by the governing Communist Party.

title: Residents Rally (Politely) Against Plan to Move Washington Depot Post Office
description: TO get a slice of life in Washington, residents say, just stop by the Washington Depot post office. On a recent afternoon, Helen Armstrong, a violinist home between concerts, was there to pick up her mail. Hugh Silk, a retired corporate executive, chatted with a neighbor. Darlene Blanchard, a calligrapher, said she was at the post office for at least the fourth time that day, mailing invitations she made for a customer running a charity benefit in Manhattan.

title: Headliners; Full Court Press
description: Lee Kuan Yew, the former prime minister of Singapore, seems to have convinced Dow Jones & Co. that athletics is not the only undertaking that involves a home court advantage. Back in 1987, Mr. Lee didn't like something he read in Dow Jones's Far Eastern Economic Review. He sued for libel in Singapore and was awarded a judgment in 1989. Dow Jones appealed, and Mr. Lee cross appealed. Then Peter K. Kann, the president of Dow Jones, issued a statement asserting that the judgment was unwarranted. Mr. Lee said he took this to mean that Mr. Kann was accusing him of improperly influencing the trial judge, and he promptly filed three more libel suits against Dow Jones publications in Malaysian and Singaporean courts. Last week, Dow Jones threw in the towel. Mr. Kann issued a statement saying he "never meant to defame Mr. Lee in any way." Mr. Lee dropped his pending libel suits, Dow Jones dropped its appeal, the original judgment stands, and Dow Jones will pay Mr. Lee's legal fees.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Glen Cove 245,000 19 Reynolds Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31- year-old ranch; den, 0.5 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $6,200. Hauppauge 187,500 10 Sheila Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; new kitchen, family room, den, deck, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,500. Islip 150,000 1024 Broadway 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $4,900. Oyster Bay 216,000 38 Adams Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; sun room, fireplace, basement, attic, pool; taxes $4,600. Smithtown 295,000 5 Roundabout Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, in-ground pool, 1.25 acres; taxes $6,000. Syosset 225,000 37 The Mews 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old ranch-style condominium; dining room, eat-in kitchen, tennis, pool; monthly maintenance $207, taxes $4,500. OTHER AREAS Essex, Conn. 140,000 73 Woodland Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old ranch; open-floor plan, wraparound deck, 1 acre; taxes $1,252. Mount Kisco, N.Y. 272,000 31 Daly Cross Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, dining room, eat-in kitchen, terrace, hot tub, 1 acre; taxes $5,477. Chester, N.J. 235,000 143B South Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; 3-acre wooded lot, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,583.

title: September Bridal For Ms. Rowland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Rowland of East Northport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Valerie Ann Rowland to James Francis Gesualdi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Gesualdi of Bohemia, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: American on Their Own Terms; An Epistle From St. Paul's
description: BLACK ICE By Lorene Cary. 238 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: Bridge
description: It is generally acknowledged that no man or woman can be in two places at the same time, but Zia Mahmood has long created the illusion of ubiquity. On every bridge occasion, in America, Europe, Asia or Australia, there he is. At almost every world championship, there he is, usually representing his native Pakistan and, at every National Championship in North America, there he is, usually contending for a major title.

title: Gutters Require Care Twice a Year
description: GUTTERS defend a home against many potentially serious problems like basement leaks, foundation settling, decaying roof framing and soaked, ineffective insulation.

title: Lisa B. Friedman Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Friedman of Rye, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Beth Friedman, and Adam Jonathan Savitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Alan Savitz of Los Angeles.

title: IT'S A WRAP
description: WHEN A HAT IS REALLY NOT A HAT, IT'S AT ITS best. There is nothing wrong with a "serious" hat, of course, complete with crown, brim and some trim. But, honestly, how many women really wear that kind anymore? First of all, you must have the place to wear such a hat; then the outfit for it to complement, and not least the confidence to carry it off. For most women, that is a scenario that passed from view decades ago.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: RONDO CELEBRATING 20TH

title: On the Street; Pleats for a Spring Fling
description: The movement of the pleated skirt is giving the spring suit a fresh look and providing an escape from the slim skirts that have ruled for much of the last decade. There are many variations: sharp accordion pleats; the wider, flat box pleats; the classic kilt style, and knife pleating set on hip-hugging bandeaus.

title: Style Makers; Luca Bonetti, Accessories Designer
description: Ten years ago, Luca Bonetti was roaming the stores of Canal Street in search of nothing in particular and discovered circuit boards: plastic sheets printed with copper mazes that tell computers what to do. "I was fascinated by the logical geometry, the flow of sequences, the beautiful lines," he said.

title: A Fall Wedding For Amy Tucker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Tucker of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynne Tucker, to Jonathan Matthew Meltzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Meltzer of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: The Big Bang -- Mostly Smoke?
description: THE SHADOWS OF CREATION Dark Matter and the Structure of the Universe. By Michael Riordan and David N. Schramm. Illustrated. 277 pp. New York: W. H. Freeman & Company. $18.95.

title: For the Royal Ballet, New Talent and a Fresh Spirit
description: The Royal Ballet's two-week season at the Kennedy Center in Washington this month was good news. The British company's first visit to the United States since 1983 revealed a crop of outstanding new talent on several levels and a fresh spirit. The even better news is that the company might come, as scheduled, to the Metropolitan Opera House on July 8. At this writing, the Royal is making every effort to return under its own power for this two-week engagement in the event that talks break off with its impresario at the Met, the financially troubled Entertainment Corporation.

title: College Basketball: It's a Final Surprise: Duke and Kansas; Blue Devils End U.N.L.V.'s Long Victory March
description: There will be a new national collegiate basketball champion. The Duke Blue Devils, playing practically a picture-perfect game, defeated defending champion Nevada-Las Vegas, 79-77, in the N.C.A.A. semifinals here tonight, ending the previously unbeaten Rebels' hopes for a second consecutive national title.

title: All About/Making Recycling Pay; In Solid Waste, It's the Breakdown That Counts
description: The first thing everyone needs to know about recycling, said Charles F. Oyler, is the difference between trash and recyclable materials. Mr. Oyler is the recyling manager at the big materials recovery center in suburban Philadelphia. The center is operated by Browning-Ferris Inc.

title: Experts Differ on Autopsy in Police Murder Case
description: Independent reviews of the autopsy on a Queens car-theft suspect whom five police officers are accused of killing indicate that the medical evidence may be inconclusive and probably will be sharply questioned at the officers' trial.

title: College Basketball; Despite Chance at U.N.L.V., Adams Ran Wrong Way
description: When Richie Adams watched the University of Nevada-Las Vegas play Duke last night in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, he felt a longing to be a part of the picture on the television screen.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I'd be real embarrassed if one of my friends who's been laid off saw me here. I mean, it's not like I go out so much any more, but I feel sort of guilty going out at all." -- Eric Wyka, a lawyer dining out in Manhattan. [ 1:1. ]

title: Italian Dishes Make Good Use of the Leftover Ham
description: IF you are celebrating Easter with a ham today, tomorrow you will be thinking about leftovers. This I learned one Easter years ago after baking a country ham in a motel kitchenette down South.

title: Jack Daniel Rehm Jr. Plans to Wed Kathleen M. Millard in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. Millard of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Maura Millard to Jack Daniel Rehm Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rehm of Des Moines and Fenwick. A September wedding is planned.

title: Swimming; Wharton Goes Out in Style
description: David Wharton ended his collegiate swimming career tonight the way he started it -- with success, dignity and a personality so laid back that it befuddled even his home-grown, laid-back teammates from the University of Southern California.

title: A Dark Day for Trout
description: Although rain and snow visited New York yesterday, those who sally forth tomorrow morning for the opening of the state's trout season will -- if weather predictions are accurate -- encounter reasonable, albeit cloudy and damp, fishing conditions.

title: Postings: Rising in Williamsburg; 59 Subsidized Rentals
description: The Williamsburg section of Brooklyn will see a new six- story subsidized apartment house rise on Union Avenue at Maujer Street this summer under the Turnkey Program of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: College Hockey; Boston U. Players Are on the Move
description: By the count of Coach Jack Parker, Boston University will be losing at least 11 -- maybe 13 -- of 19 players from a talented team that played for the national championship tonight against Northern Michigan.

title: Miller Comes Back to Haunt Former Teammates
description: Thirty minutes after his Red Wings beat the Rangers by 6-5 at Joe Louis Arena today, Kevin Miller stood in the corridor wearing a suit, a trench coat and a big smile.

title: Money's Worth From Puckett
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sludge Composting And Its Benefits
description: The recent article "Sludge: New Focus on Recycling" discussed Camden County's plans to construct a sewage sludge composting plant, but overlooked the existence of the first in-vessel sludge composting facility in New Jersey. It is in Middle Township and is operated by the Cape May County Municipal Utilities Authority.

title: Girl Scouts Are Mastering Survival Skills In Cities, Too
description: NOT far from where the police routinely arrest drug dealers, a group of young girls hurries down a darkened street, heading for the familiar lights of the South Norwalk Community Center. The girls are on their way to a meeting of Junior Girl Scout Troop 464. And they will not have to check their cultural identity at the door, because this scout meeting will be conducted entirely in Spanish.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: I recently purchased a Magnatours package to Cancun. I was charged $248 for land fees that covered three nights in a hotel whose posted fee was $30 per night, airport transfers (a $10 value), the U.S. departure tax and a representative to greet me on arriving and departing. Part of the $248 charge was a penalty of $25 per night for single accommodations although the hotel charged $30 total for a single and $35 for a double room.

title: Hope in New Jersey for Bridge to Ellis Island
description: Two New Jersey members of Congress say they are confident they can obtain Federal funds to build a pedestrian bridge to Ellis Island from Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

title: Moving From Mozart to American Ragtime
description: WHAT does Mozart have to do with Scott Joplin? Masanobu Ikemiya has chosen to point up the contrasts and similarities between popular forms and "serious" music in a program he is calling "The Classic/Ragtime Connection."

title: Outdoors; Boaters Hope to Gain More Access to New York Waterways
description: If you want to paddle your own canoe or kayak on a river in Montana or Idaho your freedom to do so -- indeed your legal right of access to the waterways -- is guaranteed by state law.

title: Chopper Skiing
description: To the Editor: Readers should be aware of some facts surrounding the item "By Chopper to the Snow" (Travel Advisory, Feb. 17).

title: Visionary Heroes for Business
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRANSIT OFFICIAL OUTLINES BIG CUTS
description: New York City transit officials are drawing up contingency plans for drastic cost-cutting that would severely trim bus and subway services, lay off hundreds of workers, reduce repair work and virtually abandon the war on graffiti.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic from 44th to 57th Street today from 11 A.M to 2:30 P.M. for the annual promenade known as the Easter Parade.

title: Notebook; 'Slugger' Isn't a Nickname Among Speed-Reliant Cardinals
description: Among the St. Louis Cardinals, the home run is an endangered species. The Cardinals hit home runs so seldom no one would miss the home-run column if it were dropped from their statistics. You could forgive the team's first- and third base coaches if they forgot from one home run to the next how to greet players trotting past them (if the players remembered their home-run trot).

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Caldwell
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Anne Caldwell to Richard William Collins Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Collins of New York, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. David F. X. Caldwell of Paul Smiths, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

Chester 235,000 143B South Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; 3-acre wooded lot, fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,583.
