Glen Cove, L.I. 245,000 19 Reynolds Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31- year-old ranch; den, 0.5 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $6,200.

title: Tomczak to Packers
description: After six years as a quarterback with the Chicago Bears, most of them as a backup to a succession of starters, Mike Tomczak is getting a new beginning: as a backup to a starter on another team.

title: Yankees Not Eager to Get Bonilla
description: Bobby Bonilla grew up in the Bronx and he loves New York, but it will apparently take some doing for him to become a member of the Yankees. Not only are the Yankees lukewarm about obtaining him, but the Pirates now say they will also not rush into a trade and jeapordize their pennant chances this year.

title: U.S. LAWS DELAYED BY COMPLEX RULES AND PARTISANSHIP
description: Because of bureaucratic foot-dragging, complex directives from Congress and in some cases ideological hostility, the Federal Government has failed to carry out major parts of health, environmental and housing laws passed with much fanfare in recent years.

title: In Banking, Big May Be Ugly
description: The Treasury Department's proposal to reform American banks would dramatically consolidate the industry into a few giant institutions. Some features of the plan would make the industry more competitive and efficient. But apart from allowing the U.S. again to boast of having the world's largest banks, big might not be so beautiful.

title: Columbia Teacher in Line for U.S. Education Post
description: Diane S. Ravitch, an author and teacher of history and education at Columbia University who has written for many years about education in America, will be nominated this week as one of the top deputies to the new Secretary of Education, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Don't Intervene
description: Americans are appalled by the spectacle of Iraqi forces slaughtering Kurds and Shiites. And Americans instinctively favor giving these people their own homelands. But before skewering President Bush for not throwing U.S. military power into Iraq's civil war, let's be clear and honest about a few matters.

title: Black Britons Speak of a Motherland That Looks Upon Them as Outcasts
description: World War II was raging when Allan Wilmot set sail for England from his native Jamaica to serve, in his words, "the mother country."

title: New Medical Technologies Challenge Hospitals
description: FOR a 14-year-old who had an amazing heart rate of 380 beats a minute when she was an infant, for a 27-year-old boxer who suffered a half-hour of dizziness and chest pain and for an 18-year-old with a precipitous drop in blood pressure, a new medical technology available at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center offered an alternative to riskier treatment.

title: Kocur Deal a Bad Move
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tennessee Williams Without the Neuroses
description: New plays, we know, have a tough time making their way in the world. But I wonder if old plays don't have an even tougher time of it.

title: What the Market's Saying About Oil Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: The Drama of Documentary
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: A number of career women, even those with secretaries of their own, find it irritating and insulting. They don't like the fact that when they're asked out these days for something that's is strictly social and personal, it's very often via the other person's secretary. They almost never hear the voice of the person issuing the invitation until they arrive at the designated spot on the designated day.

title: In Paris, Shellfish Platters
description: THERE are few gastronomic creations as expressive of the French nature as the festive plateau de fruits de mer, a glistening and briny-fresh assortment of fresh shellfish, or fruits of the sea. Perched mid-table on a large, round metal platter elevated to shoulder level for easier eating, a plateau de fruits de mer speaks of abundance, gourmandise, refinement and conviviality.

title: Cool Outrage for Los Angeles Mayor
description: The day after the police beating of a black motorist, Mayor Tom Bradley huddled in his office with Deputy Mayor Mark D. Fabiani and a few top aides to watch the videotape of the incident. In the darkened room, they concentrated on the blurry image until it ended. Then there was a long silence.

title: Teachers Like New Lighting
description: Two years ago I conducted a study in the Florence A. Smith School in Oceanside on the effect of full-spectrum lighting [ "Long Island School Test New Lights to Reduce Glare," March 3 ] on attendance during the winter months of January, February and March. I replicated a study devised by Dr. Wayne London of Brattleboro, Vt., and reported in The Lancet. Dr. London is a psychiatrist interested in the holistic approach to treating health problems.

title: Senate Power Over Naming Of Judges Argued Anew
description: PROPOSED legislation that would restrict a governor's discretion in appointing State Superior Court judges could magnify what legal experts consider an already undesirable intrusion of personalities and politics into the process of selecting an independent judiciary.

title: A May Wedding For Susan Weed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Adser Weed of New Canaan, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Susan Elizabeth Weed and Alexis Meeus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Meeus of Antwerp, Belgium.

title: 'Oklahoma!' Sings To Another Generation
description: IMAGINE people calling up a theater to ask what the current show is all about when that show is "Oklahoma!" Life goes on, but ignorance of "Oklahoma!" is hard for members of a certain generation to believe. Yet, the management of Connecticut's Broadway Theater (formerly the Darien Dinner Theater) reports such telephone inquiries from the members of a new generation.

title: Love Conquers Nothing
description: HARDWARE RIVER By Alyson Hagy. 190 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: FAITHFUL FLOCKING TO IRAN'S SHRINES
description: As the final call to prayer echoes through this capital, Iranians from Tajrish, a neighborhood in the northern part of the city, begin filling the square in front of the shrine here to pay a visit to the Imam Zadeh Saleh.

title:
DANCE;
Stellar Dancing in Pivotal Balanchine Works
description: ON sheer firepower alone, the dancers performing under the banner Stars of the New York City Ballet pack an explosive punch. As principal dancers in the New York City Ballet, they spend half of every year dancing at Lincoln Center. On Saturday they will present a program of ballets at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, offering New Jersey audiences an opportunity to see stellar dancing at relatively bargain prices.

title: Pro Basketball; Inept Nets Help Knicks to Resolve Frustrations
description: The Knicks found relief tonight for their recent frustration. All they needed was a game against the Nets.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ABECEDARY By Goffredo Parise. Translated by James Marcus. Marlboro, $17.95.

title: Borders Don't Make Middle East Tensions; Jews in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: More on How Montauk Was Parceled Out
description: We served as consultants for the Montauk exhibition at Guild Hall that Dan Rattiner critiqued in a letter [ March 3 ] . Mr. Rattiner's critique was flawed and misleading about the role of Arthur Benson and his family in the dispossession of the small Native American community at Montauk.

title: Social Events
description: The Blue Hill Troupe

title: Headliners; On Their Honor
description: In fact if not exactly in law, adultery in Brazil has long been punishable by death -- provided the offender was a woman. But that state of affairs apparently came to an end with a recent ruling by the Brazilian Supreme Court that outlawed "defense of honor" as a justification for murder. Over the years, thousands of men on trial for killing wives accused of adultery have been acquitted on the ground that their honor was jeopardized by the wife's behavior. One study showed that over a two-year period, 722 men used the honor defense in Sao Paulo State alone. The Supreme Court's ruling asserted that "homicide cannot be seen as a normal and legitimate way of reacting to adultery" and said that in such instances, "what is defended is not honor but vanity, exaggerated self-importance." Jacqueline Pitanguy, a Brazilian women's rights advocate and a leader of the campaign to outlaw the honor defense, said the decision reflected "a victory of the women's movement in the political game."

title: Sunday Dinner; The Avenue of the Americas, Midtown: A Boulevard of Delights
description: The stretch of the Avenue of the Americas from Rockefeller Center to 57th Street is a congested sea of humanity during the week, but on weekends, when the skyscrapers are empty, it becomes a wide and sunny strolling boulevard. Dining options are ample, too, if you know where to look. Here are three. Corrado

title: Travel Advisory; Insurance Plan Covers War And Terrorism
description: Although fears about international travel have subsided somewhat since the end of the Persian Gulf war, travel industry executives say people going to politically restive countries remain as nervous as ever about terrorism. One company, in what it calls a first-of-its-kind service, says it will insure people against injury or death caused by war or terrorist acts.

title: Travel Advisory; Kuwaitis Back
description: Kuwait Airways, which suspended service Jan. 15 because of the Persian Gulf war, will resume some flights from New York next Thursday.

title: More Cubans Try to Leave as Hard Times Deepen
description: Faced with ever-tighter austerity measures, Cubans are seeking a way off their island in numbers not seen since the Mariel boatlift of 1980.

title: Perpetuating a Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds; Chasing the Shrinking Yields
description: Yields on money-market funds, which have tumbled since Iraq invaded Kuwait last summer, have reached their lowest levels in almost three years.

title:
Morristown Journal;
Ejected by Library, Homeless Man Sues, and Town Reflects
description: WHEN some of the homeless of Morristown need shelter, they go to the public library here on South Street. They go there because it is warm, comfortable and safe.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FLIGHT OF THE AVENGER George Bush at War. By Joe Hyams. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.

title:
ART;
19th-Century Works Recall the Heyday of a Norwalk Mansion
description: A BAROQUE ghost from an earlier era is one of the most compelling aspects of "LeGrand Lockwood and the Taste for American Art," 25 19th-century paintings and several sculptures now on display at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk. In the expansive period following the Civil War, the public was admitted once a week to the house's unusual, octagonal rotunda gallery to view a fabled art collection. At his death in 1872, Mr. Lockwood's collection included 85 paintings and many sculptures.

title: Miss Tananbaum To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Tananbaum of Commack, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marjorie Joy Tananbaum to Howard Mark Gitten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Gitten of Ocean Township, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: Egypt
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a business trip to Egypt, and it seemed to me that travelers were missing the opportunity of a lifetime. Because of the gulf crisis, tourism was down at least 60 percent, by some estimates 90 percent. I think there were fewer visitors there than at any time since Herodotus. But this was entirely unwarranted.

title: Ideas & Trends; Hollywood Looks to the Oscars for Clues
description: THE annual orgy of self-congratulation that Hollywood calls the Academy Awards ended with a sweeping victory for Kevin Costner's revisionist western, "Dances With Wolves." That movie's commercial prospects were once considered so dim that studio wags, recalling the millions lost many years ago by "Heaven's Gate," dismissed it as "Kevin's Gate." Oscars also went to Kathy Bates and Whoopi Goldberg, two actresses who have repeatedly been passed over for choice roles because they were deemed not to have the right appearance. But the next morning, the same executives who made the wrong decisions were back in their offices trying to determine how to copy those successes.

title: Campus Life: Southwestern; From This Class, Many Signs Point To the Windy City
description: Once the social-science laboratory for the University of Chicago, the city of Chicago has become the site of an urban studies experiment for an interdisciplinary humanities course taught about a thousand miles away.

title: Merchant Shoots Boy by Mistake, Police Say
description: An 11-year-old boy clung to life yesterday after he was shot in the head by a Queens bodega owner who was examining a friend's pistol and accidentally fired it, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Britain's Blacks: Invisible?

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: A CHILD'S FIRST BIBLE. By Sandol Stoddard. Illustrated by Tony Chen. Dial. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) Each of 40 stories from the Old and New Testaments is told in a double-page spread. The brief texts are pleasant to read.

title: The Antithesis Of My Sentiments
description: I was startled to see, under my photo, the quotation: "I think war is an exciting time and peace is boring," taken out of the context of my remarks. [ Westchester Q&A, "Using Fiction to Probe Women and War," March 24 ] The quotation could be taken as the antithesis of my sentiments, and it is conceivable to me that readers who saw that might have chosen to turn the page. More important, I would hate anyone to think I was advocating anything about war -- its excitement or passion or anything else.

title: Ideas & Trends; Can the Scales of Justice Be Calibrated for Scientific Fraud?
description: IT has taken five years so far to decide the case of Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari, the professor of immunology at Tufts University who has been accused of scientific misconduct. If the National Institutes of Health upholds a finding it made earlier this month that fraud had been committed, there may be another two years of appeals ahead.

title: Off the Field, Giants Call New Jersey Home
description: WHERE are the New York Giants spending their time in this, football's off-season? New Jersey, more likely than not.

title: A La Carte: Aroma of Fried Clams and the Smell of Success
description: RESTAURANTS have a hard time on Long Island. It is a competitive, unstable, even volatile place. But Bigelow's in Rockville Centre will be 52 years old in June.

title: Headliners; A Ray Union
description: Contrary to the impression visited upon many tourists, there are plenty of New Yorkers named Ray who are not in the pizza business. But among the hundreds of pizza parlors in Manhattan may be found a dozen or more plays on Ray, including Ray's Real Pizza, World Famous Ray's, Original Ray's, Famous Original Ray's, One and Only Ray's of Greenwich Village, and plain Ray's Pizza. The latter, in fact, appears to be the original Ray's, though its founder is named Ralph Cuomo. Now Mr. Cuomo has joined forces with two other Rays by other names, Rosolino Mangano of Famous Original's Ray's, and Gary Esposito of Original Ray's, and the three of them intend to make all the other Rays change their names or pay a franchise fee under the banner of Famous Original Ray's. Mr. Mangano has since warned some of the other Rays that they may face legal action. He recalled: "I said to them, 'You want to be Ray's Pizza, you got to pay.' "

title: The Fall of de Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Border Boom's Dirty Residue Imperils U.S.-Mexico Trade
description: Little more than a muddy creek when it starts flowing down a hillside in Mexico, the Nogales Wash passes by factories, shantytowns and noisy commercial streets before it reaches an invisible line and then suddenly becomes a swirling, stinking foreign policy problem for the Bush Administration.

title: The World; 'Clean Win' in the War With Iraq Drifts Into a Bloody Aftermath
description: AS the nightmare continued for the 18 million people of Iraq last week, President Bush sought to put a period at the end of the Persian Gulf war, but it would not end. Indeed, the United States' "clean win," as Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had termed it, was being soiled by the bloodbath it had unleashed inside Iraq.

title: Exhibition Depicts Migration From Alabama to Bridgeport
description: DURING the decades before and after World War II, hundreds of thousands of black Americans left the rural South to seek new lives in the cities of the North and the Middle West. This migration, which changed the face of America's urban areas, is illustrated in a photographic exhibition, "From Fields of Promise: Gee's Bend, Ala., to Bridgeport, Conn.," now on view at the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport.

title: Devils' Loss Sets Up Date With Penguins
description: The Devils suffered a 4-0 defeat to Washington tonight at the Capital Centre and thus will finish fourth in the Patrick Division and play the Penguins in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: A Star In Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Melancholy's Daughter'
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Sweet Song Turned Bitter Long Ago
description: The singing sextet known as the Comedian Harmonists is a legend kept alive by a nostalgic appetite for memorabilia from the Weimar Republic, by an appreciation of superlative musicianship and more than 150 historical recordings. The story of the rise to fame by the six-man group is the stuff of which Hollywood dreams are made.

title: About Men; A Garden Regained
description: THE WORST SCENE IS indistinct. I see it through the haziness of an English summer, through the smoke that encircled it and now through the frosted glass of memory. But its horror, like that of a nightmare still felt but no longer remembered, is palpable.

title: Between Home and Heaven, a Ball Field
description: The approach of spring in Washington Heights, the Santo Domingo of New York: People fling open their windows, and into their tenement apartments comes the call of merengue, a dozen different variations blasting from speakers in bodegas and record stores and cars cruising Broadway. And they get ready for baseball.

title: Cuba's New Hotels Dream of Dollars
description: EACH winter the number of jets unloading Canadians, Germans, Spaniards and Italians for stays in the hotels and bungalows that are sprouting all over Cuba seems to increase. Many of the visitors head for the seaside resort of Varadero, which has become the center of Socialist Cuba's headlong rush to develop a mass tourism industry. So far, this expansion has worked well. Over 320,000 tourists visited the republic in 1989 -- more than in any year before Fidel Castro came to power in 1959 -- and the annual growth rate over the past six years has been close to 10 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; The Golden Kid of World Soccer Goes Into Free Fall
description: It was only a year ago that one of the world's leading soccer officials spoke these prophetic words about Diego Armando Maradona:

title: Anthropology in Government, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Coup Leaders in Mali Agree to Share Power
description: Coup leaders have agreed to share power with civilians and said they would organize Mali's first democratic elections in 22 years by year's end, the official radio said today.

title: Headliners; Earning His Stripes
description: Harvard University has bagged itself an escaped Princeton tiger. Neil L. Rudenstine, a Princeton graduate and Rhodes scholar who walked away from a sure offer of the Princton presidency in 1987, was confirmed as the 26th president of Harvard last week. Mr. Rudenstine, who held the No. 2 job at Princeton for 10 years before jumping ship for a top spot at the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, said he left his alma mater simply because it was time for a change. "All things have their seasons and that season was done," he said. "Now I am a slightly different person and this is a slightly different university." Indeed it is. For one thing, Harvard's agenda, and now Mr. Rudenstine's, includes a $2 billion capital campaign, the largest in the history of American education. There doesn't seem to be any question that he is up to it. William G. Bowen, who was president of Princeton when Mr. Rudenstine was provost, said his former No. 2 was "the ablest academic administrator I've ever met, or expect to meet."

title: College Basketball; Smith Ejected on 2 Technicals
description: North Carolina versus Kansas in the Final Four was billed as the student versus the teacher. But there was a twist in this plot as the teacher, Dean Smith, the Tar Heels' coach, got his knuckles rapped and was sent packing before the game was over.

title: Style Makers; Darius Krzemionka, Custom Label Maker
description: When Darius Krzemionka was 11 years old, he was in a bicycle accident that left him unconscious and requiring immediate surgery. Not until he was revived -- long past his curfew -- could he tell ambulance workers the phone number of his parents in Wallington, N.J.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE old slat gate was smothered with vines that resisted my efforts to gain entry.

title: Fated to Be a Classic
description: To the Editor:

title: Dirty Deal? It's All In the 'Cards'
description: Curious thing about British television. The stereotypical Briton is stiff-upper-lipped, addicted to understatement and ever so proper. Yet at its best, British television is far more wicked and devastating than its American counterpart. Television in this country is curiously timid when dealing with truly sensitive subjects, while the supposedly wimpy British can carry a big stick in their television entertainments -- and use it ferociously.

title: Business Diary: March 24-29
description: COMPANIES What Sort of Price for A.T.&T.'s Reluctant NCR Prize?

title: A Talent Manager Guides the First Steps
description: THE image of a talent manager conjures up the stereotype of a beat-up office on Broadway permeated with cigar smoke and the gravelly voice of a curmudgeon in a derby saying:

title: 80 Acres Isn't Enough Personal Space
description: THE TOMCAT'S WIFE Other Stories. By Carol Bly. 209 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kennebunkport, Me.;
A Seaside Inn In Bankruptcy
description: THE owner of a seaside inn that housed members of the White House staff and press corps during President Bush's visits to his summer home at Walker's Point here has filed for bankruptcy reorganization to prevent a bank foreclosure auction.

title: In Trinidad, 'Calypso Diplomacy' With a Beat
description: When the rebel leader Yasin Abu Bakr and his followers captured Trinidad and Tobago's House of Parliament and broadcasting studios in an attempted coup last July, one of the first things they did -- after taking the Prime Minister and his Cabinet hostage -- was turn Trinidad's television station into a calypso MTV. Until the authorities jammed their broadcasts, the rebel group Jamaat al Muslimeen ran continuous videos of politically aware calypso singers like David Rudder, Watchman and Cro Cro in between Mr. Abu Bakr's running commentary.

title: New Look for a Chinese Traffic-Stopper
description: LONG ISLAND restaurants continue to play musical chairs. Italian cafes replace Irish pubs, and Greek snack bars follow on the heels of Brazilian bistros. But anyone who had even glanced at Woks in Huntington knew that only another Chinese restaurant could fill those premises.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard house is finished with an oil stain. Within a year after the stain was applied, mildew stains appeared. We plan to stain the house again this spring. How can we remove the mildew stains and prevent them from coming back?

title: New? Used? No, Guess Again.
description: Malcolm Bricklin is back. Or at least he intends to be. The man who brought Subaru to America, who manufactured the Bricklin gull-wing coupe of 1974 and '75, and who created the inexpensive and ill-fated Yugo, has plans to change the face of automobile marketing in this country.

title: Review/Music; Czech Bill by Talich Quartet
description: Unaccountably, the Talich Quartet, founded in Prague in 1964 and most likely Czechoslovakia's leading string quartet, had to wait until Wednesday evening to make its New York debut, at the 92d Street Y. Unfortunately, the foursome was saddled -- an unkind but accurate word -- with a pianist who was presenting the group.

title: Looking Forward And Backward
description: The dinner tables were covered with leaves, white stephanotis, gardenias and white orchids at Macy's annual dinner, always held during the Herald Square store's flower show. The party on Wednesday evening raised money for the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation's Greater New York Chapter.

title: Streetscapes: The Tompkins Square Boys' Lodging House; Pioneer Home for the Homeless
description: TWO and a half years after the riots in Tompkins Square, the tension is still there as nearly 100 homeless people who have changed the face of the park coexist, but uneasily, with those who use it for recreation instead of residence.

title: Cool Outrage for Los Angeles Mayor
description: The day after the police beating of a black motorist, Mayor Tom Bradley huddled in his office with Deputy Mayor Mark D. Fabiani and a few top aides to watch the videotape of the incident. In the darkened room, they concentrated on the blurry image until it ended. Then there was a long silence.

title: Telling It Like It Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Helena Napolitan To Wed Jeffrey Morash
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Napolitan of Pottersville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Helena Napolitan to Jeffrey David Morash, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Morash of Boston. A September wedding is planned.

title: American on Their Own Terms; Feeling American -- Sort Of
description: TURNING JAPANESE Memoirs of a Sansei. By David Mura. 376 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.95.

title: Millionaire's Taste Guided an Era's Artists
description: THE Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum's yearlong 25th anniversary celebration leads off with an exhibition called "LeGrand Lockwood and the Taste for American Art."

title: Shrine Where Hindus Died Reopens in Calm
description: For the first time since scores of Hindus were killed last winter when they battled security forces in this holy Hindu town, hundreds of thousands of pilgrims traveled peacefully to a shrine here in the last week.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: 'ROUND MIDNIGHT
description: "The sight of jazz," observed the critic Leonard Feather, "sometimes seems inseparable from the sound of jazz." The fact that the music has regained its animated and theatrical flavor after a long period of hypercool pleases Vincent Chancey, for one. "I'm all for it," says Chancey, who posed with his French horn, showing off the hat that is his own dramatic trademark.

title: The Budget's Got (Gasp!) an Income Tax
description: THE first budget from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is a $7.48 billion spending plan that would reduce the sales tax from 8 to 4.25 percent and eliminate the corporate surcharge and taxes on capital gains, interest and dividends. That plan however, would impose an income tax on wages, a tax long resisted by many state legislators, at a flat rate of 6 percent.

title: Family War Stories
description: THE GREAT WORLD By David Malouf. 330 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.

title: Food; Soup, Beautiful Soup
description: IF I HAD TO CHOOSE ONE DISH THAT I COULD NOT LIVE WITHOUT, it would have to be soup. And if I had to name my two favorite soups, they would probably be vegetable soup and bread-and-cheese soup.

title: Away From It All?
description: To the Editor: My response to Michael Konik is commiseration by participation.

title: Louise Newman Marries
description: Louise Newman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Williams of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Raymond A. Charles Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles of New York. The Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender officiated at the First Presbyterian Church. The bride, who was a widow, teaches prekindergarten in the Mount Vernon school system. Mr. Charles is a commissioner at the New York State Workers' Compensation Board in New York. His two previous marriages were annulled.

title:
FOCUS: PHILADELPHIA;
Finding Tenants for Low-Income Philadelphia Units
description: State and city officials are finding that it is sometimes easier to build low-income housing than to find people to live in it.

title: Failed at Suicide, Succeeding at Life
description: WHEN he was 27 years old, Edwin B. Gallagher tried to kill himself by "rolling off the top of the Kensico Dam as if tossing in bed." The 110-foot plunge left him with a broken neck.

title:
Gardening;
A Weeder's Digest
description: When first I learned that there was such a tool as a trowel, I couldn't distinguish between an incipient violet and a potential potato. Now I'm a graduate weeder.

title: Data Bank/March 31, 1991
Mutual Funds; Rebound in Financial Services
description: The stock market has begun the year with a bang, with the average stock fund gaining 12.8 percent. Overall, the market has been driven by the small-company group, which had risen 21.2 percent through March 21, according to Lipper Analytical Services of Summit, N.J.

title: Liberty, Autonomy and Daiquiri
description: I have served my time with the fetus police. I have been told that sushi, salami, iced tea and chocolate mousse were bad for the traveling companion I hauled around inside my midsection, and I have been told it by perfect strangers.

title: A Quotatious Confidant
description: A LINE OUT FOR A WALK Familiar Essays. By Joseph Epstein. 331 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.

title:
FILM;
For 'New Jack City,' It's the Same Old Story
description: DEAR SON:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine today about Dr. W. French Anderson, a genetic surgeon, misstates the date of the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. They were held in 1988.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charleston, S.C.; Court Sinks A Choice Lot
description: WHEN David Lucas developed the 1,600-acre Wild Dunes resort on Isle of Palms 15 miles northeast of here in the early 80's, he picked out two choice oceanfront lots for himself. But by the time he was ready to build, the state had changed the law and made construction on such sites illegal.

title: The Thin Red Line; Gorbachev Fails To Stop the Forces He Set in Motion
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV could only manage a parody of Kremlin terror last week as his nation sank ever deeper into domestic despondency. Muscovites had the good grace to be more annoyed than scared by the sight of the 50,000 troops and police officers he had ringing the city's center on guard against political protest rallies. Some citizens, perhaps 100,000 or more, also had the good sense to hold a political protest rally as the best way of salvaging something from one of the most tense and sorry days of Mr. Gorbachev's spotted career as a democratizer.

title: Blair T. Kloman, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Felix Kloman of South Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Blair Trapnell Kloman to Ralph Talmadge Birdsey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdsey of Atlanta. An August wedding is planned.

title: Community Psychiatric Centers Is Ready to Take on Debt
description: Call him dedicated. Call him a tightwad. But when James W. Conte visits one of the 50 psychiatric hospitals owned by his company, he refuses to pay for a hotel room, preferring instead to stay at the hospital -- behindlocked ward doors. That way he can try out a mattress, the air conditioning and cafeteria food. It saves his company, Community Psychiatric Centers a few bucks, too.

title: Travel Advisory; Oil Spill Fouls Caribbean Isles
description: The black sand beaches of the Caribbean islands of St. Kitts and Nevis are being despoiled by an oil spill. The Trinidadian barge Vesta Belle was bound for Antigua carrying over 500,000 gallons of bunker fuel when a towing cable snapped on March 6, causing it to sink 12 miles northeast of Nevis.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Jack Higgins's novel "The Eagle Has Landed," which was published in 1975, sold more copies than there are pine cones in Maine, was made into a movie and brought celebrity to the British writer. It was about a German attempt during World War II to kidnap Winston Churchill and bring him to Berlin. Heading the German team were a parachute colonel named Kurt Steiner and an I.R.A. assassin named Liam Devlin. The attempt failed. Devlin got away. Steiner was captured and sent to the Tower of London, no less.

title: Budget Plans Leave Schools Uncertain
description: SPRING is final budget-planning time for schools, and this spring is a time of more frustration and uncertainty than usual as local officials face deep cuts in aid from Albany, where deliberation continues over the extent of the reductions.

title: Plus Ca Change, More She Is the Same
description: WORD has been coming back for -- I don't know -- a decade or more that Parisians have stopped curling their lips at Americans who try to speak to them in French with anything less than flawless grammar and pronunciation. I'm back from Paris, and all I can say is plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose, or, as some French person might have remarked to me at any point during my vacation, "More this changes, more this is the same thing."

title: Double Victory For Navy Crew
description: Navy's varsity heavyweight crew opened its 1991 rowing season today with a convincing victory over Princeton and Columbia, capturing two trophies in the same race.

title: Lisa Olshen to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Olshen of Livingston, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Meryl Olshen, and Richard Jay Adelsohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Adelsohn of Livingston. Ms. Olshen, 25 years old, is a law student at George Washington University. She graduated from the State University at Binghamton. Mr. Adelsohn, 26, is a professional civil engineer with Frank H. Lehr Associates, engineering consultants in East Orange, N.J. He graduated from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and is studying for an M.B.A. at Rutgers University.

title: Barbara Swinton To Marry in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Neil W. Swinton Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Benedict Swinton to William Fitzhugh deButts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. L. deButts of Norfolk, Va. A July wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WRITERS' CONFERENCE

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SLIVER By Ira Levin.Bantam, $19.95.

title: Set to Enter a 2d Season
description: The National Hockey League's six-month regular season concludes tonight with nine games, including home finales for the Rangers, against the Pittsburgh Penguins, and the Devils, against the Islanders.

title: Postings: 58-Unit Trailer Park; Putnam Co-op
description: When their 58-unit trailer park in Putnam County, N.Y., was sold a year and a half ago, its elderly residents turned to the Mobile Home Cooperative Fund for help. As a result, the 10.8-acre Brookside Senior Citizens Cooperative Community in Phillipstown is close to becoming a done deal, with 43 expected to become owners and the rest continuing to rent.

title: Dr. Baltimore's Experiment in Hubris
description: Dr. David Baltimore, president of the Rockefeller University for the past six months, is among the cleverest scientists of his generation. He was awarded the 1975 Nobel Prize for Medicine for research on molecular biology published in 1970, when he was only 32. Now in his early 50's, he still thinks much faster than most people. Why should it matter that he has now disowned a recondite and obscure scientific article published in 1986?

title: The World; People on the Move Tax Nerves and Resources
description: ITALY showed some of Western Europe's new toughness toward migrants from the East when it yanked the welcome mat from under 20,000 Albanians who had sailed across the Adriatic in rickety ships early this month.

title: Alexander Gotfryd, 59, Dies; Former Art Director and a Photographer
description: Alexander Gotfryd, a photographer and a former art director of the Doubleday Publishing Company, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and resided in New York City and in Bellport, L.I.

title: Q and A
description: Is English Beef Safe?

title: Wall Street; Slippage in the Hodgepodge World of Warren Buffett
description: On Wall Street, the treats of spring include the annual report of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the hodgepodge enterprise run by Warren E. Buffett, renowned both for his investment acumen and for his pithy commentary. His report for 1990 arrived last week, and it minced no words.

title: IF THERE'S A WAR, HE'S THERE
description: William Prochnau's tribute to Peter Arnett was most welcome ("If There's a War, He's There," March 3). I would like to comment on the curiously understated quality of Arnett's own description of his project, when he says: "It's better . . . to learn this stuff up front so that we don't have surprises and start being ashamed later for what we didn't know or didn't want to know at the time."

title: Automatic Tollgates Ease Traffic Congestion
description: I read with interest your excellent article "The Commuter's Destination Is the County" [ March 17 ] . In the article, the point was made that "one of the most visible signs of job growth is the increased rush-hour traffic congestion, particularly on the Tappan Zee bridge."

title: A Look at the Last Century Through American Indian Eyes
description: AT the Rye Arts Center is "Visions of the Past Century: Paintings by Native Americans (1897-1987)." This is a group of some 30 works culled by Evelyn Bernstein from the collection of the Smithsonian Intitution's National Museum of the American Indian.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
New Ways to Make Housing Affordable
description: FACED with the continuing need for affordable housing in Westchester, some housing advocates are pushing new measures to fill that need and municipalities are offering incentives to developers.

title: Escrow Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: Urban Preservation; 'Civilized City': A Public Forum
description: The ever more complicated challenge of preserving urban neigbhborhoods and buildings will be discussed by experts from a broad variety of civic and environmental groups at a conference on April 15 being sponsored by the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation and several other civic groups.

title: Cold, Scared, Hungry and Free
description: PASSAGES TO FREEDOM A Story of Capture and Escape. By Joseph S. Frelinghuysen. Illustrated. 301 pp. Manhattan, Kan.: Sunflower University Press. Paper, $17.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MANHATTANVILLE COLLEGE;
Plunging Into a Foreign Language, With No English Allowed
description: MELANIE CANES began dreaming in Spanish. So did Margaret Slattery. Courtney Gray said she had not yet dreamed in French, the language she is studying, but that she was beginning to "think in it," rather than having an English translation constantly running through her mind.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rockets Go Out Like Lambs: Having won all 13 of their games in March, the Houston Rockets had to like their chances of closing out an unbeaten month. After all, only two weak teams, Orlando and Miami, remained to be marched over in March. But the Rockets stumbled against Orlando yesterday, being routed, 114-82, to fall short of becoming the first team in 18 years to be undefeated in a month. Orlando, playing at home, got 25 points and 14 assists from Scott Skiles and set three team defensive records: fewest points allowed in a quarter (12 in the first), fewest allowed in a game and lowest field-goal percentage by an opponent (30.7). (AP)

title: The Region; Another New York City Tradition: Dirty Streets
description: DIRTY streets are hardly new in New York City, where many residents carelessly aim their trash at the litter baskets with the abandon of tourists throwing coins into Rome's Trevi Fountain. But the newest threat of accumulating grit, as a result of drastic budget cuts, follows several years of what appears to have been record cleanliness.

title: Borders Don't Make Middle East Tensions
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Vocal Duo Plus Synthesizer
description: The team of Nancy Marano and Eddie Monteiro has taken the kind of fast-moving jazz singing developed in the 1950's by Lambert, Hendricks and Ross into new areas made possible by Mr. Monteiro's virtuosity on an accordion that contains a miniaturized organ and synthesizer effects. At their one-night engagement on Wednesday at J's, Broadway at 97th Street, the accordion was so effectively integrated with the two voices that the act became, in effect, a trio.

title: God and the Critics
description: WORDS WITH POWER Being a Second Study of "The Bible and Literature." By Northrop Frye. 342 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph last Sunday with an article about the business community's lack of help to New York City was published in error. It showed Mayor David N. Dinkins meeting with city officials, not with the New York City Partnership group.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Katonah, N.Y. 285,000 10 The Terrace 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; fireplace, 1-car garage, patio; taxes $3,690. Larchmont, N.Y. 407,500 4 Bryson Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old colonial; fireplace, new eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $8,966. Mount Kisco, N.Y. 272,000 31 Daly Cross Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, dining room, eat-in kitchen, terrace, hot tub, 1 acre; taxes $5,477. Deep River, Conn. 17,000 114 Georgetown Woods 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old studio condominum; 320 square feet, galley kitchen, needs work; monthly charges $63, taxes $557. Essex, Conn. 140,000 73 Woodland Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old ranch; open-floor plan, wraparound deck, 1 acre; taxes $1,252. Lyme, Conn. 175,000 29 Birch Mill Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 350-year-old saltbbox; stone fireplace and bake oven in lving room, library w/fireplace, 0.50 acre; taxes $1,827. OTHER AREAS Glen Cove, L.I. 245,000 19 Reynolds Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31- year-old ranch; den, 0.5 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $6,200. Hauppauge, L.I. 187,500 10 Sheila Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; new kitchen, family room, den, deck, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $5,500. Morris Township, N.J. 180,000 54 Fairmount Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; stone facade, h/w floors, fireplace; taxes $2,611.

title: Even When Children Are Hospitalized, They Still Have School
description: AT Public School 404 in Queens, illness is not an excuse for missing school. It's the reason students attend.

title: Dual Addictions a Growing Problem for Women
description: NEITHER alcoholism nor cocaine addiction is new on Long Island. What is new, experts say, is the rising number of people addicted to both, particularly women with such dual addictions.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SLEEPWALKER By Michael Cadnum.St. Martin's, $15.95.

title: Away From It All?
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Michael Konik's piece. How true it is.

title: Jane Isaacs Plans August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jed P. Isaacs of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth Isaacs, to Mark Edward Schoenholtz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schoenholtz of Kingston, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Jamie Fortunoff, Physician, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Fortunoff of Muttontown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Jamie Allison Fortunoff to Dr. Paul Peter Romanello, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Romanello of Bayside, Queens. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Teachers Go Hunting For History
description: THE 1790 United States Census noted that the household of Thomas Fitch, an 18th-century lawyer in Norwalk, included two slaves and two "free Negroes."

title: Mandela and Zulu Chief Meet on Strife
description: The leaders of the two largest black political organizations in South Africa met today and promised to cooperate more closely in stemming the unrelenting violence that has shaken black townships.

title: IRAQIS BEAR DOWN ON KURDISH REVOLT
description: Iraqi troops moving to crush a Kurdish rebellion in northern Iraq shelled the outskirts of the provincial capital of Dohuk today as tens of thousands of frightened civilians fled the city.

title: Kay Shadley Marries Daniele Myara
description: Kay Lee Shadley, a daughter of Wilma G. Cates of Hillsboro, Ind., and the late Kenneth Woodroe Shadley, was married last evening to Daniele Myara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Juda Myara of Casablanca, Morocco; Torremolinos, Spain, and Villemomble, France. The Rev. Marie de Young, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Grolier Club in New York.

title:
DINING OUT;
French Fare and a Fine Wine List
description: A FEW years ago, La Petite Auberge in Cresskill was considered one of the best restaurants in New Jersey, serving basic French food at a time when nouvelle cuisine was all the rage. Although it is still possible to have a good meal here, recent visits have proved that the restaurant no longer shines with the same brilliance it once did.

title: The World; Affirmative Action, Chinese Style, Makes Some Progress
description: SOME years ago, when three Red Guards tried to carry the Cultural Revolution to a village inhabited by the Yao ethnic minority, the Yao peasants dealt with the annoyance in a traditional way: they bound the Red Guards and prepared to slaughter them as a human sacrifice. Yao elders eventually managed the release of the young revolutionaries, but the incident left a lasting impression of the delicacy of relations with China's ethnic minorities.

title: Dr. Anderson's Gene Machine
description: "HOW ARE YOU DOING, KID?" THE DOCTOR ASKS HIS young patient, hugging and tickling her and trying to make her giggle. The girl looks up at him with huge dark eyes, but since a stranger is in the room today she is too shy to smile. She is a quiet 4-year-old whose solemn gaze can be a bit unnerving. As she drinks chocolate milk and zaps the hospital television with the remote-control device, she seems oblivious to the fact that she is making medical history.

title: Do Electronics Have a Place In the Concert Hall? Maybe
description: Architectural history may one day honor Silva Hall in the Hult Center for the Performing Arts in Eugene. Visually striking, it also affords first-class sound on most evenings. Not incidentally, the hall, completed in 1982, brings home perhaps the most controversial issue for the future of concert-hall design: "electronic architecture," combining traditional construction techniques and electronic "enhancement."

title:
Northeast Notebook: Kennebunkport, Me.;
Owner of Inn Fends Off Bank
description: THE owner of a seaside inn that housed members of the White House staff and press corps during President Bush's visits to his summer home at Walker's Point here has filed for bankruptcy reorganization to prevent a bank foreclosure auction.

title: Robin Reingold To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael H. Reingold of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin H. Reingold to Matthew Patrick Donegan, a son of L. Edwin Donegan Jr. of Yarmouthport, Mass., and JoAnn Donegan of Milford, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Talking: Refinancing; Lowering The Costs On a Loan
description: ALTHOUGH this may be a good time to refinance a mortgage loan -- interest rates are lower than at any time in the last four years -- the upfront costs may come as a shock to many home owners.

title: Wall Street; A Better Way to Track Your Assets
description: A leading Japanese insurance company and one of America's foremost pension consulting firms last week unveiled a new computerized asset-allocation model that is many times more powerful and responsive than the ones currently in use on Wall Street. The development could reshape the way in which trillions of dollars of financial assets are managed.

title: Japanese Enclave Thrives in Hartsdale
description: ON East Hartsdale Avenue in the Hartsdale section of Greenburgh, one can shop for food and magazines, get a haircut, take driving or piano lessons, see a doctor, or make a real estate deal -- without knowing any language other than Japanese.

title: Visit to an Ideal Landscape
description: CATHAY A Journey in Search of Old China. By Fergus M. Bordewich. Introduction by Jan Morris. 304 pp. New York: A Destinations Book/Prentice Hall Press. $19.95.

title: Vienna Nurse's Aides Convicted of Killing Patients
description: An Austrian court this week convicted four nurse's aides from a hospital here of murdering scores of elderly and infirm patients either by lethal injection or by forcing water into their lungs.

title: Q and A
description: Teaching at Home Question: I am a full-time school teacher and want to offer computer tutoring in my rent-stabilized apartment nights and weekends. Do rent guidelines permit that? . . . Houda Chawki, Corona, Queens Answer: Yes. Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said that no rent regulation bars you. There are, however, two other potential obstacles.

title: Corrections
description: A quiz about the U.S. economy on March 10 misstated the nation's reliance on imported energy. The U.S. imports 50 percent of its oil, not 50 percent of its total energy.

title: Out of Love and Necessity, Cars Boom on L.I.
description: IT begins weekdays at dawn. Across Long Island, people turn on the ignitions in their cars, vans, pickup trucks and all-purpose vehicles to drive to work on some of the most-congested roads in the country.

title: Recession and Guilt Pare Dining Trade and Menus
description: In the last two years, the euphemistic Closed for Renovation sign has nearly eclipsed the Happy Hour signs in the windows of New York City restaurants. Crowds have thinned in the best dining rooms. Same-day reservations are rarely a problem.

title: Borders Don't Make Middle East Tensions; Touring Saudi Arabia
description: To the Editor:

title: One of 4 Escapees Is Arrested Leaving Manhattan Subway
description: One of four convicts who escaped from a maximum-security prison in the Catskills last week was captured yesterday as he stepped off a subway train in Manhattan into the grasp of two dozen state police and corrections investigators, state officials said.

title: The Modern's Blending of Mediums Is a Mixed Bag
description: Judging from recent evidence, the Museum of Modern Art seems to be turning over a new leaf -- one that freely blends photographs, posters, architectural models, airplane propellers and other less exalted forms of expression with the "high arts" of painting and sculpture. In two winter exhibitions, "Art of the 40's" and "Artist's Choice: Chuck Close, Head-On/ The Modern Portrait," the museum's canon has been opened up and shaken, making modernism look less like an avant-garde enterprise and more like a cultural phenomenon.

title: Susan Norton to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Norton of New York have announced June 1992 wedding plans for their daughter Susan P. Norton and Michael C. DiCerto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick DiCerto of New York. Miss Norton, 24 years old, is a theatrical dancer. She graduated from Skidmore College. Mr. DiCerto, 25, is an independent movie producer and director. He graduated from the New York Institute of Technology.

title:
MUSIC;
A 'Spicy Soup' Blends Mozart and Latin Jazz
description: FOR the Hudson Chamber Symphony, a program featuring styles from classical to Latin jazz to folk music is a departure from the norm. But when Gary M. Schneider, music director of the orchestra, invited a Cuban saxophonist and clarinetist, Paquito D'Rivera, to be the guest soloist, the two musicians assembled a program blending a variety of influences.

title: There's More Than One Way to Save Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Penny Murphy To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Wilfred Murphy of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Paula Graham Murphy to Theodore Harkness Ashford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Harkness Ashford of Wilmington, Del. A June wedding is planned.

title: Renting a Condo
description: To the Editor:

title: A Script Recipe: One Kidney, Lots of Writers, Beat Well
description: When I signed on to write my first television episode, I thought I knew what I was letting myself in for. In the best case, some of my words might be rewritten, but I would be a good sport, get screen credit and lots of money for five or six weeks' work. In the worst case, my words would be trashed by blithering idiots and I would loathe the whole process, but the payoff would be the same.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mahopac
description: IN its heyday, in the 1870's, Lake Mahopac was a summer resort that "rivaled anything found in Newport or Saratoga," according to a history written by a local resident in 1906.

title: Ms. van Ogtrop To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Piet Hein van Ogtrop of Newark, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristin Anne van Ogtrop to Dean Costley Robinson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Glen O. Robinson of Charlottesville, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kristin M. Clough To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Clough Jr. of Concord, Mass., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Kristin M. Clough and James E. Canty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Canty of Schenectady, N.Y.

title: Sara Hinsey, Editor, to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hinsey 4th of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara Ruth Hinsey to John Michael Raveret, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Aiken Raveret of Wilmette, Ill. A June wedding is planned.

title: Travel Advisory; Losing Perks
description: War calls for sacrifices, even for first-class passengers on British Airways flights between New York and London. Because of a 26 percent dropoff in traffic in February as a result of the Persian Gulf war and the poor economy, the airline has eliminated breakfast in first class, removed cashews from the mixed nut selection and reduced the salad dressing by half. Gone, too, are the fruit basket and flowers in the bathroom. Saddest cut of all: only 27 After Eight mints will be available for the 18 first-class passengers.

title: American on Their Own Terms; 'The Complete Other Side of the World'
description: TYPICAL AMERICAN By Gish Jen. 296 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: Review/Film; Young Man Not at Home, Not Alone
description: "Career Opportunities," with a screenplay by John Hughes, calls to mind almost every good idea Mr. Hughes has ever had. Since his last good idea was the one for "Home Alone," it's not hard to see how or why this happened. At least Mr. Hughes (unlike this film's poster, which is modeled on the "Pretty Woman" ad) is content to borrow only from himself.

title: Review/Music; Variations Project by the Akoshia Quartet
description: The precedent for the Akoshia String Quartet's Variations Project is certainly Anton Diabelli's publishing promotion of 1819, when composers from Ignaz Umlauf to Franz Schubert contributed brief treatments of a given theme. Were it not for Beethoven's compulsive 33-part exploration of the comic and the sublime (now known as the "Diabelli' Variations), this little money-making scheme might have fallen into the black hole of history.

title: Cycling Tours
description: To the Editor: In answering a question about bicycle tours (Q & A, Feb. 17), you listed the usual for-profit groups. I have traveled with one of them in the United States, and they did a super job. But I would like you to know about a nonprofit tour group called Bicycle Adventure Club (3904 Groton Street, San Diego, Calif. 92110), which my husband and I have traveled with in Europe four times. Their cost is much less, and they usually go farther each day (30 to 40 miles). We always take our own bikes (they do not have rentals). Once in a while an accommodation is not quite what you hoped or a day is a little long -- but it's the surprises that make a trip fun and alert you to better planning next time. TRUDY KENNEDY Dallas

title: The Cat With the Killer Personality
description: FELIX The Twisted Tale of the World's Most Famous Cat. By John Canemaker. Illustrated. 177 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $30.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on page 9 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film "Guilty by Suspicion" misstates the relationship between Irwin Winkler, the writer-director, and Abraham Lincoln Polonsky, the original screenwriter. Mr. Polonsky said that Mr. Winkler tried to persuade him -- not that Mr. Winkler persuaded him -- to take the title of executive producer and continue the collaboration.

title: The Nation; The Bailout Agency Becomes A Highly Motivated Seller
description: IN its latest attempt to spur the savings and loan bailout toward a conclusion, the Government last week announced a spring and summer clearance sale -- with discounts ranging as high as 50 percent -- on items including $65 billion worth of houses and horse farms, junk bonds and delinquent loans. And instead of free balloons for the kids, the agency said it would give away 2,000 to 3,000 houses. These and a wide array of other assets had been financed by savings and loan institutions that have since collapsed, leaving the legacy of their demise in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation.

title: The 'Terrible Beauty' of Easter, 1916
description: In Dublin 75 years ago, a tiny army of Irish rebels and patriots took possession of the main post office. There, on Easter Monday, they proclaimed the birth of an Irish Republic and the end of England's imperial rule. The rising was quixotic, had little support and was swiftly put down. Yet with vengeful ferocity, the British ordered the execution, one by one, of 15 rebel leaders, including a trade unionist, suffering from gangrened wounds, who had to be propped up to be shot.

title: Arab Strike Held Only in Occupied Areas
description: Palestinians conducted a general strike in the occupied territories and Israeli Arabs held rallies today to mark their annual Land Day protest against Israeli policies.

title: Data Update

In the Region: Long Island;
Bed-and-Breakfasts Gaining Popularity
description: KATHY BURK and William Kiriluk own a renovated, early 19th-century farmhouse on Route 25A in Port Jefferson. They operate a bed-and-breakfast business called Compass Rose to which local residents look for pleasant, inexpensive lodgings for out-of-town visitors.

title:
ART;
A Few Standouts in Large Juried Show
description: AS usual, the Huntington Township Art League's annual juried competition attracted a large number of entries. The jurors, Harvey Dinnerstein and Miriam Schapiro, two well-known painters from New York City, chose 71 works from 700 submissions.

title: 'Field' Diamond Opens to Public
description: The "Field of Dreams" diamond officially opens for business this week, although the movie set draws people year around.

title: The Delights of a Japanese Garden
description: JUST before sunset, the fishermen down the last of their beer and gather their gear and bait. Nearby, two kimono-clad women take their farewell bows; a solitary painter, perhaps inspired by the changing light, tints his watercolor trees a shade of orange. So ends another day at Arisugawa Koen, one of a handful of homey Tokyo parks resisting the image of a city known more for finance than fun.

title: World Markets; Dollar's Gains Upset the Exchanges
description: Oh, how the dollar has hurt Americans with investments abroad this year. And with so little warning.

title: On Language; Contrariwisdom
description: "REGRETTABLY," SAID the President, using a sentence adverb that causes stock-market speculators to hit the sell button, "the noon deadline passed. . . . " Mr. Bush then laid the rhetorical and legal foundation for the allies' ground attack on Iraqi forces: "To the contrary, what we have seen is a redoubling of Saddam Hussein's efforts to destroy completely Kuwait and its people."

title: Margaret Siliciano to Wed Eric Nilsson
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. Siliciano of Elmira, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Ann Siliciano to Eric Andrews Nilsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Nilsson of San Diego. A July wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
In Tappan, a Reliance on Tradition
description: THE charming little village of Tappan may be Revolutionary General Washington and the unfortunate Major Andre are noted as sojourners hereabouts -- but Il Portico relies on tradition and established custom to please its clientele, which comes for gracious and leisurely dining. No chef wildly juxtaposes unlikely ingredients for novelty's sake here.

title: From the Ragged Land, a Forest Preserve
description: THE forest preserve called Manitoga in the Hudson Highlands shows the glories of nature revealed through the hand of man.

title: Children's Books
description: URBAN ROOSTS

title: Miss Alling to Wed Gordon W. Sewall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Wells Alling of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Scott Sykes Alling, to Gordon Ware Sewall, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Edgar F. Sewall Jr. of Winchester, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: Islanders Win a Finale
description: For some Islanders, this was simply their final appearance of the season before their home fans at Nassau Coliseum. For some others, this was their last outing as Islanders possibly forever: when a team ends a year ranked 20th out of 21 clubs with a For Sale sign serving as its only decoration, a personnel shuffle seems mandatory.

title: Cartographers on the Map
description: Before Earth could be seen whole from space, some people imagined what it would look like, then slowly encompassed it through a mosaic of points, symbols, lines and shadings -- through maps. The epic story of mapping the world is told in a six-part series, "The Shape of the World," to be shown on public television beginning tomorrow at 9 P.M. The series was produced by Granada Television in Britain in conjunction with WNET in New York.

title: Miss Johnson to Wed S. M. Atkinson in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Rollin M. Johnson of Northampton, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Katherine L. Johnson, and Stephen M. Atkinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Atkinson of Agawam, Mass.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: In Malcolm W. Browne's excellent article, "The Military vs. the Press" (March 3), one misconception should be corrected. The panel chaired by retired Maj. Gen. Winant Sidle in 1984 did not conclude that future wars should be covered by pools of reporters.

title: 18 Filipinos Presumed Dead as Heavy Seas Claim 2 Ships
description: Two ships capsized in heavy seas in the central Philippines and 18 people were thought to have died in the separate sinkings, the navy said today.

title: Kathleen Battle at Carnegie
description: The soprano Kathleen Battle will sing works by Handel, Mozart, Liszt, Rachmaninoff and Richard Strauss in a recital at Carnegie Hall on April 27 at 8 P.M. It will be the soprano's first recital in the hall. Her accompanist will be Margo Garrett. Tickets, at $12 to $50, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: No Wild Card Offered to Borg
description: There is no welcome mat out for Bjorn Borg at the Queens Club, the grass-court tournament in June that leads up to Wimbledon.

title: Style Makers; Jessica Vartoughian, Nail-Care Specialist
description: The hands are smooth and expressive, the nails 10 red ovals with no hangnails, no chips, no rough edges. No wonder: the hands belong to Jessica Vartoughian, the founder of the Jessica nail-care system, which has produced some of the country's best-groomed hands.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Coverage of home video has moved to the Thursday arts and entertainment pages, where it appears every week.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: LISA KATZ;
Looking Out for Other People's Children
description: THE attention in recent years to child abuse of all kinds has led to a proliferation of programs, aimed at preventing this abuse and at treating the victims as well as the abusers. Locally, many of the public and private agencies, as well as individuals, are part of the Westchester Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect, a self-described "coalition of children's advocates" based in White Plains.

title: Carol H. Newhall to Marry Lewis Neilson in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Newhall of Penn Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Harrison Newhall, to Lewis Levick Neilson Jr., the son of Caroline Molthan Wurts of Wayne, Pa., and Mr. Neilson of Chester Springs, Pa. A June wedding is planned. Miss Newhall, an officer at the Mellon Bank in Philadelphia, graduated from the Shipley School and Williams College. Mr. Neilson, a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Stewart & Neilson, graduated from the Hotchkiss School, Babson College and the Widener University Law School in Wilmington, Del.

title: Raided Fraternities Are Ordered to Prove They Are Drug-Free
description: The president of the University of Virginia has told the three fraternities whose members were arrested in drug raids that they must prove they are drug-free or face suspension.

title: The Fall of de Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; Bhutan Trims Package Rates
description: Price reductions for tourists' accommodations and meals in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan have been announced by the Government. The tiny country between India and China is also admitting more visitors. It was once among the most expensive and exclusive of tourist destinations. All-inclusive rates that ran as high as $250 a day or more per person for accommodations, food, guides and transportation have dropped to $220 in the peak months of April and October for visitors staying in hotels. Lodges now cost about $150 a day and campsites $120 to $130. In March, May, July, August, September and November, rates range from $175 for hotels to $100 to $120 for campers. Low-season rates for January, February, June and December will be $130 for hotels and $80 to $90 for campsites, with lodges only slightly higher.

title: Renters Find Silver Lining In an Overcast Realty Market
description: IN January 1987, when real estate prices in Connecticut were soaring and rental units were being quickly transformed into high-priced condominiums, Nancy Suttenberg placed a newspaper advertisement offering to rent a two-bedroom apartment in Norwalk.

title: Suzi R. Schiffer, Producer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Schiffer of New York have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Suzi Rachel Schiffer, and Franklin Parrasch, the son of Walter Parrasch of River Edge, N.J., and the late LaRae Parrasch.

title: Tokyo Perplexed on Islands Issue
description: Two weeks before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives here for the first visit of a Soviet leader to Japan, Government officials said today that the Soviet Union had yet to offer any concrete proposals to solve the territorial dispute that has chilled relations between the two countries since the end of World War II.

title: Strong Women Live Again in Monologues
description: SITTING in the bookcase-lined living room of her home in Westport, Page Hedden Wilson was speaking in Southern accents as full blown as magnolia blossoms in the spring.

title: The Failures of A.T.&T. Strategies
description: The stable and conservative American Telephone and Telegraph Company of old has become today's newest corporate raider. Its attempt to acquire the NCR Corporation raises questions about where it is going. The company believes that the NCR acquisition is consistent with its strategy in computer networking. Is it? Should we trust A.T.& T.'s management when it comes to computers, strategy and vision?

title: Inexcusable Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding Plans For Penny Bunn
description: September wedding plans for Allison Pennell Bunn and Joseph James McCool, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. McCool of Wilmington, Del., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emory F. Bunn of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Students Feel Alienated On Campus, Study Says
description: Life as an undergraduate at the University of California at Berkeley can be a hostile and alienating experience, concludes a committee that has been studying campus conditions for three years, and university administrators say they will try to correct the problems -- if slowly.

title:
FOCUS: Philadelphia;
Finding Tenants for Low-Income Units
description: STATE and city officials are finding that it is sometimes easier to build low-income housing than to find people to live in it.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of Easter music last Sunday gave an incorrect date for the Great Pascal vespers at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City. It will be performed at 4 P.M. next Sunday, not today.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard house is finished with an oil stain. Within a year after the stain was applied, mildew stains appeared. We plan to stain the house again this spring. How can we remove the mildew stains and prevent them from coming back?

title: Shopping for Co-op or Condo Managers
description: RELATIONS between co-op and condominium boards and their managing agents are a little like modern affairs of the heart: The boards want to be sure they are appreciated for their special qualities, management firms seek to prove they are hard and attentive workers, and neither side is afraid of divorce if things don't work out.

title: Tarpley Arrested
description: His season with the Mavericks came to an end with a knee injury in November, and now, if the Dallas police have it right, the entire career of Roy Tarpley may have come to an end with a can of beer early yesterday.

title: Kenwyn Fuller to Wed Andrew Kind
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Fuller of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kenwyn Anne Fuller to Andrew Henry Kind, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Kind Jr. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. A July wedding is planned.

title: Review/Dance; Uplifting Works by Robin Becker
description: A program presented by Robin Becker and Company last Sunday night at St. Mark's Church suggested that Ms. Becker wanted her dancers to look like angels and her audiences to feel good. She succeeded on both counts. But the dances were most persuasive when Ms. Becker let the rougher edges show.

title: Officer Says Beaten Man Resisted
description: A California Highway Patrol officer has testified that a black motorist appeared to resist being handcuffed in the minutes just before he was beaten by white officers four weeks ago.

title: Sunday Outing; Across the Upper Bay And Into S.I.'s History
description: Occasional riders of the Staten Island ferry may wonder if there's anything to do when they land in St. George. The view from the ferry terminal isn't promising. There's a bank, a courthouse and Borough Hall.

title: Sports of The Times; Will Parcells Quit Giants?
description: The silence at Giants Stadium is deafening. And in the silence, Bill Parcells's return as the coach of the Super Bowl XXV champions is suddenly uncertain.

title: Between Home and Heaven, a Ball Field
description: The approach of spring in Washington Heights, the Santo Domingo of New York: People fling open their windows, and into their tenement apartments comes the call of merengue, a dozen different variations blasting from speakers in bodegas and record stores and cars cruising Broadway. And they get ready for baseball.

title: Camera
description: Murphy's law: the probability of a wonderfully photogenic scene appearing right in front of you is in direct proportion to the number of feet, yards, miles or light-years that separate you and your camera.

title: Striking Coal Miners Defend Yeltsin
description: Striking Siberian coal miners came to the defense of Boris N. Yeltsin today, demanding that the Parliament of the Russian republic strengthen his post as the republic's President by making it a popularly elected office better able to stand up to Kremlin pressure.

title: Elihu Fowler Robertson to Marry Elizabeth Chapman Clark in June
description: June wedding plans for Elizabeth Chapman Clark and Elihu Fowler Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Robertson Jr. of Norfolk, Va., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chapman Clark of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Inside Politics
description: Money and Mouths

title: Betsy Jassen Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack H. Jassen of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Betsy Wynne Jassen and Ira Scott Dizengoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Dizengoff of Manalapan, N.J. Ms. Jassen, 24 years old, teaches science at George Washington High School in New York. She graduated from the State University at Albany and received a master's degree in biology from New York University. Mr. Dizengoff, 22, graduated magna cum laude from Brandeis University and is a law student at Yeshiva University.

title: Ms. Roosa Engaged to Edward May Jr.
description: Benjamin P. Roosa Jr. of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter Elizabeth A. Roosa to Edward T. May Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. May of Richboro, Pa. Ms. Roosa is also a daughter of the late Elizabeth H. Roosa. An October wedding is planned.

title: Youth Shelter Thanks Supporters
description: I am writing to thank you for the wonderful article that appeared March 17, concerning the Youth Shelter Program of Westchester [ "A Youth Shelter Expands to Include Female Offenders" ] .

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Minimum wage increases to $4.25 an hour. * Report on construction spending for February. * Purchasing managers release index for March. * K Mart annual meeting. * Treasury Department reports results of three- and six-month bills auction. TUESDAY: February factory orders. * Lockheed annual meeting.

title: Where Every Day Is April Fools' Day
description: FOR Samuel Sorenson Adams, the road to success began with a sneeze. His fateful moment, in 1906, led to the creation of the S. S. Adams Company, which bills itself as the "world's largest manfacturer of practical jokes and magic tricks."

title: The Region; Albany, Squeezed, Puts Pressure on Local Governments
description: WITH its vast office complexes and almost 200,000 employees, New York State government often seems like an empire unto itself. But despite its imposing size, the government is, for the most part, just a way station for tax money. The state collects it from all corners of the state, then redistributes it to counties and villages and school districts according to elaborate -- and often manipulated -- formulas.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON GIVING BIRTH TO ONE'S OWN MOTHER Essays on Art and Society. By Jay Cantor. Knopf, $19.95.

title: When Curvy Free-Form Designs Were the Rage
description: To millions of people in the years just before, during and after World War II, amoebalike tables, potato-chip chairs, undulating vases and lamps with off-center holes in their bases were objects that meant modern . Curvilinear was in, spawning everything from kidney-shaped swimming pools to Al Capp's shmoos in a free-form abstract idiom called biomorphic modern.

title: Higuera Out 15 Days
description: A torn rotator cuff can spell big trouble for a big league pitcher, but the way the Milwaukee Brewers and their left-handed ace, Teddy Higuera, see it, Higuera's shoulder injury is minor enough and his potential is great enough to justify a certain optimism.

title: The World; American-Soviet Dealings Switch to the Slow Lane
description: WHEN Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was in Moscow two weeks ago he drove to his meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, in the embassy's Cadillac limousine. As the sleek black car approached the entrance of the Foreign Ministry conference center it broke down. Mr. Baker had to get out and walk, while his security guards pushed the car the rest of the way.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a money manager, Patricia Ostrander, misidentified a lawyer who testified at sentencing hearings for Michael Milken about discussions with her. The lawyer was Craig Cogut, who had done work for Mr. Milken's firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.; he was not Casey Cogut of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett.

title: A Curbside Clinic Offers Prenatal Care
description: IN an effort to reduce New Haven's infant-mortality rate, which is twice the national average, a hospital is carrying prenatal care to the city's streets. A van from the Hospital of St. Raphaelregularly visits seven neighborhoods, offering health care to people who do not ordinarily seek it.

title: Review/Music; Marilyn Horne Offers Bolcom Cycle's Premiere
description: Predictably, Marilyn Horne's Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday evening was something of a love feast for the mezzo-soprano and her fans, and the quality of the performances made it hard to stand disinterestedly apart. A listener who has heard worrying signs of intonational slippage in the veteran singer's recent outings found it remarkable how few allowances needed to be made on this occasion.

title: 660 Black Bears Slain in '90
description: Hunters killed 660 black bears, including the oldest on record, during New York State's 1990 big game season, the state Environmental Conservation Commissioner has announced. That is slightly below the previous 10-year average of 668 bears killed, the Commissioner, Thomas Jorling, said Friday. He added that 553 of the bears were killed in the Adirondack region. One bear, killed in the town of North Elba in Essex County, was estimated to be 42 3/4 years old. That broke a 1974 record of a 41 3/4-year-old bear killed in Newcomb, also in Essex County. Biologists determine the age of dead bears by counting microscopic layers of deposits on their teeth.

title: Unease About Rate Parity and the New Dollar
description: You can listen to what Wall Street says -- or you can watch what it does.

title: Miss La Londe to Wed John Darcey; Miss Darcey to Wed B. J. McGarry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L.
