La Londe 3d of Liverpool, N.Y., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Jacqueline Marie La Londe, and John Leo Darcey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Darcey of Bloomingdale, N.J. The Darceys have also announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Frances Darcey to Brendan Joseph McGarry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eamon McGarry of Yonkers. That wedding is to be next year.

title:
The Executive Life;
'It Was a Dark And Stormy Night . . .'
description: "That first evening in Kuala Lumpur, she met an Amsterdamian student at the Digger Club. After two bottles of George Hermitage, they stole into the lush tropical garden behind the club. The moonlight filtered through the palms. Amanda sighed."

title: Borders Don't Make Middle East Tensions; Toward Lasting Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Across the Pond the Old Way
description: I wanted to get from point A (the New York area) to point B (northern Europe) in a comfortable and civilized manner. This precluded flying. No long-distance flight, with its lack of room to move about in, its commencement and conclusion at some crowded cookie-cutter airport and its jet lag, can be considered comfortable, much less civilized. That explains how I ended up in Port Newark standing at the foot of the Stefan Starzynski's gangway on an overcast October afternoon. The fragrance of bunker oil greeted me as I ascended the folding staircase hung over the ship's side, and a thousand memories of voyages past suffused me.

title: Review/Music; Early Faure Violin Concerto
description: Gabriel Faure's reputation rests mainly on a repertory of passionate but gently scored works that draw on the pastel coloration of turn-of-the-century French style. But among his early works is a violin concerto in which the soloist is pitted against an orchestra with a distinctly Wagnerian accent.

title: Another Roosevelt Makes His Mark
description: WILLARD ROOSEVELT of Orient is the first person to concede that growing up a Roosevelt has its advantages.

title: Ellen Schonfeld, TV News Producer, To Wed Robert Bienstock, a Lawyer
description: Maurice Schonfeld and Karen Lamberti, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Doud Schonfeld to Robert Harry Bienstock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Bienstock of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: College Basketball: It's a Final Surprise: Duke and Kansas; Smith Ejected as Jayhawks Triumph
description: Dean Smith's grand exit was as bizarre as it appeared to be gracious.

title: Advertising's Antic Upstarts
description: A lunchtime crowd of some 40 Italian silk ties and 40 short black skirts was munching on tortellini at the Art Directors Club in New York one recent afternoon when the least fashionable of their number, a lanky Texan in a blue blazer, gray slacks and white shirt, shuffled up to the microphone and held them rapt by condemning their chosen profession, advertising.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about two City College professors who were rebuked by a faculty committee for comments about racial superiority misstated the circumstances under which one professor, Dr. Michael Levin, expressed his views. Dr. Levin has contended in articles in academic journals that blacks, on average, are intellectually inferior to whites. He has not voiced those opinions in class.

title: Managing; To Sell a New Idea, Vary the Pitch
description: Why has the Northrop Corporation's B-2 division practically eliminated conventional photography in favor of electronic photography?

title: Travel Advisory; Mozart Opens Osaka Festival
description: The Bach-Mozart Orchestra of Tokyo will open the Osaka International Festival next Friday with an all-Mozart program. It will feature Symphonies 35 and 41 and the Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola K. 364. The conductor-composer Ikuma Dan will lead the Century Orchestra of Osaka in his opera "Chanchiki. The violinist Galina Heifetz will perform Tchaikovsky and Brahms, and the pianist Juliana Markova will offer Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7. The Yomiuri Nippon Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Heinz Fricke, will close the 33d festival on April 25. Tickets, from $16 to $100, from Osaka International Festival Society, 530 Shin-Asahi Bldg. 3F, 3-18, 2-chome, Nakanoshima, Kita-ku, Osaka, Japan.

title: Sunday Menu; Chicken Cacciatore With Fewer Calories Than Years Ago
description: The chicken cacciatore style (or chicken hunter style) of my youth had a far different flavor from the recipe below. What I remember is large pieces of chicken on the bone in a sauce made with whole tomatoes, lots of garlic and lots of oil. The dish of today calls for a good red wine (leftovers will do), much less sauce, chicken breasts off the bone and without skin, a shorter cooking time and far fewer calories.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: Brenda Fowler's article "The High Life in St. Moritz" (Travel, Feb. 24) depicts an aspect of that area that we retirees have dreamed about but cannot afford.

title: Gulf Allies Lay Down Rules for Postwar Arab Relations
description: The pro-Western Arab countries appeared to lay down the law for new inter-Arab relations at an Arab League meeting here today, dismissing all of Iraq's justifications for occupying Kuwait and hinting that they no longer regard the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole representative of Palestinians.

title:
American on Their Own Terms;
He's Been Dreaming on the Railroad
description: DONALD DUK

title: Ideas & Trends; Remember Big Brother? Now He's a Company Man
description: IN George Orwell's "1984," Big Brother is the dictator of an all-powerful government that systematically monitors the lives of its citizens. But now many computer professionals and civil liberties specialists say they fear that if a Big Brother finally arrives he may be wearing not a police uniform but a business suit.

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: Trans World Airlines certainly knows how to irk its passengers. On the flight that leaves Kennedy International Airport at 8:55 A.M. for Los Angeles, the carrier serves what amounts to two breakfasts (breakfast and, later, a snack). When asked why no lunch was served on the transcontinental flight, the passenger agent said that the flight arrives in Los Angeles before 1 P.M. Pacific Time. EDWARD KATCHER New York, N.Y. A spokesman for Trans World Airlines replies: Yes, that's our practice. The flight arrives in Los Angeles at 11:45 A.M.

title: 100 Years Later, a Jewish Writer's Time Has Come
description: Hundreds of books and articles about Israel keep appearing each year, analyzing and reanalyzing its foreign policy and internal politics from every conceivable point of view. But very little has been written about Israel's culture, and it remains a mystery, except perhaps to Israel itself.

title: Homer's Epic: Seascapes Grand and Gentle
description: During the last 20 years of his life, in his studio home alongside the family house in Prout's Neck, Me., Winslow Homer painted between 20 and 30 seascapes that changed American art and made him a near mythic figure. These paintings are remarkable, as original in their own American way as the landscapes Monet and Cezanne were painting at the same time in France.

title: Perspectives: Rent Decontrol; Unlocking the Tax Gold in Apartments
description: MENTION the word "decontrol" and New York City legislators head for the woods. But the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog of city finance, has mentioned it in a Feburary report called "Reforming Residential Rent Regulation."

title: Political Memo After Atwater, G.O.P. Suffers Spiritual Void
description: Many Republicans fell into a mournful habit after Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was stricken with a brain tumor in March 1990 and left the political scene.

title: Headliners; A Surprise From Reagan for the N.R.A.
description: IT was like a one-day reprise of his presidency. Last week, Ronald Reagan rode into town, made a speech that was long on schmaltz and short on details, answered a few questions shouted by reporters and turned the capital on its head. The issue was guns, specifically a bill, named after Mr. Reagan's former press secretary, James S. Brady, mandating a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of handguns. Ten years ago, Mr. Brady suffered permanent brain damage when John W. Hinckley Jr. tried to assassinate Mr. Reagan. The former President, a member of the National Rifle Association, has endorsed waiting periods before, always insisting, however, that the matter be left to the states. By endorsing the Federal Brady bill, he caused the political ground to shift. "It's sort of like Nixon going to China," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-13

title: Ms. Kaye to Wed J. P. Hagemeier
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Kaye of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Luisa Marion, to Jan Patric Hagemeier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich Hagemeier of Frankfurt. An August wedding is planned.

title:
Your Own Account;
Overcoming Corporate Gridlock
description: There hasn't been much good news lately for the corporate population. Even those who aren't worried about losing their jobs feel thwarted about getting ahead as companies strip off layers of managers. "There are fewer spots at the top and more people clogging up the channels," said Craig E. Schneier, managing principal at Sibson & Company, compensation consultants in Princeton, N.J. "So the opportunity for promotion has decreased significantly."

title: Barbecue Experts Open a Slicker Place
description: FANS of Stick to Your Ribs, who for years have made pilgrimages to the Texas barbecue specialist's roadside shrine just off Interstate 95 in Stratford, will be pleased to learn that a new location has been added -- also off Interstate 95, at Exit 9 on the Stamford-Darien line. This newer, slicker version makes dining downright civil -- no picnic tables within sight and sound of the highway. Instead, there's a real indoor dining room, a full bar and the expected take-out area.

title: Loyola in El Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeast Notebook: Providence, R.I.; Finding Life In Foreclosure
description: A NONPROFIT organization in what used to be one of the most crime-ridden neighborhoods in Providence is taking advantage of bank foreclosures to win attractive financing packages that lure buyers to the neighborhood.

title: Yen, Mark, Pound Lose More Ground
Dr. Sharon M. Geaghan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Geaghan of Lexington, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Sharon Markham Geaghan, to David Steven Breiner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Breiner of Portola Valley, Calif.

title: Review/Theater; Huey Long Is Portrayed In Solo Act
description: Although Huey Long was only 42 years old when he was assassinated, he packed more excitement and controversy into his relatively brief career than other politicians have in a lifetime of office holding. As T. Harry Williams wrote in his authoritative biography of the Louisiana senator, he aroused every feeling: "amazement and admiration, disbelief and disrespect, love and hatred, and, with many individuals, cold apprehension." Once, when reporters were trying to define him, Long responded with full-throttled arrogance, "Say I'm sui generis and let it go at that."

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Toronto
description: Toronto has too much Canadian civility to flaunt its charms, but the main ones are not far to seek. The Royal Ontario Museum, the Blue Jays' Skydome, the Art Gallery of Ontario, the mix of big-city restaurants and shops with parks and ethnic neighborhoods are about where you'd expect them to be. But some of the city's most gratifying little pleasures are tucked away in highy unlikely places.

title: When a Kiss Is Not Just a Kiss
description: So Molly Dodd has a black baby. After a long and suspenseful pregnancy, the unmarried, thirtysomething heroine of "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd" gave birth a few weeks ago to baby Emily -- clearly the child of the black man with whom she had been romantically involved.

title: Transplant of Oysters Awaiting a 'Sniff' Test
description: FOR three years, commercial fishermen from the Towns of East Hampton and Southampton have taken oysters from Oyster Pond in Montauk and transplanted them in May to certified clean waters.

title: Going the Distance, by Wheelchair
description: ADELE WILSON will be in the Super Cities Walk for Multiple Sclerosis next Sunday -- although she won't exactly be walking the 9.3-mile course through Rye. Mrs. Wilson, who has multiple sclerosis, said she will be "rolling" in a wheelchair, "going the whole distance, propeling myself with my hands rather than being pushed."

title: Until Working Father Joins Superwoman
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, an erstwhile challenger for the world championship, is supposed to have said, "Whoever wants to be champion must be able to defeat Gary Kasparov's Sicilian Defense." It was a peculiar remark to make because the current titleholder's play in his favorite opening is so impressive that Anatoly Karpov, his challenger in five matches since 1984, has given up challenging it.

title: Tech Notes; An Orthodontic Work Station
description: Responding to worries about exposure to dental X-rays, a Southern California company has developed an orthodontic work station that combines sonic imaging with videotape for diagnosis and measurement. Produced by Dolphin Imaging Systems Inc. of Valencia, Calif., the Digigraph Diagnostic Work Station uses three-dimensional sonic calculations to take the measurements required for orthodontic assessment and treatment. A sound-emitting hand-held pointer and four microphones placed above the patient's head allow the computer to create 3-D models of the head and jaws. By superimposing that information on video images of the patient, the work station can measure deviations from physical norms and create an "after" picture before the patient undergoes treatment. "It is a great way of showing patients where their teeth are relative to their face," said Marc Lemchen, a New York orthodontist who created the Digigraph. Dolphin recently received Federal clearance to market the machine.

title: Good, Bad and Just So-So
description: Among the most useful reference works for record collectors are "Opera on Record" (three volumes) and "Song on Record" (two volumes), all edited by the English critic Alan Blyth. In a field as chaotic as that of classical records, any critical guide is welcome, but these comprehensive books, besides being invaluable for their expert critiques, also provide substantial histories of performance practices and recording styles.

title: Two Counties Gird to Trim Services
description: BOTH Nassau and Suffolk Counties, reeling from a sluggish economy that has provided less-than-expected tax revenue, are expecting severe cuts in social-service programs under the new state budget.

title: Heather Riegel To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Heather Knorr Riegel to Roger Conant Harper, the son of Wende C. Harper of Stamford, Conn., and Dr. Richard C. Harper of South Salem, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Riegel of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Commercial Property: Columbus Avenue; Turnover Stabilizes as a Street Finds Its Own Niche
description: KNOWN since the mid-1980's for high turnover, the tenancy of Columbus Avenue may have stabilized somewhat, to judge from a year-to-year survey that shows a net increase of only three vacancies out of 241 storefronts from 66th to 86th Street.

title: 'Parsifal' Still Awaits Its Einstein
description: The neophyte Wagnerian must wonder, upon first acquaintance with "Parsifal," what in the world (or the otherworld) it can possibly mean. In that respect, the beginner who happened on the Metropolitan Opera's new production would not be much worse off than the greatest authorities on this "sacred festival drama." Scholarly attempts to explain the old work would fill a small library. "Parsifal" is the elephant described by the blind men: about all they might agree upon is the creature's size.

title: Can Nuclear Power Be Rehabilitated?
description: Dozens of warning lights flash in unison. A bell rings out a chaotic rhythm as an electronic tone warbles just in case the bell goes unnoticed. One person calls out abbreviated commands, a sort of code language read from a 3-inch-thick operator's manual, as two others scramble about the control room throwing switches and pushing buttons. Another watches from the sidelines, ready to step in if he thinks his co-workers are losing sight of what is happening to the reactor. The four men of shift "C" at the Duke Power Company's Oconee 1 reactor are rehearsing a highly choreographed ballet, a sort of industrial dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy.

title: Away From It All?
description: To the Editor: I appreciate Michael Konik's need to travel ("On Not Getting Away From It All," Travel, Feb. 24), but when his abstract ideals lead him to viewing the people he meets as "strange and wonderful" because their lives are different from his, he is turning them into tourist stops and taking their humanity away from them.

title: Inside Gitmo
description: SUBTRACT THE PROPS, AND THE FACE ON the T-shirt could be Milton Berle. But with the fatigue cap, wooly beard and jumbo Havana cigar, it's clearly Fidel Castro, the man who rules all Cuba -- except, that is, for the 45-square-mile stronghold on the shore of Oriente Province where the T-shirt is sold. For more than 90 years, ever since the Spanish-American War, this tip of the island has been under the jurisdiction of the United States military -- which is the point of the T-shirt. In the caption under the caricature, Fidel demands indignantly, "Where the hell is Guantanamo Bay, Cuba?"

title: Review/Music; Flute-Harpsichord Recital
description: Whatever advances have been made elsewhere in recent years, London remains the center of the world's early-instrument activity. Lisa Beznosiuk appears to have most of London's Baroque flutist positions securely sewn up. She is the principal flutist of three of London's best-known early-instrument ensembles -- the English Concert, the Academy of Ancient Music and the English Baroque Soloists -- and she has made records with other groups, too.

title: Penguins' First Title Is Cause to Celebrate
description: Most of the time, winning a division title in the National Hockey League's regular season is a little like qualifying to buy life insurance. It's good to have it, but there isn't much cause for celebration. Even local sportscasters sometimes announce such a hometown achievement after the Final Four basketball preview and the baseball scores from spring training.

title: Golf; Alcott Tough to Defeat With a 7-Stroke Lead
description: Amy Alcott may be packing a bathing suit in her golf bag for Sunday's final round of the Nabisco Dinah Shore, because if she keeps playing the way she has for the first three days of this tournament, the first thing she plans to do is go swimming.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Photographic Memories
description: Known as the father of photojournalism, primarily for his work for Life magazine, Alfred Eisenstaedt has covered many of this century's most significant events, as well as its political, scientific and artistic movers and shakers. In EISENSTAEDT: Remembrances (Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $40) Bryan Holme, Mr. Eisenstaedt's former book editor, provides the photographer's biography in his affectionate introduction: born in Poland in 1898, young Alfred received his first camera at the age of 13; his first professional assignment was to cover Thomas Mann's acceptance of the 1929 Nobel Prize in Literature in Stockholm. Soon after photographing Hitler and Mussolini, Mr. Eisenstaedt emigrated to the United States and began his career-long association with Life. In addition to the photographs of Winston Churchill, Albert Einstein, John F. Kennedy, Marilyn Monroe and Martin Luther King Jr., and the famous shot of Marlene Dietrich in a tuxedo, the book contains human-interest photographs, for which Mr. Eisenstaedt displayed the "intuitive sympathy and identification" with his subjects that Life's editors wanted. "Eisenstaedt: Remembrances" is as lushly nostalgic as its title suggests.

title: Celebrating Paint
description: AS SHE OFTEN DOES, ELIZABETH MURRAY SITS AT A TABLE IN her studio, sipping coffee from an oversize cup and thinking about her work. She lives in a loft in lower Manhattan, and her studio, a long, bright room, occupies the front half. There isn't much in it beyond the usual trappings of an artist's work place. Brushes in all sizes and crumpled tubes of oil paint are heaped on wooden carts, and the air is thick with their greasy scent. A miniature easel, complete with a picture by one of the artist's children, stands in a corner.

title: Postings: Mural Going to Queens; Moving the Vanderbilts
description: A bit of artistic history in the Grand Central district -- a 40-foot mural depicting the times and triumphs of the Vanderbilts -- will disappear next month when the Manhattan Savings Bank closes its branch at Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FAMILY HISTORY

title: Falisha Mamdani, Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Iqbal G. Mamdani of Bahrain, London and Shelter Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Falisha Mamdani to Ari J. Benacerraf, the son of Mrs. Samuel Ainsworth Hird Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., and Shelter Island and Salomon Benacerraf of Caracas, Venezuela. A December wedding is planned.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Fine Excess of an Age To chart the history of love, Martin S. Bergmann argues, we must look at the most extreme figures of an age. This is from "The Anatomy of Loving: The Story of Man's Quest to Know What Love Is" (Fawcett Columbine, paper).

title: The Theme Is Humanity (or Inhumanity)
description: IN New Jersey, this has been "Jacob Lawrence month," with the artist's whistle-stop tour that has taken in the Montclair Art Museum, Bloomfield College, the Jon Taner Gallery and Aljira. But the strange thing is that there are only two exhibitions marking the event.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our clapboard house is finished with an oil stain. Within a year after the stain was applied, mildew stains appeared. We plan to stain the house again this spring. How can we remove the mildew stains and prevent them from coming back?

title: The Baby Bell Problem
description: To the Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portsmouth, N.H.;
Mall Becomes Office Center
description: A DEVELOPER who bought a failed suburban retail mall has turned it 182,600 square feet of office space, adding windows, narrowing hallways and redesigning the landscaping.

title: 'Immigrant' Yields a Near-Perfect Match
description: AN accent on Yiddish is paying off for the Forum Theater Group. In recent seasons, such works as "A Shayna Maidel," "The Rothschilds" and "Crossing Delancey"have played here with variable results. Only last year, virtually everything went right with "Kuni-Leml."

title: Kennett Square Journal; A Corner Of Mexico Takes Root Far Away
description: Jesus Pizano was 14 years old and had the equivalent of $5 and a pack of gum in his pocket when he left the arid highland plains of central Mexico for southeastern Pennsylvania. Here, in long cinder block buildings, amid the gentle slopes and less gentle scents of Chester County farmland, he and the other men of Moroleon pick mushrooms.

title: A Complicated Murder-Mystery Satire
description: "A STING IN THE TALE," a murder mystery satire by Brian Clemens and Dennis Spooner at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is a stylish braid twisted out of plot strands from "Dial M for Murder," "Deathtrap" and a host of other well-known hits.

title: Celebrating Spring, Tokyo Style
description: WITH its neon and noise, Tokyo hardly fits most visitors' idea of a majestic walking city. Like Los Angeles, it has no real center. Like the wilderness, its winding pathways -- most not big enough to let two cars pass -- have no names. And Tokyo's sheer size makes it appear particularly forbidding to newcomers: you can take a train straight west for an hour and never pass the city limits.

title: Tracy Elwood Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Elwood of Hudson, Mass., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Tracy Lynn Elwood and Lieut. Michael Scott Hill, U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hill of Palm Beach, Fla. Miss Elwood, 21 years old, is a photographic technician at Northern Telecomm in West Palm Beach, Fla. Lieut. Hill, 23, graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point. He is on assignment in Kitzingen, Germany.

title: A Genteel New York? Timing Is Everything
description: For a moment, Bev Jackson thought she had stepped from her Upper West Side apartment into the Twilight Zone. People were moving at a casual pace. A man who bumped into her quickly apologized. Strangers opened doors for her and let her go to the head of supermarket lines.

title: World Premiere for a Storyteller's Score
description: FOR Edward Diemente, a resident of West Hartford, his large orchestral-choral score "Credo," dating from 1982-83, marked a turning point in his stylistic development -- away from the electronics that had fascinated him earlier and toward a more tonal, melodically expressive means of communication. Only now, though, has the world premiere of the score been scheduled, and for the composer, only now will his statement of belief and purpose be truly complete.

title: It's Just Not Fair
description: UNEQUAL PROTECTION Women, Children, and the Elderly in Court. By Lois G. Forer. 256 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: An Issue of Consumer Privacy . . .
description: Last April, the Lotus Development Corporation announced plans to release the Lotus MarketPlace: Households, a revolutionary mailing list complete with the names, addresses, demographic and prior-purchasing behavior data for 120 million Americans. Equifax Inc., a consumer information company, supplied the data. But nine months later, Lotus and Equifax cancelled the project, citing consumer complaints and "the substantial, unexpected additional costs required to fully address consumer privacy issues."

title: Kuwait's Fate, and the Emir's Ease
description: For seven terrible months Iraq turned the Emirate of Kuwait into a penal colony and its citizens into virtual prisoners. Only the worst of this ordeal has ended for the 250,000 Kuwaitis who stayed and survived the brutal occupation. Hellish oil fires blacken the sky, rudimentary services are only now starting to return, and shops and banks are still shuttered.

title: To Disguise Bulges, Girdles in Disguise
description: To many women, the word girdle conjures up images of a wincing Scarlett O'Hara being laced into a corset, or memories of hugging a comfy grandmother, only to shrink back from the feel of something like armor under her apron.

title: Rwandan Truce Is Signed
description: The Government of Rwanda has signed a cease-fire agreement with rebels who have been fighting for six months to topple it, Zaire's official press agency reported today. The report said the accord had been signed on Friday and taken effect at midnight. It calls for the Government of Maj. Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana and the Rwandan Popular Front to release all political detainees and prisoners of war before talks on a permanent settlement start in 15 days, the report, received in Brussels, said.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Arias in the Museum

title: Mets Notebook; Gooden Is Stoic Over Pace of Talks
description: As late as a week ago, Dwight Gooden still checked his telephone messages with a quiet excitement, anxious to see if there was word from his agent about the status of contract negotiations with the Mets.

title: August Wedding For Miss Rubin
description: Dr. Robert M. Rubin and Joan C. Landauer of Norfolk, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Stuart Rubin to James Stephen Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Campbell of Naples, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: Inside Iran-Contra
description: OPENING ARGUMENTS

title: Horse Racing; Meadow Star Surges to 9 and 0
description: The track was heavy, the pace was slow, the Kentucky Derby was five weeks away. And halfway through the homestretch, the lead was lost.

title: Kimberly Goldfarb to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morton Goldfarb of Birmingham, Ala., have announced fall wedding plans for their daughter, Kimberly Anne Goldfarb, and Jeffry Barry Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gordon of East Meadow, L.I. Miss Goldfarb, 24, and Mr. Gordon, 26, are law students at Vanderbilt University. Miss Goldfarb graduated from Hollins College; Mr. Gordon from Yale University.

title: Leonard Tells of Drug Use
description: Former boxing champion Sugar Ray Leonard acknowledged today that he took cocaine and drank heavily during the early 1980's when his career was jeopardized by an eye injury..

title: Borders Don't Make Middle East Tensions; First, Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A New Union County Bid for Commerce
description: AFTER a long dry spell in new commercial development, two office buildings have opened in Union County since the start of this year, strengthening the county's ability to provide first-class space.

title: Township Squatters Build, Bit by Bit
description: Edith Silayi, her worn brown sweater snugly fastened with a safety pin, sat hammering a twisted strip of corrugated metal. Once it took usable shape, the metal would be added to the roof of her new dwelling.

title: Strawberry No Big Loss
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: She Heard America Talking
description: HANSBERRY'S DRAMA

title: An Issue of Consumer Privacy . . . And Corporate Retreat
description: Economic factors were important in the decision by Lotus and Equifax to cancel Lotus MarketPlace: Households, but privacy concerns were given the greatest weight.

title: Victory in Doubles Gives U.S. the Edge
description: Rick Leach and Jim Pugh struggled to a pivotal 6-4, 4-6, 7-6, 6-7, 6-4 doubles victory over Leonardo Lavalle and Jorge Lozano today to give the United States Davis Cup team a two-match-to-one lead over Mexico.

title: Juliet Tammenoms Bakker Is Married
description: Juliet Priscilla Tammenoms Bakker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Age Robert Tammenoms Bakker of Amsterdam, was married in Washington yesterday to Barrie Holt Thrasher 3d, a son of Dr. Thrasher Jr. of Atlanta and the late Matilda Parker Thrasher. The Rev. John Carsten Harper performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;
Research Park Moves Ahead
description: A DEVELOPER was chosen this month to build the $50 million first phase of the long-delayed 192-acre Milwaukee County Research Park.

title: Karen J. Mankes, Singer, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mankes of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Joyce Mankes to Mark Alan Egert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Egert of South Plainfield, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Seeley Thumann, Lawyer, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Thumann of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Seeley Ann Thumann, to Preston William Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Brooks of New Haven. A November wedding is planned.

title: Holly Craig to Wed
description: August wedding plans for Holly Lynn Craig and Jonathan Paul Marcus, a son of Judith Fishman of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late Martin Marcus, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Craig of Darien, Conn. Miss Craig, 31 years old, is the national accounts manager for GQ magazine in New York. She graduated from Sweet Briar College. Her fiance, 30, is the director of the children's emergency crisis team at the Center for Human Services in New Bedford, Mass. He graduated from Monmouth College and received a master's degree in social work from Adelphi University.

title: Identical, but Not Models of Each Other
description: Breaking into the top rank of fashion modeling is never easy. A young woman must be at least 5 feet 8 inches in height -- most of it in her legs -- wear a size 6 or 8, and have coat-hanger shoulders and a face that is, if not beautiful, at least striking. You might think it would be doubly easy for identical twins with all those qualifications. And indeed twins do make a strong initial impression, but they also have singular problems.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JOHN AIELLO;
Giving Obsolete Currency a New Value
description: HE deals with diplomats and belly dancers, finance ministers and magicians, corporate executives and artists. And his job regularly takes him to some of the world's most exotic destinations.

title: Combat on the Hudson
description: For some, it's close to a blood sport. They don't wring the necks of those who beat them to the prize or trample innocents who stand between them and a display case. Still, set loose among the stalls, they become Attilas, Conans, Tamerlanes or worse. They are the antiquers, and last weekend they were in full cry at the Triple Pier Expo & Sales, a lesson in the sublime and the ridiculous housed on three Hudson River piers.

title:
FILM;
For 'New Jack City,' It's the Same Old Story
description: DEAR DAD:

title: Campus Life: Missouri-Columbia; 10 Top Teachers Get Recognition (And a Surprise)
description: The Chancellor of the University of Missouri-Columbia went around last week barging into classrooms, interrupting 10 professors in front of their students. The professors were surprised, but hardly minded: the chancellor brought along with him bonuses of $10,000 in recognition of what a university committee had decided were their superior teaching skills.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STOLEN WORDS: Forays Into the Origins and Ravages of Plagiarism, by Thomas Mallon. (Penguin, $9.95.) In his book about plagiarism (a word derived from the Latin for "kidnapper"), Thomas Mallon notes that the importance of originality did not become firmly established among authors until the 18th century. "He writes vivaciously, and is almost never dull," Walter Kendrick said in The Book Review in 1989. "Along the way, he assembles a beguiling portrait of the plagiarist (at least the habitual one) as an oddly plaintive psychopath."

title: Topics of the Times; Tooth Fairy, in Constant Dollars
description: The tooth had been loose for weeks. But when the 6-year-old finally wiggled it out last week, her parents still hadn't settled the big question: What's the going rate for the Tooth Fairy?

title: Christina Black Plans to Marry
description: Mrs. Cyril E. Black of Princeton, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Christina Ellen Black, to Francis Carling, a son of Mrs. James A. Carling of New York and the late Mr. Carling. A September wedding is planned.

title: Many Blacks on the Court but Few in the Offices
description: College basketball will enjoy its finest hour tomorrow evening when it crowns its 53d national champion. But for an increasing number of critics, the tinsel of another Final Four can no longer hide the inequities of an industry that has been energized by black athletes but has been slow to reabsorb them.

title: Julie Harris at 65: Gossamer and Grit
description: It sounds like every woman's fantasy. James Dean rings your doorbell. He's standing there in jeans, looking alienated. He nods at his red sports car with the top down and says, "C'mon, I'm going to take you for a ride in my new MG."

title: At State's Oldest Town Transit Agency, Civic Pride Rides the Bus
description: A FEW years ago, Barbara H. Schmerzler was riding a bus in Westport when the dispatcher radioed the driver, reporting a call from a woman who was worried about her children. They were two hours overdue in a snowstorm.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: EASTER SUNDAY

title: Oil Spray Protects Woody Ornamentals
description: THE buds have not burst open yet, so there is still time to do a good thing for many woody ornamentals. To protect them from insect pests, spray them with horticultural oil, which is available at most well-stocked garden shops. Those who are familiar with this practice have made good use of oils in the past.

title: They Sang the Delta Blues
description: Black culture was on the march in the first decades of the 20th century, be it the Harlem Renaissance in New York, Duke Ellington in Washington, or Jelly Roll Morton, Sidney Bechet and Louis Armstrong in New Orleans. Even in the Mississippi Delta, one of the poorest places in the United States, black musicians were creating a new musical language for the blues (and later rock-and-roll) -- and they were making enough money for record companies to send them all the way to New York studios.

title: Boxing's Hardest Call Is Its Most Important
description: We have Richard Steele, the referee, to thank for reminding us that some issues in boxing, like some fighters, keep coming back. The issue: When should a fight be stopped?

title: The Executive Computer; One Day, Laptops Could Rule the World
description: Several of the newest laptop computers, including an eight-pound model introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation last week, have the potential to replace desktop computers in the executive office. The new laptops, and even some new notebook-size computers, come closer than ever to matching the power and features of desktop machines.

title: Topics of the Times; Dirty Dollars
description: Who do they think they're fooling, these funny-money people -- funny money as in the green paper that looks like currency and is littering sidewalks, gutters, crosswalks and even phone booths.

title: Empires on the Sand
description: A HISTORY OF THE ARAB PEOPLES By Albert Hourani. Illustrated. 551 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: Nanette Halper To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Halper of Mountainside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nanette Halper to Andrew Lawrence Marks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Marks of Great Neck, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: What Color Is Your Reading List?
description: ILLIBERAL EDUCATION The Politics of Race and Sex on Campus. By Dinesh D'Souza. 319 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.
